reviews.review: Lovely shops, pushy sellers. All the shops are selling amazing stuff. We have bought tons of cool goods. Nevertheless, the stuff is too pushy and most of the goods are extremely overprices. You should bargain for %40, %30 of initial price.
Crazy Place. You can find anything here! It is seamless shopping. It is part of the tourist attraction to see all theses shops and items for sale.

Bustling with life. A real must for your trip. The 'streets' are very narrow and noisy and you have to be careful of scooters, carts and the general busy-ness. Also be prepared to be accosted by locals keen to sell their wares. You will need to haggle, but you can pick up some real bargains if you hold you nerve and start with a low offer.

See it once and then move on ...... Unless you are really in the mood to buy carpets, shoes, leather goods etc. worth one visit. Not for the faint hearted or those who are weak on negotiation you get led on by virtually everyone to buy something.
Hectic Souk. Interesting and many things to buy but be prepared to negotiate. be aware of scooters and keep to your right when walking.

Sight seeing. Good place to be, varieties of shops with a lot of locally made ornaments and argan oil of course, the sellers are able to take time to explain the use of the oils for treatment and coametics

Fun and vibrant . Yes, the souks are very tourist-oriented but they are hubs of energy and colour. They are a must-see for any visitor, enjoy some haggling, take it for what it is. Top tip is to not take it too seriously (yes, there are hawkers but they are polite and respectful if you are) and bargain hard!

If you're in Marrakech, you have to go here. The souk plays a huge cultural part of Marrakech (and Moroccan life in general). You can pick up some nice souvenirs, catch a bite to eat and people watch.

Get ready to haggle and have fun. I bought some handmade suede shoes ,just wonder about, watch your bag but you need to do that everywhere. Everyone is very friendly and will try to steer you to a relatives stall. Smiling and a polite no Mercie will help.

Amazing!. Don't be intimated, this is a wonderful place, ladies cover your arms/shoulders/chest & wear long skirt or trousers if anything it's respectful. I had a henna hand tattoo, don't pay more than 50dirahms, barter with the shop owners they love it as much as we do, stick with your highest offer & just walk away if they don't budge, they soon call you back & agree your price! It's a wonderful mix of sights/sounds/smells. Buy some leather it's so soft & cheap, have sweet mint tea, delicious! If you don't experience the souk whilst here you may as well have gone to Benidorm for you holiday!

too much. too many stalls selling the same thing and much of it total tat , deep in the souks yes there were crafts people at work producing I expect some good items but you couldnt stop to look as you were hassled to buy all the time , having to be careful of motorbikes, pedal bikes, and horses and carts down the narrow alley ways made things stressful

Quiet time to visit. We arrived during the Eid festival only to find most of the traders had taken leave to be with their families. It is therefore difficult to rate this otherwise popular destination. The upside was the lack of hassle, but we missed out on the intrigue. The few traders open were good to deal with and seemed to enjoy the haggling over prices. There were a number of coffee shops on the edge and it was possible to walk up grab a table and enjoy a meal . As the eid festival is based on a lunar calendar, it would be advisable to do better research than we did and avoid the holidays so as to see this place in full swing!

Annoying sellers. Marrakech just visit it for max. 1 day, men are annoying, agressive, blocking your path and touching your shoulders to stop you from walking further. I've been backpacking around the world Indonesia, Thailand, Peru, Brasil, Moskow, Amsterdam, Capetown, Istanbul but this type of agressive men I've never met. Almost decided me to leave the country,......

Too Much Fun. The Souk. Where do I begin? Well, how about the snakes? Snake charmers with flutes, great big cobras, and fat rattlesnakes greet you in an open air plaza under a tent. Their buddy is a chipmunk on a leash. If you want your picture taken with them, you must tip.I had an English speaking guide who was very helpful. He started out by saying he had to pray for fifteen minutes at noon during our visit and then we were off. The souk has everything under the sun for sale in a maze of little ally ways and open air smaller market areas.Our guide said he had a wholesale place for us to see which translates into he has a friend who was tipped off beforehand we were coming to shop. Many convoluted hallways later, we came upon a closed big wooden door and our guide knocked three times. The door opened to a private shopping store which was a souk unto itself. This was when our guide had to go pray for fifteen minutes leaving is the hands of the proprietor who spoke perfect English and wanted to sell us everything in the store.Fair is fair. He did have some good stuff, jewelry in the Berber tradition in particular, but everything started at $1,000. Duly noted, we cruised around hemming and hawing when he produced a pair of tin lighting sconces which looked pretty good until he claimed they were silver and were for sale for $1,800. Sensing our resistance, he reduced the price quickly, but still nothing in that store was worth the asking price.Which is pretty much the way it is in the Souk; everything for the most part is overpriced. The saving grace of our entire visit were the custom made remedy stores using original Moroccan spices and herbs. Saffron of a high quality was quite reasonable compared the USA prices. So we ended up buying a bunch to Moroccan concoctions like essence of Eucalyptus which is mind bending powerful to clear the sinuses and lungs and will motivate me to sturdy more when I get home.Tour the Souk. No trip to Marrakech is complete without it. The guide left it up to me what his time was worth and I gave him $10 per hour. He was fine with that.
16000 stalls so theres something for everyone. Haggle, haggle, haggle -they want you and expect you to. Walk away if you still arent happy with the price they will come after you

Crazy!!!!!. This is truly a crazy and chaotic market where donkeys, cats, people, bikes, shops and trolleys share tiny little streets covered with arts and crafts from this beautiful and rich culture.The sellers are very persuasive and will try to drag into their shops where you will have to haggle for a bargain. After a coupleOf shops this you get tired of saying no or trying to guess a fair price for something and you start to walk past without looking to much to avoid being dragged in. The place is also a maze so expect to get lost since all the shops are very similar but there are always signs indicating the direction to the main square.Tip: Watch out for bikes and walk on the right to avoid being ran over!

Illusions. The souk is crowded and you may have to watch your purse as yHow you may have to protect your wallet in the Paris Metro.Right on this famous place you will find the police de tourism,a gruesome place you should try to avoid.How Unesco chose this square a a wonderful site of the world is certainly a good study of change.Possibly it was history,which travellers discovered half a century ago,tradition and unspoiled beauty.Now it has turned into commerce,mass productions,soem,if not the majority made in China,imported from Korea.What happened to the Morrocan artists,those talented craftsmen?Some paths in the medina are fun,colorful,still filled with inspiration.Most roads in the medina are dangerous;;;nto because of thieves,but motorists,agressive motorbike and moped drivers.They are ready to kill and tourist have died.Yes.The famous square,the medina itself,is an illusion,a relict of the past,The citizens destroying the treasure,a kind of autodestruction.Sad.Disappointing.

Install compass app. Souks (narrow streets with mini stores). Install compass app to navigate souks. Sellers don't bother too much. In the side streets you can find mini production of shoes, bags etc.

Fun but don't buy anything nor get directions. Prices are stupid inflated and quality is questionable. But enjoyable to window shop without engaging in any dialog.AVOID anyone offering 'no money' directions, they take you to shops/places. An example "This road is closed, where are you looking for?", then they take you to friends' places and push for a thank you payment.

Loved it!. You can't go to marrakech and not come here! Be prepared to be dragged in to every shop, unless you learn to say no.Luckily I'm quite a big guy so 1 no from me was enough, but on many occasions my girlfriend was dragged off in to a shop much to my amusement to look at fake bags or lights!Learn to haggle, but if you really don't want something offer them an amount so low they take offence, it's an easy way to leave a shop if you don't want something!!

Is ok. Lots of markets: Great if you want to shop&haggle.
All kinds of goods are available from bags&shoes to leather goods.
Spices market smells nice.
Anything and Everything to Buy. Beautiful and vibrant wares by local artisans handcrafted for you to barter and take home to remember forever. Freshly ground spices, as well. A must see.
New experience. in this souks find everything you name it éven they specialised per group of products you can find anywhere this experience narrow alleys beatifuly set up spices olives

Watch out for scooters. The souk markets are amazingly colourful in many ways and we could have wondered all day but scooters and mopeds whizz up and down the walk ways all day and my elbow did get clipped a few times. You cannot come to Marrakech without visiting the souks but hopefully they will soon ban the scooters to make it safe and more pleasurable for tourists

Shopping on steroids. This is a must see attraction. Not sure if the merchandise is great but the atmosphere and people are not to be missed. Please note that this can be crazy busy especially at night when tourist, hawkers, vendors, and food-carts fill the square.
Colourful and busy. Be prepared to haggle and say no a lot to the people approaching you to buy their wears, there is only so many times you can get a henna done.
Great handcrafts. Be prepared to barter hard, think of your price and always offer well below and work from there. We found a lot of things outside of the Souk were better made

Face paced experience.. We decided to give ourselves a full day to look around the Souks as we were told it was huge and very easy to get lost. We found most of the aisles were different shops but were all selling the same things so if you want to buy something I would highly recommend looking around and getting some prices first. The shop keepers didn't seem to enjoy haggling with us cause we had walked around a couple of times before we decided to buy anything so we knew we could get everything cheaper and made sure we told them that. Be firm when talking prices. if you can't agree on a price then just walk away, 9 times out of 10 they will drop the price if they think you will go somewhere else. The only issue we had was every time we stopped to look at anything the shop keepers would come out and either grab our arms or put their arms around us to get us in the shop. At night the whole area comes alive with lights and music. The narrow paths through the souks can get very crowded and some of the slightly wider paths are shared with mopeds. We were approached by several young men offering to show us around but would recommend saying no. They try to take you off the beaten track and will expect money. We found ourselves being harassed by women offering to do henna tattoos on our hands, We had a few of the ladies walk behind us, grab our hands and try to start drawing. That aside It was an amazing experience and would happily go again.
Wow. What an utterly amazing experience. Stop reading reviews and just go. It's shamazeballs colours smells and wares of this beautiful country are so beautiful as are the people

Market Heaven for those that like Markets. Good during the day but brilliant in the early evening, just a short walk from the Jemaa el Fna square. Hustle and bustle, often known more as the Mellah or Jewish quarter, this is a little bit more upmarket. Spices and hand made items abound. stalls that are a bit more presentable. Less aggravation from guides and stall holders trying to drag you into the shops to spend your money. a more relaxed approach and it can get busy. Lots of solo sellers touting their fake goods from watches to iPhones. don't buy from them, you will be disappointed. you can have a good time here with some nice restaurants that have viewing platforms so that you can see the activity going on below. Enjoy it.

Great fun especially at night . Grab a bargain, leather, handcrafted wood, pottery, clothes +food. Great day or night out. Wouldn't recommend to anyone with walking difficulties unless u have a good walking aid and u r not alone. Pavements very uneven and my friend fell over quite badly in the hot and packed square. If u don't like to see snakes or monkeys on chains, I would avoid the big square and head directly into the market. But if u wanna buzz around +soak up sum culture it really is a must do. X

Wonderful!. I didn't find that sellers were as aggressive as people say. Be prepared to haggle, and don't be afraid to walk away - there are so many stalls you'll be sure to find what you are looking for somewhere else! We spent hours here on multiple days, as there's so much to see. Loved it.

An experience . We had fun walking round with a guide for a little while, telling us a little history, he took us into a few shops that he wanted us to go in. Then left us to enjoy the market. We found the haggling a new and fun thing and most shop keepers were not pushy. We enjoyed the sights and bought some nice things.

Crazy. Don't be intimidated by the sellers and those trying to peddle their wares. The souk, despite being crowded, is quite safe. My partner and I thoroughly enjoyed people watching and observing the locals interact and bargain.

Shop Till You Drop in the Marrakech Souk!. We couldn't get enough of the incredible small shops and their energetic proprietors. Our tour guide Josef led us through the narrow alleys and into some of the most interesting shops. Artisans working on leather, wood, metal, cloth were around every corner. We bartered like pros and I will forever treasure my beautiful bag crafted from a Berber carpet and leather. I also scored sandals and two hand-hammered bread warmers. If you don't go deep into the heart of the souk, you haven't seen the heart of Marrakech at work!

energizing shopping experience. If you love shopping or like to get a feeling of local culture, make sure you visit the souk. Please take some with you with a sense of direction, as it is very easy to get lost in the maze of small shops. In all honesty after 30 mins you probably have seen all different kind of shops, and they keep repeating the same ones over and over (pottery, leather, cloathing etc). However if you are in marrakesh surely worth to spend at least 2 hrs here

Amazing. This was one of the highlights of our trip, buzzing with culture and vibrancy.. Can be a little overwhelming if your not prepared for the haggling but is great fun and you can buy some fantastic stuff! We has to buy an extra suitcase!
very busy need to be prepared for it. interesting need a guide cannot do it o your own you will get lost a lot of selling and wanting you to buy
Haggle and enjoy. Smile as you haggle, vendors are persistent, but if you aren't interested just say no and keep walking. Bustling and colourful, busy and noisy, but loved it all

Good if you want to see culture . Had a bad experience here with friends as we decided to take a horse ride around the old town, but the driver decided to leave us in the middle of no where, and then when a local offered to help us for free we were taken to another random place and asked to pay a lot of money!!! Obviously we had no choice but to pay as otherwise we'd be stuck!! Also locals tend to take you to shops and force you to buy things! And often pretend to know you so you'll ask them for a tour!! Good experience however and after all I am glad I went as it's a beautiful place!! I would just advise everyone to be wise!!!

Lots of shops. It looks small from outside but when you're in there. You can easily get lost. All shops are repeated and eventually everything start to look the same. So try to remember your way round. Lots of beautiful local items and good to buy but some are too pricey. It's all covered so good to hide away from the heat from the sun outside.

Never again ! . Terrible !crazy place ! Busy , scary , everyone just looks at you like they want to rob you ! No road etiquette ! The worst holiday in my life and I have been on few! Everywhere smells of dead animals and its dirty ! Haggling is a must an example dress was suppose to cost 350 but I'm the end they were going to sell it for 100 I believe I could have got it for even cheaper but didn't buy it in the end ! Everyone is overcharging ! Unless you want to be disappointed don't book to stay anywhere within Medina !

An attack on all the senses!. What a way to be transported back to medieval times. You can see crafts here which haven't changed in centuries. We saw dyers, metal workers, jewellers, spice stalls, leather workers and much more. If you are not a native you will get lost and the best thing to do is pay a child to lead you out! It felt safe but we stayed together and held on to our bags, you are expected to barter but the stall holders weren't threatening. If you are at all worried pay a guide or take a tour but don't miss it!
Angry arabs. Not worth the hassle, full of angry Arabs with no concept of the customer.no wonder they're so far behind the mighty USA.they just want your money .

Wow! . Make sure you go, make sure you haggle. People are friendly, not intimidating.Have your wits about, we found it impossible to get lost, (during the day) at night different story! Watch out for begging children. Little hands fit into big pockets! Tell them no, and they will move on, if you do not want to give themAny money. People will ask you to come into their units, etc better to say ' maybe later' if you do not want to go in, Bargains to be had. Friends to be made. What an experience. Do try the little hidden cafes for a break out of the heat and a rest. Loved it!

Lively, authentic. The morning hours are the best time to go there. It's still not so crowdy and you can walk through easily and enjoy all the stuff, feeling yourself being transferred in a world of difference. I like the smell and flavour of all the oriental herbs, ointments and food.Watching all the craftsmen and artisans in their small dark workshops is amazing. I admire their mechanical skill and their ability to make something out of nothing. Would like to get there again.

Nice and busy as usual. I finally managed to buy an authentic Moroccan tea pot, if you take your time and ignore the screaming sellers, you will always get something very unique and something beautiful
Busy!. Always busy and just as fun to walk through as to purchase.Great if you want plates, bags and general morrocco type stuff.
excellent. worth the time and a pleasure, do not get exasperated by the locals and enjoy the time, views, senses, bargains to be had.

A Must See. We organised a tour guide through our hotel concierge, very reasonably priced. When the guide arrived promptly at our hotel, I remembered him as our guide who we had met 10 years prior on our first visit to Marrakech, so I knew we were in good hands. He asked in advance what parts of the Souks and markets we in particular wanted to see and led us down all the windy passages pointing out different things of interest. It's a must see, the sights are unique, a totally different world. The vendors are happy to haggle, but its not done in an aggressive way, we had a lot of fun haggling over a pair of slippers with the vendor trying to convince us his price was as 'cheap as chips'. It definitely made sense to have a guide as you don't just visit the edges of the souk but instead have the confidence to go further in. A great morning tour, finishing with the tour guide either organising a taxi back to the hotel or pointing you in the direction of a good bar to have a drink and carry on people watching!

A bit Daunting . The experience of the Souks was a bit daunting to say the least. The traders are quite intimidating but for have to be firm them. We just said No thank you and continued walking trying to to be too rude but I think most of them are used to it. They do pursue but don't let them push you into buying anything you don't genuinely want to purchase. Quite an experience but glad i have visited. It is easy to lose your way so take note of things along the way to find your way. A compass (mine was on my mobile) is very useful to keep you on track as most of the narrow streets are under cover and you can lose your bearings. People will try and guide you, be careful as they will expect you to pay them. Also they will try and tell you they work at your Riad to get you to follow them, they don't!Don't be put off it's a an experience not to be missed

Worth a visit. Recently back from our holiday in Marrakech and we took a couple of trips to the souk, wow this is a busy busy busy place, well worth the visit and plenty of bargains to be had, haggle haggle haggle! Never pay first price they give you. Be prepared to be hassled to visit every store and restaurant as you walk round but a firm no from you will do the trick. Enjoy the atmosphere and keep your wits about you as i say, this is a very very busy place
Shopping !. If you want to shop for some spices and other moroccasions craftsmanship products, then this is the place you should go.

Interesting. Don't be afraid to look around the souks. Yes you may get a little hassle but a polite smile and 'no thank you' will suffice as you move on to the next one. You never know, you may find a bargain! My daughter wanted me to bring her back from harem trousers. Found some I thought she would like and had an interesting haggle with the vendor. Very good natured and fun.

Love the shopping . Absolutely loved shopping at the souks. There are so many amazing products available here from home decorations to spices to soaps and everything. The best part is bargaining. Advice is to make sure to bargain to at least half of the asking price. And if you aren't happy with the price walk away... there is always another store selling the same or similar product.

Constant harassment . When in the Souk as soon as you step out your cab or transfer a man is standing there who says he is a tour guide, he then follows you around & expects payment & even says that if you don't have money you can order or take the goods you see at the market Souk to your hotel & pay them. The harassment is terrible it is not haggling at all. Apart from that, the culture is lovely, hot, & not many places to eat apart from a KFC across the road from the Souk by the square. The horse & carriage drive is lovely.

Souk - a must visit. To visit Marrakech is to visit the Souk. I would suggest around 6pm so you can wander around and see all the snake charmers, monkeys, and various other circus acts. Be mindful that if you take a photo they want money and will get very abusive if you don't give it to them. This is also the case where ever u go Morocco - a photo of anyone (whatever they may be doing) will require payment. Of course, if the people are part of a photograph from a distance, that is fine. The big downside of the Souk and the Medina in Marrakech are the streams of motor bikes that practically knock you over as they speed through narrow lanes and make a hell of a racket. On the upside, try to stay around until sunset (7:30pm), which is magic. You can have a drink on top of one of the many roof top bars - that's soft drink by the way.
Hustle and bustle .... Terrines, plates, silver tea pots, clothing, rugs, shoes, handbags, backpacks, spice, jewlry, blankets, red, blue, green, yellow,purple, pink, orange...

What an experience. Wow, what an experience, loved the signs and sounds of the souk, it felt as thought you would be able to buy anything here. Even if you didn't want to buy anything, it's well worth walking through the souk and seeing goods being make, visit the herbalist and eat at the street vendors

Not great experience. Prepare to be hassled and jostled and be aware of anyone I mean ANYONE that talks to you as the prime objective is money. They will offer to give directions but expect at least 100dirhams. I was stung on my first day but wised up afterwards. It's such a shame as they do everything to discourage you buying anything from them. A bit more friendly and allow people to browse without constant harassment and they would actually make a lot more sales.... I liked marrakesh in general but wouldn't go back because of the way they are with you.... and I'm glad I didn't go with my other half as she would have hated it.... its defiantly an experience.... a very intense one!

What fun. Be prepared to get wonderfully lost and be prepared to haggle and walk away if you cannot reach a mutually acceptable price. Don’t be bullied or feel harassed we have brought some amazing things from a metal lightshade that started at 2,800 Dirhams and we agreed on 750, after I walked away at 1,000 and was called back (you know if you walk away and that does not happen you are too low) to handbags, hats, slippers, shawls, bowls, lanterns, necklaces….We use an app called maps.me which is great for finding your way out when you have shopped enough.
Interesting . I don't think anyone would come to this city and not visit the souk. To my it is the heart of the city.

Madness. Wow what is there to say but wow. A touch apprehensive about our visit to the Souk but it turned out to be an amazing experience. We got a shuttle from the hotel we stayed at and at the drop off point our coach driver asked what we were doing when we said the souk and said we were thinking of getting a guide he hopped out and found us an official guide. Now it seems there are official and unofficial guides, my advice, get an official one they will have a card round their necks. Our guide Mohammed made the trip for us, 61 years old and had being doing it for 20 years +. Bearing in mind it was 40 degrees he shimmied along, white robe flapping leaving us in his wake. Fortunately he realised quickly we couldn't keep up. The souk itself was a cacophony of sounds, smells and sights. Different areas for different items, a souk for leather items where all the artisans worked making handmade shoes, jackets and bags. Carpets, jewellery, the spice market soMuch to look at. So easy to get lost - so relieved we had Mohammed! As well as guiding us round the areas in the souk we wanted to go, Mohammed was a font of knowledge about the area, giving background information and suggesting places. We went along to the Koran School which is in the souk area, a sight to behold, the carvings and tiles amazing! Then back into the bustle of the souk, a buzz as a moped zips past you, stall owners calling out to you to stop and come in for a look at their wares. Cats weaving their way through the shadows and the sun finding its way through the gaps in the makeshift covers over the alleys. A break for a late lunch and to rest our weary feet, as for Mohammed he didn't seem to need the rest, he had carried the bags of shopping, guided us round and still looked as fresh as a daisy. We went in the morning and the central square had only a few people on it but in the evenings at around 7pm lots of stalls set up including acrobats, fire shows etc. There are also monkeys on leads, snakes, squirrels in cages, you will be encouraged over to look at the animals. Horses and carts lots of smells as you can imagine. Keep you valuables close and your wits about you and you will have a good time.

Be careful but worth a visit. Lots of pick pockets and people who want to rip you off. All goods are fake. If the morrcans give tou directions they try to charge you for them. One person asked for the equivalent of £40.00. On girl tried to grab my friends arm and put some hena on it and wanted £45.00 for the mess she made. The children will ask for money but they also steal and try to mugg you. They stole food off the table next to us in a restaurant. You will constantly be harassed to spend money. It smells awful. It is worth a visit at night. Some good street entertainment. The animals are treated really badly. Especially the animals for sale. They are in extremely poor conditions. The people with monkeys and snakes try to get you to have a photo with an animal and charge you a fortune for doing it. They can be aggressive if you don't give them money stay clear. If you are going to by clothes try everything on because they are all different sizes. Many of the fakes are bad. The ones on display may be good but check every purchase. Keep your hands in your pockets and money safe. Don't buy electricals. You are forbidden to drink alcohol here. The square comes to life at night.

What's not to love?. The Marrakech souk is what the place is all about. Crazy place. Enticed into a carpet seller's treasure chamber, piled high with jewel coloured rugs and the assurance there is no need to buy, you are then treated to an absolutely world-class performance of rugs being thrown on the ground in front of you while someone serves you endless mint tea from a shining copper tray, and all the while they are teaching you Arab words for 'love it' or 'hate it' and you are believing you are going to come out of there without having bought anything.Wrong. You will leave Marrakech with at least 3 rugs in your luggage. But a) they are beautiful, b) they are cheaper than in the UK, and c) it's worth it for the hilarious, entertaining, and fun performance they put on to sell their wares. And then afterwards, when you pass by on subsequent days, they treat you like an old friend, and don't try to sell you any more rugs.There's more to the souk, obviously, but this was my highlight..... :)

A must visit. Even though some of the merchandise is really tacky, you can still find fine crafts, spices and pottery in the souk. The experience is great, but watch your pocket and purse. Bargaining is required. Don't be shy.

great spot. spent an afternoon in the market Square haggling with vendors for scarves...and other wears...typical tourist trap stuff there too...monkeys and snake charmers...fortune tellers...all great fun....remember that if you take a photo of a local...you are expected to tip..
Good haggling and bargains not much hassle. Lots of bargains to be found. Haggling is good fun and good humoured. Not as much pressure to buy as many places I've been.

Amazing Sights and Sounds. Felt very safe. Really enjoyed exploring, don't worry about getting lost as the locals will always show you the way back to the main square. Bartering is great fun. There are the usual beggars and people selling fake watches and phones, if you say no firmly they will leave you be. Keep your money in a money belt to keep you safe from pick pockets.Sun set is amazing to watch from the square. The scarves and pashminas are beautiful and well worth bartering for! The sites and sounds are like nothing you will experience again. Get a prearranged taxi to pick you up, this can be booked from your hotel and will make sure you get back to your correct destination if you prefer not to walk, as it can be daunting if you are unsure of your route!

A visit to the Souks. Lots of advice about how to deal with the Souk and here's a bit more!Enjoy the experience, talk to people, haggle politely and don't be afraid to say a firm no. That aside relax and take in the multitude of colours, sounds and smells. If you go on an organised your the guides are excellent, our was, good English, obviously he will take you to the place where he gets a cut, but the experience is good. Be aware, as you would anywhere in the world, but don't let it get in the way of your trip.

Eye opener. You must not stop or touch anything otherwise your not left alone. Be very alert with the mopeds,they don't give way to anything. Very easy to get lost, if you look like your lost your get pestered by men wanting to be your guide.

A must do when in Marrakech. We initially went to the souks with a tour and then decided to go back on our own. Providing you are not rude the stall holders will be friendly with you. I used to smile and say "may be later". They all sell the same produce. To barter you have got to be strong. Work out what you are prepared to pay and do you really need the item. I would start at 50% of the original price and came away with some bargains. I have even walked away from a stall and the stall owned has come after me agreeing my price. Be strong minded , but not rude. Remember it is their country and we are guests. Take a bottle of water with you as it is under cover and can become very hot. The majority of people speak English and if you start from the Big Square "El Feena" near a landmark you should find your way around. DO NOT take any photographs of any official buildings; if you do you will be surrounded by police and soldiers. Just a waring. There are plenty of cafes to have a cold drink and sit and watch the world.

You don't experience this place, it happens. You need a number of things before you venture into the Souk, bottled water, a compass, a good sense of direction, tissues and the ability to say NO!You will meet lots of young men who will want to show you the way back to the square, but very firm, despite telling you they don't want money, they do and they will lead you deeper and deeper in. If you have your senses about you there are signs high up on the sides of buildings pointing back to the square, be aware, some have been defaced or removed. Best advice is pay attention to the route you took in and return by the same way, don't be tempted to just aimlessly stroll about, you will quickly get lost and it maybe many hours before you find your way out. I mean this seriously!

Lunatic moped riders and pushy salesman. We tried wandering around the souks around 7.30pm but gave up as we were almost afraid to so much as glance at a shop or stall before finding the owners trying to drag us into their shops. Most of the goods were not of the greatest quality, similar dodgy goods to that found in almost any Mediterranean holiday market. There were a few little gems dotted amongst them but the prices reflected the quality and were massively overpriced. The scariest thing that we found was that the moped riders would go down almost any ally as fast as they could with no respect for anybody and we were nearly hit several times!
Good, but you have to barter . Good place to visit but you need to barter to get a good deal. The prices start very high and sometimes they seem stuck on the price

Below average souk, beset by aggressive hawkers and gangs of children. I'm a pretty seasoned traveller, and used to being on my own wherever, but Marrakech souk is pretty dismal. I don't mind people trying to sell to me, but I resent being pawed by women trying to daub henna on me, and male children grabbing my clothes and shrieking. They will also follow you as far as your riad, so just be a bit careful. Yes, I am very blond, but my head is covered at all times, and I'm clothed from wrist to ankle when in North Africa. We were here for five days and it really became very tiresome.

Not As Traumatic As We Expected. Having just recovered from being lost and nearly held hostage in Istanbul's Grand Bazaar a few years ago, we were slightly anxious about entering the Souk, but we had a great time - only hassle from the tour guides in the Square, and that was just crazy - snakes and monkeys everywhere. A great atmosphere in the Souk and the vendors we passed were very friendly and put no pressure on us at all. The locals were very pleasant too and one asked me to walk on the right side of the path as if I walked on the left, I would be visiting the hospital! Take care as health & safety has yet to be considered here, but it was well worth the visit.
Amazing souk. WHen you visit Souk of Marrakech, you need to get more information before that. Also, to plan better your visit.

Soak that lives up to its expectations as the one of he best soaks in the world. What a magical place. Don't get me wrong it can get extremely busy and u do get the ppl bidding to get your attention and try sell u something but that is all expected. It adds the magic to the experience. Love the place and will defo be back every time I'm back in marrakech. Defo must go
Great fun. We had great fun bartering in the souks from t shirts to spices everything you could possible want and more
Expensive. For the quality of the items sold in the souk it's very expensive. Turkey or Thailand are much better for shopping.

A good place for your tourist souvenirs. Like many other market areas around the world, you are constantly being 'invited' to look at the stalls by the stall holders, and not allowed to simply browse. The stalls become all much of a muchness, selling a fairly limited range of goods, but you can't go to Marrakech without a trip to Souks!

It's a must!. You can't go to Marrakech without going to the souks and here is everything you need to fill your cases and struggle home trying not to break the bowls, lamps, secret boxes etc which you successfully bartered for. As a rule of thumb we didn't start bartering unless we really wanted the item and knew how much we were going to pay. The opening offer was usually 5-600 and we would start at 100 and usually settle for somewhere around 150 dirhams. Only one vendor got a little pushy/ irate and followed down the street a until he eventually relented and sold us the skewers. We didnt see any evidence of pickpocketing but were told it went on. Just take sensible precautions. Have fun!

Right out of Indiana Jones. While it may not have been filmed here you can certainly easily picture yourself cast in the film. Surrounded by vendors, snake charmers, silks, baskets, leather, rugs, spices, lanterns and pottery. It is a colour and sensory overload. We had a personal guide who was fabulous and I strongly recommend hiring one as they know how to get through the maze of the Souks and can take you specifically to what you are looking for and also help negotiate if needed.

Great Souk. Like all Souks a lot of the same. However several really good different areas. We come across a lock maker in the Metal makers area. Great ornamental lock olde world. Of course everyone wants to sell you Aragon oil, lots of rip off merchants take care and seek out trusted merchants from your hotel. Be aware of the guides that promise to show you the souk, they all appear to be commission gathers from the places they take you, family friends etc, yes they claim to know the best places to go.If you go to the main square after 730pm you can experience the mad clash of hundreds of stall operators much fun. Keep away from the snake charmers they have a snake around your neck the minute you get close and show interest. Very safe at night enjoy!

Crazy. Lovely visit to the souk Marrakech.If you don't do this visit your mad.It is not what people say!People are friendly, yes it's crazy but wouldn't have it any other way.It's a fantastic experience. Yes they hassle you but come on they need money & want to earn a living. All you have to say is No Thank You!!!If you want something for £10 stick to it or walk & say no thanks I buy round the corner! It's that simple. We got 2x silk pashmina. 1x large copy Gucci travel bag & 1x leather belt for £44, Bargain .Try it! We would highly recommend a visit, lovely morning out.

Mental Maze! . It's definitely worth visiting the Souks to grab a bargain, I managed to buy some nice leather bags for a fraction of the price that I would get at home just be prepared to haggle. I wouldn't really recommend wandering around on your own though as it's so easy to get lost. We got lots of people offering to show us the way but obviously they were expecting payment so we declined. The stall holders will all try to get you to come into their shops but it's all part of the experience. Just relax and enjoy it!

Prepare to view lots of tat!. Rows upon rows of touristy tat is the best way to sum it up however its one of those things you just have to go visit and say you have been there. Its ok just don't make it top of your list for things to do

7 out of 10 but Maze of Tat!. Perhaps I was expecting too much with the shopping for Morocco but we were very disappointed overall, the souk was for the most part just cheap tat aimed at tourists, as they say in Thailand, " same, same but different". There were a few exceptions with some nice, interesting shops, and the souk is definitely something to behold but we didn't buy anything. It is good if you like cheap souvenirs, which is not our thing. It is a maze, very crowded and an adventure to take in but unfortunately the shop keepers are so persistent and in your face that instead of looking, which you might if they didn't harass you, you just keep walking past trying not to make eye contact. Best to keep a sense of humor. The side streets are the best for a real taste of the local culture.

Dirty, smelly and they harass everyone! Don't go alone, you'll get lost.. I've been to markets like this in Istanbul, Jerusalem, etc. and I've never been so uncomfortable! It stinks real bad everywhere, it's also very dirty. Now the shop owners or sellers harass you to the bone. This people don't understand word NO. If you lift one eye of the ground they assume you're there to buy something and they will not let go of you. Never again. Don't waist your time, there are plenty of things to see, the Souk is not worth the effort. If you lose your way there's always some weird boy that offers to find the way out but demands money on the spot. Disgusting.

Enjoy the bargains. These shops have such a variety of items that you will be in for a surprise and will be wondering where to spend your money. Leather goods are a must buy and do not hesitate to bargain. Start with a quarter of the price and settle for a third. Be prepared to walk away and that is part of the ritual. You will eventually get used to the experience.

Maddness. Mental is the best word ,it's a proper maze make sure you keep an eye on where you,you could be lost for days in there...it's a must to see but be aware it's all about the dirhams the friendly guy showing you were to go ,the Sellars some are very pushy and it can be very annoying after a while but that's the souks

Excitement with a hint of danger. To enter the souk of Marrakech takes you back in time, a place of colour, noise and a chance to buy those gifts and reminders of a holiday well spent. You can quite literally lose yourself at any time, following the trail of spices, soaps, rugs, shoes, you name it and it's here. Be wary of pick pockets, do not be lead down a passageway by children telling you this is the best way to bargains or the only way out. If you are lost ask the stall holders, they will give you the best directions whilst trying to sell with their best smile and funniest lines, "buy this cheap stuff here, I have 14 children to feed, and only 1 bowl, I need a bowl, you need this rug". Barter hard they are experts and love the challenge. Go early evening and wander round watching the square come alive at night. Hold on to your wallet as you walk around feeling like Indiana Jones in the midst of an adventure.

female solo - 26yrs. Keep one hand on your bag. Explore and take your time walking. Don't smile at vendors, a simple glance and mini smile as you shake your head is fine. Never suggest a price unless you intend to buy!! Remember your path from Jema to not get lost.... unless you're with friends! The shops mostly sell the same items so don't be afraid to walk off! Find places to eat where there are locals! The Babouch restaurant is nice though. Café Bazaar over prices but romantic. Gorgeous items and food, some over enthusiastic staff but an amazing experience.

Mezmerising. This is a must if you are visiting Marrakesh. The experience is truly unforgettable. It soon become apparent why its the largest shopping experience in the world set in 5 square miles and you can buy anything you wantI would advise going with a guide, you get their experience whilst giving commentary and history of the souks around the Medina whilst visiting some of the what i would class as real life Morocco.The only draw back with this for me was our guide insisted on taking us to a spice merchant who then spends 45 minutes going through all the spices they have and their respective remedies to cure all of your ailments. This bit didn't interest me at all and for that i felt robbed of visiting time around the markets. If i hadn't of left it until the last full day of my trip i would have gone back under my own steam for a close look around.Be careful, there are motorbike and push bikes a plenty, the Moroccans are obviously used to the smell and speed at which these bikes zoom around so be on your guard. We were told to be mindful of pick pockets too, the Moroccan routine is to spend time sitting around and hanging out on street corners so just be careful in the most they are very friendly and always want to say hello and chat.Its NOT a place if you are unsteady on your feet, the paths/roads are very poor definitely not for wheel chairs either as they are very narrowYou get to see the local products/souvenirs being made in the workshops, but when it comes to selling to you the tourist watch the prices go up. The Moroccans love to barter so have a price in mind and stick to your guns.The square is a very busy place, with snake charmers and monkeys all dressed up, but be careful here, they want to charge you for taking pictures, the guy with the monkey extends his hand to shake yours, and before you know it the monkey is on your shoulder, and they insist you take a photo and charge you for the privilege. The same with the Henna tattoo ladies they want to shake your hand and then slap on a tattoo, some of these are henna tattoo's have been found to make people ill be careful even if you want one done.
Craxy. Was not my cup of tea but certainly an experience, worth the visit to judge yourself, don't let reviews change on your mind on if you should go, just do it!

Full of choice but pricey and merchants drive a hard bargain. Things here are much pricier than other cities in Morocco but everything is good quality and so much variety and choice. The souk is endless!

Maze of stores. I can't remember how many times we got lost in here. So many treasures to see and buy no wonder why we got lost. We spent a hot 55c day shopping. Lucky for us its covered from the sun so it was really nice to walk around longer.
Must see. Experienced the whole feeling of what I imagined Morocco to be. Full of all kinds of merchandise. Friendly people.

Interesting but easy to get lost. We visited the souks on our trip to Marrakech, it was very interesting and great for Instagram, but it was silly easy to get lost! We took a couple of wrong turns and ended up in a pretty dirty part of the city. One thing that really let it down was how every other shop sold the same things.

Fun times. A great place but to truly enjoy it be prepared to be lost and don't panic. Please do not take any 'help' from so many people willing to 'guide' you along the way. And if you cannot handle getting lost or do not trust your navigation instincts then do get yourself a proper guide from your riad or hotel. It will be expensive but worth it. Do not pick up any unofficial or free guides in the medina. We sit it without a guide, got a bit lost, but had a fantastic time. Enjoy.

Keep focused. There are some great items to buy. We came with 1 suitcase and left with 3.Just remember when you walk around guys will come up and just start showing you around. They want to be generously tipped and they will steer you into some shop you probably don't want to see.
Very entertaining and pleasant souk... Lots of different sorts of shops from traditional clothes to spices to lamp shades.....shoes and sweets....a little something for everyone....

Cool Souk. My friends and I we just came back a few month ago from wonderful tour in Morocco we really enjoyed it. Definitely this souk it a great place to visit in Marrakech there is a lot of deferent stuff I recommend it to people. Great memories and I hope I will be back to Marrakech in the future

Don't get Lost. very easy to get lost. You can get a guide which would probably have been a good idea. Plenty of people touting for your business. You MUST barter. Morrocan leather jacket start price 4500 (about £300) finished at 1500 (about £100)

Mayhem . Go for a wander offer quarter of price they offer you and stand your ground there are plenty great deals especially on leather goods. A good haggle will include patience and lots of mint tea, remember to smile and just enjoy it - good luck
SOme good bargains if you can barter. We spent several afternoons here. Bought a few things. Bartering is mandatory. Go for 1/2 the price quoted the move up.

Better off the beaten track..... Typical kind of westerner's favourite attraction - but never lose sight of the fact that you are the prey & these folks are the hunters! Best experience is where you find a good specialist & take time to talk to them. We found great herbalists & metal sculptors - one so good we've taken their details for my landscaping business back in the UK. Steer clear of the generalist sellers in the main square - they sell cheap tat for as much as possible. Many will tell you "don't go down there - there is nothing". That's your signal there is something worth looking at! Everyone has "an auction". It's a euphemism for go inside & we'll sell to you till you drop - avoid. I also hate the captive monkeys, snakes & horse drawn carriages. Horrible animal exploitation! Overall - if you keep your wits about you & are prepared to keep taking the unexpected turn - you can find gems.

Friendly soul. Fast bust soul with loads of bargains be prepared to bargain as they tend to overprice at some stalls unless u look Arabic this soup is one of the best I've been to and quality is very good especially men's cloths and trainers

Shopping!!!!. Best place for leather, textiles and pottery and much more. Had fun shopping with my daughter and now we are proud owners of nice scarves made from cactus and new leather house slippers! Haggle though, a lot!!!

Crazy crazy crazy. You'll never prepare yourself for this experience, the assault on your senses is overwhelming. There is so much to see and it's very colourful, the smells and the noises are excellent but watch out for the bikes stay to the right.

Shopping. Visiting this market, you need to be ready to haggle for a good price... If you want to buy copies of Gucci, Ralph Lauren, LV, Amarni, Nike Adidas, anything you want really also beware of the sellers trying their hardest 2 sell things to you, even following you... Just stand your ground if you don't want to buy anything...

Awful. Avoid. A friend and I came for a 4 night city break. The souk is awful. Full of mostly tat. Dreadfully rude, pushy, intimidating traders, all trying their hardest to rip off unsuspecting, silly tourists. You take your life in your hands trying to navigate around the alley ways as these are used by crazy moped riders, cars, vans. All hurtling along at break neck speed with no thought for pedestrians. Came to marrakesh in 2003 and came back as had vaguely pleasant memories. But never again. And don't get me started on the cruelty to animals here. .. the poor wretched horses forced to live out their likely short lives giving rides to to ignorant tourists who sit like lords and ladies in the carriages circling the city while the horses breathe in the fumes of the cars etc and get whipped for not going fast enough. Stray dog's, half dead cats.. I won't go on....

Interesting. Look, it just has to be done. There are a large number of stall food restaurants in the main square (simply referred to as the Square). Each has a similar selection of grilled meats and tagines. Very good value for money. Lots of atmosphere. Cheap yet cheerful.

So exciting, but be wary. We toured the Souk when we first arrived as we were eager to see what it was all about. It was very busy as we had arrived the day before the festival of the sheep, so lots of moped traffic which can catch you out if you dont keep your wits about you. Lots to see and smell, with so many different stalls you could be there all day and only see half of it. Be aware of illegal guides as we found out the hard way. He attached himself to us and would not leave us alone until i had given him some money which he deemed not enough. Gave him a little more then told him to leave us be until he relented. It can be daunting and its definitely not for the timid. Still, it was a great experience

Be Alert Here. You need to have your wits about you here! Everyone wants money and they will entice you they will charge you for photo's, directions and anything they can get away with.Enjoy but just be alert!

Does exactly what it says on the tin.. Amazing colours, heavenly smells-an assault on the senses never to be forgotten. Superb crafts at corner-shop prices set amongst an array of quiet and comfortable eateries.

Souks....unforgettable!. I can definitely say that we loved Marrakech; even with the whirling chaos often left us a little frazzled lol. But.......we loved the experience! The Red City is wild, unapologetic, and unforgettable. Angela and I found it the ideal place for a relaxing holiday, we can't think of no better location for a mind-blowing introduction to the Arab world. ( Berber Empire ) ☀️☀️

Hideous. Not for the feint hearted! Dirty, smelly, endless narrow streets where you easily get lost. All selling same old rubbish at ridiculously inflated prices. Yes you should haggle but beware, once you start battering you'd better be prepared to buy as they get very annoyed if you don't! An intimidating experience and not one I want to ensure ever again.
Souk visit. Found great courtyard cafe le bouganvillier in the moursanne area worth a visit for a peaceful break from the souk

It'd bigger than you think. An amazing experience. Once inside this is a labyrinth of twists, turns and missable passage ways. Don't go in without a guide, you'll miss so much and it's very likely you'll never get out! Get a good guide and they'll also help you haggle with the sellers

All selling the same thing at some ridiculous prices. We were shopping with someone who lives locally and actually is Moroccan - she actually struggled to get some good deals, the shops are quite greedy and the sellers are all persistent. We did buy some trainers, shoes, watch, bags but it wasn't as pleasurable as I had expected. There are some bargains to be had but you need a lot of time and patience. We found very off-putting in this day and age the monkeys with chains round their necks being thrust at you and all the snake charmers. Don't stop and even glance unless you are prepared to have your photo taken and then pay. In fact don't ask about anything unless you are intending to definitely buy, enquiries and then not buying is not welcome.

Unique . This is something to keep in my life experience forever. Is simply amazing. I have the luck to be there during local holiday season, so didn't had that suffocating experience of crowd overload most of the time. Lucky me!The products are amazing, bargaining is a science that is not for all. The looks are cinematic, romantic, exotic and all that you wish for. Lovely time!

Endless and marvelous. We thoroughly enjoyed wandering the souks. Much to see with shops and museums and quite a variety of shops. We enjoyed tea with many shop owners and cleared out heads in the apothecary shops. Only caution, don't buy until you figure out the system.

Crazy!. A crazy tangle of narrow streets full of stalls selling leather items, metal goods, spices, baskets etc. be prepared to haggle and get the vendors down to around half their original prices, good fun

Mad crazy frustrating but a must. Firstly if you are on a time restriction do not go into the souk. Every trip takes you longer than you think and you always seem to come out in a different place. It's basically a maze. If you go wrong you get lost for hours just walking in circles. Everything looks the same! All the shops are the same. Same stuff. Same prices. You just need to barter. But....do not stop at one unless you want to buy. They do not accept you leaving ! This is a shame as you want to browse but are scared too. You will constantly be told where the square is and they direct you. Ignore them. They tell you the wrong way often or they want payment for it. Do not get sucked into their kindness that is not genuine. We were often told the square is closed come this way. All lies to get you to go their own shops. The idea is keep going straight. Don't divert off. Don't lose your bearings. Just keep walking straight. Recall where you came out and go back in same way. We thought we would try it a different way back. Got lost for hours. Exhausting. Confusing. All looks the same in the end. Do not be taken in by anyone. They are not being kind helpful or anything like it. They want money. They say they don't but they do. Or they take you to the Berber shops. However do not be put off by this. By day 2/3 you are more confident. Great atmosphere. Busy. There are cafes in there too. You will see and smell some unpleasant things. Animal heads hooves insides etc but just wear sunnies and by pass. Be careful taking photos. They can get cross.

Like not other place. During the day stop to get a fresh orange juice for less than 50cents...then come back at night when is more chill and enjoy some olives and brochetts!! be careful with what they serve you as they like to add extra to your account with out previous notice. End the night with a marrocan tea!!

Bartering in the Souks. Beware people with No Teeth!Visiting souks while in the city is a must! However be prepared for the hassle and creeping from the Men!Great teapots, purses and bags.When entering give yourself plenty of time to get out as getting lost is part of the experience
Mixed Review. Loved some parts & not others. After 3 hours needed to escape the heat, smell of horse urine & beggers

Bustling but not intimidating. I found this to be the best souk I'd been to. The selection of stuff is what you'd probably expect with some stalls having some stuff of questionable quality but at the bargain end of pricing. Others you will find top quality stuff at. We bought 6 traditional candle lamps that weighed a lot and were solidly built from Bennani at 23 souk semarine. The list price was 1200 dhirams but by the time my partner had finished a friendly 'haggle', we got a healthy discount which we were happy with (I don't know if the stall holder was). Whilst this place is a maze (and make sure you know your way in and out if you can) it is not intimidating compared with other souks I've been to.

So much to see!!. The souks are absolutely incredible with so much to see (and buy)! I found the shopkeepers to be easygoing and friendly, and not too aggressive. Haggling over prices is half the fun. If I'd had more luggage space, I'm sure I would've bought more! Leave plenty of time to explore here.

A maze of activity. The souks are a maze surrounding Jemma El Fna and are well worth visiting to soak up the atmosphere. In all honesty the wares being sold are not great quality and the first price you are quoted is always laughable. If you stop for even a second, you'll have shopkeepers beckoning you (often quite insistently) to take a look at their goods.Strong recommendation is to download a GPS made before you enter as it is quite easy to get lost and many people will try to guide you - which is code you leading you to their shop or scamming you for money so beware!
Wow!. I loved this place. Chaos, mayhem, hustle.... You name it. Beware, the shop owners will grab your arm, shake your hand and do whatever they can to make a sale. Bartering is expected.

Crazy busy, never ending maize of stalls. Is a must! Even if you don't like shopping get out of the hotel and go see the Medina. A never-ending maize of streets packed with stalls. Start haggling at a third of what they ask and aim to finish at around 50% of their initial asking price. I managed to get two big (Ryain air cabin size) leather bags for 300 dirham each and they hand made me (from scratch) two very thich, studded dog collars for my two doberman for 150 euros. Took around 40 minutes but we had plenty of tea and chat whilst we waited, quite a nice experience. Haggle at two or three places before you go in for a serious shop so you know what price to expect and you'll find as you're walking away from one, the price drops to whatever your last offer was.
Crazy town!. Everything u want you can buy here. Prepare to barter HARD. It's not as cheap as you might expect even with good bartering.

Hectic. If you love to barter and find a bargain and you have the time and the patience this is the place for you. From fake goods to carpets to real Moroccan merchandise, it's different from the grand bazaar of Istanbul as this place mixes tourism with local community trading so you feel as though you have seen the real Marrakech and ancient Arab markets. You do meet nice shop owners who try their up most to help you (for some strange reason they have a beards) and then you also find the salesmen (who don't have beards- don't ask me why it is this way) on comission that insist on taking you to every shop they can in the hope you will get sick of being dragged around and just buy something you don't really want so they can pocket a days wage. Stick to your guns and politely tell them to 'do one'! There is no obligation to buy and if you tell them it is haraam to harass they soon get the message. I did see one salesman physically push a lady out the store as she was not buying...hence my next point of some Moroccan men in the souk, they are not representative of Moroccans and certainly live with a chip on their shoulder as if the world owes them something. Steer clear of these clowns. If you don't get lost you haven't ventured far enough and ignore any one providing directions as the easiest way to get out is to go straight until you get to the wall where you can find an exit or end up back in the jemaa el-fanaa. Definitely worth a visit for some gift shopping and experience local life. Not recommended with kids.
I never get tired on my shopping streets. Early mornings before opening, late nights with magical lighting. Embrace the feeling of getting lost. You will always end up somewhere.

Ryan Flynn . Listened to a few negative reviews and was a little concerned especially for my wife. I have been to Turkey a few times Bali and Sri lanka and visited markets in each and I have to say that the souks are grand. We didn't get tortured by sellers etc it was a very enjoyable experience. Keep a few coins in your pocket for entertainment etc but just be wise and use commonsense.
Shopping old world style. The souks of Marrakesh are not for the faint-hearted, but you can find all kinds of merchandise in this historic trading place.

expensive and lot of hassle. If you go to some off the beaten track streets, you can see how the real trade looks like in Marrakech. Main roads are just for the tourists. What they sell there is not worth buying because of the behaviour of the salespersons and high prices in comparison to the shops in other cities.

So much to look at. Much of the charm of the Morrocan souks is that it is not a purely tourist undertaking; real people are still living and doing their shopping here in between the tourists stalls. If you are not fond of aggressive sales tactics and hard bargaining you probably won’t buy much but if this is your thing then have a ball! The main souk alleys can be walked extensively in half a day or less depending on how lost you get

The best souk in Morocco . I have visited a lot of souks in Morocco(Agadir, Rabat, Chefchauen and Tangier) and this one is the best. A big market with a lot of shops where u can find everything!(but fruits are sold in another place) Don't forget to cut the price in 4 times and be careful! There is a lot of guys who can steal ur stuff

love walking around this area! real culture. although morocco is visited by so many foreigners, it hasn't lost its culture at all. love this area. they all have pretty much the same stuff but walking through the shops and alleys is an experience that everyone should make!
Hectic but could get a bargain!!. Very busy indoor market, but did get some bargains :). Haggling is accepted, so worth knowing prices of what your haggling for.

Souk. Not a good experience. There were many stalls selling the same products all badgering us to buy their wares. A few young men, we believe, were working together going out of their way to show us around the tanning area. We tried to lose them as we had an idea this was a ploy to extract money from us as a gratuity. They were well dressed and spoke very good English. Despite our efforts they were very persistent and sure enough wanted a reward. When we denied having cash, one of them even asked for my friend's hat! I, personally, would not return.

Bartering in the souks. Whilst at first thought,the business of the souks can be quite intimidating, but once you get lost and immerse yourself in it, we found it to be some of the most fun we had. There was a small amount of 'hassle' from the sellers,but we felt it was generally good natured and didn't cross the line. We bought a few presents for ourselves and family and thoroughly enjoyed the theatre of negotiating and bartering with the store owners. A must for a trip to Marrakech.

Great place to get lost. This was a wonderful experience. Just walking around seeing all of the fun stuff on sale and interacting with the sellers was great fun. People were really nice and the atmosphere was lovely. Not too much hassle from people trying to sell stuff. A great way of spending an afternoon.

Let yourself get lost!. It's easy to be overwhelmed in the souks, but if you relax, wander, (and get used to haggling), you will find great bargains and interesting conversations. Hit the side streets with fewer tourists for more personal interaction and better deals. The spice section is not to be missed, if for no other reason than the incredible aromas.
Something to see. It's part of Marrakech, it's nice to get lost in the labyrinth of shops. But, like everywhere in Marrakech, it's chaotic and after a while tiring

YOU HAVE TO SEE IT TO BELIEVE IT. We had a guide for this trip into the souk. The streets are narrow with wall to wall traders all trying to outbid each other. The variety of goods is amazing and if something takes your fancy, then go and take a further look as these places are true treasure troves. The leather goods are wonderful, but make sure that you are not paying a lot for cheap camel & you can tell by rubbing with a damp tissue & if the colour comes off, it is usually camel. Good leather you can hold a lighter under without any issues. Having said that, if you just want a memory or your trip, then cheap goods are fine. There are the most beautiful scarves to be seen, but read the labels well if you are looking for real silk as a slight rewording can be misleading. It is good to barter over prices & the general rule of thumb is half whatever they tell you & work on the theory that you just slowly increase & then stop & if the haggling goes on for a long time, so much the better. If you are not serious about buying an item, then please don't start the haggle as they have a living to make & you would be wasting their time. The wood carvers have to be seen to be believed, especially those who carve with their feet & the end product is quite delicate. If carpets are your thing, then you wont be disappointed as there is an abundance of many types of carpet to be seen. Have fun, go open minded & I know you will love it as much as I did.

Not as bad as we thought..... An interesting place - we only had one wander around during the day and only covered a small section but once you have seen one t-shirt or spice stall you've seen then all. Make sure you barter on price starting at around 30-40% of the original price and then work up. Never pay more than 60% of the asking price and certainly don't fall for any of the sellers 'my uncle is sick....' stories.

Souk well worth a visit !. I personally loved visiting the souk it gives a great feel of Moroccan culture.You don't need to buy anything there are some excellent food outlets one tip don't pay for a guide they will generally take you to there friends to buy something

See, Smell, Taste, Hear, Touch Morocco. This Bazaar is a feast for all five senses. I only wish I had a whole day to wander into the little nooks and crannies of everything that piqued my curiosity. The souk had separate sections for leather merchants, metalworkers, women preparing henna powder, street artists, carpet merchants, and various craftsmen. My favorite was smelling and shopping for aromatics. Don't let the local merchants bully you into buying something you don't want. However, you can haggle for a decent price (haggling is expected), and you can definitely find unique, local goods that aren't mass produced by some factory in China.I would recommend going out at night; it's too hot during the day, and you can experience a lot of local culture in the evening. A lot of local women and families go out to the Souk at night, so I never felt safety was a concern as an American female tourist.

So much to see & buy. Wondering the souk is quite an amazing experience and a great way to spend a few hours out of the heat. The covered roof on many of the streets is a blessing! The vendors were very attentive if you showed interest in their shop but not overly pushy if you just wanted to browse and take in the wares. It can get very crowed at times and we were warned to always keep an hand on your bag and in front of you. We never had issues but followed the advice throughout Marrakech.
Amazing. 1000's of shops and stalls in this amazing maze what an eye opener fantastic!! And there are some great bargains to be had don't visit Marrakesh without a trip to the souk.
Same as the medina. The same as the Medina mind your surroundings. And try not to ask for help if you are on the street ask for help inashop as they can't follow you.

Must-see in Marrakesh. The Souk of Marrakesh is exactly what a souk should be: busy, loud and wonderful. From bras to leather bags to silver bracelets and from cheap headphones to fresh sugarcane juice (qasab, see picture), it's all there, waiting to be found. Do not forget to bargain, you're expected to!

Small shop after small trader and artisan. This amazing place is full interesting nooks and crannies. small shops and some artisans at work on their products. Obviously if you stop to look you are fair game. It is so easy to get lost and not always easy to tear yourself away from the traders who are extreamely keen to make a sale.

Great gifts . Nice place local banter the people were very friendly and comfortable to talk to the area is a awash with goods very fierce competition they all watching each other so if you know how to haggle and bargain hard this is the place for you get that tongue waggling this ain't currys pic world you offer what you feel it's worth they done gent offended that understand it's business as usual !!!!

Wish I had more time. I paid for a guided tour of the souk via an app I downloaded called "Get your guide".I went during the day. I didn't realise just how hot it would be once inside the souk. I managed to buy a tagine at a bargain price of around £20 GBP but I haggled for so long that I almost gave up. There are sooooo many different shops once inside the souk. I advise to go in the evening. Be prepared to haggle and take a fan with you. I had an electrical hand held fan with me. I don't know if I will have time to go again as I go home in 2 days but we shall see.

prepare to be amazed . me n hubby didnt even know this existed but its a must see its a market just like the madina square u have to go pass the souk sign theres shops in alley ways but be careful u can get lost aswell

amazing souk - must do!. One of the great souks of the world.
Just about anything for sale that you might possibly want.
Sounds, smells, tastes....!
Bring your wallet and be prepared to haggle.

Very busy. It is very busy and quite overwhelming if you are not thick skinned. The shop and restaurant owners can be pretty busy and rude if you do not buy or respond to the comments. That said, I love the atmosphere and vibrancy and recommend always travelling with others.

Bargains Galore. Its a labyrinth of stalls and shops but is worth a look around.
Make sure to haggle your price down or you'll pay way more than you need too.

Nice!. One of the best experiences is to trade everything you wanna buy! Trade, trade, trade as much as you can! And don't stop and buy from the first place you see the thing you're interested in, just walk around because another 10+ shoppers might have it, at a different price as well.

Fab experience if you like to haggle.. Large square with hundreds of alleyways and stalls, coming off of it. Snake charmers in the middle. Try the fresh squeezed orange juice but make sure it's not the watered down version. Loads of restaurants and bars with roof top views all around . Go in the day for a quieter experience but go at night for the evening atmosphere.

Beautiful, busy but sometimes dangerous. The medina and souk of Marrakech is one of the most lively I visited in Morocco but this positive aspect is mirrored by threats of mugging, pickpocketing or just being ripped off. As always in Morocco, the price you are offered for goods in the Souk is much beyond what they are worth, always haggle. I was cautious of my valuables and never had a thing taken out my pockets but I suspect it does happen. One night myself and three friends (all males) walked deep into the Souk to find somewhere to eat that might be cheaper and less touristy than the main square. As we walked further the streets became quieter and there were less and less stalls. A man started to lead us back towards the main square but suspecting he'd want money from us we insisted that we'd walk alone. He did not listen. It's worth noting, this was not just because of a language barrier since a member of our group speaks Arabic. After a while the first man left us and another man took his place, the two of them swapping roles as we walked. The second man insisted we pay the first although we had constantly said we would not do so, to both men. The second man became aggressive and threatened each of us with 'a problem' gesturing to his shorts as if he had a knife. Eventually we made it back to the familiar area of the souk unharmed, only shaken.

SOUK SELLS EXCELLENT LAMPS. LA CAVERNE D'ALI BABA (#93 souk) sells lovely metal and glass lamps. I had one shipped to the United States. It was very carefully packed and arrived in excellent condition. When there was a question, the owner called on the phone & sent me an email. Of course you may have to re-wire it for your domestic voltage. It comes with EU voltage and fixtures. More reviews here - https://www.tripadvisor.fr/ShowUserReviews-g293734-d318060-r122831202-Marrakech_Souk-Marrakech_Marrakech_Tensift_El_Haouz_Region.html

Amazing spot. This market is a hive of activity day and night. Day times the market bustles with shoppers and tourists alike as they wander amongst the numerous stalls looking for a bargain or browsing through the thousands of items on sale. The sound of Snake charmers wafts long the air mixed with the smells of cooking foods.Evenings the lights glow illuminating the smoke from a thousand food stalls enticing you with their smells of local cuisine. It is an exotic feat for the senses and so worth a visit. Sure, vendors approach you trying to sell their wares and the slightest glance at a stall will encourage vendors to approach you eager for a haggle. It is however part of the ancient charm of this market and you should just enjoy a visit to this vibrant place.Beware of some of the food stalls especially if you have a suspect tummy, as they can cause stomach upsets. Keep a bottle of water handy for use. Don't let it put you off. It's a wonderful place and a unique slice of life in this city.

Crazy place!. As two white women travelling together I found the souks quite intimidating to begin with. They are very busy, loud and often crazy. So many items on offer, and lots of haggling to be done if you want to get a bargain.

Different . Very hot, but shaded with lots of interesting vendors and products.
You need to be aware of pickpockets, mopeds travelling on the footpaths and lecherous stares from men of all ages if you have a teenage girl with you.
Well worth a visit.

Great experience . Women cover up. So much unwanted attention when me and my friends were there. It was a fun experience never the less couldn't really relax and stroll around and always conscious of scams.

Got to do it !! Cultural and mind blowing !!. Been on guided tours through the souks for the past 11 years. Always a maze of crowded alleyways shared with mopeds and donkeys !! Concentrate on the vibrancy, colour and atmosphere. Shopping can wait until later despite the 'encouragement' of locals !! Be open-minded because this isn't Camden Market. Don't be judgmental because whatever you think, things seem to work !! The tanneries are an experience to be avoided in summer unless you really must !! Come in from the North West corner and do a clockwise loop to the main square

I want to live here!. The ultimate experience of Marrakech: visiting the Souk!! Get lost in the maze, stare in wonder at all the beautiful hand-crafted items, and bring home the most unique, stunning and remarkable souvenirs. Get ready to bargain like you've never done before! Don't take anything personally, it's all part of the game. Have fun with it! Also, bring comfy shoes and clothes, especially if you're travelling in the summer months. The heat is intense - although slightly less-so in the souk as most parts are shaded over.

Bargain to your heart's content!. If you have the time and inclination, you can get very good deals on practically every type of Moroccan souvenir you want to buy - except the dry fruits. They wouldn't reduce even a single dirham from the price of dry fruits! It's a maze but fun to get lost in!

You Get What You Pay For. Absolutely worth wandering around, but beware: the merchants will follow you around throughout the market if you show even a little interest in something.
