There is no such thing here as peaceful browsing -- but don't be afraid to negotiate! A good starting point is 30% of their asking price.

Visit to the souk. Loved it. We were looking forward to a bit of bartering, well my husband was, and we got a couple of bargains. The shop owners don't hassle you to buy, which was great, although the 'lookey lookey' guys will hassle you, but eventually they do take no or an answer. Walking across the Medina we saw snake charmers and men with Barbary Apes which I found upsetting as they were on chains, if people stop taking photos of them this trade would stop. All in all a great experience

Mrs S Sharma. This is a magnificent market square, where you can pick up everything from souvenirs to fresh food! You have to be ready to haggle though. It's an extremely busy market in the evenings. There are snakes, monkeys and baby lambs that you can have your picture taken with! There are bars and restaurants! We went to a Shisha lounge there which had a buy 1 drink and get 1 free Loved the atmosphere. Just wish we had more time there though, as we were only there for the day!

A must do in Marrakech . This is a must do when in the city to really get a feel for Marrakech! Lots of bargains can be found however beware of the workers. I visited with a female friend and we were constantly stared at, heckled and generally made to feel uncomfortable. This is a shame as it is a part of the city which should be seen by all tourists.
Nice place . Beautiful place to visit, don't forget to spend a couple of Hours to visit the market and trade with the sellers. Very beautiful also during the night
Los of bargins. Nice atmosphere, lots to see and buy, lots of entertainment, different in the day and night, must see.

Ladies Beware. The souks are amazing. However I have to stress there are women who will take your arm and atempt to lead you, or henna tattoo the ladies. I walk with a stick and thehand that holds the stick was pulled causing me to fall! Some have no concept of respect. Food is cheap however if you are after local goods, shop around. Most are mass produced, of poor quality and very overpriced! There are bargains to be had tho!

Busy, busy, busy...... Tiny narrow streets where you can buy anything known to man and more, haggle if you really want something or go to the Ensemble Artisan where you can buy in peace and at set prices, you cannot visit Marrakech without a trip to the souks....

Haggle for bargains in the maze of alleyways. You enter the Souk from the main square. The main square has a lot of entertainment, with dancers, monkeys and snake charmers. You did get hassled for money (dirhams) when taking their photos.Once you enter the Souk, there is a myriad of craft, leather and metal workers.There is a number of different smells including spices, herbs, teas, dates and apricots.Traders are constantly trying to get you to come in and view their merchandise. A lot of them understood "No thank you", however some got offensive when you walked off and started shouting and swearing!Remember to bargain for the goods you do want, as some of these goods were purchased at a third of the original offer.We visited during Ramadan, so it was slightly less crowded, however it is still easy to lose your sense of direction in the myriad of alleyways, so try and come back through the alleyways you have come down.Also keep a wary eye out for speeding mopeds!This is a must see when visiting Morocco.We enjoyed this amazing, vibrant and cultural experience.

Our 2nd trip. A vibrant maze of tiny streets full of lots of shops/stalls selling fairly standard goods but with some hidden gems where you can buy more special items. An experience in itself with eateries scattered throughout. You can get a guide but we chose not to, didn't feel intimidated one bit & there was little hard selling. A must visit

Great fun!. Took my time walking through the souks, found some bargains and haggled for some others! Great atmosphere and fun to haggle, drink mint tea and watch everyone and everything how its been for hundreds of years! Be careful to research other stores before commiting and go in with a very low price and very slowly go up, be prepared to walk away. They will call you back! have fun!
Amazing . Beautiful part of Marrakech. Amazing food and entertainment options. Good for families and younger travellers. Went here 3 nights in a row.

A maze of artisans and shops. The souks of Marrakech are really worth a half day. Be prepared to get lost but that is half the fun. Metal workers, leather workers and lots of traditional artisan craft workers can be seen here still.

An experience. visited in the evening, which was recommended due to the temperature. The souk itself is a maze of alleyways. Yes people are trying to garner your business and drag you into see there goods, but a polite no thank you WITH A SMILE, was enough to stop them. Getting out of the souk was a nightmare, which turned very scary. We had asked some people for directions and they pointed us in a direction, which seemed to be going down smaller and smaller alleys, not going out into the wider main area. we stopped again to ask a couple of ladies who were buying food at a stand, and they looked alarmed and told us we had been sent in completely the wrong direction, and not to follow anyone and only ask women for directions. A couple of moments later one of the men we had asked directions of appeared and started shouting at the lady, her response was not good.We followed her advice, and only asked women for directions, and about 25 mins later we made it out into the main square.We did return to the souk, in daylight and it was a far better experience.
Rat run of alley ways. Noisy, smells and easily get lost. The Souks of Marrakech were so interesting and aMust see when visiting Morocco. I really enjoyed the whole experience.

Moroccon delight. You have to be prepared to haggle if you want to buy from this place. Be careful of holding on to your purse as it can very crowded and intimidating. The vendors will try and sell you things that you dont even need and it is easy to get hookedin.Always shop around.
Marrakech Souk is a special one. It is so great to walk in souk, watch people, look how the artisans are doing their work and bargain for goods when you want to buy them. I love souk of Marrakech!

Madness. What I like about Marrakech is delving into the madness, the noise, the color, the smell depending on what is passing by-of leather, spices, herbs, mint, to soaps, jasmine, honey, a sweet, cinnamon. It is a feast for the senses. You can find everything: carpets, leather bean bags, suitcases, bags, slippers, silver, spices, herbs, ceramics, and everything you could imagine. Souk in Arabic means disorder, but in the great disorder is an order, and each souk corresponds to a craft bazaar at the tanners, the silversmith, to the weavers, the potters of the spices, the seller of nuts, suddenly you're walking and you only see dates and apricots.
Amazing views from restaurant roof tops. Very reasonably priced cafe's with roof terraces that offer amazing views. Beware of the henna women grabbing arms to use black henna!

Fantastic experience!. The contrast from afternoon souks to nighttime souks is amazing! Afternoons is perfect for shopping and nights are crammed with street entertainment, food, henna painting etc. Be prepared to give small amounts of money to beggars/children/disabled. Loved every minute of it and will be returning in April!

Madness. Make sure you you go down an alley way and come back up as if you keep going you will get lost. We didn't realise just how big the Souks was. I personally don't think it's ideal for kids as its just too manic. A henna lady grabbed my sons arm and done henna on him the demand 500 dirham which I refused to pay she was very threatening so I gave her 100 Dirham and told her no more. There are some beautiful items you can get from there from pottery to rugs. There are a lot of fake goods shops. Good experience
Souk.... As long as you are ok with the hassle, you will enjoy the souk. Many shops in narrow streets, you have to bargain the prices. Walk around and enjoy looking at the shops.
Do not recommend!. You should take care! Take a guide with you out maybe a local friend. People are not to be relied on. It's a maze there and you can get lost really easily. Just take care!!!

less original, but more acceptable for Europeans, I suppose. Comparing to Fes - it is more ordered and cleaner perhaps. Meaning - reminds me a bit of Grand Bazaar in Istanbul. Bargaining for everything is a standard here - you will love it or hate it :)A minus for motor bikes as a usual mode of transport :(

Ali Baba and so many carpets!. Crowded, with people from all over the world and from all walks of life; full of color, smell of spices and perfumes, of fruits and vegetables, of wood and metal and all types of merchandise. One can get lost: better have a guide.

Lively with bargin prices. Souks are massive and a part of a fun is to get lost between stalls and shops. I loved walking around and looking at the bags and jewelry, some shop owners were calling me in but if I said no they respected that. The only problem was the local people who tried to convince us that every pathway or road is closed in order to guide us somewhere else and get money for that. Some people were really annoying, trying to follow us for next few minutes.

Shopping the Souk. On an extremely hot day we had a great walk around the Souk. It was cooler in the souk than outside due to being in the shade. We had an excellent day and although everyone wants you to shop with them there is no pressure and no hard sell.You can wander around all day but a few hours is more than enough, you will get lost and find yourself again and this is all part of the adventure. Do watch out for the guys whole give you directions on where to go but take you along to a shop where they are on commission.

Sooo many shops. You've never seen so many shops in all your life. Easy to get lost but if you're prepared for that, just wonder and enjoy. Does get old ppl hassling you to shake hands, come into my shop etc. That always puts me off and I refuse to ever go in with pushy salesmen as so many others selling same thing. I didn't buy anything but was experience you have to do in Marrakech to at least see what it's all about. If you get claustrophobic you might not like it.

Crazy fun at night. Love this place....the smells the colours the people! Everyone wants you to visit their shop or offer help but we just love getting lost in the souk which are laden with all kinds of shops! This is a hagglers dream! Best quote ' sir this is a real genuine fake!' Be wary of the henna tattoo ladies....they have serious grips and once they have grabbed hold you ain't going nowhere! They then expect to be paid for the forced henna tattoo! Keep my hands in my pockets now! Definitely to be experienced as unforgettable...great place to just take time and soak it all in

Souk without any hassle . The souk was okay. I was worried about shop owners touting calling you in to shop which can be annoying but this didn't happen which was so great to look around without the hassle.
Souk souk. Busy way to shop huge choice clothes gifts food must haggle it's expected means of shopping don't expect things to have price tags Generally people friendly and polite so not too difficult

Truly exciting. The Souk in Marrakech is one of those experiences that is impossible to forget. It is one of those sensory experiences that is complete 1. seeing - things that are unique and so very different to the UK 2. smell - the spices are awesome - for instance - just entering into the small square where Café des Epices is located and the spice smell is wonderful3. taste - some of the wares are great (but beware flies and sugary foodstuffs though!)4. Sound - from the bartering, the hubbub of masses of people of many nationalities, to the sounds of the call to prayer - completely different to my part of the world....!5. Touch - two aspects here when I think about it - be careful when bartering - touching an object can tie you into a negotiation that you may find difficult to get out of - (these guys are good!). On the main alleyways, the crowds and people mauling trinkets is one thing, but go slightly off the beaten track and the handling of goods signifies considerable intent to purchase - be wary (see review of Shopping tour of Marrakech Souks for more!). However, also wrt this aspect, you might easily think that there would be hustle / bustle and pushing / shoving - but there is NOT. Don't be frightened. Yes - keep a close eye on the scooters and donkeys etc, that share the alleyways, but people in the UK could learn a lot from the avoidance of barging / contact in a crowd - truly amazing and says a lot for the people - just getting on with life.As far as the variety of material on sale - highly enjoyable.By the way - if you don't get lost - then you haven't explored.[Camera phones are good ways to take snapshots of junctions to remind you of your way back to base / the J'maa.]

Same as a market!. Visited souk one evening last week. Worth paying for a guide to gain more of an experience and insight. It was hot and crowded. Haggle for everything. Leather bags, belts etc - real and fake. Clothing, slippers etc. Plenty if freshly cooked food. Entertainment in main square til after midnight. Beware of henna ladies offering henna. Went for the experience but wouldn't rush back.
Mel hovell. Went souk with guide tour with thomson holidays had a fab time we went to the bakers chemists the metal workers very interesting then went round the souk shopping loved bartering

A must-see cultural experience. As others have said, a warren of small lanes crammed with stalls and sellers. Many areas are covered so it is a bit cooler than it otherwise would be. We had an interesting experience on our first day with a friendly man who pretended to know us from our riad (we were skeptical but didn't want to be rude) and told us we should go to the "Berber rug auction that is held only every 2 weeks". Then he just happened to see "a Berber man I know who is going that way" and would show us. Since we were going roughly in that direction anyway, we did follow him. However (of course) we were brought to a permanent- looking rug shop and given the hard sell for a few minutes before we extricated ourselves. We never felt unsafe...just not very comfortable.

Maze of visual and smell delights. Be prepared to take a lot longer than you anticipated as a 10 minute walk takes 30 minutes due to being stopped and asked about shop wares. Men and boys alike stare intently at your female companions which can be a little unsettling but they mean no harm other than white skinned humans are reasonably rare. Amazing culture with no animosity between religions, that make you wish that the rest of the world could take note.

It's enormous!. If you go to Marrakech you go to the Souk , otherwise, why are you there. Many items can be purchased for as little as a third of the original offer. Why they start their bargaining so high ? It's worth a try I guess.

Beware of the snake chalmers. The souks are a great place to buy lots of items. Very colourful and so many things one can buy. However beware of the Snake Chalmers. Don't take photo's unless you are prepared to pay for them. A lot of the moroccans will want money if you take their photo. As we found out. Oh well once bitten, twice shy.

So Stressful!. Some reviewers have written they love to get lost in the souks. I did get lost and there was nothing to love about it. There are few exits so I felt a bit trapped. One of the locals saw me wandering and offered to show me an exit. I know I shouldn't have said yes but I did. He did show me out, but when I couldn't find a small bill to tip him with he shouted every obscenity you could possibly imagine at me. So definitely go, and have some small bills handy for when you get lost!!

Place not to be missed. There was something for everyone nice souvenirs delicious pure orange juices had more than a few. Topped my vitamin c also restaurants with delicious tanjine dishes. There were leather handmade bags and sandles.Clothes and lovely printed scarfs and shawls. Entertainment for the whole family. Safe and secure area running throughout the night. Highly recommended to visit enjoyment and shopping under one roof for the whole family wish I could go again if I had the money.

Too crazy for me!. Souk madness is real. I felt like a cornered rat in a maze with no view of the skies. Although they say that getting lost is part of the charm I felt that people were deliberately giving wrong directions. It certainly is fine for a half day but that's about it. Not my cup of tea!

Wonderfully overwhelming!!!. As an avid shopper, the souks with all of it's twists and turns is shopping heaven. We went through some parts of it before we bought anything. We had to get an idea of what was sold and what we were interested in. It can a bit much to have merchants calling to you to look at and buy their wares. If you show any interest they put the hard sell on you and don't want to take no for an answer. My daughter and ended up prioritizing tge things we were interested in buying and then went to the stalls where the merchandise looked the best. Basically the same merchandise was being sold from stall to stall, but some charged a high price and were stubborn. That made it easy to just walk away, because you would see the same thing a few stalls down. This is a must see and must experience place. WOW!!!

Single mum and two kids (aged 4 and 10). Don't get a guide... Bring a compass with you! Sorted. Didn't get lost once, explored deep within all of it and found our way out perfectly fine on two separate occasions.

Do not go. I always wanted to go here. All my adult life. Hated it. I grew up in Saudi so thought it would be similar but....nope. Total nightmare. Pestered badly. Grabbed by women and men alike. Followed by xhildren begging for over a mile!!! Was meant to stay 4 hours. I lasted just over an hour and HATED every second. Horrible horrible people. Would NEVER go back.

Inspiring manifold place. For all the shopping, antique, vintage, furniture, fashion, ceramics, interior, shoe lovers - this is the place! We loved to get lost here every day during our trip, we discovered a new area every day, carpenters, basketmakers, spices, everything that comes to your mind, you should get it here in each color you can imagine!Great for all those who love all the beautiful things, to walk around and bargain a little over a nice tea - my favorite place in the city :)

interesting. busy and alive!
even though, weather was hot, but we still enjoyed our tour. watch out from beggers. best time to go is between 7pm and 11pm.

Nuts. Amazing place. Would be even better if you were not badgered into things.lots of little alleyways with intriguing sights smells and traditional music. Watch your back for scooters I nearly got run over a few times.

Amazing. This my second time here.You can buy anything you want and need. Clothes, ethnic clothes, souvenirs, jewellery, shoes, bags, leather goods, kids stuff, lighting lanterns, food, Everything. This is the place to do you shopping if you want to buy gifts because you haggle and get a low price. I hit a pair of harem trousers for 60dhirams down from 120dhirams

A lot of souvenirs stands. *its better to go here at the evening around 7 or 8pm,. It is located just behind the square, * YOU MUST!negociate for the Price ALWAYS! you can have your wanted things for a cheaper price,. **Don't show them that you are so interested for that thing for they can took advantage for that. **otherwise, theres a lot of interesting things here

Maze of streets. With something like 400 streets and 1600 shops it is very very easy to get lost in here. Have a plan of how and where to get back to the entrance by turning alternate left then right to then reverse when wanting to leave. Watch out for the unofficial guides who will take you to their friends or cousins stalls where you are sure to get ripped off. Try to start very low as they will start very high in bartering terms. Pay roughly 1/3 of the initial asking price, if you are not convinced ,walk away they will soon run after you if they want your custom.Above all stay calm

Eye opener. I had heard stories about the souks and was fearful of going but so glad I did !! Yes you get hassled but a no is all that's needed. The people are friendly but we warned touch it and it's yours . It's like a different world and it's certainly different to Asda lol!! Great to see how they live and shop. Now I've been I wouldn't go again it's a been and experienced it and that's enough.

Scary place . HighlightsAbsolutely beautiful rugs, ornaments, pottery and metal work. Lots of spices and fresh food. This place is huge. You can haggle to reduce the price. Lots to see. The handbags range in quality so check the product you are buying carefully as it may be different from the display oneDownside Some of the vendors are aggressive and it can be quite intimidating. We actually got lost in the winding lanes and dead ends and almost missed the bus back to the hotel. The smell can also be quite overwhelming is places. Quite a few beggars. Motorbikes and cyclists will just ride into you and people will barge into you.

Horrible. Just avoid nothing to see same stalls with the same overly priced crap. Rude people they will shout abuse at you if you don't buy, they will start of with a ridiculous high price do not buy haggle personally everything at the stall I wouldn't pay more that 50dh
very interesting. lovely people, be prepared to haggle, they do not bother you once you say no thanks. plenty to choose from.

"Amazing places to visit". The Souk is amazing,with so many colours,sights and sounds which seem to change depending on the time of day or night.I loved this is where you can learn to bargain and get the best deal you can do.
Colors of the East. All colors of the East are here. You can find a lot of interesting and genuine things. But be aware of the initial prices, you should lower them at least by half or even more.

Massive Souk... Taken back by sheer size of the place, full of some pretty amazing stuff. Some irritating shop keeps but if you just say no and ignore them they leave you alone. Mostly covered so can brave in the fierce heat. Prepare to get lost in the maze .. Keep reference of some shops to help when you want to leave. We got lost and had to take taxi back home I didn't feel cheated on any purchases as I paid what I thought was a fair price.. We all need to make a living after all!!

I was robbed!!. Night one - Arrived at the hotel around 10pm, decided to go straight to the Souks as we were so excited to finally be in Morocco.Within minutes of being there, we had shop keepers calling us in, people heckling us asking us to buy excursions and little children following us, explaining that they were sick and needed money.At first we were taking all of this into our stride. We had read the warning reviews but being quite a savvy, and usually street wise couple, we thought we'd be fine.Soon after we reached the main square my partner walked over to an orange juice stall to buy us two fresh OJ's for the visit. Suddenly when I was stood waiting for my partner to finish his purchase, a woman came up behind me and grabbed my skinny arm extremely tightly. With her other hand she started quickly applying Henna from a syringe to my arm and hand. I tried to tug away and explain I didn't want this, and my partner turned around and was also unhappy about the situation. Suddenly about five more Henna women approached my boyfriend, attempting to put Henna on him to. It was really stressful but we agreed to let them do it, after all it would only cost equivalent to £3 sterling right? WRONG. Quickly as my boyfriend was still surrounded she started screaming “800 Dirham, pay me, pay me!”. Now £800 is about £60 so instantly I was saying no, that’s too much, but then more women were screeching for me to “PAY HER, PAY HER” for the flower she’s drawn on my arm. My money was in my bum-bag and so I undid the top zip, to get her 100 Dirham out (£7 approx). Suddenly she stuck her finger into my bum bag and started ripping all the notes out, and then ran off. In total she took £75 from me and then the other women had the cheek to demand another £15 off my boyfriend. It was very intimidating, and an awful start to the holiday. We made a quick exit back to the hotel.A couple of days later, not wanting to let the event of Night 1 deter us from experiencing the Souks, we hired a guide. WOW what a difference! Nobody approached us, although we still had the usual heckling when walking past the stalls. We had chance to delve further into the Souks, and make a few purchases, but there was no trouble and we felt far less intimidated. We were slightly disappointed with the variety of stalls, as most were copies of one another selling either pottery, spices, leather, teapots and wooden decorative items, Moroccan clothing, or rip-off brands of fashion clothing. All in all though - a successful day.We were all Souked- Out to be honest so didn’t visit again until the last day of the holiday. We wanted to spend our remaining Dirham’s and after our last visit we decided we were brave enough to go alone, not wanting to pay for a guide again. Within seconds of arriving, we walked past the men with monkeys on chains, to get past into the Souks. They approached us and before we knew it, I had a monkey sat on my shoulder. Having learned our lesson my boyfriend agreed a price this time before hand, of around £3.50 for a photo. The men took our phones and began snap, snap, snapping. Suddenly the price had risen to £15. We couldn’t be bothered with the agro so paid it. We ventured into the Souks slightly, to the area which looks like an indoor street. My boyfriend wanted a wallet so we looked at a few on our way through. The second we laid eyes on anything the stall-keeper would demand “how much you pay? How much you pay?” And on a couple of occasions when we said no they screamed “you go then! And go quick!” which was really scary. Soon, as advised would happen without a guide, we were lost. We were at a sort of cross-roads area and were deciding which row to venture down next, when a man who appeared to be friendly approached us. He advised us that he spoke English and would be happy to point us in the right direction. We asked him where the best leather shops were and he told us his friend (who came out of nowhere) worked in the main leather section and would take us there. The friend was walking really quickly, we could barely keep up, through lots of confusing, winding roads and alley ways. After 5 minutes we stopped thinking that something wasn’t quite right, when the gentleman turned around and pointed to a sign saying “tannery” to show us we were getting close. We then reached another man who gave me and my partner a lime leaf each to smell and began to tell us how the leather was made and dyed etc. We quickly stopped him as we didn’t want a “tour” or we just wanted the shop, so he took us next door to the leather shop. Everything in there was way out of our price range, with bags costing the equivalent of £900 upwards, so we decided to leave. The man who gave us the lime leaves was waiting outside and started screaming at us to give him 100D for the tour. My partner said no, we hadn’t had or asked for a touch and he continued screaming at us with obscenities that are far too aggressive to put on here. Then he jumped on his moped and started following us around, continuing his swearing and shouting. We were so intimidated, and there didn’t appear to be any English tourists or any policy around to lean on for support. My partner advised me to pretend that I knew where I was and to walk quickly. Eventually we finally found our way back to the main square again when we were simply ready to leave.The souks are not cheap, like we’d been advised, apart from the OJ. Nobody ever gives you a reasonable price to start with, and even after tiresome bartering, you’d only be able to get items down to the price you’d find something similar for in Next or TK Max. Everybody wants something from you; everyone turns vicious if you won’t part with your Dirham’s. At one stage we had a 5ft 5 bloke following us around pretty much demanding money from us, without having anything to sell to us. I’d be really careful, it was scary for us and I went with a bloke, I can’t imagine how scary it would be on your own or with just females. My friend went with her female friend before I’d been and they caught a plane home after day 2. Although I didn’t let this put me off, I can now see why she made that decision.Please don’t hate me for this post, I know the Souks have many fans, but if I can prevent one person from getting robbed like I did, then my post has been successful.
Amazing Souk. We didn't really want to buy anything but came out with bags full. From spices, nuts and more. You have to haggle, great fun !

Crazy big shopping area. This is a city center and one of the biggest souks we saw. Mark your entrance to make sure you know where to get out from. It was fun getting lost in souks and looking at the colorful shops selling clothes, jewelry, artifacts and local artist stuff. There are lots of open eating areas for the brave hearted.This place is open until late night. Beware of pick pockets.

Shop,explore,enjoy,experience. A MUST see if you're going to Morocco. There's so much commerce going on and the leather goods and hand crafted items are just to die for. The souks provide us with the authentic Moroccan bazar shopping, they are like a maze, cobbled, not very buggy friendly I might add, and if your interested in buying something haggle haggle haggle! Also ask around before you commit to the first shop as you might find something better just a shop ahead. Start with a third of the price n work your way up. The locals are very welcoming and contrary to other travelers I've never felt harassed, they just want your business n if you're not interested just smile n walk away. I really enjoyed getting lost in the souks :) will definitely visit again if I got the opportunity.
Great for shopping local stuff. There a lot of things to buy from local herbs, hand made stuff and accessories even some cute little animals
I promise you, you'll get lost!. We had a guide take us around here and that makes a world of difference. The other option is to enter the Souk and simply roll with it, because you will get lost!

Overwhelming experience . I was advised to rent a guide to take me around the souk. So I am glad I did as a solo traveler I don't think I would have survived. So many store owner wanting you to have a look in their shop. No is always a nice strong word to use. The markets were amazing so many different areas, lights, leather, blacksmiths ... My guide showed me lots I think I would have got lost with out him. He knew how to haggle with traders and got some good deals. The square area had lots of street entertainment from dancers to snake charmers and outside cafes. I would be very careful when you take out your camera or you will attract a lot of performers for a "nice price" to have their photo taken. I tried to only use my phone. It is definitely worth having a look through, an amazing experience.

Shop shop shop! Fantastic range of options and easy bartering.. LOVED the souks in Marrakech! If you are new to shopping in less western style environments like souks and markets then Marrakech is actually in my opinion, a pretty good and easy start and introduction. The range of good and craftmanship is fantastic, especially if you stray a little into the further back souks away from the Djema square. When shopping in any market like this, the important thing to bear in mind is not "how cheap can I get this" but "do I want this, and what do I think is a fair price". Obviously its nice to get a bargain, but as long as its a fair price, it leaves me feeling happy as a consumer. My second piece of advice, SMILE! Being approached by sellers and talking about buying is a unfamiliar process for many, but in the majority I found the sellers in Marrakech to be polite, and helpful and not at all aggressive. You can find workmans stalls of lamps, leather goods, ceramics, textiles, its an aladdins cave of shopping, stopping off every so often for some tea along the way. This is a great shopping experience. Ask for items to be packed for flights as well and the sellers will, in my experience oblige. A lot if places also accept cards for larger items but its useful to have cash, Obviously dont be waving this around too much! If you are looking for more western style goods, then then there are some great shops on and around Avenue Mohammed V, great stored for leather bags, luggage and shoes. Marrakech is a shoppers dream destination!

Need to See This. Something for everyone from shoes, to gowns, to candy, purses, shirts, snake charmers, brace wear etc! Loaded with venders who are ready to deal prices! You haggle prices until you come together! After awhile you just want a fixed amount and go on! Very colorful and a must see spot!

Spend a day and get lost.. Food, drink, spices, leather, glass, clothes, bags, shoes, - for what seems to be endless covered walk ways, which you will share with tourists, locals, donkeys, carts, mopeds. every one of the thousands of stall holders will attempt to get you in and will offer you the best deal. Generally what ever the price they say the real price is half! it takes time to get to this level often with saying thanks and walk out the door (you can always get the exact same thing in the next 20 yds) - most times the price will come down.3 top tips:1) don't make eye contact, don't reply when spoken to BUT smile and walk on. (this is not an insult - just practical help to get along a road with out being constantly accosted).2) have the exact right change (lots of small denomination notes and coins (no one has change!!!).3) have a Hamman, Grommage and Massage - awesome

Average. It was nice walking around but we didn't feel comfortable to stop and look at things as the shop owners hassle you to buy. Also a lot of strangers try to give you directions etc. We read about the scams so we would always ignore them which made us felt anti-social. To be honest all of Marrakech was like that.

Breathtaking Commerce. The variety, quality and quantity of goods for sale is simply breathtaking. The Souk is a maze of trade and life. Don't be scared of getting lost, just dive in and enjoy the markets, vendors and street stalls in all their glory. Get some street smarts, buy a map, use google maps, smile and ask for help if you need it. Most of all shop till your hearts content or simply enjoy the life that pulses all around.

Bargains Galore - if you know how to bargain!!. Great place to wander around aimlessly taking in all the sights and sounds, everyone was very friendly and welcoming. Easy to get lost, but just as easy to find your way back out to the main square, so many knick knacks to buy.
nice. You can find anything in here, it is incredible. The sellers are quite overwelming while trying to get you in their shops yet nice.

Quite an experience. Loved visiting the Souk in Marrakech. Vibey, colourful and filled with interesting smells. Venture deep into the massive market place to find hidden gems and better prices. Late afternoon and evenings are even better as there is a completely different, more lively atmosphere

Fun. Best not to touch stuff unless you want it. Dont buy anything until you have looked around and always barter. So many stalls. The fresh orange juce is delicious and refreshing. Have fun. Dont walk round in little shorts or mini skirts or you will be harrased. Best to respect the locals.

An amazing experience! Thank you Marrakechdaytrips,com. We had a great day tour organised by Marrakechdaytrips. com. The guide walked us through the Kasbah, Medina and Souk. We had a great lunch which was included and we saw all the important historical sites in a timely manner. The souk is a smorgasbord of delights! There is so much to see and choose from Argan oil to silver to slippers to scarves etc etc , but if you want anything more than cheap trinkets, you need to go there with a licensed guide. You will be hassled from the start to the end but it's a great experience and they back off when the realise no means no. I highly recommended tour if you only have a day or two to enjoy Marrakech.

Very scary at night. At night this place oils scary but we went on a tour during the day and it was fine. We were taking money out of the bank and a man was standing behind a piller and when we walked off he came up to us and said im form your hotel I'll show u around but one of the persons with me seen us lift the money and told my dad so we let him walk on and we turned round and went back to hotel So if your going here have money with you befor you go in so this doesn't happen to u

Fantastic. A great experience, sights and sounds just amazing. Really important to understand that YOU DO NOT HAVE TO BUY ANYTHING if you don't want to. We spent hours walking around enjoying it all, sure you will be invited to buy everything but it was never aggressive or alarming, just say no thanks and walk on. If you relish the fun of haggling, go for it and remember it's just a game.Wouldn't say a guide was essential although I can understand the benefits, but try to get some advice you trust before setting out particularly on finding your way around. But if you do get confused, just ask the way back to the square and start again.Be bold and go for it.
A little to comnercial. Great experience, thought the comments as cheap as asda spoiled the visit, better going as a group of people.
lovely Souk. Lovely Souk and worth visiting. It has a local feel to it and the buzz at night is amazing.You will have to barter to get the best price but its worth it :)

Day out. Took a guided tour of the souk with Lalla a government appointed guide. Cost 300 dirhams for about 3 hours. She explained about the better quality products being inside the souk rather than in the square. Bartered with the taxi drived for the fare and advised how much certain trips should cost by taxi. Showed us a place to change our sterling for a better rate than the bank. We went to some quite specific traders while on the tour, so I guess there was some type of agreement, but there was no obligation to buy anything, but they will try. Enkoyed it and probably got a lot less hastle as we were with a guide.
Madness by Day and Night. A great place to visit when in Marrakech. It can be busy and very hot during the day and don't forget to haggle on the first price given.

Practice your haggling skills. This is a great place to visit but be prepared to be hassled as you move from stall to stall.....come and seek, looking is free easily becomes a pressure sale so if you are not interested in the items on the stall.....politely refuse and move on. There are a plethora of 'guides' who want to take you to the 'best' place, but it is obvious that there are a number of alliances formed....you get the tourists and bring them to my stall and we profit share. Be firm and confident in your ability to navigate the area, you can't get lost in the Souk, just make note of various vendors and landmarks. All roads lead back to the square.Be prepared to haggle and haggle hard, I got items for up to 1/5th less than the original asking price.....if they are not prepared to hagglrpe, move on there are plenty more of the same to choose from

Marrakech Souk. The Souk is an attack of the senses. There's so much to see with fantastic colours everywhere, slippers, rugs, tagines, clothing, jewellery etc. It really is a maze & you need to dedicate time to it. The Souks are not to be rushed, the vibrancy & life should be enjoyed, taking the sights & sounds in as you weave in & out of various shops & alleys. It is an absolute must, a beautiful, enchanting, exhilarating & powerful experience.

Very busy and hot. The souks are good to visit if you are looking for a cheap souvenir from Marrakesh. They also sell fake goods at a cheap rate. They are very busy with loads of people and animals. There is not much protection from the sun here and no air conditioning.

Aggressive Salespeople. Walked around the souk at about 21:00-22:00, when it seems everyone is eating. Every stall we passed was very aggressive in having us stay for food.It was very busy, and not well lit, with many people bumping into you as you walked around. Some places smelt great, though!

Shopping gone mad. Unbelievable experience - always be polite - although you may be pestered constantly do not be rude remember this is how this people make a living. Did not like the poor wee monkeys SO do not let them put the monkeys on you as they will want money for the pleasure and a picture, the same as the SNAKES! if you are watching and take a photo with your phone they will come over not terribly happy and demand money. BUT! enjoy it was a brilliant experience so please go and experience the Souk
Lovely souk. Lovely market. Plenty of souvenirs shops. Make sure you bargain if you decide to buy something from there. It is much cheaper than Minara mall.

Overwhelming.... I visited the souks with my partner and had read previous reviews and warnings about the souks but nothing can prepare you till your there.As soon as we entered the market we were chastised as we walked with people constantly coming up to my partner trying to push us into their shops. Because of this we weren't actually able to have a proper look at anything as we felt harassed. After many no's we ended up giving in to one gentlemen which wanted to show us his spice shop. We had a sit down were his colleague explained about all the teas and products they had, we sat and listed baring in mind we had no intention of buying any of this as we mainly came to the souks for leather goods and little trinkets rather than spices and tea. However I was appreciative of the man's efforts as he explained everything well and clearly so I bought some tea as a thank you thinking this was enough. He was visibly not happy that I only bought 1 thing and his attitude changed.After another 15 mins in the souks we just wanted to get out so we left.As we were leaving I was approached by a women who offered to do henna on me. I politely declined , she acknowledge I said no yet proceeded to hold my arm and put henna on my hand. My boyfriend had to step in and ask her to stop. We then was approached by a group of men in traditional clothing who asked of we wanted to take a phot with them. After the photo they started asking for money for the photo my boyfriend gave 10dhs and they wanted more. At this point we was sick of the constant ask for more money and just walked away. When walking away we was approached by a little boy who was begging. After saying no because by this point we had given out a lot of money to beggars and people in general we said no. He then tried to prevent my boyfriend from walking by holding onto his arm and pushing him back. My boyfriend was really uncomfortable with this so gave him dirhams to leave us alone.That was our experience of the souks , I'm glad i got to experience it for myself however I wouldn't go back.

If you like markets or just want to feel the atmosphere of Arab-world traditional souk. The place is different during the day and in the night.In the night - there are a lot of different food stands with very basic prices. Also a lot of artists with all kind of acts that may be interesting for someone.Very crowded of course. Be careful with your bags ( as at any market ).Shopping experience: first it is better if you know Arabic or French. English is not very useful here ..If you are not going to buy the item, just curious - do not ask for a price. The moment you ask the price they are not leaving you and get very angry if you are not buying.So if you really likes something - then ask and start bargaining. Usually you will be able to get to some acceptable for everybody price.Finally - it is extremely hot in the summer.

Get a tour guide . Very interesting place in which you learn just by visiting the lifestyle of the people that live and work there. You will find restaurants and markets. At the markets make sure to ask for a lower price and in many places you can pay with dollars and euros. The market owners are not humble but very persistent when you past by their stores. Have small bills ready to shop.

Ruined Morocco for us!!. We got off the hotel run shuttle bus and were immediately disgusted, horses and carriages lined a walkway and it stunk of their poo and god knows what else. All of the animals were in terrible condition, the horses had open wounds from the chains they were in and all of them looked distressed. Almost immediately some fancy dressed guy insisted we take a photo then demanded 100 dirhams - roughly £10, for a photo!!! We refused but he seemed almost aggressive in enforcing his charge. Then before we even made it into the Souk my hand was snatched by a woman and she started doing henna on me, little did I know that she would then request 2000 dirhams for it (£200)!!! I tried to haggle with her - seeing as I didn't ask for it and as we only had 750 dirhams left (it was the 2nd day) between us but she refused and said that she would come back to our hotel with us, or walk us to an atm!! We ended up giving them all the money that we had, and immediately turned around and got back onto the coach, we didn't even make it to the market!! It totally put us off Morocco as a country, I know it's prejudice but we were completely conned of all our money on the second day of our holiday.

unfortunate. The day we visited it decided to absolutely hammer down so was not a great day. The souk came across as just pure mayhem & chaos Stall holders shouting out at everyone walking past (then sounding abusive & rude if you didn't buy from them )& none of the goods being sold or the premises looked particularly inviting. Maybe it looks better in the sunshine but not so sure.....

A must when visiting Marrakesh. A veritable treasure trove like Aladdin's Cave where you can buy beautiful, hand-crafted and colourful Moroccan products. It is a labyrinth but don't worry about getting lost because that is part of the experience. Remember to haggle and take plenty of cash!
Exotic . Very amazing place where get lost is a pleasure. A sea of contrast and a great opportunity to discover Moroccan souks!!!
One time to visit. It was too crowd and feels like everyone look at me.You could feel what is authentic tour here.

Good place to buy Moroccan Stuff. Similar to your typical souks you see in the Arab World. However, they do have some nice handi craft stores, and this is the place to buy spices and oils. Very reasonably priced and all authentic and originals.

Go there. Just do it. . Fabulous adventure. Hit the souks. Haggle over prices, don't get put off by the hard sell. Find little treasures like cafe des epices and Le Jardin. Drink mint tea. Hit the Jembaa at night. The only certainty is that you will get lost. But whatever you do don't get taken in by the rogues who supposedly help you find the way. They get you lost on purpose then want money, and can be really unpleasant ( even physical one time). Refuse them firmly they can ruin your experience, and more troubling is that no one else comes to your help or even offers sympathy.

Lovely to walk around, easy to get lost. Lots to see and buy. We resisted temptation and bought items out of this area, where the locals buy things. It is a blaze of colour and scents.Things to take with you: i loaded an offline map of the city. Marrakech from GPSmyCity was good as it can show you where you are and can track where you are walking. Means you cannot get lost.We had a number of people offering us directions who we politely declined or ignored. Sunglasses help block eye contact, as do hats.In this area, you will get charged tourist prices, more than double. We bought some plain tagines (to actually use) for 50MAD in the souk they wanted 120 for a similar tagine (price drops as you walk away)We had people saying hello and asking us the time to engage in conversation and then offer to show us the markets.. Having a map to hand helps. What i really liked was hitting some of the back alleys where they actually make the stuff. Language can be a bit of an issue here, i speak some french so could get by. We did not get accosted by henna ladies. Some stalls have misleading prices to get you in. If that is the case, we walked Away.Definaltly worth a visit, haggle hard if you do want something, dont accept their first offer as it will be double the normal rate. Tell them you have seen it on the way into the souk at half the price and you had not started haggling with the. We told them we were not paying tourist prices.We felt safe and secure at all times. You do need to keep your eyes and ears peeled as there are lots of scooters running through the area.As mentioned, and off line map with gps is crutial to enjoying yourself without the worry of where you are or how to get out/back

Mad wonderful place.. Haggle haggle haggle .............. check the prices in the fixed price shops it will give you an idea of what you should pay ......... usually about one third of the initial asking price is the norm... if you agree a price then you are honour bound to pay. Visit the tanneries ... its smelly but a great experience cost about €10 a head make sure you are taken back to Le Place ( The Square ) souk is a maze of tiny alleys.... or it will cost you again to be taken to the square.

A different shopping experience.. This is extraordinary. So much choice and can be a bit overwhelming to the newcomer. Take your time to explore and compare prices with each stall. Do not feel obliged to buy as there will always be another place to get what you want. The stalls around the square tend to be more expensive, so wander deeper into the Souks to get more of a choice at cheaper prices. If haggling is not your thing, then maybe try the Ensemble Artisanal instead for fixed price goods and a quieter, more sedate shopping experience.
Be confident!. Fabulous place...amazing. Be confident in your bargaining...but always polite. About half their initial suggestion of a price can be a rough guide.

A must go!!. Crazy crazy place but absolute amazing talent and crafts all made by hand in a tiny little square unit!! Just keep your hands in your pocket and be firm when haggling!! It gets enjoyable after your first couple of goes at it!! Felt very safe though!!

Shop till you drop but HAGGLE. Be prepared to lose your bearings take cash but make sure it's 10s 20s and 50sA great trick once they have finished haggling with you is to say they haven't got change. Some of the the shopkeepers can be rude in their sales technique some are just plain rude just about stopping short of pulling you into their shops. One guy put his arm round me and said "my friend do me a favour come to my store" if you have trouble with this kind of thing just dont make eye contact and no matter how much they call you don't react keep walking. Whatever price they quote you is just an opening salvo. They come in high, respond low really really low. We wanted some items from a store he asked for 300 I came back with 50 eventually met in the middle. Hold your ground and don't be afraid to walk away. Lots if the stalls sell the same thing. Remember that anything western is fake don't come back with a pair of Nikes that you have a pair of actual Nikes so buyer beware. If you want that sort of thing go to Carre Eden the whole area is European brands or try the Minara Mall where there are plenty of Italian brands.

Hustle. Everybody wants to sell you stuff. It's overwhelming. Don't visit this if you are not in the mood to shop. If you don't like to be hustled, visit Essaouira's souks instead. It's smaller and calm.

Shop The Artist Cooperative Instead. Our tour leader said to wait until Marrakech to buy the majority of our Moroccan items because the prices at the souk were so low. Boy was he wrong! We actually went to the government run artist coop first to get an idea of the prices before going to the souk. What we found is a) the prices are lower for most items b) the variety and quality of the items is MUCH better (we bought things that the we never saw anywhere else) and c) they DO bargain. We went to the souk and found the same items stall to stall and the owners wouldn't really bargain. In fact we were kicked out of 3 shops. So our recommendation is go to the coop (which is in the shade a much cooler) and skip the souk. You won't be disappointed.

Very unusual . Rather unusual experience for an average European person. At first it seems there is a lot of different stuff at every shop. But then you will see, that most of goods are the same. Especially leather. Nevertheless, it is also easy to find something truly unique. Don't be afraid to get loss there always will be someone who can help you to find the way out. Better avoid the living part of medina. There is nothing special and it will be rather hard to get out of there.A little tip: if you're thirsty and there is no place to buy water, try to eat a cactus (photo 4). It tastes good and really refreshing. Usually costs 1-2 DHM per 1 item.

The heart of Moroccan life. If you don't go into the souks here, you're missing a major part of the life and history of Morocco.It can be overwhelming. There's so much to see, and often you don't get to look over items at your leisure because the shopkeepers want to help you and make a sale. The main thing you can do if you don't want to buy anything is to just keep walking and smile and say no when a vendor tries to entice you into the shop. Just keep your cool and your sense of humor, and enjoy the uniqueness of it all.If you are worried about getting lost or going alone, ask your hotel or riad for a guide. There will be many people offering to guide you around once you enter Jemaa Square, but it would be better to get a more trusted reference. You will still, no doubt, be steered to a shop owned by a cousin or friend of your guide, but you can just look and not buy. But there are many beautiful things for sale, so you no doubt will be tempted by much of it!The biggest challenge in the souks is avoiding the motorcyclists who seem to think they're driving in the Indy 500!

Fascinating . Very interesting to walk around although can be a little confusing at times, it's useful to hire a local guide (maybe via your hotel) however be aware that they may be associated with local companies and will take you there to buy things sometimes under a bit of pressure!) but you can always politely refuse and they will be understanding! Still a must visit as they are so unique and fascinating.

Must see it once!. Ok you have to go to experience this unique market but I found the merchandise was average to low quality and certain vendors can be pushy but isn't that part of the charm! I wouldn't have missed it but I enjoyed the market in old Fes 100 times more! Enjoy it for what it is a fun new experience!!

Souk mayhem. Once you accept that the stall holders will try to entice you into there shop, and some are very, very, persistent, and you learn the art of saying no, it is an enjoyable experience. It doesn't hurt to be polite but be very firm "no thanks" or "non mercy" and move on once you have seen enough. Lookout also for the guy who has a father or cousins shop just around the corner. These are usually just ploys to get you into the shops.

what can I say. Go have a haggle see how other people shop it a laugh a hassle but so worth doing from spices to clothes, bags ,you name they will find it, amazing i love it, be Moroccan for the day .and polite no works well

You Will Get Lost. You will absolutely get lost unless you're some kind of savant. We did twice. Even with GPS. So be prepared. Only once did we allow one of the boys to direct us back after we had stumbled far away from the souks and into a not too savory looking area. 20 dh was worth getting back.You can't come to Marrakech without experiencing the souks. They are overwhelming and annoying and thrilling and exotic and touristy and fun. Haggling isn't my strong suit, but I got out paying half of the asking price for a caftan, scarf, jellaba with a smile on the owner's face (and he threw in a fez).Learn to firmly say no. Or to ignore. Don't engage with anyone you don't want to pay. Watch for the constant mopeds and scooters. Look around and find a few places that. Isn't have what you're looking to buy. The products seem grouped-leather, brass, ceramics, clothing, etc.

Great place for goods but be prepared to bargain heavily. I would recommend going to the Emsemble Artisinal upon arrival to Marrakech as there is a good variety of the same goods offered at the souks. The ensemble has fixed prices, and although they are high, it is a good measuring point as to what to pay at the souks. Afterwards, make a first short run through the souks just to see what is offered, pick out a few places or good you want to look for. Don't buy, instead ask the vendor for a price. This is not the time to get in a bidding war as once you make a counter offer, it is expected that you continue to bargain until there is a sale. Again, don't make a counter as much as the shop owner asks unless you are willing to seriously purchase the item. Only ask what their starting point is and be clear that you are only looking for the day. Usually the price they quote you will be at least 3x what you should pay.Once you've got a starting point for certain items through these means, and you are ready to buy, decide on what the max is that you are willing to pay, make a counter offer about 1/3 of the original price and be firm only going up in little increments. Once the vendors understand that you know the value of the items and don't wobble, they will sell it to you as long as they are still making a profit for themselves. Be clear that you know the value and say that you can get the same item at a different shop for the price you offered and walk out. If they want your business, they will go after you.

Fun bartering. Bartering is a must. Take any price and half it, half again and start from there. A good variety of goods, genuine fakes and real local genuine goods available and the food markets are something to behold.

Could have been nicer!. I was there during Ramadan, which may explain some disagreements.. I enjoyed the narrow paths, full of colors and strong perfumes, the plethora of products,... But I would have enjoyed it much more if the vendors had not been so aggressive and insulting or sometimes even violent when I did not accept to buy. I also resented the motorbikes that were circulating in the very narrow streets without any consideration for the pedestrians.

Fantastic Bargains to be Had!!. Although after a while the stalls can become much of the same, there are some fantastic bargains to be had within the souks. It's great fun to have a barter and strike up some banter with the stall holders. A truly authentic experience of Marrakech!

Marrakech Souk. Visited the Souk first time in April 2010. The atmosphere is amazing very busy lots going on and you don't know where to start. However you will have to be one step ahead as the local business and stores will try to make you spend more than you need. Always negotiate and don't have anyone take your pic as they will charge you £10 for every pic you take with them Also don't give away too much information and keep your wits about you.

An adventure not to be missed!. Our Moroccan guide, Noura, made this trip to the Souk so fun & safe. She helped us navigate our way through the maze of stalls. She let us know how & when to tip performers. She also told us which stalls had safe foods to eat & which didn't. There are some hidden stalls that sell the high quality goods that hotels use. When night fell she showed us the best rooftop to view the folly & spectacle that is the Medina at night.
Great time shopping here. A wonderful place to do some shopping and observe the authenticity of the products. For moroccan souvenirs, this is the place to visit.

Its a Market in Morocco!. It really isn't any different from other places selling stuff!!! they do have some very interesting things though, but most things are expensive in fairness as it is directed at the tourist. not for the faint hearted in busy times, but worth the experience

Challenging and Exciting. You cannot be in Marrakech without spending a good amount of time in the souks. Each souk is a specialised area like wood work, pottery, iron, clothing etc but they all merge into one so don't try to distinguish just let it happen. Be prepared to bargain for all purchases except food. The locals make this an art form and you will develop your own way but generally offer half the original amount and negotiate from there - the less you show you don't really want the item the more chance you have of getting it at your price. Now a warning - you will almost certainly get lost, the souks are a maze of narrow winding alleyways that all look the same .. there are young locals everywhere waiting to rescue you, for a price, they are almost impossible to shake off. There is no getting out of paying somebody once you ask for directions except ask a trader, someone who cannot leave their shop and take you somewhere that you really don't want to go. This can be very tiresome and annoying so try very hard not to get lost.

its an experience. I'm still can't figure out how all those olives stay fresh when there are vats of them sitting in the hot weather, and there delicious. there are many other things to see and or buy silver which is big clothing its tight quarters but you can get around try not to lose your way...
Haggling. Not our thing at all, ok if you enjoy haggling, noise and being run down by mopeds. The smell from the horses was awful.

Very busy - surprisingly polite traders. We visited the souks twice during a recent stay. Once with a local guide and once using our resort shuttle service. There is a really enchanting vibe about the place and the stall and shop owners really are a delight in comparison to other places I have visited. Go with an open mind and be surprised how good it can be.

Like Stepping Back in Time. This is truly Moroccan heritage at it's most charming. Sure there are the people asking for money but their is also craftsmen/ladies hand making almost anything you can imagine. It's the hustle and bustle of people trying to sell their wares. Purely fascinating to watch these artisans continue the centuries old crafts. Do not miss the palaces and the cobras and monkey's at the square.

Amazing but very frightening. We were in the souk last week and we loved the atmosphere but the traders and locals are very aggressive. Me and my daughter were molested which was distressing to say the least. We were threatened when we were lost and asked for direction and the chap led us 500 meters down the road in the wrong direction, then demanded 200 dirhams for his 3 mins of time. When we refused, he got violent which was scary.We were constantly appoached by men "from our hotel" (NOT!) to be led somewhere to be sold to. I was bullied into buying a packet of nigella seeds for £5 as the seller got so angry shouting he "hated people who didn't care about their health" . I was so intimidated I bought them!! Anyway, if I went again I wouldn't engage with anyone.

Alf leyla wa leyla. In the souks you can find lots of exotic things such as argan oil, perfumes, traditional Moroccan clay pots, dresses for men/women you name it... But you better be prepared to bargain for the price and in the end it comes down to how cool you can play it.Don't buy from the first guy you see, go around and enjoy the place while asking for prices, after 3-4 places you will have a pretty good feeling of how much the item you want is worth. And don't worry most of them sell the same things so go for the one that gives you the best service and price. Good luck and remember not to stress but enjoy your time here :-)

Don't go without a guide!. Walking tour organised with Thomson. Hustle and bustle. If you go with out one, it is easy to get lost. If you go the wrong way, you could get landed buying off a local to find your way out. There are 1,600 shops. Bargains yo be had but haggle and haggle again.
Visit. Every interesting, got some great bargains A must to see.. even to sit have a freshly squeezed orange juice and people watchRecommend

Daunting at first. I really didn't know what to expect on entering the souk for the first time! It was all very energy consuming having to say "no thank you" or "la shukran" to the many vendors and slightly intimidating walking down dark and narrow alleyways. But after getting over these teething issues I found myself really enjoying the haggling aspect of buying stuff! The sellers can be fairly persuasive but you get used to it after a while! Loved the variety of things to buy! Hugely enjoyable experience even after realising I'd spent double for things that I bought on the first day. Massive learning experience! Looking forward to returning again in the future+

A stressful must. It has to be done and you usually end up there without wanting it. A lot to buy but it can become stressful since everyone tries to sell you and they are a bit pushy sometimes. It's difficult to leave the souk it's like a labyrinth and people won't help you because they want you to stay. Interesting but I'd have enjoyed it more if I could have looked without being pushed to buy !

Colourful Souk. Running of the main square in the old town are the colourful souks you can buy uniquely Moroccan goods , leather slippers , leather bags and jackets, ceramic pieces, clothes, jewellery, food and much more get lost and make sure to batter have fun .

terrible experience for a lone female traveler. its impossible to describe in words how terrible the harrassment and cat calling is for a lone female traveler. i was covered but clearly looked like a foreigner. i have been to souks in essaouira, casablanca, rabat and chefchaouen but the marrkech souks behind the big square were absolutely the worst experience. i left after 4 minutes. its better to goto the smaller souks near Rue Riad Larous, which eventually opens up near the sqaure. far less harrassment.

scary. can be a very scary experience when you first go , can be chased , grabbed , and sworn at . Glad we went in a group of people and stayed together , but did enjoy the experience and most of the locals friendly and funny. You can easy get lost in the market as very busy.

Watch your back!. Exploring the souks in Marrakech are great fun with loads of little shops offering some great bargains. Watch your backs though there are crazy mopeds that drive through the alleys weaving in and out.

WHAT AN EXPERIENCE !!. There is a huge square in front of the Souk and it is your aim to get back there once you have finished wandering around the Souk.................. good luck !! I went with a girlfriend and we did chicken out and used a guide - there are stories of people asking to 'help' you when you get lost in the Souk and charging lots to get you out but I don't know if that is true what I do know is that the Souk is a maze of alleys with some being dead ends and it would be very easy to get lost in here. Be prepared for the usual stall holders trying to vie for your attention but its nothing more onerous than in Turkey or Dubai to be fair. Enjoy the experience and haggle haggle haggle if you buy anything you should be able to get them down to at least half what they originally ask !!!

Interesting and colourful. A visit to Marrakesh is not complete without a good few hours exploring the souks. My partner loves the challenge of the bartering for bargins, the shop keepers all seem to have a good sense of humour so even though you get the hard sell it can be fun rather than tiresome.
Buzzing. Great atmosphere. Wasnt bothered too much, just be polite. Lots of things going on. Watch your belongings.

An experience to remember . You will be hassled from the start to the end but it's a great experience and they back off when the realise no means no. If, like us, you do buy something remember to haggle, we were happy to settle on around 50% of the original asking price.

Go with a licensed guide. The souks are great, but if you want anything more than cheap trinkets, you need to go there with a licensed guide. Make sure they are officially licensed! You can typically find these either through your riad/hotel (assuming they are a reputable riad/hotel). Also, there are plenty of guides on Tripadvisor to contact.The guides will keep your harassment at bay, and they will take you to some of the better dealers based on what you want. Yes, they do get a cut, but the pressure to buy will be much lower and makes for a better shopping experience.

Crumbs!. Souk after souk after souk! There are so many it is impossible to know if you've seen them all but, in fact, you don't need to see every one of them. Even staying for a week, I doubt we saw them all. You need to be good at bartering! I'm not so didn't buy a thing but it was still great fun.

Keep your wits about you!!. The souk is a smorgasbord of delights! There is so much to see and choose from Argan oil to silver to slippers to scarves etc etc.The arrival is very interesting at the entrance you are pounced several 'local official ' guides who claim you need protection from the souk traders or in case you get lost!We declined this service and it worked out ok.,But if your sense of direction is poor keep your eyes open as it is very windy and twisty and goes on for ages up and down left and right. The other thing is the heat was intense about 38 to 40' awful to negotiate the souk in those conditions.If you love market and colour and amazing smells go for it!

Authentic Shopping Experience. The souks are a little mad in Marrakech and you have to be open to the fact that you may get a little lost. Don't let this put you off- it is a really positive experience.Are people trying to sell you things? Of course they are! They are trying to make a living. But a friendly 'No thank you' will get you everywhere here. The people are really lovely and I didn't find them pushy at all. Go for a great shopping experience.

Stay in the area and don't be led elsewhere by locals!. There are locals in the area that will tell you the women from the mountains are here for JUST ONE DAY and you must go to buy their product for cheaper! DON'T GO WITH THEM, IT IS A SCAM! Stay in the Souks!! And, don't go to the tanneries unless you plan to be shocked and then have to pay for what you are seeing/smelling!!

Mental . So you are asked constantly 'come look in my shop ,looking is for free' which is fine but they will try pressure you to buy things. Just be stern with them but always stay friendly. They are just doing there job. It's good experience anyway!

THE MAGIC OF MORROCCO. Be prepared for your senses to explode, here anything and everything happens, a hive of activity, especially after sunset when the whole are really comes to life.The culture, the aromas, the people, the food, the activities will captivate you sheer magic to experience in your lifetime - wow !!

A wonderful place to visit. Make sure you are strong against the venders , they are all over the place!!! But once you explain you're not interested they leave you alone, most of the people are very friendly.
Interesting. So many stools! make sure you know how to agree on lower prices, as they try to charge you more than needed!

An amazing experience. The souk is just an amazing place, so colourful and busy. You get swept along in the hustle and bustle of the souk and before you know you are deep within and wonder how you are ever going to get out. You just keep walking and you do get out and you will always remember that experience. It is fascinating seeing the different areas which include, leather, wool, tin & metal, ceramics, food, clothing & shoes. It is a little addictive, as I went back several times and felt quite comfortable shopping there. You just have to watch out for the speeding mopeds, cycles & men with their small trailers. Keep to the sides and you'll be fine. Be brave and give it a try, it is well worth it.

Expect to walk. Spend more than one day here as there is way to much for a day visit. Make sure you have cash of various denominations so that you have the right amount when bartering. A visit in the evening is totally different than a day visit and is definitely recommended.

Wonderful. We went to the soukh in the evening (about 9pm) and really enjoyed walking around, visiting the shops and talking to people. It's amazing all the motorbikes zooming around the little alley ways; stay to the right!!! You have to haggle!Lovely experinece and so glad we went.

Crazy. I tried to avoid walking through souks. People here are crazy. They will do anything to make you buy something. I've been called Shakira a 1000 times. My friend and I purchased a burka to cross this area in peace.

bargains galore. It can get frustrating with haggling and also constantly asked to buy their wares even if only looking but we enjoyed it too. We did go to the Souks 3 times on our visit to Marrakesh and come home with a few bargains

Mad. I've been round the souks 3 times now and still managed to get lost on the third time round and discovered places I'd not been before. I came initially in early May and actually got pestered more than late June which we presumed was due to there being more tourists. Every so often you come up to what looks like it might lead to a dead end, they generally do and there always seemed to be a lot of men sitting about and would generally give you a bad feeling, at which point you leggit! However we didn't come to any harm, the first couple of times in May I had blokes sling scarves round my neck and even this time I had a few grab my arm and even when you tell them not to they carry on. Personally I wouldn't want to go round anywhere in Marrakesh on my own. In the evening we went for food in the square and that was horrendous until you choose somewhere, at one point I had 3 men blocking my way. But anyway, the souks are quite fun to look at, a lot of the same stuff but it just means you can pretty much get it for the price you want if the first guy doesn't relent but usually they call you back anyway...Also the olives are so cheap! The nougat stuff is really tasty too.

Dont be afraid. Some other tourists in our hotel said that they felt 'scared' when they visited the Souk.There is nothing to be scared about.What people need to realise is that the vendors are just trying to make a living.We found that if you say no thanks the majority move on to their next prospective customer.And don't forget to haggle.You can be really 'cheeky' with your opening bid and then agree a price that you are happy to pay.If you don't get the price you want,just say sorry,and walk away.They will either let you go or call you back with a better offer.The choice is yours,but believe me,there are bargains to be had,especially on leather goods

You should have a guide first time round!. Our hotel was nice enough to provide us with what Guide free of charge, although busy a real taste of morocco life, but be prepared to HAGGLE! Normally if you look like a tourist unless it's price marked divide it by 3 then that's a more reasonable price! We were told 120d for shoes when we walked away saying forget it, he somehow dropped the price to 20d...so make sure you don't get ripped off, also go to rosa huile for your cosmetics/oils, they're 100% organic, so you know your not getting anything dodgy.Lastly, watch out for the pickpockets children will distract you, so be weary...!

Good fun - be prepared to be hassled!. We had a few hours there today, probably a bit less crowded than we expected because it is Ramadan right now. Of course expect to be hassled by vendors but mostly they accept when you are absolute about not wanting what they are offering. Can get good bargains in pottery eg Tangines and leather. Have fun and negotiate hard!!

Could Spend Hours. A fantastic place to shop and just walk around. I could spend endless hours here. It is a wonderful part of the city and a great taste of Moroccan culture from the tourist standpoint.

Prepare to give a good haggle. Loved this area with all the wonderful shops. I bought some scarves, glasses and a little aladdin lamp for all under 500dh...that was after some intense negotiation. The only thing I really REALLY did not like was how people would keep trying to get your attention. We are here during Ramadan and that doesn't change people's attitude towards women. It is quite frustrating having to say no to the same person for the 7th time. One chap actually told me to f off once I said I really didn't want to go down an alley with him. You can't really stop and admire and take pictures as they will take this as bait and that's it you could be followed out to your riad (as we were) whilst trying to make out they helped you leave and so deserve some money. The best advice I would give anyone going is to go with a local. Not only can they negotiate for you (if that's not your thing) but they can navigate much easily around the souq then you will ever be able to do and I think they're presence deters the chancers. We went both with a local and on our own and for someone who has travelled to India and Thailand I was truly scared in the souq at one point. Not one for doing on your own!!!
Spend the time and look around. Crazy - a must see - nothing like this in Australia or Europe. Its just jam packed with things to see - and avoid. Take care, but enjoy
Night and Day Adventure. The souk and the square are must-see places to go. The souk during the day and the square day and night.

Great fun and less intimidating than you would think. Great fun, felt perfectly safe and it is so interesting. You can buy pretty much anything here! We found the stall holders not too pushy and it's well worth hunting out the metal work part and the shoe workshops, most things seem to be made by hand.

Lot of people. We went at night very busy , had dinner at one of the street diners , wouldn't recommend as wasn't the best or we just picked a bad food seller, watch out for pickpockets , have to pay to take pictures eg snake charmers , monkeys , lots to see and have to haggle for best price some stall holders got a bit aggressive if you started too low , better in the day time didn't go back again in the evenings

Awe inspiring, breath taking, so foreign, so beautiful, take a deep breath of courage and go in.... The sights are amazing, do NOT forget your camera, entire stalls with layer upon layer of lanterns, animal skins that I've never seen a picture of the animal or knew it existed, snakes on the ground, but being used to make money, you are safe.... An experience I will never forget but take note, barter or be charged exorbitant prices, stand your ground and simply walk away if the first price offered is far too much.
