They followed me and apologised when I did this. I wanted a beautiful silver twisted spout mint teapot and I decided what price I wanted to pay and I GOT it for that price. Move from stall to stall when they refuse to barter, find the exact thing and try again. My husband was told he was 'a lucky man sir' by the man who sold me the teapot, he admired that I refused to pay the exhoribitant prices they asked.... Take note some will get angry, but there are more nice stall holders than angry ones... Stalls that are filled with puzzle after puzzle, hundreds of them, mostly wooden, the stall holder will help you with the one that you cannot fathom.... Beautiful metal work, some stalls SO small and yet mum, dad, two kids a sewing machine AND their goods for sale are all here! Stalls filled with leather work all hand done, right down to western rubbish, plastic and cheap stuff unfortunately... But at the start, not inside... Donkeys walking through pulling heavy wooden carts from the dark ages.... Some are very mistreated, it'll break your heart... Very nasty men in some stalls, simply walk away, there are lovely people in other stalls, buy from them! Take home some African jewellery, never seen before... Great souvenirs! Some will allow photos, some will chase you away. So best to ask first. Don't get lost, it's a myriad of maze upon maze, I don't have a sense of direction my husband guides me or I may still be there! See how they sell food, meat hung in the open on hooks, baking attracting wasps, all normal... Find a local grocery shop, and really see how the locals live and what prices THEY pay for the local goods, then know what prices you should be paying with a little extra on top for profit.... An eye opener... Buy your argan oil here!

Don't get lost in there! . You have to go to the souk when you are in Marrakech - it sells everything to be honest - but the most are leather goods. You will find sometimes the leather goods (e.g. small wallet) are cheaper at the beginning of the market rather than deep inside. The best tip is you need to spend time to explore and compare the prices - so would recommend spend a day to explore then decide what to buy then go back to beginning the bargain process. The other tip for not getting lost in the souk is try to look up for the road sign - yes look up! They put the sign up at the corner of the building - not many tourists know so they often to pay money to the boys running around to take them back to the market square.
Tourist trap. It's a must see when in Marrakech. However you should avoid buying anything. Prices are too high and it requires some hard bargaining to get value for money.

Its like a different world!. If you want to buy something most stuff doesn't have prices labelled and for those make sure you haggle at least half the price they tell you and be firm! If in doubt just smile and a no thank you they will understand. If you don't want to be hassled do not ask anyone for directions, do not accept anyone's help even though they say they don't want money because at the end they always end up with wanting a small price for helping you. I know it might seem rude but you have to ignore it when they keep telling you this way to the square as some people point you to the wrong direction on purpose then someone else will tell you a different way - the map on TripAdvisor app will be your best friend! It is the most interesting experience in my life well worth the visit but you have to be street smart and savvy! The best stalls for us were the nice leather stalls and spices.

Crazy and wonderful. Tiny little streets withe donkeys and scooters flying through. People will stop and tell you that the street is closed and they will show you the way but 99% of time they just want money. Say No thank you and keep walking. Most of the stuff is from China we didn't see much hand made stuff. A little disappointed but still worth the crazy trip.

THIS IS What I came for!!!!!. The souks are a shoppers dream, but unless you are really interested in something avoid the eye contact as the vendors are relentless. If you love bargain, then this is a wonderful place to do it. Workmanship varies so get a certified guide on your first day as they know the souks inside out and will help you through the various sections so the you can recognize landmarks as it is easy to get lost. My favourite sections were the Babouche.inspect the workmanship and make sure they do not smell. I chose more of a berber style with tassels approximately 90 D leather bags also were beautiful , look around before you decide.Bought a metal lantern and bought the leather bag and slippers to stuff the bag around the lantern. The spice section was great , bought the pickled lemons used in cook, and bought saffron, ask your guide for a real saffron spice vendor. We went almost everyday in the morning before it got too hot and we were there a week.

Not a nice experience. Not a nice experience, People are unfriendly and if they "help" you to find your way trough the maze, they ask ( on a very aggresive way) like 20euros for a 5min guidance which even isn't the right way. If you van avoid the Soeks. Do it
The place to go for shopping. This is the place you should visit to do some shopping and buy all the typical moroccan products quch as spices, leather...

so so much to see and do. it just to big with the noise and smells of a grand market its a great experience to walk around and look at very thing some great photos and bargains. We got lost and took 5 minutes to find a way out if you are looking to buy anything look at the stalls first and try and get a price then move on and find it a the next shop and ask and the start with the haggling 1/3rd is a good start we bought a bag started at 900 and we got it for 230 less than a 1/3rd off the price Plenty places to have a drink and break

1001 Nights. When visiting the Suq in Marrakech you really have the feeling that you're going 100 years back in time. It is very exotic and lots of things to do. The hard thing for Westerners is maybe that you have to negotiate really everything. Specially at nights the suq is full of life and activities.

Colourful, exciting and fun . The souk was exciting but you get followed by locals who try to lead you to shops where they get a commission and this ruined it somewhat for us. There were some good buys to be had. Had a horrific experience at the tanneries where locals lead us astray and tried to take our money. Travel in groups and be safe.
So much to see. Such an interesting and exciting place to visit with loads to buy and lovely eating places. Never a dull moment!

Shopping in the Souks. A wonderful experience, but be wise and wary. Wear sunglasses even in the shaded souks, so vendors can't see what you're looking at, otherwise they will make it hard not to go into their shops, much less buy their stuff. Don't look at snake charmers or the monkey guys, because they'll drape a snake around your shoulders and demand money. Walk with a purpose.

Lovley but be carfull. Very nice place just dont get dragged in to a shop given a free orange juice with the pretence that the guy works at your hotel. On the other hand i dropped my sunglasses without knowing and a shop keeper chased me to give them back with no more than a hand shake to say thanks. Very nice people but as anywere just be sensible. They get a bit ratty if you ask for a price and don't buy anything.
Nice. These souks are never ending and ur sure to be lost at one point or another. Its not that bad though... you can always ask ur way out of them.

A fun experience . Really, if you're in Marrakech then the souk is a must do. It's a little terrifying as its huge & easy to get lost in, but thankfully exits are plentiful and many of the market workers were happy to point out exits and ways out when we got super lost. Haggle like your life depends on it, most will come below 50% of their starting price. I'm not a believer in haggling to the last penny but pick what you think is a fair price and haggle to that. It worked for us in almost all cases, paying between 5-10€ for shoes or 10-20€ for bags for example. If you do haggle too aggressively they will ask you to leave so don't be surprised if that happens. Mind the henna ladies, they tend to grab you and start doodling on you without asking. And while the snake charmers are cool to see in one respect, it's also pretty upsetting to see how the snakes and monkeys get treated so be wary if this may upset you. Overall I must say we felt pretty safe here despite being 3 females on our own. It was an experience to say the least :)

Get ready for aggressive Moroccans. THis was by far an unpleasant experience due to the cultural differences within the market. The market entrepreneurs basically rush you and demand money while throwing snakes and monkeys on you. I lost my cool here and the authorities came to settle down the situation. nevertheless, it was a learning lesson.

Stressful!!!!. All I could say buying anything in souk was very stressful. But I suppose this is an experience we need to experience when we go to Marrakech. There were hundreds of shops and all selling similar things.

Very hectic and pushy sales people. I love that there is a rule that the sales people cannot touch anyone. The souks is absolutely a labrynth and you can easily get lost. But there are deals to be had!

All what you always wanted and never needed. I love the souks. The amount of goods and people is amazing. Perfecct place to find souvenirs and practice your haggling. Get enough free space in your luggage in advance :)

Dive in and have a bit of the haggle fun. Make sure you are not followed by incessant salespeople or "tour guides", especially as a single woman. Try to alight with other tourists so you feel safer. The souk has a lot to offer, and you have to haggle very hard. It is great fun though. I bought lots of lamb skin Moroccan slippers, jewellery, cookware and teapots. Very happy ending!

crazy shopping experience!. this was my first visit to a market and it is massive so i was a little bit overwhelmed with it all, we went during the day but have been told it is very different in the evening. i was amazed by the bartering! my boyfriend loves to haggle so he had fun arguing and buying a few items as cheap as he could, we were told to aim for a half or third of the price they are asking for. we went early morning and didnt really get hassled too much however as the morning went on and it got busier people began to sell things not even in shops at one point a man selling belts followed us around for about 15 minutes and wouldnt take no for an answer which started to get annoying really. we spent half a day there and it was a fun way to shop but i wouldnt have wanted to spend any longer there.
Wowsers !!. Be ready to be blown away! It's an amazing experience walking through the markets and the sounds of mystic snake charming - just incredible

Only ask for a price if you are serious about buying. I was looking forward to really shopping in the Marrakech souk but was rather disappointed. I like haggling and asking questions but the locals at the shops did not seem to like this. Once you start to ask for a price, they will not leave you alone until you buy. If you are not buying, they tend to be aggressive. I did not feel safe after a few experiences. There is lot of stuff to go thru so take a stroll, look around and only ask for price if you are serious about buying. Otherwise, they will keep pestering you.

Unforgettable. If you want to get the most out of the Souk I would recommend to hire a guide who will also explain the history of the places seen, as well as, ensuring you are safe. This gives you an overall better experience. We hired our guide through our hotel and was not disappointed, he was really warm and protective as we walked through the windy streets. It is important to mention that the guides don't get a lot of money and to increase their income they will take you to shops that they have an agreement with. This is not an issue if you make it clear that you are not interested, they will not insist and move on. Be prepared to do a lot of walking as there is a lot to see therefore, wear comfortable footwear and light clothing due to the heat. When walking through the Souk everyone is trying to sell you something, hence the buzz of the place, be ready to " haggle " hard and to be sure you are getting a good deal by knowing the conversion factor of the currency and if you are not happy with the price by walking away will sometimes work in your favour, they don't want to lose a sale. Other important points to note are; try and not expose all your notes when buying an item, have your notes organised differently in your pockets and ladies need to hold their bags close. You can easily get carried away with the hustle and bustle and spend a lot more money than planned. A good place to visit again.

Crazy but awesome. Make sure you ain't in a rush to get back to hotel if you visiting the souks. It's like a maze... Iv been 3 times all 3 times I have entered the same way but never came out the same. This is the place to pick up all your holiday Nick backs for taking home. Amazing

Amazing. This is a place where you get lost and see some amazing things! It really is a rabbit warren, so you need to keep moving and look for light at the end of the tunnel if you want to get out. We walked around it for hours and still didn't see it all. Don't be afraid to say no to coming into the shops, and always haggle on price!!
shopping in marakech. this fairly typical of the markets, i have been to several in tunisia, turkey etc and found it to be a bit pricey compared to few others

Worth a visit! . Great place and amazing atmosphere! Try your luck at the haggle however be aware they are very good at what they do! I didn't like how they pressure you to buy however just hold your ground and walk away if it isn't for you. Just always smile and say no thank you and they are fine. Well worth the trip!!

Haggling and Shopping. The trip to the Souk was great, but when haggling you are never quite sure what the price should be, how much can you lower the price without upsetting the sellers, which is something l learned :-). E.g. a product l was interested was priced at 350 Dirhams I bargained the product down to 120 Dirhams, thinking l could go lowered l offered the guy 80 Dirhams and l got a rollicking :-). So always convert prices to your currency £'s or $'s or Euro's and think, am l prepared to pay this, then bargain to reduce the price always half the price.

Much of a Muchness. The shops and stalls sold the same products which is a pity as I'm sure Marrakech could have so much more to offer. Beware of the mopeds and scooters careening through the narrow streets.

Fascinating place. It's a great way to see how much you can get involved with the market sellers we bought a few things from there but you have to be careful as they can take quite a bit of your money in the day time the snake charmers can rip you off no matter how much you argue with them they will take your photos and charge a lot so be wary of that in the evening it is fascinating so much hustle and bustle and noisy I enjoyed it thoroughly the drums and cooking smells it's wonderful,

Lots of interesting staff but bargain hard!!. The souks are a must! Get lost in the narrow streets and test your negotiating skills with the locals. Always start at around 1/4 of the original price and work your way up. You will find excellent staff but dont get too attached on an item, you will find it again in the next corner and probably cheaper.. Also, ignore people giving you directions or telling you that today is the last day of a certain festival...

A must see part of Marrakech. It is difficult to navigate and you have to be firm with the locals selling their wares or the unofficial guides who try to get you to visit certain places, especially the Tannary (best avoided). However you should make at least one trip so that you can get a real feel for Marrakech. On the whole the people are friendly and we found if we wore are sunglasses it was easy to avoid I contact with those who you did not wish to engage with. Go visit, the spice stalls are amazing.

Wow. Amazing visit.. whilst they try to haggle higher price, the atmosphere is amazing and we picked up some great bargains. We tasted the orange juice stands and purchase some items. If you like photography this would be an extra amazing place.

Good experience but be cautious. They are customs to a very good sales techniques but be prepared to negotiate or just leave if it beyond your budget. Sometimes one might take you off track to a series of other shops and at the end that small guide would demand a little cut. But it's still was a safe experience.

Only one to ruin it. Came here to get a LV bag and got punched in the back as i walked off as he gave me a ridiculous price. Horrible man but everyone else was pleasant with there pushiness. Roof top cafes are worth a visit.

Like a big car boot. We went here expecting to find exotic foods and interesting little stalls - but in actual fact it's like a dark, smelly, expensive car boot sale!! People kept telling us to take a tour because otherwise you'll get lost - so we did and basically the guide took us to all his mates stalls and expected us to buy from them- one tried to sell us a handmade rug for £500!! Probably worth a walk about to say you've done it but don't get your hopes up! (And we did NOT get lost!!!)

Great place for shoppers and bartering. If you enjoy shopping and bartering this is the place for you. If you dislike either it is a living hell, get used to saying no and be careful of looking at things you aren't interesting in buying

Absolutely a blast. We were on a tour with several other people out of Spain, and six of us were the English speaking contingent. Our guide went with us all over the market and took us to some great places I'm sure gave him a kickback. We had so much fun looking at everything, meeting everyone and bargaining. We went to a place specializing in Argon oil and herbal remedies. I dropped a wad here, but they gave us lots of freebies and neck massages which you have to tip the masseuse at the end. So much to see. It truly is the essence of Marrakech.

See Marrakech coming alive! . This place is not for the faint hearted! There's horses and carriages waiting to ferry market goers! There are snake charmers, musicians, dancers and beggars! There's plenty to buy and eat, not to mention the shopping that one can get up to. Be warned, you must be willing to bargain, bargain and bargain. This is the place to go in order to get a real feel of Marrakech.
Interestinf. Not the best and most interesting things to find but still fun and good. The most stands have the same stuff.

must do but be aware that they will harass you!. Nice souks, very typical, small streets with many many shops for goods/decoration/food .. A lot of choice so take your time before buying and always negotiate, I would recommend between 30% and 60% less since they always exaggerate the prices and prices are almost never displayed. most of the sellers will harass you, oblige you to enter their shops, push for you to buy, grab you ..
Fabulous day spent in the souks of Marrakech. Why not go and try to learn to barter - remember this is a part of their culture no price is fixed in Morocco!!!

Must See... When in marrakech. These souks are off the big square .i.e. jemaa al fna.These sort of reminded me of the bazaars of istanbul. You can easily get lost in these souks so bear that in mind when travelling with young children. These are lines of small shops with alley ways leading from one to another souk.Also what we didnt do and should have is taken the buggie/pram with us. Doing so we could have spent more time exploring the "maze of souks".Good for shopping and spending more than a few hours of the day should you want to.

If you are in Marrakech you cannot miss it. Is teh best place in Marrakech, full of life and people, even during the Ramadan. It is divided in different areas depending of the products. The best places are the Jewish market and the Spices market. If you have time try to visit a Riad and when you need a break enter in one of the Spice shops/Cafè and anjoy a mint tea.
Moegammad Hendricks. Lovely atmosphere, feel like local, cannot stay away from all the bargains, this is a must visit in Morocco.

Visiting the Marrakech markets..be careful . If you go into Marrakech, without a group, just be careful as the markets do feel quite unsafe. You have to haggle otherwise you'll be ripped off. Also, I made the mistake of not having enough small change. Haggled down to 120mad for a bag, gave the man 200mad and he refused to give me back my money. It's creepy and there's nothing you can do. In future I will have smaller change to prevent this from happening.

Great People Watching. You will find snake charmers, monkey charmers, men dressed as female belly dancers, etc. A great place to go for fun, free entertainment. Be careful about pick pockets. There are food vendors in the evening which is a great "cheap eats" experience. Enjoy!

Another type of soukh. If you compare this one to the soukh of Cairo or Damascus it is somewhat different and somewhat the same. Good experience, people for sure not so pushy as Cairo was my experience.
highlight of Marrakech . great the different markets in medina. make sure you know the price of the good you want to pay in advance. ask locals eg in your hotel/riad what the price is.

Overwhelming, But Worth It for Deals. Haggle your way to spices, rugs, shoes, & ...dentistry? Marrakech's souk, the second largest in the world, has everything--beware of local guides and pickpockets. Recommend traveling in a larger group with at least one male, and dressing conservatively. Worth it for cultural experience and deals to be had.

One of the worse experiences of my life. My husband and I are experienced travelers and have taken students all over the world including the former Soviet Union. Jemma el Fna is pure chaos and the most intimidating place I've ever been to in the world.People will grab at you, harass you, get into your face--all in an effort to get money out of you. The monkeys and snakes are mistreated and will be placed on your shoulder followed by a loud demand for outrageous sums of money.People will deliberately send you in the wrong direction, try to to become your guides, and generally make your life miserable unless you give them money.If you insist on seeing the square and the souks please hire a guide from your hotel ONLY to escort you and don't plan to take any photos as the locals will tell you, "No photos!" and be very aggressive toward anyone carrying a camera.As you get deeper into the souks and medina local men will take great delight in giving you the wrong directions or to tell you the museum (or location of your choice) is closed or it is forbidden to walk down a certain street. Most of this information is not correct and can lead to confusion and to becoming lost very fast.Please make sure to dress appropriately (covered arms and legs) as we saw many tourists in skimpy outfits and felt embarrassed for them. Please read about this culture and observe its conventions for clothing. But think very carefully before going into the medina--it is not for the faint of heart.

Culture . We used a guide from our hotel one morning to visit the Souk as we weren't really sure what awaited us. This turned out to be a good decision as he was able to guide us through the labyrinth and point out loads of interesting things that we would have otherwise missed. He was full of interesting stories and thanks to him we didn't feel harassed by the different vendors. The Souk itself was an incredible culture shock! To explore the different "shops" each displaying an array of different wears, silverware to spices, clothing and oils was an incredible experience.
Bit intimidating. Went here both at night n during the day would say the night exp safer . We got nothing but hastle in the day telling us to go home due to ramadan .....

Souks . Amazing to see this, can do a bit of shopping if your prepared to haggle, a few hours is enough as not many shops. Snake charmers in the streets, and people with monkeys to have pictures taken for a few coins. Well worth a trip.

Lots of shops. The souk is like a labyrinth but the locals are very friendly and helpful so ask for directions. Have a map with marked out spots and take pics of landmarks to get back to certain spots as most locals don't speak English. The traders over price their goods so haggle prices down to about 1/2 to 3/4 of the initial price given. Walk away if there is no agreement, you will certainly be called back if the price is right. Shop around to get a feel of prices before you buy.There are different grades of leather so be careful.Check your change there and then as there is a habit to give you less with a view of trying to get the balance as they have no change but you don't get told - This happens at stalls, shops and cafes everywhere. I experienced it all.

my advice is that you keep clearity about the price which you are willing to pay for product. surely the wide variety of products you may find in odl town is very large when it comes to artesania. Marakesh offers much more in any type of products that you might imagane, but some secial products, which historically were not produced you would need to go out of the cold town. f.e. if you wish to buy portable clay stove, despite there is a lot of artesania with clay they do not produce stoves, or you just cannot buy in the oldcity something that would be bigger to carry in your hands. You might find good contacts who would go with you to place you need, people on bus station are usually very friendly. they helped me to find my diary, which I FORGOT IN THE BUS. they were able to recognize bus ticket based on time, on my surprise.
Mad chaotic challenging but loved it. Amazing markets, the colours, stuff for sale, prices! Careful with taking photos and letting people give you directions! Nothing is free there...

UNSAFE SOUKS DON'T GO THE SCARIEST PLACE IVE EVER BEEN TO.. The Moroccan tourist industry need to sort this dangerous unsafe place out! My daughter & myself visited the souks and it was there scariest experience we've ever had abroad. Nobody cares about tourists they see you as walking wallets! We fell for the "hey lady come with me" "I'll show you the way" well we walked and walked and basically got took round in circles by young lads,who when demanded money off us became aggressive & one grabbed me I felt unsafe & unable to protect my daughter. This place is hell on earth and the stuff they sell is junk ! 2 women alone they saw us coming,scary men everywhere just waiting to pounce on vulnerable tourists. I'm pretty street wise but this place is something else! If your with a man I would imagine you won't get hassled and terrorised as much. No way ever would I want to come back to this place. Please take my advice and really don't bother going your missing out on nothing, I've never felt as scared in my life. When you didn't respond to their shouts "hey lady" we got abused and they shouted things like "nice tits" nobody is to be trusted there no matter what story they give you. They see your wrist bands for the hotel and pretend they work there & know you, they don't it's all part of their scam. Terrible scary & really felt like our lives were in danger. Horrific!

Great experience... you can do it yourself with map from hotel. This was a unique experience in going from Jemaa el Fna to the Souk. On the first day, it is overwhelming and the touts/guides prey on you to buy herbal products and their services. If you take a deep breathe and use the maps provided by your Riad, it gets easier after the first hour.

Keep your wits about you. Travelled in during day to a bustling city teeming with people and sounds. Crossing the main roads is an experience but followed the locals which worked. The souk is vibrant, noisy, and a bit over whelming at times. Didn't like being hassled all the time and then having to bargain constantly. As a touist you stand out immediately and it can be very intimidating at times. Bought some shoes which are fabulous. Tried to buy some scarves but felt I was being ripped off so left them there. Overall I've seen it, experienced it but would not hurry back. I think if they were less aggressive with their sales tactics they would do better business. Didn't travel in at night. Were advised against it and with our experience during the day I thought no that was sound advice.

8 Ladies over 21 holiday. 16/05/2016 - 24/05/2016 You have to be prepared to barter. Be polite but stick to your guns. What ever they want, and let them give you a price first. Do no t be tempted to make an offer. We never paid more than half of the first price and many times even less. Even if you leave the store the chances are they will come after you. If they do not you will see the same item again in another shop and you will have an idea of the price. But do not be afraid to go back and say OKAY. They have some beautiful silk large bed cover so much embroidery they weigh about 4 killos but so much work involved be prepared weight wise. you do get a little hassle from children trying to sell you packs of tissues (begging) just be firm and give to them when you are leaving the market for the day. If you are seen to give to one they will all hassle you. So just say NO until you are leaving for the day 20 dirhams less than 2 pounds Example ladies sandals no more than 60 Dirhams, We paid 150 Dirhams for a medium sized letter bag which is about £11. Really nice bad with fringe all leather. Paid the same for ornate necklace in silver metal and £4 for long silk scarf. So much to buy so leave room in your baggage allowance or purchase extra from hotel rep at least 2 days before your return date.

Hustle and bustle. However can a donkey, scooter, salesmen and tourists get through these tiny passages, blend in with the smells, noises and the rhythm of the souks and make this an Unique experience.

Family visit. An eye opener to say the least. Interesting to see how people of Morrocco live. We went with a tour guide and saw things we wouldn't have seen if we went on our own. We went to a bakery, blacksmiths and had a talk and shopping at a Herbalist.

Aggressive market traders selling cr4p. The worst part of our holiday. And the food vendors outside the market are thieves.
The market traders give the people a bad name. They are horrendous people. Give this place a miss and the beggars are relentless. The monkey abusers will chase you with their monkey if you even look at them.

Great Experience but keep your cash close and your phone in your front pocket.. This was a great place to go for the day. It was very colourful and vibrant part of the city but was repeatedly warned by locals to keep pockets fastened and to move mobile from rear to front pocket. If you are going on excursions to the atlas mountains you will find things much cheaper there than at the market which is very tourist orientated and although cheaper than uk are not as good value as they could be. the little hotel shop was cheaper for pretty much every thing at the market. Look out the the bag man who speaks with a cockney accent and shouts come and have butchers.
Amazing. An amazing place to visit. Marrakech is full of souks and it is a delight to get literally lost in any of these. You are bound to enjoy your visit.

Souks!!!. Beautiful awe inspiring experience. Really loved the experience of wandering around looking at the beautiful and authentic items on sale. There was a little pressure from the shop owners but they were happy to take no for an answer when firm. This was a lovely way to spend a day and many of the items sold are intriguing and special. Just need to ensure you keep your wits about you. Will definitely return!!

A chaotic, extremely fun experience. You can't miss the markets when visiting Marrakech; see all the strange things for sale (for better or worse!) and marvel at the 'high energy sales tactics' used by the stall owners.Just keep an eye out for 'no photo' signs so you know which of the locals don't want to be photographed. Don't travel all that way just to annoy the locals!

As you'd expect but without the hassle . This might be my shortest ever review: the soul is exactly what you'd expect from the pictures you've seen - and while every single shop keeper will invite you in, they are gracious when you decline. A genuine pleasure strolling through them.

Go!!!!. Becareful of random taxi rides that will take you on a 'tour'. We went and spent half the money on goodies that were over priced in the mountains. Only plus side was knowing that all the money went to women in the community that where out spousal help.

Two women on holiday, glad I went, won't go back!. There were things I loved and things I did not. The clothes were great value (a few quid for some lightweight trousers, beautiful leather bags for £15). However, there were stalls selling tortoises, Falcons etc and and this made me uncomfortable. There were also (overworked) donkeys pulling carts through the streets. Beware of the motorcycles travelling through - keep to the right! We didn't have an issue with being harassed but were constantly approached. We kept our shoulders and knees covered to minimise attention! There was a lot of rip off designer gear. Glad I went, but wouldn't go back.

Chaotic. Super busy, all the time! full of motorbikes everywhere... Went there with grandma and we had trouble with even casual walking around as I had to lead her from side to side to hide from zooming past bikes. All the locals by the shops shouting you to take this take that. Only advice, fight for the price! Make sure you found exact quality of the item that is worth paying, if not - move on and you'll find better. But once you enter the shop a lot of places just insist you on buying at least one thing, even if they offer you a price triple lower from the 'original' one. I did not come across anyone to be angry or threatening towards a tourist, they often fight with each other, but do not involve others. Also as many places suggest, best decision is to walk around and get lost without a map, if you do lose your way back home and want to leave, ask elder people or women for directions, younger men tend to 'lead you towards the exit' and then ask for money. Think that's all...

Be careful . It's an interesting place to visit but very expensive. We did a conversion on everything we wanted to buy but most things were overpriced. Also make sure you get a price of the menu before you sit down to eat at the outside restaurants in the market square or will be stung by the bill.  Just be careful when big harassed at the souk.

Too much hasseling . Is must see when you visiting Marrakech, but is too much hassle. They was everywhere, trying to put snakes and monkey on us, you have to be very careful as there is loads of pick pockets, they are very professional. We end up buying some argan oil and spices.

Great place to visit and hotel usually take u there with a bus. Visit here it is an eye opener and also is very enjoyable.Also barter with prices don't make them fool you.Please if anything keep all belonging with you, as it is very easy to get lost and stuff to b stolen.

Just be smart.. I read the stories of being harassed by shopkeepers, and being duped by men offering directions, and the pick pockets. If you get rattled easily, don't go. I found the souk's fascinating. Great pictures and a treat for the senses. It was 95 degrees when we were there and I didn't come across and disgusting smells that I've read about. Keep your valuables in a safe place and just walk away if hassled.

Over-rated BUT you get a great bargain if you haggle. It does get exhausting having to haggle all the time. We managed to get something down from 900 dhiram to 220 dhiram!! They do contradict each other though about what the other is selling so you have to be clued up. Mostly it is the same stuff in most of the shops - just small variations here and there. I went with my gut and bought things as and when I saw them as did not get into the comparison as this is very confusing. I wanted to buy a tegine and did not realise that the display represented two different shops. They kept contradicting each other and in the end, resulted in me asking them - "are you two different shops" when they said "yes" - I just walked away really frustrated.

vibrant. The Souk is eye opening, there are dozens of tiny alleyways all lined wiith "shops" half the time you are surrounded by the most wonderful aromas from the spices etc and the other half smrells like you are in an open sewar!! It is a definate must see but once is enough.
Timeless. Bought bits of furniture, high quality rugs, leather etc, shipped back to UK within 5 days :) very happy. Love this place

breath taking. Welcome to the souks of Marrakech. Here the air is rife with cries of gypsies, snake-charmers, wandering minstrels, magicians, and folk-singers. There are tanneries on pavements, street artists in every corner, and vegetable vendors popping out of alleys. If you’re not paying attention, you could end up with a monkey on your shoulder or snake wrapped around your arm.Oh, what do we tell you about Marrakech’s souks – Overwhelming? Yes! But they are the perfect amalgam of colour, energy, and vibrance. There is nothing that isn’t sold here- perfumes, spices, bags, clothes, baskets, shawls, carpets, shoes, even safety pins.
SOUKS. It was funny...you'd walk through the souks and you would here "No Chinese"...they pride themselves on things made locally

Brilliant. The souks are a fascinating place to visit there are absolutely lots of stalls selling everything you could possibly think of , it's the smells ,it's the atmosphere,you see snake charmers , monkeys ,there's lots of food stalls there's the hires and carts but be aware of the guys who say they are official just say no

An assault on the senses!. Amazing place!! The souks are like nothing else I have experienced, you will get lost in there but it is fine. Soak yourself in the culture and love it. If you only did 1 thing in Marrakech, make sure it is this.

Soul experience . Souk was ok! Ensure you keep a bag that has a top zip as it can get crowded.
Ensure you barter well as they can easily knock down prices if you try hard enough!

Maze. The souk are an absolute maze of wonders. I think you could go around the world a couple of times if you lined up all the sandles and bags sold here. Just be prepared to get lost! definitely take a phone with GPS and try and look like you know were you are going or you will be accosted by people helping you find your way for a heavy tip. Amazing though and can get some real bargins!
Jones family . Very busy area full of products. You must negotiate nothing is set. Lots of fun. Very safe. Each business has its own prices . The crowds increase later in the day.

Horrendous . I went here with my mum, I'm 23 years old and my mother is 50 I wouldn't recommend travelling here if you don't have a man in your group. The first night we went in as soon as we got off the bus I had a man follow me all the way to the souks who would not leave us alone! Even when we shrugged him off he followed me about until we went in to an exchange bureau. Right then I was traumatised from the word go. When we got there it was very busy in the square, a henna lady came up to me and grabbed my hand and started to put henna on me, to that I completely flipped out and told her to wipe it off and told her no and she cursed me in another language. We didn't even get far in to the souks as it was just awful, way too busy. We ended up getting a taxi back to our hotel and decided we would go early in the morning which we then did. You don't seem to get hassled as much in the morning as they are still setting up their stalls. Around mid day it starts getting busy, you need to be careful as there is little vans, horse and carts, motorbikes and all sorts going down the alley ways. We got lost and ended up following a guy in to a tannerie which was good to see until the man who showed us around expected 200 Durham each from us which we refused to pay, then we got lost heading back to the square which to young boys showed us the way and expected money from us which we refused and then he told us we had to go the opposite direction which thankfully we ignored and went the way which seemed busiest! Even at that they kept following us! We told him we had no money and they said they would show us where the ATM machine was! Literally everyone in the souks is out to rob you. I bought argan oil I'm a shop one night and the man ended up showing me some hijab outfit which he put on me whilst groping me! I totally froze and was shocked, if anyone had done that at home I'd have gave them a mouthful of abuse but it wasn't until he was trying to take it off me to which I snapped that I will do it myself. The whole experience was scary, they are all out to get money from you. Even when sitting in a cafe or restaurant they come round trying to sell you watches, cigarettes etc and the restaurant staff just let them which is shocking. It is filled with culture but their greed just makes the experience a bit sour, do not trust anyone in the souks and be very firm and assertive! Also I spoke to a woman in the hotel who told me if you are with a man then they have no time for you, she told me that if she tried to haggle they told her to be quiet and spoke solely to her husband. Do not go here if you do not enjoy any of the above or feel like it is something you could handle.

Go go Marrakech souk!!!. Crazy place to be, overwhelming, noisy, but you would love it!You can find everything and anything here!All depends on your bargaining skills and on what you want to buy and how much you want to spend!Its a great game if you do accept itDefinitely try fresh orange juice and harira its worth it, honestly, believe me Just forget everything and enjoy!!!Thats what Morocco us about!

Must must must visit. We spent an entire day at the Marrakech souk, it is such a lively place. The souk has so much to offer. Leather products, clothes, first copies, berber medicines, accessories, jewellery everything. Leather products are great for the price. All the merchandise is good and cheap. Never accept the first price the shopkeeper offers. Haggle like a pro. We spent a lot of our time haggling. Don't be shy to offer just a quarter of the price, they will settle for 50% less at least. Everyone will invite you to their shop but don't stop if you are not interested in what they are selling, if you waste their time some of them may get angry. And if you are a genuine customer they treat you real well. Even if you don't want to shop, visit the souk, take a stroll, its a one of kind experience. Don't miss it! The leather products we got stink quite a lot, however keep them under the sun and the smell will slowly go away eventually.

Enjoyable way to experience the city and get some respite from the sun!. Good luck trying to navigate your way through the souk! We thought we were doing well but ended up in an entirely different place than we intended. That being said, we enjoyed our experience. The market stall owners will heckle you, but we found it less annoying than in Egypt and Turkey. We heard lots of horror stories of stall owners more or less holding customers hostage and hassling them into buying things, but we did not have that experience. I think it was useful that we knew what we wanted to buy (pillow cases and wooden jewellery boxes), as this resulted in being very targeted about the shops we wanted to visit. Be prepared to haggle and walk away if you don't think the price is justified. But don't forget - if you are happy with the price, it doesn't matter if you could have potentially found it cheaper a few stalls down. As long as you are happy, it is worth it!

Beware of "Berber leather market" scam. What else is there to do but visit souks in Marrakech? (Other than touring the palaces and museums, of course) Be sure to bargain hard, and survey around if you really fancy the items. We got medium-sized plates (~20cm diameter) for 60DH and leather poufs for slightly under 300DH. Don't believe anyone who tells you that today is the last day of a Berber leather market and asks a "passer by" to help bring you there since it's on his way. Unfortunately we fell for this smooth operation involving 5 men. There are separate reviews on this market on TripAdvisor. Pls read before heading to the souks.

Mind boggling sight... Visited the Souk in May 2016, hundreds of shops selling all kinds of merchandise, some lovely pieces (I love leather goods and ornaments). It is easy to get lost in the maze and the stall-holders do understand if you say 'La Shukran'. Worth a visit.
very busy, be patient to say no!. Good to experience, but you have to be very patient to respond "no" all the time. Good to see but can be annoying after an hour.

Haggling Market. Lots to see and buy. Don't just go for the first price they say. If you have a price in mind or advised by your hotel then stick to it. For example our hotel said don't pay more than 30MD for a Tagine. At the Souk, we were told 80MD we said no, he said what's our best price we said 30MD he said no. So we decided to leave and look elsewhere, shortly after the guy came after us saying ok 30MD. If haggling/bartering is not your style, then just shop around for the lowest price. Horse and cart ride available around the old town. The new town is literally 15minutes walk up the boulevard from the Souks.Taxis will charge 50MD to go there.

Has to be on your to do list . A must visit when in Marrakech however we had mixed feelings in our group ! There are some local goods but also quite clearly lots of imported Chinese tat !We were hassled and guided (sent to their family stall) by 'friendly " not after your money locals who quickly became unpleasant and spat at our feet when we didn't purchase any goods however not all were like this and we did have a haggle with some stall holders and purchased some nicely made leather back packs so been there and done that but wouldn't rush back.

Crazy in a great way!. Get lost and start your way back... I went two times, one time just to enjoy and see the many beautiful things in the bazars. Then I went back to buy.Take a lunch at a roof top, and suck in all the great atmosphere.A very memorable place!!

Loved it . We visited the souks on two occasions. They are very easy to get lost in and you could walk around them for hours. I absolutely loved the souks got some nice gifts for my family and a few nice things for myself. They also have snake charmers and monkeys on the big square although I was too scared to go near them! I would 100% recommend you to take a trip here!

Magnificent Marrakech mayhem. Absolutely surreal, amazing, a must for anyone travelling to this wonderful country. By day this market is bustling, alive, encapsulating, it draws you in with the smells, sounds, colours textures and people. It is of another world! Beware the locals will harass you to pay them as your tour, I would recommend an arranged guide the first time if you're bothered about getting lost as the souks are like rabbit warrens and can be difficult to navigate. Everyone will try luring you into their stall/shop with the promise of "just looking" but once you're in whatever you look at will be hard sell. Have fun, they love a barter and some banter always goes down well but have a maximum price set and don't be badgered into paying more, don't be afraid to say No, if there's room for movement on the price they'll chase you through the market trying to sell if not they will just let you go! Nothing is for free if they ask to give you something they'll expect a gift in return ie payment, and the women doing henna tattoos are the worse, they will grab you and start tattooing be if they can and whatever they do they will definitely demand payment so don't be pulled in by "just a small one for luck as a gift from me" they will still want paying! Many love photos but ask first as equally as many will be offended, some expect payment for the privilege. By night this becomes the most extraordinary outdoor food court, hundreds of stalls selling food and drink, all calling you in to sit and eat. It's mainly al la cartel but each item is priced individually and many will automatically serve the bread and sauces regardless of being asked and will charge, however food is so cheap it won't break the bank! Throughout the whole thing there are beggars and kids trying to get money, food and cigarettes for their families, you've got to be tough or you'll be broke or broken within a day! Any left over food can be given to them if you like otherwise the stall keepers in the restaurants will move them along. It's a truly magical place by day and night, I could spend a lifetime trying to put it into words but the words do this place no justice at all, you really do 'have to be there' to appreciate it. Oh yes the horse and carriage through the souls and medina is a must especially at night!

A maze of colourful little alleyways . The souks are a warren of little winding alleyways with a riot of colourful shops selling everything from spices to leather slippers (babouches). The best thing to do is just dive in through one of the entrances off the Djmaa El Fna and spend a few happy hours getting lost. The shopping is great but you need to haggle for everything or you'll be fleeced by the wily shopkeepers. A good rule of thumb is not to show too much interest in the Item you'd like to buy, and when they give you a price, drop it to a third of the asking price. Eventually you should arrive at a price somewhere in the middle. Also, only haggle for things if you really want to buy them. If they won't budge on price, be prepared to walk away. You'll no doubt find the same thing elsewhere.

Shopping paradise..if you can bargain resonably. Go shopping..non stopGoo deals great items..Lots of fakes but I sure u can spot it.From leather items.. shoes ,jackets, pottery, bracelets, oils, Parfums, clothes so many items... I know you will pull your camera and start shooting wvwrythibg just to bring a lil of it with you.
A bit too aggressive. If you enjoy haggling then this is the place for you. Personally, I like set prices and found the souks to be far too aggressive I couldn't look at anything in peace.

Sensory overload...in a good way!. I love this place. Every time I see it, it gets better. Steer clear of the snake charmers and the monkeys. Instead, walk down the crowded alleys and enjoy the colors and the smells. Yes, the shop keepers may be a bit aggressive, but if you are firm, they will leave you be. Be mindful that you will be expected to bargain, but if you do it cheerfully, no one takes offense.
Exotic . A exotic place in this Unique Country. I enjoyed very much and I recommend to everyone. Is safe and very fun

Nice Maze. The souks are a nice maze filled with people trying to sell their many wares. It's a great place to get a brief reprieve from the heat. However, having been to similar markets in Turkey, Tunisia, and Egypt, I did not find this to be anything special. As female tourists, even though we were fully covered (long pants and long shirts), we were still verbally harassed by the men in the souks. Nevertheless we were able to pick up some things inside. As a word of advice, NEVER pay more than half of their initial stated price. Many shop keepers have the same items, so if you don't like the person running one shop, the next one probably has the exact same thing. Also if you have certain items in mind, do you homework before you go. For example, when buying scarves, the sellers kept trying to tell me they were handmade of silk. I asked what type of silk, and he told me cactus silk (vegan silk). As I sew, I knew right away it was neither "silk" nor "cactus silk", and was most likely a polyester/rayon blend. I asked the seller to do a burn test on the fringes of the fabric, but he refused. Realizing that this was obviously not handmade, nor was it a natural fabric, I got him to reduce the price from 180 MADs to 30 MADs.

Very interesting. The souks well, they are an eye opener, if you can go yourself I advise it because all your tour guide will do is take you into the places it seems are his friends shops and they pull you in, make you tea, all seems very nice but its only so you buy things and you feel obliged to buy. Not a pleasant experience.

Mopeds. This place was absolutely everything you are told to expect in Marrakech. Windy alleys that are bustling with vendors and an assault on your senses in every way. Definitely worth a look but they're are constantly mopeds flying through the lanes so be very careful and stay the right. Also aggressive selling is a thing here so be prepared to be assertive when declining help or purchasing things.

Something for Everyone. This place is huge and offers hours of exploration. As others have said, if you show interest, be prepared to be engaged in a bargaining session whether or not you are serious. However, we found the shop keepers to be jovial and non-threatening. Wander into side alleyways where there is something of interest around every turn. The same items are found everywhere so it pays to look around and bargain hard. The motor bikes drive fast in places you never thought they would even fit, so be careful. We came upon the community bakery which was really interesting. Hundreds of loaves of bread waiting to be baked and then distributed to both restuarants, food stalls and private individuals. One could spend many hours here so budget your time and money.

An experience!. Amazing sights and smells of spices,mint and leather. Full of people, some donkeys and carts and some motorbikes in very narrow paths so keep your wits about you. You will probably get lost but eventually find your way back to the main square. It is a great experience so don't miss it.

Spectacular . Bustling with smells , sounds and visual treats the souks would totally blow your mind away. Go with an open mind, haggle like your life depended on it and walk away with a smile if the prices seem too high. The people are very warm and friendly and visiting the souks is an experience not to be missed!
what a expiriance. if u love shopping u will love this place, shop till u drop got some lovely bargains make sure u barter, cant wait to go back

Manic. A sight worth seeing but disliked the mopeds going past at high speeds down narrow walkways. Great sights and not so good smells and easy to get lost. Be careful in the main square. Warned about looking at the snake charmers as will put the snake around your neck and not take it off until you pay them. Also had my had grabbed and was painted with henna and could not get away easily. Worthwhile doing with a guide or a good map!

Danger - shopping frenzy!. Phantastic handcrafting at VERY reasonable prices, all the smells of the African continent. You simply HAVE to negotiate - it's grewat fun, and it's part of the game. They even sometimes accompany their own first price with a broad smile, aka: you'd be nuts to take it! Loved it!

Find the black magic . This is compete insanity and worth the trip. Be ware of people shaking change. That means tourists coming. You can haggle anything to around a fifth of the starting price. The black magic area has some things that are shocking.

Barter your way around. The Souk was what I expected, very very busy and a lot of stalls selling the same kind of things but one thing to remember is never to accept the first price, bartering is a way of life stick to your guns keep polite and the price will fall. Careful if you decide to go to a cafe to eat some are best avoided as I have now learnt, but it was an experience.On the outer area of the Souk is where the guys with the monkeys and the snakes are, if you do not want to have your photo taken with them do not go too close and then you will not be troubled, but if you get close to take a photo expect them to either ask for money or expect you to have the monkey /snake on you so they take the photo and then charge you.It was an experience and everyone should pay a visit as it is part the natural way of life.If you have gone as far as the souk walk a little further up the main street and visit the Artisan Centre, skilled crafts people fantastic leather at affordable prices.

Full-on blast of bazaar. From expensive antiques to junk from Asia and everything in between. They have it all.! You'll find nice carpets,leather slippers(if they smell bad don't buy them),lanterns,Moroccan blue pottery,the wonderful tajine dishes,exotic spices,etc..It's a huge maze with lots of sounds,colors and smells. Not always good. I saw snake charmers and jugglers and magicians. Donkeys and camels next to the tuk tuks and motorbikes. Cars are not allowed in the marketplace.This souk is a truly crazy place but if you visit Marrakech you should go.

Souks galore!. The souks are a fascinating experience which is a must when visiting Marrakech. There are four main areas in the souks - slippers, leather, the dyers and spices. There are many areas that sell all these items and much more such as tassels, lamps, kaftans etc. You will pounced on by vendors as you walk through the souks but a simple Non Merci and deaf ears will suffice if you just want to look as you pass. If you stop to look more closely at an item be prepared to haggle as you are unlikely going to be allowed to easily leave without buying something. Aim to get the item you want for at least 50-60 % of the starting price. Haggling is fun and you will soon get the hang of it. You will find you keep returning again and again. Don't be afraid to branch off the main walkways and explore. You will eventually arrive somewhere you recognise! Enjoy!

Try to go a bit further away from Jemaa el Fna. Yes, there will be pushy sellers, annoying shop owners, etc.. but it seems that the further away from Jemaa el Fna you go, the better the souk gets: not as many people and not as much in-your-face trade.Another advise is to ask your riad owner or a local person who is not interested in selling you staff how much this or that would cost. The most annoying thing for us at the beginning of shopping (and I suppose for the majority of people) is total lack of information on the prices, that is when you don't know how much things cost and you just want to get a rough idea of the prices and then keep on looking. It is hard because the sellers won't let you go sometimes if you inquire about a certain item. Most of the time, we were told by the locals, the first price that the seller announces is about 3 times the real price. So, the shoes that are 180 dirham could be purchased eventually for 60.Once you know what things cost, and you decide on what you want to buy, it will be easier dealing with the sellers. We chose the least aggressive sellers, as it seems that most of the tourist goods come from the same producers (regardless of what the sellers would tell you).Also, don't be afraid to walk away as you can always come back and you WILL find similar things in the next shop or stall. Remember, the more you engage in a conversation with the seller, the less likely you are to walk away empty-handed.
everything you could possibly want. There isn't anything that you can't buy in the Souls. A labyrinth of alleys with stalls & shops. Not tasseled too much - a polite no seemed to work most times
Souk . Bustle and fun to be had!!! Make sure you are ready to Barter! Lots to see. We were fortunate enough to go when it was quiet!

Haggling a way of life. From carpets to shoes to lanterns to bags to pottery to Niknaks - a feast for the eyes.You want it they've got it but negotiate negotiate it's the culture. Can be a little overwhelming but a great experience.

Experience to say the least . Very very busy place, a lot of people around and a lot of stalls. Have to make sure that you all keep together. If you don't like something then you can just tell them, if you are polite with them then they will be nice back to you. Ignoring them doesn't always work as I found out. Some of the people can be abit rude if they don't get what they want but that's very rare and you can get that anywhere. Haggling is like their sport out there so it is normal for them to say a high price as they expect you to haggle. Make sure you do because otherwise they will try and rip you off. One thing we wanted they started off at 500d but then by the end of it we got it for 100d so stick to your guns. If they won't budge straight away pretend you don't want it anymore or have seen it for cheaper somewhere else then they are sure to drop the price. One of the stalls at the back on the right is a very lovely man who sells a lot of fridge magnets and key rings, all the souvenirs stuff and he is a lovely man, he doesn't try and rip you off but he is also okay with you offering the price you would like to pay, we had no problems with him at all. It is a very different experience but you have to bare in mind that this is their way of life, what they are used to and it's their livelyhood at the end of the day so you have to give them some leeway. It's not everyone's cup of tea but you can't go to Marrakech and not go to souks.
souk marrakech. place is full of local music players snakes,merchants, local food stands all traditional products are sold here as if you jumped back in history

Beware of overpriced products and fakes. some shop owners try to sell poor quality archaeological artifacts for way above value, notably flnted points and other artifacts that normally sell for 30 to 50 euros are proposed in Marrakesh souks for 40% above to double these prices.Do not pay more than 50 to 60 euros for a berber hand made wollen caftan. Normally do not pay more than 50% OF A PROPOSED price, you may go down to 20 to 25%.

Careful what you photo!. We visited the Souk as part of a guided tour whilst staying Marrakech. It's everything you would expect it to be. Crazy, colourful, dangerous, vibrant. It's an excellent experience. Make sure you leave hours to go down every alley and wear comfy shoes. Whilst pushy the traders are never aggressive and in most cases quite witty. As the title suggests be careful who and what you photograph. I took a photo of a Snake charmer from what I thought was a safe distance which resulted in me being harassed until I paid 20 dh for him to stop waving his snake at me!

Overwhelming and Epic, Chaotic Shopping. What an experience for shoppers. There are signs for the different areas of these Souks. It does seem chaotic but I do think there is a system. I just don't know.

An experience. It is worth a wander around the souk, especially if you fancy yourself as a bit of a haggler. We had a guide for our first visit who introduced us to the Medina and the Souks which is worth doing so you understand the way of life a little better.

A memorable experience. The good ,the bad and the ugly. .  Lively, souk. Like you'd expect. Should visit when in Marrakesh but spend too long and it all gets very samey.Beware of the henna tattoo artists these women will just grab your arm as you pass and say let me show you this. Then after they have done squiggles on your wrist as you pull your hand away and say no thank you they demand a lot of money. Refuse to pay if you didn't want a henna tattoo. Best not to let them grab you in the first place. I seemed to spend the whole night telling these women NO! Other than that it's an interesting experience the souk. Always haggle the price for everything your interested in buying. The stall holders they love to haggle it's their way of trading. If your eating on the open market there we found the best value and quality was bar number 1 it recommended on trip advisor. At all costs avoid bar Chez Simo 81. Our experience was terrible there they completely ripped us off with the bill and when complained they just laughed in our faces. My friend got a bad stomach from the food that night.

Interesting but hassle. Having lived in the Middle East I am accustomed to visiting souks, and in general feel safe and free to roam, look and decide if/when to purchase. In Marrakech souk you'd aren't look into a window because immediately you will be hassled to go inside and chased down the street if you don't buy. As said I have been in Middle Eastern souks and never had this level of hassle and intimidation....... Okay, it is relatively easy to handle, but really it shouldn't be this pressurised....... Also get lost for a minute, and some 'guide' will want to show you the way - for a cost of course....... Which is never enough. Untrustworthy and hassle from those selling in the souk. It should be fun and an interesting walk, with genuine sellers who respect a 'no'.

Fantastic experience - although manic. A warren of alleyways with hundreds of sellers all wanting to show off their goods. The vendors are friendly , chatty at the same time drawing you into their stalls to buy - just trying to earn a living. ALWAYS bargain NEVER pay the 1st 2nd or even 3rd price but also respect that selling is their wages and food on their table. An overall fascinating experience

Don't worry if you get lost. Great for exploring and bargains. Easy to get lost but you'll always find your way back eventually-part of the fun really. Just be aware that sometimes people will direct you to the main square but actually they're directing you to where there stall or shop is-no malice in it and not unsafe-they are just trying to make a living-but just politely decline as there are plenty of signs on walls saying Djemaa El-Fna. So just keep your eyes peeled.

It was good. It's easy to get lost in the souk, it's made up by hundreds of little alleyways it seems everyone is selling the same thing over and over again. Good experience but be careful what you buy there, make sure you bargain to at least 1/4 what the asking price is...

a shoppers paradise. Don't go unless you like shopping and are prepared to haggle. The contents of the souks are overwhelming and every stall holder will tell you he is the cheapest and/or you can't buy anything like it anywhere else. Both are lies!!! Lots of beautiful scarves, shoes and brass. The spices are amazing and all this mixed up with locals selling chicks dyed in neon colours and butchers with unidentifiable bits of animals. Your senses will be attacked on all sides! It's great fun but easy to get lost. Don't let anyone lead you off anywhere as they then ask you for money to show you the way out (or worse - try and sexually assault you, no joke). Mostly everyone is friendly. Learn the phrase La, La - which means No, No. And bring extra bags t transport your purchases back home because you will buy more than you expected.

Souks what can i say ! . We have just returned on 20/05/2016 after spending a lovely week there in Marrakech , The souks were very very busy at night with an array of different stalls with all kinds of tagines and foods that were absolutely tantalising, Would definitely recommend going here as they say you haven't seen Morocco unless you have seen the souks.

Follow your senses. The most interesting things are sold in the vast labyrinth of the souk and luckily you just stumble upon them. So set your mind free and follow your senses, the shopkeepers are not as pushy as outside. There is an excellent new paper map Marrakech Evasions with a detailed section of the souk also naming the locations for different goods, if you feel lost just look around you at the merchandise and consult the map and you know where you are.It also indicates where to find taxis when you feel you've had enough. Seeing the speed of modernisation in Marrakech roundPlace Ferblantiers and the Spice Market the souk might be on the list much too soon, so enjoy the chaos now.

Crazy experience . One of the craziest but best experiences of Marrakech. Definitely with a trip to experience the realness of the city. There are lots of people and mopeds driving everywhere though so can be quite scary. The shopkeepers tend to be quite Friendly but can sometimes get offended when you barter so try and keep it light hearted I would say if you aren't looking to buy lots then don't go too far into the souks as it is so easy to get lost. We stayed on the outside and generally in the main square and managed to find what we wanted for a good price.

Unmissable. Any trip to Marrakech would not be complete without a trip to the souks to get a real taste of Moroccan culture. Haggling is encouraged and it is worth walking around and checking the price of goods at several stalls before making a choice. There are many streets to explore so give yourself a good amount of time to fully experience all on offer. There are many good restaurants and cafes for a pit stop between purchases.

Everything you need. Absolutely loved it in and around the Souks, loads of hassle but nothing that a friendly no thank-you doesn't solve. Ensure that you have your haggle head on otherwise be prepared to be ripped off. This was one of the highlights of our trip to Marrakech & will certainly be visiting again.

Must See When in Marrakech. What can I say.. you can't possibly say you have been to Marrakech without going to the Souks. I will say it is easier when you have a guide...and preferably one that is honest and not just trying to take you to his friends' overpriced shops (there are plenty of those tours out there so watch out) It is possible to get lose but if you follow the flow of traffic it will usually lead you to the center. If you find yourself down a street and its only u and a bunch of cats then youare probably in a residential area or just not headed towards the souks so turn around! don't be afraid to walk away if the vendor wants more than you are willing to spend you will see the same stuff probably 2 shops down. Also a word for the the wise the decorative tagine are not for cooking only for serving. The vendors won't tell you that so just be aware. If you pay more than 200 MAD for a tagine for cooking you got ripped off!!! It happens to the best of them but just keep that in mind. The best ones to buy are found in the stores located in the residential areas because they aren't tourist traps. I went to a store and the owner was honest and sold me a tagine for cooking for 60 MAD that's like 6 USD, don't be fooled. Enjoy and have fun haggling for deals!
Shopping and food. There is good shopping here, and some good, safe, inexpensive restaurants here. Visit day or night. Takes on a carnival atmosphere at night.

Go for it. Great place. Wonderland. Millions of shops that are one garage wide.. The people sell for a living but will never become difficult. Take you time to find the exceptional stuff among the cheap rubbish. Smile. Shocran is thank you. Laa is no. Na'am is yes...

Amazing. Loved it down hereh, lots of hassle but overall friendly people, had a couple of nasty comments but I just cried on walking. Loads to see and smell and touch, got ripped off but hey ho, my own fault and it wasn't by much, be aware of the pick pockets here and in the square. Would come back for sure.
Not for the faint hearted. Complete madness. Very pressured selling. Felt very intimidated. Had to find a1st floor cafe to get away.

Fantastic shopping experience. Great experience, great fun haggling, fantastic food.
Look for where the local eat and try these places. We tried some lovely local dishes. Whether your going for lunch or dinner you have to go early or the home made food gets sold out

Labarynth, but you won't get lost. Go there.. Coming to Marrakech and not visiting the Souk would be like going to London and not stepping out of your hotel. It's an absolute must-see. It is fascinating, and so long as you are firm with your No's and willing to bargain to the bone with your Yes's, you'll have a whale of a time. We came away with some silver jewellery for less than 10% of the original asking price, so bargaining is absolutely 100% essential. If you don't like doing it, don't be shy to learn the skills.
Incredible . What ever comes in your mind you will get it. Artisans, incredible art , cultures, traditional very helpful people and very lovely people.

Haggle, haggle, haggle. If you go into the souk then get ready to haggle, everyone wants you to go into their shop and buy, if you browse then you will be approached to buy.The Souk is split into different areas, and as well as buying things you can see the craftsman making the items.

Great to visit. Great place to experience and certainly if you enjoy to haggle over the price :) whatever they ask for start at a third of that then find somewhere inbetween that suits you both. Remember these guys Gotta make a living tho so pay what you think it's worth to you. Happy shopping.

Soukmania. We had been in a souk in Dubai and the Bazaar in Istanbul, so upfront we were not very enthousiastic about the marrakech souks. We could not have been more wrong. The souks are great, they are clean, they carry a wide variety of things and some things are actually very nice and worth buying (not only mass production and souvenir carbagge). The salesmen are not pushing too much in general and the temperature is really nice (shade and no burning sun). If you want to buy a carpet, I recommend souk Joutia bazaar Jouti.

very famouse souk. Close to alfana mousque square variety of shops selling all type of goods,clothes, leathers, souvenir, spices, materials all oriental and hand made beautiful products reasonable price but you have to barging a lot may more than half price to be cut or deduct.

Exotic, crowded, fascinating !. If you are in Marrakech, you MUST visit the souk...it's everything that you think an exotic Marrakech market should be, and much, much more. Camel meat ? Got it ! Cell phones or computer parts ? Got it ! Pots, pans, spices, flowers ? Got it ! Two cautions, though...it's very easy to get disoriented and lost in the warren of alleyways, and motorbikes go zooming through at sometimes a frightening speed, so stay always to the right.

Very disappointing. We were on a weeks break in coastal Agadir, but felt the trip to Morocco would not be complete without visiting Marrakech' famous souk. We went via a Thomson tour, whilst the guide was quite entertaining, everything felt very rushed & most places we visited felt as though was in his interest in taking a cut on what was purchased rather than showing us the true Marrakech. The Souk was vast, however, every 3rd 'stall' was selling the same items, knock off football shirts, Argan Oil or an assortment of lamps, there was probably a little more on offer, but you get the gist.Plenty of beggars about or people pestering you with tatt, which grew very tiresome, very quickly.Happy to say I've seen it & tick it off the list, but won't be rushing back.

Dont get lost. Dont ask for directions, if you want to go to see any Museums etc, whoever you ask will always say it is closed and point you in the direction of the leather area etc, dont walk with anyone. You get used to it, but it can be daunting, no names to follow or signed but the nethertheless an amazing area and lots to buy.

Shoppers delight!. Loved this medina, a lot less full on than Fes. Got to see some beautiful trinkets for sale here that i had not seen anywhere else in Morocco including Fes, Chefchaouen, Casablanca and Essaouira. Prices are a bit higher here though but they bargain down a lot easier than other places.We bought some beautiful Moroccan shirts for my boyfriend and i got some fresh made harissa that was sooooo amazing, i wish i bought like 5 jars!Excellent fun here, can't wait to go back one day! You definitely need a day or 2 here, one day was not enough for me personally.

This one's for cultural connoisseurs. If you are a travel junkie and love exploring culturally-rich places, you should go here (alternatively, if you are not, then do NOT go here). The sights, sounds and smells of this place can be intensely overwhelming. The layout of the souk is confusing and you can easily get lost. This can be a full day trip in its own right. Be careful not to take pictures of certain things; you can easily anger the locals (they'll let you know pretty quickly if you should not be photographing). This place can send you into culture shock pretty quickly -- that's the attraction. Do not bring children or people with special needs to this destination; it would simply be too much.

An additionto the Jemaa el Fna. At the end of the Jemaa el Fna you can find one of the souks. The daily life of the locals: their own shops: meat, fruit, vegetables.. interesting place to spend some time.
Great fun place. Great fun in the souks. Full of hustle and bustle, You can't be scared to haggle hard !! Make sure you have comfy shoes as they winde on for miles

Come prepapred. The Souk is a unique shopping experience but be prepared. The shopkeepers vying for your attention, motor bikes, and constant negotiation can be a little overwhelming. I was very happy with the quality of goods and prices. Be prepared with a list, an idea of price, and negotiating strategy.

Must see. I really enjoyed wandering through the souk. You can get lost, as well as ripped off by vendors. Get a guide who can walk you through it so you can just enjoy the experience, learn some history, and shop a little.

DO NOT ENCOURAGE ANIMAL CRUELTY. The markets themselves were very good. A huge range of products and food as well as happy stall holders. Obviously you have to haggle and barter to get a good price. Some of the clothes are not great quality but when you don't pay very much for them you don't mind. Be prepared to be pushed and pulled into buying things, you do have to be strong.Only thing I really must stress is when you enter the souk there are horse carriages, snake charmers and performing monkeys. Please please please do not indulge these people. If you tip them for a photo or a show they will continue to treat these animals badly. Monkeys should not be chained by their necks and beaten until they do what their capturer wants. Spend your money in the market instead, giving to those families who earn an honest living.

A must, good experience . A great place to explore the culture. Never pay the price they ask for. 1/3 I would say. Be very careful. If you do not want to be harassed do not go. It is an eye opener we enjoyed.

Mr. Youssef Mamouni is the best Concierge!. I am currently staying at Le Meridien N'Fis. Mr. Youssef Mamouni, the Concierge, booked all of my activities: souk tour with private guide, camel ride and a car and private driver to visit rhe beautiful Ourika Valley. You should get a private guide for Jemaa al Fena and the souk as it is a busy hectic place and you will not get lost nor hassled as much with a private guide. I totally recommend the souk tour. Thanks to Mr. Mamouni- the best Concierge in Marrakech!

Shop till you drop :D.
