Well I thought the Bazaar's in Istanbul were amazing but this goes up another notch - a bit daunting to start and we did take a guide having been warned about getting lost and then coerced in to paying to be shown the way out !! - The quality and craftsmanship is amazing and to be honest a full day there wouldn't do it - it's covers everything you can imagine - food, spices, leather, all types of metalwork, fabrics and textiles,oils perfumes and cosmetic items .......... That is only just the start ................... :)

IF YOU DRINK THE TEA, YOU WILL BUY.. We spent 20 glorious days in Morocco and wandered around in the souks wherever we went. But there's something special about the Marrakesh Souk. Hard to describe but it is unlike any other. The feel and the energy is different. If you are with a guide, you'll end up paying more because the guide expects his 'cut' at the end of the year. Never mind, how they keep a tab on it. We were in Marrakesh towards the end of our trip and joked that "If you drink the mint tea, you'll end up buying something even if you don't want it." That's how good the Moroccan merchant is about making you feel thankful to him for the purchase. So if you have no intention of buying, do not sit down and accept the tea. You will buy. And when you hand over the cash you know you've been screwed, but not how badly :-). That said, Morocco is a surprisingly beautiful country and offers an amazing experience. Go there and Enjoy Yourself. You'll love every minute of it. We did. B'Saha!

Safe and wonderful.. There is everything! Take a guided tour or be prepared to spend days finding anything again. The alleyways near and leading off the Medina are easy to negotiate, but going deeper requires knowledge if you want to find things efficiently. A great place.

Shopping ��. Marrakech souk is fab for the people who like a good bargain. It's very busy and everyone is very friendly. There are some good deals to be had but you need to be very good at negotiating the price. Lovely leather and spices.

Bloody hell. You have to come look around here. So much variety, prices. You got to haggle it's brill, we got all sorts. Everything hand made like bags, shoes, leather goods. Can get overwhelming if you let it, go late afternoon when it's cooler. Keep hand on your money thou. There's lots of kids begging don't give in to them it's a scam. Up to you thou. Great experience thou
usual tourist stuff. once youve seen one you have seen them all never really get a chance to look properly at anything much prefer the fixed priced stalla in the square

An experience that must be had in Marrakech. Even after having a house in Marrakech for 19 years I can still get lost in the souks. It's smartened up a bit over the years with new floors etc but it has retained most of its character. The metal souk is the most fascinating to me though the age of some of the workers worries me. The spice souk is also nice though as a tourist you will inevitably get ripped off.

An experience... . We visited here on many occasions on our visit to Marrakech. You get harassed a lot!! The people do not take no for an answer, you have to barter for everything as they are constantly trying to rip you off! The souk says no bikes or motorbikes however you often find yourself crushed against a shop whilst one pushes past. The men often cat call the women which is extremely uncomfortable especially as I was dressed head to toe. It is like a maze and you often get lost however some people are willing to help you get out whereas others will take you to their mates shop. It is a good experience to see the goods on offer (although many imported from China and are the same) however it becomes tiresome after a while. Watch your bags at all times whilst in the souks as you are very close to people.

Amazing look into the life of Moroccans. My sister and I spent so much time wandering through these souks, they really are a great experience. When bartering start lower then what you actually want to pay and then eventually you will get up to what you want to pay and they will accept this. You can get things for cheap but you have to be confident ;) Enjoy and don't be afraid to explore, there are many hidden gems

Amazing market. This is a great place to take a walk in this amazing city. You will love the people and the various things. I would bring a ton of Beautiful things from there. The small street are the best, where you can feel the real moroccan lifestyle! I truly loved it!

Got fed up. They have everything u could possible want to buy. However they seem to increase the price when they realise ure from abroad. It was always a ridiculous price. Even the fake goods they would try and charge what u could get for the real thing! Got really frustrated in the end trying to bargain which stil wasn't a reasonable price. Literally had to spend bargaining in one shop for half hour to 45 mins.Some of the shop keeps get really rude because you refuse the pay the ridiculous price they suggest.
mood for shopping. Souks are also very special in the Medina. Its a very big area with different parts designated to different products.

Bargain hard. Amazing souks selling everything from carpets, lamps, ceramics, pashminas, leather goods to local souvenirs. Worth a visit if you want to take home some local souvenirs and crafts. Beware of the high prices though to start with but bargain hard and you can always get it at a price that both you and the souk trader are happy.
One of the best attractions in Marrakech. Probably one of the best attractions and characteristic places in Marrakech. Nobody can miss them! You can find lots of handicrafts and local food.

Avoid or at least be alert. everything we read about this place was true. It was too crowded, too full of aggressive sellers, beggars and hustlers, and I spent so much time saying no to stop people from bothering me that I really didn't have a chance to enjoy myself there. On my first night I got yelled at by a random woman who accused me of taking her photo, but even when I showed her my camera photos, she continued to scream abuse and some random man joined in. On our second night there, we found a food stand to eat at despite men physically dragging my friend towards their kiosks. On the third night, some man put a dirty monkey on our arms when we weren't looking, forcing us to tip him. So all in all, I'd avoid this place if I were you. And Morocco is full of decent markets, it doesn't have to be like this. Because Marrakesh is such a big tourist destination, some may think this market is authentic or typical and it really isn't. Prices here are much higher than other parts of the city, so be ready to haggle or browse around at least before you settle.
Short Break. Really nice garden. Get your own taxi it is cheaper than a tour and so easy. You can then stay as long as you like without worry. Nice cafe there also

Amazing . This is what makes Marrakech! Such a buzz with everything authentic on sale. Tagines, carpentry, herbs & spices etc. It's great to chat and haggle with the locals especially for items you like. Plenty to see and go around. Never settle for the 1st place and price. Always look around and haggle as much as possible. Soon as they see tourists they bump the price up considerably but you can always get it down !!!
Can get crowded..... Interesting and worth a visit. Does feel a bit samey after a while. Various sections cater for different product ... carpets, clothing, herbs slippers etc

Always an amazing experience but keep your wits. Having been to Marrakech three times since February, we thought we were street wise for the Medina. Careful with the bartering. Know how much you think an item is worth and go for it. Watch the plastic sandals and bags, the jewellery described as silver!! The south bit of the medina seems to have Morrocan prices not tourist prices!! Example lady in Riad said spent £80 on drink in a "bar" a bit stunned and sober. Others spent half that and drank during happy hour. Sardines and chips in Kasbah half price to price quoted in medina. Young couple asked price of calleche (carriage and horses for 1 hour) and told 300 dirhams. Another chap offered 150 dm. Checked out lovely healthy brown horses, no hips/ ribs showing and they stopped to let horses drink in the New Town. Ask price before you buy. Try to have small change from bank. same young couple had snake put around their neck and demand for 500dm!! Then hands grabbed and hennaed. (Not very well). Gave them a little cash!! However lots of lovely jelabas, scarves, (dye may run/need washed before use). Lots of lovely pastries. Argan oil might be cut with another oil. The local cafes usually have local prices and lovely snacks. Tok Tok drivers seem to be disabled, so worth a go using them for trip from Kasbah to Jemma el Fna especially if tired/hot. about 40 -50 dm. Enjoy the amazing experience, just know your price and don't be bullied into paying more than the value.
Vile place. Prepare to be harassed and patted down by pick pockets - food is vulgar and stacked in heat all day, will make you ill. Stray animals everywhere and monkeys chained to people.

Wish we had a guide... The souks are obviously a very vibrant and authentic place to go, and although this review might not sound like it, I would recommend people to go. As many people will tell you, you have to be cautious of being conned or feeling trapped into buying things. We had been told not to go with a guide as they would lead us to places where they'd get a cut of the sales, and we thought we were smart in venturing alone, but we definitely weren't. A seemingly sincere young man pointed us in the direction of the square, and then left us be, before catching up to us 'casually'. He was lovely but it turned out to all have been a routine. After leading us 40 minutes through the maze of tiny streets, he attempted to abandon us at a tannery where they were making leather. We told him to stay and he said that unless we bought something at the tannery then we could find our own way out. At this point I was quite irritable and refused - we hadn't wanted to go there and the 'tour' was two minutes around a smelly work yard with men staring at you - so they left us. This then left me and my friend, both of us girls in our early 20s, to find our way out. It took us about an hour of being mislead by people and given the wrong directions, until a native Moroccan doing his food shopping took us to the square. We were so grateful as we were starting to panic with not knowing who to trust or where to go. We hadn't seen any other tourists anywhere nearby, so we knew we were in a sticky one! My tip here would be to make sure your taxi drops you off at the square, not near any of the smaller entrances, and stick to where you can see other tourists. Once you get stuck anywhere where you feel uncomfortable, don't engage in a dialogue. We're glad we were staying in the New Town of Marrakech because if our whole stay had been on the same lines as the Medina and souks, are experience would have been very different (for the worse). I can see the appeal of the souks and Medina experience but for us it was a bit too lively and unpredictable. I definitely wouldn't go there with children due to the volume of people and the amount of bikes and carts speeding through the small side streets.

A Must visit in Marrakech. I have read a lot of the reviews on the Souks, They are mostly true however it is not a place of great crime pick pockets etc, You will get hassled to buy, you will get lost and there are some locals who send you in the wrong direction. the vast majority are fine people just trying to make a living. If you don;t want to buy just walk on by.

Shopping spree or just stall browsing.. The souk has many passageways and tiny stalls. This feels quite an exciting place to be. Leather goods, vie for space with woodworkers and clothes stalls all made by the owners. You must be prepared to haggle for any goods that you wish to purchase, the vendors expect it and rather enjoy it.On one small place there was a woodworker, working in the traditional manner, he had a chisel held with one foot and a string bow to turn the wood. He was very talented and made very intricate designs in minutes. Step inside the wooden articles will take your fancy and I can guarantee you will not walk away empty handed.Try to find a guide, they will take you around the souk and you will not be pestered too much. Not that it is a problem, all vendors are pleasant and helpful. Some speak very good English
Big souks. Very huge market place, loads of Moroccan items to look and buy. would highly recommend but would advise you try to haggle with prices.

Half day tour recommended. The souks are overwhelming at first but once you get your bearings and understand the geography, you can relax and shop till you drop. If you get lost, pay a child 20 dirhams to lead you back to the square. The half day tour is highly recommended as your guide will take you deep into the souk where the trades are including dyes, leather and metal work. Watch the artisans at work and buy their products. Remember to negotiate and pay no more than 30-35% of their starting prices. I recommend you go to the Government store before shopping here as prices are fixed and set by the government, helping you to benchmark. You need to walk away and have the vendor chase you to ensure you are not paying too much. And if they give you a free gift as you leave, then you know your negotiating skills need to be sharpened!

good fun but be careful. Although I met my friends in marrakesh, i was alone when i went to the square. I was warned to be careful, and although i enjoyed it and had fun, I had to hide my money and belongings due to lots of pick pockets and thieves being present. Definitely keep change on you, if you want to see some entertainment, as they don't do anything without tips
Not great. Too pushy and too many mopeds whizzing around narrow streets. Very easy to get lost, which can be fun. Worth going to the main square in the evening to eat at one of the stalls.

Boring, don't expect to find anything else than the same cheap quality you find everywhere . ...a large area, same things all over the place..touristic , no authenticity..it reflects what Marrakesh has become .a shopping mall for tourists
Good market . Need to hassle and bussel the prices but it's a good experience really tests your buying skill lots of live small shows like snakes monkeys etc

A must do thing!. The souks are definitely something to experience when you visit Marrakech. It's the heart of the city.The stalls ask shops are all so wonderful but you must haggle at everything. Unless there is a price tag on the merchandise you can pay pennies for anything you see. They will bump up the price which may still seem cheap to you but you must haggle as they know if you don't buy from them you'll buy the same thing from another stall.The souk is full of men making inappropriate comments but you must just learn to ignore them as although they make these comments they never try to approach you or touch you.The best part of the souk is the actual markets where you can have real Moroccan mint tea and sit amongst the locals and other tourists and everyone is so friendly you'll gel in.The souk's in the night is a beatific site with the market holders selling Moroccan lamps which they light up and lay on the ground. The prayer call from the mosque's is also very lovely to hear and the snake charmers and monkey's.

Don't stop. We went to the Marrakesh Souk with a guide. I am now glad we did. Although the locals always tried stop you to buy their wares, our guide would leave them until we insisted No then he would intervene. Best thing if you want to buy is ask the guides advice, although I think they may well get backhanders for sales made. It is quite amazing some of the conditions the metal workers operate in, I don't think health and safety exists

A great place to get lost.. Thousands of shops, stalls and restaurants. You will get plenty of attention, but after a while if wears off and you can take it in your stride. Spices, clothing, leather, knick knacks, shoes made out of old tyres, you name it you can find it. So much to see and do, it will take you more than a day to explore this wonderful souk.

Bustling, colourful and aromatic. The souks were an eye-opener. So many stalls, many arranged in souks with special interests - leather, jewellry, spices, fabrics etc. It can be intimidating and you wonder whether you may get lost and then suddenly you come into the square. Haggling is great fun if you're up for it. Start at aboue 40% of what they suggest and you will find the level below which the vendor will not go - generally about 60-70% of asking price. The storeholders were all charming and we were able to break away easily.

Great shopping. So much to buy here from clothes, lamps and leather to spices, medicines and teas. It very easy to get lost here as everything kind of looks the same so top tip would be to have the souk downloaded or saved on your phone so you can use the GPS without roaming when you are out. We didn't get hassled much at all but did have a 5 month old baby with us so maybe the Moroccans gave us a break.

Everyone what to sell!. Everybody is selling something and if you stop to look they will pull you in and sell you something. So much to look at and some junk, but some nice things as well. Even some very expensive, beautiful Antique shops.

Unique. A unique spot in the world. If you come to Morocco, you must come here. So much has been written before, so I won't try now. But I was here a few years ago and the scene has mellowed out considerably. There is much less hassling than before (though one guy did want 200 MAD for a snake photo!) and it is much easier to get around without being pulled all directions by touts. So off you go! Enjoy!

Fun shopping area. I can definitely understand why some people wouldn't enjoy the haggling and fast-pace of the souks. I found, though, that the sales people weren't mean or aggressive - haggling is just part of the culture and I had fun with it. It's a great place to buy gifts and household items, but you do have to be careful if you buy oils or spices. I bought two bottles of "argan oil" from two different vendors. One was real and one was not.

Wonderfully Colorful. Beautiful distractions to draw the eye, warm hospitable people and very good prices - if you're willing to negotiate;)The maze of shops and streets and food vendors and metallurgists and leather carvers, shoe makers, wood carvers, fabrics, textiles, sweet smiles and gently aggressive sellers are the soul of the souk!! Word to the wise-wear comfortable closed toed shoes-it's cobblestone or dirt streets, that are wet in some spots. Also, bring an empty satchel for your purchases and wear a cross body bag that you don't have to carry with your hands! Prepare yourself for walking and being overstimulated with colors, smells, people and sounds, because these all make up the souk!!

Quite an experience. Test out your haggling skills! Talk the talk and walk away when the price isn't right.. and if they really want your custom they'll come after you with a much lower price! Initially it's quite annoying having to haggle in the souks but once you've got the hang of it, it's fascinatingly addictive! There are some genuinely good people in Marrakech, and I really enjoyed talking to them while shopping. The souks have almost anything you need, but it takes time to figure out how to navigate them. Enjoy!

Loved loved loved it. Loved the colour and the variety. The old men sitting together for a chat. Artisans making things right there among the shops. My kids enjoyed it too. Have a good idea of the right price (a visit to ETS bouchaibe mall will help) to pay and try a little bargaining. It can be fun.
Souks . I loved the souks!!! I actually wanted to buy everything. Bartering was easy and I felt no one was overly pushy with you

Lots of shops in tiny streets . The souks are divided into areas with each area specialising in certain types of product. The range was interesting, particularly leather, wood and metalwork. The streets are narrow and the scooters/bicycles/donkeys/etc all cane it around so you have to keep your eyes open to make sure you don't get run down. Walk on the right hand side - it's safer!

A must experience. Unlike all the other Souks in Morocco, the Souk in Marrakesh was actually cleaner than the rest. We walked all over the Souk and were asked by many vendors to purchase gifts but they were not as pushy as other places. The many leather products, dry fruit stalls, lanterns etc... were a sight to behold. A visit to the souk is a must, if you are visiting Marrakesh.

An experience . The more time we spent there, the more we enjoyed it. It's great to haggle and discover all the goods that are on offer. Some of the shop keepers were too aggressive for me personally as people blocking your way so you have to go into the shop or pulling on our clothes was a bit much. These people were however in the minority. It's worth bearing in mind that there are some livestock markets dotted about if anyone is an animal lover. You can tend to smell and gear when you are coming up to them though.
Colorfull. You nust visit during the day and watch the colors.. And great shopping expriance.. Then in the evening yiu will see how the food market builds itsekf up to a grrat food experiance
Real Traditional Morroco. A lot of good traditional stuff, but don't buy from the first time. Ask several shops and for sure you have to negotiate the price A LOT.

Chilled out and nice for a wander. We didnt get nearly as harassed here as we did everywhere else in the city. It was a welcome escape from the usual harrasmemt of the medina. A lot of the things for sale are the same in each shop so just have a look around before buying and always haggle of course. Offer 70% less than their first price and never pay more than half of what they 1st offer it for.

Not for the faint hearted but excellent experience. Wow! What an experience, from snake charmers, monkeys, henna tattoos, music, drumming and shops as far as the eye can see this place is nuts. There is so much going on and so many people attracting your attention it is easily a place that could possibly be a little overwhelming! I jumped more than in a Halloween theme park but found the experience absolutely fascinating! It's a must visit if you're visiting Marrakesh, just use your head, respect their culture and keep your valuables safe. I found sunglasses on a quick walk not giving eye contact was a good tip!! We also had a fab taxi driver who brought us and picked us up so we didn't wait around.

a bucket list experience!. agree with other reviewers....go prepared, its not for the faint hearted but its amazing and fun and best to do it at your own pace without a guide, an evening visit is a must too. Don't worry about getting lost, its inevitable but plenty of help is available, on the whole the people are lovely its only the sales tecniques that are agresive not the men. keep your sense of humour, they love to laugh. Be aware that goods are not cheap but most are beautiful and hand made and you have to be prepared to haggle as much as they do. Even if you don't want to shop the whole thing is a brilliant experience not to be missed.
The heart of local market. Colorfull square with lots of caffe and small restaurants around. Suok is very nice! You can feel the city, look around sitting in the shades with a cup of local coffee

Not the best. Compared with the souk at Fez this was not of the same quality. Many of the items on sale seemed to be of inferior quality and to have been imported. It was alarming to see the skins and furs of many animals, some rare and endangered on open sale.

Crazy place! . A must see for anyone going to Marrakech. We had a tour guide booked through our hotel for the morning in the souks who inevitably took us to he's friends shops where he hoped we would have bought things. I would advise getting a guide for first time but so wish we had gone back to experience this at our own pace. The men at the stalls are v persistent and if you show an interest in anything they will try to sell to you but as long as you can smile and say no thanks they did seem to leave us alone. Massive eye opener to see things being made how they have been for centuries including carpets and metal workers. Just have lots of change on you and remember to smile and be polite.

Once or so you will get lost - 100%. Zillions of little narrow streets, paths, countless dealers, everyboy offers more or less the same stuff. Watch: prices are high ! even after tough bargaining, they are not cheap !!! . However thsi souq is a place which is an absolute must ! And: yes. you will eventually get lost. But it does not matter: there is always a way out. in fact, there are even road signs, perfectly hidden, but they actually work, otherwise just ask !...A pity: the tradition of being offered mint-tea is somehow fading a bit... tough times for the dealers ? maybe !...

Best Handy Crafts I've ever seen. Ok I really can't say enough about the souks!!!! There are too many beautiful things to comprehend. The male shop keepers are AGRESSIVE so you need to be prepared to sort of tune them out and not be intimidated by them. Do some research online before you go to see what items they sell here, and what you might want to purchase. I googled souks of Marrakech images to get an idea. My favorite things are the pottery, spoons, blankets, tea glasses, and leather bags and shoes. Bring a lot of money and an extra suitcase if you can! We found the agreed upon purchase prices to be about 1/3-1/2 what they sellers tell you originally. Start low when they ask you your best price because they will bargain with you all day! Also if you are buying Argon oil, try to buy it from the women's co-op. The money will go to VERY NEEDY women who are widowed or divorced and not allowed to do any other work besides Argon and weaving. Have fun! You are in for a TREAT!!!!!!!

Culture Shock. This is nothing like the markets in England, it is better! The people were lovely and all sold individual items. The people in the square could be a bit rude, but the souks were a lot better as these people are trying to run a business so they want you to buy but will not harass you.

A shopping maze. What have you come to buy in Morocco? Crockery? Carpets? Linen? Tea sets? Even if you haven't come to the country to buy something - the salesmen in the Souk will convince you otherwise!It's a maze in which we happily got lost in, browsing (never committing to anything!) and avoiding where possible the pushy vendors. If you look like you're even slightly lost, helpful young lads will offer to show you the way (expect a tip to be asked for!).We were shown to a 'special' one day Berber festival of cloth. Seeing the way they colour the cloth before weaving into garments. Of course it ended in a shop where the lad was very helpful. It clicked eventually... But nice all the same to see the back alley process of colouring and the shop. Lots of little stalls to eat at as well.

Marrakech souk. I went to the souk the day before my holiday ended as I wanted to buy some spices I got quite a few & much cheaper than the UK. Freinds we met on holiday brought a large lamp for £100 which would be £300 in the UK.i fancied a little lamp wot I could put a candle in for summer night"s in the garden they wanted to much on the stalls so I left it, on the way out I saw a little old lady sitting on the floor selling lamps & felt sorry for her so I brought 1 of hers she wrapped it in newspaper when I got back & took it out the paper it was battered oh well it was only 20 dirams £1.42 so I wasn't to bother all in all it was a good experience don't realy get bothered by the locals to buy so good day out, we went on the evening it's much nicer all lite up x

A must.... Quite clearly you cannot visit Marrakech without spending time wondering aimlessly though the Souks!There are literally hundreds of little shops selling everything from lights, to slippers, to clothes, to even 1980s Polaroid cameras. Be ready to batter with the traders but remember to always have a smile on your face and you will enjoy.Don't worry if you get lost, because you almost certainly will, there are plenty of locals that will help you out...for a couple of dirham of course!!!

Buying Trip. The Souks in Marrakech have an amazing variety of goods that are not available elsewhere. From wooden and metal crafts to carpets and various edible offerings. As you entre the souks people will pounce on you for your custom, and if you show any interest in products it is difficult to get away from the sellers. As you go deeper into the souks the prices get better, but the price on offer is always much more than you need to pay. Typically you can barter down on major items by around 65%. I bought a Berber rug that was priced up at 6000Dh for just 200Dh and the seller seemed very happy to make the sale. If you venture past the main souks, off the beaten track of the tourists, then you will find the most ineteresting items and the best prices.

A sensory assault - fantastic!. At times chaotic yet very organised! A multitude of stalls and vendors all trying to separate you from your Dirhams. Virtually an undercover market stretching out for what seems eternity. Lots of repetition in stalls but a great choice to view. Top class pottery next to a butchers stall with carcasses and live chickens waiting to be portioned up. Stylish restaurants adjacent to a man sleeping rough; where else but Marrakech. Yes, you are hassled constantly but being polite and refusing politely is the only way. Look shocked at the first price and then barter hard, never pay more than half price and push for more; don't be afraid to walk away if the negotiation doesn't feel right. Refuse all offers of help from cheerful, helpful young men - they want a tip for showing you the way and will show their displeasure when you refuse. A truly stimulating experience but don't forget to take your wits with you!

Wow . What an experience . Dont follow any advice .they lead you on a merry dance and then ask for money if they take you anywhere however genuine they seem . Just take a chance . Find a land mark and go

Awful experience. It is indeed a shame the attitude and agressive behaviour from the stake holders won't let you enjoy this colourful place... Absolutely not chance to buy, I was asked 900 dirhams for an object that I did get later for 100!! Unbelievable, annoying and really but really stressing.

A different experience everytime. I love Jem el fina you can get everything or anythingI needed a watch repair, so round by cafe france, is a local guy, who repaired my watch to better than it was before, just for £9 bargainOpposite cafe france is a traditional French cafe, where you can sit all afternoon for £2.50 and watch a acrobatic show, be greeted by fake mobile phones, watches and traditional African waresAnd if your feeling a bit peckish treat yrself to a traditional sandwich for £2If you wont a pair of false teeth then jem el fina is the placeI love Jem el fina and jem el fina will love you back
Very interesting experience . Great to get an insight into a time gone by,can't help but feel the history. Easy to get lost, guide very helpful in the route and dealing with over zealous salesman

Like a movie set! People so sweet!. Loved the atmosphere and colorful energy! Be careful in the narrow corridors... Don't get hit by a scooter! There are moments and snake charmers just like you wouldImagine.

The BEST souk ever!. I have been to many souks: Istanbul, Cairo, Doha, Bahrain.... but this is by far the best. What I liked about it was that the workmen were right there doing their craft... a wood worker spinning newels and spindles, a metal worker hammering at a fire, dyers working with fabric. It was not just a buying experience, but a learning experience. It was easy to spend all of your dirhams and then some!

Don't get intimidated, just enjoy. In my opinion a great place. Some might get a little intimidated by the shop owners wanting to sell you stuff. Most of them don't bother you mutch though. And if they push you a little, Just stay friendly but clear. Don't worry to get lost allthough sometimes you will feel you do. You will always reach the walls of the medina, so you know where you are. Enjoy! It's a great place!

Great place - too much hassle !. The Souk is a fascinating place, an Aladin's cave which unfortunately cannot be explored & enjoyed at leisure because of the hard selling stall holders. You daren't make eye contact with anyone or pause to look at goods, as you will not get away easily until you buy something. Such a shame, as I would probably have bought all sorts if I could have browsed. Oh, & I had an attempted pickpocket on my last day, so ladies watch your bags & gents, don't keep anything in your back pockets !

It's what you expect . The souk is a massive culture shock but if you expect the "look at my shop very nice very cheap" hassle off every store holder and get use to just saying 'no thanks maybe later' it becomes fun aim to ask for a quarter of the asking price and barter up the vendors love a good barter and enjoy it, just be polite.

Lively Souk area!. Souk is medium sized and easier than most to get your bearings. Do not hesitate to go out on your own. Small enough that you can get your bearings. Full of history and lively people. Safe for Westerners - many tourists are also exploring with you.

Hustle & bustle.. Amazing time at souk smells sight & sounds. Love the atmosphere. Loved the horse & carriages. It's like a maze once your in it take a while to get out. Just go and try it, say no thanks to the guides. Go at night time it's buzzing!!

Amazing bazaar. A little like the big bazaar in Istanbul but more authentic.The salespeople are so friendly and some are just hilarious.We loved haggling for small items and were offered mint tea almost everywhere we went.
Really nice to see all the different shops. Really nice to see all the different shops. Some very small shops with daily products but also with tourist stuff.

Do not go.. I would consider myself streetwise having been born and lived in London all my life and eve i found this place a nightmare! If you must visit this square do not look at anyone or engage in any conversation because the street performers or stall holders will hassle you in an aggressive manner until they get your money, dont go close to the poor performing monkeys or snakes because before you know it you will have a flea bitten monkey on your head and or snakes draped around you then cash is demanded and im not talking small change, visit the cafe/bar on the edge of the square which has a large roof terrace where you can watch all the unsuspecting tourists getting fleeced..

Souks. The Marrakech Souks are a great place to venture into. Be prepared to haggle and barter with the artisans. It's a fun way to shop for souvenirs. You can hire guides to take you through which is what we did. I recommend it as it's very easy to get lost but saying that you may be okay especially if you have a map. You won't always get the most direct way out, when asking the locals as they want you to stay in there so you spend more money. There are so many things to buy and see and makes for a great morning or afternoon. Keep your belongings in your front pockets to ward off pick pockets!
exotic smells and colors, but.... if you like to shop, get aggressive sellers hounding you, lost, and lost again, the souks are it! for me, just some good fotos!
WONDERFUL. What a fabulous, vibrant and friendly place the souk is. If you are in marrakech do not miss it, but barter hard!!!
Interesting shopping. Busy, colourful market with so many different items to look at or buy. Never pay full price, start at half price and bargain.

Marvelous variety with some great buys. The maze of passageways crammed with small shops, each filled with its own specialty and creating a riot of colors and people, should not be missed. It can easily, and profitably, be visited more than once. It is much less crowded early in the morning when the shops open. Be firm and say you are not interested (in French or English) when approached by an eager merchant. Do not pick up or touch an item unless you are interested and always bargain over the price (a good rule of thumb is to start at 40-50% of the stated price. If you then walk away, the merchant may even come down from his "final" offer). While you can navigate the Souk on your own with the help of Google Maps, you probably need a guide to direct you to the best shop for each type of goods (which is what we did). Beware of pickpockets, though. You are asking for trouble if you have your wallet or iPhone in an easily accessible back pant pocket or exposed side pocket of your purse. Enjoy!

Great Experience. The Souks can be a very chaotic place, however if you're in the Medina it is definitely worth visiting. It is very easy to get lost in this maze of market stools and be expected to get hassled by the seller - it is their culture! Be prepared to haggle if you're looking to buy and don't be scared to say no. Lots of opportunities to buy gifts with a buzzing atmosphere along the way!

You have to go. Really interesting place, crowded and crazy. You can find from chinese knock offs to really nice morrocan crafts: if you go you have to fight the price they give you, for example they wanted to sell a lamp at 1800 dirhams and I payed 450.

Same old stuff . If you've ber to North Africa you'll know the score:
Lots of tat, hustlers, copies of designer stuff
Great fun if you keep the sellers at arms length
Some proper bargains if you look carefully and haggle
If that's not your thing AVOID it!

Lots Of the same!!. The souk is the market place, with little alleyways that all look the same, so you get disorientated, you can't look at anything as you are approached immediately which puts you off! No prices on anything so have a price in mind what you would pay back home.

Good for presents. Do explore the hustle and bustle of this market. Lots of stalls to buy your nik naks for presents and a lot of them all hand made. It's a experience you won't want to miss. Mopeds everywhere just keep to the right on the little cobbled streets and you will be safe. I enjoyed it immensely an experience you won't forget. They rely on tourists to buy their gifts here.

Chaotic but worth a visit. Do wander round and explore the market. It's a trip back in time. It is a maze but look up and you'll see signs for the exit. We managed to find our way out without difficulty. People offered to help but we knew they wanted money and politely turned down their offer. We fully explored the areas and were amazed with the wide variety of goods on sale - the market is divided into specialties area for example textiles, ceramics, food, leather, antiques, pets, spices, shoes etc. You can even see the artisans at work.Best tip: visit the Ensemble Artisanal to have an idea of the prices before coming here. Haggle for prices below that of Ensemble Artisanal and walk away if the prices do not suit you. They'll call you back! Be reasonable though. Do not pay for the price you're first quoted.

GO EXPLORE. Just do it! Let yourself go and explore the souk. You'll see both the familiar and the unknown, fine art and junky trinkets, recognizable foods and things not imagined. Life is so good in Marrakech!
All you may need is here!. Loved rambling through the Souk, great artisans and beautiful artifacts....if I could I would take a bit of everything!!!

You can get lose very easy but it is fun if you have time. What i dont like is barging for everthing you would like to buy but it could be fun make sure you loock and check out prices then go shopping the next day the more you go you find your way out easyer
Lovely Day. Very good day out lots of shopping marrakech people very welcoming, make sure to have fresh orange juice there.
Cultural differences. So culturally different to England was a great experience, guide was very helpful and showed us the 'real' Marrakech souks

Amazing!. I would recommend to take a guide on your first visit as it can be overwhelming to walk through the souk. Then, if you have a second day you are more familiar with the area and can go alone. You can always ask the stall holders, or young people who are more likely to speak your language, the way. I would recommend that people still dress appropriately for the country as offence may be taken by inappropriate display of the body.I had a great time there on day one with a guide and day two on my own.

Miss . Very nice atmosphere It's very modern , very well decorated very clean with super polite staff . Is got live music with very super professional singer from America . Also got very good dj It's great for partying . People there are so friendly . Is mine of the best in Marrakech and is as good as private night club in london .100% recommended
A Must See. We did an organised excursion to here which I would recommend as you get to see some things that would not normally be possible.

A shopping lover's dream?. Endless choice of anything you may want: spices, leather goods, lanterns, prettily decorated mirrors, products made of iron and silver, traditional clothing, jewellery, olives, nuts, there is all sorts.
Amazing. The square is definitely not to be missed go in the day and evening it's like two different places this really is a great place to visit.

loved it, went with my friend. went to merrakech with my friend as a short break away from kids an husbands....we had a blast. loved the night clubs and the market was great to experience. when we first got off the bus from the hotel we had to attach our selfs to 2 men also walking to the market who said they didnt mind but once we got there we were fine.. Being on our own we did get hassled by the men....i found the younger men were nicer when you told them no thankyou an we were able to have some banta with them,,,the older ones not so nice an once we told them we were looking for our husbands an that we had lost them at the market they left us alone...but i still worth experiencing ....we felt safe walking around on our own but we did not go to far into the lanes as they got smaller an felt darker so styed nearer the main market...

prepare to barter. great fun & hard work at the same time, if you ask anyone a question they want paying (only coppers) if you take a pic they want paying, it is very lively and also great fun, I bought stuff I did not want just to see how cheap I could get them lol

OMW... shop shop shop. This souk is like many others... Shops shops and more shops.. which means spend spend spend. Looks like some good leather and wood products. Morrocon mens Islamic wear too. Will Definitely go back to do shopping. Be prepared to get lost..

Experience, not to be missed, but tedious!!. If you want lots of hassle, then go this fascinating place.So many stalls, selling identical items, how do they ever make any money??The problem is, you can't browse, and in fact they make it impossible to buy anything. They are on top of you in a parasitic way. We tried several times to purchase times, and they drove us mad, we walked away.To be honest, they are fools to themselves and the stall holders who learn to adopt a laid back approach will benefit.Do the Souk, but be warned

Organised chaos. The epitome of Marrakech, the Souks are an exciting attack on all your senses. The stall holders do of course want to sell you something but they are mostly charming and full of good humour. A must to visit even if you hate shopping!
Haggle to your hearts delight. Don't accept there price, enjoy the fun of haggling, it's great. Stand your ground, offer what it's worth to you and stay at that.

A nightmare,!. We were warned about the various scams but still managed to get suckered!! We couldn't go in any of the streets without getting accosted !! We ended up literally getting robbed by a couple of men !! If you go to Marakech and want traditional wares go to the government funded craft centre this is really reasonable and no haste !!
must have seen. it´s looking so nice and quirly. That´s a place you must see it.Der Souk ist sehenswert, besonders kann man hier preiswert Lederjacken erwerben.

The real Marrakesh. The souks are a rabbit warren of little streets crammed with traders. We hired a guide to walk with us and show us round and advise us on the best places to purchase. This meant we avoided getting lost and saw a lot more of the souks than we would have on our own.Do expect to haggle on all purchases and dress respectfully covering shoulders and cleavage.

This is the heart of Morocco and must be experienced. If you are of a nervous disposition, then this might not be the area for you. You will be hustled and hassled every second you are in the square, however "La Shookran" (no thank you), usually gets you through!If you like monkeys on chains, then there are some of those you can have you photo taken with - at a price. Likewise snakes. If that is really what you want to do, negotiate first, otherwise you will find a monkey on your shoulder before you know it and a hand held out demanding mucho dirhams. There are also story tellers, musicians and henna artists in abundance. To get the best effect, go as it gets dark.There are a coulple of cheap eateries where you sit at trestle tables and can continue soaking in the atmosphere. Best bargain is freshly-squeezed orange just from one of the many stalls, for just a few dirhams.There are lots of souvenirs and knick-knacks everywhere, but for better bargains and a more peaceful pace, take the lane "Rue Riad Zitoun" south from the square. It gets less frenetic, the further you go. At the end of it, you will come out into a small square and there is a "covered market" close by. Shop here for scarves, jewelry and spices. You can still haggle, but the prices are much more reasonable to start with.
souk van marrakech. you can lost easy. there are very little streets but is is not dangerous. people are very relaxed in the souk
Interesting but average market. Hard selling market stalls. Not much to buy though. Went on a horse drawn carriage around town during the day and we enjoyed that!

Shopping heaven in the souk. you have to visit the souks for the experience and you don't get forced into buying things. Naturally, these people rely heavily on tourists buying souvenirs  Do not, underline, do not, ever trust the children who offer you help! We got lost, were helped through a series of alleyways and then the child demanded money

Hustle and bustle. I knew it would be colourful and vibrant, and I knew it would not be my cup of tea. In every country with aggressive salesmen and hagglers you easily get cheated. Egypt was one of my horrors. So, this was a fast run for me, trying to avoid every invitation. Of course there are some very nice people as well, but most of them are just too much for me. And then not being able to photograph - that is really a problem for someone as photo interested as me. If I ask - they say no, if I do not ask, they might even scream and chase me with a stick. (Happened to my husband...) I'm used to this problem from other countries as well - where they hide their faces or I must pay them to get a photo. Of course religion is important, and I always respect that, but this was the worst country ever in this way. The conclusion is of course, that I should stop visiting this kind of area, while others only enjoy the show. But, in Marrakesh, the Souk is a "must", so I DID it.

It's a trap, a big tourist one but an experience. i have visited a few souks in Morocco and always enjoy the experience. The one in Marrakech is a bit of a tourist trap and you are easy prey. If you are looking at buying anything of value I would go elsewhere and haggle haggle haggle ...... but for nick nacks and souvenirs it's all good fun. Don't get a guide as they are simply getting backhanders from the places they take you.
Lively, culture and full of energy! . Visited the souks, amazing experience better than the first time I visited. People very warm and welcoming! Lots to do and many places to shop!!!
Labirint . It's nice to see and all.. Very intense but the bargain can be quite stressful.. Visit a coast city called essouaira and you will find nice sellers,no pressure,and better prices!

Amazing but polluted. Just take time to drift through the streets. Yes, some wares get repetitive but there is complete sensory overload - in a good sense. A HUGE drawback was the moped traffic inside the narrow aisles. Here in Marrakesh the noise and fumes were unbearable in some streets. As a sunshade, most streets are loosely covered by strawmats (better) or corrugated tin (worse) that trap the fumes. But while I could hold my nose and breath, locals selling wares and food (!) were sitting in the fumes all day! Why that is allowed? No idea. In Fes and Meknes there was no motorized traffic inside the medina,

EWomen travelling alone. so, I decided to go to Morocco with my 19 yr old daughter, both of us light brunettes with long flowing hair, she with startling clear blue eyes. we had a 10 day gap so off we set via bus to Algeciras and then on the ferry to Tangiers. It was just after Xmas and as a travel guide advised sharing our food we took all the left over goodies in an old ladies shopping trolly. Travelling on a shoestring we had decided on a very tight budget so upon arrival my daughter announced that if she was expected to live on hard boiled egg sandwiches she would need a lettuce..a dash into the poorly lit souk followed by a taxi ride and we were at the train station washing our lettuce in the basins of the ladies loos (gave the attendant a stollen cake) and then onto a shared cabin to Marrakesh....people in and out all night so we shared fresh pineapple.The following morning we arrived at the huge square Jemaa el Fna, found a pension down a little alley, haggled for the room price and shared christmas cake with the men who sit in the back room drinking tea and set off out to explore. We spent the next four days, morning to night wandering the souks, visiting old palaces and ruins, walking the seemingly endless old walls of the city, trying amazing foods in the open air restaurant that is the square by night, dodging snake charmers in the market that is the square by day.We were never hassled once, in fact were treated with great respect I suppose as it is so obvious that we are mother and daughter and spent many lovely smiley moments as the morocan women marveled at my daughters beautiful blue eyes.For any woman who fancies a little adventure this is the place to go and the shopping...well where do I start! If you enjoy fun and haggeling the old city of Marrakesh is for you. A truly wonderful experience.

visit with a guide. this is a real labyrinth. and the sales people are pushy and imposing. best to visit with a guide. the guide will show you the shops you are interested in. the guide will make sure that sales people don't impose. and give you lot's of background info on the souks and history

interesting. was interesting to see - had a vast array of spices, pots, jewellery, shoes etc we had a private tour organized by the hotel so no one hassled us and went much deeper into the souk where more traditional things were made and not just imported from china

A life of vibrancy . Going to Morocco you have this idea of what it's like - but once you're there the colours, life and markets are overwhelming! One can spend ours in a maze of streets (which I certainly did) getting lost from food markets to clothes shopping - especially leather! Bags, sandals, purses... The list goes on! All of it is available and at reasonable prices too (bargaining & haggling!!) The Souks of Marrakesh were absolutely delightful, people friendly (sometimes pushy, but being firm is all that's needed). My last recommendation: fruit! Fruit/ fruit juice that will cause explosions in your mouth. And if you are faced with the choice of Marrakesh or Fes, if you're a shopper Marrakesh is the place (although Fes does have exciting souks selling a variety of stuff you can also find is Marrakesh.) But if you're into more history - Fes is great. Marrakesh will see my face again.

Beautiful wares!. So many beautiful things to see and buy but impossible to even look without being haggled. We found it way too much. We did not enjoy the experience because we were hassled too much.

Tiresome, noisy and expensive.. Unless you really love hard bargaining and nevertheless bring cheated this place should be avoided. I recommend the artisans marker outside the Medina, where the prices are fixed and very low.

Same thing everywhere. We visited the souk after hearing from everyone that we 'must go'. Firstly, the souk is not really just one area as we had thought, but more a collection of streets with vendors as well as a few 'souk markets'. We went and of course got lost (as you do) navigating through numerous stalls selling a variety of items such as paintings, clothing, ornaments, souvenirs, household items and just about everything. The experience was ok, but after just a few minutes of strolling around, we figured once you have seen one, you have seen all. Most of the stalls sell the same thing so never settle on prices from one stall. Similarly, HAGGLE!! For example-I was quoted 140DH for a magnet and after haggling it was knocked down to 4DH..They purposely quadruple (loosely speaking) the prices so always ensure you haggle. Also don't try converting prices to your home currency and say 'Oh that's not bad' as this is what we were doing and yet still found out we were being ripped off completely.

Interesting place. Visited as part of a tour . Our guide didn't let us stop anywhere to shop so we just walked around, would go back later but we didn't have time. Lots of things for sale bit of an aladdins cave with slippers,lamps,pottery items on sale would have loved to haggle,but as I said a little rushed due to the guide,so best to go without a tour and just browse,but may get lost,as it is a bit of a maze!
Interesting Experience!. No visit is complete in Morocco without visiting a souk (medina)! The sights, sounds and smells are like no other place on earth!

A Fascinating Labyrynth, Where You'll Get Hassled Every Time You Look or Pause. I'd strongly recommend that visitors to Marrakech don't wander into the souk on day one of their visit - it's rather full-on and might deter you from revisiting. Once you're more acquainted with the layout of the City centre, feel more relaxed and have no pressing appointments then it might be a good time to enter. But beware you will get lost, mercilessly hassled and fall prey to opportunists looking to 'Guide' you somewhere and expecting to either drum up business for friends or family or simply to press you for a tip. Which is a shame because it's a fascinating area crammed full of interesting merchandise that would be great to amble through at a leisurely pace with the ability to stop and look without the hard sell.I must say that we did come across some genuinely helpful locals who simply wanted to be kind without ulterior motives.

Buyers beware . My favourite souk in Morocco aside from perhaps Fez (which is the more authentic of the two). Great if you wanna blow wads of cash or just explore it on your own. A large variety of interesting items to see, and the vibe is intense at night, when it is peak time for locals out and about. You can find 5 MAD panaches (50c euro) and 9MAD moroccan cheeseburgers (90C euro), along with other miraculous discoveries.A few things to keep in mind for this specific souk to get the most out of it are - beware petty theft, it is quite high in the Marrakech souk, especially in the large crowds (so keep your wallet, valuables and cash in moneybelt, or breast pocket, nothing in open pockets or back pockets). Also do not accept the open invitations of people wanting to show you to their store which is 10 mins walk away, chances are you walking into a hustle for money. Be firm but polite. - tourist markup prices. There is up to a 1000% markup on items for sale to tourists, do not be scared to walk away from a sale if you aren't happy with pricing, guaranteed you will find the same item elsewhere for much cheaper. Bargain is the word and don't settle just because the sellers are pushy, they know how to act to make you feel bad. Do your research and check out a few different places- it is worth getting lost in the souk as there is many different industrial sectors, from metalworking to carpentry, sewing, pottery etc etc. However if you end up lost, just keep walking around until you see signs hanging down from the souk ceilings pointing you in the directions of various gates and the main square of Jemaa el Fna. Ask a policeman for directions or other tourists you see before asking the locals on the street, chances are they will demand money for showing you the way out- try and dress a little respectfully. You are in a different culture and should endeavour to respect this to make your going easier. I have met many people who have complained about the abrupt comments and whatnot that goes on. The majority of this can be avoided if you are wearing trousers or a long dress and a long sleeve shirt. If you have thick skin, by all means wear a singlet and a pair of shorts, just prepare yourself for the attentions of locals. If you use this as a rough guide, you will have a great time inside the souk and find all the secret, niggly places that sell delicous food, smoothies and rare beautiful products as well as interesting architecture and live works. Highly rated and recommended.

Souk. Good for designer wear bargains but harassment to buy is rife ( reminded me of Egypt), the police were in view as some characters were always about so look after any valuables ie mobile phones,watches, wallets, bags etc but apart from that you'll be able to buy just about anything

Its a must go!. If you haven't payed a visit to the soukena you haven't been to Marrakech. Its easy to get lost but its a part of its charm. You must walk futher in because in the beginning its just fake bags and hectic salesmen. Love it! Bargain a lot!

Amazing but annoying people's . Great place to shop around or just to get lost into but the people there see you as a cash machine and not a tourist - you can not walk 5 metres without being call to go into their shops, sometimes in a aggressive way - we did not enjoy this - people tried to tell you where to go too without you knowing if they are genius or not , so be very careful - Bottomline, we went there once and that was enough for us - for shopping go to the new town of Marrakech (Gueliz) or one of the state own shopping center where the prices are fixed and much lower - despite us going there, we were told off but a couple of local shops owners as we were walking around with the bags from the centre , for not helping the local businesses....who is faults is that?!?...definitely not ours.

Know your way around.. I was lucky to have a local take me around but this place is a maze! Do your research, keep your head down and March. Or explore leisurely and prepare to bargain and be harassed.
Wow. A must, what a great experience, the sights, sounds and beautiful aromas.This is the essence of Marakech, bartering for what you want to buy is all part of the experience .

An Experience. Not to be missed this one. Despite the rhetoric about being hassled and being uncomfortable we ventured into the medina and into the Souk. It was as I imagined and walking across the Square were were hassled by a snake charmer and a henna lady wanting to paint SJ but once past this we walked into the inner sanctum of the shopping experience of a life time! It didn't take us long to find a friend, Ayoub (oh if anyone reading this wants his mobile I am happy to give it to you) Normally I would have felt weary about this but this young man was very pleasant and took us deep into the Souk to some every beautiful places to shop, window shop mind you, as well as making sure that we got a good price for anything we wanted. He seemed to know nearly everyone and those he didn't he made the language barrier much easier to cope with. Our French is very poor. He stayed with us for about 3 hours or more and we believe we would not have had the experience we would have had without him. He made our visit and when we said goodbye back in the medina he was very gracious and deserved every cent of his 200 or was it 400 tip. Great young guide. We didn't end up buying much but we bartered a lot saw some exciting stuff and as the evening drew dark and the square came alive we were really pleased with what we had experienced.

An experience, but beware of scams. This is such a great experience, to see all the lovely stuff they have there.
it is ruined by the constant hassle you get from the locals. Being 2 young women (one blonde) at times it was scary and unbearable. people try to take you down alleys to their dads place....all a bit much.
Colourful, dirty and full of life. Lots to see but easy to be pestered by local shopkeepers . If you take a photograph, expect to pay! Snake charmers run after you and are very persistent.

Amazing shopping, great sightseeing. If you like shopping the Souk of Marrakech is where it's at! You can buy anything you can think of: argan oil, jewelry, spices, clothes, everything. Be sure to never accept the first price they offer you (unless there's a fixed price sign, in which case you shouldn't try to bargain). Always bargain! You can get the same item for 50%, sometimes 60% less than the first offered price. This doesn't go for every item, paintings and carpets are usely an exception, but for all other items it's really worth a try! We got amazing discounts after we bargained with the sellers. Even if you're not looking to buy anything, just wandering around is amazing. So many shops to see, so many sight to marvel at.
Massive and vibrant. Only some shop keepers are really aggressive! And the selling price can be too high for the quality! Otherwise it was a nice to have fun shopping and bargaining.

Same same. If you're into your trinkets then this is the place to come as it is loaded with them. Lots of little alleyways to explore and find a bargain or have a chat about local ingredients, spices or animalsNot so keen on the live animals, but that's my preference, keep your valuables close and ignore the locals ...they're just trying to make a buck

Vibrant and brilliant. You need to prepare yourself for the souks mentally as you will be pulled from every direction!!! they will tell you 4x the price so remember to go right down and haggle your way up.. its fun but tiring as we used to paying ticket prices. you will get plenty of gifts and its very reasonable if you know what you want, enjoy the hussle bussle and colouful souks, a brilliant experience

Place to be visited to see real Marrakech!!!. Its excellent place to see the differences between the new city and old city of Marrakech. Recommended to go with a guide, not to be lost in such big and very confusing place.By taking guide you should be ready to pay him between 20-40 EUR depending on how long you will stay with him. But you will be sure that everything is organised simple way, he will bring you to the things you want to buy, he will find you the taxi or carriage and will agree the price. If you love the actions and attraction you should go there in the evening.

can buy anything, cheaper if not interested. this is the place where you can practice the real negotiation skills.a glance on any object returns a price tag that then you have to bring down. Have achieved 10x drops in price or larger. yes, 10x.How, you can't really be desiring and as you show less and less interest and stick to your numbers... you get it.Great leather, fabrics and many other handcraft stuff. Don't miss it.

Highest Quality Craft. In the Suq in Marrakech a longlife dream of mine came true: at last I could buy all of those wonderful handicrafts I was looking for purchasing. Green pottery, leather bookcovers and sandals, steel lamps, sumptuous fabrics, thuya wood boxes... Only remember to always negotiate: you could get your desired object for less than the half the first price the seller told you (prices are never written down).

Worth a visit. Our hotel had a free shuttle to the Souks and we ventured here one morning. It was hectic, with monkeys on leads, miles of horses waiting for tourists and lots of people trying to give you a guide. We didn't have a guide and got a little lost though. Interesting experience - we weren't in much of a rush to go back but glad we went.

A good way to get a feel for Marrakech and the way of living here. The huge variety of shops frequented by the local people interlaced with tourists wandering around somewhat bemused by the noise, the motorcycles and the colours and smells. Definitely worth a visit and if lost just ask for 'The Square" from a merchant.

Real feel of Marrakech. I was a bit nervous about going to the souk at first as I'd heard stories of people being harassed. However, I felt fully safe there and really enjoyed soaking up the culture. I particularly enjoyed the square and souks at night when they really came alive. Be prepared to haggle and walk away to get the price you would like to pay, we got some real bargains!

Hello! Where you from?. It's only a bargain if you wanted it to start off with. There is such a dazzling array of products - so much stuff - and such eager sellers, I challenge anyone to get out without buying something. And take on board all tips about bartering. If the seller looks cranky because of the deal you struck, it's just part of the game to make you feel good about how clever you are.

Bargaining heaven . We left our shopping until the very last day and found that we found better bargaining ability during the week when there was less people in the souks so the shop keepers were willing to make better offers.

Great Day in Colourful , Chaotic Souk. I firstly went with my husband and child but not really the place for a 5-year-old to wander round so went back myself on a different day. I felt totally safe, though admit to getting lost a couple of times as it is like a big maze! However, I thoroughly enjoyed wandering the narrow streets and admiring the beautiful products on display. A must do if in Marrakesh!

Great fun. Have fun seeing all the goods Morroco has to offer. Be prepared to haggle and bring your sense of humor. If you don't get the price you want, it is almost 100% chance to find it again. It is much more freeing to to know you can walk away. Be prepared to get lost wandering through the tunnels and shops. Some shop keepers will help you, some would like you to visit a bit more and send you down the wrong way. It is usually fairly easy to find your way back to the square if you lose your way. After a day we figured out the paths and enjoyed revisiting a few specific vendors once we knew we had time to think about sizes and colors. They appreciated the revisit but usually still had to negotiate from scratch.
Shop. You can always get a bargain ere never pay the full price alway a 1/4 of the price, always haggle, this place is not for the fant harted. Go in and try

Its a little crazy. Its a must see but after 2 hours i got a little nuts in this organised chaos. People can be a little agressive but in general pretty nice visit. And whatever you do dont go to the tannery its a rip off. Every day is a special holiday and you end up paying for it or have a not very nice exoerience

Grab a fresh orange juice!. This is a busy square but it is laid back and safe to explore. The shops and bazaars offer lots of browsing. I find the cafes can be a bit of a let down food wise. The animals used for the tourist trade, such as monkeys or snakes, are a disgusting sight. Please do not encourage this trade! The area where the horse and carriages line up absolutely stinks - there are eye watering levels of ammonia hanging in the air! My advice, go shopping and have coffee.

Excellent Bazaar Expeience. The souk is adjacent to the famous Jamaa el Fna. Great for old bazaar haggling & price reduction games. The souk has it all but mostly traditional stuff. Pleasant & enjoyable experience. Try to do it late in the afternoon due to hot temperature during the day. Nice food places all around. Don't forget to ask for Tanjiyah.

Crazy, but you've got to see it.. Get some orange juice and settle in for some of the best people watching that can be had. The food is prettying old and the people are friendly. Salesmen can be a little pushy, it a firm "no" does the trick.

Very busy. But lots to see. . Can be a lot of fun. If you are careful and have a good idea of prices, you can get some grea bargains. Keep your wits about you and enjoy the experience. In the end remember if you don't like it, you can just walk away.

Exciting and diverse . It is a unique experience to feel the buzz of the city. Not advisable for cars- on foot is the best way to experience it, even rent a motorcycle- Just consider they move fast and you have to flow with them.
entertaining!. spend a day around here... entertaining street vendors of everything! Be equipped with haggling skills - even for your bottle of water!

Great place to visit. Excellent experience walking around the souk. We saw tons of typical products and practiced our negotiations skills :)
The people who work there are very nice and kind with the tourists.

souks shops. this is place you must go to if you are in Marrakesh the experience and the lifestyle of the souks is amazing the shops and the colours the vibrancy of this place is amazing knowing we would get lost for several hours we did not mind as this is a lifetime experience

Shop till you drop. If you need a shopping spree, this is the place to come. Practice your haggling skills in the 100s of shops selling everything you could want.There are also a looooot of cheap restaurants and food vendors with various cuisines whether you just want a bite to eat or a full sit down meal. Great Ice Cream/dessert places too.Was only 10 minutes away from our hotel so we came pretty much everyday. Great atmosphere and would definitely recommend to anyone staying in Marrakech.

Loved every minute. Brush up on your French! You cannot walk past a single stall without a bonjour etc, learn to ignore it or a polite bonjour wiil suffice, make no eye contact unless you are interested, they will keep you talking for ages and if you are weak you WILL buy something! Have the attitude you don't want anything and keep saying no, otherwise haggle them down to usually 40-50% less than original asking price. They will say they recognise you from your hotel last night! Strangers will come at you by scooter, tell you the way to the souk, come back (presumably after contacting their taxi friend) then find you again, take you to where (surprisingly) there is a taxi to take you (presumably to his friends tannery where you will spend a good few hours) DON'T BE FOOLED. Don't worry about getting lost, there is now way that you won't so just enjoy it, you will keep coming to the same centre time after time each time getting your bearings

seriously into haggling?. get lost in the maze of souks, this place was great there was so much to take in and sometime a little overwhelming, beautiful furniture, jewelry and trinkets though. Cute little eateries line the square. Not too keen on the performing animals, and don't let them catch you taking a picture unless you want to pay for it.

extorted for money for directions. My 18 year old daughter and I spent 90 minutes hopelessly lost in the Souks. We knew that would happen but had looked forward to finding new artisan producers as we meandered around eventually finding our way out. We had only last year become " lost " in the Grand Bazaar in Instanbul and quite enjoyed the experience. This was very different!!At every turn we were met with " I nice man I give you directions ". The first 2 " nice men " had led us down into empty alley ways to then extort money out of us. They would then point the way and when we walked out again we were greeted by the second man offering " I nice man I help you ". We were on a relay of false directions , being charged for the experience to be handed to the next man for his turn. Need less to say we refused to pay and so the " nice man " took payment in kind with groping my daughter. It was awful and we lost all confidence of asking directions. It is the weirdest sensation to be around so many people and feel all alone ! Google maps doesn't work in the souk and there was no sun to help us get our bearings. We had been warned not to take directions from young boys for the very reason but we had asked older women you " referred " us into their son " to help ". Yes we got out eventually put. But my daughter was in tears and it was an awful experience. My advice. Go to the Souk. They are worth seeing BUT even if you feel lost don't take directions from the boys or young men who offer to help. Find something to buy and ask the shopkeeper.

extorted for money for directions. My 18 year old daughter and I spent 90 minutes hopelessly lost in the Souks. We knew that would happen but had looked forward to finding new artisan producers as we meandered around eventually finding our way out. We had only last year become " lost " in the Grand Bazaar in Instanbul and quite enjoyed the experience. This was very different!!At every turn we were met with " I nice man I give you directions ". The first 2 " nice men " had led us down into empty alley ways to then extort money out of us. They would then point the way and when we walked out again we were greeted by the second man offering " I nice man I help you ". We were on a relay of false directions , being charged for the experience to be handed to the next man for his turn. Need less to say we refused to pay and so the " nice man " took payment in kind with groping my daughter. It was awful and we lost all confidence of asking directions. It is the weirdest sensation to be around so many people and feel all alone ! Google maps doesn't work in the souk and there was no sun to help us get our bearings. We had been warned not to take directions from young boys for the very reason but we had asked older women you " referred " us into their son " to help ". Yes we got out eventually put. But my daughter was in tears and it was an awful experience. My advice. Go to the Souk. They are worth seeing BUT even if you feel lost don't take directions from the boys or young men who offer to help. Find something to buy and ask the shopkeeper.

Great experience...but wow... Classic Marrakesh experience but it was mighty stressful at times. Even as a large, muscular man I felt rather intimidated at times because of the intense solicitations. Definitely a must do for the city though, have fun with it!

Great for shopping !!. We visited the souk during a week day. It was not that busy and we did some shopping. We decided to go back on a Sunday night, and it was like festival. It is a night out for locals when the snack charmers, the story tellers, the acrobats are displaying their charm The food stalls are busy with local people and there is a great sense of enthusiasm, happiness and culture.
A-maze-ing. I absolutely love the souks. We have spent hours wandering around looking sampling smiling at the attempts to lure us into stall and shops then out of nowhere pops up a shiny bank!!

You have to make this part of your visit!. When in Marrakech, this is a must-go to place, even if shopping is not your thing. Just the activity and people watching makes it worth while. A guide with you is very helpful - while they are clear they will not get involved in negotiating prices, they can help you figure out what and how to engage in the process if it is new for you. Even those of us who have done it many times in other countries need guidance as each country has its own methods and informal "rules" about it!. Don't hesitate to try - it should be part of your experience.
Souks are the soul of the city. Awesome and great, they are there for business and make money, they have many tricks in their sleeves to sell you anything, bargaining always works

Very colourful and interesting. Walking around the souks was great, I can't stand the men that are taking advantage of travellers that get a bit lost. They can be quite threatening. Don't accept any strangers help to get you back to your Riad, the money they expect for doing so is ridiculous, but one couple I met said that when they didn't give it, hours later when they headed out if their Riad, they were still waiting, and harassing them for more money. They ended up giving in because they didn't want them following and harassing them

You have to go there..... Great place if you like everything mixed together... Smells, flavors, people... I like it :) I bought there a lot of souvenirs for my friends - cheap prices and a little bit of true life :)

Treasures in the souk.. I loved getting lost in the souk, every corner we took we saw something new and exciting and some of the repeated items but at different prices. You can do lunch here as we stumbled on few cafe's such as Nomads and cafe Epice as they are 2 of this location.Be careful, when you are starting to steer away from the souk and it starts to look local, go back and make a different turn as this means you are starting to different away from the souk. Few passage ways are a little upscale then the others so make sure you see everything and try every corner and most of all have fun!
Scary as hell and smelt disgusting!!. Absolutely vile!! Hassled non stop really unpleasant and I like to barter In most markets after travelling many different places!! This is something else!!

What fun!. Don't miss finding your way through the Marrakech Souk but if you can get a guide to go with you, so much the better. The alleyways are winding and you'll never find your way back and there is some concern about pick-pockets. Still, if you have a guide and several specific destinations in mind, the souk is well worth your time. Great buys on art, jewelry, clothing and more

A must-see when in Marrakech!. While not as good as the souk in Fes, the Marrakech souk will def slake your thirst for shopping! Everyone says it's confusing - and it is because it's large - but just go with the flow & you'll be fine. You don't need a guide. Just a sense of adventure and the realization that you really can't get lost. Or, if you come out of the souk & aren't sure where you are, you can always grab a taxi to take you back to your riad/hotel. Try to stay away from the stuff obviously made in China. And bargaining is expected of course.

Souk lunch & shopping. 1) What ever price you are given when you get given a price half it, they will always take less. "branded stuff"2) Be very mindful of your valuables to the point you set a reminder on your phone every 10min.. Because you will forget, and if that fails, you can always pretend your phone is ringing and walk off.. Lol3) Your exchange rate calculation. Get your calculator out and put in..
