Example 150dh ➗ divide exchange rate 13 press = equals £11.53

Amazing maze of shops...be sure to buy a carpet..everyone does. did lots of exploring of the Souk...lots of variety and don't buy the first thing you see...also be sure to go to the artisan market a short walk away
Memorable Experience!. What a wonderful experience, loved the colours, aromas and sheer experience of the souk...brought home wonderful treasures from this experience.

Crazy but fun . This was a experience within its self but worth it we went around 3:30 and was there till night,I would recommend going before dark so your not overcome with the busy sellers trying to get you buy stuff,be sure to haggle and shop around don't buy from first person you see.this is s very big place and not sure if we even did half,so much to see and so many Back ally's,but also great places to eat.

More hassle than it is worth. Maybe some people like bargaining and are immune to being hassled (or rather bullied) into spending their money, but I didn't. Every time we stopped, someone would try and say they would guide us to the main square/museum/the best carpet shop. Every time I so much as glanced at a scarf or piece of jewellery or metal work on display in the souk, the shop keeper would be hassling me to buy...saying there is a good price now but if I go away, the price goes up. It became a bore and put me right off buying anything. In the end, I went to Central Artisan store (looks unassuming but is massive and has everything that is in the souks but at a set price, and no-one hassles you. Also, if you want to buy fossils or silver, you will get the real thing here rather than one of the many fakes in the souks (though no doubt some stalls had real fossils, real silver..)Shame, the tourist board should give the souk stall owners a good talking to as they would sell much more if tourists were able to browse without being bullied.
Pay for a guide. Marakesh as it is in the medina and souk. Crowded and constantly hassled by leering men and sellers. Went back with a guide thoroughly recommend this for a stress free trip.

Experiance. You have to visit the souks to believe it,it is crazy there. Their are hundreds upon Hundreds of market stalls crammed so tight it's like sardines in a can. However it creates a maze of alleys with stalls selling practicllly anything you want from leather goods ( Excellent by the way ), spices, sports wear, clothing, the list is endless. In fact I'm convinced you could get lost in there. Having said that its great fun, and you definitely have to haggle over the prices. Whatever they ask for, your first opening bid should be 50% less than what was asked.We visited both during the day and a night shopping spree, we felt quite safe. People were generally very friendly and helpful. If your going to Marrakech you have to visit the souks it's like a tradition.

Grate experience. Definitely one of the most insane places I have ever been to. The colors, the sound and the smells are totally new and fascinating. A place everybody visiting Morocco should put on their bucket list. You can buy there absolutely everything metal work, glass work and very good quality leather. Plus You can train Your negotiating skills. Always start from 50% of the asking price, because usually that's the real price for non tourists. Visit it 2 times once during day time and one after sunset. I promise You won't regret it.

Craftsmanship. Don't be afraid to get right into the souks - the nearer Jamaa El Fna the more hassle. We found the quality of objects great for the price. Do bargain, with good humour, but who cares if you or they get a good price - if you like it and it's worth it for you everyone wins. I found a really beautiful box I could never have afforded back home. And once we'd bought from a couple of people, they were friendly next time we passed and we had some splendid Berber tea! It would be a shame if these artisan trades died out, so explore and support.

Exciting, beautiful and exotic. Although you may find the Souks overwhelming, they do offer a masterclass in Moroccan culture and produce. Never buy first time and always walk away to force a price down as invariably they will charge you too much as a tourist. Be aware that the Souk to the North of the Square becomes cheaper the further North you travel.

Colourful, vibrant and a bit claustrophobic.. Spent an interesting morning in the Souk which comprises a seemingly endless warren of narrow, dark streets, occupied on both sides by small shops or stalls selling a wide variety of goods. These included: pottery, clothing, trinkets, leather goods, food (meats and vegetables) and beautiful displays of colourful spices and colorants.Unlike similar markets I have visited in Egypt and Turkey, the hassle factor is very low. Naturally, you are invited to visit their shops and stalls but never in an intimidating manner and they will accept a "No!" with good grace.Finding your way out can be a challenge and, not being able to easily leave made us feel a mite uneasy and claustrophobic. No visit to Marrakesh would be complete without a visit to the Souk.

Wonderful experience. I really enjoyed the souk. I would recommend a guide taking you for the first time. Have been to markets in Istanbul and Dubai and this souk was my favourite by far. Have fun bargaining! For those who are headed into the Atlas mountains, you can find more carpets, pottery, and jewellery as well and you can get a better price

Shopping heaven. The souk is suffering from lack of tourists. It is such fun, you need to join in and go with the flow. The silver metal wear, the leather wear, the slippers, the pottery, the scarfs, the baskets, it's all wonderful! Bargain hard and keep a smile on your face and you will be rewarded with treasures to take home.

All the things. There were all the things except striped socks in a size 47+ and a plastic plate. I am one bagging and don't have the capacity to take on much stuff. The ceramic plates are beautiful, as I am careless. .

Proceed with Caution. The souk was a sensory feast with monkeys and snake charmers and a myriad of food offerings. The market exists for people to make money and when we chose not to buy something at a stall, it was not uncommon to be cursed and sworn at. Ensure that food is cooked before eating it. There is limited access to water so levels of hygiene are variable. Proceed with caution. When photos are taken, people expect to be paid for it.

A step back in time, watch you don’t get lost. On our first day, I must admit I got a bit of a culture shock. Never seen anything like this before and felt intimidated. Eventually you find and follow your feet and start enjoying this crazy place but if you've never been here, it will take you about two days. There isn’t an inch occupied by traders who all want to sell and although the majority are nice (as in respectful) traders, you will see a few unpleasant ones who are extremely pushy. La Shukran, a smile and continuing to walk away is the only way out. If you want to buy something, haggle, haggle, haggle - set your own reasonable price and don’t budge.

get ready to make a deal. Bargaining is part of buying. They start high to see what they can get. Have your price in mind and stick to it. But if you really want it get it at the end things are very reasonable. Remember tho the merchants need to make money also so be fair.

Maze of markets. The local Marrakech market stalls within the medina are very iconic and make for an extremely pleasant day out. Go early to avoid being run down by mopeds. Go hungry to sample some local cuisine from one of the street vendors. Go prepared to bargain hard for that ultimate souvenir. Go without a map and get lost in the maze and rabbit warrens and enjoy the attack on your senses from herbs to leather to bubbling tajines of chicken and beef.

Worth a visit. The souks are amazing, so many people selling everything you can imagine but watch out for people trying to force things on you. The souks themselves are fine, just the usual sellers trying to get you to look in their shop. Watch out for the square, there are many people trying to get money out of you, people will just come up to you and put snakes around your neck or monkeys on your shoulder, they will then encourage you to take pictures, then they will demand money. For women there is an extra hurdle to contest with, women will come up to you and start talking to you, they will then take your hand and try to put henna on you, it doesn't matter if you politely decline, they will continue and then guess what... Demand money. My favourite part of my visits to the souks was the orange juice 4d for a glass of fresh squeezed oj - money well spent!

What an experience!. Loads of hustle and bustle, numerous horse and carriages, many stalls, and people everywhere, of course they try to sell you things, that's what they are there for, but luckily we haven't had any negative experiences.It's great to just wander and take in the sights and sounds, or to sit in a cafe and enjoy a coffee and watch the world go by.

Souks in Marrakesh. There are so many souks you can go to in Marrakesh. I just kept walking through many different souks and got lost in the city...this was a great experience. If you want to buy souvenirs for family and friends definitely go and look around the souks and see what you fancy!

culture shock. I have been to many souqs /markets but this one cannot say was my favourite. A definite step back in time, much more basic than say Istanbul or Cairo which I prefer. Would not travel here again without my husband.

Quite an experience.. These North African markets/souks are very entertaining and this one is very big and quite a labyrinth to negotiate. Unlike Egypt the traders are pleasant and not to pushy and of course the asking price is not the final price so you need to haggle well.
No hassle shopping. Easy'ish to navigate the second time round. No one bothered us and easy to haggle. Great bargains to be had.
Souk. Tourists, here we are!. The Jemaa el Fna souk is very much focoused on tourists. I would very much recommend the other one close to Bab Dukhana.

A maze of shops!. Wear comfortable shoes and be prepared to haggle! There is nothing they don´t sell here! Be polite to the vendors and you can make finds! Spices,lanterns,baskets,clothes,materials-just to walk around and look is nice! Have a fresh orange juice and keep on looking!
great place if you like Moroccon stuff!. I loved to walk around. You need to be able to negotiate prices. If you can you can get some great bargains!

An absolute assault of the senses! . I can't decide how I feel about this place. Half of me wishes I'd bought a long dress and headscarf for myself an teenage daughter - but on the whole people were friendly. They will all try and get you to buy things but a lot are very funny and accept ' maybe next time'!!Some are very unfriendly and rude but on the whole they are the minority.They expect money if you take a photo but I am very glad to have been there and experienced it!!

Shopping, anyone?. Whatever Moroccan souvenir, trinket or knickknack you're looking for, you'll find it here -if you're prepared for a long search in meandering alleys among zillions of other tourists and for the constant hustle of shopkeepers. Thanks but no thanks!
interesting. interesting place for visiting and sometimes buying ! try to keep the price low because the seller give you upper price ! and after that they will tell you " WHATS YOUR PRICE " ;)
A must visit. Go with a guide or take a compass very easy to get lost as it is huge, and above all haggle. Be careful when taking photos as most people will want money for photos

Stressful haggling. After seeing Souk Waqif in Doha, this place was simply poor. You can not even browse any shop without the shopkeeper breathing down your neck. We ended up buying nothing as we were not comfortable with aggressive selling techniques and do not have the mental energy on holidays to haggle. There is hardly any special thing which you can not buy from elsewhere. The whole attitude was terrible.

Food tour through souks. Favorite foods we would not have tried without learning from our guide what was tourist friendly and what was better left to locals: lamb tangia, roasted goat cheek and tongue, msemen plain and spicy fried square pancake, sardine sandwich, avocado shake, orange juice and dried fruit from vendors on Jemma al Fnaa square. We missed out on couscous from restaurant Naim and roasted lamb 1/2 kilo portions from vendor at lunch and pastilla from restaurant.

Interesting! but buyer beware. I have never been in a Souk quite so cramped as that in Jemaa el Fna. Yes it is very interesting and the quality of the goods for sale well made, but the prices these traders try to charge you is way over the top even for North Africa. Before you think of entering the Souk I would suggest you go only a few 100mts north up Avenue Mohamed V and on the right hand side you will find the Government Artisan Complex, where you will find all the same goods for sale and being manufactured by the Artisan's where you can watch and talk to them and everything is a a set price so no haggling and you know the price being asked is giving them a reasonable profit. If you then want to enter the Souk you have a good idea of what things are worth when striking a deal..

Heaven for house decors. Moroccans are great artisans. Lots of beautiful find for the house. But beware lots of citizens (old and young) trying to cheat money off of tourists. Learn the art of bargaining!

If you love to negotiate go here. I loved shopping here. As i love to hagle and you be suprised what you can buy, if you know whqt to do. Always offer them 25% of the products value and stick to your gun. Eventually they will say ok. Otherwise walk away and they will agree, as there are over 10,000 shops in square.

coolest place ever!. craftswork, leather slippers, tea and spices, musical instruments, colourful pottery - your eyes just fall OUT! nothing to eat when you're insinde the souks though, so be prepared!

Get lost and enjoy it. Wander, marvel and generally take in everything. The sellers are never aggressive and actually mean it when they say it's ok if you don't end up buying. Go in at least one herboriste drink some tea, get a tour of the Moroccan spices and be thoroughly entertained. You will end up spending more than you thought and will never "win" at the haggling but it is fun.

Exciting and mad!!. Visiting the Souks is a must when visiting Marrakesh - it is Marrakesh!! Dodging the scooters, the donkey and carts, the trollies, the bicycles and still trying to buy your "bargains"!! The smells, the noise, music, colours, variety of goods, the busyness of the lanes - so exciting!! And then you need to make sure you don't get lost through the winding alleyways!! Whatever you're trying to buy don't settle for the offered price. The bargaining for possible purchases can be enjoyable and the rule of thumb I used was firstly don't settle for that offered price. Negotiate what you think would be a good buy for you and when you and the seller are happy and have agreed the price then you have a bargain!! I was particularly impressed with the Spice area where there are two good eateries to escape from the madness and people watch - Café Des Espice and the Nomad.

A must do.. The souk is massive and best done with a guide. I booked my excursion through the Thomson rep at my hotel. The Guide knew every nook and cranny of the souk. To wander around on my own would have taken forever and would have been very intimidating as it would have been so easy to get lost because of all the winding streets. So many shops and local businesses to see and plenty of items to purchase. Well worth the visit.
Shopping. Just about everything, right from clothes, to rugs, to bags to shoes and household etc etc. You have to bargain as price quoted is normally double.

Flintstones . If you get the reference, it feels like the same shops over and over again. Very easy to get lost but that's half the charm of it. We bought some beautiful scarves for our desert tour and had tea with a shop owner which was lovely. Keep limited cash in view in your wallet to aid in haggling which is lots of fun. Usually settled on half the initial price they offered. Prepare yourself for poverty. Can be overwhelming at times.

Confusing. It is so confusing and you can easily get lost. The food places inside where horribe and flys everywhere i thought i was going to be sick. Theres motorbikes trying to pass through and it is so tight. As soon as you are outside the maze it is much much better and cleaner. You get fresh fruits and juices and much more to see. Im not a shopper so maybe it wasnt an experience i enjoyed and wouldnt ever go souk again. If i did i would stay on the outside. There wasnt much that caught my eye to be honest. Just wanted to go home an hour later.

Essential shopping in Marrakech. I wish I had wanted to buy more things in the souks! There are a lot of nice leather bags, lamps, ceramics, etc that you can buy. However, we were there during the beginning of a 2 week trip so did not want to buy any big items to carry around. The souks are vast and organized by types of good they sell. It's an experience just to wander the souks and let yourself get lost. It's also pretty shady in the souks and a good place to cool off during the day. Warning: You cannot really window shop or browse in the souks if you are not interested in buying something. Any indication of interest means a vendor will be coming to you asking for you to take a look through the shop, begin negotiating prices, etc. It's a little bothersome, but you just have to say no a lot!

Marrakech market . Lots of nice things to buy, very easy to also get lost in the market because everywhere looked the same. Foreigners need to know how to price items at least 45% off the price said. Friendly people... They have different restaurants around the market..
Madness. This place is crazy day or night, you have to strong and firm with the locals, but still so full of culture and great things

A Must Do. The Souks offer almost any product you want in an environment that will charge all of your senses! Absorb the level of artistry. Haggling is expected, and adds to the experience. Language may be a barrier. The shop keepers can be pushy so don't be afraid to issue a firm "no" as you walk away. You will get lost but do not worry as you are bound to end up on a main thoroughfare. Shop keepers are a good source for directions (for a small tip) but beware of those volunteering to help (especially children). This is an experience you should not miss.

Smell some local culture. Whenever you are in such a country, the Souk and local markets are sort of "must see"! We spent more than half-a-day with strolling around and discovering this marvelous Souk in Marrakech. For anyone who likes spices and local handicraft, you will find a huge variety of offers in the different parts of the market. It's a great atmosphere, surprisingly clean and traders are friendly and not too intrusive. Don't miss this opportunity.

Must see!. You can't go to Morroco and not go to the souk! It's loud, noisy, vibrant, colourful and will attack all of your senses. We went in the day with a guide (highly recommended for first timers) and were shown round and managed to get our bearings so we were comfortable going back at night. It's a completely different feel at night as street vendors give way for street entertainment. We also did a horse & carriage ride as its a perfect way to see more of the city. You will be approached but a firm no is enough to make the vast majority of sellers to leave you alone! You are in morroco and that's the way it is. Get stuck in and enjoy the experience! It's a one off!

Fun shopping. All the shopping you could want in this winding market area. Sections for leather, textiles, metal....low end to very high in all mixed in together. We did hire a guide to help us find the specific things and quality of things were were looking for and he was a big help. But if you are just looking for casual, fun, shopping...just go by yourself and wander around and enjoy. The merchants start height so counter low, maybe 40% of their first price. Then shoot to end up around around 50-60% of their starting price, if you like the game...stick to your price. If not, oh well. Fun either way. Note that were were here in March, weather and Cronus was perfect. It would not be nearly as fun in the heat of summer or the crowds of high season.

Movie style market. The markets of marrakech are simply beautiful, Marrakech is such an exotic destination for American's like myself, and I really consider myself lucky to be able to visit such a beautiful country. I will be back very soon, with my family this time.
Gird up your loins for hassle . If your partner enjoys shopping you will probably have to go to the souks. We had a few laughs but otherwise quite painful..

LOVED IT!. This is such a magical place! it is completely different from what we are used to in the Western world. The first time you go in it is a bit of a culture shock but once you get over that, try to relax and just enjoy it! Salesmen will try to talk to you and get you in the shops but just smile and say no merci and carry on if you are not interested. As you go deeper in the souks it gets better and better - the smells, the colours, the noise. If you speak arabic or french then thats great as some shopkeepers dont speak english or if they do communication is limited. Most shops sell similar things, but we had a good idea of what we wanted and managed to buy everything before we left. Haggle haggle haggle!! We didnt know if we would be able to do it as it is so different from what we are used to but once you know how much you are prepared to pay for an item then you wont be ripped off. Once we decided to just go in a shop and try and make our first purchase, and we got a good deal we were unstoppable then:) We got some great deals on everything we bought! And we really enjoyed the experience, I think my boyfriend got addicted to haggling and debating with the shopkeepers about prices - even though I was doing most of the talking. You will get lost by the way, no map can rescue you but this is the magic. We got some great souvenirs and every single thing we got has its own little story which makes it very special.
Friends and family . Very dirty and busy watch young children walking about watching you, acting suspicious after your purse or bag can't haggle a lot very stubborn.

Pick all your souvenirs here. The souks are buzzing with so many people. There are many shops and winding roads and alleys just loose yourself and don't worry about getting lost. You will always spot a taxi parked up somewhere to hail down. This is a great place to visit even if you don't need to do shopping. I got all my presents here at really good prices, u just need to haggle. Never take the first price they give you and also always get individual prices for your items you pick. These market traders say you pick the things you want and after we give you a good price but this is just a way to raise the price. Get all the prices individually and then calculate the price into your own currency and see if it's worth the price or not. I saw a shawl in the souks which the man selling it tried to sell to me for 600 dhirams. I saw the same scarf afew shops away at only 100 dhirams! When I told him this he tried to tell me it's made from real silk and the one I saw that was cheaper is cheap quality from China. Funny how when I tried to leave the price fell dramatically from 600 to 150 dhirams!! Also try to reach prices before you sit in any cabs. Once your sitting inside they will feel they have the upper hand and will triple the prices!

Tough work but unique. You have to haggle for everything and the constant attention gets tiring. You need to be in the mood. It's very unique and very Moroccan however. Be firm and stick to your price.

A step back in time. To wander either with a guide or by ones self is an experience in itself. the smells are a delight and intrusion on ones senses, the colour's that surround you are amazing making it a photo opportunity at each turn and alleyway you wander down, through and out of. Its a step back in time ful of hustle and bustle like no other experience. Enjoy the experience

Colourful, worth a trip but you will be hassled. You cant visit Marrakesh without the standard tourist visit to the Souk. Its colourful, interesting and has everything you need when it comes to tourist nick nack's.However, be very aware that you will be hassled by the worlds best salesman. Everything is either "best price" or "special price" What they actually mean is you will pay the most expensive price. Stand your ground and barter hard, they will give in at some point but not by much. Good luck

Definitely worth a visit. I have just returned from my first visit to Marrakech and absolutely loved my visit to the souks. These were very fascinating to see and there wasn't as much hassle as I expected, definitely had experienced much worse in Egypt, Tunisia and India. We inevitably got lost but did find our way out relatively easily. We bought a couple of things, I don't think we were particularly good at haggling but we didn't mind the prices we paid so it didn't really matter. Highly recommend a visit.

Busy but fun. Felt very safe here. Be aware of your surroundings & try to get lost. People do not bug you here To buy anything but if you are out in the square they are a bit more aggressive. I enjoyed the areas out of the sun that were covered and remained cool as it was a warm day
All women family birthday trip. This definitely described the exotic nature of Marrakesh. We went in and out of stalls and winding streets to shop and bargain endlessly.

With the right attitude you will love it!. Be prepared to see anything and everything for sale. Of course the vendors will seize on any opportunity if you show interest, but we also found them to be fun and friendly if you use a bit of humour. Once you start wandering around you soon realise that you see the same items for sale, so be content with following a course around a few alleyways and you should be happy with the items for sale. Certainly a great experience!

Amazing. Loved the souks! Although very easy to get lost in! People will offer you directions and give you bad advice but there's signs everywhere. My advice would be to go as deep in as you can as that's where all the magic happens.

Walking back in time.. Huge souk area with lots of different alleys & passages. Bound to be lost in that area. Lots of old traditions remained selling traditional and locally made crafts, feeling you were back in time exploring for trade goods. Just be lost in it and you will find a way out of the souk eventually.

A feast to the senses. This is a maze of alleyways with vendors selling everything imaginable, mostly catering to other Moroccans: meat, fish, vegetables, fruit, dates, olives, spices, wedding dresses, pointy shoes, teapots; blacksmiths, tailors, wool dyers, on and on. You will easily get lost in this extensive market without a guide.

Very nice . I liked it very much, loads of colors and different impressions! You can get lost easily. Just download an offline map; also handy when you are going somewhere by taxi (to check if he is fooling you).Advice:- be careful with taking pictures some people ask money for that- they ask thrice as much as they ask locals!! (A local told me to divide the price by at leaaast 3). Always negotiate. Make sure you negotiate long enough then just say no thank you and leave; they often are willing to give you a way lower price. We once had a man who asked 300 dirhams and while we were leaving he lowered it to 80 dirhams, ridicilous!- do not immediately show that you like something just be a little nonchalant

Arabic market. It is possible to buy almost any souvenir in the souk. Buyer beware of fakes and quality of goods. Haggle over any price quoted. If you walk away it is amazing how the price comes down. (usually less than half the first asking price.

Stressful. . What a wonderfull place to visit full of culture and sights..great leather goods and spices ...lots to see....bad part..over aggressive market stall holders..grabbing ya arm or jacket etc...would have loved to look at more stalls but soon as you make eye contact they are on you like a hawk ..enjoyed the visit and would possibly go back ..better prepare for the onslaught
Marrakesh Souk. All souks very interesting but a lot of walking , be prepared for crowds. leather bags & jackets & wraps & all sorts of goodies.

Crazy but exciting. A fantastic experience, be aware of the guides and as long as you are robust with them you should be fine, don't make eye contact lol. Great place to get lost and if you look hard some bargains to be had

A whole new world. This is a must do if here in Morocco, the smells the sights the thousands of shops to browse brushing up on your bargaining skills is also a must! Lots of opportunities to see some real culture grab a nice tagine bowl ah there's spices of every variety nice horse and carrage ride was a great day and would defo go again although not a place for the shy so man up and you will be fine don't shake hands be polite and say no thank you prepare to be asked questions Enjoy

Artificial compared to Fès . Fun and interesting to see, lots of shills trying to sell or steer towards their stalls, almost all sell the same souvenirs, once you go to Fès and see the real deal it's just more of the same

this is a must do, see and particapate activity in Morocco. You must visit and see the Souks of Marrakech if staying in Morocco. MUST...we spent 4 days and night at Ryad in the Media and visited different Souks each day. They all have a unique flavor, tempo and offer different items. Some have more jewelry, others have leather and lamps. You simply have to explore..

One for the bucketlist if you like citys. If you like citys you defenitly have to see this historic streets and the little shops. For sure don't forget to eat on the great plaza and drink some more mint tea.But take care of your pockets in the crowded streets -not to "loose" some of your property ;)In the other hand it is a good place to buy clothes in good quality for a small amount of money

Crazy, fun, like another world.. There are so many words to describe the Souk but the best one would be fascinating. The sights and smells take you to another world. Everything is so colourful and everybody so busy. Be prepared to be shouted at and chased (but not in a scary way) for your custom. You need to expect it to be hectic and it will all be fine :)

Maze of streets where one can buy anything on earth. We got the attention of what turned out to be a man touting for trade and was taken through a maze of narrow ally ways to what could only be described as an "Aladdin's cave" full of antiques clothing anything one could think of. We managed not to buy any of the items and the experience was quite pleasant. One is expected to haggle so the initial prices quoted are quite high but the traders are happy to haggle.

Marrakech Souk -traditional and hand crafted collection. Marrakech Souk - sale all sort of traditional and hand crafted collection. It is enjoyable and every visitor should visit this beautiful place.

Oh what a wonderful way of passing many fascinating hours!. Don't even try and have a plan of where you want to go, as inevitably you are likely to get lost in this labyrinth.. The paths wind round and branch off everywhere, and it's great fun to stand at a crossroads trying to decide which way to go next. Just let your feet take you where they will, you will come across some fascinating things, and some gruesome ones. Some of the stallholders can be a bit pushy but just keep walking if you don't want to look. Most of them will respect it if you say you just want to look without talking, but don't say it rudely, they are trying to make a living in their own cultural way. Some lovely things to be had if you are not afraid to do some bargaining.

A colourful nightmare. an interesting experience, but a a horrifically stressful area of small alleys and narrow streets where the "fun" of getting lost all the time is marred by the extremely intrusive and sometimes aggressive young men who insist on showing the way to places you do not want to visit and then demanding exorbitant tips Tyr the technique of of looking surprised if approached and then say " Mais j'habite ici" ( I live here). It works wonders!

One of the oldest souks .... There are 18 different souks that combine to on eof the largest souks in Northern Africa. Don't be afraid to negotiate as this is a local habit and the sellers expect this as a sign of your engagement. If you speak French or are French this is an advantage as prices will be lower than for English or German speakers. Most sellers won't reject it if you call them "Mon ami" (my friend) and this may be a nice way to get into a serious negotiation. Between 50 and 60% of the original asking price is a good deal. You know you've reached the limit when the seller let's turns away.

Mad but fun. Being accosted by every single vendor is the norm here so you need a tough skin. It is possible to be polite as you continue your stroll though. A smile and a no thank you doesn't stop them trying to get your interest but it made me feel better about it at least. I found most people to be charming and of course they do have to work very hard to make a sale. I bought a bronze casting in the end but spent a couple of days making up my mind before tackling the shop. I decided what I would be prepared to spend and then used that as my haggling maximum. It didn't really help me save a lot but it did give me confidence to buy. I felt it important to only approach a seller when I actually wanted something.

My favorite place. Marrakesh is the Souk, you can spend hours looking, shopping talking to the shops owners, the spices and odors, the artisan work, the colors of everything is so nice and charming, the small cafes or restaurants, the Moroccan pastries full of honey, or grilles, I just love it
No words to describe it. It is amazing, but you need to have a thick-skin because everyone in there is "too-friendly" and you will get a lousy deal if you're not careful

Evening excursion. We went on a horse and carriage by night that ended at the souks bartering is a must. We didn't wander to deeply into the souks as we heard it was easy to get lost in amongst the stalls. Our holiday rep did have an excursion which included someone to go with you and haggle.

fascinating hive of activity. endless labyrinth of passages with everything from spices to solid block of perfume, fossils and geodes, beautiful metal lanterns and lamps, fairytale curved leather slippers, carpets, blankets and jewellery. Download City Map app not to get lost!

The resume of Marrakech. Contrast, excitement, lifestyle, colours, smells, feelings..... All of those are being apported to you in a walk through the souks. This is the place where you can find everything, I may add that you need to fight for every price, you should adapt yourself to that. The truth is that the merchants can became really annoying trying to charm you with their products but also you need to know that's their lifestyle so you can't blame them when their are trying to get an extra money from the tourists. This became a must-go in your plans!
Tourist trap, but nice and exiting. The souk in Marrakech is a tourist trap, but it's still nice to see this world of trade and bargain.

Down the Market. A fasinating place to visit. Best to visit the souks first with a guide before going solo. We found it to be an hassle free experience. You need to keep your wits about you and be prepared to haggle for anything you want to buy. Its easy to get lost in the souks, so I would reccomend you keep to moving in straight lines and keep a track on the way you came in. Its a great place for spices and leather, so you can pick up some bargains. The only down side is, if you do get lost, someone will always offer to guide you back out. They will want paying though and could be costly. If you do get lost find someone who is English to help you get back out and hope they are not lost as well.

good for people watching. This is a place you will love or hate on one hand it's a square where you have to watch your wallet , try to ignore the animal cruelty and Dodge the pushy salespeople but on the other its a place that can bring a smile watching the musicians and dancers and storytellers and fill your stomach in the frenzied night food stalls

Post climbing stopover. The souk is one of the must see experiences of Marrakesh. Like all souks in the Arab world it has developed over many years and is a rambling expanse of shops crowded around alleyways; all of which are under cover. Getting to know your way in and out should be an early priority. I find that constant looking back over my shoulder and checking out obvious landmarks or significant objects enables me to navigate my way out of these places once I turn around to retrace my steps - obvious I know but it is surprising how many people get lost once they start to concentrate on shopping. The souk is good for the obvious leather, brass, jewellery and other tourist items but seek out the spice stalls for more local colour and smells.
Ok!! . Went here on a Thompson excision I would recommend going with a guide or on an excision as can be very overwhelming and very busy at times but great for shopping!!
Any visit to Marakech makes this a MUST.. It is my favourite part of Morocco! You just have to get in there and buy food and embrace the busy market vibe.

Too pushy . Marrakech Souk is a huge area of small shops. You can find all kind of things from the souk and all the prices are negotiable. I hate this place because of pushy merchants, you can't even take a short look when they stop you and try to sell you something that you don't need. I saw blonde European women to be in real trouble with local men and merchants. Some of the products are from Morocco, but a lot of them are, like all over the world, from China.
Just love the souks. So much to see. Was pleasantly surprised at not being hassled much at all...Worth finding the workshops and getting top see how things are made. So much nicer buying from them.
WOW. What a place to get the feeling of Marrakech, hustle bustle, smell and sounds. This is shopping with a difference plenty of bartering and mint tea. If you wnt it you will find it in the Souk's.

You will get lost in there. What a place. So much to see, so labyrinthine! But worth visiting, absolutely! It is the biggest souk I've ever visited and the most colourful. I didn't feel this souk as aggressive and intruding as some others.

just like the medina. just like the medina but you must be prepared to go to the tanneries as you will kkep getting hassled to go just a polite no should be sufficient. if you do end up going be prepared to tip guide

very rich offers... both visually and in local produce.A huge labyrinth of clothes, raw and cooked foods,the sheer size of the place offers a character all of it's own, compared to many other souks.Prices vary, so it is a must to compare and bargain.Stands offering local specialities give off strong rancid smells,Local moroccan pastries are absolutely enchanting although those bought from the souk revealed a dead bee or too...Alleys offering local footwear and metal handcrafted lamps are quite magical at night.As usual, one must have strong nerves and deaf ears on command to ignore repeated calls from vendors.. Here and there, local quick snack stands frequented by locals, offer delectable and very cheap snacks of freshly fried sardines, flatbreads wtih local salads of tomatoes and onions, washed down with local mint teas.Ambulant vendors of french "millesfeuilles - thousand layers" pastries etc. are worth trying out.On the fringe of the square of Jemaa el Fna, wonderful icecreams with moroccan-french flavours worth a try.

Busy as always. Lots of people but very exotic.
Good cafes and restaurants, a lot to by on the square, eat there at night if you can.

The best part of an amazing trip. We just spent 4 amazing days in 'Marrakech. Nothing prepares you for the Souks. We have been to the Bazaar in Istanbul and this one was much more fun. People are not pushy but fun. We went back 3 of the 4 days we were there. Be prepared to haggle and start way low around 10% of their first offer or you will way overpay. If you are seeking a specific item go FIRST to the fixed price store run by the government near the tombs and see the real price FIRST.

Great experience!. It was fun haggling for bargains and believing you got a good deal. However, Moroccans wanted money for everything, even for looking at a performance for 5seconds and they approach you with a hat to put money in! If you refuse, they start hurling abuse saying you're not welcome here! Go there with a thick skin and you'll be fine!

Marvellous Maze. This place is simply a maze of stalls/shops that sell literally everything. A lot of them sell the same thing but it's still nice to get lost and just follow the paths before you. If you even glance at a stall you'll be bombarded with "Hello, come here" so eye contact is everything here. Be prepared to negotiate whatever price they throw at you.

Best part of Marrakech. Just remember to never take the first offer. Example. Women Leather boots starting price was 700 dirhams we got them for 200 dirhams. The souks are huge and are a maze but you will find so many little gems in these souks. So worth the walk and the bargaining.

Experience it for what it is. I loved visiting the Souks. Initially we booked a half day tour of the hidden city which gave us an interesting brief history and helped us get our bearings. The Souk is a market place with hundreds of small stalls selling much the same things, the fun comes with the interaction with the sellers. Yes parts of it does smell and yes you will get hassle from the sellers, but that is part of the experience. Make sure you have some patience and good humour along with cash in your purse and the experience will be enjoyable.

Try to relax. Busy, smelly, easy to get lost (not just saying this, it is VERY easy to get lost), panhandlers...However, do not let this deter you. It is an experience that you will never forget. Jemma el-Fnna is the main open air square in Marrakech where you will see a range of acts from snake charmers to people blowing fire. It is like something out of an Indiana Jones movie. I went with my brothers and our itinerary went something like this. We started out in Gibraltar (Spain) took the ferry to Tangiers, overnight train to Marrakech, out to the Sahara with Top Desert Tours, back to Marrakech, and then to Casablanca for a flight out. We did this trip in september 2014....not 15 as written below (did not give me an option)

A very interesting place. We visited the Souks with our guide as you can easily get lost (or unfortunately) deceived by the locals.There are so many things to buy but please make sure to lower the prices as much as you can prior a purchase. Do not feel bad about it, they still make a great profit out of it.If you are a female, please make sure to have your shoulders covered, it is highly unlikely that something bad might happen but the more flesh you have exposed the more uncomfortable you will feel due to the comments you'll get from the locals. For me it was really interesting getting to talk to the locals and buying all the lovely souvenirs I got. Definitely getting back soon!

annoying. it is pretty much impossible to not get lost a million times. in the evening when the stalls close everything looks so different and it can seem a bit scary in some corners when it is dark (overall we felt that it is safe though!). some people are very helpful but the majority are trying to rip you off and deliberately send you in wrong directions. you are being yelled at pretty much all the time ("this is not the direction to the square!!!") even when you don't ask anyone and are just walking arround minding your own business. We didn't like being pushed all the time, and it is a miracle people aren't being run over by the scooters more often. the air is very dirty, you just want to hop into the shower after being in the souk. the quality of the products is often poor. we'd recommend to go to the "Ensemble Artisanal Marrakech" instead.it is an experience and we get the fascination, but we didn't really enjoy Marrakech due to the souk. When we come back, we'll only use Marrakech as a transit to go to the Atlas mountains again. To us that's the beauty of Morocco

Have fun. Like it or not the Moroccans love to trade it's in their blood. Visit the souks get lost and buy some presents. Barter is the name of the game, nothing is priced get a price from the seller and make an offer we usually started at a third of was being asked. If you can't agree smile and walk away. There is always another day or stall. Great fun and bargains to be had.

Wonderful, vibrant and fun!. I've been to other souks in Dubai and Tunisia but this was my favorite by far! It was not as intense as I had expected. We usually went in the morning while not too crowded and just "got lost" walking around enjoying the smells, colors and stuff for sale. Every now and then I stopped, haggled and bought small pretty things. Remember to always smile, be friendly and enjoy this part of the buying process! Have some fun with it! I especially loved a shop called Michi with is a bit different and you do not haggle in the same way there, but there things they hade for sale were fantastic.
Shopping without fear. Spent ages looking around, great old buildings, lovely people and lots to look at, can be cheap trip if you want it to be
An experience. Myself and my partner found the Souks very intimidating but it was an experience. I have never been anywhere like Marrakesh before but I am glad I have, it's a real eye opener

how to get lost in one easy lesson :-). This souk is the size of a football field. Narrow and turning alleys will get you lost in no time, a guide is a must. Hundreds of stands and stores with everything you would expect to find in a souk.
One of a kind. Possibly one of the largest and best of its kind. Great to wonder around. Better in early mornings before it gets to crowded .
Too many of the same thing!. Got bored within 5 minutes looking. They sell the same thing stall after stall. Anyway we are not interested in buying anything there.

Best and worst of morrocco. A maze of stalls selling and making everything you coukd inagine. Some pleasant sellers but some who hassle you to death. Bewsre of friendly directions or prople saying"square is this way" polite no suffices most times

Fabulous Souks - shame about the touts. Take a good map and bargain hard. A few pieces of advice: Only look at things you really want to buy. When you do see something you want, bargain hard (offer around 1/3 of what they originally ask and agree on half. Walk away - they will chase you). ONLY ask women for directions. If a man starts following you claiming to be a guide, suddenly " lose interest" in where you are going and lose them. Then find your own way, otherwise you will be pressured for money. Try to find the craft areas (leather work, wool dying area, metal work). Use your google map phone if possible to find your own way back to your riad or hotel. Recover with a lovely cheap meal on the evening food stands in the square!
Best. It's a great place all should do this but beware once in there it's hard to find a way out so just some shopkeeper for way out

If you like the crowd and aggressive sales tech., it may be perfect for you!. I would of loved to have tried more things to eat and shop my heart out.. but this was not that place for me.With much excitement, we stayed conveniently in the city. But soon my excitement turned into annoyance for we couldn't walk 20 ft. without someone trying to sell us something or divert us to different shops they likely get commission from. Would of loved the opportunity to look more closely and taste the variety, however was so turned off by the ever so aggressive Moroccan sales style, we ended up briskly walking past any shops and attractions the Souk had to offer.If you can handle the crowd, the aggressive sales people EVERYWHERE, and willing to fork over more than its' worth (after negotiating heavily), you'll probably like this.However, I found that further out of the city, people are nicer, much less aggressive, and prices are far better for my pocket.

Mekka of the big hustle. frenetic place definitely worth to visit but you must be ready, I mean like really!
Best time 9-11am and 16-21pm. Dont stay in hidden streets of medina and souk after 11pm if your not experienced traveler or woman....

Colourful, but products the same from stall to stall, except for exclusive items.. Wandering through the souks it s best to look and not ask as the friendly hard sell will come on. Always start at 1/3 of the asking price and you will end up at a deal. If you look lost there are always people who will guide you for an exorbitant price.There are many beggars, give to the old and those with clothing in tatters.

Shopping. It's a great place all should do this but beware once in there it's hard to find a way out so just ask a young boy and he will take you where you want to go (for a fee ofcourse) but don't be alarmed it's all normal for this city. What we did was to look for an official guide of the city. They all have badges with there names and a photo of themselves the one we got was Muhammad and what a great guy he was. He took us wherever we wanted to go and at the end of the day it cost us 300 dirhams we took his phone number and called him 2 days later to have another day with him as are guide. So don't be scared get in there and enjoy you get a lot less hassle with these people. We have made friends and next time there we will look him upAndy and Joanne on a father/daughter holiday
Shopping mad!. If you like shopping, you can spend days in the souks but be prepared for bartering, prices start high and sellers have patience to take a long time to get you to buy something!

Souks. Had a great time in the Souks of Marrakech. Better be good at bartering and be sure to leave enough to keep the shop keepers happy. You can get an idea of what the prices should be by visting the nearby visitor complex. you can likely get your purchase for 1/2 the price of what is asked

Very busy and must be experienced. Marrakech square and the souks are full of a Haggling and wonderful goods to buy. I am going to point out the obvious but never ever pay what they ask, as a guide to what we paid for things.....Ralph Lauren swimming shorts 120dhm, 2 x Pashminas 150dhm, small Gucci Handbag 250dhm, Ralph Lauren Hoodie 200dhm, Hugo Boss belt 50dhm well done if you do better, I love a haggle!The evening brings the squares markets to life so well worth an evening visit.The people here are not rich by any means but are courteous and the place is very safe, do something nice and buy a bigger a sandwich, coffee or as I did a KFC, it makes you feel good about yourself and you are doing something to help.

Single traveller. Such great fun withall the banter and totally safe for a solo traveller, really enjoyed my stay and wouldn't hesitate to go back. People are very nice. I went for Christmas it was fab.
Beauteful. it was beautiful... but the price were to high. so it was very plaisant with a beautiful weather. to be done again

Beautiful small streets. Real arabic! Like the Aladdin movie. Very nice! All the streets got very good lights so its in evening not dark. You have to bargain but some shops got written prices, saves the hassle, and thats what it is. Beware of people who wants you to show the leather factories. They are very intimidated and can give a unsafe feeling. Take a guide from the hotel if u want to see things. Ask only tourist the way not the people, u wont get ride of them and after 50 meters another one is waiting. Its what they do whole day, chasing tourist.They look helpful but they want to have money for just pointing a corner. Sorry ,i dont like to write this either but its the truth. But even for that its worth it.

An experience . The souks are really a Moroccan experience that you can't and shouldn't avoid. While there are deals to be had you'd better be damn good at haggling if you want to come out on top. There are a lot of stalls selling the same faux antique tat at crazy mark ups, but the are also lots of good quality hand made items , especially leather. Shop around, get used to saying no,and enjoy.

Charming Souk :)). Souk here is charming . Lots of stuffs you can see and buy :) but dont forget ! Need to bargain 3 times . And drop the price such as 250 to 150 or 120 :))) carpets here , ceramics is famous , also leather stuffs too .

Crazy but fun. . Can get some good bargains if you haggle well and lovely to see the culture of this crazy, beautiful market. Unfortunately you will have to ignore most of the people trying to talk to you because as soon as you say hello they will pull you into the shops. Great walk around and if you get lost, don't worry! We found ourselves in the factory side and it was so interesting to see them all making the shoes, bags and metal work. Will be going back! Oh and if someone tries to show you the way or says one of the alleys is closed, ignore them. They will send you elsewhere to gain commission to a shop they want you to go to!
Use price tagged shops if not haggle price down to 25%. Vibrant markets to find all sorts of interesting jewellery and other local arts. Need to familiarize yourself first before any purchase.

. Went here on a trip with Thomson who had organised the trip, found it good but scary, they come up close in face and tend to pester you awful lot. Can recommend if haven't been before but wouldn't go again

Watch out !. The souk is really a great place and it's fun to haggle with the vendors, we even had Moroccan tea with on. Just one tip: if you buy saffron be careful and look closely as vendors use cut glass to add weight to it, this obviously rips you off and also could be a bit dangerous when cooking.

Brilliant as always. Little has changed in the souk since I last visited over ten years ago. Make sure you give yourself plenty of time to wander and get lost, not the place to enter if you have a specific shopping list and a tight timeframe!

What a place!. Words cannot describe how fabulous this place really is, the locals are lovely and unlike other places eg Egypt they don't get offended when you say 'No sorry' they just wish you a good trip and thank you for looking.There are some lovely little places to eat and it is reasonably cheap as well.

Open all your senses. If you can deal with people touching you and wanting you to buy something from them - even if you are note interested - a visit to the Souk in Marrakech is an amazing experiences to all of your senses. Granted - there is some plastic and bamboo directly important from China - and there is also a lot of interesting smells, colors, cloth and ceramics that look amazing. Only so much one can take home!
Souk or market. The name does not cover the sights or smells that you will encounter in thd narrow winding streets take a guide or on your own an amazing experience
Amazing. This is a must - you have to haggle its all in the game !!! The people are friendly and have a brilliant sense of humour so go with the flow and and enjoy!!!!

Never ending. You might as well surrender to the Souk, because a visit to Marrakech wouldn't be anything without a visit to the Souk. The narrow ailes with its maze of primitive stores is endless and you will get lost - but there is always a kind soul, who will direct you the 'the big square' from where you can easily navigate the city.You will be 'attacked' by the army of eager salesmen, promoting their goods at special price just for you - but either stay away or lean back and enjoy it, play the game and hackle over the price of the many beautiful items, you suddntly can't see how you have lived without so far. And if you get the price down to half of the starting point, you might even have made an OK deal ;)

Time travel at it's best!. When you visit Jemaa el Fna you are immersing yourself in a thousand year old activity. The noise is deafening, the sights blinding, the atmosphere overwhelming.In short.It's great!As long as you're in a good mood and can smile you will be ok. Everyone is out to earn a buck and it is the duty of the tourist to keep the economy vibrant, so don't be getting annoyed at the constant attention. They are doing a job, and you are there to enjoy it.The orange juice at the OJ stalls is delicious. And a bargain.Everything is on sale at Jemaa el Fna.. If you don't want to buy anything.. Don't. Simply say "No thank you" "Merci mais non" or "La Shukran" and they will probably leave you alone. If you get taken to Abdullah's brother in law's carpet shop and you don't want to buy a carpet you would be wise not to accept the tea as that is the opening round of the hard sell. I have to say though that, personally, I do like the odd carpet shop visit as it is a very interesting experience. (and no, I've never bought a carpet) If there is something you really want.. Start low. at about one third of what you would like to pay.. And, most importantly, enjoy the experience.Caleches. Horse drawn carriages which will give you a tour of the city. Years ago when there wasn't so much traffic, a Caleche ride was quite enjoyable. But what I saw on my visit last week is that the Caleche is overwhelmed by traffic. Can't say that I'd like to have a go now.. But don't let that put you off. It may still be really good and you will be contributing to the economy and helping to support a centuries old tradition.Dining. There are plenty of good cafes all around Jemaa el Fna, and when the food vendors set up in the evening you will be spoilt for choice.Top tip. You will be seriously harassed by restaurant/food stall touts. To stop them in their tracks simply say "Sorry, I've already eaten".I had a selection of cow bits at one of the food stalls one evening. Absolutely delicious! Be brave :-)

Souks Galore.. So many souks all leading into one another in the heart of the old Madina. You can bargain with them. I recommend you knock of two thirds of the price to start. I find The souks are easier in Marakech than they are in Cairo.

A maze of shops and persuasive sellers!. Fantastic for leather goods which are top quality and at ridiculously low prices. Bought a fab man bag in camel leather with pockets and zipped compartments for just £18. It was worth well over one hundred pounds of anyone's money. The maze of alleyways and terraces with rooftop cafes is a must to visit. Everthing from food, spices, leather goods, shirts, clothes of all descriptions, means you can easily spend a few hours here with fun. Watch out though for the extremely persuasive shopkeepers and what ever price they demand, start by offering them a quarter of that price and always be prepared to walk away, they'll tap you on the shoulder and sell it anyway to you!

Colour and life. colourful and busy. Not too much hassle from vendors. Have a guide if possible. They will explain about the ancient Riads, how people live. Explain the pigments used in dying leather and wool and take you to see how local tradesman work.

The "Souk" Or Arabic for Market is a must see!. I loved shopping at the Souk. The Souk has home decor, herbs and medicines, beauty products, bur bur rugs and even live entertainment like henna tattoos and snake charmers. Be prepared to barter!

A place where you have to hold your own. Amazing food ,spices, local friendliness but they know how to empty your wallet with a smile.The local crafts are just fantastic,with all the elements metal,wood,tin,silver textiles,ect,ect treated with skill and technique.I f your not prepared to bargain,stay away.in The Square are story tellers, snake charmers, monkeys,water carriers and Orange juice sellers,horse and carriage rides.If anyone leads you into the Souks don't follow unless you want to pay,Inshalla was the most common word used,the call from the Mosques all adding to an memorable experience.

Fun, be ready for some hard negotiation. A huge array of shops with merchandise at every level of the quality and price spectrum. You need to hunt and barter. Be prepared to walk away and never pay more than half price - often a third id acceptable. The deeper you go into the souk the better the quality and the price !

Expect to be hassled . It's important to read up a little so you understand the parts of the Souk, start well away from Jemaa el Fna, the commercial/tourist trap! If you do you will experience the real souk with merchants and trades going about there day to day business. There are many places to eat and you can enjoy the bartering for whatever takes your eye. As you near Jemaa el Fna through the souk the traders have more tat and start to hassle and hustle more.

madness but bargains to be had. not as authentic as the inner souk, but easier to navigate, it stays open quite late as well, at least 7pm so is good if you have been out touring. some of the goodsame are good quality and can be got at a good price

Get lost, literally!. One of the rights of passage in Marrakesh is getting lost in a souk. And the souk around Jemaa El Fna is the best one to get lost in...and you will get lost. Don't panick, you can always find a taxi at the end of a walk way to take you back home, or find a helpful stranger to walk you out the right way (although a tip will be expected for this service). The rule in the souk, I learned, was what ever price they start with, you divide by two and start there as your bargaining point. Have fun, smile and don't offer a price that you aren't willing to pay (it's bad manners and frowned upon by all merchants)! Other than that, you'll come away with a once in a lifetime experience and some good swag to bring home!

A Very Busy Place.. When visiting Marrakech you cannot avoid a visit to the Soul. The square is a meeting place, busy market and rendezvous for eating at anytime. Part of the charm is talking to the stall holders and bartering over a purchase price. The restaurants around the square have an upper level from which you can see and hear the bustle below you. It is also a great place for people watching.

Moroccan Madness. Your eyeballs will be bouncing over the hustling and bustling of swarms of busy traders anxious to relieve you of a dirham or two! Many hawkers vieing for your attention. The stalls are great and packed with artefacts, souvenirs and keepsakes. Some of the stalls are selling the tackiest of things. Please be wary of buying freshly squeezed orange juice as it may run right through you within half an hour or so! The cleanliness of the Souks is negligible and if you are squeamish of watching an old man squat down and drop a load in front of you then a Souk is not a place for you. Admittedly, I was so astonished to see this I almost took a snap with my phone. The meat and fish on sale are swarming with flies and the sweet pastries and cakes are swarming with bees. A really stark clash of cultures that might be a little tricky to adjust to for some travellers. It can be exhausting trying to constantly fight off the traders trying to sell you something. If approached by any beggars, put up your hands and most emphatically refuse...this is the only message that will dissuade then from hassling you. Great to see the vibrant colours and hear the many sounds of Morocco. The snake charmers, monkey trainers and horsemen are to be avoided as they treat these animals deplorably. The leather goods are lovely but be mindful to find out what beast the leather has come from, the leather briefcase I bought was camel leather and it's muskiness was overbearing. The Souks are not the best place to be around at night. This is a place for intrepid travellers with steely stomachs and no sense of smell.

worth of a short visit. Very Hot , polluted, noisy and crowdieThe places and monuments are interesting its the peoplecontinuing make nuisance of them selfs and pestering you to buy thingsRestaurants and bars over priced

I had a great time looking at all the arts and crafts . The souls are great. I don't like the feeling when a guide brings me to a merchant where he is commissioned.with Ibrahim it is all freedom and creativity

What a place!. Just arrived back from Marrakech and spent some time in the souk just past-the main square wow!! what a place , a maze of shops and hotels(riads) resteraunts and cafe's I think we even saw a crèche ! A fully sustainable town within a town a place where you can buy anything and everything, hundreds of people carrying parcels pulling carts riding bikes, no real hassle ,however they have a living to make and the quality of there wares was amazing, just one watch out..it's a huge place and you can get easily lost, certain locals will want to guide you for a price others misguide you ,so be careful buy a map and look up ,the square is sign posted regularly above your head, don't panic and you will enjoy the experience soak up the sounds and the smells of real Marrakech ...

Shopping. Shop till you drop... the minute you make eye contact or show interest in their wares, they will have you in their shop. I found it easier to wear sunglasses so I could look without them noticing. Do not be afraid to barter, they seem to expect it of us. We had the philosophy of only paying what we thought the item was worth. Watch out for people wanting to show you around as they do expect payment for this and try not to get lost it is huge.

A Treasure in the Choas. What a glorious place to stay after the hassle and bustle of the markets. The rooms are spacious and elegant with air con to relieve the temperature. The decor is so tastefully done with a French touch from the delightful owners. We loved the cat who ruled the roost. Nothing was a problem and we were even given meds when we feel unwell. The breakfast is delicious make from all local produce. I highly recommend this soul.

You must go, get lost, shop and haggle!. By far -- of all the places that I have traveled to in my life, this is by far, the most exotic place to shop, eat, get lost in, and haggle. The shopping was wonderful, shop keepers were all delightful and kind., the sights and smells were breathtaking and I can't wait to go back with my family. This place should be on everyone's bucket list adventure.
Unique but never again . Didn't enjoy the experience, very dirty! I felt pressured to buy things and even with a guide I didn't feel it was good enough. Perhaps for more confident people.

Experience we had 😳. Well worth a visit a little unhappy with the keeping of there animals 🐒🐢🐫 around the place . But amazing experience the market looks all the same very easy to get lost but funny .

Not what I was expecting.. One of the main attractions of Marrakech but also one of my main disappointments. I was hoping to find it full of culture as well as goods for sale but it was just empty with a handful of people trying to haggle you to buy some rubbish and will not leave you alone...very disappointed

A must. No visit is complete without being at the souk. It's big, it's loud, it's great for bargaining if you like that. You will notice the shops sell about the same thing everywhere, and unless you are good at bargaining you are probably paying too much. Still, a great experience but be prepared to harangued constantly.

Mental and so much fun!. Throw back 30% of price they quote, haggle and giggle. So much fun. If you're not enjoying the haggle move on, there'll be a seller that wants the sale at a price you're both happy with!

My favorite. We have been in souks in many Moroccan cities and this one is my favorite of the lot. It is newer than the one in Fez so the streets are wider and straighter. That makes it somewhat less crowed and much easier to navigate without getting lost. It is arranged in sections, leather goods, clothes, metal working, etc which also makes life a bit easier. I was particularly impressed with metal workmanship

Must visit in Marrakech. We roamed around the souks for hours and managed to get lost. However, it was a blessing in a way - as we went to places we wouldn't have gone otherwise! We enjoyed the bargaining part; it was intense but funny at times! We bought several items. Beware of frauds though - make sure you keep a magnet if you want to buy solid brass item! People are friendly, helpful even though we spoke in English only.

Mad shopping!!. Well you kind of know that Marrakech is renowned for its bartering and its best to read up before you visit about the do's and dont's as we did. However we were not prepared for the constant stream of motorbikes, carts, donkeys, push bikes and people entering such small streets making it a battle ground to walk through!! Generally if you are polite to the stall holders and don't engage in conversation you can get through without much hassle. It is a shame that they hassle you because it has the opposite effect on us.....we just DO NOT go in and look or buy, so it is there loss. Many of the stalls are full of the same stuff and you see the same items again and again and again!! It is a maze of streets and one can easily get lost. Just ignore the guys telling you that you are going the wrong way and I suggest that you set up your iphone with directions and you will be ok. Act confident as you walk through and we didn't carry bags or open ourselves up to potential pickpockets. The worst thing was having to avoid the constant motorbikes that drive like maniacs and the fumes they produce.....take a scarf to cover your mouth!! It has to be done as it is colourful and the spice aroma's are pungent.........good luck!

The heart of Marrakech - touristy but essential to visit. Noisy, narrow, winding confusing network of streets with an interesting mix of goods for sale. It's essential to visit when in Marrakech to get a sense of the traditional way of life (such as locals transporting goods on donkeys etc)Pros: Fascinating mix of goods for sale ranging from spices, metal work, dyed fabrics and leather.Good for picking up souvenirsA chance to haggle (if that floats your boat)Go in the off season- was not too packed in FebruaryDifferent areas specialise in different goods which provides an interesting contrastYou can buy locals sweets and pastries Cons: to a European traveller, the inability to browse without being constantly hassled can be off puttingThe network of roads is hugely confusing- stopping to look at a map can lead to unwanted attention from locals offering to 'help' (for a price)Many of the stores sell exactly the same things and not really at 'bargain' pricesThe constant stream of locals on noisy, smelly motorbikes is pretty hazardousIn all, its an essential part of the Marrakech experience but don't expect a relaxing stroll or to particularly pick out a bargain.

Haggling is emotionally draining . Depends on what you like. You might end up feeling good for getting a good bargain, but trust me, tourists are always charges 10 times the price anyway, so even after all the haggling, you are still being ripped off.
Not for me. Constantly being harangued was something I expected, but not on this level. Makes the Turks look like amateurs. Spoiled the experience for me

Know what you want and what you want to pay!. We had a really fun time meandering around the souks. We knew what we wanted to buy (a blanket for my daughter, a silver hand evil eye decoration and some scarves). The people are all friendly. No trouble with women here at all. I wore a dress over my knees with sleeves. We had no problems. You do get the odd rather forceful stall holder, desperate to stop you but we had a strategy of not breaking our stride and smiling politely which worked. We struck good deals for all the stuff we wanted. We bought some beautiful silk wool blend pashminas. A silk scarf, a traditional blanket and a silver ornament. We just knew what we would pay max for each item and stated our price. Most stall holders can see you are serious and meet you if they can. All very fair and no drama. I love the colours and sounds of the souks. Really fun place to aimlessly wander about all afternoon. We loved the mellah souk, south of jmnaa al fna. Enjoy!
Great fun if you like getting lost. So many little streets and shops that look so similar. Google won't help you. It is a must for a visit to Marrakech. So vibrant and busy.
You have to visit . We had a great time the people are amazing and fun we had Moroccan tea with one of the sellers don't forget to haggle there some beautiful things for sale in the is amazing place

Great but beware of frauds. Nice place with a lot fo people, companions and someone who promis you to be a guide only. They'll show you something from marrocan manufacture and then they will request to buy you something. It' our experience... But I have a nice bag from goat skin.

Mixture of junk for sale. Various stalls of junk, tat and crap. Some even half price according to the sales pitches of the stall holders. Have a look and get hassled every time you just want to look. If you don't mind the constant sales pitches go have a look.

Have to go, but be aware !!!. Everyone and everywhere is designed to extract the money from your pockets. From arrival you will not be left in peace more than a few minutes before you are approached with people selling watches, iphones, shoe shine, food, tissues, the list goes on and on. Even when you sit in a cafe they are around you like flies !!! Some can be quite forceful and one or two of them scared the wife. Thats just the beginning going into the souks is 10 times worse but great fun. Its a must do..... Just keep your wits about you !!

Easy to get lost but some great bargains to be had for shoppers. As someone who is not a natural bargainer I was a little worried about haggling over the price of items. I ended up going to the government run, fixed price Ensemble Artisanal, to see what fixed prices were before venturing to bargain at the Souk. Pay what you think is fair and don't be afraid to walk away. You can always come back to purchase as long as you don't forget where you saw your bargains. The average Western salesman or woman could learn a lot haggling with these professional salesmen in their various stalls.
good people !. my husband and i visited marrakech just for half day we really enjoy our tour the medina it was intressting we have seen the sights but the best place for shopping it was fez !

Fascinating but can get very irritating. If you love to bargain and barter, this will be heaven for you. But if you give the slightest glance at anything, the sellers will be immediately on your case to make a purchase. I bought a beautiful poof for about 60% of the original asking price. Expect to offer 30% of the sellers opening price and to settle for 50 to 70%. If you walk off, they will usually shout at you with a lower price. Look around first, as prices do differ. I wanted to buy a second poof (they are sold without filling, so you can pack some into hand luggage; and can fill them with old clothes, newspaper etc). Another time, I won't she just hand luggage and will buy some leather, and a quilted bed cover amongst other things.

Crazy and fun all in one night. This place is busy busy busy. We first went on a Sunday night and it was mad busy. On Monday night just busy! It's noisy and crazy with wonderful smells as you walk around. The market is in sections, ladies, children's, men's, homeward etc. The hotels offer guided tours but just be brave and go it alone. If you loose your way don't worry just have fun browsing whilst you find your way again.

A bit scary but fun! . We went on an organised tour and our guides helped us through the maze of market traders. Be aware of the motorbikes and scooters which whizz through the narrow alleys. Offer no more than 30% of the asking price and then walk away and don't look back to get the best bargains. Best day to visit is Friday as it's quieter... avoid Sunday as it's the busiest day
Easy to get lost. An experience. Lots to look at but so easy to get lost. Loads of young men try to give you directions but they expect paying and are difficult to shake off

A nightmare of the worst kind. This is noisy, intimidating, dirty and full of tut! The locals don't care about safety and they certainly don't care about your safety, they are aggressive and pushy, you are better at the Government sponsored stores!

Start your bargain at 1/3 of the price the article is worth for you. Don't let the people know you are interested in a product. They will not stop trying to sell it to you if you are interested. Lots of different nice products. The prices they ask are outragious. Think about what price you are maximum willing to pay and start you bargain at 1/3 of that price. Don't go above the maximum price you are willing to pay. They will sell the product to you for your price. have a good look around first, because lots of shops sell the same goods.

Manic. One of the most captivating places you can visit. If you like a bargain this is the place for you. Make your starting point for buying to be around a quarter of the price the seller is wanting and finally pay around a third of the original price. Always be prepared to walk away. You will probably get a wee bit lost but resist the urge to ask the way as tis Will cost you upwards of 100 MAD

medina flavours. i have been to marrakech six times with this one.. i love just to wander around and be absorbed by the medina, its colours .. smells and its people too.-.. endless mint teas on the way and lots of chats with shops owners who are trying to sell u their products... its mesmerising .. its chaotic .. its just marrakech.. let urself be cuddled by it and you will love it !

Awesome shopping experience. Sharpen your haggling skills and you can find anything you are looking for. The thousands of unique shops in the souk areas will keep you coming back over and over again. If you know what you want and how much you want to pay, you can usually negotiate to your price. If you do not like haggling you will pay too much and you are better off shopping at a mall. But, part of the fun is the haggling :-) At the very least, a must see and walk through the narrow walkways.

Bargain!. The souk near Jemma El Fna is full of pretty stuffs. Morrocan traditional crafts are soooooo beautiful that I wish I could buy all kinds of them. Don't forget to bargain, though the merchants say that they already give you good prices. It can be fun!

An awful and interesting experience. Sure, you can find anything: lamps, clothed, shoes, old keys, argan oil, spices, scarfs etc. But you have to earn the shopping experience... Awful smell (urine drained in the morning with the broom and a glass of water, smelly animal leather, meat, bread, shophran, fish), insistent shop owners (But not so diferent from the ones in Grand Bazare of Istanbul). Gas noxes from motos...
