Indeed, you can find authentic pieces of marocan tradition (Wood carved windows frames etc), but you have to pay the price. the spice shops near Bahia Palace offered me a pleasant experience (Clean floors,Wood carved roofs)

Hustle n bustle. This is the main vein of evening life in Marrakech as far as eating ,street entertainers and shopping go ,in my opinion . The best part of all the sights smells and sounds of this modern day Mardi Gras is sitting in a rooftop cafe and watching the sunset with a mint tea or similar . It's crowded snake charmers , macaques dancing on the lead and I I dare say the usual rogues . Watch your gear and keep your valuables tucked away . Spices are good value saffron is especially appealing if your a foodie . Have a laugh and a joke with these guys on the stalls and you'll win them over . There's leather goods ,snide footy tops and everything you see in every other toot fest the world over .

Not to be missed experience!. Not for the faint-hearted or those who don't want to bargain. Start by offering 50% of what they're asking for and be prepared to walk away. More likely than not, they won't let you. My favourite comment was from a seller who promised real fakes!

Good fun..but... Around the main square the shop mainly sell the same tat as the next shop.
The further away from the main square the more relaxed, fun and interesting it all got.

Bored by repetition. There is a lot to see in the Souk. Shame that it is mostly repetitive, and crap stuff aimed at tourists.I imagine that just outside Marrakech there is a huge warehouse which peddles "rubbish for tourists" and every stall owner visits every week to top up.This a great experience to see, but after about 30 mins it becomes very very boring.

Amazing souks. The Marrakech Souk is amazing. It covers a large area leading off the central square and the stalls go on and on full of tempting items. We were not hassled at all and this made it a very enjoyable experience especially as we are over 65s.

A feast for the senses. A wonderful experience, market stalls, art, leather goods, spices, metalwork , food markets, antiques - you can find an array of traditional hand crafted products and even if you do not want to buy a great deal the souk is still a fantastic place to visit to see locals and their skills. You can wander through the maze of alleys on your own although it is impossible to find a map that details the intricate labyrinth of streets.We included the souk as part of our guided tour, and it was well worth it, our guide took us in to many areas where we could see the artisans at work in the various quarters, metalworkers, woodworkers , the stucco being hand carved. We got so much out of the visit. We plan to visit Marrakech in the future and I would definitely use a guide again so we don't miss a thing, the cultural information you get is fascinating .

Very hectic . I would definitely recommend going to souks but be aware how busy and chaotic can get there due to amount of tourists, locals and motorbikes. You can get some nice souvenirs for a reasonable price, probably cheaper than in the main square.

The original shopping mall.. You can find everything at the Souk. This is a labyrinth of endless shops and stalls. I could spend days wandering. Come prepared to bargain and prepared to walk away empty handed. Most times you will end up with exactly what you wanted at a price you are happy to pay. Be realistic, these people have to make a living too. Pay attention to where you are as it is very easy to get lost. Most shops close for prayer but will reopen after. Closing for the day is typically around 7PM.

Avoid the guides. Fascinating place. However anyone approaching offering to take you around needs avoiding. Generally they will attempt to get you lost in the place and tent you to their friends who sell rubbish. Best to just walk around unescorted... But keep you bearings!

Great shopping. This is one of the worlds iconic tourist destinations and it doesn't disappoint. Yes, it can be confusing and at times you might feel intimidated if you're not a confident traveller. But on our second visit to the Souk, on our third visit to Marrakech, we've not yet had a bad experience with shop-owners hassling us or making us feel unwelcome. Yes - there is a lot of hustle and bustle - thats sort of the point! This is commercial trade in its original form and thats all part of the fun. Go and buy yourself some leather slippers or a lantern to take home. There are plenty of small trinkets and gifts to be purchased so you really won't need to spend very much to experience the markets.

Good experience . The souk area is a great immersion into morroco culture , very traditional , the hustle and bustle of people and animals is everywhere. Although we didn't find anything to buy the experience was eye opening.

Utter madness ! . It's everything you expect it to be. Very busy. Some tiny lanes hiddenaway, crammed full of tat ! Great atmosphere. Vendors constantly asking you to look in their stalls. The starting prices for items will be ridiculously high, even when you can get the price down to half you are unsure if you are still being ripped off. Start very low when bartering and if you walk off and they don't call you back its s good indication you have gone too low but just start a gain and the next stall, they all sell the same tat.

It is very hot in the souks of Marrakech. Our main problem was that after about one and a half hours to two hours on the private guided tour I was fainting mainly then I finally did collapse mainly due to my ill health, but also it was extremely hot and it was a very long walkThe local people in the souks were very loving, caring and even poured water all over me to try to cool me downI was lucky because every now and then I sat on the workers stool to restSo even though I found it really tough, I thoroughly recommend coming to the souks for an eye opener as well, but only if you can cope with the long and hot walk

Great experience but know your limits . Souks are always worth a visit though in Marrakesh they really know how to sell. It's first class pitching with a dash of charm. It's easy to find something attractive in the marketplace though know your limits or you could end up returning with a lot of product you don't need or can find where you live or on eBay. Take a good look but make sure what you purchase is of value, handmade in front of you.The colours, warmth and people that inhabit the red city make it an enjoyable experience. Morocco is full of kind and generous people and here in the souks you are sure to find just that.

Big market. A sprawling market that will struggling to keep your bearings. There are lots of turns and you can be walking for hours, if your not careful. An interesting and lively place.If you do get lost,don't trust the kids offering to point you in the right direction. They seem to like sending you the wrong way and if they do show you the right way, they will expect to be paid.Be prepared to barter and enjoy yourself.
Haggle! Haggle! Haggle!. I really didn't enjoy my experience. Was hassled far too much to shop. Over priced and as a moroccan I find it all cheaper in tangier

Quite a challenge to make your way through the souks. Everything I have heard about the souks was true. It's crowded, everyone is asking for your attention, they will try to sell you everything and to show you the direction against money of course. It's better to lose lose your way instead of allowing them to lead you, because pretty often they mislead you on purpose. However If you are prepared for that you can have quite fun :)

fun batering. just like going into aladins cave, dont be worried the people are amazing and you need to be smiley and happy not cold saying no, its part of the experiance to barter, laugh with stall holders and get a good price, I have so many happy memories here, got some great bargains and was offered to drink mint tea with lovely stall holders, let go and enjoy!!
Overwhelming . Lots of things to see. A paradise for people who like to haggle but we found it too exhausting and annoying at times. Easy to find.
An experience!. Hectic,lively meeting place.Lots of banter.Reasonable prices for good food and friendly chatter.Good area for people watching and making new friends.A gathering place of nations
loacal attraction , interesting. we visited Marrakech Souk , nad it was so magical , local people , we learn many things there , worth a visit

Interesting but very crowded. All the different, colorful merchandise is very interesting, but the men on scooters coming through the narrow streets and the merchants that keep trying to contact you make it a tiresome experience

Total mazy madness ! . Just assume you WILL be lost within minutes of entering here and then that it may take you HOURS to find your way back out ! The souk - you find everything- but you find it many many times over !! Good luck and enjoy 😀

Nice shopping place. We love it nice place to shop specially for ladies who loves silver jewellery only thing to keep in mind that you have to have good scale of bargaining otherwise you will be trapped

Shop till you drop - Just gets irritating. Every 2nd stall looks the same and you can negotiate prices. Even if they tell you the get nothing out of the deal... They do. Someone asked 600 dh for 2 scarfs and we negotiated it to 220 dh.
Good luck shopping

Very average. Sorry cannot share too much here as it was all a bit underwhelming as it seemed been there done it type of place.There are plenty of fresh Juice places here but beware they are cheap but most of them do not use Juicers but blenders and there will be lots of bits in the juice.If you do not let them know they will add sugar to your juice to sweeten it up but we had unsweetened juice and it was sweet enough without the sugar an only cost 4 Dirham about 35p per glass. Ask them to use plastic glasses as the glass ones are just rinsed in the same water over and over.

Medina market. Overall the market was good. However the men do look alot at the women we experienced this ourselves. We ignored them and looked away. The reason why they look at you because you are foreign and also they like to guess your nationality.

You've got to love it!. What frenzy, the smells, the sights, the people, the items, truly amazing. A lot of junk, many things that look cool, but not everything that would suit a normal household. The buying process is like participating in a theatrical piece. You either love it, or... I love it! Getting lost in the zouk is not just a saying, even worse after it closes as everything looks very different, almost like a ghost city. A true must! Remember, no one will sell to you without making a profit, so whatever you have paid, it was probably too much!

Good and bad.. You have to look and get lost to get use to the Souk, and you will start to recognise the small alleys and streets, kids and vendors will lie to you to keep you in the Souk, you will get fed up of being pestered, but you have to go back and you leave with a pleasant experience once you understand the place.

Heavenly . Had dinner here and it was an amazing experience of morrocan food and culture staff were helpful and always willing to advise and make suggestions. The roof terrace is a great place to spend a few hours.

This souk is quite big in comparison to the few others that I visited in Morocco.. This souk is quite big in comparison to the few others that I visited in Morocco. I didn't have time to make it to Fez. This souk is really busy and active, a lot of totally expected but very different stalls from leather shoes to human teeth! Well worth a few hours of your time and maybe a return visit to continue bartering about a preferred purchase.

Haggle, Haggle and Haggle A Little More. I often found myself at this Souk especially late at night which in fact for me was the better time to go, because it was much cooler, there weren't as much beggars out and you really got to see the true beauty of some of the items. As long as you are street savvy, keep a strong eye on your things and the surroundings you will have no problems here. my friends even nicked named me the Habibi Haggle Queen, Haggle! and if it seems like they will not budge then walk away. REMEMBER someone else will be willing to sell it cheaper, trust me!

Good but Fez is much nicer. If you only go to Marrakech and not Fez than this is a great place to go and spent galf a day. Dont let all the reviews scare you anout getting lost and so. Yes its a maxe but you will manage to get out. If you manage to reach your Riad you can manage this.The souk is vibrant and packed with all giftshops. Make sure you bargain at least 30% ! Spices, leather bags, leather accessories, tableware, oils, hats, shoes, weapons, clothes, food, antiques, meat, fruit, paintings, leather jackets, argan oil, etc.Make sure you drink enough water.And oh Marrakech can get really hot in summer so check out the weather forecast !As said i like the Fez souk more, simply because we saw it first but mainly because it looks more authentic and you really get the feeling as if you walk back in time ages. Its also less commercial.
The biggest Souk and open market i have seen. What really impressed me is that the hundreds of shops are all selling locally made items, nothing imported really worth spending the day

Organised Chaos. Organised chaos is defiantly the only way to describe the souksThey are a great experience for the senses, weather is be smell of the fruit stalls, the banging crashing from the metal working area or the bright colours of the fabric stalls there is something for everyone.the only way to explore the souks is to totally get lost as there is lots of little gems hidden down random streets.be warned like many people have said before of asking people directions there was lots of people trying to tell you the wrong directions for the fun of it.and most of all Haggle and you will get a good price and thats the fun of the souks

The best I experienced in Morocco. This souk is quite big in comparison to the few others that I visited in Morocco. I didn't have time to make it to Fez and just found Casablanca really uninviting.This souk is really busy and active, a lot of totally expected but very different stalls from leather shoes to human teeth! Well worth a few hours of your time and maybe a return visit to continue bartering about a preferred purchase.

Souks visit. The souks are huge and you can easily get lost and disorientated and lose your way. There's a huge variety of goods on offer from scarves, silver, pottery, leather goods etc - you can get some really love traditional souvenirs and some great bargains. You do not get hassled much compared to many other places in the world and if you say no thanks and keep walking they do not bother you.

A must. If you come to Marrakech to have to come here to experience the ultimate in market stall trading. Expect to barter for your choice of purchase, never pay the asking price. Definitely not for the claustrophobic it's busy cramped and crowded. The only draw back is that browsing is difficult for as soon as interest in any item is shown the trader will pounce and do his best to get you to make a purchase.
The best experience. The souks are definitely an experience. Definitely haggle as everyone comes down in price. Allow yourself to get lost in the souks- they are well worth it.

Amazing . I visited the souk at night time. It opens in the day but I prefer evening time for the souks. I loved the souk, I felt safe, it was a great atmosphere. There are pick pockets around but you need to be careful with your personal things. In the day time there are shakes in the square, but in the evening there wasn't any. You can easy walk round them to avoid them to get to the souks. I would recommend Morocco to anyone. I felt safe and loved the atmosphere.

It's a Bazzar / souk / market. What else can I say. We loved walking around the many souks just window shopping and enjoying the atmosphere. You can bargain plenty and get the price down by 40-90% on the first price mentioned. So shop away. We are in a few restaurants where we saw locals enjoying the food. Best food we are was found in these places. For 3 adults we paid approx 25-40D for really great lunches. The locals are really friendly and welcoming. We spent time walking a round and just chatting and stopping off for ice creams, teas, cakes or a lunch.

Worst thing ever. This was the worst part of our trip. Wanted to see a bit more of Morocco so thought we would go, as soon as we got off the bus a man approached us and wouldn't leave us alone saying he was a tour guide (which we didn't want in the first place) he was leading us into lots of back streets further away from the markets, this was very scary considering it was just two girls, me and my mum. He then asked if we wanted to see Argan oil being made which we didn't, he was on the phone to someone and next thing we come to a very dark alley with several men waiting and staring at us. I refused to walk any further and made him take us back, we finally managed to get rid of him and surprisingly he didn't even ask for any money. Worst bit of the whole experience was the amount of animal cruelty. I am a massive lover of animals and seeing monkeys on chains performing acts broke my heart. DO NOT go here if you hate snakes, they are everywhere, you literally have to watch where you are walking, even though I don't like snakes they should not be performing these sorts of acts and be in the wild ! I wanted a henna tattoo done and we agreed on the price before, then they wanted to charge us 500 dirhams after they had done it. We only gave them 150, but it came off within two days anyway. Be careful of the women who will just grab your hand and do it without you agreeing then charge you. Luckily me and my mum are strong willed and will not pay anything we never asked for.

Dont drink the orange juice. I love the Marrakech markets but please don't drink the orange juice that is on offer, its very cheap for a good reason, they add water to the oranges before juicing, the tummy trouble is just not worth it. The markets are fantastic, shop around for the best prices, if the market and haggling are not your style, try the shops located on the outer of the souk, they are not as pushy as inside the market but if you love to haggle its amazing. The centre of the market is filled with snake charmers (pay before you take a photo) ladies applying henna tattoos and so much more to look at....a definite must do!

Souks Galore. The Souks of Marrakech offer a wide range of items for sale ranging from cheap imitation jewellery to good quality leather goods of all shapes and sizes. The handbags are particularly of a high quality but be sure that you are buying a totally leather item - some of them are only partial leather. We paid about £35 for handbags (for my wife) which is apparently a good price compared with English high street outlets. The sellers in the Souks are very friendly but a bit pushy. Just a smile and a no thank you will not cause them any offence - then just walk away. Within the Souks there are "Guides" who are keen to show you to a particular area - this will probably be where one of their relatives' shops is and they will expect a tip for their guidance. Overall the Souks are very safe places - pickpockets can be a problem (although not for us this time) so keep your cash and cards close at hand. Avoid putting anything of value in your back pocket. I kept my cards and money in the thigh pocket of my long shorts.
Nice to visit. Nice place to visit when you are I'm Marrakech it is located in Marrakech old city and to see Moroccan goods and cloth with a reasonable prices and to get gifts

Heaven!!!. The most wonderful, cultural and exotic place I have ever experienced. Don't be put off by people telling you how pushy the marketeers are, just relax and get into it, the more relaxed you are the more you will enjoy it. The locals aren't rude, they are just trying to make a living. Haggle!! This is why you're here! They love you to haggle! I worked on a third of what was originally quoted, I found I had to come up slightly on this but give it a go. It may take a bit longer to haggle but you'll get fabulous bargains! A trick is to walk away on your final price, if they call after you you're in! If they don't your offer was too low. Enjoy!

Design led shopping. Spend a day (or at least half a day) getting lost in the lanes of this massive market. The bartering is friendly - be prepared to spend time chatting to the stall holder, have a joke and you might get a good price!

Busy and chaotic but good fun.. We were well prepared and careful to follow a simple route a bit like Hansel and Gretel but it is easy to get lost and trying to find a particular stall again nigh on impossible at least to start with. If you know your prices and what you're buying and you're a good bargainer, you can get some fantastic deals. Worth checking out the Artisans market first to get an idea of quality and prices in a more fixed price place. Just as much fun though to look around the market not buying anything.

Amazing experience - but get a guide.... ...unless you're OK getting lost, then don't bother. :) We arranged a guide through our hotel and it was totally worth it. We didn't get hounded as much and we saw way more than we likely would have on our own. An experience you'll never forget! A must in Marrakech.

Love the place. Now this place is both a gem and a modern health and safety disaster. I will start with the gem. I bought a leather jacket and I paid roughly £160 for a quality that I struggled to find in the uk for under £600. It was hand made in the souk. They pride themselves on great workmanship which is evident when you take a tour. Now the health and safety bit. There are black smiths. Welding. Also all the chemicals and flames etc associated with various trades. No eye protection except ray bans. Using bare feet to hold metal in place You get the idea. Also go on a tour I promise you will get lost if u don't.

Watch out for aggressive stall holders, tourist tat and scooters. The souks remain a tourist destination but since I was last here I sense the tradespeople have become more desperate to make sales and their haggling is less fun. You should still aim to pay no more than a third of the original asking price, having checked it's something you really want. There's an awful lot of tat which doesn't really fit into a UK home. And watch out for motorbikes and scooters which roar through most of the souk making the whole shopping experience much less relaxed than it used to be.
Local souk. In marrakech souk. You can see local people and discover a new things about moroccan culture. It was great part in marrakech

facinating. very interesting tour round the Souks ,but glad we had a, Guide would not have ventured
without one.

AMAZING PLACE MAGICAL. If you want to go back 50 years in time where nothing has advanced and people are still living under primitive conditions, visit the Souk in Marrakech . This market sells everything and in abundance, from fruit to carpets, spices, jewellery, shoes, clothes, meat; love chickens.....;it is an experience!
Hager ling city. Full of culture but have your wits about you as pick pockets are common, check with hotel shop prices before you go to give yourself a guideline on prices.

Fascinating place. I was expecting this to be like Cairo, dirty and crowded, but it was so different. The place was very clean, the people friendly and so many interesting things to see. Very colourful.

Pain.. We visited here for a day out, we managed to stay here for an hour and had to leave, we were surrounded by people who don't take No for an answer, constantly pestering. The place is busy and pickpockets mingle amongst the crowd. I Could'nt wait to get a cab back to the hotel, but even the taxi driver wanted to argue about the fare, they want every bit of money they can get from you. One other thing worthy of a mention is the Non existent toilet facilities, they are poor to say the least, I do not want to take a pee, whilst within my visual range are others sitting on the floor, moaning out loud whilst taking a crap, not a pleasant experience, filthy to say the least..

Get your game face on. The souk is great as long as you go in understanding everyone, EVERYONE, is out to get your money. Leather is good and cheap--sandals, wallets, bags and books. Spices, herbs and perfumes. Rugs, scarves and garments. Bargain! Counter offer with 50% of what they ask and be prepared to walk away. If you don't get it, you know where to start the next time.

Get lost in the souks. As we stayed in a Riad near the souks we passed everyday through them. Try to visit the nothern west ones, higher off the places des Epices. There they are much less touristic and you see also how the work with the metal, the leather, the wood.Bargain a lot. Never start if the 1st price they say is higher than the 40% you want to give. Because usually this is the price you get finally.Start at 25% of the price, and have in mind what is the maximum you want to give for an item (but never say it). Do not argue about quality or the price. I am only saying "you are right it is a good value value for money but I do not have so much money " and of course one of us says to the other "it is nice but we do not need it, move on".I usually get it at 40% of the price. Others may get even better results. Whatsoever the seller is always the winner. He never sells without a profit!

An experience. The souk is a must-do when in Marrakech. It has become a little gentrified since I first visited but is still quite an alien experience for a Brit! The noise, the smells and the sheer vibrancy of the stalls crammed into seemingly endless winding streets makes this a really intense day out. Literally everything can be brought here, from fruit and veg, to chameleons (you don't want to know what they are for!) to slippers and bike parts. If you know what you are after make sure you know what you are willing to pay and enjoy the bartering. Just beware of coming home with something you never even knew you needed until you spotted it- I came home with a copper sink and lion taps...

Sensory Overload. The vast majority of visitors to Marrakech come in order to experience the Souks and so they should. The hustle, bustle and energy can be quite overwhelming, in a good way. Treat buying as a game and you will have so much fun. The haggling process is an art and if done right both you and the seller will enjoy the experience. Do not be afraid to go in at 25% of the original asking price. The seller will fake shock and insult but it is all part of the negotiations. If he comes down only slightly then you fake shock and insult, this can go on for some time but will eventualy lead to a mutually happy result. Once done, return back to your riad or hotel for a good G&T.

Visiting the Souks. I went with my husband in September and we had no idea what this was going to be like. All I can say it was fantastic we went on a Saturday night and it was so busy the food, the smells, the music, the dancing, snake charmers, horses and monkeys on leads and a massive array of people. Such an experience that I will never forgot and a must do. The souks were amazing they had everything and anything you wanted.Yes I bought some bits that I am happy with although I feel that you can barter with the shop owners but to be honest they are ridiculous the prices they first come out with. When I looked a Hermes bag the owner kept saying do u know how much this is in the UK. Well I did and I still wasn't going to pay £100 for a fake. I do feel the shop owners get a bit carried away as they know how much originals are in the UK. Same as when we bought some saffron cause it was expensive in UK they thought I was going to pay more. This irritated us a little. Although the whole experience of being at the souks was fantastic and I would defiantly go back.As a lady with blonde hair I did receive unwanted attention and feel maybe ladies from other countries should be respected more, I covered my hair next time I went and did not receive any unwanted attention. I feel if English men gave unwanted attention to ladies in Marrakech their would be a huge problem.
sweet souk. marrakech souk is fantastic place to discover the real morocco , if you are in marrakech it worth a visit

Eye opener . A very speciale place, lots of different cultures, lots to see with thousands of stalls. Plenty of restaurants to go in and sit up high to a breathtaking view. Cheap. but if you cant hagle or barter then its not for you. Its manic busy but well worth going to. I would recommend to anyone, go and try. Be prepared to be harrazed. Just be polite say no thank you clearly, then ur left alone.

Dont get sucked in by ANYBODY!!. Its very interesting and colorful. If you wan to purchase something always start at 1/4 of what the vendor is asking. Never go higher than 1/2 as your already paying more than the value of the item, NEVER let anyone lead you anywhere and don't be afraid to walk away from anyone wanting sell you something, take you somewhere (even if you are lost) or offer any kind of advice or guidance. It always has a price attached to it! Just be firm and careful and you can enjoy a colorful vibrant experience. Don't really recommend single females for this city, sadly.

A TIP ON BARTERING. It's a must do, try your hand at bartering with the locals and get a genuine local souvenir. TIP; know your money, work out how much £10/€10 is in Dirham. The souk owners will charge huge amounts, so be theatrical, have a maximum spend in mind, and be prepared to walk away. Come back later or find another souk selling the same product but don't jump in and show your hand on the item you want, they'll have the upper hand on you then. Also, if you get pulled in and feel pressured into buying something don't feel rude if you have to be very stern in drawing the line.
local souk. this was a great visit into marrakech souks , was amazing to see a locals daily life , interesting and amazing

Stay away from the guys with monkeys unless you are rich!. I enjoyed the food here and looking around but I hated the way how the street performers put monkeys on you without asking and expect a payment, I even got swore at my one.

Great arabian market to negotiate.. Great place to spend your day and get souvenirs for everyone. Very cheap, when they know you are a tourist they will amp the price. What every first price they say don't ever accept. They use the sales tactic of making you feel and touch the product so its harder for you to say no. If you don't hear the answer you want start walking away, and you will hear it. Just be smart in this place and you will be fine!

Interesting Arabian market to have a look. It is worth to take a careful walk there - it is interesting to see people and bargaining. But you may get easily get lost on many un-named small streets. Kindly help from local "guides" may end up in strange shops or paying some money. This time we did not buy anything there.
would recommend the Souks. We walked around freely and stopped where we chose to. We picked up so lovely bits for decent prices. I would recommend it

Good Experience. Lots of Husser! Be street wise and do not buy until you know that you want to buy. Always haggle to a third of the price then decide what you would like to pay as you'll effeminately find a cheaper one after you have paid for the item.

Meh. If you like dollar stores in the USA, you will love these. Personally, I did not care for them at all. Obnoxious people selling crap that you can get in the United States without the hassle. Bargaining over ceramic trinkets and tin garbage is a waste of time. See it, but don't spend all day here. There are much more interesting things to see
Shopping spree. a good place to come to those shopaholic. a lot of items to choose from clothes, bag, shoes, jewelry and a lot more.

The streets are better. I found the shop / stall sellers more aggressive and pushy here than the medina I didn't enjoy it very much but go and see make up your own mind we all travel differently - and it's an experience

What an experience! !. Well.....a visit to the Souk is very interesting and certainly an experience you will either love or hate.The Souk is very traditionally Morrocon, the way it is set out, the locals, the goods on sale, horse carriage rides, everything.You can buy everything from low to high grade Argan Oil, the way to tell is if you shake it the oil will bubble rise/ slowly to the top, as there are many low grade products on sale, so don't be caught out!As you would expect there are many fake goods on sale but I would say you are better off buying them from Turkey, but that is only because I have bought from Turkey many times.Look around before you part with your Dirham, as items such as kaftans can range from 59 to 200 Dirham. Cold chilled water is available to buy as is freshly squeezed orange juice. Look around before parting with your money, just find a landmark so you know where you entered. Be wary of traders who will encourage you to enter their stands, the word LA [that means NO in Arabic) said strongly will have some effect. Watch out for cild and adult beggars.Hope this is useful - Enjoy the Souk.Some hotels run a courtesy bus to the Souk, so take advantage of this if you have it available.The Souk is a massive market with places to eat traditional food cocked by local traders and buy kaftans amongst other things.

Like nothing else. The souk is a series of different souks that merge into each other on first visit it appears to chaotic and random. The more you venture in the organisation becomes clearer and once you have Sussed out who to talk to and who to ignore it is a pleasurable experience. So much to see. Beautiful objects, rugs jewellery, smells of amazing spices. Also be aware of mopeds and scooters that weave in and out. But just go with the flow and you will be fine.

What an experience!. If you don't have a detailed map or a very good GPS, don't enter in souks! I have a very good map on my phone, but I saw many tourists without maps that was in a very dark place in this souks! We escort some people fron this souks and they was very thankfull:)! This isn't compared with Istanbul Bazar but the athmosphere is related.
local place so nice. souks of marrakech is so nice and local place , you explore the daily life of marrakech people , we had a great visit

A must visit day and night. An exciting place of happenings. Snake charmers, monkey handlers, musicians etc. At night a mecca for eating local food and atmosphere of the exotic. Stalls like Alladins treasure cave so much colour and variety of wares. However tourist be aware of taking pictures of performers they expect you to pay for the privilege. Also be aware when monkeys are put on ones shoulder the owners then expect you yo pay to remove it. Touti g for eating stalls is also rife, often you can be abused for ignoring them. However tourist also have to be assertive both in eating choices and when buying goods, dont forget to bargsin. Also can be dark and crowded suggest keep your wallets close yo chest. Of so worth going too this is Marrakech and Morocco

probably best to employ an official guide. Full on crazy enormous place, just incredible to wander through, so much to see, sights sounds smells everywhere, we had a guide Mustapha an official guide who was really good well informed, good english, helpful, interesting and funny, we couldnt have done it without him, we for sure would have got lost and missed out on the best bits to see, looking back I think one day to look and another to buy perhaps would have been a good move, Like a favorite film you get more and notice extra things with a second viewing, this is one of those places, you have to do it even if it is only once, just for the memories

What you expect. Such fun, good bargains to be had. Locals can be pushy but I found them over all to be polite. There is a lot of begging and crime so just don't advertise yourself as as victim and you'll be fine

Fine souvenir shopping. It's pretty fine to walk across this Souk along old narrow streets & buy old memorial souvenirs. A lot of people are descent & cooperative there but take care you've to decrease the sum of money of any article or any thing you want to buy to almost less than its half

Interesting experience and cheaper "brand" shopping than at the square. I was reading reviewes and all of them said it is easy to get lost. Map is really not going to help you, but if you will follow red sign to Jemma el Fina square, you will get out at the end, just make sure not to miss any on the turn. Alternatively ask someone, for few derhams they would be happy to walk out with you.

International Shopper's Paradise. What distinguishes this market from many others around the world is the good nature of the Moroccan shop owners. Yes, they can be a bit pushy - but always back off with a smile and "maybe tomorrow!" A veritable feast for consumers, the narrow isles are occupied by mostly locals, not tourists. Food, spices, clothes, jewelry, rugs, leather goods, handbags (don't trust the designer tags), anything you can think of can be found here. It's actually fun to shop here, even though there is the time honored negotiating that usually involves a glass of mint tea.

Shopping . Probably the best place in Marrakech to go shopping. And especially if you have bargaining skills. I don't and ended up paying too much for every item bought. But it's entertaining anyway and people are nice :)
Great hustle . Great to talk to locals, barter down for goods etc. Fantastic scene, colourful, cheap, great fun. Be sure to check out all the watches, aftershaves, tagines bowls and plates

Fascinating!. This is an amazing and fascinating place. Hundreds of shops selling absolutely all sorts of goods. This is not tricked up for tourists as it is the place where all the locals purchase everything. The sights, sounds and smells of the spices form a memorable experience.

Crazy. Bussleing, noisy, amazing, crazy, sometimes smelly place!! It is a must. Could be a little over bearing. Whilst walking around you WILL get lost. In some points it reminded me of how the Victorian streets of London may have been. When you immerse yourself and allow your brain to catch up it almost feels a bit biblical! As you go deeper into the souks you loose daylight and it could be night time. In an area there was blacksmiths working it was dark and almost reminded me of a scene from Lord of the Rings. We went in the morning about 10 ish and then later on another day so from experience the earlier in the day was much better and less intense.

Amazing.. The souk is a feast for the eyes and all your senses! Its amazing to believe that in a three and a half hour flight from gatwick you are immersed in a a different culture. My husband and I felt safe wandering through all the dark passage ways of the souk, no body bothers you, except when they want you to buy their goods. There were some beautiful crafts for sale, lovely shawls, sandals, bags, jewellery, perfumed oils,carpets, lampshades, and much more. You have to bargain with the seller for anything you buy. Go to the exhibition craft centre first to get an idea of prices which the government has set. The cost of their goods are reasonable and a good guide. A fascinating experience.

Crazy place... Be cool!. If you are in Marrakech (or any other North African city) you must visit the souk. Hundreds of shops selling everything you can imagine. Be ready for the amazing mix of colours and smells, but be also ready for some very upsetting sellers.

Sensory overload!!!. This place is amazing...the sights, sounds, and smells are incredible. The souks wind throughout the area north of Jemma el Fna, and it is very easy to get turned around and lost. Be sure to take something with GPS, which makes it fairly easy to navigate and find your way out. Spice markets, pashmere, street food, restaurants, local wares...fun to just wander and take in the sights and smells. The vendors are aggressive, but if you don't make eye contact and ignore their pleas for you to enter their shop, they will leave you alone. For a clean bathroom, just find a cafe (their are many), and buy a cup of coffee or tea. A great way to spend a morning or afternoon.

Shopping overload. Some incredible shopping to be had in the Souks. Brush up on your bargaining skills though with small purchases before buying anything expensive! Offer a third of what they are asking and maybe settle at half. Go to the Artisanal first as this is a government run 'mall' where prices are set so you can see what you can expect to pay for something before buying in the Souks. Learn the word La Shukran (no thanks) as you will need this!! Watch for the teenagers that want to show you the way as they end up taking you to one of their stores where you will be hounded to buy. The Big Square comes to life at night. Enjoy the food and the experience.

Great but beware of the greedy merchants. My favourite shops in the Rue Semmerine are no.5 Tifalelet the jeweller owned by a lovely man called Ibrahim and his family and they are honourable and straightforward merchants to deal with - I also love no. 46 and 96 owned by Adil who sells great scarves, blankets, throws, wall hangings, cushions etc at fair prices whilst other merchants will try to rip you off. For the best carpets go to Aux Merveilleux and ask for Driss who speaks fantastic english - I have bought so many carpets from him over the years. Don't go with a guide - go on your own to get best prices.
Nice. Very nice souk very cheap all the time busy you must keep your money safe all it of thief can tike it people very poor every saler give you different price
Exciting Atmosphere. Lots of buzz, atmosphere very noisy and busy, expect to barter. A lot to see, spiceys, sandals, tagines, jewellery.

Market Experience You Will Never Forget. An amazing vibrant market, full of amazing smells and sounds and sights. Very easy to get drawn into places where you feel pressured to buy but on the whole a must do whilst in this slightly mad and frenzied City!

Definitely an interesting experience. Very unique, sometimes overwhelming. Something worth experiencing, but I felt the need to decompress after spending an hour here. My biggest issue was that the people could be a bit too pushy and aggressive. For instance, one of the snake charmers came up behind me and tossed a snake on my shoulders while I was standing around in a square. Not only was this shocking, he then demanded money for holding his snake... Would definitely recommend a visit, just know what to expect you'll enjoy it.
nice for shopping. i find a lot of markets in Marrakesh but i think that the most popular is the one near jama fna square they call it samarine ,-.

Keep your wits about you. I can't say I enjoyed this place. At the start it seems crazy and exciting but after a while you realise there are 20,000 market stalls all selling the same stuff and they all want you to buy from them. Be warned; if you show an interest that means the negotiation has begun and you then have a battle to move on. Also expect to get lost. The souks are laid out like a maze designed to trap the unwary - don't be surprised if you lose your way but you can be assured that some helpful local 'guide' will always bob up to navigate you back to the main square (for a price) - and its wise to agree that price before you start.
step back in time. ancient City. Very unique place. My husband and I enjoyed our trip, our shopping and our sunset at the plaza. Indeed a very sweet place.

My kind of place........ ........being a magpie, loving sparkly shiny things and being a belly dancer! Decide how much you want to pay, learn to haggle and stick to your price and you can't go wrong. The twisting, winding streets are absolutely fascinating and there is something amazing round every corner. Amazing place!

Souk Your Troubles Away. The Souk is a really good place to get lost in the maze of shops available. If you are unsure about venturing out into the vast array of endless alleys and what reassurance that you know where you are then I would recommend getting a guide however I didn't get one and even though I was with my wife and 1 year old, we just went within the souks and explored what they had to offer.We had an idea of when we had to have lunch and set off looking for a restaurant 20 mins before lunch so we had ample time to look for one.I didn't carry a map as I looked on Google maps at the hotel to get a rough idea of where things are. You can get a INWI PAYG sim and use this to navigate via your mobile as well.There are plenty of shops here and I would advise not to go into the first shop and buy something that you like as you will find the same thing cheaper further on.To give you a rough guide, what ever the price you are told, half that and then negotiate on a price from there.There was only one shop (a metal ware shop)which was close to Mosquee Bab Doukkala which gave me a reasonable price and I didn't feel the need to negotiate.Outside the Souk, there were people with monkeys and when I took a picture said I can give them anything between 200 - 250 dirhams, I ended up paying them 20 which I thought was too much as well.I would suggest just enjoying the whole experience of the shops and of haggling and walk away if you are not happy with the price that you want.

I wish I knew the secret. My main problem was that you cannot express any interest, stop to look or point before a shop keeper is on you. It made it really hard to buy because you didn't want to pick anything up to look at it. I am sure there are tricks as a tourist but I just found it impossible not be be drawn into negotiating for things I didn't even like nevermind want. I found I got far less attention by covering my head so you might want to consider it.

Extremely tiring experience. Unless you are coming to Marrakech to shop and haggle and fight for a good price, Marrakeh souk is simply exhausting. Every 2 seconds someone asked you if you want to try, buy, see... A lot of people are "guides" so they "guide" you into places they get commission from. Be careful of people telling you something is closed or the street is shut - it's a lie. They simply want to "guide" you into the shop of a friend or family member. Prices are average. Leather is everywhere. Of course not ecological :) for all you organic Eco freaks... Let's make it obvious. It's not happy leather. Most of sources are in baskets outdoors with all the pollution, motorbikes dust and crap settling over it. I suggest buy from pots or shops that have lids on stuff.Be careful with henna ladies - they start paining your hands without your permission and boom there goes 35€... If you don't pay they start shouting. Generally the dirt, smell, animal abuse is ever present in Marrakech. It's seriously not for everyone.

Give it a miss if you are female - this is an embarrassment to the people of Morocco. This is one of the biggest disappointments in Morocco , the the behaviour of the men brings shame on the country. I was travelling with my wife and two daughters - all were respectfully dressed with long sleeves and loose fitting clothes and they were constantly abused verbally and touched - the Moroccan Tourist board should take note and if they want people to recommend Marrakech then clean up the mens' attitudes.This was the only place in Morocco we experienced this - very sad.

Jemaa el Fna it's a best and fantastic touristic area in Marrakech.. I've visited Marrakech several time and every time I go Morocco I've to go Jemaa el Fna and I enjoy a lot my self my family and my friends.

Disappointing and so cruel. I really can't understand people's excitement for this place atall, don't get my wrong Marrakech is a beautiful city. But I feel the souks let it down massively! Yeah it's an experience to see a different way of living.. But I kinda wish I didn't see it! It was the animal cruelty that got my the most, monkeys on chains, dressed up for entertainment in silly clothes and sunglasses, in dirty nappies which I'm sure are rarely changed! Those poor monkeys dragged around all day plonked on people in such a busy manic square must be torture alone! Let alone the abuse they get before going to work to be so well trained. Snake charmers with drugged up snakes completely taken out of their comfort zone! Apart from the animal cruelty people/locals were rude and desperate, purely using you for money! Do not think anything is free.. Not even a compliment. They don't appreciate tourists atall as they are so rude! So many stories or pick pocketing and being scammed by fake tour guides. Lucky we were warned of this before going but still weren't prepared for the total poverty. I didn't even wanna buy anything in the environment! And tbh none of it was unique you will find if all at the airport shops! What a let down

Great day out!. Very fun and educational. Bought lots of bits and bobs, be prepared to hustle! Can be a little intimidating so make sure you feel confident. Had some great henna too! Someone also offered to buy me for 1000 camels
So much to see and experience.. A must see, do, hear and smell. Exciting to see this place. Some good haggling to be had too. Take time to soak up this place.

Chaotic and action packed, lots of fun. I loved the souk in Marrakech. But take caution to not get swayed by anyone whacking you away to take you somewhere else. The vendors can be a little bit aggressive, but as long as you ignore them you are fine. Don't bargain unless you really are interested otherwise they can get angry. I would go back again for sure as it's a fun experience, just a bit drawing after a few hours.....

Wander and look around you. The soul is the place to wander and explore. Most of the stalls sell tourist souvenirs but look down alleyways and signs above the walkways for clues about what to see. There are areas known for dying wool, leather slippers, ironwork, leatherwork, food markets and fresh birds animals waiting to be chosen for slaughter. At every turn there is a small doorway with elaborate mosque entrances. I wasn't overly pestered unless you show an interest in their wares. Beware of scam artists:-1 trying to guide you through the Souk then want to charge you money - there is no need2 stalls saying they sell genuine Argan oil and saffron - go to a reliable herbalist.

Atmospheric tat shops. The general impression of the souks, especially those that have lots of metal work, is of an amazing treasure trove, especially at night when all the lamps are switched on. All those fine fabrics and bright colours - really something!However, having spent this morning trying to buy some beautiful tea glasses for a friend, I actually had occasion to look more closely at the merchandise, and to be honest, it's not generally of high quality. Most of the shops sell replicas of the same mass-produced stuff, and most of it is a bit rubbish - the sort of thing you might find in a pound shop in Britain. Also, and this will come as no surprise to anyone, people lie to you. Obviously they tell you a much higher price than something is worth, and lie about what pashminas are made of, but I was fool enough to buy a lot of "saffron" which on closer inspection was clearly the much cheaper turmeric.Fun to look round, fun to haggle, but it doesn't stand up to the cold light of day.

be prepared to haggle hard. it is a place where you can get carried away buying holiday Souvenirs only to find out when you go back home you have just brought alot of tatyou must always haggle hard and if your not happy of the price being offered to you walk awaybut i must say its defo worth a vist

Dont get lost ;-). A maze of tiny bending winding streets and intersections. Hundreds of little shops and steamy tangines all around. Watch out for aggressive salespeople and turn down any "friendly" directions as they will claim streets are closed etc to (mis)guide you and claim payment. Very easy to get lost so make your way slowly or keep walking till you reach a main road and grab a cab. Extremely charming and very exciting but watch out for your money ;-)
the times square of marrakech. if you like that kind of thing, this is your spot. i felt it was a "must-do" but only spent about ten minutes there and i was ready to go

Don't expect to see the same vendor twice!!!. HUGE! We were told this is the second largest souk/market in the world, next to the Turkish bizarre. It's massive, and if you're expecting to return later on to a little shop you liked, make sure you write down specific directions or turn by turn to get back. Many many people will try to offer you free things and demonstrate or show you their shops/items, but will be very pushy and forceful with demanding that you buy. VERY colorful and busy! Lots of photo opportunities, but make sure you're a little sneaky, or you will be forced to pay ;)

Great for buying stuff you probably don't need. Don't ask the price or look at something unless you want to buy. Decide what the item is worth to you and never go over that figure. When you ask the price they will say a figure at least offer a third that price as a starter. Bargaining is an art, the more you comeback with funny lines the more they are likely settle at a good price

Very busy. Very busy, but very interesting spot, full of everything what you can possibly imagine, plenty of colors, everyone wants to sell you everything, but that's quite typical. Nice experience, good prices. Remember to haggle.
He who dares wins. The Stallholders of the souk around Jemaa el Fna will work you hard to bag a bargain, but if you are genuine and respectful it can be great fun trialling he who dares wins.

Harrasment from start to finish. As soon as you look at something, the sellers begin hassling you. They follow you down the street to try to get a sale. One even got abusive to someone who said no quite loudly and firmly. We went out one and I had my hair stroked by many of the people so refused to go back again.
souks. whent to the madina , main square is good with snake charmers ect , also have your pic with the snakes ,

Robbers paradise!. We had several unpleasant experiences in the souk but one stands out for the sheer hell. Our hotel taxi dropped us near to the tannery, having been asked to drop us at the Museum. He then summoned a man to 'guide' us to the Museum, I refused and my elderly mother and I tried to find it alone. After a while, obviously looking lost a huge guy approached us and informed us that we were in a very dangerous area and to watch our bags. He offered to guide us but I refused. He then walked ahead telling us to follow him as it was safer to show us the way even though I protested numerous times that we would find it ourselves. He 'guided' us to a deserted narrow alleyway and demanded 600 dirhams! I was outraged and refused. He became very threatening and aggressive, shouting in my face and waving his arms around. I handed over a small amount and threatened him with the police. He then left still remonstrating that he was very angry. It was a very frightening experience. He had in fact led us away from the museum so we were even more lost. I approached a covered woman who asked a gentleman to guide us to the museum. It took 20 minutes of stressful walking, dodging mopeds, sellers, children and touts. We eventually arrived to find a couple shaking and in tears. They were students who had just experienced exactly the same as us, just a different guy involved! This is a total scam!!!! Taxi drivers and local young men are clearly in cahoots. It is daylight robbery and very traumatic. From the moment you set foot in the medina you are harrassed and told you need to go right, left, straight on, or back the way you have just come by young guys who then want to guide you in the right direction for money or hand you over to another friend to be guided, we talked to people who had been passed on several times and still left in that maze of streets! We hated our experiences in Marrakesh. Never in all our travels have we been so aggressively pursued for money nor have we felt so unwelcome. It felt hostile, threatening and very uncomfortable. My mother's age was no deterrent for these merciless guys nor was she shown any courtesy. We will never return to this scam city ever again!

Authentic!. We went through the souks nearly everyday we were in Marrakech. The locals can be quite forceful but once they got to know our faces most left us alone. Make sure you're with someone. Thing is, it never stopped us going through the Souks again. Loved every bit of it. Make sure you barter as the prices for items come down considerably! Loved the vibe!

A stroll. Great to stroll around!! Easy to get lost but you always get back to the main square! The atmosphere is nice and you are not forced to buy stuff. There is much to see and take your time to observe it. In the beginning, it might be overwhelming.

The Souks are a true wonder of Marrakech. The Souks are a a true wonder of Marrakech. Just entering the busy meandering alleyways lined with shops is an amazing and immersive experience.Be sure to haggle with shopkeepers to find great deals and magical gifts. Keep and eye our for the iconic canary yellow slippers among other traditional items.

Standard but good experience. I have been to Marrakech before but still enjoyed it. It can be very confusing getting around but I had no problems with Google Maps on my phone (could not download the map but it stores the last place that you have looked at). We used a tour guide (Yousaf) one day, which added an extra dimension. Yousaf took us to places that we would not have found by ourselves and really explained the history. You can get some good deals, if you have the time to haggle.
The Souk. An interesting journey but do take a guide as you could get lost. 9,500 shops yes!Lots to buy but a lot of Chinese goods so if you want Morrocan a guide is essential

So much STUFF!. You have to visit the souks ; they are such an amazing phenomenon. So many people strolling slowly through, so many stalls all selling much the same goods, so many stall-holders sitting on stools outside their stalls or vainly trying to catch the eye of the passers-by. How do they ever survive commercially?Marrakech souk is extensive, and labyrinthine! It is VERY easy to get lost in so take care or, better still, take a guide. Then, having experienced the atmosphere of the souk, go instead to the Ensemble Artisanal to actually buy anything!

Endlessly Fascinaing- Love All the Different Areas. The souks are vibrant, colourful and at times totally overwhelming due to the persistent shop keepers. What I most loved when I visited were the different areas. The main thoroughfare is Souk Smarine which has general tourist items. I loved the roof slats which cast shadows and created an atmosphere as I walked through. Nearby is Rahba Kedima, an open square with its fascinating apothecaries stalls. Then there are areas devoted to carpets, fabrics, dyers, ironmongers and leatherwork. It's worth walking around and trying to see the craftsmen at work.Many of the stalls sell similar things so if you see something you like and can't get it at a fair price there is always somewhere nearby to try.

Mesmerising. Be careful I got done in a herbal shop,but went back and threatened them with the tourist police,I got it, but they send out a man to find anyone with an inclusive bracelet from their hotel,and then keep pestering them to go with them,so beware.The people are lovely mellow and kind,so don't be put off.its worth the visit.lots to see and take in.enjoy.

A polluted tourist trap. I've been to a few markets around the world now and this would have to be one of the worst. The main reason is that unlike, say the Grand Bazzar in Istanbul, the souk's many laneways are also open access to any small vehicle that can fit down them. Unless you have a very efficient mask I would suggest you enter at you own risk.
good place. marrakech souks is one is t beautiful souks in marrakech , the local people in a daily life , and simple things , its amazing

Fun but Busy!. We didn't spend long in the Souks as we found it quite intimidating!Looking around all the stalls was lovely but the constant harassment from the shop owners got a bit much for us.But we got some amazing gifts at great prices so can't complain!
Try and see the non tourist part. Don't be afraid of battering and saying no thank you.Take a map from hotel if possible. Wear sensible shoes.

Be very vigilant.. Don't ask locals for directions unless you're OK with giving them money. Don't even talk to anyone about anything because they will demand money afterwards. Don't take pictures with or of monkeys/animals without asking the price first. Because you do have to pay for it. Not sure why anyone would support this sort of animal cruelty anyways. The monkeys have to wear nappies and I doubt they're treated well. Went here with a Caucasian friend and he was constantly harassed. We ended up getting followed one day by someone we had a brief chat with, he demanded money afterwards because he had apparently given us a "tour". He then told us of how he lost his whole family and kept repeating "give me my money". We eventually lost him, but it was pretty scary lol.I got a decent leather bag but ended up paying £18 more than I should of because I was manipulated by the shopkeeper. You will be asked if you want spices/hash/drugs approximately every 30-120 seconds here. Which gets annoying after a while.Definitely worth a visit though. But it's one of those go once never go back again type places.
Marathon trip. Great place to see the real Marrakech. Just bartar even though they say " asda price". Such a fab city
to go shopping. Interesting shops, long narrow and clean streets. We have also seen many craft shops. The shopping and negotiate a lot of fun

Atmospheric. Get a licensed guide for your first orientation visit. It's a labyrinth of shops with a vast array of goods. Bartering is a must. No visit to Marrakech is complete without at least one visit. Lots of attention from stall holders but non feels threatening or intimidating.

Fantastic adventure!!. As you would expect - full of people, noise and anything you could want to buy....Avoid if you hate heat, noise, crowds and being bothered by locals. We just waled for miles. You can get lost but just keep walking. Most locals are friendly - and the others....well just ignore or clothes line!Avoid anyone offerign directions or offering to be a guide - they will want paying and can be quite aggresive and will follow you. Keep your wits and seasoned travellers will enjoy the entire city not just the Souk!

Awesome souk. The wife and I were here for our honeymoon, and we spent everyday of our trip at the souk. I have been to souks all over the mid-east and this is one of the best. If you visit Marrakesh, your trip will not be complete without a visit here.

Anything your heart desires....... Imagine the biggest car boot sale you have ever attended. Mix in a village fete and a craft fair. Add a food market selling just about anything, designer clothes made to measure in 24 hours, household goods, furnishings and antiques and you begin to get the picture of the souks. They are a warren of lanes that meander, dividing at small squares with cafes around and then wandering off again. Some lanes are very narrow, and blind alleys abound. Everywhere the traders want your attention and money. Follow the rules and you will be fine.Oddest offer for sale? Tiny Horsefield tortoises. Best advice? Take time to explore. It really is worth getting to know this Aladdin's cave.
Must be done!. The Souks have to be explored. Just wander around and eventually you return to daylight every time. Lots to see. Be prepared to barter.

Wild! - Marrakesh Market :-). This place is mental :-) So much art true craft and culture.Avoid if you don't like crowds or people selling stuff at you.Fab for bargaining - handbags, belts, jewelry - everything....we were in the souk for about 3 hours - it goes on for miles.Be prepared to barter - its part of the fun. If you don't want to buy it don't show an interest in it ..... :-) A must....
Chalenging. Well such an exciting experience. Just keep your wits about you and a curt "Non merci" stops too much hassle from the traders.

easy to get lost in this hellhole. As a solo female traveller this place was one of the most intimidating places on earth. Grabbed from all sides, groped multiple times, and simply surrounded by a group who demanded money. The stall holders and wannabe travel guides are something warned of in guidebooks, but nothing can prepare you for the sheer weight of intimidation and the ease of which you can lose your bearings completely in this place. Avoid, unless you really want to buy a massive amount of tat and see how awful this place really is.

You will get lost. But you are safe!. The Souks are the main shipping locations in Marrakech. They tend to be grouped into product types, so you nerf to go to the one that matches the thing you want - Leather Souk, Tin Souk, Spice Soul etc., don't buy straight off, take a look around, make a few 'test' offers and tell them you will come back if they ate offering a good price and quality. They will do all they can to keep you and make a sale, you will be offered many mint tea's. Make sure you are both using the same currency, make are when they say 50, they are referring to dirham's and not euro. And most of all enjoy it and don't take things too seriously.
Love everything about marrakesh. Love marrakesh just watch out for the motorbikes and you will be fine. Lots of different shops so your bound to find something you like.
Loved walking around the Souk. It is amazing!!!! Very beautifull, we wanted to buy everything! It is very safe, we walked even around the time it was closing and didin`t feel unsafe at all...
Be Prepared!. if is your 1st time / day, be prepared to be overwelmed by the bartareing and lack of prices!Start low, have a bunter and a big smile!

An Experience not to be missed!. Endless streets of covered market stalls; all types of products for sale from spices, fruit, traditional cakes and 'sweets', leather products & every fossil you can imagine! Tolerate the endless sellers trying to get you to buy their goods! A must experience for anyone in Marrakech.
Get a guide. All I'll say is its a must during your visit, but get a guide. It's easy to get lost and not everyone "helping" is doing do with the usual Morrocan hospitality

Intimidating !!!!. The Moroccan people hassle you none stop and its annoying if you ever go here go in a group and you will not feel as bad The argon oil doesn't work neitherDon't get drawn in tontge so called herble shops with a man in a long white coat selling all kinds of herbal remedies as you will spendva lot of money on nothing

Wow an Aladdin's Cave of Goods!. A fantastic place to visit - don't be intimidated by the locals, they're generally very friendly and just trying to make a living! Bartering is simple and expected... Offer half what they ask, then work up to what you are prepared to pay... Don't hesitate to say no thanks, I have seen cheaper and walk away - the price will often drop! Ignore any kids or locals who try to say the road or alley ahead is closed - it's not, they're just going to offer to show you the way (and then expect 5-20 euros!). Just smile, say no thanks and keep on walking :-)
Fun fun fun. You could spend hours walking around the Souk looking at all the different stalls and tat to buy. Great fun haggling with the locals.

Worth a trip. If you respect them then they will do in turn. We took our two children 10 and 8 and they enjoyed it. They had fun haggling the prices and talking to the locals. A polite no is more than enough for them to top pestering you. We had lovely fresh orange juice.

Beautiful little winding streets, but a complete pain to visit!. Impossible to just look around and explore the cute shops. Extremely pushy shopkeepers, who overprice everything atleast 5-7 times. Constant nagging, people who want money to give you directions (And then take you even deeper in the souk so you land up buying something) Okay to visit once, just for the experience, but will not recommend!

Certainly an experience. If you want to have a good look around and an explanation of what's there you do need a guide. Ask your driver for advice on this, and pay about 150-200 in Moroccan currency. Also barter and don't be afraid to walk away if you don't get the price you want.

This Square Rocks....... Its reputation alone is enough to guarantee a crowd, especially after the sun goes down. Its organized chaos on a grand scale but definitely not to be missed. Between the snake charmers, the acrobats and the vendors, who could fail to have a great time?
Mr . Vibrant, and exciting market place, different atmosphere daytime to nighttime, if you want to avoid the hassle of kids trying to sell you stuff as you walk around then go daytime..

Lots of interesting stalls and sellers - if you want to buy, don't forget to haggle. The Souks of Marrakech are a must see of any visit to the city, and are a wonderful sight. Great to buy souvenirs from, however you have to remember to haggle! We managed to get a teapot from 800 dirhams down to just 200, and never feel pressured into buying anything.

Interesting experience. First time in Morocco and a very different experience. Exotic and different. Very touristy. Be prepared to have everyone want to welcome you into their shops. It gets old after a while and most of the shops end up selling the same stuff. negotiate hard on the prices. We started about 70% lower and settled nearer to 50%, sometimes even lower. Don't be afraid to walk away as the next shop will have the same stuff and more willing to sell. But still great to wonder all over the ally ways. The main market is more aggressive in terms of the food vendors wanting you to sit at their tables.

Amazing place. Amazing place, def a experience, but quiet in the day but come to life from 6pm onwards.Felt quite safe with kids, although did keep hold tight, you do get few beggers and wanna be guides so be firm with them.

Have fun while shopping. No other place in the world. Really fun while shopping. Sellers are friendly and smiling. Goods are unique and authentic. Everything is locally produced - leather goods, gifts, lamps, slippers, pillows. Furthermore, prices are great and you can get a great discount.

Paradise for shoppers & Marrakech lovers. The Marrakech souk is not just a paradise for shoppers, but for anyone who likes people, fun, photography, story telling. One can almost get lost in these souks ... everything is available from herbs, rugs, attire, baskets, ceramics, jewelry, dried fruit. It is an amazing place to visit. You are at liberty to bargain and to also enjoy a nice chat with one of the merchants. If you want to pick up a nice gift for a dear one or a soevenier, then this is the place to be.

Expect to get lost. A maze of alleyways. I used a GPS app on my phone which was helpful for telling me I was no longer walking in the direction I though I was. If you do get lost ask a shopkeeper rather than one of the young men standing around as thye will offer to show you the way and then want payment.Don't be afraid to let some of the shopkeepers explain things to you as you will learn a lot. Yes it is their way of trying to get you into their shop ... Do you know what this is... but as long a you are firm and friendly you don't have to buy anything. Maybe tomorrow is a good way to exit.There are lots of different trades which seem to congregate together, you never know what you might turn up with a bit of random wandering. Metal working, taning, dying, leatherwork

What an experience . Wow what can I say !! I found this an experience I will never forget , the town came alive with around 2000 people there , we stuck together You do get pestered quite a bit you have to stay strong to say no Pleased we experienced , you can pay for a guide also Taxi's easy to get to and from

Patience. Having been in Fes, Chefchaouen, Essaouira and Tangiers we had a reasonable understanding of the Souk situation.It is worth pointing out however that each are their own worthwhile adventure, and the merchandise varies. We found ourselves getting a lot from Marrakech Souk, because it was later in our travels and we wouldn't need to cart it around. Give yourself time to explore, you'll soon realise your eyes are where the focus is.We didn't endlessly explore each day, we took time out to find a cafe and sit down, take in further views and decide on where next or review the many photos. Snake charmers, henna girls, fruit/ nut vans are in the main square to enjoy.We also ventured at different times of day, the evening is busy in the square with music, side shows and great areas to select fresh meat to have cooked for your meal. You see this being setup in the latter part of the day.On our last day we purchased a chameleon for our Riad proprietor who had lost his last one (where can you do that). It was an amazing feeling to release her from a cage and see her moving to explore her orange tree....wow.

Enchanting Marrakech. When our bus dropped us off to walk to the square we were confronted with 2 rows of horse carriages queuing up for customers. It was a welcome sight but alas the stench was pungent and we practically ran through to the square. The Square looked exciting and there was something for everyone. Beware! The vendors, ranging from food stalls to exotic jewellery and mini targines, were a charming lot. Do bargain for a third of the price at least. I found an interesting French pastry stall in one of the alleys serving the best looking desserts. However, I was attracted to people watching in one of the cafe seats facing the square. It was amazing to soak up the atmosphere of Marrakech.

Madness. Loved the colours, sounds and smells (..most of them). Need some serious haggling skills and a good sense of direction. Felt some of the merchants are too pushy in trying to sell to you, in some cases blocking your path to tempt you in. Need to be very stern and hold your ground. All said and done a great experience with lots of hidden gems to stop, chill and escape the madness.

Not a fan of haggling.. If you go thwre you should have in mind what you want and how much you will like to pay for it..then you could end up with a barging if you haggle the vendor. Usually if they say something is 300 dirhams start with offerinf them 50 Dirhams and let them work you up! Not you them down!!

Not a fan of haggling.. If you go thwre you should have in mind what you want and how much you will like to pay for it..then you could end up with a barging if you haggle the vendor. Usually if they say something is 300 dirhams start with offerinf them 50 Dirhams and let them work you up! Not you them down!!

We Got Lost Inside. We got lost inside the Souk. They sell almost everything here. What you see in the movies are real. They sell carpets, beautiful lamps, knives, swords, clothes, antique things, jewelry, etc. If you are good in bargaining, you might just get the price you want. If you know a local here, the better. Don't buy argan oil inside the Souk. They sell it way too expensive here. Plus, sometimes they mix it with vegetable oil. If you want argan oil, buy it in a herb store outside the Souk. Take extra care of your things too. When you eat at a restaurant, if there's bread on the table, or beans, or something edible, don't touch it, it's not for free. You will be charged for that.Orange juice is freshly squeezed. They don't allow you to take photos of their shop not unless you buy something from there. Most of the locals are nice, and friendly.Do a research on what to wear there. I did mine. For the ladies, don't wear anything too revealing.

Shop till you drop. Wow.....I wish I had been warned that I would be split for choice in the souks, there is some amazing items there from stunning, silver berber jewellery to bright, funky felted slippers. I can't wait to go back.

Shopping Heaven!. An extraordinary experience which completes the visit to Marrakech. As with every other souk, there are stalls for all tastes, but unlike most souks, this is on a grand scale and no visit to Marrakech is complete without getting lost inside. By taking sensible precautions, I never felt unsafe or threatened, but the traders can on occasion be a little pushy. The motorbikes, trailers and donkey carts create a heady mix, you need your whits about you. Enjoy the bartering, it is great fun.

Awesome souk. Beautiful comprehensive souk. Must bargain but nor over the top,, they do get a bit peeved when u overdo it, but some things were really overpriced so the shopkeepers took offence at some of our offers, which were realistic

Plenty plenty and plenty to see. Too much to see and venture but not enough time. The souk comes alive in the evenings. Gets very crowded on weekends and public holidays. Beware of 'middle men' that wait outside the stores. .Tourist price is hugely inflated. Cant stand the idea of being rip-off.

Full of goodies you never knew you wanted until the sales-person saw you!. Leather goods are plentiful, although some are now made in China. Similar goods prevail at many stalls, prices are negotiable. Bargain! but bear in mind it is their living.The atmosphere can be overwhelming as it is mainly covered in. The shops are endless. Generally vendors are happy for you to look without hassle. It is part of the .Moroccan experience'

Great to look around but terribly overpriced. You can spend hours getting lost in this maze of colours, smells and sounds! What I'm sure was once a vibrant market is now a tourist trap selling made-in-China keyrings and over-priced pashmina scarves.. but none the less fun to explore. The sellers can be very pushy and try to charge ridiculous amounts, so be prepared to walk away with a polite smile. I'd recommend heading out of Marrakech during your stay in Morocco for a more authentic experience.

Wow, just wow!. Ever since reading the book Hideous Kinky I have longed to come to Marrakech, and was not disappointed. I enjoyed my daytime visits, however the buzz at night is like nowhere else I have ever been. Magical.

Morroco souks, not Asia or morrisons . Being a typical man I can honestly say shopping doesn't Realy rock my boat.BUT the souks and their settings and prices are fantastic.Real bargins can be found with just a little haggling.Just remember how much the item would cost at home-remember your in morroco and walk off in a strop/huff when the merchant thinks your an easy touch, when he follows you down the dark alleyways you know you will get your bargin.

Can't visit Marrakech and not visit a souk ..... There are a number of souks, some interlinking, others stand-alone. Some are very obviously tourist focused and others catering more to the local residents. The riad we were staying at, was off one of the passages that make up the Souk El Kessabine, which is a tourist focused souk, which leads off Jemaa El Fna square.
