We felt comfortable at all times when walking through the souk and although the stores shut down around 8>9pm, there is street lighting at night. Yes, vendors will try to draw you into their space, but a smile and a no thanks - or a complete blank if very persistent - works just fine. Be confident and determined and it will be respected.Don't enter into negotiation, if you have no intention of buying. Be firm if you are not interested in making a purchase. Know what you are prepared to pay and stick to your guns - be prepared to walk away if necessary. I have been haggling in Turkey for twenty odd years and the experience was really no different here. In my opinion, you can expect the final price to settle around two thirds of the vendor's initial price - a little less if you drive hard.Be aware of your belongings, just as you would be in crowded places in the UK - or anywhere else in the world if it comes to that. Don't accept anything offered as a gift, until it is established if there is to be a fee attached or if it is being offered as an addition to push the price up to a vendor preferred price and don't shake on a deal until it is clear what you are shaking on. There are bargains to be had and some lovely things to buy, just be definite on what you want and what you are willing to pay.Also beware of cyclists and mopeds in the souks - damn dangerous and strictly speaking, they shouldn't ride in the souks, but it isn't policed so it happens anyway. Really enjoyed the souks and by and large the vendors are friendly enough.

A maze of colours, sights and sounds. The Marrakech Souk is a real maze of hundreds of shops, alleyways even dead ends.Filled with an ambiance of colours, sights, sounds and smells.Although the more you look, you may also start to notice similarities within the many shops, styles and merchandise.Some may find this experience a bit claustrophobic especially the deeper within the market you seem to go.A few of our travel companions even commented it was an overwhelming and unpleasant encounter dealing with some of the proprietors, constant assertive sales tactics.This was mainly described by a few of the ladies within the tour.On the contrary to popular belief, or what some people may say, most of the sellers are not at all aggressive, only occasionally persistent.If you understand that this is their only lively-hood, but if you are not interested, they will leave you alone.We also found, that if people respected the vendors and politely declined, there was never an issue.
The Craziest Place in the World. Like attending five circuses at once. Snakes, monkeys, dancers, musicians, handlers, merchants.... the assault on your senses is undescribable. Watch your wallet!!!!

Different to anything in Europe. Different to anything you would have experienced in Europe or the UK. No fixed prices so haggle hard. You know you've got a good deal when the shopkeeper barely shakes your hand and doesn't smile at you when you leave

Wear good shoes and wear a backpack. This has been the highlight of my many travels. It was very clean, every night things are swept clean. The food was cooked fresh in front of us. We had some of the best fresh Orange juice ever. They still have the snake charmers and monkeys. It is crowded and you have to do a lot of walking but so worth it. Lots of places to stop and snack or get something to drink. Take your time shopping, not all prices are the same and you can make an offer. Look in the little small shops for treasures.

Shoppers paradise. Very varied market. Stallholders ask seriously inflated prices but can be haggled down to a reasonable level. Don't pay any attention to the price asked. .it bears no relation to the value of the item. Near the souk is a large square with snake charmers and people with animals and birds that you can pose with for photographs. Well worth a visit.

The experience itself rates a 5 but caveat emptor!. Amazing experience with everything they have and overall safe but you do need to understand you are an outsider and separating you from your money is a prime source of income.Our last evening, as their currency is not supposed to leave the country, I had just enough money left for a particular gift, a cab ride to the hotel then a morning cab ride to the airport.As I stopped to negotiate a knit cap for my niece, my wife was offered a "gift," a henna tattoo. I negotiated the purchase at the price I envisioned and prepared to leave but the henna lady then insisted on the equivalent of 40 euros for the henna tattoo. We told her "you said it was a gift," her answer was "I would normally charge 250 euros, for 40 euros, it is virtually a gift." The majority of the crowd (all local vendors) sided with her. As I saw a no-win situation for us, I gave her 10 euros (my cab fare to the hotel). The woman was still aggressive but placated enough so we could leave.We walked 2 km back to the hotel, my wife sporting her 10 euro henna tattoo.Watch out for these "gifts."

Intimidating, clousterphobic and noisy. We are a young couple (early 20s) and did not enjoy our experience in the souks. The locals and shop-owners were rude and annoying and we found it very intimidating to walk around. It was an overwhelming and unpleasant experience.

A mixed bag of experiences. Prior to visiting the souk I had read that you had better have a thick skin while visiting there. That may be the best advice I could give or receive. If you can easily shrug off their aggressive style of salesmanship you will find many good things here to experience and explore. Personally, I would have been much more inclined to purchase their goods and interact if the hassle would have been toned down a bit. I much preferred the Agadir souk to this one for that reason. Still, I believe the more you experience this souk, the more you will enjoy it as you adjust to what it is. I was cautious and conscious of pickpockets and consequently had no issues there.
Gr8 bargains. It offers everything you would want to shop for but have to bargain at each and every shop which does take a lot of your energy.. Great place to shop but need to be good in bargaining!!

Nice. Nice place. You can go and see. They sell every kind of goods. Sellers are very kind but you must negotiate. It is a real experience. We liked going there and walking. We never got lost! We always felt safe, only be careful of bicycles and scooter passing through!
Berberic!. if you are in Marrakesh you just can't miss it.I think some scenes of the 1st Indiana Jones film were filmed here.Great atmosphere ;great photos.Just take care with the pickpockets

Anything and everything. Our visit to the Souks in Marrakech could be described as overwhelming and exciting. There is so much available to buy and you could spend a couple days exploring every shop and section. It can be stressful if you don't like people urging you to look and buy and there can be pressure to come back and make promises. Be sure to know what prices should be before you go so that you can haggle accordingly. They do see "tourists" from a mile away.

Bustling, crowded and atmospheric. Always busy and avoid Friday if you prefer less crowds. Always barter for what you buy. If you don't like to see performing animals, walk around the edge of the square and keep your eyes averted. It's very atmospheric and colourful, not to be missed.

Authentic experience of a lifetime!. Wow -have to admit didn't do much research so found the whole experience amazing and real! To some up in a few words-colourful, hectic and hot!To stay in a group for safety is wise...allow bartering to take place but realise theses people are trying to make a living...the food wasn't as good as anticipated but the livelihood, people, goodies and people made up to it a hundredfold!

Be prepared for vendors. Lots of shops to stop & have a look, although not to look too long as the vendors will try to sell to you. Quite a number of shops although not as big as Fes. Enjoyable visit.

Look don't buy. It's an amazing array of different stalls, some very expensive others not. The little streets (kissariat) where stuff is being made are cheaper and more interesting. Don't let anyone guide you round_ unless you don't mind paying afterwards.
Just take care. Take care not to get lost in the Souk. Also look after your money. It is a fascinating place to visit. A must place to visit

Pretty amazing. I very much enjoyed seeing the Souk, I went with my family and they hate to shop so unfortunately every time I stopped to bargain with someone they yelled to hurry up. My advise don't go there with people who aren't interested!!!

Messi!. You definitely need to go there as an experience. Do NOT speak to anybody there. Have your belongings close to you! Do not follow anybody who tel you there is a good place to take pictures! All prices will be expensive! Deal with them and offer the lowest. If they say no walk away at the end they will sell it to you to the price you want! Just be very careful!
Go down south to the covered market. A nice experience, but not for long. Unless you are patient and can cope with all the attention otherwise it might be annoying.

CRAZY. What an amazing few hours spent trying to keep up with the tour guide as we tried our best to not lose sight of him in the maze of the souk. This is definitely an experience I would recommend to anyone, some beautiful things to be bartered over, best of luck if you can get them down otherwise hope you have the guide we had... did it for me...thanks very much.When you safely emerge from it's dingy depths there's only one thing crossed my mind... HOW DO THEY DO IT WITHOUT A ROAD MAP ?????

Do not drive through souk, Don't attempt that. First day of Morocco, we drove through a Souk, this even before we checked in a hotel, fortunately people were very helpful and helped us navigate through that narrow stretch and we were quite glad that we rented a small car! overall experience was anxious, nail baiting and nervous feeling on what shop keepers may think on us for driving through Souk and having to make their stuffs to be taken out to give us way...after finally coming out, I and my husband really really felt so relieved and whew!

Fascinating. This is where you can find hidden treasures for good prices when you haggle. It's colorful, interesting and I enjoyed their stalls and what they were offering. Of course they call you in but it's part of their salesmanship but they didn't pressure us to buy.Just make sure that you find your way back as it can be like a maze!

Colourful. A must visit, whether to shop or just look around. If you are easily bothered by people trying to make a living from tourists, don't bother going here. You will be hassled for business and haggling is a must. On the other hand, if you can haggle with a smile, you can meet some very interesting people and get some good bargains. It's about the experience and not just the goods. Even our kids loved it and were treated very well. For those who really want to explore, there are sections within the souk that offer different types of goods and also cater for locals.

Like buying a car. We found that most of the goods were imported from China and could be found in multiple souks. Also, the people were quite nasty. The whole process was like buying a car. Throw in the crowds, the scooters and the pollution and it was not good.

Never again!. Hated the experience! People are so nice, but in the end all they really want is your money and they totally rip you off! I hated that. I am NOT a haggler and I don't like the game! It turned me off Marrakesh! I also didn't feel like it was genuine. All too tourist trappy for my liking.A person who speaks French and likes the game of it all may enjoy it. A young traveller may think it's exotic. Maybe if I'd gone without my kids it might have been a better experience. It was interesting for the experience for a few hours and then that was enough - we didn't even buy anything because just felt so ripped off all the time everywhere!

Colourful, impressive, exotic, interesting. An experience you must not miss. Diferrent things from traditional nomad carpets to fragnances and spices of all kinds, argan, rose and almond oils, colourfull fabrics, traditional cafe and restaurants, shoes and bags, hammersmiths, carpenters, tailors and whatever else you can imagine, but the most interesting anon stop bargain.

Where to buy pottery in Marrakech. Hi all! After three days walking around looking for a colourful bowl and checking different prices, we found an awesome place on Riad Zitoun Lakdim towards the end of the street near Palais Badi (the only narrow street south of Jema El Fna). It's quite a big shop compared to the others so they have more to choose from and the prices are fixed, so they don't hassle you. We bought a bowl for 50 Dirahms. The same ones on the square were between 80-120 Dirahms.

Chaos!. I have been here a few times but I still can't find my way around the souk as it is so large - as with all souk's the downside is that you are constantly hassled by the sellers. But you can't come to Marrakech and not visit it.
Arabic delight. The souk seems never ending and has such an atmosphere you just cant take it all in. There is nothing you cant buy in the souk, and the place just goes on and on.

Good Bargains and experience but constant hassle. The souk is a good experience but you do get hassled constantly and haggling is compulsory otherwise you are going to get ripped off. You have to learn to say no and not make eye contact otherwise before you know it you will be wearing a fez, with a monkey sat on your shoulder and a cobra ready to pounce whilst tumbling in your wallet for 2000 dirhams for the memorable picture on your own mobile phone. If your hands aren't straight back in your pocket you will be sporting the most expensive henna tattoo known to man boarding the horse and cart to their family shop. Just have your wits about you and if you firmly say no thank you and walk on you will be fine. One tip, we ordered 5 drinks in a restaurant without asking the price and was billed 100 dirhams £7ish. I went to another restaurant the following day and asked for the price before ordering and was quoted 30 dirhams so paid 50 dirhams leaving 20 dirhams tip.

Exactly what you imagine. We went to the souk most days we were in marrakech , and it was brilliant. A little dirty and annoying Moroccans but its part of what you go to morocco for. You can have a laugh with most of them. Fantastic items being sold at good prices just don't be afraid to barter or say no and walk on.
all Marrakech becomes souks. i've visited many places and i think that all marrakech old city will become a big souk , also we have to walk a lot to see more and more .
Great shops and lots of them for you shoppers. Overwhelming shops with fabulous people and many things to purchase. Spent hours in the souks and loved it

Just like every other Souk. If you haven't been to a souk before then I would recommend you visit this souk, e is nothing special to see here. They have all the same handicrafts as every souk I have ever been to and all the same vendors hassling you to come into their store or buy from them on the street. Be aware that you will be asked (demanded) money if you take photos of the water walkers, snake charmers or Monkey handlers.

Must see, you need to know how to handle locals though. Pretty stressful for most, everyone shoves stuff in your face to sell it, but unique and fun. 5 years ago they had decided to "tame" locals a bit, I feel it's changed back to how it used to be. Even looking at a shop gets you harassed, you'll get tons of sexual offers. Exciting and annoying at the same time.
So much bustle and life. A really alive place with very courteous vendors who are friendly but not irritating. Some lovely memories of Marrakech
Morocco art and artisans on show. A Tourist mecca of Moroccan Goods. Goods cover all the traditional work of morocco from leather, to wood, to carpets, and paintings, traditional jalabers.
Souk. Prepare to be ripped off and do your best to bargain.Set a price in your head that you want to pay and don't go above it.
A definite must!. This is one must get lost and wander through the labyrinth of the Medina, searching for the ideal souvenirs. Check the prices about before buying!

Be prepared for the worst. Not long after entering the souk, a shop owner insisted me and my boyfriend enter his shop and have a look at his leather goods. Just when he started touching me all over. Struggled to escape. We got a chance to look at his phone and it was full of tourists pictures (female only). Lost all interest in exploring after.

Oh my god you need a compass. this place is huge,the streets inside are very narrow and you take you life in your hands wandering about, the place is a rabbit warren and you can easily get lost, you need your wits about you as you are constantly dodging small mopeds, motorbikes, hand carts and donkeys which are \all allowed free reign, it's a constant barrage of sights and smells, some wonderful and some not. beware of the food for sale as it would not pass any food hygiene tests but if you have a cast iron stomach they are very tempting.Having said that it was an experience I'm glad we visited.
A Must. You should take a lot of hours and do stops in between walking though this labyrinth. Every day you get better and you find your way to the huge square el Fna without asking for help

nice but over whelming. the souk is a nice place to come and look for all sorts of stuff IF you dont look like a tourist and you can speak arabic otherwise youll get hustled.pretty much anything can be found in the souk at all different levels of quality and price and the people are generally friendly and will point you to who will have stuff if they dont
Bartering bartering bartering . If you'd like to barter then this place is a deal for you to take your family and have some fun start at 250 normal rule pay 40.

Most charming experience of my life!. Full disclosure, I'm a history and art lover and this place is the perfect combination of both! - The souk is a street market that has everything from spices, textiles, art, traditional clothing, rugs, lamps, jewelry... I was over the moon happy. Tip: Get a local to walk you around the streets, it gets crowded and confusing if you don't know your way. It is helpful to know french as the population speaks little english.

Get lost and enjoy yourself!. Getting lost in the souks is all part of soaking up Marrakech. Be prepared to haggle your way up from around 1/4 of any asking price. Hunt hard enough and you can find real gems, but be wary of fakes especially stones and saffron. We enjoyed roaming up and down the alleyways, drinking in the smells of leather and amber, trying mint tea from vendors and shopping for jewellery.

Must Go, Must See, Must Shop. A local sight to behold full of beautiful sights, sounds and goods waiting to be bought. The experiencing the shops full of rugs, middle-eastern dresses, lamps, spices, and oils. If you have a guide, it is handy to help with the haggling. I bought a rug, I couldn't resist.

Easy to get lost but easy to get out again. I was determined to find the dyers souk where wool is dyed using natural colourings then hung out to dry on the rooftops. I had some general directions but once you are inside the narrow passageways they all seem to look the same. If you ask a local they will be keen to show you the way but then they want payment. Anyway I had no option but to hook up with my unappointed guide and he led me past stalls selling carpets, tagines, lanterns teapots and many other exotic products. Dodging between donkeys pulling carts, scooters and cycles we finally arrived at the wool souk where I was given a demonstration of the dying process and then draped in pashminas supposedly made from the dyed wool. I was doubtful of this as I had seen the same pashminas for sale in India. Anyway I avoided buying any to add to my already large collection and made my escape. I would have liked to have seen the tannery but not wanting another guide I decided not to bother. There a what seems like hundreds of stalls but after a while you realise they are all selling similar goods. I bought some pretty pottery dishes but I could probably have bough the same thing at home for less.

BEWARE. Just want to warn others about the little ploy the people use (the young and the older generation)in the souks?Our experience was, we were looking at a map to find the Yves Saint Laurant gardens when we were approached by a man around 50years old who said he worked at our hotel and asked where we was headed,us thinking what a nice person. He advised us that it would be better to go at midday because it very busy with coaches doing tours in the morning. He then advised us the go into a more government regulated part of the Medina. We walked with him and then bump into his "friend" who just happened to be going our way.  We were shown into a rug shop where we were duped again and bought what we thought was a fair price for a rug.  We carried on with our morning and went to the gardens as planned,a must see place.  Then back to the souks again in the afternoon. Came out of the Ben Youssef and was spoken to by a young lad of about 20 years old who told us about the tanneries,still unaware by their little ploy,who then shouted to another lad who happened to be going that way.He was insistent that he was not a guide!!We followed him till we got to the tanneries. We went in but the smell was horrendous,even with the mint we were given to mask the smell. We told the owner we was leaving because my partner began to feel sick. At this point he told we had to finish the tour with the young lad. It was also at this point we had realised we had be duped in the morning as well.  He then followed us around the narrow streets for about 10 minutes making my partner very nervous and ruining the rest of our day. When he stopped another lad became noticeable. We managed to find the main square again and left The Medina.  We had paid about £60 for the rug which later we seen very similar for £30 in the Complexe artisanal which is situated very near The Medina. I had read so much about the souks and their little ploys to get you but they were so convincing and pleasant you get sucked in. On the whole it was a good experience but you can get very disoriented because of the many little alleys and streets. Always walk on the right and the mopeds do not care!!!!Also when you enter the entrance just past the Complexe artisanal you will pass all the horse and carriages,take heed it smells really really bad.  Andy
Over hyped. You wont get out of this place without someone harassing the hell out of you. Try not to make eye contact with any sellers.Not just that, everything that they have to sell is total junk.

BARGAIN HARD. Like most souks, the Marrakech Souk's items for sale do not include price tags or labels. The only way to know a price is to ask — and then you'll be told a price that, depending upon the vendor's assessment of your wealth, will be between 2x and 10x the price that the item actually should be. Bargain hard.
Office Tour guides. Dont go with an official tour guide - they get you into carpet, perfume shops to get their own commission and its hard to get out!
Good shopping but hard bargaining. It becomes tiring bargaining in the souk but you can pick up some real bargains and souvenirs. A must to to take home a taste or Morocco.

Take time to find the areas where the artisans make the work!. I had always looked forward to seeing and experiencing the souk. It is an amazing place but it is very easy just to look at the shops and get carried away haggling on silly pieces you can find anywhere. A lot is so overpriced that too much time is spent try to get it down to a reasonable price. The real gem of the souk is to see the makers at work, the tanners, the metal workers, etc etc. and just people watching, there are also some great food stalls. The carpets in the most are overpriced and poor quality compared to other places. The people are lovely to talk to if you take time. Also women Please please cover up. I met so many women who despite having been to Morocco several times still insisted on wearing vests (sometimes tight) with little to imagination and then wondered why they were hissed at or hassled (some even put it down to part of the culture and accepted it) HELLO.. Nevertheless is a great experience and place with lots to offer. A word of warning, check your change, do not flash the cash (obvious) and remember after dark when the souk shuts down it is a very different place and just looks like lots of dark alleyways easy to get lost in. You will end up being offered 'helpful' directions that sometimes lead to 'cousins' restaurants or nowhere near where you want to go. Enjoy

Fascinating & a bit intimidating. I really loved it in the Souk - I could immerse myself in all the atmosphere and activity - 'the buzz' it is incessant - dodging motorcycles - pedestrians - mopeds - bicycles down very narrow paths with no sight lines or buildings on which to base your navigation. The multiplicity of trades, and very effective recycling of materials, being practiced in small alcoves is truly amazing - I would have stayed and chatted with so many people about what they were making as it was fascinating. Only trouble is if you talk to anyone they mostly then want money - and give you directions to the big square (that you are trying to avoid!)

love it!. Despite people warning me that sellers are very pushy and aggressive, i didn't find this at. A simple 'hello' or 'maybe later' was enough to keep everyone happy and i didn't encounter any pushy sellers. You do have to haggle though!

Be Perpaired to haggle . Visiting the Souk during the day or night is an experience never to forget.Amazing stalls selling everything to fake designer clothing and bags to local crafts.always haggle otherwise you will be ripped off. We had it down to a tee . The price they started with we went to a 1/4 of the price and worked half way. Night food court in the square was amazing. The wife was hesitant and wanted to go to a restaurant. But I persuaded her to try it and it was an experience. Great food. Good price.

Madness and mayhem - enjoy every moment. This is the place to go to experience the chaos that is Marrakech. Vendors speaking in many languages and doing everything they can to get you into their shops "just for a look". Be wary, though charming a thick skin is required to get what you need or away. Everyone will offer their own tips but for me, 1/3 of the asking price is the MAXIMUM you should ever pay. I bought everything I wanted for less but it can be an exhausting task. Despite that, the people are lovely and getting lost in the souks is half the fun. Be wary of fake and counterfeit goods (such as fake saffron and carpets) - do your research before entering the souks for such items.

At times intimidating. The souk in Marrakesh is an impressive myriad of small streets and dozens of businesses. You can find plenty of articles NOT made in China. Haggling is of course part of the experience and that is fine and can be fun. What is not fine is the young men trying to give you directions for money and at times even being intimidating when you refuse to give you money for the directions (that usually are wrong, so that they can make even more money) that will eventually get you out of the Souk. Recommendation: buy a local SIM card, download the maps and be prepared to say no. The Souk experience is definitely worthwhile, but beware of deceitful (and intimidating) young men who cross your path.

A must do... despite the hassle. It wouldn't be right to come to Marrakech and not visit the souks. Getting lost and frustrated, whilst bargaining hard for things is all part of the experience. Once you've visited once it gets easier.

Amazing, neverending. This has to be particular to Marrakech - Winding narrow streets with markets and shops all around, the noise and smells are exceptional, it is quite an interesting experience just walking around and looking at different artisans and shop-keepers - everyone would want you to look at their shops and goods, if you're not interested in buying anything, don't look! we loved it, we got lost in it but you can find your way back with one of the main known places such as Jemaa El Fna - brilliant and unique Experience!!!! MUST VISIT!

A must upon a visit to Marrakech. A must see upon any visit to Marrakech. Can be easily to get lost with all the alleys although always work your way back to the main mosque. Like with any market you can get hassled by the stall owners but be firm and say no and you'll be fine. Don't follow local guides.
The souks. The souks are a great place for shopping! But if you're more of a shy and antisocial type of buyer, than go for the fix price shops.

Lively. It's an amazing place with all the hustle and bustle you might expect from a busy market. Items are nice, some of them made of a good quality, some not... Ensure you don't accept the first price they give you and haggle over the price (ask for at least a thrid!) . The con?? Like always... too stressful as sellers are a bit pushy, specially if you're a solo travel and a woman!! (one seller tried to touch my bottom while taking a picture). I just ignored them and try to pretend I couldn't speak Spanish, English or French, otherwise they won't let you go.

Cheaper and more variety than jema el fina. Unlike jema el fina you will not gets swamped by many people including children begging, people offering to show you around for a fee,monkey owners wanting pictures for money. The indoor souks are more cheap than the main square even though they sell the exact same stuff e.g handbags, wallets, clothing ect. However same rule applys only pay 70% of asking price. P.s try not to go in dead ends try to stay where there are peaple about.

Carpets, spice and all things nice. Not to be. missed! The carpet 'shop' is in an amazing building that was a hareem. Now its several rooms filled with carpets. Sample the mint tea and buy a carpet. We did!

A warren of stalls, expect haggling and harassment.. This place is mental, stalls everywhere, colours, sounds, it's great. You just want to stop, stare and take it all in, but that's the problem, you can't give anything more that a passing glance or your being bothered. There is no help or advise only the relentless pursuit to sell, sell, sell. There is a lot of tat, and a lot of the stalls are the same. That doesn't take away from the fact this place has to be seen to be believed.

Wow!. The souks are unbelievable. Totally different to anything you would have experienced in Europe or the UK. No fixed prices so haggle hard. You know you've got a good deal when the shopkeeper barely shakes your hand and doesn't smile at you when you leave. Many of the shops sell similar things so don't be too worried if you can't get the item you want for the price you're prepared to pay for. Another seller somewhere down the line may be able to do it. At night, the souks are even busier as there are more food sellers and the locals also make their way through the souks. Watch out for donkeys and carts and people on mopeds - stick to the right. I read many reviews where people said that the vendors could be quite rude and aggressive but we didn't experience that at all.
Good for improving your bartering skills. a must go and see place, will help improve your bartering skills, ensure you do not accept the first prices that is offered to you, start as low as possible

Interesting and a little stressful though. Had the pleasure of popping round these very interesting places but to be honest. ..very glad we had a guide.I remember being hassled in Egypt many years ago and it's much the same hear. Being pulled into shops and having everything under being attempted to be sold to us was and could be stressful without a guide. Was very upset about an Art Gallery we were ushered into that displayed huge ornate vases about 4 feet tall decorated in Ivory. These were newly made and clearly assisting the demise of the poor African elephant. Wasn't happy. Great experience though and we had fun in the square with some silly fun things like fishing with coke bottles and tasting some of the street food delicacies.

can be hard work. Don't do this on your first day. My advice is have a good breakfast, wear comfortable shoes, get ready to bargain and don't lift anything up unless you are at least mildly interested in buying it :). You're in Marrakech so it has to be done....

good to wonder round and get lost in ...but. - but many many stalls all selling the same thing (slippers, cheap leather, metalwork - all made for tourists). Of course, be prepared to haggle! You will get hassled..alot! You will also get approached by men saying you are going to wrong way (that way is closed, only Muslims this way etc)..they then expect you to pay them to take you back to the main square. Don't fall for it! We saw several poor couples that did, who ended up paying theses "guides". If you want to do the souks, really be prepared to get lost several times - take a bottle of water with you - but there are plenty of places to stop and have a drink / food.

All the same. It is very narrow. And busy. People are bothering you. No interesting Stuff to buy. There are several areas you Can attend. But experience the crowd, smell, and people. You may like this

Exciting, but can get disturbing, too. The souks are exciting, but can get disturbing, too. Plenty of different goods, sellers trying to convince you to buy just their stuff. From time to time torrents of people, sometimes you get lost and are suddenly alone. Some of the goods is really nice, another not really. Some of the sellers do impose, another are decent. On the other hand you know they have to make their living and you are there to contribute, otherwise you would not be there. If you feel you would be unable to resist on your own, just take an official guide and agree in advance, what you would like to see and buy.

A must do!. Strolling around the Souks is not to be missed when traveling to Marrakech! Great experience!Prepare to bargain with the shopkeepers and keep your wits about you.We navigated perfectly by ourselves without a guide with a little help from Google maps. The souk was one of my favorite experiences in Marrakech.

Interesting but overwhelming for tourists. It was an interesting place. Local food, drink, spice, perfume and lots more. But the shoppers are pressuring tourists to buy, everyone asks for money when seeing a phone/camera facing them, beggars and a lot more that a visitor might not be comfortable with. We tried henna tattoos unfortunately was very fade and only lasted two days. We tried a food stall in the evening and later discovered that a couple of stuff they gave us were from other stalls, but price had been doubled. Only went there once and wouldn't go back again even we are to visit Marrakech again. If you enjoy haggle and are not afraid of being hustled, it could be a place for you.

What should have been a memorable trip was totally spoilt by harassment from locals. My daughter and I arrived at the Soukh in a taxi and walked into the square. Within a few minutes we were being invited to have our hands painted with henna. My daughter was pulled away from me as a woman started painting on her hand, without any permission. This turned into a nasty and intimidating experience as other women appeared and made it difficult for us to leave. They then demanded a lot of money for the work, which I refused. I paid them what I thought was fair and they became aggressive and nasty. This completely spoiled our visit and my daughter was completely put off the shopping experience in Marrakech. Be warned.

Unfriendly, commercial, no respect for tourists. I had a good time in marrakech but the Souk was really nothing special. Nothing authentic and over priced. Everything is FAKE. And if you want to go on your own through the less touristic alleys you will be bothered when u not want it and when u need advice they will point out the wrong direction deliberately. Not all of them of course but many.

A week in Marrakesh. There is plenty to do here and it is possible to walk to most attractions though the taxis and calech are not expensive . Bargaining in the Souk is essential and start with a third of the asking price being prepared to come up to %50 depending on how much the item appeals. Easy to get lost and found again but these days the motorbikes and mopeds racing through the narrow cobbled streets are a perfect menace. Until someone is seriously injured it is difficult to see this culture changing as they have no regard for human life and it is the only real downside to visiting this fascinating city.Restaurants are plentiful but be selective - those in the square are variable but the Taj is OK as is the Italian Bistro bar, both with great views from their uppermost terraces.Don't agree to be shown anywhere as they get stroppy at the end of it wanting more money.A week may be too long but one is never bored when there is so much to experience.

Mayhem . My advice is stick to the square, dont get lost as we did and have locals trying two lure you away to somewhere. Strongly advise getting an offline map on your phone that has walking direction as this place is huge and you can be lost in no time. The big square is where everything seems to stem from and the alleyways shoot everywhere. Some really good bargains to be had but there on a lot of rubbish on sale. You will get pestered at every stall and after a while it gets really annoying, everyone is after your money. The square has quite a lot of entertainment Inc monkeys, snake charmers acrobats and other things. Food is available all over and in the evening there are literally hundreds of of street stalls cooking in the square. As yet we haven't sampled any but there are a lot or people eating there so I'm guessing it's pretty safe to sample the food. I'll be doing it later in the week. I cannot stress enough about keeping your whits about you and not walking of with anyone offering guidance, they will tell you, not that way, it's closed and dead etc but trust your sat nav and follow it, as it works very well. My experience was one of very busy, all they want is your money and it stressed me out a little as i wanted to just wander and soak up the culture and atmosphere. I will go back later in the week but with a very different attitude as i had the first time. All in all a very eye opening cultural experience not to be missed.

This place is fun - enjoy it.. On a family visit, we went to the souk. I decided to treat it as a bit of fun - those working there are up for a bit of a laugh. They respond well to some friendly banter, in best French. I regarded it not as a 'shopping experience' but somewhere to go before lunch.

The real Moroccan experience. This is the typical medina you would see in a hollywood movie. Its bustling with activity, colors and shops. I suggest a guide who can help you navigate the medina and allow you to browse with peace of mind. The suggested fee is 100-200 dirhams for 2-3 hours. If you're unsure, there is a tourist police office at the medina. Go in there and ask them to help you with a official guide and they will find one for you.Bargain hard in the medina - i would suggest starting at 40% of the stated price and then making your way up.
A Labyrinth. Plenty of guides will show ýou out of the souks, but don't pay up intil you réeally kno where yoy are, DAM 10 is more than OK, athough thy will claim DAM20 for 3 mins of "hard labour".

Discover the culture of Marrakech. We went there on a sunny morning, it was packed with people and tourists. My mother wanted to get some traditional gifts for my grandmother. After looking around, she ended up getting her henna and traditional Moroccan foot wear also known as belgha in arabic. It's a really good place to go to if you want to discover the Moroccan traditional products, to get yourself Moroccan souvenirs or to get your friends and family unique gifts. The people are very friendly and sold us the best products they have.

If you haven't been to the souk you havn't been to Marrakech. It's crazy, it's busy, it's full of colour and smells (and not all of them pleasant). Touristolice are now controlling the olace to make sure visitors are not hassled too much. It has calmed down since I have last visited in 2011. You can get some real bargains and have fun and banted with the stall owners. Don't be afraid to get lost or taken advantage off and you will have a great time. Lots of areas are now being renovated and the whole souk is dotted with little cafes and tea shops where you can relax and watch the world go by.

Lot of stuff to see, very chaotic.. Lot of people hustling you. If you are not interested in buying, dont stare, just keep walking. Otherwise, use your bargain skills and ask for 30-40% of their price and choose to walk away if they say no.

Frantic activity. Be prepared to be very patient and spend a lot of time here. The Souks cover a large area, and it is very easy to get lost, so take a bearing from some outside landmark that you can work towards from any laneway or access point of the square. Also it take some time to get used to the continual frantic activity, and approaches from various traders. Be prepared to "haggle" with most items as they inflate their prices to take advantage of us "rich western tourists". Be particularly careful of pick-pockets and bag snatchers. DO NOT FLASH WADS OF CASH AROUND. Enjoy the sights and smells as well as the local foods in the cafes that surround the square.

The heart of Marrakeck. Don't be afraid to walk and loose your way into the little streets of the soukes of Marrakech ! It's noisy, crowded, but so full of life ! Don't hesitate to talk with the sellers and negociate and bargain, and if it doesn't work go to the next shop ! (every price they give you, can be divided by two !)

Disappointing . Sadly the people working in the souk have resorted to harassing making what should be an enjoyable trip awful at times. They have cottoned on to travel advice telling tourists not to allow people to "show you how to get somewhere" in the souk as this usually ends with payment. Now they offer to lead you for free but you only end up paying them via any commission that is added onto prices you pay at shops. Some offer false advice too. One gentleman said he was going to show us a Berber market with traditional work being showcased, he spoke very clearly to my husband about football and when asked how far away this place was from the Djemma el Fna (as we had a bus to catch back to our hotel) he kept saying 4mins. What he led us to was a tannery, a place we had no intention of visiting, there was no work on show and it took us a good 40mins to make our way out subsequently missing the bus and the second later bus to end up paying 100 dirhams for a taxi back to the hotel. It's sad as there are some real gems you can find the further you venture into the souk but so many people are not honest with help for directions, best to avoid straying too far from the entrances and stay where you can see other tourists. Prices have also rocketed by more 3 times what I paid 2yrs ago (I purchased a suede bag for 100 dirhams 2yrs ago and an identical one was now going for 400 dirhams with the gentleman originally asking for 1,000 dirhams.) Go in at 20% of their asking price and never pay more than 50% to avoid being overcharged. There's a lot of tourist tat on sale here so if you want something unique, best avoiding here as you'll pass hundreds of shops and waste a lot of time.

Chaotic but with undeniable character.. It's a treat to all the senses. It's real and it's Marrakech! The Medina holds the magic tourist are looking for without a doubt. You must quickly learn the traffic patterns around it, filled yourself with curiosity and be ready to smile a lot while saying no thank you. Everyone wants your business but you must be cautious. That said, I couldn't get enough of it. Sit at various tea houses within the walls and people watch to your hearts desire. It's fantastic!
Amazing. The spices were incredibly delightful. People were very warm . Everyone demonstrated great hospitality.
Filmset . The souks are an amazing rabbit Warren of sights sounds and aromas. Surrender to the topsy turvy routes and make sure you get lost as it adds to the fun

Amazing. The Souk can be a little confusing as there a myriad of alleys and streets. It's noisy and there is such a variety of goods on sale. It's best not to point or touch an item or the vendor will be at your side immediately. Be assured that you will get lost but that's part of the experience.

It is like being in a movie!!!. One of the places you shouldn't miss!! So beautiful with all the colours and smells of leather, spices, perfums and delicacies, you will feel like you could lose yourself there for hours and you will! I recommend you join a tour or hire a private guide like we did as it is so easy to get lost in this beautiful labyrinth and be ready to haggle prices without offending them, always smile and be polite when trying to buy something , if you think it is overpriced kindly refuse. Have it in your mind that there are two prices, the tourist prices and the locals prices!But you will find the most beautiful things there!

To experience in Marrakech. Numerous small stall selling various items. Must bargain vigorously. Prices on certain items can reduce drastically as you walk away. Interesting sites, sounds, tastes and people. Try targine, a dish of. Morroco cooked in a traditional clay pot. Also many eating stalls .

Great shopping in a safe and friendly part of the city. This is a great place to shop if you like this sort of thing. Narrow streets with sellers and small shops of all kinds. If you find something you like, buy it as chances are you will never find it again!

Fantastic choice, everything you want... and more!. We had several trips to the souks, knowing exactly what we wanted. It is colourful, a bit smelly but the floor is now paved, which makes it easy to walk, obviously you get called but if you know what you want and are not afraid of haggling... it is a great place to find amazing presents for yourself and everybody!

OK.....!. If you have never experienced a place where there's plenty on offer, although you will see multiple versions of the same item in lots of different stores....then do take a look. Its something different. If you have been to Turkey and been to the Istanbul markets which have a lot of character then these souks might be slightly disappointing, however still worth a look.

A Must to See...if visiting Marrakech. If you travel to Marrakech, the trip would not be complete without a trip to the souk. Enter via Jemaa el Fna and lose yourself in the labyrinth of covered streets and side alley ways.I have always found the souk to be a relatively safe place to visit and have never felt threatened. Bit do keep your wits about you and keep valuables and money concealed and secure.If you are looking to but be prepared to barter...its not fun if you do not. Never ever pay the opening price...you can expect to haggle then shop owners down to at least a 1/3rd of the opening price. Also be prepared to walk away if the price is not right for you. Only recommendation I would make is be firm but polite.The souk is made up of numerous different zones, with each zones specialising in a different craft or goods. So move about and explore the different areas and linger at the ones you like.The souk can be a little overwhelming to the faint hearted so I would suggest you go a few times during your stay...maybe at different times of the day and keep the visits relatively short. It can become very tiring and draining to keep telling people you don't want to buy their goods.It is a great place to go also even if you do not want to buy anything. I go for the photography opportunities but make sure you ask before taking pictures, some shop owners clearly do not like their pictures being taken but are happy for you to take a picture of their stall/shop.

the sights and smells are intoxicating. do try the various foods being cooked in the street. they are usually very cheap and a try.there is one street where they roast a lamb and you can have some in a roll.
too many guides. stay away as the shopping is poor and the people are very pushy with a maze of busy streets with mopeds, donkeys and undersiables
Always fun. Just go and get lost inside. More to see and buy than you can fathom. Worth a half day. Instead of worrying about real prices, decide what you'd be happy to pay.

Intimidating approaches from lots of people. We were pounced upon by endless people who were difficult to shake off. One self appointed guide would not take no for an answer until another (somewhat better self appointed guide) helped get rid of him. I had to run away from people bringing live snakes to me! We managed to get shown two interesting coops in the Souk to buy a couple of things we actually wanted, but the low tourist numbers in December meant people there were pretty desperate and it meant we didn't want to hang around the Souk or visit it again because of it. We are not people who are normally easily intimidated!

everything in one. Yes that's right , Jamaa el Fna is the most central place where everything take place .Shops , bazaars , food , drinks , friends , people all over the world , music , cultural and Maroccian style . Everything in one

Great market . Blew my mind, awesome place for shopping and lots of entertainment. If you are wanting to buy anything ask the price and then divid by 3. You can walk away if you aren't happy, the people are very pushy but be strong and you will get a good deal.

Great experience in Morocco! . Fun to see and experience! The smells, the colors, the sounds reminded us that we were completely away from home! Enjoyed seeing all the colors. Be warned though, you will pay more here than in other parts of Morocco but this souk seemed easier to navigate that most.

Bargain bargain bargain . We visited the souk for the experience of course. I personally enjoyed the sport of bargaining and that's how I treated it. However my girlfriend hated it. Just try to have fun with it, look and chat. Don't let yourself be intimidated though. Our rule was to only bargain for something we really wanted. But I do think if you do buy anything however good you can bargain, you have paid to much. Eg we wanted some tea, the guy said 60d, we said 20d and he laughed us off saying it was way too cheap. But we found the same tea in a small local shop 15d, with no bargaining.

A mixed experience. On the one hand, there are some good deals to be had in the souks--if you're good at haggling. My partner would often counteroffer with a third or less of the initial offer and work from there. I hated all the hassling, especially when, after I'd turned down a place, I was occasionally taunted with mimicking of my voice or slightly rude remarks. Advice: don't point at or pick up something unless you're really interested.

A must to visit. Better to go with a guide from hotel, but get a price 1st, The guide will take you to the cheap and tacky items whats for sale 1st, then medium made then the best quality, but still you have to barter with prices. You cant take photos of the butcher shops, as they dnt like or the bakers , you can see how they make but you cant take pictures, I got told off :(, they really don't hassal you into buying, I found it quite pleasant. Stopping off at the spices, and when I had something in mind what i wanted to buy, our guide Miko went out of his way to find for me. Its a place you cant go on your own as its like a maze.

Overwhelming. Around the marketsquare lots of colour, deeper into the souk less colour and more odeur. Never a dull moment. Beware of the youth on mopeds. They use the small streets as racingcircuit. Skills!!

A must see on a visit to Marrakech. It is not possible to visit Marrakech without a visit to the souk and Jemaa el Fna, you truly must experience this at least once in your lifetime, especially Jemaa el Fna in the evening. Be aware of pickpockets and vendors who will try to charge you too much for items. We found some of the quailty of the items being sold in the square to be subpar compared to items in actual shops. Buyer Beware. The entertainment experience is wonderful, but be prepared to give tips if you stand and watch, especially so if you take pictures or video.
You must be resiliant!. Great Souk/Medina...but be highly prepared to bargain and endless hassling.......Hard to "re-find" places...I found the best shops were those near the Ben Youssef.

You will need time to negotiate prices. As part of the Arab culture, they all love to negotiate the prices of the items they sell, so they will always ask you at least 3 times more than the price they are prepared to take, so you will need time for that, is part of the trip... but if you are not patient don't bother going there...

Do not buy anything spice from Herboriste du Paradis. I was in Morocco this fall, Our tour guidance took us to a spice store in Marrakech. The store is in Place Ben Youssef, in Marrakech and it is called Herboriste du Paradis.The tour guidance told us the store has good reputations so I foolishly trusted his word.I told the store owner that I wanted Moroccan spice for Tarjine. So he opend a sample bottle and let me smell the aroma. It smelled wonderful. He told me it is a specail spice containing blend of 35 spices. the aroma smells so good, so I bought 50 US dollars worth of spice, it came in a very small sealed pouche. very expensive given the samll quantity and expensive price. When I came back to my home in the US, I could not wait to open the spice and use it for my targin. But when I opened the spice bag, it has a terriable smell of only tumeric, the guy has fooled me and did a magic. I talked to some Moroccan friends, and they told me I was fooled. They told me this is a thousand year old trick, get the customer see one thing and give them an another! the magic switch.Please do not go to this store, it was a set up between the tour guide and the owner to fool people. I hate to even wirte this reivew because I do not want to give this store publicity, but I want all innoccent people know about this terriable expereince. it put a very bad taste in my mouth, no pun intended. it is not the money I lost, but the deception that makes me angry and sick to my stomach.

Dangerous snake charmers. Well, where to start...I stayed in Casablanca and wanted to see the market here -some said it is cheaper than Casablanca. Wrong! Prices are usually double as compared to Casablanca and if you want to buy leather products, Casa also has a wider selection-beside the much lower prices. The snake charmers at the forecourt...if you go there to take pictures, they would approach you for some money. If you don`t give them and try to keep taking pictures, they get agressive! Own experience...so be careful! The souk-the market-itself is a real maze. We had a personal guide to walk us through the alleys. People don`t really speak english-french or arabic.

i was huge. What an interesting place it is so huge in area, there is lots to see as the evening approaches it gets more livley. With the snake charmers and the food stales. lots to see and buy and eat good [place to be.

Interesting. Interesting experience. It was very busy and I managed to get lost in the market streets however it was an experience!DosHaggle haggle haggle!Look at the spices stalls and the inscent stalls they do some lovely scented amathyst and amber rocks as well as perfumes! Cover up a little. More out of respect than anything although wearing a little less will draw attention to you. Be weary of the henna ladies! They will grab you and they do work fast before you know it your a walking peice of henna art! Check out the prices in the fixed price market by the medina gardens a ten minute walk from the souks but it will help to know prices before you haggle.Dont Wear sandles you will trip or get your feet stood on! And dont do what I did and wonder too far in. It seemed a good idea to keeo the mosque in sight but as big as it is I lost that too.

It's a must . Enjoy the trip!!! It's a crazy place busting with life.. Me and my girlfriend spent the day in the souks and loved it we enjoy the buzz and the traders were food sport. Grab a bargain and haggle hard!

Jemaa el Fna. As a solo traveller it was an experience of course, but if you want high energy, music, food, life, cultures then this is a fab place, but stay close to people you can trust and dont speak to those you become acquainted with for too long......

The Marrakesh Souk. Kick back, get lost and enjoy this. Dont worry about everyone trying to sell you things just be polite and move on. If its your first visit you might "acquire" a guide, they can actually help you find your way around and help to fend off unwanted approaches. At the end they will expect a tip and to be fair €5 (suggested tip) for a guided tour of the Souk and the information it provides is well worth it.

Wonderful sight!. I didn't buy anything and so really wasn't bothered by the stall holders. It seemed a lot quiter than I was expecting, but we went in the morning and I understand it's a lot busier at night.

So much fun!. The square by day is busy but it's better by night. Avoid the snake charmers who are anything but charming and the people dragging sorry looking monkeys around with disposable nappies on them and head into the maze of little streets. There are streets that specialise in fabrics, some full ow woodworkers and others with metalworkers. The variety is amazing but it is easy to get lost. Take note of the position of the sun in the square and look up to orientate yourself. If you do get lost, there are always lots of children willing to guide you back to the square for a few dirham. Don't be tempted to visit the tanneries as they are pretty grotty. The ones in Fez are the ones to see. If you do go, expect to make a contribution to the 'cooperative' that runs it. At night, the square comes alive with food stalls and entertainment. I prefered the more specialist stalls selling a particular style of dishes to the ones that sell a bit of everything. I ate at a tiny fish stall one night and a vegetarian stall another and they were both excellent. The one I wanted to go to on the corner sold all sorts of kebabs and other meats but it was so busy I couldn't get near it! The entertainment was centerd around 2 or more people playing instruments and was really good. Others were going round the crowd looking for tourists to 'contribute' and got cross if you gave them small change... It's hard to believe everyone was having so much fun with no alcohol in sight. You have to go outside the souk for that. The Orange juice stalls were brilliant. It's a few years since I was there but a large glass of freshly squeezed juice was 10 dirhams. That's less than 70p. Have fun with the people on the stalls. They love to haggle. If it gets too much, just walk away. They can't follow you. Also don't buy fossils or geodes. Most of them are faked or dyed. The dye washes off and the 'silver' crystals (galena/lead crystals) are glued on!

Not for us.... Some nice items for sale but didn't like being followed by local people trying to throw you off course and ask for money.Ive been to similar places in other arab countries and enjoyed the souks but didn't like them here. Just felt like someone was trying to scam you at every opportunity.I preferred the fixed price shops where you could browse at leisure and not feel like you are going to get ripped off.

Fun, noisy , colorful , hectic!!!!. Great place to see & experience colorful locals -- including snake charmers!- Moroccan handicrafts, spices & foôds. Watch out for pickpockets. & shady characters! All in all, a fun place.

Amazing place. Marrakech is an amazing experience, quite unique. It's so busy, lots going on all at once. Souks are like a Warren like, think you need to go with guide for first visit as could so easily lose your way. The main square is not to be missed and well worth a visit especially at night, so busy and entertaining, the noise is phenomenal, lovely to relax in one of the many cafe/bars and watch the world go by.

You MUST go!!. A real must when you visit Marrakesh!! The sights, smells & sounds are intoxicating, ideally you should get a guide for part of the visit and the have a wander around to fully experience the Souks, spices, jewellery, homewares and clothing are all there to explore, LADIES please cover your knees and shoulders out of respect for local culture and it will also help to steer off unwanted attention for males.

Be ready for the haggling - its full on but a must visit - the best souks in the world. I have been to the souks in Turket, Egypt and Morocco and this is by far the most aggresive and the best at the same time. Be prepared to haggle, ignore people and have people try to sell you things constantly. Go in with the right mindset and its a lot of fun. Feeling like some time to yourself and unwinding - spend the time sun baking. We bought rugs, blankets, kitchen stuff (bowls, cups, plates) and a stack of random things. With anything the price something is worth is what you are prepared to pay. As a rule, I was normally able to settle at close to a third of the asking price, but they were almost unhappy to sell at that price. They are really happy with around half of the original price, but make sure its what you want. If you do start negotiating, I walk away unless I get the price I wanted. Only then do they normally finally drop down. We also found some wholesalers at the back who made plates and cups and got some really good prices.Be careful, its easy to get lost in here, so you may want to load your location on google maps as you leave the hotel. It can be quite unsettling if you get lost at night.

Lots of hassle - a trick or two. Wandering around the souks can be fun. Avoiding hassle when walking: Google Maps if lost (not a paper map), no big camera and no jeans!"Guides" - don't believe them if they tell you the street is closed. be really firm, impolite if needed, and tell them you have no interest and will not get any money - not even 1 dirham. Don't believe them if they say the Berber Market is for one day today, or the museum is closed. Anyone who will walk with you has almost certainly has a money agenda (taking you to a tannery, then their Uncle/brother/sister/dog's shop, e.g.). If you want a guide, get your riad/hotel to arrange. You won't get hassled then at all, probably.Taxis: their meters work (except to/from airport) - be firm, and move on to another one. Shops: if you want to buy at the cheapest cost with zero hassle, go to the "soukamarket" Complexe d'Artisanat on Rue de la Kasbah. Slightly ruins the magic.If lost: ask a shopkeeper. They won't leave their stall.Photos: don't take photos of people, snakes etc without asking. They have every right to insist on payment. Agree prices upfront - ensure it's in Dirham!Pay your restaurant bills using a card in Dirham (not $/£/€ no matter what they tell you).Though if you get fleeced - it'll only be for a few dollars.

Interesting . Visited the souks last year September as well as this year. Purchased many beautiful products there, art and wood work.
Yes the men did "harass" us being 2 young ladies, but got used to it after a while, although we were dressed appropriately.
Would recommend.

Marrakech Souk. This consists of small winding streets & it is very easy to get lost or not find the same stall again. Be prepared to bargain hard.If you prefer not to bargain the Artisan Centre which is near to Medina Gardens Hotel has a wide range of small shops. The government sets the price here. There is a pleasant courtyard where you can get a coffee, a light meal or snack.RMR

Glad to discover some of the souks have fix price!. If you're a fan of bargaining, the souks are a great place for shopping! But if you're more of a shy and antisocial type of buyer, than go for the fix price shops. I was glad to find out that there are a lot of them in the main square, actually! There's nothing wrong with bargaining, but sometimes I just don't feel like interacting with the sellers and just want to have a look, pick that and that and that, give the money and walk away. My advice is to be polite and keep your wits. You'll never get the price a local would get after a good bargaining session. So just enjoy the experience, buy what you like and never feel sorry about the money you spent. Go for the jewelry, the traditional clothing and the leather products, they are amazing! We even bought ceramic products and got them in one piece back home, even if we were afraid they'll be smashed in the plane.

Busy, narrow shopping streets. The souk shouldn´t be missed if you are in Marrakech. The narrow streets with shops on both sides seem to go on for ever. You can probably find anything you would like to buy there, and after a bit of bargaining at a reasonable price. The crowded streets are also used by motor cyclists and donkeys so one has to look out.

Obligation to see, to be avoided. Well, call me ignorant but what s the main reason to go to a place to argue all the time?! PPL folow you to go to an specific place all the time, men ask u to go to ¨holes¨to get massage, girls in Hijab asks u to pay Euro 50 for a henna tattoo. Really? I mean, really? It s def not a place for me.

Amazing sights and sounds.... Definately an experience not to be missed, the sprawling Souk surprised me with its workshops where the items were being made. No hassle seemed to be the order of the day, with very, very few peddlers trying to push their wares, Definately a friendlier, more laid back environment that markets I've visited in Turkey and Egypt.
Surprising. Go in the morning when it's less busy and much cooler and you won't get hassled. Be prepared to haggle, the shop keepers expect it.

Take Care!. Be very aware of what is going on around you. The people here are as "artful as a cartload of monkeys" and will relieve you of money and valuables. They try to put monkeys and snakes on you. They thrust things at you and if you take them, they shout at you and demand money.

Dusty souk. Very chaotic . Narrow streets and guys driving motorbikes too fast are things you have to keep in mind as you debate prices. Very dusty so pace yourself and don't try to do too much too quickly

Amazing souk. Amazing souk , if your a shopaholic your gonna have a field day great for leather goods you can spend countless days wandering around the souk and go back the next day to find more parts its a maze of a market ,

everything you ever wanted to buy. sometimes you have to dig to find your treasure. Of course, you have to bargain. go to a fixed price shop (like a gift shop in a lobby of a hotel) to figure out the ballpark of what you should be paying and always demand to get less. We did not get bugged to go into shops as much as we thought we would.

Fun. Enjoy the noise and the excitement. If you are looking to buy stuff, there is plenty of junk. Look for the artisan areas for metal work, leather goods etc. Pay a visit to a Berber pharmacy for spices and essential oils - a must visit.

Crossroads of history and culture!. You can go it yourself, but as a non-arabic, nor french-speaking traveler, I suggest getting a guide for the market. The barkers and bargaining get to be annoying (for the shopping traveler) after a while.. its good to have someone to show you where it's less hectic, even if they do lead you to their friend's shops who then presumable get a cut from the profits made from you.. but who cares... You get what you want and you support the locals, for relatively cheap food and trinkets! :) We came for a tour in the afternoon, then returned again for dinner to see how they converted the scene to a completely different layout. :)

A Must See and Do. It's literally a 'mazing' place to shop, meet people, bargain, soak in the sounds and sights. It may be well planned for those who know, but I certainly couldn't tell heads from tails but no matter, that's part of the experience. No need to be anxious; it's all good.

Haggle and do a guided tour. Was in and out of the souks over the period of a week and with hindsight it would have perhaps have been better to to the guided tour early on. Didn't really master the haggling until the end but by then had seen some shop prices so it was easier to judge what prices should be paid. The sellers will come after you if they really want the sale so think about you can afford to pay and hold the line and whether we bought or didn't buy, not taking it too seriously and keeping it all light hearted meant there was no unpleasantness. Bought some leather goods, clothes and souvenirs and never felt under pressure to buy. It is easy to get list but don't fall for the trick of someone taking you somewhere - just head back in the direction you came from and you will get back to the square. Better during the day for getting your bearings and quiet on a Friday.

Great fun and grab yourself a bargain. The souks are great fun, and lots of opportunity for a bargain. They are a lot more extensive than you first think, with so many different places to see and explore. Have a good look around and get a feel for what you might like to buy before starting to negotiate with individual vendors!

Complete Madness!!. This place is crazy! We got lost evertime we went in the souk! That's part of the fun. As mention you do get bomarded by stall holders and local kids trying to make a bob or two but its not too bad. Enjoy the vibe and atmosphere.

Funny, exotic and pretty safe.. A great experience. Spend at least a full day here. Expect being sheeted. Thats part of the deal. One of the more interesting places I have seen on the planet. Get lost in the smaller souks with hand craft. Amazing. No, you don't need to buy anything, but you will.
Crazy Place. A lot going on - sensory overload. Not always good bargains with lots of haranguing shopkeepers. Not fun for me.
Shop if you must. Wide range of goods which can be obtained for good bargained prices. Some brass items are quite reasonable. The aisles are fairly wide so it is comfortable to move around.
The markets of Marrakech!. You have to visit the Souks in Marrakeck, great fun, a real feast for your eyes, ears and nose... with amazing art, leather goods, souvenirs, herbs and olives!!!

Too many hustlers!. What a beautiful place! Sadly, the sellers/hustlers in the souk make this experience very unpleasant. I went once before in 2007, but I guess I was too young to remember how horrible it was. I was so excited to be there, walking through tiny alleys, enjoying the great colours and products and I was keen to take pictures of the locals and their products. It's a different reality though. As soon as you set foot in the sook, be prepared to be harassed by hustlers. They just cannot let you pass without annoying you with their products. They do not take no for an answer and I can assure you, after the 5th time (make that a few meters), it becomes VERY VERY ANNOYING. The first day, you have patience and you keep saying no politely. But it does not get any better, and I had to devise methods of not being harassed by looking down and avoiding eye-contact. Some people can make you very angry as well by blocking your way and then having a laugh when they succeeded in ruining your day. Be very careful when taking pictures, as they would expect you to pay them! People are very keen to offer 'help', but nothing is free - once they see you are a tourist and trying to find your way, they will immediately come and offer 'help', and they expect a lot of money in the end. Also, be careful of young boys who lie to tell you that 'the road is closed', and they will take you round a longer way and then ask for a lot of money in return! Be careful of mopeds and bicycles in the tiny alleys as well, as they don't care about pedestrians and are unapologetic as they whizz around. This has been a general experience in Marrakech.

Once in a life time experience. A fantastic area to visit, however I wouldn't recommend going there over and over again. Be cautious of the traders selling. Ensure you start asking for at least 50% of the pricing, and negotiate. Be careful of people who misguide you in the souk. Worth a visit.

Haggle or go home.. I hate shopping - it's boring, this was not boring! The whole place is a labyrinth once inside you can easily lose sense of where you are, don't panic, you're not lost you just don't know where you are for the moment, keep walking you'll be fine. You don't have to buy anything to still have fun looking at (and smelling) the goods on offer. There is a lot of tat but if you do see something you like then haggle hard and be prepared to walk away if you don't get your price. You can always try again with someone else.

Weird but Interesting. Firstly, I would not recommend anyone to visit these souks without a guide that you have arranged before hand. You will get lost. I also would be very careful as there is no health and safety here. You are walking in tight dwindling alleys with motorbikes left right and center! A little dangerous in my opinion. However that aside, they are very authentic.

Interesting place. We loved the Souk, our guide took us there so we got to see the best parts, lots of walking and avoiding mopeds,donkey carts and bicycles all working in the Souk, it's very narrow and they come from all directions.We visited a herbalist which was very interesting having everything explained to us + a neck/ shoulder massage. You don't have to buy anything, I bought 3 items + 2 massages for about £70.

A hassle from Start to Finish!. I was reading somewhere that the King of Morocco would like to double tourism by the year 2020 (or something of the like). Here's a word of advice, you really need to get the souks and the people who frequently deal with tourists under control if you're going to want visitors to keep coming back. From even before we got to the souk, it was a hassle. We decided to take a horse drawn carriage from our hotel (less than a mile away) to the souk to do some shopping - we agreed on a price (30 dirhams which was fair according to everyone I talked to beforehand). However, the driver decided to take us on a round about route, that probably tripled our time, and he wanted to charge us 500 dirhams instead. Outrageous!!! Eventually I "settled" on 200 which was more than I wanted to pay, but was enough to stop the conversation and let us go on our way.Also, another piece of advice, have the folks in the souk post SOME prices, and start hanging price tags on the merchandise like every other civilized country. The sales people in the souks could literally charge ANYTHING they want, and get away with it with uneducated tourists. Luckily we had done our research and knew what was a fair price, but having to haggle over EVERY purchase is tiresome, and honestly just made me want to leave sooner than we should have, and made the whole experience not as enjoyable. We had plans to spend 2-3 days shopping at the various souks in the area, but once was enough, and we didn't really want to come back. We don't plan on coming back to Morocco after this experience unless significant changes are made.

Great holiday but caution henna ladies. Loved my holiday in Marrakech and the souks are amazing, just wanting to warn people about the henna tattoos offered by the ladies in the square. I have had henna before in the past and have been fine so i had a little one whilst there, when I returned home i washed it off, and found a small rash underneath, this has now turned into blisters in the shape of the henna, I have since found out that it's a chemical burn. The ladies told me how it's all natural henna and not in any way harmful, but as I now know they will tell you anything to get the money out of your pocket. As i know this is not isolated to Marrakech but wanted to warn people as these tattoos are very desirable to children.

Haggle. You can't go to Marrakech and not visit the souks. Just be prepared to be hassled the entire time. Look straight ahead, do not point at things and ignore what everyone is saying to you. If you do find something you like, start your price very low and work your way up. It is a fun experience but an hour at a time was enough for me. I did however get some pretty cool items and gifts for Christmas.

The souk was amazing but tack caution. We where pounced on by a so called fee guide payed for by the government's tourist budget. This seemed good and the guy was official so we let him take us around. Every thing was safe and in order but what they do is take you to very very overpriced government run shops where you will pay nearly 1000% than you could buy the items for elsewhere in the souks. Over than the guide the place and the vibe was compleatly amazing but in hindsight I would have paid a guide or just gone exploring.
Very crowded. Depends on what sort of experience you're looking for. Too crowded for me and too many hagglers. Lots of snake charmers and if you're looking for a bargain then you'd like it here.

Local market . If you had in mind of something you wanted to buy you're in the right place. It's busy, chaotic, and lots of hasslers. If you're not interested just keep walking. It's a lovely market to walk around along with the locals.

You can't miss the souk in Marrakech. Afterall, why would you go to Marrakech and NOT go to the souk! You don't have to buy anything, you can easily get lost at each corner and it doesn't matter, at some stage you'll emerge into the open air. Until then, enjoy the haggle - if you're good you'll get called a Berber woman like my fiance did, but hey, it worked at the next stall to haggle harder - and in the end, we shook on a price exactly half what they said at the start. So you fairly well know where you'll end up price wise. We had code words before we went into shops and limits on what we would spend on each item, plus a shopping list so we didn't get too sidetracked. In the end I know we didn't rip any vendors off, everyone was smiling when we left and we got some great items.

Plucking and sniffing.. A visit to the Marrakech souk needs a bit of preparation; women need to hold their handbags and their breath. There are stories of bag snatchers and there is definitely evidence of some very 'human smells' as you stroll through the catacombs of merchandise. It is not a place for the faint-hearted. You will have snake-charmers waving a Cobra toward you, traders chasing you down an alley-way offering their 'best price' on something you merely glanced at and all that rough and tumble of haggling you'd expect. There are various opportunities to eat 'street-food' which we avoided. A nice restaurant tempted us which was authentic, calm and had a secluded courtyard. Le Bougainvillier was an oasis of sanity and charm. Not expensive and true Moroccan cuisine.
