There are bargains to be had in the souk but there's no such thing as a free lunch and so you pay dearly in other ways to save a bit of cash. The mandatory haggling is a chore. Be ready to feel sorry for kids selling meagre things as they sit in rags and all that conscience-stirring. Be brave, walk with a confident stride and leave with your handbag, stomach and pity intact. Definitely an experience !
Marrakech Souk. Bargain hard people. Look to pay about 50% of their original asking price. Check the lining on the bags and ignore the watches as they just brake.

Great fun!. It's really fun walking around the souk and haggling for anything you want to buy, there are a mesmerising number of different shops and stalls and some of the shops look really beautiful. It's really busy and some people might find it a bit overwhelming at times. It's lovely how you walk through little alleys and then pop up in squares full of vendors and their products.

Watch your back!. Bustling busy narrow alleys lined with leather, spice, jewellery, pottery, clothing and carpet sellers. Fascinating and great fun BUT the alleyways are far too narrow for the lunatics whizzing through them on mopeds at dangerous speeds! I would definitely not take small children here, they would be at serious risk of being run over!
Do it, tick the box and move on.. Not everyone is your friend. They appear to be so, helping you to find places and shops, but in truth, they just want your money.

Nice and retro. Retro souk but very expensive, I don't like the shop owners when they are calling. The souk look like a maze, you can get lost easily. Most of goods are shoes, bags, souvenirs and spices.

Speechless about the amount of people. The square is always busy and full of little shops. The souk has everything from clothes, food, artisan and craftsmen live at work. There is one little alley with olives please go there and eat some if you like them.

So much fun if you go along with the banter. We visited as a group of five feisty middle aged women and had a lot of fun as we weren't intimidated or annoyed by the banter but took it on. Mostly you should be able to get prices down by at least a half and for more expensive items often two thirds.

Haggle hard and enjoy. The souk is a busy labyrinth of small streets with shops of all shapes and sizes. The insider tip is to at least halve the price quoted by the vendor.
Great for leather stuff and spices.

Amazing. This is a must see place from the snakes to the monkeys in the square.
The restaurants are not dear and worth going to a roof top one.
The horse and carriages are cheap and nearly the same price as a taxi if you haggle !

I wouldn't buy anything here. Prices were highly inflated. Tagines were quoted at 150 dirhams where I was able to buy 4 similar ones for 150 dirhams total elsewhere! Always bargain at least 60% down their asking price!

If it exists you can buy it here. Might be the best souk (or set of souks) in the world. My wife who is an expert on these matters rates it higher than the Muscat and Damascus (unfortunately now off limits) souks. You can get great carpets/kilims (we did), argan oil products, leather, pots, vases, sweets etc. Items that are old and new are here; and while its easy to get lost its not hard to find your way out.

An assault on the senses and shopping paradise ...just go with the flow. This took my straight back to my childhood in the Middle East...the smells of the spice, leather and carpets, the quaint streets, where you can get lost and the frenetic activity throughout they day. Find a cafe, sit back and watch the world go by or try your hand at bartering. Just go in with a smile, respect for their customs and enjoy. Some vendors were pushy but most were happy for you to look, but then came the hard sell, but all in a good humoured manner. You do have to watch for the crazy moped riders so not ideal if you have young children as you need eyes in the back of your head, but is something everyone should experience.

Souks is better with a guide. The Souks is typical of market stalls in African cities but notable for its stalls operated by Berbers, the original people of Morocco. The area is composed of narrow arteries, with overhead coverings for shade, and heavily oriented to handicrafts and foodstuffs. The maze of pathways can be quite confusing and is best navigated with a guide which is inexpensive if you bargain well.

Interesting, fun and don't be afraid to BARTER!. Like with everywhere you wander someone will be vying for your attention in the Souks. If not interested a firm but polite no thank you I found was sufficient that I was left be. When interested in something I picked the price I was willing to pay and if they wouldn't match it I walked away and found it further on. The amount of paths and streets, we must have spent hours wandering and it is very interesting, you can find practically anything and it's the experience - the husband even got asked if he was a Berber man with his harsh negotiating tactics!

Fun!!!!!!!!!!!!!. Our experience on the days we visited to Souks was fun , be prepared to haggle for any thing you buy here, we got some good bargains ..... Also beware of the locals asking if you want to visit the tenniers as you will get conned for your visit,, would i go again to the Souks YES !!!!! it was a fun experience not to be missed while on a trip to Marrakech
worth a visit for sure !. Strolling through a maze of little streets, filled with people and shops of all kinds. A must when you're in Marrakech !

So many different things to buy . Do not hesitate to bargain. Some at aggressive sellers, but many do understand your intension and exploit that part of you wanting to buy. A nice market to buy from innumerable choice of products.
old market. this market place very quite during the day but get really towards the evening, amazing place and nice
very good experience. we went in the morning to buy fresh veg for cooking in our accommodation . everything was fresh as we bought spicies at the same place .it is recommended to go in the morning

Great experience. The souks are really interesting but you can easily get lost if you dont take your time and landmark your way through them. There are lots of goods on sale including silverware, jewellery, leather goods, wooden goods, spices, amber perfume blocks, fabric goods and much much more. You need to find out what a realistc price is from the fixed price shops and then learn to barter with the locals. They are really friendly and share lots of information about their goods.It can feel quite intimidating at first but you soon learn to relax and enjoy the experience. Watch out for the mopeds riding through the souk as there is not much room for them to pass by you.

A must visit. Usual goods like leather, ceramics, lanterns and jewellery but unexpected owls and guinea pigs on display. A Fun morning spent meandering through and a welcome drink and selection of food stalls at the square at the end.

Crazy, amazing, frustrating . The souks are huge and easy to spend whole days in. You can get some great bargains from leather wares, rugs and pottery. You do realise after a while when you notice everything starting to look the same, that a lot of it is mass produced despite what the vendors will tell you. You will get hassled A LOT, particularly if you're a woman. Sometimes it borders on offensive and it can be VERY frustrating so bring your thick skin and nerves of steel. The prices they give you first up are massively overblown, start by dividing by 10 and work your way up. Seriously. You will get the best deals when you genuinely don't want something and are walking away. If you're patient & willing to put in the hard yards of bartering you will come away with some really cool stuff at a good price.

Fun haggling but it gets tiring. It's part of the experience, getting lost in the souks. Once you've engaged with a vendor, it's very difficult to escape without purchasing. Some good stuff in there too. But it gets tiring repeatedly getting lost and also haggling when you're not used to it. Pleased with my purchases though-and when you do agree on a price which is a third of what they started, you feel satisfied that you've driven a hard bargain (though I doubt that's really the case!)At night many are closed and the atmosphere isn't that pleasant-probably best avoided if you can find an alternative route.

Interesting . Crazy in a nice way. Anyone will find something for them as there is soo much to look at, even if you don't know how to haggle you still can find staff that doesn't seems to be very expensive or overpriced . And prepare to have some change for beggers as they follow you everywhere you go until you give them something.

Interesting, but......... Great place full of many sounds, smells and sights. We used a guide to show us round. This had the advantage that my wife felt safer, we were never pestered and we saw unusual sights such as the hammam boilers and a local community bread oven.
Fantastic . Fantastic please too visit I loved it and I love too come back here again and again the food was very good and taste loved it xx

All round horrible experience. Non stop hassle, rip off extremely overpriced and abuse when you don't buy something you didn't want in the first place. Pervy men all over the place and you can't even look at a shop without being practically forced to go in. Awful.

A Marrakech must do. An experience that isn't for everyone, but if you can be firm and polite with the vendors you can have a fun half day wandering through the Souk. If you have already been to Istanbul or the middle east I wouldn't loose sleep over coming here

Must Visit BUT for the culture experience only. I could not envision visiting Marrakesh without a visit to the Souk . . . merely for the spectacle of it. As one enters the area of the souk into its main square, there are musicians, men with birds, and the snake charmers. Not sure why anyone would use the word "charmers," when describing the men with the snakes for they are as mean as can be. If you so much as make a move to taking a photo, one of the snake charmer's road crew will run up to you and aggressively (in a threatening manner) demand payment, even if you have not yet taken a photo. Just be careful. If you simply look, the experience seems to be fine.Once entering the souk itself, you are met with an endless number of small booths, each with an owner who shouts out to you, trying to lure you into his shop. Its fine to take a look, but be prepared to be hassled about purchasing an item. Don't worry though, as you can just walk out and, for me, they did not follow me. I also noted that most of the shop owners, once you make it clear that you will not be purchasing anything, were relatively pleasent. I think they have some sort of a code among the shop owners that they will not follow you once you leave their shop. The stated original prices for the items are high . . . outrageous actually . . . for most items. Be prepared to argue over the price and I do mean argue. Name a price 25% of asking price and be prepared to pay 40 to 50% of the original asking price. If you pay more, you are likely being ripped off. I am sure my algorithm may be imperfect, but suggest using that as a guide.You can easily get turned around within the souk and even those with a strong sense of direction will get lost, especially in the evening. It is a maze. By 7 PM, the stalls begin to close up and the tourists clear. If you stay too late, it can become scary as you literally do not know which pathway to take. Young boys/teenagers are happy to help you out (speaking facetiously) and will offer to lead you out. I saw little alternative to follow him and this young man started to lead me through a scary maze of back alleys to the point that I was worried about my safety. Fortunately I spotted a tourist and found my way out, abandoning the young man as he demanded payment. Thus, I strongly recommend that you leave the souk by 6:30 pm by following other tourists who hopefully know they way to the main square. I saw no evidence of pickpockets, but I suggest being very careful. Keep your wallet well tucked away. As you leave the souk into the main square, beware of the women trying to put henna tattoos on you. They will run up to you with something that looks like a needle, grab your arm and trying to draw on your arm. Do not let that happen, if for sanitary reasons alone.So, visit the souk for the spectacle. It is an interesting adventure.

A souk from antiquity. This souk will take you back into time . When you enter the souk from the Mosque side you will come across snake charmers playing music to "dancing " Cobras . A local brought my son a monkey that climbed onto his shoulders making for a great picture. It's a very busy souk , very crowded and densely packed but you will find something for everyone . The souk is an intricate maze of alleyways. Suggest you hire a local guide to aid in its navigation . It's best to go early before it gets too crowed . The local sellers are not as aggressive as they are in Cairo . This was nice for a change that they don't follow you after you express no interest in what they are selling. The only real down side of this souk is the motorcycles that drive right through it . It becomes overwhelming after a while . Every few minutes they zoom right by you . Always have to be on guard . Some regulation for this in order . Otherwise a must see in Marrakech.

Interesting but be careful of black henna!. Interesting place to walk around and some lovely things to buy. However, at all costs avoid the henna tattoo artists who walk around the square using black henna. I made the mistake of agreeing to 'pay what I think the henna is worth' then being charged 30 euros for a 2 minute job. 1 week later, my foot reacted very badly to the black henna that had been used, and has left scarring - still present nearly 6 months later. Just be wary - do not let anyone force you into using black henna!
Lost at night . Don't get to worried if you get lost most Lanes take you back to the square . Lots Of good buys people are very nice .. Better Eating out of the square

Extortion. Lots of nice items but ridiculously expensive and you really have to ask for discounts up to a quarter of the price. I honestly think it's a waste of time and better buy from the shop with a fix price. Some shop keepers also get annoyed when you don't buy after ( I know cause I understand the language and they did not think I can). We were able to get to a big shop near Sadian tombs which is fixed price and better quality items.

Hugh selection of shops to buy from. But irritating shop keepers. Souks in marrakesh are full of selection and you are sure to find something for everyone.Beware of doggy shop keepers who will invite u in shop saying 'looking is free' and when you try to leave the same shop keeper will yell at you to go home. Really bad customer service.Not all sellers are like that but they get affected due to bad experience we got from others.Barganing is a must. Do not pay more than half the price seller quotes you.
amazing place to visit. loved going around the stores however watch out because people will ask for money if you take photos

Unique experience . This is the second time i have been to the Marrakech Souk, the goods sold can be repetitive but it is an experience that you can never find at home. Be prepared to haggle hard - aim for minimum 50-70% of the price offered. Dont be afraid to walk away, chances are they call you back and give you a fair price. If not, there will be another trader selling the same goods a few stalls down

Short break. The Souk was amazing and we got very lost whilst exploring this vast market place It's full of the most interesting artisans, products and characters...We loved it and loved all of its treasures.

Cultural experience. In the souk you will find everything. The prices vary, and the cheapest shops are the ones found further in. The souk is easy to get lost in. Remember that asking price is 3 times higher then market value, so prepare your bids and keep cool if you are buying anything. The south medina has cheaper products, but is not so charming.

No hassle .... ... well, almost none and certainly none that one couldn't cope with. The place is a fascinating labyrinth of every type of Moroccan artifact one could wish to have - we could have filled more than one suitcase, and I suppose that's the answer - take an empty one. The colours! Oh my goodness the colours ... The spices - keep an eye on the Dirham conversion rate, it's too easy to get carried away. We had our own entrepreneurial guide who ensured we weren't ripped off and weren't hassled unnecessarily, although I started to feel a little sorry for them when my wife got the bartering bug - she slayed them all! Great fun, can't wait to return.

Full of handmade shopping. Nice place to walk around all the day.You can find everything for house and more Be careful about the labels,are not always correct and they dont give the correct directions,trust only sonebody from a store to ask informations

Must Visit. The souks are great fun. Wander around and get lost. There is always someone to point you in the right direction. Offer a third of the sellers price and stick to it! We did and it never failed. Tiny alleys that are packed with people but we never once felt uncomfortable. The local people are very friendly.

Was thirsty so asked for a Cobra. back from Marrakech and what and experience.The Medina & Souk are certainly the highlight of the visit. Hustle and bustle galore and a maze of alleyways.I'd recommend that as soon as you get there you chat to number of the 'official' guides and choose one that you feel you will get on with. It will cost you about 50-70 Dhms for them to be with you for around 2 hours.They tell you the history; they know where the merchants who sell what you want are; MOST important, having a guide with you stops you getting hassled be every single trader that yopu walk pass.Be wary of taking photos though of the entertainment to hand; they will ask you for money at every opportunity. Its not a bad thing, but you could end up parting with loads of cash!!Once out of the Souk go to Jarden de les Koutoubia in the street next to it. It is a great place to escape to for some peace (and a beer) and no snakes!!!.
Wonderful experience. The souk offers great shopping and photography experience. One can test one's bargaining skills while enjoying the shopping. Do not feel afraid to quote your price :-)

A must experience when visiting Marrakech. An amazing amalgam of jewellery, leather, foot ware, vegetables, spices, woodwork, natural herbalist, metalwork shops and micro factories all mixed in with the medina that houses thousands.Behind the walls can be luxurious riads beyond imagination, or very simple homes as Moroccans have learned to avoid outward displays of wealth in the interests of social harmony.Then there are the young hawkers who inhabit the main square who are only interested in parting you with your hard earned-snake charmers, watch sellers-you name it , it's there somewhere!On the whole, the shop owners are less in your face but are very skilled sellers and do your homework beforehand if you are planning a purchase. The tourist price can be up to two or three times the price that a local may pay, so be prepared to bargain hard. If they are prepared to do a deal, there is a profit in it for them as they won't sell for a loss.!In some respects, while smaller, the Fez souk is less touristic and inhabited more by the local community than MarrakechTake a guide for several hours to give you a better understanding of the ins and outs of the souk and make sure you don't miss the highlights-they get a commission on introductions but it also helps to get better deals and the hawkers tend to leave you alone.

One of the more interesting. Spent a good hour walking around the souk, with a guide. Very interesting. A must do when in Marrakech. Lots of great characters. Artisan work shops turn out great quality goods. Prepare to bargain.

Chaotic but good natured and fun...... The souks are everything you might hope for and expect. A real rabbit warren on unnamed streets; ask for directions and you will be shown to some ones uncles shop, but then offered lots of things you didn't know you wanted but might end up buying! Haggle hard and don't dwell on the one that got away. All conducted in quite a good natured style and with lots of banter
Amazing country. Marrakechhhhhhhhhhhh the best city I live it so muchhhhh ohhh my god I feel so happyyyyyyyyy I love jamaa lefnaaa it's a magic place

Fantastic. If u love shopping then this is the place to be...this is a warren of little shops selling some beautiful things but be prepared to barter for the price, some of the shop keepers will try their best to get u to look in their shop but be polite and say no!

Venture inside. Though soukhs in other cities are claimed to be the bigger, I beleive the one in Marrakech is the largest. The difference is that the one in Marrakech is not a specifically designated area, unlike other soukhs. It's streets and alleys grown together to one big market; a large part of it is covered with corrugated roof and therefor making it even more like a whole. And it goes on and on in every direction, though the density of shops somewhat lowers on the outskirts.Don't be afraid of getting lost. Just use google maps and location services on your phone (but make sure you zoomed in on the area when having a wifi connection). No need for paying guides to get you back to the square. Enjoy shopping and seeing locals do their shopping here too.As for shopping and bargaining: we found starting prices pretty low. Still they expect you to bargain and why shouldn't you? We we're told half of the starting price is a good first bid. But I must say we did not always practise this. With prices of a few euro's we found it unfair to bargain the hard way. We like to keep in mind we're the wealthy tourists; what are one or two euros to us and what are they to them?

Must do on your itinerary. At night the square changes with the emphasis on entertainment covering boxing, gambling, transvestite belly dances and other delights to behold.The sensible watershed for the souks is to leave by 10pm for tourists to avoid any potential problems associated with night life.We are well travelled but found all this an experience well worth making a must do on your itinerary
Fun to explore. Boiling activity, thousands of people, beautiful marrocan things. Bargaining essential but with a good mood it may be welcomed

Busy. Wasn't really for me, my husband enjoyed the hussle bussle of the Medina went day and evening , both times found it so crazy with ppl and traffic bikes, donkeys, constant hassle, if you like the fast track and the vibe , you will probably love it , as my self prefer the calmer Zen feel but just go with the flow and enjoy , watch out for the monkeys and snakes

Know what you want, how much you'll pay, and bargain, bargain, bargain. Before you visit know what you want (jewelry, textiles, etc) and know how much you should pay and how much you're willing to pay. These people are businessmen and have more experience than most of us!That said, if you are an educated consumer and aren't afraid of bargaining you can have a good time and come home with some memorable souvenirs and stories.You can get a fair deal (no vendor will accept your price if he/she won't make a profit) but you certainly can get ripped off and over pay. Just know the value of what you want and be prepared to bargain hard! Don't worry about offending them by offering 30% of their first offer. It's all part of the game. Don't make an offer if you're really not interested in buying/bargaining. And certainly, don't bargain, settle on a price, and then walk away. That is really bad form.

exciteing ramble. usual lookie lookie come into my shop best price around, but not to aggressive sale's pitch from shop keepers always worth buying and bartering for the experience, but watch out for the young men[late teens early twentys] on street corners who lie and mislead you

An experience . Loved my visit to the souks. We took a tour guide to show us around. I think this is best option as the locals do hassle you quite a bit to buy things but felt we were more left alone with the guide. Watching how they make the carpets and visiting the Berber pharmacy was an excellent experience. Is love to do it all again and take in some more next time. Don't be too intimidated by the locals trying to sell things. A firm no thank you with a smile is good. Really is a must see if you are in Marrakech

Moroccan Culture at its best. The Souk is split into many sections depending on the trade carried out, e.g.spices, leather, blacksmith, weavers and many more. At the front of the Souk there are hundreds of stalls selling good and bad tourist "stuff" and the odd gem. It is noisy busy horrid (dont go to the butcher bit) but safe and all in all quite good fun, probably best to not go alone not for safety but just moral support and always haggle

Bit boring. Wasn't overlly impressed with the souk's if I'm honest. Boring stalls with fake trainers & brands. If you move into the back of the souk there are some genuine shop keepers who give you a fair price on things. I bought a lovely traditional teapot and X2 glasses for tea for 100DH & the shop keeper was not at all pushy. Be careful of your belongings, my friend unfortunately had her phone pick pocketed which doesn't surprise me as you are hussled & bussled around

shopping. Go night time as lot of acts on but be careful of pick pockets.If you buy make sure you barter if they say 80.00 you say £ 10.00 make sure you get to the price you want as there is always another shop with same item

You should go. This is the second time I've been to Marrakech and it hasn't changed a bit thank goodness!Here's a few tips to help you on your way around.First of all get a good street plan of the Medina and on your first day have a walk around and get to know your way to and from your Riad or hotel. Don't get too anxious if you get lost, there will always be someone to escort you to where you want to go, of course this will cost you a few dirhams, but not much.Secondly make sure you have some small change in your pocket to tip etc the endless stream of helpful people!I am concerned about previous comments about faeces and stench of urine. This is not the case. The drains aren't the greatest so they can pong a bit at times, but not all the time for sure. There needs the of reality about this place, it's not the West. If you are expecting the locals to be as hung up about hygiene as the Brits then you'll be sadly dissapointed. Look, we've got white blood cells for a reason. You'll not catch anything, so relax.A couple of previous reviews mention loads of cats and dogs. I'm not sure why, perhaps some people don't know what a dog looks like. In four days I saw a handful of dogs, let's face it they're Muslim , they don't keep dogs! You will see loads and loads of cats however. Anyone who has the misfortune of walking around a town centre in the UK on a Saturday or Sunday morning will know the real stench of urine in shop doorways, you'll get none of that in Marrakech. The main reason being that in Marrakech you don't get the drunken idiots, so refreshing. You can walk the streets safely at night, something that the UK can't offer as often. If you do not want something, you need smile and firmly say no, if you give an impression of weakness, expect to be badgered. Once you get the hang of this, everything is easy. The traders and locals will have been told no a thousand times already the same day, it won't cause a problem. Previous reviews mention being intimidated. There is no need to feel this. You are far more likely to get assaulted in the UK than here. Just remember to be very direct about what you do or do not want. If someone overstays their welcome, just tell them to go away and wave them off. All they want is your money, whilst they think they are in with a chance of getting it, they will persist, the nanosecond they realise you're not going to give them a bean they will instantaneously move onto the next soft touch. But no need to be impolite, be respectful but firm.The hundreds stalls in the souks are great to walk around, but it is easy to lose your bearings. This can be unsettling at first but there will always be a helpful soul to help you find where you are going for a few dirhams. Don't be too surprised if you ask the way to be sent in completely the wrong direction, then the helpful soul will reappear and take you there, saving the day and earning a big tip.Ladies will regularly get offered henna tattoos. Don't bother asking how long they last as if you are only there for 4 days they are highly unlikely to outlast your stay! If you allow your hand to be taken for a couple of seconds, expect an instant tattoo and request for money.The reality of Marrakech is that it is jam packed with thousands of people living on their wits. They work hard, long hours to scrape a meagre living. They don't have the welfare state allowing millions in the UK to spend a lifetime swinging the lead. As tourists we are understandably viewed as very wealthy in comparison. If we spread some of this by way of a tip here and there, it's nothing to us and a big deal for them. Personally I find the work ethic refreshing compared to the UK.Finally, NEVER EVER change money at the airport at Gatwick. The exchange rate is so bad Id rather be robbed by someone with a gun, at least you'll know you've been robbed. Use the ATMs. Unbelievably even HSBC will give you far far more currency for your money, at least 30% more.

The Souks. The Souks of Marrakech are off the famous Djema el Fna and are easy to stumble about in but an App Hip Marrakech available for free will mean you never get lost again and you do not need a phone / data link just GPS and a battery.

Fabulous Must if you Visit Marrakech. You have not visited Marrakech if you have not gone to the Old Souk. It is bustling confusing array of narrow streets and tons of shops that sell everything. I highly recommend finding a good guide, but there are a plethora of guides around and if they have an "official guide badge" you can probably count on them. They at least have a wealth of knowledge about the city, and can help to find what you are looking for, or caution you about quality. Yes, they probably have favorite places and probably get kick backs, but they are very helpful if you have a limited amount of time. We found ourselves in a carpet women's cooperative, and of course expected not to buy a carpet, but the bargaining game is so much fun at carpet shops that you will probably leave with a carpet. (we did) We also went to a Argon perfumer and saw the pressing of the oil, heard about the remedies of the Argon oil, and made it out without buying though I did buy later in the mountain valley. The hustle and bustle is fascinating and the people so friendly. The amazing culture of the area include both Muslim and Jewish religions, and you can see it all right there. An awesome place to be. Keep your wallet in your front pocket and you will be fine. Drink some mint tea and relax. And, of course watch out for cars and motorbikes in the alleys as they do find just enough space to zip around.

An interesting experience. Each time I have been to the medina, I have had a different experience. This time it was fully of pushy sales people, some take the answer no quite well, whereas others refused to listen to you. Be careful of the ladies trying to sell packets of tissues, as they follow up and grab at your arms to put bangles and rings on you.

Can be overwhelming. Myself and my partner, when to the markets and souks on saturday night. As we arrived in the main square we were overwhelming with people trying to get out attention/selling us things. Including a lady trying to henna my hand. You need to go with confidence and determination. You need to haggle and barter for the best price, and be prepared for some not so friendly comments if you walk away,.

So many streets. We visited the souks at 2 different times of day, in the late afternoon, early evening and first thing in the morning. There is a big difference going at different times of day, going late in the day means you can pick up a bargin from some of the sellers that have their goods on hand pushed carts and on cloths on the floor, where as the proper stall/shops are more expensive. We didn't go very far into the souks when we went in the evening as it's quite easy to get yourself confused if you don't stick to a rule of turning left or right only when you go in this way when you realise you've gone quite a way in you just reverse your route to get out, we did just that when we'd gone quite a ways in and ran out of shops and found ourselves in local housing. We never had anyone approach us which others had said happened to them, but we turned around and walked back and it wasn't long before we were back in the square. The souks are quite narrow and it is quite busy, not just with people but mopedes, donkey and carts, push bikes, people on horse back and in some areas rascal type vans!! They do beep their horns but it's quite hair raising at times, so if you are going with children be extra careful as we think it's an accident waiting to happen!! Our over all experience was good the sellers do keep trying to get you to go into their shop fronts but you just say no thankyou or you go and have a look and if there's something that you like the look of then ask how much and then when they say you shake your head and come in lower, the only time you don't barter is when they have an exact price on the items. If you still can't reach a price you want to pay then walk away, they don't get aggressive or try to keep you in their shop. It is somewhere you have to go to if you ever go to Marrakech.

Intimidating but a good adventure. Personal prefrence preferred the Medina to the Souks. Very compact and close. Just like hand to hand combat. Still got some great deals and i am battle hardened by many medina visits around the world. Did find more choice in the Medina than the souks but a great hunt in very narrow alleyways.

Shopping the Marrakech Souks. What a great place to shop. A place you buy almost anything. Don't expect to see prices clearly marked; ask the price and then play the game of bartering. Come in low so you can work up to a price your willing to pay. You can usually get things for around a 1/3 or 1/4 of the asking price if you play your cards right.

Get lost. This should be an absolute must for anyone visiting Marrakesh. It wasn't really about buying products and shopping for me but more the experience and environment within which the traders go about selling their wares. This can be a little bit intimidating so it is not for the faint hearted and it is probably one of the most confusing places you could visit in the world but then that makes it all the more exciting. As a rule whatever price you offered I would reduce that by at least five times maybe even seven and start your negotiation they'll be prepared to walk away and normally they will chase you for approximately 100 m to try and close the deal. Watch out for the mopeds and the boys with carts but go with the flow and enjoy it

Interesting!. It's an experience that you can't miss going to the souks. There's several souks selling different things all intertwined through the streets and alley ways. The touristy ones are selling all the souvenir type items and they are abundant and overflowing with pretty things. Haggling is a must and the traders enjoy the dance of negotiating the best prices. There's definitely some bargains to be had here, but at the same time it's easy to get carried away and end up paying over the odds. There's also food markets which are mostly used by locals and you'll get to see some interesting foods there. The narrow streets are used by pedestrians, donkeys, bikes, mopeds and cars and it's sometimes a bit scary as the mopeds go really fast, but it seems to be an organised kind of chaos and there's no accidents. The leather tanneries are detectable from some distance away by the stench. They use pigeon poo in one of the processes and there's lots of dogs and cats hanging around here so overall the whole place has the mixed aromas of faeces, urine, death, rotting flesh and decay and various other unidentifiable pongs, all overlaid with the subtle scent of mint! It's absolutely filthy. Seriously. Do not wear flip flops here. Do not touch anything. Do not let anything touch you. If you have a sensitive disposition then do not go. It's not just the smell, it's the piles of rotting skin and fat and tissue and fur and faeces and rotting food and rubbish and so on that you just can't avoid. It's interesting, but disgusting!We were followed around by some guy who ultimately ended up demanding money for his 'guided tour' so we begrudgingly handed over the small amount of change we had to avoid the rising unpleasantness. We argued that he hadn't mentioned being our guide or even asked if we wanted a guide or indeed told us that he would want money for doing it but he was insistent. There was only one exit which he was blocking so we just gave in to avoid trouble for our kids. So be aware of this when you're there. Everybody wants your money.

Beautiful Markets. Absolutely love Marrakech. Stunning shops selling alsorts of... Spices, teas, hand crafted goods, Organic foods, jewellery, lamps, musical instruments. ...Just about anything. Perfect this time of year for Christmas shopping in HOT Marrakech. Escape from the cold UK and barter with the Moroccan Locals to get beautiful gifts for everyone.

Buying Time - Not to be missed. Phew!!! This is complete overload to the senses, leave it to day 2 of your stay so you are relaxed, have a laid back approach to the whole experience, it's all abit of theatre but not to be missed. Even haggling is fun, start at half what the trader is asking for and go from there,& smile alot. Even if you didn't haggle prices are so cheap compared with home that you might just want to pay that and go. You will probably get lost abit but don't worry, either ask a stall holder or just keep wandering round as you will eventually come out somewhere.Helps if you can speak a bit of French but the majority speak a smattering of English so between the two you will be understood. Safety- never felt threatened-just the opposite in fact, but obviously be sensible as you would be at home. Do enjoy the WHOLE experience!!!!!!!!!!!!

Good price . I went to that souk in November 2015 during my stay in marrakech, it is good for shopiping and souvenirs with lot of varieties of morroco style gifts but you should bargain about the price because the sellers give high initial price but still better than bazaar.

The best part of the Medina of Marrakech. Jemaa el Fna is a large place located with in the Medina but on it's outer edge. As such, vehicle traffic such as taxi, private cars, and especially delivery trucks have after hours access to the area to stock the local shops and stalls. Starting in the afternoon, street vendors open their tents and stalls, along with snake charmers and street food stands which provides a festive feel to the whole area.
Wondering without map and destinations. There is no street signs, and easy to get lost in the streets. Holding maps makes you are a target, attracting unwanted helps.

Hectic market place!!. Crazy market place!! While the area and its host is interesting, I found it difficult to take it in because of the people hustling to charge you ridiculous amounts for practically anything. Do not pay attention to anyone unless you plan on buying something. People offer to take you around the area, but will hassle you to pay for it. I advise you do not take pictures of some things as they may charge you for that as well.
Fun but very busy. Well worth a visit. A lot of stuff to buy and lots of smells, sights and colours. Very busy at times and you have to have great bargaining skills.

amazing!. Going into the souks is a crazy experience!! Certainly if you are claustrophobic you have to think twice about venturing in as it can become a little bit scary! Watch out for the motor scooters who also venture in there. A brilliant experience though!
Jemaa el Fna. the first impact is kaos, noise, rushing people, motorbikes, horses , snakes and monkeys, sellers noise, but afterwards you get the sence of enjoying this place

Lose your bearings. The souk are a network of small alleyways crammed full of stuff to sell and shops and traders selling it. It is mystery tour as nothing is what it seems or the price it seems. I was very nervous about going there as I had read reviews and get quite annoyed when pestered. The network of alleyways will get you lost eventually but just walk on and you will come out of them. If you show the slightest interest in anything then they will pounce on you and call you in. Even if you think you have got a deal once you get back to have a look somehow there is stuff missing or it is different. I realised that they were poor people so bartered with a smile and just thought ok will just get my pressies from one shop to save me going over the need to have everything thrown at me with confusing prices. So asked about a jilab which I had no intention of buying then focused on the scarfs that I wanted and they dropped their prices so I complimented them on that and just got the scarfs I needed for my daughters and said I couldn't afford three of each which they accepted ..... eventually. The picture shows a small street market in the souk just passed it is small alleyway on the right (going to the square) it was full of african and morrocan women and loads of kaftans, etc. It was small but I thought that the money would at least go to local women who probably needed it. Paid their asking price (which was actually quite reasonable) as charitable act. The kaftans were good quality and the price was v reasonable and most importantly it went directly to locals who needed it. I found that going into the quiet shops where they weren't trying to bundle you loads of stuff meant you got straight down to business and they were reasonably priced. Bought a tea glass in just 15 seconds and one price drop from a mature guy who was tidying his wares whereas a vigorous seller had wanted 4 times as much up the road. I am happy to barter if I have to as I don't like being ripped off but I am more than happy to give e.g. £2 - £3 to someone who I think needs it. I eventually enjoyed walking through the souks as I had dressed down and stayed alert, tried to look confident (even when doublling back a blind alley) and didn't browse directly - walking behind better dressed tourists helped me avoid being pestered. It can be intimidating and annoying but don't miss it just because of that suck it up and go.

Good afternoon/evening visit. We went here between 3 and 8pm just as things were beginning to get busy. Walking around the winding streets we walked past lots of little shops selling very similar items, but interesting non the less. As darkness fell it became busier with lots of tourists, sellers and entertainers. It was an amazing place. Food was good and fairly cheap. It was not as good as some of the other centres we have visited (Fes for example), and is very touristy. However it was a good night out.

Hello you'll hear. It's incredible how these traders manage to sell anything. If you tire of getting shouted at, ordered and dragged into shops then it's not for you. It is a little intimidating but if you stick to your guns, smile and walk on you'll be fine. It would be nice to be able to browse without being pounced on but you simply can't, a shame because some of the displays are amazing. Like the Jemaa el Fna, it's an experience but probably not everyone's cup of tea.

Overwhelming but a must do. You will get lost in the souks. You really will. They're huge and they wind all over the place and every third shop looks the same. But it is an incredible experience. It is definitely very overwhelming and you don't feel like you can look at anything without being harassed. I had one shop seller chase me through the souks when I refused his price. The souks really have everything you need and don't need, and everything in between. Just make sure your vigilant. There are a lot of pickpockets and you are likely to get harassed. and you will get lost. Know this, and get down there anyway.http://www.tripadvisor.co.uk/ShowUserReviews-g293734-d4234431-r327168248-Marrakech_souks-Marrakech_Marrakech_Tensift_El_Haouz_Region.html#

Overwhelming but a must do. You will get lost in the souks. You really will. They're huge and they wind all over the place and every third shop looks the same. But it is an incredible experience. It is definitely very overwhelming and you don't feel like you can look at anything without being harassed. I had one shop seller chase me through the souks when I refused his price. The souks really have everything you need and don't need, and everything in between. Just make sure your vigilant. There are a lot of pickpockets and you are likely to get harassed. and you will get lost. Know this, and get down there anyway.

Was hot,busy and smelly!. Well after hearing so much about this place,I was really looking forward to seeing it my self.Honestly it's not as people say it is.its very busy,full of Morocco people shopping,there's cars,bikes everywhere.Theres little kids and woman begging any foreigner they see for money.Theres a lot of Little shops,with a lot of things to buy(I spent a lot on shopping)but the shop keepers start off with very high prices,then u have to bargain it down.(what ever they say,it's half that price)if there not going down on price,just say u can't afford it and walk out,they won't let u leave and will give it to u for your price.(it's a lot of time waste).im glad I've seen it,and if your in Morocco then I would say visit.

Great place, must to visit. Great market, you will find whatever you are looking for here in this market,. The culture is at its height. Yes sellers will approach and will try to sell at artificial prices so common sense will be your best friend. Simple suggestion, do not buy until you have checked the prices at least thrice from different shops. The further you move away from market the cheaper prices will become.

A living museum. This is a truly magical place that has so much to offer! There is a huge amount to do and see with everything from cultural sights of importance to beautiful Riads and great restaurants and shops!

Everything you expect and better. This was my 2nd trip to Marrakech, 1st trip we went to the square on the evening so it was dark, and we were a bit taken back by the amount of hassle from everyone and also children begging etc, this trip we went into Marrakech again to give it a try in the days and we were so glad we did! The souls are beautiful and you really feel your part of the action it's tiny alleyways the friendly Moroccan people the smells from the spice markets all made for a great experience, there is very little hassle in the soul compared to the square where they are a tad aggressive, you have to barter for everything but that's part of the fun, making deals laughing with the traders etc, I have to say it's an experience that everyone should try!! Probably not in the evening / night for a first time cause even in the day it's quite a massive rowdy busy and intimidating place!

A nice sight to see but very busy. It is the same as any souk or market with a twist. They have monkeys and snakes on display where you can have a picture with a price. Lots of shops selling almost the same products. Just be careful and always barter with the price of the product you want to buy. Overall, a nice experience.

Haggle haggle haggle . Been twice and some lovely store owners remembered me, beautiful one of a kind merchandise to outfit homes and bodies alike. They use good quality materials and are always willing to bargain. Be wary of pickpocket though and of the Orange juice stands- if you go to one and not the other, it's very likely that someone will start cursing you. Otherwise an amazing experience which I hope to relive as many times as possible.

Rip off. They charge you extremely high prices because they know you are a tourist bought some dates from agadir at 20 dh per kilo and here 40 which is double each stall will have a different price as you move away they drop by half straight away put me off from buying anything , too many beggars yet not sure who is genuine snakes are so dehydrated they hardly move and monkeys being treated like money making things. I bought a small seesha for 80 dh I was first quoted 250 from various shops it put me off from shopping there.

Morrocan and Touristic ambiance. The souks in Marrakech are spread in a very large part of the "Medina", the center of Marrakech. Many tourists, many people trying to sell you lots of bags / spices / souvenirs / plates etc... Nice experience, but take care: be full of energy before entering the souks!Note: For any price proposed by the seller, you need to negotiate at least 50% of the price.

Marrakech souk is spoilt by constant hassle. You either like the haggling and combative buying culture or not. If you don't you will hate Marrakech as it's even more hassle than I experienced in Egypt. If you do it's full of interesting stuff. You can actually get some souvenirs cheaper at the airport surprisingly !
What a different shopping day!. Making your shopping at the soul (zocco) is an experience by itself. Bargain is the key word here and you will su rely find everything you are looking for! Magical.

Not for the faint-hearted but a must-see. Study your maps - getting lost is great fun but can lead to being misguided by the locals. Glittering metalwork, a rainbow of colours, the smell of leather and spices make for a unique stroll around the shops unrivalled anywhere. Haggling is fun if you approach it with the right attitude - it's cultural not cheapskate, don't offer if you don't intend to buy (even if you can't agree a price and leave) and keep smiling.

Like being on set filming Indiana Jones!. Wow a real experience! This place has a fascinating selection of hand crafted goods made of leather and pottery. There are a range of spices and oils. In the middle of the square are snake charmers with loose snakes!!

Hold on to your hats!!! Its a wonderful ride!. You have to experience the souk when in Marrakesh, its an experience you have to embrace. Colourful, lively, noisy and fun. Do not accept the first price offered by the sellers offer a quarter of the price first then work upwards to half and stop. If you do not want to buy, walk away. Try the street food, choose a busy place, (the food will be cooked and served fresh) Make sure the food is hot. Use wet wipes on glasses and utensils for your own peace of mind. Alcohol served at most restaurants, but you have to go upstairs to drink, but gives a great view over the souk and street entertainers. Enjoy!
traditionelle. a pleasant place observe cleanliness and agitante evening with traditional music and a dream marrocaine show

Markets!. Large mazes of fun stalls. Easy to get lost. Hagglings a must. The figurine i bought today went down from 800dh to 250dh for example.
Hastling is a bit strong, similar to Turkey 15 years ago.
Market Square Marrakech. The snake charmers are interesting and the vibe of the square is lovely, best seen at night, also useful to help you find many sights

ALADDINS CAVE. Everything Moroccan you could ever wish to buy!! And more. Haggling is expected. Start at about one third of price and go from there. Dont be mean cos things are really cheap and support a lot of artisans.

Shopping experience like no other.. The souks are a great way to meet and communicate with the locals...you can find all things from clothes to carpets. Be warned as it's a tourist sight don't settle for the first price given, you must haggle and push to ensure you're not being ripped off! If you don't want the attention - never make eye contact. It's worth learning a few phrases as this will come on handy when trying to bargain.

STAY AWAY AT ALL COSTS - REALLY SCARY. Myself and my partner decided to walk to the Marrakech Souk from out hotel. On the way a man approached us and said he recognized us from our hotel, he then said we were going the wrong way and he would show us how to get there. 2 hours later he was still with us!!! We could not get rid of him and he took us into the awful maze of stalls which was the most frightening experience of my life!! I didn't even open up my bag to take my camera out for fear of being mugged. Motor bikes were constantly going by and nearly knocking you over, donkeys had their hind legs tied together to stop them running away. Our so called "guide" would not leave us and was trying to get us into shops to spend money. Eventually we'd had enough and told him to leave us alone, he then was demanding money from us! We gave him 100 Dirham in the end even though he wanted 200, just to get rid of him. We then carried on walking round trying to find our way out of the awful maze. Another man approached saying he would help us to get to the open plaza but again he led us in the complete wrong direction and demanded money too!! There was nowhere to go to the toilet or sit down and have a drink. Eventually after walking around for what seemed like a lifetime we came out to the Plaza. After sitting down for a drink there we decided to watch the snake charmers. Again big mistake!! A man immediately put 2 snakes around my partner's neck and started demanding money for a photo. I made out I hadn't got a camera on me so he then got aggressive and said to give money for snakes. Everyone is out to con you. One so called guide even swore at us because we asked him to leave us alone. I couldn't wait to get in a taxi and get back to the safety of the hotel. The roads are so dangerous to cross too and the pavements are mostly in an awful state with large holes in them. I would never go back there again. I have travelled to quite a few countries over the years and I have never feared for my safety so much as here!!

Find the secrets in the Souk. If you wander alone around the narrow, bustling and mostly covered streets of the Souk it's easy to lose your bearings. I have previously reviewed Marrakech Guided Tours and their educated local guide Abdul. He will show you the secrets of the Souk which most people miss completely and instead leave feeling brow beaten and bothered by the constant invitations to buy things you just don't want. I like to be polite when saying I'm not interested but a smile and shake of the head leads to even more efforts to persuade me to at least take a look. With Abdul (and other good guides) you are not bothered by sellers and instead are left to enjoy the surroundings in the knowledge that wherever he leads, you will be safe and not get lost. On this trip he took us to see a 96 year old man who has been hand stitching slippers (see picture) since before World War Two. His slippers are a wonder of an ancient and dying craft now that machines do most of the work. Abdul also takes us around the back of the stalls to show us the legions of workers squatting on the bare ground beating copper, tanning leather or engraving metal objects. He also has his favourite coffee shop in a local part of the Souk where it's just fun to watch the people. My tip to enjoy the Souk and not get lost is to hire a guide and ask to see the secrets.
A maze. It feels like you are in a labyrinth no end to it. There are stalls to whatever your heart desires but remember you look...you buy. he he

Tiresome tat-touting tourist trap. I guess the souks of Marrakech have to be experienced but half an hour of being pestered by vendors who just won't let you browse in peace, irritating young men constantly trying to offer their services as guides or trying to send you the wrong way, the constant motorcycles passing by (occasionally at dangerously high speeds) and the simple fact the shops all sell the same old thing, is enough to get the picture. A walk around the souk does give you some feeling for how the place must have been in the past, and there are some cobblers and tailor shops and the like, but the truth is it's now just a tourist trap selling mostly crap that you have to bargain constantly for. It's fairly clean but the fumes of the bikes can be irritating.

Really intimating environment, lots of animal cruelty. Very upsetting. So many people I had met at the hotel were talking about their visit to the Souks so I wanted to check it out and see for myself. In a way I am glad I went because it's educational in terms of seeing raw culture from your own perspective. However, the overall experience was very intimating! I'm a 20 year old student, believe myself to be pretty feisty and know how to use the word 'no', but there was something about the locals that really made me feel at ease. I have been to many markets in lots of different countries who try and haggle you into their shop but eventually lay off, the locals here actually get nasty with you and can be quite abusive. The whole environment is dirty and un-hygenic. If you're thinking of purchasing any sort of food from here, DON'T. There are flies on everything and I dread to think how they handle & prep the food. The Souks are guarded by massive 4 walls, I think many people refer to this as 'Old town'. And it's just complete poverty, which is such an eye-opener. Many pickpockets so be very careful and don't take any valuables or a lot of money. The place is insanely huge, almost impossible to walk around the whole place. From the moment I entered here, I was cleverly approached by a stranger who convinced me he worked at my hotel. He then dragged me to a spice show and returned after 5 minutes forcing me to give him £80! There are also so so many forms of animal abuse which is just crazily upsetting and ruined my day. If you're easily upset by this I would advise you to give this a miss. There are drugged monkeys on chains which are trained to steal from your pockets, they are left all day in dirty nappies etc. There are also drugged and docile snakes. There were auctions to buy and skin live sheep. The whole thing was just completely insane and out of comfort zone.

Such a different place. So different to anything I am used to, full of sounds and smells both exotic and a little icky at times, exciting and scary as well. You will have people coming up to you and offering unsolicited help and they will expect a tip, and many of them expect big tips! Be aware that you will also be lead around the houses and taken to lots of 'friends' and there is an expectation at each of them. Don't feel obliged! Remember to bargain it is amazing how you can reduce prices with a little conviction.Having said all that, it is an amazing place to visit so have fun and be prepared to be lost!

A crazy experience!. The souks are a maze of wonderful shops and interesting people. It was an incredible experience..so much so I visited them twice!There are some amazing things to buy, but remember to haggle and don't be afraid to walk away as a shop round the corner will have the same thing, it's just likely to be cheaper!I would recommend that anyone visiting Morocco should visit the souks as it is fantastic!

Worth a look. It's worth dipping into the souks just to see what it's about but I didn't like it personally. It's too busy and closed in for my liking. We went all through it once but that was it. There are some nice restaurants further in and you can get some good bargains. But so easy to get lost and in general the locals will send you the wrong way in the direction of their shop

Great for Bargin hunting and artisan goods. Great way to get lost the narrow streets and all the Shops etc. try to go to the souk where the locals go, Less hassle, less touristy tat more Artisan goods + prices are cheaper.

A must. The Marrakech souks are a mix of everything you actually don't need. We took our two daughters who were shocked because of the numerous cats and dogs wandering around. Visiting the souks is an adventure, a treat for all senses and a must!
enjoyed.. Was an experience however once was enough. I found it hard to walk as were very buzy and with donkeys and motorcycles

Absolutely Essential part of the Marrakech experience. A visit to the souks is essential for any trip to Marrakech. Be prepared to refuse many advances from traders and people offering you directions. The only real way to view the souks is to go in and get lost (careful not to go down too many routes that have few shops, when in doubt, take the busiest looking street). Do not take directions from anyone even if they claim "not to be a guide" they will either lead you towards their friends' shop or lead you to where you want to go in exchange for a fee of course. The souks all in all are a great place to get some bargains, don't be afraid to haggle, start at 1/3 the asking price and go from there but always have a maximum price in your head. Don't be afraid to say you are walking away, the traders will most likely take your offer.

Huge souk streets. The Souk in the Medina seems to radiate from the main square (by the minarette) with stalls in the square itself but then covered streets off from there also and these tend to get you away from the mopeds constantly buzzing around the city. Different parts of the Souk have specialities and there is a particular leather area of the city for example. We found the Jewish quarter (near the Bahia palace) best price for spices, the range of which is amazing. Otherwise, ceramics, Moroccan metalwork, leather, shoes, tee shirts can all be found. Many of the goods are overpriced at the start, offer 30% of whatever you are told and go to maybe 50%. Walking away always tests whether you have found a fair price!
Shop till you drop then shop some more. You want 500 dirhams I'll give you 100 and off you go , No where else like it a maze of sights and smells Put it on your bucket list !
colorful. there is so much bargains to grab and food places to eat at good prices but make sure ur ready to haggle

Make sure you're in the right frame of mind - then it's fun!!. You need to seriously negotiate here!!Slightly dubious as to the "made in China" origin of quite a bit of the stuff for sale - as opposed to bring locally made....It's fun if you take it in the right spirit and are prepared to walk away from the "negotiations"... Suggest early evening is best and then you're more than ready for your aperitif...!! It's a little exhausting!

Terrific Fun. You can't go to the Median without visiting the Souk. Its a crazy place, bustling, chaotic, but fantastic fun. You *must* bargain hard if you see something you'd like to buy. There are beautiful things on offer, lanterns, spices, textiles, perfumes and so on. Authentic, historic Marrakech condensed into a small place. Loved it.

Go Ahead, Get Lost. The Marrakech souk is a great place to wander, and, if you find the right shop, perhaps to buy. It's the wandering that you will remember, however, so look for the rooster souk (listen, you will find it), wander through the smaller alleys, look through the doorways, get a glimpse of local life. Morocco is full of sights and sounds and smells different from your own home town, and there is no where more colorful and exotic than the souk in Marrakech.

An absolute must. No visit to Morocco would be complete without venturing into the souks and, once in, you will probably get lost! Of course, there is a huge hassle factor from traders trying to sell their wares, and the whole point is to haggle relentlessly. But be fair, the traders need to make a living. Most guide books have a few rules of etiquette to follow when buying in the souks.

A Maze ing. Two visits to the souks of Marrakech, a few days apart, helped us to appreciate and enjoy the sensory delights and differences of the souks. Starting in the less confined but no less exciting main square where all manner of goods and services are offered, for a consideration. Whether it is false teeth, snakes, spices or freshly squeezed oranges the choice is yours. Entering the more confined and convoluted spaces of the souks, avoiding motorbikes and cyclists carrying baskets of live chickens, you are presented with a wealth of choice on all sides. We didn't feel threatened or unsafe but worried about getting lost. Leaving trails of breadcrumbs wouldn't work and there weren't balls of string long enough so we gave up worrying and went with the flow. Our first visit was exploratory, with the intention of returning to complete any purchases. This worked well as we were able to observe various negotiations and examine products, without the pressure of buying. The second, more focussed visit, produced several bargain items including leather, pottery and a rug, which we knew would be appreciated and fit into our luggage ! Our haggling experience, en-route to the desert, came in handy in the more intense atmosphere of the souks. We returned to the main square, to a cafe terrace, to witness the transition from daytime to nighttime accompanied by the sound of the call to prayer from the various surrounding minarets and the backdrop of hundreds of rooftop satellite dishes !Provided you have a good sense of direction everything else will fall into place in this fantastic environment.

Fascinating, but take your time. If you have a few days in Marrakech, then take some time to wander before you buy anything. By about the third time in we knew our way around better, and what to buy (or not!) and what price to expect to pay. Take your time, there are LOTS of stalls, and lots of options. Negotiation is all about you both being happy with the price, not about either of you getting the better of the other. We never felt unsafe or threatened, and just politely said 'La, Shrukran' when we were not interested. No one really pushed it. Really like walking back through there towards the end of the day, a lot less busy.

Shopping. Keep your sense of humour & your wits about you and enjoy this unique shopping experience. Tall tales and taller prices are all part of the haggling experience. Throw yourself into it and you won't be disappointed. Never bid if you've no intention of buying. That's disrespectful. And always have a price in your head that you won't go above, and stick to it! The souks are a fantastic way to get lost in the medina and discover hidden gems.

The ultimate Market. This is the biggest Souk in Morocco and its huge with thousands (yes thousands) of stalls. But its easy to get lost so be careful. you barter for everything (offer half what they ask). the shops and the workshops that make the items are all here in many, many streets. Huge displays of items, all sizes and colours and if they don't have what you want they go off and get it from a friend (lots of cooperatives). it can be intimidating if you are not used to haggling. once you stop to even look the owner will approach you and want to sell you something, he will not want you to walk away empty handed so if you don't want to buy simply say no politely, walk away and keep saying no and keep walking. Its the norm and they will not be offended. when you see the amount of goods for sale you wonder how they sell it all. a real experience, And ladies cover your body (not your head) out of respect, no shorts or short sleeves blouses, it will not be appreciated. go in the evening when its cooler, its open until very late. most hotels offer free buses to the centre and always stop at the souk
Quite touristy but good all the same. Very busy, hot and bustling - but that's why you go! it is touristy but fun all the same. Make sure you barter hard for your bargains!
Don't miss this bustling colourful experience.. Don't miss this bustling colourful experience. The market stall escargots were fab! Good to visit during the day but especially at night.
WOW. An out of this world experience. Has to be seen to be believed. Such a great atmosphere and def worth a visit - getting lost in the souks is part of the fun!!!

a Unique experience. We were told that a visit to Marrakech is not complete unless you have seen the Souk. So off we went. It did prove to be a unique experience. so many small stalls and shops full of all kinds of stuff . What we liked were the ceramics. They are absolutely gorgeous. We had a suitcase full by the time we left. We soon learnt that you have to haggle to arrive at a mutually agreeable price. We did it, though it was not a very pleasant experience.

Heavy heart. With a heavy heart i am leaving Marrakesh where i stayed in a little hotel in an alleyway in the Souks. Very saddened by how much struggle it must be for these people to survive - all selling their wares, 1000s upon 1000s of the same thing.But most saddened by seeing the monkeys on leashes for us to take photos off, attacking their owners out of frustration of being constantly pulled around by their neck; the coach horses are the ones with the heaviest most gruel some labour. I can only imagine what it must be like to pull a coach in traffic that is so intense that even just crossing the road ranks high on my stress raider. These poor animals having to navigate the traffic noise and pollution and staying up way past midnight where all their nature instincts are severely overriden day after day, night after night...........i am so grateful that i have had only 2 days here and have an exit from all the insanity of the struggle for survival that we all live in some form. Please do not support these businesses ............we are all creatures with the same needs......please start reconnecting with our most beloved and threatened animals and think before we purchase .....a ride.....a photo...... is their suffering involved?

Crowded, but fun. The souks are a blaze of color and life! Note that Fridays are a holy day and about 1/2 of the souks are closed and many of the craftsmen do not work on Fridays. The prices are not cheap, so definitely bargain drastically. Note also that the sellers are very aggressive. If you don't want them to harass you just say "La" or "No Merci" and keep going.

A must do. Beware the happy friendly locals wanting you to photograph them and offering directions - it all costs - be firm and they'll ease off. At first it's intimidating & takes the fun out of it but when you embrace it there are many bargains to be had. The cafes in the square are very well priced and have many options on the menu - with a side order of begging and touting, but it's all part of the experience
Fun. You can spend a whole day here walking around- great place to wander around in and look at all the different stalls.

A real experience. Ths souk has anything you want. There are multiple stores that carry the same things so look around a little. In addition many of the same type of stores are owned by the same person. Just remember to negotiate on everything, push hard and even walk away, they will come after you. Just look the items over well as some are not that good of quality. Leather items are inexpensive but look carefully. The owner of our riad offered to have someone come to the riad with leather items if we wanted and he said he would negotiate.

Huge array of goods.. Great range of goods, ranging from good quality, to typical tourist stuff. Be prepared to bargain hard, but do not rush into early buying without having a good look at all the shops.

getting better !!. the souk is getting better and better to visit. it feels that people are less of a hassle trying to sell you constantly. you still have some, but in general it feels friendlier than in previous years, the souk itself is magical... the light is amazing, the things you can buy are diverse enough and there are great places to stop for lunch or diner

Bargaining is an art. Spent 2 afternoons in the souk this visit and had fun bargaining...some vendors freely share knowledge and chat with you...it is a fun experience, keeping in mind it is mostly a tourist trap...some nice restaurants...

A challenging visit. We used a very good professional guide to visit the Medina and the souk which was ideal as we coils you could have got lost in the narrow alleys. We had to be quick to avoid the scooters and motor bikes! . The souk had tanning and blacksmith areas that are pre industrial revolution. The retail area has a multitude of stalls selling everything from leather goods and metal work to fabrics and jewellery. We avoided most of the bartering on our first visit which familiarised us with the area. Don't expect it to be like the more upmarket Grand Bazaar in Istanbul or the Souks in Doha or Dubai.------original review-------
Must visit. Soak up the atmosphere of the souks...use your bartering skills and get a bargain it's all part of the experience!!

Interesting. We paid a guide 50 dirhams (approx £4.00) who showed us around & stopped the shop keepers pestering us but once we had learned in Arabic No thank you ( La shukraan) they left you alone. Our grandchildren were not happy to see the monkeys which the sellers were trying to get them to hold for photos which they want payment for, as did the snake charmers, even from a distance but I suppose this is their lively hood.

AMAZING WALKING THROUGH THE PASSAGES. The Souks are just amazing, walking through the passages full of beautiful pottery, lanterns, rugs and cushions. I would have bought so much more home if wasn't hassled every 5 seconds

Bargain, bargain and then bargain some more !. The real price is about 1/4 to 1/3 of the price they first quote you.Bargain hard !Head for the very crowded and somewhat claustrophobic interior for the best prices.Watch out for pickpockets !Never felt in any physical danger, but I was bumped unnecessarily a number of times (they want you to reach for your valuables). Plus, at one point a young man in neon orange Bermuda shorts circled us three times in about 10 minutes. I mean really, neon orange shorts ! Anyway, I pointed him out to the rest of our group of 4, and he was gone.

It's all you read about. Amazing labyrinth of sellers of carpets, clothes, shoes and virtually everything you could think of.We hired a guide (£14 for 2 hours) to avoid getting lost.Saw more cats (alive and dead) than I've ever seen before.

Avoid eye contact, don't point to anything and haggle, haggle, haggle!. Love the souks, but it can get wearing after a few visits. Shops full of colourful and pretty things you'll find hard to resist, but divide the seller's price by 3 and start bargaining from there. It's all part of the game and should be played with good humour. If you're not interested, decline politely and walk away. Friday evening is a bit less busy as is early morning, so go then if you want to shop more peacefully.

A must do. The first day you are there, AVOID THIS PLACE DURING THE DAY. Its far more impressive at night time. Go at night for the first time for the most amazing sights and sounds. It starts around 7 and finishes at midnight. Go for a (non alcoholic) drink on one of the rooftop bars and sit enjoying the views.

Not the best experience in Marrakech. The Souk is usually considered a highlight of a trip to Marrakech but in fact it is dirty, smelly and you are constantly approached by locals for money or to buy goods. It is not very different from the experience in other third world countries like Thailand or India and if you have seen one you can probably minimize the time planned for this one.

Touristy. Coming from Fez, Marrakesh is more tourist orientated. Things cost more and people are more pushy to sell. Lots of things all the same and not the best quality. Found it tiresome and only bought a few trinkets. Not the place to shop for quality rugs, pottery or metal.
Crazy!. Busy and fast, but excitingly unique. Nowhere else like it! It is not as hassly as other places in the world, and much more enjoyable fro shopping

Rudeness and non stop hassle. The fun has gone out of browsing through the souks. I could not look at anything without being harassed. At one point, as I was looking at interesting dyes, I suddenly found myself with a headscarf of the colour of the dye, whilst my friend was having a scarf of a different colour round her neck ! On numerous occasions I was told Fiche le camp ( basically Get Lost ) or Va- t-en or Bon Voyage all said in an aggressive manner

Busy and exciting. Enjoyed a couple of hours in the souks of marrakech on Friday. Great bargains yo be has but make sure you have a price in mind and stick to it. Walking away if you can't make your price will almost guarantee the stall holder to come after you and agree to your price. The sights and smells were amazing. Only down side is the constant harassment and the stall holders refusal to take no for an answer!
Wow Don't miss this!. There is always something happening here - snake charmers, fortune tellers and hustlers. Hang on to your money. Beautiful rugs are for sale, but bargain!!!!

Just another souk for me.... A souk is like a market or a grand bazaar where vendor are selling a wide variety of items from live animals to jewelry, leather goods, woolen items, crafts, etc. This one was crowded and rather dirty. Luckily the vendors aren't rude and pushy like the Grand Bazaar in Istanbul. There are areas in the souk that are dedicated to different items like leather, wool, jewelry, food, etc. It will take about 2-3 hours if you want to see it all.
Shopping Experience. If you like to haggle then this is shopping paradise. Although I dislike haggling I think this is a must see place to visit in Marrakech. The sellers are friendly.

What a sensation. Your eyes might catch various goods from clothes, foods to unique souvenirs offered by shops. Sometimes smells from leather product are strong enough enhance the sensation. Vendors are most likely to greet you and invite to buy their products.
Busy place. Who like shopping, and busy place - Jemaa el Fna is greate place :) around are nice cafes, kiosks where they make fresh juices.
Loud, colorful and fun.. You will be invaded by a myriad of smells (many not pleasant), sights and noise. It's crazy, loud and busy but a lot of fun. Be prepared for bargaining as this is expected.
You've got to haggle. Something to experience. Relax and get among it. No offer, no matter how low, appears to result in a no-sale

Dianne. Too much to go with children. The people were over friendly which scared the children. Dont get conned by the guides. You are warned that they will come up to you as soon as you get there but what isnt mentioned is that some of the smart young men see the arm bands and say they recognise you from the hotel because they work there this is not true. They dont want money but take you around their shops

You need to visit. but as many are aware off, if you're not with a trustworthy guide and you're not comfortable with the haggling then most likely you'll be disapointed to realise that you've been slightly ripped-off.
