On top of that there's non-genuine items all over and it's very difficult to know what's worth looking at, most reasonable price, etc. Go to Ensemble Artisanal first, get an idea of the prices and then come to the vibrant souk, better prepared certainly. A tip: if you don't express interest and you're very stiff with your first response and don't feed the conversation, you'll be fine.

Bargains!. If you love shopping and haggling for a bargain then this is the place to do it. Haggling can be fun here with a smile on your face and some friendly banter with the stall holders....they love it!

DEFINITELY DO NOT LISTEN TO INTERNET HYPE!!. Without doubt this was one of the best cultural shopping experiences of my life to date (aged 45). I read a lot of comments on the internet about various safety/security concerns but I have to say my family and I enjoyed a wonderful day out in the Souk and whilst of course, one does need to have the safety of the children at the forefront of this experience, we personally did not encounter anything other than very pleasant, fun, playful locals who are simply trying to make a living selling their goods in the Souk. Bartering was fun and made the whole experience so enjoyable for the whole family and our children aged 9 and 15. We did not ever feel uncomfortable and not one local person was rude of offensive in anyway in fact I have experience quite the contrary here in England on occasions. The Souk has absolutely everything you could possible want to buy and the key not to getting lost is to have methodical strategy of which section to walk down and then simply return and change course. DONT WANDER OFF INTO A STREET THAT CLEARLY HAS NO VISIBLE GOODS FOR SALE AS YOU WILL BE GOING INTO AREAS THAT ARE NON TOURIST PRODOMINANT. Keep to the main square and you cannot go wrong. We went in the day and then returned at night - nightime is very different and it basically becomes a food market which lots of morrocan culture eg; Henna Tatoos, Snake Charmers, Monkeys doing tricks and local storytellers, it's a very different experience but both so equally enjoyable. Really do not be put of travelling to this wonderful place, very rich in cultural experiences for anyone!! Will definitely go again and get some more goods. One final tip - what ever the price asked go in with less than half of this and work from there, they respect a good barter and find this very enjoyable but the key thing is do not insult them and their trades as many souk sellers have family run businesses and work very very hard to produce the most amazing goods. They do business with a smile and it is important that we respect that they have to make a profit here and there and the whole tradition of this wonderful place depends on this - it is not about getting everything for a ridiculously cheap price!

Colorful and exciting. Part of the Medina, or old city, the souk is made up of many alleys spreading out from the central square. Vendors are friendly and there are wonderful spice merchants and lots of fruits and grains.

Hate it or love it. Hate it or love it - I haven't even decided myself which it is. There is simply just too much of everything, but in a fascinating way. Expect loudness, crowds, and getting lost. Whatever products Marrakech is known for, you will find ot here - I did a little shopping myself.The upside is the variety, the exotic products and the food and juice stalls. The downside is the aggressiveness of the sellers. Some sellers may throw you bad words if you pass by without entering, and some may try to hold you back by force. Find the ones that you feel comfortable with - all products are everywhere, so if you don't like the sellers, go somewhere else.Whatever you do, watch out for scams and thefts, and remember nothing comes for free.
great walk around. got some great bargains and had a greta time haggling. The people were great and loved banter. The kids enjoyed it also.

Worth a visit. In the center of Medina. Really worth a visit. Many small shops selling anything. From fish&meat to hand made boots from snakes skin. Be prepared to get lost but don't worry. If you can coordinate yourself you'll find your way sooner than what you except. Don't forget to negotiate the price. Even 10-15 times lower than suggested price.

People Don't Like Their Picture Taken. Ask before you take pictures of people. If they do give their OK expect to pay for that privilege. Avoid scammers who will tell you they work at your hotel and recognize you. Be aware of pickpockets. Should be experienced once but I would not go back again.

A feast for the senses. A riot of colour, noise, smell, taste and texture - something you'll never forget. Market sellers tended to be pushy but invariably accepted a firm no and a smile with good humour. I loved this experience!

has to be visited. This is an experience you cannot miss unless you are squeamish. Alleyways lead to alleyways of shops selling every thing from Roy Banns (lol) to every spice you could wish for. Go at night and it looks and smells totally different

A must to visit. This is Marrakech as it has been for thousands of years. What an exciting place to go to. In this souk you can find everything - you name it and it is there. I stocked up on Argan Oil and was given the most amazing foot massage in the process! Allow several hours to get the benefit of this place! It is amazing.

you can't miss the expierence of visiting the souks. Most pf the souks seemed to open after 10am. The plates are beautiful, I bought 2 med size for 100 dh.the slippers are not real cheap,I think I paid about150dh.they had rubber soles.the spices I bought were reasonable, prepacakaged, in small plastic bags.It was suggested to get the spice that has 25 different spices together.most merchants were nice and you couldconverse in English. They took Euro or DH, as payment.I had a sore leg, and they even gavr up their seat for me to sit.

Fascinating!. First visited with a guide to get our bearings and avoid being hassled as a mum and daughter.This did help so on our next visits we had a bit of an idea.However we still managed to go round in circles twice and end up at the same place.! I loved the atmosphere and we had no trouble from anyone.We did have one man who was trying to tell us which way to the tannery but we politely told him we were going the other way,it all added to the adventure of wandering around,not really knowing where we were going.I don't really like bartering and I'm sure I paid too high a price for some things but this was my fault.Stopped for lunch at café in main square on the rooftop and had great view of all the sights below. So many people selling the same thing it makes you wonder how everyone makes a living.

Same old, same old. Although the souks are a major part of life for a lot of locals, most store sellers like to start prices high for tourists and this puts you off buying goods. Furthermore, almost every other store sells similar things; usually scarves, dresses and lanterns. Be prepared to be hassled by store owners!

An experience. Was a buzzing, filled with smells and experiences Was a bit busy but fun although lots of pushy salesmen which worried the kids slightly Was glad at one point when the football came on coz the shop keepers ignored us, which gave us time to look in peace!

Fun - but be careful!. This was a lot of fun! Be prepared to barter your backside as this place depends on tourists! So as a result, they up the price of every item to a ridiculous amount. Also, you get some good and bad shop owners i.e. the aggressive ones, and the ones who enjoy a good negotiation. Have fun!@instabuilt
Feels unsafe. I would not recommend going on your own or as a couple easy to get lost so take a guide and you get hassled all the time but worth a visit

Look if you dare!!. The men are a pain, they hassle you from beginning to end and are shouting after you if you pass their stall, if you dare to look and find your not interested in anything on their stall they all have an uncle who will have a spice stall that your bound to find something you want!! There must be bargains to be had but because of the hassle it can make it impossible to get your head round it!! If you do see something you like haggling is the name of the game, the first price they give you is about 4-6 times the price its actually worth, for example I liked a small chopping board made out of lemon wood, the guys first price was £25 and after haggling it came down to £4 but it took me so long to get to the real price its a real putter offer!! Every time you want to buy something you have to go through this insane haggling, it puts you off buying anything and I can haggle with the best of them!! A real eye opener and a sight to behold though!!

Be Prepared!. First visit to the souks was alone. I dressed head to foot, arms covered, head covered. It honestly bought me some time to look at things without being hassled constantly. Of course, the moment you stop to look you will be encouraged to look for free with your eyes as it costs nothing! :)This was an enjoyable experience although very confined with bikes, donkeys, traders, tourists and locals wondering around in relatively small spaces.It's not M&S so best to accept it and immerse oneself!For me the souks were better than the square as the store owners don't touch you to try to get you in and people are incredibly polite, unlike the henna ladies in the square.At the end of the day, there are hundreds of people selling identical items and it's a wonder how anybody carves a living from this. Depending upon your mindset it's going to be very easy or very difficult to make purchases here. Not everyone is geared up to barter or to take the copious amount of cliché flannel you'll hear over and over again. I found it a highly enjoyable experience because of these aspects to be honest. All the stall holders are incredibly courteous about you and your city or country and naturally, they are all giving you the ''best price''. I'm certain we overpaid on almost every purchase, but in context it's nothing and hopefully somebody will benefit from it.There are many stray cats and the donkeys pulling carts are straight from an RSPCA Christmas begging letter. It pulled on our heartstrings but again; hopefully by making purchases the benefits will be spread out.If bartering and tight spaces make you feel woozy, you could try the ENSEMBLE ARTISANAL. More spacious, less desperate feel to it but with many of the same items you'll see in the souks.When venturing with two tall blonde female teenagesr I was still comfortable; there was no apparent anger from anybody at the way they girls were dressed (one of them was wearing a vest) and there was no unpleasantness as others appear to have experienced.Overall a good experience I'd happily undertake again.

For the best bargains go direct to the crafters. By going to the back of the souks you will find the people who craft everything that is sold there. You will often find an excellent bargain by haggling with these people than those nearer the more touristy bits.
What an experience.. Amazing experience. So much colour and vibrancy. Bargains galore to be had. Brush up on your bartering skills. What an incredible place to visit.

Souk souk souk. Wow whT a buzz this place is enjoy and relax...loved every second of being there.
Super hot tempreture during day and those muggy nights...just perfect.
Beats the cold british wet weather any day

Haggle your way through!. The souks were beautiful, we spent a lot of the time walking through them and speaking to the locals who also offered us mint tea, talk about hospitality. You will get a lot of people trying to get you into their stalls to have a look, but be firm and polite and they'll just leave you alone. Don't accept the first price someone gives you!

enjoyable anytime.. When i first came to the souk it felt so lively.It had entertainment,places to eat and plenty of shops.It is so lively when you enter the souk coming from the side where all the horse carraiges are.If you want to go on the horse carraiges make sure you haggle the price start from a third of what they ask.If you go back of the queue of the carraiges you will get a better price.When you go to eat they are all nicely priced and the food is good.We always ate in the souk before going back to the hotel.The price and quality is good.MAKE sure you have plenty change when taking photos because whenever you take photo of snake charmers,monkeys etc the people see you and pester you for money just give them few dh.

Don't hesitate to take side streets. Try also the side streets and you will discover magic places. Don't be afraid to get lost...you will find your way eventually. The souk is safe as long as you behave like a wise traveller.

Gangsters....... Can't really blame them.......Everything I say below is a result of both seller and buyer haggling day in day out.... Year after year.....They can put the monkey/snake on your kid so you feel guilty not to play along and eventually paying.Many shops are truly friendly even if your offer is really ridiculous, but some can get a bit rude...! But one can feel proud of a long haggling and only few shops down felt ripped off, in this case a toy top/spice/tea...But that is the fun .... Go ahead make their day..!!!!

Hagglers heaven. You haven't experienced marrakech to the full without a visit to the souks,hundreds of little shops nestled together through narrow streets,a hagglers paradise for sure.You can find everything from clothes,leather goods,hammered teapots,rugs,scarves,confectionery,even suitcases!The secret to the souks is patience and tenacity I found two silk woven scarves the chap said 900 Dirham ,to you.and me around £80, I laughed shook my head and said non as.a wee bit of French really does help 100 Dirham he laughed non 700 my final offer I again laughed my final offer 200 non Madame I cannot ,ok I said shook.his hand and walked out of his shop...wait for it ...he ran after me ok Madame 200dirham deal done,game played brilliantly by both.Yes you may find it exhausting to have people take you by the arm and leading you towards their shop or hearing "Madame monsieur come look it's free to look" but go with it have fun with them,we went nearly everyday during our week long visit so addictive.Every little street holds an Aladdin cave waiting to be discovered no sign posts to let you know about these hidden gems,but the square is well sign posted in the souk.We found a little street followed it round and were in the midst of a wool dying factory ,well an old man in front of a very large vat dying wool, which was then put on the roof to dry,all the colours found naturally in plants fascinating ,we also found.a shop selling crafts made from recycled inner tubes from bike and car tires,nothing seems to go to waste here.Take lots of money a sense of humour and a few spare hours and enjoy the sights sounds and smells of morrocos largest market.

A Dream for bargain hunters of the unique. When I was in Marrakesh, I came to the souk about 4 times. It was just so fantastic. So much to look at - shoes, spices, kaftans, poufs, etc. - and buy!The trick I learned to negotiating is:1) do NOT speak English. I only know a few words in Arabic, so French got me through. People could tell I was not a native French speaker, and sometimes spoke in English, but I responded in French. This seemed to go over well. I have several Moroccan friends, and the prices I reported paying to them I was told were "very good". 2) Another trick is NOT to go to the stores at the opening of the souk - wander inside, and to the far corners. Watch the locals and see where they go. Don't stick with the tourists or you're doomed. 3) Don't feel bad about negotiating. This is the culture, and it's like an art. In fact, I really thought that was half the fun of buying. :)4) Pay in Euros. Pretty much anyone accepts them - bills, coins, doesn't matter.In the end, I'd recommend buying things like shoes (because they are so unique), which can run as little as a few euros to maybe 10 Euros for something exceptional. Poufs are also a great travel-friendly item since they come empty and flat (just fill them with bubble wrap at home). I bought 2 medium/large ones and paid about 10 Euros a piece. I also bought kaftans as pool cover-ups for family. I found a place in the souk where I could get them (from shorter to full-length) for about 4-6 euros depending on the style. The beautiful wooden inlaid boxes set me back maybe 10 Euros for a smaller one (roughly the size of my hand) with pearl.If you can do it, buy furniture. I didn't want to worry about shipping, so I didn't go there. But it is so exceptional, I wish I had. I, sadly did NOT buy any purses/bags. This is the one item I thought was overpriced pretty much EVERYWHERE I went. I mean, REALLY overpriced. I've bought cheaper bags from Moroccan street vendors in Belgium an Italy - same leather bags with the hand-hammered details. Keep in mind that while hand-made, the components (eg. zippers, liners) aren't always the best quality, so despite the cool leather colors, etc., nothing was worth what they were asking in my book. Sad - as buying a bag had been on the top of my list - but in the end, I'm glad I spent my money on other things that were more unique anyway. Plus, the leather items really do carry a distinct smell for a LONG time (I swear, I can still smell the souk in my poufs).Last note - as is everywhere in Morocco, the souk is a family-friendly place. I had my son with me every time, either in the stroller or in a carrier on my back. I've never seen a culture that is so delighted by children and so kind to them. I've never felt safer and my son was constantly smiling.

Intense. The souk is a must see on your trip, however be prepared to have your senses assaulted by sights, sounds, smells and tastes. It is very busy and the likelihood is that you will get lost in the rabbit warren of souks, my advice is just to go with it. Do not agree to have someone show you the way back to the main square, as you will either have to pay them or you will get conned into going into a tannery or something similar. Also watch out for pickpockets.

Busy at all hours. Frantically busy at all times of the day. Preferred the atmosphere at night when all the street food stalls were set up. Lots of entertainment both day and night. Try the orange juice from vendors around the square. only tried one food stall, no 1, which was fine. Just make sure that you choose one which is busy.

A maze that must be experienced!. I agree this deserves a high rating, because it is enjoyable (if hard work at times!) and must be experienced. Maps are more effort then they are worth but we did get our bearings over the course of our trip. We were two young women and while you do get a hard sell and plenty of offers to guide you, we did feel safe and people were pleasant. It is important to keep your wits about you and be polite but firm. We did lose our way occasionally but always found it again, without the help of all the young men hanging around assume you are looking for the Jemaa el Fna square, and shourtand point you towards it. Some of the shops are also lovely.

Crazy Marrakech market. I loved this crazy hussel bustling city - noisy , smelly, enchanting. Be prepared to barter for your goods, if you can speak French you get a better price than in English, Wonderful leather and metal workers - try to avoid the un official guides who will just guide you to their shops. It's work going to the tannerie and the spice markets too. In the evening you can get great street food in the Place. Avoid the snake charmers and men with monkeys
You can't miss this.. The old markets adapted to tourism today. Here you will find all the Moroccan handicrafts you may wish for.

Busy and bustling but you have to be careful. As any traditional market area, it is expected that stall owners/shop keepers will try to get your attention to purchase their items. Most shops sell the same items and will offer extortionate prices to start with which you have to haggle hard to get a decent deal. To be honest, it is not ideal for a woman or even a group of women to be travelling alone through this area as the men pass comments which are not at all flattering and just make you feel very uncomfortable. I had a male family member with me most of the time which made my experience easier. In the evening there are many stalls that offer food but I was told by our guide that it is not recommended as being the safest to eat. Overall, a very busy area, full of tourists, there are horse carts, snake charmers, various stalls around. I did not feel very comfortable seeing the monkeys chained or kept in small boxes, there was a man selling tortoises and chameleons all stuffed in the same cage. I would also advise that you do not take pictures of the monkeys/snakes (unless you are posing with them) otherwise you will be asked to pay money for doing so

An intricate labyrinth. This earns an "excellent" rating, because you really have to experience the confusion, the smells, the sounds, the shadows, and the winding pathways of the souks. Wandering around may be better than trying to follow a map. It's certainly more enjoyable. Just follow your eyes to see what looks interesting. The maps are impossible anyway. All the young men hanging around assume you are looking for the Jemaa, and they will yell and point you towards it. But just keep walking and you'll be fine. If you look lost you will find all kinds of volunteers who will pleasantly offer to lead you out or toward your destination, but the trip will end with a demand for payment. If you say you are looking for a particular item, you will have offers to take you to "the best place," undoubtedly owned by a brother, cousin or friend who is handing out commissions. Just be wary, keep your wits around you, and know that you can get anything at a better price that what is initially stated. In fact, one seasoned traveler told us to start by offering 1/3 of the named price. It's kind of fun, once you get the hang of it, but you never really know if you are getting the best deal. The souks are the best and in some ways, the worst part of Marrakech (mostly at night when the sellers have gone home and the alleys are dark, winding, and impossible to navigate), but you have to see them.

Busy market place. The soul is fun to visit and a must if you are in Marrakech. Alleyways are small at times with lots of motorcycles and donkey carts negotiating the same paths as you, remember to walk along the right hand side and be prepared to move aside for the locals who maybe in more of a rush than you. Remember to haggle and never settle for any first prices. Walk away and you may find the price drops even further. Have fun in the adventure of the souk!

Shop til you drop. Here's the place to get lost for a few hours and pick up bargains galore.Go in with items in mind, or you will end up buying nothing or everything.Haggle, haggle, haggle!!If they won't accept your price, then move a door down, simple!

hecktic. This is where you will have to learn how to haggle. I have witnessed prices being changed from 80 dirhams to 20 just by using the walking away technique. All in all got some very good buys for really good prices you just have to be strong. quite cool to see what the culture was like.

Amazing. Wow what an assault on the senses, amazing place, barter hard and if you're not interested then be polite but firm. Never accept guidance or help from anyone that offers it, they will take you on a goose chase and expect to be paid. Either get a map of the souks, ask the shopkeepers or use a fab app called 'hip marrakech' women please cover your shoulders and your knees out of respect and really try to speak a little french. Can't wait to come back to marrakech.

Haggling Is So Much Fun. A chance to buy the traditional way artisan goods made in Marrakesh. No offence taken if you just want to look, one comment I got was what are you looking for sir, when I replied nothing the boy asked what colour I would like that in -what a laugh.

A gem for shoppers. I have visited a few souks in Morocco, but this is something else. Amazing variety of local products, from clothes, to household goods, fantastic spices, food, vegetables, you name it, it's there. Practice your bargaining skills to make the experience more enjoyable.

Buyers and hagglers paradise. I am not a shopping person believe me! But you will find all sorts of goods, tagine pots, gifts, carpets, clothes, food. The souks have their own charm even if you just want to see the sights and smells without buying.Be prepared to haggle hard, these guys have 200% markups at the start, but work your magic, use the walkaway technique and I am sure you will get some cracking deals !
Amazing. A must visit, yes its bustly, yes its busy, yes you need to haggle but the sensory experience the souls are is unlike anything else. Beautiful people as well.

Fun, but gets old quickly. The Souk is fun to visit for sure and also very exciting. There are a bunch of different smells, small shops, many locals and just about any item you could possibly think of. The roads are tiny and if you have a bad sense of orientation you might easily get lost. It is an adventure and somehow what you would want to experience and maybe even what you might expect from a trip to Marrakech. However, traveling as a blonde girl (my appearance basically screams foreigner in any possible way) it gets very bothersome (here old / boring) quickly. At every booth they start talking to you and you cannot even show the slightest interest in an item without being captured in this little booth and urged to buy something because it is "oh so cheap". Also me and my friends got insulted quite a lot if we then just passed by, completely ignoring any kind of comments - this is a bit sad, but I guess anybody who has been to either Tunisia, Egypt or any other northern african country before can relate to the situation.
Marrakech Souks. An active hive of activity to find anything you desire! Be prepared to haggle as is customary . . .but excellent keepsakes to be found! Alleyways criss cross but navigation is easy!

A must visit. . A fan of markets we had to visit here. It is massive and you can certainly get lost. Lots of similar stalls. If you show interest they will talk to you and try to make a sale. Have a price in mind and be prepared to haggle. You will get the item for at least half they price they first say sometimes less so start low. Also walk away and they will drop the price again. Lots of weird and wonderful things to be bought. Mopeds and small vehicles drive through the narrow alleys so be careful and stand aside. Locals will also barge past and expect you to move out of their way, we took this with a pinch of salt as we are on third territory. Some are forceful with selling but walk away and say no thank you, there are a lot of people about so you soon get lost in the crowd. Have fun.

Busy & bustling. Just what I expected. Lots and lots of stalls in a bustling and brightly coloured streets. Lots to buy and you have to have a good barter on price. Generally we found you halved it and you went up a little. Don't be afraid to walk away they will come after you and come down on price. You have to decide the maximum you are prepared to pay and stick to it. Lots of little roof top restaurants and cafes not to mention the snake charmers in the square. If you are going to Marrakesh you have to visit.

Essential visit!. So pleased to have the opportunity to experience the Marrakech Souk. A wonderful variety of unusual goodies to take home at affordable prices. Always expect to negotiate downwards, never accept the first price - keep going down until you are offered "last price." Take a large suitcase! Keep your wits about you.

** Aladdin's Cave **. The Marrakech Souks are HUGE ,, Please don't stress and worry about getting lost - its all part of the fun. Yes some of the traders do tend to pester you to have a look at their goods, but others are happy to just greet you with a smile and be there for when you need assistance. I found that if i just ignored someone who was pestering me they would leave me alone and try the next person, if i engaged in a conversation with them (even just to say no thank you) they would continue to pester. The treasures you can find are abundant, it really is like an Aladdin's cave. You can purchase almost anything at the Marrakech Souks. Remember to haggle, ALWAYS HAGGLE, tell them what you are happy to pay. There will always be another stall selling very similar of not the same items. Have fun - it really is an experience ! x
Great for shopping . Great for shoes and clothes. Must be prepared to bargining to avoid disappointment. Small very narrow streets with fast motorcycles if a turn off.

Fantastic market . The souken in Marrakech is really a fantastic place. I just loved it. All the nice things, smells, colors and all the nice people you'll meet. Also you'll have to haggle. If you dont like the ending price just say so and part like friends. An experience to remember.

Great experience. So we went and the tip is if someone ask you to look in there shop if your not interested smile and say no thank you left us alone every time, another tip HAGGGLE! What ever there price dived by 2 then minus another 10% worked every time

You can't not go if you're in Marrakech. Such a great experience - you can find pretty much anything you're after here, and for a great price. Make sure you barter with the stall owners though (especially if you're British) as they'll try and get as much money out of you as possible! Would advise women to make sure their shoulders and knees are covered just out of respect, but to also make sure you feel comfortable too. Most of the Souks are in the shade too, so perfect for a really hot or rainy day.

Amazing experience!. Highlight of our trip.Some tips: Be careful if you are a female travelling alone or if you get separated from a group. I got followed and the man was very aggressive towards me when I was on my own. When my boyfriend was there, there was absolutely no issues. Get lost in the souks, that's the best way to find the unusual trinkets. A lot of stalls sell the same things but the deeper you go into the souk, the more interesting it gets! NEVER pay the price they initially ask. Always pay a max. 50% of what they say. Some are harder to bargain with than others. The best thing to do it to keep your change small. Walking away from the stall is the best way to get the price you want, they know you will see a similar item a few stalls down so they would rather have the sale than see someone else get it! Make sure you watch them wrap your item in newspaper. Some decide not to put your item in at all! Be friendly but keep walking, they will ask many questions to lure you into their stall but if nothing interests you, just say 'no thank you' and keep moving. Taking pictures is quite easy as long as your not inside the stall! Get your travel buddy to stand near the stalls and use a camera phone if possible! No flash! I got lots of lovely photos of the souks by doing this and nobody asked for money. Last but not least, enjoy it! You'll have never seen anything quite like it! :)

Treasures of Marrakech. The souks of Marrakech hold so much variety. You can find bags, souvenirs, carved wood, ceramics, jewellery, products made from tyres, spices, argan oil, rugs, and so much more. The huge downside however is that you can't go there without being bothered. My mum and I were afraid to show any interest in their goods because they wouldn't let us leave after we did, even when we told them we were just looking around. It's such a shame, I think someone should tell them it puts tourists off...

A rabbit warren of 'stuff'. Short of fighter-aircraft and cars, I'm pretty sure this place sells just about everything else!!Well worth a good few hours wandering... but keep track of where u are, cos this place is like a rabbit warren... small lanes filled with shops, some of them no bigger than a wardrobe!! WORD OF WARNING... don't take pictures of stalls.... they get reeeeally upset about it, even if the owner is not in the shot... believe me, one one occasion we almost caused on international incident!!!

Yes this square (is) was a classic but now ......its is just full of jobs sticks bad food that you can just get at home. Yes this square (is) was a classic but now ......its is just full of jobs sticks bad food that you can just get at home..If you live in any reasonable city with a mix of races, cultures and religions. Then this square will not really be its once awesome experience. In fact you may find a lot of items cheaper at home.Yes the smells, noise, wailing music and fires are evocative. I am not sure about the snakes and the mis treat of the apes. And you be better to eat at one of the adjacent restaurants unless you do want food poisoning, and then you can also view the square.Don't miss it but keep your expectations level.
A must. Different atmosphere in the day to the night. Much quieter in day..If your a little more adventurous than the night is for you..

Shopping!. Ignore the 'cheaper than Lidl' and go for what you like.... regardless of the label, fake or otherwise. If you do save a few dirhams maybe consider giving them to the beggars ... I'm not sure if they have an NHS there.

amazing experience. This is a really vibrant exciting place and the souk is around the perimeter! It's a place to be cautious but the square is full of dancers water sellers snake charmers and peddlers! Of course it's a must to any travel to marrakech it's why your there

A must do. This was an amazing cultural experience , we arrived in the Friday which meant it was a bit quite and gave us some time to orientate ourself and shoo did we need that.. Its quite overwhelming but you get used to saying no in a polite way.. by the last day we got the hang of hackling but still I was not really good.. I priced some things in the UK before I left therefore I knew what the prices are here and what I would consider as cheaper this gave me a base.... However I would say go down to 1/3 of the price and stop and 2/3 . When you walk away they always call you back which is funny. At the end of the day I just remembered that this is a poor country and these people are just trying to make a living so if I can afford it I payed it. Thats how the world should work, give a little take a little

VERY interesting if your have a guide to show you the "local" stuff. Our guide showed us the ins and outs of the souks and it was VERY interesting to us. We saw where the locals have their bread made, where the man feeds the fire to make the steam that serves the Hammams, etc. I found it fascinating to see how much happens in the souks! You will see craftsmen of all types (iron workers, those that use old tires to make products, jewelry, wood workers, etc.)I will warn you that most of them do NOT like to have their photos taken, and if you do take photos, expect to PAY them for the photos. Many of my pics were taken 'on the sly' (see attached), so the quality is not great - but it gives you an idea of what it is like in the markets. We really enjoyed it and found it to be very interesting!

Great but crazy place. Be prepared for this, go past the first stalls and into the depths of the souk, great fun bartering and came home with some bargains. There are plenty of other things to do in Marrakech but this is a must.

Beautiful goods and high pressure. Basically, the traditional morroccan artisan goods are stunningly beautiful and you will probably open your wallet and buy something. However the bargaining and excessive high pressure to buy something makes this a less than pleasant place, in my opinion. Also, it's a maze thats hard to navigate and once you've decided you've had enough, good luck finding your way out. I'd recommend coming here for no more than a few hours on your vacation unless you have a xanax supply.

While away the day. While away the day feeling a million miles from Europe. Watch the henna being prepared in the square, straw hats being made or discuss spices and herbal medicine with shop owners. Find the smaller square of spices for an insight into the locals stalls as well as typical tourist stalls.

Experience of a lifetime. The Marrakech Souk is an amazing place. Be prepared to have every sense tantalized! The colors, the energy, the smells it's all exciting. Make sure you watch your surroundings, it's easy to get lost in the maze! The people are wonderful!
A MUST DO. complete must do for everyone visiting MARRAKECH. this is the sight to see. it holds surprises and many nerve racking moments but has to be done.

very busy place. So much to take in. there are so many stall holders all trying to get you to buy their goods. Very cheap for allsorts of things from Bags made of leather or camel to pots and pans, anything you want you can get here.the spices are amazing to smell and look at.

Colourful, smelly, intense, great fun. One of the main attractions of Marrakech this warren of lanes is confusing but easy to navigate after a day or so. Thousands of shops grouped by type (spice, metal work, leather etc) all largely selling exactly the same things. Worth getting off the main drags to get a better experience (and price)

Shopping in the souks can be loads of fun. The souks of Marrakech seem endless and the winding streets make it difficult to find your way. That said, the sights are exciting and interesting. There is a wide variety of merchandize available and even though it is often very hard to tell what is authentic and what is not, meeting the shopkeepers (many of whom speak English and almost all of whom speak French) is fun. This is a unique part of coming to Marrakech and something that every traveler should experience.

Lots of Fun although One Bad Experience. I went to the souk with a friend who intended to have a henna decoration done. She found the design that she wanted and negotiated the price and paid the woman prior to anything being done. We found out later that this was still a lot higher price than normal. The woman began and finished the design in a couple of minutes, she then said that "for good luck" she would do a small design on my hand. I reluctantly agreed as I was wary of her motives. She agreed that this would be included in the amount already paid. Within minutes my small design had grown very large and I then told her to stop. We then tried to walk away but she grabbed my shirt and demanded more money from both of us double what my friend had already paid her. She became very aggressive and then swore at us, we managed to walk away from her, but the dealing left a very sour taste with us and shocked us. After that we were very wary of all traders but found everyone else that we dealt with after that polite and extremely helpful. I loved the souk so much colour and life.

Snake-charmers-ain't!. We wanted to get a feel of the old Marrakech....we sure got it!...had an enjoyable horse & trap ride, amoungst the mayhem that is the traffic system!...ambled around the stalls and took in the smells and sounds of the market, and tried to be polite with the persistant traders....be prepared!.....and one to watch at a distance are the snake-charmers, or you might get a cobra draped around your neck like I did!.....henna tattooists aren't pleasant either!....have fun!

First compromise!. Every seller welcomes you to their shop. Don't look their eyes directly, suddenly they will touch your arm and take you to their shop. Be aware of the danger ! Also don't touch any items when you stand of the shop. You could be compromise.

High street shopping with a difference. Hard to not get lost in the amazing sights, smells and sounds of the souks. Bargains to be had, especially the deeper you go, but also rip offs as well so you have to be careful not to get carried away. Often it was great to just watch the locals once you got outside the touristy parts of the souks.

Such an amazing maze of market stalls. Actually the difference between a souk and a market is in a souk the items sold are also made there, where in a market it is sold only. At first the souks can seem intimidating as every man in his shop is asking you to come in and look. Its amazing to see as there the variety of items on sale is actually very few but the number of stall selling the same goods is vast. Its amazing how they all survive but I believe this is down to the Muslim culture or helping each other out.Id definitely recommend a visit here although don't be afraid to barter and be prepared to pay a little but more at the souks than elsewhere for the same items.In the marketplace there is plenty of entertainment - monkeys, snakes, fire eaters, pal readers, henna tattoos and stalls selling food in the evening.

a fun experience but be prepared for a haggle. Like any middle eastern souk you must be prepared for some haggling. Did not like them grapping my hand or touching my shoulder though. Usual goods like leather, ceramics, laterns and jewellery but unexpected owls and ginea pigs on display.Afun morning spent meandering through and a welcome drink and selection of food stalls at the square at the end.

Impossible to navigate. If you love to haggle and shop then this will be heaven to you. The down side is that the signs only direct you towards El Fna Square and none the other way. There are lots of nice reasonably priced items and not all stall holders are sharks, some are very nice and very gentlemanly. If you are not very assertive I would recommend hiring a guide.

Overwhelming, but an experience. A definite labyrinth, and all the streets are filled with stalls so it's really easy to become disoriented. If you stop and look at anything, you will be pounced on. Once you get used to the environment,mint becomes easier, but I recommend a guide you can trust at the beginning so that you can get your bearings. And, don't be afraid to say no. Can't say I enjoyed the haggling, it was too intimidating. But, all that said, when you do stop and talk to the right merchant, it is really delightful. Many people are really nice, but it's hard to know who to trust. In the end, buy a few things you like and don't worry if you overpay - think of it as the price of entertainment.

Amazing experience!. It was amazing experience and one of the best markets I visited! Thanks god I visited it with a person who has balls to say NOto sellers <3 As I predicted, we even got lost in the marked and could not find the way back as Sellers were pointing us to incorrect directions....!!!!! In the begining of our tour we had an excursion to the local pharmacy were we had chance to smell and try different oils, teas, etc. loved it loved it loved it!
Same old stuff. Loads of stalls and interesting to go round but we didnt buy anything lots og hand made stuff but nothing really good quality leather is probably best selling items

Fantastic smells of local food and cuisine. Frightening place at face, especially when you leave the main area and head down the narrow alleys. All the haggling, pushing, beginning and false directions become tiring after a while. Got lost a few times and had to get out the satnav to find my way back to the Riad. It would be much better without the madmen on motorbikes trying to run you over, donkeys and carts and all the false direction and expectations of cash for everything. Good place to buy handmade gifts though.
Best medina in the world!. Step back 1000 years in time and ouk up the magic! The Marrakech medina is a unique labyrinth to get lost int

Don't miss this. We ventured into the souk twice. Our guide gave us excellent advice on how to keep our belongings safe and took us there first to survey and later to shop. Prices are rarely posted. Bargaining is expected. Be willing to walk away. I could have spent days and days there.
Beautiful Market. Loved the Souk - great for shopping. But be weary of the pocket thieves and dodgy guides. I went in June 2014 the weather was bearable.

overwhelmed and traditional. A mhst do when in marrakesh but strongly recommend a guide if it's the first time. Make dure you have good walking shoes and spare money as loads of beautiful things and you will get tempted.Make sure you bargain. I managed to get two bags for original price quoted for one.

Like Nothing You've Ever Seen. This is a haven for anyone who wants to see crafts being made (and the prices and selections are great for leather, lanterns, wood carvings, clothing and embroidery). There are also food stalls with fruits and vegetables which look great but which I was afraid to eat, and stalls with goods for the people who live in Marrakech, since this is the area that locals shop in. The architecture, comparing the Muslim section to the Jewish area showed the differences in lifestyles of the communities. The synagogue is still in use. It is impossible not to get very lost, so if you want to ever return to the place you started you need to have a guide. Hire someone from your hotel, since local guides on site will steer you to shops where they get a commission. My husband and I spent almost a full day here, and the time was very well spent.
Shopping Heaven. Start with a fresh orange juice, then enjoy wandering the souk and pick up jewellery, clothes, leather slippers. Enjoy bartering - otherwise you will pay far too much.

amazing experience. the souk has got to be one of the most interesting places I have been. Just a few rules to watch out for.Don`t take photos before you have agreed a price, and learn to keep walking when being approached by guides or sellers of souveniers, a polite but firm no usually does the trick. Bargain for everything but do it with a smile, and do visit the tannery.Go during the day and then back at night, if you need toilets be prepared to buy a drink in a local café and then you can use the loo.You can`t really get lost just ask anyone to direct you to the square and you will get back where you started,

Wear decent clothing . We hardly got harrsed at all, and part of the charm to go into the stalls.Do come dressed covering knees and shoulders. you Will Get More attention if you dont, and if you dont agree with Being covereed up ( a scarf will do) then marrakesh isnt the place for you.We were sitting with 2 girls next to us in a cafe complaining about their experience of the souks, both wearing short shorts ad vest tops...We never had anyone ask us to be guided either. Despite all the reviews. Maybe i was too covered up!!

Mad mad mad!!!! But well worth the visit.. The Souk is one of the best markets that I've been too ,you just have to learn how to say NO politely.All they want is your money so the more you spend the better the treatment you'll get.I hired a guide ,just to learn a bit more from him , he was very nice and new everyone still not sure if that was a good thing or a bad thing .All I'll say is , go visit it's an experience you will not forget,

Carry pocket change. Carry pocket change, hide your notes. What ever figure they offer you something for take a 0 off as your starting price (1000mad offer 100mad), even if they shout. Then look through your change. Always walk away. If you want it come back later. Never impulse buy. Always shout back, don't be intimidated.

A Trip Back In Time. What a feast for the senses! Sights sounds and smells that are totally unique to this city. Get your best bargaining skills out as there are some great souvenirs to be had for great prices.

Sensory overload and I love it!!!. Ok it's crazy busy, you will be over whelmed with the sights, smells and sounds of the souks. There are beggars, hagglers, donkeys, mopeds to navigate. But there are also some amazing stalls, gorgeous things to buy and some of the kindest, loveliest and polite stall o nets you will ever meet. Be firm. Don't engage in eye contact and conversation unless you are interested in the product or stall. A firm no thank you will suffice. If interested show manners and respect and you will have a fabulous time. I've visited the Souks at least 20 times and always have a fabulous time. Slightly less crazy in the afternoon and at prayer time. Don't wear mini skirts, hot pants etc if you don't want additional harassment. Be firm, relax and enjoy.

Hossel, hossel.... A must see and the perfect way to get lost if you take another narrow street during your strawl.Never pay the price they ask for an item just bid 25% and keep it this way.. the fun to hossel and deal is for both pleasant if you do it with a smile !.. try to learn som arabic words.. most of the locals like that very much..
Get lost. Be prepared to get lost and be careful who you take advice from! A shoppers paradise - that's if you're a shopper!
The Marrakech Souks are a must see whilst visiting Morocco. You can wander for hours in the historical and beautiful souks and barter for goods until your hearts content .
Shoppers paradise. This was a shoppers paradise ,you could buy almost anything you wanted , just haggle with them .you normally get that price from pottery .leather goods ,jewellery . henna

Guide or map essential. We as a couple entered the souks before dinner time, this was to be a big mistake. We got off our shuttle bus right by the square with no problems but you get pounced on by beggars and guides. Our bus had our hotel name on it so everyone claimed they were our hotels official guides, and we should choose them. We ventured off on our own and one chap stopped to say hello claiming he recognised us from the hotel and said he would show us to get some spices (we then twigged he followed us from our shuttle bus) we declined and ventured to the nearest alleyway. The haggling side was fun and enjoyable and as cheap as you want it to be. The aromas and noises were memorable and you get carried away and follow the streets to better bargains. But then we seemed to stray into some areas that maybe didn't welcome tourists as much. People then guide or take you to areas we didn't choose to go all for a fee. By then we bumped into two others who had a street map (also lost) but 4 heads got together put us back on the straight and narrow made it an adventure again. We ventured back at different times and enjoyed it. But take a good street map or remember certain shops/cafes etc along the route or get a guide recommended by the hotel. This will create the memory of a lifetime.

At least I can say I've been. Lots of stalls very much the same thoughout, the men selling goods were very 'in your face' and when you didn't buy appeared to be a bit aggressive. As you are unable to just look at anything (even a side ways glance!) I didn't buy but went to the Agadir Souk and got it all there, which was a much pleasanter experience. However, the workshops and leather markets within the Marrakesh Souk were interesting and gave an insight into how a lot of people live their lives. You have to keep your wits about you at all times because there are motor bikes and donkey carts zooming around the narrow streets from all directions. The square is very vibrant and hot during the day, unfortunately quite a lot of insistent children begging so be careful as little hands just seem to fly into pockets to see what's there. Generally though, good banter. There are snake charmers and dancers as well, very unfortunately, little monkeys dressed up in nappies but that is the Moroccans way. Everyone is out for the quick buck so be careful taking any pictures. Incredibly busy in the evening, people just pour into the square at about 6pm. Enjoyed the experience but wouldn't do it again!

Interesting But Be Aware. We visited the Souks on our first day knowing it is easy to get lost, but didn't realise how lost you can get. After getting off the hotel complimentary bus we were approached by several guides saying they were from the hotel. Knowing the hotel has no official guides we by passed these, further on we were approached by a man saying he worked in the hotel and would show us which way to go. We almost fell for this, but then realised he had followed us off the bus. So we carried on by ourselves and ended up lost, trying to find our way back to the square we strayed out of the soukse and we both felt out of our comfort zone, with lots if people trying to guide us down small allies to get back to the square. I would recommend, but make a note of where you are going on a map and follow it back. Also don't be afraid to haggle and walk away if you can't get the price you want. There are many shops all selling the same so you won't miss out.

Trip of a lifetime: Face to face with the cradle of civilization. For a westerner, Marrakech has to be the most exotic experience ever to be encounter. With its epicenter, Jemaa el Fna; A sensorial bombardment of sights,sounds,smell and unimaginable surprises.

Avoid the tannery. when u explore somewhere make your mind up..motorcycles donkeys and carts..just remember you're not in the Arndale Centre..or Bluewater..however somebody will offer you a better price than Morrisons..

Take a satnav. Lots of everything you'd expect except its not totally rammed with beggars and dodgy hawkers as i thought it would be.Very easy to find your way in but much harder to find your way out. But the fun part is discovering new bits as you try to get out :)Personal recommendation: make sure you're familiar with The Life of Brian before you go. It makes the visit much funnier ;)

Fun and great bargains to be had.. Good fun haggling with traders who have a great sense of humour when trying to do a deal with you. Great bargains to be had. Very interesting looking around and getting lost in the miles of mazes of stalls. We went twice during our ten night stay.

Great spot for shopping. Best place to get souvenirs, jewelry, scarves, leather products and many other interesting items. It's a must see place. Don't forget to grab a bite to eat at the market. There are several small dinning spots in the middle of the square/plaza where they offer delicious morrocan food. These dinning spots don't have names but just numbers. Go eat at number 1 which belongs to Aicha. She is the only female restaurant owner in the area and here food is fantastic. Try to get the mixed grill dish.

A Taste of Moroccan Culture. If you want to feel the real culture of Morocco spend a day here and stay longer to eat the street food at night....especially the lamb.Be prepared to eat with your hands.When in Morocco do as the Moroccans do!

so much to see and so much to buy. The souk at Marrakech is huuuuuuge, you ll need few days to visit it/ There are so much to see, buy, taste , take pictures of etcI have spent 5 days in Marrakech and I must go back as I couldn't see everything nor buy everything i wanted to buy. From the beautiful exotic lanterns, to the real genuine leather bags, the souk has everything u r looking for. The only thing that might be annoying is negotiating as they real think tourists are stupid and will rip you off if they can. However it is business and we can't blame them form making a living. So keep in mind you will have to negotiate for everything. If they say 500 dirham give them 200 and start negotiating from there. The average salary is 200 euros per month there but since they see that tourists think in euros they even started t put prices in euros...weell besides that, the streets, the smells sometimes very strong are what make the souk an exceptional and unique place u ll have to visit at least one. It is a perfect place for home decor.

OK but too much the same on offer. Perhaps, (well almost certainly) we didn't see all the stalls. As we had specific items in mind for decorations for the house, it was disappointing to see virtually identical products in so many of the stalls.Still however plenty to see and the visit worthwhile.Just don't forget to haggle!

Much to appreciate but hold on to your belongings and your sense of direction. One of the problems at taking in all the mystery of the Souk is whilst it is full of much to look at it is also a haven for pick pockets and the opportunity to be lost. I found the men selling goods to be very heavy hand and when you didn't buy to be a bit aggressive. Don't get caught in the game the carpet sellers play asking you to show which one out of two you like the best, from there it becomes a mission for them to sell you the carpet. Have a look by all means but be prepared to pay someone to get you back to your car or bus once completely lost. The young kids do a great job in getting you back don't be mean with them.

Middle ages in Marraketch . Traditional square where musicians, story tellers, and snake charmers will entertain you if you like that sort of thing. Walking many kilometers through the shops is fun but one reaches saturation after a while. The souk is divided by sections such as leather, wood, metal, etc. This no longer exists in the West.
Huge market. Loads of stalls selling basically the same stuff, if you don't want to be hassled too much visit earlier in the day, much quieter.

Get lost and enjoy. There is the Souks and there is the Souks. The first Souks are those where most visitors end up, get lost and move out. The second Souks are those that you find if you go deeper and find the places where the real craftsmanship takes place. Dive into the little alleys, often missed as they are small. These are the interesting Souks, to our taste at least. See the leather workers, the carpenters and iron workers. Take a right and a left and a right again and keep going and suddenly you find a little tiny place that sells the most amazing Touareg adornments you can imagine. And keep going....
Aaaaaaagh. You have got to do it. Enjoy the banter, haggle and don't take offence. An enjoyable experience but so glad to get back to the tranquility of our Riad

Couple tips. Taking pictures: In some areas there are signs that say "no pictures" - try to respect that. Don't take individual portraits of locals - they will be either annoyed or will ask you to pay. The best way is to find a quiet spot, keep to the wall, and take a general picture of the area and then crop it down to the spot you need. If you want to take a pic of inside the shop then find the one with a busy owner - he is unlikely to pay you any attention.Navigating: Start anywhere at Jemma El Fna and move upwards, walk as much as you want and take any number of turns - there is little you can do not to end up back at Jemma El Fna. We tried this trick a number of times - works without fail.Buying food: If you want to sample a few olive types or some sweets then just tip the owner 5-10 DH and dig in. If you want to buy some food for later, then what worked for us best is not asking the price and then trying to hustle down, but saying/showing exactly what you want and giving a small note or a 10 DH coin - this makes an impression of you knowing the price and even left us with some change a few times. The general idea is not to show any doubt over price.

Souks is better with a guide. The Souks is typical of market stalls in African cities but notable for its stalls operated by Berbers, the original people of Morocco. The area is composed of narrow arteries, with overhead coverings for shade, and heavily oriented to handicrafts and foodstuffs. The maze of pathways can be quite confusing and is best navigated with a guide which is inexpensive if you bargain well.

Everything from a thimble to a bathtub.... Great to wander and haggle for bargains but beware. You WILL get lost; people will help, some will ask for money afterwards. And the further you go from the main square after 7pm, the less people there are. We got lost about 9.30 one night and kept walking. Suddenly everywhere was shut, no people about. Young man offered to help, took us down some dark alleys to somewhere we knew (took less than 5 minutes), and got very angry when I offered him 30 dh. He demanded 5 euro, but didn't get it. So don't wander too far, too late, and you'll enjoy it. An ex Ok evidence like no other.

Like every other souk . There is nothing special about the souks, like any other in that part of the world. All the stalls sell the same tat and you need patience to find something worth buying. Its worth lookin at several stalls as the prices cad differ drastically if you have the patience. You will need to haggloand if you dont get yhe price you want move on to the next stall. This place is a maze, so easy to get lost in and go round in circles. Its hot smelly and smokey with terrible roads so make sure you are dressed appropriately. Walk on the sides as everyone rides motorcycles in this city and they wizz down the middle without any regard for pedestrians. Dont accept help/directions from the locals as they will take you to a stall or demand money.

Sellers and souks. This is a really vibrant exciting place and the souk is around the oerimeter! Its a place to be cautious but the square is full of dancers water sellers snake charmers and peddlars! Of course its a must to any traveller to marraketch its why your there

Marrakech Souk Tour. We booked a 1 day shopping tour with a guide called Abdul which was really good. He gave us a historical overview of Marrakech & the Kotoubia, before taking us through the souks, ticking off items on our list as we ventured hassle-free through the busy market.

Lovely but can easily get lost. The Souks was an amazing experience. As you walk through it both sides are full of small shops selling leather bags, leather coats, traditional shoes and clothes, spices and many more beautiful things. The Souks can go on forever and one can get easily lost. When walking just be careful of the bikers and cyclists.

Friendly less pressure to buy but the further into the Souks you go they especially at night can be foreboding and less. Lots to buy small shops in Souks beware of traffic. People very friendly not so much pressure to buy as in Medina can barter but don't expect prices to half.
Souk exploring. Great very interesting , but you do get lost, take a guide more enjoyable, and learn to say NO, people in Morracco can be rude.

Lots of tourist wares but great for leather goods. The majority of the souks around Jemaa el Fna are of course aimed at the tourist trade. However you can find some great leather goods, slippers and travel bags in particular. We bought a big weekend bag that was beautifully made. They initially asked for 2000 dinar but we bought it in the end for 800 dinar which we felt was a good price, so be prepared to haggle hard, but that is part of the fun.

Al Matjar--A wonderful Carpet/Rug experience.. Short and sweet, Chabi S Mohamed owns and operates his store at #26 Sauk semmarine (in the bazar)--He's a first class gentlemen running a very nice Rug/Carpet and pillow shop. His goods are beautiful and of fine quality and very affordable prices. Most importantly, Chabi is a very kind and gracious business owner that welcomes you in to his shop, with NO pressure what so ever from the first hand shake of his introduction. The part I liked best was the British couple that had been to his shop on a previous trip to Marrakesh that stopped in again to introduce his mother to Chabi. The exchange was priceless.I found two beautiful kilim that will adorn my office and my daughters living room.Thank you Chabi!

A must visit. I love souks, they are a feast for the senses, the colours, smells and textures. If you don't like haggling then this is not for you but if you keep your sense of humour and treat it as a friendly experience, you will have fun. These are not just for tourists but the locals shop and bargain here as well.

Sights sounds smells and hospitality. What a wonderful place. so much to see, so many windy little alleys, stalls, shiny things, brightly coloured things. all so beautiful. Don't go for the bargains - the Moroccans know what their stuff is worth, go for the experience, have a chat, sit down and drink tea, soak it all in before you even think about talking about money. Then you'll have a story to take home with whatever you buy. we were dressed up in mountain turbans, bedoiun face makeup and packed off with gifts as well as our purchases. and you don't always have to buy stuff... get it right and you won't feel pressured at all. just soak it up and enjoy yourself.

Must visit when in Marrakech. Stalls in the souks by Jemaa el Fna tends to open at about 1100 and stay on until late at night. Some may close for siesta. The stalls mainly sell souvenirs, brass/ copper/ silver ware, jewellery, sweets, medicine and leather goods. The latter are good buys if you get a good price. After walking around for an hour, one should know the approximate price of items. The only problem is, like most other places, there are no public conveniences - unless one goes into a restaurant.

Greta fun of haggling and shopping. The souks, or with other words, Marrakech's shopping area is great fun!! You can buy anything, and i mean it! The shoemakers will make a pair just for your feet for a good price and in little time. Everything is for sale and expect to haggle! It is worth checking out prices first in the Artisan market just on the outskirts of the Medina to get an idea of the prices(everything is price tagged there). Also some products are price tagged inn the souks too, generally small stuff that you won't be able to haggle on but otherwise, whatever starting price you are given, especially if you do not have a clue, offer back one quarter of it and take it from there. (example: a nice blanket was quoted for 800 dirhams, i offered 200, settled for 240 and was told i haggle like a Morrocan woman!). A true sign of under-offering is when the seller puts the item straight back onto the self and is highly offended. However once you OK-d a price, you cannot go back. As you walking along, sellers will hassle you and chitchat but you don't actually have to acknowledge them one by one, it is ok to walk by! Also they seem to have a 6th sense about where you from and will start talking in that language to you!!If you want hassle free shopping, this is not the place for you because as soon as you look at something, a person will appear and promote it to you. I must mention that they are nowhere as bad as in Egypt, for example, Morrocan souks are a lot friendlier and they don't mind if you just chat to them a little bit.No harm in saying you come back later, even if you don't!

Exciting....... An overload of all your senses: sights, sounds, smells, taste and touch. There's always good, cheap food to be found, and you're always served way too much. Make a sandwich out of what you can't eat and give it to a begger - you will reap the rewards in some way. Sit and people watch - cool off with a fresh orange juice and make sure you visit both in the day and at night-time. Very similar and very different to Prague!
Fantastic shopping. Great shopping experience , easy to get lost bit lots of help getting out. Haggling wasn't as stressful as I thought it would be. Great bargains to be had.

Warning for solo travelers. The place is a labirinth and if you go by yourself to visit it try to stay to the main streets and never, ever ask or trust the locals for directions. All of them, regarding the age will point you in a direction who will end with you deeper and deeper in the souk. And all of them will ask you for money. Might be a cultural or bussiness kind of menatlity but that let me personally a bad taste in my mouth.

An experience. This was our first time going . I advise you to take a tour guide, as there is over 3,000 souks. It is so much to see there, the palace was beautful. They do try to make you buy but you just need to say no thanks, if you don't want it. Over all it was an experience I won't forget

Uncomfortable experience . Sadly this wasn't the fun I had read about. It's difficult to stop and look at stuff without being verbally attacked.My female friends had her bum pinched by a random man walking past.The stalls/shops basically all sell the same things so you don't really have to keep wandering too far.Go but just be prepared

Not for me. This is a must see for anyone who goes to Marrakech a truly wonderful experience but not for me,anything you could possibly wish for you can get here,but the noise and constant looking over yourself for mad motorcycles rushing past you is not for me.The sellers are all so polite and the constant offers of mint tea mean you would never go thirsty.I only wished I could have brought something from everyone to help the the local economy

Real market atmosphere, you gotta want it though.... Visited here just an hour in the evening.It's the grand championship arena for gaggling.Will people get pushy trying to get you to spend money at their shop? Yes... and in any language.Best bargains are gotten with a bundle of multiple items. Expect the asking price to be about time and a half over the settle price with bundles earning a bit more discount. They price you, not the items so know what to pay and don't be afraid to walk away and take the best price to the next shop.It's fun in a stressful way, but be prepared because you cannot be anonymous.Interesting place to visit.

Good experience. We went during day and night and it was great experience. We were treated respectfully and a firm no thank you/no eye contact seemed work great for us. Have idea what youd like to buy and rough price willing pay and prepare to haggle. If you find that fun this place for you. If not just go for the experience. It is worth seeing & experiencing.

Just get lost in the souks. I defy anyone to actively shop in the souks and not get lostIt is part of the fun to guess which way to go preferably using your own sense of direction because if someone gives you directions or worse offers to show you the way they are more often touts for a business and you end up at the sales area but some great shopping to be had
Not to be missed. interesting mix of stalls, full of colour and bustle. Get a real taste of life in Marrakech by visiting the vegetable, meat and fish stalls and not just the tourist items.

ONE OF THE MOST FRIGHTFUL EXPERIENCES EVER. We booked the shuttle bus to Marrakech from our hotel as we were told the square and souk were worth a visit. Also we were advised it was safe and we wouldn't need a guide. As we departed the shuttle bus a man directed us to the square. We proceeded along a very narrow dirty street and tried our best to avoid being hit by the passing motorcyclists and donkey drawn carts. We arrived at the square which was full of horse drawn vehicles, men with monkeys on chains making them do tricks, snake charmers hitting their snakes with sticks to wake them up, shabby bars and restaurants and stalls selling would could only be described as junk. We walked on to the souk, which was also very dirty and narrow and we again had to avoid being hit by donkey drawn carts and motorcyclists. We felt really intimidated by the stall holders as they were shouting and grabbing at us to buy their wares. The stalls incidentally were full of the same old junk as well as fish, meat and vegetables full of flies. It was a maze and we got lost although we had a map. When we asked for directions back to the square we kept being sent in the wrong direction. By this time we were very frightened. A man came up to us and said he would take us back to the square. We were tempted not to use him but felt we had no choice. After a short time we saw some signs on the street corners which directed us back to the square and told him to go away but he kept following us and demanded money. In the end we gave him MAD20. He threw it back at us and said he wanted MAD200. We just laughed and carried on walking. As there were now crowds of people he grabbed the 20 and ran off. When we arrived back at the bus pick up point we were exhausted and realised that we had about half an hour to wait. There was a restaurant on the corner so we ordered 2 bottles of water. Believe me we were glad to get back to our hotel and would advise anyone not to go on that excursion.

Interesting adventure. It is everything you've heard of and seen in photos. Everything in abundance, but be warned if you show interest and engage sellers in conversation you will spend money. Very aggressive sales tactics.I would recommend asking for price from different sellers before you commit and do not be afraid to walk away.

Negotiate, negotiate. This area is possibly the major reason why so many people visit Marrakesh. You need to be ready for some overtly aggressive selling by the locals, and it would be rude of you to just accept the price that they suggest. Practise some doubtful face expressions; have the notes ready in your pocket, and make your starting offer at 50- 60% of their price. Don't ever pay more than you think that it is worth to you.

Great crafts pity about the wild animal skins. It's everything you expect, some great artefacts, craftsmanship & things to buy. I didn't expect or like to see animal skins for sale inc. big cats, zebras, snake & croc? Nor ivory topped walking sticks? I thought this was illegal? Needs to be stopped!

Go for the experience.... Be warned. You will get hassled from the moment you give any sort of eye contact to any stall. The bustle and hustle of the souks are inspiring, but the constant hassle can be annoying and tiring.

A confident shoppers dream. Amazing place haggle hard and it will pay off, ceramics are a really good buy, rip off bags are ok, look at all the detail zips, trims and leather quality. Don't let the henna girls tattoo on you as they will say it's free and ITS NOT!!

Let's bargain!. Amazing opportunity for you to try your skills as a merchant! You can - no - you HAVE TO bargain for everything. Nothing there has its price - most of the times things are worth exactly that much money you're willing to pay for it. And watch out for leather items there! Mostly these products are cheap and ain't worth spending a dime, as they're not properly colored and tend to lose the color after one wash. For nice leather items better wait till you visit Fes! ;-)

Marrakech in May. After a lot of research on trip advisor before our trip to Morocco in May 2015, my friend and I would now like to share some of the things we learnt. We are two female friends, in our late 50’s. We have travelled extensively through South America before, but this was our first time to an Islamic country. We prefer to do our own thing, book our own accommodation, usually in small B&B type hotels. We like to hire a driver for a day or two to visit areas outside the main cities. In the cities we will pick up a day tour. We also catch the local buses and trains between cities.We flew into Casablanca and were picked up by a private driver and driven to Marrakech, this we arranged through Riad Rafaele, where we stayed. This riad in the heart of the medina was a calming oasis from the madness. We arrived in Marrakech in the middle of May and it was 45 degrees celcius for our first 4 days there. Marrakech - Things we did in Marrakech: We did a half day private walking tour of the medina hoping to get our bearings and the tour ended in the main square. This knowledge didn’t stop us getting lost on numerous occasions on our way back to the riad.Another day we caught a taxi to the Yves St Laurent Garden, Jardin Majorelle. The taxi driver waited for us. An hour was enough time to have a wander through the gardens. We did go early, as again it was very hot, and arrived before all the buses. Our other days in Marrakech we wandered the medina, trying different routes, sometimes getting lost, but never troubled by this. We always found our way to the main square.Places we ate – Café Arabe was nice. We also had a delicious meal at Riad Rafaele but our favourite was Le Jardin, where we ended up eating three times.Found Marrakech fascinating, only the motor bikes zipping past at times was a bit too close for comfort. The people we met were friendly and helpful. It certainly wasn't the scary place people who don't travel make it out to be. We loved the different culture, religion, customs and dress, all so different to home.Just a note on appropriate dress – We wore mostly mid-calf length pants or skirts and shirts with short sleeves and felt this was quite appropriate and not revealing.
Always agree a price!. Be sure to get a price before you eat after 6pm in the square otherwise you will be fleeced! Enjoyed the souk day and night!

Visually great. This is a site worth visiting.During the day you can wander around the shops and alleyways bartering for gifts. In the square itself are snake charmers, people with trained monkeys etc., and juice sellers with the most delicious orange juice i have ever had.During the night there dozens of stalls set selling great food.Right in the middle of the old city, by the kings palace.Brilliant atmosphere

Hard sell and hustlers. You gotta be careful here. Hustlers will try to be your guide and animals will be thrown around your neck. Walking through the souk is interesting but it's definitely not a relaxed affair.

You will get lost and that's ok. We walked in with map in hand and determined to follow it through but the individual market stalls took us in totally different directions so of course we got lost .and that's ok. You will get out eventually Fabulous shopping but please haggle its part of the experience. Probably the best market we came across in Morroco. Stop at a roof top venue for a yummy lunch and take off again. You need to be strong at heart to enjoy. Only thing I wouldn't do again is go to the main town centre for street food at night. Basically a rip off and not good. Citrus juice from vans fabulous but don't touch the street markets at night for food in the main market centre. All the other little restaurants im sure are ok

Very very busy. We went here with an excursion tour guide from Agadir and I don't want to use the word disappointing, but it wasn't great. Our group was way too big and the souk is huge and repetitive. There are lots of stalls selling the exact same thing. It's an interesting experience and it can be enjoyable to haggle and talk to the locals but it eventually gets a bit samey.

Endless Market Place, full of wonder... compare prices!. Exciting to weave through the maze of vendors. Friendly and ready bargain vendors. Be prepared with change for your purchases. Try to have a map so you can navigate the areas.

Ugh. This was a terribly disappointing place.Locals keep horses, monkeys, snakes etc in appalling conditions for cheap entertainment. Horses covered in sores standing tied to carts in 40° heat with no shade or water. Monkeys chained to stalls in football shirts. Horrible. The souk itself is very samey - acres of slippers which nobody seems to be interested in. All seems phoney.

Exactly as I had hoped a Souk would be. This was my first visit to Morocco and I had visions of how a Souk should be: Colorful, crowded, lots of unique merchandise, spices, scents and food. The Souk in Marrakech is all that for sure! The only drawback for me was the fact that I couldn't look at anything for longer than a split second before one or more merchants were all over me, urging me to enter their small shops and just pushing me to buy.
