I'm sure it's part of the fun of a Souk for many visitors but I like to have a little time to think, touch and really look at things, pondering what they would go with or how to display them at home. That certainly was not possible. Also, the haggling didn't usually go so well...Other than that, LOVED it!

Hold your breath.. As delightful as the souks appear there was a less than romantic aroma at times from the drains and the horses.Walking through the souks can be hair-raising as scooter, motorised trikes, large handcarts, bikes & people all jostle for space. Not for the faint hearted!

Exotic Market Unlike Any Other. The Marrakech open-air square and enclosed market are truly something to experience. Some will be overwhelmed and discomfited by the merchants and touts grabbing for their attention, and others will welcome the sights, scents and sensations available perhaps nowhere else in the world. Many interesting items are available for purchase--leather goods, handwoven rugs, jewelry, clothes, food, perfume, cooking utensils--but the price is only cheap if you are willing to haggle in a good-natured fashion. Jemaa el Fna now attracts tourists but it used to, and still does, attract rural-dwellers coming to the big city to sell their wares and witness snake charmers, story-tellers, diviners, gamblers, musicians, tooth-pullers, and a cast of characters found few places else. I recommend visitors make several trips, one to case the place, another to buy items that caught their fancy earlier, and once at night to see the square transformed into hundreds of places to eat under the stars. The government has cracked down, somewhat, on overly aggressive guides. If you hire one, be sure he is identified as an official guide. He will at least shoo away other guides. I have eaten at several of the night stalls, all good, but the food can vary, from tagines in one, to kebabs in another, and chicken and sausages in a third. I recently went to stall 14, which offers calamari, fried fish, and shrimp. An excellent, hearty meal for four persons came to $12. That's not a misprint, only twelve dollars, for all four of us. If your travels seem to run together, with one city's shopping mall and museum indistinguishable from another's, come to Jemaa el Fna. One member of our party couldn't help saying, "Toto, I've a feeling we're not in Kansas any more."

Don't be afraid to get a good price - Haggle!. It is the culture here and haggling is expected. Don't ask about prices if ure not willing to buy the product as some sellers get kinda agro if you don't buy anything. You will experience all kinds of sellers - make sure you never pay the 1st quoted price and have fun! Be confident and don't let the seller take control of the price. When you have a price in mind - stick to it and be prepared to walk away!

A must for all,. We spent a few hours at the Medina, and found the entire experience rewarding and very interesting. At no time did we feel intimidated, to the contrary we found all the local people friendly and helpful. Spend some time having a good look around, it may well be of use to you.

Marrakech Souk. The Marrakech Souk is crazy! You need to understand that this market it up there in the most hectic, energetic, busy, lively places that I have ever encountered.. The noise, the colour, the smells, really set the senses on almost overload.. I really enjoyed just wondering around - it's an experience and then some!A few words of caution: at times you can find yourself in quite closely packed crowds, in very narrow streets - if you're claustrophobic, this might not suit you.. Haggling is expected - you can cause offence if you simply offer the initial asking price (which doubtless will be too much) - try to think of what similar item may cost you at home, and offer 30% less than that - expect two or three rounds of pricing before settling - do NOT be afraid of walking away if you're not happy with the deal... Google Maps does NOT work in the Souk (they'd perhaps need a Google-donkey to scan it all...) ;-) : take a map! Be wary of locals offering to show you to where you want to be - they WILL expect to paid for helping you..Don't let the above put you off - I really enjoyed the hustle&bustle - but to be forewarned and all that...:-)
A Must See in Marrakesh. We spent a bit of time wandering around the souk and managed to pick up some real bargains. From the snake charmers to the various shopping stalls it was a place to remember

Must see but loads of hagglers. Be prepared to be bombarded and harassed by the locals as they try and sell you everything under the sun. I wanted henna from a vendor and she started to proceed drawing henna on me before i had agreed on a design and they went on to ask a lot of money for something i never chose. Beware!

Step back in time. Enter the Souk and be prepared to cast your imagination back 100 years or so! A myriad of small lanes, with sensory overload everywhere. Great value items and always worth a haggle with the willing shop keepers.

Great fun. I really enjoyed the hustle and bustle of the souks. We went twice, one was in a tour and then we went by ourselves. The noises, smells and sights are all wonderful. You will get pestered but it's all fun. My only advice is if someone offers you help for directions don't go as you will be lead off to some tour, shown around then they'll ask you for money! This happened to us and was asked for 400 dirhams, we didn't expect this so we managed to give 50 each but he wasn't happy! We were taken so far out we had to get a taxi back to the main square. But other than that it's all great fun :)
Always fun to walk the souk. Weather was great to walk in the souk. Not too busy which was nice. Vendors were a little less aggressive than normal which was also nice.

My kind of market. Red, yellow, green, blue, rugs, pottery, baskets, leather goods, silver, ceramic all side by side, in the small alleys surrounding the Fna square. You will get lost but it's part of the experience, bargening is the name of the game.

Fantastic place to stroll. The Souk has a variety of shops. Souviniers, clothes next to Jemaa I'Fena square. The Aragana cafe near by is also a classic. There are fresh juice stands near by. Must go if you are in Marrakech. The prices seem reasonable.

Shopping trip. You do get pestered by the Morrocans, but that is part of the experience.. I just found them to be happy, friendly people, and couldnt do enough for you, especially if you were buying off them too!! There are so many smells and sights to see, so very enjoyable experience of a different kind of shopping

It was OK. Our only trip out during our weekend stay in Marrakech. It was very hot and we had a lot of hassles from the snake charmers and stall holders. It was obviously very busy and everyone was trying to sell you something. The orange juice was lovely but to be honest we went for the experience so couldn't really be bothered to haggle for items we didn't want.

somewhere you have to visit. The Souk is a vibrant and entertaining place but the people are mithering and obnoxious if you do not look in "their shop" or buy "their product. The women who where doing henna tattoos were really obnoxious and would'nt take no for an answer. Everyone was only interested in your money. However I loved the Riad we stayed in even though we had a long walk through really dark streets at night to get back to it after being in the Medina.A lot of the men were intimidating and because we were two women on our own,thought they could bully us into giving them money and we were eventually told to f--k off because we said we had no money and wouldn't go to the bank as they "suggested" .

Enjoy-but don't be a victim of hard selling. We went out of high season and found the experience vibrant and memorable.I asked about female clothing at the riad where we stayed and was told as a Westerner,covering my head wasn't necessary.l wore long skirts and kept a scarf handy-blending in maybe helped against aggressive selling,as did replies in French[or Spanish].If vendors were pushy,'Perhaps tomorrow' seemed enough.Be prepared to barter-and check prices at other stalls.We bought jewellery and were tempted by leather goods.Argon oil from a pharmacy in the Jewish quarter was a good buy[and the other spices and herbal cures were offered by a brilliant salesman!]Flat shoes are needed as the cobbled lanes are uneven,and be aware of sudden passing motorscooters which go by at speed.Relax with cheap snacks and fresh fruit juices where the souk opens into the amazing main square.

Heart of Madness. If you want a crazy experience, then this is for you. Keep your wits about you and all will be well. Maintain a sense of humour at all times with all people and enjoy. There aren't that many places on the planet where it is safe to have an experience like this.. Tons of eating and drinking (non alcoholic) places, good service despite the crowds.

Colourful. The souk is in a dark setting in intrigue alleyway,yet full of colours and aromatic perfume of spices and leather goods, sea of people of all nation walk the Souk andyou love to be part of the people.
Marrakech Souks. This is one cultural experience you will Simply be in Awe. Go at night to see one of the most spectacular lightings in the Wotld.Excellent! Excellent! EXCELLENT! A Must Experience.

Visiting the Souk in Marrakech. Amazing experience, visiting the market - absolutely huge, with a myriad of stalls. Some selling authentic homemade goods, some just tat. But beware !! - Crazy people on scooters / Mopeds, career through, with no care about pedestrians. Make sure that you barter for EVERYTHING !!! - But you CAN get bargains !!

Nothing in the world is like it! . Our Souk experience was unforgettable. It's definitely not for the faint hearted but once you get the hang of it, it's one of the greatest experiences in the world. The trading and bartering is almost like an art! You have to really haggle well. The trick is to tell them what you're prepared to pay for the item you want to purchase. For example a scarf in UK usually costs an average of £5. When buying from the souks, don't pay more than 70 dirhams equivalent to (£5) The seller would usually start very high but always haggle for half or even less. Let's just say the seller is selling a scarf for 130 dirhams, just say you're willing to pay 50 dirhams. Then the art of negotiating happens. It's really fun! You will earn their respect if you've done really good bargaining. Enjoy!

Crazy. Our experience was spoiled by a girl doing henna ......oh it's a gift she insisted as she gripped me friends arm.no no she replied but I'm expecting g a baby and you should pay me no was the reply as she hounded us back to our riad then with one nasty swoop she smeared the wet henna up her arm getting it on clothes etc hence we had to wash and change once more my advice is take a guide making it quiet clear your not to be harrased and do the horse and cart at night around the kasbahs that was great and so different from the day also if buying its dark and your not sure of the quality in the souk best to shop in the day

Souk tour. Had a tour around the souk with a guide, good tour as lots of information ,places you would not see if you went without a guide, you have to relax and take it in and be firm if you don't want to be hassled but it's a place not to miss, plus we had a look at the main square with traders and snake charmers, don't forget if you want to take people's pics you have to ask.

Have fun and haggle. My wife and I spent 2 afternoons in the souk, the first with a tour guide, the 2nd on our own. While the first afternoon was useful in terms of understanding the various sectors in the souk (potters, leather, dyers, metal goods etc.) it was a bit sanitised because the guide kept us on the move, and clearly had a couple of 'tame' shops in mind for us to visit. We had a lot more fun on the 2nd visit, and were able to have a couple of good 'haggles' for some local pottery and a top for my wife. Haggling rule 1, never take the first offer seriously. Haggling rule 2, for the best offers walk towards the door or even into the street. Haggling rule 3, always remember you don't have to buy at the end.One thing to be aware of, there is no 'street map', and if you ask a local for directions, he will insist on accompanying you and you will have to pay him. Seemed a very safe environment, no hesitation in recommending it.

It is an interesting vibrant place but be very careful. A really too busy place day and night and you have to be very careful with your belongings ; shows ,dancing ,animal exploitation shows but everything they do there (if in case they see that you are watching them )they expect that you have to give them money ;they see tourists there and they think you are euro or dollar ;do not dare take a picture while a show or a dancing is going on because they will be after you shouting to give them 10 euros ; so look around the square and avoid any conversation with them because if you do they will expect something(money) I find it cruel and unacceptable to exploit animals-like monkeys and poisonous snakes etc in an effort to collect money from tourists . Do not dare to eat the food that they sell around the square because you will get food poisoning .
Shop, shop shop. Be prepared for the constant invitations to look and buy. Easy to get lost in the myriad lanes. Try a guide for your first time visit.
Get lost in the crowd. Like any souk, this is a busy place. I'm not really fond of markets because to me you can only find junk there, But it's always fun to walk around these busy places.

Just get lost in amongst the stalls. Many alleys and even more stalls - best thing to do is to take time out with no plans and just walk and get lost. Do ask stall holders before taking pictures and always barter!

A Maze of Madness. Growing up playing video games, the souk was a magnificent Zelda game in real life. Taking cover in the bazaar to escape the blazing, dry heat, we found ourselves in a wonderful maze of Moroccan trinkets. Every store owner calls you out trying to drag you into their lamp/sword/jewelry store while young kids chase you around asking if you are lost. It really is a magical place that is a must see.As a tip - I've found that you can barter most places down by half the price before they get too angry at you. Do not ever agree to their first offer as I guarantee, they will be willing to work with you just to make the sale.

Take your husband/boyfriend, two girls alone was not a good idea. I visited the souks a couple of times, once in the day with my friend and once a night with my friend and some other girls we met at the hotel resort. Stupidly we first visited the souks at night and it turned out to be a very scary experience. We had almost finished our shopping and this man was trying to sell me a pear, he didn't have a stall or anything, just a pear! I ignored him and carried on walking and I realised I'd obviously offended him when he began chasing me and my friends down the narrow souks. He was clearly unstable or on drugs, but that didn't matter after he threatened to kill me! The stall vendors obviously knew this man and were very nice and chef him out of the market, telling him to leave us alone, but this put a massive downer on our holiday. I understand that this could happen anywhere but I thought it was best to mention it so other travellers were aware. I would definitely recommend that you visit this place with a boyfriend or husband, as the couples didn't tend to get as much unwanted attention, especially from the men. On a lighter note, when we visited in the day everybody was really friendly and the hassle was more banter than anything else. One very nice tour guide on his day off offered to take us to the tanneries, as it was the last day and wanted a thank you and no money. The stalls sell all the same thing so have a good look around and haggle your socks off. One vendor was selling a souvenir for 150dhs and another was selling the same thing for 30dhs, so there is a huge difference. One piece of advice we were given is to always walk on the right hand side of the souks, as mopeds, horse and traps and every other mode of transport will fly down the narrow streets without a care in the world. Overall a great experience and a definite must if you're visiting Marrakech.......just be careful at night.

interesting but with heavy undertones of unpleasantness. I spent a half day here after a week of hiking in the Atlas mountains. On the one hand it is a great experience with all the shops and produce. However I felt this was tainted by the incredibly unpleasant behaviour of the hustlers and local vendors. I felt intimidated, pestered most of the time (I am a pretty widely travelled man and not easily intimidated). I also think these people spoil their own business: People would actually buy more if they could wander around and browse in peace. One vendor pulled my arm (literally) and shouted abuse at me for not buying his produce. Another called me a racist because of my refusal to buy and a third one cursed me and my remaining holidays. Therefore, despite all the interesting things on offer I think of the cities I have visited in the last couple of years Marrakesh is the one I am least likely to recommend. I was actually planning to come back here at some stage with my girlfriend but have now decided against. I don't think this is a place to bring a woman and would also caution single women against visiting this place. I think this place needs some clean up and perhaps either government intervention or an initiative by traders to establish some standards.
Souk. An experience. Good for getting out of heat. Most places selling similar items so can walk away if price not right.

Shopping in the souk(s): do not miss it. The souk(s) of Marrakesh are as charming and wonderful as they are vexing and difficult.But regardless going to Marrakesh and not going to the souk would be like going to the beach and not getting into a bathing suit!Just about anything you can imagine is available for purchase in the souk so for those who like to shop and shop some more you will be in heaven.Beware the touts and non-registered guides, as well as paying the first offered price. Good bargaining skills can reduce that first price by at least 50%, and for those who are highly skilled at haggling even more.Getting around without getting lost is neigh impossible, but do not worry getting lost is part of the fun.Few bathrooms are available so take that into account before venturing out of the main square where a number of cafe and restaurants have facilities.
Fascinating. We had a guide that walked us through the souks as you can get lost very easily. This is a different type of shopping than in the US

total assault of the senses. we were expecting it to be full on in the square and it was.totally frantic theatre best describes this square either by day or eveningif in Marrakech ensure you take your brave pills and go and experience it but if you want to see the real Morocco get out into the outlying towns around Marrakechsaying that we found the people to be friendly, helpful and understanding even when they are selling you some tat or sticking a snake around your neck for few diramstotally enjoyed the experience

Get your haggling head on!. I hate shopping but lived the souks. Be prepared to haggle for everything and beware rip offs. Many many bargains to be had though and lots of silver and leather products. (Sniff the leather - some is treated with urine and stinks forever!). It's much better than on the streets but - Ladies please be ready for many inappropriate comments from the local men. At times amusing at others down right scary. I hate to say this but you are safer if with a man. Don't let this stop you going but be forewarned. I found the souks much better and some lovely gentlemen stall holders who stepped in to help but as with everywhere in Marrakech this is 'normal' behaviour.

Hectic but worth it. We hired a private guide from our hotel to take us around the souks. He was fabulous and told us a lot of history about the surrounding area. I would recommend doing this as nobody approached us which happens alot and when they did our guide moved them on. You have to go quite far back into the souks to find the best stuff. Shoes, jewellery boxes and handbags and so much more. Worth it for the experience.

OK but full of tat. Everyone raves over the souks, to be honest there full of tat and a constant source of hassle. If you like shopping for belts bags rugs and slippers then hey you've reached utopia! Me personally after 5 minutes I'd had enough!

Marrakech Carnival. We loved Fes so much that Marrakech was a little bit of a disappointment but still interesting if that's the only place you go. The Marrakech souk is like a carnival in the square (snake charmers, henna, food stalls) with miles of bazaar-type shops winding around the outskirts. We had a guide which I believe helped us to not be harassed as much as we would have been without one. He also took us to the more up-scales shops which were much more expensive and we were really looking for the bargains so make sure to tell them what you want before starting out. If you are heading to Fes after Marrakech save your purchases for there. We found much better prices and you felt as though you weren't going to be ripped off as much (maybe just an illusion?) Also, we were told by our guide in Rabat that the pure Argon oil is found in Fes and that they mix oils in Marrakech and sell it as pure but I can't say if this was true since you really can't tell the difference looking at it. We bought it at a co-op in the mountains hoping that the young girls making it would end up with more of the profits. Enjoy the ride!

A Maze of Wonder. Has to be seen to be believed - could be quite daunting if you let it be for sure, but nothing like it. Haggle shamelessly, but don't haggle if you have no intention of buying. I'm actually wearing a fake pair of converse I picked up for 8 quid right now :)

Moroccan Only Fools and Horses. This place is brilliant and crazy at the same time. Take your time to wander through looking uninterested first. When it comes to haggling then if you start to walk away you'll almost always get what you want at the price you want. Never pay what they ask, you'll always get it cheaper. Paid 500DHS for 2 very intricate lamps, 380DHS for a medium/large leather bag, and around 100DHS for spices and Argan oil to give an idea of target prices.

Yea. I was looking forward to going to the souks. You can easily get lost. The first time was a bit scary, but towards the end of holiday - I got used to them. I just used my mobile and I also figured out the signs for direction. You need to haggle for goods - don't shy away from doing so, as you will be left paying really high prices...... Also flat shoes is a necessity.....

Very busy. The Souk is best visited in the company of a guide, the whole place is a rabbit warren of approx 6 miles of alleys, the guide we had was a font of knowledge and made us feel safe in what is quite a daunting place

Fun but touristy.. While this is a very dynamic place it also is too directly geared up for tourists and you feel very much like an outsider waiting to be ripped off. There are monkeys and snake charmers. Everyone there wants to make a buck off of you.
Be carful. Please be carful. People can appear friendly but arnt always honest. Can be a bit scary im glad i was with my partner but it still comes on strong

You gotta haggle!!!! :). Fantastic, a real market, not a fake one for tourists.Dont be frightened to haggle, they all start high, but you can nock them down normaly to a third of what they are asking.

Hate or love - no other option . The souks are like nothing else: a maze of small streets full of shops, stands, people, bikes and motorbikes. An immersive experience for all your senses. Nothing can prepare for what you'll find here. Stay calm when getting lost - it's impossible not to get lost - and enjoy your experience at maximum. You can relax in your Riad or a restaurant. Try to visit during the day and night. And don't forget the good manners and negotiation good sense.
Amazing. You need a guide for a walk around the souk.What a fantastic place.All of your senses working overtime.Every turn of your head brings something amazing.

Hussain Rassai . A typical market of ancient age. It's crowd a lot of traffic n very noisy. . There were many riads - houses with central court yards. . There were beautiful local artifacts available in the souk .. It's an interesting experience

Amazing walk. Our English speaking guide Eder took us into the Souks and started where there were workshops. We saw sheep/goats hides which had been tanned which would sold to the workshops or traders. We saw wood products being made. There was metal workshops. Leather shoes were being made. Wonderful to see.Eder then took us in to the various parts of the Souks covering the spice, fruit/veg are. The leather and wood sections were close to each other. There is a section for butchers and some fish shops. There was the obligatory rug shops which were pretty big.The main areas had a complete mixture of shops which were very small. If there were 4 people inside, it looked very busy. The fact that you could only fit 4 people was irrelevant. There is so many small shops crammed in the Souks , you just wonder how they make a leavingA truly amazing experience.

A visit to Morocco is not complete unless you visit the souks. Something like 60,000 small businesses within the souks.Felt really safe here. Excellent bargains to be had. People really friendly. Well worth visiting during the day and the evening.
Haggle, hassle but fun!. Although busy you can still get a bargain. Great atmopshere both day and night .Be prepared to haggle.In my opinion the leather is the best bargain.

Very interesting City thats the old part not the new area. Very interesting in the day time but comes alive after dark.Even more so if you take a ride in the Horse drawn carriage first as then when this is finished you get out into a flood lite area whichis worth the visit

What Marrakech is all about. The Marrakech souks are what Marrakech is all about. The hustle and bustle creates a fantastic atmosphere, one in which over two visits has never gone over the top. People are friendly and bargains are there to be had. Barter hard, be looking to pay 1/3 of the original price at most, don't feel guilted into to buying anything, be respectful, brave and have fun with it. Can be a great way to get out of the sun in the middle of the day as the souks are covered. Spend time getting lost, picking up bargains and easy the bartering.

Take it easy. The souk is place where you have to be an experience shopper to get any type of good merchandise for a good price. The trick is knowing the good merchandise from the bad, because sometimes you get sucked into paying top money for an item that is worth absolutely nothing. I mean NOTHING.... Always bargain, and if in doubt just walk away, you would be doing yourself a favor..... Go around, look around, price things as you go, and use your good judgment, the merchant's, because after all he is there to take as much as he can from you ...

Don't listen to the horror stories. We went to the souk on our own with another couple and not on a tour. I will firstly say that I am terrified of snakes, and yes they were there and yes I did have a ''moment' but other than that it was great!The snakes are in the main square in the afternoon, you will hear them before you see them and you can avoid them (just go round the edge of the main square).The souks are great, the shops sell similar things but it's all really fun to see and you can barter anyone down! All the people were lovely! No one pushed us or shouted or any of the bad things we heard, yes it's hustle and bustle but that was part of the fun!We had a lunch on a roof top cafe, which was basically someone house, but the food was great and cheap!You should go and enjoy this place for what it is and make the most of the sights, smells and people!

Better than expected. The market is like a maze and you will want a guide for your first visit. There is more sites, smells and people than you can image. It was all I expected and then some. You need to watch what you pay, and negotiate well. The snake charmers are very very aggressive and be ready for them to attack you if you take a photo.

Complete madness. Over 60,000 stalls inside The Medina. Very easy to get lost and should you require help to find your way out, you can be sure that it will cost. So go on an organised tour if you're not sure of your way around. Keep to the right when walking because there are mopeds everywhere riding up and down, so watch out! Fascinating place to watch artisans at work because here, different to our society, they repair things not just throw away and buy new. Be careful with photographing without first asking permission. People, on the whole are very accommodating and friendly and will agree. But beware, some expect payment and if you photo without permission they can be very aggressive in demanding payment. And you MUST barter, it is expected.
Very interesting . You can find almost anything in the souk,we watched snake charmers,bought lots of gifts back very cheaply is a must for a visit.

Nicer. The Marrakech souks was really nice to see a lot of things handecraf original from morocco the ambiance was good and the merchants are very helpful i both same souvenir and we enjoyed match. Very diferent than ather city we hop to come back again thanks a lot.

Manic. Very busy, was lovely to get a literal flavour of Marrakech! Some of the local men made some women feel slightly uncomfortable but a firm no thanks and they left you alone. Some lovely food and markets including 100% pashmina scarfs made in front of you! Wonderful experience

Crazy!. Colourful, noisy, congested and hassled from start to finish!A tourist trap in every sense....with virtually everyone who's not a tourist hassling to get you to buy something!Definitely worth a visit, but be mindful that there are sights, smells and experiences you may prefer not to witness! (Eg monkeys dressed up on a chain, snakes in bags, with their 'charmers' at hand, young turtles crammed in tanks, beggars with babies, food cooked in black filthy oils, women keen to grab you and start their henna 'art'....the list goes on).Nonetheless, it is different and certainly an experience! If you like to get a good deal and want some of their goods, then it can be fun to bargain. But be aware that you need to be quite abrupt to get rid of the persistent hassle to 'just look'! That is not the case.Good photo opportunities, however be wary of taking picture of locals. Most are far from keen, some clearly not happy and others only ok if you pay up front!!

o.k. for a stroll. To stroll the Marrakesh Souks is quite an adventure but one realizes after a short while that although the Souks are rather large, most shops and their offerings are repetitious and identical. It is either blankets and leather, pottery, fake Argan oil and spices, or brass. Also, some of the sellers tend to be a little too aggressive which is a turn down. If you have ever been to a bazaar in Turkey with their large varieties and charming sales guys you will understand the big difference in having fun and having to feel uncomfortable at times.

The Best!!!. No visit is complete without a visit to the Souks in Marrakech. It's like visiting London but not seeing Big Ben, Buckingham Palace, Westfield etc. The souk is massive but there is no danger of getting lost as you'll eventually find your way. Best way to navigate is at each turn take a picture of a shop or sign and then try and come back same way. Do try and keep with the crowd. There are many foreigners here. Avoid walking into quiet alleyways for precaution. It's all about bartering here. Keep haggling and eventually they will succombe to you. The shops are repetitive so there are many options for clothes, leather bags, shoes, wooden crafts, souvenirs, spices and herbs etc. Do try some of the cafes inside the souk. Cheap! Some cafes do food. It's very nice. Many children beg here. Some sell tissues. Be careful when giving change as you may be hounded by other children. Sad but reality. The souk is the pinnacle of Marrakech. Best time to shop is mornings/early afternoon. After 7pm it's too busy but the buzz is amazing.

Crazy!!!. We love the local markets or Souks as they are known. If you are a '1st timer' here be prepared to be harassed by the locals trying to get you in a taxi, horse and cart, shop or restaurant! They mean no harm, they're only trying to make a living. 1 piece of advice..... HAGGLE HAGGLE HAGGLE

Sensual assault. Top tip For your first visit go with an accredited guide but be prepared to be steered into "buying opportunities" from which he will get a commission If you don't want that be clear from the outset and say so

AWFUL!!!!. The worst experience of my life! my friend and I went to the market at mid day to get some authentic gifts for our family. We were dropped next to the market and made out way into the Souk. We did not feel safe at all. We were moderately dressed however the men were saying derogatory comments to us and made us feel very unsafe. It is very easy to get lost and the locals try to direct you in the wrong way. my belief is, this is to see if you believe them so they and judge character. We were followed and I even had to message family in the UK to warn them of how unsafe I felt. We finally found our way out and bought a few items from the front of the market. You must always negotiate with the market stall owners as they inflate the prices massively.

a scary day in a souk. I did what everyone tells you not to do....? I don't know why? I felt pretty safe, but I followed a chappie on a Motorbike through the tiny streets to go and see a leather producer, where I was taken into a shop and almost forced to purchase something....I stuck to my guns and the owner threw me out...I was lost......but the signs on the streets are straightforward enough...lesson learnt......do not ask for directions...locals charge...
Visit the Souk on a guided tour. I would advise visiting the Souk on a guided tour! The market is huge and the likelihood is you will get lost.

Pushy vendors. The souk had a very large selection of Moroccan items for sale - the major negative is how pushy the vendors are when you are looking at the items - almost takes the fun out of shopping

Not to miss the Marrakesh Souk. This market can be overwhelming but it is very interesting to see the locals as well as the atmosphere in this typical "souk". One can try the food without any problem.

AVisit to the Souks is a Must!. My husband and I visited the souks without a guide and we had no problems. Admittedly we didn't go from one end to another but we did straight lines as much as possible. We haggled away. I was called Berber but it's hard to know sometimes if you get a bargain or not. The lamps were fabulous if you could carry home. They were great value. One visit was enough.

Mysterious souks of Marrakech. Great fun walking the maze of souks in Marrakech, not knowing what is around the next corner. Plenty of locals offering advice, but beware as they will expect payment at the end, so get as much info as possible. End the day at Jemaa el Fna, a place not to be missed especially in the evening.

Morocco. Those of you that have visited Morocco will know that this is like any other souk in any arabic city. Lost of people all trying to sell you something. Although this is my second visit to Marrakesh and I must say that they do not hassle as much as they used to.

The land of stories!. This is the place where you can see and buy everything you want to! But be careful cause is also the place you can be lost! People are a little bit closer because they all want to show you something so you have to get into the spirit of Marrakech Souk! You'll love it!

Good souk, as all of them tend to be.. I can't say this souk particularly stood out over the others. It was interesting: we walked around inside, and saw some nice ceramics. It's easy to get lost in it all.

Best Souq I have been in my whole life. Marrakesh is known for its souq! Narrow streets, people, mules, donkeys and horses mopeds and motorbikes in the streets! I love this souq, If you want to shop you can you can find everything you want, from rugs, traditional Moroccan clothes, souvenirs, best food stalls! You can find snake enchanters, people who do henna tattoos and live traditional Moroccan music.

Go up high and enjoy the sights and sounds.. It's madness but don't miss it. Go up high to one of the terrace cafes and enjoy a cold drink and a little respite. You'll love the sights and sounds from above.

Worth a visit. Very busy narrow streets with hundredds of people and motorbikes and donkeys. Watch out for pick pockets and note that if you get lost and ask a local on the street you will have to pay to get directions (we stopped for coffee and asked the waiter to point us in the right direction)

Interesting place to visit. My first time visiting Jmaa el Fna, a place which is worth getting lost in. It is when I got lost that I found little alleyways which led to numerous little shops and stalls selling a variety of goodies. I also enjoyed bargaining with vendors and got a good price for many items.

Hit and Miss, good luck you will need it!. Positives - the souks are undoubtedly fascinating, they are extremely busy and there are enough stalls and sights to keep you occupied for a week.Negatives - on a hygiene scale the souk is pretty grim. We saw a dead dog, excrement up walls and flies all over food for sale. The worst thing though were teenagers who constantly try to scam and rip you off. All in all a worthwhile visit just be careful!

ugh. Anything you want is somewhere in the hugely spread-out souks of Marrakech, if you can stand the badgering and avoid getting plowed by a motorbike. We bought some lovely bananas, our only purchase from the souks. They make for a twisty and rather harrowing walk between museums.
Definitely worth it. Really nice authentic morocco bazaar. Will need to haggle but bargain galore. Good choice of restaurants and entertainment but be careful of begging.

Really interesting.. I myself didnt buy anything but there is a hell of a lot of choice, I happened to see a man carving wood for chess sets with his feet and a file which was very impressive considering the speed and accuracy. I would advise to go in with a thomsons tour guide because i would imagine it would be easy to get lost.You dont really get hassled hardly at all in the souks compared to the market though which was interesting.

A very different experience.. ONLY GO IN THE MORNING!!As the later you go the more people there are and the more they harass you!!The morning people are calm and nice and the in the souks people are really nice but you can get some very good prices, especially if you go in further, however it is dark so when you walk out some of the products don't look as good. And there is a promenade where all these horses are and its sad if you don't like animal abuse as thy aren't kept nicely, same with all the monkeys as they have makeup and clothes on and personally I didn't like that but inside the souks everyone is fine.

Visit but be aware and careful. Use a guide and be careful !!! If you are a women or have children traveling with you - be aware and careful. We actually surrounded the 2 kids with the 3 adults bc it was getting a little scary.
Hotel odaya . Very basic hotel, had to get the room changed 3 times, electricity not working in one room, A.c not working properly in the other room, toilet not working in 3rd room, please avoid .

Love to get lost. Ah! The Souks. What an experience. Spend a day getting lost among the vendors. Each one has a different speciality, there are spices, fabrics, leather, food, etc.
A visit to Marackesh would not be a visit without time in the Souks

Same old same. I'm not sure if it's because we can get similar things in abundance in our country now at places like home sense but I feel like the souls were much of the same old! Once you've seen a few you've seen them all!You do get hassled to go and take a look, but once you're in it's ok you don't get hassled. Be firm but fair and be prepared to walk away. They'll respect you for it.I did see some magic in the place but not what I thought I would see.

Annoying. Its so great to go and see another country and experience the culture however it is so frustrating every 10 meters someone is hassling you for money or to buy something. In the end i had to develop a stern face and be ignorant and I suggest you do the same just to make your experience better.The markets are beautiful and you will find many bargains. One word of warning there are lots of dodgy alleys. If you go down the wrong one turn back and please please dont let someone try and show you around or if your lost ask for directions but dont let anyone take you.We were being taken to a place as we didnt know where we were going then one guy would run off and then suddenly there were 3 guys. I was on red alert but a police officer stopped them as we was walking and searched them. At that point we just walked off. If he didnt come i think we would have been stuck up. Also watch out for pick pockets as usual. Other than that enjoy.

Excellent experience, how could you come to Marrakech and not go to the Souks......be polite.. This is an absolute highlight, it's completely bonkers though. My tips:-1) Be polite - the sellers can get on your nerves but don't be rude, it's their job. They will soon leave you alone.2) If you want to haggle, aim for a 1/3rd of the price they want.3) Go into the souks and come back out after an hour on your first go, acclimatise yourself before going in for another go.4) Go with 50 drm notes, if they see you with large amounts they'll want more money.5) Avoid the monkies on chains dressed as Messi, not cool.6) The snakes are harmless, don't be afraid.7) If you don't want to pay for anything, don't stop and look, especially the snakes and henna ladies.Enjoy it, it's brilliant, if not chaotic. There are plenty of rooftop bars around where you can chill out before diving back in to the melee.

A must see. A friend recommended visting during the day & again at night. It turned out to be great advice.During the day it's quite subdued and although you are approached by people begging & wanting to sell you stuff they weren't anywhere near as persistent as we expected.At night the square comes to life. There's a lot of hustle & bustle, lots of stalls selling local cuisine, street entertainers & shops that weren't open during the day. Having made purchases (prepare to barter) we found a rooftop bar, grabbed sone drinks & watched the world go by.

Sights, Sounds, Sense Overload. Truly must be experienced. An overload on all of the senses. Take in all of it, a tiny part of it or both! I suggest sitting at one of the outside restaurants/bars on the perimeter first to take in the larger picture then go exploring, get lost, haggle for anything under the sun, try new foods, people watch and interact with the locals. Beware of pickpockets (especially in the square) but most all of the vendors are more than willing to help.

Lost in the Souks. Anyone who has been in any busy market in the eastern hemisphere will still be blown away by this one! The overall first impression is the sheer vastness of the place, it truly is a rabbit warren and though easy to get lost, the locals are glad to direct you out (even if it is via their Uncles, cousins Herbalist stall!) The hazards and pitfalls are much the same as elsewhere. Traders are persistent and if you aren't interested in their wares you have to be just as persistent in your determination to just walk away! Keen to trade and haggle. Felt like a safe place though unaccompanied females can be a target for unwanted advances! All in all, worth at least a couple of visits.

scary. Be Careful and don't get lost otherwise they charge you for directions! I found them quite scary and was getting hassled a lot by the men calling me "jordan" or "paris hilton." For the record, I look like neither, but my blonde hair seemed to attract them..

Souk. We went after visiting the YSL gardens. Super interesting - snake charmers and people with monkeys outside (wasn't very nice). Lots of horse drawn carriages too.Inside the souk, much the same thing. Market stall owners constantly asking you to come in. Whilst walking through the market a guy barged into me, purposely! Not for the faint hearted!

Nice experience, my first souk visit. Honestly, I was here in 2012, but I think nothing has changed here in Marrakech souk. Crowded of people who wants to sell you something (and insisting), I think it's an important experience for all people who visit this city.

We got very lost. We accidently ended up in the souks and then we're lost for 3 hours. It's kind of scary, everyone is shouting to get your attention (we are quite obvious tourists) and when you ask for directions they either send you the wrong way on purpose or lead you to a couple of their friends shops (where they get commission) and then ask for a tip for their 'tour' and don't even lead you to where you wanted to go. It's a real shame because if the people were a bit nicer it would be a really interesting place we would frequent but this has put us off.

If you love getting spoken down to then this is the place to go. I agree with what other people say about the 'Souks' its pretty much like any other market in the world, same cheap tat is being forced upon you in every shop. I can imagine a decade or so ago there was probably some genuine haggling to be done here, but not anymore. Their vastly hyper-inflated prices were ridiculous, on items we could pick up here in the UK for a third of their lowest prices. If you want to enjoy Marrakech avoid the souks and the market, unless you enjoy being treating like your an idiot.

An absolute treasure trove. We loved the souks by night. Anything and everything is on sale to be bartered for. Don't expect the designer labels to be real and go with the flow. We didn't get lost although it would be quite easy to do so if you don't think about where you've been and where you're going. The traders are great fun and friendly. They embrace tourism and tourists and really made our experience a great one. Everyone speaks French and I was even able to use a few words of Arabic which surprised the traders and they were really keen tell me all about their language - in English!! We were never hassled although they're really quick to pick up on it if you show an interest in anything. Bartering is fun and expected but to be fair everything was so cheap we never tried too hard.

Don't get it. I don't get it at all. An open air market with a bunch of stuff for sale. Really obnoxious vendors. Morocco was fascinating, but this was not. Rent a car and head east over the Atlas mountains and don't stop until you get to the Sahara, get on a camel, go into the desert, stay in a tent. It might still have been touristy but it felt way more real than this. But, it you like that sort of thing....

Normal market. Ok, this is pretty big market, with many shops / stalls for locals (Where you can also get pretty good food for low price), then there are many shops with wooden things, stones, spices , ... (And other interesting things for me) , with reasonable price (After some "discussion" about it). And then there are some monkey owners, snake owners, musicians. They are there only to rip off your money. Avoid them as far as you can. (Actually this is the point with made me rate this lower)

An amazing attack on the senses!. We visited there in he evening before dinner at a local restaurant. What a vibrant location with all sorts of food and entertainment. We tried the local snails and dates and spent some time with the snake charmers and the watermen. The frantic pace of everything coupled with the sounds, smells of untold other visitors make this a place that to me symbolises Morocco. Not for the faint hearted!

An amusing place when everything seems possibile. A great spot to spend a week end or an entire week. Do not forget to bargrain any item you want to buy and est in The jamal el fna square, food si delicious and chickens are always from a local farm, an experience not to be missed

Do get lost!. The markets - souks - are places where even locals get lost. So don't worry! Pay attention at your pocket and be careful when taking pictures - Moroccans don't like it so much, and if you don't buy from them, they may ask you for money for the picture. The best is to take pictures on those from whom you buy. Also, if you are not interested do not ask prices or start a negotiation.Try to know the 'OK' prices for the products before - in your riad or something.If your lost, ask where the central place is, they will tell you. (Do.not accept fake guides to do it for you)Do negotiate!!! You will expect that. Sometimes they ask 4 or 5 times the price.When the price is fixed and written there, it is more difficult to negotiate.

Very interesting but super busy. We visited last year and this year.Very interesting and a lot to buy but so busy.Sometimes we didn't even asked for prices because we didn't wanted any long charts.We couldn't take any pictures because of so many people just wanna charge us for taking pictures.Some stores a beautiful with lovely people.I bough few thinks and they are amazing.Best is to book a tour so you will feel more safe and secure.recommended to visit if you in Morocco just for experience.But be ready super busy.And try to focus where you going!

A non stop place!. The souks really are a sight to see.The bazar (market) is a place where goods are sold, a souk is a place where goods are made and sold. There are thousands of souks here selling many of the same items - shoes/slippers, belts, bags, lanterns, jewellery, spices, Argan oil, traditional clothing and scarfs.Be prepared to barter. It's expected. Some sellers are more desperate than others but don't make you feel pressured. They will all ask you to come in and look. I'd recommend wearing closed toe shoes as the ground is uneven and dirty. It is also very hot due to the small streets and volume of people.There is also lots of street performers and eateries around the medina

Lovely . Such an amazing market but not the best place to go with young children . Shop keepers tend to pester children and try to get them to come into their shops to buy things , this can be a big pain for parents as if kids wonder off they will get lost . The prices are very expensive but you can try to bargain . Argan oil is pure and made right infront of you , great purchase !!! Fresh juices are made which are great , they boost your energy !!! Cart horses are available to give you a tour of the city !!! Good way to learn about the city .

Great experience. You can find just about anything in the market however be careful of how u navigate ur way around cars bikes ppl n motorcycles all travel along the narrow ally ways at high speeds... Also never accept the 1-5th price offer always go for lower and pretend to walk away n they will go even lower... A must see place good bargaining...

A worthwhile experience . You really can't go to Marrakech without visiting the main Souk/Medina. My husband did an initial visit on our second day with our oldest son (10) to get his bearings, know where the shuttle stopped etc. a couple of days later, I joined them with our younger son (7). We went around 6 o'clock so it would be a little cooler (once inside the main medina (walled area) within the main square, it is covered so much cooler. It can be quite daunting for younger children because it's busy, noisy with lots going on. There are snake charmers, holy men, monkeys wearing nappies and footy kits. Be careful not to take pictures as the handlers will badger you for money. There are also lots of ladies offering henna tattoos. I declined but one lady grabbed my hand as I walked passed and started drawing on my hand. The children were fascinated so I let her carry on and had to pay her what I thought it was worth (10 dirhams my not impressed husband had to hand over as he had nothing smaller!). As nice as the tattoo was, not a good idea if you have to hold on to a child's hand. That said, it takes 10 minutes to dry but it lasted approximately 2 minutes before being smudged by my son so i had to buy some wipes to rub it off (and from my sons hand) as well as the annoying glitter they also sprinkle on!!! there are hundreds of shops and stalls. The vendors try to get you to come in but a polite no thank you is all you need if you're not interested. I certainly didn't feel hassled and despite my reservations, enjoyed the experience of watching my husband barter for 'genuine fakes!' as the vendors called them. When we came out of the medina (8.30pm) all I could say was 'wow!'. The square was packed, lots of people everywhere, loud morrocan music, wonderful smells coming from the food stalls-it really came alive. The smell of horse poop when you walk passed the horse and carriages (for rides around the town), was quite overwhelming so hold your breath. There are elderly people and mothers with newborns begging for money which can be upsetting but as long as you keep you children held tight, you should enjoy this experience. We ended up going 4 times in total (my husband is a shopaholic!) so it can't be that bad!!

Great fun bartering. Great experience, all hustle and bustle and every type of product Morocco is famous for, spices, leather, rugs, pots - you name it, they sell it. Always be prepare to barter, about a third of the price they offer.

Chaotic Madness. What a place.You must haggle HARD for everything .. NEVER accept the first, second or third price for anything.Haggling with a smile and good humour will get you a long wayYou can buy just about anything hereIt is quite tricky not to lose track of where you are thoughAnother Must visit
Market lovers heaven. Fantastic place! The further inside you go the better (&cheaper) things get ;) if you aren't a pro haggler it's still lots of fun and very beautiful

Barter Time !. I wanted to buy everything I saw, from kaftans to slippers and lamps to tagine’s. Please do haggle, unlike my husband who is terrible at bartering.The Djemma el-Fna is surrounded by cafés where you can watch the street theatre going on. Every evening they fire up a feast in the square and serve the latest street food from grills and steaming cauldrons. We decided for sizzling aubergine, and chicken tagine with caramelised pumpkin.

Love to haggle and visit to see the square . Absolutely loved the souks...as others have said offer 70% off their price and stick to your guns. We returned several times to the souk. Here's what we bought...dirham price on left.180 ladies Purple shoe £ 12.80 160 ladies grey shoe £ 11.42400 four xxxl polo shirts £ 28 200 two fold up large bags £ 14 (plus two for 220) 15 hoctagonal wooden box £1 40 two square wooden boxes £340 heart wooden shape box £3420 big wooden box £30250 Two metal chrome like tea light lamps 20cm high £1840 tourist hat £2.80115 75ml argane oils and soap £8280 three belts £20400 egg, bracelet and soap dish £29100 Kebab skewers £7

Madness, but great madness!. Where to start, how not to get lost, what to buy, what not to buy!The souk is a truly amazing place. So much hustle and bustle. Haggle (it's all part pf the fun) and never buy the first thing you see.

Amazing experience. Thoroughly enjoyed the Souk to spend some time exploring and soaking in the sights and sounds! Visited as a family and was something for everyone.Be prepared to haggle for whatever you buy and remember as long as you are happy with the price that's the main thing but if your seller looks too happy you paid too much! You will never be sold anything for a loss.Also please be careful as this is a prime spot for pickpockets and I watched someone try to do it to my father, luckily they were the worlds worst pick pocket and who seriously keeps their wallet in their back pocket in a busy market.
fantastic souk. Excellent old souk,lively and vibrant ,there are hundred and hundreds of little shops ,selling all sorts ,a fantastic souk.

Slightly scary, slightly exciting, very enjoyable. Chaotic, dizzying and yet quite exhilarating! We went without a guide as the Four Seasons organisational skills had been untrustworthy and we were absolutely fine. It's so different, like a maze but the people were charming. They are trying to make a living so want you to buy but not particularly pushy and very humorous. Certainly worth visiting, you would be missing out to not go.

Lovely during the night . The souk was a really good experience, you have to bargain a lot with the shop keepers to get the price down on items. Also if you take children do always keep them next to you as it's very busy and you could easily lose each other! Lots of shops to buy pretty stuff, and it looks lovely during the night.

Better than I expected!. I loved being in the Souk. It was a mixture of bartering with stall holders and trying to find one that sold water (definitely difficult day we chose at 45 degrees) ! Go and chat to the locals and feel Moroccan.

Beware you'd end up buying more that necessary.. Get a guide if possible so you don't get conned into paying beautiful handicrafts. Well you will not be able to resist some but get what you really love and leave with no regrets. Another point to note is that with a guide, you won't get lost on the maze like souk and also will never miss the must see sights within the souk. The guide was somewhat affordable and ensure that he has a license before deciding on one.

Best Visit. I loved my visit to the souks, before I went people gave me the view that you get bombarded as soon as you get there but this wasn't the case at all. We walked around freely and stopped where we chose to. We picked up so lovely bits for decent prices. I would recommend for your first time going early. I can't wait to return to Morocco and visit the souks.

Embrace the experience. Great fun, sturdy shoes, water and good negotiation skills a must. Spices and leather goods a must. Locals as colourful as the goods they are selling. Be ready to haggle it's all part of the process. Don't be shy!

Great fun in the hustle and bustle . This is a labyrinth of alleys and streets that are filled with small to medium stalls and shops selling everything Moroccan and everything else, clothes and food to pottery and jewellery.The traders do try and encourage you a few times to enter there stalls, politely say no thank-you and they stop.If you do like something barter be prepared to walk away they will reduce further.Great place to explore and fun when bartering, a must visit whilst in Marrakech

The Madness of the Souks. We decided to pay for a guide for the morning to show us around the Souks, after getting lost several times around the Main Square. Initially it started off fine, and the guide did speak relatively good English. Then he decided to take us along to a place he described as a Co-operative which turned out to be either a friend or a contact he had to try and sell us carpets and rugs!! We declined politely his offer of mint tea, as once they have your attention you will be there until they brow beat you to purchases a rug!! Then the guide again tried to take us to a spice shop, probably yet another contact where he earnt commission!! The guide seem to loose interest in us after that!! Just be wary of these Guides, as although they have been paid by our hotel, they will still try to make EXTRA cash from you buying things from their associates!! Other than that the Souks are well worth a visit, there are shops there if you are adverse to Haggling!!
A must do.. As souks go this is good. Be prepared to bargain hard. Young backpackers will get a better deal than us old folk.

GO AND ENJOY THE EXPERIENCE - NOTHING LIKE IT. Like another reviewer said, there is no point going to Marrakesh if you do not go to the Souks. It is a MUST!It is incredible, very busy and a bit daunting at times but absolutely great (you may get lost, but that's all part of the experience). I never ever haggle but I did and it was fun, prices are cheap, loads of things to buy, loads of things to see (food, clothes, music, tricks, animals, bags). A firm "NO" is all you need to say and you will be fine.It is alive, bustly and mesmerising, day or night. I LOVE the place.I travelled with 2 females, no guides - no problems, we just stayed together, remained 100% observant and polite at all times and did our thing.GO AND ENJOY THE EXPERIENCE.
Worth visitng. The souk and sqaure are very modern and clean. Possibly sind of the old Atmosphäre is lost, but it still is worth a visit.

Incredible Experience. There's no point going to Marrakech if you don't go to the Souks. Take a guide the first time you go so that you get a feel for the place and to get an idea of how everything works. Afterwards, get lost in the mazy streets and enjoy yourself.

Amazing!!. The sooks are incredible - day or night although the place comes alive at night. Get yourself a guide as you can easily get lost but the experience is amazing!!Get your bartering skills brushed up prior to attending as the traders can drive a hard bargain and will come out with some random prices!! Always pay roughly half of what they ask but you will hAve a good idea of what you want to pay and what an item is worth!Great for a city break or a weeks holiday (that's what I did!)I felt extremely safe here. I would say I watched my purse though, especially at night as it was immensely busy and had kids begging!Be firm with the loal

Not for the faint hearted. Spent a couple of hours in the souks, wonderful array of spices, herbs, pashminas and leather goods . Really good prices after much bartering, but you really do need to be strong to do it convincingly. Had a really enjoyable, although very tiring time. Make sure you keep your bearings,very easy to get lost if not careful.

Vibrant Loud and lot of haggling. Very noisy and busy souk. As soon as they see a tourist the traders attempt to attract your attention at the same time tripling their price ; which means that you have to always divide the selling price by three. They will do their best to keep the price up but even though you are interested try to walk away and they will soon come running. I got the price of a pouffe dropped from 650 to 200. I have seen high end desighner watches for £10 but obviously they are real looking fakes! And there is the tempting appetising aroma of kebab, shawarma and targines which hard to resist.Went there on Sunday evening after 2200 and the souk comes alive especially at night as if all the population of Marrakesh decided to come to the market at night!! But one has to be aware of pick pockets; apparently the souk goes on until dusk.
Be patient. The souk is always a diferent experience. You need to be very patient to listen to all the sellersand to negotiate with them. Calm down. Yet, some sellers are nice.
Worth a look . An eye opener, worth a visit for the experience.... Some bargains to be had if you know what you want.

Vibrant and Fascinating. Hundreds of souks, ranging from beautiful colourful leather goods, scarves and pottery to even colourful spices stacked in pyramid shapes. The atmosphere is brilliant, need good bartering skills.

Worth a visit!. The souks are amazing but be careful as you will get lost its like a maze!
There is so much to see from metal working to spices and the store owners so give you too much hassle. Definitely a must see in marrakech.

A maze of stalls. Once you have got your bearings, it is pleasant to walk around. As always you will need to haggle, we found this great at first but getting more tedious as the day wears on. Being honest we found it easier and cheaper to go to the Jewish quarter where the products are better quality, better laid out and you can still haggle. We sat and drank tea and people watched which is a great way to while away a few hours, but you will get constantly hassled by watch/phone/trinket sellers. Depending on your personal stance the monkeys, snakes and various other animal entertainers can be amusing or horrifying. They will hassle you for money for taking photos too.The street food in the evenings is good to eat....and as always watch your belongings and check your change

colourful adventure!. When we were in Marrakech, we knew we just had to visit the souks. all of the stalls and shops are so colourful and full of funny characters. There is lots to buy, from henna to spices and leather bags to ornaments. There are some great deals to be had. Don't be afraid to haggle...and remember to keep your belongings close to you at all times as it is really really hectic!
Crazy busy place. A must have to visit for everyone but be prepared! Lots to see and buy the usual in any market really! Some great little treasures to be found!!
shopping. A great experience, be aware of pick pockets! Enjoy the food and soak up the atmosphere. Amazing colours and smells, try some fresh orange juice

what an experience. we had no idea what we were in for when we came across the souks only a few hundred metres from our hotelyou can get and see anything from a haircut to a motor bike wheel, pigs heads , fish , spices, snake charmers and I could go on forever what a wonderful city and country Marrakech , morocco don't miss

Rough. Rough, rude, dishonest traders. It takes the fun out of the experience. Also the Souks at night is not pleasant, my husband stopped a pick pocketer from going into my bag. Buy your stuff from a supermarket it's less hassle!

Worth a visit. Try to visit this huge Souk late afternoon , we did it early afternoon , the heat and the humidity was unbearable , the quality of the food and the vendors are in general of low quality but there are some gems hidden in this vast Souk ,worth mentioning is Miloud El Jouli the owner Abdulah is very welcoming and accommodating ,although the prices are not cheap but for the quality is well worth it , after a hard bargain we were successful in acquiring a fantastic piece of artisan work that is amazing in workmanship and detail.

China meets Morocco. If you want to visit an original Moroccan Suq skip this.Go to Fès and visit the real places of the art crafts, go to Safi and visit the pottery making.. But honestly what you'll find here is just a commercial very bad quality imitation of original Moroccan beautiness.

Discover. The souks was very fameuse and we can find every thinks we need without any problem i feel very surprised to be in this souks totely diferent than ather city we enjoyed match and i both same souvenir and we are very pleased t hanks a lot .

Pressured selling!. We have been to both Egypt and Tunisia, and the sellers here are by far the most aggressive!!! watch out for blokes who latch on to you and follow you around trying to interest you in everything!!!
Amazing experience. You have to visit this place & don't forget to haggle before paying for anything. You can pick up some great deals

Don't be daunted... The firat time i visited was a little daunting, avoid all the guides that are waiting as you get off the bus, there are some will say they work for your hotel and charge no money..this is sometimes trueas they get commission from the stalls they take you too and i have spoken to people in my hotel that found this a good way to get orientated but its your choice.The square is very large so make sure you remember where you came into it if you need to get back to a pick up point, our hotel shuttle dropped us at least 2 streets back so it was a bit of a maze.Don't be tempted to buy at the first stall, if you go right into the Souks then you will eventually come to the less commercial and therefore cheaper goods. They are all selling more or less the same things overall and some is better quality than others.I wasn't sure how i would be with haggling but as i heartd one stall holder say its how we do business, it is like a game in a way and i wasn't as bad at it as i feared. Decide what you want to pay and if they say no just walk away, i guarentee they wil come after you and accept eventually.In the square are snake charmers etc, try going into one of the rooftop cafes for a better view, we had lunch and it cost me about £12 for the 3 of us, i had a chicken and veg terrine , my 2 sons had toasties with chips and we all had drinks so very good value.I am told it is another world again at night time but i didn't experience thsi as the hotel shuttle stopped at 6pm, however there are trips you can do.I now have some very nice coloured tea lanterns in my garden, as do my frineds, a lovely wicker basket, bracelets, sunglasses, purse and a couple of pictures on my walls all thanks to the trip into the Souk. Have fun but be careful of your money!! Also beware that if you want your family to take a photo of you with a snake around your neck or a monkey on your shoulder they will charge you so negotitate first. Similarly if you get a taxi to the Souk make sure that you agree a price before getting in.Enjoy :)

bargain hard. interesting winding alleys and little shops. get off the main tracks and take a look at the little workshops. expect to get everyother shop keeper trying to entice you in - a firm no thank you is sufficient. also expect to haggle hard if you do want to buy stuff - never paid more than a quarter of opening price!

Must See. I went to this souk several times a day, for several days. It comes alive at night though.I am very experienced in haggling in many markets from around the world. This was my first time in Marrakech though.At the beginning it was very overwhelming and to be honest i was not enjoying it a lot. 95% of the guys at the souk are very very agressive and as soon as you ask for a price, they refuse to let you go. Then, they will get very angry. It was very annoying that you could just not ask for a price. It was energy consuming trying to deal with these guys.Then, I just relaxed and I really enjoyed the souk. If you are really not interested in buying something, better don't ask for it. I know it shouldnt be like that, but thats the way it goes.If they tell you a price, ask for at least 70% discount of the price they are giving you. Then start working for the price you really want. Sometimes its just hard to judge, so ask yourself how much would you be wiling to pay for it. If no agreement is made, walk away gracefully. Dont get caught up in their intimidations techniques! Better not to accept coffee or tea as that is one of their little tricks to catch you.The first day I got caught in a carpet shop trap. It was near our Riad and we decided to go in. Big mistake. We did want to buy carpets, but rule #1 is dont buy from the first place you visit. We wanted to visit a few places and then compare to make an educated decision. We stayed in this shop for about two hours as this guy would not let us leave!!!! He got sooo angry that it was our cue for not to buy from him. He was asking 22,000Dhs for 2 carpets. Then we saw the same carpets somewhere else for 4000Dhs.So anyways. Be smart, keep it light and enjoy!

Leaving to shop Marrakech style. Pluck up the courage..... Get lost and found again. Try your hand at battering and don't be intimidated by the sellers the motorbikes and the busyness some good fun to be had.
Kevin ritch. Great time at the souls was in marrakesh for 2 weeks and went to the souls 6 times great for bargains and local cafes to eat aldso bought loads of gifts here

Definitely an experience. The souk is a must-see in Marrakech. Bring plenty of small bills with you and hold onto your purse though! The vendors can be very pushy, but its all about bargaining. Don't be afraid to walk away if the price is too high, you'll see the same item at least 50 more times at other vendors. Also, the fresh orange juice is AMAZING.

Good market . Good bazaars where you will find all sorts of good items. However be aware some sell fake leather and imitation products. Some of the merchants are rude and don't haggle especially when they know your a tourist where they try and rip you off.

Very interesting but Fes is better. Really enjoyed the markets but definitely found Fes to be better. Though the night food markets are fantastic. 13 has a pair of Moroccan 'Hamish and Andy' and 42 has 'great bloody food'and 'no diarrhoea'. You have to experience it

Don't mention leather. Great fun if you like to barter but be careful not to mention leather, you will get guided to the deep dark filthy smelly and dregs of the souk, even the locals look scared in this area. We were taken to places and shown raw leather and dead animals. Not a pleasant experience especially for my wife and 14 yr old daughter. It smells that bad that they give you fresh mint to smell to disguise the smell of the animal and sewage permanently in the air. Got totally lost, but did manage to get back to the main tourist square. A little tip offer them a third of there first price. You will grab bargains there. Even with the horrors we had I had great fun, definitely worth a visit.

A little crazy, messy and dirty but this is exactly why you will love it!. A little crazy, messy and dirty but this is exactly why you will love it! Discover all the wonders of Marrakesh and the Morocco by visiting the Souks. What use to be a bargain is not really anymore. It use to be a place where you could get cheap stuff, and it's not really anymore, yet you can gt very authentic Moroccan items, leather, carpet and other Arabic wonders. I would still recommend to be careful if you are a woman travelling alone, not that it is scary and would recommend not to do it, but just be careful.
Worth a visit but with caution. Good but very samey. Every few stalls the good repeat them selves and a lot of men trying to get the ladies in!

If you are in marrakech you must visit at night, maybe a dinner. It worth the time to do. It is a mix of everything, the caos, food, noise, smell, all kind of pleople and animals. The souk around is crazy.

Lived up to it's fascinating reputation. We hired a guide to take us through the Souks and all of us agreed afterwards that this had been a great idea. The Souks are HUGE! I don't think we would have been brave enough to venture as far as we did without the guide so we'd have probably just stuck to the more touristy and poorer quality bit near the entrances. Our guide took us to dye workshops and ironmongers. It was fascinating to see everybody just about their daily work. Our guide also helped us a lot with batering. We spent over 4 hours there and we could have spent much more! Just be ware though that on Fridays a lot of the Souk is closed for the Holy day.

Magical!. If you are visiting Marrakech I would highly recommend visiting the Souks! You can grab fantastic bargains on all sorts of weird and wonderful things. For the best experience I would recommend delving deeper into the Souks! We thought we would be hassled and find it uncomfortable but in fact it was quite the opposite. You get hassled near the start of the Souks near to Jemaa el-Fnaa square but further in they are happy to let you wander through and take in everything.If you are wanting to buy anything don't be afraid to haggle and haggle hard! Go in at a price that is at least half price or even less and stick to it - they don't like you walking away so you are more than likely to get anything you like at the price you are prepared to pay! We grabbed some great bargains on leather goods and herbs and spices and would love to return in the future.
Colors,...colors,.... Has to be visited,...if only for the smell of spices, the colors, and the bargains too,...very busy, do keep children close.

Terrifying. I went with another female friend. It was the most terrifying experience I have had. We got a bit lost trying to find the main Souk and asked a taxi driver to help us.Upon arriving there we found a place to park, which was a nightmare, as it was the tiniest parking and cars were parked in every angle.Upon walking through the Souks, men would come up to you and ogle you. I felt completely harassed. When asking for directions the always wanted money and if you ignored them you would be shown the wrong direction.We were totally conned as we were invited to go into the Tannery, which smelt horrendous, and afterwards we were expected to pay them for this event. I was only there for a short period of time as it was far to overwhelming for me, and I did not feel safe. Apparently if you stay longer you get used to it, I did not want to find that out.On the plus side I found a beautiful bracelet for my friend and lovely vase for myself.

Absolutely crazy! Avoid Saturday evening . Travelled as a group of 3 young (ish) women, advised to go at night due to Hest and crowds etc. What an experience Saturday night was. Men men men everywhere we turned, eyes all over us, a few tried to touch us (nothing horrendous) i felt uncomfortable and scared to be honest I was jumpy and tense the whole time and felt like I was a circus attraction (I'm a tall blonde) few tried to follow us and guide us but we were firm and told them no and ignored them from then on. We braved it and returned the next night (due to not shopping enough sat eve) and what a difference it made. Sunday is family night and it was far more relaxed and a much better atmosphere we loved it. The souks are amazing and beautiful hand crafter products. The bartering is hilarious and just don't give in just say ok no thank you and walk away they will run after u and agree to your price guaranteed! I loved that bit. I'd advise you to more than half here 1st price.
Busy bargain hunting. Busy busy atmosphere be prepared to get hassled a lot, some fab bargains but also some sellers trying to make you pay more.

Accessible busy chaotic fun. A must do on a visit to Morocco. The twisting endless lanes of stalls selling all sorts of lovely items that are so tempting. Go with an open mind. Try not to buy on your first day so that you are in control of what you want . Don't bargain unless you intend to buy. The guys selling at the apothecaries offer interesting items and do really fun stuff as you approach to get you interested. Prices are better and there is less hassle in Essaouria if you are also travelling there. Btw my daughter was in a very basic travelling wheelchair and she was able to access all areas with moderate effort. When a bit fell off the chair a man kindly helped us repair it at no cost.
The best ever. The most colorful and atmospheric souk ever! Go in the afternoon when most sellers are a bit sleepy after lunch, they bother you less!
Marrakech souk, big square.. Very calm during the day but after sunset you can see the souks at full glory. Lots of great bargins, Just need to haggle with them.
A touristic attraction. Difficult to miss the place when you come for first time. Not too much things to buy in this noisy and crowded area.
