Pleasant to the eye.... I enjoyed my walks in the Souk of Marrakech. The shops are beautiful and the products are candy to the eye.....That was really unforgettable. On the other side, I was not happy with all of those people who were pulling people to come in to shops to buy. At some point of time, that became a bit too much.

Scary. The Souks are a bit like the square but narrow and scary. Everyone watches you but didn't feel comfortable in the outside section. Walked into the covered area filled with shops and stalls... Rabbit warren! We did enjoy it but didn't relax too much as we were worried about getting out. Wonderful to see it all.

Crazy Must-Do. A visit to Marrakech isn't complete without a trip to the souks. Crazy, fun and a bit out of most travelers comfort zone, there is a bit of everything. A great suggestion is to visit a price controlled shop (Theres one outside Hotel Medina Gardens All Inclusive) before you head into the labyrinth of stalls to get a basic idea of what to pay for items. You might think you got a great deal haggling down that wooden dinner tray from 1500 MAD down to 600, but find that the price controlled shops sell it for 300. Be willing to walk away and don't show too much interest. Give an honest and fair price, but don't ever "feel sorry" and overpay. Know what you want to pay and don't go above it. Treat it like buying a car. A word of caution: Outside the souks are many "snake charmers" and a long stare at their reptiles can often garner an unwanted approach with a snake in hand.

Crazy, noisy, amazing!!. You have to visit the Souk at different times of the day as it is very different whenever you go! In the morning there are a few things going on but mostly people are just setting up. As it gets busier is when it gets more fun - but it can get annoying as everyone wants your money so they hassle you at every stall! Ay first I was too nice and said "No thanks" very politely - I soon learned to just ignore and not make eye contact!! Much more effective! I was lucky to be with my partner and didn't get too much unwanted attention (as he's quite big) but a girl we met on the plane said she wished she had been with a man as her and her two friends received lots of unwanted attention. I was worried before I went about what to wear - I though I had to cover up a lot - but there were lots of tourists wearing stroppy tops and short shorts and nobody batted an eyelid! I wore vest tops and either skirts to my knee or three quarter length trousers and they were fine! I also invested in some walking sandals before I went! They weren't the most attractive/trendy/cool shoes I'd ever bought but they were fab for all the walking!! Haggling is a necessity - never give them their first price and if your'e not happy walk away - they will follow you if they know you offered a good price and if not - there are plenty of places with exactly the same things!! The evening was extremely busy and loud - but a fantastic experience!! Loved it!

I just Love, Love Love the souk. The atmosphere in the souk is buzzing, people are nice but very pushy to sell you something. You can find treasure there, original lamp, Lantern, rug,jewellery, all leather bag belt that are made close by. You can find very nice things to put into your home but there is different quality and if I was you I won t go for the cheap one because if you put couple more pound into buying an object you will see the different and will have so much compliment by all your friends once back home.Take a guide a before coming into the souk and you will feel safer and nobody will bother you, you can find one on the jemma el Fna it cost around 20€ for couple of hours.You have to discuss the price for anything do not forget this is a game, always start at 50% less than the price they are asking and then start discussing.overall this is a must see while visiting Marrakesh.Enjoy!

Cheap stuff and chauvinist vendors. Most of the stuff here the native moroccans would refuse to buy, since this souk is aimed just for the tourists -- you'll notice that as you walk around. They also think the food in the square is unclean and unregulated (apparently better than before) and prices are skewed up 3-10 times the actual price you could get for them at a legit store.

Excellent atmosphere. Excellent variety of items. Inflated prices so expect to barter! Great variety and a must see. Easily accessible by bus or taxi. Get petit taxi and insist on them using the counter (meter).

Interesting. Myself and friend went (2 females ), we weren't really hassled but my friend new a few words to say politely we weren't interested. Haggle for everything you want, it's fun and they like it as well. DO NOT go with anyone who offers to show you the way. It can be very scary. Plus they demand your money. To be safe stay close to the centre or best go with a guide first to find your way around. Going back in Nov but staying longer,Go to the real Herbs and oil place bought 2 bars of Amber £8 it's lovely. I think it's just off the centre.

Be on your guard!. Travelled to the Souk at night during Ramadan and found it to be extremely busy. Didn't feel very safe and constantly being badgered by children and traders can become quite intimidating. Mainly just trinkets for sale, pashmina and poor quality counterfeit goods. Be prepared to haggle and goods are cheaper the further into the souk you go. You will be fined for drinking alcohol in the street and women are expected to cover legs and shoulders, this is advisable. Good for trinket gifts.

a must see. There are a number of different Souks together in the Medina and therir range of goods is amazing ! You have to haggle over the price of everything , even the mint tea but the place is an absolute treat to visit . Be prepared to see a whole range of colours of goods on sale , smells to tickle your nasal passages and sights , well just about everything from teeth pullers , donkey carts , motor bikes and the thing that surprised me most was the level of stock these stall hold - thousands of rugs etc and no matter what time of day you go the stall owner is always there , often asleep on a chair in the entrance or more likely inviting you to come into his shop - its free !

Not the best Souk. MArrakech souk - too westernised compared to others eg Fes.Lacking enough whiff of authenticity.Very few 'local' stalls eg spices, meat, provisions etc.Allows mopeds and motorised carts.There are better eg Fes

'Leave me aloooone!'. After hearing a lot about this city, obviously we went visiting it. But as we just lived 7 days in the mountains, Marrakesh was terribly loud and annoying. On the market place there are monkeys, snakes and other animals that are bad treated. Also the souks were overwelming: the salesmen just don't let you look at things on your own.. Nothing for me, I will never go there again, but yet I'm happy I did visited it! The 'tombeaux Saâdiens and the old school 'Ben Youssef' where worth a visit!

Colourful!. A great way to shop! Very noisy, colourful and hectic, but an experience nonetheless! Practice your Arabic and French otherwise you'll be hassled to death. But in a nice way! Seriously though, it does help to speak one of these languages as not only can you pick up some bargains through haggling, but you can quickly make yourself clear to the more obstructive vendors! Well worth a few visits.

The real and authentic Souk. It's my second favorite souk in Morocco. It's easy to visit and you don't get lost easily. It has nice stores, it's colorful. There are some areas very modern, but In general, it's nice! Don't miss it.

Bustling market. The souk is the old market in Marrakech and although it would not seem so it is divided into food, carpet, lantern, clothes, and shoe markets. It is great to get lost in the narrow streets. Sights and sounds unlike any that you have probably encountered before. There are signs around to help you navigate the maze of streets but you will end up lost keep a map close by and you can use your phone to navigate your way out but keep it secure. You have locals trying to get you into their shops as that is their custom. Although annoying try and not let it get to you and remember to barter and haggle when buying something.

Amazing!!. The souk was amazing. It is a must see. Everyone is trying to get your attention to bring you into their shop, but they take care not to cross the line and pass the limits. You can get dinner, juices, souvenirs, see the snake charmers etc. I would highly recommend to everyone, especially in the evening. It's open until 1 am.Do cross the streets carefully. It can be a bit challenging at first. Enjoy!

A crazy experience. When visiting the souk you really get a feel for the 'real' Marrakech. The place is very vibrant, bustling and colourful with thousands of different things to buy and see. We spent a good couple of hours just wandering around and taking it all in. My only complaint would be about the treatment of animals here. I am totally understanding of the fact that it is another culture and differences are to be expected, however some parts I did find unnerving. I wanted to go on a horse and carriage ride around the town but when I reached the front of the queue, I saw the man mis-treating his horse and so I changed my mind about this. There was also a group of men holding a large monkey in chains. They placed this monkey into my shoulder without asking for my permission and when I told them to take it off as I felt uncomfortable, they angrily demanded my boyfriend gave them money and followed us until we paid something. I completely understand this is how they make their money and we did try to keep an open mind when visiting but this experience did intimidate me and would make me wary of returning. However I imagine this was a one off as most of the people there were very friendly, pushy but still friendly, and so I would still recommend the souks as an interesting place to visit (just be careful around the monkey men!)

Your senses will be blown - sights, sounds, smells simply fabulous - see my tips on bargaining. Souk is what they call the market area in Marrakesh. It is full of shops and market stalls selling everything from tourist items, to leather goods, to deli food. Go with an open mind, enjoy this cultural experience.Most people spoke English and if they didn't, they would go and get someone they knew nearby who did. People were friendly, welcoming - even if you didn't buy anything. Yes, they are pushy and bargain hard but consider this an experience. I would suggest you divide their price by 6 and start there, moving up to no more than dividing it by 4. If you go even half of their price, they know they have an inexperienced person on their hands and will take you for even more!Be prepared, they will come up with every hard luck story to get your sympathy to pay more - it's all an act, don't fall for it. Walk away if you're not happy with the final price, they ALWAYS come after you and try to bargain even more, then eventually give in at your price so be strong. Keep a smile on your face and remember it's not personal, this is their way of life. Spices - smell them all and try them all, ask how to use them in cooking and learn a new flavour, then bargain for them. Same with delicious olives and preserved goods (see pics).When walking through the undercover markets, keep a lookout up to the roof for signs that tell you the exits which lead to different areas of the Medina. Very handy to leave at the correct exits. Don't worry if you miss a few - all paths lead back to the market and signs will indicate further opportunities to exit where you thought you had missed one. Walk close to the stalls to avoid being in the way of cyclists, motorbikes and carts. Very important - learn to say "thank you" and "please" in Arabic - they will appreciate that you've made an effort to learn their culture and always thank them even if you don't buy anything, it's all about respect.

Fantastically crazy place. The sounds, sights, smells and people make this and amazing place. My wife and I had our 15 year old daughter with us and I have to say over our 11 day stay at no point did I feel worried about anything. Yes people haggle and want you to buy but that's the fun. Go and enjoy it as it is a very unique and wonderful place.

Interesting but frustrating. The Souks are a wonderful place to see......But,the touts and sellers keep annoying and dragging you into their stalls,trying to make you purchase anything...which is so annoying.Just wish they would all leave you alone to peruse their stalls in peace,maybe they would have more trade this way!!The motorbikes are always hooting their horns for walkers to get out of the way,and they should be banned from this area....also they pollute the area so much as they are all old and exhaust fumes are very offensive.Do not let this put you off visiting this wonderful,colourful,vibrant place...but beware!

Has to be seen to be believed . As many have said previously, they are a must see for your trip to morocco. We visited during the day - morning is recommended due to the heat on an afternoon. On a morning the square is a lot quieter, still plenty to see and buy and lots of haggling to be had. Be wary of locals telling you that the tanneries have their last day and you must see them. This is a lie and they simply want your money for guiding you. Politely decline.We went back on the Saturday night and it was like a different place. Full of life and so much going on. There is no need to be scared or feel unsafe. The locals are friendly and love to talk and banter. I would recommend a mint tea on the roof top terrace cafes and take in the night life.
Surprising. Very busy, though lively & jovial. But have to keep a watch full eye on your kids, due to crowds and extremely noisy. Good place to shop, but only if you can haggle

Touts and sellers in souk discourages you to walk in peace. The souks is not impressed me maybe I do not have any interesting for the sales or i am already familiar this scene from Turkey. Also, touts and sellers discourages you to walk on the streets in peace. But of course it is a very old market and it has labyrinth streets which makes worth to visit when you are in Marrakech.

Ban the Motorbikes. The souk is a vast rambling area accessed by a myriad of alleyways selling anything and everything you can imagine.From my perspective I was not at all interested in the 'rip off' clothing items which seem to dominate large areas of the souk.What I found far more interesting were the artisan areas, such as the copper and woodworking areas where you could actual witness the craftsmen at work.prices were very reasonable if you are prepared to enter into the game of haggling which by the end of our stay I had become could adept at.The one major complaint I had about Marrakech in general, but the souk area in particular due to the narrowness of the alleyways was the annoying presence of all manner of scooters and motorbikes which hurtled through the souk at alarming speeds without any regard to the pedestrian shoppers.I was amazed that I did not witness several accidents during our visits to the souk, but was told by the shopkeepers that indeed there are many accidents and injuries due to this issue.I do not know why or how this is allowed to occur as it certainly does not happen, or at least to any great extent in Fez, which provides a far more pleasant and relaxed experience.

Very colourful. If you enjoy the trill of finding smthing unique annd also teh excitiment of haggling ovr teh price, you will love the Souks. If not go along with your camera and take capture some holidays memories.Hint - be careful of people on bikes. They are everywhere and you are likely to have one crash into you if you are not looking where you are going

Great place !!!. This place is so amazing. It's typical for Arabic country. You can find everything. The most popular is argan oil, but be careful and don't buy fake. You can buy many kinds of souvenirs, clothes or spice. Watch your personal belongings and if you do not pay, so donť takes a photos of people and snake charmer etc.

Bargain city. What a brilliant and fun place. The bargains range from 30p tagines to £100 leather handbags. Must be visited both day and night as the atmosphere is so different. A must for true Moroccan shopping

Worlds Away From Normal!. The Marrakech Souk is right out of a movie, but you are the star! The shops and sellers are so interesting and when the suns starts to go down and the entertain begins, you know your "Not in Kansas anymore Toto"Of course this is a place for tourists and the hawkers will try to extract as much money as they can from you. Be strong, barter hard but in the spirit of a purchase and you'll have a great time.

Great experience. U can't go here and not go to the souks.. From smells of fresh herds to raw fish its so worth a visit. U will also get great bargains and more than lightly get lost, as every alley way looks the same and the locals will send u in the wrong direction! Most of them will try get u to go to certain places as they get commission if u buy from that souk or shop. If all else fails u can get a taxi back to main square we actually walked a good 20mins drive out of the square. In the main square then are the snake charmers, markets and henna tattoos. Loved it worth a visit you would spend a day walking around it.

Get Lost!. Sensory Overload! The sights, sounds, smells - it was amazing! Pro Tips:- Get lost, and if you like something, buy it, because you're probably not going to find the shop again. - I wouldn't walk in groups larger than 3 without expecting to lose someone.- "la shokran" = No thank you.- Be polite and respectful, and the price will likely drop without much effort.

Great atmosphere . As you wind and meander through the Souks you see a whole raft of factories and local producers, if your prone to getting lost make sure you go as apart of a tour as it is a rabbit warren of alley ways to which our guide said there was circa 60k stalls

What a wonderful plkace. Oh my god, what a magical place. It was like being in a time warp. Very easy to get lost but thats part of the fun. Many many shops to browse through. The buildings, the people, the atmosphere were all wonderful. DO NOT miss this area if in Marrakech

Sites, smells and taste!. We visited Jemma El Fna a couple of years ago a day after the bombing of a French restaurant. The locals were naturally shocked and dismayed, how ever the old saying "life goes on" was very much on the agenda. Wonderful people! We went at night and there was still an atmosphere of "carnival". People were friendly and neither my husband or I felt pressured. Of course there was still bartering and banter, but that is all part of the experience and we found that if we had humor and politeness, stall holders were gracious and fun.There is so much to see and taste and smell! Of course there is the tourist attraction thing, such as "dancing" snakes, acrobats etc.We never felt unsafe. You could wander around for hours and sample lots of different foods, especially "sweets". The Moroccans love their sweets! It was actually July 2013 that we visited.

Barter land make sure your skilled up in bargaining . I love a good haggle and this place is where I thrive. Few rules to remember No.1 whatever they quote you aim to pay half or just over half, a guy quoted us 1300dhs (approx £86 for a lamp and then dropped it to 500dhs £32.67) we still didn't buy it. No.2 expect to go up from your offer e.g. he says 1000 and you say 500, he says 900, you say 600 until you usually meet halfway 750. No.3 This works especially in the souks. If he/she doesn't budge don't be afraid to walk away as they will come after you if they want to sell if not you will defiantly find another shop selling the same item a few feet down.No.4 Have a sense of humour and don't get too strung up with a bad experience it's all part of the fun and if you buy and find another one cheaper it doesn't really matter as you've bought an item you really like. Happy haggling y'all as you will find almost everything in these alleyways
a must see. have to see when visiting, a very interesting insite of how marrakech people live and work and how lucky we are

Diamond in the rough. Amazing!! Went to the Souk twice during the day and once at night. The wide range of stalls was amazing and the range of things sold. Owners/staff in all the stalls are lovely and you are not pestered to go in. Two of the stalls I went into, as I spent a lot of money, gave me a free gift. At nighttime there is the food market as well - I found the souks a night time very crowded and a lot harder to get around. The food market everyone was at you to go to their stall. When went into the souk at night time felt like I couldn't find my way around - definitely prefer it during the day. Anyone who goes to marrakech has to experience the day and night market even if it's just for a quick look.

Good fun - lots of samey products though. If you're in Marrakech you have to come here - it is good fun (and shelter from the heat), though not the place to come if you don't like arguing, as you *have* to haggle - I bought a few souvenirs, all of which I got at least 1/3 off the asking price, and a couple of times over half.You do not get hassled as much as some people say - they all try and entice you in, but some do also come and lead you to places - which you can follow, but you can always simply walk away.

Interesting experience. My gf and I visited at around 8pm on a Sunday night. The place was teeming with people, so many games, food and drink stalls, arts, crafts and other things to grab your attention! It was fun to walk around and in general was a good experience. I will warn potential visitors - if you choose to walk down the extremely narrow pathway that separates all the food carts, be prepared for a confrontational experience that exceeds all those prior. They will do everything possible to engage you and have you stay for a meal, and very little you say will discourage that. The approach generally starts with friendly and welcoming (Hey, you Kiwi? Please sit, the other restaurants are no good!!"), then after a few "sorry just looking's", it shifts to trying to guilt you ("why won't you stay and talk to me man, what's your problem?!") and finally aggression ("GET LOST THEN!"). Worth a look but wear thick skin.

Barter then barter some more. What an experience, my tattoos and the fact I tan very well made every noticeable by the locals hahaIt was very close in the souk's and very personal. I loved it walking around and bartering with the shopkeepers. There's everything you could ever need and want in these places but beware of prices. Soon as the shopkeepers find out your English, they think for some reason that you are loaded and will try anything to get you pay through the nose. But 9/10 we got what we wanted at a very good price. Great experience and an eye opening look into the world of souk shopping.
Wow. What an experience. Be prepared to barter and only look interested of you actually are. Also go further into the souks to get a better price. But wow, what an experience.
A Must See. This is a must see, there are fabulous craftsmen here as well as cheap touristy souvenirs. The craftsmen make the experience worthwhile as well as the overall cultural experience.
Market . I felt the souk we had allocated when got of shuttle abit pushy felt.like ed. Only took us to family shops

Souks. The markets are laid with narrow walk ways that go on for miles.It is easy to loose your way but locals are helpfull and they will get you where you want to go. Be carefull of the prices they charge, you must bargin hard. Start at a quarter of the asking price and only pay upto half the asking price. Keep your cool,keep smiling and you will get a good price.Moroccans like to bargin so it is second nature to them you must keep going the more go bargin the friendlier they seem. Happy shopping

So Different, need to experience to believe it !!!. Everyone talks about the Souks and walking around all the little alleyways at all the different shops and the shopkeepers enticing you in to have a look, what a great experience just to walk around and look even if you don't buy anything, everyone needs to visit !!!
Haggling. Choices of goods to buy we're good, but did not like the fact that items had no price, so you had to haggle for everything

Out of This World Experience!. The best time to visit the Square for the very first time is first thing in the morning, around 10:00am when the souks are just opening up. This way you can familiarise yourself with the layout before the heat is too intense, the crowds swell and the light fades. This is advisable as The Square can be intimidating. It still remains the same as it did hundreds of years ago with snake charmers, pet monkeys and henna artists. One truly amazing,unique place and should be a must on everyone's bucket list.

Wow wow wow. What a mad place and mad people
But great sight you won't believe your eyes.
Keep your eye about is its so busy and they all try to get your attention.
You may be scars at first but be brave.
Well worth it

Nuts. Brilliant, very very hot weather and very busy. Keep right in the Souks as you may get run down by bikes or donkeys, be aware of your bags and you will be costatntly hounded to buy but it is all quite amazing

Fascinating!. We visited the souks as part of a guided tour and were not disappointed. The narrow passageways are all undercover which keeps them a little bit cooler but because they are so packed together and busy it is still rather claustrophobic at times. We visited the areas which sold leather, woodwork and metal and it really was like a maze! The people are very friendly and I have to say we weren't pestered too much but this may have been because we were with a tour guide. I was a little bit daunted by the experience and I'm not sure how I would feel going around them without someone who knows what they're doing or where they're going but you really shouldn't miss the opportunity to go there if you are in Marrakech as that is what it's all about after all! Make sure you walk on the right as much as possible as mopeds and motorbikes are ridden through the souks and not all of them travel slowly!
Haggle hard.... A great experience...but do haggle hard with the friendly sellers.We came away with a lot of baskets we didn't realise we needed!

Amazing. Loved it was only aloud to go once! (Other half hated it he felt scared and intimidated ) I'm a blonde young (21) female so I'd been given the usual stories from people, I didn't feel intimidated or harassed by anyone in the souks (I'm a food tech teacher in a prison, so not a lot can scare me so could be that I'm a strong willed person) We ventured well into the souks it was 10am so was g to busy people where setting up, we got abit off the beaten track from following the maze of ally ways we ended up in the "non tourist part" the locals kept saying no tourists and I had a head scarf put on my head from a woman who pointed us to a "safer" part but honestly I didn't feel unsafe was great seeing old men playing cars sat around outside their house donkeys delivering products I loved the history and the culture there was "butcher" shops with there meat on a shelf out the front of the window in the 40+ degree heat uncovered and swarmed in flies, it's great to see how the real people live and work. It's a great phot opportunity for any photography geeks Definitely worth a visit if going with I could gone during a Sunday night supposed to be magical

Just how you imagine. This place is booming with life. A vast amount of people from all over the world and all the shops that love to haggle. The entertainment is amazing with the Cobra snakes and make sure you try the mint tea. You will never find tea like this ever.

Have fun and bargain!. I dont like bargaining, it's not my strength. But I visited the complexe artesanal before heading to the souks and when I saw something I liked, I insisted that I would not buy unless I got my price, and I would walk away if I did not get a lower rate. It worked most of the time. Some were pushy but many more were kind and agreeable. The complexe artesanal is no stress, but the Souks have a huge variety and it is so much more fun to visit. Don't get afraid if you get lost, at the end the road will lead you to some place where you can catch a taxi or a caleche...:)

Amazing market. Brilliant, great craft stalls deep in, you could lose days in here. Especially as its much cooler than out in the sun.The real beauty is that you never feel threatened or unsafe no matter how lost you are despite the constant buzz of mopeds and scooters down the narrow lanes, the people are friendly and there are signs hanging directing you to the Jamaa el Fna square all over. The stall owners were nowhere near the pushy, blocking ways of Tunisia / Egypt with most inviting you to have a shufty or a gander and leaving it at that.The stalls close to the square do just tend to sell all kinds of fakes and cheap import goods, so you have to immerse yourself to find the true craftsmen but they are there.Haggle hard and you can get some good deals, the fixed price shops are expensive and generally just used by tour guides to claim their commission.

Marrakesh Souk. Shopping in Marrakesh- a great variety of items to purchase. Make sure to bargain and bargain. They love to bargain and want the challenge while making the transaction. Start out more than half lower than the price they ask. Also, be sure to go into the 'old souk'; you will see men at their craft-hand working wood, making shoes, instruments, woolens, and many more.

Exactly how I imagined it to be-mysterious and an overload of scents and magical sights.. I have always found Marrakesh intriguing and have been drawn to visiting for many years. Well I finally made it and it didn't disappoint-it is like a well kept secret that I fell in love with but am desperate for others to experience as well !The souk was a 10 minute walk from our hotel via Jemaa el Fna which is the central square at the entrance of the souk. Once you were through the main square you were presented with several alleyways which I am sure I never took the same one twice. Each one winds its way through the souk and I never really knew where it would lead me but this added to my experience. As a women you do draw attention-remember to dress respectfully with your shoulders and knees covered. I also wore my sunglasses as this enabled me to glance at a sellers goods without them knowing what I was looking at and not be pounced on ! A friendly but firm no always did the trick though and my pigeon French was always appreciated. I loved haggling-Moroccan slippers, leather bags and scarfs are a steal if you are prepared to bargain and remember they won't sell for a ridiculous price so don't be afraid to start low. Don't flash your money or wallet, keep map reading for a drink stop and be streetwise-also look out for mopeds as they speed through the alleyways !Don't be tempted to be taken anywhere from the souk by a guide or a friendly local-you will end up.at a friend's shop or the Tanneries and be expected to buy something.

Dissapointing. Ok, so it's a must see on any trip to Marrakesh but the abuse of snakes and monkeys is not my idea of entertainment. This coupled with the youngsters trying to offer you help with directions continually when really they are just trying to extort money from you adds to quite a stressful day. It's a real eye opener and some of the market stalls are amazing but once seen and ticked off the list, it's doubtful you will want to go back.

Eye opener. A little disappointed with the snakes and monkeys being used for tourists but other than that worth a walk round it was a real eye opener but try not to make eye contact and don't acknowledge the youngsters that say hello they are mostly plants for directions to uncles shop or expect money for showing you around, ignore them and follow your own route.
Lovely!!. Simply lovely souk where you can find everything for every taste. Bargain is an art de vivre in Morocco so do not hesitate to do it or you will pay too much.
Fun but crazy.. This is definitely a good experience. You have to be able to haggle and have your wits about you. There's plenty to see and buy here.

"Tappa obbligatoria". One thing is certain, the square and fantastic. The gardens outside are well kept and the trees offer a bit 'of shade during sunny days, Djemaa El-Fna is a compulsory stopover of Marrakech!

An amazing Maze of lanes. Visit to an older established souk is always an experience and this is no different in that it has a maze of lanes that sprout off in many directions and the deeper you delve the more you come to understand that this is an ever changing, vibrant and evolving site.Expect to get lost, but if you come to the end of a lane, just turn round and go back in, the place is to be discovered and the best way is to wander. You'll find yourself back at the main square before long. Look up there are often signs at junctions.I recommend walking deeper than the first 200 yards or so, that's for the tourists, go deeper and you'll find the souk has speciality areas and is still the main place for the locals for many items. Don't be frightened, it's safe inside, just a little confusing and can be hot, so take some water.Be aware that this is a working market and expect to meet donkeys, carts, motorcycles and the like. The motorcycles can be a pain, but the rest is pure souk delivery at its finest.Remember, be prepared to haggle, even half the initial price is still too high, be prepared to walk away, they'll chase you back if they want the sale and then you have the advantage.Overall, go in and wander about, expect to lose at least 2 hours easily, and just soak up the atmosphere....

Amazing experience but not for everyone.... Souks are the traditional market places or Morroco. They are sperated into various areas such as spice sellers, metal workers, tanners, or food markets, shoes, materials and herbs etc.The souks can be found off from the main square in Marrakech. Me and my friends made the mistake of going there around 5pm and this was stupidily hot. I reccommend going either later on as we were told they shut about 9.30pm or earlier in the day and not in the height of the heat. If you are a strong person that can say a definate 'no' and really dont mind being bothered or hastled or ogled at (mainly the women in this case) then you will get in and out of the souks fine if however you are of a nervous nature and cant handle people being quite pushy i suggest maybe this isnt the place for you. If you do go... go with a open mind and a friendly smile - i found if i said no and with a smile and wave of the arm the guys would stop trying to get me in their shops. On the other hand I have a tattoo on my leg which got many a comments together wolf whistles and remarks but im quite a strong girl so this i just brushed off with a pinch of salt and ignored. I know some people woud not like this at all but at the same time this place is renound for behaviour like this. When buying anything from the stalls do haggle with a smile and a friendly approach. We managed to get some good haggling done and save alot of pennies. I do think though the further you go into the souks the more haggling can be done as the first few shops at the start didnt seem to budge on price but the further we went in the more haggling we did. When it comes to buying the fresh orange juice from the stalls in the main square be very careful and specific on what you order. The orange juice is 4 dirhams but the other juice shoots up to 15dirhams and they will try and get you to buy that without making it clear on the price. The orange juice is really lovely and refreshing. Be assertive of your surroundings and people coming up to you, use common sence and be aware of your personal possestions and bags, wallets etc. We didnt come across any problems but im well aware some problems may occur. Be smart but really enjoy the experience, have fun and take in everything around you that you would not see anywherelse.
not for everyone. Ignored local jeers because I was not interested in buying goods for the sake of it. Just wanted to pass through on my way to and from the riad. Left me cold.

Very busy and unique. Great experience.. It is very unique and very busy with lots of hustle and bustle. There are locals which show tourists snakes and monkeys which is interesting. There is a lot of diversity of things which are for sale so you can buy a lot of things which can be hand made or not. A tip would be to haggle prices down as locals will put the prices quite high if you are a tourist. Other than that it is a fantastic place to visit.

I love markets and this is the Mother of them all !. Wow wow, never a dull moment this must be the most varied and interest spotting market ever. Souks surround it so you have been more and more to see. The main square has everything from goat's head soup and boiled snail stalls to snake charmers( I pity the poor snakes I believe they like in India have their fangs ripped out- hate it hate it all exploitation of animals for profit ) and acrobats. It is intensely exciting, there is an air of magic and circus atmosphere , its fantastic when the sun sets.The souks are so varied...from nail makers to leather workers to souvenirs to steaming mint tea shops, some souls are only a door's width and crammed with goods. Fantastic .

A must in Marrakech. The Souks really are a must if you visit Marrakech. Although they can be a little bit daunting at first they are a hive of activity and it can be great fun haggling with the traders to get the best price you can

Just be careful. My partner and I unfortunately don't rate the souks highly at all. We were pestered by 'guides' offering to show us round when we refused they told us to 'look after our bags then'. There isn't an awful lot to buy and we felt uncomfortable a lot of the time. I also got grabbed by an unwanted lady putting Henna up my arm. I told her I didn't want it and asked her to take it off, she refused until she had some money. We refused to pay her and she shouted at my partner tell him he was a 'bad man'.We couldn't wait to get out of the souks and spent only 2 hours there. Some friends we met had also been taken out of the souks by 'guides' and demanded money before they would take them back.If you are at an all inclusive resort and have a wristband on from the hotel, I recommend taking it off or covering it up, I believe you are seen differently if wearing them.An experience but just be careful.

Great souk !. I have been to a lot of souks and Marrakesh is definitely one of the best.Lots of cool shops and not too much hard selling. It would take ages to explore it all but in a few hours you get a real feel for the place Loved it !

Hustle bustle, real life. Hustle bustle, real life, snake charming, fresh OJ, sample the market delights day or night with a glass of mint tea. Float along and enjoy the sights and smells, try not to get persuaded into any shops, it is sometimes hard t leave without a purchase!

It's what Marrakech is all about. Talk to anyone about Marrakech and you can't have a conversation without referencing the souks where trading takes place every day. If you visit to buy then haggle and ensure you get what you want at the right price. Haggling is the name of the game
How to get lost in town,...... A very nice, but busy place. So much to see, all sorts of stuff being sold from leather to tea set,.....Very noisy, but very enjoyable.

The way a souk should be. Crowed, very busy, the shop holders are not too pushy, donkeys and motorbikes. Be aware for the young "guides" at each corner of the souk, don't trust them and tell them immediately and firmly that you don't need their help, don't let them guide you or follow you.

brillant. hassle hot and magical - fakes, artisan, tea - great feeling . stall holders could cool it a bit with the shouting but once you adapt its not a prob, a lot of fake football shirts and bags - better ones in the souk than on the square - bring water as its hot

Unique Place. I don't think there is anywhere in the world like the souks of Marrakech. Other places try but this place is special and you known you are in Marrakech. The hustle and bustle of market life but with the heat and atmosphere this place is unique.

Haggle hard!. Amazing place to do a spot of shopping and really is the heart of Marrakech. Make sure you haggle well if looking to buy something as you will usually be able to half the price that many merchants initially look for.

Magical place to spend, spend, spend!. You can spend a couple of days solid, just perusing the stalls. So much to see and buy. Leather goods all over the place but if you can make it to Essouirra (not sure if thats to correct spelling) much better prices and quality of leather...but its about 3hrs by car!

What an experience!. A place full of winding alleys with mopeds sppeding past and donkeys laden with all sorts of things trundling along. This place is fast paced and fun! The people are very friendly and love to have a joke with you. They can be very pushy as all merchants are, they are just trying to earn a living but be polite and firm and you can end up coming away with the most wonderful handicrafts such a leather goods, metal lamps, slippers, rugs, dresses, anything you can think of is there. A great experience that cannot me missed in Marrakech!

Shop until you drop!. We shopped on a number of days within the souk and it was an interesting experience! There are many stores with thousands of items available. You will need to haggle the price and don't accept the first offer made.Make sure you allow plenty of time to explore the souk and be aware it is very easy to get lost in the maze of alleys that make up the marketplace!

Fab fun. Wander and prepare to get lost .. if you want to make serious purchases I'd recommend getting a local guide. Go to the Artisan centre beforehand to get an idea of reasonable prices when haggling then go for it!

A Great Experience with right mindset!. The souk of Marrakech can be a cool, calm retreat from the rest of the Medina whilst being a fascinating and diverse market if you handle yourself well. Go in willing to barter (the starting price is always 5 to 10 times what the merchant will accept) and don't express an interest in something unless you fully intend to buy it. If not, you will be pursued from the shop with new offers shouted to you for quite some time. Though this does work as a technique to drive the price down, its not a relaxing experience!

An assault on the senses!. Take a deep breath- prepare to be harassed and enter the souks! Your senses won't know what's hit them and the hard selling shop keepers will be relentless- but that's what you expect- you would be disappointed by anything else! Remember everything has a price- even directions- and if you stand still for a second someone will try and sell you something- go when it is cooler in the evening- go for a couple of walk through a before committing to buying anything- and it is very easy to get lost- strategy is important-but the good available are gorgeous!

Enjoy Marrakech Souk but do it in the company of a local professional guide. Better is to visit the Marrakech Souk with a local professional guide provided by the tour operators or the hotels. With the guide you will walk through the small streets of the big old Souk, if not guided, you will loose the way and getting out of the Souk will cost you money. Enjoy the place, but do it with professional company, it will avaid problems in finding your way and you will not at all be harassed by anyone trying to sell you goods. Be advised, do not follow individuals in the Souk, they will bring you deep in the centre and leave you, getting out will cost you money. Stay together and don't get lured. Stay friendly and correct. It is a different world, it is the gate to Afrika. Enjoy the place, you will feel like walking centuries ago, it feels like walking through history.
Great experience. Was disappointed with The Market Square - but trip into the souks more than made up for it. Loved the haggling. Great salesmen and women.

An experience . Definitely do this whilst you're in Marrakech! It was an experience to say the least, but we wouldn't do it again. We went firstly on our own and then shortly bailed due to our lack of direction and the heat. We then booked a tour of the souks and medina through Thomson which involved a guided walking tour round the souks. This allowed us to see parts of the souks we wouldn't have seen if we were on our own which was great! We also went into a Berber pharmacy and a traditional bakery. The only thing we didn't like was at the end we were taken to a shop for 25 minutes and some of the staff were intimidating and rude which kind of ruined our trip. We also enjoyed the roof top cafe looking over the J'mma El fna square. Beware of the henna ladies there as they will take your hand and within 20 seconds you will have a henna tattoo which will cost you a bomb, also don't take photos of the snake charmers unless you want to pay, and we also didn't like the monkeys which were on leads. Have fun dodging the mopeds, donkeys and bikes and enjoy the haggle.

Souks of marrakech. Loved walking around the shops, didn't enjoy haggling EVERY purchase and did feel quite intimidated by the Morrocan people. As long as you take precautions with keeping hold of your money and know what your getting yourself into, as well as being able to say 'no' alot! Its an enjoyable experience

Thomson day trip to Marrakech Souk. Be prepared to do a lot of walking, at the end of the day our guide told us we had walked approximately seven and a half miles! We actually had two guides, one at the front leading the way and another at the rear keeping an eye on the stragglers; I was guilty of this as passing many of the shops? You had to stop and constantly be surprised. The guides were very knowledgeable and keen for you to ask questions, we stopped at mid day to have a typical Moroccan meal in a restaurant, tables of 8 – 10. The tour took us to a bakery, my thoughts aarh cake! Not quite, a hole in the ground with the baker standing in it, the guide once again explained the why and how, interesting and that’s all I’ll say, finally the tour ended in a pharmacy, this is the part where like all tours you end up in the gift shop! The pharmacist did a presentation about all their herbs and spices and what they could to enrich our lives, he was very funny and we parted with our cash. Before catching our coach back to the hotel we were given twenty minutes to do some souvenir shopping.I think the only down side of the tour was the fact we didn’t stop when passing by all the shops, it would have been nice to have purchased some of the merchandise that you could see being made. It must have been torture for the shop owners seeing all these customers walking by.

Awesome place. The one and only place in the world. It's amazing also for those who doesn't like shopping. All handmade, unique products. But the best thing is go there in the evening. thousands of people, gathering in smaller groups for some different events, starting from reading books (not may Moroccan people can read) finishing on animals hows, snakes, dances, musicians. You just have to see it on Your own.

A part of Marrakech that you shouldn't miss!. The souks are a great attraction and definite must do when visiting Marrakech! Full of all sorts of bits and bobs ready for you to part with a few Dirham for. Clothes, trinkets, herbal medicines, foods of all kinds and the entertainment of snake charmers and monkey's will ensure you put this place on your to do list.Travellers note: Spend that few extra Dirham on a local guide to take you around, he'll definitely be worth it and can advise you on realistic prices to haggle with.

Main place in central Marrakech. If you go to Marrakech you will definitively go to this place. If you go to Morocco you already know all pros and cons of this society. So children cannot walk alone or far from parents and you should get familiar with disturbing people talking to you to offer things. All these things happen here as well but are not cons of this specific place but a society problem.There are many shops in this souk but the things they sell are more or less the same. Once you have seen 10 shops the rest of them are just copy/paste

We got lost !. So much to see and buy ,lovely to watch people taking their families to buy new clothes for the end of Ramadan ,good fun bartering with sellers always start low then come to a joint happy agreement if not happy then walk away as there will be another stall selling similar if you've got the energy ! We had a good look around - then we got lost ! Managed to get a taxi back to hotel fairly easy though .

Culture shock. In all of my travels I don't think I have ever experienced such conflicting feelings for a place. The souk and Djemaa el Fna are an incredible, magical assault to the senses. The smells vary from the deliciousness of the street food, to the rankness of the tanneries. There is so much to see that you will get a headache from whipping your eyes around so much. The positives are that you will feel like an extra in Aladdin, the old buildings, tiny stalls, pyramids of spices are truly magical. The food is cheap, abundant and delicious. The shopping is fun, cheap, and exotic. Now for the negatives. The animal welfare is horrible. Monkeys bleeding at the neck under their collars as they're thrust on tourists' shoulders and heads. Half dead snakes being held for photos. Souvenirs of endangered animals body parts. Donkeys also bleeding under harnesses. The poverty. Old men and women begging in the streets, very small children swearing at you when you don't buy the tissues they're selling. And the nonstop scams being perpetrated by almost everyone you meet. A magical, heart wrenching place. Do go, and make up your own mind.

Marrakeech Souk. This is one scary place to bring children. I so would not bring any child here. You are warned about pick pockets my children were terrified. You are approched and annoyed by the locals to go on horse drwn carraige they will follow you till they realise they are getting nowhere. THey follow you with Snakes and Monkeys you try get money out of you. You are almost knocked down by people on scooters. I would never go again you can not shop in peace. My husband went back on his own with a list for any gifts we wanted to bring back.

Noisy & Busy. This is much like any other souk lads of shops selling Leather goods, Spices, pastries, Lamps metalwork, clothes etc, Its worth a wonder around there did not seem to be a lot of hassle when we went there a polite no and walk on seemed to suffice. Watch out for pickpockets as we had a phone stolen at the top end of the souk these seemed to be a more of locals aera with very few tourists around and we did stand out a bit just one of those things , it did not spoil our trip to Marrakesh. We brought some leather bags, scarfs, Shoes in the souk and after a bit of haggling got decent prices.

Jemaa el Fna a must for everyone. went for Xmas and the new year, perfect temp, amazing atmosphere, yes you get hassled but they do take a polite no as a no. Market is real eye candy and not to be missed
Magical place. Each city in Morocco has it's own unique feel-Marrakesh is red hot and African-- there's an other worldly feeling- somewhat disturbing and magical at the same time-

Fantastic!!!. This was my favourite part of my week in Marrakech! The atmosphere, the jokes and laughter along with plenty of haggling make the souks an amazing place. Don't be scared to wonder around and stroll further into them. It's inevitable you'll get lost but the people are so helpful, they'll tell you how to get back to the main square. I bought so much stuff in the souks I filled an entire suitcase and all of it was at bargain prices. Never settle for any price they give you. If you're not happy with a price, thank them and walk away... I guarantee they'll call you back. I spent hours just wandering around and having jokes with the stall owners. Just a fantastic experience!

The world's fastest direct marketing lessons. Fascinating old Arab town, living from trade and tourists. Amazing bouquet of fragrances, stalls selling leather goods, brass lamps, jewelry, herbs, natural cosmetics, fruits, carpets, rugs, textiles, clothing, headgear. If you have the strength and patience, you can hit the zebra skin and live snakes, hawks in cages and Moroccan Viagra. But most of all see how people are trading. Good advice: do not buy anything at the first day :-)If you do not know the prices of items, everythings can happen. Shrewd traders push you herbs worth $ 10 for a 50 and a lamp for a $ 20 will buy 80 iron rule: first get to know the prices.
Mind blowing. wonderful, busy, crazy, assault on senses, fun, interesting shopping and the people are incredibly friendly. You need to barter, so don't be shy

Hectic Marrakech. Really enjoy going to Marrakech but 3 days is usually enough before I need to escape the hustle & bustle! Be prepared to get hassled by the sellers and be prepared to give some money if you take any photos. One water seller in the main square demanded around £5 for taking his photo, when I refused and only gave him £2 he swore at me and spat on me too! Love the way the square comes alive at night too, usually you'll get some street kids asking for food as you're eating at the stalls. Be prepared to see woman begging on the streets, usually late in the evening and with sleeping kids in their arms. Try the freshly squeezed orange juice sold in the square too, it's yum!

Good and bad. First, I went to Marrakesh during Ramadan so my experience was not typical in some ways. That being said, the souk is not for everyone at any time of year. You have to have a good mind set to enjoy it...which, over-all I did.Best parts: Super interesting seeing a culture so different from mine, booths arranged in an esthetically pleasing manner, vibrant, lots of photo ops......doors in souk especially, good food, when by the spice and perfume booths the smells are awesome, goods can be purchased very inexpensively. If you've ever been to Mexico or Bahamas, or the like, this will be familiar territory.Worst parts: Lots of scooters, bikes and people, very aggressive sellers, lots of beggars and people who "help" you - but really drag you to a booth to buy crap, there's a lot of trash and feral cats everywhere, and it's VERY CLAUSTROPHOBIC. Ramadan difference....the souk clears out right near sunset and a calm descends over what was a cacophony just moments before. All of a sudden, your head clears, you can actually enjoy each artisans' wares without the constant pressure of having him show you 497 variations of the same item with a constant narrative of the benefits and quality of his product over the other identical products. The booth owners become less frenzied, and there are far fewer scooters to avoid. But as soon as everyone finishes with prayer and meal, watch out! The chaos is ten fold compared to what it was earlier! The square fills to the brim with revelers.  If you can find a place to sit and have tea on a roof top cafe, do so. It will make your experience of the souk better....the bird's eye view is pretty amazing.

Busy, dusty souks - touristy but still worth a visit. Be respectful.. Very busy and touristy but a fun experience. Much of the stuff is tat but there are some interesting antiques shops in the quieter parts and good quality / value leather bags. Don't miss a rooftop tagine lunch - look up and when you see a shaded terrace full of people, dive into the narrow doorway and go up to the top. Haggle, tip and be respectful.

Weave your way through culture and tradition.. An exciting sensual awakening! Let your eyes feast on the vibrant colours, the exotic sounds fill your ears and the spices sting your nose. Even better if you visit after dark - The place comes alive!

Beautiful City. I loved Marrakech! However, I was not fond of the large tourist market at all! I have many friends that recommended it and had a great time there, but we encountered a very handsy shop owner that made me VERY uncomfortable. We were traveling without male companions, so I don't know if that contributed, but I will never go back to the market. I will go back to Marrakech.

A Moroccan gem !!! . You really do have to read other reviews & take them with a pinch of salt. I traveled with my partner & we absolutely loved it. Our riad was about a 3 minute walk from the souks & we visited them nearly every day. At first, it is extremely overwhelming, the mopeds speeding down tiny little alley ways, how dirty it is, cats EVERYWHERE & sellers coming at you left right & centre wanting you to come in their shop. We got used to this very quickly & soon just took it on the chin. 99% of the time, the people in the souks are very kind. The first couple of days I think we were being typically British & ignored the sellers but when we started smiling & saying no they were perfectly happy & we even had a bit of a laugh with them sometimes too.Moroccans are the best salesmen in the world so bartering here is a must. On average if you barter a third of the price you'd get a good deal But if they don't accept your offer, just simply say no thank you, walk away & they'll soon agree. Getting completely lost in the souks is totally normal & really fun. You get a taste for real morrocan life & gain insight into the daily life of living in the medina. Just don't let people give you directions as they will most likely want money. We traveled over Ramadan so it was pretty quiet during the day & rammed at night time up until 1am As a tourist you don't have to cover up but out of respect for the Muslim women I always had a scarf on hand to cover my shoulders. This definitely helped with getting less attention. I would definitely recommend this to all tourists.

Best view after 7pm. Souks good place to go to when your in Marrakech. Best time to go after 7pm when they got all the lights on but it can get very busy. If you got phone,money ect in your pocket put it in a separate bag because there is a lot of pick pockets. Watch out for the mehndi (henna) ladies because while you walking they will grab your hand and start doing it on your hand. Just keep saying no and sometimes you got to shout at them. Can be easy to get lost so be careful where you walking. There a lot of people selling orange juice which is really nice but before buying ask how much it is because they over charge. It extra money for the red oranges. Ask the price before buying because they charge you stupid prices.

Market visit. It is very different as men bother you all the time wanting you to buy and also will send you in wrong direction so be careful . Did not want to stop and buy because of all the unwanted attention

Beware of the motor cycles!. Having spent some time in the Fes medina, I have to say the Marrakech medina and the souks compare unfavourably with their Fes counterparts. The main thing is the presence of motor cycles and scooters zooming up and down the narrow laneways (so you have to leap out of the way to avoid being hit) and the dirt (not sure if it is related to the motor bikes). For this reason- and due to the aggression of some of the stall-holders (not seen in Fes) I have to say I did not enjoy this medina- or the souks.
A great experience!. I love the souks wherever I go but I am useless at bartering. This souk is massive and it's so easy to get lost. Great experience though!

The Souk has been. The souk has become one big shopping center where every shop is selling the same; old traditions have disappeared. Example: The souk of the wool colouring has completely disappeared and has been replaced by industrial painted fabrics. Bah. It used to be so colourful.

Interesting. Glad the souk hasn't, changed much over the years have visited 5 and 10 years ago.most of the sellers are quite pleasant and are fun to barter with which adds to the excitement of shopping there, must say we had some good bargains.word of advise watch your bag and don't wear any bling !! If they tell you a price think !! only offer half that price if not accepted just walk away .9 times out of 10 they will run after you ,wanting to sell.,

Beautiful, exotic, intimidating and oh so much fun!. In my travels around the world, I have never been in a place that has tickled my senses in so many ways. A walk through the Souks to realize what you are seeing, smelling and the significance of it all is quite mind blowing for westerners. We walked through the first time with a guide and that was good as he had explained to us the signficance of a lot of things. He also kept us from getting lost in the maze. I think the Marrakech Souks are an experience in itself. If you are headed to Marrakech, try to stay in one of the Riads in the Medina, the experience is truly unique!

Have your wits about you. Glad I went as it was a bucket list location for me , but I'm not sure it's a location for a relaxing time . The wife found it intimidating and someone tried to pickpocket her ( their mistake as she know Ju-jitsu ) . You can't go Marrakech without going here, but just remember you are in North Africa , keep your personal belongings close to you. We meet a pair of young ladies who were swindle into spending all their money...none-thing is for free.

A Must.. It's heartbeat of Marrakesh. Bargaining with stall holders in normal here and I never got the sense of anyone trying to rip me off...just that they want to get the best for them as I did for me. It seemed more honest than some European shops. You will get lost in the maze of stalls...really..you WILL. And 'This Way Out' signs means nothing. But you can always get a cheap taxi to get you out! I loved every minute!

STAND YOUR GROUND!. This is a great place to try out your negotiation skills. However, be warned that the market square before entering the Souks can be off putting. There are chained monkeys who get slung on your arm if you are not careful and their handlers tell you to take a photo, they then demand money and can get aggressive if you don't pay them enough! There are also tortoises and other creatures in less than adequate cages which is upsetting to see, but you have to get passed that and head to the Souks. Here, my advice is to at least halve the price as to what they're asking for, then re-negotiate. Stand your ground on a fair price and if they won't budge, walk away - they will call you back I promise and you therefore win! However be very careful to check over properly what you are buying before hand, my lovely heavy duty necklace had no clasp and I didn't realise until I was home.The Souk itself is like a rabbit warren and you can easily lose your way, but it makes for an interesting time.

A unique experience!. The souks here are an intoxicating experience of sights, sounds, and smells. While they may be overwhelming, spend time getting lost on the little streets and appreciate the handiwork of the craftsmen. We strolled casually and politely declined the salesman approaching. If you are into bargaining, this if your place!

Typical, nice to buy souvenirs. Typical tourist place, to see at least once, but unless you want to buy souvenirs or you like to be in crowded areas, I would go there only once during a trip to Marrakech.

The sights, sounds and smells of Northern Africa!. What a great experience. The noise, the smells and the sights are outstanding. The people are friendly, the goods beautiful. The haggling obligatory and great fun. If you want something haggle that price down and when you finish say no and move onto the next stall, you'll soon get the price you want.
Marvellous experience.

A must see.... The souks are everything I expected. They are overwhelming with scents, sounds, sights, yet distinctive and beautiful. Leave some time to get lost amongst the streets. Certain areas focus on certain types of artisans. It is incredible to see the products for sale made before your very eyes. One of our favorite stops was the wood workers, who were carving chess pieces in front of us using the Berber "black and decker." We were approached and called to shop regularly, however we politely declined and moved on. Our hotel gave us the recommendation to wait to purchase any items until the end of our stay. A smart suggestion because we wanted so many different items. One thing to note- many people were adamant about no pictures until you purchased something. Also, if you like something, ask for a business card and try to make your way back after the visit. Sensory overload in a way only Marrakech could offer.

History. It's one the loveliest places ever I saw.But do bargain and get discount more than 40%. The leather bags are too expensive but shoes prices were good enough.They won't let uou to take pics I you don't walk there with a native.Only some of them doesn't have problem with photos...Antique shops are expensive also but if buy something small prices gonna be reasonable!

Once in a lifetime. The Souks were not as intense as I was told they would be. Although, my visit was during off season, which may explain why. The variety of goods available is incredible and I'm always proud to show off what I got there. You have to be persistent if you want to bargain, and if you want the merchants to leave you alone. For two women traveling alone it was a bit uncomfortable at times. Given that they know mostly tourists are coming through these days, it is definitely inflated in price. Don't expect to buy a bunch of stuff for a low price, even with bargaining, it's a bit pricier than one is led to believe. Also, don't follow anyone who offers to let you see the leather making places. Overall, its beautiful and inspiring, but overwhelming especially for foreign women traveling alone.

Organised chaos. This place is crazy thousands of people everywhere, which out for the people asking to be your guide you don't need one. Keep valuables ticked away and keep hold of wallets and handbags. Plenty of beggars including little kids coming up and trying to hug you. But this aside its a place to go just so you can experience it, snake charmers and monkeys everywhere, if you want to buy anything you must barter a lot, we had nice Moroccan mint tea in one of the restaurants as you walk into the souk. Worth a visit.
Sorry Souk. Poor animal welfare which was upsetting to us.Had to be careful not to take directions from Souk locals as to do so sends you round in circles.

Lively souk.. I really hate places like this, but used it as a though route to my flat. It was full of life, though, and seeing butchers shops with sheeps testicles is something different. You have to be quite ready to reject all the tradesmen trying to sell you something all the time. I felt a lot safer there than i thought I would. No one trying to grab my bag neither.
Dirty hot and scary. Felt uncomfortable had to have ones wits about you wouldn't visit again on future visitsDirty hot and scary at times but if visiting MARRAKECH you have to experience this place

Awful experience. went here for the day to this smelly awful place. The sooks are dreadful with a constant flow of motorbikes riding through and the smell of petrol fumes is overcoming in this closed in area containing over 3000 "shops". All the traders try to drag you in and will not accept the word "no". We sat in a coffee bar for over two hours as we couldn't face going back out into the main square to be accosted again. It's nit worth the hassle believe me. If you don't buy they swear and spit at you. Couldn't wait to get back on the coach .

Must Visit. Great atmosphere in a vibrant & colourful area. This market offers so much from food, spices, numerous crafts, clothes and of course the genuine fakes! Be prepared to haggle over the price with the genuinely friendly stall owners & you will probably get lost in the maze of the souk. A place to visit at least once in your life

A day visit to Marrakesh souk. A very happening place full of activity. The nick backs are lovely, cheap and typically Moroccan.
Evenings are full of lights and sound with street performers and hawkers selling their wares from food and drinks to pottery to everything ethnic.

Like Trip Back in Time!. We got the free shuttle bus from our hotel which dropped us near to the souk. Beware as you get off the bus you will be approached by groups of men wanting to be your "official" guide. They are not official but just random guys wanting money to show you around. When you get to the souk as soon as the traders spot you they are calling you to look in their shops. I would advise only stop at the shops where you genuinely want to buy something. If you slow down just to take a look at something they will pounce! Most are friendly and when you say no, mean it. Walk away and don't look back, then they will leave you alone. We only had one guy who was quite intimidating. It is a fascinating place, like going back in time. It can be confusing as to which direction you are walking but just go with it and you will come out into the open air eventually ! They have some beautiful goods but to be honest I would have bought more if I could have just looked without being hassled. We were told to offer a 1/3 of the price the traders ask as a guide to what the goods are worth. But as you are buying its up to you. We went during the day and at night. I would recommend going inside the souk during the day. At night we only went to the square not inside the souk as it was quite scary. The whole square was alive and buzzing with people, babies through to grandparents, snake charmers, traders, motorbikes! It was so noisy and as it was Ramadan it was extra lively. Also there are people on motorbikes and donkeys riding through the souk so watch your back! Definitely a place to visit while in Marrakesh!!

One of a kind. Really enjoyed my visit to the souks. There were interesting handicrafts, reasonably priced, of course one has to haggle. It was April and the weather could not be better for walking long hours

Marrakech Souk offers great deals but be careful of motorbikes!. Our first day in the Souk was a little confusing. But we soon learned how to navigate through the narrow alleys and through the maze to get where we were going. The Vendors are friendly, helpful but slightly aggressive in their efforts to lure visitors to their shops. After all they need to sell their wares, and they offer many fine products. All of these things would add up to a first rate experience for any shopper if not for the near constant flow of motorized scooters and motorcycles through the souk during the day. One quickly learns to keep as far to the right as possible, and more than one shop keeper kept us from being hit; but these motorized vehicles would fly though the alleys and narrow streets, weaving in and out of pedestrians with practiced skill. I only had one occasion where I actually thought I was going to be hit but he dodged at the last minute.To be fair, let me say that all of these bikes had good mufflers because noise was the least of the problem with them.Were it not for the issue of these non commercial motorized bikes, I would have given this attraction a much higher score. Otherwise the Souk seemed very safe during the day and at night. I actually felt safer here than in many American cities I have visited and lived in. The Souk is definitely worth visiting. Don't forget to negotiate on the price!
value souk.. wonderful again plenty of different crafts, foods, souk and old traditions and copycat designers clothes too. it was 2007.
Fantastic atmosphere. Fantastic place to visit. Wherever you go there is something to see. The atmosphere is amazing. All stall owners are so friendly and they don't push you to buy anything.
Love it!. Patience is necessary for the Bartering but you have to understand that's how it. We bought some lovely things And had fun at the same time.

Certainly an experiance. Going to the souks is a must and an experience like no other with 1600 shops and over 400 alleys. There are a couple of warnings tho - with that many alleys and shops you will get lost, so relax accept that and try to follow your nose back out when your done, but make sure you have plenty of water. Locals will help you find you way and if they just point you in the right direction say thank you and follow their directions but be aware if they take you somewhere it might not quite be where you planned and they will want a tip

Great and hard to find anywhere else. Great "attraction". You can spent hours just walking the Souks, browsing through the shops and relaxing on the rooftop terraces of the riads and cafes.People are friendly, respectful and smiling. This made shoping a lot easier and pleasant than expected. Dressing appropiately would be recommended as a sign of respect, though. To us it seemed like some locals did indeed disapprove of people in hotpants and tank-tops, which is not surprising in a country like Morocco. However, normal skirts, dresses or shirts seemed to be absolutely fine.

Great to wander around. Have a map with you that shows you the different areas for leather, copper, hats, food etc if you are looking for something specific. We were a group of 6 women and were not hassled as much as expected and in comparison to visiting other places where I have felt very uncomfortable. The stall holders were quite laid back and not persistent even when we showed interest. It is a colourful experience just wandering around - we made the odd wrong turn but it was easy to get back on track and find where we wanted to go and also just sit in a cafe and watch the hustle and bustle around us.

Not Safe at all...Don't recommend Marakesh, Morocco at all!. We stayed at the area:EL MOUKEF, MEDINA, MARRAKECH, MOROCCONot a good area.We walked to the souk, the streets were hard to navigate due to poor signage.We knew which way we were going but there are many young men who can speak English and offer in a very friendly way to help you get to the souk. But they point you to the wrong direction according to the map, we were warned by the riad manager.But when you ignore them and say no thanks, they start to swear at you in English continously.One man grabbed the map from my husband's hand and told me that he will "f#*#@ me!" And started chasing me.We went the square of the souk where one local was beating up a tourist. On the way home, a young lady was running from a man and jumped into our taxi before she was assaulted.Some merchants in the market are rude and aggressive.Things to know:1. The young men will purposely mislead you so when you panicked, another gang member will offer to help you only if you pay them.2. You need to bargain and start at 1/3 of the price. Maximum 50%. Don't worry as all the shops sell the same thing. You can always say someone in this market will give me the price I want as you all sell the same thing.3. Women- don't ever walk alone4. Food- eat cooked vegetables or peeled fruits. Don't drink water unless you open the bottle. Watch for certain brands as they used recyled water. Soltane is a good brand.5. Walk with your back in front of you, use money belt.6. Better with a guide as they leave you alone. Get a certified guide, Youssef Karroubi is good.7. Some parts of the market is better as the people don't harass you.8. Watch for motor cyclists speeding in the pedestrian ally way.My opinion:I am a seasoned traveller having travelled to poor areas to the Philippines, China. And have been to Italy, Turkey, Hong Kong, France, Germany, Cuba, Mexico and many other places. I can deal with pick picketers as they are non- violent. You just need to be cautious.There are other places to go aside from Morocco. It is the most backward country. I know the country wants to promote tourism to get money but you cannot change the mentally of the people especially in the poor area. Women are still considered 2nd class citizens. There are many nice people but the bad ones just ruin the whole country for them.Because of this - I appreciate my home, Canada even more.The riad was beautiful and the staff did everything to make our stay nice and were apologetic of their people. But it was not their fault.

Shopping. Souks are a thing you need to see at least one of in Morocco. This one, in comparison to many others is more structured and the vendors less pushy. Once you get them talking, they will not let up, but in comparison to Fes this is a much more laid back souk. Some real artisans are here (e.g. the lock maker, the lamp maker) as well as many vendors who just want to sell you cheap tourist items. The prices are pretty good for what they sell if you bargan (start at 70% of what they say and go up to 50-60%). Overall, you should at least see it, even if its a 30 minute walk through it.

Good for cheap goods. Bargain. Unless shopping is your passion, there is no need to spend more than 1-2 hours here. Most stalls sell the same thing. Good to buy cheap trinkets. Don't expect to get anything of good quality. Bargain. Bargain. Bargain.One word of caution, tour guides are relatively cheap - get one. If you get lost anywhere in Morocco, the "friendly" people will volunteer to help you out. There are a lot of people in Morocco who are unemployed or under employed. If they see that you are lost, a bunch of them will follow you to help you / point you to the right direction. It can be scary if this is at night because each of those expect monetary compensation. The tourist police is not much helpful.

A maze of stalls/shops with very intense stallholders. Experience unlike any other!. We visited here twice. The first time with a guide and the second time without. I would definitely recommend not using a guide. They tend to direct you to the higher priced stalls/shops deep within the souks whom we suspected they had prior arrangements with. The souks are easy to find anyway and we found the second visit far less stressful and were able to enjoy the atmosphere and visual displays more. Beware though, if you pause for too long to admire or wonder at anything you will soon find a snake or monkey being draped over you or your hand being decorated with henna...for which you then have to barter a deal for something you didn't ask for in the first place. Stallholders will thrust items into your hands in an attempt to secure a sale. They will also try and charge you if you take photos in some of the areas so be aware of this. Don't make the mistake of thinking the deeper you venture into the souks the better bargains you will find.This was not what we found at all. In fact we secured better bargains and found the tenders were more open to bartering in the stalls just off from the main square. The smells of spices and argan oils create a unique smell within the souks which will both delight and confuse your nostrils at the same time! Expect to get dirty when you visit the souks. They are dusty and dirty. You have to be prepared to be firm and not be afraid to say no to people.
