We found it a great experience and got some beautiful unusual items at great prices to bring back home. Worth a visit, just be prepared for the reality that the souks are a little crazy.

Beautiful but a little annoying. You have to practice the technique of ignoring vendors. They can be really intrusive but never dangerous. My advise is not to look at them unless you really want something. However, it is really beautiful and charming every street in there.

A visit to the Souk. It's well worth taking the time to visit the Souk day or in the evening, once you're inside the heart of the Souk with all its alleyways it's quite easy to get a bit disorientated don't worry just head north and you will come out in the main square. We felt walking around and was not hassled too much. But remember always have a good haggle start less than half what they won't.
Great shopping but very confusing. A little maze in the medina great for shopping and good value for the traditional gifts (when you bargain). Try to go with a GPS or a guide as you might get lost!
Waste of time. What can I say?Don't bother, smelly, unhygienic,pressure salesman !!!!!Nothing like we were led to believe!!It was a horrible experience.
Shops shop shops!. Great experience wandering around and seeing all the shops and goods to buy. Definitely negotiate on price!!

Disappointing souks. Really disappointed with the souks. Massive area to cover but most of the stalls that we saw were no better or interesting than the market stalls here in the UK selling knock offs. Didn't really appreciate the amount of pestering to buy which really put us off.Word of warning: I had read the reviews about avoiding guides to show you around the souks but we were approached by a chap who claimed to be registered/authorised by the government. He even had an ID badge. I was persuaded and although the tour started off really well it evolved into a selling job. He was not so happy when I refused to buy anything.
Avoid.. Pestered bothered and irritated by the locals . The prices are special for tourist that is to say higher . What would happen in the UK if we but up prices for " non locals " ie foreigners .

Disappointing. I visited Marrakech in June it's my family. The place sounded so exotic and wonderful and it was on my bucket list. This turned into my most disappointing holiday due to mopeds driving at you on pavements and all through the very cramped souks. There are signs up to say that they cannot drive through there but nobody seems to enforce it. The souk itself is a sight and experience to behold and perhaps should be done at some point in your life. I do, however, think at 49 I was a bit old for this and it and you need a great deal of stamina to deal with the haggling, mopeds, the heat and never being able to relax as people were always watching you. You needed eyes in the back of your head. Sorry Marrakech but not my cup of tea!
Great experience!. This place is like a maze. So many stalls, places to shop, money exchangers and so much more. Found great deals. Of can course haggling is a must!
Just Do It!. Great fun - just keep your hands in your pockets! There isn't much you can't buy and some interesting sights on the way round.

Its crazy but Marrakech. Having been to this souk a few times it gets no better but you get smarter, you are there to spend money so avoid the henna ladies, monkey owners, snake charmers, watch the acrobats and have a mint tea. Its a spectacle and full of mad characters, its like a theatre of the bizarre.Don't read a map in public, accept advice from strangers, or be too friendly, and do not buy toot you don't need. Its Marrakech - what do you expect - enjoy !

Incredible colours and smells, lovely warm people. Throw away the maps and get lost in the souks. You'll eventually find yourself and a lot more besides. Yes if you're a woman alone wear sunglasses and don't make eye contact unless you want to buy something. Everyone is there to sell something - it's their livelihood and eventually that's what the conversation will come down to. The best bargains and the nicest people are in the deepest parts of the souk so don't be afraid to keep walking. Many people will tell you that of you ask someone for directions or assistance they'll demand money. I'm afraid that's really not the case. I met some really lovely people male and female who were only to happy to direct and help. All of the goods are transported via donkey and cart and the carts move quickly in the narrow streets. You're expected to know to watch for them and move out of the way quickly - it's really not that difficult a task in fairness. Haggling is fun but remember never give you 'final price' unless you want to buy something because 'final price' is taken as sale agreed. Enjoy this incredible place.

get lost in the souk. the souk is a place to get lost in all the alley ways, the smells of the spices is amazing the stalls selling everything from leather goods to spices to pots of all shapes and sizes, people told me i would not like the souk but it was a good experience seeing the day to day lives of the morroccan people makes you feel at one with them yes you get lost but that is part of the experience and there is always a friendly local willing to help you out of the maze i would reccomend a visit to the souk and be sure to haggle the people are really friendly its an experience you wont forget.

Awful Experience, not enjoyable in any way!!. I have travelled to many places in the world and have never been more disappointed than with the souks in Marrakech and the filth, harassment and visible animal abuse in the main square Jemaa El-Fnaa. Be careful, people are rude and become aggressive very quickly when you do not hand over your money. Tourists are viewed as if they are a walking dollar sign and you are constantly harassed for money from the time you leave your hotel, even to the point where they lure you into a friendly conversation and then demand money from you in a very intimidating and frightening manner. My advice, Don't Go There!!

Another world today, great prices!. Wow, what an experience! We spent time there 2 days. The shopping is fantastic. Bargaining is fun and exhausting to get the best price. We had to leave more than once. Keep smiling though! :)

Always an experience. No matter whether it's the spices or the carpets the leather goods or the shoes or the donkeys pulling building materials the souk is ever changing.Ok you need to have your wits about you but it has more personality than any indoor market I have ever been to in the UK.The latest fad is the use of tyres to make everything from bi-kinis to picture framesAs the title says it's always an experience

arranged trip. Went to the souk as part of an arranged trip though the Eden Andalou Hotel. Not the safest place to go, lots of mopeds and people with carts and horses running up and down the narrow uneven streets where the general public walk Expect lots of haggling.If you go with the guides all as they are interested in is flogging you you items from three particular stalls. 1 spices and herb shop, 2 carpet shop 3 souvenir shop. They can be quite pushy and don't like taking no for an answer. You have been warned.

Unique, but beware. You're going to come here anyway regardless of this review, and you should. I've been to many markets all around the world but this one stands out. This is not necessarily a good thing. True, it's a genuine, functioning everyday market for many locals, which is great, but it also preys on tourists. It has the sights and smells you'd expect. Many of the stalls and shops repeat in that they sell such similar goods, but the stallholders and shop keepers can be very aggressive. They don't give you a chance to stop and look before they are over harassing you into buying. I found them vocally and sometimes physically aggressive. Understandably tourists are a great source of revenue but some of the prices they quote are astronomical, be prepared to bargain and bargain hard. I found that I got some souvenirs at around 30% of the initial asking price, in one case I got it for 10%. Beware too of the motorbikes and mopeds that drive all around the souk, without lights too at night! A sudden step and you could get an injury. Certainly it's worth a visit, if you're apprehensive consider employing a guide.

A must see!. Take your time and wander around the souk. It is a fascinating place - full of interesting items and food as well as the usual tourist tat. It's easy to get lost but just keep walking and eventually you will come across somewhere you recognise. Try not to worry too much about the shopkeepers & touts etc - just keep your wits about you and be friendly.

It was an experience. Having traveled all over the world and experienced the "selling styles" of many different cultures, I don't think anything prepared us for Marrakech! Positives - very interesting, a massive variety of different stalls and if you go out of the main square you feel that you really are experiencing a different part of the world. It was great to see the colours of the pottery, the animals on display and if you want to buy gifts, more than you can choose from. Once you've seen a few stalls, most are selling the same kinds of things, but still great for an exploreNegatives - if you stop and look, this creates an expectation that you will buy. This became frustrating when you wanted to stop and look, then think about buying. Pressure to buy was everywhere and you must be prepared to haggle as the starting price they quote is generally 3/4 times what you'll actually pay. Avoid anyone who offers to be a guide, or even a friendly face offering directions, unless you're happy to pay. We were "guided" to the tannery, which we weren't planning to go to, but having been giving a very rough direction by a lad in the street, ended up with 3 people hassling for money. If you're female, cover up. I was spat at even though by Western standards my shorts and t shirt were not revealing, this wasn't an experience I'd like to repeat. It was an experience and one that we would repeat, but would be better prepared for. As much as it's not in our nature to be blunt and tell people "no" or "leave me alone" this is a must for your visit. But overall an experience I wouldn't have missed

great crazy experience. The souk has many different stalls the deeper you go in , the more mysterious,it becomes!Yes you will be pestered, by the rip-off henna women, the snake charmers, the water seller, the illegal guides, taxi's etc. etc.But don't be put off, just say no firmly and walk on..I have been to Morocco, many times.....The best Haggling tip,i always ask the staff,waiters, how much, they would pay?most hotels will have a free shuttle bus into the the square[Jemaa el Fna.] and back.Go in the day,first, get your bearings, then go in the night, starts about 5pmthey want money for taking pictures[max 1 pound= 14 dirhams]make yourself a ready reckoner, for the values going up the scale pounds to dirhams 50 pence to say 100 pounds.don't wear flashy jewellery,use common sense finally Have A great time

Good luck!. So, the Souk is everything people have said and more. We went twice during our four day stay the first time we got back to our hotel we said 'Never Again!', but we worked up the nerve and went again the following day and we were so glad we did. We dressed respectfully, lightweight trousers and cover-ups on top, but when we were in Marrakech it was 44 degrees, so we were a bit too hot. The next day we visited we still wore cover-ups, but over shorts and this was fine. Basically the key is to hold your nerve. I saw a top which I liked, the guy asked for 370 Dirham (about £26 at the exchange rate I got), I suggested 50, he eventually agreed to 60 (about £4.20). We got beautiful leather slippers for about 50 Dirham after the original price they gave was 250. Nobody was rude at all, but they were very persistent and at times once we got in the shops they did block the doorways so we couldn't get out, we just remained firm and asked them to let us leave. We also got a couple of people giving us unrequested tours, who obviously then expected money for their help, again a firm 'No' is enough to fix that. It's definitely worth a visit for the experience.

Another world. What a place to walk and shop.Fantastic bargains and beautiful things to buy."branded goods" which are probably genuine when you look at the labels of clothes imported to England, especially leather.Stop for mint tea,it's very refreshing ,drink it all the time at home now.

The authenitic sights, sounds, and smells of Morocco !. I traveled with a group of 15 from OAT with a terrific Moroccan guide for 25 days. We spent several days, not consecutive, exploring Jemaa el Fna. Much like the medina in Fez it offers a plethora of sites, smells, sounds and colors. One could find anything Moroccan from the shabby to the exquisite. While in Morocco be prepared to barter and do so from the perspective of how much the item means to you as opposed to always getting what you perceive to be rock bottom price. Be sure to return at night for the nightly bazar for an unparalleled experience. Every manner of performers, foods, and much much more! I always felt safe, and explored with the group and alone. The Souk is easier to navigate than the one in Fes, but as always, you need to be aware of your surroundings . If you have the opportunity, you should also explore the medina in Fez.

Experience the old and new. If you go to Marrakech you must experience the Souk. Old world meets new . You can wonder around forever r the day or perhaps even get lost. Having a guide is a nice idea. You will experience everything from freshly tanned leather goods and chicken laying eggs to some of the most spectacular hand woven rugs to pieces of art worth10's of thousands +A must see

Just go. You wont be disappointed!. We visited the Jemaah el Fna Souk with some trepidation, as we expected to get pestered to death by sales people. It never happened! The traders are so laid back its untrue. We saw some fabulous stalls, stacked high with fabulous spices of different colours. As we are genuine foodies, the smells of spices was wonderful. There was pottery of all descriptions, 'designer' everything, from footwear to handbags at very low prices. Its just a shame we had travelled hand luggage only! We visited twice, once during the day, and again at night. What an experience it was. The traders in the souk are really nice people. Don't be afraid to visit. Unlike some North African countries we have visited, Marrakech is fabulous.

A step back in time. The Souk is like stepping back into biblical days with everything being sold and haggled over. The spices looked amazing and the smells were enticing. I would recommend a guide as it adds interest and you see things you would otherwise miss. Also some parts are a little unsavoury so be careful. Yes you will be hassled but just smile and keep saying no thank you and they will leave you alone. Beware the scooters too, and keep a hefty hand on your valuables. Other than that, enjoy!
Not all tipical market. It's a market, much is modern or for tourist but some part of this (the covered market) it's old and real market.

Shop till you drop. This is a must if you go to the medina, daytime is the hustle and bustle of the souks, which is an experience. Dont be afraid to venture in, even if its only a little way. The locals are friendly and will understand a polite "NO" you can find some great bargains and for getting any delicate items home, you can buy bubble wrap, brown paper etc on the stalls, just ask what stalls do this. The square come alive in the evening, with more street food, entertainers, snake charmers, etc etc. If you take picture you will be asked for money so maybe ask before and agree a price.

Busy and colourful - be prepared to haggle!. If you're in Marrakech you have to visit the Souks! I wasn't sure what to expect as I'd been warned about crowds, hassle and getting lost. The souks are indeed in a maze of little streets (we accidentally left the shopping area, followed an alleyway and ended up in someones house) however they occupy a small area so keep going or come back on yourself and you'll end up back in the main square. Don't be fooled into accepting a guide, they will take your money and lead you to shops they get commission from - you are fine on your own. Many stalls sell the same sort of touristy stuff but there are some real Aladdin's cave's in their so don't be afraid to look around and have a good hearted haggle! I loved the bright colours and busy market atmosphere.

Avoid if you are easily offended by sexual comments. Overall, not a pleasant experience for us due to the constant badgering from your Moroccans offering their over eager services to show you around which we did not want as we wanted to explore at our own pace. When one young Moroccan said to my wife (who was respectably and not at all overtly dressed) "Nice T*ts" - I blew my top and threatened the young lad with the Tourist Police at which point he scarpered. My wife was pretty shocked by the comment and felt an immediate need to leave the area.

Very bad experience . The minute you get out of the Taxi you are plagued with people hassling you to buy stuff from them. You can't shop in comfort because the souk owners drive you mental trying to sell you stuff. Got lost in the Souks one day and was set up by some of the locals. They brought us out of the souks and demaned money , very intimidating experience & left a very bad taste in my mouth for Morocco. Will never ever go back there again.
ok for a visit. visited this once and wasn't very fond and mainly because of all the hassle, my husbands a big guy and kept getting touched and looked at so we left after a hour

An absolute "must visit" when in Marrakech!! A feast for the senses!!. We stayed in a side street in the old city so visited Jemaa el Fna most days and nights of our stay! A vibrant and exciting market during the day where you buy amazing ceramics, fabrics, shoes, silver jewelery, metal light shades, musical instruments, delicious cakes, fresh oranges, spices...just about anything! The spice displays are amazing! There's something different around every corner - and it's a photographer's dream! One of our fave pics is a young shepherd boy with a live goat wrapped around his shoulders, possibly on his way to the meat market.We were given great advice by our Riad hosts to "get lost, relax and enjoy the experience"... When purchasing anything "bargain the prices way below the original asking price" - which is great fun and you earn respect from the seller (they will still be making a profit!) Also jump close to the wall and 'pray to Allah' when motor scooters shoot past you - This was essential for survival.At night the medina turns into a food festival with hundreds of food stalls with lots of seating. Men from different tribes arrive to play music and dance - its a brilliant experience!

Great experience. Everyone told me that when you visit Marrakech, you must visit the souks and I am really glad that we did.The souks are essentially what we would call a street market but these are different. There is so much going on - so many smells, so many colours and so many things to buy. It is such an interesting place and something that I have not experienced elsewhere.If you do decide to buy anything, never pay the asking price. You can ALWAYS knock them down by quite a lot so get your haggling hat on and barter with them!The only downside is that I did feel a little uneasy at times because it is like a complete maze of markets and you can feel a little secluded especially as a woman. Don't let this put you off but just make sure you are not on your own at any point.

Still Amazing. The souk in Marrakech is everything you expect and more. We were there 3 days. First day open eyed tourists hassled by everyone, 2nd and 3rd days we got used to it didn't return looks or just said no and meant it and had no problems. The colours, smells, sights and sounds are amazing. You can wander round and get lost then pop up and find yourself again. Despite all the warnings we had no problem with pickpockets or other crime. Everyone seemed very friendly.

Open shopping mall . You can buy almost everything whatever the price is always cut at list 80% percent and offer yours the winner be You .... Be careful with kids they always want to show you something afterwards -give me money,where's mine money. In general it's nice and something good memories for the future You must be good traider and get best deal otherwise it costing at list twice more .Have a nice stay in Marrakech

Just get lost!!!. I received the best advice before entering the market, which was expect to get lost. Once this Is your expectation then you can relax and take in all the smells and sensory overload this place has to offer. Just take a picture of your hotel or point of entrance and when you are ready to leave a local young person is ready to show you the way home for a very low fee. Believe me this is the best way to see the market in all its beauty!!! Make sure to drink the fresh squeezed orange juice, it's like liquid gold that instantly makes you feel alive!!!

Must must do. Everyone must visit the souks- they are a feast for all the senses!Busy fun exciting interesting packed colourful talented craftsmen cheeky men. Don't worry about getting lost, just throw yourself in - take your hotel map it's all you need. Barter hard and you will be rewarded. You cannot visit Marrakech without visiting the souks.They are highly recommended

An assault on your senses. So much fun and always more interest around the next corner. Obviously the locals want you to part with your money, but in the main a polite no thanks will make them leave you alone. There were exceptions when "Egypt style" hassling happened. For those of you who are asthma sufferers I should imagine 35degree heat combined with exhaust fumes from the many mopeds being ridden through the souks cannot be easy breathing. I saw new bollards installed at on entrance and I wonder if the authorities are slowly going to stop them coming through, however be aware they are sometimes driven at speed down very narrow alleys. We wandered far and wide and always felt safe. I think the tolerance of Morocco is a good example of how North African countries could be.

Well worth a visit. We made 3 visits to the souks in total on our week long trip, all at varying times. The difference in timing is amazing. If you go early there is a lot less hassle and pressure...some sellers even seem actively disinterested. We passed a whole section where about 6 sellers were far more interested in watching something on their phones. Haggling is a way of life here. Don't be afraid to walk away. Chances are they will run after you and accept your offer unless you completely lowballed them. Some of the stuff on offer is generic tat but there are some lovely pieces to be picked up. The souks were definitely one of the more fun experiences of our holiday

Be ready to bargain and enjoy the hustle and bustle. We spent a day just visiting the souk and for a shopper/bargainer like me this was so much fun. There are tons of interesting things to see and buy and I loved looking through the intricate lamps, handmade rugs, clothing and trinkets. Some of it is commercial looking stuff but you can also find some handmade pieces which are really unique and beautiful. The pottery was my favorite. Be ready to bargain and only name prices you are actually willing to pay.

Quite the experience !. Myself and two other ladies visited the souks. On arrival we were approached by a young boy who begged us for money. As none of us had change on us at the time we apologised and politely refused. The young boy walked away, only to have come back three minutes later and beg us again, this did leave us all feeling a little uncomfortable. We had decided not to get a guide as we wanted to explore the markets ourselves, however if you may be intimidated by the begging of locals and stall owners a guide may be advisable. In regards to our experience with the shop keepers it was very pleasant ! They were very friendly, and every other one greeted us with "Africa!!" or "my sisters" which we found quite amusing. Yes we did experience the begging of owners to come and look in their stalls but that is to be expected. In regards to the price of items/ goods they are set very high as a significant amount of their income comes from tourists, however it is very easy to walk out with the item 40-50% less than their initial asking price sometimes even more... Tips for haggling: If you want to purchase multiples say if "I buy 3 I want them all for....." state your price, also claim you've seen it cheaper on another stall, or just begin to walk out if they don't give u the price you want, they will soon chase you with a better price ! Most importantly, be polite,it goes a long way..Experience of the environment:Mopeds and scooters coming from in front and behind which is very frustrating with all the other things already going on. A large funeral party (along with the coffin) also walked through the market, which did leave us feeling a little uncomfortable also.Overall a decent experience, I most definitely would not advise women against it from our experience as we were not harassed or ripped off at all, if you are worried just ensure you are dressed properly.

Excellent . Treasure trove Very big market for local produce, souvenirs, art etc everything you can think off. You can spend hours browsing and then enjoy a meal on the rooftop restaurants overlooking the square. The stench of the horse manure can be overpowering and off putting though. Yet still I loved it.

Where magic Happens !. What a pleasure to visit this Historical site in Marrakech!Go talk to every single person, they have so many things to teach you!Eat anything you find, it's 100% bio healty and tasty! Don't be afraid to try different things, Moroccans have been eating this for centuries!Ask questions, Moroccan have a great Hospitality skills!Love the place, and get lost in the small streets of the Medina !

Colorfull, tradingplaces in the Medina. Places With colors in many ways. You have to know that if you are interested in buying things you should be serious about it. Else you are caught in a tradingsituation thats not easy to come out from. Nice People.

Hectic but good fun. Daytime is less busy - you won't see the snakes and the monkeys but less crowded and you get a good look around. It is huge though so wear sensible shoes and keep to the right as they ride scooters and donkeys through the streets. Haggling is expected but would advise charm rather than aggression when doing a deal. I really enjoyed the experience but my partner found it a bit overwhelming but this is a man who finds ikea challenging.

Touts spoiled wonderful place. Today I had the pleasure of doing a Marrakech city tour which ended with free time shopping in the souks. This was fantastic handicrafts and fun interactions while bargaining.As most people do, I hot lost among the many stalls. It all turned nasty when one young man forced himself into showing me the direction of my triad. I did not ask for his help and was shocked at the verbal abuse when I refused to pay for advice I did not want. In the heat and confusion I was left in tears..until a kindly local couple came to my aid.This is a lovely city...but if tourism is important then security for guests should be prioritized. Others I have spoken to had similar upsetting experiences.I have travelled extensively in the Middle East and as a single female am very aware and in other countries been luckier. Today I was shocked at the abuse. I am fearful now for my next three days here

Wow. What a place if your looking for bargains and the hustle and bustle of Moroccan life then this is the place to go there is everything from tagines, lamps, lights, clothes,shoes to name a few. There is also a food bit but be prepared to be asked by all the stalls to eat in there restaurant but there all very friendly there is also snake charmers and men with monkeys you can have photos with but be warned they will want money so its up to you but its the maddest place I have been to and I can't wait to go back.

Typical market local & beautiful. I've been to many similar markets throughout the world, which are exactly the same as this one, in the sense of chaotic and hectic, and completely different in the sense that is local with different Moroccan products. It is worth seeing and experiencing, worth visiting for the spices and herbs, lamps and bags, etc. Be advice we got almost 50% off of everything we bought after negotiating.
Shopping. Great place to shop. Do your homework. Many places sell the same item and many places don't have set prices. Bargain when you can. Compare prices.

worth a visit. I enjoyed the hustle and bustle of this market town but thankfully I had my husband there to barter because im not very good and they seem to no this so home in straight for me,,, if unlike me you can barter this is a place for your bargains although remember if you want to to take any pics you have to pay

Not for everyone. The Marrakesh souk has been there long before European, American and other foreign tourists from north and west came to Marrakesh. It was there for those living in the hinterland, especially the mountains, but also for those on the caravan path that connected Morocco and points north with the lands to the south in Africa. To be sure, much has been adapted for the "newest tourists," but the reality is that most remains geared for the others. In this regard, it can be off putting, nerve wracking, at times disgusting and definitely uncomfortable to a certain degree for nearly all Western tourists. There are locally made products, but so much now comes from China, so beware. If you want locally made, well crafted artifacts, you are best advised to save your money till you get to Fez.

Interesting products but I don't like the selling culture. There is a wonderful array of unique products in the souks. The attitude of most of the shopkeepers really ruined it for me though. Firstly, they are overly persistent to get you inside their shop when you walk past. Then, when you express an interest in a product they give you a massively hyper-inflated price. I bought a kaftan for 50 MADs for which I was initially quoted 250 MADs... I usually enjoy haggling but this is ridiculous! It annoys me that most tourists get ripped off.

Interesting visit. You simply can't miss a visit to the souks.We opted to take a guide round with us on our first day to really see what was what and the best areas to buy different pieces like leather etc.Highly recommended

Terrifying . We were 2 women in our 40's wandering around the souks. We were told what to expect by our Riad owner and fully expected the bartering system and the things to avoid etc.However we found that the men in the stores were very aggressive and very disrespectful. We got suckered into a 'Herbalist ' shop which was pretty and interesting. The guy claimed to be a pharmacist and proceeded to wow us with herbal remedies and argon oil and creams.We each had a pile of must have things by the end of it but didn't have enough cash and hadn't brought our credit cards - thankfully!We agreed to have the guy come to our Riad to pick up the money and deliver the products that evening. When we returned to our Riad we asked the manager if we had been ripped off considering the cost of the items. He confirmed that we were over paying and also that we shouldn't buy 'herbal teas' because they are not heathy blends. We asked him to call the guy and tell him not to come because we'd changed our minds. He showed up anyway. He came back every day for 4 days. Our Riad manager sent him away each time. The day before we left my friend wanted to return to the souks for a bag. We were recognized and harassed by a man who knew the herbalist. He ran off to tell him we were in the souks. We ran as fast as possible out of the souks to avoid the confrontation. It was a terrifying experience and we felt we were in danger.We spent 6 days in Marrakech and thought we would enjoy the souks but honestly it ruined our trip.My advice would be to hire a guide to get you through it safely. And expect to be ripped off by everyone.

Interesting but totally mad. It's a fun experience if you don't mind ... Crazy moped, bike riders missing you by an inch, sellers who almost rugby tackle you to get a sale and the crowds. On sale the usual load of rubbish but occasionally something interesting. You will get lost but soon find your way back out to the main square. To sum up its an experience enhanced initially at least with an official guide to show you round and give you a better understanding. Leather, Shoes, carpets, lights ect are all there and get your haggling head on if you find something you like. Good luck! and make sure your insurance is upto date in case a nutty moped rider crashes.
Like a local. Got introduced to the Souks by the staff and was rarely treated like a tourist. Great experience and got to meet locals.

Once is more than enough. You must see it. But some of us ended up hating it. Og course it brings you good photo opportunities. And for those who like to buy all sort of junk, it is a paradise. But rude people (men), abused animals is difficult to look away from.

FULL OF CULTURE AND TRADITION. Very hustle and bustle as you would expect of the Souk, full of culture and tradition but please take a tour guide with you, tell them what you want to see or buy he will take you straight there bi passing the aggressive selling that takes place.

don't get lost. Great place, full of colour smells & experiences. Went as a group of four, male & female, men hated it partly due to the fact it's shopping! However we went back a few times as just 2 women. The people are friendly and yes some do pressure you a little but a polite no thank you was accepted. The spice part is great but food/meat area in the heat wasn't my cup of tea. It was a very different experience.What I would say is wear a hat! As every seller as we got there was selling hats. We ended up paying £1.00 and it was well spent as didnt get pestered again. There are many people offering you photo (for a small charge) but we skipped out on that to. Would deffently go and experience it though.

Keep your wits about you!. Noisy, fascinating, loads of bargains but you must haggle hard and walk away if not interested! Shop keepers are very persistent but if you stay calm and polite, and say "No thank you" they back off. Prices start very high, so watch out and don't get ripped off. Spice shops worth a look, and the orange juice stalls in the main square are fab. Street food stalls a bit dodgy, but fun to watch.

Hustle and bustle loved it. . The hustle and bustle of this place is not for everyone's taste however we loved it. So much to see taste smell and experience. Would advise learning a few words in Arabic, please thank you, yes, no and thank you to make your experience even better. Never felt uncomfortable and locals very helpful and friendly.

Worth a visit!. Dirty, noisy, smelly and amazing! It's well worth visiting the souks but be prepared to get completely lost and have an assault on all your senses! You will not come out without purchasing something you don't want or without being hassled by shop/stall keepers, but that's all part of the fun! Be prepared to haggle with everyone for a good price- just walk away if you're not happy to pay the price they want.

Busy loud and a experience . Be prepared to be stopped hassle and its so busy. Very full on but a great experience. Lots to see but be warned you stop and they will not let you go. Haggling is a must and don't give up. If not happy with price walk on there will be another seller . Dress appropriately as they can be intimidating.

Its Bonkers. The Souks of the medina , must be seen on a visit to the city, there is nothing that you cannot buy here, ( if you want to is another matter ) but the vast quantity of merchandise is mind blowing and as you pass every shop the owners try and entice you in to make a sale, the souks are surrounded by the main square which has numerous street performers , restaurants, fast food outlets , fresh orange juice vendors and pick pockets ( so beware ) Don,t forget to haggle hard in the souks, the owners will always ask about double the going rate, so do haggle, its all good natured and expected and you know when you have gone too low, its when you go to walk away and they do not call you back.

OMG....What a Place !. WOW ! This place is a trip! You can buy just about anything here.....soup to nuts as they say.....or in this case, carpets to false teeth.... I spent three days here, staying at the Nesma Riad (see my review) about a 5 minute walk from the main market square in the Souk.Restaurant and food stalls abound in the main square and it's fun to just eat a good meal and watch all the action. There are lots of entertainers too. You can see snake charmers, monkeys, and other animals normally found in the zoo. Of course, if you take a photo of the entertainment, payment is normally expected. The Marrakech Souk is an absolute "must see" while in the Old Medina. Hopefully, you will have good navigation skills while wondering the isles in the Souk. It is easy to get lost, so set your bearing on one of the Prayer Towers near the main square.. I visited a number of Souks in Morocco, but the Marrakech Souk is the best ! Don't miss it.....

Average. When you first enter the souks its like stepping into a different world. After getting lost, being pestered constantly and seeing the same stuff over and over again it becomes tiresome. Go once, early in the day before it gets too hot.

Nice Place. Great place for vacation 100% recomended, they go the extra miles if you want to get Wonderful spa experience go there for live your life at enjoyable. But most important thing if you are outsiders and planning to go marrakech souk recently you have need to buy visitors insurance before leaving your home country.

Jamia alfna. Shop keepers just jump on visitors. Most of them forcing you to buy. If refused they become abusive. .. also majority of the stuff is fake and they ask more then double of the original price. But if u walk away, they sell it for less than 50 % they asked for.

Great cultural experience but lots of tat and hard for women on their own. As a woman traveling on my own walking around the souk was especially hard as I couldn't walk for than 1m without being hassled. It's not unpleasant but it is persistent! For many this is one of the cultural highlights of trip but I found it uncomfortable. You cannot browse so hard to buy things and while there are genuine handicrafts in leather, wood, metalwork, clothes etc there is also lots of manufactured tat so be careful. Rug shopping if you are a serious buyer and can haggle, and spices were the only thing I enjoyed getting.

What an experience . Visited as a couple on June 6th when it threw it down with rain!Stalls are fab and the people are brilliant! Majority of items are the same but some gorgeous Moroccan outfits and pottery. Good prices as well!Be careful of the Henna ladies as they just grab you and henna your hands expected money in return.The monkeys appear very tame but are on chains like leads to their owners. Some wear nappies and football shirts! They allow you to take photo with the monkeys but expect money from you. The rep in my hotel said its respectable to pay between 10-20dnh.Snake charmers were very pushy trying to put snakes around your neck but just say no very fermly and they leave you alone.Great atmosphere and certainly worth a visit
Thrilling souk. ...with treasures a plenty and keen sales men willing to bargain with you for hours! enticingly displayed locally made goods of all sorts from rugs to tea glasses.

Haggle for everything!. We spent 3 days doing the souk and still didn't manage to see it all!you are expected to haggle,so make sure you have a price in your head and stick to it,there are some fabulous bargains to be had.be quite stern with the shopkeepers,they seem to respect you more.ibeware of the henna women who will take hold of your hand and start tattooing you before you even know about it.agree a price on everything before you purchase something,even bottles of water from the orange juice sellers,they will try to get the most out of you,so be careful.Apart from this,it's a fantastic place,this was my second time,and I can't wait to go back!!

Not for the faint-hearted!. Definitely worth a trip or two but I can only reiterate what others have said below. You are taking your life into your hands vis a vis the moped riders. Before you know it they're tooting their little horns for you to jump out of the way a la Indiana Jones styley ha ha!! Not sure why its allowed in such a tiny space but clearly no one else is bothered. If you've any sense you'll avoid the snake charmers and monkey handlers on the way in. These congregate in the main square before you reach the Souk alleys. (Hey! Some of you might enjoy having a photograph taken with a monkey wearing a pampers having been kept in a black box no larger than itself all morning in blistering heat. Who am I to say!!). The snakes look so half dead you'd swear they were made out of rubber. This is also where the horse and carriages park which don't smell too badly until later on in the day (when the horsey poop is clearly building up). Apart from that I wouldn't say I found the souk's all that smelly. Some of them are smellier than others like where they tan the leather and where they dye the wool. Anyway, its great fun wandering around the souk. You can really get lost in here. Be prepared to barter - its a given. We visited on a day when it was a bit overcast just after lunch time and I assume they'd had the coach loads of tourists through in the morning and by the time they'd had lunch they didn't seem to overly bother us at all. It was really quiet in some of the alleys too - barely anyone around - I could have wandered about for hours. Some stalls are better than others : the more traditional ones selling lamps and trays and crockery and leather goods. Be aware of the young boys who tell you they'll show you the way to where they dye the wool. They make out they're doing you a huge favour (even though you don't really want to go there) and make you go up and down and up and down all these alleyways. We ditched them in the end but I assume once they get you where they want you to go they'll want money. Lots of shops don't let you take photo's without handing over cash which I thought was a shame. You're more likely to engage with them if they let you take photo's. Some shops/market stalls even advertise the fact that they 'no charge for photo' so that's how much of a problem it is. Well worth a visit and a re-visit in the evening.

An amazing shopping experience. The souk is the most amazing experience in Marrakech. Talk about hustle! Everyone has a hustle of some sort. You will find great quality, camel leather handbags of all shapes, colours and sizes. Scarves, silver jewellery and clothes are available at fabulous prices if you have your haggle on!! The great thing is that you really shouldn't get lost in there as all the cobble stoned alleys lead back to some point in the main square. It's a must on your visit to Marrakech!
Crazy but has to be done!. Crazy place where you will get hassled but remain strong willed and barter like crazy and you can come away with some stunning goods!

Beware of the Snake people at the Souk. Loved shopping at the souk but the group with the snakes right at the entrance of the souk really put a damper on our experience. Just before you enter the souk, you will see some snakes (at the open space). Walk close and the people there will start putting the snakes around your neck and "blessing" you with the snakes. Then they will take out their hat and ask for some contributions. We gave them some coins and they started getting aggressive saying they do not want coins, only paper money. When we refused, they started getting a little physical and pulling us back. So we told them that we have no money and they got angry, asking us to show them our wallets. We felt threatened and between us, gave them about 200 dirhams before they left us alone. It was a really bad experience so please remember to avoid the snake people.

Spectacular for its noise and atmosphere. From photos seen before our visit I was keen to experience this Souk, and it certainly did not disappoint. The atmosphere was festive a fun and at night it was more so.

How to destroy a Souk. I first went to Marrakech probably before most readers were born. It was a small city then which ended at its walls. Its very different now but this is not a nostalgia for the old times review. Many things have improved above all the standards of many of the riads where one can stay.However to allow the presence of speeding motorbikes roaring down narrow covered souk streets is madness. Many driven in the evenings by young guys seem on a sort of dare to just miss people at speed. Why the souk shop owners are not up in arms about it is beyond me. They ruin the place with noise, pollution and actual danger . The traffic is awful throughout the old city but this is expected but the motorbike menace in narrow souks and medina is beyond a joke.It does not happen in the Essouira souk so why does Marrakech allow it?

Its an experience. The souks are crazy but worth a visit, they are very crowded (and smelly) down small roads that have motor bikes whizzing through in all directions so you need to be carful.The haggling techniques are a must as they start with a ridiculous price but you can bargain them down to a more reasonable level, there is a tourist market which has set prices so this is worth a visit first so you know what ball park figure to pay.

You will be accosted. Every vendor has an angle to get to stop and look at his wares. If you show the slightest interest in anything, you will be pounced on. If you a stop for a minute, you will be approached and offered an escort to where you need to get to. First, however, you will be led to a relative's store, or the tanner's area, or the dyer's area. If you buy something, your guide will get a commission. If you don't buy anything, your guide will get a little angry and demand a "tip" for showing you around. This whole thing get so tiresome and detracts from the experience. If you do decide to buy anything, start bidding at 10% of what the vendor's first offer. Be ready to walk away. You will likely be followed or yelled to as you get further away. This is all part of the game. Even though the Souk is very crowd, it is seemingly safe. Never saw any sign of pick-pockets.

Fantastic Shopping. The souk in Marrakesh is one of my all time favorite shopping experiences. The first day we went with a guide who showed us the different areas. It is a large bustling labyrinth so it's easy to get confused, but the vendors are separated into areas by specialty. In one part you have the tanners and cobblers who are making shoes and purses. Then there is a section where the craftsman are making things from metal like light fixtures, locks and iron work. And there is pottery and things made from wood. Then there are spices, teas and oils. And many selling rugs and some selling jewelry. It's so fascinating to see these talented people making everything by hand. Most were also gracious if I asked to take their photo. (You must ask and get permission. A smile goes a long way in getting permission) The culture is to bargain but I wasn't really into that as I know how hard these people are working so most of the time we just paid the asking price. We bought beautiful hand sewn silk purses, argan wood boxes and oils, several table cloths and some handmade shoes. I also bought a lovely silk brocade coat. I would have loved to buy some of the fabulous light fixtures I saw but will look for them online. It's a shoppers paradise despite the crowded narrow streets and constant motorbikes zooming through.

A bit of fun. The Marrakech souk is not large and very easy to negotiate. There is a main `street` which is full of tourist items - leather, ceramics, etc. and some sideshoots with probably more interesting goods on sale. You do not need a guide. If you do have one he will only take you to the places where he receives a commission and you won`t get the feel for the area. If you do get lost just ask someone and they will point you in the right direction. The souk in Fez is quite a different matter and enormous. You do need a guide here. Don`t forget to haggle - never pay more than half the quoted price - start at a third.

go for it xx. forget the maps,,we got lost for hours and so much to see and your senses will be blown away!!!try haggling,,its really fun and the banter is a great way to get to know the locals,,not once did we feel unsafe and we used our basic french and got by quite well,,but make sure you take an empty case,,you will want to buy EVERYTHING!! cant wait to visit again ,,,marrakech is my fav place so far xxxx

Typical market. I've been to many similar markets throughout the world which are the exact same as this, still for a first time it is worth seeing and experiencing, worth visiting for the spices and herbs, as you will find the best prices and variety
Amazing. Brilliant shopping. Don't be put off by people winging about the hard sell. Just be nice with the sellers and they will in return.

Fabulous!. Wonderful experience! I visitted this Souk three times at night by myself and at no time did I feel unsafe - of course I was still very careful with my money and phone and didn't talk to anyone unless making a purchase - so much excitement - snake charmers - story tellers - dancers - just wonderful!

A Little Souked Out !!. I may have been tired and emotional after two weeks in Morocco where it sat around 40 degrees each day but really the Jemaa el FIna is a bit of a disappointment. Dozens of orange juice stands, cheap sunglasses, toys, trinkets and guys with poor animals who look wretched and sad. The area is past it and needs a revamp. I suspect the tourists are only going through the motions to tick it off their lists without much enthusiasm.

Amazing. Let's be honest, it's crowded people are likely to invade your personal space!But for sheer fun and haggling adventures coupled with awesome street food this can't be beatDay time is best for shopping evening is for the experienceIf you get intimidated you can always shout out for the tourist police who are always aroundThe souks are truly fun

Throw away your maps and get lost in it all!. The best way to experience the Souks is to go in blind and wonder around. If something catches your eye, engage the tradesmen and barter. If you set a price you're willing to pay in your mind, you'll find the whole haggling experience really enjoyable. If you can't agree on a price, move on! There are so many traders selling similar things, you don't need to settle on the first one you see.Overall its a great experience, but definitely not for the sensitive type!

Love to go there again, but no Ramadan for me.... I traveled to Marrakech a few years ago and i loved it. We visit the Souk for the first time with a guide which was extremely helpful since the souk is like a colorful labyrinth. You can visit the Place des épices and take a break to refresh yourself in the Cafe Des Epices. The only less positive thing was that we traveled during the Ramadan, and it can be a little bit stressful to deal with during the day.

It is an adventure. It is a great experience, there are loads of goods, colorfull, many different things, you can see donkeys overtaking you and of course crazy people riding motorbikes as fast as if they were in a motorway, when they beep just move closer to the wall, very friendly people, everybody welcome us, if they offered you something and you said no, they replied with a "maybe later" very nice people. I am not very good at haggling but at the end of our trip I got some new skills ;). Just be careful when you are walking in a very crowded area, as some young kids tried to open my boyfriends backpack (of course can happen anywhere). Definitely is a must!

Feels like being some centuries back in time. Had a feeling like being some centuries back in time. It was very unusual to meet a donkey in the narrow alleys of the souks. At the same time had to be careful from the motorcycles. But overall a good place to buy souvenirs and practice bargaining skills. It took some time to find our way out, but it was also part of the fun we had. A must visit for everyone!

You name it...They have it!. Not much of a shopper,but enjoyed my visits! Used my phone compass and did not get lost!! Lots of goods, people friendly, cleaner than expected. A colorful,exciting time out!! A must!

Haggling info!. I like these Souks for the fact that they are, in general, artisanal and generally sell Moroccan artefacts - e.g. leather goods (small luggage bags are a very good buy), light fittings, shades and lanterns, and the little glass bottles with metal or even silver lids which are very cute, along with hand painted pottery items. As an experienced market shopper from all around the world, including China, Mexico and, another famous market, the covered market in Istanbul, I would say that true bargains are more difficult to be had here due to UK and U.S. tourists who are not used to haggling! It is very time consuming to drive down a price at these Souks to something reasonable. Certainly, the leather goods, whilst reasonable, are still way more expensive than in India. Getting the lightshades down to a good price takes some time. Nevertheless, there are bargains to be had by being a good poker-face haggler, going further "into" the souks and by going in the late afternoon/evening, you may get a better bargain if the market seller has not had a particularly fruitful day!!

Quite an Experience. This is a must see but two warnings: first, you need to be very alert for the motorcycles and donkey carts that are constantly streaming through this place. Second, it's really really easy to get lost. With that said we had a fun time and picked up the obligatory slippers and argan oil.

Love it or hate it! I LOVED it!. Yes its full of aggressive salesmen, yes its full of beggars and yes everyone is trying to run you over by motorcycle or donkeycart. But boy oh boy is it worth it! The first night l was a bit overwhelmed and l didnt really like the experience but by day 3 l just couldnt get enough of it. Its very different from Europe but once you immerse yourself in the atmosphere, its magical! Go at night and try some of the food from the local stalls, its half the price of the restaurants and in my opinion twice as good.

Shop till you drop!. Had a great time in the Souks, bought lots of bargains. However, beware of fakes. I bought a 'silver' ring and it was only thanks to the kindness of the hotel manager taking me back and sorting it out, that I did not lose out.

Aggressive motorcycles everywhere in the souk. You would expect the souk to be free of traffic, but not so in Marrakech. Motorcycles squeeze even through the crowdiest and narrowest alley, quite aggressively, always with the excusing grin of a culprit.As a tourist in Marrakech, you are a walking dollar sign... you are constantly bugged by the merchants and beggars.

Amazing. You gave to experience it to believe it - nothing quite like it. The hustling is never-ending with everyone wanting to make a sale from you. But it's all done quite pleasantly and although it may feel like resistance is futile, they will let you move on knowing that the next tourists is only a few seconds behind you!! Go for it and enjoy the haggling - it's expected!

Get Lost! It's the best thing you'll do.. On our first day in the souk, our map could not even save us. Getting evermore disorientated (thanks to false advice), we ended up getting totally lost to the point where we stumbled upon chaotic no go markets with not another tourist in sight. We were amidst extremely dirty narrow quarters where artisans sweated in the oppressive mid 30s with sparks flying wildly and rusty machines hammering. After the entire morning building anxiety at cat calling and pushy street urchins trying to trick us, we ended up in panic, running around trying to get back to somewhere recognisable. Getting lost in the souk was one of the best things we did and an inevitable part visiting Marrakech. By day 4 in the chaotic city, my travel partner had left and I was navigating the endless souk alleys alone confidently, shaking hands and sipping tea with people I'd haggled hard with. Don't pass by the opportunity to haggle; enjoy it. It's part of life in Marrakech. Offer a fifth of their initial price. Work your way up slowly, tell them in fact you don't want to argue today and be firm but not rude. Pretend to walk away, laugh at their suggestions. Argue with a smile and you'll end up winning, walking away with something beautiful, a handshake and a fond memory.
Fab. We went to the souks in marrakesh and it was fab. Be prepared to haggle its expected and you will get a bargain x it's great.

Amazing Marrakech. The souk is a place to find almost anything Morrocan, including leather bags, slippers, clothing etc. The vendors are relatively polite, compared to places like China and can be bargained down reasonably easily. We found some good quality gifts for friends but you need to go deeper into the market and avoid the sellers around the edges of the main square. Good fun and definitely worth a visit.

Dirty and a waste of time!. I was so looking forward to visiting the Souk but it was awful, dirty, smelly and the shop keepers making a grab for your arm at any passing moment! I also needed a new suitcase as mine had been damaged at Marrakesh airport, bought one after much haggling, got it back to the hotel where it promptly fell apart...... Just a word of warning, there are snake charmers, monkeys there etc, take a photo of them and they pounce on you for money, when you refuse they get very very angry......

Dont take a guide. We took a guide for a visit to the souk His name was Abdelhay Binebine and was organised by our hotel. We wanted to buy carpets and he took us to a VERY expensive carpet shop through dark alleys. The carpets was still too expensive after we bargained for half a day and the guide tried to fix the price. We realised that he must get a commission.After he took us to another expensive shop we went back to the hotel By this time our guide was actually very rude to us.We were upset because we wasted all that time and didnt get anything and we were to fly out the next day.We decided to cancel our flight and get a car to travel to Cassablanca and went to the souk on our own.We then only saw how much the souk offers as Binebine took us through back alleys.I bought 8 carpets for a fraction of the price of the previous day.This carpets shop was just off the main passage and easy to find. The owner was very helpfull and sourced the carpets that I wanted from his friends. We had to pay cash as he didnt have credit card faccilities. I am just sorry for the whole day I have wasted with the guide. Go on your own it is a lot of fun.

Go it alone! . First of all anyone complaining about being harassed to buy goods, you have come to a country where they barter for everything and tourists are the main source of income to feed their families. What did you honestly expect? The souks are an interesting place to visit full of colour and a lot going on. It would not be a full visit to marrakech if you didn't get lost in this maze. Lots of items on display to look at, purchase and practice your haggling skills. We found it useful to try and pay half of what was originally proposed as the selling price of an item. You are paying over the odds compared to the locals but is not much more this way and it is worth it for some unique items. The two things we found disappointing was that most of the shops catered for women only and that every other shop similar items are being sold. We were hoping for more variety but that might just be us being picky. Make sure you visit and like us refuse to get pictures with the monkeys in the square. They are in chains and was not pleasant to see. If you want to see them head to the mountains where they are wild and enjoying life.

Crazy, crazy place!!!. Leave everything you know about humanity at the hotel (or at home)! There are snakes, monkeys, people selling spells, women with boxes on their heads selling different kinds of spells, there's a tounge stall (don't....), there's a man with a magic carpet, a donkey whose legs are tied together :(, and so much going on that you forget which turning you took! You get pulled into shops to buy rugs and end up on the fifth floor of some tardis like place that you can't escape out of and it's just CRAZY!!!! I took the kids who didn't appear to be able to process it all like we could. They have this ability to think that it's all just ok - like crazy cartoons they watch on TV. As an adult though it's nuts - no donkey welfare rights there I'm afraid. The streets are very narrow so watch out for the motorcycle that's hurtling towards you carrying three people and an iguana - I kid you not!!!!!!It's an unforgettable experience and you really do have to do it - even briefly!
Constant hassle. Not a relaxing place to shop it's non stop hassle. All they wanna do is sell you crap. You don't get a moments rest.. So if you go good luck

Sacary but fun; needs several trips to see the whole thing. Overwhelming market, easy to get lost but easy to find your way out again. Not really able to browse or window shop, everyone so eager to sell you something that as soon as you look interested they're trying to get you to buy their things. You MUST haggle; never accept the first price, and don't haggle if you don't intent to buy.Beware of flying mopeds, lunatic cyclists and handcart men trying to get through the narrow passageways and people - all good fun. Very uneven underfoot so not really suitable if you can't walk well. I wouldn't take a baby buggy either - better in a baby sling or backpack.
souks. if you go to the souks go with the guide because it would be so easy to get lost in the maze, and don't forget to haggle.

Brace yourself for a constant hussle. Be ready for every passer by to ask you to by something, thats there culture but all you have to do is say no with a hand gesture and they will understand.It can get on your nerves but their harmless.What ever the price is make sure you bid down. If there really getting on your nerves offer them something so bad they will walk away.Enjoy there expressions.

Day trip to souk. Took a trip to the Marrakech souk from our hotel and it was an eye opener wonderfull sights sounds and smells, go early afternoon when it's not so busy, unless you like it to be busy of course. we ate there and the food was fine. Just the usual precautions needed in a extra busy city area, but I never felt worried, the people were friendly. Lots of walking involved so plenty of water/drinks needed which you can buy there.

Scary. if you are rich filthy rich go there other wise don't ! Don't talk to other people they want your money you are nothing but white money bag for them not all moroccoan are like that just the shopkeepers it's very easily to get lost gps wont help you no reception don't go there after midnight you will get robed and raped both male and female are subject to assault no police to help you ...

Just get ready to barter. The Souk, oh the Souk, where does it start where does it end. They say 400 you say 40, you agree at 80, an experience not to be missed. Get lost in it, dont be afraid to say no, and in the end pay a person 40d to find your way back to the sq :)

Worth a visit. We went to the soul as the sun was setting it looked beautiful, people didn't pester as much as some had said didn't like the snake charmers although that is part of it have a phobia of snakes also thought it was cruel to see monkeys dressed in clothes and wearing a nappy

Lose yourself and enjoy. Brillant experience! Don't worry about where you are, just lose yourself and enjoy the life of souks. Prepare yourself to enter an ocean of colours and textures, to meet amazing people and experience the kindness of Berber and Arab people, to bargain on everything (your initial offer usually must be ⅓ of the price asked by the merchant), and to buy exotic and amazing things. Learn to bargain, it will take time and patience, and learn to say NO. You can easily spend an entire day. Talk to the herborists and visit the tanneries.Please don't buy wild animals (alive or death) or its parts, many of the animals offered at the souks are threatened. If you buy wild animals or its parts, you are contributing to their extinction.

Better than I expected. Covered streets so that you don't feel the heat, clean markets and a very positive attitude of all the shopkeepers made this a really great experience I wasn't expecting much but it really grew on meI would suggest letting your feet find their wanderlust and spending a day "being with the place" - it will give you memories for a lifetime

One of the worlds greatest markets. Wow, so stimulating of all the senses--sight with colors and textures, sounds, and smells. Really seems like a movie set. Try not to rush. Take it in one day and come back to buy if you can. So so many things you will want later--slippers, jellaba, pottery, glasses and spices. If you can handle it, check out the chickens....

place where you can buy everything. Some of the stuff you buy there it's in really good price- very cheap. But as a tourist from abroad you will be paying much more then Moroccan tourists. you will be in a center of attention as you have money to spend. they will make you buy stuff you don't really need, telling you its a good price. you might get this guys around you who knows best shops for leather, herbs, jewelry etc - these guys are paid by the shops to bring you there. i had actually good experience with a guy who brought me to a "fairly cheap" jewelry store. was waiting around while i was shopping then showed me another store with tea pots. not sure though if i didn't overpaid for these goods, as year before everything was much much cheaper.

GO WITH A GUIDE. The souks of Marrakech are interesting to see, but definitely go with a guide. If you go solo, people will constantly harass you to get you to go into their shops, and will try to get you lost by telling you streets are closed so you can't find your way, and they will offer to get you un-lost for a heavy price. Hire and official guide from your hotel and all of this nuisance disappears.
Wild. Though I prefer the souks of Fes, Marrakech is highly entertaining. Just be open to adventure and go in with a good sense of humour!

The Ultimate Berber Cultural Experience. This is why people go to Marrakesh. best after dark. take care though of your bag and take lots of small change for the performers. DO NOT GIVE TO THE BEGGARS. If you do you risk being hounded. Street performers everywhere, street food and cafe culture round the square with good toilets, many with panoramic balconies on first or second floors. Women should not go alone unless streetwise. We found a mixed group of four worked very well but ladies should be aware of who is standing behind them and where their hands are!! If you feel sorry for the poor and destitute, arrange for a donation through your hotel reception to a local charity.

I loved it!. Marrakech Souk transported back in time and felt like I was just a character came alive from Arabian Nights. Though there are shops in the souk that are like others but the vibe all together is nothing that can be comparable. We went through the back alleys and saw artisans doing what they are best at doing with crazy amount of devotion and dedication.

Be prepared.. Like many first time visitors to Marrakech souks / market it seems quite over bearing. I have been to many places where as a tourist you are targeted by sellers and merchants to buy their goods but never hounded so much as in this place. I'm all for the thrill of haggling over prices for local goods but things got a bit too much.The worst of it was being suddenly approached by someone being friendly and offering you help you didn't need. They tell you that you may be interested in an leather auction which is just down the street and give you directions ( misleading of course). A bit further on some else takes over to show you the way then another person, who just happens to be going in your direction takes over. In the end you are bounced around the souks and end up being herded though the gates of the Tannery or a shop where the hard sell begins. They have it down to a fine art. Although I would say that there was no aggressiveness and nobody is forcing you, as a tourist you don't want offend peoples offers of help and you MUST be firm when saying no. Also be aware of people who offer you something and say 'take this for free' as 10 minutes later the will appear in front of you demanding payment.Be aware of coming out of your hotel / Riad and being approached by someone claiming to work there and wanting to show you a good restaurant or shop, again you will be led to somewhere you don't want to be.Now having said all this you can still enjoy the place as it is a must. Just stay calm keep a mental note of places you pass incase you feel lost. Go sit on one of the terrace cafés and watch everything going on and chill. You can get an official guide from your hotel to help you. They will still take you to all the places in the souks and certain shops ( slippers, bags and herbalist) but you wont be hounded as much and it gives you a little more confidence. Good luck.

Great wondering around . Just remember you are in a different country. It is a market with locals and it is great. We spent the day. Shopped. Lunch. More tagine. More shopping or at least looking Loved every minute. I have been to better but have been to worse too. You should go if not for an hour.

Ladybrith. First time there, the stalls in the souks may be overwhelming. After a while, you will realise they all sell pretty much the same stuff. Always bargain. Do not show any signs that you really wanted the goods. Spend some time to compare not just prices but quality. They will always push some low quality goods with a high price before dishing out the good stuff! It is nice to get 'lost' in the Souks and you will be amazed where you will walked passed. Maximum 2 days is enough for me to walk around the Souks to look for things to buy.

Sensory overload but an absolute must on your "To do" list!. If you visit Marrakech, you really have to experience this place. I will try and offer advice based on my own recent experience. 1 Allow yourself several visits. Do not buy anything on your first visit. Once you've been a couple of times, you'll have seen the items you want in several stalls and can then decide where you want to haggle. Believe me, you WILL see that item in more than one place.2 If you wear a backpack, use small padlocks on it. Pickpockets are rife here. My fiancé got his camcorder deftly removed from the outermost pocket of his backpack. Lesson learnt the hard way.3 You will get lost. There's no way round it. Locals have even spray painted false directions to the main square and removed signage to disorientate you. Use your common sense - try to find noise, lots of people and you're generally not far away. Quiet lanes with Riads are usually a sign you're wandering away from the area. Be aware that young local lads will offer to assist you with directions. Don't follow them - they will take you a merry dance and elongated detour and then ask for money. Politely decline and use your own judgement.4 Haggling. Its obligatory! There's maybe only a couple of shops with fixed prices. If bartering doesn't appeal to you, then the souk isn't for you. Have a price in your head you would pay for your item and don't go over it. Most of the time, if you can't agree, the shopkeeper will often run after you and try to re-negotiate. Keep it light-hearted, have a bit of banter and it can be quite enjoyable.5 Harrassment. You won't get ten feet in the souks without someone wanting your business or money. When you stop for a coffee break, make yourself walk those extra few steps up to the terrace rooftops of the square cafes- its worth it for the view, people watching, and you'll get a reprieve from the constant bombardment of men trying to sell you mobile phones, ornaments, paper hankies etc! When walking through the souks, walk briskly. The most useful phrase you'll be able to say is "La Shoukran" (phonetic Arabic for "No thank you"). If you look at anything, or worse still, lift an item up, the shopkeeper will go in for the kill and expect a sale. If you don't buy, you are quite often cursed as you leave the shop. 6 Safety. Keep your wits about you. Locals zoom up and down even the narrowist of the lanes on motorbikes with very little notice or room to manoeuvre out of the way. All in all its a rollercoaster ride. Quite exhausting in some respects. Take your time to take it all in, take plenty café stops to re-energise and re-hydrate and go for it full pelt! Very much a marmite experience, its one you won't forget. Who knows, you might even get that elusive bargain and great keepsake for bringing home.

An experience for sure. You will get lost in the souks, but don't worry about it, just adk for the square and somebody will direct you. You name it you can buy it, some if it tacky some of it reasonable. Be prepared to barter. As everyone says start by knocking a third off, if you walk away they will come after you. If you like it - get it. I had to constantly remind myself that 80 dh although sounds a lot is just over £5! Everyone wants you to look at their stuff, just be polite but firm and say non Merci takes a bit of getting used to though and the constant hassling you get can be a bit tiresome. They are lovely people trying to earn a living and rely on tourists.The noise, smells, dust, people, items for sale, (ranging from teeth, clothes, leather bags, jewellery, spices etc) donkeys pulling over laden carts, and mopeds galor all add to the experience. An absolute must do.
Just a dump. Food covered in flies, excrement in the streets, don't bother there's nothing nice about this place. People try to rob you constantly.

Noisy, Exciting and great fun!!!. We walked to the Square and Souk in Marrakech from our hotel, it was very easy to find. The best time of day to go is the early evening onwards. The photographs you will see do not convey the hussle and bussle of the square where you will see snake charmers, boxing, fortune tellers, somersaulting monkeys and the most amazing street food. The throb of the drums and the music make it a magical experience! The souk is fascinating, where you can buy all sorts! Spices, pottery, leather goods, local clothing and just about everything else! Be prepared to barter heavily, they start at the craziest of prices, and you can usually pay about third of that.. Be prepared to walk away, they want the business, so they will follow you! The average wage, I was told was about €300 per month, so bear that in mind.. A fantastic experience!!

Excellent but... impossible to choose your items without being hassled all the time.... That's Marrakesh souk... I know. And I have already been there 5 years ago. So... no surprises at all... But if owners would stop hassling, I think it would be way better. 'Cause I went away from some shops only because the owner was starting to insist, so I could not take a serious look at what I was trying to buy. Anyway... Wonderful handicrafts everywhere: amazing amazing amazing place. :)

60,000 stalls in Souks. Very busy with motor bikes cycles,donkey, carts all weaving around you as you shop. not suitable for small children or pushchair. Lots of haggling,Great fun easy to get lost but don't get a guide cos they take you to their mates stalls and charge too much, Very Hot

A hectic and enjoyable place for shopping. The souks of Marrakech is an ideal place for shopping enthusiasts who like to haggle. This area in the Medina is a little less hot than the rest of the city. You can find lots of exotic goods here: Wooden items and figurines, musical instruments, tea and spices, slippers and shoes, leather bags and belts, lamps and lots of other stuff. Be prepared for lots of shopkeepers wanting your attention, lots of people wanting to sell you their products, and for lots of fun and good stories to tell when you come back home. The prices stated by the shopkeepers are way too high, so you have to aim for at least half what they're asking, preferably less than that. Do a search here at TripAdvisor or Google to get an idea of what reasonable prices for the items are. It's a good feeling when you close a deal (even though you still might be paying a little too much) :-) Lots of the shopkeepers have very similar items, so if you don't get a reasonable price, simply walk away and you'll find another shopkeeper somewhere else, where you can get a better price. Haggling is really enjoyable here when you get the hang of it!The souks are a maze within a maze within a maze, and it's surprisingly easy to get lost. If you have a smartphone, simply get a free offline map app which uses the phone's GPS. Problem solved!

Interesting place, but don't buy anything of any value. The souk is an interesting place to visit as part of a tour of Marrakech, but the place is littered with fakes and ripoffs. Even if your haggling skills are good, you will be ripped off. You are better going to a supermarket where the prices are fixed. Places like Acima or Marjane are your best bet when buying candle holders, argane oil and other touristic items. Saying that, no trip to Marrakech is complete without having a glass of orange juice near the souks and watching the action in Djemaa El Fna square

Everything a souk should be. If you go to Marrakech you can't avoid the souks. It's a full on experience that's not to be missed. But it's also pretty full on. Don't freak out. Do sensible things. Look out for motorbikes and donkeys. Keep your bag away from the roadside. Ask at kiosks for directions - strange men and groups of boys will offer to help you and they may or they may get you hopelessly lost and demand cash. Don't forget to haggle but accept gracefully that you will pay more than the locals will - as long as you are happy with the price, be content that you got a bargain. Most of all, relax and go with it. It's exciting and fun. And you'll find great things and experiences.
Amazing. Everytime in Marrakech it is worthwhile strolling thru the maze of shops and narrow pathways - exotic, interesting and vibrant - make sure you go there at different times of the day

Loads of fun. Be prepared to haggle in the souks, and to walk away if you're not interested in something. You'll soon find out if the price you're offering isn't what they're after.
