Cool after being in the squares, the souks are a great way to spend a day (or two, or three!) if you love shopping. Don't keep to the main streets but veer off where anything interesting looks like it's taking place ... we went to the iron making area - more untidy than my house!!

The Souks of Marrakesh will test you in ways you never imagined.. If haggling over prices is not to your liking shopping in a Marrakesh Souk will be self inflicted cruelty. The merchants here expect you to haggle and delight in it. They can size you up faster than a speeding bullet and you'll realize that they know your purchasing tolerances better than you know them. This is a shopping experience like no other !

Number 1 attraction. Aren't the souks the main reason people come to Marrakech or did I miss something? This crazy vibrant place where you can buy old or new and authentic Morrocan things. It has to rival any market in the world. Any must for any visitor.
experience the souks. need to experience the trip but make sure you go on an organised one. the pharmacy is a must if you like beauty creams oils and spices
Another World. Incredible watching this all being set up - watch from high up in one of the cafes / bars. A major problem around the winding alleys is pollution from mopeds gets on your chest.

Souk it and see. We're used to minimal contact with sales staff in the UK, but stallholders here will show you how to tie a scarf or explain how they dye their wool and are always keen to make a sale. Be prepared to haggle politely or just say 'pas aujourdhui' if not interested. People were helpful if you got lost, but don't let anyone 'show you the way' unless you want to go via all their family and friends' stalls. Great for seeing places you might miss like the blacksmiths in medieval surroundings or wool dyers, but expect to pay the guide especially if you don't buy anything.

great for shopping and bartering. lots of stalls goes on and on, good thing in the day, is that there is shade and you can get a bargain if you are good at bartering and they can be quite hard with the sell but you have to stand your ground with your price you want to pay, you can go up a little if you wish to.

Souk at Night. Over a hundred thousand people decent on a square outside the medina at marrakash to buy, sell, entertain or simply an on looker. This night market or as it is called Souk is a den of many things and one of which is buying and selling of souls. Whether this is true or not there is a need for heighten caution and awareness of the possibility of such intrigue.The food sold in the square at the Souk are home made and re-heated upon arrival. The level of hygiene or lack there of can only be imagined. The service is one of a kind, with food being slapped onto the table in an unprofessional manner. Whilst there are no flies competing for your food, often, used and unwashed cutlery are given to dinners and portions are very small. Ha, yes you can get Moroccan dishes there and the famous mint tea ☕ too. Okay, that said, they really need classes on health and safety or general hygiene. Then the dancers, snake charmers and onlookers. Good entertainment all round if you are not relieved of your wallet. Come early if you must 7pm and make your way through as quickly as possible. And not just the square, but the main market itself is open too at night. There you will get to see the spies pyramids and hand crafted goods. Bargain for the prices at least half of the asking price. Try it, it is therapeutic.

Urban exploration defined!. To get lost in the souks is all part of the experience! Do make sure you walk and keep walking in a straight line and you will eventually get to the metal work souks along with the dyers souls....brilliant fun!

The Souks & Madenas. visited both in the day and then again in the evening. A hussle & bussle place to visit in the day, winding through the different stalls. If you're easily led this is NOT for you, as you may feel pressured into buying something you really don't want. Bartering is a MUST for both fun & experience. A completely different place in the evening, stalls come 'alive'. watch the snake charmers and jugglers, a great experience.if you get lost (and you will) make the tall mosque tower your focal point of right direction.

Authentic. Very authentic experience of the sights, sounds and smells of old Morocco.Traders expect you to haggle - some are more aggressive than others so be vigilant in what you are prepared to pay and when you are prepared to walk away!

Is out of the movies. Is one off the unique and last places in the globe that you have to visit at list ones in your life time. Not to forget to check the food court and specially the Lamb street befor 1pm, is the Mecca for lovers of roasted Baby Lamb.

Nice to have been there, but.... We came to the Souks right before noon, so it was not too crowded. But the constant nagging and haggle is not too my particular taste. It is simply not possible to just stop and look at items at the shops. Beware of the people trying to "guide" you, they´re just pushing you towards some of the stores, and get you inside. Not easy to visit the Souks with a baby troller, but that was expected. Of course a visit to the Souks are mandatory when in Marrakech, but once there, I just wanted to get out. Been there, done that.

Sensory overload. people, shops, and more shops and more eager people to sell you stuff. There are few artisan shops which we really enjoyed. Most of the shops are packed with similar stuff, lots and lots of haggling. A guy asked for MAD 1000 for a necklace and sold it to me for MAD 200, really!!Overall it was very overwhelming for me personally.

No wonder it's a World Heritage Site. Nothing else is like this for the scale and variety. A lot of stalls sell similar items (eg shoes) so shop around. Useful to visit a fixed price centre first to get an idea of what local prices are, then get them for less in the souks. We found 2 centres, one near the Saadian tomb entrance and one near the Koutoubia Mosque.When you're out watch out for people being 'helpful'. They often actively mislead you with directions or saying something is shut when it isn't and still expect small change. We got very good at switching off the automatic politeness mechanism and just blanking everyone that talked to us (works well in the souks and for any unofficial 'guides' too). No offence seemed to be taken and there were no threats.Although data charges were high (£5/day with Vodafone) I used the map function a lot to find specific addresses. A lifesaver in the souks and Kasbah! As always, TripAdvisor's 'near me now' was very useful. Given the low costs of the rest of the holiday I thought it was worth the data charges.

Must do!. Brilliant experienceThe winding, colourful lanes of the souk are enchanting!A must see! We were polite to the owners, sellers and snake charmers and had no issues what so ever! Barter and you can get a bargain!Enjoy

Loads of fun, easy to lose your way -- and your money. Of course if you're in Marrakech you have to spend time in the souk. If you've never seen this sort of bazaar, it's worth a wander, whether you buy anything or not. If you do want to buy, be prepared to bargain. And if you're a Westerner you'll probably spend too much even if you think you're being a hard-nosed haggler.

Happy customers guide to the souk. This is the most magnificient souk in Morocco and my favourite place to shop. You enter from either side of Jemaa el Fna and arrive to souk Semmarine, the high ceilinged main corridor with most expensive shops and all the goods available on show. At the end on left is La Perle Fassie, a large shop with fixed prices under 10 euros selling all kinds os babouches, sheepskin slippers. There are basic and exquisite models, remnants from last season and stock changes constantly. Further on are two monsieurs selling lemonwood kitchen utensils also with prices on show. I like to cook with their perforated laddles, they last for years and make a good present for anyone back home.When you proceed further down the souk prices go down, but in general they are up from last year. Consider if you really want the item before asking how much? to avoid endless discussions.You won't get totally lost if you keep to the streets with shops and people and don't wander to empty alleys. The direction to ask on returning is La Place meaning Jemaa el Fna. People will point you to the right direction, or the opposite, this is magic Marrakech.My favourite items are painted, woodframed mirrors, small handembroidered leather bags, babouches. I have also carried a wooden, painted table home and it goes well with my newest acquisition, a boucharouite, a colourfull berber rug woven with fabrics. The asking price in Tanger was 140 euros, but I got mine in Marrakech for 60 euros back in the souk and didn't even bargain.

Good market experience but has its downside. The market is so beautiful to experience in terms of the stalls and the entertainment (snake charmers, monkey shows, dancers) however be prepared for annoyed stall owners who get angry and may curse you if you're not interested in buying or going to their stalls. My husband was called a bad man because he declined an invite to a stall. We worked out that if you try not to give eye contact to anyone you will enjoy the market more. Snake charmers do not like you taking pictures without paying them something after - we were told to delete photos unless we paid the man, which was worth the money as I got to hold a snake and watch a cobra do a little show. This is also the best place to get a horse and carriage ride around the local area which is so relaxing - try to haggle the price!

Expect to get lost ..Very lost !!. Been to Marrakech several times, and must admit one of the main draws is to visit the Souks again. It is Vast ! and their is no way once in them to find you way out, which is all part of the fun !. Guaranteed when you do find your way out you will have bags of purchases from the haggling street vendors! Well worth a visit :)

A must see. Getting lost in the Souk is a tourists obligation!! A chaotic mix of Moroccan life. Watch out for the bicycles, scooters and laden donkeys carrying goods in and out of the narrow allies. Beware of locals offering to take you anywhere, they expect payment and will tell you anything to get you to follow.If you want a good fixed price choice hear to the Ensemble Artisan on Mohammed V1 avenue, we found fab leather sandals for 100 dirham, and no haggling. A good choice of quality clothing and cheaper than the Souk and Bazaar.

souky super. Stand by, this is for real, get your haggling head on and have a laugh, dont get intimidated, just let them know whios boss, i love this Souk, can be scarry first time, go in a group and stick together until your familiar with the toutimg tactics, you can get a bargin but you have to be prepared to sell your "mother" and plead poverty, plat the locals at there own game, amazing at night, again go in a group and dont forget to have a drink on top of one of the open roof resteraunts overlooking the souk, square etc, it amazing. PS do not go in dressed up with watches, bracelets, neclaces etc, you will stick out, and dont buy something you dont want, there are tourist police about if it gets to heated.

GET CARRIED AWAY. Entering the souk you must NEVER think about directions or try to find your way by help of a map. Enjoying shopping in the souk just "get carried away" and stay for hours. The traders are all extremely friendly and if you need to find your way out, they will asist you.You always get a better deal on your own than accompanied by forrenstens a guide.Negotiate with a smile - this is the way it must be done - and you will find odd things, beautiful things and different things. Items that cost next to nothing and antique items of great value. Have cash on you but the more exquisite shops accept credit cards.

Souk. We'll worth a trip we went on our own in the day which is quieter than in the evening we went with rep at night had pony and trap ride into Marrakech it's a sea of people good stalls loads of market traders take note of ladies doin hand henna before u can blink she will have done your hand so just say no thankyou and walk off be prepared to barter or walk off there is always another stall with same thing I wouldn't advise. Going at night without a tour guide there are that many little alleyways have fun

another world. My wife and I visited the souk with a guide, passing thru it to get to the main square.It was an eye opener!! We had read the reviews but nothing prepares you for this,every sense is attacked at the same time, How anyone finds their way about I can only wonder, its a maze of sights sounds and smells. If you show interest in any thing your captured, do your best to be polite and smile no thanks.Don,t be offended if some of the shop owners pass remarks as you leave.Some of the goods on sale are unique,especially the metal workers fascinating to watch.I could have spent hours in fact days wondering around this incredible arena of life!I recommend it to anyone who wants to experience North African Magic.

Great fun but not for serious shopping. The atmosphere is great and just what you might expect from and Arab market. Hustle and bustle and pestering salesmen. But it is safe and friendly. You can probably buy everything g cheaper at IKEA or John Lewis but what the hell; for small cheaper items this is much more fun. You are guaranteed to get lost!

Do Not Go Without a Guide, But be Aware. The souks are worth the visit and are very good for wood carvings, leather, berber products and spices and it's great fun bargaining. But go with a recommended guide booked from you hotel. They can take you to the best artisans and you can save time from aimless wandering a getting lost, unless that's your intent. Expect that they get a cut even though they help you with the negotiation. Even so, every guide we booked in Morocco took us to a rug dealer, one time even when specifically stated we didn't want to see one. Unless you're seriously in the market for carpets do not stay long or accept an offer of tea or you will be there forever as layers of carpets are spread out and you are relentlessly harassed to buy. It is NOT a good experience, even if you specify you simply want to learn Berber technique and pattern. They expect you to buy and peeling off a sticky merchant as you edge to the door is like harvesting abalone with an iron tool.And if you think you can find rug merchant relief in Rabat, Fes , Chefchaouen or Tangier, forget about it.

Unthreatening; great fun; the heart of Marrakesh. Why am I not surprised that a contributor who calls herself Lolita felt unsafe? Although admittedly almost certainly somewhat older, I went with a group of 6 girlfriends and we had a fab time. We never felt uncomfortable or threatened and found the traders friendly and helpful. More than once they put us back on the right path when we were lost (which is mandatory and part of the whole experience). Take the whole thing in the right spirit and you will be fine; enjoy bargaining; joke back with them; say hello and walk on with a smile rather than ignore them; and don't believe them when they say the museum is closed. After all if it's good enough for Bill Clinton, it's good enough for you (he brushed past us with his entourage in the lighting section).

Great experience. We experienced the souks in a group with a guide and it was fantastic. So much to see at every turn, the smells, colours, sounds, theres is so much to take in. I loved seeing how the people that live there did there everyday things, the communal ovens, the eateries and how they made a living making and selling there wares. We got too see so much, a real eye opener. As I said we were with a guide and I think this is why we enjoyed it so much as he knew where to go and it felt very safe being in a group ect.

Literally mental, got lost so many times!. Everything looks the same so it's so easy to get lost, don't let people direct you as most of the time they will want a fee. It can be scary when ur lost but it's all part of the fun and the experience -take a deep breathe and go for it!!

What I expected. Really not as intimidating as might have expected in some reviews that I have read. Just need to use common sense and don't put yourself at risk by carrying valuables and be respectful of their standards of dress. They are trying to make a living like any other market around the world but haggling over the price is all part of the experience if one does descide to buy something. There is plenty of choice with tons of stalls, many just for the tourist, just enjoy the place and use common sence.

Very unsafe. Traveling there as a single women was very unsafe. Also the Riad I stayed was the worst. Traveling as a women you experience a lot of harassment and the men are very disrespectful, but mostly from the expats that live there, for example a lot of the French expats that own the Riads. I wouldn't recommend going there alone or with a group of girlfriends. It's kinda dangerous. I experienced a bad situation there and I would never recommended to any of my friends. Beware! And they try to ripped you offa lot! Never again!
Nice experience have fun bargaining.. Lots of shops varieties of goods great fun if you like to bargain.Have to really remember Your way or you might get lost,good place to buy souvenirs .

Be prepared. We made a mistake of trusting a taxi driver to take us to the main square and ended up at his cousins rug shop. It was morning and I was glad it was not at night as it is intimidating . You can easily get lost in the alley ways where donkeys and motorbikes are the mode of transport . People will volunteer to guide you but you will probably end up at another family members shop. You are experiencing how people live and survive and I wouldn't consider it as just another tourist attraction. The people are respectful and yet they need to live by selling so expect a little harassment . Also, ladies be respectful and cover up and as in any hustle and bustle protect your valuables. An experience but not one I would probably repeat.

What an experience. The shopping is fantastic but remember to haggle! It is in their nature and don't be afraid to walk away as you will find the same item further into the Souks! Got some good bargains but were hassled a little bit by boys trying to give us directions then demanding money! Just tell them you are fine and to go away as they are pests!

The most over-rated market. As the title says, I think this is the most over-rated market I've ever visited. It's smelly and dangerous. While walking through you will have to dodge and avoid being run over by motorcycles and donkey carts. I went with my 4 year old and constantly had to get her to walk on the inside as she'd otherwise be hard to see by the endless onslaught of vehicles. The amount of times she jumped thinking she's about to get run over was too many to count.Do not eat here unless you want food poisoning. Food was covered in flies and bugs. One time we saw a dessert place that had hundreds of wasps all over the biscuits. On our way back, we passed the same place and the wasps were all gone; I'm sure others would be none the wiser and buy.The only positive is that you can sometimes see people making goods which is interesting. Despite that, you will find a lot of fakes. For example, Argan oil 10 times cheaper than in the pharmacies. Many times we were told to avoid buying fake goods in the souks by taxi drivers and other Morrocans.By all means, make a trip but be prepared to be disappointed; it isn't the best market experience.
Busy. It is a busy place and ensure you go in groups. Good value for money is you know what you want but not so good if you just want to browse.

Amazing. It's a colorful bustling Souk and no only spending on the exotic items, you can also see how they are made.. the leather dying, carving and turned into a bag... the steel being cut and bent into lamps and threads being dyed and made into shawls.. exciting and learnt so much.. the place is huge so let's get lost... love love this place so much!

Bonkers!. A maze of people selling their wares to make a living. You will get lost,take a compass and just keep walking.Haggle hard if there's something you want.. We were advised pay no more than a third of what they ask, so you need to start lower than that still.It worked for us and it was fun. They won't sell to you if they are not making a profit. A friendly smile and lots of "non merci" works wonders. Better value goods than the fixed price Complex Artisanal.

A must see!. This is probably the most adventurous thing you can do in the city! The colors and scents are mesmerizing and don't even try to go into a souk without expecting a conversation with the shop owner who will tell you that he will "make you a good price" for whatever you are interested in. Golden rule: never pay any more than what you think something is worth. Rule of thumb: pay no more than a third of what is being asked...and most of all, have fun - because it is just that!

An experience for sure!. I had read reviews before we went to Marrakech about how you should ignore the sellers as much as possible and have to say that for your sanity, this is the way to go! Just walking through the souks can be exhausting and the best way to deal with it is to walk past and just shake your head and/or hold up your hand in front of you and shake it. Having said that though, it really is the experience of a lifetime - there are places like it but nowhere the same. The people have very little and just trying to make a living however they can and keeping this in mind does help when the calling is relentless. Soak it up, roll with it and just be aware that most conversations will lead to a hard sell
Souks are Amazing. Totally amazing experience. Enlightens every sense. The souks have been cleaned up in past couple of years so it is now an extremely safe and enjoyable experience.

Take some money!!! Fun, fun, fun!!. I love love the things i brought back!! I got a rug, a lamp, and some little camels, some Moroccan slippers. I would definitely not find that in Europe!! You have to haggle!!! Many shops can even send you, your things through DHL if what you bought is too big. The market people are very big on "keeping their word" so you can trust that your deliveries will make it. Our rug was delivered to our Hotel and that made things easier! I loved the market, i wish i would have bought more slippers! lol :D

Disgusting for those that don't like to haggle. The souk smelled, it was dirty and I felt so harassed by all the begging to buy something. I had a hard time embracing the whole experience. I also didn't like the Cobras and monkeys in the square that smelled heavily of urine. I won't be coming back.

Not worth it . Visited once here, I like a haggle as much as the next person, but to be fair it's all tat and low quality goods.So many people offering to'guide' you...at a price!!which they'll tell you at the end !!, it's VERY easy to get very lost in here !Being part of the hustle and bustle of the locals is good to see ...that's where it ends, don't be sucked in by so called guides and go back the way you came is my advice x

Honesty is the best policy. I loved my stay in Marrakech - and enjoyed the trip to the souks - however if you get uncomfortable with being harassed from start to finish in the centre then go with a day trip a bigger group is better in some ways - we got lost on several occasions - which was fun the first time but the locals know a lost person when they see one and take pleasure in capitalising on this. But just keep your whits about you and you'll be fine - just make sure you polite and you will be fine

the same old Tat!!!. You just have to go, but it is all just a pile of tourist junk. Some very clever trades people clearly, but haggle!!!Alleyway after alleyway of stalls selling basically the same stuff, stall after stall. Trinkets made from stone, wood, spice or cloth.

A Must Visit, Amazing sights and friendly People. I was not sure I wanted to visit Souks after visiting other countries and the pushy sales technic I was dreading it, but could not have been more wrong.The people are friendly and happy for you just to look, its a win some you lose some view, which was really refreshing.Once you have shown intent to buy they will hagal well and we were told could get them down to 30% of original price.Its a maze of different soukes, with lovely smells and amazing sights.its a must on a visit to Marrakech.

Souk Shopping. Do not take the overpriced tours offered by tour reps at the hotel. They rush you through the souk and then "trap" you in an expensive souvenir store. Most hotels have a free coach service to the souk and you are quite safe. The shop owners speak several languages and they expect you to barter down to less than half the original price they offer. If you get lost, there are plenty of other tourists around and shop owners will always point the way to the main square where you can pick up your hotel coach or get a taxi. You can also hire a horse and carriage, but confirm the price before getting in.There are some excellent "buys" in the souk. Spices are very reasonably priced; sandals, leather goods and handbags are good value, but you must barter in a friendly, smiley way. A great shopping experience.

Madness. This place hasnt changed in hundreds of years, hundreds of twisting alleys lead you from one delight to another, although at times you fell lost you are never far from the main square. Yes, you get approached and invited to look a lot,but it is never aggressive like I have experienced in other parts of the world, just say no thanks and they will leave you alone. Haggling is a MUST, the locals expect it and its all part of the game!.In the evening is when it all happens though, the sights/smells/noise is really stunning, just wander around and see all the different foods on offer, stop and sample!!. Lots to see and photograph/film, top tip, if you snap pics of the entertainers give them 5/10 dirhams, it is after all how they make a living! try the fresh orange juice, very cheap and refreshing on a hot day.A fantastic experience that you will never forget or regret!

excellent but a guid e is highly recommended. living mess of cratfs shops everywhere... a pure maze within the city ... you want somebody that know its way around! Of course the tour guide qill make you go in predesiganted shops which he has some arrangements with (like any othe place in the world) but you can end up in a prttey shop so why not?!
Learn to say NO. Beautiful and interesting place.A bit smelly and dirty in places.Too many touts hassling you to buy things.Learn to say NO to everything.

FORGET HARRODS. The Souk in Marrakech is like being in the movie Casablanca,apart from the techno shops it is probably the same as it ever was.The hustle & bustle is so dynamic & once you get into the swing of it you are on a roller coaster ride.The majority of westerners are terrified at first just like in India,but once you embrace the vibe you are on your way.Watches,Phones,Bags,Shoes,Jewellry,i could go on & on about the bargains to be picked up.The prices are embarrassingly low & if you like your hippy gear then wham bam. In the evening the Souk takes on a magical vista as the musicians come out & the proper food goes on sale & its party time. I was here in the 60s when the Stones took over the place,not much has changed thank god.In short,Marrakech & the Souk in particular are a must visit for anyone with a bit of imagination,let the chip eaters go to Majorca,get on down to Marrakech & live a little.Enjoy.

brilliant. if you enjoy haggleing and bargaining, enjoy quaint little stores and shops, lots of lovely smells, and very friendly people then you need to visit here every day!!! i loved it, all the little winding streets, one woluld end up infront of a big religious site, another would open to a main street and another to a indoor souk!!! but dont worry about getting lost, you always end up out in the main area and can get directions from anyone!!! loved it!

Lots of twisting alleyways through this area - take photos on your way to find your way back. It's different by day and by night, best time to get there is after lunch, find your way around the stalls, barter for everything (at least two thirds off to start with) and walk away if the price doesn't suit you. Sometimes they run after you, sometimes not, but you'll find usually find the same piece you wanted in at least 3/4 other places so have a good look around before you buy. Nice to find a terrace seat at a cafe and watch the sun go down then go looking at all the stalls that are cooking plain but sometimes weird stuff, up to you if you eat it!

Looking is for free. But that's it.. We have been in the medina for 5 days now and have not yet tired of walking through the various souks mazes of alleyways and multitudinous shops. One thing we have learned is not to be pressured into buying (or looking or anything else). They say looking is for free (over and over and over again), however, when you walk past the shop more then once, they can be quite pestering and in some cases harrassing and rude. A downright nuisance as we're here a month and the souks are the coolest and shadiest way to get to the big square for us. This does not deter us as most are genuinely happy to show you their wares - so long as you are aware you are simply a wallet-on-legs to the vendors. Don't be fooled by the usual scams - the classic is saying only 10 dirhams (which is about 1 euro) for a belt for instance - and they will be very clear about it. Right up until you show the slightest interest and it will become 10 euros (or pounds or whatever) - you will so no, they will argue, follow you, wrap the belt around you. Do not give in - it just encourages them to use the same tosh on the next tourist. Resist your inate pesky western politeness and move on. If they won't take the belt back, drop it on the ground. Also don't be conned by Berber (or Touareg or Tribal) silver. That's what they make pipes from back home. Would you pay 25 euros (or 40 euros for that matter) for polished tin? Nope. Move on. In short, there are lovely, lovely handcrafted things in the souks, but develop your peripheral vision, walk slowly - look without looking and only if you are particularly keen on something should you show interest. Or just go your own way - you'll figure out the system soon enough you little mobile ATM you.

A maze. The souks, because there are more than one, are located off the main square in the Medina.They are in narrow laneways with grouping of shop together, ie the live chickens are together, the olives are together etc etc.There is constant offers to sell you something however from my experience it wasn't pressure selling, just trying to get your attention.Haggling is the way of life and you need to make sure your interests are looked after but I suggest that you only negotiate if you really want to buy.The soaks are a maze and you can stumble on many different things. Certainly different from a shopping mall.

Full on but fun. Weirdly, the souks reminded me a lot of the tourist district in Kathmandu. The same small, winding streets crammed full of open fronted shops people trying to sell you things. They even stock some of the same things!Once you get used to the way business is done, shopping in the souks can be a lot of fun. I personally really enjoy haggling, although it can take a bit of getting used to, especially when someone acts like you've mortally offended them by naming such a low price. A quarter or a third of the stated price is usually a good place to start (unless it's already very cheap), but keep in mind that you only need to haggle to a price you're happy with - don't make the process too stressful! You can probably find what you're looking for elsewhere when it comes down to it. Also, go further into the souks/down little side streets as you can usually get a better price in the less easily accessed places.Shopping aside, the souks are fun just to wander around in. The sheer amount of things for sale is astonishing, and I really enjoyed just looking into shops. The more relaxed you are about people trying to get you into their shop/make a sale, the nicer the experience is. Downsides are that you can get a bit lost, so try and find a map with an enlarged view of the souks and have shops you can use as landmarks. The sheer volume of people can be a bit stressful too, especially when you throw motorcycles and animals into the mix. Also, be careful you're not being sold a cheap/faulty item - do some reading first if you can. Overall though, the souks are definitely worth exploring.

what a ride. what a ride and even more full on at night, street food, entertainment shopping and more dodgemeisters than you can shake a stick at. Forget using Google earth inside the souk use a gps compass and a map or Nokia 'here' gps maps worked reasonably well for me. Buy a Morocco telecom data card (60 DHS for 4 GB) and 7 days and use data location for peanuts as well.If the Moroccan police would like to use the spotting services of my wife and I to clear Jemma square of the prolific number of thieves and dodgemiesters, we can do it for you in one night.....they are that obvious. So why cant the Moroccan police ??????

Friendly Haggle. The Souk is amazingly unthreatening and amusing place full of banter and good humour but there is a code one must observe, once one has agreed a final price one must pay it. We loved bargaining and purchased an great range of well made items including made to measure shoes, exquisite necklaces and rugs. We were particularly lucky to find a talented jewelary designer with a great eye also for fabrics and rugs in one of the courtyards off the main lane through the Souk. He is Aziz at 70 Rue Dar et Bach Condom Kharbouch Shop 13.

Overwhelming. I found the Souk to be a thoroughly overwhelming experience - the sights, smells, sounds. Bewildering and to be honest, I didn't enjoy it. Felt like everyone was trying to con us out of money. Like if you ask for directions, next thing you find yourself being bundled along by a person to a destination you may not have been aiming for and then the "helpful" person requests money for their efforts. You have to have very good boundaries and if you are a lady, perhaps try and ask other ladies for directions etc. Easy to get lost - take a good map. Would recommend staying away from the Tannery if you don't have a strong stomach for bad smells. I do and I barely kept my breakfast down. I was just in the Souk for half a day but I have been advised that if you give it more time, it grows on you.

Dont bother with a guide. We visited the souk twice - once with a guide and once without.When we went with the guide, we were shepherded to carpet shops and pharmacies - which we weren't interested in - and we felt very uncomfortable and pressured.We went back the next day, and the shop owners were so very different towards us - much less pushy and more friendly - and we had no trouble getting lost as all the locals were very helpful.If you don't want to buy something just keep saying no.

An assualt on the senses !. A wonderful experience on all fronts. The atmosphere is electric the noise deafening , dancers , musicians , jokers and snake charmers are everywhere but be prepared to pay for pictures you take of them about 3 Dhms for each one but well worth it. The food stalls are great about 40 of them and all competing with each other for your custom, you sit on long benches choose your food it is cooked and bought to you and so cheap ! The market sells almost everything but be prepared to barter which is half the fun and when you have had enough wander over to one of the coffee shops and soak up the atmosphere. But please do not be an uneducated tourist , resist having your picture taken with one of the monkeys exploited cruelly for tourists.

Bring lots of money!. I love Marrakesh and the hustle and bustle of the souk but it may not be for everyone. You do have to be firm if you don't want to buy and i just generally walk away saying no thank you. Be careful of the henna ladies, they will grab you and put henna on and then try and charge. With bartering go to half of what they ask and don't go up from that too much. The food was great, we ate at the street stalls that are set up in the evening, good food and a cheap price too.

HUSTLE & BUSTLE WITH PEOPLE AND MOTOR BIKES. Interesting, beware of cheap tourist gifts and brush up on your bartering skills. --- A tip, if they ask for 500dms the lowest they will go is about half of that so you respond with 200dms then bargin (if its worth it) and settle for a figure between!!Its crowded so watch your pockets, although they are generally honest people.You can get the same stuff cheaper in other markets in town as the Souks are generally tourist attractions.

Row after row of the same cheap tat. The place goes on forever. It reminds me of a scruffier version of the Grand Bazaar in Istanbul. As per the title, it's mostly row after row of the same leather goods, lampshades, spices and clothes. It's worth a visit though - have fun bartering, paying maybe a bit more than you should've then feeling satisfied knowing that maybe you grabbed yourself a bargain - but really, there's a lot of tat in there.

giid. Vibrant, colourful and very interesting place to visit so much to see and do. The market stalls are wonderful but do barter with them. The snake charmers are great to see, there are some snakes can be held and you can have your photo taken with them if you are brave enough.

Well worth a visit but don't pay much. This has got to be done and was a cultural experience. Its easy to get lost but also easy to find your way out, just ask someone on a shop and ask if 'its that way or that way' so they have a choice as they do not like to appear unhelpful. Beware of anyone trying to 'guide' you as they want money, just say you have been loads of times and know where you are and smile and they go off happily. Barter hard as the same thing is on the next million stalls and you can get a deal further on. The bartering is good natured and part of the experience.

Shopping paradise. I went to Marrakesh with a friend, and we spent a lot of time shopping in the Souk. You can have really great things here. If you are into interior decoration, this is definitely a place you want to visit, and all at very reasonable prices. Although remember that what looks nice and fantastic in Morroccan environments may not look the same in your living room in your house in.. Denmark..:D. Recommandations to buy: Lanterns, Fossiles (at your own risk), huge round dish /tables made of tin, perhaps a tagine and Spices. Remember to haggle and buy more luggage space for the flight home! ;D
Fun to haggle. Busy worth the experience. Haggle you can really get some bargains. Eat out experience the real Marrakech.

Hustle and bustle. The souk and medina of Marrakech are full of history, mystery, smells (good and bad), sounds, sights, colors. Very stimulating and exciting. Definitely wouldn’t miss it. But keep your wits about you. It is a maze and fun for that reason, but then you can also get tired and lost and cranky before suddenly you are at a familiar intersection and can find your way home. You will inevitably find yourself solicited, offered a deal too good to beat, paying more than you ought to, but much less (lets face it) than you would for similar goods in Europe or America. Go with the flow. Bargain for it and do not be afraid to walk away, because then you will get the price you want. Sure, there’s stupid tourist crap, just like in Times Square in NYC, but you’ll know it when you see it, so it’s easy to avoid if you want to. And try the fresh juices in the square! They are delicious.

Colourful Chaos. The Souks were not as scary as referred as far as you don't point out and show too much interest in the wares. If you like something you need to bargain like a pro the prizes are 3 times higher than other places.We observed that initially when the shops are just opened the vendors are not very aggressive so that is the best time to shop as the day proceeds they start getting very aggressive.You will find beautiful jewellery, lamps, bags, shoes and spices here. The souk food is s must have. We ate at Shop no 1 and it was lip smacking.Yes there are crazy snake charmers, monkeys and watermen on the streets but as far as you stay away they won't trouble you. But remember nothing is free here if somebody helps you they expect you to pay.You could sit on the terraces of the hotels of the square and enjoy beautiful sunset if tired of roaming.Overall a nice experience

A whole different world. Utter Madness yes worth the trip. It is chaos heightened and one must be alert to all that is going on around you. The sounds, smells, sights are all intoxicating and delightful. However you must not be taken unawares. The snake charmers & monkey handlers will try to have the snakes or monkeys placed on your person and then try to extort money from you. Everyone is trying to call you to buy their wares at high prices. This is where the bartering comes in. Everything is haggled and it can be exhausting. What ever price you are given do not pay more than 1/3 of that price. And be careful when services are given and charges are given for packing, or services and before you know it you have paid 300 MAD for a service you would have never requested or paid for. All in all an experience to experience.

Great fun but you WILL get lost. A warren of stalls selling a huge variety of jewellery, leather, fabric, slippers, copper, tassels, rugs, spices etc etc. Be prepared to haggle and compare prices - the best price is always offered after you have walked away! The stallholders are keen to sell but not too insistent - the biggest problem is men 'helping' you to find places or things (or your way out!) and then demanding money for their trouble.Be aware that if you photograph people (and many don't like it) then they will always demand money - the snake charmers and dancers in particular in the main square will follow you until you pay the amount they want - and don't think you can do it unobserved!

Dive In. Abdul introduced us to the Marrakech souks. Knowing who and where, he found needed SIM card for a telephone and a memory card for my camera. More importantly, he showed us that the souks are places to plunge into and feel/smell/see/hear whether or not you buy anything. It really is a part of the culture, and the way most of the world shops. The fun part of the challenge is to see what kind of communication is possible if you do not speak Arabic, French or Berber. In any case, it will be fun.

Jolt to the system. Born and brought up in India, the souks were not something different for me. What intrigued me more was what were people looking for?was it the chaosness? the loud noises? the crowd/ the snake charmers? the people bargaining in each shop/ the best advice I can give is, to go to the souks, with open eyes, dont buy anything in the first time, just see if you like something and go back again if you like something than bargain it. For me, I saw everything which was sold, like jewelry, pottery etc, is also sold here in U.K in camden london etc.

Fab finds!. Loved the Souk in Marrakesh. So many beautiful things to buy, from jewelry and scarves, to hand painted plates and ornaments. Good value for money as well! But make sure that you bargain with the sellers, as they tend to give a high price at first and then will always go down in price once you start walking away!

Souk Trip. It was an interesting trip, we went deep into the Souk, we wouldn't have done that on our own. Not able to stop and look at the stalls. We didin't lke the pharmacy visit, as we felt compelled to buy something.

A riot of colour, smells, noise and mopeds.. We took the wonderful Abdul as a guide for a morning round the Souks and it really helped. He showed us where to check prices do we knew where to start haggling. The stalls nearer the main square are a little more Del Boy style knock off bags but the further you go into individual artisan areas the more you seethe real Souks. A must see if in Marrakech, have a list of what you want though and ladies be careful as stall owners will grab you and drag you in!

Colourful and amazing!. The souks are like no other place ive been. Rows and rows of different things for sale. Its like a spiders web so its easy to get lost. We used a compass in the end so we new which way the market squar was. Its better to think of the souks as a cultural experience. Everything that is for sale has been made. If you go deep enough you will find the workshops of people dyeing material for scarves, hand stitching shoes, cutting leather for bags, beating copper panels its facinating. Each row of souk has a theme, it could be shoes, copper, leather, lanterns. Be prepared to haggle. If you dont want to buy say so imediately do not let them waist their time thinking you will buy just say i dont have any money. If they offer you tea or freebies they will ecpect you to buy so be careful. But if you do want to buy then haggle haggle haggle. Offer them a 3rd of what they say and then come up to between 3rd and 1/2 of what they origianlly offered. Its a game to them they enjoy it so have fun and make then laugh it helps! Also be weary of people who help with directions around the souks they will also expect to be paid however if youre really lost and might miss your bus then its worth it :) We also recomend eating and one of the little places in the souks. They will be a tiny room with a stove and 2 pots bubbling, they will be the niceat meals you eat and the cheapest they like tourists trying their local food and will talk to you and answer your questions. Local people also make the best tea :) My advice is learn to haggle, take a lot of space in your suitcase because you will want to buy everything, be aware that nothing is free and make sure you eat locally during the day :) xx

First visit. I visited Marrocco for the first time and after the accomodation in Riad we went to explore the territory. We were advised to go into the Souk.....and....at the beggining as was "shocked" of all the people that were trying to sell you something...anything. its important to bargain...that is the culture....go down from high price to less than a half ;) . The streets were like a labirint, a lot of peolpe, motobikes, very claustrofobic in some way. It's incredible how they still make the products by themselves...in front of you they treat the leather, they make shoes, bags, clothes and lot more. It is like inside the souk there are many small family factories. The restaurants have marrocain cuisine but not only...very tasty...we went only to the ones with best Tripadvisor reviews and we always made a good choice. Peolpe are friendly and always look forward to help the touritst with ibformation ....but they are also sometimes insistent and that is a bit annoying. However it is an experience I recommend....the Souk it is one of the mant faces of Marrakesh and that is why it is so beautiful.

A haven of Hustlers. To be honest unless you're looking for something in particular the souk is just a confusing place of junk that is even made in china. The onslaught of people trying to sell junk is a little annoying, especially the fact that your gonna have to bargin for even the smaller item. But hey that is me, you may be a person who loves that. The people are still friendly though inside the souk for me though it just feels like a typical tourist gimmick, and when you journey off the beaten path and go into a local supermarket you'll find all your morrocan herbs, gifts, fruits etc freshly packed with a cashier, Hustle free.  The souk is good for buying hijabs, jilbabs, there's, and morrocan slippers. Don't let my review deter you from experiencing it, but maybe once is enough, ya dig.

Crazy colorful and noisy market excellant. Wonderful experience wondering the souks, don't be afread of being pushed into buying just be firm and polite and they generally leave you alone to look, a must see

Walk Quickly, Don't Talk. The souks are all very nice and there is lots of stuff to buy, but the problem there is the same stuff everywhere you go. You can't just wonder through enjoying Morocco, you will he hounded by every shop owner and there are many shops. If you try and stop they will leap on you and talk you in to buying something. Sometimes they will drag you into there shops, which can be worrying if you are by yourself. I would say only stop and look/talk if really want something. Also what ever the price ask for aleast a 1/3 of the price otherwise you will be getting taken for a ride.

Mad but unmissable . The city wall is 19km around its perimeter. Entrance gates lead you inside from the busy wide streets into a maze of small alleyways and roads and of course into the heart of the Souks. Take a wrong turn down an alleyway and you may happen upon an oasis of calm in a rooftop riad or restaurant. Suggest saving a Google map for use offline and favouriting your riad or hotel. Then use GPS offline to guide you back. Getting lost is so easy. The Souks at first appear intimidating but persevere you'll long for a stroll through them on your return to normal life.Take care as bikes, motorbikes, donkies and carts and even the odd car go through these narrow walkways narrowly avoiding the unsuspecting tourist. You'll get hassled to take a look in the shops, but decide on what you're prepared to pay for something then start haggling! You should aim for about a third of the starting price. Alternatively, visit the Ensemble Artesanal, the prices here are fixed and reasonable and goods are of good quality. This is near the tallest mosque by the main square. Just another cautionary note. In the alleyways outside the Souks young men will often tell you that the way ahead is closed. If you're sure of the way persevere. If you follow them you'll take a long detour and be expected to pay them. This was a daily occurrence.

Don't be frightened or intimidated. This is an experience which most people are daunted by. You won't get lost. There is always someone to direct you or guide you but you need to keep handy some MD to pay. Everything seems to be available in these twisty alley ways, full of shops and work places. You probably will be shocked to see young children working and caged animals and lots of things which would not be allowed in Europe. Watch out for mopeds, carts and even donkeys.There are a couple of ways of approaching these areas. Some small children can find it frightening and some teenage girls can be intimidated by the comments made towards them. I recommend the following:- Hold children by the hand at all times and tell them not to speak to or take things from strangers. Totally ignore approaches made by the vendors, children or beggars. This is unnatural to most people, but once you speak or acknowledge their approach then quite often it is hard to get away from that person. You can try just saying no but sometimes you still have to be forceful or rude to stop them from bothering you. NEVER take anything off anyone because it is considered that you have bought it. Some people enjoy the banter with the locals so you get what you get. They learn English from tv and adverts - this is amusing the first few times of hearing!If you are female and blonde and sometimes ginger haired you will receive attention. If you are a larger lady you will receive attention. If you don't like this I advise always have a head scarf/pashmina and cover your hair and sweep the shawl over your shoulder like the locals and totally ignore the comments. This works well. I have been told "you are local" as I have walked about, but I have been left alone. I speak when I want something and no other time. You are expected to BARTER. Don't be frightened to drop the price low, then go up and even walk away. You have to decide what you want to pay. There are plenty of places to buy. If you are near the price when you walk away they will follow you. You can buy lanterns, leather goods, scarves, recycled items, jewelry, spices, cosmetic type oils, argan oil, remedies for anti-snoring and things we do not get in the shops. Some are really good. ENJOY the experience, you might never get the chance again and it would be a shame to miss out!

Gillian Walker. We have just returned from Marrakech having stayed in a wonderful Riad just minutes walk from the Souk. On arrival I was a little apprehensive on the border of nervous. The hustle, bustle, locals and traffic, which incidentally seems to have, right of way whichever direction the are travelling. Many an occasion I could have ended up on the handle bars of a scooter! However, I did feel safe at all times. Be sensible, take care respect their culture and all will be well. My daughter who is not a 'seasoned' traveller did not mellow quite so well.

Amazing colourful and noisy market - prepare to get totally lost!. We went into the souks on many occasions, and almost without exception, got totally lost! Even with a map, you will not end up where you expect and you will never be able to find your way back the way you came, so, just go with the flow and relax, as long as you have plenty of time on your hands and don't mind losing your way. I loved looking at all the goods on display and did buy some, but wished there wasn't such a hard sell and pressure to buy all the time, as I really would have liked to browse at my leisure and would have bought more. However, the moment you pick something up or show any interest in it, you will be hassled until you purchase. Not that they will tell you the price at the beginning....they will just promise a good price. So, my advice is1) Be clear about what you want and don't want, whilst remembering that looking is not really free, despite what they say2) Don't try on slippers just for fun unless you think you might actually buy them, because they will get cross! Don't let them take one of your shoes away (for size, when they go off to find what you want at their friends stall) otherwise you will be left in their shop with no escape!3) If you want to get from A to B quickly, just don't maintain eye contact, close your ears and keep walking4) Haggle like crazy. Start at 25 or 30% of the asking price.5) If you really want something, buy it there and then, as you wont find that stall ever again!6) If you're not sure, don't buy, as all the stalls sell pretty much the same stuff, (and im sure most of it is made in china, not in a little workshop behind the palace, which is what they all say!)Its brilliant fun - but be aware that as a tourist you are a walking cash machine and depite them appearing friendly etc, all the stall holders and vendors have one sole aim which is getting as much money out of you as possible! Have fun :)

A great place to shop and people watch. Dont be afraid to wander into the Souks. These are people who are making a living so they will try to sell you something and if you are interested let the games begin. If you are not smile and say no merci and move on. The deeper you get into the Souks the more interesting you will find it. The main alleyways and areas near the square are full of touristy stuff. As you get deeper into the Souks you will find unique Souks selling interesting stuff. I usually started with a 30% of the initial offer and worked to my real price. Just decide what you are willing to pay for an item and negotiate kindly and use the normal tools for getting a good price. Its half the fun but after a full day of shopping and battering you are ready for a beer or two. There are also many things to see including watching the other tourists. While our crew shopped I spent much of my time people watching and talking with locals and tourists. Quite entertaining.

Shopping with a difference. Ok. So we all know that when in Rome....... The souks are a maze of narrow streets with stalls packed on either side and the occasional on the floor in the middle of the street trader. Everyone wants a sale and they try sooooo hard to get it. You will be hassled and invited inside to look for free. Be polite and persistent. Good idea to keep sunglasses on and avoid eye contact. Donkeys, scooters and people on foot all squeeze down the streets, but it kinda works. There are a few signs directing you to the square, they hang overhead and are in burgundy. Kids/teenagers are always on hand to tell you that the square is in the opposite direction to the way you are going, ignore them. They will take you there via their shops or friends shops and want paying. We got lost loads of times, but eventually got where we wanted to go. We used the line" finished shopping heading back to hotel / riad " when we where approached this worked for us. Also handy line "meeting friends will call on way back ". Let's face it, they are trying to make a living, and they don't have the support we get in UK. Although the souks can be a little trying sometimes, we kept going back for more. So who is the fool here ! They are like those in Turkey but more intense. Some great bargains to be had, but you must be prepared to haggle. We got some great buys, so be patient and stick to your guns. We usually paid between 30-40% of the original asking price. The Moroccan people at first may seem a little full on, but soon you get to understand theirs ways and relax into it, and enjoy the experience. Never felt threatened or in danger. So head on in, and shop, ... But relax and be polite.

Nice to see, not to buy at!. If you've been to Fes you will wish you had done your shopping there, if at all. To walk around it is nice but we found the merchandise generally disappointîng - just the atmosphere and do the shopping elsewhere!

Fabulous. It was brilliant, wandering around in the maze that is the markets. Only problem is trying to retrace your steps to get back out in the main square. The locals can be quite aggressive in getting a sale and very demanding, but hold your own and you'll get the bargain you want.

Best avoid if you are timid, or single female. We had bad experience of the place, my wife nearly had a heart attack when one of the locals walked up to her with a live snake inn his hand. Needless but it killed the mood for rest of the day. overpriced copies of brand names yes,

very loud and colourful. My partner and I braved the madness and chaos and really enjoyed ourselves, having read up on the souks we set out to get some bargains. Did we get any? honestly I don't know all the previous reviews and help guides say only pay what you think its worth and barter we honestly didn't know if we got the bargains we wanted as at the end of the day bartering does not come naturally to me and maybe naively I was thinking this is there lively hood I don't want to be a rude tourist who to them clearly has money. but I am glad of the experience and would recommend having a wander just watch out for the locals on there motor bikes.
The real heart of Marrakech. What a maze of shops, stalls and buskers selling their wares. Be prepared to haggle and you will usually get what you want for 50-60% of their original asking price.

Traditional market. Great shopping but you'll have to bargain for a good deal ! Handbag and shoe heaven for the ladies ! Henna painters are very good and very quick , snake charmers and monkeys for pics - you must pay even if you just watch the showmen they get upset !! At night time it's brilliant but take care of your valuables ! If you have a problem make plenty of noise help will soon arrive . Morrocans don't like thieves and will hand out corporal punishment

Average by day, Crazy by night. The souks consist of hundreds of stalls selling clothes, bags, jewellery, shoes, tourist tat etc.The souks are an absolute maze! It is extremely easy to get lost as you can exit to many different squares throughout.The only downside it that the men casually shout degrading comments at women walking past, which does get really tiresome after a while.A definite must see if you're looking to explore the real Marrakech! Just make sure you know your way out :)

Great experience but don't follow anyone!. A fun and vibrant place to be but be careful of people who ask you to follow them anywhere - it will always be to a friend's shop! Sometimes this can be done in a very subtle way - we stopped for a moment to check where we were, on our way to the Maison de la Photographie and a guy on a moped stopped to ask if we were ok. He told us that the Maison was closed until 2pm (it was 1:30) but there was a great 'Berber Auction and Market' down the road we could pop into in the meantime, and guess what - "oh look there is Ali, who works there, just follow him" - stupidly we followed Ali to a shop with a silver-tongued salesman, who relieved us of more money than he should have, and would have taken us to the cleaners if he'd had the chance!

The Berber Souk. Do not trust anybody, do not take, touch or accept anything from the people on the street as this will cost you money. Even if you just ask for direction they will offer you to walk with you but then will ask for money. So be ready with change like 5-10 dirhams for tips. You have to tip everybody anyway they will ask for that. The markets are very busy and interesting but there is no prices on products so be careful as they usually starting with double price and then dealing. In general I had a great time there.

Be aware!. Marrakech is a lovely place to visit if you haven't experienced the rest of Morocco! A beginners guide to seeing what the whole country is about, there will be many young men wanting to "help" you find your hotel etc etc etc... For the most part these are good men but they will not take you to where you want to go... The prices here are expensive when comparing to other places in Marrakech and Morocco generally but the atmosphere is amazing.

How to haggle for a bargain. I loved this place!! It is so colorful and the sellers are so friendly, you have to get the price down-do not accept the first price -we managed to get the price down to a third of the asking price. Some of the people are just great at selling-Like Omar who when asked if he had any batman t-shirts replied" yes! I give you Marrakesh Batman!!", He then produced a T-shirt with the head of an Arab on it complete with turban! When we all laughed he asked us why we were laughing as this was his Grandfather! My son (aged 15) laughed that much that he bought it! Please be aware that most toilet facilities nearby are not European toilets and use the toilets in nearby KFC.

Brilliant shopping. Fantastic and colourful shopping experience. Make sure you haggle as the price is what you will pay so is different for everyone. It was amazing. Make sure if you want a carpet to see instagram @Berberloom as got a great deal and a beautiful carpet from Yassine

Race round the Soukh. Taken round by a professionally qualified guide. Sadly he rather rushed us and we got the distinct impression he was driving us from one establishment to another where he would earn commission. Having said all that, the Soukh is absolutely fascinating and I would love to come back and spend a full day there - it's very similar to the ~Soukh in Tunis.
Excellent. Exciting and vibrant atmosphere - cafe Za Za excellent on a roof terrace behind main square- clean including toilets. Inspect carefully what you intend bartering for .

Loved it!. To me, this is the heart of Marrakech. Don't listen to anyone who tells you the souk is filled with tack. There are some great leather and artefact shops and half the fun is getting lost in the winding alleys. I could spend days there just soaking up the atmosphere. The streets are cobbled and romantic, the locals are generally lovely, especially the older ones, but so watch out for young 'guides' who latch onto you and won't let you go until they've extracted guilt money from you. The old and wrinkled fortune tellers give you good news, who cares if it's true or not? All part of the fun. At night the square is noisy and alive with revellers and touts. The food stalls are fabulous. Delicious and better than most of the restaurants. Enjoy.

try it.you will love it.. just keep going in a straight line through the souk on your first visit.we walked from one end to the over and didnt diverse.the small shops are amazing .everything is made and sold here.surprisingly ,the shop keepers were not pushy at all .very friendly.and safe .very colourful .bikes .mopeds .delieveries.mad. went back again and diverted down little alleyways .lovely pics taken.loved it.

You either love it or hate it!. Stepping into Marrakech Souks is like another world. The Souks are spread over many narrow roads or alleyways and they get very busy. You'll see lots of people walking, riding bikes, motorbikes, scooters and donkeys all at the same time! It really is chaos!!It's hard to believe people can make a living as there are many little shops crammed into the same area, all selling the same products. The competition for them must be fierce You will have people making comments as you walk past trying to engage you in conversation and eventually show you around their shop...it's all good fun and banter. We used to get people shouying "India, India, Sharuk Khan" to us almost every corner we turned...Haggling with shop owners is great fun! I usually found that a price about a half/third of the initial price was acceptable to both. Have a clear idea of what you'd be prepared to pay, try get close to it and eventually as you walk away they will usually meet your demands...I had to remind myself its not always about getting the lowest price possible!You will get lost. One invaluable piece of advice I got was to download an offline Google map of Marrakech! This was a life saver! Turn on gps and you'll rarely get lost! You'll have a map of the souk streets to hand and If you do take a wrong turn you'll see how you can get back on track easily! When Google maps isn't enough, don't be afraid to ask a local, they are very friendly and will point you the right way. We usually asked shop owners after reading stories of people getting followed or being asked for money after being escorted to where they wanted to go.It is a must see when in Marrakech and you will either love it or hate it!

Full of colour. Vibrant & exciting the Souk was full of weird & wonderful things. Loads of food stalls with the food cooked freshly while you waited. Dozens of freshly squeezed orange juice stalls to choose from. I found the food from the Souk was better than what was on offer in the tourist restaurants down the side streets. Worth a visit if only for the manic pastry men pushing their sweet laden carts in & out of the smallest gaps imaginable. Great value you for money. Even though it was obvious that some of the sights were for the tourist enjoyment they hit the spot. Especially liked the random stall keepers with treys of human teeth!! There was a discreet police presence which was comforting. Only down side I found was late of an evening (stalls are open till the wee small hours) there was some unsavoury aspects such as what appeared to be cock fighting & gambling but at no time did I feel threatened or ill at ease. The backdrop of the snow clad mountains framed the woke square & gave an impression you were on a film set.

As expected. The souk is chaotic and noisy - but as to be expected. It is very touristy and there are lots of hawkers. But it is something which is a must visit on a visit to Marrakesh. Enjoy the negotiations with the stall holders and have fun. Don't take it too seriously and have fun.

Repetative!. We went to the souk because it's the done thing and felt we should. It was hot, and maybe I'm just getting old, but I found it really irritating. I am a very polite person and wouldn't offend anyone intentionally but I felt offended and irritated for most of the time I was there. I was grabbed and painted on by a random woman with a syringe of henna and was mocked for saying "No thank you" repeatedly. The shops are very repetitive, in fact I think they only sell about 4 different things and this is then repeated over and over. I don't enjoy haggling, if you do and you want a pair of slippers or a silver teapot, this is the place to go. Sadly not for me!

Don't show any sign of weakness!. We are well used to haggling having done so in various places in the past and to be honest this was no different.Most of the shops have much the same things for sale. There are a few fixed priced places and seemingly a large shopping mall in the new town but we never ventured there.We only had hand luggage so were limited to what we could buy.I got a Michael Kors tote bag, originally wanted 650 DH, around 65 euros but got it for 20 euros, only pay what you think something is worth, also got some candles for 20DH, originally asked for 40DH, if they let you walk away you know they won't go lower.

Great fun and worth a visit - do not take it too seriously!. Well it is one of the reasons to go to Marrakech so you really should go and enjoy it. Be prepared to be enticed into looking at all sorts of things you don’t need or want! Walk away if you are not interested and haggle, in good humour, for anything you like. The more time you spend the more friendly they become, you may be offered some bottled water or some tea, but it doesn’t mean you’ll get a big discount! Make it fun and don’t take it too seriously, when you think about what you actually pay it is an inexpensive few hours!
Amazing. its large labyrintyou will be lost in few minutes :)definetely you have to ask locals for the way out to Djema el Fnamay to pay some coins for thatenjoy your trip

Gotta do it.. So. Yeah. You've got to. It's kinda the point of the city. Be prepared to barter. By this I mean: have set lines you use once the original price is set. My top three responses. 1. Laugh & say you must be joking. Suggest your price well below what you'd like to pay. 2. When they suggest the starting bid, suggest..."You mean for these 3 items?" Suggest your price well below what you'd like to pay. Or 3. When they suggest 1500 you say, "Um. Maybe more like 150, right?" (Removing a zero from the end of their suggested price.). Be brave. You can do it.

Just experience it, but dont believe a word any shopkeeper tells you.. You will get lost and a bit hassled. Much of the "artisan" workers are just for show - the vast majority of the goods are made somewhere else. Try and get a feel for prices before you go in otherwise you will pay much too much. Rule of thumb - for many things you should try and get down to a third of the original if not more. Dont buy at the first shop you encounter. It is the biggest tourist trap I have been in for a long while. Having said all that I still had a great time.

souks. when you stop to shop they expect you to buy. sometimes first price is 4 or 5 times from what you pay. walk away cuz you will see the same things again. the maze of shops is safe but ask for directions on how to get out. its one of the biggest markets in the world.

Fascinating area of Marrakech. The Souks are a "must visit" in Marrakech but can feel quite threatening at 1st. If you show any interest in buying anything you will be hassled and almost bullied into a purchase.....just say no and try not to look too touristy; don't get hooked unless you really want to buy and then haggle strongly over prices but good humouredly! Don't accept offers of guides unless you are prepared to pay at the end or buy something.....even though they say no cost! You can buy almost anything in The Souks but much of it is not of good quality so be careful and think about what you can get home! The sights, sounds and smells are fantastic but it can get very tiring fighting off the vendors and being bombarded with offers.

The most harassing holiday experience your ever likely to take part in. Not usually faint hearted when it comes to standing my own but beware when visiting Marrakech souk this will test the strength of the best of us. Not long after arrival we wereapproachedby a middle aged man. He offered us private guide of the market. We politely refused. He continued to follow us pestering us continuously. Eventually we agreed to allow him to show us the way to the Tannery. It was not far in distance but to try and get through the meandering alleyways on our own I have to admit his local knowledge came in useful. On arrival out came his hand as expected although he had offered to take us for free - I don't think so !!!!!!!!!. I gave him a few pounds in local currency , probably 3-4 pounds but this was not enough. He got very agressive. His stance and spechbeame threatening. We refused to give him anymore and made our way into the Tannery. We stayed here a couple of hours but when we came out the man was still waiting for us and took up his abuse of us where he had earlier left off. It got pretty nasty especially as wherever we went that da he was either following or would suddenly appear from nowhere to contine to ask for more money. I would never return to Marracech but I am pleased I did experience it the once as the rest of the holiday was O.K. Never without the begging though and the insults for not paying them enough.

Enchanting but overwhelming. The souks are fantastic. There is lots to see and buy and you can always negotiate the price. Some people will find the assertive salesman a bit off putting or intimidating but after you learn to ignore them and only pursue things you are interested in the souks are very enjoyable.

Too stressful!. PWe didn't dare walk slowly cause the shop owners were so pushy they were dragging you into the store. One tried to put a scarf around my neck even though I said know and I had to run to dodge him cause he didn't understand "no". We also had to arch our pockets ALL THE TIME, dodger bikes and their fumes in roof covered souks, dodge people, cats and dogs (which I felt sorry for most of all) AND figure out where you're going without any signs. By the time we left Marrakech we were exhausted! It was like someone was constantly chasing you..

Must do, but don't get sucked in by vendors and haggle!!!. A new before trip what souvenirs I wanted. For example some leather poufs. So easy for me to walk by most booths. If even engage just a little with a vendor they will make it very hard for you to leave. So just walk by if not interested.

Fascinating meanderings!. It's a bit like stepping into an alternative universe when you enter the Souk labyrinths. It's hard to believe they can all make a living because there are so many little shops and businesses, often all crammed into the same area, all selling very similar goods. You do get accosted a lot but in a friendly and often jokey way as you pass by. We were impressed by how safe we felt going round anywhere in Marrakech. Haggling has to be treated with humour and the Moroccans are very good at it! I generally found that a price about a third of their initial asking price was one acceptable to me and acceptable to them. If you have a clear idea of the max you are prepared to pay don't go beyond it and as you say sorry, that's my final offer and start to go they invariably accept the deal. I'm not interested in getting the very lowest price, just one that I feel is fair. These guys have got to make a living and they have a very hard life compared to ours in England.You do have to keep your wits about you in the Souks as they are narrow and often used by motor bikes/scooters/bikes and donkeys. One of the city maps we had showed detail of the Souk area which we found invaluable. You're bound to get lost sometimes but it's nothing to worry about and someone will always help you if you get totally disoriented. There are definitely bargains to be had and some of the leather work, ceramics and carpets/throws are very good value. The experience is very colourful and exotic, an absolute must. Relax and enjoy!

Another World. You cannot visit Marakkech without getting lost (and you will get lost) in the Souk. Be prepared to get hassled, though not aggressively so, and probably pay more than you could for some of your souvenirs (maybe you're a better negotiater than me) but it's all part of the experience and there are some great little cafes to lunch at.

You'll either love it or hate it.. You just have to accept there is a different culture here where every stallholder is your friend and will give you a good price. I ended up buying a couple of things I hadn't intended to but everything is so cheap it's not a problem. What you can't really do comfortably is look at each stall and then go back to the item you like best because in the meantime you will have been assailed by so many stallholders.We got lost and ended up in a tiny alley where the weekly leather auction was taking place. We got in everyone's way but they didn't seem to mind.I'm sure they'd sell far more if they weren't so pushy.

Good fun!!!. Be prepared to be dragged into shops, being offered loads of tea (with and without sugar) but most of all be prepared to haggle for absolutely everything and everywhere.I've read many comments about people feeling intimidated by souk staff. I had not a single problem and me and my friend did quite some shopping so we were at the souk several times. If you are not interested in buying or you are just looking around let them know that. Be firm. We had not a single issue. We usually offered to pay half of the quoted price. After that initial offer it's up to you on how much you are willing to pay.

Jekyll and Hyde!. I visited in September with 2 girlfriends and we all had mixed emotions. During the day although busy it wasn't manic. We did get hassled by men literally everywhere we went and we were not dressed provocatively at all, it is just because we are western. Some of the little areas you walk through are fascinating filled with beautiful traditional items. You will find the more commercial stalls nearer the centre of the square which sells knock offs and fakes. We did get followed a couple of times by a young man trying to take us to his fathers stall. Beware of people like this. During the evening was a different story, the square completely comes to life, it is crazy and we did find it slightly overwhelming. Again we were followed pretty much the whole evening even to the roadside where we hailed a cab, this as 3 girls in our twenties was quite unnerving and I would probably never visit again without my boyfriend. There are loads of people playing music, boxing, monkeys dressed up, snake charmers. It really is like nowhere else I've ever been. You will get hassled by food vendors at night time in the main square but just tell them you've already eaten. All I would say is keep your wits about you at all times, like you would anywhere else.

"go back to sleep". Called "BIG SQUARE" too, a lot of food, souvenir, postcard..etc...When u go to the shop, just have a look and ask some question for price, but don't buy anything finally, the sales will told u "GO BACK TO SLEEP" .this is my experience.....-_-''really sad!!!
