But some people is really nice. By the way, the souvenir is cheaper than other Medina(Fez, Rabat...) But please be careful your wallet, camera....

How Much. When I went to the Souk thought it was gonna be a nightmarebut it turned out to be a great fun day all the guys on the stalls were friendly and we enjoyed bargaining for what we wanted my partner spoke to them in a few arabic words which they loved,we had saffron tea with one of them he was so welcoming we sat in his slipper stall he spoke english to us quite an experience but be careful if you wander from the main souk you could get lost.

Such a mixed bag, I don't even know where to begin!. Gosh, I’m so torn on how to review the Souk – a place I’ve dreamed of going since I was young. Looking back I think I disliked the experience as much as I liked it. For whatever reason I think my hubby and I are the only people on the planet who just didn’t care for Morocco. The people were not pleasant, the food not as good as we’d heard, and the overall “je ne sais quoi”…well…just wasn’t present. We didn’t visit the Souk until the day of our departure (night train back to Tangier) and I wished we would have had more time. Overall the haggling was just too much of a haggle (pun intended) and didn’t feel worth it. Did I get some good stuff? Yeah, I did. I got two pouffes at a very good price (beat that, Jonathan Adler, with your overpriced Pouffes!), two tea sets and some other small odds and ends. It felt when I was haggling that there was more to the conversation than what was on the surface; an angst among the haggle with the proprietor taking out a long history of aggression with me – a white American chick – almost to the point that he was going to get violent if I didn’t give in to his ridiculously high prices. We bartered, ran through the souk in search of ATMs (there are a few, all kind of hidden behind the madness that is hanging carpets, shoes, spices…), bartered some more, all in a rush to get back to our hotel which was out of town a bit. Leaving I felt like I needed more time to experience it, almost as if I was about to start enjoying it, but left too early to get the bad taste out of my mouth. I would give the souk another try, but only if it meant not returning to Morocco. So, in other words, I doubt I’ll go back. Please keep in mind I’ve haggled in other scenarios, other cities, all over the world, including in Mexico all throughout my youth up until now. I LIVE FOR THAT EXPERIENCE. So, I’m no newbie to this and hence let down by the experience of the souk. Now when I’m home in my bedroom looking down a the little blue and white pouffes I scored (finally got a good deal after what must have been a half hour of battling with the guy) I have a mixed emotion of, “was it worth it? Did I enjoy that?” *scratches head, shrugs shoulders*. So, it’s not for everyone, the Marrakesh Souk, but it’s worth trying to form your own opinion. Just be ready to WORK for whatever it is you are buying, don’t show too much cash, and be ready to walk away if you cannot get the price you think it’s worth.

Great shopping if you are good at bargaining. Long winding roads with shops on either side. Here you can find tons of interesting stuff however it can be quite an experience as you need to bargain really hard for everything. Overall a great experiencePros: Good place to buy authentic ethnic stuff.very rustic surroundingsCons:You need to haggle a LOT to buy anythingMost of the shops sell almost the same stuffIf you dont have a local point of contact it's really difficult to figure out what may be the right price for stuff you intend to buyThe leather items had a very strong raw leather smell that has now permeated to other things in my suitcase - no very nice.

Surprisingly hassle free.. I'll be honest, I thought I would be getting dragged into every other shop al around the Souk. On the contrary it is the exact opposite. You can wander around at your leisure. At some point a seat/coffee or drink may be required. The souk is dotted with posh hotels and fine eateries. Part of the experience is wandering about till your feet get sore and remembering where you saw the really nice restaurant/hotel for that well deserved coffee.

Did not enjoy. It was an experience and interesting to see the souks but quickly became frustrating. The souks seemed to be full of local men just hanging around. The young boys that offer to take you to your location seemed to be mostly drug dealers. When my partner declined the offer of hash the boy attempted to put it in his pocket. When I (female) then asked the boy to leave us alone he shouted at my partner that he should not listen to me as I am a woman. Not really a good experience over all but glad we went and saw it for ourselves. Will definitely not return. It was hard to trust anyone as a lot of people we met seemed to want to take us the wrong (and much longer) way to get more money out of you

What an Experience. I guess people go to Marrakesh to see the souks so this is a must. If locals left you alone and stopped touting you to buy things this place would have been very inspiring and peaceful but on the contrary it's all hustle and bustle with higgledy piggledy alleyways and cul de sacs. In there you see and come across everything you think of from souvenirs, inlaid wood, leather, jewellery, musical instruments, carpets, condiments, food, drinks and much more. there are many types of specialist souks and they all overlap each other in a very quirky way. It's a must for Marrakesh, just make sure you avoid walking in alleyways if there is not many tourists walking in it

Wowwww. I had heard how disorientating the souks were when you ventured into them - but I was still blown away by the intensity of the narrow streets, the magnificence of the merchandise and the motor scooters, barrows, bikes and donkeys that appeared from nowhere end pushed their way forward whatever was in their way. I saw quite a few narrow escapes. It was a fantastic experience: the smells of the spices, the desperate sounding calls of the vendors, offering ridiculously small sounding prices. The dates, kilims, curly-toed slippers, wooden artefacts. I've been in souks in Jerusalem, Colombo and Sousse for example but have never felt so shaken up (in a good way, I think), as I have in Marrakech's.

Mad but great. All I can say is to keep an open mind, walk as close to the wall /shops as possible so not to get run over. Haggling is the way of life, only pay what you think its worth. If you are approached by someone saying that they are not guides but want to help you, this is usually a scam, they will guide you free to a friends shop or even worse to the tannary!

Intimidating and scary. Yes it's a bit intimidating, but keep one hand on your wallet and your wits about you and it's fine. Take plenty of change with you and don't engage with anyone you don't want to do business with. Prepare to haggle and if someone tells you a street is closed, ignore them and carry on as they are only going to lead you somewhere to sell you something. Don't get angry with people, simple say no.........plus unless you are prepared to pay, don't take photos of people or their animals.

Certainly an experience!!. I personally really enjoyed the overall experience of the Souks. It is absolute madness and I did feel claustrophobic the first time in. I was scared to look at anything having seen reviews on here before our trip and couldn't help but feel that living nearby would be terrible for your lungs. Having said that, (although much on sale is definitely 'tat') it was a great experience. I think the trick is to appear confident. We refused to take out our maps and as a woman, I didn't find the hassle too bad. By smiling and saying 'no, thank you' the sellers did leave us alone. My partner took the 'ignore them' route which was also quite effective. I didn't really feel that the men were letchy. Some comments were made but generally more polite and complimentary than comments I've had over here. I didn't venture into the souks on my own as my parter didn't let me(!) but I would have felt comfortable doing so in the day. At night we did get offered 'something to smoke' etc but again a polite 'no' and they got the hint. There is nothing really to buy here, I came away with a pair of sandals and my partner got a 'genuine fake' football kit but generally I wouldn't suggest going with the intent of buying anything outstanding.We didn't really have any experiences of anyone offering us 'help'. In fact when someone pointed us the way, we didn't believe him owing to what we had read, but it turned out he actually was only trying to help. I think it's important to keep in mind that if you look like you know what you are doing, people will leave you alone. Failing that most souks lead upwards to the square or taxis are dirt cheap (negotiate and check your change though) so jump in one if you get really stuck.

Got to be done. It's like not visiting Time square if you were in NYC or Taj Mahal in India or track agar square in London. So this is a must do in Marrakech and the Vendors will always be asking you to come in to their shop as their goods/products are the best. You don't have to stop at each shop but after stopping at the first few you will get the idea how things are priced and believe me there is a huge variance. So you have to haggle and it's works- if they say 100 you can start at 20 and be assured you will leave paying around 50. Try and keep change money I.e not hundred dhiram notes so you don't have to wait for them to go and find change and also sometimes you will get that lower price is some was decided at 70 and you just have 50 you give them the 50 and that's all you have!  Don't get items from the first shops you see, you should go through into the main souks and it's an amazing experience. People will be calling and you just keep looking and walking. The scarves are really nice and there was shop we went I and we got brand new ones in plastic covers. The candle holders are also very pretty - make a great decor for the house or as a gift.Been told to be weary of the people who do henna - we didn't do any. You will also see a lot of snake charmers!

Not Safe for Women. I have to say that the sights and sounds of market are fascinating but I was quickly made aware by both the tour guide and the street vendors that the expectation is that we spend money. I was blocked from an exit by a store owner who said I must purchase something before leaving. When I said I needed to catch up to my group the man said he saw them move on down the street and that we were being watched. It was very frightening. I was also pushed in the street by a man and told that women did not belong there by another. I was dressed appropriately. I won't go back.

Great fun to walk around, but expect hassle. It really is a rabbit warren of little streets, just wide enough to walk down (or ride a moped at high speed). Full of character. You are certain to get lost, and if you look at a map you will be hassled by some evil character who will misdirect you, then "help" you for a large fee when you get even more lost. One guy pointed in the direction of the Jmaa el Fna, only his direction was 180 degrees out, and he took offence when I asked whether he was lost.Trick is to just relax, and not mind being a bit lost. At worst, you end up walking out of the souk in some random direction, and you can sort yourself out from where you end up.A problem with the stalls is that if you look at anything they really expect you to buy. It is not like browsing in a European or American shop. So you end up walking around with your eyes straight ahead. If you actually want anything, it is much easier (and generally cheaper) to go to the Ensemble Artisanal. At the very least, go there first to have some idea of prices.

Prepare to haggle!. This is the heart of the city; tiny alleyways crammed with stalls. Bargains galore if you are bold enough to start your bidding low and hold your nerve. A must do on your trip for an authentic experience.

Very crazy!!!!! . The souks are out of this world. Like no place I have ever visited before the experience is one I will never forget. The market stalls sell anything and everything, expect to haggle as the traders will start at a very high price, and watch out for the scooters and carts that go through the thin streets without much regard for any pedestrians. It is very easy to get lost in the meandering streets so keep your eyes out for the blue signs hung in the rafters as they will direct you back to the Main square. The street food available in the centre on an evening is delicious. Definitely the place to go if you want to experience a bit of culture on your visit to Marrakech.

Okay, but the Fez Medina is more interesting. This Medina is okay, but pale in comparison to the Fes Medina. As you have probably read, there are thousands of ways to part with your money here. Be careful, and negotiate everything. Start at no more than 50% of what they are asking, except for food and toiletries I found the key to bargaining there is to keep it friendly. Feel free to make ridiculous offers, but smile while doing it, and try to make a sport of it. The bargaining really stars when you start to walk out of the shop. Be sure to sample some olives while in Morocco. They are excellent quality, and come in many flavors. Have fun, and good luck!

Not for sissies......not to be missed. Visited the souks with a local (trustworthy) guide. What a marvellous and exiting experience. This was a unique experience which cannot be found within Europe were chinese goods engulfs all marketplaces. The handcrafts are alive and wauwww what amazing stuff to be bought. Keep in mind that fraud was probably born in this country and you will probably never get to know the real price of goods but whats important is that you are satisfied. At the end of the day you need to help the local economy.

Delightful maze!. You really need to get you bearings right, the souks are like a maze! Everyday we discovered a different path that we had not walked through. Can easily spend many hours here just strolling through admiring all the colourful wonderful products. Get ready to haggle!!

A maze of wonder. Don't be put off by a bit of hassle. Do wander, you will get lost but so what? Don't look lost...youths will appear from nowhere and offer to guide you back to the square...and charge you!Be confident. There are bargains. Decide what price you are prepared to pay and stick to it. Smile. Be polite. Speak a few words in French and enjoy the experience. Don't expect to get z beer or wine with your lunchtime tagine.Next time we will stay in the Medina. Great atmosphere.

Incredible.. What do you want from a visit to Morocco? THIS.A bewildering display of goods and colours and aromas you can only dream of (most good some v. bad) but wonderful to behold.Don't touch or they feel a sale coming on.Dont be frightened to haggle,my wife is brilliant at this(I was told she's like a good Berber woman).A firm but polite No thank you is enough to stop the market holders.A fantastic experience just take a little care.My opinion is you should feel safe.

Bewildering array of life and products. Assault on the senses , aural and visual . Play the game of bartering , it is an enjoyable experience in itself, remember they will not sell it to you if it does not make a profit , so start LOW and build to a value you think it is worth , then stop , and leave if the price is not to your liking. They will typically be 2- 3 times it's actual value as a base point from which you barter them down towards the price you are willing to pay.

Getting ripped off. I've been to Morocco twice so far but this time I cane on my own, wanted to get a bottle of shampoo and some food. First two shops I managed to dodge then I got sucked in to a shop which to me seemed like it would sell some shampoo. I got the usual chat "my brother..." I ended up with a whole bag of stuff I never even knew existed nor did I want them, luckily acording to the man in the shop the bag was worth €120.00 i only had €10.00 on me, never the less the guy was happy to take it and in return I got a bottle of shampoo and a "present" which again was something I didn't need. I think the way to get around this problem is to either be rude, put your head down and carry on walking and if you do choose to speak to a guy there, twll them you've been there for a couple of days and pretend you know what you're talking about...

Surprised this isn't #1 Attraction. If you can't find it here, then you don't need it! The Marrakech souk and the medina have to be the best attractions on any trip to Morocco. I have to admit, however, that I really liked the medina and souk in Fez, as well, especially the tannery. But, I guarantee that you have never seen anything like this and won't see it anyplace else, so don't miss it while you're here!

Denis534. Well worth the time and effort. Found the marocan culture fascinating. The best time to visit is just before sunset. Be iin one of the coffee/tea places with upper decks to see a amazing African sunset. After dark the square turns into one big interesting and lively restaurant with all of the marocan culture alive there in front of you well worth the time. Will I recommend ? Yes I would will I visit again ? A definite yes

Back in Time. It is like going back in time , just to stand in the square and take it all in will stay with me forever and so will that sheep head i tried to eat as well lol. if you can stay over night in one of the many houses in the square a small bit high about €60-€80 per night but well worth it .

Marrakech, and all of Marocco, must visit!!!. Marrakech was the highlight of our trip to Marocco, but truth is we really enjoyed every single place we visited: Rabat, Tangiers, Meknes, and many more. People very social, food very good, and such beauty everywhere! Don't miss out!

Go get lost. Getting lost inside the Souks and local artisan shops is part of the experience. Learn to negotiate and say "No, thank you" like you mean it. It's perfectly safe and no one will bother you unless you want or let them if you become interested in some thing or other to buy. The deals vary greatly so don't be surprised to find it cheaper later on but again that is part of the experience. Enjoy have fun and make sure to see the artisan areas where the goods are manufactured. This is somewhat out of the way and main souks but still part of the market. Have an explorer attitude and you will find all the spots. Enjoy!

AWESOME. Be prepared to have your senses assaulted!!! A huge area of souks selling everything you can imagine from genuine, fake bags to huge beautiful doors. Be prepared to negotiate price politely and with humour. They want to make a living and you want a bargain!! The quality of the scarfs are fabulous and reasonable. Spices, lamps, shoes, local dress, jewellery, all laid out. They are polite but will say come and see my shop just be polite. Experience is amazing. Well worth going.

I didn't feel safe. Vendors are very aggressive and I was even verbally harassed by a guy outside a shop. Traffic is chaotic to get there, very dangerous and also as you walk around you risk to be run over by bikes and motorcycles all the time.

Sooo mutch to see. First of all its huge to expet to get lost a couple of times ;) Other than that there are lots to see and buy if you feel like it. Expect to be invited in to a shop more than once but you learn what to do after the first couple of times :P

Not to be missed, but take your time and practise saying 'no'. You have to do it, there is no choice, and it will be a largely wonderful experience, but as with all things everything is in the preparation.Firstly, with a good map, you won't get lost, and you are very unlikely to come to a sticky end (but do keep bags and purses protected). You don't need to accept any invitations to show you anywhere, partly because you can get there yourself, partly because any 'helper' will have an ulterior motive - either a specific shop or at least a fee for helping.Also, don't rush in and buy. Take your time, and if possible use a first visit to see what there is and to sound sellers out on prices. Never accept the first price, but try haggling to see where it gets you, and you will soon see where the bottom line is likely to be. The good thing is that you can always say no, and you will not have people chasing you for your business. Life is too short for them too. Prices on the edge of the souks (entry and exit points) will always be higher, so sound a variety of people out on prices. You will be surprised what a difference there is. Even such a small item as a knitted hat, for example. One square quoted a stunning variety of prices, from an outrageous 150 dirham (15 euro) down to 50 (5 euro) as a starting point. We bought for 20 (2 euro) after 5 minutes of animated discussion.Even the famous babouche slippers vary significantly, and there are plenty of sellers. One lovely shop in the centre of it all had fixed price babouches for a mere 50 dirham.Avoid jewellery and trinkets unless you like it, and try not to go into shops more than you need to, as they will smell business and snare you like a Venus fly trap!If in doubt, walk away and come back another day.It has to be said that the souks are generally not the cheapest places to buy things - you are a captive market - and you will find cheaper outside. If you can get out to the Atlas mountains or to Essaouira, you will find everything a lot cheaper, although the hassle factor is ever present. For example, a carpet costing 'only' 3000 dirhams (300 euro - good by European standards) in the souk will be less than half the price in Imlil. But you need a car for that!

Lots to see. Never once felt intimidated going round the huge markets, yes the locals are at you as soon as you stop to have a look around asking what price you are prepared to pay for their items.... If you haggle which my partner is prepared to do they will drop the prices, if not walk away and nine times out of ten they will call you back and agree on a reasonable price. You can spend hours walking around as there Is so much to see but can definately say the locals are friendly and most speak good English.

Shoppers paradise. Best advice is take a huge suitcase and bring home carpets, leather handbags, lanterns jewelry and ceramics.Yes the stall holders can be aggressive and it is wearing, but there are bargains to be had and beautiful wares to admire. Go for short time bursts and visit again and again. You will see something different every time.

Great cultural experience but nothing worth buying here. We went here to see the market and immediately my friend who is afraid of snakes grabbed my arm leaving it bruised. Snakes don't bother me. It was really a great spectacle to see the sheer amount of smoke from the cooking (there are food vendors on the square) selling snails, grilled meat and other dishes. What put me off eating there was the hygiene or lack of it. Take for instance the Orange juice seller who sold juice in a glass that dipped in a bucket of water, there is no sink or running water, and gave it to the next person to drink. Also, the hot snails looked gross, they were in some brown broth. Most of the stuff sold was junk, I've seen better in a Croydon car bootsale. The only thing I liked was thf guy who sold albino peacock feathers.

Love this place!!. I have to say I absolutely loved the souks in Marrakech. When we first arrived, my partner was quite nervous and so the first day we didn't buy anything and we just had a wander around and got acquainted with the area. Luckily, I managed to convince him to go back again because I knew he would enjoy it if he stopped worrying. On our second trip into the souks, we had an absolutely brilliant day and it was difficult to tear ourselves away. It's a place where you could spend an hour having a look around, or all day hunting for treasures through the winding streets of the souks!!We kept our distance from the men with monkeys on leads, snake charmers and from the women with the henna, but these are only in the main square, once you get into the souks there isn't anything like that. The women with the henna certainly didn't appear to be very friendly so we avoided eye contact, I was convinced they were going to curse me!!If you visit the souks, don't worry, keep your wits about you and you'll have a brilliant time. I'd recommend women to cover up, as you would expect in a Muslim country anyway. This is not because there is a risk of leery men like in Turkey etc. because it's nothing like that, but I personally felt like I was able to enjoy the experience more knowing I was walking through the busy souks covered! If you are a softy, this may not be the place for you because the vendors drive a hard bargain. However, if they say something is 1000 dirham, offer them 100 and stick at it! It sounds ridiculous but they only start with high prices in the hope you will just cough up because your a tourist. We found that sometimes they laughed our initial offer off, as it was a fraction of what they wanted, but we didn't budge and just left the stall and on more than one occasion we were shouted back only for them to accept the offer. Not everyones idea of fun but I must admit I loved it!Not all of the stalls have that sort of atmosphere though, some actually have prices on the items, so I suppose if you don't want to haggle with the locals you can still pick up some things there - but you will probably pay 3x the price!There are a few shops on the outside selling fakes, but once you get into it theres pottery, mirrors, lanterns etc. We bought some lovely lanterns and a mirror. One thing though, don't buy the black soap, I thought it would be a great idea, but I was obviously just in the spirit of things at the time and realised when I'd got home that in reality I'd just bought tubs of black slime... I'm not sure exactly what it was but I must admit that I have slightly fell in love with Marrakech!

I love to shop, but this can be exhausting,. Im sure a good guide would have been helpful ours was not. Someone could make a fortune publishing a map of the area...could not find one.We skipped the picture taking. Wanted to buy some spices.....research what you want before you shop you get all kinds of sales pitches there.

Did I do the souk wrong...?. Everything seems very expensive/just the same as prices back home in the UK, it's either the same kind of tat over and over or crazily priced antiques... Everyone says it's wonderful and atmospheric and full of bargains but I didn't really see any of that today. What am I missing exactly?

Utter chaos but a 'must see'. Just as we never quite believe a sign saying 'wet paint' you won't really believe what you have read about the souks. There is a veritable labyrinth of stalls with every stall holder and his mate clamouring to part you from your money. There is in all honesty too much to see, it can easily overwhelm. The following will happen to you. 1) you will get lost, one parade of leather goods stalls looks very like another- stay calm there are the occasional signs which help a bit unlike the people who offer to 'help' in the street. 2) you will be enticed into a stall, once they have you inside the stall holder will hassle you to buy - yes he has to earn a living, but I found it irritating. 3) inevitably you will spot something you might like to buy, sadly we Brits are just not cut out for haggling, I doubt it will be the bargain you believe it to be, but I was born in Yorkshire. 4) someone WILL annoy you profoundly I defy anyone to remain serene and swanlike in there! 5). A motorcycle will get a lot closer to you than you'd like, top tip is walk on the right and be very careful crossing the alley to enter a stall (see numbers 3 & 4 also)! Having said all the above, it's probably best to experience it, seems silly to get to Marrakech and not!

Brilliant Fun!. You can't go to Marrakech and not try a bit of haggling! The souks were brilliant, like a huge rabbit warren of gift shops. Yes you get pounced on and the salesmen can be quite aggressive in attempting to get you to look at their products but if you're not interested just say so and they do leave you alone. I found most of them very friendly and chatty and we often went back to see our favourites on numerous occassions throughout our trip. I didn't think I had the ability to haggle in me but surprised myself and saved an absolute fortune doing it. I found it easier to work out what I intended to buy beforehand and when suggesting a price to the salesmen stick to your guns as they will always accept it if they think the alternative is for them to not sell it at all.

Aggressive vendors spoiled the experience and tips for Morocco travel.. I've experienced markets similar to this in Istanbul and Bangkok, but the vendors in Marrakech were far more aggressive. Some would not take a polite "no" for an answer and followed us for blocks. I would certainly advise being discreet when taking photos of anything in this area of souks (or the Medina) because you will probably be harassed for money. Taking photos of the snake charmers or monkey handlers will almost certainly create a demand for money. I saw one woman take a photo of a monkey and instantly the handler grabbed the monkey and put it on her shoulder and wouldn't remove it until she "rescued" by her companion. The friendly locals would offer to take your photo (with your camera or phone) and request payment for doing so...repeatedly.Dining anywhere was a very lengthy experience, so if you have limited time, you will need to let your server know...traditionally the meals are leisurely. Lots of trinket type shopping, but there was a good selection of scarves and spices (both easy to pack) and argon oil (Moroccan Oil) (which can be challenging to bring home if not securely packed and stored in zip lock baggies to prevent leaking). Was easily able to use a credit card and American dollars in the souk. If you have Moroccan money (Dirham) you should exchange it prior to leaving Morocco as I don't believe you can do so anywhere except in Morocco. There are places at the Marrakech Airport that can exchange the Dirham, but if you want to purchase items at the airport many places will only take Dirham. Airport also offers the ability to "shrink wrap" your luggage if you want it protected against theft. Local airlines were very stringent with carry-on bag sizes, and I saw numerous passengers at check-in being forced to check their carry-on bags because they were too large.

When you think Morocco, you see the Marrakech Medina. This for me was the best part of the trip. It was exactly what I expected loads of people, things to see, to buy and to eat. The sights, sounds and smells will stay with me forever. It is an experience and the locals are wonderful people, even those following you around. Just remember if you go for a closer look at the snakes you are likely to end up with one drapping your shoulders. Also, be careful of the monkeys we were told that they are not regulated and a very high probability they have not been vaccinated. But we ate an open air restaurant and enjoyed every moment. I cannot do the experience justive with the review but would definitely say if you can visit Morocco.

Wow, wow and wow again!. Amazing colors, sounds, sites, people and stuff. Noisy and crowded. Everyone wants your dirhams, dollars or euros... but also friendly.
It is a maze of shops and alleys. Easy to immerse yourself in and truly get lost.
Do not miss it!

Marrakech Markets!. The markets are really busy & you do get hassled to buy stuff but that's part of the Moroccan shopping experience! We bought some great items at a good price (you basically should half the traders 1st offer) and had a great laugh with the local traders! Before travelling we were slightly worried about our dress code, (we all wore 3-4 sleeve tops & long trousers and had scarfs) but we shouldn't have been, I was surprised by the amount of 'western dressed' locals I saw! Basically you should be respectful and cover your shoulders, cleavage and not wear anything above the knee... I did see a couple of English girls with really thin strapped vest tops & short shirts on (they obviously didn't read up on the country beforehand!) Tutt tutt!! Everyone should visit this country at least once in their lives :)

Crazy, but don’t be intimidated.. Read elsewhere for how the souk is ‘divided’ up into various niche markets. For instance, shoes, livestock, wool, leather, brassware, clothes, food, etc. As I could see there were three main interconnected alleyways. The smelly bits (livestock) are on the perimeter. Be bold and just peruse the main alley ways. I would go in any stalls as you will be trapped into buying something. You get a bit of hassle in your walks but nothing too intimidating. We ate at a café on the perimeter; the food was excellent; freshly cooked.
A MUST!!!!!. If you want to see, smell, feel, hear and even taste the old world...the Suq of Marrakesch is a MUST!!!!

Fab atmosphere. Great shops here and worth a visit. Loads of lovely items - would definitely recommend taking an empty suitcase with you. You're expected to haggle here but don't be to over ambitious because you will get thrown out of the shop - all in good humour may I add. We accidentally ended up in the food section which for me was not pleasant as many of the animals were alive and would be killed there.

Sensory Overload at the Souk. VIsited the Souk during the day adn agani at night time. It is best described as sensory overload. The smells and colors and noise all mix to create a fantastic experience. Enjoyed browsing during the day and loved the energy of the night time marketplace and food stands where the owners work to entice you in to their areas to try the delights of the Souk!

Amazing experience. This is one of the best places i have ever been, its vibrant colours, the sounds, the smells all calling you to get deeper into the souks! You can buy anything and everything but make sure you have a price in mind first and be prepared to haggle! we added a extra case to our luggage just to bring our goodies home
A shopaholics paradise!. Everything under the sun is for sale here! Great experience bartering with the soul merchants. Some amazing bargains to be had! Fantastic!
For the Strong. Be ready to bargain hard. Do not stop and ask a price unless you are really interested in buying or you will be worn down before you can even get going.

What an unforgettable experience. What an experience such a diversity of people and stalls, very daunting. People will come up to you asking you to buy from the stalls. Most people were friendly but some pressurised you into looking in the soul but always try to haggle for better price. There is many other stalls that will offer the same for less. always have your wits about you but have fun

All the same. Every stall sold the same,very dirty and motorbikes and donkeys were all going way to fast(was nearly knocked over twice)not good if you have children.
Could get quite dark and intimidating at times.

Not an impressive experience.. The most notable piece of advice we received when heading to Marrakech was along the lines of 'get lost in the Souks and soak up the experience.'Don't, it's not much fun at all - and it's not that we're not adventurous travellers. It's a pretty grim experience. The goods on sale are majorly tat (although a few are of interesting local distinction) and there is a keenness amongst some of the locals to aggressively pursue lost tourists to lead them on a merry dance - in our experience this was to the tanneries, or just on interesting routes back to Jemma El Fna. Marrakech is a nice city but we wouldn't recommend the 'get lost in the Souks and soak up the experience' idea.

an experience. Embrace the atmosphere. Constantly being called in to look. Shop keepers initially ask the most crazy inflated price! Cut it right down to 10% of their price. Keep your own top price in your head. Walk away and they soon call you and chase you for your best price, stick to your guns and theywill soon be packing that pot for you!

An experience !!!!. Wow what an experience....You really need to speak Arabic or french the people struggle to understand English, but as soon as they know you are English the price shoots up. All prices start high so expect some hard haggling.The people dont like you to take photos of them even of there stalls so ask first.Very easy to get lost in the alley ways so b careful..Young men will try and lead you to family stalls so be careful.When walking down the crowded alley ways again b careful there are lots of mopeds driving about.I was struck by how poor people were.If you find your self straying ouut of the Souks to the slums turn back as we were advised this is dangerous.As i said this is an experence not to be missed but after a few hours you will feel drained from haggling and from people shouting you to look at there goods.There are a few good cafes and roof top restaurants in the Souks keep your eyes open as the views are amazing.An experience not to be missed.

I love it!!!. It is noisy and busy and everyone is trying to sell you something but Marrakech would not be Marrakech without a visit to the souk!!! If you feel brave combine it with a meal in the square if not at least try the best orange juice in the world! it will refresh you body and soul!

It's Great shopping. I loved all the shops hustle & bustle . Unless you really see something you want don't look interested. The people were really nice. To be honest if I had a bigger case I would have bought much more. It's a bit daunting at first but honestly it's a great place .

Beware motorcycles and stay on right side.. Some wonderful shops and stalls - look for animel on way to spice market for different finds. Bargain hard - my husband was asked if he had Berber blood. But all good fun - ended up paying about half of asking price - but serious bargain hunters could do better. Loved ceramics, wooden marquetry, scarves and mint tea glasses.
great fun. vibrant & busy with everyone wanting to sell to you but good naturedly if you really mean no put up your hand say a firm no & walk away do not engage in conversation and you'll be fine

Bargain they expect you to !!. Just wander through, see the sights. Dont open your purse until you have bargained for what you would like. Be polite if you dont want anything . Keep an eye on where you are as you can easily get lost and dont get the map out as someone is bound to become your instant guide. That will cost you and you could end up anywhere .Just enjoy the madness.!!!

Go early to avoid being pestered. Be polite and say no thank you and they will leave you alone, if you want to buy think of a figure that you would be happy paying and go lower to end up at the price you want to pay, YOU are expected to haggle

Great for shoppers!. If you are looking for a good deal and love to shop, this is perfect for you. They have all kinds of things in the shops, and you will get everyone trying to get your attention. My advice is to ignore anyone unless you are interested in that shop. It is not rude to ignore them or to walk away, so don't feel bad. If you give them your attention, they will physically try to get you in the shop and even chase you down the street. But lots of fun and good deals uf you can bargain. Always start at a very low price and do not go above 75% of what they ask. If you have small children, bring them along cuz the shop owners are partial to kids! Our kids got 1000dh down to 32dh for a necklace she wanted!

Be prepared to pay for picture of the Cobra Snake Charmers.... This is an experience you have to have while in Morocco. Marrakech is really known for all the sites and sounds of Morocco in one place...a do not miss~!

Scary. Loved the area but was too overwhelmed by people pushing u to buy or pay to have photos taken. One guy put a snake on my neck hoping for a pic...luckily they dont bother me but could be terrifying for someone else. Be carefull of people trying to send you in the wrong directions. They can get quite intimidating. The city is spoilt by the constant nagging to buy or look at or come eat....you cant stroll around and look at your leisure as someone is always trying to get you to do something or buy. All that said. The architecture is amazing and has sone beautiful public gardens. Find out from your hotel how much u ahould expect to pay for a taxi as they all charge what they like...stick to your guns. And if they wont go to your price there are a 100 other taxis waiting for business.
Haggle. Interesting sites to be seen. If you don't like haggling or being ushered into a shop don't go. If the word no is not in your vocabulary do NOT go...

Bring an empty suitcase. What can we say? it's what you expect and much more.They sell everything (babuchas, leather goods, scarves, metal work, food, spices, wooden items, ...), they speak every language and they don't leave you in peace for a second.Great fun, but make sure you have your haggling tactics ready and bring an empty suitcase!

Shopping. Nice bits and pieces among lots of tat.Must bargin to get best price. Easy to get lost. Many beggers all over the place. Some are desperate with no state support, others try to pick your pocket
What a Buzz. Loved the Buzz of the souks, haggling was expected of you & fun. Sellers were so friendly & if you said no-thankyou you were not pestered in any way.
Enjoyable madness. Exciting shopping, the colours,the variety, the vendors, the noises, the smells, the traffic, the bargaining - all great!

Exciting, but expensive!. A visit to the souk - or one should say the souks, because it´s not only one - is propably inevitable when staying in Marrakech. There are innumerable shops in the area, north of the central square Djemaa El-Fna.The get an overview of the souks is virtually impossible, so the best you can do is to dive into the jumble unconditionally. You will find leather goods, metal works, traditional clothes and thousands of other things - and you will constantly be approached (or one might say attaced) by sellers trying to persuade you to buy exactly their goods.If you don´t watch out you will probably pay way to much for what you buy. Haggling is of course mandatory, but as it will start from a sky high level you will probably pay too much, even if you succeed in haggling the price down a lot. Therefore it might be wise first to check the price level out in the city (e g at Ensemble Artisanal) before you start haggling in the souks.To avoid getting lost, and to easily find the places you want to visit, a properly working GPS is most useful. We used the GPS in a normal smart phone and found our way almost like the locals...

Interesting experience. Besides getting hackled and harassed by the locals its a cool place to see. women you might want to cover up just a little because people stare and make comments ...it isn't that bad it's just the old people but everyone there knows you are a tourist so they get over it

Organise chaos!. It feels like anytime you'd see Alladin running in the bamboo roof tops..the prices are ridiculously high, so really have to haggle...but there is so much to see and so many people pestering you to buy, but dont let it put you off, that is part of the experience.

An adventure. Fairly easy to find your way about but not for the faint hearted. There are motor bikes, push bikes and crowds of people and you have to be alert as they don't care if you're in their way . Lovely crafts and goods to buy.

Do not expect a bargain!!. Fabulous place to spend some time . Very interesting and a hive of activity.. More leather slippers and pashmina wraps than you could imagine. HOWEVER- be warned... DO NOT EXPECT VALUE FOR MONEY! Prices are ridiculously high and the stall holders understand every word and don't miss a trick. Only have a small amount of money visible on your person because if they see more in your wallet- you're stuffed! Despite haggling them down to a quarter of the original asking price , you are still cheaper to go to recognised shops Overall id say - go to the souk for a sensory experience but buyer beware!
You have to see it. Go now before it is spoilt by new shopping malls. haggle and you will get a good price don't be put off a place to see before you die.

Mayhem in anice way. So much to see, so much to take in..... always felt in demand but felt aggressively pestered. Got off the beaten track leaving the "sales units" behind & found the production lines - so interesting....

Souks night life. I didn't like that they pester you but the overall experience was amazing because everyone comes out at night. You can hear people laughing, songs, instruments and lights everywhere. Definitely a place to go back to.

Not for the faint hearted.. We spent 5 days in Marrakech, our Riad was a 2 minute walk from the Medina. We found the walk through the Medina was challenging, trying to negotiate people and scooters, which seemed to go to fast given the environment. A good place to get an idea on prices you should pay in the Souk is to take a look in the Artisan Centre about a 5 minute walk from the Medina. At the Artisan Centre, crafts are being made and are items are priced. If you plan to go out for dinner in the evening, plan your route, and if coming back later than 8pm, I would recommend, walking outside the Medina or taking a cab. Cabs are cheap. After about 7ish the stalls in the Medina start closing and can be challenging to negotiate as signs/direction are almost non existent. We will visit again given, the short flight, temperature and the general relaxed atmosphere.

Fascinating Experience. Be prepared to get lost, buts that's part of the experience! There are lots of little areas that specialise in particular crafts, metal, leather,food etc. you can often see the craftsmen making the products they are selling. You can pick up lots of bargains but you need to pinch yourself not to buy things just because they are 'cheap' ! We bought a mahogany chess / backgammon set for £20 & a good size & quality leather overnight bag for £30. There are lots of stalls selling the same / similar products so make sure you check out the 'real' price - it's usually 1/3 of the starting price. Go - it's a real experience
souk. you could spend all day wandering along the lanes trying to barter for clothes and bags just about anything you wanted great fun

A shopper's must in Marrakech. It's a shopper's delight, with everything you can imagine from souvenirs to food and clothing. Take the hussling bit with a big simile as it's a local sport and you'll experience the good humor and simles in return. Pay what you think something is worth because you'll probably never quite figure out if you got a good price or not and don't be afraid to walk away if you do not want to make a puchase ... just keep similing even if this is not quite your usual shopping experience !!

A Must See Yet, not for the faint hearted!. barter for everything including a glass of delicious fresh squeezed orange, But don't take Long to drink it, unless you want a beggar to stand with-in breath smelling distance, eye balling you pitifully until you can give the glass back to Vendor ( we let the the doe eyed, but well fed beggar boy, the last of the orange in the glass ... it was very hot.) and continued into the corrugated covered warren of stalls and shops. The colours smells and sound is a sensory immersion into a scene from Indiana Jones, James Bond or carry on up my Camel! You CAN NOT BROWS. The seller will engage with you before you know what he's actually selling. I found repeating 'No thank you' in 3 different Languages a soothing Mantra after a while. And we bought what we wanted and only what we wanted and yes it is possible to get a bargain there. you must to be as cheeky and doggedly but Politely persistent as they. luckily for us, My Girlfriend has this knack (I was SO proud!)the exercise of continuously converting Dirams to the pound was Invigorating and exhausting. So taking a coffee or mint tea, in one of the many many rooftop Caffe/restaurants felt well deserved. Oases of Calm that look down the technicolour bustle, over the city roofs out to distant snow capped Alas Mountains. Its Not short On Scenery.After Dark, the food Stalls, Snake charmers, and performers fill the area with noise lights and sound. well worth pitching a spot on a roof top café to observe and enjoy. I, wore my back on my tum, Camera round my neck, wallet deep in the pocket of close fitting trousers. Pickpockets are rife, but if you look like you are aware, take sensible precautions, you can become less of a target.As I said, A Must See Yet, not for the faint hearted, so if you're easily flustered. take a guided tour in a group. but see it. Happy Travels ;)
Lots to see and haggle for!. Lots of different things to see and haggle for. Most people don't like being photographed. Linger for more than a moment and expect to be sold to.

Scary but also a real eye opener.. From the minute we got to the souk to getting on the bus I felt uncomfortable. We had a tour guide but even then he took us to a few places who tried to pressure us into buying rugs etc. You have to have your wits about you and be very strong and not look weak.I found the way the men treated us a little uncomfortable and in some places the men were a little to much, and the way you couldn't look at anything without being harassed or ask to pay was horrible.For me even though I know bartering is part of their culture if items had prices on them I would have purchased some lamps, rugs as the craftsmanship was excellent but I'm not playing the haggling game as I feel its a complete rip off. Its not fun or exciting as I kept hearing them tell us. I found it hard seeing the animals who look neglected and tired. As a vegetarian I found certain parts really not nice.I don't regret going but would never go to another, real eye opener and I wish we had that level of craftsmanship here on show , also the fresh food everywhere was amazing.Great but for a one off

Hard work fending off dishonest peddlars. Whilst I understand that the Souk is a hagglers paradise, I didn't like the fact that everybody is trying to rip you off. Happy to bargain, but am not an idiot and don't like being treated like one!!Another thing that was very disconcerting was how rude the peddlers were if you declined to eat/purchase at their establishments. I appreciate that woman are treated differently in this country, however, if you want me to respect your culture, then I would like the same courtesy!!
A Must Visit place. Wonderful experience, shopping, haggling, laughing with the friendly shop keepers. Be aware of the motorcycles, push bikes and donkeys, they go every which way.

You will see everything here!. From clothing, rugs, spices and animals, you can expect to see some of the most colorful and interesting wares in the world. Watch for motorbikes, donkeys, bikes, dogs and other busy pedestrians who are all looking for the best deals. Enjoy going into the pharmacies where spices for cooking and medicinal purposes are demonstrated. You can even get a neck and shoulder massage while you hear about the spices.

Souks visit. We took the advice of our tour operator and hired a government guide and this was worth it as it stopped us being harassed by all the sellers. However, be aware the guide seems to take you to the souks where he clearly gets commission on your purchases. He was very determined that we should purchase items.

rude and unwelcoming people. This was my third trip to Marrakech. The others were over 20 years ago. It has really changed. Picture-taking is very difficult now. Many people are rude and nasty when you try to take a picture - even if they are not the subject. The shop keepers are pushy. I got sick of being called Ali Baba by everyone.

Well, it is what it is.... Most useful tip is this... Pay 1/3 of whatever price you are first offered. That's it, all the rest is just noise, and if you don't buy at one booth there are several hundred more selling the same products all around you.We bought many Pasminas (£5 each), wooden boxes, chess sets and dominoes (under a tenner each, prices vary lots)....raw incense (£3-4 for 200grammes) .... prices will go up when there are more customers, so find quieter shops further from the main square, you get better prices.BUT REMEMBER if you're asked for 300 Dirhams, pay 100... and not more.

Amazing. It goes on forever, can get lost really easily. Great if your good at haggling as nothing has a set price. Ps never settle for the first price always shop around as a lot of shops sell similar stuff.

Stall after stall of everything from lamps and leather to spices. Be prepared to barter for everything !! Can get a bit overwhelming at times ,just be prepared to say no forcefully but politely and most won't pester you ! Watch your wallets and be careful of the odd motorbike or donkey and be prepared to jump out of the way Otherwise well worth a visit

No Kidding ! 4000 stores !. Amaizing quality products, real handcraft everywhere, even if mixed with fakes and chinese merchandise. Crazy as hell, you will get lost, but eventually find the mains square and be recued. Not all the same, many different areas, and locals shopping there all the time.

Lost in Souks. If you really like hustle bustle and being 'collared' all the time, this is the place for you. It is such a shame as we found that you cannot even glance at something without the smallholder coming after you. One even followed us for about 100 yards through the souk!! There is so much to look at and the colours are lovely. Beware mopeds, donkeys and in fact anything coming through the tiny streets. Also beware of 'fake' guides. We had a local friend to show us around so were very lucky. Some of the signs to tourist places have apparently been put up by someone out of town so they are not correct. You can therefore get very lost or go around in circles! This is when the 'fake' guides come into play. If you get lost ask a shopkeeper. DO take a map with you. Many things in the tourist part of the souk are cheap and cheerful and WILL cost you an arm and a leg if you don't barter. Get them down by loads. They are the best salesmen in the world!! Things are in areas i.e. all carpets together, ironmongery together etc. There is so much to see which is so very different and in many ways exciting but potentially intimidating. One of the best phrases to use in the Souk is No thank you in Arabic. I can't spell it so can't write it. If they believe you speak a bit of Arabic you can be left a little more in peace!! Happy Souking!!

Lots of tat & pushy salesman but a definite must see!. Really interesting place- especially if you're coming from Europe/US and not used to it. The salesmen are really pushy and sometimes aggressive, puts you off looking at things as you don't want to be pressured to buy. Offer 50% of what they offer and deal at 60%

1001 nights...... Of course it's hard to find anything useful to buy but the oriental atmosphere is most impressive.The sellers are shall we say most persistent in their effort - sometimes annoyingly so.

no hassle souk. we loved this place as you can actually wander around and look at stuff without being hassled too much. It doesn't appear to be too touristy and sells some amazing stuff such as "upcycled" car tyres but you can still buy spices and slippers to your heart's desire. Easy to get lost in and also easy to avoid the bits you may not want to see like the snake charmers! Watch out for mopeds and bicycles being riden at speed
just so much fun. great shopping, fun haggling, felt really safe, clean, English spoken, and lots of French. easy to get lost! great to get there early the first visit!

Aladdin's Cave. Almost everythng here is hand made in the actual Bazaar or very nearby. It is amazing that people are still dyeing, cutting, shoemaking, weaving, metal and wood working to such good effect. When everything else in the world seems to be made in China, Morocco has its own craftsmen. I think it worthwhile to support them. But remember - don't pay a penny over a third of the first quoted price, will you!!

You get what you expect. The souk of Marrakech is what you expect. If you think you will be bothered by agressive salesmen you will, if you think it is a colourful and vivid market where you can find everything you want, you will. Visiting the souk of Marrakech (or any other souk in the middle east) is all about attitude. Hundreds of people try to make a living by selling goods mainly to tourists. They overcharge you but that is part of the deal. And it's yours to decide to buy anything, to bargain or just walk away. You can have a good lunch, dinner or even a drink in the souk. Buy nothing or a complete household. Ignore everybody or spend a day taking with everyone. Resumé, the souk is what you want it to be.

Great experience . Don't haggle unless you want to buy, if you are interested in something ask for the price, when given a price, offer 1/4 and haggling starts from there. Don't act attached to the item and be prepared to walk away and try another shop. Decide what the item is worth to you before you go in. When haggling give reasons why it's too expensive (you don't need it, find a mark, too big /small), they will drop the price or find you a better one. It is rude to offer a price and not pay out of the seller agrees so be careful. Remember that haggling is part of the culture so enjoy the experience and find a middle ground where both parties are happy, or just walk away. Don't spend the rest of the day wondering if you could have gotten it cheaper West of Djeema El Fan on the P2006 Road there is an artisan market with sey prices, go here of you can't handle the haggling!

confusing. You will get lost! Just stroll around and enjoy.Evenings are very crowded,so not as good as a daytime wander.It is very tiring,and must be more so in the summer months,a great place to rest and eat by the museum of Marrakech,just across from the entrance.A very pleasant and helpful young man there.Again,look out for the donkeys,horses and mopeds.

souks. Be prepared that you gonna buy things, that you not even expecting to buy:)Don't be afraid to huggle,if sellerasks 400 dirhams,start your huggle with 30-50 end in the end bouth parties be happy to agree on price somewhere around 120-150dirhams.

Fun. Only time we made a mistake we forgot to ask the guide showing us round the tanneries how much it would cost before he took us on the trip. When it had finished he held his hand out for 200 dirhams bearing in mind we had only been with him a short while. We got him down to 150 but still not a bargain.

Chaotic shopping experience. You cannot avoid the souks and if you get lost (which you will) someone will always offer you to find your way (for a fee - they will ask for €10 - give them €2). You will need to mind your step as bicycles, moterbikes wheel barrows and donkey pulling carts are everywhere.I suspect that there is nothing you cant but, but you will have to haggle starting at about half of what is asked.Hint - dont start haggling if you do not intend to buy

Be prepared... The souks offer an extraordinarily vivid glimpse of life and industry that remains little changed from half a century ago. Artisans still crouch in narrow openings banging bits of metal together and there are still some genuine, local crafts being pursued, if you can find them in among the bought-in tat. The problem isn't that there's nothing real there to wonder at and observe or even buy; the centre of the old city is unique and to walk its streets is to experience an assault on the senses. It's that to pause anywhere for more than a second invites relentless pressure and however much one tries to stay loose and enjoy the whole experience, falling into one carefully crafted ambush after another becomes depressing. Even after 'bartering' (why do the published guides persist in using that word as if it's a real fun experience?), spending ten times as much as something is worth just makes the buyer feel as though they'd rather be somewhere else. It's a shame none of the guides tell you the truth - not one I've read anyway. Perhaps if they did, the locals would wise up, hassle less, understand the difference between haggling and fraud, realise tourists have souls as well as wallets and make this wonderful city a better place to visit.

SOUK. Really great takes about three days, wait until you buy as the same goods are for sale everywhere and the price changes in each area, we bought mens slippers for 100 and were offered them for 400 so look around and wait until the end of your holiday and then go and buy, the leather is good quality but some is cheap so smell it if it stinks it will always stink because it has not been treated properly, I bought a bag and it smells. The thinner leather is not good but the thicker leather is really good, we met a guy at the airport he bartered for a nice leather holdall and he paid 400 which is about the right price so look around.

A trip into a maze.. An amazing mixture of everything with e.g. high- class craftsmanship and pharmacy cheek-by-jowl with the most desperate scraping of a living from recycling of materials. A veritable maze of narrow streets and alleyways - would not like to attempt to do it without a guide!
plenty to buy. The soul has plenty to offer. The guides take you to fixed price and cooperatives. Be prepared to haggle it is expected.
An Absolute Must. An absolutely facinating place.Not seen anything quite like it!Lots of 'Arcades' selling all kinds of Goods.Not to be missed.

It's an experience. well if you can drive a hard bargain but unfortunitly not for us , give us a fair price and il pay it it truly was fun for about 1 minute but horses for courses I suppose did really enjoy having coffe in one of the roof top terraces as we watched other people do there bargaining Still it's an experience I glad to have had but won't bother going back unless I have my mother in law with me might get a few camels for her ha ha All in Al fun but just not my thing

Surprisingly little hassle!. Simply row upon row of fascinating Moroccan gifts and souvenirs and was pleasantly surprised after Tunisia how happily the majority of vendors allowed you to browse their wares. Be prepared to haggle about the prices, they will start incredibly high! Not an experience I enjoyed too much but well worth it to get your goods at a bargain price! Check the quality of the wares at a few stalls before starting to haggle! A maze of colour, each turn in the souks brings you to a different shopping experience?
A never ending maze!. A great place to visit, you will 100% get lost while exploring the narrow cobbled streets. Plenty of character and charm running through these streets and a truly majestic feel.

Marvelous. Fantastic stores for leather goods, nuts, pashminas, and fake everything. Must walk around, must negotiate HARD, and be mindful of pickpockets. Be weary, there is a reason why there is NO price tag on anything, you will be quoted whatever the merchant feels like, and believes you can pay.Negotiate hard.Example, wooded chess board with hand made pieces, from 1800 dhirams, to 350. A fantastic place to walk, see and shop.

Hounding Tourists!!!!. Be very careful not to take any photos of the monkeys or the cobra's without negociating a price first. They hound you for $$$$ and its never enough. The Morocaans want to sell you everything and anything. If they ask for an item 200 duram then you can probably get it for 50- 70 duram. Less than half the asking price. Be savy!

Colourful. A very interesting morning spent looking at the stalls. All a wonderful blend of colours, smalls and sounds - if you want to buy anything make sure that you barter - a discount of anything up to 70% is available, but it might take a little while to get the stallholders down that low!

Daunting.. But fun. On entering the souks we were hanging onto each other, however we soon overcame this and found if you showed no interest or said no thank you with a smile all was well... Got lost few times but always found way out. Would not take children here.. Too busy..

Shop til you drop!. A maze of heaving narrow alleyways and side streets where every shop owner will try to entice you in offering the best price for whatever you want - lots of "genuine fakes" and well as typical Moroccan souvenirs. Haggling is the only way to buy but don't be afraid to walk away if you don't like the price. Shops are a bit samey after a while but it's worth trying to find your way deeper in to the various souks (dyers, iron workers, wood workers etc) but don't rely on the signs for directions.Guides are available at a cost but they will take you to the places where they get the greatest kickbacks and you'll have to sit through demonstrations in the pharmacies.The butchers are not for the faint hearted......

Aladdin's cave!. Colours, smells, noise, busy, shocking to all your senses! look around, don't get pressured to purchase unless you are sure! Walk away, haggle haggle haggle and SMILE! I think you have to take it for what it is and enjoy it... yes the stall holders want you to spend but that is part of it! WE managed to get some great bargains and we live in Portugal where things are cheaper than the UK and USA already... but had do do some hard bargaining.

Fantastic colours, marvellous place to wonder!. If you should ever go, take time off to wonder through the different souks and be sure to get all the way out to the outskirts of the souks where prices often go down! Sellers eagfer to get into a conversation with you, trying to get you into their shops - but almost all the time, very freindly and kindBe prepared to haggel to the 1/5 of the price first offered. Even if it means you have to start leaving the shop, the owner might just come running after you. Know your items before hand, and their correct price. Do not buy pigments at the tanneries and wool dyers, go to the herbstore instead. The tannery was a total rip off for us, beware! beware of locals who offer to show you the way, they will all want money in the end.Weather rather chilly while we stayed. People very friendly - but lots of exhaust in the Medina. cats everywhere!

Haggling Galore . If you're a bunch of girls with no male in your tourist group, prepare to be cat called and commented on at all times! You learn to ignore it but it can be off putting and almost scary too. Haggling is key in the Souks. Never pay the price that they tell you and you will be sure to bag a bargain.

Absolutely fantastic. Sights, sounds, colours, smells and the ever present welcome from the stall holders - a full on sensory experience. A bit overpowering at first, but haggling becomes a simple game and quite fun when you get the hang of it. It's quite liberating not to be tied to the price tag!

Grubby. I personally did not like the souks i felt it was dirty & was full of beggars who tried to keep touching me i could not get out of there quick enough to be honest! My husband on the other hand loved it so maybe i am just a one off!Just walkin ere from the hotel was like risking life & limb as the roads are soooooo busy & dangerous.

A great experience but be prepared to haggle. We loved walking through the souqs and looking at the various wares. We found that if we did not want to look sellers responded well to a smile and a no thank you and rarely pursued it further than this. There was a lot of different items to look at including spices, medicines, clothes and odd assortments of items. It became quite a competition between us to see who could get the "best haggle". We had been advised by our hostel owners to offer at least 50% below the asking price (and one of them suggested 75% below the asking price) and did try this several times. We were lucky in that the weather was not very hot but I can imagine that in the summer months it could be a bit too hot in the souqs so try and go in the evening then.

Enjoy the Souk experience. Loved bartering and visiting the diverse 'shops' talking to the friendly locals, eating the local food with friendly waiters and fellow guests, then having a ride around the city in horse and carriage
Caution. Good deals to be had, but communicate clearly and exactly so as not to be misunderstood... Or cheated.
Too expensive. You have to be aware because shop owners will do anything to sell you sth 10x the price.Do not buy anything unless you are alone without a guide
A bargainer's paradise. Great to visit but the pawing soon palls. It's difficult to shake off the sales folk when ignoring people is not in one's nature.
Just looking!. Loved haggling in the souks, keep a price in your head and don't be scared of walking away. Some fixed prices stalls for those not so keen on haggling.
Wonderful experience. Loved the little shops, the historic atmosphere and helpful shop keepers.Due to my eldest daughter's fluent French we had no problems conversing and bartering.

A Sensual Roller Coaster of Delights. Having been to souks and night markets in other cities we were prepared for the onslaught of salesmanship. There is all manner of goods on offer from the fascinating to the downright kitsch. We enjoyed moving from one métier of souk to another and really enjoyed the ferroniers which seemed more real than some of the others. Once again some clearer signage would help the frustrated tourist but when eventually you work out the two principal entrances it becomes much easier and even more enjoyable.

A MUST FOR ALL TRAVELLERS. One of the worlds most vibrant places, Go and haggle, eat great food, chill on a roof terrace,watch the snake charmers,take a tour in a pony and trap taxi, meet some real characters and grab a bargain.

just an experience. To us this was just an experience, we did not buy a thing as everything on show is available in street markets everywhere, but the experience is definitely unique, at first you do feel uncomfortable with the clash of cultures but we soon found the people to be friendly and a lot of the sales pitch is definitely tongue in cheek.If your looking for bargains Home Bargains and B&M have bucket loads but if your after s cultural treat and unique experience this is the place to come.

Cultural excursion!. It was a crazy wonderful sometimes stressful experience!!! Sights and sounds to remember, very crowded. Primary stress was all the speeding mopeds on the narrow winding streets and sidewalks. Also lots of hustling to buy their wares. Beware of fake items from China. Recommend a guide do you don't get lost - it's huge! Overall, it's an amazing experience!
A spectacle but better shopping elsewhere. Great to walk round to experience Marrakesh, but there is much better shopping elsewhere on street corners/smaller markets.

Another Souk. It is a souk (market) like many others but in Marrakech due to the city is well-known around the world the people try to cheat you and they will rise the prices more than you are expectred to pay. Be carefull when you buy in Marrakech, because they sell you the same things that they sell in the other cities but for a higher price.

Loved the colour and the craziness. The Marrakech Souks were bustling with activity, shiny objects, colours and great smells.It's worthwhile going a couples of times during the day as storekeepers have different opening times. It's not the easiest job in the world navigating around stuff on the ground, other people and vehicles whilst simultaneously paying attention to shopkeepers and their wares. You could easily spend an entire day wandering through and getting lost, exploring shops, bargaining, buying random (and mostly pointless/useless) things. It's definitely worth bargaining hard and walking away if you don't like someone's price - you will definitely find what you're looking for in another store and it will let you know if the price they're asking for is the going rate everywhere or if you're just being taken for a ride.

Good fun. It's binkers fun, full of street sellers and gifts. Haggle for everything (about a third of the original cost) and don't get talked into buying more than you want. Stay safe, keep your bag secured, don't wander off deep into the souk after 8pm and be confident. If ladies find men following them, just stop, look at some gifts or go into a cafe and make sure the men pass. I took photos of some men who followed us, which put them off.

Haggle Shamelessly. Never be scared to walk away if you dont like the price - if he doesn't lower it you'll find the same thing in at least another 5 shops! Whatever amount they ask for, offer half as a starting point! Be polite, try and laugh with them, and you'll do well.

best shopping on da planet!. first thing that will capture you its the shady light showering from above, giving a charming atmosphere to the small streets.There are millions of things you would buy and bring home, from kaftans to sandals, from carpets to amazing lamps, beauty products based on argan oil and rose water - a beauty secret that will keep your skin hydrated and wrinkle free, guaranteed! Spices, best olives in Africa, pastries to die for, etc etcA tip to enjoy cruising the market without being stressed and pulled to every shop >> I ALWAYS go there with big visible headphones and music - after a while they give up talking to you and you enjoy a nice movie!

crowdy souk. The souk is very crowdy (like most of the souks), but here it was too touristic for me. & take care for pick pockets.The northern souk is more authentic. You cannot bargain there because most of the "shop" are owned by cooperatives. (more interesting if you like the real herbs, soaps,oils etc & much more quite.

Nice but boring. If you are in Marrakesh just for 1-2 days it is good to spend there like 3-4 hours, but if you want to buy something like leather bag or shoes it is good to spend there more and know what is real price. (They start with 500%-1000% of ordinar price)

Scary and fun. At any time in the day we got men staring at us and trying to chat us up which is really scary to begin with. Be careful that tourists easily get ripped off and don't feel bad if you even half the price they are asking for and to think what you would pay in your currency. It's such a culture shock walking down these souks and a once in a life time experience however it is easy to get lost and i know you can download a Marrakech app that uses gps that will never get you lost! Dont always trust the directions you are given or follow any one who is leading you as they just want money from you. Definitely bring lots and lots of hand sanitizer too!!

Bargain with respect!. Colours, fragrance, exotic ambience, like wandering from one page of the 1001 Nights Fairy Tales to another page. The chaos, to some disturbing while to me fascinating and captivating. The sellers are always trying, yet in a gracious and respectful way compared to many other Countries I have been. Extremely friendly and helpful people. Dare to take the first step forward, relax and open up ....... a whole new exotic and beautiful world awaits you in the medina. In the Soukhs they selff from denchers to spices to herbal medicines to anything and everything that you might want and also would never need! From my travelling experience, one thing I would recommend for those who wish to buy something is leather products.Bargain bargain and always bargain! Bargaining is not a trade but a culture – where two people communicate with respect! Be your nicest and wittiest self, play (bargain) with mutual respect and at least visit two to three different shops before you eventually buy. For heaven’s sake do not bargain for the sake of bargaining or because your Tour Leader told you that you have to ask for 1/3rd the price. It looks attrociously ridiculous and sad when Tourists bargain for 1/3rd the price for something that to start with costs half a Euro.I love Marrakech, Moroccon People and the Berber Culture that many prowdly retain. Moroccon People are extremely friendly and kind. But this does not mean that you should leave your antenas and brains behind.PLEASE BE WARNED : I would not recommend you to take out Money from the ATM vending Machines at Djema el Fna. Your card might end up being copied or fished.

Fascinating. But keep on your toes. Small narrow streets full of merchandise, very much the same thing gas you walk round. Keep your bearings as easy to get lost then get people advising you to go the wrong way cause it's past their uncles shop. Overall though did enjoy the visit, but relieved once back out onto the square.

Very different. There are never ending shops selling the same thing and all the shopkeepers want you to look and barter as always the same line we give you very good price. You must go to experience the atmosphere and its not as bad as people make out. We never felt threatened at all by the people but don't know how they make a living.

souks you sir but does not souk me. I recently went to the souks in Marrakech I was not impressed as the streets are full of motor cycles and as they are very narrow it is highly dangerous in terms of walking as you take your life into your hands.Be careful or you may be accosted by a local begging for money or offering to show you the way down the maze of streets and then leading you astray and asking you for payment as you have somehow unbeknown to you employed them as your personal guide!I suggest that you do not attempt to travel to the souks alone particularly as a lone woman for your own safety!

Worth a visit. The soul goes on and on .. You realise the merchandise is all very alike .. All the traders are very insistent .. A few have some understanding of Western customs and purchasing habits !

Fascinating, but SUPER intimidating.. Loved it for five minutes, then it became too intimidating as you are HASSLED by EVERYONE. I know it's part of the experience but it does get a little old, especially when you're basically cussed out for merely browsing in a store, or because you genuinely don't want something, nor give any indication you did.

authentic - a must do. I expected many items made in China - but found most items are authentically made locally, some in the market itself.The fact that the locals buy from the souk is what makes it special....

Dont look in their direction. when in the seek look at all the interesting things from a distance as the "Minders approach anyone near to them with a camera demanding a fee for supposedly taking a photo of a snake - monkey - whatever - my son was actually changing his camera battery when a man approached him demanding a fee for photos he had not taken and whilst told to clear off was extremely reluctant to do and even yelled over to some of his cronies for assistance .Never gave into his demands but worth watching out for .Also if you don't want a snake hung over your shoulder don't get too close , likewise with the monkey's .The Souk itself is good apart from the high pressure pay me mob and the Lookie Lookie men selling fake gear by the drove .was good once but having seen it never will I feel the need to do it again

Souk.
