Love it, felt very safe, only thing , if you wanted to take any pictures of snakes/ charmers , monkeys etc they want you to pay , did not like that , loved the hussle and bussle of everything going on. I bought a leather briefcase for my work , paid around £40.00 which i think back in scotland would have paid £100.00. Quality was superb . You do need to barter as thats there way.

Cacophony of noise. Disappointed in this place...glad I went and think everyone should go...for a brief hour to see it...snake charmers (aaaghh!) men dragging poor little monkeys around by the necks...people yelling...getting harrassed by street venders...so easy to get lost...we did...and then everyone wanting to "help" you....for money....One of those things you do...and say...well I am glad I went but....!!!
good day. went in the day and at night, eaten in one of the bars here it was very traditional and good food. did some bargins with the locals all good fun not in your face as much as tunisa.good fun
Nice. Lots of shops, good things to buy but you have to haggle... Very big and a bit confusing with all the small streets and alleys.

The place to be. Yes, this is the place to be in Marrakech alright. Not that it's posh, quite the opposite in fact. It's nightlife writ large. All the mini restaurateurs set up their little eating places come the evening, and they vie for your patronage - sometimes rather over enthusiastically. Don't make the mistake of saying, "later" if you don't mean it. Some get very cross with you if you don't keep your word. The food is cheap, not great, but what do you expect for the price. There's lots of free entertainment going on too, but they do like a freewill offering - and why not, you're on holiday. Watch your bags and pockets (of course) and go to the new city if you want to eat well. By the way, there is just one public loo. It's pay-per-go, and a bit smelly, but it does the job!

First Timer. I have no point of reference, so unable to make comparisons. I would describe myself as risk averse, so some of the comments on TA and in various guide books had me not exactly quaking in my boots, but very much on my guard. I was expecting tat and coercion. What I found, especially in Moussaine, was a clamourous, colourful and charming excursion into a different and fascinating world. Ventured in twice during our 4 day stay. I only got to see about one fifth of what was on offer. Next time I will plan shopping calmly at home, take an extra shopping/hold bag, research DHL delivery costs and take 4 days to souk it all up! Oh, and no offence intended - encourage my husband to stay at home. Come on girls, you know what page l'm on. Don't believe I will feel threatened as we were treated respectfully by everyone.

yuck. Have been to many souks and this place is dangerous , got knocked by a car jumping every five mins motor cycles whizzing by and the place very dirty. Vendors can be agressive especially locals demanding money. Go somewhere else for a holiday.

Here's what I paid in the souks... and had a blast!. Alright, so here's a detailed list of what I purchased and how much I paid, with some pictures at the end. I was looking for how much other people had paid for the items I was looking to buy prior to me going out on my last day of my trip, which I had dedicated as a "shopping in the souks" day. Knowing what others paid would give me an idea of how I should barter and what to expect to pay. Also, I felt saving my last day for shopping was wise. The three days prior I had spent plenty of time walking around the medina and in the souks, picking out what I wanted to buy and from which shop (even though almost all of them sell the same things). Hopefully this is helpful to you.Let me also say that I found the souks fun and interesting. There's so much to see, smell, taste, and hear. The metal smiths area was really fascinating, to see them all pounding away and making things. If you can find that area, really stop for a minute to watch.You'll get lost for sure - it's part of the experience. On my second day I pretty much had the place mapped out in my head. But getting lost was truly enjoyable. As the days passed, I recognized places I had been and would purposefully go down an alley I knew I hadn't been down before, which is how I discovered the metal smiths area.Tagine: I only paid 35 dirham for a large tagine, the largest I saw. That's right, only $3.50 (roughly). I was able to do this because I had the staff worker at my riad use one of her local friends to purchase for me. Yeah, I know, that's kind of cheating, but hey I got the "locals" price. Maybe you can do the same.Teapot: I also used my riad's staff worker's friend and only paid 150 dirham - $15 for a brand new, shiny, handmade teapot.Small tagines: This was my first attempt at actually bartering. I ended up paying 220 dirham, or about $22 for FOUR. So, about $5.50 each. I think I lost that battle badly, but after looking at what others had paid, I was close to the same prices.Lamps: I was looking for some simple, dark coppery/steel colored, multi-color-glass lanterns. I purchased six of them for 500 dirham (~$50). I bought these directly from one of the smiths in the smith alley part of the souk. He originally asked 600, and after a few back and forths with prices he started saying that the "democratic" price was 550. I kept saying 500 and he said OK. I'm sure a tougher bargainer than me could probably have gotten them cheaper. 500 for six of them is about $8.50 per lantern.Slippers: Paid 300 dirhams ($30) for three pairs, two regular pairs of indoor slippers, and one pair of outdoor slippers. I believe he originally asked 500 dirhams.Scarfs: 200 dirhams for two of the nicer scarfs. He asked 220 and I countered with 180 (I know, not much of a bargainer I am...)Jewelry: One large necklace with turquoise and some other stones, along with a pair of "silver" (real silver? - who knows) for 200 dirhams. He originally asked for 250 dirhams.Signs: I picked up three hand-painted signs for 250 dirhams ($25). He originally asked for 650 dirhams!!! I think I did better bartering for those than other items I purchased.Carpets: Alright, so this was the big one. I read a lot about carpets. This was difficult, and I'm pretty sure I didn't do very well. I did make sure to purchase from a store involved in a woman's cooperative, so that most of the money would go back to the women in the communities involved in the cooperative, which I really felt good about. We were in the carpet shop for probably 1.5 hours. We looked through a LOT of rugs. I wasn't looking for anything large, in fact I was looking for two small rectangular rugs to place in door entryways. Well, they didn't really have those, so I ended up buying a runner and a small to medium sized area rug (pictures attached to this review). He started his price at 5,200 dirhams (roughly $520). I eventually paid 4,300, or $430, after some bargaining. He threw in a small square rug when we were done bartering.Overall, you will never come out on top. But then again, what is on top? You have to set limits for yourself on how much you want to spend. There are no set prices, but there is I'm sure a price at which the seller would not make any profit. Yeah, no doubt they rip tourists off, but that's how they make their living. And their standard of living is extremely low relative to developed nations. At the same time, it was fun on a few of the bartering sessions, and interesting to say the least on all of my bartering sessions. The sellers can be genuinely humorous, but truthfully you can tell ALL of them just want your money. On most occasions, immediately after the exchange of money and goods were completed, the sellers wouldn't give me a second look.I've read that most people start at roughly 1/3 the initial asking price. The sellers will be overly dramatic about your counteroffer, but believe me, it's all part of the game. They huff and puff, ask you if you're a Berber, etc, etc, but again it's all part of the game. Don't be afraid to start low, but at the same time don't go SO low you insult them. I have read a couple articles about tourists countering so low the sellers refused to barter and essentially were asked to leave the shop.Take your time, get lost, and be fascinated by another culture. The sellers are annoying, doing or saying anything to get your attention, even if you rest your eyes in their shop for just two seconds! But, you'll become immune to it in no time!Recommendations:-Go in the morning, 9-10AM, when there are less people. (The souks can and do get VERY crowded, with locals and tourists alike).-Get lost on purpose. Just ask any shop-owner to point you in the direction back to the main square, if you need to. Do NOT listen to anyone who approaches you and asks to be your guide or begins to tell you where the square is when you didn't ask - it's a scam.-Keep your money in different pockets. I had money in just about every pocket - front jeans pockets, zip-up jacket pockets, wallet, but NOTHING in my back pockets.-Smile. Laugh. Makes jokes with the sellers.-If you're from the US, UK, Canada, Australia, Germany, or other similar Western, developed nations (or Japan), the prices are higher for you. I was Canadian for one purchase, a Kiwi (New Zealand) for another, and American for another... it was fun telling white-lies like that. Didn't really make a difference.-I thought it was beneficial to have my girlfriend with me. We would "consult" or "agree/disagree" on prices. In one instance, by arguing amongst ourselves, the seller reduced the price by 50 dirham after I told him my "wife" wouldn't let me go as high as I had stated; it worked to our advantage. In sum, be creative on your bartering.Good luck!

So Many liitle stalls in a Rabbit Warren. the famous souks - hundreds of stalls, usually collected together by product in a real maze. The vendors are not as pushy as other places we have been, and if you say no will direct you on to where you want to go. Very easy to get lost, and a few people will try and lead you out (usually young men) either for money, or via their stall! Tip - the Jemaa al Fna Square is usually signposted on green signs over your head - so fins your way out and start again. And always negotiate - of course the first offer is far more than they expect,,,

Too many faux guides, aggressive store keepers. The souks in Tanger, Fez, Chefchoauen and Meknes are better in all aspects - interest, pricing and variety. Shopkeepers very aggressive. If it your only soul, by all means go,

Could be better if... This place would be better if you visit with a local person or with a friend from Morocco. It's easy to get lost and some local people may be quite disturbing to pretend to explain you the way and to get you completely lost and then to ask for money when, after an hour or two, you find the place you were looking for. By the way, I think they don't get you lost your way on purpose but they really do not know any place.

so easy to get lost. my advice to here would be if you want to buy something but it there and then because unless you really know it then trying to find the same place twice could be a pain. Again we didnt get much hassle walking through.We hired a guide for our first morning and so glad we did as we seen places and things inside the souk we would never have went to.

overwhelming. The souks are crowded and huge. You will likely get lost inside but enjoy the journey, there is no wrong way. The sellers will try to get you to stop and look, they are friendly merchants looking for business. Keep a smile on your face and enjoy the banter. My first entry to the souk was short and I departed quickly. My second foray I was better prepared and enjoyed the maze.
exciting. Didn't like it when the locals tried to touch you but overall felt safe and fascinated in the contents of the stalls, loved the spices and the leathers!

An experience!. A real experience that will bombard your senses. Sights, sounds and smells that grap your attention. The people are polite and friendly. Don't confuse their desire to sell you their wares as anything other than a need to make a living. We had some great fun bartering and buying.
what a buzz. took my friends this time was fun watching them haggle for a bargain I also convinced them to eat at the night market quite something for girls who usually cruise.

Shop till you drop!. The souks are full of interesting objects and some possible bargains but you have to have the energy to look at lots and haggle away. I found the whole experience a little exhausting but also fun and different. I was better at haggling than I thought and always started by cutting their first offer to under half - at times they laughed out loud but this is all part of the game! The streets are pretty narrow and packed and make sure you walk on the left. I kept forgetting and just wandering from side to side but there are crazy mopeds and donkeys and carts everywhere. There are some quirky gifts to be had and lots of leather goods if you have the patience to search for the right ones.

Just another world. Marrakesh souk covers a vast area and you will get lost in there. It's a fascinating place and a must see. if you do want to buy something, go to one of the government fixed price shops first. That will give an idea of what is a fair price. In places like this there is always some scam, here your 'guided' to the tannery for a tour then a visit to their shop. Don't go!! The shop is vastly overpriced then your extorted money for the tour. It's done very cleverly and friendly until they get into the shop.
Great Fun!. Bargaining is a must and not difficult! The number of little shops is overwhelming but just like you expect them to be....so atmospheric!

Tired to be robed . What the point ! People are trying to rob you every corner . Price are 4 times the price of Essaouira. And the Berbers village . Buy a carpet or any thing just start your Nego at a quarter of the price . Do not follow any guy in the small late they will try to rob you . If you are lost ask the lady they are trustworthy.

Exciting place. The Souks are exciting to visit. We felt safe and if we were approached by sellers and we were not interested we just said "no thanks" with a smile and they went away. They are divided into sections selling spices, clothes, leather goods etc. Well worth a visit.

A mazeing. A maze from start to finish can be a little intimidating the first time.
Had an argument with a seller who tried to tell me all the goods in England were from China and of poor quality. I pointed out he'd never been to England and I live there and leather bags were just as good there and cheaper

A must visit but not to buy!. The rush and colours of the souk is a must experience for anyone going to Marrakesh. Involve yourself with the banter the barter the fun the laugher. You will be harassed you will be called fish and chips I truly enjoyed it. But wow it's difficult to get a decent price they start ridiculously high and don't move, go local to say the Kasbah and barter there!
maze. This place is a maze. There are lots of alleyways, shops, dirt, animals, men! mosques, noise ... bargains to be found tho!
eeeeee- not my fave. A little too congested and crowded and smelly and muddy and stressful. Probably there are better souks elsewhere where better quality stuff.

Bargain hard. If you are tempted to buy anything in the Souks, offer a maximum of 25% of their asking price and when they say no, walk away. They will follow you and the price will tumble. Still do not buy, and with the "final" price you can gauge where to start with another seller. There are hundreds, so just be wise and patient. However always be cheerful and polite even when saying no, they will often say "maybe tomorrow".

Must see.. Stores and stalls filled with traditional Moroccan crafts. This was my favourite area to shop as there is so much choice. Be prepared to barter. Advice - carry a spare wallet with a smaller amount of money inside to avoid traders pushing up the prices on sight of a full wallet.

Be prepared to get lost!. Be firm but polite if you don't want to buy and always haggle in good spirit. Lots of bargains but lot's of characters waiting to take advantage of you so keep your wits about you. Resist what appear to be kind offers to show you around as they will undoubtedly just take you to their friends shop. Take a map but at the end of the day keep walking. A great experience! Have an idea of the maximum you would be prepared to pay and don't be afraid to walk away.

Crazy beautiful. It's a market, what more can I say? It's hectic, with people, donkeys, motorcycles and cats all over the place. And of course, millions upon millions of things to buy. It's hot, people are friendly, you can bargain, you laugh alot. It's a wonderful place :)

Barter is what it's about. The souk and markets in the main square are just filled with lovely presents to take home. Bags, Pashminas, wooden boxes, lightening, spices, trainers (inc: Converse), branded t-shirts and bartering is the name of the game. You have to remember that this is a very different experience so go with an open mind. you will have cars, motorbikes, cycles and carts coming at you from all directions but it all adds to the atmosphere. Watch the main square in one of the roof top restaurants etc around late afternoon as it's transformed into pop up restaurants all wanting you to go in. Quite simply amazing

Great fun. Super fun throughout, have you wits about and never ever pay the first price! Aim for 40/50% and haggle to get the price you want! So many things to look at, to buy and to avoid. I general the metal work seemed to be of a good quality. Remember Haggle Haggle Haggle!

Vibrant colourful souk. It is great to see so many of the products being made in souk; leather goods, material, metal lamps and fabrics. Easy to get lost, but that is part of the fun and every corner produces a new feast for the eyes.

Interesting City. Maraakech is a very diverse and interesting city. The new city is spacious and modern and the Medina and its different areas are traditional and mysterious, The main interest areas are the Big central square in the evening as it allows a glimpse into the origins of traditional life, food, and culture. Be aware that if you take a picture during the day or night on the square you will be intimidated to pay for that picture! To buy items in the square and around it use the rule of tumb of offering 35 to 40% of the asked price and not increasing it until the final negotiation on the part of the vendor is pronounced. The more you stand on your price firmly the better a deal you can have. If they let you go you can then increase your offering by a small amount. That is when the deal can be made. Look at it a a bargain dance that you will be the winner if you stand your ground.

overwhelming, but in a good way. the most important advice I've received in Marrakech was "don't buy anything the first time you visit the souks" - cause at first it all seems so amazing and you want to buy everything you see (at least I did)), but really most of the things you see are ridiculously overpriced and of low quality. so look around, try to find something you wouldn't regret in the morning and haggle like crazy.

rip off for tourists.. everything you can see in the souks is sold by government run shops. any single piece you see can be bought for a tourist price in those shops. so my suggestion is to check fixed price shops first and then find it in the souks trying to get a cheaper price. Never pay for what they ask you is at least 10 times more. for example they try to ask 20 dirhams a gram for euclyptus crystals when i could get it for 1 dirham a gram (and still expensive considering the market price). wooden boxes sold for 100 dirhams are sold in essaouira for 10. So have fun but don't pay anything more than what you would pay in your own country or online. Leather is not expensive if you have tons and tons of it and all the handmade things you will see are actually mass produced and you will see them in every souk of every city in morocco.

Lovely variety. Greattt stuff to buy you are almost overwhelmed. There is a lot of repetition as almost everyone sells the same stuff, but be sure to HAGGLE and never accept the first price! EVER! Unless it's something silly like a keyring for 10dirhams, haggggglllleeee!!!!!
Souks.. Very good experience would highly recommend a trip to the souks. The bartering was something you should try they love to haggle with you.

Fabulous experience spoilt by being badgered. The souks are a wonderful set of craft shops in a quaint maze of narrow streets. Unfortunately we were continually badgered by locals trying to be our 'guides'. If only they had left us alone the shops would be much more interesting and undoubtedly they would sell more. My advice would be to only go in with a real guide so that he can keep the children and adults away and allow proper consideration of the local (excellent) craft products.

There's no substitute for experience!. If souks are new, Marrakech's will be somewhat intimidating at first. Mind you, most things are at first... Driving on the right, eating with chop sticks, riding a camel etc. Everything gets easier after a bit and the souks are no exception. We've been to many that are much worse than these, though!The stall holders do take no for an answer especially if it's in Arabic (La) and followed by thanks (Shokran).Everything has to be haggled for, which is fun and good natured as long as the customer is... well, fun and good natured.Keep smiling, only haggle for things you're interested in and take the precaution of a visit to the Ensemble Artisanale before arrival. It's a government, fixed price craft emporium where you can work out the going price for all sorts of stuff before trying to beat it in the souks.Getting lost in the Souks is genuinely delightful but never accept unsolicited offers of assistance from anyone, though. You'll end up being charged for 'help', guided to the tannery where some rather nasty people might demand even greater sums to get you out!Ask a stall holder or just keep wandering until you see a way out!You can find everything you can think of in the souks but my highlight was the result of a search on Trip Advisor. I found 'Marrakech Food Tours' and booked an evening with them. It was the best thing we did in Morocco and we discovered parts of the souks we would never have seen otherwise. Just great!
It's mad but cool. It's so crazy at the square but I went everyday lol still ! Liked the food, did get harassed by locals only 4 us to buy from them,

i love this place. for the colors the crafts etc but it is a pain to shop especially if you dont like haggling! its in their culture be firm/ joke around and show them that you know about their products and just make sure you have a price in mind that you would like to pay for anything u wish to buy- dont get annoyed they are a bit forceful but only stop in one shop after you have been there for one or two days and you have made up your mind on what you want to get! some vendors are really nice!

Awe and wonder at its best !. A trip to Marrakech is not complete without a visit to the souk! We had a half-day tour for our first visit as it helps to orientate yourself before going it alone ! We went 3 times in all - at different times of the day and all were wonderful. Leave plenty of time as you will undoubtably be pulled in for a display of carpets, then "my friend next door" at the fixed price shop, then another friend at the perfume shop. At the time you feel annoyed that your time is being used up, but the products on display are wonderful and the shopkeepers all have such an easy-going attitude if you don't want to buy their goods - if you don't then someone else certainly will ! The souk is marvellous. It is a maze of tiny winding alleys between crumbling buildings which house small workshops with houses upstairs. Here you can see the craftsmen at work - making everyday items for the locals - and you realise how much the souk is a way of life rather than a tourist attraction. The streets open out towards a smaller square and the area is filled with the more familiar free-standing stalls selling everything from fruit and veg to leather jackets. It is a feast of sights, sounds and smells and it is wonderful just to take it all in, regardless of whether you plan to buy anything. During the day, the main square is fairly empty and you are more likely to be targeted by ladies offering henna designs, men with pitiful monkeys with their teeth removed, snake charmers and water sellers with exotic outfits - all trying to have a photo taken ... at a price ! The trick here is to go to a restaurant with a roof-top terrace, then take in all the atmosphere along with a cool drink and a zoom lens on your camera ! You could easily be viewing a medieval scene .. if it wasn't for the jumble of satellite dishes on the rooftops. At night the main square is transformed into an enormous bustling throng of stalls, entertainers and people. The food stalls are manned by locals who have clearly grown up in England, so many have cockney accents and the set phrases "Cheaper than Aldi and much cheaper than Asda!" or "Hey, have you been watching Eastenders recently?" , however the majority of other stalls are there for the locals and only offer a smattering of English. The entertainment is vast and varied - very much along the lines of Covent Garden in London - with musicians, acrobats, fortune tellers, boxing, cock fighting and various gambling activities. Despite the huge crowds, we felt completely safe all the time.We bought very little on our trip, as our intention was to look rather than to buy, but the leather goods were fantastic, the fabrics were beautiful and the perfumes were intoxicating !
get a tour. i would highly recommend getting a tour organised for the souks otherwise you will miss out seeing a massive amount of the souks and quite probably get lost ;-)

The best souk ever. Many many streets full of stores where the locals shop and the tourists stroll. We felt very safe, even at night, and as long as you can deal with the many people trying to sell you something, you will have a great time. You have to bargain for your items, and mostly can get your item for 50% less then the first offer.

Crazy. This is one of the most interesting places that I have ever been. For me it was a place to observe. The craftsmanship is variable, you have to walk around for a day as you will see the difference in quality between vendors. And a price is ALWAYS negotiable. Not just a small amount. We paid on average 60%-80% below their asking price.

Genuine quality shoemaker. Walking through the Marrakech Medina Souk looking for leather 'Babouche' shoes and not finding anything worth buying in my size (45), I happened upon the small shop of Sayd Tahiri Youssef. Finally someone who made quality shoes himself in many different styles. After a bit of haggling walked out there with with lovely leather babouches at a very good price (120 Dhiram).Youssef himself was very friendly and also imparted upon me that he also the keeper of Geocache GC4YXKY, which meant a lot more to him that it did to me!Well worth a visit: 79, Sidi Ishak Azbezt, opposite the Azbezt mosque.

Lost in Souk. I was really lookingn forward to seeing the souks. This is larger than any we'd been to in Turkey or Tunisia and it didn't disappoint. Get your bartering head ready, you're going to need it. There were some amazing offerings from leather, fabrics, metalwork, ceramics and lots of stuff I can't remember. Mostly good value. Got the other half a pair of boots. Really nice soft leather and carpet panels. She's worn them a lot they are so comfortable. The trader started at 3,500 dirhams and I ended up paying 550 for them. Bargain, or what? Watch for the mopeds down the really narrow alleys as you don't hear some of them coming and keep to the right hand side.Overall an experience not to be missed.
Crazy but fun. We downloaded the Marrakech City2Go free app which meant we didn't get lost (this time!) in the souks. Great bargains and lots of fun bargaining!

Big hassle for China made goods.. I found the constant hassle to be too aggressive and exhausting for this to be a fun experience. There seemed to be very little authentic Moroccan culture, it's turned into a huge trap designed to con money from tourists for items which mostly seem to be mass produced in China. I'm sure there are authentic craftmade things there too but the aggression put us off so much that we daren't look at anything. There is zero regulation or protection for visitors.

souks experience was uninspiring. The Souks, we're pleasant enough and suprisingly understanding if declined with manners and conviction. No need for a map in my opinion, easy to navigate round, easier by day than night though, as it seems less busy by day, night it is rammed! The goods are much the same from one Souk to another, haggling is the deal, I suggest you pay no more than half than the opening offer and that is top end...The experience was good, but I'll not repeat it, nothing stood out for me in the Souks.

Bargain Hunting. Loved the variety of goods, colours and bustle of the alleys.
Must buys, textiles from pashminas to throws, amazing.
Don't but without bargaining, it's expected & such fun.

Everyone wants you money. No exceptions. You have to go here when you visit Marrakech, it's kind of a given. I'm pleased I went and I got a couple of nice little gifts to take back home, but they will, of course, ask for outrageous prices which you then have to haggle to bring right down. It's fun the first couple of times, but after that it just becomes rather tiresome. The smell isn't great, and you will be knocked over by people on bikes or carts if you're not careful, they literally could not give less of a s**t about pedestrians lolKeep your wits about you and you'll have an eye opening time.

Overwhelmingly varied and interesting. One cannot help but admire the craftsmanship and variety of things made by artisans in Morocco. The souks can be a little overwhelming, especially the motorbikes!! Shop til you drop!!!

Best value if you have a friend from Marrakech with you. I have a friend who was born in Marrakech. To walk with him in the many small shops was a great experience. He helped me lot to get the right prices. They sell everything here. Shoes, cakes, souvenirs, belts, clothes and spices. The area smells like Africa and Morocco with a mix of French. You can have a cop of mint tea when you do the dealing with the many smiling and nice people who works here. It is easy to get lost. I did last time I was here but not this time. An idea is to bring with you a compass so you know your direction out of the area. Great experience for everyone.

Hire a guide for the day if its your first visit!. The Souks are a must see as the sights and smells make it an exciting adventure. However if you are visiting for the first time i strongly recommend that you book a guide. It cost me 80 euros for the whole day 9a.m/4pm and it was a good decision. (book through your accommodation). You get less hassle and can request to go to places you may not dare venture into on your own, like the tanneries! (here the hassling can be a nightmare) Beware though because your guide may still take you to certain shops where people will try (often successfully) to rip you off. They know all the tactics and before you know it you have spent too much! Every body no matter where you are is after making money out of you. Having said this i can assure you it wont take long to adjust to the bartering and this should not deter you. One important thing you also need to know is that often local kids, mainly kids, will yell at you that your going down the wrong way or a dead end! Chances are your not just keep going, if you engage in conversation your likely to be guided somewhere else and asked for money! Again a guide is a very good idea for your first visit. The day after i was confident enough to tackle it on my own and was fine. Remember if you do get lost hail a cab! dont pay more than 40dhms to go any where in the Medina, settle this price before setting off!

Don't let people put you off. It's amazing. OK, it gets a bit samey the more you go in but it's amazing. The knock off shops are everywhere but so are excellent craftsman shops. Just wish we had a van we could have filled up & drove home in

So much fun. Be careful, get lost for a while, and have fun. Just a note, never ask anyone on the street for directions. Ask the people in the shops if you need help. Everything is to be bargained for. Never offer the price they ask because it will be greatly marked up. Still, it's loads of fun

Very busy and slightly dodgy. The souks are extensive and very busy with local Moroccans going about their business. It is quite hazardous as they ride their motorbikes, mules, bicycles through the packed precincts. Keep to the right!. Getting lost is obligatory and unavoidable . Just keep wandering and you will emerge eventually. The worst part is that if you look at anything or show any interest in an item you are harangued. We did not buy anything as it was just too unpleasant. The Moroccans are constantly trying to get your money in whatever way they can. They are dishonest and lying is habitual. There is no point in asking for directions as they take you to where they want you to go - their carpet shop for example. They will also spin you are yarn about being poor Berbers or Government sponsored - or being a cooperative. Or that they are a representative from Tourist Information You would not believe how many women's cooperatives there are in Morocco!. Dirty and smelly too - especially if you get near the Tanneries. Allow a couple of hours for the souks - maximum.
Fascinating. It was a trip organized by Thomson/Tui a very long day but well worth it. The guide was great and we saw more of the souk then we ever would have seen going alone. Food was great too

Amazing to see but not many bargains to be had. Firstly I would say wandering around the souks made my holiday! It was simply amazing! I loved it and the seller's here are not as aggressive as in the square......You get a variety of goods.....if you buy slippers make.sure the soles are leather not plastic foamy stuff and check the leather handbags inside and out....Bartering is so much fun and the majority are good natured.....however some are truly awful....I don't mind bartering when they start at a realistic price....when they start at 1400 dirhams for a pair of.sunglasses I feel like walking out because you just feel they are making a fool of you!Best advice we were given is don't show too much interest in particular items.....don't pay more than a third to half of their first price ( locals are probably always given a third of what we are for first price) and if they aren't going down in price walk away and 9 times out of 10 they will change their minds!!!I got beautiful mirrors, slippers, scarves, glasses and dishes........one thing I will say is a lot of things are mass produced and poor quality....a lot of the stalls r selling the same stuff....spend some time and shop around and you will find some gems...also don't wear open sandals / shoes because your feet will get dirty

Hustle and bustle of the Souk. I love the Souk.Look out for the Henna ladies, who, although you tell them you don't want Henna, will still Henna your hand and then ask for money. Great fun.The allies ways that lead this way and that to some unknown place or surprise place. The people were fun. My friends and I were called a variety of celebrity names, all with the aim of making us smile and getting us to buy. We thought we were special until we heard other people receiving the same treatment. I went when it was quite chilly, so I never really experienced the real hustle of the Souk. I will have to go back again when it's warmer so I can soak up the electric vibe of this place.

An Interesting, chaotic maze of colour. Hard to do this place justice as there is just so much going on here. A wide range of goods on sale from a variety of stalls, shops and alcoves. People everywhere from tourists to locals going about their daily shop. A true cultural melting pot. Don't be afraid to haggle and barter for the best price. Especially as the quality of the goods on offer vary greatly from one place to another.

You must go but be prepare. You must be prepare to be patient and ready for making deals. People that sells carpets are the must stubborn. Don't ask for prices unless you really want to buy. It is use in Moroccan culture to bargain for the price. They say you should offer less than half that the price they give you. The souk are really big and seem the same so you might get lost. I recommend going with a guide.

Oh my goodness, you can easily get lost in this wonder!. Highly recommend a trip to the souk, give yourself at least a day to explore the lost wonders... don't be afraid to haggle either and politely say no if you're not interested in any of the wares.

Enjoy the bartering.... An intricate maze of colourful alleys which are equally charming and annoyingCharming - the variety of goods available and the sheer authenticity of it all. During our visit, tourists were heavily outnumbered by locals adding to the sense of reality.Annoying - the volume of motorcycles speeding unnecessarily through these narrow streets. Add to this seemingly suicidal cyclists and donkey-drawn carriages and a simple stroll can become death-defying. The occasional pushy and overly-sarcastic stall holders. On the whole, one did not feel harrassed however some are nothing less than obnoxious.Make the most of it. Enjoy the bartering, if the deal's not good enough, walk away, plenty more opportunities lie ahead...
Souk Visit. Busy and bustling but exciting. Great interaction with the traders although some of them generally do not appear to take rejecting of their prices/wares nicely.

Not like anything else. Well worth taking at least half a day to wander around the souks. We didn't end up by much (a few pieces of jewellery) but it is worth it just for the cultural experience. A lot of people get guides, but I would recommend trying to navigate on your own. You will get lost. But that's half the fun.

Lots and lots and lots of stuff. Meandering along the narrow alleyways of the Marrakech souk is a delightful experience, just remember to negotiate! They sell grate dates, of course fresh nana mint and all sorts of stuff, sometimes cheap junk, sometimes beautiful goods...one of the most famous tailors is to be found here and he won't negotiate on his prices!
Crazy. so many gorgeous colours and items to buy. when bartering offer a quarter of the price and you should be able to get the price down to half of what they have offered.

More than shopping, a cultural adventure. Be ready for an intense afternoon :) You can buy here everything, from all kind of handicrafts to various food and drinks. Bargaining is a must, and you need to be strong and confident, quote a very-very low price, otherwise you will be ripped-off by almost everyone. Do not buy food on Jamaa el Fna, prices are ridiculous, the size is small, and food is not really traditional. Go to the neighboring streets instead for fish, cheese crepes, kebab, etc.

Chaotic and a lot of fun. We actually stayed in a riad in the souks. We roamed around the are daily. Bargaining is de riguer but be careful you don't make a silly offer the merchants get nasty and start pointing at your clothes jewelry and shoes siting the prices you paid for those items. Just walk on there are always others who are ready to bargain in a good natured way.After a day it gets a bit old. The snake charmers, tranvestite dancers and acrobats all pass a plate around for donations from the people who have stopped to look. The restaurants around the square are a good option but eat at the cleanest places, I was struck down by gastro and was in bed for 24 hours. Things to purchase are the baboosh shoes make sure you only buy the ones made in leather. Tinware lanterns are pretty and the hand painted plates are a must if you can put it in your hand held. Alas we couldn't so passed on the plates. It would have been a nightmare to pick one out from the thousands available.

Good and Bad. First the good.. The Medina is interesting place with all the small streets and shops. It's easy to get lost wandering the streets but thats the fun of it! The aromas, sights and sounds are all a part of it. The carpet and textile makers with their hand looms are a sight to be seen. The Riads are beautiful! Yes you have to put up with the haggling but just politely say no and you should be good. Now for the bad, the streets are dirty and the locals have lived like this for years so I don't see it changing anytime soon. Once you step out of your Riad it's a shame and sad how the streets look and are kept. It's said that the crime for the most part isn't an issue but you need to smart. My wife's phone was stolen out of her hand and the thief jumped on a motor bike that was waiting for him and we never saw them again. Think twice when carrying purses, smart phones or jewelry that can be tempting to these criminals. Put your wallet in your front pocket and if possible have some cash in your other pocket so that you won't need to open your wallet out in the open. I would like to see the police do more to crack down on these individuals. Something like this can really make your vacation take a turn for the worse.That said we met some great people in Marrakech! Warm and friendly souls that I will remember for a lifetime.

Interesting and different. Going to Morocco this is a MUST although I tough it was a very tiring experience.Getting into a shop is a "fight" with the salesmen as they are hard sellers. There are no price tags so you can find the same object varying in price from MAD250 and MAD30 but in the bottom of your mind you know you could have got it for MAD20...But it is a definitive must do experience.

A maze of colour and smells. A visit to the Souks is a must, and as long as you are prepared this is a great experience. Noise, an array of colours and tantalising aromas will hit you as you step into the Souks. There are lots of interesting things to buy, clothes, handbags, pottery, jewellery, herbs but do not pick anything up unless you are actually interested in buying it and remember to barter, do not pay more than a third of the original price. Be polite and smile and do not take photos unless you ask and you will get charged for it so do bring change. Enjoy!

An essential experience of Marrakech. The vast variety of items for sale in the suiks is fantastic. It is essential to barter as the asking price is always way too high, but from experience if you barter too low you may offend! Usually go to no more than a third of the initial asking price, and it helps to walk away if you really want a lower price (9 times out of 10 they will shout you back). Try not to be led away by people who want to show you other shops, you may end up walking far away from where you started!The colours, smells and general atmosphere is very unique and should definitely be experienced if you visit Marrakech. It is a bit of a rabbit warren though so if you can download an app to help if you get lost then do (I never looked for one but I'm sure they exist). The sellers are generally friendly and don't pressure you too much to buy if you're not interested. I found it easy to walk away if I wasn't buying and moved on to the next stall!

Wandering around. Just let yourself be sucked in and enjoy the smell, the noise, the people. Eat in the streets not in the tourist places and enjoy fabulous food for a low price. Take your time. Don't always listen to the guys on the street (and to the signs) if you ask for your way around but just try yourself and get lost. Don't be afraid, there is always a way out.
Amazing warren.. Go for the sights and sounds rather than for bargains or quality. I recommend you keep your money in your pocket and save it for the nicer artisan shops around Rue Mouassine

Lots of bargains & colourful characters. The souks are a maze! The Trip advisor Marrakech App was brilliant as it helped us navigate the maze! People are friendly and love banter & barter - just dont get your money out unless you are sure you want to buy. Look out for 'guides' who want to show you a stall and then you end up following them for ages and paying them to leave you alone. The same with people who offer to show you the way back to the square. If you do want a guide, agree a price first.
very busy place. full of shops from tourist trinkets to shoe menders and butchers theres everything under the sun, but dont forget to haggle its great fun
Easy to get lost. Be prepared to be hassled non stop. Great for tat! Some good deals if you like tat. Amazing what they manage to manufacture, from tin, wool and leather.

Just wander and get lost !. Don't be put off by this - the Moroccans are very friendly. Particularly try to find the dyers, the ironmongers and the woodworkers - all have their own area. Must haggle for purchases !
Excellent. As markets go, these are some of the best I have seen. Brightly coloured plates, traditional shoes, leathergoods and spirited traders vying for your attention.

A shopper's haven. A feast of shops selling just about anything. It's a little daunting what with motorbikes, donkeys and the endless throng of people but hey what an experience. Ignore the people who harass you to come into their shop and learn to bargain hard whilst remembering a couple of dollars to you is a lot of money to them so play fair! My only criticism is that I would have liked to have seen more variety in their artwork (canvasses I am talking about) and the women's clothes were all very similar.

Try to Avoid Visiting the Souk on a Friday. Friday is the Muslim holy day and many of the workshops will be closed and not as full of life as expected. Many of the shops in the Souk sell the same merchandise and much of it is unfortunately made in China, forcing the real craftsmen out if business. Try to purchase from a stall where you can actually see them creating unigue pieces.

A must see, but DON'T get lost!. A miriad of narrow streets with endless intriguing market stalls. However, if you go without a guide, it is very easy to lose sense of direction and get completely lost. It took us over an hour to find the exit from behind this walled market place. In the end, after being given wrong directions from some of the stall holders, we hailed a motorised wagon which then took us back to Medina Square. Without it, we would have gone deeper and deeper into 'Market World!' That said, we loved the experience. The true spirit and atmosphere of Marrakech.
Just like Arkwrights.. You name it they have it. Take a guide or you could end up anywhere. Worth the money, you'll see what you want to see and buy all the right gifts.

Noise, noise and more noise but very interesting. We toured the main square with all its snake charmers, jugglers, traders and food stalls with a guide who then took us through the souk. Very typical of souks throughout Middle East with hundreds of stalls selling just about everything imaginable. Very noisy as traders vie for your attention (and hopefully you money). All very friendly and bartering is truly an experience and a test of your resolve. We were told that in most cases the actual price will be around 40% of the initial asking price but getting there takes time and being prepared to walk away several times. They love bartering and are good at it so be prepared to stick to your guns. As is usual when you take a guide he will include one or two places where the proprietor is known to him. On our tour this included a carpet showroom, a carpenter's workshop, a silk scarf shop and a herbal pharmacy but all very friendly and no hard feelings if you do not buy anything. At the end of a three hour tour a glass of fresh orange for 4 Drs was most welcome.
Lots of fun. See my review on the Medina -- be ready to get totally lost! But there's some fun stuff in here if you take the time to look.
Loads to look at. A big market. Sitting people watching whilst drinking coffee. Great !Too many Beggars, Bumsters and Guttersnipes!

Great Experience. The sellers are not agressive they are just persistant and will always ask you to look at something or try something. It is not something that should put you off going through the souks, just enjoy it and keep saying no or 'la' unless you are interested but then you should expect to not be left alone whilst you browse. The maze of the souks is fascinating and it is incredible how vast it is. There are day tours in to the souks however, you don't really go that deep into them. My partner and I went by ourselves and I must admit we did get lost - ended up having to get a mint tea in balcony terrace tea shop and ask the man who was managing it to direct us back to Jemaa el Fna. All a good experience though, really enjoyed it!

Bargain till you dropp. you can't go to Marrakesh and not visit the Souk. It's enourmous, but with a little thought easy to navigate. Most of the shops sell exactly the same stuff. Ao barganing must benyou're trade to not overpay. Walk away if pricing is not right for you. We sometimes managed to get three items for the initial price given for one item! People are not pushy or trying to much to get you in a "shop". Go and try to get the items toy want for bargain prices.

Managed not to get lost. Just hold your nerve and wander. So much to choose from.We bought pashminas and leter spices from the jewish quarter.Younfg men all to willing to help you but they will take you to the shops where they no doubt get a payment. It is however part of the fun of it.

Fascinating. The Souks are fascinating and full of all sorts of goodies, especially the part where leather goods are sold. You have to be careful as I think the stall holders are trained to see where your eyes are looking and pounce as soon as they think you are eying their goods. Personally this puts me off so they lost themselves a good few sales! Barter hard as some of the prices they quote initially are ludicrously high. Easy to get lost, but there are signs here and there for attractions such as the Medrasa so you can orientate yourself by them. Be careful of helpful young men offering to show you the way as they will usually want money for doing this. Get a good map and look at it as discreetly as you can.

Keep EYES OPEN for weirdos!. Marrakech is fantastic and a wonderful place to visit. I will be back. I wish my TripAdvisor friends to be aware of some shenanigans that may happen.We were walking in the Bab Doukala area late at night. A young adult man was following my girlfriend with his hand on her behind. After we confronted him and he and friends backed off, then another man in robe and hood approached. He grabbed her hand and put it on his hard woody. I spoke outload, 'you dishonour allah by touching this woman'. I know that the good folk would keep their eye on us the rest of the night.Very infrequent but I was surprised at that nonsense in the shadow of the Mosque.Enjoy yourself! But stay alert!

A must-do. The souk area of Marrakesh is as it must have been for centuries - busy with the hustle and bustle of trading in small streets. The colour and flavour of Morocco is here, but be prepared to be hassled to buy

Much like any other souk!. The souk in Marrakech was pretty clean, stocked with the standard touristy stuff with little variety and haggling for best price is expected. Nevertheless there were no real bargains; however, neither was there aggressive sales pressure.

Getting lost is a pleasure.. Watch out for young men wanting to "guide" you. A map of the Souks is a good idea as some will be more to your taste than others. Plan to but small items that can get in your luggage unless you've planned to get items shipped.

Not for the faint hearted!. I have visited Marrakech twice now. The first time I was completely over whelmed by the souks and the aggressive selling. This was 8 years ago when i wasn't used to any arab countries. I was so put off i never went back to visit the souks and didn't buy a thing! the ridiculous haggling can only be described as ridiculous. An item worth 50p back in Britain they will try and sell to you for £50. I visited the souks again last month on my second trip to Marrakech. I have since been to many other arab countries, and this time around i was not phased by the aggressive selling at all. I learnt to just ignore the sellers or reply 'no English". Souks are defo worth visiting as there is an abidance of things to buy and you can grab yourself a bargain. Myself and my brother brought gorgeous genuine leather bags from the souks (roughly £17 and £25 each) would would easily be worth at least £60 or more here. A good code to follow would be whatever price they offer you, counter offer a quarter to a third of the asking price and then negotiate up to a reasonable amount. So in conclusion, visit the souks but have your wits about you!
An experience!. Noisy, interestingBought a magic wooden box in souk,haggled a price.Found it half the price later in the day at Carrefour!
souks. Whatever you do don't lose your bearings as we did and end up paying locals a fortune to guide you back. In the main Medina/souks you don't get any help Unless you pay

a day at the souks. we enjoyed the souks although my husband felt a bit intimidated its well worth a visit but remember to say no and keep walking ,i didnt like the snake charmers in the square and some of the smells,if you speak french its an asset and you cant drink alcohol if in line with a mosque.Also,dont accept anything as you will be expected to pay for it.

Good at first, but the novelty soon wears off. The souks of Marrakech seem to go on forever, and once you start exploring you will soon lose your bearings as you following the narrow, winding walkways which take you off deeper and deeper into a world rich in colour, smells, character and atmosphere. Luckily it is difficult to get completely lost as there are lots of blue signs overhead which will point the newcomer in the direction of the main square, the Djema El Fna.I don't see how the souks can be dismissed as just a tourist trap since it is clear that the locals shop here also, in fact Moroccan shoppers generally outnumber the tourists (at least when I was there during January). However, there's no doubt that the stallholders see the greater money-making opportunities when a foreigner comes along and many will try and lure you inside for a closer look if you pause to look at something, or sometimes even if you don't.The vendors generally speak good English and will come across as very friendly, but sadly all-too-often this is just part of the rehearsed sales pitch: "Where are you from? Oh, I like that city, so for you I will offer a special price" etc etc. Haggling is the name of the game, and if you're too soft, these guys will rip you off. It will take a test of your willpower and no little effort, but you can buy items for half of the price the vendors will initially quote. Unfortunately for those unaccustomed with this method of shopping, the practice soon becomes a bit of a chore once you've done it a few times, as does the fact that you can't have a proper look at anything without some salesman chatting away at you and insisting how good the product is and how good his prices are. Some will let you browse without hassle, but they are few and far between.However, here are a few tips which may assist visitors to the Souks:1) Never show too much interest in anything. The more interested the vendor thinks you are in a particular item, the harder he will haggle.2) React with disbelief at the first price he quotes. If you react as though this is a reasonable price (albeit one you think you can drive down a bit), then straight away you're telling him that any haggling on your part is just a case of chancing your luck rather than a sincere argument on the genuine value of the item.3) Although there are hundreds of market stalls, there are only about a dozen or so different types - whatever you see in one stall, you can almost certainly see in many others. Shop around for the best price, and make it clear to the vendors that you are doing this. They'd sooner sell you an item cheaply than miss out altogether when you buy the same type of item from one of their rivals.4) If possible, try to buy multiple items from the same vendor. You will usually get better deals this way, and also it means less vendors you have to haggle with.5) Assuming you're going to the Souks from the main square (the Djema El Fna) - the worst, most 'touristy' ones are those straight ahead of you as you enter the square from the direction of the Koutoubia Mosque. Aim towards the ones at the extreme left of the extreme right - from my experience these are a little less pushy and were sometimes a little cheaper. However, if you're staying in Marrakech for several days, then I'd recommend a day trip to the coastal town of Essaouira, where the prices are cheaper still (for exactly the same range of goods), the items are often priced so you don't have to haggle, and you don't get pestered by the stallholders as you walk past - an altogether more pleasant experience.6) NEVER agree to go anywhere with one of the stallholders, even if it's only to look in his brother's shop around the corner. These guys are after your money and whilst the souks are generally safe and friendly to walk around, you don't want to get into a difficult situation.7) Also, no matter how friendly a vendor seems, don't let them try clothes on you or they may then insist that you pay for them. In spite of everything I've written, the souks can be a fun experience, especially in you just want to sample the atmosphere and you're not out to buy very much. As long as you employ common sense, not flash too much money around, be careful of passing motorbikes etc, don't stray into quiet areas at night on your own, then they are generally a safe and friendly environment, and well worth experiencing. I walked round them alone and didn't feel ill at ease. If they're really not your cup of tea then try the nearby government shop (Ensemble Artisanal) when you can buy most of the same items for fixed prices without hassle (although it is a little more expensive, which can be evidenced by the fact you won't see many Moroccans shopping in there!)

Vibrant souk. We loved the hustle and bustle of the people as they went about their daily business but found it impossible to browse without being badly hassled and pressured to buy. In the end, we stopped looking and kept up a brisk pace. It's a shame because we would have bought more without the badgering shop-keepers.

Something that should be experienced. The souks in Marrakesh spread out over a very large area which are interconnected by a range of tiny steets, mostly inaccessible by car. If you have trouble walking far you should get a tour book and plan a rough route as taxis are only available on certain side streets. The souks can be accessed from Jemaa El Fna as a starting point, just by walking beyond the square northwards.Here you can buy everything from teapots, to clothes to spices. Everything requires bargaining and the majority of store holders will try and rip you off if they see you are a tourist. For example on a high quality and ornate teapot I bought (not just a flimsy decorative one) the guy started at MAD 380, which I told him was "outrageous" and "UK price". After 15 minutes of bargaining, I got it for MAD 90, which personally I felt was reasonable. If you want to know the rough value of an item you can also find some "fixed-price" stores where price labels will be displayed, although only take it as a guide.Some store holders will also not want you to take photos of them, so taking photos from afar is recommended. Also, if there is anyone that mentioned anywhere ahead is closed or not worth seeing, ignore them as if you follow them you will likely end up in a carpet / leather shop being coersed into buying something.
Everything is here. Dodge motor bikes and other fast moving things. Enjoy the experience, there will be a hard sell and you are expected to bargain.

It's not for everyone. It's only really worth it if you like haggling and want to bring back some tacky knick-knack and take some nice "authentic" photos (if the sellers allow you to take pictures of their stalls). Overall, it does feel like a huge tourist trap.

Mad!. Definitely go and discover the Souks, they are an experience like no other and try and make your way to the area where the locals go for their food. As a lady though, do NOT lose your partner(like I did!!) I was haggling a price for a pot and my partner wandered off............50 mtrs away. I couldn't see him and when I tried to leave the stall, 5 men surrounded me and tried to send me off in the wrong direction...............just be careful!!

An aladdins cave. This is a must the sights, the smells, the atmosphere this is a wonderful place just to lose yourself in all the wonder things you can buy and the people make this a special place to be

brilliant. Great place full of colour and excitement,don't eat at the food stalls they are expensive and a bit dodgy I think. When entering the square in front of the Souk there are lots of guys trying to get you to go on a horse and carriage ride, my partner and I took one and it cost about 20 quid, so if your not interested just say no and after a while the guys leave you alone. The Souk is great but just remember keep saying no as the guys trying to sell stuff are experts at selling so be polite and direct and say no. I paid a fiver for a little castle thing in the Souk when I came back to the main square there was a guy with a cart selling the same castle for a pound. There are little sit down cafes on a street leading to the square these are a better place to eat, cheap and good food the waiters are on the street and they will ask you to sit down they have menus with pictures and prices are really good great food and nice people, the locals eat here but the locals don't eat at the food stalls in the square. If you go into the Souk on your own DO NOT allow the guys who come up and tell you the area ahead is closed and they will guide you back to the square tell them NO and keep going you will find your way out, they do know short cuts and you might have to tell the same guy no three or four times but he will get the message these guys are real chancers. They will try to hastle money from you if you let them guide you.My partner and I and our two year old son had a lovely walk through the Souk with no problems so don't be afraid just remember what turns you made and you will have a great time and HAGGLE if you see something you like remember the seller will start high so haggle hard walk away if he's not prepared to drop the price stick to the price you want to pay. There are local prices and then there are tourist prices to get an idea there are some fixed price shops before you get to the square they are on the main road opposite the old tower.Fantastic day out, any questions give me a shout.

Walking in the souks. Once you enter the souk you will be bombarded with hard sell traders,be firm otherwise you will end up with junk,the silver is good and cheap,leather hand bags galore for ladies and men,but once you have seen one stall they are all the same.

An obvious place to explore.. Interesting, though be careful that what you buy is not a cheap chinese copy. Chanced upon the place where the chickens end up, which was a bit unsettling. You can buy leather goods which you can see made, however you need to haggle hard, and to be honest, I couldn't be bothered. Watch out for the motor bikes, and on occasion your bag can be snatched this way.

Crazy. It is crazy. Whilst trying to shop, you have to dodge motor bikes up and down the narrow alleys. Bargaining is huge. You absolutely have the master the art of bargaining else you loose big time on prices. If you love crowds, this is where you should be

Such Fun. Give yourself a good three hours to explore this fascinating warren of tiny streets. It might seem like a maze but you do eventually find your way out. There are official guides but we explored by ourselves. Web aware of friendly locals who happen to work at the Berber market and point you in the right direction and then discretely follow you and "guide" you to their shop by lucky co-incidence. If you really want to buy something, offer half of the price and be offended and walk away when they say impossible, they will lower the price little by little, stick to your original offer and eventually with a big sigh barter up a little to what you think it's worth. Good fun espeially if you like a good old laugh and theatrics. Keep money in separate places so you're only getting out a little at a time rather than all at once.

Watch out for the mopeds!!!. Brilliant place to visit and buy, just be aware that locals drive cycles, mopeds and small carts around these narrow streets, and don't have horns to warn you if they are coming up behind you. The range of merchandise is wonderful, however they seem to group alike items in certain areas, so just keep moving to see it all.

just be sensible buyer. the market is full of fake branded stuff and if you are into authentic Morroccon stuff the inside shops are the best bets. A small tagine which was around 50 Dhs in market i bought it for 10 Dhs from inside shops.. just be sensible ask prices but don't go into serious bargain. same stuff can be bought for cheaper price from shops which are away from main market

Nice but it stinks. The soux markets all that you see on the television is true,, the sights the sounds, there must be apporx 10.000 shops and stall all with the family willing to crab you and hastle you times that by 50 and thats the amount of hastle your going to get. The spices are fantstic but you darnt look at anything as they pounce onto you, and you can only get the aroma within the shops as most of the external areas are full of dirt with the scabby donkey's, you also have to literally have eyes in the back of your head with the moped rushing about even within the tight alley ways most of the time with 2 or 3 people riding. We tried some of the local foods but this came in a bowl with massive crack through it and within the crack of the bowl what I seen put me off the food. Thank god for mcdanalds. If you cross the roads your going to die, with the manic driving mind you if you walk on the pavements your still going to die with the massive holes This place is not cheap as long as your not going to pay the correct price but you have to haggle all the time and with being in this place all day and with most of the time being lost ( I had to use the sat nav on my phone to find the way out ) you get very tired and eventually you get very fed up with the hasstleread less

amazing. this is the place to people watch there is so much going on from freshly squeezed juices to fantastic food they sell everything from oils, genuine fake goods to stuffed lizards we walked around and never failed to see something different . its a must to sit and eat here

Great experience. Nice experience you need to bargain for good price. The bargain should start from less than half and see how the shopkeeper responses. Do not get tempted to buy in the first shop you visit. Go around and see many shops and then ask for prices.

Shoppers paradise. All the colour , sights and smells one expects, but experiencing it first hand. An Alladins cave of exquisite things to buy and see. Need to barter, but a lot of the shops are co-operatives so it's wise not to beat them down too far, however, you will still get a bargain.

Disappointing. I have always wanted to go to "magical Marrakesh" but was so disappointed when I got there. Stayed for 4 nights in the Medina but would have been happy to leave after 2 nights. The souks are a maze of alleyways, once you have seen one you have seen them all! Definitely haggle on price, walk away - they will come after you to get a sale! I am glad I went but would not got back for a second visit. Definitely an experience - but not one I would care to repeat.

Shopping heaven. Please do not worry about being hassled, just smile and say a firm no thank you.
Do try and pay at least half of the asking price, start off about 25% and then go up slowly to 50% but no more. Above all have fun.
what a maze. very busy, lots of alleys going off in different directions, people trying to get you to buy, so a bit hassly but overall a good experience

Get the knowledge. The most fantastic experience - however get some local knowledge first. Visit the Emporium on Rue de la Kasbah first which has fixed prices for pretty much everything you will find in the souk. That way you at least know what stuff is worth (or what the going rate is). Only pay what you think something is worth and don't get carried away. Everybody is friendly and getting lost is part of the whole experience!
Dont get lost. Lots and lots of busy stalls / narrow streets and difficult to remember the way in and out.Must haggle
It huge. I have been to souks before in Turkey but this one is huge and full of great things to buy. The sweets are fabulous. The spices amazing. Lots of leather, jewellery and shoes. Enjoy!!

This is it!. This is what you come to Marrakech for! Chaotic, vibrant, a sensory overload - it's the craziest and most eye opening shopping mall in the world.Look out for snake charmers, spice merchants, and save some room for the food stalls that come out at night.Don't be surprised to see donkeys and motorbikes whizzing along the streets - be prepared to jump out of the way.Make sure you haggle - and go low. Don't be directed from your path by locals trying to persuade you to visit anywhere, or telling you the road ahead is closed - stick to your plan. It's not nasty or dangerous, it's just a hard persuasive sell.Bring a camera, soak it up and join in!

I discovered that I love haggling!. Obviously this HAS to be experienced when you visit Marrakech. I completely understand people getting stressed or finding the experience over-whelming. To avoid this go armed with a full understanding of what to expect:Every stall holder wants you to buy something - they will not let you pass by easily if you look at anything, and especially not if you touch it! You must expect this. If you were simply looking and don't want to buy, just be firm - 'No' smile, wave your hand, move on. No problem.If you come across something you do want to buy take your time to work out what you want to pay before you even start talking to the stall holder. Only now ask 'how much'. Shake your head, go much lower. keep going until you get the price you want. If they don't come down to the price you had decided then walk away. If you have suggested a price they are happy with they will call you back, believe me. If they don't call you back then you really have gone too low so use that knowledge at the next stall!Don't try and take pictures - they don't like it and will ask for money.Look down every alley-way. You can see them making the lamps and the leather goods right there. It makes you realise (and feel a little guilty) that you really have got a bargain for that hand-made lamp!Above all, just enjoy the experience.

Truly Moroccan, truly touristic!. If you do not mind a milling crowd, constant honking of motorcycles and bicycles, this is where you can smell, taste and hear how Moroccans carry their everyday life. You will need to learn to enjoy the constant 'invitations' to eateries, tour guides, cats, and many more.

Different shopping experience from UK. The souks are small shops with unique items. We need to carry cash to purchase items in the souk. The items are of good quality and relatively cheap compared to UK. You need to bargain to get a good price. The bargain should start from 1/3rd and see how the shop keeper responds. Do not get tempted to buy in the first shop you visit. Go around and see many shops and then ask for prices. You will get an idea. People are friendly and helpful generally. We did not see pick pocketing or anything and found the place to be generally safe. Toilets are not common to find, you need to go to a big restaurant for a toilet. Public toilets in the souks are not good. We liked the souvenirs, wooden items, scarves etc. At night, the open place around souks will have loads of food shops. They are all at a reasonable price. But be careful about the food, it might upset your stomache. We liked the herbal tea made of different spices. Orange juice is very cheap and you can get it for 4Dhs. The shop keepers are so friendly that after you finish your juice and give the glass, they will refill and say 'Have it, it is free'. I never saw this gesture anywhere. I recommend visiting the place to experience the shops and the culture.

Busy. The souks are very busy. Evert one tries to sell you what they have And so do all the Neighbours. the prices they give you are at least double of the value of the goods so don't say yes to easy or to quickly. Be aware of people who try to take you with them. Say no Thank you and go your own way. There are clear signs to show you the way to jemaa el fna so you can find your own way out of the souks.

Interesting visit. This is something everyone going to Marrakech needs to see but be careful of people who may try and mislead you down side streets etc. We were advised this by our hotel and took note and whilst there a man did ask us if we were lost and to follow him to which we just said no thank you and he walked off down the side street. It can be abit maze like too we felt abit lost at times. Down tiny side streets. The shop keepers are mainly very lovely and just want you to buy things from them. we didn't eat from the souks as we were unsure if the food would be ok as a lot is out in open air and it is very hot there. Some may find the site of some of the animals there distressing as they don't appear well kept. Also be careful for vehicles just appearing out of nowhere and they don't slow down. Keep bags close and the locals really don't like you to take photos so we respected this as it can cause an argument. Overall it was definitely worth seeing and would encourage people to go and visit but to be vigilant to your surroundings.

Just about anything you could want. A fabulous maze of lanes containing hundreds of small shops selling typical Morrocan crafts - you can actually see some of the items being made in some parts of the Souk. The colours and sights are wonderful. Prices are very reasonable, provided you bargain. Enjoy the bargaining; its great fun and the vendors expect it, and if both parties come away with smiles then everyone is happy.

AN EXPERIENCE THAT'S FOR SURE. This is a trip that is a must when visiting Marrakech. A market like no other you will have experienced - hundreds of traders all selling the same merchandise - definite bargains to be sourced. It was extremely busy, over crowded at times, but not uncomfortably so. Although sales were desired we were not pestered if no interest was given.

Great on a Friday. We happen to have a guided tour through the square and souk. It was Friday which is an important religious day, hence a number of stalls were closed and crowds were well down. A great time to wander without any hassle and still see plenty of merchandise for sale. Naturally you need to batter but we were not hassled. Watch for the scooters flying through at break neck speeds.

Don't be intimidated by the madness! . On our second visit to Marrakech we were at ease straight from the beginning.Be sensible and alert when it comes to the mopeds, cyclists, donkeys and any other form of transport you find yourself dodging in the souks. Just use your ears and don't stop slap bang in the middle of the "road" every minute and you'll be fine! Shop wise if you stop and browse you'll probably be wearing or feeling what you wanted to look at in seconds, no doubt whilst being poured a "thé à la menthe". My recommendation would be to visit the Ensamble Artisanal co-operative just past the Koutoubia mosque away from jemaa el fna first and take note of the prices! You can then barter with store owners to get what you've seen in the artisanal for cheaper! I hide money in different parts of my wallet and if I want to pay 150hs for something their asking 400dhs for then I show my 150dhs and say it's all I've got! Trust me it's soon worth 150dhs ;-) Street guide wise, just say non Merci and walk on even if you think your going wrong! It isn't worth being led the long way around and getting ripped off! I would recommend downloading the Trip Adviser Marrakech City guide (60mb) and you can use it with roaming turned off just using the free gps signal to keep you on track in the downloaded app!

Day and Night Center of Action. It's been a while since we were there but the Jemaa el Fna is one of the most famous market places in the world. It's definitely not to be missed even if you don't think you're much of a shopper. As with most market places, it's really where any given society expresses its cultural values in what it offers as objects of desire. Every manner of artisan and local products are exhibited in stall after stall staffed by the most experienced of hagglers. The winding and meandering alley ways seem designed to compel you to navigate through a labyrinth of bargains in clothing, art objects, foreign designer trinkets, platters, hookahs and rugs to name a few. There must be hundreds of stalls. It seems nearly always busy with the national pastime of haggling which is elevated to an art form here. Master the "look of disinterest" and practice "the walk-away" technique if you hope to survive the maze without loosing your shirt. Seriously though, it is an exhilarating, fascinating, entertaining cultural experience. The busy-ness of the market though, makes it a difficult place to keep track of each other so those with children (small or big) need to make a conscientious effort to stay close, maybe hold hands etc. Similarly, physically impaired should curb the excursion in accordance with the density of the crowds, etc. The good news is, most of the market is ground level so wheelchairs and strollers can be used. But the human traffic can get a little heavy at times. There's always something going on from dawn to dusk and dusk to dawn. In the morning, there are all manner of entertainers gathered in the central plaza (yes, there will be jugglers...). At dusk, the plaza fills with food vendors offering local produce and seafood. Yup, there are vendors selling braised snails (the biggest, succulent, inexpensive escargot anywhere, had a whole bowl myself), and fried sardines. Really quite tasty and not like anything you were likely to experience anywhere else. There are also cafes lining the plaza offering tea and coffees. We enjoyed a lovely dinner one evening at one of the larger cafes with a second floor patio overlooking the square.
