It felt as if the buzz of the market has not (and reportedly, it has not) really changed in hundreds of years. The market is an iconic part of Marrakech's rich architectural and cultural heritage.

Labyrinth worth solving. These crazy markets that I have no idea where start and stop are really entertaining. You have to have some patience, try and explore and you will find many interesting spots. Once you get in there, it is hard to find your way out or which way you want to get out. I found the local people very helpful. For a bit of tip they'll guide you where to go. Some might stop you while walking confused and say which way to Djamel-Fna for example. Use their help, anything else is optional. The salesmen can be as in other places a bit bothersome. Always a tip to be strong and fair!If you are tired or hungry, try and find one of the rooftop cafes to relax and watch the whole thing from above with a good view.
bargain away. Excellent bargains here for those can haggle, dont be shy and barter away with the locals, they are friendly and there is endless supply of souvenirs to purchase here.
very touristy. if you want something real stay away from here, most goods are industrially produced and not worth your time and money
Old market. There are lots of thing to see and buy . But make sure that don't give any body asking price there. If they ask 300 then offer them 50.Lots of shops old and new thing.
Crazy City. This is really great to see the culture but not reallty a place for young children - but a must see if you like shopping, haggle haggle

Bustling Souks. So many things to see, so easy to get distracted and you may lose your way. You'll soon realise that there are a lot of the same items for sale in different shops, always haggle your price but don't come across as rude (nothing too low) if you still can't get them down, walk away, you'll be amazed when they accept your offer. Most shops will also give you a discount if more than one item is bought which is good for groups of people.Be prepared to be pounced on if you point out something you like, sometimes they'll just take no for an answer, others will bug you a little but a firm "no thankyou" usually solves the problem.

It's a must. You have to be at least once there to experiment the crowded moroccan street markets. Vendors are often brazen and annoying, but this is the price you have to pay to be there. Sometimes is stressful and overwhelming, but as almost everybody that has been there would say: the crowded souks of Marrakech are the best place to be in this extraordinary city.

Overwhelming must do.. The souks are extraordinary, overwhelming and a must do if you are visiting Marrakech.If you want a discrete shopping experience ....... Don't come here. This is fully leaded.If you are prepared to laugh, smile, and say 'no sir', 'non Monsieur', or 'la shukran', then the souks will remain with you forever. Get lost and don't worry. Go where your feet lead you and watch realartisans at work actually making the goods.Acceptable prices are probably 40 to 50% of the original price quoted. It is not a crime to walk away. Arm yourself with a few French and Arabic words.

Souks. Something else. Have to see for yourself. Snake charmers, monkeys, bands playing. People begging. There is so much going on. Plenty hassle, but guides are cheep and worth every penny as you don't get hassled.

Only look if you're going to buy!. Don't walk around looking at items in shops, you will get hassled. Keep your head down and look indirectly at items. Only pick something up if you're going to buy. And don't forget the barter, never go with the price they give you. The range of vibrant colours livens the place up. Get a good map of the souks, we got lost for nearly 3 hours trying to find our way out!!

Overwhelming. Lots of fun and almost impossible not to get lost. Much of the things being sold were not if a high quality and the vendors were not making many sales which made sales techniques at times somewhat hard sell. The worst thing though was the "guides" who endlessly hassled you and that sort of spoilt it for me as I stated having to be rude and just wanted to be happy and be friendly, but that just encouraged them.

get taken for a ride. Shops selling high priced shoddy goods. People looking to take as much money off of you by any means necessary. Don't believe anybody here. You will get horribly lost but can't ask anyone direction because they will take you to their family shop.

Culture Shock but what an experience. Snake charmers, monkeys, whirling dirvish, henna ladies, acrobats , jugglers, traditional dress, drums, spices, foods, juices, street cafes with local foods, smells and tastes .................. and that's all before you even get near to the souksBartering is both expected and enjoyed by the souk sellers.We so enjoyed this experience, yes it is intense but so very non-threatening, so fun!You can not miss this experience.

Be preapred to haggle and enjoy. Souks usually sell the same things so be ready to haggle.. if you dont like what you see or what price your getting just say no thank you and be firm and walk away, usually they will greet you as well. I wouldnt advise getting into a fight about things as business is asking for the highest price and then bargaining a price downwards after.. if the seller doesnt want to sell then say thank you and look elsewhere, be prepared to haggle again if you think its worth it, you win and you lose thats life
What an experience. For a hubbub of humanity, diversity and a bit of shock to the European culture the souks are an amazing complex of all you'd ever want or need. Remember to barter, it's expected.

Too intense. We found the souks far too intense to enjoy. For a quieter experience, try the Chambre d'Artisanat Marocain, only a few blocks away at Ave. Mohammed V and Rue el Adala, which features a limited selection of Moroccan handicrafts, no doubt at higher prices than you could bargain in the souks if that's you pleasure, but local source and authenticity is guaranteed.

Relax and enjoy. An absolute labyrinth but a must do. There is nothing you can't buy. The golden rule is ask the price if you are interested haggle at 30 -40% of that price and pay no more than 50%. Best advice given by our host. Don't feel intimidated if you are being asked to look a furm thank you usually suffices. We didnt experience any aggression just friendly banter. You will get lost but go in a shop to ask directions back to the main square Jemaa el Fna. Also keep your eyes peeled upwards there are often signs pointing the way. I can't tell you how many times we where told we were going the wrong direction we ignored them and thank god we did as everytime the sign confirmed they were lying.

Best place!!!!. I have to say I LOVED Souks in Morocco. That was the best experience. All those smells, colors, shouting... It was so interesting to negotiate prices and taste different flavors. You have to be really really carefull with prices. DO NOT get anxious... prices can go 5x or 10x higher.... walk around, same products are sold in tens of stores so offer way less than asked and start feeling what the real price is. One example I bought a Tajine for 70 Dh (Aprox 7euros). Initial asking price: 250 Dh. And I am not saying I got the best price... you will never know but it was almost 4 times less than initial price. Enjoy!!!

Let yourself get lost in the souk. The bazaar is most enjoyable but the best are the less touristy little streets and courtyards with artisans working on leather slippers, cooper and colorful glass lamps, the hidden riads, the street food vendors, tea shops. I really hope the mopeds will shorty be banned from the souks, but the donkey carts create a unique atmosphere and are welcome. It was my second time in Marrakesh ans found it wonderful again.

Worth a visit. My husband and I enjoyed our browse through the souk. Being honest, I found it less intimidating than the souk in Dubai. There is a main passageway through the souk from the main square. Its fairly straight and unless you venture down off down a side lane, you will not get lost. There is a huge variety of goods in the souks on this passageway and I cannot see the need to deviate off this main route. We had a leisurely stroll along this route with other tourists, locals and their families then returned to the main square on the same route

Overwhelming for me. I was overwhelmed by this place. Lots of touts and hawking and noise and people and things. Many of the same things over and over, orange juice, hand of fatima, Aragan oil, musk, scarves, herbs & spices, metallic stuff, trinkets, women with henna, shoes, more moroccan slippers, bowls... So, my style of haggling was to ask one shopkeeper for a price of an item and when you don't like it, go down 50% to the next one..People will generally give you what you want. In my travels I have learned this...bargaining...negotiation...is like a dance. You can laugh your way through it and it's quick. So many people, so much noise.. In some ways, it's more than can be adequately captured by a still photo.. Yes, I almost got robbed from my ipad, and my bag was in the back of me. I caught that little fat kid and he handed it over quickly and disappeared into the crowd. But, I wouldn't trade our experience in Marrakech for anything though. Glad we went!!

Plan to spend a day here. This souk is quite the labrynth of alleys but it's well worth just getting lost here for a day. There are tons of shops with everything you could possibly want and most are willing to negotiate with you on price. Lunch at any of the nearby restaurants that has a terrace also a good idea as you get an aerial view of the medina and it's fascinating to watch all of the people.
it's what you make of it!. Monkeys, snake charmers, colors, textures. Unforgettable experience. Ignore the aggressive hagglers. Highly recommended!

Tons of items sold in hundreds of little stores. The souk has hundreds of stores selling everything from meat to jewellery, paintings, sweets, Moroccan handicrafts and lots of other items. They even sell shawls and cushions from India and try to pass it off as Moroccan so beware! A basic lesson we learnt is that no matter how well you bargain, you'll later find a shop that sells the same item at half the price you paid. We managed to navigate through the never-ending souk without a guide.
Shopping. Lots to interesting things for shoppers be determined when bartering found some great quality things but lots of cheap touristy stuff too

Samey. Quite exciting if you want to haggle, less so if you then visit the government owned shops, better priced, and quality assured. There is a leather section, metal section, cloth section and pharmacy section, the latter being the best value for money and the one where you don't need to see the government shops. Always best if you see the guys making the stuff they are selling, sadly on our visit, Paris Saint Germain were playing Real Madrid in Marrakech, which was televised and taking the attention of the stall owners. You can get lost which is part of the excitement. Girls must wear bags in front, as thefts are quick, and the mopeds are a nuisance.Reason for the pharmacy up, and the third star,are the prices you'll get for Argon oil and saffron
Oh boy. Definitely not to be missed but not particularly for me....fascinating place and less hassle than we'd expected but it takes some stomach in places....glad we went but no rush to return

Exotic, colourful. Good place to barter for some bargains. Snake charmers a bit scary as don't take no for an answer so expect to get up close & personnel with some breed of snake. Could easily get lost as so many different little lane ways. Lots of different colours & smells. The women love this place for jewelry, leather products. Also some great jackets. A very good place to view the culture of Marrakech.

Very pushy traders. There is lots of choice in shopping from scarves and wooden boxes to the Tajines and teapots. However, as soon as you slow down to look the Traders pounce on you which takes away some of the enjoyment. We bought more in the Medina at Essaouira as they were less pushy there

Not pedestrian friendly. Just found the sooks to busy and to confusing. It is almost mandatory that you will get lost, you won't know who to ask for help as they will likely want money and steer you to a rug stall. Also the narrow streets are inhabited by motorcycles, donkeys pulling carts, bycicles, etc etc. You are forever ducking from one side to the other. Could not wait to get out of there. Go to the palaces instead.
New year holiday. Great place good fun be careful of taxi drivers they charged us per person also not many places to go for New Years
Take it all in. Allow an hour or 2 depending if you get lost, and explore the Souk. There is a lot on offer to see, we did not buy. Its all about the experience

Must see but not for me. We walked around and it was interesting to visit. The winding streets and atmosphere are a kyat see. It took us an hour to explore. Granted we did not buy anything. There are many shops with workers VERY eager to help. I preferred shopping at the coops outside of the city with our hiking guide.

Marrakech Souks. Morocco is a fascinating country and one we are glad we went to Loved all the stalls in the souk areas along with the snake charmers and other acts surrounding this Need to keep your wallet or purse close by as so crowed and perfect place for pick pockets can easily barter for what you want to buy would not travel to Morocco as woman only and was very glad my husband was with me at the time Clearly a Muslim county where woman treated as second class citizens

Pretty much as expected. Went through some of the souk areas twice on a short first visit to Marrakech. Having read up a bit in advance, the souk areas were pretty much as expected. We did the obligatory getting lost the first time, which was a tad disconcerting, but we got out eventually.A bit difficult to navigate anyway, but the constant flying motorcycles, donkeys, wheelbarrows, etc in 6 foot wide alleys (sometimes narrower !) meant we had to be pretty careful for our safety.Only one minor hassle experience where one of the local wide boys tried to lead us off in the opposite direction from where we wanted, but we got rid of him easily enough. Apart from that, the shopkeepers were invariably pleasant and helpful. On our second visit, my wife got into full haggling mode and we came away happy with the stuff we bought (including the scarf that the owner ran down 8 shops to sell to us after we'd walked out not prepared to pay more than we did).
Get used to declining service !!. But seriously this place is a maze and you could spend weeks here. The view from a cafe terrace is great - drinks cost more for the privilege but worth it!

Bit Bonkers!!. You can't visit Marrakech without a trip to the souk, they'll try and sell you everything, especially if you linger to long outside a stall, "looking is free" as they say, your response is a polite "maybe later" and if you do want to buy then HAGGLE, honestly they're dissapointed if you don't. Good hunting...

A tourist trap. This smelly noisy market located in the heart of the medina this is just not my idea of a holiday ! Be ready to bargain and start with 30% of what they quote . You may still pay too much !

Just do it. Set yourself a budget and enjoy the experience. Once you understand that chances are you will be overpaying you can relax and settly into enjoying the experience of looking at pretty things where everyone is your friend and if one catches your eye, engaging in a spot of haggling. I especially enjoyed the different souks with their own specialities where you could get more away from the ones located on Jemma el Fna into the quieter neighbourhoods. Definitely recommended.

Only for the chilled. I breezed through most of it with moderate hassle, was only propositioned for drugs four times and sex three. The major irritation is the constant grabbing for money, even after you've bought something they still want "a little extra". Best to whizz through quickly for the fanfastic magical vibe, and buy elsewhere.

Unique. There aren't many places left like this in the world outside Morocco so a morning wandering in the maze of streets and shops is a unique experience. If you dress modestly, speak politely, smile pleasantly and don't ask the price of things you aren't ever going to buy the hassle factor drops markedly. Yes, you will overpay for what you do buy despite your best bargaining techniques. No, you won't get permanently lost - most folks are happy to tell you which way to get back to the main square if asked politely. You will occasionally get some annoying pressure from the more tourist-oriented shops but moving gently on is usually more than enough. Fabulous.
shopping. great going round the many shops lots on offer be prepared to bargain hard and walk away if necessary there will another round the corner....
Mayhem. Hectic and easy to get lost, but worth the experience. Some areas nicer than others, some sellers less pushy than others. Bargaining can be fun when you're in the right mood!

Get lost and haggle for a bargain. So many different sights and sounds. The Souqs are divided into different sections, but it takes a while to figure that out. Make sure you see the leather section, the olive section, the silverware, the spices, the ceramics and the clothes. Start bargaining at 25% of the price they ask, don't pay more than half of what the original price was. You can always go to the next stall!

great. Everyone chatty not too pushy........everywhere is so clean.....the smell of all the spices are out of this world...
amber, safrron, snake charmers were good
Great shopping. And surprisingly little hassle. Friendly sellers with lots of interesting wares. You can't really miss it, even if you're not a shopper (I'm not either, but I enjoyed this).

busy. lots og negiotiation required and a strong nerve to manage this but some bargains are to be had!
we bought a runner for 400dhs and another for 700dhs

The souk had fun bargains and a lot of selection for souvenirs. I really enjoyed the local market in Marrakech. I did not feel like the shopowners were extremely pushy and really helped me find what I was looking for in terms of souvenirs. Compared to souks in other cities I found this to be a better experience.

Nothing impressive - not in a positive way. This is a crowded bazar, witzh narrow streets, many shops, selling nearly the same in all of them, with often agressive sellers.I expected more "moroccan atmosphere", but it was just a crowded bazar. Guide took us in a carpet shop - nobody from our group wanted to buy carpet - still we had a detailed presentation (some nice pieces indeed) - but we left with the feeling of being guilty as we did not buy anything. Better avoid these shops!!!

a experience not to be missed!. This was like going back in time. Some parts are full of tourists, but other parts are very much local stalls, selling everything from second hand clothing, to tortoises! Be prepared for narrow alleyways filled with people, mopeds, donkey and carts. It is like going back in time. The stall holders don't really hassle too much, and if they do, just whisper 'police' and they soon stop!

You have to be strong and negociate hard. The soak is a bazar or a market place where they sale a lot of traditional stuff. When you want to buy something you have to negociate hard coz they are trying to trick you and to charge you more than it should be so be prepared to negociate and also be aware of some stuff that they say is made from leather coz is actually made from other stuff is not leather

Crazy atmosphere!. Great to walk around the souks and just take in the atmosphere, beware of motorbikes and donkeys railroading you out of the way! You don't really get hassled in the markets, if you just say no thanks they let you go off. Get into the haggling, good tip is start low and meet them somewhere in the middle, and don't let them force you up. Pay less than half the original price quoted, we were told 300 Dh for a scarf that I got for 100! Beware of getting directions form people in the markets as we found they will sometimes try and divert you to friends shops etc.

ooooooooooooooooooogh!!!. This place is sure to take you back in time!!! Beautiful women, good looking men! The fragrance of Kabab cooking everywhere! LOTS of things to shop! I can spend a huge chunk of my life just sitting here and watching all the action!!

haggle as hard as you can. If you are good at haggling, this might be your heaven. My husband is kind of a haggle god, try to half every prize the sllers offer you, good luck! If you want to buy items here, make sure to have an idea of what you want and what good quality shoud lokk like.

Ultimate shopping experience. For good or bad the souks are an experience. They sell everything and as long as you know you need to negotiate, they are an interesting experience. Remember to start at a price well below their 'asking price' and that the quality might not be as they tell you but you have to just get involved!

Go with a guide first….. This is an amazing place and souks split out into spice souk, ceramic souks, shoe souks etc. plus its a maze you see lots of people with maps who are lost as its easy to do so. Those who had been before all suggested we go on a tour to get our bearings and the feel of things and it was a good idea. Barter for everything its the countries main sport! Also check out the stalls in the squares they unlike the shops in the souks have less overheads and can sell cheaper!

Great walking experience. The souks are amazing and the deeper you penetrate the more authentic life you find. To do this you have to pass hundreds of small shops selling goods targeted totally at tourists. We were not bothered too much by touts, when approached we just said a firm no. If you want to buy always bargin. Just under half the offering price is a good place to start.One warning be very traffic aware! Just because the passages are narrow its does not mean that there will not be mopeds and donkey carts coming at you from all angles.

Souks. I have already raved about these in my previous review. The only thing I would say is that whatever price is asked for an item, at least halve it - don't be afraid of offending the sellers, I really don't think that's possible. Have a good look around before buying also, as you can invariably get whatever you're buying at a cheaper price elsewhere

marrakesh souk. fabulous place to visit some people complained that they felt intimidated we didn't at all .think you have to be assertive and sure of yourself .me and my husband had a lovely walk around .snake charmers tumblers and some strange looking men in even stranger hats very friendly had pic taken with them and the snakes for only 10 dirhams also took a lovely carriage ride around the city ,came back and had a lovely orange drink at a good vantage point could see all the souk very good go and enjoy you do not need a guide be assertive but smile

Something for everyone. A warren of narrow streets and passageways with everything from iron foundries to high class carpet shops. An unmissable experience which you can do on your own if you don't mind getting lost (or stay fairly close to the main square and just dip into small sections of the souks). But for a more in depth visit take a guide - just make it clear at the start if you are not interested in buying and you should avoid being led into too many of his "brother's" shops! We visited in the winter and perhaps it was because it had been a long busy season but there was a lot less hassle than we expected. Saying "no thanks" or "maybe later" generally seemed to work fine.

Never ceases to surprise. The TRICK is definitely to keep say two 100 dirham notes in your pocket and absolutely INSIST that is all you have. A 1000 dirham 'silver' (it's not of course) cigarette case was mine for 200 using this method. Forget haggling and look out for every slick move in the book. 'La Shukran' (no thank) and 'Waha' (yes) will fox them a bit. I tried selling the souk owner's ware to other people and they really couldn't get their head round that - fortunately they found it funny...

You really can't win here despite being the customer. Each shop hassles you to get into his shop. If you are friendly back they will hassle you more, if you just ignorse them they will get angry and shout things like "no education" or even try "you dropped something" - anything to get your attention. They also do not want you to take photographs mostly. Many items had a sticker on goods saying no photography. Strange. You are not allowed just to browse so you can't really enjoy the experience. Prices start way higher which leaves you the customer no room for bargaining. You have to walk away twice before a decent initial bargaining price can be had. Example: 180 dirhams starting price or a normal cotton scarf! That scarf sells for 20-30 dirhams. That is insulting. After the price was agreed he still tried to squeeze 5 dirhams out of me as he was handing me the bag.That being said it is a unique experience.

Great Haggling Territory. If you enjoy battling it out with local merchants, then you came to the right place. This market rivals, and perhaps beats, the Grand Bazaar of Turkey. Just be careful of who you trust for directions. Its always better to ask fellow tourists! Make sure that you also watch your personal belongings, as in any crowded market.
Horrible experience!. Dicing with life and limb to cross roads to and from it. Hold on tight to personal possessions and bags. Dirty and over crowded. Couldn't wait to leave!

Great atmosphere. The souks are a must in Marrakech - although they can be quite intimidating at the start. Everyone expects you to bargain (in fact they actually enjoy the back and forth - that's how they do it, as one of the friendly shopkeepers explained to us!) so never pay the initial price you're quoted - it will be significantly inflated. Unfortunately I have no talent or joy in bargaining so I probably overpaid for my purchases, but there are some lovely exotic things to be had! :)

Bring your wallet.. But be ready to negotiate.. HARD. We came to Morroco with the intention of doing some shopping and the Marrakesh Souk was the perfect spot. If you are looking for a cheap magnet or a US$20,000 mother of pearl and tortoise shell chest they have you covered. Be ready to negotiate... Have in mind what you want to pay as the first price is a joke. Give your counter offer of 75-80% off their original asking price then walk out if they don't take it. They always came after us accepting our counter offer. I even heard a shop owner ask a tourist how much do you want to pay?Our day trip had a tour through the market where we saw the metal workers and leather-smiths making some of the items found in the market. Seeing the handicraft skill in the market was very interesting!

Go deep. This is Marrakesh but the souks close to Jemaa el Fna are totally touristy. Get as far away from the square as you dare. The further away the more authentic. You might even see an occasional Moroccan customer!
Wonderful stay in Marrakech. Really fascinating. Incredibly busy and so many sights and sounds. Loved all the textiles and handicrafts.

Be cautious of asking advice!. We entered the Souk looking for pottery, and after a long time found what we wanted. Our troubles started trying to find our way out. In the end we asked for advice. Bad move. The male took us all over the place, with us stopping and saying we will sort out ourselves. Then the troubles started. He wanted a sum of money I was not prepared to pay. A long series of "stand off's" began, my wife getting quite scared, ending up with the "guide" with NO money for his greed. We came out, never to enter again!!

Very Interesting. Not as intense as the Souk in Fes, this souq had everything one could imagine. From the spices to the animals, from the galleries to the jewels, this is a great place just to wander and get lost in, having some delicious food along the way.

Go during the day first !. Our fist visit was at night and it was all over the place and we missed out on so much. We then visited during the day and truly enjoyed the experience. The entire place is magic where can buy anything and everything, bartering us taken to a new art here and don't be put off by it. The locals love it and the will only sell when the are making a profit so if the say 1000 dirhams go on lower and you will come out what works for each party. We felt very safe at all times and I must say that the Moroccans want you to have a great time in their city. Loved the place so go and enjoy

Worth a visit but you aren't missing much. We got a couple of bargains here but you get easily lost and people are ready to jump on you to scam at least £50 off of you to lead you one street on that May or my not lead you back to where you want to go. Without trying we got caught out and ended up outside the city walls that resulted in us spending a wasted 3 hours trying to find our way back in, luckily for us we didn't have much cash on us and he wasted his time as much as ours. My advice don't go near the souks in the dark or you will have the same trouble as us. Most of the stuff here is fake and can be cheap but not always, it's fun haggling for a bit but as we learned from artists around the city a lot of stuff in the souks is reproduced and copied in China. Pay a little extra and go to the craft centres instead for authentic moroccan merchandise

Good but not great souk. Limited hassle. Obviously this is a must see for most visitors -particularly if you have not been in a souk before. Good range of leatherwork,carpet,spices,materials. Prices more than smaller locations in Morrocco but fun all the same. Definitely worth spending a little time getting lost in. Mostly good humoured vendors who do not go overboard in trying to entice you into their particular store.

souk mayhem and atmosphere. vist the souks and the square , great atmosphere and smells , do not be intimidated its very safe and friendly , a tip do not buy anything at night poor light and sub standard goods , go back in day light to see the goods in daylight might not be as good as you thought .we had food but only in restaurants not of the stalls and we were fine you will get lost but follow the crowds and you will make it back to the square tip do not ask anyone for directions as they will want money ,no local will do anything for nothing but enjoy

Great place to stroll around if you have some knowledge of the way they operate. I love to get lost in all these little alleys , but do not do it without a professional authorized guide.Whatever you buy, do not pay more than more 40 % of the asking price. People are mostly friendly and do not be afraid to say no.Recently I have noticed that the security improved and a lot of security guards are wandering around now.

Souk It Up. No visit to Marrakech is complete with getting lost in the Souks. We found the way to avoid being completely disorientated was to look at the stalls ahead of you. If there was one were selling brightly coloured mini tagines you were heading toward the main square. If not, you were heading into the local markets and need to retrace your steps.
Souk. Crazy fun .friendly and safe . Don't ask anyone how to get out cause they will have you in there all day
scary. Lots of beggars hanging around, cover up as you look really out of place with questions summer dress on.

The real thing. This really does give you a flavor of Africa. Everything for sale, gritty streets smoking street food places everywhere and a touch of donkey piss. It is a mix of the real thing and relentless commerce and rip off. The rip off follows you into every little corner of this town... it never ends there is always someone else to point you in the wrong direction so you pass another shop.

Marrakech Souk. It is amazing there!! I saw snake charmers and entertainers!! There are beautiful fruit and spice stands and then all the shopping you can handle in a day. There is such a wide variety of items and at really good prices. Then after shopping you can take a break at an outdoor restaurant or cafe or go for a full meal in a restaurant all within the area of the souk. I love the souk there and will go back to explore more on my next visit!!
Scary. I found the experience a bit scary as a lot of marrakech men shouting at you to come to their shop and buy found some moroccan men rude.

Do not be taken in that its a dangerous place with out a guide!!. There seems to be a scam between friends or families were the Taxi ( Yellow cab) will drop you off at a point near the Souk. as soon as you get out of the Taxi there is a man saying hello( this later turned out to be the Taxi drivers Cousin), are you visiting the Souk? We said yes but later, first we want to see the square. He made us feel that the square was dangerous, and that we should see the Souk first, of course with him! OK the rules are, that you have to be a registered guide to show people around the Square and Souk and the Police take anyone else pretending to be a guide very seriously! So either book a registered guide from the hotel or pretend you are local!! There are people that come up to you and try and sell you things if you are on your own, which gets really tiring. Also there are beggars. However it's an amazing place!!

Lovely. Lovely shopping experience. I loved just walking in the narrow alleys and smelling the authentic leathers. They are also very nice people although they would follow you and insist you should have a look at their store. Don't feel threatened. Just keep smiling and be patient. Then, you will see how kind and generous they are in bargaining or even, in hearing a no from you. I loved the people. I was expecting more fake materials but to be honest, it was hard to find fake things especially in leather section.
Amazing!. If you are a lover of folk art and awesome clothing made of natural fibers, this is the place for you.
Delicious. Too many to choose from didn't like being man handled to try and get you in. You also can get lost very easy.
You will get lost. Great experience seeing locals going about their business but you can so easily get lost however for me that's part of the fun. Enjoy the experience.

Hustling & bursting in the souk. The souk is an important place of interest where you could practise your haggling skills. But be mindful & careful because prices of goods differs and depends on your Country of origin.

How not to buy :). Beware as you will experience pleasant and unpleasant here. Yes, you will be harassed, pretty much on every step you will take. That's part of souks and Moroccan culture if you cannot handle that, just don't go. Or just... don't pay attention and walk on - you will be left alone. Few useful tips. 1. You will definetly get lost! On our first day we were walking about for 3h before we have managed to find our way back to the main square. Look up - there are wee green and red signs just above the shops that lead you to the main squares. And don't listen to local ppl trying to tell you that road is closed and pointing you in another direction (they do that constantly! God knows why, to sell more stuff on they own stand?). Trust your own instinct - after a day or two we were able to take shortcuts and go everywhere faster. Getting lost is good too! On non-touristic dodgy-looking side streets we managed to find real craftsmen in their dirty, wee workshops making real Moroccan scarves, carved stones, wood paintings and selling them for half of the price of the main market shabby stalls (that are loaded with stuff "made in China")2. Bargain of course. You should get everything at least half of the starting price. 3. Check what you're buying. Everyone will try to rip you off - sad but true. Giving you higher price but also selling you worthless stuff. When buying famous Moroccan black soap make sure you're buying one in sealed container with label etc (not the one on the pile, without any smell, and probably way out of date). Be careful with saffron (cheaper, dyed flowers may be sold as saffron)4. Tips on argan oil, that we were given in the hotel: The good cosmetic one doesn't smell. It has almost no scent at all. It also should absorb very quickly. If it leaves your skin greasy, it's not a proper argan oil. Also - if put in the fridge - it will set. 5. Watch your step. There's scooters everywhere and they drive like crazy! 6. Don't get intimidated, just enjoy your walk! :) Don't buy if you don't want to but also be respectful.

Worst Part of Morocco. Marrakech aka "India lite" is definitely the worst part of our trip around Morocco. We travel extensively and can readily handle aggressive touts (india, south america, etc..) but in Marrakech they are more akin to thieves. There is nothing in Marrakech that you won't see or can't buy in other parts of Morocco at a fraction of your best hard bartering deal. Save yourself the hassle and skip it if you can.

Get a guide. We hired a local guide to see the places you wouldn't want to venture into alone.Prepare to be shocked.As one visitor put it 'folk living rough on our city streets have it better than theses poor devils'

World Class!. No need to write a long review here. If you are in Marrakech this is a place you need to go and see and experience. It is big, crowed and easy to get lost in, but it is something that you must see and experience. Do it!

amazing. You WILL get lost when entering here, we tried to keep track of our movements but that didn't work A lot of the shops sell the same things and you need to haggle for everything.When you want to get back to the square just ask a shopkeeper and the are more than happy to help as they are used to seeing people lost in the maze of alleys.Did'nt get much hassle from them and they seemed polite

Magical Marrakech. Step back in time as you wander through the exotic souks of Marrakech. Temptation awaits at each corner. Be thrilled by the explosion of noise, colours and aromas that awaken the senses. And be in awe of the craftsmanship and pride invested into making those pieces of art, be it jewellery, carpets, lamps or trinkets that brighten your home.The Moroccan people are proud, warm and welcoming. You are in a market place so expect to be approached they will haggle and bargain it's what they do to make an honest living. Generally the prices are easily reduced. If you go too low it can be insulting. A good bargain can be readily had. Enjoy the experience for what it is.I have been to the souks many times. They are many entrances and exits. Some parts are more touristic than others. The best experience and place to go is where the artisans are busy at work. Here you can watch the creation of many of the true treasures of Morocco. Handmade originals are more expensive but still negotiable. You can pay with several different types of currency or Debit/Credit card. Many places will organise delivery of the goods to your home. The food markets and stalls are interesting many delicacies are freshly baked or cooked in front of you. But please do check the quality and freshness before indulging. Unfortunately Health and Safety takes on a new meaning. So here are a few tips to help you with your visit to the souk:Have a guide the 1st time to save time and money. They are educated polite and helpful and not expensive.Have small change for photographsDO NOT TAKE PHOTOS with out asking and expect to pay for them 5 d local currencyRespect their way of lifeTake hand gelWatch where you are going its very busyEat in a Riad - good experience and lovely traditional food.Your personal belongings are usually quite safe but still watch them anyway.Enjoy our little friends as they experience first hand the souks, the kasbah, tombs, and Ourika Valley https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XO5HYbOWcEY
Take care. I visited the souq but the atmosphere didn't like with hearing story if robbery but myself was safe and people was so friendly it worth taking care

pay for a guide recommended by your hotel. Do not listen to anyone in the street that tells you they are from your hotel!!!!! Ask your hotel to book a regulated guide. We stayed at la maison Arabe and they gave us a phone to call them on if we got into any difficulty. We did get lost, its very easy to get lost, honestly. Take care of your belongings. Be prepared for anything and everything. An experience you will remember always.

Shoppers Paradise. Wonderful time in the Marrakech Souks. Recommend you first go with a guide that can help you navigate through them and understand the culture (bargaining) and layout. Then go on your own and just get lost in the vast catacombs of shops.....never be afraid to ask how to get back to the main square (the Madina) everyone will always graciously point you in the right direction. Have fun and enjoy!

Like many others around the world. Full of that with some small bargains and some expensive outlets.Not as impressive as the Grand Bazaar in Istanbul but well worth a visit...... and it's fun trying to find your way back out.

Nice experience, but be careful. We went to the souks as they're around the Djemma el Fna. There are lots and lots of stores, with different types of items solds (shoes, clothes, spices, lamps, etc). I think everyone will tell you to bargain the price...well do! We bought everything 70% off the original price, and I think we could have got even a lower one. Vendors we engaged with in bargaining were nice, kept us from leaving the place until we bought something, and tried to get the most price out of us. There were a couple of places where we were not sure about the quality or the price so we offered a really low price and they left us go. On the other hand, be careful about people calling you or trying to take you to their stores, they told us sometimes they charge even more and it would be very difficult to get rid of them afterwards.We grabbed a bite to eat in the souks too, being much cheaper than in Djemma el Fna; in the Kessabine souk there was a very little place that served like crepes made of some traditional ingredients that were really good; there was one made with onions that was very tasty; and they were very cheap: only 5 dirham for each crepe (about €0.5). In another souk (I don't recall the name) we also bought bread (round big one) for 5 dirham too; and we had lunch in a small restaurant called Chez Bahia, where I enjoyed my first chicken tagine and a chicken pastille, they were both really good and tasty; these dishes plus two small sodas cost us 100 dirhams.We really enjoyed the souk experience!
Scary. Would only recommend a visit with a guide! Very small and high pressure. Not my cup of tea at all. A very scary experience
Buyer beware. Beware of folks leading you to specific shops and pressure tactics to purchase goods (at very elevated prices).
Souk visit. After travelling a fair piece of the World this Souk was much like any other as far as what was available to buy.Be careful though as the Souk is very extensive & one could get lost!

HOW MANY TAGINES DOES ONE NEED. We had a guide to take us round the more unusual parts of the Souk. I am a shopper and came away with NOTHING. There was nothing much very original. The interesting shops were the herbal shops where ther shopkeepers seemed very knowledgeable.

Shopping in the Souk. The arts and textiles that are offered in the Souk are beautiful. We had a male friend with us who is fluent in Arabic to negotiate prices for our purchases. Otherwise as a tourist I would have ended up paying three times the cost. I bought traditional camel leather and red fabric ankle boots, blue and white leather babouches, (slippers), a red suede handbag with silver and turquoise colored medallions, a tea pot for one person with a small round serving tray, and of course Argan oil for my hair. If I had room in my luggage I'm sure I would have bought a lot more.

Busy, Be prepared to Haggle!!. This is definitely something to do once. We were told at our Riad to haggle everything down to at least half the price offered, which we tried. It's tough work so only go to the effort with something you really want to buy. Always count your change! It is overall good, plenty to see, lots of colour and people. If you are planning to go to Essaouira though, you can get your souvenirs much cheaper there, (half the price for most things).
Nice building!. A bit of peace inside and nice decor outside, makes it unique as a train station: couple of take away and all necessary service around!

"Too much customer service" . We were in the souk and after an hour we left. We couldn't even look around without being harassed. At the beginig looks funny but after 3 steps, got annoyed.
Different atmosphere but they should let the tourism enjoy more

Marrakesh Souk. This place full of small things for house and not only. There is possible to find something interesting for everybody!!!
And regarding the guys who always happy to help you for money, just ignore them and be confident, they are not talking to people who don't look lost.

Love the environment but be careful of scams. I really enjoyed the souk, it's a great experience but you should be aware of scams (fake tourist guides) and overpriced items. Always bargain the price, they tend to ask for much more and they are really annoying... Apart from that, once you're in the spirit of Marrakech, you will love it.

Get ready to be overwhelmed. The medina's labyrinthine souks are never ending and while exploring you are sure to get lost at one point or another! Just relax, enjoy yourself & get ready for overwhelming sounds, smells & a distinctly medieval atmosphere - you'll come beak to beak with magnificent hawks in bejewelled blindfolds advertising their owners' wares from copper goods to elaborate wedding djellabas for hire. There is permanent smoke in the air from smalltime blacksmiths operating in the crowded alleyways, & alongside them traditional spice merchants pedal spells & potions, hemlock & mandrake, next to honey-flavoured saffron for scenting an authentic lamb stew, piled high in tempting mounds. Watch the craftsmen at work, carving, dyeing & weaving. As for the main shops - each souk has its own local craft speciality, from pottery & wood to silver & textiles, leather shoes & glittering jewellery to cooking pots & pretty, scented candles - perfect to take home. You could emerge with a richly patterned rug, an assortment of glazed ceramics or a metallic leather cushion! Feast your eyes on the displays of glimmering silk slippers, glistening piles of olives, exquisite inlaid wooden boxes & beautifully woven shawls. Bartering is expected, so see it as a game & don't be shy. For heavenly homemade organic soaps, heady with the scent of local flowers, visit L'Art du Bain in Souk Lebbadine. For aromatic oils as exotic as frankincense & myrrh, & amazing fragrances, visit the traditional Herboriste Avicenne in Souk Laghzel. The chic Akbar Delights in Place Bab Fteuh is famous for its finely-embroidered & beaded tops & skirts. In the bustling Place des Epices, vendors offer covetable china & woven baskets in many colours.But for me the best part was getting lost and just exploring the shops rather than actually doing some shopping!

Souks. You will get lost but that's part of the fun. Don't be beguiled into taking a guide- everyone is a guide and even a point in the right direction will lead to a demand for money. Look confident and look out for landmarks and you,ll find your way.

You can't just browse. Really didn't like being hassled by every shop keeper, in fact if they had backed off, I would have probably bought something. In Essaouira, they are very relaxed and leave you alone so I did my shopping there.

Worth a quick look - but don't buy !. The Souks are worth a quick look. The experience of the hustle & bustle of the Marrakech Market is worth half a day, you'll pretty much have had enough of it by then.The best advice I would give is look but don't buy - you'll most certainly get ripped off. Firstly, it's worthless junk, not authentic Moroccan produce. The money that they try to get from tourists is laughable. For example, the starting price on a tea set will be about the equivalent of £50, the idea is that you haggle and get the set for about £25 and think that you've got a bargain. In actuality the tea-set is probably worth no more than a couple of quid, it's the made in China stuff that you see on the cheap market stalls at home and would never think about buying. I opted to buy some spice, I thought this would be a safe bet, so I bought some Saffron. Unfortunately when I got it home and went to use it it was useless. It had no taste whatsoever, it was either so old or wasn't Saffron at all - probably some copy made to sell to tourists.So basically, whatever you buy you will be ripped off. Furthermore, you'll have the hassle from the seller. If you merely look at something he isn't going to leave you alone. The Souks are packed with people but if you look closely you'll see very few people actually buying. This place could be so much better with some education from the government. If the sellers stopped hassling everyone then people would not be afraid to look at the merchandise instead of just walking passed. And if they charged reasonable prices than they would actually sell something.So as I say, it's worth a look but not to buy, and the restaurants are ok and reasonably priced.

Loved them - but beware the motorbikes!. An amazing place, loved it, very vibrant and exciting, lots of different areas selling lots of different things - a leather area, a metal area, jewellery, baskets, spices, etc. Good fun bartering - it is all in good spirits and I didn't ever feel threatened. Lots of genuinely helpful people (that didn't request payment) giving directions or showing you the way. Just watch out he souks are skinny and don't be surprised to have motorbikes/ horse and carts/ etc coming at you as you go round a corner!!

hugley entertaining but dont get sucked in. If you have never seek a Moroccan market your eyes will be popping out of your head.Hugely entertaining with a mass of colour & mostly friendly traders, that is until you want to return something then you will see a completely different attitude.Great free entertainment for all the family.Tip on haggling what ever the start price you should try & end up at one third of that price or less despite what yarn maybe spun.

Get ready for a fleecing and plenty of mobiletes. The usual array of stunning wares is let down by the incessant buzz of speeding motor scooters up and down the souks, which aside from fouling the air, puts you even more on edge from the hyper-inflated prices suggested by the majority of shop keepers. You may say it's all part of the experience, but I find that the souks of Fez are much more enjoyable and walkable.

Amazing place for shopping, but not for all.. Marrakech souk is a huge commercial center. You can find thousands products at resonable price.The problem is that they don't show the price, so you need to compare the prices and decide how much give to the seller.Is not esy and very stressed but if you find the way you can make a very good deal.

Proper souk with so many outlets. Awesome Souk, so many alleyways and places to get lost. Some stallholder like to think if you are a westerner that you are an easy take. I walked away and of course the further I walked they were prepared to come back to the price I had offered but at that point I had lost interest. Still got some beautiful pieces that I love. Would definitely go back again
A must in Marrakech. You'll get lost in the narrow streets drunk on smells and colours...best place for shopping..relax and have fun!

Culture shock!. Our first time.... well what can I say. Group of ten. Glad we had a guide although still intimidating. Second day we went alone just 2 of us and loved it, enjoyed haggling, talking to the locals who are quite friendly if you give them the chance. Bought some lovely gifts. Best experience so far.

Marrakech mayhem!. We found the labyrinth of souks to be less hard sell than the outer shops . There was a slightly calmer feel to them but you will still be unable to casually wander round without a shop owner trying to persuade you that their goods are the best . We felt quite intimidated in some of the outer areas and encountered some sinister characters on occasions, often sensing that we were being unduly observed and followed. Basically everyone and their brother wants cash off you somehow .Our description of our Marrakech experience would be to say it was like the Trafford Centre on acid!!

Very interesting and MUST DO but be careful not to ask for help!. We went to the souks on our first day and it was great and very interesting but we got fouled by locals. They can spot tourists and even if you're not asking them where to go, they tell you they know where the souk is and they have to go anyways (for work or to see a family member) and then at the end they ask you for some money. Either be prepared to give money (as all is all they can help you find your way) or say NO straight away is someone is telling you to follow them. We also had one guy who showed us around and was taking some money form the people we bought stuff from. That's another way for them to get money. But make sure you know what you want before accepting help. Also, you have to bargain there. Maybe decrease the price by 50%. Be ready to leave the shop and come back later. Sometimes they will call you back and accept your last offer :)

So much to choose from . When you are buying make sure you go down 1/3rd of the price they are giving you. You will get it somewhere close to it!Good if you can speak French and Arabic. Our trip was a wonderful one. Don't miss the Hammam - a treat for yourself to take away all the pain. We had such a wonderful experience!

get lost for the day. fantastic days lost in the winding lanes and alleys, find the spice market and sit with a snack or just a drink and watch the world go by.i found this much more enjoyable than the main square and cheaper and cooler.

Shoppers' Paradise. One of several musts to visit. Get fun over bargaining but don't be intimidated. As a rule of thumb the fair price is about 1/3rd of the vendor's opening bid. Shake off anyone who wants to show you their sister's argan oil shop or offers to guide you anywhere.

Marrakesh - an excellent short break. My wife and I have just returned from a 4 day break in Marrakesh, Morocco. These breaks are currently being widely promoted in newspapers and magazines at present and ours turned out to be excellent value. We were fortunate to stay in a 5star Opera Plaza hotel which is adjacent to the Opera House and the newly built main railway station with its many cafes on the roof. Marrakesh is full of contrasts - the 500 year old city is enclosed by a wall and is known as the Medina. In it is a treasure trove of buildings, monuments and homes - the most remarkable part we found was the "Souk" with its myriad of ancient passageways, mostly undercover, housing craftsmen of every kind working in conditions that have not changed for centuries. There are a large number of specialised areas such as metal working, leatherworking, woodworking etc. encompassing every trade imaginable to provide for the thousands of local population. You emerge into a huge open market area- Place Jemaa El Fna where you are offered everything you might need including garments, shoes, headgear and even complete sets of false, or individual loose teeth. There are also snake charmers and owners of monkeys who are insistent that you hold one in your arms whist they take a photograph, or you can tour the Medina in a 2 horse open carriage. Two distinct cultures are represented everywhere, the original Berbers and Arabs, but also more than 25% of the city are Jewish, and this amazing mixture exists side by side in perfect harmony, speaking mainly Moroccan, Arabic, French and English. You really appreciate you are "abroad" but never feel nervous as you walk anywhere. Outside the Medina millions of Euros and Dollars have been spent in building a new totally modern city with all it has to offer in 21st century living. Overlooking this unique combination are the snowcapped Atlas Mountains shining brightly white in the sunshine against the azure sky. There is so much to see and all this for less than the cost of 4 days half board in an hotel in London, Birmingham or Manchester.
Souk. Again, the weather stopped us - from wandering for too long. We weren't that harassed weather was a natural deterrent.

time to get lost. the best way to explore is just walk in and out of the ally ways - there are bargains to be had the price quoted is not the price you pay - start the barter 50% of the quoted price and stick to your guns if they don't agree simply say thanks smile at them and they will chase you and then agree at the cost but don't be scared and don't be rude to them - joke with the people they like it.

Place Djemaa el Fna - Marrakeshs top attraction. If you visit Marrakesh you definitaly must see Place Djemaa el Fna. I recommend to visit this place one hour before sunset. There you will find a lot of attractions as the water sellers in their traditional red ponchos and big hats, snake charmers, monkeys etc.. Enjoy a fresh orange juice from one of the orange markets and enjoy the vibe of this place. Close before sunset take a thé du menthe from one of the rooftoop terraces and enjoy the sunset behind the Koutobia mosque.

Getting totally lost and having fun!. My friend and I spent the day wandering the many areas of the Marrakech Souk. We found 2 museums, both very interesting, a little tiny shop serving mint tea, lunch in a coutyard and shopping galore. We ended up in the main square, in the evening, to see all the action and samples some of the food stalls.
Amazing and atmospheric. What a buzz! It's a fantastic atmosphere. Great to go when the sun is going down - it come to life!. Be prepared to haggle and you will grab yourself a bargain .

Marrakech souk. If you visit the souks in Marrakech you might want to have a guide. The vendors are very aggressive. Be careful of your purse. Do not show too much interest or the vendors will harass you at times. Be aware of your surroundings and don't venture too far into the souk or you can become disoriented.

Average. It is exactly what you imagine. Locals go about their business at the food stalls and salesmen try to flog a mixture of locally-made craft goods and knock-off designer items to the tourists. Quite good for leather goods. If you really don't want anything, don't get upset with the requests to look- it's their only way of advertising what they have - just smile and keep moving. It is a large area and you can get lost. To be fair it is no better or worse than similar markets in the Middle and Far East. Try it.

Great experience. I travelled to Morocco with my Mum who is approaching 72. We had a lovely time in the souks, the people are very friendly. Best to smile and walk away if you are not interested in buying anything from souks. There are hundreds of shops, we took our time and chose some lovely pieces of gifts. You will always need to bargain, my advise would be only pay what you think it is worth.

Chaotic fun. We had a great time wandering around the Souk. It is fantastic being able to walk down the narrow alleys and see products being crafted and sold around you. Anyone interested in anything from home furnishings to food will have a great time rummaging around the small market stalls and chatting to the locals. The smells are rich, the colours vivid and the streets bustling. You will need to use your common sense in this area, keep your bags close to you and watch your toes when the motorbikes and mules tear up and down the streets. Shopkeepers will try and talk to you continuously and when you tell them no thank you, they will leave you alone. A friend and I received some funny lines from the locals, some a little unsettling but many entertaining, our favourite being 'fish and chips'. Females are best keeping themselves covered as much as possible, the markets are very heavily male dominated and some of which are not scared to stare. Be careful when buying raw meat from the markets, some is not kept cold and is not covered properly. There are stalls where you can purchase fresh chicken and if you ask they will prepare it for you on site. If you are sensitive about animals, I would perhaps avoid looking in any butchers, chickens are sometimes kept alive in cages at the back of the shops and it is not uncommon to see sheep heads hanging from the front of some stalls.I would highly recommend the street food here, my friend that I was travelling has a sensitive stomach and was perfectly fine afterwards. There are many foods to try and most do a small taster portion which is great if you are attempting to try them all. You can see how heavily influenced the street food is from French cuisine and you will find many of it different from what you see in the restaurants around the city.For your first time in the market I would recommend aimlessly walking around without a map. You will soon pick up landmarks to help you navigate. Remember if you are lost keep on walking in one direction keeping the sun or a large building like a mosque on the same side of you, you will exit onto a larger street or to a landmark that should be named. Don't follow any of the men that try and give you directions, I've heard a lot of stories for them asking for money when you reach your destination. The terrace bars are a great place to stop and refresh yourself whilst having a perfect view over the souk, enjoy some mint tea or an arabic coffee and take advantage of the toilets.Last of all don't forget to haggle, this is part of the charm of the market. Expect to pay around a third of what is offered, even if you are buying cigarettes. There are even more benefits of buying multiple items. If a shopkeeper isn't backing down and your price is reasonable, try walking away and they will often try and call you back.

Crazy experience!. I spent a couple of days exploring the souk and it was quite the experience! My first day I was a deer in the headlights and a bit overwehelmed. It is really easy to get lost. Beware of teenage boys wanting to help you as they will demand payment and argue with you if it is not enough. After a couple weeks in Morocco I was much better prepared for the souk and enjoyed it more. I got very good at bartering. Do NOT pay face value! They vendors will keep asking you for your "Best Price". I got to where I could negotiate down to half of the original price on some items. They are fun though and will serve you mint tea and chat like you are their best friend. They are the best I have encountered anywhere at parting me with my money!

Colours everywhere!. We loved exploring Marrakech Souks! did not find it as crazy and busy as people had warned us..loved seeing the colourful carpets, fabric, leather goods, food products and so much more! For more details of our experience see www.selimfamily.com on Morocco blog posts..great experience!

Be aware for "guides". The Souk in Marrakech is a maze of alleyways and can be quite intimidating. As a result the unsuspecting tourist can fall foul of locals who, when seeing you aren't too sure of your way will offer to help.For us this included a trip to his families leather production site and trying to encourage us to shops that he thought we would like. We paid for the trip around the leather site and then paid him a tip for his help. At this stage he got abusive and wanted an extortionate amount of money. We told him where to go and started walking on (even though we didn't still know which way was out)

Busy, busy , busy. . You can certainly get a bargain here but prepare to haggle and to be harassed. We were followed more or less everywhere by people asking if we wanted a guide or directions. Some of the stall owners were find and not pushy at all, they were the ones that got our business as we felt less intimidated. I also found it hard to walk past the woman and children sitting in the street selling tissues/begging for money I so wanted to give them all some money. Be careful also of the Henna ladies as they do try and grab you even if you don't want it done. Also with photos be aware of people around you and the stall/person you are taking a photo of will want some money too so make sure you have some change handy.

The thing to do in Marrakech. These are a bit Mad ...Barter barter barter.Keep an eye on your pockets and bagsBargains to be had and goods to be purchasedBe friendly. Get lost and don't panic when you do. Orientated yourself and soak up atmosphere

The Souks. Totally bonkers! Spent the first few days getting lost and too worried about looking, in case they tried to sell you something, but then 'something' happened. I think it was the air of confidence you must get after learning your way around, as by this point nobody asked us to look, even when we stopped at their shops! You don't tend to get hassled as you might in other countries, just one or two non mercis is enough for them to smile and let you on your way. Beware of children saying 'Mister, mister, that was is closed' as they are not speaking the truth! Lots of fun to be had shopping and don't be afraid to haggle!
Hell hole!!. Filthy, go to your local tip it will be more interesting!! I will probably be cleaner! I'm no snob and respect other cultures but you will be harassed from all angles.... Beware!!!

Marrakech Souk. Visited here with my daughter and we thought it was great, smells and noises, people everywhere. Shame though that they won't leave you alone to peruse the wares and are constantly in your face. Probably would have bought more if they would just give you the opportunity to have some peace and have a look.

The souk of Djemaa el-fna square. Just goes on for ever. A great deal of leather goods You may need to ask the way back to the Square. All the sales people are male. One does wonder how some make a living in the rabbit warren. Haggling is expected but you are not pestered

lovely crafts. very nice to see peope working in their own shops, the presence of mopets and cyclists is really annoying. Very pleased to see the number of women using them! This is unprecedented in the arab world! You can clearly see the pluristic side of Morrocan society, some women are fashionably covered and some are not!

Aladdin's cave. This place is a must when visiting Marrakesh, however expect to be hassled and hounded to 'come into my shop' every step you take . Putting that aside and keeping open minded this visit can be a great experience .All kinds of souvenirs/gifts can be haggled for here and many items if bargained for can be a great purchase to come away with . The narrow 'streets' seem to go on forever and you will find that touts tell you 'this is the way out' just to get you towards their shop. However, this is the place to visit in order to feel that you are in the heart of Marrakesh and Moroccan culture . You will get lost , but just go with the flow. Personally just one visit or half a day is enough , but if you are really into your haggling this is a hagglers paradise !
Shopping fun.. Great place to pick up souvenirs, lots of good local ceramics and textiles. Lots of imported cheap rubbish too. Be prepared to haggle hard.

A must visit experience!. As a single female traveller I was a bit apprehensive at entering the souk but after a strong coffee I managed to enter via one of the many entrances/exits with "you will survive this" repeating on a loop in my head. Be prepared to get lost... it happens as every stall starts to look the same, the vendors all have the same patter and you are focused on getting out the other side... I made it out after an hour or so and have to say it wasn't as scarey as I thought it would be. Be firm and keep eye contact to a minimum and you will be fine. After a few days in Marrekech I was feeling so relaxed about the souk I was popping in and out of it several times a day just to experience the sounds,sights and smells. By my last day I felt almost like a local. Do be aware of men wanting to help or guide you... Unfortunately I fell foul once and was led into a rabbit warren of back streets before being guided towards a shop that my helpful guide had taken me to... I politely but firmly refused to enter and started back the way we had came... a little shaken but more annoyned at myself for falling for it than anything else... on my way out of the souk a young man told me "walk to the right to avoid the puddles" which I was actually doing but my mistake was to say "thankyou". He walked along in front of me trying to engage in conversation and despite me totally ignoring him he was within a few steps of me all the way through the souk... finally getting to the public square I went into the first big cafe and drank a coffee very slowly... he followed me in and sat watching me for the full hour I was there.. only when I approached a policeman on leaving the cafe did he get the hint to disappear. My own fault really but not a pleasant experience that I want to repeat.

Investigating the area. Felt very brave when we embarked on our first outing to the souk as the traffic is unbelievable but having said that we didn't see any accidents although traffic is whizzing around you from all sides you just need to keep very alert. It is a fascinating place and we loved wandering around looking at all that was going on.
great busy souks. I loved the business of the place and the haggling! great that everything as it was nearly 1000 years ago!

Wander, get lost, enjoy. You will get lost. That's fine. Just ask locals to help you. Vast and so very interesting to explore. Vendors are friendly and want (expect) to bargain but no need to buy anything to enjoy the atmosphere.

Cultural and interesting.. The fiancee and I visited Marrakech for her 21st birthday. We went into the souks as part of an excursion provided by thomson. Who we booked out holiday with. The souks are small alleyways which have many of market type stalls, where the locals sell their homemade crafted items. You really get to experience the culture of morroco through the souks with interesting smells and characters. You do have to be aware of mopeds as the locals travel through the souks on them but if you keep to the right of the path you will be fine. Also for women it can be a little bit intimidating with the men looking at you and calling you. If you don't make major eye contact and ignore them you will be fine. Overall the souks are a must visit when you are in morroco to get a real insight into morroco culture.

THE SOUK - FULL ON!. We stayed 10 days in riad just north of the souks - we really couldn't go anywhere without facing the onslaught of sellers - the novelty wore off after about Day 3! Be prepared to get lost - a lot - even on our last day we still ended up making an unintended turn and walked for miles to reach the square when it should have taken 5-10 minutes -it's just impossible to figure out and forget your maps - no use! In hindsight, 3 days in Medina combined with remainder staying outside might have been a better choice but the riad was so beautiful we loved our visit anyway. It's noisy and smelly and busy..and fascinating and a true shopper's paradise. I'm not the world's best haggler so visited the Ensemble Artisanal (where prices are fixed) to get an idea of what you SHOULD be paying for things - it helped enormously - it is so easy to be ripped off - but, then again, I suppose whatever you're buying is worth what you're willing to pay. You need to keep your sense of humour. Most people will back off if you just say 'No thank you' and walk on - don't catch their eye! Also be careful of kids trying to guide you to 'La Place' (Jemma El Fnaa) - they will take you out of your way and try and lead you to a stall/shop - just tell them you know where you're going and walk on! Some can be very persistent but be strong!

Its fine to get lost...... This place does not stand still and its hard not to get carried along with it all. Go with the flow but keep your wit's about you and take time to stop for a tea and sit back and watch it all, that's part of the experience. Watch out for the motorcycles, they don't stop for you. Would also suggest wearing closed shoes or a least sturdy toe covered sandles.

A map or a tour guide is essential. This a sprawling rabbit warren of narrow paths and passageways. Don't be surprised to come face to face with bicycles, scooters or even a donkey and cart. Always walk on the right.Like any big city, watch out for pickpockets. We were targeted but due to being vigilant they did not succeed. Due to the nature of the place you would be best to use a proper tour guide or a map ( you have to be good with a map as most streets have no names) If you do venture in you will be treated to a sight of metal workers, leather workers and shops selling all sorts of wares. It is well worth a visit as it is quite an eye opener to what we are used to. It is probably not suitable for young children or the infirmed due to the " traffic " and the uneven path surfaces.

hustle and bustle. you dont know where to look next. this is so busy . there are people mopeds pushbikes coming at you from all angles. the people of marrakech are so friendly. there are sights and smells all over and its difficult to take it all in. i would advise seeing at different times of the day. in the morning it is quiet so you are able to see more. in the early afternoon you can take in the snake charmers and monkey handlers .at night it is so frantic but never once did i feel frightened. highly recommended

lots of shops but most of the same stuff over and over. When you hear this is the largest of its kind in Africa one thinks of a wonderous variety which is lacking in this souk complex. the areas facing Jemma El Fna are heavily tourist orientated and only towards the back do you find souks that the locals use. not complaining as the locals need to encourge the tourists but it takes away from the experiences.

Stressful. 've been to markets in Egypt, Turkey, Thailand etc and this labyrinth although large and pretty cool, is a bit frustrating. A lot of the stuff they sell is obviously stuff you don't really need but would be cool to have. I work as a buyer so I know how to negotiate but it's such hard work sometimes when they start so ridiculously high. No one wants to pay an arm and a leg for tut. You go to a market to get the best bargains. Stick to the right as motorcycles and mules whizz through the labyrinths unapologetically. Do not ask or accept any directions from locals. They will either lie to get you to see a friend or families stall or they want lots of money. Nearly had a fight with some local who said made inappropriate comments about my body. As a woman, you will get oggled big time. Holding hands with my husband made no difference. You have to be strong or be prepared to spend your hard working holiday money as virtually nothing is free in Marrakesh.

Magical but you must haggle. Fortunately we were accompanied by a guide to the souk or we would have been so lost in the labyrinth of streets inside. Use an offline map app to avoid the roaming charges or take a guide with you, the hotel concierge should be able to help you hire a licensed one.If you intend to buy anything, make sure you haggle. We experienced retailers who eventually relented to a quarter of the offer price! That said, there are some beautiful pieces for the shopaholics out there. Otherwise, enjoy the hustle and bustle of the market and take in the sights and smells. The colours are beautiful!

Love the Culture.. Loved the culture, It's very third-world country but overall very beautiful country to visit and you will experience the culture in many way's. Please remember to haggle a good price and don't be afraid to say no! Overall Nice people.

The best salesmen in the world? Possibly!. As soon as you step into the souks of Marrakech expect the hard sell from every direction. Wow, i've never seen so many people vie for my money in my life. "Take a look, take a look! Good price, we make you good price, not tourist price!" with a very vibrant and large grin across my Moroccan friends faces. Then you are in the shop and things get a little interesting. They set the prices so high that you almost feel you are being made to be a bit of a mug. They barter so well and play on your good nature once you are in the shop and the feeling of wanting to buy becomes actually quite high with how they deal with their great humour and friendly approach. My first reaction was that it was overwhelming and being polite comes across as reason to keep talking to you so I soon had to learn how to just turn away and stop talking.After an hour of walking around you get used to the nature of the place and it does become a festival of colour, sites and sounds. At one point we got speaking to a random local who was walking the same path as us and led us to a few different shops ( that were obviously friends) in order to help us make a purchase for a lamp. He was a nice enough guy and it was actually an experience to have him lead us deep into the souks without knowing where we were or where we were going. I definitely spent more than I wanted to here and by the end of the experience I was feeling quite ticked off about being asked 'to take a look' and 'what you looking for', it became irritating and I just wanted to get out of there.Again, its a place you have to visit whilst in Marrakech but have a bit of a guard up , don't be too polite and know what you are going for before you go in and you should have a really enjoyable time.Good experience but the hard sell can get too over bearing

Street Sellers Sell Fakes. Despite the enjoyable street atmosphere, beware of the high pressure street salesmen. The (£500 retail) Samsung S5 that I was pressured into buying (after over 45 minutes of him returning to café where I was eating to pester me). I eventually paid 800 Dir (£65) for it. It appeared to work fine but was a Chinese FAKE.The Addidas stuff I bought was all FAKE.Watch what you really want to buy. Don't give into the pressure.

Just wonderful. I loved everything about the souks, from the "patter" of the merchants to the actual merchandise itself. If I had been on a longer holiday, with a larger suitcase, I would have bought a lot more stuff.

Sit at the Cafe de Paris with a coffee and drink in the sights, sounds and smells. The main souk is on two sides of the Jemaa el Fna but as the day progresses, more and more stalls and attractions fill the square itself, becoming the bustling, vibrant heart of the city.The souk itself is a maze of streets that twist and turn, leaving many people disorientated. Take you mobile phone and Google maps (or a ball of string !!). The market is divided into specific areas - food, clothing, souvenirs etc. If you want to buy something, make sure you barter, and barter hard or you will pay more than you want.
