There are many tips online about bartering but the most important are "Don't be afraid to walk away" and "be respectful".I spent a couple of very pleasant afternoons just snacking and watching the world go by - I learn a lot about other cultures this way. If your are from 'the west', be prepared for something different and don't be afraid to jump in with both feet.Enjoy

Bustling market place but be on full alert for pickpockets and scams. Do not be scared to venture into the markets aka souks. Just make a note of the route you took or stalls you have passed so you don't get lost.Be confident and do not be afraid to tell the local sellers to go away so that you are not hassled unnecessarily. Haggling and bargaining on items is essential and the stalls will usually give you a good deal, even better deals if you are persistent.Go both during the day and at night. The experiences are completely different.

A must to see !. The market place of Marrakesh is definitely worth a visit. We didn't intend to buy anything, just to wander and see it all. It is a labyrinth. On our 1st visit we wandered so far in that we got lost and ended up being "guided" back to the main square. Locals who offer this expect to be paid and are often standing around waiting for tourists who look lost or they hear a key word in a conversation and immediately step in to offer to show the tourist where this place is. There are stalls selling beautiful craft work and others selling household items or fake football shirts, track suits, etc. Different parts of the market sell things of different quality. Bargaining is expected. We found the type of flooring a good clue. The fresh orange juice on sale is good as are the nuts and dates sold in the main square. All over the souks there are cafes where it's very enjoyable to sit and watch.

Amazing. An amazing labyrinth, if you want to buy something just make sure that you argue the price. They will try to sell things for ridiculous price but you just need to argue and you buy a lot of things for a small price.

Markets of Marrakech. The bustling sights, sounds & smells of the Souk (market-place) of Marrakech will definitely send you on an almost euphoric trip as your eyes, ears and tongue enthusiastically responds to this overwhelming offering. The locals welcome a bit of haggling so do not be shy to be politely hardcore, you will end up earning their respect. There are items that will cater for almost any and every taste, from handwoven fabrics & hand-stitched shoes to ornaments, trinkets & perfumes. The food section of the markets offer fresh fruit & veg as well as hand-made sweets and desserts that are dangerously addictive.About 2hrs is sufficient, however, one could easily spend an entire day here.

Good price sir, good price, to look is free!. If you're in Marrakech you have to see the souk. It doesn't matter if you're looking for something specific or you just want to see how this place looks like. Be assured that someone will approach you and say that in tihs particular stall prices are very good for you. These guys speak in 10 different languages and they will insist that you have to see this or that. Bargain very hard. Bargaining is part of the culture, so don't feel uncomfortable. Remember that price for tourists is at least 3 times higher, so bargain extremely hard or walk away and find the same item in different stall and negotiate the price once again. If you start negotiations, but you decide to walk away - say very nicely thank you and start walking, shopkeeper will call after you and will give you better price. Don't accept it though. Keep asking for better price or walk away. These guys might try to "intimidate" you, but it's a mean business, so be persistent. It's worth to have gps and maps in your smartphone as it's easy to get lost. Get simcard from inwi network (120dh for sim/micro sim card with 3gb limit) and you will find your way out very easily. If you don't have map then ask other tourists where to go. If you ask locals then you'll have to pay them. This place is very unique.

The location for the souk scenes in SNTC II. Some beautiful things and some cheapies - distinguish as it is over priced. The best shops are those whose owners don't harass you into buying and show you their range knowing you can come back or walk away for good. The rude ones are to be blanked fast.

A favourite souk in the Middle East. I loved this souk. After being to the Allepo and Damascus souk, Khan el-Khalili in Cairo and Grand Bazaar and Spice Bazaar in Istanbul..this one is a favourite. So much variety on offer and a great buzz which does retain some tradition flare. I found I could get items for 75% off the initial asking price...if you bargained hard.

Souks for sake!. this is not be missed, brave it and take a stroll. "everyone gets lost"as they say. there are so many stalls and so much to experience. The silver jewelry is lovely (be sure to look for the stamp that assures it is sterling), and the spices and tea are not to be missed.

Rue Mouassine preferred over rue Semarine. It is madness, but you will remember and cherish the memories. However, there is a difference btw rue Mouasssine and rue Semarine, the latter having more rubbish on display.

Totally bewildering. Gerat shops, loads of choice but..................so so easy to get lost, and I had forgotten how I hate the fact that you cannot stop to look without being pounced on to buy. Puits one right off......

Venture deep. I thoroughly enjoyed my second visit to the souks in marrakech. The locals were very friendly & willing to have a laugh with their customers. Do not be afraid to say no strongly, they won't mind!Venture further into the souks to get the best prices, the sellers at the front of the souks will always ask for more, as they are the most easily accessible, but if you go further in you can find similar items for a cheaper price
Can be alarming. Heard alarming stories of being misled and women mildly abused. And not much worth buying. Advised not to accept offers of help and keep valuables safe.

OMG this is great. We loved it here. You could go on for miles I think. We haggled and got some bargains and there are some fantastic smells and sights. All the herbs and spices, perfumes and produce. We saw snake charmers, musicians and someone selling teeth!! Plenty of cats about and the food for sale was good. We had skewers and tagine. Plenty of cats but I expect that there would be a lot of rats and mice if the cats weren't there. Only saw one dog.

Haggling is hard. But if you like a challenge go for it. Be selective. There is lots of crap- and they know it. Try to get off the main pathways and ask prices from different vendors. They all have the same thing - so if the first 3 give prices walk down to the 4th or 5th and try your hand at haggling. Then, (or if you hate to haggle) go of the souks to the Artisnal market. This is up the street a few blocks straight past the tall minaret at the square (past the white building in front of the tower) and past several restaurants. On the right hand side. This is all the same stuff in the souks -cheaper - fixed peice co-operative. So they are not always trying to flece you. While it is fixed price - if you are getting multiple items here - always ask for a discount. They will likely give one.

Loved it!. The senses are assaulted by the sights, sounds and smells of this amazing place. Lots of traditional crafts (pungent tannery) and modern tacky stuff. Difficult not to be ripped off but I see it as a bit of charity. Tagines excellent value.

Looking for the square?. We headed into the souks from the square confident in our Marrakech map. Whoops! It did not take long to get hopelessly lost in the labyrinth of market stalls and vendors. New to Marrakech we fell for the whole free trip to the tanneries tour but refused to give any money, much to the anger of our originally friendly guide. It was a great experience though and the people are friendly. The style of business is different but once you realize that slightly raised voices and hard bargaining is part of the culture it can be a lot of fun trying to get good prices on items. A quick search on the internet to find what others are paying doesn't go amiss, particularly if you are looking to something specific.

A USEFUL ARABIC PHRASE. I have been visiting the souks of Marrakech for 30 years. It took me a long time to find my way around with confidence, but now I can get to where I want to reach and back out without assistance - but I still make the occasional wrong term. If visiting for the first time, go with a guide. When visiting on your own, the mornings are best, while after 4pm it is a seething mass of humanity. Goodness you have to haggle like mad when you make a purchase. Trust no one! This month I wanted to visit a guy in the artisan's quarter for leather workers. I had not seen Hassan for 7 years and I wanted him to make a suede waistcoat like the one I had bought in the mid-90s for a friend of mine. I more or less walked to his kiosk with a couple of minor wrong turns. On the way back I stopped to take a picture to remind me of the turn. It happened to be outside a Berber herbalists. 'Come in he urged'. I obliged, but said it was only to look. The conversation got round to perfume oils. 'We have something really special', the guy said, instructing an assistant to fetch something. 'This is Morocco's finest', he said handing over a 5ml file of pure perfume oil. 'It is only 65 Dhs (then about £4.75).', he stated. OK, I asked, 'But since when has Jeddah been in Morocco?' We agreed that Saudi had some fantastic perfume oils. I said it was too expensive. He protested that it was fantastic, what Moroccans used themselves etc. I said I would show him something. I opened my bag and produced 10 boxed files of the same brand, but a different perfume. 'Can you explained how I have managed to purchase these at 6.5 Dhs each?', I asked. Needless to say, I went back to my original supplier the following week and purchased 12 of his favoured perfume at 84 dhs (it had gone up to 7 dhs each!). My advice 1. Never buy as a new arrival - wait until you have a tan and have become familiar with the pricing structure 2. when you see something you want to buy, work out what you would be prepared to pay for it in £ and convert that amount into dirhams 3. if this is then less than the asking price from the vendor, offer half of the price you would be prepared to pay and take it from there 4. if it is more, then simply walk away, smile and say 'anna ma skeen' - which means, 'I am broke' in Arabic. 5. When they come chasing after you, offer half of the amount you would be prepared to pay and take it from there. Have fun, it is a great place!!

you will be amazed. Get lost haggle with the sellers,A lot of crap for sell but its all part of the experience.Stay alert as you are seen as walking cash cow,and they will try anything to get you to part with your money.A little common sence goes a long way.Enjoy you will never forget this place.
Fascinating. Absolute must when visiting to the Medina area of Marrakech. A guide is not essential with a reasonable sense of direction. Quite safe but useful to learn the Arabic for 'no thank you;.

Varied prices. Loved walking around the souk and found all the shopkeepers pleasant, with no major harassment. I have been many places before where you are far more pressured than here where we were able to browse. Need to be careful of prices, we bought some lovely Moroccan lamps for €4 each, but some things quite expensive.

Colour and atmosphere valour! One of main attractions in the medina. Wandering through the souks (getting lost too) is one of the main pastimes whilst visiting the medina of Marrakech. The shop owners are well natured - expect to pay about 30% max of their initial price, if not less. Everything from leather goods, to scarves, bags, jewellery, knives, metal work etc. Best to take an empty suitcase! :-). It helps if you know what similar objects are sold for at home if you are interested in something in particular. If you go to the north end of the souks you will find artisans making goods and sometimes you can buy from them directly i.e. I bought a beautiful morroccan carving direct from the carver for an absolute song.

Very interesting. If you like a bargain and like to barter you will love the souks
Did not like all the fake crap they try to sell you

Test the senses. Overhelming in both good and bad. There's an explosion of colourful artefacts with their sellers at the ready to invite you into their shop for a look. They're very clever, speaking multiple languages and familiar with slang conversations. It's 'peak-hour' just about very hour through most of the alley-ways as bikes and scooters zoom past you. I enjoyed taking my time wandering along, admiring everything... And just smiled and said "thanks" / "merci" when invited but just kept walking along. I did go into a few shops but only when I was serious about buying and negotiating. Overall, I loved the souks and having so much to choose from, the only problem was getting lost sometimes...

A must if you visit Marrakech.... ....it is intense and unique but be prepared that you are experienced as a walking wallet and will be treated as such. As much as this may be the case, being chased for it may not be on your vacation wish list. Just be prepared and enjoy!

Not to be missed. The Souks are an amazing warren of tiny alley ways and roads with stalls selling everything you could possibly want!!!! The stall holders are generally not too pushy but if you linger too long they will pounce on you and try to get you inside. If you wander too far into the souks you may get disorientated and lost so either stay near the outer stalls or buy a very good map as roads are unmarked. If you need help try to ask other tourists rather than locals as they might send you in the wrong direction if you are stuck the police were quite helpful. Be aware of the numerous scooters and mopeds which race up and down the road ways without a care for pedestrians. Well worth a visit though.

Good deals, if you can bargain. We are Americans, but we love to bargain (we learned in India). If you can't bargain, this souk is not for you. Keep smiling, no matter what the vendor says or does, and you'll end up with just what you want at your price!

Haggle.. Join in the game of haggling its expected and fun the shop keepers love it. If you don't want anything just be polite if something catches your eye then the price is always up for negotiation. You are never lost in the Souk just not 100% sure where you are.

What a place to get lost in!. We had a personal guide on our first morning in Marrakech - not absolutely necessary, but he took us to areas we might have otherwise missed and gave us masses of useful/interesting information. Wood carvers, metal and leather workers, carpet merchants, a bakery, creperie, and pastry/sweet stalls, a hammam stoker, the wool and silk dyers, spice merchants, argan oil specialists, chickens, ducks, tortoise, iguana and chameleon sellers - the sounds, sights and aromas are amazing. Yes, it is crowded, yes you do get hassled, but we soon learned that a big smile and a firm "non merci" worked wonders! Haggling was light-hearted and good fun - we bought several pairs of gorgeous babouche slippers for a very good price - and a glass of "Berber whisky" (mint tea) thrown in to the bargain! The metal lanterns and carpets were to die for, but not so easy to transport via Easy Jet! Our guide told us that there is very little tourist-related crime in Marrakech and that there are plain clothes "tourist" police patrolling the Souks and Square - we felt totally at ease, even when slightly lost - everyone is incredibly friendly and helpful (perhaps a small monetary tip might be useful). Oh and wear comfortable shoes - there's a lot of walking!

get lost!. just stroll through, you will get lost. but somehow one finds the exit. besides their are a lot of inhabitants who tell you the way to "la place" ... and you can use gps from your mobile to get an idea, where you are, a map won't help. there are many different suqs, all of them are colourful and the things offered are worth some bargaining. if you see an open door, enter! you will find working people in their small stalls and be able to see how things are done

Freaking out Galore!. It indeed is very interesting for anyone coming from the Western world, for a traveler from India, it was certainly not a first for me. Despite that, I still enjoyed myself thoroughly and freaked out shopping for everyone back home. I love the concept of small shops and big markets!Even if you don't wish to buy anything, you get to see immense creativity everyone around you!! A must go for the feel of it!! If you have a lot of time and patience to figure out the place on your own, then venture out. But if you'd had to get lost and don't want to go round and round in circles, then go around with someone who knows it well.
Shopping galore!. You can buy anything here. No pushy vendors as in other places, this is a joy to visit. Food, wood carvings, clothing, silver, pottery... You can probably find it here.

Hagglers Paradise!. Visiting the souks are a must in Marrakech...why else would you go? If you are a fan of haggling, then you'll enjoy the fun and deals to be had. The souks offer a variety of leather goods, spices, pottery, jewellery, metal work and loads of other weird and potentially wonderful things. When you find something you are interested in and want to know the price, the shop keeper will demand an unrealistic and verging on insulting price. Now this is where the haggling begins, my rule of thumb is that you generally want to pay 25% of that price give or take. A good example are Barbouches (the little leather shoes) which are worth between approx 70 Dh (£5) and 100 Dh (£7) a pair, depending on quality, not the 300+ Dh they will initially ask for. They will also try and tell you they are the best shoes ever made and also likely compare them against some cheap 'plastic' looking shoes. Don't be fooled!During the haggling, aim to look slightly offended when hearing the initial price. Also give out signs that these shoes are way to expensive, even tell them so. They will then ask you for your best price. This is where you have to be strong...hum and har for a good 20 seconds and then tell them 60 Dh. It is their turn to look offended now, although actually we are near to the right price. They will probably tell you that you're 'crazy', but again don't be fooled. They usually come back quickly with another price, but this will also be extremely expensive. Again refuse. This is when you start heading for the door, handing back the shoes and shaking your head. During this walk to the door you are likely to continue haggling, incrementing your bid by 5 Dh or thereabouts but staying in the 70 to 100 Dh bracket. Haggling even continues 10 steps up the street in some instances. Deal done! If this fails, no problem, the exact same shoes will likely be sold in another 50 shops within a 5 min walk. So plenty of chances to hone your skills! ;)Some other tips:- only buy Argan oil from the chemists, the oil sold in souks are generally of a poor quality (i.e. topped up with olive oil).- watch out for poor quality leather products, which generally smell bad as they have been softened with camel urine and pigeon poo.- if you don't want a henna tattoo, make sure you give the henna ladies a wide berth as they will try to physically snatch your hand to give you a so-called 'gift'.

Intersting - so much to see. Great to do the Souk but a little intimidating for me. You daren't give much more of a glance at anything otherwise you get swooped upon. However this is my European wimpery - just don't get too sucked into it. I did enjoy it but ended up buying from one of the set priced shops (your guide book will suggest one or two), out of the souk area where allegedly you don't pay much more than the souks and don't get hassled; certainly I was happy with the set priced shops and happy with my purchases.

A 'must' visit but be warned. This is an amazing maze of tiny streets, most of them unmarked, so make sure you have a good map. Spoilt by the numerous times we were deliberately pointed in the wrong direction, the lies we were told about the places we wanted to visit being closed, and the intimidation of some sellers - which unfortunately made you suspicious of everyone there.

Extreme shopping experience. Mae sure you have plenty of energy and verve for the souks. Work out what you are willing to pay for something ahead of haggling for it. Only offer half or a third of their asking price and be willing to walk away. We worked hard to buy stuff at even just a reasonable price ( ie around the same price that we might pay in a market in the uk) and were very surprised to find a lot of the same things on sale in the airport on our way out, at much lower, fixed prices! Great fun though just browsing and soaking up the atmosphere.

Take the guide!. When we got off the hotel shuttle bus we were met by a 'tourist office' guide. Although initially suspicious it turned out to be 100 Dirhams (less than £10) well spent. He walked us around the souk and told us lots of interesting facts. We didn't go into the shops he wanted as we told him no shopping to start with. We did give him 200 Dirhams in the end as we went down alleys we would not have dared on our own and saw so much more

Fascinating and confusing. Eveything it is hyped to be! Highly recommend going here with a guide first to understand the social etiquette of buying etc. Once we did this we grew in confidence and had a fab time buying fragrance, oil, pashminis etc for Christmas. We were delighted on our last day to be invtied for tea with mint with a herbaliste. To find your way, we spiralled around until we used the "touristeye" app with google maps.

Hmmmmm. I enjoy shopping and haggling at the best of times and we have done it all over the world (always worth getting a good feel for the customs before you start - here you are advised to half the starting price and the haggle up) but this I found hard work - quite apart from the endless offers to sell you anything (literally!) and hooks to attract you, the noise and crowds, found our attempts to buy things a little testing since the starting prices were always ridiculous so haggling to a realistic figure was going to be difficult; had to walk away many times as the process simply stalled with no resolution possible. They didn't like you walking away. Doing this with a guide in tow proved much more fruitful but the feeling that you're fair game isn't a pleasant one as a constant. An oddly unsatisfying experience without a guide.

O wonderfull '' you will smell 'it long before you see it 'burst with flovours 'incenes ''. well am a market ''mucher 'but the Souk was beond my wildess dreams '' it was like wonder land to me ''it was midday when we got there ''an 10.30 when we left ''and there was no sign of any one goin home ''people were pile.in on when we was leavein ''' but this is a massive place ''theres lots of ally ways ''leading all over the place ''full of stalls ''you could get lost easy ''so stay more in the center ''plenty there ''cafes you can sit out side '' I have to say again ''the smells flowing in the humid air ''were setting my tast buds on fire ''and the smell of jasmin ''The taxi from were we stayed '£3 for the distance ''this was a dream ''my bag was full ''of herbs 'and jasmin ''ave loads picture ''will put them up '''The Best Market Ever been to ''in its self ''its a hoilday ''so much to see ''its like ever thing in life ''every one will experience ; something different ''

Fab. Have been to all the souks and did not get lost. So much to see and do. Great experience, Do not be afraid of the locals they are very respectful and do not bother you. Great products and just remember, pay the price that you would be happy with. Just keep your wits about you and enjoy.

A pleasant day spent haggling and smiling!. Worth a trip to Jamaa El Fna square and the surrounding souks. We were not hassled as much as I have been in other souks in other countries and as is natural, if you show manners, you get smiles. Everybody understands Thank-you. French speakers will fare better, but do not be afraid to haggle and don't expect to pick up anything worth more than a few pounds - unless you want to buy a carpet!

First Souk ever. So wonderfully chaotic-- full of sights and sounds and smells that were completely foreign to me. Traffic was fast and furious, and on occasion almost got run over by careening trucks. Was here a few years ago and have just gotten around to reviewing this trip. I am not a shopper so I don't know how it compares to values in other Souks, but the ambience was intriguing.
Much and crowded . It's perhaps to big because you can get lost very easy but you have a lot of souks and you should bargain.

Not the best one. It's been my 3 Arab country so I guess I'm already somehow familiar with those souks.. The general atmosphere was nice but it's definitely away from what I call "a great souk". If you've been to Egypt or OAE then you know what I'm talking about.The souk itself is a giant puzzle of little (sometimes dead-end streets) full of everything - from fruits and vegetables to cloths, shoes, souvenirs and digital gadgets. Like every Arab country here you have to bargain hard for a discount. Normally if you offer 1/3 of the initial price and the seller agrees to give it to you - you're screwed. That means that even on this price the seller has already fooled you and received a lot more that it actually costs. But the feeling to bargain itself is great :)One more thing you have to be very careful about is not to get robbed. There are a lot of people just wondering around and trying to talk to everybody. Keep in mind that those people are actually trying to distract you and steal your phone, money or other valuables. Always keep your pockets safe.

A must-see, but be careful. The souks sell everything you can imagine, and you will want to buy it all! I will definitely visit Marrakech again and will re-visit the souks. Beware of the men who hang around and try to "show you the way". Ignore them! some are harmless, and you can throw them a few dirham if you genuinely need help. However, there was one man in particular who seemed to be the messenger-type for the leather bag souk area. When we decided not to buy the over-priced leather bags, he was extremely verbally abusive, like nothing I have ever experienced. I was quite frightened, as he continued to see us a few times afterwards, giving us "the finger", and shouting "f#%k you" as he went by. Many of the souk-salesmen have this attitude of entitlement from the tourists. I do not agree with this, as nobody should feel bullied and ganged up on, to buy anything, or to do anything. I dread to think if I was a lone female traveller here, you really need to keep your wits about you, especially in the evening time. (This abusive man was tall, wearing sunglasses and a baseball cap, dark skinned, ignore this horrible man.)
An experience..... Loved mooching around taking in all the hustle and bustle - looking at all the things for sale (including baby tortoises - oh dear!!)

Beautiful aladdins cave like stalls. Visiting the souks has always been on one of my dream things to do lists and it certainly didn't disappoint. The stalls were vibrant in colours and personality, the prettiest ones being the stalls selling the lanterns, clothes and handbags. The only thing that ruined it a little bit for me was the weather as it was torrential rain and we got absolutely soaked. But then that made coming back to the hotel to have a hot shower and good meal even more enjoyable. Will definitely visit again.

Deals to haggle for. Haggle galore all day. Sticking to your guts to go 90% below asking price with a hard face on.We refuse to be mugged with "I am not making any profit" response. We were called tight fisted because because we matched them with the prices.
Souk. Barter barter barter, the ambience was fantastic, loved it and would definitely go back, again and again. But you can get harassed but always friendly.

Like nowhere else. The first time I visited Jemaa el Fna was also my first experience of an Arabic country. Arriving in the hot afternoon sun, laden with suitcases, pale skin and the look of someone not having a clue where they were going, I soon found myself on the outskirts of the walled market area having taken the short bus journey from the airport. There were no shortage of young children (watched from a distance by their parents) who were very eager to guide me to the Riad I had booked and of course relieve me of some of my money. Having found the Riad, I paid my very helpful guide who went on his merry way, not before trying to squeeze me for a bit more cash. Best thing is to be direct, with a smile and laugh it off. The sounds, smells and colours are like nothing else I had encountered and for the more claustrophobic of you I would not recommend it. If you enjoy everything moving at 100 mph, bikes and people from every angle then you will enjoy every minute. There are street vendors offering every type of food you can imagine, drinks, fruits and I was happy to try most things. The place is quite an attack on the senses. Along the quieter alleyways and away from the main tourist areas you can feel quite isolated as the night goes on, every person you see will try and direct you to the well known tourist restaurants, with roof top gardens. I did indulge for one night to such a place and found it most enjoyable with wonderful food, although I usually try and avoid these places. What I didn't know, is that late in the evening, gone midnight, they begin to close off some of the gates within the walled city itself. So I found myself, having left a random bar and talking with a most welcoming Moroccan family, walking around at about 2am totally unable to find my way out! Every alley I turned down was a dead end with the huge wooden gates locked from within. Each time I found a new path it was blocked, often finding groups of men chopping meat on large heavy wooden blocks, with meat cleavers. Merely people preparing food for the next day. Eventually I gave in and paid for a road sweeper to show me the way out. Now the actual market is full of snake charmers, monkey handlers, various showman, fire eaters, acrobats, something for everyone. If you do stand about watching, as in every big city, be mindful of pickpockets. Otherwise it is a very safe enjoyable environment. If shopping, never pay full price for anything, taxis, clothes, shoes, you will notice that there are no price tags in any of the shops or stalls, the price goes up depending on how wealthy you look. If you don't want to bargain, don't bother buying anything. The atmosphere here is quite amazing, I often stand back and watch what is going on and have often found a rooftop to see the whole of the square to watch the comings and goings. I've been back many times and can understand why some people don't like it and why others fall in love with it. I'd advise only coming to Marrakech for 3 to 4 days and go on elsewhere. It is a unique place to visit but if you want the history and a more authentic experience then go to Fez in the north of the country. Think if London was your only experience of England, the differences are the same. The nightclubs I found to be friendly places and a lot of fun, drinks were in keeping with mainland Spain and other major cities. Generally, people are friendly, helpful and happy to chat to you. Respect the culture, read up on the laws and you'll have a great time. Read "voices of Marrakech" by Elias Canetti before going.

Brilliant but.... The souk when I went to marrakech during the summer was lovely. Even though everything wasn't original the atmosphere was brilliant. Only thing is to be careful not to get mugged and watch who you are talking to. This wasn't great concern as when anyone goes abroad you should be keeping this in mind. 4/5 amazing

Ok if you don't weaken.. There are some wonderful stalls selling beautiful moroccan goods, but there are also quiet a few stalls selling tacky, cheap stuff - sports sox and onsies! There were also disreputable dealers in baby tortoises and lizards. Not as oppressive as I expected but difficult to feel it's charm. Not really for me.

great back streets for the architecture but tat everywhere. I love the streets but would like to be able to walk and look without irritating locals trying to screw you over. All in all a good experience but it could be so much better.

Amazing place. Don't be intimidated: explore the place with enthusiasm. This was the an amazing and fun experience. We felt safe. BARGIN FOR EVERYTHING because nobody will offer you a deal.
Incredible.
Don't miss this place!!!
Beware the vendors are "hard sell", just take it in stride.
loved haggling but. we had a gret time in the souks but you have to know what you aredoing to make sure u are not taken for a ride

Get in there have fun Get a good map, FAB!. What a maze of treasures, people, food, and trying not to get run over by bikes mopeds and donkeys. Our maps were invaluable and we got around very well. Only got lost once. Bought a jacket at a reasonable price after a good haggle, shop keepers very happy and pleasing, no badness about them. Sat and people watched at a cafe on a corner, donkey's getting pulled this way and that, people going everywhere. Lots of tourists, felt comfortable walking around.

Go, but read a book on purchasing before you do.. Leather, lamps, tagines, jbalas, it has it all. And if you are not prepared, in mind, body and spirit to deal with the shop owners, be prepared to be exhausted. Having said that, the owners here are not as aggressive and scary as those in Cairo, but they are still very assertive about selling their goods. It is very easy to be ripped off.

Incredible experience. Excellent time walking, smelling, touching, bartering. The people are great and the goods are fantastic and well priced if you join in the fun of bartering. It's a great experience that you should all benefit from whilst in Marrakech.

This is an amazing place to visit, you have to haggle with the Moroccan's,. This is an amazing place to visit the sights , the colours the people they love to haggle with you. You end up buying something you really didn't want

Hustle bustle hassle and haggle. Haggling is great fun, but telling people to go away and stop touching your girlfriend is not so funny. Crazy people riding mopeds down alleys make for some excitement. If you hear the word free, it will be a lie 100% of the time. Be ready for scammers who will try to get you to follow them to their friends places and charge you for the "guide" service. Prices are superinflated so knock them down or keep walking. It can be unsettling if you dont like crowds. if you are not assertive, you might not have a great time. Shopping is not easy when there is someone in your ear all the time, but as experiences go, getting something for the price YOu want to pay, its very satisfying indeed. Dont forget, here nothing is free, advice, toilets, nothing at all.

If Yo visit one souk in one country, You have seen them all... but still worth of visiting. Nice to walk around and enjoy the atmosphere. You can see how the men make the shoes, bags, lamps - whatever You can imagine.
Marrakech Market. Good real bargains available at this market place. It was a very special experience walking through the souk

Good local fun. The Souks are a sensory overload.You will get lost - often that's the best bit. So colourful, vibrant, awesome people watching - kind of a feeling of escapism.The people are mostly friendly, humorous and astute salespeople. Note - whilst u don't want buy the first thing you see as a lot of items are available everywhere & you must haggle a few times to get a price guide. If you really like something unusual be sure you can find your way back if decide to walk away and call their bluff... I am still lamenting ...Make sure u buy awesome snacks - nougat, dried fruits, nuts, breads, olives, fresh fruit and whatever else takes your fancy.There's some cool cultural attractions dotted around so stop in to some of these when you do locate as hard to find again.Don't get stressed have fun with it - drink a mint tea or two with the shopkeepers, have a chat and you will start to feel like a local.
Fantastic!. What a way to get lost! Such fun - just seeing and smelling, talking to locals and just to love it all.

High Pressure Selling..... If the Souk operators backed off a bit, they would get more sales. I disliked them trying to force you into their shops and when I did make a purchase of a Tagine at one stall, the guy tried to up the price when we had already agreed on the price. He then started shouting I had 'memory problems' - I wasn't going to back down and asked for my money back. His colleague told him to back off and my purchase was successful, but not sure it was worth the hassle. We got lost one night in the Souk - its a complete maze - and it had a different atmosphere - wouldn't recommend it after 7pm. You are in danger of constantly being run over by mopeds - they don't slow down and you have to dive out of their way. Men don't seem to have a lot of respect for women - constantly stare at your chest. Would have been uncomfortable visiting with another woman.

Souk Bargaining. You will probably get lost in the vibrant winding corridors of the souks but don't worry you will find a way out. its colourful and some bargains are to be had in leather etc. Don't forget to haggle you should never pay more than half of the sellers first price. Try some of the petit fours on sale. visiting the souk is a must and is also safe.

no pressure to buy. I have been to many places where you expect to haggle in souks and markets and Marrakech was not exception. Make sure you DO NOT BUY THE FIRST THING YOU SEE. You will see the same items again and again. You must negotiate/ I found I got leather goods for about one third of the asking price or less. Remember that the people are trying to make a living. a great place to shop and a lovely, friendly atmosphere. Easy to get lost so have a few landmarks in mind.

Go also to the not so touristic souk. the tourist souk is very busy,but once you get behind it its a real treat to see all the hand workers and nice areas. Get a good guide that shows you these sides of the town and you will be surprised.
Crazy. You need to be prepared to be harassed. It can be a lot of fun but venture in with the right frame of mind. The older, more local Souks are more authentic. seeing how the locals buy.

"Worth the visit". Souk KessabineYou enter the market (souk) using the entrance on the right of the square (exit on the left) - sign says Souk El Kessabine. There you find hundreds of shops selling carpets, handbags & scarves are among the few. The best place I recommend to buy Pashmina scarves is Abdel Alillah, No 11 La Rue Rahaba Kidima. When you enter through the Souk El Kessabine entrance, take the 1st left. Go inside further down, next right, at the end turn left and it is the 3rd shop. It is a big shop with scarves on display and leather goods inside. There you would find a huge selection of scarves. When you buy 3 or more, the salesman will give you a discount. Nice salesman, tall slim guy, can speak good English. You shouldn’t pay no more than 70 dirham per pashmina if you are buying more than one.
good day out. Bargains Galore. Take a shopping day out there, so many cheap stuff to bring back home. Nice leather jackets. make sure you bargain hard.

Easy to get lost. Hotel had free shuttle bus which dropped and collected from same spot. We got horribly lost and could not find our way back. It was a stressful experience. Ended up,getting taxi after being guided by many around and around. Even so excellent shopping, but bargain hard, don't be conned into using a guide and keep an eye where you are. Excellent on second trip. Very exciting.

Get ready for long walk. Very good variety, but you must must negotiate about prices and see the same product in different stores before you get it (even if you like it). Better to ask for a recommendation from a local trusted person first.
MAYHEM BUT FUN. Great fun running the gauntlet and trying to avoid getting asked in every shop. Bartering is a must - good bargains to be had.

So much fun, but invest in private guide.... With a private guide you will see so much more than you could ever find on your own. Souks will generally do a lovely presentation for you with little to no pressure when a guide is with you. You will also be sure to see the best of what there is to offer in any category. Beware to book these guides through your hotel or agency...so called private guides at the Medina are not true licensed guides and will lead you where they want and take advantage. The Medina is a very complicated complex of buildings and you may never get all the way in or find your way out without a guide. It is VERY inexpensive and worth every penny!!!
A colourful Delight. There is so much to see here, make sure you bargain hard, dont be afraid to say no and try not to lose your way!
fun. must go and see, the sounds colours and smells of Africa, just great. Dont be intimidates its all in the name of fun.

An experience... but not pleasant!. The souks are a labyrinth of shop lined alleyways. It feels confining, it's dirty, smelly from the exhaust of the motorbikes zooming around, and many vendors who try to tempt you with a variety of tactics to purchase from their shops. If you slow to look at anything, you are immediately pounced on and given the 'hard sell'. Many vendors claim that they have hand made Berber items and unique antiques, real silver, etc. Marrakech was our last stop of travelling for 2 weeks around Morocco and we saw those 'unique' Berber items at practically every tourist stop during our travels in Morocco. Unless you really know your antiques and silver - beware - it's just mass produced junk.We were one of the unfortunate tourists that got lost in the souks and when we slowed to try to get our bearings, we were approached by a young man. He told us the way out was just a few minutes away and pointed us in the 'right' direction. When we started to go that way, he went out in front and keep telling us to go this way. We knew that he would ask for money but and pulled 10 dirham discreetly out of our wallets to hand over and be less likely subjected to demands of more money. He did show us a way out but what was surprising was that when I gave him the money, he claimed he didn't want it. Just at that time another man approached, told the money from the younger man and began to berate us, saying that 'This is not money for a man! It is money you would give a boy'! We just kept walking away and not engaging, but he kept following closely and yelling. Finally, he gave up with the final words of 'Get out of Marrakech, and never come back'! Ummm... okay... I have no objection to never going back there.

A fantastic Moroccan experience........ The Souks of Marrakesh Medina remain largely unchanged for hundreds of years (the Medina is a protected UNESCO World Heritage Centre). The sights and sounds (as well as the bustling crowds) make the Souks daunting for some, but relax and enjoy. The locals are very friendly and there is little to fear (other than the small risk of pick pockets and the many mopeds that share the narrow passage ways). The Souks are divided by crafts/goods. Stick to the leatherware, fabric, and metalwork sections and steer away from livestock/food preparation areas would be my best advise ! Don't forget to haggle - you should look to pay no more than one third of the original asking price. A must do experience in Marrakech (most hotels offer guided excursions if the don't feel brave enough to visit independently).

Just for tourists. You should see it, but if you have ever seen something simmilar in another african cities, don't loose too much time . Sure there are ceramics and nice carpets, fresh and dried fruits , nuts but also snakes , apes and some china products just for tourists . Worth to try the local kitchen and drinks.

Nice to walk around in the evening.. It is a good outing for a evening walk but please make sure if you are buying things there is more than 50% bargain or more, every shop have their own rates so they will look at where you coming from. People worry about having a guide which is not necessary you enjoy by being alone. The trend that guide or even a taxi driver takes you to the places to buy where they get commission, which is common i guess any country.Anyway please visit in the evening after 4 so the shops are ready, during the day there wont be the local market and it opens everyday like some suggest Friday they don't open which is not correct. we did our shopping on Friday afternoon.
So much to buy. Haggle and then walk away, the next stall will probably be cheaper! So much to buy and see. You will get lost and confused, but just go with it!

wandering around. the best way to explore is just to wander around, there is always somebody who shows you the way back to the place jemaa el fna! Observing, smelling, talking, smiling, tasting, a great experience! Even with kids, my son of three just loved it!!!!!

Souks. Loved the Souks, so much fun, people very friendly don't get annoyed, just enjoy it. if you want to get away just keep walking and say nothing. I found the sellers are a lot less pushy the further you go into the souks,

You need to be robust and alert to enjoy this authentic city. Just a warning to those considering a trip to the walled city of old Marrakech as this place is not easy to handle but it is still worth it because you are taken into different world. There are few street signs and it's easy to get lost, the traders pester you and don't give up. There are some nasty young men around who pretend they want to help you to get to your destination but actually get you lost and then demand money from you. There are a lot of fast motorbikes, bikes and small vehicles mixing with pedestrians, so you have to be alert. In the square people shout out at you to get your attention to get your money, locals can get annoyed with you if you take photographs or may demand a payment. If you pay for your meal in big notes you need to demand the change as the staff are happy to keep it without asking. Haggling for goods got the price down by 40%.The place is dirty. the hygiene is very poor and animals are seen as animals and not pets. But like i said, it's still worth going for the experience of entering a world removed from the one I am use to.

A most atmospheric market, eating and entertainment venue, but watch out for tea leaves!. Great place if you like to bargain and still pay way over the odds for everything. This didn’t stop me, I bought a copper wash basin, some silver jewellery and a mother of pearl inlaid box, all more expensive than elsewhere and probably made in China, despite assurances that “everything is made in the desert by my cousin, who is a Berber”.There are some good restaurants around the edge of the Souk, mostly aimed at tourists but the food is good and at least one can have a beer, even if one does have to endure the ubiquitous belly dancers.Steer clear of the smelly arm pits and beware of thieves. I was distracted by a woman in a burka, who grabbed my arm and started speaking in Arabic, when two other women bumped into me, the first woman then pushed her hand into my hip pocket and stole the wodge of paper which I keep there, especially for pick-pockets in places such as this. My wallet, I keep clutched firmly in my hand and buried in a side pocket. A tip worth remembering for those who like to hang onto their hard earned cash.

Much more fun without a guide. Bought some good high quality locally made metal and leather goods for decent enough prices from pleasant, helpful sellers; haggling seemed to work quite well so I imaagine we could have paid a great deal less. However, I really dislike the angry, testoterone-fuelled hucksters that shout at your retreating back when you don't respond to their stuff. Why do they do it?

Full of life - smile and enjoy it for what it is. I read some reviews about needing a guide, the threatening atmosphere, dirty, it’s a rip off, high prices etc. Just go with an open mind and a smile on your face. You certainly do not need a guide –take a map, but don’t worry about getting lost in the souk, that is part of it. If you really feel that a guide is an absolute essential, then book one that is trusted though your Riad. But at least give it a go on your own first.Tend to agree that most of the stuff is the same or very similar. But it’s still a damn site better than seeing the exact same retail chains in every single city across the world. Just go to Marrakech new town (Zara, Starbucks, McDonalds etc.) and you could be anywhere in the world. Makes you want to run straight back to the souks!Of course the shop keepers try to entice you into their shops. When there is so much competition around why wouldn’t they. But a polite ‘no thank you’ or ‘non merci’ with a smile on your face goes a long way. You will soon find that the vast majority of owners are not the slightest bit threatening, but have a good sense of humour and this is part of the game.Haggling – yes, you have to haggle for everything. After a while it can become a bit tiring. But it is part of life here. Embrace it and take it for what it is. Just remember a successful negotiation is not about winning, it’s when the seller thinks they have a good price and the buyer thinks they have a bargain. Pay what you are happy to pay and what you think is reasonable, that way you can’t feel ripped off. As a rough guide the end price should be somewhere between 30% and 40% of the original price offered. Prices appear to be higher around and near the Fna square. Check your purchases before handing over the cash.Don’t try to do the whole lot in one go – take a break and have a mint tea somewhere. If you see that one item that you must have and you stumbled across it by accident – buy it. Chances are, unless you have a very good sense of direction you won’t find it again.Hand trucks and trollies are used in the main souk streets to move things around. Keep a listen out and move aside. Mopeds use the side streets around the main souk areas and within the median itself, so look and listen. Looks chaotic but it works.Safe to wander around day and night.

I don't really like shopping, and I dislike mopeds.... and I absolutely hate the constant threat of being run over by a moped, so...I wasn't thrilled with the souks within the medina... Nor was I thrilled with the proprietors of the shops within the souks, who are as opportunistic as they are moody. They'll try to unload their bad merch on you first, and when you finally get to talking about the well-crafted stuff, they'll quote you some ludicrously high price, and then the bargaining begins, which is about as much fun to me as arguing with a homely student about an "unfair" grade. Then, you either walk out of the stall with a package under your arm...or you don't...and it doesn't matter much which circumstance occurs.

ETHNIC, CULTURAL AND FULL OF HERITAGE. This is definatly the highlight of this cute little town. It's a place you can go and get lost in and never get bored. Full of exciting things to see and do with the whole family. The friendliest and most sincere people I met in morocco were in Marrakech.

Go and get lost..... Walk, drink coffee, walk more. Eat, walk, eat again, Olives, spices, fruit, local sweets..... 1,000 years of history! Get lost, walk into any shop, you never know what you will find. Talk, enjoy - you don't have to buy! take a compass, check the sun..... just have a blast!

It was OK!. Certainly, the souk was a vibrant place with plenty to see. We were with our young 14 year old daughter who felt intimidated by the place and the people constantly staring at her and at one stage a local offered 800 camels for her!!! In all seriousness this was disconcerting when they are stood right in front of you making such a statement. In my humble opinion, the souk for all its history, sights and sounds, is not the best place for young children. Our guide was great with a wealth of knowledge, who took us around the best places

A must even if you're not a shopper. Quiet browsing it isn't - be prepared to be called at from all directions - but the haggling can be fun. Actually got some cushion covers made from a Berber Kilim by an artisan in the souks and very happy with them. A lasting momento of our trip. Recommend researching online the kinds of prices you would pay and be prepared to walk away.

vital, authentic and buzzing with life. The souk is vibrant and full of everything made in Morocco.The only danger we felt were the motorcycles and bicyclesin the narrow streets. This is the heartbeat of the city. I wouldsuggest hiring a guide to help find your way.

great souk. be careful - the sellers will start with a ,crazily high , price.. think how much you want to spend maximum on the item and don't go higher.. also ,deeper, you get inside the cheaper it gets. the main square and stalls on the outskirts of it are just overpriced
Dodgy people. Everyone tried to be too nice, people are touching you, gabbing your hand without asking, trying to get money from you. I felt uncomfortable.

Great banter, interesting, stimulating. I loved the souks and loved the haggling. Some great original art work at fantastic prices - got an abstract oil painting on canvas for only 150 dirham, delighted with it. Loved the iron souks, watching all the welding going on was fascinating. Do haggle hard - an example is this haggle over a copper candle holder - he said 180, I said 50, he said 150, I said 50...eventually I choose to walk away, a few minutes later he taps me on the shoulder and says 65, I say 50 and he agrees! So be tough, dont pay more than you would at home and dont worry, thecsouks are bery repetitive so the same item will definitely be on anither stall!

Once in a Lifetime Experience. This has to be done, even if just visiting for the day.Go with a guide if your shy, or do without for a real experience!Always have an idea of what you want to pay. No one is going to rip you off here, its more of a game atmosphere. My rough guide was that 150MAD was £10 ish. Have a chat with the locals/sellers, its good for a laugh.One thing to note are the fake guides who engage you in conversation and then want money from you afterwords. This can be easily avoided by being polite and say no thank you.......Also be aware of the screaming mopeds/bikes zooming past you in the narrow streets!As for the quality of goods....hmmm some stuff is real, but alot is from the uni Prix. Still good value though.So have fun and grab a bargain!

Holiday. Quite frightening at first, so go in the mornings before everybody else does. As time passes and you get used to the people asking for you to look at their wares the souks are very pretty and interesting.Haggle is a must! start at a quarter of the price.The Artisan shops give a true price, which is double what the souks start at.

Real value. interesting to see,to buy only when you are prepared to spend a lot of time discussing prices, good altenative is the "ensemle artisanal" on Avenue Mohammed V. Great choice of local craft and everything has a price tag

How much!?????!!!. Great fun and sense of satisfaction bartering the sellers down and agreeing a price about half what was originally asked. My wife was so accomplished that I felt sorry for the stall holders. Walking away does the trick!

Drive a hard bargain!. Keep your wits about you and decide what you are willing to pay! If the sellers won't meet your price, walk away! I did, and paid less than half price for a beautiful leather rucksack!

Prepare for culture shock then go with the flow!. Our second visit to Marrakech. First time all inclusive in the Palmerie this time a simple riad in the Medina. Would go for the riad every time! Once you have memorised your route from square to riad you are ready to wander where ever you want. The one time we got TOTALLY lost we were shown the way back to the tourist trail by a teenager. We gave him 10 dirham for his trouble and although he protested for more soon went away when he realised we would give no more. Visit the fixed price Ensemble Artisanal about 500meters to the right of the Koutoubia Mosque early in your stay to give you an idea of the prices you should be paying in the souk (in our experience about one third less than the fixed price.) Please don't go to Marrakech if you get offended by sellers urging you to buy as it happens ALL the time. But they are genuine and friendly people who are only trying to make a living. We were quite embarrassed by the rudeness of some of the tourists towards them. The Marrakech souks are certainly a place to experience another culture.

The must see market of the world. A one of a kind travel destination, that offers a very different food and culture experience to a western traveler. A vibrant and exciting travel destination that you will remember for the rest of your life. As all other markets in the developing worlds, do not buy saffron. You will find many merchants trying to sell you anything from paprika to tumeric and claiming that it is Saffron. Just stay safe and smart, and you will have a wonderful time at the market.
souks. good but a bit scary for me, don`t really like people in my face, they don`t take no for an answer. But it`s worth a visit for the experience

Take your compass!. Hustle, bustle, noise, excitement, mopeds and bartering. All part of everyday souk life. The 'hardcore' markets are not for the feint-hearted, but worth a visit. Keep your wits about you and be prepared to haggle and charm vendors if you want to buy anything. Keep smiling and thank people for offers too - they dislike being ignored and may keep pestering you!We got lost, even with a map (!) so make sure you know where you are heading, otherwise you could be heading in circles! People will offer you directions, but will expect payment.Not a relaxing experience by any means, but one definitely worth having.

Average experience. The place was dark with narrow little roads crowded and extremely noisy!worst part was all these local people that were so pushy and drugging you in their stores to buy something .i have been to other souks and I know how their selling system works but this one was

Easy to get lost!. The Soukes are well worth visiting. You need your haggling head on as you have to barter for everything. very lively, very colourful. Beware though as it's easy to loose your bearings in the Soukes. My advice would be to carry a street map with you.
Be brave. Venture deep.. get away from the main square. Head north deep into the souks. Less hassle. More real. Better bargains. Don't be scared!

Happy shopping. Many happy hours were spent in the souk with so much to choose from. It was colourful and busy but I did not find it overwhelming. Bartering was fun but could get tiring, but then I did fill a suitcase with my purchases. It's a bit tricky when you first arrive as you don't know what anything is worth. We were advised to halve the initial price and then go up a bit, and this generally worked very well. People were very friendly.
Brilliantly bonkers. Haggling, one of everything, noise, smells, smiles. Couldn't ask for more fun and so different from home. Anyone saying anything negative is not getting the point

quality?. nice Souk, but a lot of shops selling the same things and yet everybody is calling to you to come in. A lot of scarfs, but when you have seen 1 shop you have seen them all. Nice ambiance when it's getting dark, but not quit a safe feeling once it's really dark. Unsatisfied.

Akbar Delights boutique dishonesty. This store was recommended by Trip Advisor. I ordered a custom made 'Andria' jacket in January 2013 that Yann Dobry, the owner, told me was Moroccan made and would be shipped to me in a six months. I paid 9,000 MAD, which is quite expensive.The jacket arrived at my home in New York, USA with a shipping label that said 'made in Hong Kong, China. The jacket was not Moroccan and did not fit at all. I returned the jacket in November 2013. At that time, Isabelle Dobry, Yann's wife and an owner of the firm, said that she would have to contact the Centre Monetique Interbanier in Marrakech before she would return my money. I have never received my money and when the Moroccan guide went to see her, she said that she would not give me my money back.The owners of Akbar Delights have the jacket and copies of all the paperwork. This is a very dishonest company that is selling expensive merchandise that is not Moroccan made or Moroccan.This shop should not be listed as a place to shop for Moroccan clothes.Anne de Richemont

Know what you're doing.... Of course you have to see the Souks... it'd be insane to not go. But after a while everything looks the same - same carpets and shoes and wood and leather. And of course you're constantly being beckoned into stores by every sales dude. My advice - get a guide. Your riad can likely arrange one. At first you probably don't think you need someone to guide your wandering, but those souk salesman have every scam perfected to a T... it's actually impressive. A guide can let you know where is best, what's real, what to believe, etc.

Busy. Small to wide walkways filled with diverse merchandise. If you go during the morning hours it is much more quiet and you can see people going about their daily lives. As the day progresses it becomes more hectic and exciting.

Not great. I just can't recommend Marrakech to anyone.1. The souks are not traditional, all they sell is tourist tat and its all identical. I cant stress enough how it's just all so much garbage. Somewhere there is a big factory churning out this stuff (someone else mentioned Made In China and i can see why). Marrakech's main economy is tourism, in fact it looks like there is nothing else. You will be constantly hassled to buy. I'm good at handling hawkers but it does get annoying.2. There are no road rules to speak of and it gets tiring having to dodge mopeds zipping through the pedestrianised areas all the time. There are not many pavements in the Medina and the drivers all dangerously cut blind corners, it's pure luck if you don't get hit.3. There are three major food groups in Marrakech:- tagines, kebabs and pizza/pasta. You will get sick of them by the end of your holiday.Obviously the Italians do pizza and pasta a LOT better so be prepared to be disappointed.A lot of tagines are bland, bland, bland, like the old days when you used to boil vegetables to death.The kebabs are a constant letdown, served with greasy chips, or no salad, or no rice, or just lacking in flavour.There is an over abundance of almonds in all sweets and desserts.Overall the Marrakech food experience is extremely poor compared to any contemporary country.Souk Kafe is the one oasis amongst the culinary mediocrity, I have left a review.4. What the Morrocan's consider a tourist destination is different from you and I. There are much better examples of similar things in other parts of the world.Jardin Majorelle is considered one of the top attractions in Marrakech but they're really pathetic when you compare them to something like Kew Gardens. The only redeeming feature is getting away from the Marrakech rat race. El Badi Palace is a joke, poorly preserved, no interesting architectural features and poor signage, the storks are the only thing you won't see much better elsewhere.The other attractions have the same low quality feel.5. Having to constantly haggle prices on everything wears you down, and you still know by the end of it you're a tourist getting ripped off.6. Everybody is out to make a buck off you. This includes dodgy men and boys who keep telling you a way is closed so they can offer you a different route and charge for the privilege. At times they can be quite menacing (ignore them).Likewise expect to be asked for money from your guides etc even if you arrange and pay for excursions through your accommodation.It's a shame people like this ruin their tourism industry.7. Marrakech is not cheap for a tourist. I found things starting at not a million miles away from London prices (known as one of the most expensive cities in the world). You have to haggle but see number five above.8. And it's just dirty.If you have to stay make it a maximum of one or two days otherwise it will just wear you down. Take some proper walking shoes, my partner didn't and struggled at times.
Interesting...but tiring.. Many things included in the day ,but it was very tiring,hot, many complained at the tour guides speed to fit everything in !

Simply fantastic. enjoy getting lost here, spent several days, been to the roof tops of many of the locals, inside wood work shops, seen the dyers working the wool and the carpenters and metal workers at work, cobblers making their shoes and then of course there are the thousands of shops just selling all the local hand made stuff of this country. Every one is very friendly and we have never seen any crime. All prices are negotiable and it's not difficult to get he best price- it's always at least a 1/3 of what they start with reply with 1/10 don't budge much and then walk away. If they want to sell they will come and finally agree to what you are offering. 50 mdh gets you well made slippers, 150 mdh gets you a large double thickness pashmina shawl or a Fez hand painted large ornamental plate. Well those were my bargains today. Great local sweets like nougat etc. safe for anyone to walk around and no dress code, my teenage daughters never felt uncomfortable ( apart from in the livestock/butchery part)

Atmospheric. As an experience and photography opportunity it was fantastic.Two middle aged sisters felt comfortable and never experienced any concern. Yes, we were asked to buy things but when we politely declined we were left alone.

One of the best souks to wander in. This is my favourite souk, it has such colour and variety, and the stallholders are really good, they don't pester you although, of course, they will try and sell you something if you show even the slightest interest. The leather goods and textiles are so good and the leather is really good value, so bargain and enjoy your puchases. Always take your camera, there are so many things too see, and the light coming in through the slits in the roof covering gives wonderful effects. You won't get lost, just keep a hand over your bag, and allow 2-3 hours to wander around. It is perfectly safe, no need to go around with a guide, I wander on my own very happily and I'm female.

How to describe it? Impossible.. You just have to go there and feel. This place is full of controversy - fun and chaos, dangerous and warm, very deceptive, the poor and the rich, not for naive and weak people. You just don't know what to think at first time. Maybe you just don't need to know. Some places in the world are to be just felt, nothing more, and these souks are definitely that type of place. One thing has very different prices in many spots - you should negotiate with the seller, I admit, I overpaid for some things. Essaouira's souks are calmer and cheaper, but there is different atmosphere, strictly connected with the have-no-words-to-describe Jemma El Fna square. You can be bit shocked of bit aggressive sellers, it might become little irritating after a while. Keep smiling and telling "Shukran" or "Merci" or just ignore them. Don't buy a fresh food there - flies everywhere, cats around. Patisseries are good, but not everywhere, just look forward TripAdvisor logo (original one !! some local restaurants/shops have false, painted logo). Just go there. And feel. And believe. It is once a lifetime place you must see.

got it all. a great place to find anything you want , an experience to treasure a few dodgy traders be ready to say no thank you a few hundred times and make sure to barter for what you want drop their price by 2 thirds as a starting point and keep your mind on what it is worth to you be prepared to walk away. enjoy the food and lifestyle this place shows you.

Great fun. A lot of fun to walk around the windy busy souk, popping into and out of all manner of stalls/stores.bargain haggle - its good for jewelry but make sure you ask em for the silver acid test.. http://www.wikihow.com/Test-Silver (watch video)enjoy!

Amazing. This place cannot be properly described, it must be seen to be believed .A complete maze of filthy alleyways filled with stalls selling everything form pashmina`s to Zebra skins. All the food stall were heaving with flies, the vegetables and fruit were mostly rotten. Chicken heads and feet along with fish guts are thrown on the floor for all the feral cats. Cow and goat heads are displayed outside the stalls. People have live lizards , hedgehogs. tortoises, birds and all sorts in tiny cages in the burning sun all for sale. Donkeys with open weeping sores stand without water all day and evening . Really difficult to see and the images will stay with me for ever, but it`s just a different culture. Do not take notice of all the lads offering to give directions, they will send you the wrong way and take money for it. Very easy to be lost in here for hours and a map is not much good as a lot of the alleyways don't have names on. Be prepared to haggle, it feels wrong to start with because we are too polite but when you get the hang of it you can have fun.

Chaotic and boisterous. The souks of Marrakesh are fascinating. They are a sometimes chaotic and sometimes downright dangerous place to visit. Dangerous that is due to mopeds being driven at high speed through crowds of visitors. Cries of "Attention" are heard as the bike, mopeds, scooters and other crazy vehicles hurtle past at alarming speeds. The stall holders are good natured but, to stop for even a second to admire anything is to commence the hard sell. A polite "no thanks" or "non merci" works but after 7 days in Marrakesh it does get a bit much. Not to be missed whilst in Marrakesh but do walk on the right and be careful.

shopping fun. A nice place to shop and get lost in the alleyways-keep exploring because it is bigger than you think. The alleyways are noisy because motor bike riders cause pollution but they traders do not hassle you too much. Bargain. There are some better quality shops with something other than tourist tat if you keep exploring.

Interesting but watch out for young men out to make a quick buck!. The souks are a delight to explore. But watch out for people wanting to take you to go see the tanneries - they tell you it's free - they don't ask you for money but the man that shows you around the smelly dirty area does expect money and gets very upset if you don't pay him at least 100 dirhams. A total waste of money!

A little lost. Shopping in a souk sounds like a good idea until you try it. The little lanes are not clear on any map, so you spend a loy of time trying to find out where you are. Locals try to help when they see a map, but beware some of them will send you in the wrong direction on purpose! The quality of goods is very variable, so we went to the government run Complexe d'Artisanat near the Saadian tombs where we could chose at leisure an examine the quality of the goods. A tad more expensive but less stressful.
Shoppers paridise. Accept the fact the sellers will be in your face, and enjoy the experience of haggling and stand your ground on what you are prepared to pay. If you walk away, they usually accept.

A must see if you are in Marrakech. We entered the main square and I just wanded to run in and see everything there was.The square is huge with monkeys,acrobats and of course the snake charmers,I even met the street dentist making dentures and had a pic with him.Take lots of small bills and dont expect to leave with any.If you think you are a salesman or know a good one you havne met these guys.They make selling an art.Be prepared to haggle and haggle hard.Dont keep all your cash in tne pocket so you can use the thats all I have left approach.They have nice silk scarves ,copper and bress work as well as the Moroccan slippers.If you plan on going to Fes hold off on the leather as the prices are better there.Its a whole lot of fun and you will see things that amaze you.You will get home and look at your pictures and will think these pics do not do the place justuce.Its the smells,the sights,the action going on around you that makes this place what it is.You have to go and actually be there to appreciate it
Marmite. You'll either love or hate the souks. A labyrinth of alleys easy to get lost but just find the square and start again!!

Get lost. The souks are great fun, a real labyrinth of narrow streets lined with tiny shops and workshops. A great way to spend the day trying not to get lost in there, easier said than done. A must see, lots of things to look at and barter for ask someone for help to find the area you are looking for and they will be very helpull, they also take to all there relatives shops. buy if you want and don't if you don't. you can go all the way through from medina through the souks and out into Jeema El Fna if you can find your way that is.. In medina is the Royal palace of the king who's picture must be hung in every building by law. Don't visit the souks if you are tired or you have a tight schedule, it deserves a lot of time and patience. Happy Holidays
Great Experience. Go do it,it's worth it.Not much hassle and some good quality among the tourist tat.Try an organised trip first if your nervous to get your bearings,then go for it.

Busy Busy Busy and great fun. Wow, we had to do this twice. Once with a guide so that we got the feel of the Souk and the many pathways. Secondly with friends we met and in the evening to see how the Souk came alive and to try the delicacies. Just great and so vibrant. As for being pestered by the many hawkers, just smile, be very polite (no hand gestures) and say 'La Choukran' they will soon understand that you want to just savour and enjoy the evening in the Souk.

Rip off. You have to barter like crazy, constantly hassled and I felt the souks were at times more expensive than the shops. Locals will offer to help you find your way and will always then expect to be paid. Worth seeing it for just the sights rather than to do much shopping.

It's an experience. If you haven't ventured out into the souks you haven't been to Marrakech. We were a little confused and overwhelmed at first but later it seemed more manageable. If you don't know your way around (and who does) be sure to have a local guide.
Plenty of variety. Good for leather goods, scarves, shoes and all sorts.Confusing though and easy to get lost though there are some signs.

Must be done. Phenomenal experience. Hard to describe. You will get lost, You shop , haggle , smell , taste and see. This place has to be visited. It is often suggested to bring a guide personally i think there is no need. You will find your way. I advise a day visit for shopping and a night visit to see the square

Soaking up the Souks. Haggle! Hold on to your valuables, if you take a guide be careful that he doesn't just take you to his mates' shops! (This was an official tourist office guide!). Best in the early evening as it all comes to life, head-spinning explosion of colour, smell & sound to the senses!

Not to be missed. The souk is a great fun experience. Just walking through is fine with no real pressure from vendors. The people are friendly and if you are in the market for anything special you will find it here. Most of the souk is covered so you are shielded from the sun when it is really hot. A local guide will be very helpful. Even a short visit to the souk will be very worthy of your time.

A maze of colorful shops!. The Souks of Marrakech is such an amazing shopping experience. I highly suggest for first timers to walk through the maze of little shops and watch as people make their transactions. I was a bit afraid as I heard the shop workers may get aggressive and not allow you to walk away but after the second day my daughter and I walked through the alleys freely and comfortably. Do your research before buying items so you know how much each item is worth, don't get caught up in the transaction bargaining and walk away if you're not okay with the price, they'll follow you but won't harass you. Just know you'll find the same items right around the corner so if you can't get the price you want move on, but if you notice your asking price won't ever get taken, then you need to change your final price because it's too low. I walked away with no shoes which I was expecting to leave with at least 20 pairs. They were asking $20 for leather sandals which I can buy in the US for less and way better made and longer lasting. The detailed handwork of the items sold are so amazing, each time I purchased an item I knew each was individually handmade not by a machine that's mass produced.
Great shopping. Just located next to the square,you have to have a good look around this wonderful place,you may get lost but dont worry someone will point you in the direction of the square again.

Don't forget to bargain. Amazing souk, stay on the main street if you are not sure where to go.
Shops look all the same, don't gorget to bargain, at least 60% of the price. Even with that, our Pashmina were the same price we paid in the Souk after bargain than at the airport..!
have fun doing it, they expect it.
Colorful craziness :)!. A have to experience to do. A mess that you can enjoy, people with whom you can have fun or nice product to buy.

Chaotic. Marrakech has the largest traditional market (souk) in Morocco which was an experience itself with the sights, sounds and smells. There were bikes and motorbikes whizzing past the narrow alleys; the air was filled with the smells of various spices as well as the smell of livestock. The stalls were chilled and not that aggressive though they stared at us, we firmly said no merci and we were not harassed. We did look at some of the prices and goods as it is good to compare prices and products before purchasing.

Brilliant fun!. Brilliant fun to walk around all the different wee alleys and see all the different stalls and shops.Bartering was great fun and a real necessity and I managed to get lots of beautiful things for a good price. Best piece of advice if it's too expensive just walk away and he'll probably come down in price again - they're looking to make a profit.Also, don't take pictures in the Souks.

A great experience. A labyrinth of shops and stalls and a visit here is a must. There is so much to see like the metalwork area, the leather workers and tannery, the dyers it is amazing.Bartering and haggling is the order of the day, they will start with a sky high price, which you reject and give a counter offer of about 75% less, then the fun and games begin. In no way did we feel threatened. We were invited into shops to view the good, just say no thank you.
