If you are offered some Morrocan tea decline as you are then invited into the shop for some intense selling and told we gave you hospitality so buy.A word of caution, beware of the bicycles, scooters and other motorised vehicles that drive up and down the narrow lanes, a nightmare. If you get lost in the Souk, look at the satellite dishes as they all face the big Mosque, La Koutoubia, so you can find your way out. It is also best to refuse any offers to be guided around the Souk.We took the shuttle bus from our hotel, Riu Tikida Gardens, we were on a 10 day holiday in Marrakech, 22nd September to 2nd October. The bus dropped us at Place du 16th Novembre, follow the Avenue Mohammed V towards the big Mosque, then continue on to the square, Place Djemaa El Fna, and you are there. The walk takes about 25 minutes. A visitor to Marrakech cannot leave without a trip to the Souk, it is amazing.
Crazy!. Crazy maze of walkways and stalls, mad motorbikers, colourful, lots of neglected cats ( the main downside) but a must see in Marrakesh

Great. Interesting and fun. You have to barter which can be embarrassing sometimes, but quite honestly the things you are buying is usually so much cheaper than you would buy anywhere else you tend to pay what they ask for.
A joy for all the senses. A wonderful experience , colour, characters, and fun. You need a map, instinct , and a sense of humour.

Relax and absorb it all. Sights, sounds, and smells all make this old marketplace much the same as it was 500 years ago. You can find amazing crafts and bargains here, but it is easy to get lost in the narrow, winding corridors. Ask your Riad for a map and rely on landmarks on the corners. The best parts are the leather, metal, lamp, and wood crafts. You can also find some wonderful restaurants and don't judge them by the exteriors, which can appear run down. The open air market of the "square" is awesome, and is best in the late afternoon, especially on Fridays. Check out the lively musicians, snake charmers, dentist, and others. Best to find a Riad inside the Medina, which means it is within easy walking distance of the souks. My only criticism of the souks are the small motorbikes that zip through the corridors, sometimes brushing you in their haste. Even the locals are unhappy with that situation.

Pushy Pushy. You will find the same products being sold all over the souk repeatedly. Don't make it a day trip at the souk. Choose what you want, get prices from a few sellers and negotiate what you think is really worth it.

Amazing. If you have never been to the Marrakech Souk then i would add it to you bucket list.Prior to entering the Souk we read a review on bruisedpassports.com, which suggested that you should sit down in a cafe on the outskirts of the Souk to enjoy a mint tea and gather yourself prior to entering the amazing world off the Souk. this was a great piece of advice!

Enjoy this unique experience. From the moment you enter there will be a million and one stall holders vying for your attention and your money. For sure there are some exceptional bargains to be had but you will need to haggle over everything. Don't expect to get back to the point you started from as the place is an entire maze. If you ask directions expect to pay. My advice is to keep walking and eventually you will end up somewhere. But where is another matter altogether!!!

A must. The souks are great fun and not to be missed. I was a bit worried having read some negative reviews, but my fears were unfounded. There are some basic rules you have to remember - basically you don't need any of what they are selling, they start at an exorbitantly high price and your response has to be equally low - very very low and from there you bargain. Bargaining is great fun, again with rules - lots of acting, facial expressions of horror at the prices they say, clutching of the head in disbelief, saying no, no, no, several times, but most importantly - smile and be polite at the same time. They love it when you enter into the game. Then at the end when the stallholder is pulling a long face and reluctantly bagging up your goods you slap him on the shoulder, smile and say - 'its business yes' and offer your hand? and smile. He invariably smiles back and shakes your hand. I did it all the time and never had a bad experience. Ladies also remember to dress conservatively - cover shoulders and no short skirts/shorts. I think it helps to gain the respect of the locals.

Treasures of the Souk. We thoroughly enjoyed walking about the little alleys of the Souk, You never know where the little streets lead to. This was magical for us. One can find wonderful souvenirs, excellent Bio shops selling Argan Oil and its bi-products. Handbags, Moroccan leather footwear and pottery. Very enjoyable.

Interesting. We had read some of the vendors were aggressive in terms of their sales pitches but this was not our experience. We found the majority to be respectful and persuasive . Most allowed photographs and were very accomodating . We bought fake Beats headphones for $ 80 dirham and saw the exact one selling for $ 50 in the next store :(. Lots of bargains to be had and overall it was a fabulous experince

Never buy from the outside shops, go in!. The prize possessions are inside the Souks. The stall owners were happy to show us how they made their items. There is one shop in particular, a wedding clothes shop that also sells pillows, across from a all natural remedies place. Both shops are amazing, if i can find out their names i will be sure to tell you. Watch out for many stall owners that pull you into their shops and try to thrust items on to you. I was offered a chess set and told to "take it, take it, you pay later". To any tourist just beware about this, however haggle haggle haggle, i got someone down from 10000 Dhm to 3200 dhm! When buying the traditional slippers go else where as in the souks it's just cheap plastic they use not leather. Also i would not buy the food from stalls if i were you, a word to the wise.

Exciting.. For a few dirhams, it is interesting to see where the felt is made and the wool dyed. Tradition still prevails, but some shops are starting to put on permanent doors, which, I imagine in 10 years time will take away from the 'market feel'. Not for the faint hearted if you are trying to buy something.
Market. Yo need to remember that prices are doubled or triple to receive a right price for a product! Good luck!

Interesting. We stayed within the Medina at Dar al Bacha so we had the Souk on our doorstep some lovely shops and antique areas at our end make sure that you take a map of the souk with you as it is very easy to get lost
Not too busy but lots to see!. Not too busy but lots to see! Delicious food & juice stands. Lots of amazing jewellery, shoes & Herbalists.

good for getting presents. This is a good place to get presents if you are prepared to haggle. The key to haggling in Morocco is definitely walking away - this is when prices really drop. i didn't have a lot of cash to spend on this trip, and i wasn't fussed about not making a purchased but this had the accidental affect of me spending less than i expected! I found that i was getting products for about half the initial asking price. If you're a particular good haggler I imagine that you could get items for even less!i found that vendors next to Jeema el fna square gave the least discounts, the souk closes between 8-9 in the evening, but some vendors do get grumpy at around this time (me and my friend were a bit surprised at the level of rudeness). i think the best time to get a bargain is either first in the morning when vendors are looking for the first sale of the day, or towards the evening when vendors need a sale.I also walked round the Dyer's souk, Copper souk, and the instrument souk with my guide book, the guide book definitely helped and i don't think i could have done it without the book.

Interesting Expereance. Our first time in Marrakech. So much to see and only 5 days, just not enough time. Well the first thing to say about the souks is be careful you are not run over by scooters, motor bike riders or cyclists, they are all bloody mad. It seems that those using motorised transport have to have crash helmets. Some wear them properly, some back to front and the majority hang them from the handlebars. Walk on the right hand side and you maybe ok.Once into the souks have fun the stalls sell everything, if you go down some of the alleys you can buy live chickens then have it killed and plucked all in under 9 minutes. They also have larger beasts as well. Never be under any illusions stall holders are there for one thing only, to make a profit. Rest assured they will rip you off if you let them. Read all the background on bargaining you want but a good rule of thumb I was given by a local was ask what the price is. Then offer 10% and never pay more than half the asking price. Be prepared to walk away. An example from personal experience, I saw a nice silver bracelet, price 1500 dirham, offered 150 and was nearly thrown out out the shop, but I wasn't the guy wanted a sale. We finally settled on 500 and then I walked away. I still reckoned I was paying to much.Beware of Henna ladies in the main square they have no scruples. They grabbed my wife's hand and started drawing patterns. We protested and then they had the cheek to try to charge us 300 dirham. They operate in two's while you are arguing with one the other is trying to pick your pocket from behind so beware. It's great fun though keep a sense of humour smile and be prepared to walk away.The main square at night is just madness. People everywhere. Food stalls of all kinds. People selling everything you could imagine. All round a great experience.

It's a must but not fun. The constant pulling and grabbing and hey I got a deal you come back later. It's a complete utter pain in the ***. Dodging the scooters is by far the most annoying of all. It's worth a stroll through and you will get lost and that's not the fun of it. It's the same stuff they sell all over the city just a different face petaling it to you. We bought nothing since you can not look at anything without constant harassment. If your in one shop the other guy is scream he has better price. You can't miss it, it's everything that is Marrakesh and the one thing if they corrected would make people spend 10x more.

Crazy Madina. These people that come out into souk square each night makes the madness of Marakech well worth the visit but take care these people are shrewd and do no favours. If you take a photo of anything whether its a snake charmer or monkeys they will hound you for payment for taking the photo.. If you get lost in the Madina kids will help get you out but expect money when your half way there if you don't give enough they wont take you the rest of the way. Nothing is cheap unless you barter I succeeded in buy some items with a 75% reduction, but 50 to 60% is the norm. Don't be afraid to visit but do take care

Be prepared. There was some excellent stuff to be bought, but you have to be careful how to buy. Check the fixed price places first, and be prepared to pay a bit less at the souk, BUT don't pick anything up or show interest in any one thing until you've got some sort of definite price.

Worth a Visit at Night. Definitely need a guide as the streets are quite winding and definitely don't feel safe without one, but saying that, you never have time to stop until the guide gets you to a shop where all the prices are high and they get a commission I don't know the answer. Many shops sell the same and prices are not that low. in fact we can get lower prices in Spain.

An experience.... The Marrakech souks are for sure...an experience.Sights,sounds & smells you will never forget.Anything & everything for sale.Good to have a good map or a 'proper' tour guide to get your bearings first.Be careful of all the traffic,mopeds,horse & carriages that compete for space as you walk.Price wise its recommended to offer less than half what's asked,generally meeting somewhere in the middle.Be careful asking directions,you will receive a guide but at a price when your journey ends.It is for sure an experience you will never forget.

A cultural experience. It's a great experience - the smells, the sights and the food. Best to be with a Moroccan guide in case some of the stall holders get aggressive (which is rarely and open to opinion) and it helps if you enjoy bartering, as otherwise youj will most likely not pay an appropriate price! If you're used to western food in prepared in the west, be cautuious of the food as it can give you tummy upsets, but overall ,it's such a nice experience which is worth doing at least once in a lifetime!

One of the Worlds Best. Definitely worth a day or two. Intriguing and always interesting as many items are made in the vicinity. Incredible collections of virtually all items. Particular favourites are the lanterns.

Touristic and unauthentic . The goods in the souks are supposed to be made by artisans from the artisan district but their absolutely not! There full of Cheap tat made in and imported from China , you see exactly the same products in markets all over Europe and Asia. The market traders are the most irritating in the world, if anything they put you off entering their shops and when you politely tell them your not interested they curse you in Arabic and laugh with their friends. They seem to have nothing but contempt for foreign tourists and see you as nothing more than the next sale. You can buy any of the goods on sale in the Marrakech souks off eBay for less money..

Great Place tomeander and shop. This is a Great place to meander and shop in the heat of the day as it is so cool. They do not hassle you if you are not interested, but they love s good haggle if you are, don't be embarrassed to offer low and then go up,as they do seem to start very high, for instance 2 raffia bowls started st 45o deram and I got for 20. You can spend hours in here if not days. Lots of places to eat and drink as well. Recommend you visit. Get s guide to show you round as you would miss so much
Market shopping. Market is like any other you find in Turkey or Egypt, signs say no bikes although you have to watch for scooter's and horse drawn carts going through the market

You won't get lost. When I first visited here there was a great play on the part of locals that without a guide you would get lost. That was part of the charm, fending off unwanted guides. They have gone and along with them the interest and diversity of the souk. It used to be a place focussed on local products and services for locals. No longer, the range of goods has narrowed and the focus is on tourist tat.

Marrakech souks. Well this certainly is an eye opener .The souks are basically where everyone buys there shopping from ,as there are only two supermarkets in marrakech which are expensive for the locals.There are 60,000 yes ,60,000 souks and I have never seen so many people in one place .Although they are very safe ,it is eay to get lost in the maze of people and stalls.Probably best not to go on ur ownHere you can haggle when buying gifts They don't close until 2am and evening times are much busier than daytimes .U have to go and experience the souks!!

A must for the bucket list. It is great fun if you have confidence and the right attitude...remember, there is nothing here that you NEED...so go explore and enjoy! We highly recommend appropriate attire, that means Ladies, do not show the cleavage, shoulders, wear long pants and a top that is long sleeve if possible, we noted that those that did were far more respected than those that wore shorts and tank tops. Note: if you decide you would like to haggle for a carpet, know in advance what size you are looking for, what coloring you prefer and what design interests you, this saves much time for both you and the sales men, it also shows them that you know something about what you are doing. If you are looking for a leather item like a bag or purse and do not see what you are looking for, do not be afraid to tell them what you are looking for, they are very nice and will try to assist you.

overpriced. Very interesting and full of good photos to make kind of place. Would reccomend for anybody interested to find something to buy for family back home. A bit overprised, rip off place but its the biggest market in Morocco, so its forgiven.
not like any other markets. be prepared to haggle, but do it all with a smile and a sense of humour and you will enjoy it all the more.

Taken right out of our comfort zone!. We ventured out to the Medina in the daylight thank goodness and it was busy enough then. The taxi driver took us to the Kasbah first and said that was the square!!! We then got pounced upon by lots of men telling us the square was in all different directions and trying to get us to buy maps and their guide services, it was all a bit too much for us.We were lucky enough to be rescued by a French Family of Tourist who knew their way to the Medina so we were able to go with them, it is quite a walk from the Kasbah to the square.The Medina alleys go on forever, with everyone selling practically the same stuff, not the kind of shopping I am used to so didn't stop to barter. After an hour of wandering we had seen enough and headed out to the open air. This is where it really got scary for me with my phobia of snakes, this wasn't going to end well, they were everywhere, once they started sounding their bugles the snakes seemed to rise from the floor in all directions, at this point we did a vanishing act to the nearest taxi back to the hotel. The Medina is not our kind of place, and is not for the faint hearted, but I could see why its such a draw for the tourists. A must visit in Marrakesh, even if it's not up your street!!!

Souks. Very interesting and colourful. Although I hated the motorcycles and mopeds that speed through the narrow streets, they are noisy and make the souks stink from emissions (the souks in Fez Medina don't allow motorbikes).

Marrakech souk. massive expanse of tiny streets which are easy to get lost in so get a good street map. watch your handbag/wallet and don't flash cash. Always barter, try and get half the asking price.

Not for the faint hearted, the Souk(trading centre ). If you are a visitor to Marrakesh you absolutely must visit this place. DO NOT GO WITHOUT A GUIDE. If you get lost in the Souk ,you will not find your way out. It is a warren of narrow streets and interconnecting passages,Throngs of people, Donkey carts, mopeds, cars all cheek by jowel. It is Bedlam. Not to be missed.

AMAZING. Once you escape from the tourist trap edges and get deep into the souk where the goods are manufactured in and often sold direct from the tiniest of workshops it is a totally alien place, full of vibrancy and smells. Amazing to experience this as a visitor, but I would not want to be one of the workers. It felt very safe but it is a complete warren so you probably need a local/guide to get you back out again.

Below average level of pestering. The souks are fairly similar to souks all over the Middle Eastern world. We weren't pestered as much as in some other places (or here 40 or 50 years ago) but our guide was only interested in taking us to places where he could earn commission.
Nice place. It was cultural, cheap and cheerful. Everything is repetitive. It was extremely smelly lol. But not much harassment or heavy sales. Only touch stuff if u r going to buy. Nice atmosphere.
Fasinating. It is so facinating to walk around the souk in Marrakech with evething you can buy on show from ladies bags to spices every!this is a must see too
Crazy. A riot of colour, a warren of alleyways, everyone wants to sell, you something, and you need to barter

Sensory overload. An amazing experience but not for the feint hearted! Really need to have your wits about you as the stall holders are always ready to make a fast buck albeit with a smile and friendly conversation! It is all spend, spend, spend! Watch out for pick pockets and keep walking!! A great experience all the same by day but much better by night in a horse and carriage!!

hustle and bustle. A great place to buy lots of interesting items. Don't be afraid to barter. End up paying less than 1/2 the asking price. Start low and go up in small amounts. Smile a lot - it will pay dividends!

Sensory experience. This was the best part of Marrakech. It can be a bit intimidating, but dive right in. It is a feast for the senses. The smells of spices and the colors of the stalls were outstanding. Haggling is part of the fun. Don't be upset. If you see something similar for a bit less. Pay what it is worth to you.

Atmospheric. I love the experience of souks so this was a must in Marrakesh. Full of things you need and things you don't. It was very easy to navigate once I'd been round a couple of times. If you stay and chat to the stallholders you're more likely to get more money taken off whatever you want to buy - definitely barter! I picked up lots of lovely things and even had my shoes repaired whilst I was there, so I was very pleased. Least favourite part is the animals outside - they don't treat the monkeys very well. Also, whenever given the option when getting henna done, always always always choose brown or orange henna.

Full of suprises. Visitors must wander the souks to get the real feel of Marrakesh, haggle but don't be rude, pay what you think is correct and if unsure then just walk away, that way no one will be offended.

a must do!. Relax, smile, engage.The stall holders are out to get your money but it is all done with great wit and humour. Its a very safe place, no harm will come to you, you are vital to thier business but keep your wits about you...when we hesitated we were 'shown the way' to the Madrasa by a young man who we then felt obliged to tip. We later realised we had been on the right track anyway and he lead us round the long way. Cheeky! But hey it was only an 80pence tip, worth it for the story.

Dirty, Smelly, Hot. hated it! Hassle from start to finish, dead animals being carted about, live chickens being killed. Stallholders should realise that if they let you look at what they are selling you are far more likely to buy! Never again!

An Experience. I liked the little quaint streets apart from having to dodge the mopeds that speed along them. There was a variety of shops selling various things.Some of the shop owners were lovely some were forceful & quite rude.I would defiantly return.

Similar to all souks. If you have visited other souks this is very similar, but souks are always great places to wander round and to escape the heat in the shady narrow streets. The usual array of stalls can be seen here, with artisans also at work.

Wanderful experience. For me it' s an amazing experience, but a lot of people don't feel so confortable , because sellers and friends ( apparently, because they bring you in places they want... to have a % from the seller ) and they follow and touch you to capture your attention. But if you are not really interested to buy... don't stop or ask prices....They will follow you until you decide a price to tell them..

I never tire of visiting Jem El Fna Medina. An amazing place to visit for the history, artisan crafts, street entertainment, colour & vibrancy, music, amazing aromas and friendly people. Bahia Palace, Artisan Centre, Marjorelle Gardens, Menera Gardens and so much more.. Be careful not to allow snake charmers etc., to take your pic because they will DEMAND money from you. Be prepared to barter its good fun! you can sit in the Medina to eat and watch street entertainment including acrobats.. Cannot wait to return..

Haggle really hard. This was the last place on our 18 days around Morocco, so we were prepared for the hassle and became really good at haggling.The hassle factor is actually quite low.The prices quoted vaired between 2x to 5x what you can get it for. This made haggling really difficult as you don't know what to bargin for. It was only after going to numerous other souks that we knew the value of things.We still got a heap of stuff and had a good time doing it. The variety of products was good. Don't bother with any art, it was on the whole just touristy rubbish.
shopping. great place to see you just cannot miss it, good fun lots lots different things to see /smell/ great colours/twinkling lights and much much more

Best Shopping on Earth. Never will I ever be as excited about shopping as I was shopping in the souks. Wow! I mean, from spices and beautifully shaped tasty almond cookies to pottery and 22kt gold jewelry and leather bags and tea sets and filigree lanterns and wood carved game boards and did I say hand woven rugs and aromatics and Berber artisan pieces and custom tailored djelabas and pashminas and leather cushions and cute refrigerator magnets (for the friends you left back home)...uff...yeah, the best shopping on earth! Yeah, mmm hmm - it's all there in the Marrakech Souk.

A MUST!!!. You cannot visit Marrakech and not go to the souks, if not what is the point in going!! Its excellent there is so much on sale, very busy but we loved it. We also bought a few bits and never paid the first asking price, we got everything for at least a half of what they first said if not more. Haggling is fun and we got right into it, just be cheeky and have a laugh with them!!!!
Hassle, hassle, hassle. Too much hassle & pressure to buy. As a result didn't look around as much as we may have liked to. Also prices were inflated in comparison to other parts of Morocco.

Crazy busy but fun. A culture shock to say the least but great fun e plotting the tunnels and alleys of the old city. Everyone is friendly and there is loads to see however every stall has exactly the same thing. My tip would be for you to ask for less than half the price of what the sellers say and then only pay half price, if they don't agree, walk out of the store they will defo get you to come back for the lower price

WOW!. With 19 entries/exits, if one gets lost one is bound to find way out. I lost my tour group and found stall owners very helpful. The craftsmen are absolutely fascinating to watch. Haggling is expected and I felt no pressure when I said No, thanks.

Interesting market. This a very extensive market with a little bit of everything. The sellers are quite aggressive and you so have to bargain. The snake charmers are just for tourists as well as the monkeys with diapers. They want money to have their pictures taken. The women doing henna tattoos should probably be avoided because you do not know what they have mixed the henna with.

All the colors of Marrakech. The souks are a great experience. You have to be prepared to negotiate the price for everything (except food), which can be tiring at some points. But you can buy beautiful stuff at very good prices.One recommendation is to go to the Ensemble Artisanal which is a fixed price shop with all the items you find in the souk. You can have a good idea for the prices. I found that reasonable (not exhaustive) negotiation at the souks will get you to buy stuff 30% cheaper than in the Ensemble.Be sure to take pictures of the stores (you should ask permission first), they are truly colorful.

Loved it - Great place!. Amazing place to visit and experience at least once in your lifetime. Haggle with the stall holders, dont be afraid to walk away. Be aware of your surroundings, dont get out your phone and be careful with your cash.

definitely worth a visit. We visited the souks a few times and loved it. The owners aren't as pushy as most people make out. If you were not interested we just smiled and said no thank you which they would then leave you alone. There is the off few however who become pushy. Make sure you haggle everything, we got all out items at least half of the first price. Just be cheeky and eventually walk away they will chase you down and give you a good price. Just be careful of people directing you, we managed to get roped into a tannery your which took 5 minuets then was charged 300dirgam. We paid 100 and left swiftly. Deffo worth a visit though.

Interesting but be Alert. We were staying in a Riad close to the Souks which consists of tiny roads full of shops and work places in spaces not much bigger than a cupboard. It is a fascinating area and worth a visit but very easy to get lost. It was interesting to watch craftsmen going about their business, we saw blacksmiths and wool dyers and some shops that had extensives crafts for sale. However we were concerned about the speed of motor bikes in such narrow streets and the constant hassle from locals who wanted to take us to shops or markets who appeared very helpful but were only after money. Good to visit but be alert and on your guard.

Organised chaos. A little intimidating at first but full of life and splendour for the avid shopper. Easy to get lost and you need to dodge the motorbikes in the little winding streets but a totally awesome experience and a must do.

Take your time. Enter the souks and be prepared to wander around! You will sometimes think you have reached the outside but often it is just a small market place. Eventually you will find a way out. WC are difficult to find although there is one near the spice market and in the Marrakech museum.

A guide would be useful. We usually prefer to explore by ourselves but even we admitted that the guide we hired was useful. It's very easy to get lost, for a start, and it's not easy to find the best shops. OK, so the guide gets a commission for the purchases you make, but we were really pleased with the quality of the brass lamp we bought. Try to find Miloud el Jouli, Souk Charatine Talaa No 48 - more expensive than elsewhere but of much better quality and design. Also very interesting is the Berber pharmacy, Herboriste du Paradis, place Ben Youssef No 93.

Awesome experience, you will not be disappointed.. Alleys of stalls, from all kinds of food, colourful spices, clothing, beautiful rug, craft, copy designer goods, you name it. You will definitely find something to take home, but be prepared to haggle if you like something. Aim to knock the price down to up to 50% of the original quote if you can.Please note you do not need an escort, try and explore yourself. You cannot visit Morocco without going to the souk! Lovely and enjoyable experience.

Shoppers paradise. Everything you ever wanted was there. Yes you would be asked to have a look, but if you were not interested, all it needed was a smile and a polite no and they left you alone for you to carry on browsing. Do not buy the first thing you see, it will be round the corner at a better price, so spend time finding what you really like.
Pushy but Nice. The Souk in Marrakesh is much the same as any Souk. There are a little bit more pushy here but you just have to get used to it.

Love it!. Can't help but love aimlessly wondering the windy alleys and staring at the colours and beautiful things. Haggle to your heart's content. Even as 3 women travellers without male companions we didn't feel too harassed. It feels safer than many other world cities.

The souks of Marrakech. Of all the souks in Morocco, Marrakech has the best most extensive ones. It is a literal labyrinth where once you enter, if you are not careful, you may not find your way back out. They are absolutely fascinating, bustling with activity, colorful and full of fragrances, smells, that will capture and entice you. There is an area where you see the artisans working and in this area, the skill trades are grouped per area. So there is an area for making babouches (the famous moroccan slippers), an area for making leather bags, an area for making iron-wrought chandeliers, an area for making shoes etc... It's quite interesting to watch the artisans working in very closed and cramped, dimly lit quarters, banging away at their trade. Then there are tiny squares where you can escape and have a wonderful mint tea! Some of them have a roof-top terrace overlooking the rooves of the medina. An absolute must if you can find these cafés. One in particular is the Café des Epices. Their roof-top terrace is amazing! As for the artisan work in the souks, it's really worth buying whatever grabs you as you won't find such quality at such prices (bargaining is a must) anywhere outside Morocco! You will bring home stuff you will really enjoy wearing or using!

Definately go here. Loved the various stalls. From food to wood to jewellery, clothes, you name it and it was there. They didn't pester you as I thought they might they asked you to come in but I'd you said no they accepted this so I was happily surprised. Great bargains and do barter they like it too.

Fantastic adventure. What a great experience. So long as you don't let yourself be dragged into every shop and stay relaxed you should enjoy this experience. Just enjoy the banter, be prepared to haggle and have a laugh with the locals. The visuals are amazingly colourful and well worth seeing. You haven't been to Morocco if you haven't haggled in the souks.

Fun for the first few times, then just annoying. The souk's look lovely, full of interesting goods hanging in a range of sizes and colours. Beware that you will be shouted at, whistled at and on occasion, grabbed by the arm to come in and look at their wares. All done gently however, no malice intended or given.Once you show an ounce of interest though, you are given an insultingly high amount as the price for what seems to be, well, really, everything that you want to buy. Then you have to participate in the traditional haggle. Please DO NOT EVER accept their first price as they are taking the P.. Honestly !It can be great fun however and now and again you find a merchant who will have a joke over the pricing with you and this makes the whole experience most enjoyable. Especially when they try to tell you that the obvious fake handbags are real.. But sometimes... you just want to buy something that is priced at a fair price for. This does not happen unless you are in a govt. run shop. If you are visiting souks for more than a few days, the haggling gets very annoying.. completely put me off buying and returning..

Not cheap!. We visited the souk on our first day in Marrakech and found it rather overwhelming with the noise, heat, people hassling you if you so much looked at anything and soon escaped into the open. However, we went back on the last day of our stay (7th day) and felt much more at ease there as we had acclimatised to the madness and craziness of Marrakech. Looked at scarves on one stall, he wanted 400 dirhams for a pashmina which was way too much and each time we went to leave he would come down a little but not enough. Eventually we got tired of the bargaining process and left the shop, only to have him come running after us a few mins later agreeing to our original offer of 150 dirhams, which on reflection, was not that cheap after all. A lot of the shops had fixed prices for things and would not come down. We bought a wooden box in the souk in Essaouira for 50 dirhams, a similar smaller box in Marrakech souk was a fixed price of 200 dirhams!We went down many small back streets where the locals obviously shopped but had to keep an eye out for the motorbikes which were driven at crazy speeds weaving in and out of people. Lots of beggars particularly in the evening, women with babies/young children and cripples which was a bit upsetting at first but unfortunately one became immune to the sight after a while.

An Aladdin's Cave. So amazing! So many pretty, unusual trinkets, a maze of shops selling everything Moroccan. It reminded me a bit of Camden Market a little bit! But a lot better. Sellers aren't too pushy and I did try haggling but it didn't really work (although I did get a free fridge magnet!). You WILL get lost in them, but it's not too difficult to find your way out again. The sellers seem to recognise you once you've walked past once and can tell you which direction you came from. The iron making souk was so interesting, with craftsman hard at work. Definitely worth a visit - I could've bought so much!!
Amazing. Only bad point. Boys are too insistent. They look at as if they have never seen a woman before. RIDICULOUS.

Overwhelming amount of same tourist junk. While the narrow alleys are filled with interesting sights, the stalls are all selling the same junk that you have seen everywhere in Morocco --except for higher prices. I suppose if Marrekech is your only stop in Morocco, you will find it interesting. The vendors are terribly in your face - I got weary of it. They start with a price that is at least 5 times as high as anyone would actually pay, so there was too much bargaining for me. But --we are not serious tourist shoppers. IF you can find your way through all the tourist maze, you can still find the "old medina" where leather work and other crafts are still going on. You can find the local markets for fruits and veggies -covered with flies........ You can find interesting things, but you will need to search for them.
Souk times. Souks are great for finding little trinkets and bargains especially laterns and slippers....You will get lost but eventually find your way out!

Not what I expected. I was expecting to have to keep pushing sellers away, but not so. yes they want to negotiate, but they do not hard sell, stop you as you go by, it was actually quite enjoyable and not intimidating at all.
Hassle. If you don't like the hassle then stay away from the souks as although they seem to be polite they are persistent
A MUST SEE. Everyone needs to visit the different Souks in Marrakesh.. So interesting and gives you a feel for the country.

Unfortunately you need a guide. Noisy and very busy, a must place to visit and a guide is essential, unfortunately they all come with the same rider of chosen shops to dump you in the be bullied into sales, so long as you can hold your nerve it can be bearable, still very annoying that no matter what your remit is you will end up being dumped in shops.

Wow!. Do not miss this. We took a leisurely two hour walk through the souk in the afternoon. It is a feast for all your senses. Narrow winding passageways filled with shops of every description, a cacophony of sounds including sputtering motor bikes and donkeys braying, and the delicious smell of cooking lamb and incense of every description.
Good for bargains. Brilliant place for crafts men and bargains bit smelly and some of the traders are pushie you must barter with them and watch out for bikes and donkeys

A nightmare in the form of shopping. If you like to be constantly nagged to buy things you already have or don't want then this is the place. It was mass confusion that I had to deal with on a daily basis as my riad was on the other end of the souk. It's a huge maze of shops selling lots of typical souvenirs, poor quality designer fakes, jewellery, kaftans/djebellahs, etc. What I hated most was the redundant sales pitches, aggressive men cornering you especially when you're alone in the shop with them and naming your price when you don't know how much something should cost in the first place. This place was one big, bustling headache. The heat, people flying by at top speed on mopeds and people wanting money if you ask for directions was a bit overwhelming for me. Also beware the kids and want to "help" you. They will only help to take your money. Next time I will avoid this area like the plague.My grade: D
souk. Disliked felt uncomfortable, a little clostaphobic and it was difficult to find an exit.Lots of beggars too.Must stick together.

Exhausting. Likes: general atmosphere.Dislikes: constant hassle.If you love haggling this is for you but be wary and stick to your guns. Always think to yourself, "would I pay this much for this thing at home?" Don't be afraid to walk away from a shop and while many of the shopkeepers are good humoured there are quite a few who will just swear at you. Visiting the souk is a must of course but a couple of hours is probably enough.

Not for the faint hearted. Be prepared for stall holders trying to entice you into their shops.Great leather, brass and textiles to be bought, but be prepared for hard bargaining. Usually good spirited but not advisable make fun of the traders.

The main attraction but be careful. This place is built to get lost in. The merchandise is attractive and probably well priced. be careful if you get lost. Consult your map and failing that ask for directions from a stall holder, not a wandering guide who will deliberately send you the opposite way, follow you and charge you a price to 'take you there'Haggle. Ask for a price below half of what they ask and meet at a reasonable level. Walk away. It gets cheaper

Con Market. A giant maze, where everything happens in the streets.sell wares, food stalls, donkey carts, motor bikes, tons of people and the, babies having a wee, body wash, regular sprinkling of water, smoking, young but innocent hustlers wanting to show u the way...!, and incredible inflated price to come down dramatically only to find u have still overpaid.We bought some leather good only to discover it reeks of a very BAD SMELL because you wont smell it there, the air is that foul.The people are very respectful and there is no danger in anyway for your personal safety at any time of the day.Once u bag the shopping u want to move on somewhere else, would suggest no more than 3 days, as this is adequate time for staying in this place.
A shoppers paradise. Everything you could possibly want in one place and fun to shop, colourful, friendly people and great fun bargaining.

A lot of the same. The souks are a good place to wonder around to get some bits for people back home and there are some bargains to be had (you normally want to be getting stuff for about a third of the starting price if you can). The only problem is after a while all the alleyways seem to be the same, selling the same items and it is one of those that once you've seen one you've seen them all. It is a definite go see when i Marrakech but just don't expect to spend hours looking at different things.

Got to see!. We spent 4 days in Morocco & 2 days we visited souk. The sights, smells, crowds, shaker charmers, were amazing. I woke up next day & asked myself if it was a dream. We went back out last evening in Merrakech to sit on roof top cafe, enjoy cold drink & a pizza & "people watched". People are amazing, very warm, nice, helpful, etc. We had a private tour sett up in 4x4 to visit Altus Mountains and edge of desert, WOWWW, pix & sights I'll never forget!

Part of the culture.. Not for the faint hearted, the souk in Marrakech will give you a valuable insight into Moroccan culture, but you have to be able to ignore traders who will do their best to sell you their wares. The best thing is to just walk on. If you want to stop and browse there are always those stall holders who have twigged that the best way to do business with Europeans is not to hassle. There is range of goods from pottery to lamps. What strikes one immediately is the variety of vibrant colours. If you are happy to bargain, you will get a good price for anything you want to buy, but STAND FIRM!

Great fun but can be stressful!. We stayed for a week about 5 mins taxi south from the centre and visited the Medina most days for dinner in one of the cafes or restaurants. We ventured into the souks a few times. The first time just fills you with awe at the sheer array of colours and goods on display. After that, the wonder quickly morphs into fatigue. The constant barrage of tricks to get you into stores; pretending to shake your hand as a greeting then pulling you in; standing in your way to direct you in; shouting in mockney accents. If you so much as glance at someone's wares, they will pester you hard to come and look closer.Beggars can also be very persistent, blocking your way or getting right in your personal space, be sure not to give in as this will just perpetuate the tactics.It's once you attempt to buy something that it can really get to you. We bought a few things at around 1/3 of the initial asking price, 2 belts for 220dm (one was reversible, so worth twice as much he said...), a sturdy tea tray and some glasses for 200 - too much at about half initial asking - my girlfriends purchase, she gives in too easily... Then in one lamp shop I tried to play hardball, which didn't go down well. Oddly, I'd say it's the seemingly most cheery, affable, middle aged blokes that you want to avoid. He started at something like 1400dm (saying this was the price for nice English people, Americans would be made to pay over 2000) for a poorly made brass lamp with bits of tinted glass that he was saying we're jewels. We didn't really want the lamp, but they are often very insistent that you offer a price. So I thought of the kind of price I wouldn't mind paying in tk maxx and then dropped it a bit. 60dm I said, expecting to probably be made to triple it and walk away with a piece of scrap metal. His face dropped, he squared his shoulders. "How much?" He asked several times with the same response. Then he told us to get out of his shop, ripping the lamp out of my hands (which they will make you hold with nowhere to put down so you can't leave).The sights of the square are polarising, fascinating but inexcusably cruel.Probably the best bits were getting to look down on the square from a cafe (particularly at night - there's a good cafe atop a hotel, just a couple of doors down from the post office) It's definitely worth going, just go with the frame of mind that it's like a casino, the house always wins, but if you're having fun then it's probably worth it. (And don't take any photos of the henna girls in full burkas, they really don't like it.)

A must see tourist trap ;). The souks are amazing, colorful, loud and invading your personal space at all times. The sellers are reckles and PLEASE NOTE! After travelling whole of Morocco and seeing all the villages, the prices are sometimes expanded up to 1000% of original price and the workers sometimes get only an euro for a item that costs there 400€ so don't be easy when negotiating. Be careful with argan oil as it is often diluted as are spices. But a definate must see!
Nowhere like it. Friendly, intimidating, smelly, perfumed, exciting, bewildering, large squares, tiny alleys....a place of contrasts and a must-visit place!

Souk review2. As I said for the Medina, can be overwhelming and it is not fun when your kids are tired and hungry and you have no idea where you are. Hopefully you speak French or arabic, not many speak english for directions. Know your prices - will be charged 4-5x's the true value.

Souk, Souk and more souk!. I absolutely LOVED the souks, they are the reason I came to Morocco in the 1st place! The energy there is wonderful and the finds are great but be prepared to haggle, negotiate and be willing to walk away. I'm going to say something that might seem a bit racist but I'm definitely NOT.... they will TRY white people and Asians even more. I heard 1 lady that gave me henna for 60 dirham tell a white lady 4500 dirham! that's crazy!!!!! I think as a rule of thumb be prepared to pay maybe a third of what the "decent" vendors charge you and if the number sounds extreme trust me it IS and offer them 10-20% of what they asked. Other than that the souks are great, I got argan oil, rugs, clothes, jewelry leather goods, spices and of course a Hamman "Moroccan Bath" and it was pure bliss. Now if only Delta can find my lost bag I'd be able to enjoy my purchases. I also recommend going during the day to browse and see everything andyou HAVE to go at night to experience that.
Fun. I just loved the Souks it is a national hobby to barter so this was amazing and you can always get the prices down. The colours and nonsense is all good fun very hot though !!
Must see.. A visit to Marrakesh in not complete without a hassle in the souks. You can easily get lost in this maze of shops. One tip; never pay the price they offer (even the second of third time!)

Bargains everywhere!. The mrs was in seventh heaven, and we must have strolled the narrow windy cobbled streets no less than three times a day!There are all sorts of things on sale and haggling is a very enjoyable part of the experience. All the stall owners were very friendly and welcoming, though not pushy at all (like you usually get in such places...).

not to be missed!. You will feel like you are on a movie set! This souk is unbelievable with snake charmers, monkeys and people selling all kinds of food. The best time to visit is at 6 pm, before it gets too crazy. Beware of pick-pockets and everyone wanting money for a picture. We were told by our guide that most of the "Moroccan" things for sale at the souk are actually made in China.

Bargain. Don,t be a shame!. First rule is, It is a market place! So, Policy must follow Supply and demand. The prices are quite high, but that,s normal. It is so in Istanbul, in Mombay, everywhere around the globe. If something costs 100 MAD (Durham) Don,t hasitate to cut the price for 1/4. And stay persistant in such offer You will be happy to buy what you like, and, be not afraid, the seller will make a good busines too. If You want to make a round tour through Souks, be awere not to show, your happy face, if you saw something what You like. Be like Buster Keaton. Stone face! If not, all the familly will surrounds you and try to sell what ever they have. Remember that 100 is 25. It is quite fair!

Not to be missed; but buying elsewhere is easier!. The souk in Marrakech is an essential part of the city's experience and it's well worth exploring in some depth, because the range of items on sale is vast. Some of the items on sale, such as traditional fire bellows, are made in front of you. On the whole, there wasn't too much of the hassle that can be a feature of such markets, but if you feel uncomfortable with haggling, a few stalls do advertise fixed prices. You might also try the government-managed artisan market just a little way north of Jemmah El Fn, on the boulevard leading to the new town. There, everything is fixed-price and the traders are friendly and helpful but are happy to leave you to browse. We bought all our things there.

Good but be careful. The merchants are well practiced in getting more out of you than you want to pay but not as frantic as our last trip to Egypt. Perhaps it was the economic state on our last visit (2010) but the merchants then were desperate to get your cash.Anyway back to Marrakech, the stories about getting lost for days are very much exaggerated. We visited one of the palaces and decided to take a walk through the Souk. We were in no hurry so could take our time. We found the layout OK, lots of side alleys but overall quite easy to get around. This may be peculiar to me (I refuse to have a SAT NAV) as I seem to be able to get around wherever I go. If in doubt my suggestion is simply look up. Often there are small signs to the main square and if there you can get anywhere in Marrakech. Anyway, so good purchases at good prices and we look forward to returning some day.

Great Souk!. Hectic, noisy, lots of haggling - everything you'd expect of a Souk! Great fun, walked through here at gone midnight on way back to the Riad but didn't really feel intimidated even though we were two women walking alone. Lots more hassle than we'd experienced in Agadir's Souk, but then this one is so much bigger. As long as you are sensible and use your common sense, then you shouldn't experience too many problems. Really enjoyed it all.

A must do in Marrakech. Reading about the souks has nothing in comparison to the real experience. They are so full of life, colour, smell and amazing bits and pieces to buy. The sellers will try and make you come into their store (and there are a lot of them) but a polite no thank you and smile will suffice. Most of the stall holders know a little english and are nice people, but be ready to bargain with them which isn't as daunting as I thought it would be.

Busy area but be straight with people. Busy area, haggle if you want anything but also be prepared to walk away. Also be prepared to tell someone firmly but politely to go away as they will follow you are everywhere.Here you will find snake charmers, monkeys, juice bars shops everything.Worth the experience
Don't look left or right. get lost find a good bargain try not to get eye contact with the shop keepers.Everything is on sale. Walk on!
Loud. Loud,confusing and busy. Dive in and be prepared to haggle and get lost. If you don't like crowds it isn't the place for you.

got some babouche slippers. found many sellers didnt haggle had fixed prices inflexible not as described in lonely planet or online reviews they basically demanded expected you to pay or go no nice face just hatred tourists arent welcome really bad ideas in heads i think bout british tourists.........but in the end i found a good seller in soul el jdid he ofered me great discounts
Nice market. You want to pick everything from there… everything is nice to buy!!! I bought a quilt. The guy was very nice seller and very respectful. So much patience he had with me.

Interesting. Enjoyed going around the souk and bargaining, but some traders were very arrogant and one started ranting and raving when we tried to return a small tagine that seemed to break and fall apart as soon as we had purchased it. The trader started ranting and practically threw our money back at us saying.'i dont want your money"!! The guys at the juice stall say some funny things and even sing to you..if you buy from them but will happily say they hate you if you dont.

Got lost for the whole day. Loved this souk! We got completely and utterly lost wondering through the maze of stalls for the whole day but it was brilliant! Found so many little treasures, met lovely people. Would 100% go back

Magic all over the place. A real authentic place, it has magic all over.. it has something really extraordinary.. when you went away from Jamee El Fana, you will feel that you need to go back there quickly.. and when you arrive there you will feel that you finally reached where you belong..* Food is really bad there, do even thing of trying it

Loved it. Loads of charm and some very funny, chessy sales lines from the stall holders. Drive a hard bargain and dont be afraid to offer a ridiculous price, as they'll be running down the street after you to close the deal!!!
Brilliant experience. Brilliant from start to finish, sights, smells and sounds! Not too much hassle either, a firm no thank you was all that was needed. Great experience!

Fun shopping. Huge market with tons of vendors. Shop around, the further into the market you go the better the price. Remember that Marrakech is a city that preys on tourists, so haggle hard on your prices. A good benchmark is 50-60% of the "starting price". Don't be afraid to walk away... if your price is right, they won't let you leave. Have fun with it... I enjoyed these markets more than any others in Morocco. Stay away from the snake charmers unless you want to fork over some money for them.

Must visit but must be careful. My wife and I visited in September. In fact we are still in Marrakech. First point is to be careful. We picked up n unofficial guide for 200d, about £14 who was actually pretty good. We are not under any illusion that he was on a commission from the shops we took us to - but as we shall explain, he saved us a fortune elsewhere. First trip was to. Shoe shop where an hilarious shopkeeper tried to charge £90 for a pair of "Adidas" trainers - now not sure about the product but they were good quality. The chap didn't want to let us go but we walked away in the shoes for around £22 which we were happy with. Then ushered to a herb shop where prices were misrepresented and we spent about £100 but we did get lots of very good stuff. But best of the best that day was a huge saving on tours to the Atlas Mountains at about £18 each and a Sahara desert tour for two days at £45 each. A bargain. Official guides should cost around £20 but doubt they will tell you where to buy much cheaper tours than the hotel they work for. So advise is to pay attention and be firm but polite.

marrakech souk. very very busy souk(1000s of people) loads to see from food stalls,hand craft stalls,clothes shoes bags whatever ud look for you could find.snake charmer, birds of pray, monkeys all to see and hold for a fee of your choice which was good....think i gave one 20cents.... walking around with a young child & trying to hold onto my bag through the crowds was quiet daunting but no problems..we got a horse & buggy ride around which was great prices started at 250dh but we got him down in end to 100dh which is 10euros for 3 people...a real grt experience .... a must do in marrakech

A shopping extravaganza. As per my other reviews, the souk is a great place, lots of stalls selling lots of great things. Make sure you do not get hoodwinked into being "guided" around as you will end up in a carpet shop or Argon store. take your time, speak with the stall owners, haggle hard, and above all enjoy the experience!

good but you will suffer from dirt. the location very good easy to see & find in marrakich.i has been visited the Marrakech Souk everyday when i was in Marrakech.the good thing nice to walk.old building.great Hammams.good fresh juice.amazing hand crafts.good place to meet tourist especially in cafes.i enjoy walk in narrow streets.i enjoy see African hand craft .bad thing1-dirt around souk .2-awaful smell in the souk.3-pick pocket.4-beggars5-most of people want your money.6-some people unfriendly & aggressive with you.7-the price too too expensive for tourist you should be good in bargain.8-language big problem for me some people in some shops do not speak Arabic or English or german well they speak french or fast Arabic with french. you should go.

How to survive the souk..read here. I went to the souk 4 times in my 5 day stay. Once alone with some knowledge of Arabic, 2nd trip 2 of us, and the final trip 3 of us with one of our guys fluent in French. Now the first thing you need to know about any souk, this is not a hustle free zone and every action taken by you in a souk will generate a reaction by the locals. There are good, bad, and plain weird smells. The sights are good but there will be crowds and people trying to hustle you for money or to buy something. Survival tips: Shopping: You will need good bargaining skills, whatever they offer as a price drop it down by 50% and then negotiate and you might agree on something that works out to be a 20-40% discount. Be prepared to walk away when negotiations are slow. Have an idea and plan of what you need before going into the souk as this is not a place to browse and make up your mind.Navigation: This place is a maze and therefore download the map to your iphone or android device. Enable GPS so you know your location on this map. Set a insertion and extraction point if going in separate groups. Never pull a paper map out as that is setting you up as a target for hustlers. (worse case scenario: if lost, tired, frustrated, battery low, map on phone has failed to load, and want to find your way out, fine a bazaar staff member and negotiate a price with him, usually 50-100 dirham for a guided path to the taxi stand or main square.Food: The food market looks great and smells great, the slow cooked lamb dish is a must :) The orange juice for 4 dirham is great as well. Skip the salad and focus on cooked food.Chill Zones from the insanity: There are many roof top bars that can provide an escape from the chaos. (Le Salama is one of the great restaurants here)Attitude: Being polite here works with some people so first approach is be polite. Words like (La_Shukran, Non merci) should do the trick. Next level is the tough look into the eyes and say(Bas/khalas, assez, s'en aller), followed by Ma Salam ,au revoir). The above in Arabic and French should save you. Words are (No thanks, enough/finished/go away, goodbye).Warnings: If you fear snakes then once you hear the snake songs with flutes etc You are in the zone usually in the main square where the food stalls are. Monkeys are here as well. The trick they use here is a snake around the neck and then ask for money to take it off and you might get a photo with it or selfie if you are comfortable around it. Theft: Not a issue as the Marrakech people police this themselves and we saw a man grab a ladies bag only to have a screaming lady and a mob of 40-70 chasing him and catching him. The police got to him quite quick before the mob went crazy.Conclusion: Is it worth the trip into the souk, yes if you can handle the hustlers and hustle them yourself. You will find good deals. If the above tips scare you and lots of people around you is uncomfortable then stay in the main square instead of heading into the deep with the narrow streets etc A guide may be useful if you want to go deep into the maze.

It was so great. I was in the old souk Marrakech with my friend. It was so fun, we are shopping for the leather, we show the attraction of the cobra snake and drink very fresh juice and it was so cheap.. We also visiting the restaurant in side the souk in upstairs and we can see old souk from the top.. We eat tajine dajaj (tajine chicken), cous cous, tajine lamb. Which is traditional Moroccan food. Me and my friend was enjoying the time so much until we are so tired.. But we don't have much time because we have to travel to another city after we stay 3 days in Marrakech, we continue to agadir, Rabat, Casablanca.

Hated being hassled by Traders. If you stop to look at anything or acknowledge their 'hallos' the traders are all over you like a rash. It is impossible to wander around in peace so we ended up not buying anything and making an early exit.

7th time there, & it gets worse each time!!!. Me and my husband travel to Morrocco each year, sometimes we even have the kids with us, but this time I really have to say I had it!! Each and every one was out to rip me off! All I did was get ripped off the whole holiday. From the shopkeepers to the taxi drivers, Hammams, hotel staff, to beggars on the street, everyone took a little piece of me, and i'm done. Please do not get me wrong, I love morroccan culture & design & also happen to be a devout muslim, but I just cannot believe how people can live with themselves ripping other innocent people off all day. The souk is just about the best place to be ripped off, people just take one look at me and before I know it I've spent hundreds of dirhams. Morrocco just isn't the same anymore, not like it was when we used to visit 6-7 years ago. I look abit well off than others too, but am sad that there are absoloutely no morals left in morrocco. I stuck to the newer part of marrakech in the end, the prices are fixed there and just left tips for waiters etc. All in all, I am now looking for a new location to visit every year, where I can be me and NOT get ripped off. I have some serious searching to do!! Good luck to all!! :)

Jemaa el-Fnaa: a place to be harassed and robbed. Be careful with who you photograph because they are going to ask you money after it. Be careful with the snake charmers, the monkeys and the henna tatoos. They'll ask you money and they will be agressive with you if you don't give it to them. Never, but NEVER accept a guide!

Worth visiting for the experience...but be prepared. I loved the range of selection and the general atmosphere but i did not appreciate the constant scamming by the traders who sometimes got abit carried away trying to make a sale. You just need to be mentally prepared for certain things. Be prepared to bargain and to have your personal space invaded often. They have a habit of getting in your face, literally. if you take pictures of the performers you will most likely be asked to make a donation. Be careful with accepting "help" from locals to manoeuvre the souk. They may ask you for money once you've reached your destination. When wandering around the souk they will invite you in to visit their stalls and tell you it's ok to just have a look. However once you're in be prepared to be hassled into buying something, especially for carpet traders. Try to also visit the souk at night when the food stalls are out. The festive atmosphere and food are definitely a worthwhile experience

fun labyrinth. Shopping is a lot of fun here. Bargaining is still very much the game but for low cost items they don't charge much to beging with. People are very interesting. Walking among the souks and buying itsy bitsy things or just look around is an amazing experience.

Take a long deep breath. You're going to need to stay calm and keep composed.This place will spark a variety of emotions.For me it started with fear before I even got to the entrance. Snake charmers bewitching cobras in public view are a delight to watch. It's their friends walking around with loose snakes that scared me to death.I practically ran into the market after that.Prepare to haggle. FOR EVERYTHING (not food).I purchased Moroccan tagine spices for pennies. Bracelets for the teenagers which were about 30p each. There's a lot of counterfeit goods. With very blond hair I attracted some attention from locals. The local children follow you around trying to direct you to their uncles various stalls. They are totally harmless and we did not feel threatened in any way.After several hours perusing and observing, the Call to prayer came over the speakers. Locals dessert their stalls and go to pray. It's then deserted. Very surreal. We found a restaurant that was not exactly wonderful, but ok.Wished we waited as on exiting it seemed the square had become a delightful food market. This happens about 6pm. Stalls serving every Moroccan delicacy you can imagine. My nose was alight with the smells etc but my belly was already full to the brim.You have to see this place to believe it. It was filmed in Sex in the City 2 when Carrie met Aiden in apparently Abu Dhabi. Worth the trip.

Fun shopping- can get tiring to bargain. We had a great time checking out the Souk. It was easy to not get lost if you enter the Souk from Jemaa El Fna- thus using the Koutoubia Mosque as a point of reference to get out. Overall- great time but beware of the extremely stinky slippers near the square. I bought 5 pairs- once I got back to my hotel- I realized just how stinky they were and am unable to give them as gifts as I thought. Smell your leather before you buy!

A "Must Do" Visit. Get a guide and agree a price BEFORE you start the tour. It's a very confusing place and you'd probably get lost if you don't have the guide.Souk is in "areas" specialising in shoes in one area, carpets in another, handbags elsewhere, and so on.Wasn't too hot inside when we visited but blazing heat outside. Lots to see and to take in the atmosphere. Not really a shopper, but the ladies enjoyed it much more, glad I went.Other hotel guests told us that it was much better at night and a tremendous atmosphere. Didn't have time this trip.
Don't panic :). Enjoy strolling around the souk and don't panic about getting lost - for sure you will :) Be prepared to bargain for everything except for food.

Family visit. Really enjoyed exploring this maze of winding alleys and narrow roads packed with sellers, tourists, locals, donkeys and speeding mopeds (!) can feel high pressure to buy but a polite no thanks and keep walking usually suffices. Don't pay more than 25-30% of the asking price. We had lunch in riad jama which was very good.

Unique experience. When in Marrakech you should definitely visit the souks! They were unlike anything I had ever seen before, and were completely overwhelming (in both a good and a bad way!). If you can, go with a guide - they are a complete maze and it would be very easy to get lost and not see all the different areas if you weren't familiar with it.One thing to be aware of is the aggressiveness and insistence of the traders themselves, who will shout and pull at you to demonstrate their wares and can make you feel incredibly uncomfortable (especially as a woman). Go in with a set budget and an idea of what you want to buy and you will have a much more satisfying time. If you can, ask a local/staff from your hotel/etc. for guide prices for different items, so you know you're not being ripped off.

mind boggling. I loved the colors and the sights,i shopped alone and felt very safe. There was a lot of pleasant bargaining going on,i did find it a bit tiresome having to spend a long time before anyone would discuss prices!!! that is just me being a bad shopper! I did buy a beautiful scarf for 300 dirham but when i checked it at the hotel it had a nasty snag in it my fault for not checking.The most i spent was 400durham at one stall and my haul included 2 tubs of black soap,two scrubbies,patchouli oil and orange oil,three bags of nigella seeds,two bottles of argan oil,a few other bits. We did not haggle very much but i was happy.I woud shop there again but check my fabric purchases more carefully.

Carpets still have not arrived. I bought 3 rugs from Aux Merveilles de Marrakech two months ago. They said I would have them in 3 weeks and they would ship them by FedEx. I paid partly with CC and partly with cash. The rugs have not arrived and they do not answer their phone. Does anyone have any suggestions for me?

Go with a tour, or be prepared to get hassled hardcore. I haven't the slightest idea why the Souks are rated so highly on here, they are a dirty maze of tourist traps, pickpockets and con artists. There are only about 12 different shops copied 100s of times, all the while it's packed full of tourists that create traffic jams in the narrow pathways which in turn creates great opportunities for the local pickpockets. Every vendor will rip you off, that's just a given unless you go with a tour guide who knows the fair prices for things (often 1/3 of the "price") If you have never seen this type of market before I would say go just to experience it since we have nothing like it in the USA but I've been to the markets in Istanbul and they were sooooo much better than this pit.

Chaos is beautiful. Jemaa el Fna is not a quiet or relaxed space; it is not a logical place; and it is not a tourist attraction either. Most of all, this square... is not a square. It is a living thing; and a chaotic one as well. And that's why it is so amazing! Together with the several streets that end and start in El Fna, this is the heart of Marrakech, and where many Morrocans do business, meet, talk, or simply wonder around.Tourists just pop by, take photos, and try to get good bargains, which of course is not possible with such experienced local salesman. This is a place that will stretch your senses to new limits, while your brain will try to capture - with little success - the thounsands of rich details that unfold before you in this never-ending movie. If you spend 1 hour here, it'll feel like you're there for 4 hours; if you walkabout for 4 hours, you'll get unexpectedly exhausted as if you'd been walking all day.I guess the best way to experience El Fna is to live it up. Relax, while standing or seating there in the middle of the crowd. Let all those colours, smells, sounds, tastes and movements, grab you deep inside. Don't try to make sense of it; instead, let your emotions, spirit and imagination run free. Go with the flow. Don't resist El Fna, and you'll enjoy it more.

Interesting experience. We went to the souks with the guide and I dread to think where we would end up if were there on our own. It is a maze and the maps we had were useless and most streets just don't have any name displayed. It was an interesting experience to us and despite the fact that we got ripped off on few things, even after bargaining, we still enjoyed our time there. It's such colorful place, full of various smells like oils, spices, cooked food but also raw meat and fish to name some of not the very pleasant ones. It's definitely got a character. Shopkeepers did pester us of course, but to be honest, not as much as we expected and usually polite "No, thank you" was enough to stop them. Good advice to anyone shopping at the souks - please go to a "normal" shop with price tags (like the government one near the big square or a hypermarket Al Mazar Mall in the new town) to check the regular prices so you don't get ripped off.

Worth seeing for a variety of items sold. The souks are a maze but a good rule is to start opposite the Cafe Du France and walk straight as much as possible until you reach the metalwork section and the end of souks. There are sellers selling lots of items from spices to lamps, some fixed price (with clear signs) and most requiring haggling. Items are of variable quality - the dried fruits in particular are covered in flies which is a bit off-putting and the sellers do little to prevent this!Worth seeing and spending some money in!

Amazing place for imagination to blossom. We arrived at the souk around 4pm. The weather was beautiful. You could hear all the calling from each shop, stall and people selling on the floor. The first thing you notice is the beautiful array of colours every where your eyes touch. The aromas of different things people are selling from oranges of the juice kiosk to the leather of the bag shop. The souk is a wonderful maze of culture, food and exploration. Very child friendly and we had two prams. Good place to get fast food for kids of they don't like the morrocon cuisine. A wonderful place for all.
hectic place. Would of been ok if its was just adults but the kids were not all that impressed as it was way to intimidating for them.

A great experience, very friendly. We had to walk through the souks daily from our Riad as we visited various attractions around the medina. We did some shopping there, but not a lot, though we loved the feel of these places. Felt totally safe in there even at night, and the workers were friendly and always helpful. Wasn't as pushy as I remember Tunisian souks from years ago. It is very easy to get lost in the labyrinth of alley ways. We always headed back to the main alleyway and retraced our steps to leave, having got totally lost day one. Bought some great spices for my son who is a chef in the spices square.

Constant harassment and no respect for tourists. You really need to have your wits about you in the market. My strong advice is never make eye contact with the locals as everyone is trying to extract money from you.I lasted about 2 hours when there with wife and we were chased by snake charmers and people purporting to be guides. Ended up getting shouted at by a guide telling us to "Fxxx off" when we told him we were not interested. Realised then that you just can't make any eye contact if possible.The stalls just sell junk at overpriced markups and will always try and take you for a fool if you are from Europe. Also they get aggressive in bartering.I haven't mentioned the smell or animal cruelty I witnessed either.Suffice to say we never went back to the markets after this one visit.

Heaven of souvenirs, tapestries, jewellery, artworks and household items.. Prices are offered very high. Shop owners mostly are very aggressive and persistent but they do not get mad when we negotiated drastically like you often find in other countries.
Escorted trip to the souks. Would not have fancied it without our two guides as would probably still be there trying to find my way out now !

Find Your Hidden Treaure. Set aside a few hours of one evening to wander through the maze that is the Souks. You'll find all sorts of weird and wonderful things on sale, and bartering over the price is all part of the fun! Lovely buzzing atmosphere was you walk around, and you'll be sure to find something nice as a reminder of your time in Morocco

Wow! Souks are a bigger tourist trap than Tijuana but an experience not to be missed!. Pro:One of the bigger open markets I have ever been other than Bangkok.Amazing pictures on the sly and beautiful colorsGood, bad, and ugly everything is an eye opener and worth seeing.The souks, Medina, storks, the call to prayer anytime, the city walls, most all Moroccans and everything else about this city will be memorable and amazing!All and all research what you want to do, what you want to buy, and where you want to go and you will love it and never forget it.Get a sim card and internet before or when you get there to avoid wasted time, stress, and frustration! We got ours in Tangier for 50 Durham, not sure if good deal or not, but worth it when most streets are not marked and asking directions just makes you an even bigger target. Cons:I am a poor hagglerBought saffron that was died tree bark for my wifeBought some tea that molded shortly after purchaseKids telling you that you are in the wrong place (headed to a mosque) and really just using this ploy to take you to their commission shops, thee kids even threatened us after we told them to leave, he told us that we did not know who we were f@*king with! But none the less they are children that just need to be disciplined. Getting heckled gets oldSeeing the farmers market part and treatment of animals!Guides trying to get you to go to the stupid factories and buy rugs and antiques.
Go back in time. Lovely experience strolling through the souks. Be careful of the motorcycles coming through. You need to haggle to get a event price but this is part of the experience.

marrakech. Ive never wrote a review before but people need to know the truth.We chose marrakech for our 2 week honeymoon, the hotels are great, the riads are just as lovely as they look in the photos, but im absolutely baffled how the rest of marrakech gets any positive reviews at all......marrakech smells like bleach was never invented. If youre idea of local charm and character is holding your breath whilst running past the old city wall that the local men use as a loo and after a few years in 40degs its brutal,then book now. Outside of the riad we couldn't find anywhere to eat. When we did risk it my wife was ill for 3 days. However relief from the sticky grubby souks (cheap crap you can get in any poundshop)and restaurants came in the form of 20minute torture trying to get change following almost every transaction. I think its a local team sport because once you question your change their friends and family all surround you to"help"We have both travelled a lot and we are definately NOT fussy tourists, morrocco has given us lots if funny memories for the wrong reasons. Dont fall for the rubbish they write in the brochures.

Market of Marrakech. If you like being approached by people carrying fresh produce, eagles, monkeys or even snakes who offer cheap photo ops, creative henna drawings on your body and simple snacks then this place is for you. The market is the busiest part of Marrakech and has many things to see and do. First, this place is quite big. In the main square there are food vendors, henna artists, musicians, snake charmers, monkeys, etc. Outside of the main square are smaller alleys that lead to a more underground shopping area where there are spice, jewelry and clothing stands for you to check out. If you are a younger traveler who is travelling by yourself or with some friends on a vacation, I highly suggest staying at one of the hostel's adjacent or in the market.
