For those who travel with families, there are wonderful hotel options on the outskirts of the market. Oh and most of these hotel options are AMAZING (ate dinner one night at one of the hotels near the mosque). As for the market, if you get tired of being heckled for tips for this and that and want to get out of Marrakech, take a desert excursion. There are anywhere from 1 day - 2 weeks options for going to the beautiful Sahara desert. In my opinion this is a must if you to Morocco. For a starting point in Morocco, Marrakech is a prime location for an exotic destination. FYI beware of pick pockets and anyone who asks for a lot of dirhams (Moroccan currency) always bargain for purchases and transportation for cheaper prices.

Some great souks, some not so good. Some of the owners of the souks were great - they had a great rapport and were polite and negotiated a price with respect on both sides... even if we ended up not being able to buy anything. However, other sellers (most possible employees rather than owners) were not willing to budge from incredulous prices for items you could get cheaper in the UK - so you have to walk away and in return for that, they were not as polite as they could have been. Put us off from buying from the souks. Those shops where we got the better deals were where the footfall was not so high and so prices were more reasonable and negotiable and owners were polite and courteous (as were we) at all times! We met some lovely shop keepers!

Bric-a-Brac galore. The Souks of Marrakech offer all the best in authentic Morroccan shopping. From Rugs, to Sculptures to Tagines, Souvenirs, and many more, then pay a visit to the souks. The sales assistants are wonderful, with most of them speaking good English. If you're lucky enough to speak French then thats a bonus. The souks are also a good place along to practice your bartering skills. Authenticity to the max. One piece of advise, quite easy to get carried away, especially seeing as some shops ship abroad so beware. Lol
Got to Visit. We had a great time in the Souks.Make sure you avoid going in the heat of the day. Best time is to have dinner nearby and then have some fun bartering.

Warning - when they say they will ship your goods? they don't!. we went to Marrakech in May - we had a brilliant few days - our Riad was just wonderful (Riad El Zohor)trip to the Atlas mountains - wonderfulwe bought lots of things - Argan oil - leather bag - and we also bought 2 large lamps - metal and glass from a small factory on the edge of the Soukthey manufactured there - it was busy and noisey a small factory making the sort of lamps you see in garden centres in Uk and in france - and also in design shopswe decided to buy 2 medium sized lamps (much too big to get in our suitcase) and they said they would ship - we paid - had a receiptand you can guess the rest - no lamps - no contactour Riad has called them - visited - they give every excuse under the sun"the man who dealt with us is out""they have gone out of business"we are hundreds downand feel very very foolishI was dubious about paying by card - so gave them cashThe wonderful staff at the Riad El Zohor have tried their best for us - but 3 months laterno lamps no contactbe warned!

It's massive!. Lots and lots of leather goods. Can be intimadating. Able to barter and get some good deals. If you don't like something just be firm and say no and move on. you don't need a guide to take you through the souk. Can easily do alone. Also don't try and do all in one go. Come back as its just too big to see all in one go.

Not to be missed, haggling for presents. The one and only place that you must go to in Marrakech, just to experience the market that is spread over a maze of narrow alleys, full to the brim with, well mostly full of tat you don't really need if truth be told ... but you will find real bargains in amongst too. Be prepared to walk away and they expect you to counter their price with one half theirs, its the fun of buying in the Souk.Just DO NOT take directions from anyone under 50 ! Especially when you try to find your way back to your hotel/Riad and they tell you "that way Mosque, closed, where you want", you were warned, they will generally try to take you back around where you were heading anyway but just by another route and take a tip, or just plain send you the wrong way. Older guys are generally genuine though, but good map from hotel/Riad + google maps on your phone is a "life saver" when you want to "escape", I would not enter without them.

A maze of narrow streets, and stalls selling the same stuff.. Everyone is a 'craftsperson'. Everything is 'handmade'. Everyone gives you 'best cheapest price'.Then you walk around the corner, and it is half the price. Sadly, tourism has probably singlehandedly destroyed this place. The sole purpose is to extract as much out of tourists as possible. Often, the sellers can become quite intimidating, and aggressive in their tone. Haggling doesn't always work but when the stall or shop owner is stood between you and the door, you have to be wary of what you say. At night, the narrow streets, poor lighting, and men loitering around makes it an uneasy environment to be in. Whilst it is deemed safe, and we didnt see any violence, you would prefer to see someone in a well lit area than have silhouettes ask you whether you want certain things or not (legal as well as illegal!).
You can find everything. In Marrakech souk you can find everything from clothing to poetry, brass and silver works and their natural body care products and food.

Busy and noisy. Where to start? It's pretty safe and we didn't encounter any crime. People are generally very pleasant and will smile and joke with you. Haggling is an art form, you will lose but prices are so cheap it really doesn't matter as you will be getting a bargain regardless. Did I say it was busy? There are thousands of people here, all the time. It's very noisy as there are street dancers, acrobats, musicians, snake charmers and traders all vying for attention. One thing I would stress is that under no circumstances should you perpetuate the animal attractions by buying into them. There are monkeys on chains in nappies and baby clothes and you can pay to hold one or have your photo taken. DO NOT DO IT. It's just cruel. Same for the horse and carriages, some horses are emaciated and have scars from being whipped. Again, don't get in one. If nobody got in one or bought into it they would no longer be there. You can buy turtles and iguanas readily to 'put in your hand luggage'. These are kept in tiny crates and one I saw was trapped by its paw with its head through the bars until I told the trader to release it. It's fun, don't get me wrong and I'm sure it's a cultural thing but just don't do it. It should be illegal, it's definitely immoral. As for stalls, you can buy anything here very cheaply. The best place to be is on a rooftop so you get a good view and some breeze. It's very hot. You will be offered anything you want, mobile phones, bubble machines, sunglasses, watches etc. It's an experience you want forget and I didn't get an upset tummy at all, just take normal precautions with food, drinks and ice. People will help you with directions without wanting anything from you. Give them a chance and trust them. They are a smiley friendly people. If you are disabled it might be difficult due to the uneven terrain but most of it is flat, you could get by.

Prepare to bargain. Go in at your own peril! But stay for the feel and smell! This is the essence of a city like Marrakesh. You will inevitably get lost. You cannot be in a hurry unless you have an uncanny ability for getting out of a maze.You will find the best offers on anything from pottery, leather goods, jewellery, spices, ceramics, glassware, lamps, you name it! The souk is divided in sections by type of products but it's still chaotic. The most important thing to keep in mind is NOT to settle for the asking price. You need to bargain for everything. The more you buy, the better the prices. The asking price will also vary depending on where you come from. Word of advice: don't trust the signs to the Jemaa el Fna - you will just walk in circles! But I guess that's the point, so relax and enjoy
A must see!. This was very busy but also very fun, you do get lost but after a while you get used to it and your able navigate! Very fun but very busy!

WOW-Being prepared helps. Sundays are very busy! Lots of things, Leather bags, pottery, lamps, rugs, spices, herbal medicine......They all start with the price 250MAD which to be honest is expensive £20...if you are going to marrakech you dont want to be paying england prices for their products you want to feel like to grabbed a bargin.Dont feel bad to give them a silly price, if you convert it into pounds you will tell yourself "Oh £9/10 is great for this product but thats in england remember your in Morocco! and even if they sell it to you for £5 they are still making a profit. Our strategy was to decide a price that we wanted to pay for it and went in straight with "how much" they say 250 MAD then I say "il give you 100 MAD take it or leave it.....Put it this way my sister got a real leather bag for £8 If they think your price is silly they will not sell it to you but next door they have the same thing so you will get what you want for the price you want.Its all about money there, if you take pictures they want money, Many of mine were done in secret...if you give 10 MAD they ask for 20 (never happy) taking pictures with the monkeys and snakes will cost you ....But word of caution to animal lovers you will go home stressed seeing the monkeys on leads with dirty baby nappies on, snakes are stolen from the wild and locked up in these small drums, they are desensitised with all the pollution and eventually die or they kill them....The monkeys are also stolen from the mountains and beaten so they know how to perform!! broke my heart....Refused to take a picture or even look in amazement because its so cruel.Be prepared for children (4/5/6) years of age coming up and selling things, another thing that was heartbreaking to see, you just felt so sorry for them (just looked at them and thought of my kids).Everyone is nice to you until they get your money then they don't care (literally). Found the shops around the square cheaper than the souks and its fixed price which was nice after a day haggling....Fresh orange juice is a must.....Seeing the square at night is amazing and the souks and shops are still open so if you dont want to trudge around in the heat and do something else everything is still there at night, much cooler and pleasant.Enjoy

Enjoy it but be carefull. Its a lovely place to visit, I have been staying in Marrakech for the past two years and I have never grown tired of it but be careful as the place is always bustling with people and hence pickpockets and yes don't forget to bargain as most of the stuff is less than half of the asking price.

Marrakech visit. An amazing feast for the eyes! extremely busy - watch out for teh many mopeds, motorbikes, horse and donkey carts and cyclists - the souks are very narrow and you need your wits about you. Fascinating place - you can walk round for days. the main square is also amazing day and night with snake charmers and orange juice sellers. Get a seat in a rooftop cafe and watch it all happening from above. We never did find the tanning area but it is supposed to be amazing - albeit a bit smelly. Watch out for touts trying to show you the way to somewhere - just ignore them or firmly say no!You will want to come back

A wonderful place day and night. Bustling, busy, snake charmers, fresh orange juice stalls, herbs, spices, soaps and perfumes, clothes, woodwork, pottery, all in one square. You can sit in a bar and drink or have a bottle of cold water and watch the world go by. There are horse drawn carriages to ride in, whilst the shops sell chameleons and tortoises.

Fun and very busy place to discover!. The Souk is a very colorful place to discover.. and rediscover!A labyrinth where it is fun indeed to get lost which is the national sport in Marrakech!You will discover many aspect of the Marrakechia's life in the souk with knowing that the place is easy and relax before 4 o'clock and get very busy after..as all Morocco's people love the souk!A part of it, little advise.. don't buy first and have a look before hand to try to have a real good value of items you would desire buying!You might try when there to have a fruit juice in the "Café des épices" which is a little tiny place to discover.PS: don't follow the guys who will propose themselves to take you around as.. they will for sure try to take you shops to shops to have commission on your back!A part of it.. a magic place to discover.When you get lost.. just ask the big square "Jemma el Fna" which from you will easily know where you are!Enjoy this fine moments here!Cheers, Oliver.

medieval. Again, disappointed after guide book reviews. Smelly. Dirty, harrassed constantly to buy food (wasn't in the mood for sheep's head etc.) VERY busy. Selling EVERYTHING. Soul seemed to be missing.

Bargain bargain and bargain some more.. This souk is really big and you and get sucked in by all thats available on sale. Very important is that you bargain. Its fun but also you will most likely get what you want for close to the "true price". There is lots on offer but check for quality before you buy.

Noisey but fun. The souk is as you'd expect it to be, full of hustle and bustle, and the sights, sounds and smells of Morocco. We found the shop keepers friendly and not too aggressive in their selling technique. We'd visited other places in North Africa and found nodes to be very persistent, this certainly is not the case in Marrakech. It's very easy to by disoriented while wandering around the Souk, but there are plenty of signs redirecting you back to the big square. Once back there you do have to run the gauntlet of snake charmers and Berbers all wanting to relieve you of your money in return for a photograph. The central cafe affords great views over the square and is a great place to people watch. Overall a great place to visit either day or night.

Shopping!!!!!. What an experience. It was everything and more of what we expected. The sellers are amusing and can have a joke, bargains to be had although I have to admit I got muddled one day and paid over the odds but way cheaper than in uk never the less!
Smelly. Too busy and full of motor bikes. Vendors are just there to cheat you. Better to go to Ensemble Artisan.

beautiful colors. i loved the colors the crowd
the ambiance, the local food but we were happy to be back at our hotel.
Exactly as you would expect. Real genuine fake!! That's what they say and that's what it sells. Must barter though, it's good fun

Warning scam warning. I have already written a favourable review for the Souks however I wish to post a warning to travelers. Their is a scam amongst some touts who want to take u for a tour of the tannery we experienced this yesterday the chap told us he worked their and was on his way to work and would be delighted to show us the way..about 10 mins in I became suspicious and declined any further help, he became agitated and demanded a gift I pointed out that he offered his help and declined to pay this set him of so I gave him 20 dirham which up set him even more he demanded 200 so I promptly walked of heading to the busiest street I could see. That night we heard of several similar experiences from the other guests at the Riad where we were staying. One couple were lead to a quieter area and foreably split up the husband was driven to the local ATM and told if he didn't pay 400 dirham he would not be taken back to his wife..fortunately it all worked out .. We believe that this is only a small element most people we have met have been no problem. However we were approached this morning and offered a tour of the tannery again we politely but firmly declined and that was that.. Please don't let this put u off just be careful and avoid quite areas with no foot traffic
A Mix of Trash & Treasure. Lots to choose from here. Just be sure you know what you are buying and what you really want to pay.

Not for the light hearted. Go with an aim to either buy or not buy, cause you can't be half-hearted with decisions with the shop owners, they're experts at sniffing out "green" tourists and will not hesitate to start at a cut throat price. Be vigilant, spot what you like, be respectful with the bargaining and leave happy - always with a smile! Some of these shop owners are genuinely lovely people, most of them have probably had bad experiences with snobby tourists so are a bit moody. Don't try to take pictures of anything without asking first, or just do it in stealth. Lots of hidden alleyways with beautiful lighting in the day and be careful when wandering in the night, some of the gates get locked.

This is Marrakech. Not that many people will actually read this review due to the vast number which are uploaded daily, but here are some musings... This place defines Marrakech. From the tanneries which produce leather used in the bags sold here, to the families in the Atlas Mountains making wooden camels for sale around the Djemma el-Fna, the souks are the epicentre of Marrakechi life.You can buy practically anything here, from motorcycles to carpets, cheap souvenirs (lamps and tagines) to spices and Moroccan dress. Haggling is a must -- inspect the quality and point out any defects (use your mobile phone light to illuminate the item properly -- shops have deliberate subjective lighting), using multi-buy discounts, 'student discounts', 'Ramadan discounts' (where applicable) etc. to get your price. If the seller is really hesitant on a price you're coming close to what the real value should be, but push as low as you can. Don't have mercy. These guys are often really nice but they buy the gear for a pittance and can make a profit on relatively low-value sales. You will naturally be 'hassled' (as some have called it) when walking through the souks -- if you aren't interested just ignore them or say 'non, merci' -- they will take notice and leave you alone. Not their fault, they just want money and need to survive. They certainly work harder for their sale than many Western shopkeepers! Also, make sure the item you get wrapped up is the item you actually chose (sometimes they can swap items behind your back to give you a cheaper/damaged alternative). Always ask for a bag and wrapping service -- it should be free (if not, haggle to get it free!). Some sellers make the goods themselves (in the really deep parts of the souks (again, the deeper you go in, the better it gets)) but most don't. Many sellers purchase used tools and wood shavings to put on their stand so it looks like they make the products themselves -- but its unlikely. Sometimes you can pay more for the theatre of buying (I love it, personally!) but you don't need to. Watch out for motorbikes (walk on the right) and don't touch any Moroccan women -- that's a no no! Also, keep cash secure and if you're carrying a mobile phone, put it in your pocket and shove your hand in there so no one can walk past and pull it out. Don't accept the services of any souk guides -- they won't be free and will take you to their friends' stalls (where they get commission) and its unlikely you want to spend hours looking at carpets all day (wasting sellers' time can also result in aggressiveness, as it would do in Europe!) which will usually cost hundreds of pounds and aren't British Airways- or Royal Air Maroc-friendly. You wouldn't have a guide to go shopping in the UK, so don't take one here. They will end up spoiling your day with high prices (you can't haggle with shopkeepers if a guide brings you somewhere because the seller will know that he has to pay commission to the guide and will hike up prices even more). If you're lost, just ask a shopkeeper (not someone waiting around outside shops) -- the older, the better. You will find your way back to the Djemaa el-Fna eventually. No one dies in the souks...Enjoy the souks and go with an open mind. Haggling and trying to get the most money is part of their culture and it's something I love about Morocco. If you want shopping to be the same as it is in Europe, don't go on holiday to Africa! Alternatively, if you just can't handle the haggle, head to Ensemble Artisanal -- the Marrakechi version of a traditional department store. It's government-sponsored, has fixed prices where the producer gets paid directly, sells goods of a (generally) far higher quality (and those which are more expensive than the souks), and can be found opposite the Cyber Parc.

Watch out for the scooters. Much the same as our review on the square, like most markets hundreds of stalls selling the same thing, but certainly worth a visit. Just about any street of of the market will have plenty to sell but most will be no different than what u find in the northern part of the square. The souk is worth a visit we found orientating ourselves by the cafe de France helped. Any thing north of the market is a souk we headed for the Museum of Marrakech this takes u through the heart of the souks. In general u will be overloaded with the shear magnitude and color of this place. As with many markets u will be approached to buy things if u r not interested be polite but firm and watch out for locals on scooters.

Awful. Do not venture into the Souks area unless you know where your going as everyone tries to send you the WRONG way and then you end up lost at their "tannery". Do not follow anyone. They bring you to their own shops and demand money. You will get hassled non-stopI had someone telling me the square was down one alleyway and yet I knew for a fact it was the other direction. They even scrubbed off the directions on the signs so tourists will get lost! This place is very stressful

Enchanting, exciting and a must see!. To visit this market is the best experience one could have in Marrakech. It is a full on mesmerizing and captures the essence of Morocco. Tasting the delicious food, smelling the spices wafting through the air and witnessing the captivating scenes is beyond anything found anywhere else. Be sure to savor every element of the sensory moment.

An authentic experience. A must do if you go to Marrakech, the souks have a real character all of their own. The colours and smells, the winding little alleys, stopping to haggle here and there, and the evidently very nice and genuine locals make this a fantastic experience.In my view this place genuinely beats the Cairo markets and the new market area of Kolkata because it remains good humoured and is not aggressive in any way. Just be yourself, do not show off or flaunt your European wealth, and remain polite and you will enjoy this place.

Two visits and.... I've been twice, my wife three times, and between us we still have not found the false teeth stall. A great place to walk about and a photographers dream, and challenge. A must see and do - been in many Souks and this is one of the best.

No Marrakesh visit without a trip to the souks. Take your time, don't act like a tourist, go with a map and a plan an bargain like there's no tomorrow. The souks of Marrakesh are an institution, which one has to see and experience.

Marrakech souks (market) are amazing. The souks are amazing. A huge market with many different sections e.g. food, plants, metal work, leather work, clothes etc etc.The people are very friendly and many speak French and also some English.Prices are good and you are expected to barter.We did not get hassled.We slowly got to know our way round and recognised certain things. Just wonder and you will discover all the side parts with specialist items and people making things in metal or leather etc. If you get lost, just ask the direction to the big square and you will be helped.In one little square, there were herbalists and flowers. Also cages with chameleons which you could pick up for a photo (small charge) and tortoises.We went through early one morning and you can then see that this is actually a maze of streets with some roofing to keep out the sun rather than an indoor market.
Atmospheric. Crazy eating in the middle of madness but very fun fast decent food tone of atmosphere watching waiters flying around we went to number 1 out of I think 40

Not too much hassling. Found the Souk very interesting with the various items for sale. Couldn't believe it when I saw previously used false teeth on sale !! There was a lot of the same on the many stalls and although there was a lot of competition we were not hassled too much. It would be easy to get carried away but there is a lot of tat so best not to buy on impulse.
Souk Fun. A lot of variety and like stepping back in time. so photogenic and I found the bartering a lot of fun.

Not lost? You are not in the Souk!. When you first get there, at the edge of the square you approach with the confidence of a well seasoned traveller.After 10 minutes you know that this experince is going to be different. If you have issues about not being wanted, go here because evry stall holder is vying for your busiess.AS you penetrate deeper, watching which road (this is a road??) you take , you realise that you actually dont know you way back to the square.Howver, evryone will point you there, but make sure nobody takes you there as you will be expect to pay (even a small boy with such an innocent face cost us a few diiramar)However, it is a wonderful experince with spices, copper work, shoes etc. etc. and well worth the adventure, particularly if you go in a few times and learn you way around.

Interesting and vibrant. We visited on an organised tour from our hotel, led by an English speaking guide. I really enjoyed this way of exploring the souks. If we had been alone I don't think we'd have gone so deep for fear of getting lost. Having the guide meant we saw all the souks had to offer, including going inside various buildings such as a public bakery and herbalist. The souks were vibrant and interesting. Our visit was in the day during Ramadan, so whilst the stalls had the owners present there were few shoppers - this meant we were free to roam around and weren't hassled at all.I wouldn't rush to return, but I'm really glad we visited and highly recommend a trip to the Souks for anyone's first time in Marrakech.

An experience everyone should try. I cannot describe the assault on your senses that you will experience in the souks, the best advice I can give is don't be uptight about the dealers in there and treat it all very light hearted and have a joke with them all, haggle hard and you will be well received, Good Luck!

An experience!!. V Good only for the experience...would we go back? Probably not thanks! Too much hassle to either stop and look or 'come into my shop' or ' want you want to buy'? It does get a bit much when you keep getting pestered!

Once is enough. You need to go just for the experience but the people are rude and smelly, the streets are vile, the shop owners do not haggle but rather just get offended and the tour guides are all in alliance to rip you off!! Plus pee before you go because the loo is a hole in the ground which will cost you at least 20 drh to use!!However go just for the experience because it truly is an eye opener!!

HASSLE... if you can handle the hassle its fine, but ya get no peace, i like to go and look and have a haggle all part of the fun, well worth a look,some of the people very rude if ya dont want there goods, but hey cant buy all that tat, have fun enjoy its must go see

Sense of Humour Essential. You WILL get lost, but keep a sense of humour as far as possible. And when you notice the shops turning to residential properties or shops selling products for a local market it's probably best to retrace your steps, not keep walking for twenty minutes as we did. Enquiring of stall holders "La Place?" seemed to get us back on track. A smile goes a long way in the Souk and if you relax then the stall holders will engage in a bit of banter which makes for a great experience. My daughter could have been married off many times over! We bought curtain tassles/tie-backs for 50 dirhams a pair and lots of incredible fossils including some made into gorgeous jewellery, always at less than half the initial asking price. The best deals are made when you walk away, and if they don't chase after you then there will be another stall selling the same thing further on, so try again. The further you go, the cheaper it gets.

Explore and Understand The Culture. This Souk or Souq is of average size much smaller than the one in Fez but larger than Casablanca's. The one in Fez is the biggest and we think the best but the one in Marrakech is much easier to get around as you can get lost very easy in Fez. Remember this is not going to be like your home town market, nor the open markets in France or Italy, this is a very different culture, so explore and understand. It is smelly, dirty, has beggar's, lots of animals and shops. We walked from our hotel past the Mosque to the open market and then strolled through the side streets. Did some shopping, bought some lamps and shoes for decoration in our home. Had a good afternoon exploring then went back to our hotel.
Tiem to barter!. Good place to practice those bartering skills & the Marrakish's expect you to barter, so go 'low'. Dislikes - very very busy, hectic & chaotic.
Once a souk, always a souk. Stay focused on what you want and what you're willing to pay and know that the sellers here have several centuries of experience...!

Jemaa el fan, exciting. This place blew me away, the sights, sounds, smells. It's constantly busy, you do need to hold your nerves, haggle, ne brave. Day and night it's a wonderful fascinating place to be. If you are brave, wander off the beaten track and really explore. Some great places to eat and the food stalls are so cheap and it's tasty stuff. Be prepared to be hassled by people trying to sell you stuff, act confident and you'll be fine. It's a very colourful place and well worth visiting.

animal cruelty and culture.. awful animal cruelty and prepare yourselves to be conned and hassled. i cant say this was a 'great' experience but if you can separate yourself from actually seeing whats going on, there are plenty of amazing bargains and beautiful things to be bought. as with many cities you need your wits about you at ALL times! the commonly used sales technique has a long way to go! - dont go at the hottest part of the day. dont buy water from anyone other than a restaurant.

Wow a explosion on your senses. Don't be worried about being bullied into buying things. We found everybody very relaxed about bartering. Just remember to keep your humour and walk away if you can't agree. Loved it.

Get lost and bargain hard!. The Souks are so much fun. Beware of the saying "looking is for free" cos once you are in their shop you get strongly encourgaed to buy something. Be polite when you do not want to buy something. Tip: don't tell them it's your first time to Marrakech!
market market. Just let it go and get lost in the alleys of souks. You can spend hours in there just walking around (we managed to do like 15km each day!!). It is a must be/see in Marrakech

Fascinating. Souks are a must but be prepared to run the gauntlet of very enthusiastic sellers and definately haggle for the best prices. Take time to wander though the vast array and variety of stalls selling shoes, wooden items, pottery , clothes etc .. The variety of what you will see, smell , hear is up describable.. From medieval ironworks , literally fires on the street and workmen bashing out red/ white hot metal at their feet, to the smell of glues, paints, dyes in the leather souk , for the expertise of the wood turners . Absolutely incredible

Great place to wander. But, like anywhere, the more you look and act like a tourist, the more you will be treated like a tourist.We had a great couple of days just wandering the streets and enjoying the experience. Remember to treat the people you see with respect. If you want to photograph them, seek permission and pay the price. Don't complain.The most amazing orange juice I have ever tasted!

Be careful & be prepared to be ripped off!. The souks are a large catacomb of small stalls, shop and "boutiques". The souks offers a large range of Moroccan souvenirs. They are absolutely beautiful and great to visit once. Anymore than once or twice and it can get irritating. The souks range from things like leather bags, shisha's, scarves, tea sets, knives, jewelry, clothing and tangines. It's absolutely massive as well. Every stall you walk past will have someone trying to drag you into their shop. For some, no thank you is not enough just push past them and keep going. Some can be pretty grabby and in your face. Just keep telling them no thank you. Every single one will tell you that it's the best quality, "its not from china", and for you they will do the best price. Depending on how busy it is will depend on the price. They will look at how you are dressed and decide a price. They are there to rip you off. We went into one stall to get four scarves and they tried to charge us 1060 dirham. Another stall tried to charge us 900 dirham for one scarf. A local would pay about 15 (if that). They will tell you it's cashmere or real silk. ITS NOT TRUE. The majority is fake and cheaper versions. They will tell you their jewelery, teapots and other metal based products are real silver. It's not. It's pressed metal. If you are finding they are charging you over the odds and won't come down low enough for you just go to the cafflour store (about 30 minutes from the medina) it's got a lot better quality stuff at a much lower price. For example the teapots in the souks will be approx 300 - 600 dirham for a large one. In the store you will get it for over half that. However, the store is fixed priced and you may come across a stall that is willing to do it cheaper. It's also one that you can use rather than just being for display. If they tell you that you can use them - they cant. In the souks the majority of the teapots are for display only. There job is to rip you off and they will say anything to make a sale. However, remember, that you don't half to buy anything you don't want to buy. It's a great one of experience, however, it can be a little much. I would avoid foods and spices there too.

Not as intimadating as you might think. We've all heard tales of unwary travellers being waylaid by aggressive traders in these souks, but this was not like that at all. Yes, people tried to sell you stuff, but they've got to make a living. Generally you can walk through, gazing here and there, without being hastled too much. It's a working city, after all, not a tourist venue, so people are very business-like. However, they can spot when you're interested in something, without looking up - amazing powers of observation.The diffent souke specialise in different things, whether it's lights, leather-work or wool. Just, watch out for 'the waiter from your riad' ... yes, that old chestnut is till doing the rounds.

fascinating!. There are numerous souks within the Medina of Marrakesh, and as many reviewers have commented, it is extremely easy to get lost in this labyrinth of a place.My advice is either go with a official guide or ask store owners (esp the ones who are just getting on with their lives and not hassling you to go to their shop). You should take caution when people (esp younger teens) volunteer you the direction to a landmark or offer to take you there. Out of experience, they may be leading you to somewhere like the tannery where you then get hassled to pay, or just straight out ask for money after taking you to your destination. Obviously not all people have this sort of motifs but just be aware who you are getting directions from. It is a busy place and there are absolutely tons to see and buy there, the alleyways also produce some great photos day and night. It is a must visit when in Marrakesh.

Tiring .. You must visit the souks for the experience, but people will be approaching you all the while to sell you stuff or guide you. It's OK at first but gets tiring if you are just trying to browse and enjoy the experience.

Watch out for the mopeds....... One of the highlights of our visit. Very busy , beware down the side streets mopeds suddenly appear from nowhere !! Flat shoes are a must as the streets are very uneven . Don't forget to haggle and haggle hard.....got called a "double Berber" so knew I had a great bargain . Be adventurous and eat there . Absolutely delicious.

An experience... Firstly, I would say that this place is amazing and is a must-visit. That said, be prepared! Like other reviewers, we got a variety of basically abuse, from unwanted handgrabbers (to give you a henna tattoo for 'free'), to much worse.. Some of the men will spit at, touch and grope the women, then run off. It happened several times in the space of a couple of hours. We were also called names and sworn at. We were covered up so it was not to do with the way we were dressed. We didn't really feel unsafe but we didn't feel comfortable! Most of the vendors need to be ignored or they will do anything to get you to look at their wares, so keep walking unless you do want to look then don't forget to haggle! We got some good bargains and the sights, sounds and smells are fantastic but just be aware that you may get treated as we were just for being female. I think that the travel reps should warn you but ours didn't so thought I would post it on here. I should end by saying 90% of the traders were lovely, it is mainly the local men..

Like nowhere on earth. This is a must see place, and is mad and crazy but utterly wonderful. The souks are amazing and full of tiny stores, narrow alleys and you will get lost. So much inside you won't know where to start. Went on a guided tour first to give us some confidence on walking around later on our own. it's a maze but you will eventually get out! The square is full of noise snake charmers and lovely smells colour and drama. Will go aback again and haggle some more, we got a lovely tagine for about £6!!

The souks are good but the vendors are little devils. The souks are not for everyone. I recommend only visiting for an hour or so, because it's easy to get tired of it. The vendors really just want you to buy their product, so whatever price they give you, offer 75% lower and you'll settle somewhere at 30-40% of the original price. If you don't really, really want to buy something don't offer a price. This will infuriate them and they may kick you out of their stall. Be completely sure that you want to buy something before starting to haggle but don't have your heart set on it if you aren't willing to hand out the cash. If you ask how much somethings costs they'll most likely say "how much do you want to pay?" Don't answer this. It's a trap. Make them tell you their price and if it's way too high, walk away. Don't even try to bargain.

this is how you picture Marrakech. Hundreds of tiny stores filled with all kind of goods and unique Marrakech atmosphere. Don`t try to find your way through narrow streets, just relax, enjoy and somehow you`ll always come back to Jemaa el Fnaa square.

Crazy places. The souks are another unique part of Marrakech, Go and absorb the colour and atmosphere and try your hand at haggling. The majority of stuff on offer is tourist quality but look hard enough and you will find some hidden gems.
Amazing. Get lost in the alleys and shop a lot... do not forgett to haggle!! closing at 40-25% of the price. Did not like the aps in cage at the square.

Plan your trip. The biggest culture shock, this can be a bit overwhelming. My tips:1) do you actually want the item (or is it "holiday purchase")?2) how much will you pay (go to centre artisanal to assess fixed rate prices)?3) if you can't get the price you want WALK AWAY4) only engage if you are interested. Which essentially puts browsing off the menu!Traders can be aggressive, either hustling you into their shop or shouting at you. Try not to get flustered or upset. Do not worry about walking away. They all sell the same things anyway!Also everyone tries to direct you out towards the main square. If you want to wander just ignore them. Most are looking for money/misdirecting you to their shop - or their uncles/cousins/brothers in law.... We assessed prices. Drew up what we wanted to buy then spent one morning shopping. Otherwise "la shokran" (no thanks) works a treat. Good luck

Busy but very cultural. My boyfriend and I visited the souk on our first day. You can find some good bargains there if you are willing to haggle. I got a scarf from 950 dirham down to 150 dirham. The shopkeeper was not very happy but we got a good bargain. However, I did not like to get hassle by so many shopkeepers and random guides, trying to lead you down to alleyways. The worst was that you are sharing the tiny alley ways with mopeds, bikes and occasionally cars. I think I spent more times avoiding bikes rather than looking at stores.

Hold on to your wallet!. Very busy during the day and evening and lots of touts trying to take you to their brother's shop or a tannery tour. Avoid these guys!! Talk to the traders calmly and quietly and get yourself a deal. Just remember you have to fit it all into your suitcase!!!

Aggressive locals. Although the souks have beautiful products to sell that were obviously skilfully crafted the selling techniques are vile. I was dragged away from my boyfriend who couldn't find me and drawn on without asking for it and once he found me they demanded he paid for defiling my hand. They were super aggressive and shouted abuse at us if we ignored them like 'chavs' and 'morons'. All in all the unpleasant and aggressive locals made what should have been a nice experience stressful and a little scary

Jemaa el Fna Square and Souk. Fabulous place to visit, like Fes easy to get lost but if you find a visible landmark and make it your 'base' it gets easier. The square towards sunset is worth watching from a nearby upstairs café as it morphs from a busy, snake charming center of all things 'Marrakesh' to an awe-inspiring food fest - with stall holders selling everything from roasting chickens to pots of snails - very photo-worthy. The souk itself is full of stallholders selling all types of wares - clothing, household goods, sweets, fresh food and cooked food, leather goods etc. and expect a good fair haggle - our experience was positive and enjoyed talking to the stall holders. A place where you can easily spend the whole day and evening.

Don't be scared-Enjoy!. Go, get lost, enjoy the friendly assault of the local culture-that's what you went for! Don't part with your cash if you don't want to - nobody will make you but they will enjoy trying- so you should enjoy it too. So exciting and exhilirating! Loved the souks!
Feast for the eyes!. This place is truly unique, a real world of markets to explore! It is a real sensory experience, a feast for the eyes! We regret not having the opportunity to see it at night!

Unique, extensive and smelly - a good experience though!. Marrakech Souk takes you back hundreds of years in the spate of 4 hours. The market is the biggest I have ever experienced and covers just about every purchasable commodity known to man from leather products to metalware, from home produce to fabrics the choice is endless. This is a showcase of how the Moroccan culture existed so many years ago when every household exhibited its wares for sale, be they lush carpets, or a few tomatoes!The dimly lit alleyways contain a multitude of sellers and their products, organised thankfully for the tourists into sections - so you get all the clothing shops in one area, metal goods in another, very convenient, but that is the only tidy element of the whole market. What hits you first is the smell, be it over ripe vegetables, freshly tanned leather or the local population who do not seem to have taken a shower for months! Next are the infernal motorbikes that want to occupy the same space as pedestrians - their presence is an intrusion into an otherwise pleasant walk back into history.So after the punishing, sickly aromas and nightmare incidents with the motorbikes your next obstacle are the shifty eyed traders, who latch upon any eye to eye contact, or reason to start a conversation within an microsecond of you noticing them - they have been eying you up since you turned into the alleyway!If you are wanting a product and are prepared to haggle start very, very low and enjoy the fun. If you are not wanting to haggle don't even bother to appear interested as the traders will not let you go without showing you their entire shop - a painful experience!Next - don't get lost. The place is massive and can make you uneasy when you drift into areas where there are few tourists. Begging is rife and so is the constant offers to guide you for money. My advice is use one of the official guides - for a modest fee he will lead you where you want to go and explain the background to each section and most importantly the history of the place. He will also advise on prices and how to haggle - he will even do it for you if you ask. Of course he will introduce you to his friends and backers, but at least there is an element of security attached.

Souks. visited the souks during my first visit to Marrakech, found them slightly overwhelming to start with as im not used to so many people in a confined space. however I very quickly adapted and thoroughly enjoyed the sights, sounds, smells and the fun of bartering. my tip go further into the souks for the real bargains!!

Lost !. I guarantee that you will get lost in the labyrinth of the Souk. There's no way you can find your way, no signs, no street names, nada. Maps are confusing. Anyway you can find everything in the Souk, and if you don't they will find it for you at a "special price"

Great day out. We caught the courtesy coach from the hotel.Got dropped off in the main square.The sights and sounds were amazing. However the smell wasn't ha ha. I think someone has had a word with the local traders as they weren't as pushy as on a previous visit. Be prepared to haggle and if you buy something you want at a price your happy with then you've got a bargain.we went in the morning before it got too hot. Really worth a visit.

Follow the green signs!. Brilliant place. Always make sure you haggle them right down. Please don't take the offers of a tour, we heard so many horror stories of people being led to the middle of nowhere and then having to pay the 'guide' to get back. We had a lot of problems with people telling us that we were going the wrong way and that the path we were going down was closed. This is a lie! If you look up on the buildings, there are some official signs to guide you on your way. If you follow these, you will be fine. Oh and wear shoes that cover your feet.... Enjoy it for what it is!

three years on!!!!!!. it is now three years since we went to Morocco but the memories are still as fresh as yesterday , evenif we never manage to go back we will never forget the wonderful sights ,sounds and even the wonderful smells that emit from the souks and markets. Over and above that we found that a smile to the locals and a polite word even if it was " no thanks" went a long way . I would not hesitate to recommend this holiday to anyone.

THE RIGHT PLACE TO EXPERIENCE SOUNDS, SIGHTS and SMELLS. If you have never been to an arabian, turkish or eastern bazar-then this place will be a lifetime experience!There are hundreds of tiny shops- most things are handmade -often on the spot.If very cheap then it is probably from China!!Dont go without a guide the first couple of times or you might get so many bad experiences that you dont explore these very interresting bazars.This to avoid beeing conned in all sorts of ways-from paying for picturetaking to demands for all sorts of fictive jobs for you.They will demand money for even following behind you when you have said no !A guide will be well able to make them stay away and will also mske sure you actually get out again !The shopkeepers love bartering and so should you too.Start at about 25% of asking price(if they say 400 then you say 100)- but remember YOU HAVE BOUGHT THE ITEM IF THE SELLER AGREES TO YOUR OFFER !!)Hang on until you get it at half price-which they still get a good profit on.If they say no just smile and walk on! In 90% of cases they will come after you with a better offerKeep smiling both to them and yourself and throw yourself into this fantastic experience of sounds, sights, smells and emotions!GOOD LUCK!

Incredible sights, sounds and smells. We visited the souks in the afternoon after several other sights earlier in the day. It was during a lull as we had noticed that due to the heat and Ramadan fasting, people are very tired and lacking energy during this time of the day. Regardless of this fact, many artisans were still working in their workshops that are the size of closets. We passed metal workers, tin bangers, leather workers and fabric/wool dyers.We visited a man who carves wood on a manual lathe that he turns with his feet. He was amazing and we purchased wooden keepsakes including a hand carved domino set.We also visited a huge shop that was filled to the brim with Berber crafts. This included vases, mirrors, lanterns, bowls, jewellery, etc. The shop was two floors and things were piled on top of each other, hung on every inch of the walls and most of the floor. Our last stop was to meet a man who explained the process for dying wool and silk. He showed us brilliant colours from saffron, poppies, indigo, lavender and more. The people were friendly and yes sometimes bordering pushy. But we felt their passion for their crafts and didn't mind supporting them with purchases during their slow period. The souks can be overwhelming given the sheer number of booths, stalls with unknown food items and the many people. But if you want to mingle with the locals and see all that the craftsmen have to offer it is certainly worth experiencing.

Must visit. You can not visit marrakech without going to the souks there is miles of stalls and shops selling all and everything where you can barter to your hearts content a bargain is Definately to be had. The souks are covered over so you can get a rest from the hot sun while shopping. The people are so friendly and helpful and will help you if you get lost which is very likely! A must visit.
Marrakesh souks. If you like Arabic/middle eastern culture and experiences this maze of souks is tremendous but I stronly recommend gattin a guide or you might never be found

Too many similar stalls selling the same stuff .. No originality.. Mostly from China!!. Not really my scene .. As I look for individuality .. Not too much pestering tho which is good..interesting to do .. Went with a guide which helped to find way around

Busy busy busy. The souk was very easy to buy in but very hard to get out of as everything looks the same, so you can be walking round for ages and end up in the same place.The bartering is great fun and most of the stallholders expect it, but have a price in your mind and stick to it, they will come down as long as you are friendly, and you feel great yourself when you think you have a bargain !!!

Loved it but go it alone!. LOVED the souks-don't go with a tour guide, go it alone (or as a group) and always tried to know it down 3/4 from what they're asking (for example if the the price is 100, go for about 20-30).

Totally smashing. So exactly what I expected to see. Authentic and crowded! With a marvelous guide (French speaking) tour guide Yousseff ( Sakhaline for him, he used to be a policeman, word at the Club Med, everyone knows him. See if he speaks English, his knowledge and sense of humour are tremendous.

Fun !. Only word I can use, it was great fun - you have to throw yourself into it and have a great time, get lost in the souk and you will have a wonderful experience , just don't believe people when they say their items are individually made as each stall stocks the same items !At lot less aggressive then souks in Tunisia.

Love it. Love love love to just walk around for hours and hoursIf you are sensitive to sellers who continually cries out for your attention, this is not the place for you. Do not forget to bargain really hard, but with a big smile! Happy shopping
Get lost and enjoy. The souk of Marrakesh is a great place to spend some hours. Very charming You can get anything but bargaining is hard. Good fun for the whole family.

wow. Took my breath away, went at night. Becareful, dont let them talk you into anything, The guy with the monkey on the chain put it on my daughters shoulder, she broke down being an animal lover and he wanted money for it, my husband says I growled at him like the monkey but the guy backed off at least. So stand your ground, but the over all experience is something else. the smells, sights and general atmossphere is awesome, If you want to eat there make sure the locals frequent the stall as well but well worth it. Definately one not to be missed. If you get to go be with a guide who use well kept horses and carts to get you there to add to the experience.

Interesting to walk around - avoid the camel leather handbags. Great little day trip to walk around the market with snake tamers and good food all around... Do not make the same old age mistake we did of buying camel leather handbags - THEY STINK!!!

Something for everyone. Fun cultural experience and a great time. Beware of con men who pretend you met them before and only want to sell to you, others will offer help with directions, but only take you to their family store, and if you take a picture expect them to want you to pay. That said there is lots to see, some nice restaurants, great entertainment such as snake charmers, jugglers, and acrobats, and it is walking distance to several historical sites.
Great sights and smells. We took a fee walks in this souk . If you cannot get to FES this will be a wonderful second choice. If you can, save your shopping for Fes.
Interesting. It was a lovely exotic place. Quite enjoyed the shopping experience. We had a guide that helped shield us from many sales people.

great guide in Morocco. We travelled with our two 30+ year old sons and their wives to Morocco. (I put friends as it fits the category more than the two family choices!) Youssef Khalfaoui arranged the whole troip and it was fantastic. Especially our guide/driver Hicham who was with us for 10 days. Hicham was very knowledgeable and every night either drove us or walked us to our restaurants that Youssef had pre-arranged. Great, comfortable large vehicle- seats 16+. Highly recommend using Yousseff and Hicham when you go to Morocco.

Shoppers paradise. Loved the leather goods , the perfumes and the oils . Every corner you turned you entered a different souk , chicken souk, art souk , shoe souk , perfume souk , Berber souk , magic men souk , loved loved it .

Outrageously entertaining. It's difficult to offer a visitor's review of a place where people conduct their business and get their livelihood, and have for hundreds of years. It feels somehow crass. However, the souks are outrageously entertaining for folks who have never seen such a place, and should be experienced at least once in a lifetime. You can find everything and anything there, and a lot of it is one of a kind, handmade, culturally unique stuff. Use a few words of French and you will find it is met with polite replies. Expect to be cajoled, invited in for tea, bantered with and teased....and enjoy each and every moment of this amazing experience!

interesting to walk through and shop. Stay out of the way of motorcycles and donkeys! Some good deals if you are comfortable bargaining. You can buy almost anything in the souk. If you're not in the mood to buy, you can walk around comfortably and not be hassled.

Animal Cruelty. Before you go to Marrakech please be aware that they do not hide their cruelty to animals. It is a smelly, very hot, dirty place and if you are an animal lover PLEASE DO NOT GO. I have nothing else to say about the Marrakech only that I would never go back.

An experience of two halves. The buildings and the streets were everything I expected them to be.Tiny intertwining streets filled with vendors plying their wares. That was the fun part and the haggling,it's always worth walking away if your offer is not accepted as the vendor will generally accept the offer then. Never pay more than you think something is worth. A lot of the same types of products, i.e. herbs and spices and perfume/oil products, which tends to get a little boring after a while. Many of the vendors were polite and took no for an answer however a few do get very rude and offensive and the permanent hassling does get very waring. If you can deal with all of that there are some bargains to be had.

Must visit. If you do not visit the souk, then you have wasted your visit to Marrakech! Be prepared to haggle, and not be afraid to walk away if the prices are higher than you want to pay. You will probably get lost in the many alleys, but all part of the fun.

fun shopping. we felt very safe and the vendors were ALL very nice and helpful. I TWICE gave a vendor euros by accident and both times they were given back to me. It was good to haggle with the vendors but in a nice way.

EasyTo get lost. IF you like a market you'll love the souk. Lots of haggling will get you a deal. Leather goods are good quality. The old streets are amazing and well worth the effort to look around. Local crafts are in abundance.

Atmospheric. but be prepared to barter hard... we were on our way to the ATM to withdraw cash and enquired the price of a painted plate (so we could judge how much to withdraw - dirhams cannot be exported from Morocco). It's price dropped from 350 to 200 once the vendor realised we really were planning to go away and not just haggling! Result!Also be prepared for a constant stream of comments and entreaties to visit their shop and check out the goods ....

A true Marrakech experience. We had never been to Morroco before and to be honest I was a bit leery about the souks. We stayed at a Riad and booked a half day tour of the medina. He was able to tell us where to go and he helped us barter. It seemed like what the shopkeeper originally offered was 1/2 what the price should be. Be prepared to state your price, ask for the lowest price and if not what you want walk away. Usually, the person will give you the price. There are sections in the souks for fruits and vegetables, clothing, spices, wooden items, lanterns and restaurants. The people here work hard and recycle or reuse all the time. Scooters race through the souks so always walk close to the wall on the right side. The souks are truly the heartbeat of Morocco. The smells, sights, and sounds are so unique. I would advise hiring a guide for half day and he will help you with landmarks to maneuver through the souks. When I go home to the United States, it will not be an adventure shopping like it is here. Plus, the enormous fruits and vegetables and meat won't be as fresh or delicious.

Souks in Marrakesh see my review on Jemaa El Fna. Good fun place to navigate and barter with the locals. A visual and sensory experience Spices fruit Vegetables Meat clothing souvenirs from Light fittings Tea pots pottery to leather shoes bags and beautiful Kaftans. Don't get too serious we are talking very small prices here just enjoy the experience

Just not for me. Over the course of the week I spent many many hours wandering through the Souks, all of the different ones; it's just most of those hours were not by choice. Often just trying to find a restaurant, or to get home. Even with a map and GPS I was resoundingly lost several times, with the longest being well over an hour. At night it was even more difficult. I found most of the stores sold very similar products, and once I had seen fifty I had seen most. Directions were available, but you may well have to barter for those also in my experience. By the end of the week I would navigate around the Medina sticking to the main roads. I am sure this may be a great experience for some, but I enjoyed little of it.

Eye-opening. The shops are colourful as indeed are the vendors but for us the heart of the souk is the artisan area. To see the craftsmen making their wares and the environment they work in is incredible. The smells can be a bit much as in the tannery but well worth accommodating just to see how things are done. The artisans will also sell to you and want you to barter - be brave but don't insult them for their work is special.

So much stuff, so many shops, so many people grabbing at you. Took several trips through the souks. There are so many shops that the experience is overwhelming sometimes. All of the shopkeepers are very aggressive in trying to get you to view their wares. Some of the shops have great products and others just have junk.. You need to take your time and really look at what you are buying.. Obviously part of the experience is negotiating. Pick your price and stay with it.. If that particular shopkeeper won't meet your price, there is likely another shop 5 feet away that will..

Tons of tourists, but much worth the visit. My wife and I were lucky to be assigned to Marrakesh in the 1970s in the Peace Corps, and lived in the medina about a 10 minute walk from Souk Al Summarine, the main tourist souk tourists see. We've been back many times since, and honestly, it hasn't changed that much. It really is a different world. Don't worry about getting lost if you go without a guide. You will. So what. Eventually you'll find your way out, and get back to your hotel or riyad. Enjoy the people. Marrakshis have been selling to foreigners in their souks for about 1,000 years, so don't worry about getting a "fair price" for things. There isn't such a thing. Figure out your walkaway price for something you want, and let that be it. If you walk, you walk. You won't get a "local" price for anything, and why should you? You're not a local. Get over it. Have fun in the souk, enjoy the sights, ask as many questions as the merchants will answer, and treasure your time in one of the truly unique places in the world, even though you didn't discover it nor escape from other tourists who are also there. You're lucky to be there. If you pay a few more dirhams than you think locals might pay for the same thing, who cares. If you truly enjoy and appreciate the experience, without being gushy, you'll have a great time.
A must for every visitor. A maze with all that one could possibly desire, take a good guide or you will be lost without your Ariadne's threat.
fascinating. 7 miles of alleyways bristling with vendors of all kinds of wares. Luckily had a guide so we didn't get lost!

A must see. To us westerners this is a must see. See how the local people live and work. Barter with them at their stalls and never give more the 50% of their asking price.Beware of taking photographs of the side shows as you will be hounded to pay over large sums money for the privilege.Don't take large sums of money with you and keep your wallet protected.Don't be put off though it is a must see

This is the fun part of Marrakech!. Marrakesh was a two day stopover on our motorcycle tour of Morocco.We had to decided what to cram into two days that would be fun and memorable.Walking the various souks, enjoying the banter with all the stall owners (some of which were very humorous and quick witted), stopping for snacks and drinks every now and then made it a couple of the best days of out stay in Morocco.There is no real rule or lesson on how to get a bargain. Initial asking price is always very high and will come down depending on the amount of time you have to "play the game" and how well natured you are.As with so many of these things either party can be offended if the other is disrespectful.One good tip I can give is - Don't handle the merchandise if you do not intend to buy it, unless you are specifically invited by the seller/vendor. Go early in the day, whilst it is cool, take you time and enjoy......... and don't bother returning of a night for the pop up restaurants. More on this in another of my reviews.

Jemaa el Fna All University Games traditional Moroccan. Is the Jemaa El Fna Square headquarters for visitors from all over the world to enjoy watching offers interesting to Marwda snakes and narrators of riddles and stories, and musicians to other manifestations of watching popular abbreviating a rich heritage and unique it was behind the inclusion of this scene in the list of heritage immaterial humanitarian declared by UNESCO in 2001 , dates back to the era of Fna Square founding of the city of Marrakech years (1070-1071) AD, built the yard, "Fna" in the era of the Almoravid
Alright..... Great for exploring Marrakech. Some of the sellers are too pushy that actually scares tourists away. Also, you might need some time to get used to the traffics inside.

Back to Ancient Times !!!. Marrakech Souk really feels me that I was back in "old ancient times". Everything you need is all within your reach, except in the absence of the "barter" system coz of Moroccan Dirhams now a days.. Older items, pots, accessories, antiques articles can easily be bought here. We also tried dining out in the street market's eateries. Moroccan foods as openly displayed (thanks that we didn't see any flies). What amazed me much are the presence of honey bees "feasting" the bread and pastries as put on view to the prospective bread buyers. It's really "awesome".....Various snake charmers will make you feel "creepy" as they tried to come near you and asking for a token in exchange of snap shot with their handheld live venomous snakes.

Fascinating but you absolutely have to be cautious, we learnt the hard way.... My mum and I are currently in Marrakech and have been here for 2 days and 1 night so far, we have had such an amazing experience up until now. The souks (market side streets) are a labyrinth of stalls and people - I won't say harassing, but - incessantly insisting you buy from their stall.. This isn't as bad as it sounds however THE MOST IMPORTANT THING we could suggest is DO NOT go too far in to the souks. We found ourselves inevitably lost and there were young local teenagers trying to get us to go this way and that, without realising it we were stuck god only knows where and surrounded by them all cajoling us this way and that.. My mum made a joke to one of the boys saying "Oh, not you again" and laughed and he cut her hand with a knife and said "Bet you're sorry now!" And this was by far terrifying as we near on ran away trying to find our way out. I am NOT trying to deter people from seeing this amazing, amazing place, however warning people of the dangers of straying too far. This has not deterred us from the fascinating sights but we will definitely be a lot more wary and try not to let this spoil the rest of our stay. I do really recommend Marrakech, it is such a beautifully interesting place and the culture is so different to our own (we're from London). It is an insightful place, but at all times try and keep a sense of humour to the heckles you will receive and try to keep calm in situations which may seem a little scary. Keep your wits and sense of humour at all times!

Unexpectedly calm with no safety concerns for browsing.. Some 6000 shops in here. Go in the morning and get your bearings and enter from the Jeema El Fna Square. No WC's. Don't take valuables and dress conservatively. Take small amount of cash only, you can always come back. Most of the Souks will bring the items to your hotel anyway and you can pay later then anyway. Some more reputable and larger shops accept Cards. Shops close around 8pm and most close on a Friday for the big call to prayers. Go with someone and if you take a guide you will pay more as it includes their commission. Best Buy: Saffron stalks in a glass jar from a good herbalist. 90% cheaper than UK. Buy 2 get one free as well... that was our best barter deal. Don't engage in bartering or discussion if you anre not going to buy anything. If you accept their offer of free Tea you also need to buy something. Great fun. Be aware of kids on mopeds for petty crime.

Great place to visit. To get the real Marrakech experience you need to visit the Souks. You find all kind of merchindises at all kind of prices. Be ready to haggle with every single person. They will start at 250 DRM and you end up buying for 50 DRM if you have enough patience. Don't miss it, great experience although it gets tired after a few hours.

WOW!!!. This is a place that will send all your senses wild! All the beautiful different colours are a wonderful rainbow of delight! It is a very busy and loud place so be prepared. Be prepared to bartar. It is a game and the people you are buying from are experts! So always start low and pick a price you feel is what the item is worth to you and stick to that price and do not go higher than your set price and walk away if your not able to set that price and 9 out of 10 times you will be called back. Sometimes you win some and you lose some :) the sellers will be your best friend at one moment and abuse you the next but its all in fun and part of the game so roll with it! I recommend for women to not be on their own and even better to have a male with you or a guide. Be respectful and cover your shouldres and knees. Try not to say WOW to everything you see or show too much interest as you will be bombarded!!! Have small notes and change with you and keep in seperate smaller and larger bundles and if you have a set price for an item you wish to buy once you reach your set price and the seller pushes for more you can say this is all I have and have the amount you set in a seperate bundle and thats all you show so its a wise thing to walk in with an idea of what you wish to buy and the amount you wish to spend so you have the money ready. Do not pay more than 6dirum for a large 1litre bottle of water and its hot in Marrakesh so drink up and shopping in the souk is hard and thirsty work and you can be lost for hours exploring in this spectacular place!!(although in saying that alot of it is shaded from the sun) FYI the square outside the souks comes alive at night with many restaurants and snake charmers and music.

the maze. what an experience. Test your sense of direction to the maximum and wander into the Souks. A never ending maze of alleys small open areas and dead ends filled with absolutly everything from rugs to fruit. The sites sounds and smells are an absolute shock to the senses on your first dip in .A few things to be aware of are firstly the many motorbikes and mopeds that scoot through these narrow alleys and streets, keep your eyes and ears open or you could get run into. Secondly although the traders are on you like flies if you glance,stop or point these people are bothpolite and decent even if you dont buy so dont be afraid to interact and experience this place to the full. Barter for everything and dont be shy go in at 10% of the asking price and know what you want to pay and take your time getting there---its eventually fun. Remember these folk are traders so dont be rude, polite nos are accepted as such.Just enjoy the experience and you will see what a wonderful unique place this is. finally if you do get lost ask anyone BIG SQUARE and they will point you there or for a small fee(selling a service say 10 dhm) take you there. Enjoy

Try to smile and enjoy the experience. I hate to haggle, but I understood that this is their culture and haggling means you respect their trade and expertise. So relax, enjoy and smile a lot. And look a lot and divide the starting price by 8 if you are interested.

Respect and quality souk products. Ah, the glorious souks...in my opinion, many are filled with cheap junk. By my estimate only about one in twenty vendors will actually have genuine goods both made in Morocco/Middle East/Africa AND be of good quality. Mohamed Darari's shop is just such a place, and the best part is I was able to browse the wares without being constantly pestered by sellers. The best stuff is on the second floor, where they proudly showed me the difference between the cheap tagines, tiles and tea pots, versus what they sell. They showed genuine respect to me, and I showed equal respect by politely bargaining for a good deal. Mohamed Darari's is deep in the Medina at 42, rue el baroudiyenne a cote de la Musee. I am sure that if you email ahead he can send someone to lead you to the shop from the Jemaa El Fnaa. Darari-knou@hotmail.fr

Open your eyes to the culture. If you want to wander in and out of commercial shops with inflatable pool toys outside, avoid the Souks. For those wanting their senses to be brought to life, this is for you. The scents of spices and perfumes in the bazaar mixed with smells of food and raw meat at butchers stalls. The colours of the wares take your eye before the buzz of a moped reminds you to look out for the kamikaze riders. A polite shake of the head and a firm No Thank you is normally enough but show a little interest in something (even a glance or point) and the salesman will be on to you. Best prices late afternoon and barter for everything.

Enjoyable. An enjoyable and interesting way to spend a few hours if you follow a few tips a) dress appropriately and respectfully by ladies covering shoulders b) best to go early in the morning or after 5pm when it is cooler, c) stay in pairs, d) always haggle, as a general rule the final cost is usually half of the first price quoted to you. e) walk fast if you do not want to be hassled/approached f) good idea to walk around quickly first to get an idea for what items are more unusual compared to some products which are repeated all over. f) they will take Euros or Pounds or US Dollars as well as local currency, some traders preferred it, so be sure of your exchange rates.

What's not been said already?. Having returned from a 4 night stay, I have reflected on my journey & visit to the Marrakech Souk. I'm having difficulty coming up with something that hadn't already been said before to be honest!The smells? Are unique & pleasant & it can be fun trying to guess what spice has the strongest smell.Colourful? My goodness yes! Every colour under the rainbow!Noise? Pretty loud when everyone around you is haggling, trying to reduce the cost; then you've got the stall owners trying to make you buy from them rather than from Abdul next door!Yes, I agree - if you do it right the price came come done to 30% of the starting price but as each person selling doesn't respond to the same technique, I have no tips for you here! You can look serious so it is thought you won't give an inch OR you can involve humour in your quest... Doesn't seem to matter - so no big surprise.I was a little disappointed to read some females felt uncomfortable with the advances of the local men but perhaps it would be best to go view / shop in the morning when it is cooler? Wear something sensible to cover up - remember compared to local women the British ladies are I clone to show more flesh than locals, so can you really blame the very odd 1 or 2 for approaching?All in all the Marrakech Souk is a great adventure. A great time to envelope yourself in the culture of the country - but remember you will always be a very obvious tourist and the sellers have years of experience at their job .... We on the other hand are not adept at haggling (hence the laugh). The r's no doubt you could get everyone on your present it's sorted - my recommendation Is take some time out - do a little bit at a time rather than hours! No sane person could come away without feeling just a little bit stressed!!! Enjoy!

mixt feelings. dirty, sick cats, loooots of beggars, food, clothes, shoes, hats, bags, carpets, exotic animals and lots of things that you just do not have the imagination th recreate it. All the stuff are negotiable, nothing has a fixed price. It's easy to not get lost if you ask for the Jemma el Fna or just have a good orientation. My advice is, as hard as it is, just take a walk arround the streets, do not buy anything. Leave the shopping for the second, third day. That way you will have the experience, as small as it is, to know how much they are willing to let at the price, how good the products are, if you will find something better and so on. All my shopping was left for the last day, the 7th, and I think that I bought some good procuts at good prices. You will find stores that say they have fixed prices, they are negotiable too, but it's good to go inside, that way you will see if the prices are smaller or higher that the other souks. I bought a dress from a souk that had a fixed price, and didn't want to negotiate, at a smaller price than what I managed to negotiate at a different souk a little higher than this one. So just be patience, you will find the same product anywhere, there are not so many hand made products as you think.

An experience. Every sense is on high alert from smell to sight and adrenaline as it is so busy! Everyone is trying to sell you things - it is a market afterall!! A firm No thank you seemed to work. knock any price in half, walk away and then you will find out what they are really willing to sell at. Beware lots of raw meat hanging, live animals in cages and everything in between

All the same. After one has walked about 100m into the souk the stalls become repetitive. There is no chance of just browsing and exploring. One is hassled constantly and it just gets too much. We started to explore the side streets running off Jemma el Fna. Here you will find the same range of goods. The store owners are a little more relaxed and one can browse and explore. I spent far more money here than in the souk. Watch the prices and don't be afraid to say no despite their protestations. If you see stalls with sugar coated nuts, these are a must!
Great fun!. Don't get worried about getting lost, put an hour or two aside and head in to the Souks for a wonderful experience.

Large souk but much of the same. The souk is large and we found ourselves getting lost as it's quite maze-like. It's interesting to walk around but after we'd done a couple of 'rows', we found that all the stalls are pretty much the same. The variety of goods included spices, nuts, fruit, local beauty/health products, kaftans, rugs, jewellery, souvenirs etc. You MUST haggle otherwise you'll get ripped off. But don't start the process unless you're really serious about buying as it can get difficult to extract yourself from it once started. The length of time you need to visit the souk of course depends on how much you want to buy (as you'll need time to look and haggle). We just went to potter around and an hour was enough.

Safe and atmospheric. Lively, bright and safe if you stick to the main areas, a must if you visit Marrakech. The leather slippers, colourful pottery and lanterns are great souvenirs and good value if you haggle well. Dress modestly if you don't want to look too inexperienced and to respect the local culture.
