As expected. As expected the Marrakesh souk is full of little shops selling a wide range of items for the tourists. Prices start at one level and expect to bargain down to more than 50% discount. Ok to go and see but more to Marrakech and Morocco

Not to be missed. How can you visit Marrakech and not visit the souks. Just wander around and take in the richness if colors, smells, people, items for sale. If I looks to you a bit kitschy at first, and you are thrown off by the aggressiveness of the vendors and the hustling, after a while you will enjoy the authenticity and the ambience. Among the cheap items you will discover many upscale boutiques, galleries, and jewelry store that offer very high end merchandise. It is a whole world in a nutshell. We loved it.

Not for girls travelling on their own!. My sister and I did a day trip from Agadir to Marrakesh yesterday. We are 2 blonde girls travelling on our own. Although we realised we might get a bit of attention, we did not realise the extent of it. We travelled to Marrakesh on an organised day day with around 20 people in the group, made up of couples and other groups of girls. We aren't sure why, but we seemed to be singled out by the men in the souks. Maybe because of our hair colour, or because there is only 2 of use. Many men would shout to us and sometimes use inappropriate language and grab/touch us, even though we were in a large group. We were covered up wearing t-shirts and trousers. These 'events' have been going on whenever we leave the hotel making us almost scared to leave the pool. Having spoken to others on holiday in Agadir, no one else has got this unwanted attention, the only difference being they have been with their boyfriends. Marrakesh is beautiful and definitely worth a vist, although temperatures hit 42 yesterday. The souk is amazing and full of life. My only suggestion would be not to travel by yourself her as a solo girl traveller. Hate to say this as I have travelled solo in other parts of the world, but I definitely felt uncomfortable. I hope this doesn't put anyone off as morocco/marrakesh is a beautiful country/city to visit and definitely one to tick off the bucket list. The hotel we are staying in is amazing and I will definitely be writting a excellent review once back home.

A fabulous place to experience a different culture and shop until you drop!. I travelled by road from Casablanca, in itself a great experience. Along the way was full of interest. One fascinating sight was seeing a farmer plowing his field with a Camel pulling along a single furrow plough!Arriving into Marrakech was a fascinating sight to behold. In the distance you could see the famous Atlas Mountain Range. Then entering the Market Square was another special moment. One of the many unusual experiences, was watching a Snake Charmer plying his unique influence to the delight of all the many spectators. As I was moving away, a young Moroccan boy asked me to go with him into the Souk and meet his Mother and Family who would give me a SPECIAL price - just for me, on anything they sold! He also advised me to NEGOTIATE the price! I selected a beautiful sarong style dress to take home to my Dear wife. After walking away refusing to buy because of the ridiculous asking price the third time in my negotiation, the young boy ran after me with THE lowest price that was accepted! It was all in good taste . They and I enjoyed the negotiation with good humor. I spent many hours walking around being amazed at the variety of things to buy. I also enjoyed quaffing their famous Mint Tea..This is a visit not to be missed.

scintillating experience!. I arrived in the afternoon which was great because it gave me an hour or so to get well acquainted before the sun set. the market is laden with snake charmers and entertainers, lots of shopping and local foods. I was warned very strictly to be superbly vigilant especially as a female alone. naturally i discarded this advise and delved deep into the heart of the souk. Whilst the sun is up, I felt extremely safe, but when darkness started to set it, it was a different ball game all together. I was harassed by local entertainers who surrounded me intimidating me for money, and then got approached by a man who tried to lure me into a little store down "the stairs" to show me an ancient dark Moroccan magic! Nonetheless, had this not happened to me, Marrakesh would not be on my list of define return cities! This market is like no other. As a women solo traveler, I suggest get your bearings in order before running into a market. Also be cautious but not so cautious that you become a tourist! Carry small change so you can get rid of people who surround you. dress conservatively. and just take it in for what it is.... a fantasy!

A good place to hone your haggling skills. Winding alleyways, eager (for your money) sellers well versed in cockney slang - 'have a butcher's' ... 'lovely jubbly' ... and more. Great fun to be had and starting prices not to be taken too seriously, however many beautiful items for sale - my favourite being the leather slippers and shoes.

A busy and alive place. We visited the Souk early in the day to avoid the main crowds and enjoyed being able to move through the Souk without much trouble. We did not feel pressured to purchase and had time to appreciate the range of Moroccan wares on display.

Enjoy the mayhem. All I can say is be prepared to get lost, the souks within the medina are endless, in fact you could spend days going backs and forwards and still not see the same thing. The people are friendly and not pushy however, if you engage be prepared to barter and buy!! Much better than the souks in Casablanca

Colorful and crowded. See my review of Marrakech Medina. Don't get taken in by too much of the argan pharmacy shop, but do buy something. I'm loving my rose essence cream. And the almond. Using it reminds me of the essence of Morroco.
A real working souk. An amazing souk, still used busy the locals not just full of tourist tat. I'd recommend spending a few hours getting lost.

Busy, busy, busy. Be prepared for the different smells, spices, animals, cooking etc all mixed into one. Not unpleasant, just Moroccan! Haggle the prices with the stall owners, they really do expect it. There were hedgehogs, chameleons, tortoises, birds, vultures, monkeys, snakes either in cages or on leads. Be careful of the women who want to give you a henna tattoo, they will grab your fingers and start the tattoo before you know what they are doing then demand money or your jewellery if you complain.
Crazy place, but great for a bargain. anything and everything you could ever need! We got some great bargains from the souks, and also its great fun haggling with the shopkeepers

A huge souk. The souk in Marrakech must be one the largest I have ever visited, even bigger than the Khan el Khalili in Cairo. This of course means that the hassle factor is bigger and the smells associated. Tourists, beggars, usual 'cheaper than ASDA' sellers abound. If you go bargaining is essential and start around one quarter f the original ask as these guys are real con men!!

Different. Interesting. I am glad I went but would not go again. It is so easy to get lost with so many similar shops and narrow alleyways. Be careful not to get conned into purchasing things you don't really want or need. Temperature inside was about 35 so take plenty of water.

A must!. We preferred the Souk to the Market Place because as well as all the touristy stuff available to buy you saw genuine craftsmen making goods in leather, wood, metal and there were ordinary stalls for the locals. Guide advised so as not to get lost!

Brilliant. Just a different world, take your time and absorb the atmosphere, sights, sounds and smells, its a great experience and don't worry its safe! If you get lost don't panic just ask for the main square. Simple.

Allow your self to get lost. The Souk is big and windy, the only way to experience it is to let go of trying to remember where you are and lose your self to the experience. You can always find someone willing to guide you back to the main square.
unique in its style. loved it .. a place like no other .. not to be missed if you visit Marrakech .. attractions.. action, food.. artisan's haven ...
A bit intimidating. Another must visit location whilst in Marrakech just be prepared to haggle and enjoy it rather than feel intimidated as I did. Will visit again.

Extremely pushy and overly aggressive!. All over the Medina we found that locals could be very pushy and aggressive when it came to selling whatever it was they were pushing (trinkets, silk, leather, advice, directions). The Souks were no exception. My husband and I actually did not shop here because we hated being verbally accosted at every turn. The only shop where I bought something, was a shop which did not "shout out" at us when we walked by. And the only reason I went in, was because they didn't shout at us. To me, the Souks were awful. However, if you don't mind everybody grabbing at you, and you like the "negotiating" experience, then this might be your shopping heaven. But for us, we hated it.

Souks...a shoppers paradise. We loved the souks and there is hardly any hassle from anyone. Be prepared to haggle to within an inch of your life and also be prepared to walk away if you don't get the price you want...there are plenty more places selling the same stuff. A shoppers paradise...

Shoppers Paradise. Clean, calm and a shoppers paradise. Everything from Shoes, Bags, Rugs, Cushions, Arts, Crafts.Only downside is very expensive. Must be used to a lot of wealthy travellers as won't barter to what I as a UK resident classes as a bargain. Did not buy a lot as could get at TK Maxx or in UK cheaper. Such a shame.

Stressful and expensive. shop around and be careful what you buy, retailers can be very pushy. it can be exciting to haggle and get a bargain but for a more relaxed shopping experience visit the ensemble artisanal where you can look without feeling compelled to buy. In the Souks don't be afraid of walking away - it will mean you get a better price!
be prepared to haggle. Good fun, but if you want to buy something, be prepared to haggle. Offer about 10% of the price given, and take it from there!

Great Place To Shop!. There is no way that you can come to Marrakech and not visit the souqs.This is a great place to shop and see lots of the trinkets that you can buy. Although the majority of the shops all sell the same things, you can easily find what you are looking for in the souq.Just be sure to haggle and know that if you go too low with the prices that you offer, the shop owners will not want to do business with you. However, just be advised that they will raise the price once they see that you're a tourist. If you have a trusted Moroccan friend or guide, show them what you want and ask them to come back and buy it for you while you wait somewhere else so that they can get "The Moroccan Price!"

exciting and scary. We wanted to visit for the experience and defiantly got that! Be careful not to get lost as trust me its very easy! Women need to be covered up but the men are ok in shorts and t-shirt, I wore loose fitted trousers and a top and I was not hassled. The shops have plenty to offer just be good at haggling! We had the monkeys thrown onto us the guys are very friendly until it comes to money which they can get very angry. I felt sorry for the monkeys as they do not look happy at all and this was a shock but i understand this is there job. It was also upsetting to see the turtles caged up which did spoil the day if anything. Overall it was an experience which i am glad i was involved in.

Another experiences. Overpriced place to shop but it was a good experience for people who want to bargain stuff. You will get a good price if you know how. I don't shop a lot in the souk. I prefer 'Rue Mouassine' (google it!) to the souk. There are many good restaurants and cafes in Rue Mouassine that sell alcohol drinks and open...


More

Lose yourself. The labyrinthine lanes which make up the residential areas of the medina of Marrakech are great places to lose yourselves in. Despite your understandable concerns, you will not be hassled or made to feel as an interloper, although live goes on all around you, some of it will make your head spin. Go on, just do it!

Incredible place. Nice experience, however it's necessary to learn to say no, because the solicitation is maximum.
Change of scenery guaranteed.

very interesting. this square by night is brilliant,snake charmers,monkeys,water boys,henna tattoo women,food sellers,orange juice stalls,story tellers,overall this is the place to be at night ,locals and tourists alike mingle in a mass crowd ,a must for any visitor to marrakech.
The most magical place. Find a coffee shop and just sit and watch. Or sample the gazillion food vendors. One thing for sure. This spot will live long in your memories!!

Not to be missed. Well, the first word that comes to mind is "different". Different, as in a kinda 'Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom' different! But definitely a must see. Be sure to take your camera, but remember that most people here are performers, and will require a few dihrams to have their photo taken.

DISSAPOINTED. Maybe it was because this was my third or fourth souk of my Morocco tour. I'm not evaluating the available merchandise. There was plenty to look at and buy. It was the experience. The alleys were narrow and there were motorcycles whizzing by spewing out exhaust fumes. So here i am having to watch out for these vehicles and choking...


More

Vibrant colourful Marrakech. I visited Marrakech in March 2014 with 2 friends. We stayed at a very nice hotel the Kenzi Farah hotel. Marrakech is a very interesting city and we found the people extremely friendly and although we had all heard various bad stories about the cab drivers, we all found this untrue as they were friendly, obliging and did not rip...


More

Incredible!!!!. You must see to believe! You can't see Marrakech without going to the Souk. Its the most amazing sense of tradition. You may not want to drink much due to shortage of bathroom stops, other than that it was worth the venture out of our resort!!
Real Marrakesh. One must need bargaining skills to work out the shopping. very congested bazar with lots of options for the people who like shopping

Wonderful assault on your senses. Absolutely great experience. Busy, dirty with a wonderful mix of tourists from all over converging here. Wonderful ambiance, snake charmers, clairvoyant's, shoe shine people, magic tricks galore. Wonderful food stalls, exotic herbs & spices filling the air with a delicious aroma. Real buzz in the air. Fantastic choice of souvenirs, eateries etc., they do hassle you but just smile & keep walking it is a cultural thing.
Bustling. Buzzing with traders and plenty of good products to choose from, Gets a little overwhelming, Barter, but be prepared to walk away and ignore the pressure.

relaxed and fun. was expecting to be hassled in the souks but the experience was surprisingly relaxing. A simple "merci, non" with a smile and the hawkers retreated. Moroccan people are generally very friendly and warm. We were horrified at the number of pasty touristic bingo wings and varicose veins beneath short shorts in full view of all. Cover up a little, be respectful in the Muslim culture, use your bit of schoolday French and you'll have a whale of a time.
save a day for shooping. Take your time and visit all the shops you can. D`ont forget to bargain. The prices are all negotiatable.

An average experience that does however need to be done. One of the things to see in Marrakech however the caveats are that only tourists shop there, prices post haggle are not spectacular if visiting from London, the range of products being sold is not extensive and is very much produced with the visitor in mind. The result is that there are lots of leather bags, shiny teapots and tajine pottery items for sale. It's not bad to walk through and if I hadn't done it I would do again but once you've walked for 200m you start getting a sense of deja vu.

Bizarre Bazaar. Be prepared to enter never ending Aladdin's Cave from old to new, practical to wonderful. Be prepared to haggle hard and stick to the price you feel the product is worth. Remember to have fun and enjoy the moment!!! Everything you buy will have a story attached!!

Interesting but too many con artists and motorbikes. The souks are interesting and a maze but there are just too many locals trying to talk you into going to things like the tanneries or trying to 'help' give you directions. They don't seem to understand that you just want to wander around to take in the sights smells (and occasionally get lost).If approached say NO THANK YOU or NON MERCI firmly - DO NOT GET ENGAGED IN CONVERSATION as they will follow you and tell you the way and then expect a tip of around 10 dirham (about 75p). Sometimes they deliberately tell you the wrong direction (this happened to us). The older ones seem more helpful and do not generally expect a tip. Best tip is not to take much money.Watch the tanneries - we went in and then later told to pay 150 dirham - claimed a sign above where we entered said admission price - of course you don't notice this. We were fortunate as we only had 40 dirham in our pockets - its a good way to negotiate. Our guide was not happy - said this was nothing but still took it.All in all I think this sort of behaviour spoils the experience - if you live live to tell the tale and are not knocked over by the multitude of motorbikes, cycles, donkey carts etc all going far too fast through very narrow alleyways.
Worth it. if you're prepared to get lost in this maze then it is an abosulte must. You can shop until you drop. But remember one thing: negotiating is part of the fun

Great if you want a fake football shirt!. Wandered around the souk unguided on our 1st day.Driven mad by the hassling shopkeepers.You can`t pause to look at anything without being pounced on and a lot of what`s on sale is cheap fake rubbish.Couldn`t believe the amount of fake football shirts on offer-what`s authentic about that?

How to bargain in the souks in Marrakech. After a short stay in Marrakech recently and a few salutary lessons learned I want to pass on a few tips which would have been helpful to me had I known them before I visited the souks. - if you are new to Marrakech don't buy anything on the first day until you have had a chance to compare prices- a visit to the Centre Artisanal in the Kasbar is very helpful. It is the medina's closest thing to a department store and has a vast array of goods at fixed prices. Prices will be less in the souks but at least a visit to the Centre Artisanal tells you the most you should be paying.- if you have a guide, even one arranged for you by your hotel or riad, remember that, as happens the world over, your guide will be taking you to stores that will pay him a commission. Do not assume these store owners are reliable. They want to sell something to you for as much as possible, even it is with a smile and a cup of mint tea and the endorsement of your guide.- a general rule of thumb is that the higher the price, the greater the discount you can achieve through bargaining. For example, you might get an item with an asking price of US$300 down to US150. But you might only get 10 or 15% discount on an item with an asking price of US$10.- often the asking price does not start out at 100% of the "real" asking price. It might be 400 or 500% or more. For example, a shop owner may tell you a pot is US$500; a more realistic starting price should be US$150 and you should get it for US$75.- Westerners attribute value to something that is "old" - Marrakech retailers do not. However, they will tell you an item is old to make it appear more valuable to the Western customer. Sometimes old means it's been in the shop a few years. Having said this, some more upmarket galleries will carry old items made by named craftsmen that will have a higher value.- if you are not sure if you have reached the shop/souk owner's bottom price, walk away. He will come after you if he is prepared to take a bit less.- A good deal is when the seller and the purchaser are both happy but it is made more difficult when you are coming from a more affluent community and would normally expect to pay more. Use the pointers above to try to pay what is fair.

A must when in Marrakech. The souks are a great place to wander round and look at the wares on sale. Beautiful at night as well with all the lanterns turned on. Be prepared to barter, only show interest in things you genuinely want to look at, and don't be afraid to walk away. It's a must do !

A great experience. A "must do" whilst in Marrakech. My wife and I wandered for hours around the souks and although nothing tempted us to buy we had a wonderful time and felt reasonably safe with little hassle.With a little common sense it's a great place to visit and if you carry a GPS system, as we did, you can even find your way back to where you started!!

Magical!. Great! whether you like shopping or not, this marketplace is the place to see in Marrakech. The colors of clothes and spices added to that the welcoming smiling faces of the merchants transport you into the tale of Ali Baba.

Culture&Colors!. While in Marrakech, bringing a visit to the Souk (market) is a must. Be surprised by the many spices that are being sold, the handmade leather bags and many more items. The Moroccan people are very kind, helpful but when you're walking through the city there will always be somebody who wants to sells you something. Be polite and just say "No thank you". If they offer you something just don't engage in a conversation. While walking through this city, or any other city in the world, always watch your bag and don't bring anything with you that you don't need.

smells of africa. the souks where great to walk through each alley leading to a new smell or discovery. You can see tailors, dressmakers, chemists and herbalists, green grocers, butchers, fishmongers and all sorts of handicrafts. They seem to meander for miles seeing something new at each turn.

There are better places to shop!. Women are not respected, guys passing crude comments in different languages when girls walk by, some guys peeing on the side of the street, dirty, trash everywhere...sorry if you enjoy all that, then you might be interested in going there. But I don't like that and prefer to shop somewhere else. Just my two cents.

You might Get Lost. Exploring the Souks (markets) is a wonderful experience, however they are situated in a Labyrinth in which you could get lost. However the Moroccans are a friendly people and they will point you in the right direction although they will try to sell you something. Just say no thanks and keep walking. If you are offered tea it is considered impolite to refuse so try not to let it get to that. If it does you are going to get a show and heavy pressure to buy. I made the mistake og going to look at carpets and was offered tea.I took it and then got a show put on for me. In the end I had to politely excuse myself and leave .

The Souk. Extraordinary place when we were there many years ago, but even then there was a certain feeling that if you were not ' of the faith' you were tolerated (ie you had money ) rather than welcomed.

Avoid the monkeys!. There are tourist traps everywhere, people trying to get your money and over charge you. Ask around in your hotel for the best places to go and haggle, haggle, haggle. And avoid the men with monkeys they charge a ridiculous fee for a photograph and push you into getting one even when you don't want to.

Typical tourist market selling all same stuffs. Well, nothing much I can say about this market because it's just a tourist market. It's very big but selling pretty much the same stuffs, pretty much the same price. Good qualities sold here are not that great, just typical mass productions. I'd prefer local traditional market or less tourists involved or shops that sell different stuffs. Outside the main market area there are shops selling antiques which might be little interesting, with less tourists. Try exploring the alleys if you want something else...

enjoying getting lost and exploring. amazing place! you are literally trow into a parallel reality. don't panic if you get lost, that's practically 60% of the fun, just explore and of some is pressing on selling something or bringing you into a shop smile and decline if you are not interested. Remember always to bargain the first price they propose is usually always ridiculously high you can almost always reach 40% less. Also look closely at the quality of the product unluckily lately you can find Chinese products that fake to be moroccan art-crafts.

Enjoy but be savvy. we enjoyed the souk, however, i'd recomend going twice, one to check out what's available and then again to purchase.it is alot of the same, wood turning, carpentry, leather goods, ceramics, prayer shoes, lanterns, etc. etc. My tip would be, to exchange your money into small notes, as they don't like to give change. and that is anywhere not just the souk. divide your money and keep it safe beforehand, do not count out cash in front of a vender as they will more than likely encourage you to spend more or take you to their brothers' stall in order for you to spend.Haggle hard. decide how much you think somehting is worth and don't be made to feel guilty. if you cannot get the price you want to pay walk away. they would rather sell you somehting than not.once you step inside a stall be prepaired to leave with something. once you touch somehting in their mind you will not leave empty handed. we had not issues at all in the souk, however, one young seller became irate when my friend and I decided not to purchase any of his scarfs, he insisted that he drape the scarfs over us and tie them in turbans etc. we even took pics, he got abit agressive when we decided to walk away. he flicked his hands on my friends face and shoved her not hard but agressively. calling us 'bad tourists' this was only incident we had on our trip, and we don't feel it was typical behaviour, non the less after this incident we were far less enthusiastic about items unless we were really interested in purchaing.despite this, we bought alot of stuff, and all other sellers were great and non agressive. just be aware and mind your money... it is an experience.

Even haggling, thought this was mainly expensive compared to other countries with similar souks. I expect to haggle but I felt I was haggling to bring prices down to European prices, never mind feeling like I was getting a bargain. I would have loved to have bought a Moroccan lantern but 50 Euro for a very small table lamp made of metal that I am not sure what the provenance was? Didn't do it just didn't feel it was right. Maybe I will get better price and confirmed quality back home!! I don't mind paying for things but the fact that Europe has been in recession has bypassed souk sellers.

Hectic and unmissable. Incredible activity all day and night. It's amazing that all kinds of traffic are allowed to weave amongst pedestrians - but we never saw any accidents. Drivers are skilful and hardly ever even use the horn. It's good fun bargaining for items on sale. Despite the densely packed shops and people, the area is quite clean. Easy to get lost but it's all part of the fun - and the shopkeepers will always help with directions. Some good restaurants are tucked away. Try "Cafe Souk" or "Le Jardin" for a great Moroccan dining experience at a reasonable price.

Amazing a must visit place.. When we visited Tunisia we visited a couple of souks, Sousse and Sfax. Sousse is very touristy, in Sfax we were the only none Tunisians and we loved it. This souk is just like that. You will see some tourists but a lot are too nervous to visit the souk. We just loved getting lost and seeing the local people shopping for their everyday essentials.

best shopping experience. take a break from the scorching sun and enter the shaded narrow lanes of the souks and have an adventure, and shop til you drop! plenty of little cafes around to rest up and drink mint tea, before returning refreshed to haggle some more - and dont be shy, its the name of the game around the souks and there are bargains a plenty to be had, leaving everyone happy!!

Early evening as the sun sets. Busy buzzing souk, large open square with snake charmers, monkeys, drummers and local Berbers. Under cover market in narrow little streets, easy to get lost! Remember to brush up on your bargaining skills. All currency welcome! Get there early just before the sun sets and sit on the upstairs terraces of one of the coffee bars overlooking the square and watch the world go by....

Crazy Place but fun. The Souks are the craziest places I have ever been, there are people selling everything you can imagine and more. Narrow lanes with shops and stalls full of goodies, you will get asked to have a look but a polite no thank you and a smile and keep walking and you wont be hassled. Watch out for the horse and buggy, bicycles or motorbikes coming up behind you as you will need to get out of their way.

Busy busy busy. Busy busy busy Packed with 'shops', sights, sounds and smellsGreat to experience but just keep walking if you're not buying and try and remember which turns you take or it may take a while to get out again

A fantastic experience. I'd advise anyone to go and have a wander round, just make sure you're prepared to be firm and say no! Especially to the people who will try and usher you toward their snake charming areas.There's some great authentic ceramic bowls and ornaments, along with leather bags and oils.My top tip is stop at an orange juice stand and get a glass for 4 dirham (about 30p), never tasted anything like it!

big but not much different from Souks anywhere. I was looking here to find something exceptional as this Souk was highly praised. Other than its size ( huge ) and the fact that it was generally clean and spacious it really wasn't all that different from Souks anywhere in the world. The same type of shops selling cheap souvenirs, leather goods of dubious quality, ethnic cheap clothing, pashminas and the like, various spices, etc etc repeated again and again in a huge are. Best part were the stalls selling dirt cheap fresh cold orange juice needed to keep one going in the sweltering 40 degree plus heat. You need to see this when in Marrakech but don't get too excited about it.

A good deal can be had!. The first day your there find the things you want to buy, then go price check it. Every single thing is priced 5-10x what its worth. Walking away is your best negotiating tool, use it to get what you want. Try the olive stands their the best.

a COMPLETELY different world. What a day...you cant leave Marrakech without going to Jemaa el Fna...go early so you can see the dancing cobras and monkeys in the square and you can actually see where you are going. the sights and smells of the Souk are undescribable. I went with my Boyfriend and his family..who live in Meknes and are actually moroccan so I basically got a local guided tour. Make sure you buy leather and preserved lemons....amazing deals...the food in the souk was sooo amazing...everything from apricots to olives to cookies and peanuts..personally the figs and nuts were my favorite. NEVER EVER EVER pay full price....everything is negotiable. I could have spent days there. Dont miss this .....also...take a horse and carriage ride around the city that departs at the front of the Souk....magical

History revisited and enjoying age old traditions .. The smells and sounds is unique. The aroma of spices and the visual delights of food and fruits and sweets is unmatched. Not used to bargaining but doing so brings huge discounts. The Souk has a main artery that allows you to see the different sections selling all kinds of wares. Side alleys would take you to living quarters , and should you feel lost follow the main trail and you on track. The Qasba has its own history in the remarkable uncovering of the founders of the Saadian dynasty of the 15th Century.
A maze of endless allyways. You might need to be prepared to get lost, but don't worry, there a million and one kids who obviously for a small fee will escort you back to wherever you want to get to.

Bring an extra luggage. I really enjoyed the souks in Marrakesh, there are so many things to purchase and the choices are just immense. Silks, lamps, leather goods you need to travel light to go back with great deals. Bargain all you buy! You will probably get lost but this is part of being in the souks.

Better souks in Fes and Meknes. Less hassle and in general better quality in Fes and Meknes. It just feels more comfortable walking and buying products in other souks. Why could they not make genuine quality label for some souks to protect the true craftsmanship and quality?
Lost. Very intrest place sights and smells you can get lost ing the maze of allay ways but keep going you usauly come out right were you started

Fun if it had't been for the rain!. My partner had never been to a souk before ( I had been to souks in Agadir and Tunisia ) so he was interested to experience one! We were only on a short trip to Marrakech so unfortunately the day we were there it chucked it down with rain. Some of the stalls had some sort of roofing over the alleyways ,but many didn't, so we got rather wet. The rain was useful , in that, most of the stall holders were too busy trying to keep the water out of their stalls, rather than hassle us! Most of the goods on sale were as we expected, but because of the weather we didn't stop and buy. There were some things we would have liked , but much too big to fly home with!The most annoying thing was , that when we had had enough, and were cold and wet, each time we asked for the way out to the square, we were merely directed down another alleyway only to find it was one we had been in before!Some of the alleys and streets around the souk, as bicycles and motorcycles charge around, them with little thought for pedestrians.

A maze. This place is just like a maze with all sorts of nukes and crannies u can buy anything in here it is massive and you can not be in a hurry when you go there take your time and see everything it has inside well worth a few hours

Great fun. the souks in Marrakech were fantastic. We were in there for about 4/5 in total over 2 visits. We had so many different experiences I will share just two with you.1) i love working with wood so when i was walking through the souks and saw a lathe i was keen to see more. So i looked about for the owner he turned up and then got to work. It was a hand driven lathe and he held the chisels with his hand and his feet. It was fantastic to see. His English was really poor and my French was worse but we used sign language to communicate. We found out that it was his granddads stall them his dads and now he works there. He also made my wife and i a wooden charm on his lathe and would not take any money for it. i could have watched him work all day.2) my wife wanted a leather and silk hand bag (and one as a pressy) that she saw on one of the stalls so i set to work haggling for it the price started at 650DH. I said this was far to much and was only willing to pay 200DH we went back and forward with him going down and me going up then him staying the same and me asking for more stuff. after about 10 minutes i walked away as i could not get him down any further. We walk about 500m from the stall when i felt a tap on my shoulder and it was the stall owner he wanted to talk we haggled for an other 5 minutes and i got the bags with matching silk scarf's for 450DH. (We later saw them in the hotel for 465DH each) this is just two of the many things that happened to us.top tips go in the evening as there is more of an atmosphere and it is a little cooler, haggle for EVERYTHING. and have fun.Also if you dont like strong smell take a hanky with some Vickes on it as some of the smells are really bad.
Great intensive course to business development!. If you are a sales person, you will love the experience of negotiating with these people! What a great school!

Mustapha was great.. This is the second time I am writing a review because I thought this guy was so enthusiastic, he made you want to know everything. He gave us a tour of the souks at night with an emphasis on food. He spoke of some of the foods during Ramadan and also a food mothers make as a special treat for their children. It was wonderful and he made it for me by putting together different nuts and dates and a small baked cookie. Not only did he put it together but he then paid for it. I brought this to work and it was big hit. This man spoke so clearly and was funny and charming ,interesting and spoke from his heart about how people feel about various things in Morocco. Great job Mustapha.

Enchanting. Where do I begin. The merchandise and crafts sold in this souq are attractions in themselves. There is really something for everyone, and even at the highest request of the salesman (AKA the first) the items are affordable if not a steal. literally everything under the sun is sold SOMEWHERE in here, from antique lamps and wood inlay tables to NIKE frees and Toms. A must see, a must do. Also makes for some great photos.

Depends what you are looking for.... Without doubt souks district has its character. Especially for people (like myself), who didnt experience arabic markets/bazaars before. Yet after the first wow is gone, you'll realize that majority of those ten-thousands of shops in this endless labyrinth are offering more less same 10 odd kinds of goods... carpets, lamps, pottery, leather goods, bijoux, slippers, candies... very rarely you'll see one-of-a-kind shop or the actual person crafting the item in front of you... and once inside you'll realize that even the price tag, assuming for its uniqueness, is "somewhere else".. oh, and. DO NEGOTIATE about the price of everything. Not once I paid more than 50% of what whas the initially claimed price...But by the end of the day I must admit I was a bit annoyed from all the hustlers pulling you in and leeching "guides", that want to show you the best place/shop/restaurant/etc in the entire Marrakech... definitely worth mentioning, that some reckless scooter drivers (or carts pulled by donkeys, in some cases) don't even bother slowing down in those narrow overcrowded streets, which made me a couple of times thinking "what if i wouldn't make the jump on the side..." and on top of tha polluting the entire place with heavy smoke for quite a while as they blast by. As much as I loved the vibe of Jemaa el Fna, these souks were not so super-duper to me...

Amazing. Don't be afraid to haggle, do it in good humour and everyone will be happy. Take lots of money, I don't normally buy things abroad as taking things back is a bit tricky but I couldn't help myself here, shoes, handbags, rugs, mirrors, lighting....

Good range of things to buy. Lots of things to tempt here, though the vendors were pretty aggressive compard to Fes and Essaouaira. Noticed that the babouches I bought had 'made in Fes' on the bottom. Wonder how many things are actually made in Marrakesh? Lively place, nevertheless.

How do I get out!!. With 60,000 "shops" you can spend days here and not pass the same trader twice! It is a labyrynth of alleyways brimming full of amazing goods to purchase. It is advisable to take a guide previously booked ( with hotel?) rather than pick one up otherwise you will be steered into their cousins coffee house or pharmacy! If you dare venture in alone take some string and unwind it as you go-it's the only way to find your way back to the square!! A great day out with lots to see.

Much prefer the Grand Bazaar of Istanbul. I loved the Grand Bazaar in Istanbul and expected this to be the same. Unfortunately it wasn't. Every stall had the same goods for sale, leather bags and belts and Aladdin slippers and a lot of other tacky souvenirs. Still a fun place for a couple of hours of shopping but don’t expect to come home with any real bargains. I visited in October 2010 but friends have been back in June and felt the same.
Like no other place. Incredible diversity - a huge melting pot with lots of attractions.Try going both at day and at night - the transformation is amazing.

Do not bother visiting this place. I give it 1 because 0 is not available..I was expecting the souk to be like the Grand Bazaar in Istanbul.Instead it was extremely dirty, polluted (smog) and stressful..Now in terms of shopping experience.Not one minute passes without someone hassling you and trying to get you have a look at the goods they are selling. And if you are not interested and you dare say no they will become rude and sometimes aggressive..Also you can find anything (babouches, lanterns, spices, bags, clothes, jewellery) but most of those are low quality and ridiculously priced so you will have to haggle hard to make "bargain" (please note the quotation marks).If you want a nice shopping experience do yourself a favour just go to the Ensemble Artisanal (Craft Center) which is government owned and the goods are fairly priced.

You need to know how to bargain. I got some great things here at fair prices. You do need to have a lot of patience and not budge on your price. If you take the time to chat with the salesman, get to know eachother you can get some really good prices and make some friends along the way. I had a lot of fun here, i guess it's not for every one but with the right spirit (relaxed attitude) and bargaining skills this is a great place to do some shopping! I also felt very safe at any time of day, people are helpful and hospitable

Shopping by Department?. Westerners have modern department stores that have designated ares devoted to everything from bedding to china. In the medina of Marrakech there are souks, specialized workshops/marketplaces devoted to specific crafts or trades. There are souks for textiles, rugs, brass and metal work, and leather goods. If you want to stay centrally located and shop different merchants who create the same type of product, this is where you go. You can compare product, price and bargain for the best deal.

Easter Visit. An amazing place with something different around every corner. The sales pressure was less than expected and we eventually found what we were looking for and, more importantly, found our way back to the Riad!
This was an experience!. Miriam of avenues, stalls, passages ---- VERY easy to get lost, but good fun exploring to find your way out.
Marrakech souk. Contrary to what you might expect, you will not be hassled by stallholders. They won't waste their time on a non-sale when there are hundreds of potential buyers following you!

The art bargaining. A whole new experience in shopping. The vendors line the narrow and sometimes ancient alley ways. Always bargain do not just pay the first price, offer 50% and then start bargaining. Always ask a vendor if you may take a photograph of his wares.

AN EXCITING BLEND OF SIGHTS, SOUNDS, AND AROMAS. I was immersed in a blend of the sights, sounds, and aromas of the souk as I navigated my way along the narrow passages, further occluded by pedestrians and donkeys. All sorts of iconic metalware and leather goods and rugs were for sale. Every price was negotiable. Indeed, only fools paid the merchant's initial price. Haggling brought the sale price down to less than half of what was initially demanded. The merchants all seemed to speak several languages, of necessity, including English, French, German, Spanish, and, of course, Arabic. I came away with an incised brass plate to hang on a wall and a camel-skin hassock to use as a footrest. There were all kinds of food stalls, but I didn't feel adventurous enough to roll the dice on a souk version of Montezuna's revenge.An experience not to be missed.

morocco at its best. hustle and bustle of morocco at it's best!great choices of all wares and be careful of the prices. whatever they ask for, cut it in half and use this as your starting point. it is all part of the charm to barter and negotiate.the square beside the souk is very interesting at night with food outlets serving local delicacies.
Shoppers paradise!. So many interesting sights to see. The main square is very busy and expensive and less interesting than the main souk.
back streets.. narrow and amazing. especially liked the local shoes, slippers, and spices for sale.. watch your haggling... bid a lot lower than you dare.. and stand your ground

Take your time to look for true Artisan products and not the imports. The Souk is a fascinating experience. Dynamic, colorful, plenty to look at and marvel at. But there is a lot of junk there too. You have to take the time to find what seems authentic and what are just cheap imitations. We were expecting more aggressive sales people but they were watching a big football game that evening and were a bit distracted! If you got lost and ask for help - be ready to pay for any service that you are given. We found that some of the locals expected 20 dirhams just to point the way. Its a pity as there seems to be a desire to completely fleece tourists in Marrakech that you don't find elsewhere in Morocco.

Get lost!. Great place to get lost and explore the small avenues with all sorts of souveniers. Enjoy hours here, finding what you like and bartering hard for it. do not pay asking price, always knock down by at least 40%

A voir. It’s worth a visit, so colorful and a big variety of handcrafts: pottery, leather, metal etc.. even spices form all over the world. You can bargain on almost all articles, it was so funny  the people are nice too, it reminds me my beautiful country Tunisia we have the same kind of souks and articles. Marrakech is definitely a very nice town.

Get off the tourist part. Most tourists enter the souk from Djemaa el Fna onto Rue Semarine. The first 50 yards or so are totally geared to the tourists, a lot of whom only get this far as they have to return to their coach tours. If you take time, meander deeper into the souk (you will get lost but don't worry - that is half the fun - and you will get back to the main square on asking anyone as the locals are very helpful) you will get what you want far more cheaply than in that first section. Be ready to bargain but always be pleasant. Don't bargain if you don't intend to buy. Do know what you are prepared to pay and offer less. If you pay between one third and one half of what they ask, you are doing ok. Day one can be daunting but you will get the hang of it quickly. All you need is to see something you paid for at half what you paid as the asking price and your bartering skills will improve!!

Bargain. Pretend to walk away. Buy. Rinse and repeat.. I travelled with three ladies, being the only guy in the group (oh boy). Be prepared for endless bargaining. And the pretend "i am walking off now" before the shop owner says "ok ok, fine. yes, that price.". Picked up some local t-shirts here (of the red shirt and green star flag types) at 40 dirhams each. The starting price was 120 dirhams. For any future t-shirt buyers, hope this helps! This place is big and winding, so try and make sure you don't get lost. Usually if we lost our bearings a bit, i would usually pop into one of the mini kiosk shops to buy some water (you'll need it frequently) and then ask them for directions of a landmark (e.g. jemaa el fna square). I liked the wide variety of stuff sold here (pottery, trinkets, scarves, costume jewelry, etc) but after 2-3 hours of walking around, they all kind of blur into the same stuff.

Get a Guide. Must visit...Get a guide and be very specific on what you would like to buy and see. Detail the exact quality you would like to see and purchase. They sell a lot of the same items at every store, but the key difference is the quality.

Double bonkers. What a fantastic and exciting place. Once you get past being mithered and asked if you know everyone from Rick Stein, Jamie Oliver and randomly Stacey from Eastenders!! be prepared to haggle as they will almost certainly drop their prices if they think they are about to lose a sale. It did however become a bit samey, once you have seen leather bags, scarves and wooden ornaments several times. be prepared to give way to men with trolleys and nutters on mopeds. Don't let them see you taking photos of monkeys etc as they will expect a payment.
Wonderful!. Very exciting, best part of Morocco. Perfect place to get souvenirs. There is a surprise at every corner from swords to live scorpions. Very cheap clothes available.

A Maze. Once you enter the Souks it is almost impossible to find your way out. It literally is a maze! The items inside are varied and, if you walk far enough into the Souks, you will see the different products being hand made. This is the home of bartering. Never accept the first price offered and ignore any price tags. For those who are not used to bartering it does take some practice but the Morrocans are usually very helpful and try to encourage you to barter with them. For the most part it is a good laugh and I never managed to actually insult anyone, even when cutting the price offered into to a quarter. All good fun and you can get some real bargains for excellent quality items.
great. Wonderful experience - felt like we were on a film set! You see the traditional with the new but realise this is life as it still is.

Huge fun for shopping. We love the souk. Much easier to wander round this visit than 15 years ago. Less hassle from the traders and more smiles all round. Maybe that is because we are older. As always, watch out for your handbag and bargain, bargain, bargain. We bought rugs, fabrics, ceramics and shoes, and came away happy about every purchase.

souk. a little daunting when first entering but go in with confidence and it is so much fun. its a good idea to have an idea what you may want to buy and how much you may be prepared to spend. haggle with the taders for the best bargains. a great experience in itself.

Colourful, massive and non-threatening. We didn't bother with a guide to tour the souks and if you travel abroad a lot I really wouldn't bother. However if you are of a nervous disposition and have a really poor sense of direction you may consider a guide a worth while expense.The souks are enormous, they seem to go on forever and there are loads of little side streets and alleyways off each one to explore further. There does seem to be one area where all the leather goods are concentrated but apart from that it seems that everything you could possibly want can be bought somewhere or anywhere in the souks.It's really colourful and could be quite claustrophobic if you are that way inclined, however my overriding impression was of a really lively, colourful place. We didn't feel intimidated once when we walked through, most of the shopkeepers left you alone - although be warned if you do make eye contact, or God forbid actually pick something up to have a closer look at it consider yourself sold to!

Marrakesh Souk. This was our first visit to Marrakesh,so we just had to go and visit the souk.It's absolutely crazy and such good fun.It's noisy,chaotic and very,very busy.All the stall holders expect you to haggle,one even told me I wasn't doing it correctly and showed me how to haggle the right way.Watch out when buying spices,most are excellent value for money but I bought some Saffron which I'm not sure is Saffron!It's good to see it at night also.It looks magical all lit up at night but it can be so busy it felt a little threatening.We did not stay long.A little tip,do not take any photographs of the snake charmer's or their snakes,they will then demand money from you for this privledge. There are no notices advising customers of this and one man got quite cross when I innocently made this mistake.All in all It is well worth a visit and is really good fun.

Medina Guide, Marrakech. We visited Marrakech recently. We were two females on a city break. We used guide Youssef Kharroub. We found him to be professional, punctual, knowledgable and friendly.He went above above and beyond for us. He met all our expectations and more. I would highly recommended this guide.

Enjoyable Madness. Absolute joyous chaos, that put a big smile on my face.You WILL get lost, (and dont bother trying to follow overhead signs back to the square, they will only take you the wrong way on purpose) You Will get constantly hassled.If you do buy something be prepared to haggle ridiculously, I bought a souvenir, The stall started at 2800dh I got it for 300dh (about £25) which was probably still too much.I know all this sounds terrible but it really is good fun.
Vibrant and lovely. The souks are fantastic so make sure you go! Do not stray too far off the main routes as you end up in local backstreets which are confusing

Fun but bargain hard. The shops outside the souks have the better stuff and are more pleasant to visit than the crazy souks. If it is your first time to Marrakesh, it's fun, but after a while, it's just more pleasant going into a shop where you are not hassled.They attempt to charge extortionate prices, up to 5 or more times the value. Everything in Marrakesh can be bought for less than what they offer. By the end of my visit, I started telling the shop owners that they should give me a sensible price as I know the value of things. I then said I would make one offer only and if I walked out, my next offer would be LOWER than the first. This worked pretty well, as they always want to make a sale.It gets boring doing all the bargaining, and takes way longer than it needs to.

The best Christmas ever!!. My adopted family and I came here on an amazing Christmas that I'll never forget. We visited the market on our 10 day travels and it's amazing. Not for those how dislike hustle and bustle but its a magical place like stepping back in time. Make sure you try the fresh orange juice and the most important thing to do is Haggle done to a price your happy to pay and go for it. We also had a fantastic coffee and sat people watching for hours ..... Amazing place.... True inner City Adventure!!

You either love or hate it!. Glad we went, not sure we would go again to the souk! Think you'll either love it or hate it. Definitely recommended going with tour guide initially otherwise you'll risk getting completely lost as it is a real maze!

Superb!. This was my first time in a north African souk and I loved it. I'm not tolerant of being pestered in bazaars but unlike some other reviewers I found it delightful. The shop keepers are good-natured and take 'Non merci. Plus tard, peut etre' for an answer quite happily. The bargains to be had can also fantastic - we bought a typically Moroccan leather pouffe for the equivalent of about £28 and, as chance would have it, the Sunday Paper on our return had the identical one advertised for £130.As well as all the tourist stuff, the fringes of the souk remain 'local' and the residents buy their fish, meat and vegetables there too. I was surprised how relatively clean it all is as well. The modeds are a hazard though.Fantastic place - the heart of the city.

Huge place where you will get lost but lots of fun. Leave a half day to explore this huge market; wonder along the tens of lanes and corridors of this maze and stop to try the minted tea or the fabulous orange juice.
Colourfull. Terrible annoying. Difficult to enjoy the charming bazar because of the agressiv men from all the shops
Marrakech Market. Fresh & cheap orage juice is recommended..You must try it!

A colourful maze. You have to be prepared to just wander - the place is a maze but so colourful and interesting and the shop owners, though they obviously tout for business, are pleasant and amusing. Watch out for the mopeds though!

Great fun, worth getting lost. The souks are not to be missed. Dive in, tolerate dodging mopeds, and enjoy the craziness. If you don't want to be persuaded to browse (no charge) and buy, buy, buy....just continue to walk. Ignore the requests. Start bidding far, far below the asking price and be ready to spend a fair amount of time haggling. If you don't find what you want at one stall, keep walking - there will be many others selling the same thing.
best place. this was my best shopping experience in my life. i never seen such a crazy souk and shoppers/sellers.

Fun experience. I love a good market. The souks are endless and maze like. GPS is a great recommendation. The maps in the guidebooks are almost useless but they are always young folks around willing to lead you in the right direction for some dirhams. Haggle haggle haggle. Do not accept the first price. Plenty of different languages spoken here.
OMG!!!. If you like to haggle, then this is a must. Amazing products, amazing prices.... Can't wait to return.
The Best Souk in the Arabic World. It is for sure one of the bigger and most clean souk in the Arabic World. It is colourful with good quality shops and it is a must visit while in Marrakesh

Claustrophobia. If you're the sort that feels panicky and under stress in a strange, enclosed space, surrounded by people you don't know speaking a strange language, and you don't know the way out, then avoid the Marrakech souk. Or just look into one of the entrances, so at least you can say you've seen the place. You won't have missed much, and you'll go home with happier memories of Marrakech.
The Souks, Marrakech. The Souks were something else! There was a riot of colour everywhere. Go for the leather slippers, they're fabulous.

Souk Galore!. A miriad of colour and noise. Not for the faint hearted and a guide is a good idea. Never accept first price and don't be scared to make your own"best price" - they can always say no! They very persistent.

Buzzing. You can buy all of your genuine fakes here.You do not get as much hassle here as you do in Turkey. There are guides to show you around if you require but we found our way about quite easily. It is easier by daylight

What a terrible place to go to. Unless you say you come from Russia don't go into the Soukh. Everybody want to sell you their trade and they all want to know where you come from and how long you staying for and where you are walking to. A terrible experience. At the end I rented a guy to keep the others away from me for 2 euro!

don't miss it!. colourful, noisy, exciting, so very, very, very different from our uk shopping centres!!, even perhaps a little scarey at first - kept close to our guide to start with - but then became surprising adept at haggling!!

Very lively. Some good bargains to be had if you're willing to haggle. Lots of leather, ceramics etc Go with plenty of space in your luggage. The Moroccan lanterns are particularly nice and not too expensive.
An experiance not to be missed. Great fun walking around experiencing the Souk, at first it is quite intimidating but you soon realize everyone is friendly , helpful and wanting to please.

Fantastic experience. We loved the souks, the colours, the smells, one is immersed in a once in a life time experience. Initially we were concerned that we would find it all too overwhelming, not the case, we returned a number of times during our stay. We found the stall holders whilst keen to sell always accepted a firm polite, no thank you. I made sure that when buying jewellery I selected one stall and bought a number of items thus getting the best deal. I also stayed away from dusty, unkept stalls and tried to look for what I thought was better quality and there certainly is a range. Be careful when buying leather that the dye doesn't come off, we were very particular with our leather poufs, spending a lot of time checking stitching, leather etc I was very keen to buy a lantern but to date haven't seen the right one, again different metals and different qualities. Recognised most of the scarves from previous trips to India and China. Don't worry about getting lost you will eventually find your way out, just enjoy the experience.

Marrakech best Souk i have been to. Best souk shopping experience i have had, better than Old City of Jerusalem, Istanbul's Grand Bazaar and several others i have been to around the world. Large variety of goods of all kinds, reasonable prices and most proprietors are quite helpful and not pushy. Highly recommend ( bought from both of them)a. Al Matjar au fil d'or #26 souk semmarine for quality carpets and pillows at reasonable prices b. Chez Chraibi Rachid # 51 Souk Ablouh Semmarine for pillows, poofs and fabrics

Great Market to Spend Some Time. Although I cannot say that this souk is completely different from various bazaars you might find in other countries, there's still nice ambiance and excellent opportunities for venturesome bargaining and extraordinary shopping. I would recommend particularly to buy here the pieces of interior, spices, carpets and different cosmetics. Also check out the jewelry! The downside for Marrakech Souk is that it is very big and the goods on sale are pretty much the same everywhere, except in some exquisite shops. Especially I'd recommend you to find a store named Tafilalet Creation at Souk Semmarine, which has an excellent selection of truly original Moroccan colliers made with precious and semi-precious stones.

Bewildering difference. ..and you can buy things once you get your bearings but it is overwhelming at first and difficult to orientate at first. People come at you from all angles plus motorbikes, donkeys with carts full of produce.. Exhilarating... No health, safety, hygiene or any of that stuff. Very different... A guide is useful but will probably arrange for cousin to sell you stuff.. Just be aware and dive in..

Here you can anything. Truthfully a souk is a souk and they are much the same elsewhere. For a first time visit to a souk this is as good as you can get. Obviously one has to be careful of pickpockets of being ripped off and another hazard is children on bikes. I would say this is a "must do" if you haven't been to a souk before. Personally I prefer the souks in Dubai and Istanbul

great sights, sounds and smells. We came here as part of a day trip around marrakech we walked round and round all the twisting allyways of the souks though all the different areas from woodwork to metalwork to lamps and ceramics all of those areas were very interesting to see the men at work crafting items to sell, what let the souks down for us was the 100s of stalls selling imported junk for china etc, even our moroccan guide openly admited to us the souks have been ruined some what over the last few years because of the shortage of traditonal handy craft. It is hard to see how the 16000 stalls can make any money as they do all seem to sell the same thing, but it is most definatly well worth a stroll through to take in all the colours and sounds and smells of this crazy place

Better than expected!!!. What a fascinating place - lots to see - make sure you explore the whole area and see all the tiny workshops where amazing work is going on. Try not to ask for directions from youths - if you don't intend to hire them as guides they will send you in the wrong direction! As far as buying is concerned we tried to decide beforehand what we wanted to spend and walked away if the price didn't come down - this usually worked

good but a lot of the same. For atmosphere, you can't beat walking around the Souks. But you will see a lot of the same goods for sale over and over and the vendors start haggling at very high prices. Walk away if they don't come down. They'll follow you and offer a reasonable price in the end.
Hassgallinggg. The soul owners will constantly hassle you,. but thats ok, that is their way of welcoming you. We enjoyed haggling at the souks and my wife was just the best at it lol

Great fun. Go with just a guide book and enjoy wandering around. The traders are very polite and friendly and enjoy having fun. They do not hassle . If you do not want to buy they respect 'Non Merci'.There are a few wome with children who beg at the street corners and welcome a few coins but they do not pester.

Imposing but worth it. The souk is intimidating, masses of small shops and stalls. Don't be put off by the constant attention you get if you linger too long browsing. Be prepared to do some serious bartering.There is, amongst the cheap stuff, some real bargains to be had.I would think twice before coming here with small children and especially with teenage girls. Its really for adults.

A wonderful vibrant experience!. It's crazy crazy but an absolute fabulous experience.
First time here and can honestly say it was wonderful and amazing. Such wonderful people who really are happy for you to just look.
An absolute must and would definitely go again.

Great fun, but not for the faint hearted.. It was a wonderful experience the first time, so we had to go back for more. Haggle! Its worth it and the more you haggle, the more you enjoy getting a bargain.

Shopping for brave souls - but great for wandering.. Loved the atmosphere, colours and smells of the souk. On the whole we were not pestered as much as I thought we might be, but be warned! If you show the slightest sign of being interested in anything and just ask to have a look it is very difficult to extricate yourself, and some sellers took it as a bit of an insult if you didn't buy. Others seemed to realise that this approach doesn't work with reticent English people and so were happy to wave you off with a cheery "maybe later?". If you are bold there are bargains to be had in clothing, leather goods and spices, but you need to haggle hard and be prepared to walk away.

Leave space in the Souk-case for the journey home!. Know the rules of this place and you will come away with bargains and experiences to remember. The rules are simple - if you don't want something, politely say no. Smile, laugh and enjoy the banter, but don't be upset that they may want to encourage you into their shop for another bargain. If you do like it, as for their best price and then offer a quarter of what they respond (provided you are willing to pay that!). They will laugh and ask you to make an honest offer having reduced their offer by 10%. Come up by 10% and then walk away when they refuse. If they can sell at that price they will offer for you to return to the store and try to raise the price. Keep firm with your offer and walk away. They will not sell at a loss and you will find the same products in the souk elsewhere if your offer is too low. We brought huge amounts of bargains using this method and on only one deal did we walk away with nothing brought. You come away translating the value to what you would have paid in UK and they watch you leave knowing they have got you to pay more than they could have sold it to a local! Everyone's a winner in this place. The only problem was my suitcase was too heavy for the return journey. We joked that I should have brought a spare souk-case!Loved it

Not for the light hearted. This place is well worth a look,but if you enter expect to be hounded,if your going to buy,half at least what they ask and stick to your price,if more than 1 item get even cheaper rate remember there all selling the same and want to make a sale, Good luck .

Get lost and love it. You'll get lost, accept it and enjoy it. You'll find your way out of it eventually! You could wonder around the souks for hours and hours, pick up some bargains and see some true artisans at work. It's worth searching for fairtrade and original craftsmen as you get a better deal and are supporting responsible tourism!Always walk with the traffic and not against it if you want to save your toes, bikes will avoid you this way but if you walk directly towards them they'll expect you to move!

Several visits advised. On our first visit we were a little overwhelmed and did not want to stop and look for fear of hassle. However, having checked out prices at Ensemble Artisanale, we returned and I enjoyed bartering down to reasonable prices on sandals, a bag and a belt. Loads of choice and great in small doses!

Watch Out! Marrakech is no tourist paradise and can be dangerous!. I was nearly robbed or worse, about 10 days ago, in Marrakech. Ironically, it was the same scenario my husband had tried to warn me about before I left (I never got around to opening that link). I wandered around a corner of the souks, not far from the Marrakech Museum, and had lunch at a table in the middle of a busy (with the locals) area, a narrow corner. The lunch was amazing. A local young man, exceptionally tall and thin with a sort of weird mohalk-like blondish-dyed hair style, talked me into seeing the wool dyer, and when I showed no interest in buying scarves from his buddy, he suggested he show me "the tannery" and I agreed. He stayed far ahead of me and I found myself running to keep him in sight. After a while I had gone pretty far, all through a residential area, with a few people out and about, and I started coming to my senses. When we reached "the tannery", it was not, it was a deserted construction site, I did not go in. He and his buddy, who had materialized there, did not accept the tip I had had ready to give him and insisted on more, so I gave him what I had handy and I quickly turned around and got as far as quickly as I could. Yes, I know it was foolish to follow a stranger anywhere. I had just figured he would want a tip, which I was willing to do. This was a close call.Also, I want to tell people that I did not find any bargains there in the Marrakech souks. A few shops would sell day to day items at the local prices, but mostly they charge the tourists at least double, which isn't terrible, but after a while the wallet is empty. The merchants started out asking for 4 times what locals tell me they would pay for the same item, and you can't get them to come down much farther. After a while, I quit trying to buy anything - the scarves are just "Pashima" which means nothing; probably rayon, made in China. A great place to buy things - the only one- was the Artesan Center, located near the Cyber Park. I was very pleased with the prices and the quality of the various leather goods and clothing I purchased there. However, the jewelry store was just the same as everywhere else, including Essouira - very little actual silver, sterling or even 800, to be found. The prices on the few sterling items I found were the same as the US, as they wont really negotiate on these. Most of the metal is silver colored but completely devoid of any silver stamps, although they would always try to fake it and show some kind of tiny imperfection and claim that was the stamp.The air pollution in Marrakech was dreadful. It has to be very unhealthy (I came down with bronchitis, as had the young lady we were visiting who lives there). You just want to spit out the awful air, and it is hard to accept breathing in that pollution, but you have no choice.As an older woman, I was not harassed as much as my daughter and her friend, but every moment outside for them was a trial. They were constantly harassed. There are many many young men out on the streets with little or nothing to do. They were targets. It was a little better for them when I was with them. Taxi rides were variable. We depended on taxis and took them several times a day. We experienced everything - friendly drivers who actually used the meters who circled the area to increase the fare, or towards the end mysteriously bumped up the fare on the machine - they can do that - so a meter really is besides the point. And negotiation is a pain. The drill is that you signal a cab, they pull over, you tell them where you want to go, and if they agree you get in the cab. You then pay them what they should be paid, which ranges from about 10 to 25 Dh. Mostly we paid 20 which was about 5-10 Dh overpayment, but reasonable and fair for us. Not much to see in Marrakech. The cyberpark is interesting if you are in a larger group or not female, but the air is very polluted.We went to Marrakech for the purpose of visiting someone; I cannot understand why anyone would actually go there without a compelling personal reason. I really feel for the King - he has his hands full in that city, although there were tons of tourists, even in mid-March, which was mostly cold and dreary, so perhaps no improvements are needed to attract tourists. We really liked the riad in the Medina where we stayed - I have reviewed it, with high praise. And we were glad to stay with a very hospitable family for a few nights.We spent a weekend in Essouira, which has a beautiful beach and coastline. The kinds of fish caught there are interesting. I already warned of the restaurants on the pier - we had the worst "meal" imaginable there, at a very high cost. The prepared fish in the square Jamal Al Fna, in Marrakech, is just wonderful, and a tenth of the price. I highly recommend going to that square for dinner, although the proprietors use their hands when they serve you your food. They touch everything. Yes, I have a touch of the diarrhea and so did my daughter, and it is pretty common for the residents, too.Good luck and feel free to ask me any questions you might have.

Huge difference between day and night visit!. Our first visit to the souk area of Marrakech was at night. The area literally had tens of thousands of people. It was very lively with music, dancing, snake charmers, monkeys, very interesting food choices and plenty of shopping. We did not eat in this area since we were headed to a restaurant. While some of the food looked good, some of it was bizarre - a family was gathered around a table eating out of a boiled sheep's head (wool still attached). There were many vendors selling beautiful dried fruit and spices. The souk booths sold leather goods, scarves, moroocan slippers and various other items. The two cautions that I have are the little children begging you to buy their trinkets. Just like other areas of the world, once you buy something it starts a feeding frenzy! The other caution would be the women who do the henna tattoos. While they do a wonderful job , they will just grab your arm and start drawing then demand payment - very pushy. While the souks push their wares, they were not as bad as I thought they would be. If you are a fan of watching old Tarzan movies you will feel like you are on the movie set if you visit at night. In the day it is much different. Most visitors are there for the souks and there is not the dancing and music. You can still find a snake charmer or two. You definitely want to visit if you find yourself in Marakech.

A feast for your eyes. Don't be afraid to get lost. Eventually you'll come out somewhere you recognise. Be prepared to be tough as if you stop to look at something you will be set upon within seconds. Of course you will be the nicest person they've ever met and the price they want the cheapest they've ever offered. I stopped to examine a leather belt and was told it was 250dm's. It quickly came down to 150 until I showed him the one I was wearing which cost 85dms in Tesco. I came away with three belts for 200dms. I had a long barter with one old guy over a tagine and suddenly he told me I was obstinate. Amazed he knew the word he immediately dragged out a copy of Robinson Cruesoe from under the counter and told me he was half way through it! I gave up! The souks are just great. The locals are very friendly and there are some real bargains to be had. Give yourself at least eight hours over four visits.

Just another Souk. Not much different from other souks we have visited. The items on offer are more aimed at the tourist, I find those for the locals more interesting. Having said that we were not looking to buy anything but did purchase two items at very knock down prices when our low offers were accepted as we walked away. Can be fun but not unique.

Souken is fun but not different. To visit Souken is of course a must when visiting Marrakech. It is different in the meaning that it is calmer but also more "in doors" than other markets. But, what is offered is not very different from other places/markets in the world.
Not so clean but an experience. Went through the souks y guide. Think that is it necessary - then they leave you - otherwise they want all to take you into there store.

Better than expected.. The souks were really nice. I would love to have bought a few things; only I couldn’t take them home on the plane due to the size of items they were selling. Lots of lovely lights, tagines and tea sets. I did get hassled lots, but I just ignored the people and they went away.

Amazing!. If everybody in the world bought something here, there'd still be plenty left over!! Have never seen such a huge souq. Easy to get lost, but that's part of the fun. Loads of little eateries and local cafes - all very cheap and very good.

Brilliant, but keep your wits about you!. Its great just to wander around the stalls. Basically they are mostly selling the same sort of things, but slightly different stall to stall. When you have had enough wandering just stop for a cool drink in the square and watch the world go by. You must be aware that some of the stall holders can be a bit aggressive and my husband and Iwere literally conned into seeing the tannery when we stopped to look at a leather belt, and had a bit of trouble leaving when we didnt want anything and were told BY THE BOSS that the workers didnt earn much so we shold give him some money to give to them! He wasn't very pleasant about it, so beware

You need to be strong. Fantastic colurs and atmosphere in the souks. You need to decide what you are willing to pay and stick by your decision. I was followed for ages by a man selling belts. His opening offer was 150 MAD, aventually I got 3 for 120 MAD. They were very good quality leather and I think I got a bargain, only time will tell. The Mopeds in the souks are so annoying, but it is their market. There must be hundreds of stalls, often grouped by type. So much pottery, which is very overpriced to start with, you need to be strong to drive the price down. Lots of vegetables and some disgusting cuts of meat and offal for the locals, no charge for the flies! From previous bitter experience avoid any offers from guides, they want a lot of money and can get nasty.

Great fun!. The souks were great fun and haggling wasn't taken too seriously. In fact, we were even asked, with a smile, if we 'were ready to play' when we asked the price! The souks were nowhere near as intimidating as we were expecting and the Marrakech people were very friendly.

Good things to buy. Very overpriced. Also can be dangerous. CAUTION: nearly got robbed and maybe worse. Went with very tall thin young man with large blandishments dyed Mohawk. He offered to "show me the tannery". Just like YouTube video warns against. I walked a long way before I got smart enough to turn back. Was just about to head into a deserted area. Very close call!!Shopping: Was just too much work to get prices down to twice what the locals pay - they start the price at 4 or 5 times the local price. Everything is doubled for "whites" - and non Arabic speakers. That being said, some shops were straight with food and necessary items. But just expect to pay at least double.
