NOTE: Pashima doesn't mean a thing- it's not the name of any fabric. I was fooled every which way- price and quality. Wasted money!! Probably made in China of synthetics, just like the ones in Florence, Italy in the marketplaces.
Souks. Use a Tourist Guide (tip only) and limit the number of shops he wants you to visit. Two and a half hours was sufficient & I tipped him £7.

A real feeling of Morocco. This place is nice, quiet and in the shadows. No one is trying to convince you to buy, i mean not in the aggresive way done in other places. The prices are good, very good actually. No need to be afraid of the people not speaking foreign language, they do, you will understand each other.

Rainbow souks. You get hassled but it's an experience not to be missed. As you navigate the alleys, mopeds will whizz past you and donkeys will squeeze past. All very chaotic. You will be shouted and and cajoled to go into many shops. Difficult to browse under such circumstances. Allow plenty of time and go when it's not too hot. Take time for lunch to recharge. Cafes above the square in a souk have roof top terrace - great people and carpet watching! Buy a hat knitted rom the market here - lovely and colorful and these guys work so hard to earn a living.

Wonderful maize. You cannot go to Marrakech without getting lost in all the souks! Be friendly and if you are not interested just smile and say no thank you but if you are interested take 'a butchers'. If you do t want something don't go into the shop.Be polite and if after you have purchased something and they offer you the local tea, accept and it's a wonderful experience!

Very colorful and Unique. This souk has more choices than any other souk in Morocco,Again, bargain, reduce the prices by 2 or 3 times! Buy directly from the ones who make things, they are not at the start of the souk, deep in side the souk, and plus they are less aggressive!
robbers. I had with me a Moroccan friend in all occasions they tripled the price for me so I always let her budge with them.

A very different experience. Several specialist areas of the Souks were good, e.g. leather work, metal work and lights, but most were just selling "tourist tat". Be prepared to get lost as they are very narrow with lots of twists and turns. We always felt safe (if hastled) and be prepared to say "no thanks" often.

A must experience. You couldn't cram anymore into smaller spaces than in the shops here. Was warned not to do them at night! And to watch your bags. Listen out for the shop owner with the english sayings, really made us laugh. But mostly watch out for donkeys and men wheeling their goods, they have the right of way!. Watch out also for motor bikers.

What a chaos but I loved it!. Go for the experience and be ready to get lost. It is a labyrinth with different colors, smells, sounds and people. At some point I kept cpming back to a same place for three times. At the third time a carpet seller waved me over and gave me a direction. I sat down with him and he treated me mint tea.

Incredible centre of Marrakech. Fascinating and full on centre of Marrakech which cannot fail to interest you in the Moroccan way of life. The people are friendly and the food on sale fresh and cheap at the stalls. However, you do need to barter hard with individual sellers for all other items or you will be paying far too much. They expect you to do this. If you need to get a map out then expect a lot of offers to take you where you want to go. Unfortunately they will expect paying when you get there. We were actually taken where we didn't expect to go by what appeared to be a decent young man, the tannery which is not pleasant, then asked for money!Basically a great place but you need to have your wits about you.
Not too pushy. A pleasant change from the hassle you get in Egypt, here the people are happy for you to simply look in their 'shops' without trying to force you in

A must see but be prepared to be hassled. Visiting the souks in Marrakech is an essential part of the whole experience but be prepared to be hassled by the store keepers. Watch out for those wanting to show you the way - most of them will either lead you to a spice store (owned by a friend?) or they will want money. Best advice is look straight ahead and keep your mouth closed!

Morocco on a plate. By far the busiest souk in the country and a must not miss experience.A polite but firm non, merci normally gives the traders enough of a hint to leave you alone. If they ask you where you are from then make something up - random places in Eastern Europe works for me - confuses the heck out of them.

A maize!. We went in the morning and we got hassled a bit by the stall holders but then we went again about 6 pm. It was much better and we could look at our leisure. Very interesting and definitely worth a visit.
Souk delight. Visiting the Souk simulates all one's senses. The constant noise, smells, sights, tastes and feelings are a delight to an open mind but not for the faint hearted !

Cultural shopping. The area is a haven of small streets and shops selling varying goods in leather, bags, shoes etc etc and tourist goods. Cafés and restaurants abound, but not bars! Beware the guides who will constantly apprehend you and follow you around trying to get you to visit here, there and everywhere. Tip we were given, if they are wearing a suit or jacket, say NO and ignore them, and do not give them or offer them money!

Great place to shop for Moroccan products. In my opinion, the souks of Marrakech were much better and more interesting than those in Fes and Casablanca. You have many options of things to buy such as souvenirs or food options. I found the products to be cheaper here than in Fes or Casablanca but that all depends on your negotiating skills as most of the time the price is doubled or even tripled as they know you will try to haggle your way down.As with any high-tourist attraction I would advise everyone to be wary of their valuables and to make sure their bags/purses are securely closed and preferably in front of you so as to keep an eye on them.

Souk. I share all the other reviews - what a place - like traveling back in time. A guide is worth it if you can afford it - not to expensive but avoid hiring guide on street go through reputable company. We stayed at Sofitel Hotel and although it was just 15 mins walk we had to run the gauntlet of people offering to show us where to go (on average 6 times) Do not trust them ! If you don't what them to lead you they will point you in the wrong direction - revenge! If you do allow them to show you they will take you the long way round and demand anything from 5 euro upwards. Many will also take you to a Berber shop were you will be sat down offered tea and give a very hard sell. I say this as it was our first time in Marrakech and the maps and street are a nightmare almost impossible to navigate effectively. The best way to navigate is to use the largest mosque as a beacon - the wood structure on top points straight Mecca and to the Souks main square. Watch the taxis to they will always attempt to charge more- find out from local what is reasonable and refuse to budge. When it comes to shopping start at the state run co-op ( quality is good and prices very fair) not far from the Souk that gives you a good idea of the right price to pay then you can go and barter with confidence in Souk.Best tactic I found was to start at a good/fair price often a third of what they start at and just stick there hold you nerve and you often do the deal( although the smile is not always there afterwards!) The street food is very reasonable and good just avoid the salads and non bottled water and I found no tummy issues.

good fun to get feel of the country. The Souk is great for getting a feel of the people and county.The normal snake charmers s may not be every ones cup of tea but the shops and battering was great,Needs time to adjust to the whole scene.We felt quite safe there unlike some other countries.
souk. Geat just get lost Didn't feel intimidated wandering about.we last visited Marrakech 4 years ago and felt this time that the stall holders had calmed it down a bit.

What It's All About. It's the quintessential reason to visit Marrakech. Its exactly how you have seen in on TV and films all your life. Accept when you are there you get the full on experience no media can capture.

Know where you are!. Welcome back to a scene from the bible! Absolutely overwhelming experience having gone there after a mountain adventure. Senses knocked over with the sounds, smells and presence of the place. However, keep your wits about you and don't be frightened of telling the 'helpful' people to get lost if you are happy with just wandering. Any sign of doubt and they take advantage of the western habit of being polite and reserved. IF you get absolutely, hopelessly lost then don't panic, just keep wandering around the market areas until you find yourself again. If you find yourself in the streets behind the souks the local kids will realise you are lost and will guide you back - just appoint one 'guide' otherwise you wil be the pied piper and will pay accordingly. A few Dirham to the helpful kid is only polite as a thank- you but don't over do the generosity coins only - that fuels problems for other visitors. I even had a great shave whilst in there and paid exactly the same as the locals. YOU WILL GET RIPPED OFF IF YOU DON'T PLAY THE GAME.

Don't get lost. The souks off the Jemaa el Fna are gorgeous and the vendors not nearly so pushy as they are elsewhere. It was only when I showed interest in something that the haggling started and all done with courtesy rather than bombast.
Super confusing!. Stay focused and keep your wits about you. Incredibly easy to get lost, robbed or conned.All the shops sell the same stuff but it is culturally fascinating.
A visit to all of our guide's friends shops. My previous visit to the Souk was great. This tour was a succession of visits to places where his pals could sell us something

A must to visit, but be ready to get lost!. This labyrinth of alleyways, stalls, shops, restaurants, museums, etc is the most exciting part of Marrakech. It's impossible not to get lost, but be careful about accepting help in finding your way as it will likely involve a stop at the shop of a friend/relative before you get to your destination.

Row upon row of tat!. As an experience, the souks are great to wander around and watch. But literally, Nothing of any quality and even the spice market was really disapointing compared to Grand Bazaar in Istanbul

An experience!. Famous and hugely entertaining with the colour, noise and chaos. Everywhere you turn there is someone trying to catch your eye to lure you to spend money with them. You have to be so alert also to the ladies who try to apply black henna to you before you have had a chance to say no and then charge you 200dirhams! It isn't just the expense but black henna can cause a bad reaction for some people. Apart from the ladies there are food stalls, fruit juice areas and shops that sell anything you could possibly think of. If any shop doesn't have what you want the owner will always have a 'brother' who can get it for you! Make sure to start bargaining at least 1/3 of the price quoted and be prepared to walk away. Have a drink, non alcoholic only in this area, on one of the rooftop terraces to soak up the atmosphere.
Disappointing. Didn't buy anything for the first time ever as there was just too much hassel and hard sell even if you stopped for just a second.

Fascinating and Colourful!. A feast for the eyes and senses. Get a guide the first day but don't buy anything! Check the prices and buy your last day in Marrakech, by then you'll know what a real bargain is. And don't be ashamed to haggle, they love it!

Amazing experience. The souk is a wonderful experience, so many stalls and shops selling rugs, slippers, jewellery, wooden ornaments, lampshades, metalwork, souvenirs, food, spices, leather bags, scarves and perfume. You will have to haggle for everything, but that is part of the fun! It's a good idea to check out a fixed price shop like the ensemble des artisans first to get an idea what the going rates are.Although everyone was keen to make a sale, most people were good humoured and not overly persistent. Don't ask the price unless you are considering a purchase though, and always decide what the max you want to pay is before you start bargaining. If the seller won't come down to your max price, walk away, and they may well come after you with the price you want. It's sometimes hard to work out what you should pay, I didn't want to be ripped off but I didn't always want to drive too hard a bargain, as it didn't seem fair (especially for hand made crafts). It can easily take a day to walk across the souk by the time you have been shown around a spice shop, given mint tea in a carpet shop, had lunch, admired some oddities (like scorpions in a jar), got a bit lost, bought some crafts, and then found your way out.They do have signs that direct you back to the main square, and people will give directions, or show you out for a tip. Watch out for bikes in parts of the souk which are a pain.

The hassling spoils the whole experience. If you like to pause and browse and take your time, you're in trouble. Show just the slightest bit of interest in an item and you'll be lucky to get out within ten minutes and with all of your cash still in your pocket. This is such a shame, because the souks are fantastic and full of wonderful treasures, but the hassling you get to buy stuff just spoils the pleasure of exploring. The souks are also an absolute maze - so either get yourself a guide or pay real attention to where you're going, or you'll end up lost and end up paying one of the "helpful" locals who offers to guide you out... or at least, halfway out before he disappears, leaving you lost again and having to pay another "helpful" local to guide you out...

A fascinating place.... ... as all oriental marketplaces! To see such a lot of works from different artists, blacksmiths etc etc in one place! The bad side - a lot of agressive shopkeepers. Anyway - we enjoyed, this was a remarkable experience!

So exhausting.... Me and my mother was so excited to finally see the Souk. We looked forward to do some shopping and looking at different merchandise. Do not look or touch anything you might like, because they won't let you leave afterwards. You can haggle the price, but they also make the price much more expensive for tourists. The salesmen were so exhausting, we needed to leave. Of course, everyone gets lost in the souks, and no one will let you take pictures, without screaming at you. terrible experience..

busy, beautiful, caotic Marrakech. I enjoyed my stay in Marrakech but preferred the smaller cities or towns. We decided that we would need to try it out. Marrakech is busy with a lot of hustle and bustle. We checked out the souks and we were amazed. It's quite an experience. Just be prepared to handle the aggressive shopkeepers (especially in the food market). A simple "no thank you" and walking away should work. Remember that their prices are always hiked up for tourists, so offering a third or half of their asking price is a good starting point. Have fun!!

Caotic and confusioning but a lot of fun. You get lost easily over there but is so entertaining walking around and dealing with shopkeepers! Try to get at least half of the price the ask at the very beginning, you might waist few minutes but you will end with a deal

Highly annoying experience. Marrakech is the mother of all tourist traps, and the souks/Jemaa are its very heart. You will be aggressively hassled by every single merchant you pass. They will try to charge you 5-10 times what they're actually willing to sell for. They will try to body-block you when you try to walk away. If you stop to admire an item, be prepared for a hard-sell. You will be told off by snake charmers & henna ladies if you decline their services, and ripped off if you accept. "Guides" will accost you and follow you around, then demand a fee.Trying to negotiate a fair price down from an eight-fold ripoff is a charade that doesn't amuse me. Neither does being groped and harassed by an aggressive merchant. I hated that they cornered me into rudeness - a smile and a "no thank you" won't cut it. You need to walk fast and keep a "piss off" attitude if you want to get rid of these guys. I don't recommend Marrakech to anyone. Spend a day there if you really need to see it. Then move on. The rest of the country is great.

A day. It's an interesting experience you only need to do once. Watch out for the bikes both motor and cycles, they use the Souk like the roads. Take a map and keep an eye on the sun as a guide for an exit. Street food is OK but avoid salads.
Great fun!. Fun experience where you can buy some lovely gifts and things for the home. Be prepared to haggle, but a laugh and a smile will go along way!

The most exciting souk in the world!. It is a rabbit warren of exciting alleys filled with little stalls selling all kinds of treasures. It never ceases to fascinate me not matter how many times I go through it. Haggle well for your purchases. I offer a third of their starting price and don't go over a half.

Such Fun. Do not be put off by the guide books saying you may get lost. Yes you do need to avoid the motor bikes and donkeys and it is a pure tourist trap...lots and lots of stalls all selling the same thing. It is mostly tat so do not pay over the odds. Offer a 3rd of what they ask and keep to it. If you say no and walk away they follow you and agree your price. It can be a bit smelly, but no worse than Camden lock or any British Market and there are lots of cats. Don't use a guide or he will take you to his cousin's shop to buy orange oil and Black soap. The leather goods are great and very cheap. At night it is really special

Great if you are prepared. Returned to Marrakesh after 7 years and the Souks were a real hassle. Prepare to be pestered, not so much by shopkeepers as by local youths insisting on showing you the way. Try to keep cool about it and smile, but in truth it can be quite intimidating.

Felt like 007. I must say that it is a little bit complex visiting the Souk .It is a huge place , it 's chaotic ,most of the people speaks arabian or french languagesThe sales aproach it's rough , it's a mess , but it 'a authentic and it's fun!This is no Epcot , some things may shock sensitive persons.I had a tour guide , local , who made all the diference .Made the experience richer , save me time and kept unwanted people away .I strongly recomend visit in small groups and get a tour guide if possible
What an experience. Amazing experience, explore, get lost, barter, watch out for donkey's & motorbikes. You should only pay about 25% of what the original price given, but have fun having a barter.

Awful experience. Its a huge flea market. Not all that glitters is gold, keep this in mind when shopping here. I was constantly harassed by the shop keepers, to the point that you can't look at anything without them harassing oh to buy something. Their starting price is usually 5 times the actual value of the good o ou need to be a great negotiator. Not my favorite pass time while on vacation. I'm not sure what all the fuss is about. The only positive thing I have to say about the visit was seeing artisanal work being done from leather goods to iron, metal, cloth, etc.

Enjoy getting lost!. everyone gets lost in the souks and its all part of the fun so dont get stressed out by it. By day 5 we had worked out how to get in and out and nothave to rely on a pop up "guide" to get us through the maze of windy streets and stalls. Great fun and enjoy haggling for those gifts to take back too!

Crazy energy, wonderful experience if you can have a thick skin. WOW! We had an amazing time in Marrakesh. Get lost, make friends, shop and eat well. The medina is pretty much a huge tourist trap......If you say "La shukran" (no thanks) and keep walking unless you want to commit to buy, you'll be fine. Offer half price and continue shopping if they don't budge. Tell them you bargain like a "berber"! There are many teens/young adults offering to show you the way and convince you you're very lost, be prepared to give them 20 dirhams if they guide you. You most likely will figure it out after the 2nd or third day, so my advice is to have your riad host guide you to you destination on the first day. Cheers!

Really interesting. They certainly looked the part with narrow alleys, exotic items, small shops and shading against the sun provided by a mix of rafters and hangings. Could have spent ages here but unsure about pricing and safety of wallets, etc.

A Sunday in the Souks. Done a full day with a Guide and others from our hotel, so glad we did, as there is approx 16 thousand stalls in the Souks, it was mad and the streets was so narrow, iv a great scene of direction but I will admit after 20'mins I found myself lost, with the guide was the best way to see the most without trying to find places yourself, this was great expect for the motorbikes so watch out they are crazy!

shop till you drop. the place is steeped in history, look not just at the goods as fater a while you realise everyone is selling pretty much the same stuff, but the construction and the myriad of mazes. a good place to shop is the co-operatives of the berber and toureg people as the money goes out to the tribes etc.if you are adventurous go to the outer edges and around the melah area or Jewish quarter prices are much much cheaper and this is where locals shop.We are always happy just to wander through the souks and chat to the shop owners and stall holders, buy the odd item and its good exercise!
Get lost and then sit down at a stall for mint tea when you're tired!. They are not as intrusive and insistent as the stories say - we found we could enjoy looking without feeling too harassed

unbelievable. lots of colour and spectacle
Use a local guide to show you around, and some of the older parts / workshops. Quite easy to get lost as over 5000 stalls
Remember to haggle - offer 1/3 and end up somewhere nearer halfway

Fantastic atmosphere but buy elsewhere. The souks are amazing places and just go on for ever. There isn't much hassling which is great but the quality of the goods is pretty ropey. The best place to buy anything is at the Artisanes Ensemble (about a 5 min walk from Place Jeema el Fna). This is a government backed initiative to let local craftsmen sell their products at a fixed price. Experience taught me that the souks will eventually (possibly) come down to similar prices but with vastly inferior quality.

A madhouse but a must see!. An assault on the senses on every way. You will be harangued pulled and hassled but you must go and experience this wonderful place. We ate in the main square where they set up impromptu stalls selling all sorts of wonderful foods. We bought stuff, and haggled, for what seemed like hours, every time we wanted to buy something. We wondered at the things on sale from food, spices, clothes, tourist tat to the lady selling second hand false teeth in the main square (I kid you not!). The only down side we had was one evening in the main square there was a group of young men dancing, in traditional costumes, to drums which all seemed very nice until you didn't give them any money as to be honest a ten second dance didn't, in my opinion merit a tip. There were a few glares but nothing much worse.

Very intrusive traders, but you can find some nice stuff.. Very intrusive traders, but you can find some nice stuff. If you know what you're looking for, go for it and you can find a nice deal. In case you are lost in this place, trust none of this traders. They all say they will help you find the way out but for real all they want to do is show you their shop or get some money before they show you the way out. We bought some spices, tea and pottery here, for in our opinion a good price. The negotiating is for sure very fun to do.

Lovely souk. We have been to a number of souks in recent times and this one was very nice. We found they are not such big hasslers as some reviews make out. Just practice your Laa Shukraan and be firm. Haggling was also fun and enjoyable (compared to some Asian countries). The parts closest to the square are busier and higher prices.
Great Souk with intersting products. Brilliant place to shop but always always haggle and even walk away if you have to but then you "might" get the right price

Great place. Visiting the souk is a great experience, Small alleyways packed with stalls selling all manner f items , after a while it does get a tiresome as most shops are replicated, The shopkeepers arent as pushy as in other North African countries and you do need to barter to get a good price. Its worth doing your homework first as different parts of the souk sell different items . An enjoyable experience but keep your wits around you and your valuables safe ..

Souk Sucks. Too much hassle! We want to just browse not be constantly hassled. It is impossible just to view and handle goods without being subjected to a very hard sell - often on something you have no interested in or desire to buy.

Cannot believe this is three hours away from London!. Three hours by plane to a completely different world! So many sights, smells and colours to experience. We loved the bustling souks and really got the hang of haggling for beautiful scarves. I almost felt that the stall holders were disappointed if you don't haggle a bit! We ate in a rooftop cafe above the carpet and spices square and watched the world go by. The rooftop terraces are fantastic, make sure you have a mint tea or a coffee in at least one!We stayed for two days and absolutely loved the second day. However, we found the first day quite overwhelming and intimidating! We encountered a very aggressive stall holder and it ruined our day a bit, along with the hundreds of people who want to drape a snake over your shoulders or paint henna. Learn to say no and don't let pushy, rude people get to you!All in all, keep your wits about you and enjoy the experience!
Crazy!. A real experience. Have your wits about you, keen your valuables safe, be prepared to say "no" often and firmly and... haggle!

Sometimes overwehelming!. The souk is full of amazing treasures, leather goods, fabric, shoes, tea sets etc, but if you aren't comfortable bartering it can become less of an enjoyable experience. It feels as though you can't make eye contact or browse a stall for fear of being pressed into making a purchase, and these sellers are the most accomplished salesmen. The fact is that whatever price you agree on you still have a feeling that you've been had!But if you aren't fazed by all that and you can find your way round, enjoy the souk and I hope you get a bargain!

Marmite! Love it or hate it. We loved it.. The souks cover around 5km of passageways. It is impossible to navigate through them without getting lost, waylaid by helpful locals who are not averse to relieving you of a small payment for directions, shopkeepers willing to offer the 'best price'. The colours, the smells, the noise and the atmosphere all contribute to a great experience. If you don't like haggling and you value personal space, stay away. Otherwise, it's well worth the visit. Expect to beat stallholders down to around 40% of the starting price and you'll be about right.

Unbelievable. This Souk is like walking through a kaleidoscope. Amazing. We went back 4 times. We didn't buy a lot, but the experience is incredible. Do be careful about purchasing cheap leather- my bag smells horrible!!!

ali babba and his fourty thieves. Much more original than any of the other Souks I have seen - true craftsmen of leather , metal and jewellery jostle with more traditional knick knack, herbalist ,carpet and cloth shops in a labrynth of tiny streets . Walk with purpose , bargain hard but with a smile , ignore the obvious hucksters ....the theatre is unending and much of it enjoyable

souk explorer. Too much to choose from, so much colour so many people. A fun place to explore. Not as intimidating as others I have visited. Did feel the need to drop bread crumbs but we found our way out again eventually. Number 1 tip, know how much the things you want cost elsewhere, it gives you the upper hand when bargaining
great market. interesting place to visit, went with a guide was much easier than being hassled on your own. Snake charmers , monkeys all sorts to see

One of the reasons for a Marrakech vacation. If you didn't come to Marrakech to experience all the cultural differences, then why come at all? Sure, you can go to any store in Paris and pay a straight $100 for a $40 item. That's what I like about a Paris vacation, everything is pretty much what I'm used to. Yes, Marrakech is crowded, noisy, & dirty. Yes, you'll have to bargain a bit (you could always pay full price I suppose). I don't know what people are buying in the Souks that they have to worry all that much anyways, $20-100 souvenir trinkets? It's just part of the experience. Go, buy a $10 knife and for goodness sakes, have fun bargaining versus worrying about paying $5 too much. "oh geesh, I just paid $5,000 for a vacation to an "exotic" location, and that souk guy took me for $5." Note: If you want a straight price, there are the government stores and I'd usually recommend these for any serious purchase anyways (I.E. rugs).

Marrakesh Souks and Djemaa El Fna Square. Best experienced with a guide in order not to get lost or duped out of too much money! Our guide was booked through the travel company Complete Tours, via the tour operator, and was very good - we did a five hour tour which took in historical sites such as the Bahia Palace and Saadien Tombs as well as the souk. The persistence of the sellers did take some getting used to - you have to be very firm! They will also give a ridiculously high price to begin with, the expectation is that you will barter with them. We also visited the nearby Djemaa El Fna square, both in the day and the evening as it is like two different places! Be aware that if you take photographs of the street entertainers (including musicians, snake charmers and teeth pullers) or stand and watch for any length of time, they will expect you to pay them - which is fair enough as this is how they make their living! Try to keep some small notes handy to give them.

Banter similar to Glasgow Barras. After reading the reviews on here, I was terrified and took every precaution under the sun. The reality was somewhat different. Basically the stall holders are very down to earth and similar to stall holders at the Barras - if you take a similarly down to earth and cheery cheeky attitude they are very sweet. Prices are not particularly cheap unless you go to the manufacturers, however, and the one third rule is correct. Get your price from them, then offer a third and let them take it from there. The price will probably change another few times without you having to say anything. Another tip is not to take much money as saying you will return later improves the price also, especially if you actually turn up!  As for the horror stories about people being led up alleys and forced to buy carpets - that is simply the way Berbers do business - I spent this afternoon drinking about three hundred cups of tea and in many cases did not buy anything at all. You need to make your budget very clear to get away with this, however, they are simply very focussed on doing business with you and extremely good at it.So my tip of the day is - don't march about being flash with your expensive stuff or get snotty with people and they will respond very positively - and don't assume everyone that tries to get your attention is trying to force you to do anything - they just love doing business.

Prepare to get lost. Even armed with a map you are probably going to get lost. Arm yourself with some change to pay your way back to the suare as helpful individuals offer to show you the way. The price is negociable so barter.

Interesting sights, bad attitudes. Do not make eye contact and do not demonstrate interest unless you want to be followed and harassed. I don't have the stomach for the kind of bargaining it takes to shop here but my partner does and he got a great deal on some slippers. There are great things to see here, but not much worth buying. People will mislead you and then demand money for their bad directions. Bring a map and travel in groups.
Excellent experience. I just love shopping in the Marrakesh souks. Lots of friendly banter, bargains and a feast on your senses.

a chaotic maze. Of course, one comes to Marrakech to see the souk. It is an exhilarating place! We had only been to one souk prior to this one: the one in Muscat, Oman. The one in Marrakech is even busier. Here you'll see a lot of artisan workshops as well as regular stores. Craftsmen make and sell their goods right there. As soon as you look, they know that you are interested and ask you to come into their stores. It was fun in the beginning to look at sth and start bargaining. At least for me it got to be stressful pretty fast. I had the impression that everyone wanted to cheat me out of my money. Be careful! The prices you'll get quoted (and do ask them for a quote first!) are about double of what they'll let the item go for. Sometimes, especially if you don't seem overly keen on buying what you are looking at, you'll end up paying even less than half. I had seen a small caftan I wanted to get for my 3-year old niece. It was offered at 300 MAD. I bargained it down to 130 but still didn't buy. The next day I saw it at a different place. Same 300; this time I started right away with 100 but walked away. That person followed me and I did end up paying the 100 MAD (roughly €9 or $12). I still am not sure if I should feel victorious or if I got cheated regardless of my bargaining skills ;-)At any rate, it is just too much work to have to negotiate everything you want to buy. ---- In order not to get lost in all those little streets, try to come back to the main one and go from there. It worked for us!

Amazing ! Got the real flavour of the country .. Just what you would expect , packed with interest at every turn . What was good was that there was no hassling from stall holders and a sense of being quite safe . However , don't go without a guide - you could be a long time finding your way out !

Just as expected. The souk is just hoe you would imagine it to be. Winding allies & handmade goods.You can find it all here from food, spices, lanterns, bags, clothes, carpets and animals. A great place to spend a few hours and it comes alive by night!Beware the moped and donkey carts - but a must place to visit

Good luck finding your way out!!. Small and confusing alleyways, you completely loose your sense of direction and become frustrated very quickly. Not to mention every time you stop you are hounded by people to buy something, for a ridiculous price. Some of the things for sale are interesting, but show the slightest interest and someone will be offering you a crazy price before you know it.

Fascinating. I found the fact that you can't stop to look without being hassled to buy, a bit off putting but wandering around getting lost and taking in the sights, sounds and smells is an experience not to be missed.

Marrakech overall experience plus some tips. Marrakech Experience 31st Jan to 7th Feb 2014Accommodation – Riad Catalina please see separate entry.Eating out Al Bahriya in Gueliz 75 Bis Av. Moulay Rachid | Guéliz, Marrakech, Morocco We got there a bit early at 12 noon and it would appear that they were still preparing some of the main dishes so we ended up with two large fish platters (fried) for 110 dirham (£8.46) this was very good value and along with the olives bread and sauces a nice meal. By 12.30 though the restaurant was nearly full so timing is of the essence and there was some very nice looking seafood on the menu.We didn’t go back as for us there was not a lot else in Gueliz to attract us back and we spent the rest of the time in the old city. Jemaa el Fna SquareFood Stalls:At night there are numerous stalls all selling much the same thing – Tajines, Tanjia’s and kebabs of various types and sizes along with bread, chips and olives. The quality of these with us having eaten at four or five was much the same for each one and the prices again are similar.For an idea on prices on one occasion we had two mixed kebabs, one aubergine side dish, one chips and water for 150 dirham (£11.53).Tip: try to make sure you do the ordering otherwise they will say you want this, that etc and you end up with more food than you want and of course at a higher cost although still at good value. Surrounding restaurantsSituated on the outskirts of the square there are restaurants/cafes which on occasion turned out to be better quality and cheaper than the food stalls.One in particular was “Square food” (north side of the square) where on our last day we had a good meal for 125 Dirham consisting of a beef Tajine and Tanjia and a vegetable couscous Tajine. We wish we had found this one before as we would have eaten there more.Le Grand Balcon Du Cafe Glacier (south side of the square) to the left of the post office building.We did not eat here but the prices were good and the menu similar to many of the other places. The main attraction of this cafe is the view over the square and we sat there people watching while enjoying a drink.Something special?Dar Essalam (left hand side of the road walking away from the square) on 170 Rue Riad Zitoun (East side of the square)Despite having a popular guide book which mentioned this restaurant we managed to come across it by accident as we were souking around lunch time and were invited in to have a look around. Once in we were sold!This is a 17th century mansion and was just amazing! The food was more expensive than elsewhere (two Tajines plus water 270 dirham or £20) but it was good and the surroundings were quite something retaining the historical grandeur of high society living). Have a look if nothing else as they are quite happy for you to look around and there is no pressure to eat there.MoneyYou can readily change money at the airport upon arrival or at any of the banks or exchanges in the town all of them gave a similar and what we considered to be a good rate. Hotels will charge a commission so are not quite as good but not far of.WaterBottled only and the price ranged from 6 to 15 dirham for a large bottle, we found the cheapest places to be the restaurants at the edges of the square or one of the little shops as opposed to the juice and food stalls, some of whom will try it on hence the 15 dirham price.Things to seeJemaa el Fna SquareSnake charmers, monkeys, Berbers etc in the square = mainly there during the dayTip: The Le Grand Balcon Du Cafe Glacier is an excellent place to film/photo the snake charmers, monkeys etc from a safe distance if you are not sure re the snakes etc and if you do not want the hassle of their taking a photo of you then asking for 200 dirham (£16) I gave him a lot less explaining that that’s all I had.Music etc at nightHistorical places (or at least the ones we managed to get around to)Saadian tombs (10 dirham entry) – I wasn’t too bothered about this but am glad that I did Bab Agnaou Ornate gateBahia Palace (10 dirham entry) do this first before Badi Badi Palace (10 dirham entry)Marrakech museum (60 dirham entry including Ben Youssef Medersa) very few exhibits but worth seeing as a palace in its own rightBen Youssef Medersa a religious school (unused now) this was our favourite out of all of them.Wouldnt bother with – Menara Gardens a bit disappointing reallyWatch out!My wife was subject to the theft of her cardigan which thankfully was an old one. A woman approached her and slipped a gold coloured bracelet on her wrist which undoubtedly acted as a distraction whilst the item of clothing which was draped over her shoulder bag was taken.Henna – another guest at our Riad had her hand taken hold of by one of the women in the square and before she could do anything they squirted some henna onto her hand asking for money to make it into a design. Enjoy

Take the plunge and get lost !!!. Overwhelming riot of every sense .... Get lost and don't panic !!!! .... enjoy it .. when you resurface go sit in a cafe and get a cool fresh glass of fresh OJ before you jump back in. Enjoy !!!

Expect to get lost. If you can settle your gaze on the middle distance and except that the traders are just trying to make a living as they try and get your attention it is fun to wander through the lanes of the souk. You must also expect to get lost more than once but look for the red signs high on the walls with arrows pointing back to the Place Jemaa-el-fna if you are ready to escape.

Bargain hard. very confusing maze of shops and stalls selling everything from oils to shoes- bargain hard- Marrakechians love to make a deal- walk off if you have a set price and they will often catch you up to make the sale. A great experience to be had just wandering through the myriad of alleys taking in the atmosphere. Don't follow 'helpful' people if you are lost- they will expect payment- but in main, most people are open and friendly, pointing out directions if needed

Craziness!!. An unforgettable experience. As 2 very blonde single women, we were a little anxious about going alone, we needn't have worried though. As long as you stay together, keep you bag close it is great fun. The stall holders love a good barter so go for it. Everyone was friendly, funny and helpful.

Marvelous Maze. This is a maze of small alleyways with a zillion shops and stalls. You could actually lose your way quite easily but what a place to be lost in (assuming you can get back out). The sights, sounds and smell simply bombard the senses.

Shopping trip. Great markets with a range of crafts and jewellery, rugs, handbags and everything you could possibly want to but in one area.Make sure you 'haggle' to get the best deals and spend a bit of time with the sellers as they enjoy the bargaining and are proud to sell their wares. It is a good experience especially down the quieter cobbled streets where they have some good hand made merchandise. i got a lovely table, throw and some jewellery. There are alos some lovely amber/musk bars that will remind you of the moroccan scents when you return home.

a cultural whirlwind!. an experience of a lifetime! be careful of pick pocketers and be sure to dress appropriately and respectfully! amazing way to immerse yourself into the moroccan culture without going very far. shop around, take in the atmosphere, smell the spices!

Put your senses into overdrive. this place is sheer bedlam- the sights sounds smells noise of the entire area must be experienced to be believed. The never ending twists and turns of small stalls and market sellers- offering you everything from food, drink, shoes, scarves, spices, meat, mint tea, car parts( yes car parts)- old microwave ovens and other electrical goods, and remarkable handmade wooden boxes, chess sets, to belly dancer outfits- there is almost everything you could wish for ( and some things you would not wish for) to be found here. You will be asked to buy everything even if you just stop for a second to take a look- but always barter- and be prepared to be VERY firm in saying NO...they dont always understand the word no at times. You will get lost- everyone does, but keep a calm level head at all times and look for familiar features- after 2 days we mastered the ways around the souks... watch out for pedal and motor bikes - pedestrians do NOT have right of way in here!
Dark and narrow, but great fun.. Lots of goods on offer, so bargains to be had. Don't leave your shopping until a Friday as it's a religious day and half the stalls are closed.

Hideously filthy and threatening experience. I wouldn't recommend anyone bothering to visit Marrakech at all, not least the Medina and Souk areas. I have been to many Arabic cities and Marrakech is by far the worst of all of them. It exists only to take as much money from tourists as possible. Everyone us trying to get your money, one way or another. The old town areas are filthy, no attempt to clean up anything. I understand completely the plight of most of the folk who have to live there in such squalor, but the tourist authorities have done nothing to try to make the place at all appealing. The very few tourist spots, old palaces, Majorelle Gardens, etc, are OK to see, but nothing extraordinary that you won't already have seen elsewhere. The Saadian Tombs are a complete waste of time to see and virtually impossible to find. The worst thing is the attitude of the locals in the tourist areas who are determined to harass and pester you to get what they can. Souk owners are only interested in ripping you off, especially the more "up market" shops. We were asked to pay nearly £400 for three very average kaftans!!! Eventually found some the same for £10 each after a haggle.It is a dangerous place too, as are many cities of course, but there are plenty of bag-snatchers waiting on the pavements to grab your bag and jump onto the pillion seat of their mate's waiting moped to make a quick escape. It happened to us almost right outside the hotel, which was in a smart area too. Take care, don't walk anywhere after dusk, take a cab, and haggle with the cab driver before you get in. About 20-30 dirhams should get you anywhere you want to go, but they'll demand 50 dirhams and swear to you that this is the official tariff, it isn't. Despite their "cool, hip" reputation, I would not book accommodation in a Riad either. These are mainly in the middle if the old Medina area, and whilst the Riad might be OK inside, it's location certainly won't be. No taxis go in the tiny alleyways at night, so you'd be on your own in a potentially threatening environment. I'd definitely stay in a good hotel outside the old town walls and get a five minute cab ride wherever you want to go.Overall, I can't see why anyone would ever want to go to Marrakech, other than as a warm and sunny winter trip, but if you do, just stay in the hotel!

Marrakech Souk. We loved most of it but didn't like them trying to put snakes and monkeys on us. They try to pester you asking what language you speak in. Fortunately I speak Polish, they don't, so they give up easily and leave you alone. Pretend to be 'Z Polski' - best advice I can give.

Haggle away and get cursed out. We are from Asia so we know how to haggle, and after the initial over the top warm reception from the different sellers in the souk, the minute they found we could see through their prices unlike the Europeans, they showed their true colors -- far from pleasant. A pair of lamps selling for 1000 dirhams can be haggled down to half price and most people would be pleased with that. We got them for 200 dirhams after a wretched amount of time haggling. Waste of time. You can get much better stuff in other countries without the attitude.
an experience. Don't be afraid to say NO. It's a good experience and a must to go and visit.Recommend you go with tour guide and be aware they have there own shops for you to buy from.

No hassle. The shops were great and the people very friendly and only had to be told once politely in either English or French "no thank you " and they would leave you alone
The only dodgy group were those trying to get you to the tannery

Stick to your guns.. Loved walking round the souk but found the problems not so much with the stall holders but with people who come up behind you as you are looking at something, usually in a friendly manner, asking what you are looking for, then trying to convince you to follow them to their 'friends' 'family' stall.. Unfortunately you do sometimes have to be quite abrupt with them before they go away. It is useful to have a little knowledge of French.
A huge variety of goods!. There are different souks specialising in different lines. Worth a visit if you do not get worn down by the constant hassle to buy something.

go with lots of energy. been a few times before and felt the same-compared to other souks this one is just too hassley for me. not much realistic haggling more a lipservice for tourists. If this is part of your trip to Morocco then i would suggest shopping in other smaller towns on market days-cheaper more open to haggling and possibly more likely to be better quality. Although i cant vouch for the quality of the hash or opium offered every 2 minutes lol

Good orientation. We did this on day one to give us an idea of the lay-out of the city. We went to lots of places we might not have gone on our own. All the locals were friendly and respectful and we saw many places in a relatively short time. Gave us a sense of security to visit on our own.
Fun to Haggle. Lots of shops to haggle in,take your time and don't feel obliged to buy if you are browsing,you will pick up some bargains.

Once is enough!. A place you have to visit but once is enough! The first thing that hits you when you are entering is the smell! Horses and carts line the entrance and the pungent smell was still with me the next day!As I was with my daughter we didn't venture too far into the souks, as we were a bit wary. They do shout for your attention but we just ignored them, they don't seem to realise that if they don't hassle you they might get more custom.Also there were 3 circles of people watching something so we went up to a little café so we would look down on all that was going on. In the centre of one of the circles there were children, boys and girls, boxing and people were throwing coins into the area. I thought this was horrible as there were no headguards etc being used. In another circle was a man challenging people to bare knuckle fight him!I did not enjoy the experience of the souks, but everyone has their own interpretation of enjoyment.

Overwhelming but great. Don't buy anything until the second day. Just walk around and look for items that you want to buy and ask for the price. Always counteroffer with 1/3 of the price quoted then go up from there. A

The fun is getting lost.. Dont be afraid of getting lost, some people will help others will tell you to go the wrong way, however exploring is great and will find many treasures like silver craft and carvers.dont forget to barter with your every breath and take your time to wander and wander

Overwhelming In a Bad Way. Even as a Philly/NYC girl, I found the souk to be a bit overwhelming. Our first foray into the souk was literally non-stop harassment from overly pushy sellers and people who want to "show you" someplace, most often the tanneries. The best thing to do (I learned) is to give a very firm, "non, monsieur" and just walk past. DON'T MAKE EYE CONTACT! The smell can be horrible and seriously beware of the idiots on motor bikes, tearing up and down the narrow passageways. Great visually, though, especially the spice markets, but if you have a weak constitution, avoid the tanneries.
shop and eat!. A little pricier than Fez. Mostly well sign-posted so you don't get lost as easily as you would in Fez. Take a good pair of walking shoes, a fat wallet and bargaining skills.

Dirty and aggressive sellers. Not just pushy but aggressive salesmen. Mopeds rush past you at speed in the souk, very worrying. Men try to put snakes, monkeys wearing nappies on your shoulders. Horrid place. Stay clear.

Battered Senses and Wallet. Never been more politely mugged? Could have left with, a carpet! Camel, hand made leather bag, spices, medical remedies and potions, and an array of trinkets that would choke a Pharaoh. Did buy a local hand made, Pouf, leather Jacket, knocked down from 6000 to 2500 dirhams, and that is what the fun is all about. Bartering is their way of doing business, don't be scared get in there and have some fun. You won't be disappointed, but you may get Fleeced :)) Inch Allah

Interesting traditional market. Interesting market to wander around, you need to bargain with sellers and to take note of specific landmarks so as not to get lost. Traditional Morrocan artesan products and a variety of pasminas and spices.Beware of spontaneous guides who follow you around, if you want a guided tour better to organise one before entering the souks.

Have your wits about you!!. When you visit you definetly need to keep your wits about you, keeps cameras in and money away, traffic is horrendous down the little alleyways and its so so easy to get lost, again we noticed others had mentioned about young boys who demand money to take you to where you want to go... they do and in fact can be quite verbal about it .. ,my tips 1. Get a map, wear comfortable shoes, keep your eyes and ear open, motorbikes go really fast down the packed narrow alleyways... learn one word..la = means no and be assertive and confident... Dont get your cameras out and keep money separate... if you want to take photographs sit upon the terraces around the square..you will find lots of Europeans up there with same idea best way to watch the square. Dont be pulled into people putting monkeys/snakes on your shoulders then demanding money for it... dont make eye contact...or the henna tattooists try to start putting it on your hand and then charge ... saying that its a good idea to get a recommended guide to see the things you want to otherwise its so hard to find them... ensure guide doesn't take you to shops or pharmacy's for you to buy from ..waste of a day and money... food is lovely and its an experience you just need to do your homework before you go...enjoy
Souks. Some of them were very cramped and crowded and you have to watch out for the constant stream of mopeds and bikes coming through but overall interesting

What a unique and great experience.. When you first visit the Souk it can be a bit daunting. packed narrow alleyways with motor scooters whizzing by and still the occasional donkey cart while the shop keepers try to tempt you into their shop. My Riad advised that it's best to start bartering at about 25% of what the shopkeeper asks and go up to 45% to 60%. Don't be intimidated by the bartering and have fun with the shop keepers, they are not offended by your bids and, while they are trying to make a living they are also aware that they themselves are a tourist attraction and are, for the most part, genuinely trying to give you a holiday experience. be friendly and enjoy it but if you really don't like the price simply walk out of the shop. you'll most likely be called back and given the price you wanted as long as it's not too daft. Always try and think what you would pay for something back home and roughly convert it in your head if you can. It probably takes a couple of hours to get comfortable with the bartering idea for those who come from a fixed price shopping environment but once you dive in it really is great fun and the shopkeepers are very nice people. You are also completely safe. Much more so than in any major European tourist shopping area such as London or Barcelona for example. The only thing you have to worry about is spending too much money.

Not for the faint hearted. Its great, but go in the day as its a nightmare to find your way out at night and you may fall victim to the young boys who demand money to lead you back to your hotel. The central square is not to be missed. Great food and great for people watching.

Thriving souk -- one of the best in the world. I have been to many souks around the world and in my opinion, the Marrakech souk is one of the best in the world. The goods for sale are still made by Moroccans (unlike the sister souks of many other countries which, sadly, are selling Chinese tat). The goods are clever, interesting and decorative. I was pleased to see that the souk has really improved (since my first visit in 2002). It is much cleaner, there is no hassle and the items for sale are diverse enough to keep your interest as you wander through this ancient, historical landmark. A must see for anyone going to Marrakech.

busy,busy.. Really buzzing,but not selling much to visitors (blame Ryanair for that).Seemed like miles of narrow alleyways lined with shops trying to sell stuff that you wouldn't give house room to. But the atmosphere was good,the vendors were quite half hearted in their approach and didn't give much hassle.

Be Aware!. It would be an experience that you will never forget. The first day I was shocked by motorcycles and bicycles that show up suddenly. Then, I got used to it. Maps are useless in the souks. You will get lost at least once. However, I really like the place somehow and its bargaining culture. I have got some advices based on my own experiences:1) It is important to be serious. It is better to avoid eye contact. 3) Don`t be naive. Say "la"(no) if someone wants your money. If a kid wants your icecream or your money and you give him what he wants (because you are a nice person) don't forget there will be other kids around you who demand money from you. By giving them money, we only encourage the beggers. 4) Don`t forget to bargain. Keep in mind: They triple the price. Agree a price before buying anything. If the shopkeeper tries to sell something for 200 dirhem, don`t be shy to offer 50 dirhem for it. At first he will say "No. It is not possible. Are you kidding me?..." Don`t be aggresive. Try to be a friend of this shopkeeper and find common topics to talk about. Bargaining is a social activity. Theatrics are all part of the game. There are some tactics. You may say "It is not worth it..." And the best tactic is not to buy if he doesn`t sell it for 50 dirhem. You can act like you feel sorry. When you leave, he will probably stop you and sell it for 50 dirhem. If he doesn`t sell it for 50, you can try to buy it for 70 dirhem in an another shop. You should bare in mind that there are other shops selling the same thing.5) They can be quite agressive if they can`t sell what they want. Be aware.
Rabat souk is better. The souk is good but everything is overpriced compared to other cities like Rabat. If you have to buy, get the local souvenir items only and save your money to shop elsewhere
Interesting. We loved looking around and walking through the souks. No real hassle but not a lot we wanted to buy.

An experience but be prepared. This was our first trip to Marrakech. We thought we were prepared but we really weren't. We travel alot with work and thought we were wordly wise. This was an eye opener. Myself and my boyfriend went with my mother and her partner who have been before. You must embrace the culture and remember it is nothing like home. Take more money than you budget for as nothing comes without a cost. There are beggers and lots of people that follow you. Lots of helpful people or so they seem till they expect you to pay them for directing you or taking you somewhere. We did find some locals to come across quite aggressive or confontational if you did not give them what they wanted. This is quite intimidating. Be prepared and agree a price before doing anything. Everywhere accepts Euros but Dihrams are used more used so I would recommend taking them. Be careful of the donkey carts, motorcycles and bicycles that come up behind and next to you. It can be daunting.

Travellers Warning for Soukites. The Berber Carpet StoryAnyone who knows me will probably be aware that I am not much of a traveller; my sort of holiday is a week in Cornwall or a weekend’s folk festival. In fact if you used both hands to count the number of times that I have flown overseas for a holiday, you would have numerous spare digits.It came as a bit of a surprise then a couple of weeks ago when we found ourselves in a travel agent booking a holiday to Marrakech!Before I go any further, I have to say that bit was the most amazing holiday I think I have ever had (and one of the cheapest!), the place the people the food the hotel – just everything was brilliant, apart from…. Well, here is the story;We had quite a busy week as we had arranged to go on various tours, all of which were stunning, but on the Saturday we had a free day. I very much wanted to visit the old City on our own and explore the Souks (these are the name for the almost medieval markets that they have) – we had a brief glimpse of them earlier in the week with a guide, but did not have much time to actually shop in them. It’s almost impossible to describe these Souks, they are huge and once you are in them they are a complete maze. The only thing you can see is, if you look upwards, the sky but all around are small market stalls, mostly only about 3m wide but some up to 4m high selling all sorts of stuff; Shoes, lamps, clothing, household goods, paintings, ceramics, craft ware, food, textiles carpets and loads and loads of stuff. It’s crowded, noisy and although the walkways are only about six feet wide, hundreds of motorbikes and mopeds speed through constantly as well as donkey carts. You are constantly being beckoned by the stall-holders, in a very friendly way and not all that intimidating.Mostly it is quite amusing; they seem to have learned a few ‘English’ phrases like ‘Asda Price’ and ‘BOG Off’ and ‘Ali Bongo’!There is a great sense of fun, but underneath, these guys are all very professional sales people and if you show just one moments weakness, they have you. I have been in retailing all of my life and I have never seen such slick professional operations like these. Show any interest in any item on any stall and you will almost certainly end up buying it and, hard a negotiator as you may think you are, they are better, much better. It’s all they do all day and they are truly experts at it. Never underestimate them. Most are illiterate but don’t confuse ignorance with lack of intelligence – these people are very smart, very smart indeed.So, we decide to have a go in the Souks. That is, I decided we would have a go in the Souks, Julie was not too keen. Thing is with Julie is that she is a bit wiser than me and she also knows my capabilities and, more importantly, my limitations much better than I do.So, promising not to get us lost or robbed, we got ourselves swallowed up in the labyrinth of the Souks, firmly holding hands. All was well for half an hour or so, in fact we stopped off at one stall and Julie bought a really nice silver lamp and negotiated a fair price for it too (I was quite impressed actually) and we carried on. Needless to say that soon we were hopelessly lost. I would seriously advise that anyone who does this in the future to take a compass with them, it is completely disorientating, impossible to describe, you just have to be there.We seemed to have had no choice but to plod on hoping for a break in the stalls or a ‘way out’ sign. Eventually we came to what appeared to be the end, or at least the outskirts of the Souk, but we had no Idea where we were. The Old Town is vast and we could have been literally anywhere within its 12 miles of its walled city. However, one of the very last stallholders caught our attention and offered us, what we thought at the time, to be a life line. He said “Are you looking for the Tanneries?”Well, were weren’t, but he went on to say that we had timed it just right as this was the day of the monthly auction, and it was a good place to visit and this was the day to do it. He gave us some simple directions and sent us on our way. Julie, I think was glad to be out of the Souks, and I thought that if we had a good starting point, we could probably find our way back to the square (we did have a tourist map). So off we went, following the directions we had been given. After walking for about five minutes, not at all sure if we were going the right way when the guy who gave us directions suddenly came up behind us and told us again where we should be going. We again thanked him and were just about to start off again when a young lad came up to our ‘friend’ and they shook hands and exchanged a greeting. Our ‘friend’ then said that this lad was his cousin and was going that way anyway and would show us the way. Now, I expected that this would cost us a couple of Dirams, but at that stage I was quite happy to pay whatever it took. At this stage, no alarm bells were ringing in my head.So, this very personable young man started to lead us off into the unknown. At first it was quite entertaining and he was practicing his English on us and pointing out various things on the way, such as a real Berber bakery, and telling us of the differences between a Berber bakery, an Arab one and a Jewish one – all good stuff, he also explained something that we had noticed elsewhere on the city walls, a crudely painted grid. It was apparently used for their elections. However, as we walked we seemed to be getting into seedier and more run down areas and he was talking less and less. We were now starting to get a little worried. We were walking miles from any tourist area, we had not seen another European face for ages, and the environment was becoming more and more hostile, narrow alleyways and very run down houses and dark enclosing passageways. Then, when all that was on our minds was how we were going to defend ourselves from the impending ambush, we walked out into quite an open street.It was still very run down and shabby, but at least we had somewhere to run if it came to the worst! Also, our guide seemed to reanimate himself and started showing us cow hides and camel skins drying on walls. We began to think we were just being paranoid (at least I did), and we carried on following our little helper. Suddenly we came to a gap in the wall and he announced that we had arrived.We were greeted by a very nice chap in a white coat who introduced himself as the manager of the tannery. I looked around to thank our little helper, but he had gone. I did think it strange that he did not ask for money for bringing us here, but again, no alarm bells went off.After issuing us with sprigs of mint to act as gas masks, we were given a fascinating tour of the tannery. It was like something you would expect to see in the 12th century. Pits full of either diluted ‘pigeon poop’, lime and wheat flour to tan the hides. We were told that the wool shaved off the hides was exchanged by the Berbers in the High Atlas mountains for ‘Pigeon Poop’ and after tanning the hides were dyed with saffron, cobalt, ochre etc. to give them their colours. The tannery was staffed entirely by men, whilst the women wove carpets and rugs. We were also told that the staff was either Berbers or Arabs. The Berber’s only tanned Cow and Camel and the Arabs only tanned Goat and Sheep. All very interesting stuff really, and the smell was not too bad at all. Our friendly guide was stressing all the time that the women were making carpets in a co-operative – the significance of this was not apparent at the time. Our guide then took us out of the tannery the way we came in and walked us up the street, ostensibly to show us some completed dyed skins drying over walls, whereupon he ‘bumped into’ another one of his mates who he informed us, would show us about the carpets.Again, no money was asked for the tour – bells had started to ring by now.You have to understand that we were aliens lost in the outskirts of a very big city; we could not speak their language and were completely at their mercy relying entirely on their goodwill and good nature. We felt extremely vulnerable.We were then ushered through a small corridor into a large room. I had expected to see women working at carpet looms, but no, not at all.The room was about 40’ x 20’ and was hung from floor to ceiling with very expensive looking carpets/rugs. There were neatly folded plies of rugs all along one side of the room. It has to be admitted that they were a stunning display, oozing both quality and cost. No windows or openings apart from the doorway we came in, just rugs. At the far end of the room facing the entrance was a small two seater banquette in front of which was a low table and to the side a small chair. We were ‘invited’ to sit down.We sat down.Our ‘host’, dressed in a traditional brown Islamic thobe sat on the chair and called his assistant into the room. He then told us that it was the polite thing to accept a glass of mint tea with him and he sent his assistant off to get some, whilst he explained that he was a Berber, and Berber people were very polite and friendly, not like the Arab people who were miserable and bad tempered, and, indeed, he seemed on the face of it to be friendly, but we could both detect an undercurrent of aggression behind his smiling countenance. It was more than a little disturbing. He was asking the usual introductory questions – where are you from? What are your names? - How do you like Morocco? Etc. till the mint tea eventually came, brought by his assistant who then went and stood in the doorway with his hands on his hips, completely blocking our only exit. Our anxiety levels were increasing by the minute. Our courtesy bus back to the hotel was due and it was obvious that we were going to miss it which didn’t help our situation at all.Our host then told us that he was going to show us some rugs. We tried to politely tell him that we did not want and could not afford a carpet or rug, but he said that he just wanted to show us the different types that are made in the High Atlas Mountains by his people. We don’t need to buy anything but if, after looking we do, he will do us a very good price, and if we don’t, we all leave as friends. We had no choice but to view his carpets, so we resigned ourselves to the inevitable.He called upon his assistant to unfold a selection of rugs of various sizes and colours whilst he explained the history and symbolism of each one and how each one was made and where it was made. Again, I have to say that these items were truly magnificent, things of real beauty, but we just did not want one, had no-where to put one and could not afford one and couldn’t fit it in our luggage for the return journey even if we could.Eventually, after having shown us about twenty different rugs and they were piled up in front of us, one upon another, he asked us what we thought. We once again tried to explain that we had not come out to buy a rug/can’t afford/no room etc. but we were desperately trying to be firm but diplomatic. He said that they now had a little game – we had to choose which ones we liked and didn’t like – don’t worry about cost, just let him know which ones we liked. However, we had to do by saying ‘Loxian’ if we didn’t like the rug or ‘Desrie’ if we did. So we started this ridiculous charade but we both realised that we could not say ‘Loxian’ to all of them, we felt threatened enough as it was without insulting the guy, so we ended up with two that we said ‘Desrie’ to. But we then made it absolutely clear that we did not have room for rugs of this size. After a slightly ill-tempered exchange, he said he wold show us some smaller rugs.Whilst his assistant was folding up the rugs that we said we didn’t like, we noticed that he had a knife tucked into his sock!So he started showing us smaller rugs and we again said that they were too big. So, with a little ill grace, he started showing us some small rugs and we had to go through the whole farce again, ‘Loxian’ – ‘Desrie’ etc. until we ended up with just a choice of two small rugs and one large rug, both of which were stunning it must be said, but we simply did not want any of them. He asked us to choose which of the two small rugs we preferred, I looked at Julie and said that basically, I don’t think we are likely to get out of here without buying something so it was best to choose the one we preferred. So we settled on a red one. The other one as removed and on the floor there now remained the large rug and the small one – neither of which we wanted.He now said that he would give us a price for both rugs in English pounds despite our protestations that we did not want either of them. Drawing a notepad from where I know not, he thought for a few moments and then wrote £700.00 and circled it.Julie and I just looked at each other – both of us thinking the same thing. We were trapped in an enclosed room with a smiling crocodile asking for £700.00 and a man guarding the door with a knife down his sock, and how the hell did we get ourselves in this dreadful situation?We once again tried to explain that there was no-where in our house for a large rug – he was very insistent that it was for us, great value, took five months to make, but eventually conceded that we could not buy the big rug. This left the small one.“You need to pay me £200.00” he said. “We don’t have £200.00” we said.The atmosphere in the room which was already very cold turned icy – “How much would you pay then?”Now, I had some money concealed in my back pocket, but Julie had her handbag with her and it was obvious that it contained her purse so we could not plead that we had no money on us. So I told him that we had very little cash on us so the best we could do would be fifty pounds. I was hoping in a way that he would just throw us out and we could escape unharmed. However, he became quite animated and aggressive. He started almost shouting that it took a girl a whole month to make it and would we work for a month for fifty pounds. Julie saw that the situation was getting out of control and said that she may have more than fifty pounds on her, how much would it have to be ‘best price’.He stared at us for a while and said £170.00. Julie said that she did not have £170.00. “Well how much have you got then”Fortunately, we were given some very good advice at the hotel – don’t take any more money into the city than you think you will need. Morocco has a closed currency and it is not permitted to take Dirams in or out of the country so we were advised to just change as much sterling into Dirams as we needed each day.Julie took her purse out of her handbag and counted up how much she had – it was 1250.00 Dirams – just less than £100.00. “That’s just not enough” he was not happy “You can pay the rest in English Pounds” – Julie explained that she had no other money, English or other in her purse. He then, believe it or not, said that she must have English money in her purse and made us empty the entire contents of the purse – there was no more money. He then points to me – “YOU must have some money” – I said that Julie carried all of our money and turned my trouser side pockets inside out to show him that the only thing I had in them was a packet of mints.“Well”, he said to Julie “You have a credit card - you can pay with that” Julie put her foot firmly down on that one saying that no matter what happened she was not going to use her debit card – surprisingly, he didn’t seem to push that as hard as I would have expected him to – on reflection I think it may have had something to do with traceability.He then suggested that he would take the cash that we had as a deposit and meet us tomorrow in the square with the rug and we could pay him the balance then. Quick thinking Julie said that we were going back to England that night and would not be able to do that.The thought then struck us that we had missed our courtesy bus back to the hotel and would need money for a taxi – we told him this and he said don’t worry about your taxi money! We didn’t know what to make of that.The room went quiet for a while; there was Julie and I sitting together, our ‘host’ sitting alongside of us, the guy with the knife was blocking the doorway and 1250.00 Dirams sitting on the table in front of us.Suddenly he got up, collected all the cash and walked out of the room with is henchman saying that he would be back in a few minutes, leaving Julie and I alone asking each other what the hell we had done to deserve this.We could hear a furious row going on in the corridor but after a short time they both came back in. Our ‘host’ sat down with us again and folded up the money but fifty Dirams back on the table, meanwhile ‘mac the knife’ was folding and rolling up the rug which he wrapped into a neat and compact parcel. “I’ll take your money for the rug, but you will need this back” he said pointing to the fifty Diram note. “That won’t be enough for a taxi” I said.It turns out the money was not for a taxi. It was to pay the guy who had shown us around the tannery who was waiting outside. However, the ‘proper’ amount to pay him was 150 Dirams. We were told to tell the tannery guy that he had taken all our money, but we were also to tell him that we paid only 900 Dirams for the rug as if we didn’t he would be looking to our host for commission as well. As for the taxi, we were told just to get a taxi to our hotel and pay when we got there!We were ushered out of the building with our rug in a black plastic carrier bag, the tannery guy was waiting and gave us directions back to the square and asked for his fee – I gave him the 50 Diram note and he went quite mad. I tried to explain why we had no more money, but he did not seem to want to listen so we just walked away.Amazingly expressive language is Berber – I just wish I knew exactly what it was that he was calling me as we retreated.Our first feelings and thoughts as we left were relief and some joy that we were at last ‘free’. In fact we joked a little about it for a short while as we walked but slowly the realisation of the way we had been manipulated and the dangers that we put ourselves into began to dawn on us, and we were still no-where near the square that we were looking for. So, feeling very vulnerable, lost and pretty wretched, a very young lad pushing his bike walked passed us. He could have been no more than seven or eight, “Hello Lady” he said to Julie “You English?” It was so nice to see a friendly smiling face and the innocence of this child was quite charming. He made all of the usual enquiries about where we were from and how did we like Marrakech and introduced himself as Mustafa. He walked with us a short way and asked if we were looking for Jemaa el-Fnaa Square, we said we were and he said we were going the right way but to follow the alley way to the right as we went. We thanked him and continued.Five minutes later he was back at our side, “No, not that way, follow me” – so, have very little option, but feeling confident, we followed Mustapha through back streets and alleyways till we came to a small square in which one of the exits had been closed. Mustapha’s big brother then approached us “You looking for the square? – This way has been closed, but we will show you another way” – Oh Jesus – here we go again.Knowing that we were being taken as mugs and knowing that we were once again putting ourselves at risk, what choice did we have? We were completely lost, so, with serious misgivings, we followed Mustapha and his brother for about fifteen minutes through some of the most threatening looking alleys and streets. The pair of them eventually stopped and faced us – here we go I thought.“OK” said big brother “Mustapha will take you the rest of the way, but you need to pay him” – I was expecting this so I had transferred 20 Dirams from my back pocket to my front pocket in anticipation. I gave him the 20 Diram note and he stated quite firmly that 20 Dirams was nothing – he wanted more than that, he couldn’t give his brother 20 Dirams, and went off on a rant.
