I snatched the note back out of his hands and said that if it was nothing I would have it back. (I was feeling pretty pissed off by now as you might imagine) he took the note back off me and walked away without another word.Mustapha was still there and beckoned us to follow him which we did.Within five minutes we reached our destination and was about to walk off when Mustapha started pulling my sleeve. “You must pay me” He insisted – I said that I had already paid his brother and was not going to pay twice. Now he started screaming and shouting at me so, with the square in sight, Julie and I just walked off and left him to it. We headed for a café to get a coffee and try to comprehend what we had been through.We were in shock. I mean real shock – not just shocked. The enormity of our potential danger crept up on us slowly at first but was very real and affected us both very much.On reflection we think we were marked from the word go, and everything that we went through was a carefully contrived plot. The guy who suggested the tannery must have phoned his pal to meet us. Phoned ahead to the tannery manager, and then arranged for Mustapha to pick us up and meet his brother. We were like fish in a barrel. Obvious targets really, European, me with an expensive camera round my neck, Julie with a very expensive handbag – I suppose we were asking for it, but such a choreographed slick operation was the last thing we expected. It did colour our attitude to the Marrakechi people for a couple of days I can tell you.We did manage to get a later courtesy bus back to the hotel in the end.As for the rug – well, its lying in a corner of the bedroom on the floor unwrapped – like some malevolent reminder of one of the most dreadful experiences of our lives.

Tradition, wonderful, exciting and a must see.. This is a love - hate experience. Some people will love it and some will hate it. There is unlikely to be any happy medium. This is a wonderful rabbit warren of little shops, all open fronted on to narrow alleyways.Round every corner is another discovery or a must have object. Hard bargaining is a must and good buys can be had. Yes, you can tell, I love it even though it rained hard while we were there.

La Porte D'Or and Ethno Art Gallery. When my husband booked a Thanksgiving trip to Marrakech, Morocco, I was a little hesitant about the experience. My fears were for nothing. Not only did we have a wonderful time, we met some friendly shop keepers and had a great shopping experience. The souk was filled with a multitude of colours, sounds, people and wonderful things to buy. You have to be strong and say “No” when the vendors try to get you to purchase their items. The first day we walked through the souk on our own to get a feel for the place. The second day, our hotel guide took us to some amazing places that we probably wouldn’t have seen without him. We weren’t really there to buy anything special, but when I saw this beautiful five foot turquoise and brown vase, I had to stop and ask about the price. Our first purchase was at this amazing store called “La Porte D’or” (115 Souk, Semmarine). We smiled when we saw so many photos of very famous movie stars hanging on the walls. They all had shopped in the store (Tom Cruise, Sharon Stone, Will Smith, etc.). Hakim, our sales person was very friendly and spoke very good English. He made you feel welcome in the shop but didn’t pressure into buying anything. We wanted to buy the huge vase, but you know that feeling of being in another country and not knowing if you gave them thousands of dollars, would you ever see your items. We bought two vases from La Porte D’or with the assurance that they would be delivered right to our door in London. Our next amazing store was “Ethno Art Gallery” (19/21 Souk Elkebir Semmarine) which wasn’t too far from the first store. Our salesman, Hassani, was also very helpful, friendly and spoke great English. We also purchased two beautiful vases from his store. True to their word, all four vases arrived safe and sound right to our front door in London much to my delight. My husband and I are extremely pleased with the quality of the workmanship in the vases and can’t thank the shop keepers enough for their helpful insights into our purchasing experience. So if you are planning a trip to Marrakech, make sure you stop at La Porte D’or and Ethno Art Gallery and check out their amazing merchandise. Cheers from London.

Go prepared and have a great experience. The most important thing to remember when you enter the souk is that you are going into a shop and that the traders will try to get you to buy.That said, with a few sensible precautions, (See my longer review under Medina of Marrakech for some effective tips on handling the traders.) you can have great fun, take great photographs and not spend very much.Dressing modestly, avoiding eye contact and ignoring the "hellos" allow you to move through the narrow alleyways unmolested. You have to be aware of the donkey carts, hand barrows, scooters and cycles coming up behind you and avoid crowds and tour groups which are seen as easy pickings.Best attractions for us were the dyers' souk, the lantern souk, watching men use foot lathes to turn wood, the displays of jewellery and watching the shopkeepers ply their wares.

Fun and entertaining. Great to just have a natter they are very friendly and if you want to buy great to bargain,bought Wans for £7,designer genuine fake sunglasses for £2.00 each, we got lost but that just adds to the fun. products we saw on sell was cloths, shoes, spices, carpets, pottery and lamps, souvenirs, sunglasses but no electrical of phones or gadgets. We wanted to buy local boxes of chocolates for friends or pastries this will not be found here, only back at Airport in departure lounge.

Fun and entertaining. Great to just have a natter they are very friendly and if you want to buy great to bargain,bought Wans for £7,designer genuine fake sunglasses for £2.00 each, we got lost but that just adds to the fun. products we saw on sell was cloths, shoes, spices, carpets, pottery and lamps, souvenirs, sunglasses but no electrical of phones or gadgets. We wanted to buy local boxes of chocolates for friends or pastries this will not be found here, only back at Airport in departure lounge.

Mad but amazing!. It's completely mad but an amazing experience!! One must be incredibly firm when walking thorough as the shop owners can literally drag you in to places and make you buy things, but haggle away and it'll be an experience you wont forget!!

Sexually assualted. Around 18:00 last Sunday we were on the edge of the Souk at the junction of Derb Dabachi and Rue Kennaria. Although a very large crossroads, the crowds were so thick that hardly anyone was moving. I'm 99% certain this was engineered, as there seemed to be a couple of lads with motorbikes they were wheeling very slowly through the crowd who were causing the blockage.Anyway, I assumed it was to pickpocket people so kept tight hold of my possessions as I entered the thick crowd. My wife and our two female travel companions did the same. As I moved slowly forward, nothing happened to me, but all the ladies immediately came under sustained sexual assault, with aggressive groping hands grabbing them all over their breasts and genital areas. Be sure, we're not taking gently squeezing - this was aggressive ramming of hands between legs and around breasts. The crowd was so thick it was impossible for them to stop it and you can imagine how scary the whole experience was.As soon as we got through the crowd they told me what happened but I couldn't do anything about it, as all the people who did this had melted back into the crowds. We were all left feeling scared and angry by this horrible situation.I will never go back to Marrakech on the back of this experience and will advice anyone who asks me to avoid the place. If you do go, be very aware of the busy crowds and know that it's not just pickpockets out there

Fun to haggle. Great place to walk around but don't go too far in will get lost. People are friendly and great fun to haggle with. Make sure you pick a price in your head you will pay and walk away if you cant get the price you want. Will not hassle you if you don't buy off them.

Great Fun but repetative after a while. We went into the Souks several times during our 14 day stay in Marrakech but found it fun bartering wth the locals but there were hundreds of stalls all selling the same products (How do they all make a living considering the number of them). It was an experience in many ways & an eye opener as you have to be very streetwise or you will definately be conned. There were all sorts of different smells some pleasant & some not.The downside was the local traders attitude towards their animals. We witnesed Donkeys & Horses that were forced to carry or pull excessive loads & many were obviously not fed or watered properly.One Donkey had mucas dripping from its eyes & this is unnacceptable in these times, their poverty is no excuse but what seems so strange is that their animals are part of their tools of their trade. so why dont they look after them, they would if it was their car!!!!.Anyone out there who can help them, please do so when visiting Marrakech, what should be such an experience is tarnished by their total lack of respect for these animals.

Mad!. The variety of goods on offer was extreme, the hassle was overpowering at times. I wonder why it is in their nature to hassle coax and cajole when all that does is make you pass on by. It took a day or so to get to grips with the experience and we came away having learned how to manage the vendors.

medieval England. If you want to know what Medieval England was like go to the Souks, it was an experience,people begging,person knocked over by road bleeding from head and everyone just looking, and you take your life in your hands when crossing the road!!!!

Never understood thi hipe. Everyone had advised us to visit Marrakech souks, which we did. I am still unclear why tourists even go there - most of the products either irrelevant (e.g., food), or low quality (e.g., rugs). The place smells, it is dirty, there are way too many sales guys, and it is huge. In case you get lost. there are plenty of helpers that could show you a way out and then start asking for money. Please note that $1-2 would not satisfy them, they will be following you unless you strongly send them away, after which you have a high chances to be cursed in multiple languages. IMHO visiting souks for more than 10-15 mins, just to get a general sense, is just a waste of time.

the place where it is a pleasure to get lost. Only one suggestion: get lost among all the narrow alley; this is the real Moroccan experience.Millions of colors, smells, people, interesting objects, and many other things.you can easily loose the idea of time in your mind... but it is amazing.do not look for restaurant but try to enjoy the street food people sells in the market.It is usually very good quality and mostly homemade :-)
Warning!!. Very interesting marketplace. Rich and diversified attractions, and complete different during daylight from night life.

Fun in the Souks. We loved the Souks.... It's true you are enticed inside and it's easy to feel pressured ! But if you enter into the spirit it's great fun, remember to smile and enjoy the barter, generally you should be able to get them down by at least half, more if you smile and joke with them.

Shop 'til you drop. If you love shopping & culture . It's the best place to visit, but before you go there, make sure you set up your mind free & be positive + strong mind for the crazy hassle from the shopkeepers & people in there!Beware on the street, the pickpocket & people try to make conversation with you (they will try to sell somethings or beg you for money). Just say "no" & ignore! The best way is... put the headphone in your ears, so you can't hear what they say.There're a lot of interesting stores, good local products & hand made stuffs. If you like to buy something, make sure you bargain hard about 70% off the real prices which the shopkeeper told you. If you don't get the price you want, just walk out and the shopkeeper will ask you to come back.

Marakesh markets. This is a must and well worth the effort to go to. It's worth getting the guided tour as you get to sample the artisans actually making the products. I loved this and a bit of bartering was really fun. Marakesh people are very friendly and did not feel uncomfortable or pressured to buy anything you didn't want

Souks - Amrani Rachid Artisanat. I would recommend visiting this little shop in the souks! Not only does it sell some beautiful little lanterns and little 'aladdin' style lamps, but the owner was also extremely genuine and helpful. We had accidentally left some slippers that we had bought in another shop the previous day and he went out of his way to help us to find the slipper shop again (this was before we had purchased anything or shown any sort of interest in their products)! We would never have found the shop without his help! address: souk semmarine no.30

Visiting the souk!. It was fantastic. There are such wonderful things to be bought and brilliant bargains to be had! Even if you are not planning to buy anything I would still recommend a a visit for the experience.

be prepared to haggle... Went round most of the souks in the small streets of Marrakesh..be prepared to haggle for a good price... The spice markets are amazing. The artefacts for sale are in abundance..some are pricey! so bartering is a good thing...

Colourful. The souks were awash with beautiful colours and wares to sell..the spice market was fantastic and we bought many grams to take home with us..Be prepared to haggle..They will charge you a lot more than the items are worth...

Not as good as some. If you’ve never been to any of the major markets like Istanbul, Jerusalem, etc. then you are going to enjoy it. But if you’ve been to these places its a little underwhelming and you will see many of the same wares. There are a few treasures to be had though. Be ready to haggle and ignore the people telling you that you are going the wrong way. It’s just a tactic. Also don’t be afraid to firm with you "no's" and keep walking if you aren’t interested. One thing I always wonder when going to a market is whether or not the items are really hand made. Here you can get the shoe vendors to actually make shoes specifically for you if you want to mix and match elements. You just need to give them enough time to do so.

marvelous marrakech. We Were pleasantly surprised with the amount of pestering and hassle we encountered compared to our visit to the bazaars of Cairo and Egypt in general. When walking around the Souk and city with and without a guide all approaches were gentle and a no thanks was enough to break the contact although if you wanted to buy something the staff were very polite and patient. The leather goods, bags, footwear, etc were excellent quality and value if you took the time search and barter We thoroughly enjoyed the whole experience and would not hesitate to return.

Not as stressful as anticipated. A must do but I was concerned about being harassed. We had a guide with us so perhaps this helped but we were not harassed at all. An interesting trip and we saw some of the workshops, in the end many of the stalls have the same goods but well worth a visit.
Must visit here!. We were well prepared by our riad staff who told us how to haggle and what to look out for. We had a great time and bought some wonderful bargains-we think!

Madness of the Souks. The warren of stalls that form the souks in Marrakech certainly lived up to their reputation. If you are sensible about navigation and enter into the spirit of the banter that you can have with the traders you will have great fun. You will get a bit of gentle hassling but nothing that you can't say no to. Overload on the sights, sounds and smells (mostly good!) and you will have a great experience. Oh, and don't forget to have a firm idea of price before you buy as the starting price is likely to be about 4 times what you should pay! Play the game, it can be fun.
good food. have the courage to eat from the street shops, the foot is excellent, the experience is overwhelming.

A must for all to see. The souk in Marrakech is a must, There is a vast selection of stalls selling leather, clothes, metal work, wood items, you name it, you will find it.The air is full of spices and aromas and entertainers in the square with monkeys, snakes, cockerels and more. You need good walking shoes as there are lots to see. Would we go again, certainly.

Sensory overload !. We had a real blast here, the people were so much fun and so friendly. The array of things for sale were many and one wonders how they all can make a living this way. We were offered tea with the traders and asked to bring our friends back to shop there. We had a lot of fun bartering and got lost in the maze. A great afternoon.

Alternative to souks shopping. If you don't like the bargaining, and being hasseled everywhere is not your thing, there is a very well organized Ensemble Artisianale just 2 blocks up the wide main street from where all the caleches (horse and buggy tourist rides) wait at the Jemaa El Fna. They have all the exact same wares as the souks, prices are well marked and extremely inexpensive, you can look at your leisure, and no one hassels you. There were some public restrooms there as well,which you won't find near the Jemaa El Fna!

Don't be affraid. I am a bit of a scary cat when it comes to going new places, but i have to say, having got our baring after a couple of visits in, i really enjoyed the whole experience, don't be afraid to barter and if its not what you want to pay walk away, the further you go into the souk the better the bartering you can do. The shops on the edge don't usually shift on price.
haggle haggle haggle. great fun bargains to be had providing you haggle ! colourful and buzzing - didn't feel hassled positive experience

Enriching and educational !. Our 2nd visit to Marrakech and one of many to the souks. If you have never experienced this, you must! There are no real bargains to be had, but the experience of wandering through the labyrinth of stalls selling leather goods, silver teapots, herbs, spices and carpets is great fun. Everyone has "the best quality" and "a special price just for you" but a polite no thank you and smile is all they need not to hassle you. The herbalists are well worth a look as many offer an education in the herbs, spices and oils, in the hope that you will buy of course, but it's fascinating. We did buy some argan oil and ginseng, so are hopeful of revised energy and youthful skin...!

An experience and a half!. Amazing sights and colours! Just wander around and don't try to navigate, its like the Tardis much larger inside than outside!Never follow anyone who offers to show you the way, they always try to take you to their shop or some sight like the Tanneries where they encourage you to take photos and then ask for money! It seems quieter in the evening. Definatelf worth visiting though!

MAYHEM. Its certainly worth a visit for a couple of hours but any longer would have been mind blowing. you will be dodging taxi's, scooters, snake charmers,monkeys, and the list is endless.This Souk is definitely geared up to take any money of tourists one way or another.As i said , worth a visit if you are in Marrakesh but watch your bags and pockets.

Bad Experience. Into the souks subsequentully got lost and had a bad experience with myself and wife trying to be led away in the wrong direction further into the souks by young men locals.Not sure of the intentions of the men but we realised this is wrong so said No we not going with you and ran in other direction,eventually getting our bearings.Other people in our hotel had the same experience SO BE WARNED!Very easy to get lost!Advice for you!!Stay in souks not far from Jemaa el Fna square DONT go too far inside.Also couldnt buy anything as constantly hassled by stall holders and when we didnt buy got the comments CHEAPER THAN ASDA or DONT BUY IN PRIMARK even thogh they couldnt speak English.Visited January 2014

Keep your hands in pockets...... ...and your money in your hands. Cos these guys know how to sell. It's very colourful and exciting with all manner of things to see. Need a carpet, clothes, jewelry or spices, perhaps a chameleon or a hedgehog or two? They're all here wish I had more time to take it all in.

Jemaa el Fna Soux, Marrakech, Morocco. If you really want to try something different, visit here! It's like shopping on another planet. After my second visit the place became a bit more familiar. I would advise using the minaret of the mosque as your landmark if you've not visited before. You will be harassed to buy expect nothing less. If you take a photo you will be expected to tip. If you so much as look at anything the seller will pounce on you. Its customary to haggle, so never pay the first price. Western, young ladies beware you will be admired and called after even accompanied. It's not the polite British way to ignore people but it's best to. (Unless you're interested of course - then Bob's your uncle.) Look out for the cobras of the snake charmers, the water men in traditional dress, the belly dancers, henna tattooists, musicians and monkey man. Don't be surprised if you go into a shop to be offered the traditional Moroccan mint tea, hospitable as they are you WILL be harassed into buying. Nothing's priced - 'pressure' selling and bartering's the name of the game. For a truly atmospheric evening go after dark and be entranced by the calling to prayer from the lit up minaret. It's another world.
Family holiday. I don't like the crowd so to be honest wasn't really overjoyed going in the souk, I much preferred the one in Essaouira. It's too focus tourism.....no real character
Get lost and wander.. Just walk around and roam, don't try to work out where you are explore and enjoy. It's easy enough to find your way out afterwards or just ask.

No to be compared with other more famous souks. If Marrakesh is your first Arabic destination, then it will be a good experience. But if you visited Jerusalem, Nablus, Damascus or other old arabic souks, then you may be less enthusiast. Nontheless, it is worth a visit

RETURNED AGAIN AND AGAIN. Many souks lead off from El f'na, some are inter-connecting and then there are some which are further north and a little tricky to find. I never got lost but I have a good internal compass. Nevertheless, to be sure I did bother to check direction back to El F'na and shop keepers are the best persons to ask. Never follow anyone unless you are very confident of yourself. As it happens one guy did offer to take me out because he was going that way anyway and as it happens he had a key to open an otherwise closed door which saved taking a more circuitous route.Always start at 25% of whatever price is given and aim between 25% and 50% or 1/3rd. Even then I have to say I have seen same items in other towns for cheaper prices but then you never know what you will see again.I wont say agreeing a price is fun - at least not like in China - but it is a cultural thing and you should go along with it.

You can almost anything. A maze of tiny shops. We found it best to work in to the centre of the souks where the items in many cases are made. My daughter enjoyed haggling the prices which is expected and the shop-keepers were of good humour.My suitcase was not large enough to bring all back that I wanted to!

Great. You get a great authentic vibe especially at night when it all came alive. Be sure to haggle and get all your souvenirs from here. The food was good but if you don't like cats beware as the roam around freely in restaurants. Be sure to get a table on a terrace. Nice view and no cats.

Overpriced tat but a lovely experience!!. Want to get lost? Then plunge into the Souks of Marrakesh. Although there are some bargains to be had (especially in leather goods) you will have to haggle hard to get a good deal - and these guys do it for a living! Don't be afraid of getting lost. You will. Many of the areas have their speciality - ironworks, spice, leather, wool etc but this enables you to see items being made. There is some sensitivity to the taking of photographs so it is polite to ask if you are taking anything more than a general scene. If you want close-ups of anyone working then payment of about 20dirhams should also be offered - and will usually be accepted. There are a few scallwags around who will try to tell you everything is closed and lead you elsewhere where they will be paid for bringing you. Ignore them. Sometimes people will tell you "It's closed" but they may be telling you somewhere is a dead end... or they may be suggesting that you go with them instead. However most people are incredibly honest and show great humour so it is better to trust them than not. If you do get lost then there will always be someone to lead you out....at a price and probably by the long way round. Check the price first and don't pay more than a few dirhams.
See the real life. in the souk you will get a great experience of how the locals live from fresh produce to spices and medicines.
1/4 of the price!. Always always always say you are not going to pay more than 1/4 of the asked price .. then you can let them beat you to 1/3 of the price, but not more..

Adds price. The first time we were hassled but as they got used 2 u it got less. Get cards from. Stalls u get hassled less & barter! I did & got some deals although I acquired a reputation & some wouldn't barter after & just gave me their lowest price. If u buy from a stall u r happy with & want 2 buy other stuff ask them 2 take u 2 a stall they will. Easy 2 get lost but not at dark. It's marmite I loved it my hubby hated it happy shopping

An experience to remember. We got caught on a new scam...basically a guy just happens to be walking the same way as you...and spots a mate who is going to the Berber market...yes of course you get dragged into a tannery and a shop ...blah blah ... and come out a lot poorer than you went in....but that's what you expect going to the Souk!!

Enjoy getting lost. Embrace the joy of getting lost wandering around the souk - you will never be far away from Jemaa el Fna and will stumble across so many things that you never knew you wanted to buy!

a Tourist place to shop. You can find everything, but be prepared to bargain. Their 1st price is usually so high its a joke, so shop around 1st. and take your timewalk away and they will as a rule call you back.

Not what we expected. Initially we were excited to be in new place and intended to wander at our own pace but we were constantly pestered by people who wanted to take us to see this or that ' wonderful place..just follow me' then when you realised actually you were going miles from where you wanted to go, they got stroppy and demanded money. It was horrible and we could not get out of there fast enough. We are not strangers to souks and have been in many places in Africa, the grand bazaar in Istanbul etc and this is first time we have been hassled like this.

Magical. Last visited this fortified city packed with vendors and their stalls many years ago and while locals still throng the streets, many of the souk's stalls are clearly designed for foreigners. My friend and I departed the bus at the Medina and were immediately approached by men stating they were from our hotel offering their services as guides. Although we said no, they still followed us for awhile but soon gave up. We were also approached by several women trying to grab our hands to decorate them with henna tattoos, but a firm 'no thank you' and they left us alone. There is a lot of hustle & bustle in the souk which might not suit everybody as it can be a culture shock for some, but it's all part of it's charm. Shop around before you buy, always barter and be assertive.

Great shopping. - but a lot of dross too. Do be careful with quality - the further you wander the better the goods. Haggle hard, and be polite when they invite you to see their wares - they're only trying to make a living and are not persistent or aggressive. This is a 'working' souk - not just for tourists.

Be amazed. The souks, which you can enter from Marrakech's huge square the Jemaa El Fna, are a maze of wonder. As anyone who's been to Istanbul's Grand Bazaar will know, much of the gold will be glitter, and there is a numbing sameness to a lot of the stuff on offer. Still, if you spend a little time researching what you want, you will find wonderful people selling beautiful things for very little. We stared at rainbow-coloured miles of barbouches and bought not a one; goggled at enough lamps to fill a palace and couldn't decide. But we haggled for a carpet and got the seller--a tough, humorous teenager of great charm--down to our price. And at the lovely walk-in cubicles (56&103 Kissariat Lossta,between Souk el Kebir andSouk Attarine) run by jewelry dealer and maker Abdellatif Bellawi and his kindly and attentive son, I chose a range of gorgeous Berber and Toureg beads and had a bracelet made for me. The walls here are coated in enough pendants, beads (glass, mixed silver, amber, coral, turquoise, plastic and more) to delight the pickiest, and there are antique beads at good prices too. As for the rest, it's the atmosphere--the bars of sun filtering down, the amusing exchanges with the shopkeepers, the whiffs of cumin and sage, the dodge-em-car-like interaction with donkeys, bicycles, motorcyles and fellow pedestrians--that forms such a key part of Marrakech. This is a city, after all, built on a palmerie at the culmination of a great African trade route, and the souks are all about trade. Plunge in and forget the guides.
WOW!!. A maze of beautiful treasures and momento's to barter for was great. Even when you think you are lost you soon find your way back.

A wonderful surprise. We were very worried the Souk might be overcrowded, chaotic and dirty, but in fact were very pleasantly surprised because it is actually quite clean and organised.You DO have to half the prices when bartering, and can get the goods for even less than that. We knocked down a carpet from 2000 euros to 450 euros!

Quite eccentric. The place itself is very interesting and there is a lot to see.At night the whole place becomes alive with gatherings for monkeys doing tricks and snake charmers showing what they can do along side people who are banging away playing the Moroccan beat.If you are a person who enjoys discovering new places or likes to explore then it is definitely a must see and I would definitely recommend going.If you are a person who enjoys piece and quiet or is always conscious about safety etc. then I wouldn't recommend it and would tell you to stay in a hotel for the whole period of your holiday.For shopping it isn't good unless you have a guide who is a local and can knock the prices down for you, otherwise they will immediately see you are a tourist and rip you off.

The craziest shopping experience.. Don't be afraid to get lost, we were told, and it's true. Although if this stresses you, just get a guide from your hotel. The only people to ask directions from is either a shop owner or an elderly person. We learned this the hard way! Get ready, if you ask the price of anything, they assume you want to buy it and will chase you down still negotiating. Don't get offended, it's just how it works. Sometimes you'll get a really good deal, just be clear about what you want. It's amazing and the further you go, the more you see, we stumbled into an area of felted wool items, so unexpected after all the leather and metal work. I know we only touched the surface and we had 3 days there. It's hard on your feet and exhausting, take breaks!
Different. Some of the sellers are nice and ok if you dont want to buy but some of them dont understand the work NO.

Drums that go into the night. Great vibes in Jemaa el Fna. Street vendors and large crowds make the square come alive with vibrant colours, sounds and tastes. Don't miss it! I found it particulary rewarding to visit Jemaa el Fna at different times of the day. Day time is a bit slower and you get to enjoy all that the square has to offer. Evening is when it really picks up. We where there for the new years weekend, so tens of thousands of people filled the streets. Just incredible. The night market may seem a bit strange at first glance, but give it a chance. Have a stroll, enjoy the ambiance.
Busy. Busy, dirty. Winding little streets that are easy to get lost in. Crammed with people, but this didn't stop moped riders haring down them at top speed. Watch your back.

Good atmosphere. Couldnt have asked for more... Atmosphere, funny characters... Basically the real Marrakech... The evening is when all the main stalls open up and the lighting and people create a great vibe.

Fabulous. What better place to discover Moroccan handcrafts than the wonderful Marrakech souks? The gigantic Jemaa el-Fnaa souk is at the center of the medina. In the day the souk is active with storytellers, street performers and fruit vendors, but at night the souk transforms into a huge cooked-food market, as hundreds of vendors set up tables and tents.
lovely atmosphere. great place to see people and stroll around the stalls. The locals are very helpful, but can be very pushy when they want you to visit their stall...
A-maze-ing. Such a confusing myriad of alleyways with so many shops selling the same sort of goods. Seen one souk/medina and you have seen them all. Great vibe and main square is abuzz with activity.

Sweet feeling. We so loved the air in the souks. How big it was enable us to get lost, but local people here was so kind, simply and friendly. However, be careful with someone who try to take you to the tanneries.

souk Marrakesh. What fun, easy to get lost but no problems. Loads of bargains and loads of tat, have fun haggling for what you want. We visited in the winter - think it would be unbearably hot if you went in summer, but good fun.

Marrakech Souk and Medina. I visited Marrakesh in mid October 2013. I had never previously holidayed outside of Europe so this holiday was my first time on the African continent. I'm a 19 year old female and was traveling with my mother. There are thousands of things I could comment on, but I'm just going to keep it simple with pro's and cons.PositiveThe food! It was beautiful! I have now a new found love for mint tea. Made with the fresh mint tea leaves, it really hits the spot after a long day in the sun.The heat! Just lush! Even though we traveled in mid October it was still toasty, it was in the 30 degree range every day. It stayed warm into the night, which meant you could still comfortably explore after sunset or sit on the hotel balcony and watch the city busy life by night.The history of Morocco was also incredibly interesting. If you have the chance to get a tour, i would definitely recommend it! A lot of the mosques are also beautiful, and the sound of the horn or bell or whatever it is calling them to prayer is great.NegativesThe people. As a young female I did have quite a few situations that made me very uncomfortable. I'm not going to stereotype, but a lot of the middle-aged men made inappropriate comments or would stand just too close. I think they need to appreciate the need for personal space. It got to the stage that even though it was high 30 degrees I still felt the need to wear long sleeved tops and full length trousers just to feel less exposed to there gaze.The hagglers. I know this is what the Medina is famous for but after a while it just became annoying. People constantly asking for money for cheap tat and following you for an hour until you give in, is not my idea of a holiday. And as a lot of the other reviews have said the objects are often ridiculously priced to begin with, I would recommend halving their offer and you will have a more reasonable price.The animals. The donkeys that were overloaded with good and struggling to stand was a sore sight to see. They all seemed to have problems such as overgrown teeth, patches of fur missing. One even had an incredibly bad limp, which was worsened by the owner kicking the donkeys leg whenever it slowed down. The malnourished cats were also everywhere. Little kittens looked more like rats, and were often kicked or trodden on by people walking in the street.So they were just a few of the things I experienced during my stay! Overall I did enjoy the Medina and surrounding area of Marrakesh simply for the experience, however it's not a place I will be visiting again in a hurry, especially traveling as just two women. I have rated it as a 2 out of five. *Also I would recommended using a toilet before leaving your hotel, as there are very few toilet facilities whilst you are walking around.
Thats what you go for!. Brilliant. I mean, thats what your going for when you go to Marrakesh. Stroll around the souks and find yourself a bargain. Or just smell all the spices!

Ethnic experience. Loved the atmosphere in the souks. It is huge so can get lost but locals very helpful. Beware of people trying to take you to the tanneries. We went and enjoyed it but they wasnt money before you leave which was awkward to avoid.
Amazing maze of shops. Great location off the square. Easy to get lost with all the little streets-quite the maze with so much to see. Lots of great shops.

uneventful. International Film Festivals, associations with Yves St Laurent. Absolutely Fabulous episode -I was expecting to be really wowed by this place. No way. the stalls were pretty much selling thesame stuff, stacks of tagines, lanterns and poor quality leather goods. The moment you pausedto browse the sales hassle was intense. One vendor pursued me the length of the souk passageway and just didn't seem to accept NO or as they speak French NON.In the large square itself I could find only one café terrace that offered a reasonable choice ofmenu and looked reasonably smart. But of course don't expect to get a beer or glass of wine.Yes at night lots of temporary food stalls set up but the food pretty basic and bland. Yes verycheap In sum I found the whole experience far from exotic, just pretty tawdry and down market.

Mad House. Cheap bags, belts etc etc but be prepared to be hassled when you walk passed every EVERY shop !!! Worth it just for a browse etc but do not let anyone take you too/help you find etc etc as it will cost you !!!!

First visit to Morocco - Marrakech Souk. My first visit to Marrakech, and first stop after checking into our raid was the souk. I had endless curiosity for all I saw. I learned a quick lesson as I first walked out as a woman grabbed me and wanted to show me her henna tattoos. I was not ready for this but she insisted on a sample be given me which turned out to be painting my whole hand, and of course she expected payment, and of course she asked much more than is what is normally paid. That was awkward as I had not learned yet to give a firm no, anything less than that can bring a bit of trouble. First rule, be nice but do not be afraid to say no. Second rule, it is ok to accept tea but know this is a bit of a hospitality trap also, so if you are just looking and not ready to buy anything walk away from a tea offer. There is so much to see, and many temptations to look, ask questions, and possibly buy something; however, it is wise to be a bit careful. The prices are inflated as people expect haggling. If you have no idea what something is worth then it could be more expensive than what is a fair price. It is wise if you want to buy jewelry for example to know something about jewelry, because it is difficult to know what is authentic Berber, what is real silver, what is a true antique, etc., if you do not know before hand. There is an abundance of goods, hand crafted furniture, lamps, leather goods, spices, cooking pots (tajine), carpets, art, and so on to choose from. Still it would be good to do a bit of research on what you will find there prior to shopping, and have some idea of what to look for in quality and what is a fair price. It is fun, it is safe, but it is good advice to be polite but be ready to give many firm 'no' responses, as the souk is an active and competitive market. Also to note: you may be asked for money to use a public toilette.

Best thing to do in town. The souk is a HUGE market place, and you can walk around for hours and still not have seen it all. You can make great deals on scarves, clothes, leather goods and a whole lot more. Be prepared to haggle though, even if the starting prices seem fair enough. There is always room for bargaining. Or just walk around enjoying the sounds, aromas and life unfolding around you.

Every last dhiram. Very cool place to see initially but once you walk through be prepared to be hassled repeatedly by shopkeepers with that colgate smile. Everything is for sale as one shopkeeper even offered to sell me the bulb to the light in his shop :s the problem lies in that there are no fixed prices and everything you see is something you can get cheaper on ebay! I had high hopes for this place but it was not to be, The people of the souks are only interested in the colour of your money so dont be fooled by their charm (it fades when you suggest a ridiulous price for thier wares with classic responses like...'you joked me' and 'ha.. how much you say') and haggle for every last dhiram!!ps watch out for people sending you the wrong way or saying this way is closed as most likely its not and of course prepare yourself for the unpleasant smells that pictures cannot capture :s

Narrow streets and motor bikes. We ventured off the square and into the souk with our small group and guide as well as on our own. Note the location of the sun in relation to the square so you can use it as a guide to get out. People will try to get you to look at their stands all the time or guide you to see something. 95% of people you talk to have an angel. 5% are genuine and actually care to have an honest conversation. We wandered unguided for about 3 hours in and out of the souk never feeling threatened but occasionally a little turned around. If you do get too lost look for a tour guide with a group and ask them, they will give you accurate directions. Obviously you need to haggle for most all prices and be weary of quality and construction if you're buying big items. We bought our carpets and blankets outside the city and got a better deal. There was one carpet shop near an entrance to the souk from square, it was across from a cafe. The shop looked nice and we had an honest conversation with the owner who used to live in Orlando and work at Epcot Morocco. Lastly we would rate the Istanbul grand bazaar above this. Better organization, easier to navigate and wider selection.
An assault on all your senses. Total madness, a myriad of lanes to get lost in, shops for spices to scarves to shoes, spend a morning exploring then find a cafe with a terrace to people watch.

Colorful...... Enjoyed the visit with friends, loved the alley ways with the little shops, had fun haggling and found a veggie restaurant in the side street which was ace....be aware of hassles in the square and hide your expensive stuff, didn't like all the different food places at night was'nt lit up very well! Loved the drumming in the square...

Accept it. You will get lost. Entering the souk is like entering a different world, a wonderful world. So a few things to bear in mind: a) You will get lost, just ask any stall holder for the square; b) You will be quoted about four times what stall holders are likely to accept; so c) If you don't haggle you will be fleeced; d) be firm but polite in your negotiations. If they let you go, it is because the price is too low for them; e) If you buy any hot food, eat it on a plastic plate, not one that is washable. But most of all surrender to the experience. Not going to the souk while in Marrakech is like not going to the Coliseum when in Rome

Colorful kaleidoscope and so much more. This is a market which was bursting at the seams when we visited it one afternoon. I was taken aback by how colorful it was the shops with the various goods in it, the people with their beautiful, quirky clothes (a different style sense). The goods were reasonably priced and you can bargain as well. There was this very interesting pet shop and I was kind of tempted to buy a parrot but good thing I didn’t because God knows how I would have carried the parrot back home. Even the haggling part was fun as well.

so many things to do!. I spent one week in the souks! It's big! What I appreciated is that moroccan people are not aggressive even if you don't buy. Just don't believe those who say they are students or teachers and have something to show, or those who say it's a special day blablabla... Go alone in the souks, you'll never be lost, there are indications everywhere and if you're lost just ask the way. If you wan't to buy, the further you go from Jemaa el fna, the cheapest it is. And don't forget to negociate, at least 40%.

Hassle and grabbing. It's just too much. They will grab you, pull you, tell you wrong directions, say insulting and degrading things towards a female, one even offered to exchange me for goods to my husband.They speak all languages but they only think about one thing, to make a big profit out of gullible foreigners. We negotiated once and got to one tenth of the original ask price so be careful. Most of the things are made in China anyways.

Jemaa el Fna square. hectic - do not have your cameras in view as if you take photos the vendors request money - the snake charmers pick the snakes up and put them on you - all for a price - be careful and keep your bags and money safe - enjoy

Bargains Galore. Peruse the old Souk and thoroughly enjoy.Barter till your hearts content.!Bargains galore if you keep your eyes open and barter with the friendly Moroccans.Food/drinks available alsoThe only thing you have to be careful of is not to buy too much to carry on the journey home.....The Souk is a pleasure to walk around but don't go if you don't like crowded areas.Not for the disabled.

Marrakech. A good way of seeing how people live. Very busy and lively. We spent a couple of hours wandering around looking at all the goods for sale. I wouldn't recommend taking small children far too busy for children

Feast for the senses. Be firm saying no! If you want something decide your price in your own currency and stick to it. They use pets to attract children I.e a tortoise outside one souk distracted my son and while he was looking at it the stall holder works on parents, he got distracted by a chameleon and birds of pry outside other stalls. Therefore as parents they distract the child and when you come up against your child being keen on something and the hard bargaining of the stall holders , it may cost you! It is fascinating and inspiring but a lot of tat too. Probably best to buy things elsewhere as there is better quality and lower prices out with the main market. It is a Definately must see visit, you will get lost. But don't worry you are never too far from the main square. Haggle for everything I have been starting my haggling at about a quarter of their 1st offer and paying around a third of what they initially ask for. Don't be scared to walk away or appear rude as they will chase you and offer you a better price if you do this.

Hassled beyond belief. This was my second time in Marrakech, I traveled initially with my husband, but this time I traveled with my daughter. We took all the warnings seriously about being modestly dressed and being mindful that we were two women on our own. But from the minute we stepped out of our Riad to the minute we returned we were hassled and it wasn't the usual people trying to attract our attention to sell us their goods (that we could deal with) it was the vulgar, sexual and threatening behaviour that we were exposed to. I have to say that nothing would possess me to return to this place. Even when we were in the company of a male friend who kindly walked us to our Riad from the taxi, we were exposed to more harassment - I can not understand this behavior - this is supposed to be a Muslim country where the women are respected when respectable, well someone has forgetten to tell the men in and around the Medina.It is such a shame as we also met some lovely helpful people, both male and female, but all I have taken away from this trip is bad memories!

The Push and Pull of Marrakech. Visiting Marrakech out of the main tourist season is an interesting experience. There are fewer tourists about for the hawkers and touts to grab. This is especially true in the narrow lanes of the Souks and the old town. It only took two or three shouts of Ali Babar to get me annoyed and by the time the fourth trader had tried to pull me into his hop I walked away. I found the tanneries to be particularly bad with a desperation in the sellers that made be both hacked-off and sad... Do not let this put you off. The mountains are majestic and glower over the city. There is true and deep history in the city which is well worth seeing and is an interesting mix of Arabic, Moorish and African influences and with a cold wind coming off the mountains remember to take a warm jacket. In December there is snow on the high Atlas.

Amazing and no hassle. We expected a great deal of hassle having been to Marrakech more than 20 years ago and found it challenging. Much improved people are pleasant and welcoming. Souk is fantastic. Spend one day looking before buying, there is loads of variation. We paid approximately a third of asking price. Decide what it is worth to you and stick to it. If they let you walk out the shop it's too low. But there will be another one around the corner, just start a little higher.

Great to see hard to escape. The Souk went on and on and on, it's huge! You will get lost!Fantastic visual spectacle, but don't buy anything, it's all much cheaper elsewhere ... and you don't have to go far.

Very interesting Marrakech Souk. Marrakech Souk is a very colourful & interesting. There are so much to see and to buy. You must haggle for the merchandise you buy, this make it exciting. The souk is like a maze every corner is the same unless you are familiar, you can easily get lost and difficult to go back to the same stall to look for what you want. English and French is very well spoken, no worries of language barrier. The Moroccans are nice and gentle people therefore the shopping is pleasant and did not feel harass by them. In the evening there are plenty of food stalls pop up, abundance of Moroccan foods to choose from. Reasonable price with yummy Moroccan food to try, you might have to use your hands to eat just like the local did.
got to see. try not to buy anything on your first day here and also keep in mind the real price of things. it can be quite overwhelming.

Crazy place!. A maze of narrow streets and alleyways jam packed with little stalls selling spices, teapots, pashminas and all sorts of things. Easy to get lost if you're not careful. Unlike the markets in Luxor, Egypt, for example, we did not feel too harrassed by the stallholders and a firm 'no' seemed to work.

Bargening for a bag, slippers or herbs. Bargening for a bag, slippers or some magic herbs? Smell and tast the Morrocan life at the souks. Do never pay more than you want to. Look for the bags with matching scarf, enough to choose from. Best offers are a bit noth of the souks: Near the Ali Ben Youseph complex. Always buy your herbs inside the shop and not on the street: as all tourists have touched them, let along the exhaust of the scooters....

Souks are great but..... Souks are great - but they should ban scooters from roaring through them. Otherwise really interesting with lots of real craftsmanship on display. Careful of the hard-sell though.

Don't expect to get what you have in your head!. The souk is a vast collection of all kinds of goods and it is sometimes very difficult to distinguish local goods from imports. What frustrated me most is the fact that shop-owners don't give you any time to browse and have a look at what might be of interest. Once you have just shown the slightest sign of interest, they immediately address you with quite agressive aproaches in order to make a deal. In most of that cases I left these shops in order to get rid of such an attack, although I was willing to buy something. But what annoyed me most were these very agressivly driving bicycles & motorcycles in these narrow ways of the souk, althogh it is not allowed for them to drive there!

you have to bargain ... a lot. For those who have been to other souqs this is the same thing, we have to bargain .... you know that.. but the prices were sometimes 5 times more.. it was too much... by the end I was tired and annoyed.

What a buzzing place. Shoppers paradise if you love to haggle, which you must. We are used to it so we did. However also bear in mind that sometimes you get better bargains away from the main souk area in the shops lining the back streets to the main souk.
Time Machine.. If you want to travel back in time, then this Souk is the place. It's probably the only one in world left authentically intact. Mind the fake guides and the pushy carpet sellers.
Souk that are overpriced. You can getter better quality and cheaper items back home in the UK, Yes help the local economy, but don't be taken for a mug!!!

Haggle hard. This is the place to bargain hard for your souveniers, but also dive off down some of the little alleys and watch the craftsmen at work. They are more than happy to explain their particular skills, and you get a real insight into life in Marrakech

Fantastic Experience!. The Souk was amazing!! I had such a great time wandering and getting lost all of the tiny side streets and alleys. Contrary to other reviews I never had too difficult of a time finding my way back to the main square. Make sure you wander for at least an hour to get an idea of prices before you make any purchases, and when you inquire about prices initially don't get sucked into the shop. They are all great sales people and will make it very difficult to leave. You can find some amazing bargains and quality goods in the souk. There is also an artisans alley where you can watch them make the goods right in front of you! Beware of motorcycles, mopeds and bicycles. No rules in the souk......

Fantastic Experience!. The Souk was amazing!! I had such a great time wandering and getting lost all of the tiny side streets and alleys. Contrary to other reviews I never had too difficult of a time finding my way back to the main square. Make sure you wander for at least an hour to get an idea of prices before you make any purchases, and when you inquire about prices initially don't get sucked into the shop. They are all great sales people and will make it very difficult to leave. You can find some amazing bargains and quality goods in the souk. There is also an artisans alley where you can watch them make the goods right in front of you! Beware of motorcycles, mopeds and bicycles. No rules in the souk......

An eye-opening and colourful experience. The souk is Marrakech is certainly one of the most complex and attractive souk's I have visited. You will get lost - count on it. There is so much you can buy (and obviously negotiate - a lot). The main square has lots of attractions and is a must-visit at night (mid-week preferably as weekend nights are just too crowded for comfort). Don't try to take pictures of the cobra's without paying but at the same time be firm as the snake charmers will likely try to rip you off. Don't be scared - pay what you negotiated up front. As for the henna ladies, it's fun but it took a few minutes and felt rushed.

Not for children or single women. The Souks Are busy noisy dirty smelly colourful crazy hassle interesting vibrant. Unfortunately we never brought a thing as no time and space to look properly before being hassled in price and being shown something better!! An experience not to be missed!!

Unfriendly and over priced. Rude Traders with stupid accent and unfriendly nature.They get annoyed if you bargain for over priced items. Make sure you drop the price by 50%. A guy told me MAD 300 for a decorative item, reduced it to MAD 80. A belt for MAD 150 reduced to MAD 25. Bargain hard to get a deal, else they will rip you off.

An excellent souk. Having been in many souks I found Marrakesh's to be the most attractive by size and variety. The sellers were persistent, but remained polite. If you are interested in 100% natural products whether cooking spices, for cosmetics, illnesses etc, etc, then you should definitely find Abdellah at Herboriste Sahara at Rue Rahba Lakdima #38 in the area behind Café France. He is lovely and very knowledgeable! For excursions (daily or longer) call Abdoul 061 060 0906. Adil is ready to be your driver around Marrakesh 067 061 3047. Enjoy.

Getting lost is part of the journey. Try to lose yourself in the souks. You will always get out at the other end. Bartering is the culture. Start low. Sick to your budget and walk away if required. Leather goods are pretty good value and fake designer wear is in abundance.

You can buy anything. This place is like nothing I have seen before - u can buy literally anything from rugs to lights to tea cups to sweets - its great but beware they are persistent and some times overwhelming

Fun day out. Fun for a day! You can practice your skills with bargaining!be careful if you buy leather ... choose a good quality otherwise you will ate the smell when you will be back home. I recommend to have a nice tea at a terrace and watch the life around you!

Shopping Heaven. Has to be the largest amount of shops, stalls, floor space covered with items in the world. The smells of the spices, the myriad of colours of the scarves and the array of pots, bottles, fabrics and bags is unbelievable. You can find anything and everything here, hand made shoes, bags, clothes of every shape, size, colour and style, furniture, rugs, carpets, curtains, tie backs, furniture, spices, beauty products including of course the famous argon oil in every quality from cooking to cosmetic, shisha pipes, tobacco in every conceivable form, chameleons, tortoises, snakes, jewellery, furniture its a shopping mecca or a shopping hell depending on how you approach it. Yes they pester you, yes they can be pushy but at the end of the day they are all trying to make a living and bartering is great fun, and if your price is too low they just ask you to leave their shop then as you leave they follow you and ask you to offer just a little more. As long as you dont pay anymore than you are happy paying then you have your bargain and they are happy.Never accept the first price they give you if they start at 400 dirhams you start at 80 or 100 and usually end up at about 120 if you hold your ground. If they want too much then just go on to the next one there are so many to choose from just dont be intimidated.One word of caution if you get out a map and appear lost you will have any amount of offers to show you the way best not to follow them as it always seems they are just being helpful but it always ends up in a request for money. Should you be lost just ask a woman or ask in a shop or if you keep walking you usually end up in the square. It is certainly an experience I shall never forget and yes I came home with some fabulous curtain tie backs, a shisha pipe and lots more. A word of caution if you do purchase leather goods make sure you smell them first as sometimes the curing of the hides has not been done properly.It has certainly been an experience I shall never forget and one I am sure I will repeat.

An experience!. The souks in the Medina in Marrakech are a warren of alleyways which branch in many directions.However,you are never very far from the centre of the Medina (Jemaa El Fna) so if you get lost ask a shopkeeper who will point you in the right direction.The souks are a riot of colour with a great atmosphere,selling brass lanterns,handbags,carpets,leather slippers and jewellery.Don't forget to barter with these guys as they start off at a stupid price,but you can get the price down considerably providing you are persistent.

Better read it will help. Marrakech and the souks is some where you should go once in your life, but I think a week is to long, 5 days is great but there is not much else to see. A few tips that I feel you need to know1 do not get currency from your bank in England, they will give you UAE dhiram and you might end up paying the taxi in the wrong currency that cost twice as much 2 every person who go's will be ripped off at lest once don't worry there pros 3 don't try and work out the traffic it's crazy just cross the road when the locals do4 don't be rude there only earning a living, have a laugh and a joke, very good price means the most you will pay so if you think it's worth it and you want, buy it, don't think I will come back for it you might not find the stall again in the rabbit warren that is the souks5 food portions are cheap but small everywhere 6 alcohol is expensive where you can find it (£4 per 330ml bottle) with very little around the souks7 have fun your only probably there once

Pleasantly surprised. Having read many reviews about being hassled, getting lost etc, I was not really looking forward to visiting the souk. We went on Saturday morning and spent a pleasant couple of hours wandering round the various areas. We weren't hassled at all, politely refusing offers to look when we passed stalls we weren't interested in. Found our way round ok too, there are signs pointing back to the Square if you lose your sense of direction. Had mint tea overlooking one of the open parts and people watched. Pleasantly surprised.

interesting meander. Be careful where you shop. As you might expect there is a lot of not so good stuff aroud similarly there is is good stuff. You have to be prepared to haggle they expect it. We got two leather handbags for £40 instead of £73 the original asking price and he still made a good profit. Despite what he says
Touristy but sheer volume makes it fascinating.. Full of touristy rubbish for sale but the sheer volume of all the souks makes it fascinating and atmospheric.

Great if you love hustle and bustle. The souks are an amazing place. I'd advise being firm. Only stopping if you are considering buying. When you are given a price barter and start at 1/3 of the price given. An amazing experience to walk through even if you aren't planning on buying. 'You can look for free!' Taking photographs, may not be free!! Enjoy!

A fun place but keep your money for something else.. Fun, interesting and a place you have to see and get lost in but the products are repetitive and I do wonder if they come from somewhere other than Morroco. Prices are ridiculously high and even halving the prices and sticking to them through relentless bargaining whilst the trader attempts to add unwanted items to the 'deal' we were left thinking we should have bought in the UK. We think the Souk has to change, and some stalls do have price tickets and some have responded to European taste, they are few but I hope the trend continues.

Hold on to your purse and have a surreal experience!. Talk about the bizarre bazaar..... think every sound and color and labyrinth you've ever been in and multiply it by 10..... 'that's' the Marrakech Souk. Between the snake charmers, and the food stands, the piles of colored threads in one kiosk next to the piles of colored shoes in the next one, next to the colored hand woven blankets in the next and you get the idea of the overload of sensory sights. It's amazing!. Just hold on tight to your purses as my husband had to chase the very tall young man whose hand was trying to rifle through my big purse. (didn't get anything though).. Always smart to have zippered sections in your purses. Enjoy, and know you will get some fantastic bargains. the street food is fine and very tasty. Even the gypsy ladies selling bracelets have great deals (even if they don't take no for an answer very easily).. I actually wish I had bought much more from them as I get many compliments on the one and only bracelet I bought.
Souk visit. We were lucky and had a guide. Be careful of your possessions and don't stop to look if you don't intend to buy. If hassled just keep on walking and don't speak.

Great for shopping. Remember to barter only if you are serious about an item. Be firm and sensible and dont be took in by the animals outside the shops to get you inside. be film and polite. and ladies cover up with a shawl or scarf or you will be stared at, respect the culture.

Another overrated Morrocan experience. It's a large market with some great little shops and stalls. Then there are a lot of repetitive stalls of clothes, bags, mirrors, trinkets etc everything is promoted as 'genuine Morrocan', Morrocan it may be, quality most of it is not.

Moroccan Markets. Some amazing little shops here! Wish I had longer to spend time. Be careful of your pockets, bags and your hands you will be accosted and they want to take you to show you their shops, jewellery and try to do a henna on you which you will then be demanded to pay a ridiculous amount of dirham for! Avoid eye contact and you'll usually be left alone. If you don't want anything then don't how interest.Shopping wise, the fakes are good and most of the shopkeepers are pleasant. Yes they want you to buy and will hassle you and expect you to barter but they have nothing else to do - this is what they do everyday for a living. It's all part of the experience and the stuff is nothing like you get anywhere else. Try the fresh juice - I got grapefruit and my friend got mixed - they are delicious. Street food is much better than any restaurant here. I will go back.

A myriad of bewilderment doesn't even start to scratch the surface... I guess I'm not really going to be setting the Tripadvisor fraternity alight with this review, as anything that I could say has already been said. What you'll need for your day ( you'll probably need a good few hours ) in the Marrakech Souk: 1) LOTS of energy as you'll be walking......a lot2) LOTS of banter as these guys make cockney market traders look like timid mice!) 3) LOTS of money if you're serious about shopping, as there's so much to choose from4) A strong head and determined resolve to stand your ground. You may think you can spot a bargain, but these guys have been doing this for generations, it's in their blood. Just be prepared to walk away from something, even if you really want it, as more than likely you'll see the exact same item 10 feet down the road. Only ever be prepared to pay what you think it's worth, not what they tell you they need. 5) An open mind. You WILL be hassled and as stressful as it can be, if you allow it, it will also be huge fun and massively rewarding and gratifying, especially when you do get that awesome bargain you came for. 6) A good sense of direction. This place, although not geographically vast, is a rabbit warren of 100's of little streets and alleyways that all look the same. Either take a guide or use an offline travel app that allows you to follow a gps signal so you can always see where you are and therefore need to be. If all else fails................screw it, just go for it. Head in there and prepared to shop, chat, banter, eat, drink, bargain, laugh, get lost, rediscover, get lost again, find again and until you either come out somewhere you know or get tired and ask directions, but ONLY ask a shop owner, NOT one of the kids in the streets as they will expect money and may take you to a families or friends shop first.Be aware but go have fun and bargain hard.

Full on!. I traveled with my girlfriend and the Souks were a must-see in Marrakech I was told. I expected it to be hectic but it was something else. Sometimes the shopkeepers were friendly but a lot of the time they were rude and over-harassed and on one occasions we even got chased for a short while after refusing to buy some trainers!

A shoppers idea of bliss!. A maze of little streets just north of Jemma El Fna with different areas of speciality. Metal workers/ leather goods/spices etc. absolutely fascinating even if you are not a shopper (ie my husband!') and every step has another delight on offer. Just remember bargaining is expected and it's all part of the experience. Now I'm home I keep thinking of all the things I should have bought (why didn't I buy the lovely tassel curtain tie backs for instance?,) which are horrendously expensive in UK.

Go with a guide and ignore the touts and you'll be fine!. t found the experience interesting and fun. The way of life is so culturally different that there are surprises around every corner. Our guide told us to utterly blank those men who try to sell you things in the street and it worked. Make no eye contact and no sound whatever and they will go away. It worked for me!

Amazing!. The Marrakech Souk is very huge and a bit overwhelming at first. You need to bargain a lot and if you dont like the price just walk away, you will probably find the same thing somewhere else. However if you really do like the item ask yourself "would i pay this price in my country" and if the answer is yes then go for it! They have so many beautiful and unique things, usually the deeper you go the cheeper but also if you just roam around and get lost you'll come across even more unique things for cheaper price.

Leave yourself time to enjoy the Marrakech Souk. It's easy to become overwhelmed in the Marakech Souk. So much to see that you probably want to come several times. I bought a sweet pair of fine leather shoes with beautiful scrolling. Our real find was Chez Les Nomades, a carpet store where we learned a lot about the craft and ended up buying a sweet little Tuareg Nomad rug. Be ready to haggle, an art that may take you way out of your comfort zone. Best is to go with a knowledgeable and trustworthy guide who may get a bit of a kickback, but ultimately should help you make a good deal.

An interesting place; be wary and careful. The souk in Marrakech is a must see because of the sheer enormity and variety of everything going on/for sale there. However, the touts are the most aggressive I have seen anywhere (and I have lived in the Middle East and SW Asia last 6 years so I know aggressive touts when I see them). They crowd you, sometimes patting down your pockets or back pack. Best way to get your price, like in any souk, is to declare a bottom line then walk away. If your price is OK they will call you back, even if what you offer is 1/2 their "best and final." There are a number of restaurants who all have signs saying "Terrasse Panoramique" which they indeed have. Menus are mostly similar, not bad food and decent values. Just be careful in the souk. The number and variety of things on offer is staggering. Have fun!

Manic!. You cannot 'just look' at anytning at all as they constantly pester you. I personally would have bought a lot more if I would have been allowed to just browse. I found it very warying and going in November it was quiet so we stood out like sore thumbs as being tourists.

Not for the faint hearted!!. I loved walking through the Souks every day bantering with the owners who all believe that their goods are the best and cheapest in Marrakech! They have a few catch phrases that I think must be shared around the medina and want to impress you with them. You do need to haggle as that's the culture and it can be fun. Have an idea of what you want to pay and stick to it. If they wont meet you then walk away as there are plenty more to choose from.We did get lost on our first trip but that was part of the fun. Which corner did we turn left or right??? On our next trip out we did look out for landmarks and this was our saving grace over the next few days. We even helped others find their way!!Do not be green and conned into thinking that a local is doing you a favour by showing you the way as they will want paying for the privilege of probably taking you to their fathers factory!!!Its safe. its fun and its not to be missed.

A wonderful adventure for the senses. I've never seen anything like it! There are 12,000 stalls within this souk, which is a recipe for finding yourself very very lost! We were sure to carry a map with us everywhere we went (our Riad gave us a few on arrival) and these definitely saved us a couple of times (eventually - they're not the easiest things to read)! There are so many similar stalls that even if you think you'll remember the way back, in practice you'll easily mistake one stall for another you passed earlier, thus leaving you increasingly lost the further you walk!The Manager at our Riad did say if you're completely lost then the best thing to do is find a little boy to direct you to where you want to be, but bear in mind you'll have to give him 5 - 10 dirhams. We'd heard a few horror stories about being lead places so managed to avoid having to ask anyone! Be aware though, the moment you look lost a lot of people will start talking to you, offering to take you places (usually to the square) and you have to be quite firm when telling them that you don't need any help, as they'll just continue walking alongside you.So it can be a hectic place, with a lot of people pouncing on you trying to sell you things/direct you places as soon as you stop, but as long as you prepare yourself for that and remain relaxed then it is a fantastic experience to explore the wonders of the souk and to allow your senses to soak up all the different sights, sounds and smells. It would seem like you can also pick up some great bargains but sadly we simply didn't have the patience for it. Haggling isn't really my thing, I'm not blessed with the gift of patience and if an item takes longer than 10 minutes and an awful lot of chat to buy at a reasonable price then I'll rapidly lose all interest. My friends were the same, and whilst we had great plans of securing a bargain leather handbag and jacket, we all found that actually we couldn't really be bothered. On the other hand some people love the idea of a good haggle, in which case this place would be heaven! But whether you buy anything or not, it is most definitely worth a visit (or 5!).

Fascinating, though one must dress properly not to offend the hosts!. A good souk, a must in Marrakesh, I found that this one is smaller, more manageable and somewhat better than the one in Fez... you will find lamps, weavings, spices, dancers, and many more!
fascinating. I have been in the Souk many times and it never disappoints. it is amazing. It is not to be missed. Plenty of lovely things to buy.

A maze - prepare to get lost- again and again. Its a true maze, where you get lost and distracted very easily. There will be lots of willing helpers becoming your guides, but beware, they will ask you to pay them for taking you where you want to go, or they will take you to specific places/ shops where they hope you spend lots of money on goods/ food. Amazing quantity / quality of hand made products especially clothes and leather goods. Always discuss the price, agree on about 1/3.

Always bargain. Well worth visiting for things to buy. Ask the price the only offer about 1/5th and expect to pay only slightly more, walking away usually drops the price towards your level but only give a little and remember they have the stock and you have the money. Can be fun getting a bargain but becomes a bit tiresome after a while. Expect counterfeits and always check for faults etc. many hours of browsing fun to be had.

Peanuts. It was a great experience to walk through the Souks but we were getting constant hassle from the traders and it did become wearing after a while. Glad we did it for the experience though. Tip: leave a trail of peanuts to find our way back out!

Winding Maze - and Don't Forget to Negotiate. The Souk in Marrakech is large and has many different roads and turns. In the morning it's less crowded and easier to navigate. Mid to late afternoon is a wonderful time to stroll through because the sunlight streams down through the wood ceiling creating an array of beams (and making your pictures look more interesting). We did buy several things here including scarves and shoes. Expect to bargain on the price. We usually found we could get the item at 50% of the initial offer, though not always true. Simple babouche (shoes) should be about 80 dirhams. Scarves will vary based on the material.
Barter barter barter!. The souk is a treasure cove of delights. So many items to buy. Please barter as it is expected. Enjoy the beautiful colours and treasures.

Got Lost Here. We started off really enjoying our walk round the souks, then we took a wrong turn and got lost! The souks are great if you enjoy a good haggle and/or are prepared to walk away from the deal! We went off the beaten tourist route and paid the price by spending an anxious time trying to find our way back to the main square.

"For you, Special Price!". The souks in Marrakech as designed to impress, to ensnare and to confuse. Here you will find some of the best businessmen in the world. Hawk-eyed and seriously set on selling you something shiny.There are gems to be found, but the key is playing the game. Don't be desperate, they can sense it, take your time, many of them sell the exact same thing. As around to get an idea on prices but don't start throwing numbers around unless you're willing to put some money down.Lie, You have to lie, the simple kind of lies, the ones that hurt nobody but give you some cards to play. "I'm a poor student""I only have X money to spend""It's not really what I'm looking for"Buying from the Souks is a poker game. Trust me when I say that they will be far more impressed by a good barter than by taking their first price. Pay with your right hand, Shake after the price has been agreed and you are happy with it and for god's sake smile, life is great, and you just bought a leather hand bag for 20 Euros. Happy shopping :)- A

Shopping heaven - or hell!. A big variety of things to be looked at - from art, to lamps, to clothes, to shoes, to leather bags, to kitchen utensils, to herbal medicines, to food. The souks have it all - you just need to be prepared to spend hours trawling through the endless shops, and going back on yourself, because it's all a big maze. Lots of shops have the exact same items, which makes haggling and walking away from shopkeepers a lot easier. In general, you can get things at a very good price.

As exotic as we'd expected and hoped.. Narrow streets, thousands of stalls, friendly locals - this local colour was our reason for coming to Marrakech so we got what just we were after. Many streets and alleys are roofed over so the sun isn't a problem and it feels like the world's biggest shopping arcade, avoiding getting run over by mopeds and donkey carts is quite a novel hazard though. Throughout the Medina there are also Mosque, Hammam and Riad so it's not just shopping in the central part of Old Marrakech. If you get lost just ask for La Place and you'll get directions to the main square.
