This is where the tour buses drop off, horse drawn carriages await, and also the only place where we saw tourists get ripped off - by snake charmers, monkey men, henna ladies etc. Ask your holiday rep for the going rates for photos before you go. Or with a zoom lens you can take any pics you like from the rooftop cafes all around the square - and no blackmail from toothless vagabonds.Marrakech - I love it, another visit beckons I feel.

maze of interest. You could lose yourself for hours around the souk...alley after alley and so much to look at, see, smell....but again the donkeys passing with loads too heavy and legs buckling is distressing. I saw a few dogs with injuries and limps that needed treatment and tough to walk past. Not a great place if you are a devoted animal lover.

You must get lost. The great things about the souks is their variety of items display, a maze in all the sense. But if you happen to get lost is the best thing that could happen because you might find something unique. Don't ask for a price at less you planing to buy. Negotiated the price but be sure that if you don't have a strategy you might get out smart. Locals are friendly and charming as they live of the futurism so they know how to treat people. You have to try to enjoy the game of reaching the price you are willing to pay for the item, its part of the experience.

shop till you drop. A place of plenty, what they do not have you can not get, be warned though take care around foodstuff, not all items are covered and stray cats spray around places, plus flies settle on products, fruits, spices and there is a lot of dirt around, if your are a hygiene crusader then you will struggle to shop for edible items.
Shopping in Marrakech. Great experience - the colours. smells (good/bad), sights & best of all the bartering for the pressies !!

crazy, colourful maze!. You enter the souks in the morning and could easily be still in there at sunset, the words 'Aladdins Cave' never seemed more perfect. The place is a mish mash of kaftans, slippers, lanterns, spices, repltiles, carpets and much more. Prepare to Haggle, but the prices can end up very cheap. A must see.

Great experience. Make sure you go to the Souk with lots of time and take water with you! (We were there in the summer and it was very hot) The Souk is a bit like a maze and it can be overwhelming because of the sheer amount of shops. The shop owners will come forward to talk to you and bargain. You must bargain! It was a great experience for all of us and the sights were truly beautiful! It was an experience that I will remember fondly for my entire life!

Tourist Trap. but worth going to just for the experience. be warned that it is ALL the same and stuff probably made in a sweat shop in Asia. Haggling is obligatory - try to pay half of first quoted price. the shoes and slippers are good tho and some of the painted plates.

A fantastic variety of things you don't actually need. The local people are very hard working and incredibly skilful at making things. The souk has a fantastic range of things to buy but, apart from dates and apricots, we bought very little. Perhaps 20 or more years living in the Middle East has filled out house with enough souvenirs already.

shopping galore. The souks are amazing,the atmosphere is intoxicating and the
vast array of local traditional goods to purchase is beyond belief.
Great prices and quality.
Well worth a shopping trip.

Fantastic and full of culture and colour. An amazing authentic Moroccan experience with the most beautiful traditional wares for sales. Just be aware of getting lost and of 'Souk guides' who offer you help, follow you around and then demand a 'tip'.
An incredible experience.
WOW what a crazy place. Spent the best part of a day here just wandering round the tiny alleys finishing up in the main square, it's a must visit just for the experience..... Be wary of "guides"

A great market. There are so many stalls to see you can spend hours just walking around make sure you hassle with them if you are going to buy as they always start high. We got very lost so be careful took a while to find our way out

cool but you'll get lost without a guide!. Full of interesting sites, shops and people, you can really get a taste for aspects of the trade and local crafts. It's easy to get pressured into buying things you don't want though so unless you're interested keep out of shops. Don't go alone is you're a group of girls as you'll get stared at and heckled more and I'd recommend a guide if you can find one (lots of hotels can provide for a fee) as locals will tell give the wrong directions to laugh at lose tourists.

Great fun though the constant hassle wears a little. A fun souk experience, with more than enough to explore for several trips. Getting lost is part of the fun and browsing the various shops is absorbing. On the downside, 90% of the shops seem to sell identical items (whether they specialise in lanterns, fabrics, pottery, etc), but you do come across the odd one that's different and more exciting. The constant and occasionally borderline aggressive hassling can be a pain after a while though so take a thick skin and get ready to haggle your socks off.

the coolest place to drink mint team, barter for a rug or leather coat or get robbed- fabuloso fantastique chukron!. go in ready to have fun, don't sweat the kids or thieves and drink mint tea while you're bartering for a great rug you better take with you (or you may never get it).fun, especially for westerners, more so for Alvin and Hattie from Dubuque.

Watch out for locals saying ,,it's closed". The souks are a great experience but there are some scammers just waiting for tourists to fall into their traps and they very often tried to lure people a different way by saying ,,this way is closed, follow me" or something about the souks being closed in general. There are signs all over which point to the main attractions so follow those signs and you should end up at the right spot.

An absolute must see!. It's difficult not to get lost in the maze of the souks but an absolute must see to be believed! Haggle or don't haggle as you wish but wander the tiny lanes just to experience it.

Be on your guard and don't take the first price they offer!. Thoroughly enjoyed the souks and was probably my favourite part of Marrakech, however be prepared to barter as they will try it on with the prices. We tended to get most things for a third/half of their starting price. If you start looking in their shop, they will assume you want to buy something and some of them can get a bit offended/nasty about it. Having said that, some of them are very friendly and make the experience enjoyable. Beware of motorbikes and people pulling carts through the middle.
The real thing. The souks felt like real, that means not only for tourists but lots of locals going there. A true oriental feeling and lots of things to watch (and maybe buy).

Labyrinths of color. All the old markets have merged into vast labyrinthine markets filled with spices, textiles, clothing, leathergoods and antiques as well as art and modern knickknacks. You will get lost, but no to worry, follow any sign hanging in the covered passages at random intervals and you will eventually get out into open space where you can reorient yourself!

Bartering superclass!. a great experience however not if you like to see the price and pay what is asked.they all ask double approximately what they will sell for. be prepared to pay what you are happy to pay - if its too much walk away - they will go lower if they can and if not you know you can always go back and what the bottom price is. start by buying something you don't want for small money - this will give you an idea of how low you can go!

Bonkers. One heck of a wild place. Hates first monkeys on chains, snake charmers.Good the restaurant terraces to get your pics of the souk (get there v early or you will never sit). Try the food stalls half the price of the cafés and restaurants and it gives u a buzz choosing which number stall to eat at - the boys are persistent but deal with it it's just good old banter

Fun but be aware of costs!. I have read some really ridiculous negative reviewers recently about the souks; I think the majority of people visit Marrakech for this crazy experience! Yes there's lots of shops, yes the people are keen for a sell but you have to be strong and be aware of costs so you don't get ripped off. The souks are an incredible maze with various areas and when you find the mini-squares at various points, you can find cafés to eat and drink (some with terraces).Ultimately, yes you get charged more as a tourist; Moroccans need the money!!! The whole point is haggling - make sure you know what you want going in and how much things cost when converting into your own currency. If you have your eye on a particular item but the price is too high, walk away! We did that several times and you'll be surprised at how the price suddenly drops as they want to make a sale. We never buy things on holiday but the souks had plenty of interesting items and we bought some bowls, tagines and cushions for good deals.This is common sense but don't necessarily buy everything at the front end of the souk as obviously all tourists start there. Work your way into the maze and then you'll find the better offers as people need the money.Happy bargain hunting!

What a market. As with all people visiting the area just be aware of the mopeds and donkeys - getting run over is easy!! remember to say la la chukran and smile! There will always be those who want to tkae you to see the tsnneries - la la chukran. e confident and avoid the tat

Marrakech bazaar. A very colourful and exctiing place for all possible kinds of shopping - leather, accessories, clothes, footwear, goods for home, etc. etc. Do not forget to taste cheap fresh orange juice (about 30c per glass) but beware pickpocketers!
What an experience. The real Marrakesh, hundreds of stalls loads you would like to buy everyone should visit the souk, beware of the motorbikes they ride through the market stalls at speed

an unusual experience!!. overwhelming at times due to the crush of people (especially at night!) and the constant requests to come look inside, but undeniably local and charming. be prepared to really haggle or you will pay up to ten times the value!!

fun and colourful. It is quite overwhelming to visit the souks as there is just so much to look at! It's worth a few scouting visits to check out what you like, before actually buying. Haggling is required, but it is usually done with charm and humour. The right price is what ever you think is fair. There are bargains to be had, but it is also good to remember that this is their livelihood.

Probably the reason you would want to visit Marrakech. Dislike: Sheer mayhem. Animal abuse in the square. Hassling. I was here with my boyfriend and he was never singled out. Though you should definitely expect to be harassed extra if you are a woman, you'll likely meet your share of persistent shopkeepers whether you're a man or woman. If you're from a western country, you probably won't get used to it by the end of your stay.Like: Sheer mayhem. The kaleidoscope of colors makes for great eye-candy even if you don't want to buy anything. I strongly recommend thinking hard what you might be interested in buying before visiting, because it will make it easier to breeze by hundreds of shops without attracting the attention of every shopkeeper. The smells in the spices world are intense. We found the shoemaking souk and ironworking world fascinating but they are easy to miss among the souks selling imported goods.Walking through the souks is tiring but being in Morocco is often tiring, generally speaking. The souks are probably part of the reason you would want to visit Marrakech, though, so they are definitely a must-visit. Knowing some of the history behind them will greatly enhance your visit.

Want to ripped off and hassled?. The tiny alley ways give you no way to escape the harassment and people trying to get you in to the stores. I know they say that haggling is part of the charm but when the prices are quadrupled because you're a tourist with no idea how much things should cost really starts you off in a bad position. The Moroccans seem to believe that as tourists we are all rich and they just want your money. The souks are basically full of mass produced tourist rubbish. Please be careful not to get ripped off. Avoid eye contact and keep walking. Even if they just appear to be friendly... keep walking!

Souk. Unbelievable place. Don't be intimidated by the salesmen. Smile and keep walking! If you are interested in buying then check prices elsewhere and remember to start at least at a quarter of the starting price. Don't be afraid to walk on.....they will follow if your close on price

Interesting. We were on a cruise ship tour. This tour was basically our guide taking us to his two or three shops where i dont doubt he received some benifit. Ths market was just like in the movies. We were hounded by vendors and for those who hadnt travelled, it was quie overwhelming. We could have spent more time in the actual jarket and less time in the few stores where we were taken.

Everything and Anything. If you like bargaining then the souks are for you. If, like myself, you'd rather not, then one of the small government run malls would be better as they have prices on everything. In the souks you'll be badgered and hounded at every turn and it can be a bit daunting. Just don't be afraid to walk away..............if you can find which way to turn!

guided walk. A buzz of traders, donkeys, carts, bikes and a maze of alleyways. Not pestered much by traders and interesting to see such a vibrant market. Some do not like being photographed, particularly women, which you need to respect. Felt very safe but I am told it may be less safe for lone travellers at night.

Life of Medina. The souks are the life of the Medina. Starting from the morning and you can find everything you need from groceries to souvenirs to clothes to everything. Haggling is the key here and keep a watch out for those mopeds swooshing past by you.

Come in and find out.... Literally! Once you go in, good luck finding out again. ;-)Try the Café des Espices, haggle about the price and buy something colorful, watch out for the 50 year old motorbikes and have a wonderful time! It's one of my favorite places to go!

CRAZY GOOD. The souks are a must see when in Morocco! There is so much going on in every aspect. Stay away from the animal show people, they will take as much money as possible. Other than that, it is really safe. There is so much to see and experience. If you get thirsty for a beer, walk south on the main road for 5 minutes to Hotel Tazi.

Good experience but lots the same!. Lively and colourful. Lots of stalls, lots the same. Very helpful people. Sometimes pushy but be strong and walk away. Saw a stall holder defend his stall from a shoplifter (bit scary!)
Good experience. As long as you go with the expectation that every stall holder is after your hard earned cash and manage to say No firmly this is a great experience.

visit. Bartering is the name of the game but be prepared for a hard slog.The sights and goods are fascinating but of course it is mostly market goods for the visitors.Aim for the Artisan centre for another view of shopping in Marrakesh.A huge store with everthing you could imagine,Harrods Moroccan style,worth a visit.

Aggressive hawkers. The Souk in Marrakech is just so vibrant with just about everything you could imagine for sale. The colours of the spice stalls is remarkable as are the leather works and foodstalls. The first couple of days were OK but after that the aggressiveness of the hawkers became a bit wearing. I understand the haggling system but if all you want to purchase is a bottle of coke I would rather pay a fixed price than haggle and then feel ripped off. At times a hawker would run from his stall and physically drag me or, more often my wife, into his stall and when we said we were not interested they often became aggressive. However if you do purchase something they are very polite and well give you clear directions of how to get to your next destination. Beware the Souk is like a maze and very easy to loose your way. It is possible to hire a guide but beware as they often just take you to stalls that they have an interest in. I feel that the Souk in Fez is much better

Friday afternoon. If you want to visit the Suq go any day. You will see life, artisans and shop owners working and yelling and talking all the time. But on Friday afternoon, when less turists are around, you can stop and talk to the ones who are still working...and you can see all the details of their work that are lost at peak time

my visit to morocco. i have been to morocco about 6 times and i been to marrakech and the souk i found it was a lovely place to visit and i have to tell u the people are so nice and friendly i really love morocco that much i married my husband who is from there
must go. going to the souk is just as good as going to the medina see how they barter etc is amazing there is noting I disliked about going to these places

Shop 'til you drop. The Souks are everything I had been led to believe and shopping was wonderful. Don't be afraid to barter and it may be worth visiting the fixed price stores first to get a sense of median price. But a shopping trip definitely to be enjoyed.

Not as interesting as i thought. Definitely should do the souks once you are there , but it's not as "1000 and 1 nights" as I expected. The maze of little streets and gates is an adventure in it self , you actually don't get hassled as much as I thought ,but a lot of the products are same, same, same and I wouldn't be surprised to see "made in China" under some of them. You do have loads of different trades there though , some less touristy then others. Worth seeing the "pharmacy" area!The Tanneries are ok if you have never seen how they make leather ,but its quite smelly and you have "guides" everywhere who want to have their salary afterwards...Again best approach is being firm but polite and say " La Schokran" meaning "No thanks".If you want to buy something, prepare for a long bargaining - don't be afraid to offer MUCH less (the traders will start way over of what the product is worth - remember you will meet in the middle -so go way under of what you are willing to pay)Many products -fossils especially- are fakes! Be aware!
Haggle.. something like 6000 stalls. dont be afraid to haggle and you,ll get a bargain. the stall holders arent too pushy

Hustled, Hassled and shortchanged. The Marrakech pastime is ripping off tourists - a strange attitude to have when visitors bring huge amounts of foreign currency into the town and support thousands of jobs!! I'm happy to have a robust bargaining session - but I don't appreciate being continually short changed and aggressively cornered into buying things. BEWARE: The trilobite, and other fossils, are FAKES! I spent $80 at a reputable looking shop and on returning home I discovered I had been scammed! They are extremely good resin imitations set into limestone that fool top collectors, a simple web search on "fake Morocco fossils" will explain more.

Be on your guard, Big brother is watching you!. Be prepared to haggle they are very good at it, besides we don't make our living from it,they do, therefore it is only natural that they will not concede easily. If it costs 10 to buy, offer 3! For example I saw a belt, and instantly the guy ran over and said "you like" . To get him off my back I said I was not wanting it but it went on and on and on! In the end I asked how much for it? He replied 400dirhams, I laughed at him and walked off, he came after me and said no and continued to walk on, he asked how much I would pay and I had it for 80. Makes me wonder just how much the belt was worth, and incidentally I did check to make sure the belt had not been swapped! Simply a case of being very very vigilant and on your guard.

A wonderful experience. My husband and I have just spent a wonderful weeks holiday in Marrakech. We visited Jemaa el Fna many times during our stay. The first time we went, I found it a bit mind blowing but soon got used to the sights, sounds and smells of it. Great food stalls, good shopping and lovely music. Luckily my husband speaks Arabic, which helped a lot with the haggling. It was an experience that I'm glad I've had and I would go back in a heart beat.

Crazy place. I was dizzy within minuets of arriving at the souk, great fun and what an experience. Anything you need or want you will find somewhere. Too many great food stalls everywhere, my advice as to try as much as you can.

madness. A lot going on all the time, horse drawn carraiges, donkeys pulling carts, bikes, mopeds taxis all going down side streets, lanes etc and you are always at risk at getting knocked over. Snake charmers, people with monkeys and people doing mehndi all trying to get your custome.. DONT have the black mehndi it can scar you also it looks like its been done in black marker. Take small notes with you and definitely haggle, if someone don't like your price there is always another stall that will.

Tradition is gone. You've seen one you have seen all. Unfortunately this souks became a tourist traps. Not long ago they use to be amazing, serving the locals with alleys dedicated to a category of products. Not everybody is selling everything and we even found products made in Chine. It's a pity but probably the locals are going to the hypermarkets so the small shops from the souk adapted to the tourist needs.Anyhow, get a guide for a walking tour and he will be able to steer you 9 you will get lost in first 5 min) and show you some remaining hidden gems like Riads or particular specialized shops.
Souks. Fascinating. All manner of goods, leather, metal work, clothes, scarves... Enjoy a good natured haggle with the stall holder to agree the price.

An experience not to be missed!. This is one of the most amazing but overwhelming places that I have ever been to. Please do not pay more than $50 DIR for slippers or $150 DIH for a jewelry box. These guys are hard core sales people and you need to know your prices before you go. I think everyone overpays their first day out but you learn quickly. Negotiate at least 50% of what they are asking and not a cent more! Get lost and ave fun!!

Be prepared. Great place if you love to shop, but you're best going when you aren't tired, as every stall holder in the place will try to get you into their shop. However you can have a bit of banter with most of them, but be prepared to stick to your guns over what you want to pay.

Everything you can imagine.... This is an amazing place. I've never seen so much "stuff" for sale in my life. It's kind of like it would be if everything at Target went on an outdoor sale at the same time. It's huge, colorful, noisy...and CROWDED. The walkways are pretty wide by Moroccan standards, but the place is completely overrun with people. Took a carriage ride in the evening--very pleasant.Watch your purse and wallet. They're not safe here.
Great for a barter!. get loads of traditional souveniers at great prices. just be prepared to haggle, and walk away if you dont get the price you want, you will find it somewhere else!

Worth a visit but prepare to be hassled. No trip to Marrakech is complete without a visit to the souk. Although there are lots of things to buy it isn't easy to browse as you are constantly hassled by shop holders to look at or buy their wares. This does, unfortunately, detract from the experience and put me off stopping as the moment you show even a slight interest they won't leave you alone. In terms of pricing you need to haggle. A good rule of thumb is go just below half the price they suggest and they agree at 50% of the original quote as that is the price you should pay. If they don't agree to the price just walk away and the likelihood is that they will follow you and agree to your price.

Fun!!. Great fun if you are in the mood!! Best tip we were given was to go to the Artisan market BEFORE you start your bartering, you then get a feel for what price you should be paying for your goods! we ended up buying most things there as it was such a pleasant & reasonably priced place! Fairtrade sort of thing

It's changed. Still colourful and worth seeing but we went there about four years ago and the friendliness and charm seem to have gone. At the front of the souk the shopkeepers are very pushy and impatient. The haggling was infuriating. They start at such ridiculous prices it takes forever to get down to a reasonable price. My tip would be to get through the first few hundred metres where it becomes a bit more tranquil and you can have a conversation with a shopkeeper. Better still, if you are travelling shop elsewhere. We were after a small rug which began at over £200 and we walked away bored at £80. Went to Chefchaouen where we got similar one for £15 without really haggling.

impressive.. If you want to travel through time and understand the different traditions and Culture you have to visit the Souk. At the souk you will find genuine leather items,hand woven woollen or cotton carpets.lovely silk items,and for those ladies or men who likes to spoil there wives with an unusual piece of jewelry it's a dream land.Culinary wise you cannot visit the Souk and not buy the genuine Morokkan spices.On the souk no credit cards are accepted.

Too much of the same. The Marrakesh Souk was a bit of a disappointment with too many selling the same goods and the local (authorised) guides being surly when not getting your business.Stay away from the snake charmers, monkey photographers and the tanneries.

AMAZING BAZAAR. The bazaar is a compound with never-ending narrow allies. The more you go within the cheaper the prices get. My husband wanted to buy one of those long garments for men. We were first taken by a taxi driver to a posh area in town and the prices were $300 or even higher. As we went into the bazaar and looked for this type of garment, in the end we found something similar for $30. My husband really loved the bazaar. There are all sorts of merchandise. We loved the ceramics and the tea cups. You can buy all sorts of souvenirs. There are some restaurants and good food. One big issue was the men on motorcycles in the narrow allies. They don't care about the people on foot and you have to watch out all the time. They also really pollute the air. Still we loved our experience int he souk.

Seen one, you have seen the lot. A dirty and smelly experience with the biggest load of tat for sale that you will ever see. I think they raided everyone's garage loft to find the stock! Be prepared to be touched, taken hold of, abused for walking on and generally complete hassled. If you want an eight foot long lantern; you want to see a snake charmer with a bucket of snakes with their fangs extracted; you want to have a monkey in a nappy thrust at you; you want to be hassled to the point of anger and frustration; or you want to feel physically sick from the smells and overt filth; then this is the place to go. Morocco is a beautiful country with a very rich culture. The souks form no part of that beauty or culture.

once you are there you must visit them!. This is where they spend their days selling, most of the times, what they have produced (Souk with metal productions, lamp and artistic products). It is true that guys are always calling you saying some words in your language and they think everybody wishes to visit Jemaa El Fna Place. .....but they are very polite and kind and they try to be helpful, They know that tourism is their most important source of business and try to catch you. They are never noisy and unpolite
Another good visit. Just worthwhile visiting to see how other people go about their daily lives. And the great thing was the absence of flies!! Great experience.

A must see. If you do not go to the Souk you will have missed out on one of lifes great experiences. The hustle and bustle is amazing, there is so much to see and you can shop till you drop with some good deals to be had so long as you choose carefully and are prepared to haggle. My advice is to always be prepared to walk away if negotiations reach an impasse as the vendor will usually come down in price a bit more, if not try another shop.Beware of buying fresh dates and nuts as there are mice running about all over the piles of produce,( if you didn't already know, mice urinate continually as they go as they do not have a bladder!) so think carefully before eating anything uncooked.In the main square there are numerous stalls with snake charmers etc, if they want to put one of the snakes around your neck for a photo, beware because they will then ask you for money, usually quite a high sum too! Having said that the overall experience is brilliant and you will want to visit again, we never managed to return at night but have been told that it is an even better experience then as all the food stalls come out.

A Great Place to Eat. The square transforms from a busy market area in daylight to very large dining areas with long communal tables in the evening. Eating here is extremely cheap, but don’t let that put you off.Lots of locals come here and the fun an excitement from the stall holders makes an interesting atmosphere. You might be concerned for hygiene levels but again we did not suffer any tummy bugs. My advice would be to have a tour of the various staffs (you will get hassled) and pick one with food you fancy or with touters you like.
Alive!. The place just comes alive and there is sooo much hustle and bustle it is great! Keep your wits about you as it is easy to lose your way!

overwhelming. We visited the souks when we visited marrakech last august. our party consisted of myself, husband, son age 20, his fiancee and daughter 17. We went on an organised trip through our hotel. It was middle of august so unbearably hot, no air conditioning on the coach, so after a 20 minute trip we were already soaked.The souks is not for the faint hearted, there were some awful smells, eg sewage aromas, motorcycles coming from all angles, constant harrassment to buy things, and the men just stared at the girls. We did enjoy some haggling though and got a table cloth at a bargain price. Dont be afraid to haggle, they expect it. There was a bar in the middle of the market where you can get a cold drink, but i would not advise to eat anything from the stalls, unless you want a bad case of the runs !!. We returned again this April, but just my husband and i went this time and had a more leisurely look around without the heat and was more enjoyable, but i would not recommend taking young children here,it would be too much for them. I

It was disappointing. I have to agree with Jll F.We visited Morocco with Insight Tours in 2012 and we were looking foward to Marrakech Souk and the square after seeing the photos of it in travel brochures.I think it was the worst Souk in Morocco and the square's snake charmers were really agreesive and belligerent is demanding money from people who wanted a photo or in my case for just standing there.Before the Insight Tour we stayed at Riad close to the Souk at Mekes which was really nice, it was clean and the people were great and after the tour we stayed at another Riad within Tangier's Souk which also much much better.The Marrakech square was dirty and food stalls was most uninviting.Generally I felt that the visit to Marrakech was a waste of time.

Dirty and Unattractive. I really cannot see the attraction it was crowded, noisy and smelly; there was nothing of quality and although individually harassment was not persistent the sheer numbers made it unpleasant. No attractive photo ops and the flies were unbelievable. I saw what I thought were current buns on one stall until all the "currents" flew away! To find local goods at reasonable process try the Ensemble Artisanal opposite the Cyber Parc where local people and co-ops display their wares including a women's co-operative.

Have your wits about you, go with a guide.. Wow.. What an experience, you could so easily get lost in there. Pay for a guide, especially if you are ladies. My friend and I had an amazing time here and we had a guide which showed us around the city as well as the souk. Enjoy x
Disgusting!. Filth, squalor, live animals in dreadful conditions, intimidating locals.There is NOTHING positive I can say.

A 'must see' in Marrakech. No trip to Marrakech is complete without a visit to the souk. Bustling, narrow alleys lined by little shops crammed floor to ceiling with goods. The strets are full, with noisy sellers touting for business, tea boys running back and forth and the occasional hand cart passing through, loaded high with sacks. You can imaine that it hasnt changed that much in hundreds of years. There are different areas, for different types of goods but it seems every street has a carpet shop! Its very interesting but also quite easy to get lost - try to keep going back to the one main street that passes through it ( it is the one street that has flags hanging from the roof all the way along) and you wont go far wrong.

souks. wow the most amazing shopping experience ever thousands and thousands of stalls selling everthing from carpets to shampoo, bread, spices everything you can think of ,the smells were amazing ,there were donkeys and carts ,mopeds that nearly ran you over lol,,the stall holders were very friendly and i dont think they were to pushy either they love to barter we pick up some good bargains on gifts to take home,,i absolutely loved it and in 2 wks went back 4 times,,

Get stuck in!. The souks are amazing, albeit ever so slightly scary! You'll soon spot the stalls which are just selling tat as they stand out a mile. The best places we found were the blacksmiths area and the woodcraft areas but there are tons of stalls selling lovely spices and a brilliant little shop with glass walls selling genuine argan products at good prices. We felt very safe there even when we got completely lost but it's best for women to cover up as its extremely traditional and you will stand out a mile if you are in skimpy clothes. You are never far from the main square and taxis so no need to panic if you do get lost just follow the signs? You can haggle as hard as you like, they love it and will give you a good lesson in bartering, one man even tried to sell us a stray kitten! The only thing I wouldn't buy there is leather goods as a lot of it is not leather, unless you are quite near the tanneries it's best to go to the artisan for real leather.

Caotic. The sights, sounds smells and colours are amazing, the noise of the drums the lights of the souks and the gathering of people is wonderful, apart from the animal they have chained up, its worth a visit...just don't take photos of the animals

Brilliant. We visited the Souks/ Market through a trip booked with First Choice. It was very interesting and brilliant to see things we probably would not have seen without a rep but very tiring. We were told by our rep you cannot access the Souks without a rep born in Morocco (not sure how true this is) however we were glad we went with a tour guide as we would have definatley got lost due to the winding streets and alleys, they all looked the same and one blended into another. The only disappointment was the pharmacy as we had no choice but to visit, we felt the products were forces on us and we spent at least 1-2 hrs there. We also visited a bakery which we were charged as we took a photo. We were not told this before entering but Moroccan people are very offended if a photo is taken with no payment. Surprisingly every stall was different and they had endless choice of clothes, housewares, gifts, souvenirs etc. After walking through the Souks we did stop at a cafe nr the market where we was provided with one free drink, the view from the roof seating was amazing especially when we went back ourselves in the evening. The market itself was quite repetitive and we were pestered a lot by women and children selling. Be careful not to give them your hand - they ask to look at jewellrey and tattoos then before you know it they henna you and don't let you go until you pay. One thing we were recommended and I would definatley say to try is their orange juice (believe it or not) it was amazing. I would definatley recommend the souks however if you have the option to go later in the day I would say would be better do to the intense heat.

Great fun!!. Wow what can we say, this is a very traditional way of shopping, some of the stalls are not up to much but it's great fun finding the great ones.It can be quite easy to get lost but if you get a good map/guide book you will be ok. Just be careful as you may get some very helpful people who will guide you back the main square, the problem with this is you will be expected to pay them for this assistance and also they will probably take first to their Fathers,Uncles or Brothers stall first.Saying this You Must Still Do This it's Great!!!

Not to be missed. Who would visit Marrakech without seeing the souks. Amazing maze of winding narrow 'streets' crammed with everything possible to make or buy! Everything from traditional lamps and slippers, to carpets, spices and food
the souk. tread carefully when visiting the souk area , there are many shady charracters trying to take you here and there, just keep your head down and ignore
Loved it.... We loved shopping in the Souks, exciting, varied, full of colours and smells. Shop around and have fun. The key thing is not to take it too seriously.

different. Shopping in the Souk is certainly different to your every day market. Be prepared to barter and stick to the price you are prepared to pay. Do not be afraid to walk away. If they want your sale then they will come after you and you will get your purchase at the price you offered.Bartering is all part of the fun and a place not to be missed

Souks. This is a very traditional way of shopping in the Medina. There are different types of Souks (markets). It's good to get a guide book and a map for it. It's easy to get lost. Some of the stalls are full of mass produced rubbish and it's best to avoid them. This is where you'll need the map to go to the right souks like Rhaba Kedima, Souk Smarine or Place des Ferblantiers. And haggle, haggle, haggle!
A real eye opener!. Take the bull by the horns and go for it. It is an experience that should not be missed as it would be a waste to visit this city and not visit it's heart.
Good experience. Shopping abound, with all different price ranges and varying items. Safer than we expected. You should still be on your guard.

A bit intimidating but an absolute MUST-visit. There are miles upon miles of alleyways in the souks so if you are a good walker and don't mind - shortly after setting off and inevitably taking a mix of right turns here and left turns there - having absolutely no idea where you are, then no problem! We thoroughly enjoyed being in the thick of the souks on our very first morning in Marrakech - the sights, sounds and smells are absolutely fantastic!... but I do have to say that they can be of bit overwhelming: you do have to wisen up very quickly to the fact that there are plenty of locals in there wanting to 'be helpful' and, um, 'show you the way', or invite you to 'just come and have a look'... What happens in fact is that the friendly local is luring you into a shop of sorts - the favourite being the ubiquitous carpet shop located deep inside a building - and before you've actually realised that that is exactly what's happened, you have been sat down and given mint tea and... carpet after carpet is being unrolled in front of you and the hard-seller is talking non-stop, leading to his asking you, fairly quicklly, what you like most and, clearly most importantly, how much you're prepared to pay! It's difficult to get away but away you must get, that's for sure because it would take a split second for you to be sucked into a purchase you really don't want. The one thing to avoid doing is to answer the hard-seller when he asks you how much you'd be prepared to pay for an item you've been shown because the moment you've uttered a figure, you've as good as sealed the purchase in the eyes of the seller! So if you don't want to find yourself in a very awkward spot, keep schtum and get out!I had looked forward to buying a few items in the souks during my visit - some spices, herbal soaps, a little tagine maybe, a teapot for mint tea, a couple of bits of jewelry, etc., but at the end of the day, because it's utterly impossible to browse at leisure due to the fact that the sellers are incredibly pushy (and won't hesitate to block your way out of their shop/stall space until you've bought something), I gave up and came home with practically nothing!Having said all that, I certainly do not regret spending a lot of time in the souks - the experience was great and, the next time I am in Marrakech, I'll be able to draw on the wisdom I have just acquired... (and be firm with those sellers and just say 'NO NO NO')!

interesting / bargaining power. interesting place. performers with snakes, monkeys or some skills looking for basking $. bottled water is more expensive here. get water outside the medina before going there. try not to buy on the first instance - shop around and test your bargaining powers - it's a battle of wills.eg. 1 store had a price tag of 150 dhm and another 30 dhm.

Incomperable Experience (but I don't need to do it again). Our tour guide took us on a two (or more?) hour tour of the souk in the mid-morning. The smells in the food area are incredible-- the selection and sheer amount of spices and olives alone boggle the imagination. By and large, go for the local crafts such as the lanterns; the prices on most antiques are higher than other venues. Be prepared for a little ickiness, such as the area where live chickens are sold. The vendors are not aggressive and an amazing number speak English. This is absolutely worth doing once, not sure I would do it again.

Don't be scared but don't get lost!. The locals are mostly fine, not as pushy as other countries and happy to do a deal. The Souks are a warren of alleyways and so you really need to keep you bearings or get a guide.

do not miss this. the most fun I've had shopping in a long time. I was only hampered by the lack of suitcase space on the flight home. the market has some tat but also some beautiful items. the silver / lantern area especially - stunning. the stall holders are not aggressive and a simple no and walk away will be the end of your interaction with them, should you wish. it is not a hard sell - as in some other northern african countries eg egypt. I never felt unsafe or pressured.

Aweful experience. I found every moment to be a chore of trying to remove myself from situations that were created by the local desire to want money, offering help (for money), to eat in this one (for money), to buy tat (For money). It was a very difficult place to enjoy destroyed entirely by over populated human consumption and greed. It was worse than Glastonbury for its shops of rubbish and bloated exaggerations of positive experience. Also be careful where you eat as it is common to have loose stools and feel sick. Lovely !

highs and lows. i traveled with my partner and two children, girls aged 11 and 15, while we found the souks beguiling and colourfull the attention our 15 year old attracted from young lads became too much and got to a point when we had to get out, she was almost groped and when my partner stopped it she was sworn at, some of the comments she recieved were disgusting.the main square is quite a spectacle only marred by the young guys trying to get you into their food stalls they can get right up in your face making it difficult to move around and the comments you get from some of them when you try to politely move on aren't exactly friendly either .we found the souk stall holders to be friendly and good fun to barter with and we got some great gifts at good prices .

Souked out!. What a brilliant experience - we spent three days in the souk, and enjoyed every minute. Everyone would like you to buy from them, but a smile and a non merci is all it takes to get by. It was a help to have a little French as it's easier to bargain and they really like the fact that you 'have a go' although you may not be that brilliant.

A souk with some interesting antique shops.. We found the stall holders very civilise. They did not follow you or plead if you didn't want to buy. It is easy to find your way again when lost in the labyrinth. You will find directions to the Jemaa al Fna or you will see the Koutoubia minaret. The souk is very colourful and there are lovely things to buy.

Exotic and "happening". The souk in Marrakech is a maze of shops and areas for various trades. It helps to have a guide and Around Morocco Tours provided a day guide for us who helped us navigate the maze of streets and alleys. The square at night time is a wonderland, full of performers, snake charmers, story tellers and a sight to see.

Uniquely Marrakech. You need to visit the Souk to really appreciate the unique nature of the place.. so much going on in so small a place.. manufacturing, retailing, living, eating, negotiating plenty of locals prepared to give you advice on how to get somewhere and plenty who 'recognise' you from your hotel or Riad.. even though you don't recognise them. A must see part of Marrakech
Buy buy buy. Everything is a special prize for you my friend. Buy at 75% of offered prize You must drop the prize!

traditional bazzar. full of colour, you had the chance to see how people produce their local goods but you could never tell what the real price of the goods was, some people say fake things made in China,

Beautiful, friendly and stunning!. Marrakech is beautiful, the souk is amazing and a buzz during the night. There so much to buy and see. U can't go to the souk and not grab a orange juice, it's the most delicious juice ever!!! But don't forget to put u haggling hat on in the shops. It's a must visit in you're in Marrakech, the famous Masjid is walking distance from the souk. Enjoy, I certainly did!
Good Fun. The traders on the outside of the souk are the most aggressive, go inside to find the friendlier traders. Most of the stalls sell the same goods and it's really good fun to haggle :)

how to get lost but with fun. Well worth a visit even if you do get lost but that is part of the fun.Everyone says hello and if you just look they want you to go into their shop but just say no thank you and continue walking. If you do go in the shop some will leave you alone and some will try to sell you everything but only buy if you want it they will try to make you feel guilty but don't just walk away

Marrakech Souk. We really experienced the life and culture of Marrakech in the Souks where we were exposed to the local people and their trades. There are various stalls in the Souks with a range of things to buy from scarves, bags, shoes, jewellery, cushion covers and throws, tea cup sets and much more. However, alot of the stalls are all selling the same thing aswell and so it can get a little repetitive. Leather is sold everywhere however *BEWARE* the leather is not treated/tanned properly and is extremely smelly. The Souks are very smelly as a result of all the leather but when purchasing, the shop owners assured us the smell would pass with time and usage. Unfortunately this is not the case, and infact, the bags have started to decompose - a complete and utter waste of money. DO NOT BUY THE LEATHER FROM THE SOUKS! The leather bags from the Souks are the only downer to an amazing trip in Marrakech.

Shopping. Many of the stalls sell the same thing. Be prepared to barter. Interesting experience, as never been to anything like this before. Easy to get lost, but just enjoy the experience as you always get back to the big square eventually. Many of the store holders try to get you to go in and look, but most accept no if you don't want to.
Another world. It's an adventure touring the Souks, you meet many characters along the way, they invite you into their shops and love to barter with you. Lovely people

Interesting marketplace. You've not been to Marrakesh if you've not been inside this souk! A very interesting place to explore with all the different (leather, metal, fabric, etc) trades in one place. Always no obligation to buy, just remember to haggle on price if you do!

Literally Aladdins Cave. Its nice just to wander - there are different areas for specific things i.e food, leather etc. You must haggle - they expect it. It is advisabe to take a guide if you want to venture deep into the souk

An experience. it is an experience but can get tiring if you are staying in the medina. You have to have a strong will not to be 'persuaded' into purchasing something you do not really want. Once you get into the swing of how to say no you can 'browse' although i do not think Moroccan's browse. at first the labyrinth of streets seem overwhelming but after getting lost a couple of times it actually becomes easy to navigate even though you may go round in circles a few times before you find the bit you want to go back too. Just go with the flow and wander.

Its a must. We enjoyed a lot walking through the souk alleys: you can buy anything from a dress to an aladino-like lamp, or maybe just go for a "window-shopping", however, avoid rush hours or going in the night when it's crowded and also expect to be harassed by the sellers, you can just pass on them and follow your path but it can get annoying if you stay there for a while, aside from that, is a great experience and most of them will allow you to take pictures with no charge (make sure to get in one of the spices shops and get them explained to you)

can be stressful. there are lots of the same things but there are different areas specialing a bit more in different items like the dyers market where they dye the threads and make the scarves and linens. There is a spice market area, and and area with blacksmiths making things from iron and a slipper section where they are hand making the slippers.I didn't like the hassle we got from a couple of the traders because we didn't buy from them. Although many of them were lovely. We found Sunday and Monday we were a little less hassled. Monday seemed slightly quieter which was nice.

Always nice. You can find anything in there. Sellers are insisting a bit but they are nice when you are answering with a "no thank you". Be careful the prices are always very high and need to be negotiated!

Respect. You may be approached by the sellers, but I never felt pressured to buy ,in fact although this is the commercial part of the city, and of course a must, people are very respectful of the visitors... By the way getting lost in the Souk is a part of the experience...

Tourist Tat. Somewhat disappointing and did not live up to expectations. The initial sights sounds and smells are wonderful. However, after 10 minutes you realise that by and large they are all selling the same mass produced merchandise aimed at tourists. You can get stuff cheap if you barter, but beware, if you can get it cheap, it is generally very poor quality. The vendors are mostly all good humoured and friendly and wont pester you if you say "no thank you" or "I have already bought one of those". We found that they are not willing to barter on the better quality items and a few of them will take offence if you try to barter them down too low. Take a good look around and check the quality before you buy. We found better items and sometimes a little cheaper or the same price outside the Souk. If you are buying lamps, go to the Jewish quarter where they are sometimes making them. They are not willing to barter but you get a much better product. Be careful buying herbs and spices. It sounds very cheap until they start bagging it up and weighing it!

Manic place. Maze of alleyways with traders trying to sell you anything they can. Bartering to get the best price, start as low as you can. Bargains to be had if you bargain tough. Careful you don't get lost..... Lol. Well worth a look.

Assault on the senses. First thing we noticed was the noise, bells, drums, whistles and people all talking at once. then we were struck by the almost medieval impression it gave with the building style, myriad of tunnels and way of life and finally the smell....a combination of petrol from the dozens of scooters racing along and weaving in & out of the alleys through to cat mess in the smaller alleys. Whichever way you looked, there was something going on. Everything from snake charmers to bare knuckle fighters in the square through to an overwhelming array of goods for sale in the souk itself. You could easily get lost, it's so big, but it's divided into sections, carpets, metals, lanterns, spices and so on so that helped with getting your bearings. The stall holders were friendly but all mastered the knack of effectively 'trapping' you in a corner of their stall and doing their utmost to make you buy....even if you didn't want to. Our English culture is one of browsing, picking up and putting down, going from shop to shop until we find something we may want to buy,,,,but here in Marrakech it felt like running the gauntlet as we ended up not wanting to stop and look for fear of being hassled yet again. Of course, this is the way shopping is done here but it felt like a strain rather than a pleasure after a while. Definitely worth a visit but one of those 'once seen never forgotten' excursions that we personally wouldn't want to repeat. We did enjoy it but it was exhausting.

interesting place to get lost in. A lot of colors and smells in the souks. You have to bargain a lot for the price because the prices for tourists are heavily inflated. So take your time to look around and make sure you get the best price. If unhappy just turn around and leave and they will most probably ask you to come back and sell you the staff for the price you want. A lot of fun to "play" with the local merchants. It is gret fun to get lost in the souk.

bustling. very colourfull and interesting but impossible to buy anything as they wont agree a price and keep bringing more items so u give up in the end, it is like stepping back in time and a guide arranged by the hotel is very usefull to learn the history of the place

Souks. Great fun. Recommend arriving early and getting lost/exploring. When haggling, offer 25% of their initial price. After some haggling, you'll almost inevitably end up paying about 30-35% of their original price!

Lovely day out. A real eye opener and thoroughly enjoyed my few days getting around and enjoying the atmosphere. Went in on the bus which was very convenient - watch out for the henna ladies though - as they will say let me just show you and then ask for £20 - I obviously did not pay ...... lol
collegues weekend. brilliant place to go with lots to see, from stalls,to small shops of handcraft,to cobras an other snakes including primates,also the gateway to the sahara

Souk...it up!!. Hectic, crazy, mental, crowded, just 4 words that spring to mind on first entering the Souk, by night. If you go in the day time, it does feel a lot more calmer, & will be less full of tourists, due to the intense heat, just make sure you carry a water bottle with you.Would go for the experience really, as after the 50th stall/shop selling the same as the previous 50th, the lure of the haggle loses it's charm & you almost want them to just state the price & get on with it.Please dont use the horse drawn carriages around the Souk, the horses have stood all day in the blistering heat, dont look well looked after, collapse & then forced to work again...
Interesting!. A must visit place in Marrakech, you can buy pretty much anything in the souks just don't be afraid to have a good wander through and a simple no thank you is all you need!
Great experience. Did not get bothered just say no thank you, haggling is good, would recommend the horse and carriage (make sure you haggle and u offer what u want to pay)

Amazing!. Everything you could wish for in lots of little shops with great shop keepers! It was so colourful and there were so many beautiful things, lovdd it. Its nor scary a bit intense but you get used to it. Enjoy!

A culture shock. The Souks and Medina tour organised through Thomson is a great way to get acquainted with how the Moroccan town came to be and also what the souks are like, without the pressure to buy anything. We used the tour to give us a bit of an understanding of how the souk experience worked and also picked up some useful tips that we used later on when we came back to the medina without a guide. One such tip, was to have a drink in the cafe around the square and sit on the terrace to get great views and photos without being hassled by anyone!Remember to stay hydrated as you walk around, particularly if the temperatures are in the high 30s/40s - there is quite a lot of walking but it's a great trip

Marrakech - a vibrant city never to be forgotten. Marrakech is probably everything you could imagine ... busy, noisy, colourful. The sounds, sights ... and smells, will be remembered for a long while, but overall they will be good memories and well worth the journey. Be prepared for major hassle from the stall owners in the Souks ... you practically end up saying "no" in your sleep. The alternative is to launch yourself into it all with the spirit intended and the haggling can be enormous fun - although it would be nice to be able to browse without the constant pressure to make a saleWatch out if you are looking lost - there is always someone wanting to direct you ... for a price! Things are simpler if you go on an organised foot tour with an official guide - ours was excellent and kept most of the 'pest' hawkers at bay while showing us areas that we may well not have visited otherwise.A few days IN Marrakech is probably enough but trips out to the coast, the mountains, etc make an excellent starting point.We have not added our photos here (100's) as there are already so many out there - but make the visit, be prepared for everything you could imagine - from the sounds & smells of the spice markets to the not so pleasant smells of the drains that are always likely to be around the next corner!! Also the wealth and the poverty that is always present in a city such as this but also the overwhelming friendliness of the people met

Marrakesh Souks. We spent an entire morning in the souks at the beginning of our trip to Marrakesh. We hired a guide to take us around which cost 100 DHM (about £8) - this was definitely worth it. The souks are a complete maze and there is so much more to see than you would expect, so hiring a guide so you can see everything is advisable.Make sure you haggle! We ended up spending a small fortune in a chemist shop in the souks buying Argan oil and spices. We did ask our guide once we left the shop if we should have bargained and he said not so much in the proper shops in the souks, but always at the market stalls. You will be asked by almost every single stall owner you pass to have a look at what they're offering, which can get a bit of a pain, but they don't take offense if you just ignore them and walk past.If you are a woman, I would strongly suggest covering your arms and at least down to your knees. I had long trousers on and a vest top with a shirt underneath (it wasn't overwhelmingly hot as most of the souks are in the shade) but a lot of other tourists were wearing inappropriately short shorts and low cut strappy tops. This offends a lot of the older Moroccan men, and it will attract unwanted attention from the younger ones - they make no effort to hide the fact they're staring at your chest and I often felt uncomfortable.However long you are in Marrakesh for, you should definitely visit the souks - you won't have experienced Morocco until you have, and there are some really nice items to buy!

An experience like no other!. Be prepared to haggle for your life but have fun with it too. Paid bit too much for some items but once we got into the swing of it we were like pros. It is all taken in good fun, but stand your ground, work out a strategy of how you will tackle these Wiley souk sellers, they are real artists at what they do, but enjoy the game and have a laugh by getting the lowest prices possible...it does work!

asda price!. Might be naive here but I thought it was far too commercial - lots of 'hey Asda price' comments or 'are you from Kent' etc comments from locals - Husband and I have a little french that we found if you spoke it they did seem to back off with the 'cockney' chat and just let you get on with buying/browsing. Just one comment, everyone expects to be paid of EVERYTHING here.....if its to take you back to the square if you think you are lost, or to get his brother to take you to the tannery etc - TIP - keep loose change in your pocket, when you get to where ever you want to be dont wait for them to tell you how much they want, shake their hand and put the coins in their hand at the same time, be polite and thank then them walk away. Contrary to popular belief you DO NOT have to buy at each stall, you are safe to browse all day long if you want without feeling obliged to buy. Try the orange juice in the square - cheap and absolutely gorgeous on a hot day.

Marrakech Souk - Lose yourself in a world of history and indulgence. I am not the most patient of shoppers but my wife loved wandering through the souks taking her time to search out bargains and haggle with the locals. Normally I would be bored, but not amongst the souks. Everywhere something is going on, whether you are intrigued by what's being sold, chatting with the stall holders or just looking around at the marvellous buildings and architecture ( loosely used ) that makes the place so interesting. Every turn there's something new and a multitude of photo opportunities. Just be mindful to be respectful about what you point the camera at. The maize of alleyways, every now and then opens out onto a 'square' with the expectant over attentive sales pitches never really taking off. The locals care about this place and they care about its future. They do talk to you and want you to visit their own little patch but never aggressively and always with a smile. Indeed I had many conversations with them, firstly to state I wasn't French ( as they all seemed to presume ) and then to chat about all manner of subjects, not just come to my stall. They were just great to spend time with. Spend half a day just mulling around the souks, pick up a few bargains and lose yourself in so much Marrakech history.
Haggle!!!. Literally, start with 10% of the value they first say. If they say 100 dinar, reply with 10. and never pay more than 50% of their first offer.but have fun with it.

Interesting. Very busy in the Souk, the people were not as bad as I thought they would be as I had been warned that they would force me to buy things but 'no' was enough. We did buy some crockery from a man upstairs in the souk as his stock was much cheaper, which my husband reckons because he is out of the way. Anyway, some sights to see in the souk. Dolls hanging by their necks in chains (bit scary really) Fresh meat hanging in the heat, beggars everywhere, which is quite sad and hard working donkey's, goats lugging stock. Motorbikes rushing through the streets. It's definitely worth looking at. Bit smelly though!

did not get lost!. We had an excellent guide taking us through the souk and medina of Marrakesh. His name is Mohammed and he works with Journey Beyond Travel, the company that gave us a fantastic trip in Morocco. Mohammed has knowledge, insight and much to share about Marakesh and Moroccan history. He did not balk at the numerous questions we asked covering a wide range of topics. He was not counting the minutes and did not have only a standard number of things to discuss. He knew we did not want shopping an the never exposed us to any. We learned a great deal from Mohammed and highly recommend him as your guide and teacher.

A maze of wonders.. If you are after a local bargain this is the place to go. Don't be intimidated by all the sellers trying to lure you in. When they heard me talking in English they were shouting things like:I'll give you ASDA price! But they will leave you alone when they see you're not interested. Most definitely haggle!!! I loved it, they love it and it is expected. I bought a mother of pearl jewelery box where the original asking price the seller given me was 1800 dirhams but I managed to get it down to 600!!!
First time in a souk!. We didn't get lost and we didn't feel uneasy at any time. Like nothing else I've experienced - noisy, colourful, hetic and not to be missed!

haggle away. The souk and Medina is a(haggle, haggle,haggle) must with a guide on the first instance just to get your bearings as it is a lambrinth! Bustling part of the city, with plenty of cafes and high level bars/cafes to soak up the city in panoramic view.

Red Marrakech. It is at the heart of Morocco...
You will be amazed in Jemaa el-Fnaa.. Enjoy delicious Moroccan foods in that square.

take a guide!. I would highly recommend accepting the services of a local guide for your first foray into the souk in order to get your bearings and discover each of the areas dedicated to particular crafts and artesan activity.

Wish we had more time. Wow! recommend a visit during the day and night to experience the different feel of the place. Loved all the bartering. Wish i'd had more space in the suitcase to bring goodies home.

GREAT experience and tons of fun.. Definitely go here at least once in your life. It's an amazing place with tons of activity and variety for everyone. Food is extremely good. Bargaining with the store owners adds to the experience and makes it more enjoyable.
The Heart of Marrakech. Definitely a part of the can't miss in Marrakech. The sights, the sounds, the smells and the noise of the Souk are what Marrakech is all about

Chaotic marketplace. It's a real "never-seen-this" experience for "western citizens" ! Must admit it's a shcok at first, all of the people jumping around you, neverending crowd, barginers at stands selling jewelery, food, drinks. Stands with benches wher you can eat food made infront of you. And native people eating food without forks, but with their hands, but at the same time, well dressed. Always someone chasing you, trying to sell you something, saying "Special price for you my friend! " :)All in all, a MUST SEE!

Must visit. This is a must on a visit to marekesh , it will take all day and you must haggle with the prices , dont be scared to barter with the shop keepers , it is part of the holiday , oh and try the mint tea

Nothing to fear. For most of us used to the western way of shopping i.e. the price is on the tag and we pay up without question, shopping expeditions in places like the souk in Marrakech can be a daunting, and for some even a fearful, experience. If you understand a few things about the culture, there is nothing to fear and lots of fun and bargains to be had.In Ireland we will quite happily nod to strangers on the street in greeting and if someone bids us the time of day, we would consider it rude not to respond. In Morocco, everyone with something to sell will be bidding you the time of day or talking at you in some way. If you are truly not interested in what they have to sell, do NOT catch their eye or respond!!! To them, this shows interest and the opportunity to start the process of selling you their wares. To shoppers not used to this and trying to get away, it can be scary and often puts them off venturing further.In my experience, if one ignored the first attempt to get your attention (very hard for us well brought up westerners who speak when spoken to!!!) you were not pursued. The minute you looked at them though, you were fair game and they started telling you what 'good price' they had 'specially for you' !! If you are interested, then the fun begins. As a rule of thumb, offer one third of what they are asking and don't pay more than half - and enjoy the banter in the process. Most people enter the souk in Marrakech from Jemaa el Fna square and so, naturally, the first hundred yards or so is very touristy in content and likely to be more expensive. It is also much more crowded. Brave this crowd and push your way on into the souk and suddenly you will find that it is not crowded at all and you can walk and browse with ease. Do also venture right into the heart of it where the metal workers and the carpet dyers have their own sections of the souk and you will see real artisans at work. Also, if you ask where you might find something, don't be frightened when the guy says 'I'll take you there' and speeds off in front of you and you follow and find yourself in a warren of twists and turns and wonder if you will ever be seen again. He is probably bringing you to his 'brother, cousin, uncle....' who has just what you want! We were looking for a particular lamp and were involved in such an expedition but we got exactly what we were looking for and an adventure as well. Our 'guide' then led us back to Jemaa el Fna. Happy shopping!
interesting place to buy low cost. you can buy or not at very cheap price if you know how to negotiate and if not it doesn't matter because people are very sweet
Very interesting place to visit. Very attractive, interesting place to visit with a lot of strange staff. When you say Marrakech the first thing come up to your mind is Sahat El Fna

jemaa el Fna- worth a visit. Heard quite a lot about this place and we decided to make it our first destination as soon as we arrived into Marrakech. Taxi fare was 20DIR.Went there around 8ish at night and it was overly populated with lots of locals and tourists. We had to make sure we stayed together due to the large crowd buzzing around. It was a warm night.Looked around the souvenir shops on the square but decided not to go into the souks for we were worried we may get lost. Just stayed on the outside for a few hours and returned back to our hotel by the horse carriage which cost us 200DIR.We were told that during the day...there would be different stalls around and that it does differ from the night atmosphere. Worth the visit for the experience.
Everything you ever needed. You can buy anything but be prepared for a tough deal - they don't take no for an answer. Be prepared to walk away!
Frightening. Felt very unsafe place was dirty and beggars on the street which was very disturbing when they actually got very aggressive when you wouldnt give them money

Interesting cultural place, annoying people. If only the stall owners would leave you alone for just a second to look or browse, they might get along a bit better. They will all shout "hello" and some become hostile if you ignore them - don't they know you've heard this 25 times in the last 10 minutes are are now deaf to it? Some of the goods on sale are interesting but the stalls are certainly repetitive, and the general attitude of the stallholders makes for an unpleasant experience. If you get lost they will try to misdirect you for financial gain, and you can have two people practically point you back to the square in opposite directions almost at the same time. Another favourite is "this way is closed" - perhaps one of Marrakech's top lies. I know everyone finds tourists annoying, but they could at least have some basic respect for another human being. In 35 other countries inc south east Asia, never so much have I felt eyed as a wallet on legs, and never so much have I been stalked by people wanting my money.So I disliked the souks, but at the same time they are a cultural experience, just not one I'd care to repeat again. Far worse than their equivalents in Dubai and Istanbul. Pretend you are deaf or cannot speak English of French and you'll get through them relatively unscathed.

Must see in Marrakech. When in Marrakech, a visit to the souk is a must. There are many souvenir shops, food stalls, anything a tourist could want is in the souk. And the temperature is pleasant since the sun does not have immediat access in the souk.The streets can be quite narrow and it is easy to get lost. A good idea for finding your way there, is to hire a guide for a morning at the beginning of your stay in Marrakech to show you around the souk. that way you get an instant overview of the souk and it's inhabitants/vendors.

Haggle and be careful of scams.. When you go to the souk (market) remember that there are hundreds of stalls all waiting to sell you the same thing. Do not look at them if you Do not want to be bothered and DO expect to be harassed. There is no such thing as pure silver nor cedar wood in the souks. Don't fall for that. Pay only 25% of asking and if they say no...go to the next guy! They all say "diplomatic price" but stay firm on 25-30%. I highly suggest hiring a guide from your hotel since it will help lessen being scammed. Oh, they do not have 100% pashmina scarfs and most argon oil was not pure. Our guide took us to an olive shop where Moroccans shop and I was able to buy a liter of real oil for a third of the fake stuff. Women beware...you will be harassed. I carried my cash in my front pockets and usually a small amount on one side. P.S I got a full tea set (large pot) with glasses for 200 dh. Haggle, haggle and haggle.
Best time ever I had. Good place for holiday and family shopping and activity all you need as gift antiq sweet coffe. Morrocon tea with mint the best

Interesting but overpriced.. Marrakech Souks are definitely highlights of Marrakech. When you reach to the square you could not not miss them.From day to night, lots of lively lives, Hugh collections of local products.You can easily get lost in there and enjoy the differences of being in Morocco style of lives.There are mixed feelings of Souks. If you only liked fixed prices, Souks can be heel to you. You need to bargain, a lot. For most people, it is very uncomfortable way to get items they like. Best thing to do is look around more, asking prices buy in the e B2B d of the trip. That gives more time to used to the Moroccan way and know roughly how much they ask at the first place.If you like bargain, congratulations, you can get reasonable prices for items you like to pay and do not feel like have been ripped off. There are many things I liked but many times I felt they were very pushy so I did not want to even go in their shops. Best time going to Souks is mornings. I found they did not do very much hard sales. I walked in 3 different shops. A wooden boxes shop, A lantern shop , A ceramic shop and A jewellery shop. I bought a box with flower patterns on for 80dh(Asking price was 180dh) 2 aluminum lanterns for 220dh(asking price was 380dh) ceramic ingredient bowls were fixed prices, 10dh/each. 1 mixed silver with other material bangle for120dh(asking price was 350dh)From here, you could guessed how overpriced the Souks are. And we were advised by riad owner, do not pay the prices they ask for and bargain down to half price at least.I understand it is annoying they should just have fixed prices, but for things you like a lot you probably have to go through all these unfairness.Don't bother with those high prices jewellery shops. They measure by grams and tell you they are all silver.charge you 700dh for a little ring. But I noticed, once I said if he could find me some similar design of the ring. He went to his big collection of plastic bags for them. Well, I saw people selling this type of rings in Europe. The shop owner does not put them in a cheap plastic bags and if they are very expensive, he won't treat them like a market items. So be carefully with jewellery shopping.About carpets, not very much experience. But there are many tricks to make you buy. So even I like them so much,I dare to try.If Souks owner ask where you are from, try not to answer, the prices depending on that too.Try to think how much you would lime to pay at home and don't be shy by offering your ideal prices.:)I really hope, tripadvisor having more people comment and write reviews of general ideas in Morocco. That will help a lot for tourists to make their holidays easier.
Brilliant. A real cultural experience, don't be intimidated, people are very friendly. Haggle! start at a quarter of what they're asking and don't pay more than 50%

Nice to get lost in but tired of bargaining. Many different shops to stroll around. It's nice as long as you're ok with shop owner trying to hard sell you.Always bargain with a starting price that's 25%-30% of the quoted price and stick hard to it. You will get it that cheap! If not... Walk out and they'll agree with your price.

fantastic. When you arrive it is a culture shock.You feel unsafe and worried.There is no need for this you are perfectly safe, and if you relax you will love the experience.Refuse a guided tour as you will get ripped off and will get taken to places they want to take you to.Go it on your own you can stop when you want.A polite positive No works when you are bothered.Do not pay more than half the price, start at a quarter, I know it sounds low but trust me you can always go up.If you don't get it it is available around the corner.Say I am here for a few days so I may come back, works you will get it for less than half.

Haggle and walk away. Great experience. Don't be afraid to haggle - all the souks sell the same merchandise so if they won't drop the price - walk away. They will soon call you back. Also, don't show interest in anything you don't want as they will start haggling and they won't let you leave without it! Overall though, they are friendly people.

Chaos and entertainment. Smoking monkeys, snake charmers, shopping for carpets, junk clothes, Jewellery and kick knacks.This place is well entertaining to say the least. It can get pestering when people are trying to make money of you all the time, but get into a restaurant on the roof and watch the magic unfold. Or wait till the sunsets and eat some street side food. For all its hype this Place is completely worth it. I really enjoyed myself and being Indian i love haggling so :)

Worth a visit to see & buy some authentic Moroccan goods. Its a place to worth visiting once at least. See the market. Helps if you are good at haggling if you want to buy anything. Can get hot. We went in the afternoon when it was quieter but a bit hotter. Price you pay for if you want to avoid the crowds.

Great Experience. If you only do one thing in Marrakesh this is it!! Some people have written that they had a bad experience - just be sensible and firm when declining to enter a shop or have a snake wrapped around your neck! Done with a smile most of the locals smiled back and wished us a pleasant stay in their city.
Very busy. Was very busy and hot. We took the horse drawn carriage. There were snake charmers that I found scary.

a cornucopia of colour. Really geared up for the artisans to sell to the tourists it's an incredible place of sights sounds and smells.
