You'll have to haggle and it pays to do some research first if there are things you really want to buy, Otherwise just wander and enjoy.Special mentions for the dyers souk - so colourful and the blacksmiths souk - for all the intricate metalwork

Pros and cons...you must see them though. So many sights and smells. Take a camera, enjoy the banter of the stall holders and make sure to drive a hard bargain - it's expected! Feels a little less safe after dark, so I'd recommend not walking in alone after nightfall. Also hold on to your bag....it's a busy place. And watch out for electric scooters or your arms will be bruised from the constant bashing past. So worth a visit though!

Leather and pouf in marrakech. I was there and i can tel that it was a great experience at this shop If you wish a genie would add some magic to your home décor - poof! - here's your dream pouf, in a range of shapes, colours and prices. The traditional round ones come embroidered, embossed and gilded, and the funky square ones are available outstitched, high-gloss and in rich natural shades. Prices vary by leather quality; the best is thick, durable and carefully tanned so the dye won't fade or rub off.More information : http://www.lonelyplanet.com/morocco/marrakesh/shopping/house/chay-abdelhadihttp://here.com/marocco/marrakesh/shopping/chay-abdelhadi--504evd7f-ef72e6969c834fdabd4d47a377d57993
Crazy but fun. Great place to haggle, especially good for local rugs. Avoid the annoying "guides" that grab you on arrival

Souk and See!!. Great fun bartering for goods. However, be aware of "guides" who say they don't want any money just want to show you around their beautiful souks or berber markets. They do want money and can lead you away from the main hub. Politely but firmly refuse!!

The Heart of Marrakech. The Souks in the Medina in the old town of Marrakech are everything you would imagine this place to be. The noise, the crowds, the smells and the constant haggling for price make for an amazing adventure. Contrary to another preconception it's a very safe place with the locals eager to maintain their friendly reputation. We have two small children who we were worried about losing in the crowds but never for their actual safety. It's impossible to explain the place without having experienced it yourself but as first timers I would highly recommend a getting a local guide. Finding a good one can be tricky as they rapudly descend upon you once you arrive at the medina. They'll have badges around their necks and claim to be registered government approved guides.....whether that's true or not, finding someone with good English that can show you around the first time is well worth the time you'll waste trying to work it out yourself. These guides however are all "affiliated" with various shops in the Souk and will take you to several as part of the tour. You'll feel a bit railroaded but the best idea is to go with it and only buy if you want to. We found an elderly gent with extremely good English (says he was an interpreter on the set of Lawrence of Arabia back in 1962) and French. His name is Aziz and his number when calling from Marrakech is 0610778628. For 250drm for 4 hours is a good way to get your bearings for a subsequent "unassisted" visit. Haggling is essential in the Souks and no transaction occurs without it. Feel free to be as bold as you like. You'll be met with a smile and even a chuckle if you're being too tough but you'll never hurt their feelings so give it a shot!One of the very rare real life experiences left for less extreme travellers and I highly recommend visiting both during the day and in the evening when the night markets begin to come alive.

Amazing. This is a definite must do when visiting morocco! So glad we had the tour guide with us or we would have definitely got lost in the maze of small alleys that make up the massive souk. The square started off empty and quiet when we arrived at about 12 but by the end of the night it was packed full of people with monkeys and snakes n all sorts of stuff was amazing. If your a good haggler (unlike me) then you can get some great prices in the markets! We recommend to anyone visiting morocco!

a test for your patience. One must have seen the soukhs while in Marrakesh but be prepared for very hard selling. Looking is showing interest, fingerpointing is buying, just the price needs to be agreed on. No chance the tigers let you go before you emptied your pockets.

Brilliant experience, let yourself get lost. A brilliant experience, vibrant, colourful and exciting. Felt safe, but take all the advice about not picking up guides by accident as they can be very insistent. If at all nervous worth asking our hotel to arrange one

A tourist must. Keep your wits about you. Be prepared to haggle and don't worry about offering less than you think it is worth. Nothing worse than feeling proud that you paid £40 for a real leather hand bag to find the lady next to you paid £15. Go for it.
Great if you can handle it. If you can say no, and are happy to cut the first price by half, then you'll have plenty of fun shopping in Marrakech's souks

Bring Money & You Inner Haggle. The Marrakech souks are EVERYWHERE but beware if they won't come down on a price, the stall next to it or two down has the same thing! It's an amazing experienced but I learned a lot, they are AGGRESSIVE! So, what did I do, get right back :-) You can find things from your dreams there.

A Must!. The souks are probably the most famous part of Marrakech. A labrynth of twists and turns takes you along so many different shops from the most beautiful pottery and metal work, to fresh fruit and veg, meat, and all the spices you can think of. A treat for the senses.......apart from the butchers.You can get some real bargains.

Great Deals to be had!. This is the place to get great deals in Marrakesh. Remember, everyone expects to bargain with you and the first price is no where near what they will accept. The Souks are great for Morroccan ashtrays, kids pyjamas, souvenirs, lanterns and fakes of all kinds from Hermes to Nike. Enjoy it for what it is... a great place to pick up your souvenirs!!

Fun but be strong and say no!. One thing you need to know is that the sellers are more experienced in selling to tourists than you are in buying from them. So they are friendly and nice but very persistent! You will quickly get enticed into looking at things and if you are well brought up it's quite hard to say no. Don't ask the price of anything unless you are really interested as they take that a real interest and see a sale and it's even harder.My top tip is not to buy anything on the first day - I had decided that before I went but of course it was quite difficult to achieve, and I ended up spending money on things that I'm not sure what they are now! So if you want to get out of a situation then be very nice, very polite, put your hand on your heart and bow slightly and say perhaps you'll think about it and leave nicely and be persistent in a nice way and it will be fine.And don't get enticed to see the tanning area, it's not very nice and they will want money for showing you around. We did of course, despite having decided we didn't want to. Being brought up British does mean you don't like to be rude and it's hard in the face of persistence.But it is fun, even if you leave and realise some of the things they sold aren't really that good, but then some are. Enjoy yourself!

So much to see. I love the souks- we were in Marrakech for 5 days and went to the souks twice. You will not want to spend a huge amount of time here at once due to the crowds and the effort of negotiationg prices. If you are simply looking, you can handle a longer amount of time. You can get a fair price. Negotiate and do not get rude or angry. It's a game, stay calm :) We purchased come beautiful items that I was so happy to have- all at a price well below half the starting figure. WELL below :)We only had one incident with one of the younger men who threw the item I was looking (cheap 30 dhm sunglasses) at at me so that I caught it and refused to take it back and demanded money (something like 60 when the set price on the square is 30). I had been out for almost 6 hours in the heat at this point and I did not follow my own advice and got angry. Very angry! It was funny after, but not at the time. Stay calm :) My husband ended up taking care of the situation by giving the item to the seller with a bit of force- not physically, but the seller could tell he meant business. BUT my husband did not get angry...just me...got some good yelling out of my system over that. Silly, but it happens. You do not need a guide- we met people who did this, seemed silly. Just walk through and explore for yourself. We found simply amazing shops on our own. I found really interesting items at the scrap metal places- cool bolts for our doors and old keys, all cheap- very cool find.

Got to love the Souks'!. You can actually learn your way around that crazy maze they call the Souk's if you take some time, look around, remember landmarks. Although after 3 trips I still get lost. You can also have your hotel or Riad set up a guide for a morning session (which can be very interesting and informative but of course they will take you to the seller's they know for a commission). The Souk's are fun. The souk's are a space out of time. It's all quite adventurous. The seller's there will be able to pinpoint what country you come from before you open your mouth to say the first word. They are experts! Shop around. Spend a whole day looking before buying. The price drops if you come back the next day! And if you buy more from the same stand, or again from the same person. Fascinating place, with real artisans and craftsmen selling their wares in many of the stands. Smile and they will smile back. Don't feel bad to negotiate and walk away - there is always another tourist around the corner! Be aware that the quality is not always at a high level, unless you really know where to go. We spent a lot of time in the souks but bought quality traditional products in the Gueliz quarter - where the artisan markets and stores have "fixed" prices (you can still bargin!) to find real quality or actual "authentic" items.

Oh my!!!. Well that is one busy and hot place. I have been to Egypt and Turkey and I can honestly say that the Morrocan people are far less push than what I experience in other North African countries, thank goodness. In fact, even if you got lost, people there were willing to go out of there way to help with no expectation of receiving money. Snake charmers, monkeys etc I didn't enjoy as I feel they maybe suffering in the heat but that was my only gripe..

One day is more than enough.. Interesting souk that is walkable without a tour guide (unlike Fes' souk). Rows and rows of poor quality products to entice tourists to open up their wallets. Shopkeepers shouting possibly-discriminatory names, hoping for a rapport with you so that you will enter their shops. Open air eateries- only order food that you can distinguish its meat authenticity. We ordered lamb and beef kebabs, and served chicken instead.
Just look around. The souk in Fes is better but this one is also a place to look around and wonder. The central square Djemaa el Fna is one of the most beautiful squares in the world.
magical. most magical place. i love exploring and seing different cultures, perfect for me. Get lost in them (which you will anyway) and just find all the hidden jems

Bartering like a Berber!. We arrived on the 26th day of Ramadan so whilst to us it seemed a mad bustling busy series of passageways full of people and insane moped riders trying to make there way through the throng, we were advised that this is the quiet season and many 'helpful' locals would look at you as you headed down one of the alleyways saying "No No It is Closed" On our last evening it was the night before the end of Ramadan we went out later and There was a much bigger throng of crowds as the locals were getting ready to finish their month of fasting.

Talk about an assault on the senses!. The souk in Marrakech is a madhouse. The assault on the senses is a physical force to be reckoned with. The smells alternate between great and horrific. The colors and textures are wild. Be prepared to get lost. Be strong so you don't buy a bunch of junk you don't need. Know what you want before you go in. Be prepared to bargain, bargain and bargain some more. Nothing is priced. The prices stated, when you ask, change depending on how much money the seller thinks you have. Immediately state a price that is about 1/4 the price they start with. We tried to end up at half the initial price. Do not assume that anyone is telling you the truth about what they're selling. Don't follow anyone who offers to lead you anywhere. Don't pay anyone money to lead you anywhere. You have to have a bit of a tough skin in the souk. Don't get cajoled into buying things and don't fall for any scams. One day was particularly difficult. I was called names by a young man who wanted to lead us to his father's wool dying shop. When I politely but firmly refused, he let out a slew of nasty comments that I refuse to repeat here. Many had to do with the fact that I was American. That said, we bought some lovely leather babouches (traditional Moroccan leather slippers), a handmade Berber rug and a traditional lamp. I really think that the Souk in Marrakech is an experience everyone should have. Just go prepared (a kind of mental body armor is in order here).

be prepared to spend longer than you anticipated. Just wander off to your own desires, and don't restrict yourself to any timescale. Don't buy the first thing you see - there will be many more stalls selling the same. Haggle - haggle hard, but be friendly and make the haggling enjoyable, and don't rush the haggling - and you will get many bargains. The souk may look confusing and conjested, but it is relatively small, and if you get lost, it is easy to find your way out.Just don't buy too much, otherwise you may end up with excess baggage charges on your flight home!

Buyer beware! Latern seller didn't deliver pre-paid product!. A shop called Dukkali Freres in the medina, Mr. Mohssine Allali Atifi, took cash for two lanterns, to be shipped to the U.S. Later, he claimed that the right amount of funds were not paid, and had us wire additional money to him for the lanterns. He then stopped answering emails and the lanterns were never received. We have tried numerous times to contact him, but clearly he does not wish to be bothered.This is shameful behavior, but I have heard similar stories about items purchased in Marrakech by others. Unless the vendors monitor each other, this terrible behavior reflects poorly on all of them.
Crazy and brilliant. Watched wood, steel, glass leather all get transformed in to master pieces, remember to barter as you will get at least 50 % off!
Get ready to bargain. They will give you "democratic price" when you buy more than one. Suggest you decide ahead of time what you're willing to pay - they're quite the salesmen. Bring cash.

Negotiating is fun. I was in the Marrakech souks, on our tour with our tour operator Desert Dream4x4.I really wanted to try my skills in bargaining.In Germany, this is not possible, nobody does it in the shops - but in Marrakech, you can negotiate as much as you like, and it´s fun for both sides! I took extra money with me, just for this, and could get some very nice items for (as I suppose) good prices. It was fun, and I left every shop with a good feeling, and a handshake and smile for the shop-owner.They were all nice fellows, and happy about my enthusiastic way of bargaining.We not always found a solution, but that was okay for both. That´s what the souk is like.
Busy. Lots going on, watch your back the traffic is manic. The people lovely, most speak English and welcomed us to their city

Traditional Markets!. I loved the souks and the farther back you got the fewer tourists you saw. I always felt safe but there are some VERY aggressive shop keepers and "guides." Don't ask for directions unless you are willing to pay for the information.

Culture shock, but very interesting to see!. It was during Ramadan, so I think it was a little quieter than any other times of year. We saw a lot of people who looked very annoyed and bothered by the constant badgering you'll find in the souks but if you're polite to these people and firm with them you'll find that they're not bad guys! I really enjoyed walking around the souks, talking to stall owners and looking around at the items on sale. You do sort of find though that once you've seen about 10 shops, you've seen them all. Lots of football shirts, polo's, headphones, jewellery, pashminas and kaftans everywhere you turn! I found if you speak a little french and lean the arabic phrase "la choukran" if you are not interested, they usually just smile and leave you be. Lots of bargains to be had but you have to work for it, barter the price. Try the delicious orange juice in the square! Look both ways in the square, lots of scooters around and everybody drives a little crazy in Marrakech! I'd steer clear of the snake charmers and the monkey entertainers, they try to charge you to take pictures. I found a lot of children following me and begging for money as well which was a little distressing. We didnt see it at night but I have been told that night time in the main square and the souks is the best time to go, lots of food and performers! Be prepared to get lost, but enjoy it and look around! You might find people claiming that they're from your hotel and are taking you on a tour or that they work at your hotel and its their day off. These people are illegal tour guides, just after your money and will try and get you in their friends shops. Dont fall for it!
But I was lost in the markets for hours.. This is Hotel California: you can get in, but cannot leave. So lost. This is third world, so be ready for it. I would go back there in a minute!!

Fantastic! Don't forget to smile!. We had a great experience without any of the hassles that we had been warned to expect!We stayed near the medina, so visited it three separate days. Easy to get lost, but you find your way back eventually (note the signs to jemma el fna do lead you there, but they take you the long way).We took photos of many things, and were never once asked for money. We found the vendors to be vocal, but not more than many other parts of the world. No one was ever rude or aggressive. Meanwhile - we travelled as a couple, speak french, learnt some arabic, and I totally covered up. We also told the vendors that we were students and that seemed to help.On our 3rd day, we did buy some things - but by then we knew what prices to pay (often by overhearing other hagglers), and I often only paid 10% of the original asking price.

Haggle as if your life depended on it!. There is so much to do and see. Just mooch round and don't buy the first you see but good luck returning to the same stall, we walked miles and never saw the same stall twice. Nor eat fun and ambience!

Be Bold! Be Brave! Keep coming back!. This was not what we were used to (midwest USA). For a mother and her 18 year old daughter, My daughter turned into negotiator extrordinaire. She was determined not to be taken advantage of. The first day was about getting lost, making a few purchases and believing the person who told us our place was closed, but he could take us to a today only special market. The next day was about a bit of timid shopping and wondering if we were up to it. The 3rd and 4th day was about gaining our confidence and being determined to wheel and deal. Do your research, know what you want, and be bold. Bring a tote bag/purse for purchases, but we found it best to look like we had not bought anything. My daughter was delighted to have men call out to her as she left, "are you happy now?" or ask if she was trying to break the shop keeper's legs. For the most part, we followed the advice we were given offer 1/4 to 1/3 of the initial asking price work towards the middle. On occasion, though, my daughter told shopkeepers that the 1/3 was her "serious, last price."
Bargain,Bargain Bargain. Make sure you are well rested and hydrated before you enter into a bargaining session . It would take a while. It's a game that the seller enjoys so you should enjoy it too.

Trek Morocco Desert. Zagora ,Oulad Atmane countryside Morocco. Nourddine Ait Hommad and his Berber-Arabs Team Family took me on a tour to the Moroccan Desert and it was amazing. I found myself wishing the trip could have lasted longer. The tour was professionally conducted and my guide was very knowledgeable and informative about the culture and people. He welcomed me to meet his family and shared his aspirations with me. Nourddine was eager to show me a genuine Moroccan experience. I would highly recommend this tour to anyone visiting Marrakech, Morocco.

Same stuff everywhere, lots of hassle. Yeah it might be a big maze, but if you walk in for 1 minute you will see all the goods you will see if you walked for 30 minutes. It's just one big repetition of the same old tacky goods.And you can buy those stuff with less hassle anywhere else in Morocco.The hassle of the place makes it not worth the visit. It's not charming, it's not cute. It's just full of people trying to squeeze money out of you every step of the way. Like most of Marakesh it's really not worth the visit.

Quiet during Ramadan. Well worth a visit, the souks are full of everything you can think of. It was pleasantly quiet during Ramadan, I think it would be a whole lot busier at other times. Haggling is a way of life. Be cool and if the price stays too high, just walk away; there will be another one (whatever it is!) just round the corner! All vendors seem to accept Euros quite happily.
An experience!. Amazing to see the biggest Souk in Morocco - however, be aware that if you go on an organised trip, there is little opportunity to stop and go shopping as it really is like a maze!

Great bargains if you shop. Great bargaining with the vendors if you want the items you can go as low as 60% on leather purses my wife bought. It isn't a place to venture alone and they are VERY AGGRESSIVE here so be warned. I you look they will chase you even if they have the slightest thought you liked an item they had for sale. The snake charmers with the cobras and large boa's are worth the watch. If you take a picture they will hunt you down for money - literally so be ready to pay even if u snap 1 picture. Overall AN EXPERIENCE you should do/see if in the area but go with a guide.

Souk at Marrakech. It is so huge, you can find just about anything you want. Nearly every time time I go there, I get lost. There are some arrows to find your way back to Jemma el Fnal if you know what you are looking for. Again, it's best to be friendly with people and they won't hassle too much.

Everyone gets lost - so did we!. There is no map - don't even attempt to find your way, just go with it, then pay a small boy to take you to your destination. In fact, there are signs to the main square, but if you want to go anywhere else... Great fun.

Don't go alone! Awful experiences:(. It would have been SO much better had I not gotten followed and bothered so much. I understand they are trying to make a living however, it made me sad I couldn't enjoy the beautiful items for sale and the ambiance. When I said "no thanks, just looking" to the stand owners, they called me "angry" and said I "didn't like Marrakesh." The truth was quite the opposite! I very much liked it and wished I could have enjoyed it more. There was one guy in particular who followed me on several occasions, at different locations in the Souks trying to get money to show me around. When I said "no thanks," he began taunting me, said "why, are you racist? Do you hate Moroccans? You DO, you HATE Moroccans!" I tried to bite my tongue, but when I couldn't take it anymore, I responded saying "no, I'm not racist and I DO in fact like Morocco." This provoked him more to continue taunting me.DON'T go here alone if you are a female! In fact, don't go ANYwhere in Morocco alone if you are a female. Thank goodness for the Berber friends I made in the desert who accompanied me on several occasions so I wouldn't be hassled.

an experience not to be missed. amazing handicrafts, amazing market where new meets old, counterfeight goods from china side by side with the silversmith making jewellery how his great-great-great grandfather did. Noise, colour, smells, hustle and bustle - you simply CAN'T miss it. A polite no thank you will take care of any pushy salesmen - but be careful, you might miss out on the Moroccan hospitality and a chance to learn about the wonderful earthenware, traditional use for herbs, etc...
Dirty and smell. JESUS WHAT A PLACE!!!! You should never see this place in your entire life... photos are enough, believe me!

A fantastic experience. We just returned from a six day visit to Morocco. Only six and would have enjoyed one or two more days. The souk and medina in Marrakech was a real delight. Time warp? Yes. The people are very friendly and helpful and do not pester you as some might say. They are just trying to make a living. Never any offence taken if you walk away from them. I loved every minute of it, and the Riad we stayed in (Nashira) was the nicest hotel in our 10 city tour of Europe and Morocco.We did not get 'ripped off' so this might happen to some, but not everyone, and a lot of it has to be said about having an open mind and being positive about things.

Hassle all the way, but you have chosen to go there. It's hot in this kitchen, but if you decide to go, enjoy it. Be ready to barter hard, but there are things especially from Africa you will hardly find elsewhere in the country. The decision is very much in every visitor's hand: if you mind peddling,strong smells and evidence of poverty, then probably Marrakech and Morocco were a wrong choice in the first place. Otherwise, go for it and you will remember it.

You must go here. It was a great experience, the smells, the people, the food, the mint tea, the orange juice, the vibrant colours and irresistible souvenirs you can collect. I loved it and the people were so friendly and fun. Take care not to get lost though!

Busy Market, keep your guard up.. HiIf you are new to these sort of areas it can be quite unsettling but when you get used to it and build up a thick skin its fine.Start at a 1/4 of any price you are quoted and never go above half.If you cant get your price just walk away and go to the next stall which will have the same item.Watch out for fake or very low grade silver being sold as Morocco's finest!

Unmissable. An open mind, sense of humour and no deadline to get back are essential but this is an amazing experience - like going back to medieval times in places but with fake Nike's. The tanners, wood turners and metal working souks are the most authentic/medieval (though it's ALL authentic) and the closer you get to the square the more touristy it becomes. Still not just there for the tourists though, there are just more of them, more 'tat', and higher prices. Be brave, go further and further in. You'll escape eventually! You will be hassled, smile, take it as part of the experience and say No nicely (unless you want what they are offering, like a guide to get you out. Give him 50 Dirhams/£4). Do not go in a shop/stall unless you are serious about buying something, they will come out to entice you in and if you do enter you may as well empty your wallet then. Also beware the ladies who thrust a cheap bangle (or anything else) in your hand. Try giving it back - you can't and they will want a Euro/10 Dirhams for it (again, what's a quid for a bangle) and you will get tears and the story of their dying relatives. Go on, give her a quid! The many Fatimas who try to tattoo you are a different story..... You'll get endless offers of hashish, usually by young men offering you flyers for hammams as a cover, it is technically illegal. Don't be offended if you are anti drugs, it's their culture and their country, but if you do want some hash don't buy it from them. Wait 'till a stallholder asks if you want any because it will be under his counter, not up a dark alley with a couple of swarthy youths. And there's plenty of that on offer too! Don't panic, and a good rule of thumb to get back to the square is to go AGAINST the crowds, they are coming FROM the square. Enjoy!

It's personal. Some people will love the Souks. I didn't. I didn't like being hassled every step of the way and being ripped off. We took a guide and that was a big and very costly mistake. He took us to expensive shops and really only wanted us to spend money so he got a commission. I'm not a very good barterer and I'm now the not so proud owner of two rugs. Although we had read the advice we were not prepared for the skilfulness of the sellers and the persistence of the "guides". Next time I would be very firm about saying NO and less concerned about getting lost.

Everything we'd hoped it would be. A feast for the senses and some of the best fun we had in Marrakech, we loved our trip to the souks. We went early and found the sellers warm and ready to haggle with just the kind of humour you'd want. We found wonderful gifts for family and friends at good prices, once our ace negotiator had done his thing. We saw dyers and metalworkers producing their goods and found out a lot about how they work. The light, dappled through the roof coverings, was just like the photos we'd seen at the Maison de la Photographie. It was a brilliant experience and one we'd highly recommend if you can start early (by 10am).

Insane, fascinating, obnoxious, overwhelming, fantastic!. This wondrous place is caugh in a time warp (thankfully), straight from "The Man Who Knew Too Much" (well worth watching the Hitchcock one more time before you visit). It pays to be stubborn, knowing what you want and don't want, be aggressive or you will be run over (both figiratively and literally), and enjoy the art of bargaining. And before you're too impressed with some of the those snake charmers, double check to make sure their waving snakes are real and not motorized rubber fakes!

Great but never again!. We went on a guided tour of the souks which is a definite must, very easy to get lost! Overwhelmed by street artists, such as the monkeys in nappies and snake charmers! Also if you visit a pharmacy, DONT BUY ANYTHING. Its a complete rip off and our saffron turned our food pink not yellow! complete fake! But well worth the experience.
Crazy but fun if you like a haggle. Fab souk Northern side has better stuff go deep to find best stalls - vintage in Northern side too. Dont go to stalls nearest Jma as more expensive.

Bargain hard and don't be intimidated. You have to see the Souks when in Marrkech, it's almost impossible to avoid them. You get hassled to varying degrees by stall holders, the worst seemed to be the perfume shops and spice stalls. Very few of the stores have marked prices, so the price of the same item varies enormously. One of my friends saw some bowls she liked, 40MAD in one store with price tickets. She was later asked for 200MAD for the same item and eventually bought them for 20MAD each. Shop around until you find the best price and start your offer at a third (33%) of that and expect to pay about half (50%). Don't be intimidated, be prepared to say no and walk away (this often gets you the best price).If you don't want a leather footstool, pointy toed slippers, argan oil or saffron, don't ask the price, it will cost you at least 15 minutes of your holiday. There are no official guides in the Souks, just scammers after a tip, or directing you to a store that pays them commision and the commision will be included in the price you pay. Having said all that, the Souks can be fun. Some of the stall holders do have some good banter, you may find a real bargain and they offer an escape from the sun.P.S. If you don't know what saffron looks like, or smells like, don't buy it. Morocco is one of the worlds leading producers, but you can end up with the worlds most expensive turmeric, if you don't know what you are looking for. If the price is too good to be true, it's because it's too good to be true.

Truly incredible. The souks are truly amazing a real rabbit warren. Don't feel intimidated in the souks the locals are all very nice. If you do get pestered to visit there shop a firm NO Thank you does the trick and be prepared to barter.
mad mad mad. a must see what an experience. we got warned about the people there pestering you, but it fine and quite funny.you can not go to marrakech without seeing the souks.

Intense, chaotic, noisy, colourful and what you would expect. A must-do while you are in Marrakech is to enjoy the Medina and the Souks. So much to see when walking around and to enjo y the sheer insanity of it. If you don't enjoy crowded places with people everywhere then this is probably not your thing. Traders constantly speak to you willing you into their stores and try and engage you in the bartering activity. It's very enjoyable for the first few days but does understandably get tiresome if you're in Marrakech for more than a week.

be prepared. be prepared to be in awe and very hot! I recently went to Marrakech and visited the souk twice and enjoyed both times! the traders can be a little bit pushy but no more than you would expect! always ask how much they want for the item and start haggling from under half price! prices vary from stall to stall and often its exactly the same item so look around before making any purchase and do nit be afraid to walk away if you do not like the price! inside the souk there is a factory that makes and sells amazing argan oil and Moroccan oil with very good group discounts! also there is a section that is the leather factory where the actual slippers and sandals are made! ask a guide to take you there as there are some real bargains to be had! on our first visit we used an unofficial tour guide man called mohammed and we found him again the second time! we did tip him but this was purely our choice not a requirement!

Seek and you will find..... The souk is a maze of alleys and vendors all selling the same thing - bags, pots, jewellry, scarfs, sandals, spices - but that is exactly what you would expect. Yes, it is very easy to get lost, but look up and you will see signs back to the main square so just follow them and eventually you will get back to civilisation. You must barter - whatever the price is they quote, go in with your initial bid at just under half. And be prepared to walk away, even if they get agressive, sad or make you feel guilty! We bought some small pots, the ones 'on show' were Safi branded which is supposed to be a good quality ceramic. We pointed out the colours we wanted, the vendor got the pots for us and wrapped them up - when we opened the package at home, the pots were not branded so much poorer quality - but hey, we paid £3 for each, so what do you expect. But maybe just watch what they actually put in the bag! I found some of the vendors a bit agressive in their way that they tried to stop you to come into their shop, and you do have to be prepared for every vendor to try to entice you in, so it does get a bit tiring after a while saying constantly no thank you, but that is all part of the fun! Seek out the bargains - leather bags are definately at the top of the list, as are the scarfs. If you do find yourself wandering out of the souk into unfamiliar streets, be prepared if you are truly lost and someone helps you find your way back to pay a tip. Go there and enjoy the experience! It has to be done.

A Must Experience but perhaps alittle too much hassle!. We had a lovely few hours in the Souks with our guide (and im really glad we paid afew pound to have him with us) A real eye opener to see so many hand made Moroccan goods and in set in so many streets and so interesting to watch them making these goods but for us it was alittle too much hassle even though we did have our guide with us it is a must to go see.

The real moroccan experience. its full of unique thing that you'll never find in any other place like moroccan clothes,pants,dried fruits and moroccan tea.also there's alot of street shows that's really different from oter shows like people playng with snacks,cards and MONKEYS!!to see the whole souq there's alot of cafes above the apartments go and buy a juice and you can sit and watch everything.

Labyrinth. Loved shopping in the souks- would need two weeks just for shopping! Even if you're not a shopper its still definately a trip you have to make. Don't show that you're intersted in anything even if you are, keep it cool and casual and reserved that way you won't get harrased. If you like something, don't show it! Think of how much you want to pay before hand, then haggle away. Don't be afraid to walk away without buying even if you have spent a while haggling. Shop arround before hand to see what going rates are then go for it.

loudly and crowded.. souk is a great place to visit for a short period of time, otherwise you will have headache. everybody wants to sell you smth and at one point you will fill annoyed. put a deadline and stick to it and keep your smile with you.

Go to say that you have been... Then get away fast!. It is an experience but it becomes annoying very quickly! The vendors, the monkey handlers, the henna artist, the snake charmers are too pushy and overbearing! Just looking is not and option, they bug you to death! Beware of the guys who want to show you around! They are not being "nice" they will ask for money in the end!
Lovely week in Marrakech. This is where all shopping happens.Prepare yourself to bargain and bargain for everything. The 1st prices are always 4 to 5 more than you pay, so bargain!

Interesting at first...then repetitive.. Lots of sights and sounds, but we found the place a bit of a hassle during the day and sketchy at night unless you are in very touristy areas. After you've seen the following stores; local dress and shirt shops, shoe (slipper shops), bag shops, wood shop, lamp shops, pottery shops, metal work shops, spice shops, olive shops, rip off pharmacies selling watered down products, carpet shops, a few fake clothing/football shirt shops then I'd suggest getting a taxi back to your hotel and thinking if your trip to Marrakech was really worth all that money. Save some of the trip and visit Jardin Marjorelle.

Not to be missed shopping experience. Although the constant hassle can get you down, this is an experience not to be missed. Keep your wits about you and you will soon learn to be firm but friendly with the shopkeepers.

Cool place!. You can get lost in this place, it's a labyrinth of shops, they are endless one after another, colorful and fun to see and observe the shop owners sleeping left and right. Most are selling the same artesanal items. We didn't buy anything cause we weren't interested in things that are not practical in our world and we didn't want to haggle or to be hassled by shop owners, we just wanted to relax and let place take us to another time.. Wear your walking shoes, some places are quite dirty.

Cheap imitations. Be prepared to bater. Never pay the first or second price haggle. We liked the imitation goods. We weren't too keen on the beggars or the 'come into my shop' people. We didn't like the animal trainers. Overall.. visit the souk and hopefully enjoy a different culture at first hand.

Single and married women. It is much easier if you are married to travel in the souk as married women are not addressed and it could be a good ploy to carry a ring and walk the alleyways with a male fellow traveller.

More than a bizarr. The souk did not let us down being a (nicely) bewildering and colourful setting. Prices were subject to the traditional haggling but on the whole was always a friendly exchange. Got an antique tea pot! brill price - will remember the whole place with a lot of enjoyment

"An experience". Just 1/2 a day round the markets. My daughter and I felt very vulnerable. Maybe should have experienced it with Husband first. Still worth visiting, just be prepared to be pestered for your money!

Overcrowded market with speeding motorbikes. This whole place seems chaotic! The streets were always noisy, extremely crowded, and often dark and dirty. People got squeezed to the side when the walkways got blocked by various donkeys or carriages, not to mention I almost got run over by motorbikes sneaking from behind. One needs to go through haggling to get the right price, and many vendors might ended up arguing with you for bargaining. Not a great shopping experience.
I wish we were in 1926!. It's a shame that everything within the souk is now mass produced we looked for original items, we found them but no way could we ever afford our choices!

An interesting experience. We were in Morocco for a week staying close to the souks. My main advice is to do a lot of research before you go - especially in Ensemble Artisanal. We probably paid over the odds for a few things we bought, but it is a really interesting experience. Once you've spent money, it is interesting to talk to the shopkeepers. Bear in mind they'll want to take you to see their friends' shops. Don't buy Argan Oil, much cheaper in the supermarket and probably better quality/not fake! We found a Carrefour by Place de la Liberte that had cosmetic oil for 54 dirhams in a metal container (recommended). Also, don't be embarrassed about offering really low - it is a bit of a game really. The first price offered is ridiculous, then they often offer you a lower quality item to explain why the one offered is better. Stick to your guns and go up slow, there's no rush here. As others have mentioned, there were a lot of motor bikes and offers of guides. Just say no, unless you have a place you are desperate to go. I am female and didn't dress that sensibly, but didn't get hassled. My main piece of advice is don't go in after sunset - you'll stick out and WILL be hassled.

How to buy Saffron. Thinking of buying spices in the Souk? Yes, so were we! A few unidentifiable powders and herbs enticed us to pause in front of a shop. An elegant young man whisked us inside and into a back room lined with rows of jars. What followed was pure theatre - very enjoyable if viewed as entertainment. Spices, qualities, mixtures and uses were explained with no hard sell. The Moroccan Maestro read our body language and facial expressions like a 'pro'. He homed in. He weighed out a few modestly-priced spices before innocently enquiring if we needed any saffron, which we all know is more expensive than gold. He showed us his top-quality saffron, put a couple of strands in a glass of water, invited us to note the colour, smell and taste the aroma. It was certainly the real thing. He closed the door and lowered his voice. Just between him and us he could sell us some at a very special price. He confirmed that there are a lot of rouges cheating tourists by selling orange-coloured fibres for inflated prices, and even advised us to take great care. Wasn't it lucky that we had found his shop!Needless to say by this stage we were completely taken in by his charm and knowledge of the complex world of Moroccan spices. We bought two packs each for about £10. What can I say! Take my advice; if you enjoy theatre, then you'll love the show. But if you want genuine saffron, wait till you get home and buy it from a supermarket.

Great place to try your hand at haggling. This maze of narrow little backstreets are lined with shops that spill out onto the street and owners trying to get everyone that passes in to look around with such sayings as "Asda price" and "Cheap as chips" and as soon as you pick something up for a better look or even just lean closer to see something better they start the hard sell.Don't be intimidated into buying something you don't want and don't just pay the first price they ask for something you do. Most of the stuff is junk but sometimes you can see something nice for a souvenir. I saw a box of granite eggs and had a look through for a good one without flaws, straight away the shop owner was on me asking for 150 dirham, the rete of exchange at the hotel was about 12.50 to the £ at the time so he was asking £12.50. I put it down, laughed and walked away, he followed me for about 50 yards trying to get me to buy it dropping his price to 100 dirhams. I still said no so he asked me how much I would pay, I said 50 and he agreed. A huge difference and he would not of sold it if he was loosing money, so my advice is don't be afraid of dropping your offer to 25 or 33% of the asking price, you can always up your offer but if you go in with 75% of the asking price and the merchant agrees you can't drop down lower and once a price is agreed they see it as a contract and will get upset if you then back out of the purchase.

An experience. An experience that s better when it's done. The souks are a confusing maze, and if you are not confident with different cultures, best avoided. Offers of 'help' that you don't want every ten paces, mopeds driven by lunatics and an attitude to women that leaves much to be desired. Fun, but only after you get back to your hotel
Plenty of stuff. The souk in Marrakech is very busy with myriad narrow streets and alleys. Be careful of the large number of speeding motor bikes in the area.

Be sure of where you are heading & speak to/trust nobody. Although I was expecting it, it did take me somewhat by surprise. Everybody in the souks are after your money & will tell you anything just to get it. It's a shame, as it's a contrast to the friendly Moroccans just outside Marrakech. The minute you show any sign of being slightly lost, there will be somebody there to guide you to the tannery / which invariably is in a different direction to the guy you spoke to 2 minutes ago.The other tale you hear continuously is that the tourist attraction you are heading for is closed today. It seems to me that there is an unwritten rule by all the souks owners to keep the tourists in the souks by continuously lying to them & sending them round in circles.If you simply want to wander aimlessly & soak up the experience, then do so & enjoy it.However my advice is to have a clear idea of where you need to be, head for that point & ignore anything that a seemingly helpful local may inform you. If you need to ask somebody, look for a policeman (there are plenty of them all about centre). If you want to buy anything in the souks, there is a new store just opposite the Saadian Tombs. Everything in here is fixed price, you pick them up & take them to a till. No hassle !! They have everything so head here first, decide what you want & make note of the price. Then if you are desperate for the haggling, head for the souks & try to buy it cheaper if you so wish.

bartering skills needed. if you are not interested do not look at the shop otherwise it can be exhausting. i managed to barter a bag from £100 sterling to £40 so just keep haggling the price if you have the energy.... great fun.......keep an eye on your purse though as we were warned there were some pickpockets about, but we felt safe at all times as the people were so lovely

Not for women.. I was really looking forward to the Souks. However after being constantly commented to about my appearance (dressing modestly the whole time I was in the country) I found it very hard to enjoy the experience, relax and shop as I felt constantly watched. The mopeds/motorbikes/vans etc can be a bit of a pain, stick to the right hand side and you'll be fine. There are some ace bargains to be had but learn the art of haggling before trying your luck on more expensive items and if you feel comfortable, ask advice from your hotel/Riad about estimate prices! Be prepared to be asked to come into every shop you walk past and learn to be assertive, especially if you're a woman because the men are extremely intrusive with their language and their staring at you, even if you are with a man. An experience? Yes definitely, but not one I would feel comfortable repeating in a hurry!

A colour extravaganza!. A lovely, vibrant place. Lots of good natured banter. We have been to other countries and souks where there is an aggressive tendancy but not so here, it was such fun and so good natured, humerous, but not intimidating in any way. Expect to pay half of the price originally quoted for larger items, 55-60% for cheaper items. A joy of a souk!

Haggle hard and don't worry about getting lost. We throughly enjoyed hours wandering around the souk. There are plenty of signs saying Jamaa El Fina to help you find you're way out so don't worry about getting lost. You will find that everyday there is a special 'only today' auction for wool etc and lots of people wanting to show you to the tannery or this wool auction. If you want to see you'll find it eventually and i'd say no to this 'help' unless you want to pay for being led on a jaunt. The one time we did follow someone we really regretted it as they took as down some very quiet alleys and it was a bit scary. The key to shopping is to try to pay a third of the asking price and start low. Don't be afraid to walk away. You'll probably find the same thing a few stalls away and the shopkeeper will probably follow you with the thing you want if you slowly walk off. Enjoy the haggle and know that they won't sell at a price that they don't make a profit at. Please don't pay what they ask unless it is a fixed price place selling scarfs at 10/20 dirham. Have fun with it.

Not for female travellers!. We were really looking forward to visiting the Souks however, despite my 19yr old daughter dressing conservatively, she was constantly shouted at with males coming right up to her face. On one occasion, it felt as if a man was trying to come between us. He passed us several times (talking on his phone) and each time either bumped against one of us or tried to use the crowds to weave between us. We left immediately! On another occasion we started to look at some woodwork and were then immediately surrounded by men who would not let us leave and told me my daughter would be 'whipped'. The mopeds are a pain and you are constantly jumping out of their way!! We made the error of looking at a map (for about 2 seconds) and were surrounded by 'guides' i.e. men who then walked in front of us attempting to lead us in a particular direction. I travelled alone to Thailand and never experienced this kind of attitude, felt safe at all times and respected!
AAAAAARGH. too crowded and too many motorbikes driving through, I hadn't realised what a cultural difference there was until I went.

Great shopping. I loved the souks of Marrakech. I had read a lot of reviews and tips about them but we found it very easy and were never hassled by sales people or fake guides. In fact I read that you have to pay every time you take a photo or ask for directions but people were so friendly and accommodating we were never asked for money. And we got lost a lot! Shopping wise the closer you get to Jemma el Fna the higher the prices. The best prices we found were definitely around Place des Ferblantiers and in the alley leading from the roundabout in front of Place des Ferblantiers to Jemma el Fna.

Busy Place. If you are looking for a market with a difference, then visit this place. During the day its fresh fruits and the locals doing tricks with monkeys etc, however at night, after 9ish it becomes something else. Its packed of people selling anything and everything. Great place to get a true feeling of being in Marrakech. FYI,,, watch out for pick pockets!

Best shopping in Morocco!!!!. I felt like I was back in time as I walked through the souk in Marrekech. The streets are very narrow, colorful and full of treasures! Even though I was traveling with my children, we all felt very safe (thanks to the tourism police). The area however is pretty dirty and smelly (be prepared to see all kinds of crazy things)...

Good prices...but only if you bargain!!. Shopping in the Medina can turn out as a unique experience.On your first day just stroll around and check out the things you like and the prices...and then on your second day just put a great smile on your face a (I can live and without this ) attitude and start a bargain as if you are spending your last penny. Only by doing this you will leave with your hands full and have spent 60% less than the original price.

A treasure hunt. I loved the Souk in Marrakesh, it was very original and full of beautiful pottery, jewelry, spices, all you can imagine and more. It is important to know that you have to haggle for the price but the atmosphere is always friendly; I liked specially when the Ber Ber where in attendance.

take a clothes peg for your nose. We have just returned from Marrakech - it was a huge disappointment - the smells in the souks were nauseating, we thought we were going to be violently sick & everywhere, especially the main square in the Medina is filthy. Despite following the code of demure clothing & walking as far to the right as possible a cyclist drove into me on purpose, striking my hip with his handle bar; a fellow traveller narrowly escaped being charged at by a moped driver & another lady was indecently groped. We will not be making a return visit. Our hotel on the other hand was excellent - see our review for Club El Dorardor which is definitely worth a visit.

Fun. As long as you know here your purse or wallet are you can wander all day in the souk. You may get lost too but that is part of the fun. You can always show a friendly shopkeeper your map and he will tell you where you are and point the way out. He may also take you to his relatives?? around the corner to see something different. We were taken to the Dyers souk and bought two silk scarves. Haggle lots they really do enjoy it.

I'll Make You Democratic Price. The souks were a winding maze of tiny shops that were fascinating. Many of the shops sell the same items - you have to look really closely to find unique things. Beware, if you stop to look or ask the prices, you MUST bargain, it's part of the game. Get your game face on and go do it, it's a lot of fun, but be prepared to keep your word, that's necessary in this culture. Also be prepared to walk away if the price isn't right. more often than not, they will chase you down.Tourists, keep your money and valuables close to you - a money belt is best. The souks are very crowded and often you must get against the wall to let motorbikes pass. Do not allow young people to "help" you find anything - you are expected to tip them for this. If you need any help, ask a shopkeeper. Also watch for "faux guides", Moroccans who will lead you around the souks (to their favorite shopkeepers, who give them a kickback) and often will not let you loose until you pay what they demand. The police are on the lookout for these faux guides. My husband is a latino and was often mistaken for Moroccan - he was stopped by the police twice because they thought he was a faux guide!You can get AWESOME stuff at these souks for a very fair price. Don't be afraid to negotiate, it is expected.Also, beware of the henna artists. My daughter wanted a henna tattoo, and the artist just grabbed my arm and started on one for me and also did the same for my husband. We ended up having to pay her for 3 tattoos. Stay far away from them while they are working on someone else!Be sure to eat in the restaurant tents at night in the main square. It's a delight! The whole souk experiences was a sensory overload! It was very much fun and definitely 2 days was enough!

be prepared. As in all souks you have to be prepared to discuss the prices, pay attention to th small bikes and hand carts that constantly cross the narrow streets, we can find good articles at good prices specially if you can master their thecnique of negotiation.

Take Euros. The souk was really interesting and worth visiting a few times at different times of the day / evening / night. DO haggle - got a handbag that started at 600 DH and bought for 250DH! They like Euros in the market.

The essence of Marrakech. Wonderfully different place to home-makes you realise how lucky we are.Watch out for those helpful people looking to make money from tourists,especially when you look at a map!!Some expect alot from you.Tip ask a shop keeper if lost.

An absolute hole. My wife and two teenagers visited this stinking ,scruffy,robbing country.should have stayed a week but 1day was enough.if you like horrid food being stared at and asked if you would like 300camels for your daughter it's pretty grim .to quote my son it's like black hawk downs mogadishue.

Great to Stroll Through. Not a whole lot of diversity... Have to look hard for unique things if you want to avoid kitsch. The merchants will try and get your attention, although they are pretty good about leaving you alone if you don't make eye contact, linger or express interest. Depending on how much of a tourist they rate you or how rich, we only paid 30-50% of the merchant's initial offers. We didn't get any steals, but decent prices that we were happy to pay. Walking away works pretty well to get concessions and don't seem that interested. Happy souvenir hunting!
Lookie lookie!. The souks are typical of other souks I have visited i.e. constant hassle. You can't just browse without being dragged inside. I would buy more if I could just look first.

The Souks. The souks are the small shops of the centuries old neighborhoods off the main square, Jemaa el Fna, and form a fascinatingly colorful maze throughout much of the old city, the Medina. Although one can easily tire of the shopkeepers' aggressive salesmanship and endless price reductions for unwanted goods, a visit to Marrakech really requires this very rich experience.

An absolutely horrendous experience. Only visit if you have a very high tolerance for leeches as that is exactly what a souk is like. They will chase you around the square and harass you until you buy or dine with them otherwise they will swear and curse at you until you are no longer visible. There are millions of thieves even young children who will skilfully rob you blind all over the city but particularly more in a souk due to the lay out and small confined spaces. If you really want to visit the souks use a tour guide or local if you know one as this makes it easier.The city in general is very racist and the airport is no exception. you will be man handled and if you are generally not fair skinned you will be harassed and asked multiple questions about your own and parents places of birth even though they have your British passport in their hand! You also cannot use dirhams in the duty free and cannot take more than 1000dh passed security. On a lighter note there is no liquid monitoring so you can leave without worrying about a clear bag or 100ml.The sight seeing bus tour is a very good and cheap way to get around as the taxis smell tourist and triple the price so always agree a fare before getting in. Bus drivers are very friendly and will help you as much as they can even stopping away from a stop to take you closer to your destination - they are a real credit to the city and the buses are very regular about every 15 mins.Always try to buy from a supermarket or somewhere that has prices displayed as they will hike up prices and short change you. Always also check your change as there is alot of ripping tourists off.The only place that I have anything good to say about is my hotel and the staff who went above and beyond to help when I had my bag stolen in a souk. they drove me to a police station, translated and ensured I was watered and helped me cancel my cards and that I felt safe etc. The hotel suite Novotel is a real gem and the staff have the kindest hearts. The manager is a lovely man as is the hotel driver who helped me beyond words can describe.

Amazing. Such a vision. So many colours and sounds! Felt so safe walking around. Haggle atleast 60% off everything and walk away if they are being stubborn, they will come after you if they want a sale!!Try and go to one of the roof top cafes, especially at night. Its so beautiful!

Worth a visit but once is enough. We visited the Souks on a Saturday morning so it was very busy. We were harassed from the moment we arrived to the moment we left. Sometimes the sellers were aggressive and pushy.No matter what any of the sellers say NOTHING is for free! A gentleman shoved a pastry in my hand, said it was free, forced me to try it and then asked for 50DH we gave 60 because we had no change and then tried walking away without giving us change! In hindsight I should have refused the pastry and then at the least bartered the price but never mind!If you want to go in the Souks you really need a guide. We got lost and had to pay to get directions!Once we had got back to the main square we did have a good time and bought some interesting souvineres! I would definitely recommend going but 3 hours is enough to see everything.

busy...understatement. what an amazing experience in the souqs. Busy, vibrant, noisy, spice smells...an experience not to be missed. Prices...who knows ! The stallholders are a bit overpowering after a few hours of haggling - better to do it in small doses. Our 2nd & 3rd days we popped into the souq from our hotel (Maison MK) for an hour at a time & it was so much better.

Full of rubbish. Not impressed having visited the Souks of Marrakech. Just full of all the same general rubbish aimed at tourists. Scarves, tagines and copy Rolex and Omega watches. The only thing we found to be worth buying was the leather goods. This however was a long process and got heated and sometimes offensive at times! Extremely busy, aggressive and the most unrelaxing holiday place ever!

Different from the souk of Fes. The streets/alleys are wider and there are less hustling from the merchants.What We liked:I saw a lot of actual working in the souk - wooden chairs made, leather bags sewed, belts decorated, brass plates and vessels shined, knife sheath decorated with filigree work, lanterns built and plaster tile carved. I also walked into a market where people are buying ans selling sheep/ goat skins - a most interesting experience.What we didn't like;While the merchants definitely are more relaxed, there are still a lot of hustling going on. We are prepared for this. What we didn't like is that too many of them came too close physically that is decidedly un-nerving. Also, the young men shouted Japanese phrases after us (we being Asian), even after we reveal our ethnicity. We hope that they learn this is not a wise way to attract customers.

everyone must visit this place!. Excellent place to use your haggle skills to get a discount on the product (its actually worth) salesman will charge probley 10 times the actual value and suprisingly people do pay knocking off 20 dirhams thinking they got a bargain but i walked out with a fraction of the price.if a item is 200 dirhams drop it to 70 and dont go above 90. do the fake walk out of the store several times and it works, sometimes they let you go and actually call you back or follow you and bring you back. it happened to me.

Barter for all you are worth!. Exactly how you would imagine it. A huge open square, a confusing maze of narrow alleys lined with traders winding on for ever, bordered by cafes to sit & watch, rooftop terraces to get the best views of the sunset & have mint tea. Brush up on your French & sadly be prepared for calls like “lovely jubly”, ”cheap as chips”, “better than M&S”….. we Brits have a lot to answer for in spoiling such destinations! Beware of offers of help as they may result in a demand for a fee of 100 MAD; although that is only £10 they may have led you a merry dance to get to somewhere that was only a minute from where you were stood. We got caught but having loudly refused we were immediately left alone; shame they lived up to the bad rep.HAVE THE FRESHLY SQUEEZED ORANGE JUICE! Every stall sells it at the same price 40p/4 MAD, pick one and make it your regular and you will get a lovely welcome and possibly a free drink. You can buy water in the small shops to the right of the square for £1 a litre.If you get there around 5pm you will witness the transformation from empty space to packed, covered street food market, traders with their wares spread out on a mat, henna or fortune tellers sitting on low stools and the ubiquitous snake charmers appear. As dusk falls the hub bub of buskers/social music gatherings, applause for the acrobats & the general hum of diners talking fills the air.Do not be afraid to eat at the street food stalls; personally I would rather see what is being done to my food than go to a café/restaurant where the kitchen could be doing goodness knows what. Also, everything is either blistering hot in a tagine £4.50/45 MAD that continues to bubble when brought to the table, or barbecued on a raging grill; we nor anyone we spoke to had any upset tummies and it is so worth the experience. We tried everything too; even the “soup” & dates deal for £0.50/5 MAD the locals seem to always opt for; sort of vegetable with chick peas. There was also a huge crowd at the stalls with boiled egg rolls!?!?Barter the price for your henna & have the black one as the brown does not last. I got one up my ankle for 50 MAD. Beware the ladies “gifting” you a flower on your hand as you walk by; they will demand a payment & keep complimenting you & hennaring until you remove your hand.Take the horse & carriage for 150 MAD £15 for a “tour” of the Old & new town. Most of the drivers do not speak any English so you will only get to converse if you know any French/Arabic.If you are near the SOUK KAFE the 100 MAD/£10 set menu is worth it on a lovely rooftop terrace. It is within sight of the square but you can easily get lost in the alleyways – we got a taxi there & back for £10 which was over the odds but worth the safety.Sadly, there is a McDonalds (new town, milk shake £1.50/15 MAD) and a KFC; reluctantly, although we did not eat there, the latter which is by the entrance to the Medina, had a great 3 pces chicken meal deal £3.50/35 MAD compared to the ¼ fried chicken & chips £4.50/45 MAD we ate in the street market!This is a dry country; they do not drink alcohol, so you will only get coffee, tea & soft drinks in any public areas. Alcohol is served inside some establishments & at Hotels. This even includes open terraces of cafes/restaurants so you have to sit at an inside table!

Be carefull..... If you want to buy something, vendors asks for 2-3 times higher price than regular. Be ready to negotiate. However, if you offer 2-3 times lower price than regular, that they will get very upset and unfriendly !!!

Hustle with little hassle. The souks are many and seem endless winding down many narrow streets and alleys. Not so little however that you won't get multiple bikes, mopeds and donkey carts passing you within inches without any notion of slowing down. That seems to be the way things work here and to their credit we didn't see a single incident even though it looked inevitable. However keep to the right, and keep an eye out for traffic!In terms of shopping we were pleasantly surprised not to be hassled too much less so than in the main square. Generally a polite 'no' will be accepted. Look for nearby cafés with roof terraces to get some good views of the souks below as well as a nice cool breeze to escape from the heat.

Amazing. it is chaos but very interesting even if you are just spectating and not shopping you will love the sights and smells. The spice market area just smell lovely!! The markets are split up into areas ie leather, soap, meat, etc so get a map and get familar with the layout before you attempt to walk round. You will definitely get lost but try to avoid looking lost or getting map out as someone will want to give you directions and potentially take you to a leather tannery. A taxi is your best bet or go to a cafe and grab your bearings. Good luck!

Explosion of the senses. We arrived late in the afternoon to our beautiful riadand decided to venture into the Medina on our first night!. Yes we got lost but that was half the fun. We loved the colours of the fabrics, the smells of the spices, the cacophony of voices, music, languages & animal noises & the madness of the whole place. We left shopping there untilthe next dayto get our bearings&some idea of prices. Just loved the freneticpace. Don't miss it & take your video.

A fascinating slice of life. Only go in the morning when it's cooler. Be prepared to be VERY firm as the stall holders will hassle you non stop. Best to completely ignore them unless you are interested in something. Bargain hard but smile. (about 50% usually). Do not agree to go with anyone -they will ask where you're going and offer to take you but it will always end up in a commission for them and you getting something you didn't want! You will get lost. Our riad gave us a phone to ring them for help!

bidding wars. You have to see it to believe it. It seems like chaos and watch out for the moped riders, although they never seem to hit anyone.You could probably buy anything there and spend hours trying to find your way out.Always bargain and even walk away. If you like snakes no better place to have one be wrapped around you .Enjoy

maze of hastle and barriers to viewing.. The souks are have hundreds of stalls, all of which are interesting. However, the place is like a maze, and it can almost be guaranteed you will get lost. Additionally window shopping will mean you get grabbed or pulled into shops with people trying to sell stuff. Which is understandable, but makes for a very stressful combination when also lost. Additionally while lost, we got told we were going in the wrong direction by a local who offered to take us back to the square. Long story short he was one of the many conmen in the souks who lead tourists around the souks, purposely confusing them, only to so they can go no further and demand money. Luckily the police grabbed our guy, and helped us back to the square.....but yea....stressful.
a maze. amazing maze of shops. keep your purse at the hotel! you will spend too much and get ripped off! fab tho!
Negotiate, negotiate, negotiate. You can find very nice and good things there but you have to negotiate here for everything….if you can! Nice and tiring experience.

What a great experience!. This was one of the highlights of my visit to Morocco. I was part of a tour but I went back in the later part of the afternoon with four other women. At no time did we feel threatened. It was awesome! Felt like we were in a movie set! Yes, it was noisy but that was part of the charm.Yes, everyone wants money for photos but you don't have to take the photo. That is their lively hood. Helen made a good point about unofficial tour guides and beggars.Bathrooms are sketchy and hard to find. I would go back in a heartbeat!

Bargain, bargain, bargain!. We have mixed feeling abou the souk. It's definitely worth visiting but ladies, you may want to wear something less revealing because everywhere we turn, we get a lot of attention. But we think it's not harmful but still made us uncomfortable.Also, we thought we did a great job with bargaining but later found the same merchandise still selling for less than what we paid for!!But it was fun.

Remember to bharta!. Loved the experience but do not let them bully you. Advise them u fetch police if they become harassing, and tell ladies with the henna u r allergic as they will try to squirt you if you do not buy. If you are caught taking photos of the snake charming or traditional dress they will want to charge also. Do not give to begging children or unofficial tour guides.
Great place to see. The souk is really great to see. Don't talk to every merchant, just go there and walk and walk and walk. Don't panic, you will find the exit. I love it.

abnoxious. It I were to go again, I'd put in ear plugs. That way you wouldn't have to listen to the aggressive people trying to swindle you every 2 feet. Everyone wants to show you something, and then demands money. I found it best to say "I have no money for you". They seem to get the point very quick.

No hassle. You'd obviously get asked to buy things but no chasing if you said no. People are so friendly :D
So much to see if you can find your way around, recommend a guided tour.

Rock the Kasbah shop - fair fixed prices, fluent English, no pressure. Check out Julia's shop, Rock the Kasbah. She is a Brit living in Marrakech and has a lovely shop. Unlike the exhausting high pressure tactics employed by the other shop owners Julia is low key. She has fixed prices and nice things to buy. Go to Café Arabe, put it on your right and walk straight. She is right down the path towards the Tomb Sidi Abd el Aziz, located on the left hand side. If you encounter several bollards in the road you have gone too far.
Exciting stuff. Lots of stuff in the market . You have to use your bargains skills . Lot of choice of morrocan shoes, morrocan dresses,spices ,carpets lot of other colourful stuff .

The begging is draining!!!. What can I say you are robbed cheated begged and all in the sweltering heat. However it's got lots of nice little souvenirs and lots of keepsakes at a good price once u haggle it down. Be warned... Offer at least a 1/3 o what they ask for, if they say no walk away! They'll gladly accept what u offer once they see your serious!!! Would recommend a quick visit for something to do.

Attacks all the senses...a must visit. Although you can visit all day, this place comes alive at night.The hustle of all mankind is found in the Souk and if you wish to buy, the game is HAGGLING.Never pay the asking price as you will usually be able to barter for a much lower price agreed by both you and the owner. BUT decide what you wish to,buy before you enter the Souk or you may find you also have several camels, toy ones that is, in your luggage on the way home.There are several food vendors in the Souk but hygiene is not of European standard so best to visit one of the many restaurants. Just go with your feeling when choosing.

Enjoy wandering in beauty. We probably only saw a fraction of the Souks as they can become a little frustrating after a time - the constant traffic of people, donkeys, motor bikes and even cars squeezing through the narrow streets does not allow you time to have a relaxed stroll amongst the stalls. Stop too long, and you will be asked to come in and look... and buy. Its fun for a while as there is so much to see - just remember to only ask the price if you are interested in buying and then haggle, haggle, haggle.
Experience!. All I can really say about the souks is be prepared to haggle for everything, and stick to your instincts. Thoroughly enjoyed the experience of the souks!

Be prepared to be hassled. Be prepared to be hassled by most of the shop owners. There are over 1600 shops so its worth hiring a Guide to show you around. Our Guide was able to walk us through the main areas that we wanted to visit. Overall, it was enjoyable to haggle down prices although we did get ripped of because of being Tourists. I think Tourists pay 2-10 times more than the Locals.

Vibrant, amazing!. The colours, sights, smells are amazing. It is very busy and although motorcycles are not allowed in there - they will almost run you down regularly. The people from the stalls will ask you to go into theirs and look, but they are not overly pushy. Decide what you would be happy to pay and don't go over that - everything is over priced and they will expect you to haggle.

An incredible place. Wow, What a place. So much to see and do and lots of battering opportunities. A real delight! Such choice of things to by and see. Also many things are very reasonably priced so you don't really need to batter much.

Cheeky souks. Good fun at the souks! Be careful that you don't get ripped off but all the negotiating is fun and you can get some lovely items if you look in the right places and try a little of their language.
Lots to look at !!. If you get to the right place and don't get lost there is a lot of odds and sods to browse through, be stringent with your bargaining .
the Souks. loads of shopping and haggling was great , the people were fun and we didn't feel at all threatened at any time .

Visit but buy elsewhere. Unless you love to haggle and get pressured check out the souks but buy from the artisan store on Mohammed V with its fixed prices. Watch out for the many motos loose in the narrow lanes.

Three and a Half. The Marrakech souk is full of sounds and colour. Sellers call out from their shops, and haggling is a way of life. There are great assortments of goods, from the everyday to the touristy. The merchants are skillful in their trade, and the "guides" will lead you wherever you are willing to follow. So all in all, a great cultural experience. That said it is on par with the souk in the old city in Jerusalem, so perhaps average in the souk stakes. But, as far as markets go in general - very good. Therefore my title 3 1/2.Be warned check your prices at fixed price establishments before venturing in, unless you are in for the adventure rather than the "bargains".
Interesting. We enjoyed but are not put off by the vendors pushing their wares. Worth a visit - careful not to get lost!

The Souks are amazing.. Hassle free and amazing. The colours are mindblowing. We travelled with only hand luggage but could have spent a fortune on presents if we had room in our cases.Buy macaroons off the man selling them from a try round his neck - 1 dirham each - fabulous, leather bags/satchels are cheap and come in all shapes and sizes, they just smell a bit but wouldn't let that put you off, they are a bargain. There is so much to see and buy and always go in at 50% of what the price is and go from there. Its worth finding out more about the souks before you go because they are all so different selling all types of things.

Frightening situation. Sadly what had been a nice four days was distressingly ruined. We now realise that we had been watched in the souk & followed back to our riad. When leaving the riad that same evening I was mugged just yards from our riad. The thief ran up to me and yanked my gold chain from my neck. Although I ran after him shouting & the locals also chased him it was a horrible frightening experience. The thief was caught and my necklace eventually returned but we spent our last night in the police station. Basically although the guides state it is safe be very very aware of being followed back and then targeted. Two ladies in our riad were also followed on a separate occasion. Sadly our trip was ruined by we now realise more than individual. However the staff at our riad were helpful, efficient and very kind.

Differences. Check the hub by day and then by night.Two totally different atmospheres.Very safe.Eat at the square.Bargain!!With the staff.Salad fish and drin:130Dms.for two.Go early.Gets crowded after 8 at night
