What fun. Walk in and then get lost in the little streets and shops. What a delight. Shopping and bargaining to be done and food to be tried. Wander for hours during the day and then come back in the evening for a totally different experience in the restaurants and cafes.

Wonderful for browsing and shopping. We were a bit put off by the guide books with their warnings of being hassled, pickpockets, fake guides etc but once there we loved it all. Far less hassling than in some places we've visited and we felt totally safe. We bought a few things and thoroughly enjoyed the experience.

Visit the Souk - a Marrakech must!. If you visit Marrakech, you MUST visit the Souk. Stall after stall of hand crafted Morrocan wares (but beware of the imported tat). Some you can see being made before your eyes. Haggle hard, we were advised not to pay any more than 1/3 of the price the merchants asked. Sometimes it worked, sometimes it didn't. Don't get ripped off. Be prepared to walk away.

Come For The Atmosphere Not The Merchandise. This is a great place to wander the alleys and see all kinds of souvenirs to bring home. It is a place to haggle and have fun. Don't expect to find great fashion finds here. The clothes are more the equivalent to Walmart. Most of the "antiques' and "local' made products are not that at all but it is cute to buy. It is fun to see and slowly try to find your way back to your riad or hotel.Remember, they don't sell it to you if they don't make a profit. During the early afternoon the shops will close and then reopen in the evening time. You will find small cafes through your journey for a bite to eat.

Unique shopping experience: forget the mall!. Sometimes it feels that the all downtown is a giant souk, as there are dozens of them all intertwined and linked. We had the best fun and ended up buying tons of things from black soaps to carpets. If you like the Arabian mood you'll find most of the crafts really lovely. Beside the more "touristy" shops you will find mazing art galleries and antique shops all worth a visit. We took a small risk (after all it was our first time in a new town) and just went wit the flow: if somebody asked us to visit a shop we just followed him, even in the back alleys! And we ended up in corners that we'd never find with a proper tour or just staying on the main alley. We saw abandoned backyards, incredible spices shops, stinky meat stalls, colorful fruit, had dozen of mint tea cups in tiny shops (don't ask yourself if the glasses are clean...better not to know!) and smoked pipe with a nice guy who just wanted to chat. In a word: just get lost and enjoy! If you manage, find the olives souk and stock up: they are the best ever! Watch out for silver: we bough some real and very nice pieces but one bracelet was not silver at all :-(Bargain for everything (it's true you should offer one third of the first price) and don't think you can outsmart them:: they will always get the best deal, but that's how it should be!

Tannery, watch out!. We had a 'sticky' encounter and just wanted others to be aware. We were guided to the tannery ( all pleasantly done , though clearly a ploy we went along with it) we were shown round the tannery and then to a shop, once again we knew what we were getting into. When we came out of the shop and offered to pay the tannery 'guide' he insisted it should be 20dhms this was not what we felt to be appropriate. We were challenged by the guide and his mate with better English but we stood firm and stayed pleasant while stating there was no obligation to pay the amount the guide wanted. This was accepted but it was not the side of Morocco we had encountered previously.
keep smiling and politely insist-'la shugan'. smells, colour, ancient delights, amazing craftsmanship ,busy, nasty motorbike fumes and noise, but hey, its Marrekesh.
No hassles. No pressures to buy.... most stall owners quite happy just to talk. Australians especially welcomed...'so far away!'

Good time. The colors, the sounds, the smells, the variety....all wonderful. The only downside was all the motorbikes. It is all a bit of game. Buying something and thinking you made a good deal lasts only as long as it is until you see the same thing somewhere else and find you can get it there for half as much! It is nice to have most things in their own areas - easier comparing etc.

life pure. marrakech without visiting the souks is luke never been in marrakech. it is a MUST. take time, look for the traditional part with original handyworkers and not to the part just selling goods from china...

Fantastic Experience. Loved the Souks. We got lost on several occasions, but that was part of the charm of the place. Amazing to see all the different craftsmen at work. It is actually more fun when you get a bit off the beaten track and get into the local areas (such as the food markets) where there are not so many tourists.Watch out for the mopeds and donkeys - the traffic just seems insane to anyone from the west.

Amazing Experience. I never thought I'd be in a place like this...it is magical! The stores and their colorful wares are eye candy. It was not as intimidating as I thought it would be. Bargaining was actually fun! Remember, always counter offer with 1/3 of their asking price and you can't go wrong. If they refuse...walk away! You will always find more treasure in other stores!

Out of this world!. The souks are amazing - so much to see. It is worth having a guide (e.g. from Travel Link (tel +212 (0) 524424880) to take you round initially. This both helps to get orientated and also to go deep into the souks to see some of the inner workshops. Great fun haggling and the stall holders are all very friendly (they all offer the best prices too!). Just go with the flow and enjoy
Don't be afraid to just wander!. Don't miss this! It may seem like an effort to immerse yourself in these back alleys, but it is really worth a stop to see all the handicrafts.

You HAVE to visit them!. You have to experience the Marrakech souks: words do not do them justice. Be prepared to be constantly called into whatever shop you dare let your eyes make contact with, watch cars and donkey-carts fight for space, haggle over prices, visit "little" stalls packed with thousands of items, and just be over-whelmed by the experience. For best value, ask about "real" prices at the hotel or riad before you go: we seemed to get eveythring for between 10% (pottery) and 40% (art) of initial asking price. And be prepared to walk if you don't get your oprice: there IS another stall that sells exactly the same thing, probably just around the corner from where you are now.Be prepared for a hectic, noisy experience and don't let people force you to let them guide you somewhere ... they will want to be paid. Same thing if you think you are going to walk through and just take pictures: these are people trying to earn a living and if posing for pictures is what you want, you will be expected to pay for it. I don't say this as a bad thing -- it is how they pay their bills -- but be prepared for it and it won't seem so shocking,Be prepared to get lost. Ask a shopkeeper for directions. if someone offer to take you there, remember they are not doing it for free.Stop for a drink or a snack. Aside from staying hydrated, it is a good chance to enjoy the atmosphere. Finally, relax and have fun. it is a great experience, nit to be missed.

A lively experience. Marrakech is a surprisingly exciting and fun city; the souks are vast, colorful and full of amazing items to purchase especially if you want to bag a bargain.It's a growing city that is quickly becoming aware of its attraction to tourists and accommodates accordingly. Although French is widely spoken half the fun is trying to communicate with the locals, who very much enjoy the happy humour of us Brits.I would not hesitate to return; had a fab time as girls on tour!

Much Better than Expected.. There are so many different shops selling so many different things! Unlike the reviews, we were not hassled to buy anything and when we were a touch to the right shoulder (your own) with a light bow and a smile sent even the beggars away!

If you haven't seen a Souk, you must go. It would be far more interesting if the shop owners did not hassle so persistently and if you could stop to look at a map without being pestered by people not wanting to help but wanting to guide for money or directing you to their kin's shops or restaurants. The hard sell really spoilt the whole experience and stopped me buying things that i would otherwise have purchased
Will never go back. Too aggressive people for us ,coming from Thailand we did not get used to this .The smell,the crazy people on motorbike,the fake guide who follow you every where,very scary for us
markets. did not like the way snakes,monkeys were treated but worth a visit for the experience. Best to sit on rooftop café to take videos pictures as you get hassle if below on ground.

Hours can be whiled away here. Barter for a bargain, take in the culture of the locals, get lost and cool down in the shaded nooks of the souk. Each corner and turn has a surprise on offer, whether it be a roof terrace cafe, you werent expecting to refresh or a morrocan working away on bespoke carpets, wood work etc.

Super Souk!. Fabulous experience, not to be missed. Beware of the mopeds and bicycles which drive through at breakneck speed! Spices, shoes, rugs, household items, jewellery, candles etc. are all great buys. Ask permission before photographing people.

jamma el fna. MARRAKECH - Jamma el fna (Main Square)Visited 5 times dsuring the day and at evening times, whilst on a two week stay in Marrakech in May 2013.Firstly let me dispel some of the nonsense we heard about hassle in this place. Whether you are walking the main square or scouring the souks, day or night, a simple no thank you, to any vendor / performer, need be said only once in order to be left alone. You are NOT harrassed at all.. The only nuisance / danger seems to come from the small moped / motor bikes being ridden in and around the square including the narrow alleys of the souks, but they seem skilled in the art of avoiding you (just).At 10 am the main square is fairly quiet / just coming alive, so you can amble around in comfort and at leisure with uninterrupted views.There are a very few snake charmers and guys with monkeys on a chains etc around, but again no hassle.Basically if you show no interest in them then they show no interest in you, and frankly if it were not for moronic tourists showing an interest, then the guys would have no reason to be there. So perhaps ask yourself do you really want to look and thereby encourage such barbaric displays? (And I am most definitely not an animal’s rights supporter / fanatic). The souks are a typical Arabic / African experience, (but genuinely, the least hassle we have ever experienced anywhere on our travels around this continent and elsewhere). Once you enter the labyrinth of shops / stalls that is the souks, then it is very easy to get disorientated / lost, but there is nothing scary in this.There are some rudimentary (mainly overhead) signs that will help you get back to the main square or a particular named bab ( gate ) of the Medina and from there you can easily get a cab or walk back to your pick up point / hotel.From around 5pm onwards the square transforms into even more of a jamboree atmosphere and an outdoor food fest as portrayed by Jamie Oliver in one of his TV food programmes starts setting up and the square really begins to fill and to buzz.Do try the freshly squeezed orange juice at one of the many stalls day or night (clean and very tasty /refreshing (4 MAD) Do also try the snails at 5 MAD (0.35p) for a small bowl.(Different to escargot in garlic butter, but quite tasty).Apart from taking coffee at cafes around the sides of the square to watch the world go by, we had an ok snack / meal in a cafe in one of the side streets.We also ate a meal at stall 118. The food was ok and very cheap and we had no ill effects.We got a bit of hassle as he tried to rack up the bill at the end of our meal, but I stuck to my guns and only paid the original price, so be warned.In spite of the images portrayed by Jamie Oliver, I would seriously doubt the authenticity of about 98% of the food stalls.The more we went back, the more we realised thata) there are not as many food stalls as we expected, and they do not 'fill the entire square'.b) The food stalls looked and were very much all of the same and quite reminiscent of vendors you might find in any UK seaside town, with menus and prices with pictures.My wife had a skewer / kebab meal and I had a beef tagine and both were prepared from scratch within 45 minutes of the stall having been wheeled out into position and included time lighting of the charcoal ( so how the hell it was a genuine slow cooked tagline is beyond me ?)We also tasted a bit of sheep’s tongue, provided to us by another diner who lives in UK, but is of Moroccan origin and was having his once a year treat of a full sheep’s head.Whilst eating our meals at the stall I saw commercially labelled catering size pre prepared sauce mixtures being transferred from plastic containers into metal pots. There were even plenty of baskets of Eenglish chips being fried in square deep fat fryer baskets. So once again, Morroccon authenticity ? Margate or Marrakech ? decide for yourself, An enjoyable experience for us nonetheless, but, sorry Jamie, about as genuine as a nine bob note I’m afraid.Verdict? Definitely worth a visit in order to tick the box, but in reality, a bit overrated in terms of size, vibrancy and authentic cuisine. No need to return thank you.
night time souks. was a good experience to see moroccan culture and there was alot of people having a good time until the early hours of the morning

Don't panic!. Amazing, hassle, friendly, must see but be prepared...- don't take a "guide", you will pay too much for the tour and end up being pressurised into buying something and/or left in the middle and lost- use the tour operator guide for a softer introduction to the souks, with a guide get less hassle from the vendors (but will still get the hard sell treatment at some point - usually a natural pharmacy)- so as not to get quiet so lost start from the main square and head north. The further from the square the more narrow and basic the "streets" become- wear sensible shoes as the walkways are uneven- first visit in the day time, it is quieter and more user friendly- take your time and talk to the vendors, even if you do not want anything. It takes longer but you will not feel so stressed/hassled and will soon get into the way it works and how friendly everyone is- ask before taking a picture and expect to pay DH2 - 5
Walk. It was busy, busy but very interesting. You had to be prepared for all modes of transport from mopeds, donkey/carts and in some places cars and pedestrians.

Amazing. Came to Marrakech especially to visit the souks and it was above and beyond anything I had imagined! Never been anywhere like it in my life. A totally amazing experience, loved it all, even paying 3 times more for a rug than I would have done in the UK!

shocked and amazed. the title really does express what i thought of the souks.i was truly amazed by the artisan quarter,to see the leathersmiths tanning their goat hides and watching the tiny hovel next door turning the leather into bags,coats,slippers and all things leather without a single piece of electric machinery is a sight to behold.the same goes for bakers and sweetmakers and blacksmiths.on the other side of the coin its hard not to shocked at the the way they handle the food trades,from fish laid out on the pavement to meats hanging from hooks over the street covered in flies.you will see a different way of life that is shocking but fascinating.the tourist shops sell everything you can imagine and bartering is a must.i got more than a few things some which i got for a good price,others im not so sure after the fact but either way it was fun.i defy anyone to go into the souks for the first time and not get lost,but that is part of the adventure and its the first place i will revisit if or when i return to marrakech..

Fascinating and disorientating. We started by trying to follow a planned 'walking tour' suggested by a specialist shopping review of Marrakech. However it just isn't possible to follow directions because there are rarely street signs and the maps give you at best a rough idea of where you are ... so we did what I guess all tourists do, we got lost and stopped off where we found things that interested us. It can get annoying to be hassled all the time to see things and to be approached etc, but you have to remember that you're in a poor country and these are people who are working hard to earn a living. OK you can't talk to everyone who says hello, but I found that once finding something of interest and stopping to talk with a vendor, if you take the time to chat, smile and engage with the locals, they were very warm and interesting, charming people. I could write for a long time about the people we met, the fascinating labourinthine shops we saw and the beauty of some of the local crafts and antiques on show. It's really amazing and frustrating in turns .... but if you haven't yet been, then you really must
markets. This is still what Marrakesh does well but do be prepared to get lost and bargain. Don't ignore the big items, they will ship them.

Know How Pricing Works. Just wanted to mention as a travel operation and resident of Morocco, that the souk in Marrakeh is a wonderful stop. Here is a general pricing guideline. First, you will have to bargain. As a general rule, the very first price they offer you is not the price you have to pay. Great negotiators can get the price down 50% but if you can get the price down 30% from what they offered, you have done well. Enjoy Marrakech.

Not as good as I thought they would be. The Souks are fun to look around but the sellers are a bit pushy. There are loads of other places to buy outside of the Souks and to be honest the produce was better and more authentic in the other shops. It's a must for a visit though.

Very Interesting but. See the metal, leader, stone and other trade workers actually doing their crafts- downside very small crowded streets with motorcyles and others weaving in and out and with walled city and narrow quarters pollution from those detracts from the experience- at least it did for us.

Crazy, Chaotic, Beautiful, Awesome... and everything in between. My family and I love the vibe in Marrakesh! The souks, crazy moped drivers, bartering, people, mosques, goods... all off these things just add to the awesomeness that is Marrakesh. My advice would be to just relax and go with the flow. If you know what to expect (I.e. dirty, smelly, crowded, chaotic, etc.), you'll be fine. We didn't use a guide and honestly with Google maps and a good guide book I don't think you really need one. Google maps is a must have and with it we never once got list. Overall a totally worth it experience and I think after this you might think like mr and say 'you have not lived until you've survived crossing a Moroccan road' ;)

Don't be afraid to push for a bargain. There's plenty to buy here so have a good wander around. The vendors ask for way too much initially so don't be afraid to slice their price by at least 1/3 when bargaining. Watch out for all the sleazy men if you are a female or only travelling with females. We were appropriately dressed in Morocco and we were constantly hassled by dirty men lurking in the Souk.

Welcome to Arabia. If you thought you only had 5 senses, prepare to be astonished. The colours, the smells (good ones), the noise and the bustle are like nowhere else. Do beware of the hustlers and others who will harass you for money if you take their photo.Make sure you go there for the sunset. There are rooftop bars all round the square, where for a slightly price inflated drink you can soak in the Souk.One of life's "Must See's"

Maybe not on your first day.... ... we (parents) loved the bustling souk, for our children, 8 and 14 years old, it was quite an impact on the first evening. So if you arrive in the afternoon, maybe relax in a nice riad until the next morning and adventure yourself in the souk only then. Be prepared for heads of lamb lying next to a lamb barbecue, motor scooters almost running over you (in spite of forbid signs) and many other things an adult has no problem with, but children may need to adjust. We arrived at the airport, unloaded our baggage at the hotel and then and went on Jemaa el Fna square for dinner. We parents loved it, for the children this kind of start into a foreign culture was a bit heavy!

The Souks are fantastic. One of the best things about the souks in Marrakesh, is that you do not get pestered as much as you do in the souks inTunisia.you will get lost, but that is part of the charm, the colours, smells and charecters make this a fantastic vibrant place - it is a must do....

Getting lost in the souk. I got lost...this is the first thing you will say after you walk the first time in the souk of Marrakesh.Tons of people, bikes, donkeys and everyone wants to sell you stuff. After a while, when you get used to it you will start to notice all the beautiful things the souk offers you. From the odds and ends for tourists to the fine hand-decorated pots for design lovers. The souk can be everything and nothing. Depends how you like to live it. My only suggestion is, don't get scared, watch out and enjoy a nice walk in the souk.

Interesting yet Overwhelming. We visited the city centre. I would definitely recommend visiting this area. It's very interesting and extremely busy. I'm a very social person, but this experience was overwhelming for me and our entire party.Many of the shops have a lot of the same items. The people are willing to negotiate. Give your rock bottom price that you're willing to pay and be prepared to leave if it's not accepted. Trust me, another vendor will have the exact same item. Beware that you will be expected to pay for any pictures taking with snake charmers, monkey trainers, etc. They will simply walk up to you and place a snake around your neck. If you're not interested, immediately say NO or else, you'll be in for a ride.Also, beware that some of the locals will attempt to direct you to places and serve as an unofficial tour guide. They are very friendly and adamant. Be prepared to say No thank you numerous times and simply don't engage them. Just walk away.We were in this area for several hours. You could easily get lost. I actually think that I enjoyed shopping on the streets better than in the souks. Simply overwhelming for me.

F-a-a-a-a-r too touristy!. It is interesting to stroll around here, but the souk has become so incredibly touristy that it soon gets annoying. Better to visit the souk in e.g. Rabbat. The high prices and greedy people don't really belong in my definition of a good vacation.

Essential - but. The Souks and the big square are, we were told, the heart and soul of Marrakech. The best thing about the souks,in my view, is that you can be pretty sure that most things on sale are made in Morocco rather than China.A rabbit warren would be an easily navigated highway compared to these narrow twisty lanes, but when you get over the shock and accept that you will get hopelessly lost you can enjoy lokking at the vast amount of goods on sale. I got a very strong well made leather belt for £8 after my wife haggled well. It was fun as the trader had a sense of humour.Roughly divided into areas of leatherwork, art, metalwork etc the souks are not easy to navigate and you are sure to pass the same shops several times.But - the shopping experience is all but ruined by the constant flow of nutters on mopeds who come at you from all angles. There is legitimate traffic in the form of donkey drawn carts, hand carts and the occasional van in addition to hordes of people but the moped riders add nothing but fear and must surely affect trade. This has been a trip advisor topic since 2009 and I cant understand why the authorities allow it. None of the mopeds are registered so presumably there is no test or insurance requirement and the souks are not so big that they cant be driven around or walked through.Just be aware therefore and keep safe whilst enjoying an essential and iconic feature of this fascinating city.

Mad-house in Marakech!. The souks in Marakech is truly a wonderful and very interesting place and an experience second to none! From the Jamaa el Fna square with its snake charmers, orange juice stalls, people with monkeys on ropes, ladies doing henna tattoos, horse and carriages to the tiniest of shops selling everything from food, to hair products, to brass, to clothes, to live animals, jewelry, lamps and furniture and meat, it is a complete overload on the senses. It is a total mad-house in the little alleys with hundreds of pedestrians, to donkeys with carts, mopeds, people on bicycles and children running. To get lost in the souks is a wonderful experience, but for me one day would be enough!

Eye opener. Keep your wits about you be sure to ask before taking pictures. Narrow alleys and mopeds come out of no where. If you don't like busy cramped places this isn't for you. I loved the hustle and bustle. Snake charmers - only take a picture if your willing to pay. Keep your bag close to you. The guys are quite good if you say no. That was my experience anyway. Lots of beggars. I really enjoyed it and I went with a guide as I went to morocco alone. I met couples who were glad to have a guide. Went to a fantastic natural pharmacie too.
see medina comments as well. Sit at the top of the Panoramic Hotel for lunch to see the view of the square and Souk......................................
Enjoyable wander around the stalls. Went here twice during our weeks stay, not much hassling and plenty of bargains o found.worth a visit although the main square is not very pleasant
GREAT TO SHOP. This is right nex to the Jamaa El Fna. Good place to shop for gifts. You must negotiate by quoting 50% less than what they quote.

Argan Oil in Medina of Marrakesh. Other reviewers have commented on the good quality of the oil available at Herboristerie Firdaous. We found it difficult to find the place, so here is my suggestion as to how to find the shop. My wife tells me that the cosmetic argan oil is the real deal, and the shop can be relied upon to sell good quality products. Many of the tour guides are accused of sending tourists to 'Berber markets' where they are overcharged, or, worst still, sold fake products.OK, how to find the shop.The address is First Floor, Galerie Essalam, Avenue Prince Moulay Racchid. Avenue Prince Moulay Racchid is the second street to the left of the Post Office in the Djemaa El Fna.At the other end of Avenue Prince Moulay Racchid is the Grand Hotel Tazi.Before you reach the Grand Hotel Tazi there is a shop on the corner of the street called Solo.Just before Solo is the entrance to Galerie Essalam. It has only Arabic signage.Above the entrance to Galerie Essalam is a projecting window.Remember the shop is on the first floor of a tiny shopping mall.I hope the photos will help you to find this place. It is well worth paying a visit. I had a bad cold for weeks and my airways were cleared with the help of the essential oils obtained from Herboristerie Firdaous.

No harassment, just looking, lubbly jubbly!. Plenty to see, plenty to buy, no one seems to hassle you, everyone is ready to barter and there is lots to barter for. Colourful, bright, interesting, you get lost, you get found, wear comfortable shoes, be prepared to buy water (don't bother to take your own, live a little and buy a bottle!), be prepared to haggle, to laugh, to enjoy yourself. If you feel you've been ripped off it is your own fault, the shopkeepers in the medina love to barter and are reasonable.

Abandon all hope...ye who enter here!!. You will either love it or hate it! With the right attitude it will be an adventure you won't forget! First, it is okay to be lost. If this is something that worries you then you may not love the souks...but I am pretty sure no one has ever been lost in there forever! The souks are colorful, crowded, loud, filled with people and cats and motor scooters and donkeys and donkey carts and people who want to sell you everything. Nothing is priced and be prepared to negotiate...and rarely for one thing (the salespeople are going to try to sell you lots of whatever it is you want..best price you know...). It is a true assault on the senses....the spices, the colors of the shoes and the wool and the pottery, the noise of so much happening...the taste of dates and mint tea...so put on your big girl undies and dive right in!

Shoppers paradise. Good quality handcrafted leather goods, shoes, lamps, metalwork, jewellery, scarfs and cloathes nice pashminas and kaftans. Great price for herbs and spices. Teapots galore i returned home dreaming about teapots and a good old cup of English tea. I bought a lovely teapot with a tray and 6 nicely decorated tea glasses for about £13.00 very pleased it looks wonderfull in our kitchen. Have fun haggling be polite and firm dont be afraid to have a bit of banter with the traders they have a good sence of humour.

Haggle & Haggle Some More. Jemma al Fna is THE must see attraction in Marrakech, Morocco. Hundreds of stalls, shops, food stalls, performers and people from all around the world!Be careful of pickpockets and horses than might run you over.

Another bucket list. Agree with all the reviews and advice - just remember the souks are not cheap - you can get the same things out in the country at the roadside where they are made for less with no hassle. ie cooking pots they ask 300 D will come down after much effort to 190 but 140 by road!However grat fun but tiring would not miss

Go with a guide. for the first visit use the services of a guide so that you can find your way around. we also got to see the other side of the souk - the places where they make the items for sale, absolutely fascinating!

East meets west in an orgy of sound,smells and sights. Where everything happens an everyone is.Close to the main souk that is on of the best in Africa.Haggle hard and keep valuables out of sight.Great great atmosphere, lots of tat but good Brian's if you haggle well.
Fun !. A large colourful noisy packed market place with lots of hussle and bustle. Be prepared to barter for everything or you will be ripped off, its just the Moroccan way.
Great shopping. There is so much to see and buy. The bargaining gets old after a while, but it's fun to just look around...

Be prepared the haggle. Prices are not as cheap as you may think, so think about what you would pay for the item at home, as you may be paying over the odds. Start low, regardless of their offer, increase slightly if you wish but stick to your guns and walk away if needs be - most of the time they will come after you and agree your price. Don't be fooled by the demonstrations as they will expect you look and hopefully buy from their shop. Remember it is all a bit of fun and traditional in the souks, but if you make an offer you are expected to buy.

Exotic Marrakech. Travelling with a friend was the best option to go to Marrakech considering two woman in the middle age. Two worlds: Marrakech with the old city and its traditions (sell/buy/music/mint tea) and new city of Gueliz with its modern and confortable condominiums. Gardens with plants of semi arid climate with a range of different cactus and huge palms. You do not survive there if you do not bargain to buy something or just to call a taxi :) My shopping tip: 1. choose what do you have interest to buy2. have a price in your mind (half price)3. when been asked, tell your offer (don't be shy)4. they don't accept5. turn your back6. they come to you and acceptIt is a tiring shopping way but that is their reality, their way to make business.Even with just 5 days in Marrekech we went to sleep at Desert of Sahra and rode a camel!!!! 2 days 1 night. If you do not mind to travel all day (stopping for lunch, touristic points, toilet, views), ride a camel for 1 and half hour, sleep in tents under a beautiful sky, watch a stunning sunrise, have a typical Berber dinner, sing and dance ... Its worth.

A nice market with many soukhs. Always like the souks in the main markets in Marrakesh. Lots of stuff to see, and usually something interesting to buy if you have many homes you wish to outfit in the Marrakesh style

Mesmerising, magical place!. What a wonderful, unique place - I felt like I had stepped back into medieval times!My family and I thought we would be plagued by sellers and possible pick-pockets in the main square, but it feels very safe; nevertheless, we didn't wear flashy jewelleryor carry hand-bags. Beware of over-tipping the water sellers (men with big, tasselled hats!) when having a photo done; we fell victim to this! Have some loose change and small notes to hand - not a 200 Dirham note only, like we did!! And the snake charmers will plague you in the same way, but are a must-see/do. My hubby hates snakes, but was 'charmed' into having one placed round his neck for a photo! The souk is so atmospheric, and seems never-ending. Each 'stall' is a cavernous, dimly-lit Aladdin's cave of sparkling slippers, or rich-smelling leather - to name but two goods. Donkey carts shoulder their way through the throng, transporting all sorts of goods - and watch out for scooters zipping past you all the time. Visit the Koran school - exquisite carvings and engravings there. I think one should pace one's experience of the souk, otherwise it can be over-whelming. We kept going back for short, sharp spurts of shopping. For a hassle-free experience,Centre Artisanal is a one-stop huge department store selling everything, but apparently there is a more authentic shopping experience at the smaller Ensemble Artisanal; these places are government controlled, and sell authentic Moroccan goods at a slightly higher price, but with no haggling to worry about. Enjoy!

Very Busy.. Careful for pickpockets. Its a very touristy place. many local scenes and happening in the area from snake charmers, stalls selling various spices, local produce and crafts. It is nice to sip coffee atop the terraces overlooking the market area to enjoy the views. Things are quite cheap here. Enjoy.

Horrible. Cramped and claustrophobic. Constant hassle from every stall/shop holder. Am sure there was some good stuff to buy but we could not stand the arm twisting. When will they learn that if we could just brouse in peace we might be tempted to buy. We got out as soon as we could.

Crazy!. This place is so busy and there is so much to see..heaps of bargains but you will need to haggle and from what we were told by locals, you would normally go down two-thirds of what they are asking for..worked for us..but be fair, they need to make a profit as well.

google maps & a compass help!. This place is a maze, with no quick exit. ask for directions and you may pay!The shops sell handcrafted goods. You see shoes being made from scratch, sewing machines at full throttle, tables being carved out. Barter like you are on the apprentice and don't be shy to go low and stick there. They will come down to you. The smells and the noise will leave you amazed that the world still has places that trade like this in the 21st century.NegativesCAREFUL what or who you take pictures of during the night and day. If you take a picture of something, do so at a distance if you don't wish to pay. I attempted to take an arty shot of a patisserie cart and the young lad wanted paying. Told him the photo was gone and he left us alone. The snake charmers have lookouts who will block the photos being taken. DONT touch the monkeys!The mopeds are the main issue.They mingle with the shoppers in the windy souks. They need to get rid of them quite frankly. They risk spoling the experience.TAKE a compass or download an app,as thats the best way to navigate through the souk. I also took a few pics off google maps onto my camera, so I could see where I was heading, in case I lost phone/internet signal. PERSONALLY I WOULD'NT TAKE CHILDREN THERE..Ladies - read the advice re dress before visiting.All said - Well worth the trip. There are some nice foody places amidst the melee. Enjoy!

Get yourself a good guide. It's fab!. We had a great guide that made this experience so special. We went to places well away from the crowds that made us feel like we really experienced at least some of what the Souks had to offer. Highlights included- having a go at weaving rugs- seeing how the baths are heated (and where the lad who did this lived) - metal work shops- tiny fresh produce markets- the views from the roofsOur guide was Aziz who can be contacted on (212) 061 16 52 63 or (212) 024 42 61 40. He is licensed and has been in a Hollywood film (won't spoil his talk on that topic) He is such a character, full of fascinating information on Marrakech and appears to know everyone. It's like walking round with a bit of a celebrity and he looks the part!Allow the best part of a day for this

Amazingly vibrant place.. Brilliant place. We found it amazing and went back repeatedly. Although there is a lot of the same sort of things it is lovely just to walk amongst the people. The bartering, smells and sights and one i won't forget in a hurry. Everyone wants money though! Constantly coming up to you to do henna, buy toys, have a picture taken with them.....

Marrakech Souk. Take all the advice given by your rep. You will need it here more than anywhere else in the world.Completely mad, baking hot, noisy, fascinating and never to be forgotten.Hamid, our Rep. with Hotels4u was the best. Could not h ave seen as much or enjoyed the country half as much without him.

Bonkers and Brilliant!. The Souks are simply another world. Noisy, dusty, colourful, entrancing--a must for all visitors! Haggle--it's expected. Beware of getting lost--very easy to do. Beware of who you ask for help too!Take a map or a trusted guide to get the best experience.

Don't miss this experience. Imagine a heaving Covent Garden during the summer, throw in smells and sights of spices, leather, poultry, sweets and woodwork and your not far off what the Souk has to offer. Hustle and bustle, local produce, take-away souvenirs they are all here - you can't really say you've experienced Marrakesh without entering the Souk at least once.

Pay no more than 1/3 of the price they first mention. As the title suggests it is common to expect to pay 1/3 or 1/4 of the original price stated by a seller. We did not know this in the beginning so be aware...
dreadful people not greatest things for sale. dirty, smelly, harrassed, hissed at. goods not great quality. meat with flies all over. mopeds bikes and to many people barging about!
full of atmosphere. This place is great for a contrast of sights, sounds and smells, great food stalls and good shopping, you can get a lot of hassle while shopping though

Cool but a bit repetitive. We loved looking at all the wares in the souks. They did seem a bit repetitive though - spices, lamps, leather, teapots, back to spices. Some of the staff can be a bit pushy with trying to get you to come in. We didn't buy anything so can't comment on the bargaining. If you go further from the square though, some of the shops already have some prices on if haggling is not for you.

A different kind of shopping. The souks are sure different from what we are used to seeing in the U.S. They are absolutely "stuffed" with merchandise - which I find difficult to determine IF there is anything that I even want to buy! I imagine that there may be some very fine items in there, but what a challenge to find them! Good Luck!

Great deals... pushy salespeople... LOTS of bartering. Go here, but be prepared to have people try to push you into buying things whether you want them or not. They will ask for way more than you want to pay... so talk them down. You didn't get a good price on something unless you walk out of their store and they call you back. When you give them a "final price" stay there. If they laugh at your initial offer you might have to come up a bit. Offer them less than a quarter of what they ask... typically that's a decent rule of thumb :) Oh, and be prepared to get lost, and pay someone to give you directions or lead you out... if you don't you'll get lost and wind up like we did in a pretty terrible neighborhood :)

Friendly, great fun. We were somewhat anxious about venturing into the labyrinth of the souk and could not have been more pleasantly surprised both by how friendly it was and how easy it was to get around. That said, it is important to have your own map as asking for directions can land you with a persistent 'guide' demanding to be paid. But any hotel map will be adequate, and there are plenty of signposts to the Jemaa el Fna if you need to re-orient. We found that the best approach was to be smiling, friendly and firm ourselves, and then the stallholders were smiling, friendly and reasonable in return. It's definitely best not to spend too long wasting a stallholder's time, but if you are genuinely interested in something they are pleasant to deal with. Bargaining needs a degree of nerve, but we found that if we started at 20% of their initial price we could almost always end up paying under 40% and sometimes considerably less. Everything should be bargained for unless it is edible, we were told. So if you are buying spices regard the price as more or less fixed. Don't fall for the 'this is best quality' spiel as you will get it everywhere for everything - but at the same time do be aware that quality varies from stall to stall, even if the item (shoes, say) looks initially the same. So make your own inspection and be prepared to pay more or less accordingly.Above all, enjoy it! It's great fun!

Hard work navigating and dealing with local con artists. It's hard work in here. Every other guy in, mostly teenage boys, are trying to get money off you. They will try to give you directions and demand payment, they'll try to make you walk in one direction when the square is in the other. It's a shame as there are lot of people in the souks who are trying to make a genuine living and their businesses are being tarnished by thieving scum. It left a foul taste in my mouth and I'd never go back to Marrakech again. Tourists are prizes and they will try to fleece you of everything you have. You need to be firm and basically tell people to go and do one, which is a shame, as you lack trust with anyone, even the people who are in fact genuine.

Expect to get lost, be patient.. You have to go. It is Marrakech. Yes it's a pain being hassled, and getting lost and being asked for money just to be pointed in A Direction (often the wrong one), but you can't miss it. We just wandered....... Give yourself some time and you'll be fine.....

ONE WORD - 'FUN!'. Just come back from 4 days in Marrakech and enjoyed getting lost many times in the Souks. Having experienced markets in other African and Middle Eastern countries, Marrakech is quite tame - people seem pretty friendly as long as you accept the banter and are prepared to join in. I agree that if you offer a third of the opening price, you can get them back up to a half. This way its about the same or a bit less then at the cooperative / fixed price places - which are nice but a different experience!
Watch your purse. Every thing you see is on the barter system so bone up on how to barter. Vendors are very pushy so stick to a game plan on what you want to accomplish there. Do not go there alone.

ONE WORD 'AGGRESSIVE'. I would not recommend the Souks. As already mentioned many of the same items are available in the different shops. As soon as you stop you get hassled by the 'guides' and apparently wherever you are going is closed according to the locals, who don't even know where you are going. Some shout aggresively 'It's Closed!' while you walk in the souks innocently trying to enjoy your holiday.One chap continually mimicked me by repeating the words 'No Thank you' in a sarcastic manner. In one of the shops, the shopkeeper got aggressive when we bartered him down from 315D to 215D (Approx £19) for a small wooden guitar and small drum (Not cheap) and then preceeded to tell me to 'Have a nice life' in an angry cursing manner whilst shoving the bagged items into me. He also mentioned that he had to get food for his family and felt that the price was too low.I realise that there is poverty in Marrakech, but there's no reason to totally disrespect the tourists. I have travelled pretty well and never felt this way. In Bangkok I needed to be on my guard for scams but I never had the abuse I received in the Souks. I feel some (not all) of the locals just expect the tourists to give money out freely and that we maybe have an endless supply cash.

Get lost in the Souk. the best part of the souk is that there are no motorized vehicles allowed inside. It was easy to walk around, shop and explore the many booths and vendors. Don't be afraid to bargain. Our riad said the best time to go is in the morning when vendors are most interested in making sales.

Be bold!. If they tell you 200 dirhams, haggle till you get it for 80 dirhams. Marrakech is expensive by Morrocan standards so don't be ripped off. Also make sure that you are buying authentically made items as some are from China!!

Fascinating. The best souks are found further away from the main square. A tip we were given was to offer 1/3 of what the seller says they want - ignore whatever the price tag says, offer 1/3 of their first offer. If you then end up paying 1/2 then you prob have done OK. If you are ever unsure then offer a low price and then walk out - if they try and persuade you to come back in then don't offer more than that price (maybe even go lower) but if they don't try to persuade you back in then you know you have gone to low. Great fun.

Need Patience and Comfy Shoes!!. The souk is as you read and expect - it was crowdy, noisy and loud! It was difficult to look at things without being harassed but it is an experience in itself! It is something you have to do but just be prepared for it and have comfy shoes!

Why didn't I have a stove?. There were products for sale in the souk that I have trouble finding at home in Mexico. What beautiful legs of lamb and lambchops! And those artichokes! At least I enjoyed looking at these things and imagining.I did, however, buy and taste the wonderful little pastries that are works of art in their design. Many contain ground nuts -- pistachios, hazlenuts, almonds, walnuts -- that are readily available here. I bought dried figs and dates too. Wonderful!

A feast for the eyes. In the souks you can find everything you ever wanted and everything you did not know you wanted! Do get lost here, wander around, relax and enjoy the ambiance and let your eyes be tempted from all the goods for sale. Try to see even the deeper parts of the souks, it will give you another experience than if you just keep around the Djema El Fna. Don´t pay anyone to guide you, eventually you will find the way yourself, and the experience is so much better that way. When buying something, do not forget to negociate, it is part of the process here, and don´t be intimidated of the sellers greetings - the best thing is to just smile and continue walking if you are not interested.

souks. loved the cacophony of sounds, scents and sights. the area is a complete assault on all your senses, plus you get to shop!! although definitely westerner beware, as locals will gently try and remove you from your money, their intent is however to do it politely while being offered tea and a seat. initially it is cheaper to watch from one of the many cafe's with 2nd and third story verandas, where you can see the water sellers, snake charmers and stall holders plying their wares. but nothing compares to the fun of getting in, there getting lost, finding then haggling (not my personal favorite but definitely expected) for your own piece of Marrakech

And good place to enjoy a desert bivouac without a long drive to the Sahara. We didn't know there is a Sahara desert bivouac only 30 minutes drive from Marrakech, but we did find a flyer regarding a place where you can enjoy. Sahara desert bedouins experience right by the staff desert. We did call and went there, the experience is. Very nice. Bedouins sahara tents. Gnawa music band, Andalusia music band and a dancer. We had a nice night and we did enjoy the crystal clear sky, some shooting stars and no light pollution. We had a good time for good deal.
Interesting. Found that most traders were selling much the same thing - interesting to walk through and see people making objects.

give yourself enough time. SO VERY FUN and much more approachable than expected. The sales guys aer charming and fun, Do haggle and if they can sell at your price they will. If not, they politely say thank you and you leave. Keep wandering - it's fun and you WILL find your way out.

Such an experience, but watch your pockets!. I loved it, the maze of streets, the buzzing atmosphere, the buildings, the amazing produce. It was quite overwhelming, it was the first time i had really been exposed to the full on sales/money-grabbing tactics, be aware of the following:- Kids selling tissues and following you down the streets.- 'Guides', get lost in the souks, you will always find your way back to the square, even with no decent sense of direction. People will follow you, and every corner you turn will acknowledge it like it was their idea and then ask for money for their services.- Be prepared to haggle!! Absolutely vital. - Be discreet at taking photographs- Pick pockets, they are very good! you need a sturdy bag and nothing in your pockets. I lost a few receipts out of my jeans!Great experience, you will have a great time.

busy!. wow! Never experienced shopping like this before! The stall holder's are friendly and obviously want your custom. I did find it a bit draining at first, but once you get past the culture shock its great fun!

Wow. Real down town Marrakech market, original and untainted by technology and 21 century. Herbs spices ,Moroccan oil , pottery and many more goods to woo any new comer. A feast for my eyes, I enjoyed it so much I went to souk(market) twice.

Great shopping!. Having had the fortune to have visited a few more souks (including the ones in Damascus and Aleppo), we really loved the souks in Marrakech, with plenty of shopping bargains and pretty good quality objects on sale. Just don't be scared to say NO and shop around as much as you can. We bought the same product (like stones and fossils) in different parts of the souk at remarkably different prices! Although confusing at first, it is actually quite easy to navigate through the souks - don't ask for directions as you will be expected to pay quite a few euros for unwanted help - but follow the signs to Jemaa el Fna (or other main attractions), there are signs everywhere!

My favourite market ever. I love markets, and have been to many around the world, but this has got to be my favourite. There are good quality locally-made/grown/picked/etc goods to be bought here. Everything from the colourful spices to Moroccan tea sets can be bought here. Even great Moroccan mats. If you make a few side trips down the smaller alleys you will often come across the men making the products from their workplace. You will also see the former slave market. This place is so full of history and living culture. It's one place you should never miss if in Marrakech.

Kowloon Mongkok Market x 10. One of our favourite things to do when in Hong Kong is to visit the markets in Kowloon. Depending on the particular area, you can find clothes, bags, watches, flowers, fish, ribbons and a whole host of other things.  The souks of Marrakesh are a bit like that but the experience is 10 times more intense and the goods on offer are also 10 times more interesting. The alleyways are narrower and you have to negotiate your way round side 'offshoots' which could lead somewhere, nowhere or maybe to another souk in- between. You will get lost but this is part of the fun.Regarding being hassled, this is nothing compared to Stone Town in Zanzibar (see previous reviews). Most vendors will leave you alone if you are firm in your 'non, merci'. As for haggling, the rule of thumb is to offer a third of the opening price and be prepared to walk away. However if you want to buy, and the seller wants to sell, the end price should keep both parties happy.Always bring cash,the smaller denomination the better. Best of all, decide what you want and the price you want to pay, and just keep that amount in a side pocket of your bag. Finally, keep aside lots of time for discovering the souks as there really is a lot to see.
A typical Arab market. A very authentic part of life in Marrakech where it would be very all too easy to get lost - a wide range of local products are available at prices to be negotiated!

Haggle, haggle, haggle. Great place to pick up souvenirs and bits for home if you like an ethnic feel. But you must not accept the prices they give you. Trust me, you can always get it cheaper. Especially since many of them sell the same things.

Take it slow. Nothing compares to the experience of shopping in the souks and you could spend all day there and not see half of it. Haggle hard and be prepared to walk away and they will come to you. Don't be fooled by people offering to show you the way back to the square- it is signposted and they will want money.

Marrakesh Madness!. Marrakesh in a nutshell! Many tourists to Marrakesh Souk arrive by horse and carriage. We certainly did. Once into the square your senses are ignited by the sights, sounds and smells. Pet monkeys, snake charmers, street vendors and acrobats however don't be too distracted - stay alert,for pick pocket thieves have a presence in the square as well. Vendors sell a wide variety of fruit and vegetables plus a huge range of dates. Hot food is also available if you are brave enough or have a cast iron gut. We purchased dates a brought them back to Australia, declaring them to customs of course. On the edge of the square there are many alley ways selling spices, Moroccan tea sets,antiquities, Argan oil both real and fake, pharmacy products, fabric and a wide range of other goods. We really felt that we were in a souk that hadn't changed much in hundreds of years.

Too many motorcycles... but fabulous leather boots. The increase in motorcycle traffic and fumes thundering past you at close proximity in the narrow streets around the souks has made shopping here a bit of a nightmare, and not a very enjoyable experience any more - plus the traders have become more and more forceful in their sales techniques, which makes it difficult to enjoy buying anything. However, there are a few shining stars left... Abdellah Nezhari makes fabulous leather boots, made to measure! Find him at 91 Rue Mossine, or call him on 0667239006. I will upload some photos here of the boots we bought if I'm given the option.
Busy fun. Brillant and wonderful things especially the leather!Enjoy it .The bartering is fierce.Take lots of money as there is loads to buy.
Be prepared!. The Souks are fun and full of all sorts but be prepared to haggle and expect traders to try and confuse you. Also wear shoes as your feet get very dirty.

Avoid the spice shops!!. Avoid going into the spice shops and be firm with anyone who tries to take you to "their shop"!!! The souks are easy to get lost in, but just look like you know where you're going and you'll be fine and only ask how much something is if you are really keen to by itt!

Bargain very hard!. We spent a couple of days in the souks and know we were really ripped off. The shop keepers tend to ask outrageous prices and it is up to you to bring them right down. E.g., we were quoted 450 dirhams for a scarf payed 100, decided we wanted two more, went to another stall and for two for 100! Having said that you can't to to Marrakesh and not visit the souks as they are so fascinating. A word of caution - avoid the henna ladies. My daughter had henna put on which was supposed to last three weeks and its was gone in a few days and left her with considerable irritation to her hand/arm. And we had paid the ridiculous sum of 100 dirhams - about £5 for it!

Intriguing. The souks are a world of colour, pattern and noise. Motorbikes, mopeds and bicycles are whizzing through the narrow alleys, and the noise is constant.There are some beautiful things being sold, and in general, the smallholders are very friendly. At night, they seem to be more determined to try to get you to 'browse', and are less likely to take no for an answer, but you expect that in a market place.It is easy to get lost, but the locals are very willing to point out the direction you need.Just watch out for the mopeds, some of which carry families of four! They whip round the corners, without knowing if anyone is likely to be there, but surprisingly, we've only seen one accident, in three days, and the cyclist got up, picked up his bike, got on and rode away. No insurance details need to be shared here!

Marrakech Souk. I recommend you hire a guide to show you through the souks for the first time, unless you have a lot of time to get lost. It is overwhelming and it was helpful to have someone guide you through the different areas. They may take you to all their relatives shops but just smile nicely and say you aren't interested (or ask for a card and say you will come back later).

Peculiar marketplace. I read some tips that you should offer 1/3 of set price and work up, which I did - really enjoying myself. No deal will take place if either party is loosing money. But on more than one occation I was called a Berber from Sahara (but with a smile).

Mad!. An experience that is worth doing once in your life. We visited the craziness at least five days out of seven. Haggling for everything takes some getting used to and the constant hassling can get a bit tiring but it must be part of the Marrakech visit

Happy shopping. I had a short free time, so I decided to visit the souks in Jeema El Fna square (Marrakech Souks).I scored few good buys with hard bargaining or haggle the prices with the vendors. A lot of things and stuffs, colourful in scarves, leather goods etc....there were lot of fun in shopping this way.Surrounded the souks, there're few good restaurants also.Will come back to the Marrakech souks next time I'm in the area.

Chaotic, fun place. Bargain, bargain, bargain! Smell any leather goods before buying, most smell like goat. Most semi-precious rocks are fake and have been painted. No matter how careful you are, they will rip you off. So safety problems though.

Eek!. Busy and crazy... Some areas better than others. We found walking into the souk from the outskirts of the square, rather than from the square into the souk made for a better experience, particularly for the leather, fruit and silver markets. the market combines motorcycle exhaust with food on display, so it may put you off... We went to the artisan market first to see how much items should cost -they are government set in the artisan market - and haggled a lot. Although once you show an interest, the vendors find it difficult to take no for an answer! Well worth a visit...

Enthralling. Lots to explore -just wander through the souk. A good idea to check prices first by going to the artisan centre on the left of the entrance to Jemaa el Fnaa where government set the prices

Another Tourist Trap. The merchants in the souk are very aggressive and kept harassing us for just walking past their stalls. I have been to a few souks and markets in Dubai, Singapore and Mauritius and you would expect the them to try and sell. But Marrakech is something else, the constant pestering and the same products over and over in all the shops at massively differing prices!! I didn't buy anything simply to avoid the hassle of dealing with the merchants!
haggle!. Love it, it's so lively and colourful. Not so keen on the haggling but it has to be done. Enjoyed watching the locals make baboosh, lamps etc.

nice but busy. beaware as it is easy to get lost in the souk. it was an experience but i personally would not be going back their without my boyfriend. my and my female friend visited the souk. it is narrow and very busy with little shops full of men. we were called many things from fish and chips, to asda cheap price, to shakira, to skinny, chicken..even offered everything for free if i agreed to be the sho keepers wife for one week!!i am a patient person but when it comes to things like this i loose my temper. few of the locals asked me to smile as my face looked like thunder due to the things that were being said. i read reviews on tripadvisor before i went and people did advise to keep smiling and walking. i found if i smiled i got the unwanted attention that made my face like thunder. however i would still suggest people visit it just once for the experience. i did go back 2 more times and once during the eveing when it was a little bit more relaxed as the local women and many tourists are out. the local people are no threat and i guess they are trying to do business so cant blame them. however the men are very vocal when they see a woman and do shout out comments like, sexy, baby, nice body. the stalls in the souks are not different from each other and they all sell the same things. do haggle and do not settle for the first price offered. i wanted to buy a watch for my partner- fake armani and was told by the shop keep it cost 350 dirham which is about £25 pounds but i ended up haggling it down to about £9name your price and walk away the shop keeper will come back and agree your price and if he doesnt then dont worry there are plenty of other stalls that do the same item.

Fab but watch out!. Vibrant, intersting and colourful, but all the bartering takes its tole, and you constantly feel ripped off. Dont get a guide,get a map! keep your money in a safe place and dont seem keen on buying it, just walk away, they chase you! what ever the starting price, take 80% off, they are still making money off you! Night souk is also great! careful if you have kids and have small money available like 5d to give the snake charmers or dancers. Dont give more!

Vibrant & loud. The centre was cleaner than expected.
Met some nice stall holders but some were very rude if you didn't buy.& even used threatening behavior.

Hectic and Crazy. Explosion of colors, smells, sounds, and tastes. Unforgettable experience, especially if you don't mind madness in the narrow streets caused by pedestrians, bicyclists, mule carts, and motor-bike riders. Definitely one of the best ways to experience true Marrakesh and the spirit of traditional Arabic bazaar.

Different, crazy, interesting, amazing, funny... everything!. The souk in Marrakech is a really different place. You can find everything there, even things that you don't really need for an accessible price. They will show you everything that they have, and they're really sympathetic in general. They'll offer you tea as well, but always ask if it's for free, otherwise they'll try to charge 20MAD ( around 2 euros) for that. It may sound cheap for you, but there you can buy a few things with this money and get tea for free. You also be careful because they will always try to get more money from you once you're a foreigner. Once you're in Morocco you have to bargain even for a coke, so you'd better do it inside the souk as well if you don't wanna get ripped off. Things there are extremely cheap for you if you're European or North-American, but don't let them fool you. At first they'll say that something costs 100 MAD (e.g.), but you might be able to get it for less than half of the price if you bargain right.They're really friendly, but there will probably appear some guys trying to guide somewhere, either to see how they produce leather or something else, it's something really interesting to see, but don't forget that they will charge you for showing you around and guiding you. Don't give them over 20 MAD, no matter if they ask, they won't hurt you, so just say you don't have much money and walk away.There are pickpockets everywhere, even though I didn't see any when I was in Morocco you should be careful. Like a friend of mine said "Be afraid of pickpockets in Europe and of being cheated on in Morocco" hahahah
mad and wonderful. depends where you end up ,I had great not too intrusive sellers ,but at other hand been followed by young man around untill I managed to loose their interest and shake them off .

Marrakech souk. We had a guide the first day, which is well worth it. Gives you some idea of your way around, and most importantly, the way back home!!. But if you see something on your tour, stop and buy it then, as you will never find the stall again! Even if you think you know where you are going! A fellow traveller of ours spent three more days trying to find a particular stall ......... and never did!

Now an average souk. It appears the authorities want Marrakesh to be accessible to any travellers and so have pushed the souk towards the direction of safety and lack of hassle. It now seems interesting, but a bit antiseptic.The only risks you'll run are i) (perhaps) a pickpocket, ii) getting lost or iii) getting ripped off if you don't haggle.Sadly, the price you pay is that it feels too safe and a little unexciting - for the real thing, try Istanbul or Cairo !
In the middle of Medina. The bazaar is rather typical. Do not miss the part where people work to make goods for sale. It is an old fashioned artisan colony.

Bargains. Bargains if you offer about one tenth of the asking price and be prepared to pay about one quarter to one third. Don't be afraid to walk away. You will probably be pursued and your 'best' offer accepted. If not followed then go back and accept their best last price offer. Remember too if you are buying more than one item bargain for the price of one first and then ask for an extra discount for more than one. Always worked with us.if you like silks [cactus silk] bedspreads, throws and scarves then take and extra empty bag with you. You will bring it home full. The colours of the silks are beautiful.

How it really works. The city of Marrakech was built over a thousand years ago with streets that can only be described as a rat's maze. When you step out of your hotel room, you WILL GET LOST. Young morrocan boys will jump on you to offer to lead you anywhere you need to go. They will say they are not guides, it is a gift, but when you get to your destination, they will demand money. Best thing to do is negotiate a price for them to take you to wherever you want to go BEFORE you make another step. The guides are very pushy and you must be firm. We had this one guide 17years old, very sweet, he invited us to his home and the family was very hospitable. The next day while he was working for us he disappeared. Showed up 4 hrs later at our hotel and said he was arrested for following tourists and had to pay 200 to get out and demanded that I pay for it. When i refused he got pretty nasty. You can't really avoid having a guide, but make sure you set boundaries. The souks are magical, you can spend days on end browsing, and there are no set prices. When you ask how much something is, the vendors will give you an opening offer. Usually it is at least 3 times more than they are willing to accept for it. Haggling is the name of the game. But you are better off haggling in Tijuana. :)

main square. Its buzzing and crazy and fun, you will need comfortable shoes, and women should cover cleavage/thighs etc. Take some coins for beggars (no welfare state, the elderly and disabled have no choice but to beg) Better value is to be had the further away from the centre of the square. Jemaa el Fna is where the tourists go when they only have one day. we fortunately had longer and found the Kasbah, and other outlying souks less pushy and better value.Don't let people persuade you that you are heading in the wrong direction ! they will put you on the right track after taking you miles through tiny lanes then insist on money and get stroppy ! we only did this once then got a map.Preferred Rahma Kedima (reached via the main souks) and Place de la Ferblantiers, watching the storks over coffee.

A haggle in the markets. My wife and I decided to book a week in Morocco, as we had heard many wonderful things about country, but nothing could have prepared us for what we experienced. One place one should definitely visit is the souks (the market) in the old median of Marrakech. If you are a tourist no doubt you shall stand out and be prepared to be called and pulled in to their shops and be sold anything from shoes and handbags to small animals, when the owners offer a price, half it automatically and then negotiate, you will have to push but you will neg the person down if not they will rob you blind. One thing you must make sure that if you are going to take a picture be prepared to pay for it and at times it can work out expensive. Do try the food in the stalls, we tried a few but the one that stood out was stall number one named Chez Aicha, the food was unbelievable and service was even better and cheap. Do also try the Mint tea although if you do not have a sweet tooth ask for the sugar to be put on the side. And finally do go the panoramic restaurant and get a terrace view and enjoy the circus of the souks come to life and watch the stalls being set up, a truly unbelievable experience,

exciting but keep you wits about you. Amazing experience shopping in the souks, amazing sights and things to be bought. Just have your wits about you, you will be approached constantly, but be prepared to say no, and aim to pay a quarter of what the shop owners originally ask you! bartering is very un- british, but you'd be a fool not to try it in the souks. the souks are like a maze, it's fun to get lost in them, but i'd advise finding your way back to the main square before it gets dark so you don't get lost in an unknown area....
Alladin's world. Mixture of exceptionally creative artisan & also perhaps one of world's greatest con-artist. Pure entertainment.

AMAZING. We had so much fun shopping in the souks!! the locals are very friendly, they can be a little pushy so be sure to barter with them as they do inflate their prices dramatically with foreigners and dont be afraid to say no if you dont want something! Avoid eye contact if you are not interested in their products.There is so much choice and we are very happy with our purchases - rugs, lanerns, clothes, and so much more! Great experience.

Maybe later!!. "Maybe later!!" - remember this phrase, you'll need it! Just smile and be firm - everyone will want a piece of you, and your wallet - but they will leave you alone if you're firm. Unforgettable memories...

Konichiwa. A visit to Marrakech would not be complete without a visit to the souks in the medina. The prices towards the back are much better than aroud Djemma El Fna Square, but be prepared to haggle either way. The sellers will use every tactic to get you to buy from the store. Just know what you want to pay and be firm with your price. If you can't get the number down, maybe they will throw you a freebie. It's totally worth it to go to the carpet souks just off the Place des Espices in late afternoon. You'll see a daily carpet auction for sellers bringing carpets back to mountain townsIf you are in the market for a Moroccan wedding blanket or handira, there is a shop in the middle of the carpet souks called Souffiane. You will know it by the sea of white pompoms and silver sequins. They sell both new and excellent quality vintage handira.

Tufsytyrvy place... Marrakech is a place full of surprises, everything is not in order but it works so well, very historical, peopke are quite nice , jemma el fina s a tufsyturvy place it is upside down, all things that shoud not be is there but that is the uniqueness of it, Morrocans are sweet people, very polite and I am planning already my next trip to come back..=)

AMAZING!. It was like nothing I ever thought I would see. It is a grown up Disney World! There is so much to see and taste and touch! Everyone was so nice. The trick was to barter for what you wanted. Food and gems. I could not get enough of it. I was thankful I spent a month there and got to return many times. I think even the night time is better with food, shopping and people watching! Crazy times!

Amazing - Marrakech at it's maddest and best!. We had the luxury of a half-day tour of the medina and souks with a local, official guide, so had some idea of what to expect when we ventured out ourselves. I'd advise this if it's your first time in an 'exotic' market place!Get yourselves a map first! Prepare yourself to be badgered by stallholders, but accept that this is what they do for a living - it's a competitive place for them. Just ignore and move on if you're not interested - you'll soon get used to it and they don't take it personally. Don't feel that you have to buy, but let some show you their wares and move on when you're ready. if you are buying, state how much you're prepared to pay and walk away unless you get it. It's how things are done and i guarantee, it'll be all smiles and handshakes when you eventually agree your price.The metalworker's souk is particularly incredible - have a good look at everything being done in there. be aware that tanned camel leather bags do not smell nice inside, so make sure you smell things thoroughly before buying!There are signs throughout the souk, directing you back to Jemaa el Fna square - a perfect place to start and end, with bars, restaurants and space!

Little overwhelming. The souk is great to get some bargain gifts however at first it is overwhelming lots of tourist guides rushing at you wanting to take you around the market..just say you have been before and are fine be quite firm otherwise they will not leave you alone! The people that own the stores are very persistent and sometimes dont like to take no thank you as an answer, you have to be quite firm in your response. If you dont want anything dont touch as as soon as you touch that is it they will expect you to buy! whatever their starting price is pay 1/3 of this bargain well they will give it to you for a lot cheaper and dont give in! But remember this is their business and all they have so they are just being friendly and trying to earn a living! Be careful of the women wanting to give henna tattoos as one grabbed my arm and nearly stuck the needle into my arm before I even had chance to say No! Stay with your partner or friends do not go at it alone especially if you are a woman and be careful of traffic everywhere in the market even where you least expect it there will be a bike or motorbike scooter you name it they will be everywhere and they do not warn you that they are there or coming! But overall a great experience definately has to be done after the 1st time it becomes easier!

This place is Amazing!. If you thought the Grand Bazaar in Istanbul was something, you will really be blown way by this Souk. Prepare to spend hours here (not to mention dirhams). Or just people watch. The night time shopping is even greater. Not to be missed!

culture & experience. Senses assulted by the atmosphere, smells, colours! a definte must while your in marrakech. Had a guide (200 local dirhams (approx £16) for 3 hours well worth the cost. Make sure you have plenty of small currency while your out as their are lots of 10 dirham charges to see places.

Lost in the Souk!. Impossible at first to get your bearings! We didn't want to buy or barter but got caught once when we were dressed in scarves against our will! All in a very friendly manner but persistent beyond anything we're used to! Took our picture and had to pay for scarves and photo! Still very little money changed hands! Watch out and say NO!

Hours of exploration. The souks of Marrakech have everything - I'm no fan of shopping, but enjoyed this. Interesting products and lots of sights, sounds and smells: many of the things on sale are also made in the souks. We got some great value with a little bargaining too.The hassles are there, but were tamer than we were lead to believe - just say no to people, and ignore anyone directing you. Signs to Jma el Fnaa or various other squares can help orientate - if in doubt, turn yourself back around and you'll be OK!

Colourful.. This is a must. They are huge, diverse, interesting, you can buy anything from a bike to a saucepan plus of course every herb and medicinal preparation. We took a picture of a cafe with an advert on it saying Trip Adviser down a little alley!

Anything you need.... Inside the medina you will find souks that sell and trade everything and anything, from electronics to live exotic animals, perfect place to buy local spices and leather goods. Get a good map and directions, try not to look like you're lost or you'll find yourself surrounded by wanna be guides hustling you for money.

Make sure you have a guide. I had an older gentleman guide take me around the souk and I fell like it really made a difference. He knew most of the vendors and helped me negotiate the price I paid for things. Plus he took me down the alleys where the craftsmen were making things, VERY interesting. Also, this place is HUGE, very easy to get lost.

No women allowed!!. If you are women on your own .....take a male guide ....or you will be pestered and frightened of the harassment and physical touches you receive from men!honestly!......if you're blonde and blue-eyed - DONT GO !!!

World Famous dissapointment. The souks of morrocco form part of that 'to do' list inherent in the budding alan whickers in us all.We know we have to haggle. Can I be bothered when the start price is so high.I tried the tactic of offering a price beforehand, then got a lecture about the quality and uniqueness of the goods?Actually, they're not unique, I can find the same stuff in little morrocco, Goldman road, and its cheaper with no haggling.Yes... it IS cheaper in London. Some leather bags, are clearly not leather, only a few mind. The argan oils in the souks are suspect.Visit the first 8 outlets, and basically repeat it 100 times, and thats the souks with motorbikes constantly streaming through, clogging up the walkways and polluting to the extent your throat soon itches.Don't bother following the signs that lead you back to the square, we did, the signs stopped, we hit a crossfayre and ended up in some residential squalour. Dont ask for directions, some send you some way, some another, usually it's to where they have a vested business interest.Summary;- Far too expensive, Too much motorised traffic, Once youve been past the first 50 yards... it pretty much repeats.Portabella road/Goldman Road is much much better..... and come to that, so is any medium sized boot sale.Very dissapointed.

The souk. I liked the merchandise but bargain for all things. The vendors seem to think you are a rich fool and dont fall for that nonsense about them giving you "a democratic price". Tell them you want a local, fair, Moroccan price. If not, walk away.
