You can get lost in there. Miles of corridors full of colours, smells, textures and noises, we used to just wander trying to take it all in.

Just like in the movies! A must see. Know that you must go here to have seen Marakech. Be careful like you would in any major city and don't be worried. Most people are very friendly and authentically want to help you find where you want to go. Pull out a map and you are surrounded. Accept help from store keepers who can't follow you after they have given you directions or as I saw happen often...foreigners asked our tour guide for help. We had a great time..and if you have time..it's okay to get a little lost in the souks!

great time. Souks are another world - were not bothered to buy, think having a guide did help in this respect, but we did go another time on our own and were not bothered to by. Local people are very polite.

Great One-time experience. I am not a "shopper" so my interest in the Souks was almost totally cultural and historical. On those levels it was really fun. We looked hard and never found a "Made in China" mark on anything that was for sale;-)

Old Town Souk.. First went to the souk in the late morning and stayed around for lunch in a'locals'ryad.(good tasty freshly made tagine or couscous) stall holders were friendly but not pushy--they loved you having a go at haggling and were not offended if you didn't buy.(you know when your price is too low because they stop haggling!)Stay calm and cheerfully friendly and if you really aren't interested just smile and keep walking to see 'something further on'.The constant barrage of 'Come and see my shop' or 'Just look,best prices ,no hassle' can be wearing but don't make eye contact unless you are interested.They just want to make a living like the rest of us.About a third of the original asking price is about right and if you change your mind just say 'thanks,I'll think about it, bye' .Don't get ratty!.It's not important.Try the warm almond macaroons(5-10 DM) they are wonderful and always fresh.Went in the evening for dinner and found a lovely old ryad with a hotel above ,in an ancient building with a dip pool in the middle of the restaurant.good food and very reasonable priced. The market in the evening takes on a different feel. Keep your valuables close to your heart, not your back pocket,and don't take out money until you want to pay

Worth the hassle. Wander a while down the souk alleys and soak in the atmosphere. Don't worry about getting lost, just allow time to find your way. Stallholders are certainly assertive but not aggressive if you keep your cool and smile. If you do want to buy something, don't show too much enthusiasm or the price will shoot up! (pay under half the first amount quoted). If you don't like haggling, go to Ensemble Artisanal instead of the souk - the prices are all displayed there. Useful phrases to stop you being pestered = "Non, merci" or "La, shukran" = No, thank you.

The hustle and bustle will drive calmer souls a little crazy, but it's good for you!. The souk is the beating heart at the centre of Marrakech trade and you simply cannot come to Marrakech without visiting it. It is crazy, it is hectic, in the peak of summer it is cripplingly hot, it is dusty, smelly and you run the risk of getting run over by a scooter, a donkey or just the other tourists. In brief it is an assault on your senses in every way imaginable!At every turn you will find somebody offering to be your unofficial guide, they earn a commission from any purchases you make and may well persuasively request a tip too, just remember they are only trying to eek out a living and feed their families. A firm "no, thank you" sends them on their way. If you are not confident about this arrange an official guide with your accommodation and they will keep the others at bay.You will need to be keen on haggling, the Moroccans selling here thrive on the banter and will come up with a ridiculous initial price, divide it by ten and start from there and be clear in what you are willing to pay in your own mind. Walk away if you cannot get there! What you will find is a treasure trove of handmade crafts from skilled artisans, from leather and textile, woodwork, metalwork, ceramics and jewellery. Items that cost a fraction of the price compared with what you would pay back home. Quality varies so inspect your prospective purchase thoroughly.Brace yourself and get stuck in!

Don't get lost in the maze!. While you will see the same items over and over again, it is still a great place to get some unusual items. Just do not take the initial price at face value - YOU MUST HAGGLE. You will usually pay half the first price given. But if you give an offer, you have started the process, and you will be buying, and it is just up to how well you can bargain.

Must visit. One of a must visit places. If you havent visit souk you havent seen marrakesh. Absolutely amazing expierence. No map needed, you will get lost with it so follow your instinct and discover spirit of marrakesh yourself.

Mad! Aggressive shop keepers!. Interesting experience, not for me, they just don't leave you alone, then they get aggressive when you say no! Or you have someone being nice to you and walking with you then they want paying!!! Couldn't wait to get out and would not go again and would not recommend.

Have to go - at least once. Amazing place - hard to explain. Just off Jemaa El Fna square. Everything is for sale. Be prepared to haggle and be accosted every metre of your walk through. Good fun if you accept the spirit of the place. If you don't like be hassled stay away ! Street food is good - you can see it being cooked ... never can tell with restaurants what goes on behind the scene. Stewed snails a speciality. Craft ware, leather ware and ceramics abound - best price is up to you. Haggle and see what you can achive - enough english spoken but french does help

cheaper than jemaa el fena. worth walking through the souks... you find absolutely anything you could possibly think of. Prices are cheaper in the souks than the stalls around jemaa el fena. A price for a scarf in jema el fena was 150 dh compared to 30 dh in the souks. And thats just one example. Impossible to not get lost but worth it!
Beautiful place. I loved the colour and smells of all the spices. I especially enjoyed haggling over price :) Such a large space with so much to see.

Busy! Busy! Busy! An Experience!. You need to visit the souks even if its just once. Very busy, lots of hassle, loads of colour, noisy but vibrant! Wear trainers definitely not flip flops! Look where you are walking lots of drains, very uneven slabs and dozens of bikes - take care but enjoy!

Super Souks. A real eye opener! kilometers of tight alleys packed with shops, workshops, artisans, you name it! Watch out for mopeds, motorbikes and bikes which zip through all of the time. A great opportunity to slip back in time. No fixed price here, all is to be bartered for!

Marakech souk. It is open market,with a lots of thing to see from local craft to local cuisine,You can watch snake charmers in the market,and a lot of interesting things to watch,the locals are friendly,
Haggle. Be prepared to barter! There are a lot of people touting for your business. If you get out your map in the area, someone will try to help you but will then expect to be paid for that help.

Must see :). I really enjoyed it. after egypt I fet that Marrocan people are much more polite & not so pushy :) Please try local Market Dried fruits, spices, Olives. The Jewellery & leather is amazing & so so cheap.

A colorful maze.... Worth a visit of course however lots of repetition with goods sold and non-stop come ons to buy. Don't take pics outright of people or their wares unless you expect to give coins or be berated somewhat. Liked the souks in Essaouira much more.

Better in the middle. You learn the art of looking straight ahead. Glimpse to the side even for a second and you get dragged in. The main thoroughafares can become human gridlock at times. At others, you dice with motor scooters or desperate and over aggressive salesmen peddling piles of tat. Venture deeper inside and the experience improves. There are ailes with genuinely lovely artisans minding an Aladdins cave of hand made treasures. Copper, iron, leather, skills and techniques you might have thought lost for 100 years on display. Men and boys in little caves shaping locks, lamps, belts, shoes, nails, everything that the medieval world needs from simple tools, keen eye and steady hand. Truly awe inspiring and heart wrenching at the same time.

Fascinating! Give money to beggars please.. An amazing rabbit warren of narrow alleyways. Just remember that unlike Western Europe, there is no social security net here, so give your spare coins to beggars please. They WILL be grateful for anything, and most readers will know this is one of the five Pillars of Islam. If you can also say, "Allah yah kha-leek" - God protect you- that's good too.

an experience. its an experience not to miss, yes its just another market selling tat and every other shop is the same, but its different. its like walking though a maze and getting lost is part of the experience. haggling is part of the experience also and they always give in to your price if you are persistant.

Lots of fun but be prepared to haggle!. We loved exploring the souks and haggling for presents. There's everything you could imagine... bags, shoes, kettles, lights, spices, jewellery.... It was good fun haggling with the sellers but you have to be clear and bold when you say no to ensure you get away. Have a browse to check you get a good quality product as there's some rubbish there too. Also be careful not to wander out of the tourist area, as you quickly become uncomfortable when lost amongst the locals.

Mental, but a must. No trip to Marrakech would be complete without a visit here. The place is crazy and prepare to be lost for an indefinite period! But the stuff on offer is awesome, tea sets, cushions, clothing, lanterns, tagines, instruments etc. If I had an empty suitcase I could have filled it happily here. However, you will need a stiff drink when you finish up. it's a serious assault on the senses!

Too much of the same. The souk is vastly overated. It reminded me of a Spanish street market, where each stall is repeated every 3 or 4 stalls. Great if you want to buy yellow slippers, nuts, dates or spices but the quality of the leather goods on offer was not very good.Too many people who try and befriend you to show you somewhere "for free" then you realise that they are all trying to scam you. As long as you don't stop, brouse are make eye contact with any of the stall holders you might get through but that does not make for a very enjoyable time.

Off-putting. Marrakech Souk – Off-putting.I was really looking forward to visiting Marrakech purely for the purpose of its famous souks, exchanged cash in anticipation and was prepared to go back home with all the useless things, which I didn’t need at all, like tagines, pashminas, lanterns, anything really which I thought would take my fancy. I’ve done my fair share of haggling and banter in Turkey, Tunisia and Egypt and really was not scared of chatting to shop and stall keepers, because it’s all about warm memories for me, feel-good-factor, not only bargain prices, there is nothing I was desperate to buy. Then it used to be great fun. This time it happened to be quite the opposite experience apart from two small but nice exceptions.We arrived in Medina fairly early in the morning, decided not to hire a guide and off we went on to our adventure bypassing snake charmers and monkey keepers on Jemaa el Fna. It was not that busy, we walked into a few shops, but reaction from shop assistants was most of the time indifferent, i.e they could not be bothered to even get up from their chairs, very strong vibe of unfriendliness in the air. If we started talking, information given to us was hardly trustworthy (their favourite trick - to prove that item was genuine, all of them liked to lit up a lighter and try and test with a fire leather or jewellery to prove that the item was genuine, not convincing at all), or if we got to a stage of haggling and did not agree on the price, shop assistants were getting abusive. Most of the shops were full of goods of very poor quality. Very quickly it was obvious that we were regarded nothing but walking cash dispensers or nuisance at best, I did not feel welcome at all, my enthusiasm has died very quickly as after a couple of incidents we really did not feel like walking into any of the shops. We walked into one Berber jewellery shop, looked around, did not see anything that we liked, were going to go away when a shop assistant took us to an underground floor in the shop opposite on the empty street. There was nothing there which we liked either and in less than a couple of minutes we went upstairs only to meet four men standing in the doorway.After that we were just wandering around when a young guy from a cosmetics’ shop started talking to us and invited us to test some of their creams. While he was telling us about argan oil I was admiring beautiful ceiling of an old building, it looked hundreds years old. On our way out when we thanked him, he gave me a handmade ceramic hard skin remover. I did not want to be rude and refuse to take it, so started searching for some change, but he categorically refused to take it. When we were just about to walk out from the souks area into somewhere unknown, a group of kids and a few men rushed to us indicating that it was not a good idea to do so and pointing out in direction of the souks area. They did not pester us or asked for money, they simply wanted to help.We also went on a trip to Ourika Valley, Atlas Mountains, but, frankly, had very similar experience as the first part of walking route was going through numerous shops and cafes with very similar ‘burning lighters’, shouting and generally rip-off attitude.Our last encounter on the same note was in the airport toilet. After having used it I simply wanted to be helpful and pointed out to a woman, who was standing by the doors pestering people for money and chatting to another woman, that there was no toilet paper there. You should have seen bloodthirsty glare in her eyes when she happily replied:”Finished”. I rest my case.Nowadays, back home, we can buy everything we want and need really, at the prices we like and can always go back if a problem occurs. I hope, those shop-keepers, who work in Medina, read reviews on TA and will realise that their hostility is not doing themselves a favour as not only it puts people off from spending their money, but also creates quite negative image. Economy is not brilliant wide-spread, but it does not mean that we all should become vultures.

Be wary of the leather goods!. The Souk is great to see, a must in fact but if you choose to purchase something, avoid the leather! The aroma of the souk hides a very big problem with the leather goods you can purchase, so be warned. We purchased a poof for my daughter and on returning to the UK realised it reeked of well poop to be polite.... you see how they tanner, so I should have expected this! It is impossible to have in the house and from my research on how to sort the problem out I find there are many forums about this issue (by the way you cannot sort this problem out apparently although I am still trying!).

Hectic and fun. The souks are definitely worth a visit and if you wonder a little further than normal you can find the real souks where the artisans are making all the products. Just remember to haggle to get the right price for that perfect gift.

You will get lost. You will be (almost) run over several times a day by mopeds, donkey carts, and full on high speed motorbikes.. Bartering was not fun. (I grew up in Yemen and Eqypt so I do understand the principle). You should generally expect to buy things for around half or a little bit more of the vendor'sstarting price, the starting price is always ridiculously high. There are some lovely shopkeepers- and I love the Moroccan people generally- but oh wow there are some nasty ones too. It can become exhausting and we gave up in the end and bought little. One particularly nasty scene was when my husband tried to buy a metal (not silver) water bottle holder. The vendor wanted 150 dirhams. My husband offered 60 dirhams. The vendor shouted at us all down the busy street "you bloody tourist you want something for nothing you insult me you insult my family" Wow- very unpleasant stuff. Or often the vendor will refuse your offer and then chase you down the street saying "ok,ok" which means you trudge back to his shop to buy it (after having talked yourself out of it by then. The streets are a maze of alleyways. The souk covers 19km I believe. You are guaranteed to get lost, and we met several very distressed Europeans who simply did not know where to go.  Please do not accept the "help" of the young boys on every alleyway- they will often send you in the wrong direction and/or demand money. Do ask a respectable looking shopkeeper. And of course take a map. the mosques can be helpful landmarks, but often cant be seen from within the high walls if the souk. We were helped several times by shopkeepers (we chose the friendly looking ones), and they were happy to help and didn't demand money. Marrakech souk was just not how I thought it would be. Both my husband and I were deeply disappointed - oh and if you are a cat lover, be prepared. Thousands of strays, a lot in bad shape. Everywhere.  We escaped on a day trip to the Atlas Mountains- and THAT was glorious, absolutely magical, and an absolute must do. But that's another story.

A wondrous place. I spent hours wandering the alleyways of the souks. The magic of the sights & sounds was something I waited a long time to experience. I heard a lot of complaints about being pestered by the shop-keepers but it really was not bad. Just politely say no thank you and walk away. After all, they are only trying to earn a living.

An experience not to be missed. Went to the souks with 3 friends. 2 of them were not sure but myself and other friend enjoyed the experience.Yes you have people trying to get you on to their stalls/shops but they were not annoying.We ate at one of the open air restaurants which was good food you do need to haggle on the price or order from the menu. We agreed to have a mixture of stuff brought to the table which was all lovely but they did try to overcharge for this. In the end i gave them what we thought the food was worth and they accepted it.It was fun bartering for the bits we wanted to buy.The bikes zooming around can be a little scary especially the ones without lights but again think it all adds to the fun and madness of the souks

Avoid!. This city is awful and so is the souk: dirty, polluted, dangerous, confusing with men harassing you at every turn. I can not wait to get out of here. The Moroccan countryside is much much nicer - avoid the big cities!

Get Lost. This is what you go to Marrakech for. Do your homework though. Work out what you are prepared to pay and try to better it. There are numerous Souks representing different trades, such as metalworkers, leather souk or the dyers souk. You will get lost but if all else fails head for the main square Jemaa el Fna, which is well signposted.

really good!. make sure you where sunglasses, and when agreeing a price they alway say something riduculas so cut them down by 3/4 of the price and then work up, always have a price in mind what you want to pay.only other problem is they really get on your nerves if your a woman, as the men i constantly following you and trying to get attention.

get lost !. no seriously, you will get lost. We did, there's always helpers, who will guide you towards the square and they tend to be young boys, who know english and expect 50 DAM reward for "rescuing" you. The stalls are in their thousands and who knows if one is better than the other. Soak up the atmosphere and just wonder around - make sure you've got eyes at the back of your head, due to bikes and motorbikes in midst of tourists and locals alike

Not as imagined. Having read the reviews I expected the souk to be an absolute nightmare with people locking me in shops and not being able to walk without getting hassled. The reality was much more enjoyable. Relax and go with it and you'll will enjoy the experience.
Souk. Get a guide and see much more than you might on your own. Easy to get lost but a fantastic place to visit and an absolute must!

Manic. the Marrakech Souk is an extremely busy place with stall holders all trying to get you to buy from them. It can be very over powering at first, but you soon get used to saying 'no thank you'. You can get some excellent bargains; however, be prepared to haggle as the stall holders will generally start at an exceptionally high price. I would recommend halving whatever price they say and work up from there. They all love a good haggle! There are so many different goods to buy. You just need to make sure that you have enough room in your suitcase to fit everything! The best time to go is in the morning when it is quieter. Towards late afternoon and evening it gets extremely busy.
The Souk of the Souks!!!!. We never saw a bigger Souk then in Marrakech! The Medina (old Town) is just one big Souk!! It takes hours, to see a part of the Souk!

Souk Tour. This was good so much to see a bit disturbing seeing so many v young kids working in not the best conditions. Make sure you have your camera but do be respectful as many do not want their picture taken

7 nights in Marrakech. Just returned from 7 nights in MarrakechWe were a mixed group of five well travelled immature 50 year olds. To be honest the more I read on TA the less I was looking forward to our first trip thereHere is a summary of our tripImmigration very slow, try and get to front of queueChanged money at the airport. decent rate and the more you change the better the rate is. Work out what you should get before exchange as queue can be long and service very quickOur Riad pick up was waiting for us. Its not easy to find these Riads so I would strongly suggest you get a pick up organized by hotel so that you get dropped off in correct place. They wont be able to drive to the door so there may be a 5-10 walk in if you are staying in the Medina so best to have driver walk to Raid with youBooked 3 nights at Raid. Fantastic, my full review is on T.A.Arrived quite late so had Moroccan banquet first night in Raid. Lots of food and mostly nice. Very disappointed in Tajine, little did I know!Sunday & MondayWalked into the souks, around spice market, shopping, shopping shopping stopping for coffees, drinks and snacks, Museum of Photography, into the Jewish quarter, around the square, the tombs and generally getting a feel of the place. Surprisingly I loved it, in fact we all loved itYes the traders try to get you into their shopsYes the touts will try and take you off to their brothers shopYes people will want to be your guideYes what ever you pay the taxi driver/guide will not be enough but hey.... that is the game.Welcome to Marrakech.You have a choice go with the flow and enjoy or fight against it and go madIn the Spice market we had a fella say "is it me you are looking for" and all ended up singing Lionel Richie together. He then charmingly led us into his shop where we willingly sat for 10 mins while he explained some of the mysteries away. There was no pressure to buy and most of us didn't. He enjoyed our company and vice versa. We left all smilingTaxi's we never negioated price just got in (like a local) We were told by our Riad owner 20D for small taxi and 50 for large was more than enough. Small taxi's only take 3 people. When we got out we gave 20 or 50D Every time they asked for more. Every time they got a pat on the back and a smile but no more money. This worked perfectly. If you dont want a guide say no and then ignore them they will soon get the messageIf you have nothing to do then go on an adventure with them, you will probably end up in a Berber shop or at the tanneries but you will have probably seen some new things on the way. May not cost you anything but maybe you part with 20D who cares. Keep plenty of small notes as they will not have changeWe ended up at the tanneries on one such adventure. You are given a bunch of mint on entering for the smell. Didnt really smell when we were there but pet goat was eager to eat my mint. I didnt find the tanneries very interesting as I was expecting to see colorful vats of dye but we were taken to the rooftop to get some great pictures. Then lead into a small Berber shop which looked difficult to escape from. By this time I was ready to leave so quickly praised the quality of the goods and the friendliness of the Moroccan people but sadly explained we were leaving the next day and had spent all of our money. He understood fully and we were quickly on our way with a smile and a pat on the backTuesdayHad driver/guide for the day £80 Five of us in big car but he turned out to be pretty useless and only interested in his mobile phoneTrip to Tues. Berber market. Mainly food and veg and house stuff for local people, not particularly interesting. Then into mountains where we had a guide (compulsory we were told!) for 100D wanted 200D. Led to small waterfall, not Niagra but quite enjoyed walk in fresh airThen taken to friends restaurant for "good food very cheap" it turned out to be a tourist trap 150D per head for the usual tajine etc. we decided to just a have a drink. They weren't happy, neither was our driver. On the way back we asked to stop at Berber market again and ate in "5 star Berber restaurant" in the back of market. Cost 70D with bread for 5 of us. was pipping hot and the best tajine we had while we were there. Driver not happy but hey....You will get hassled quite persistently in the market by men selling jewelry to support their 6 kids and family. Its cheap junk at high pricesWednesday and ThursdayEssaouria. Told if we want a driver who isn't drunk and a bus with brakes only use CTM. We did. 3 hours with toilet stop. Good comfortable rideStayed one night but would have been happy to chill out for 3 nights hereFridaySpent day wandering around Marrakech, shopping, getting lost, finding cafes chatting. Did Jardin Marjorelle. Compact, quite pleasant if you have an hour to spare. Would go early or late to avoid crowds. Had pretty average massage at Easy Spa in the Medina. Changed from 2 hours to 1 hour on arrival. 270D p.hSaturdayPlanned to go to La Mamounia but were told not smart enough to get in so went to Jewish cemertary. Hello on Saturday!Wandered around and just had our last taste of everything Moroccan before we left for the airport with a contented smiles on our faces planning our next trip. 2 night in Marrakech, 3 nights in Essaoura and then maybe go to FezWeather... Very lucky, fantastic the whole timePeople...Friendly as long as you dont try and photography them. Smile and have a joke with them they will love it. Even if they dont understand what you are staying they respond well to a smile and a jokeShopping...Get a feel of the prices and quality before you start to buy. Bargain hard if you want to buy. Everything I bought was made out of of various metals. I liked the bowls buckets etc.... The first bucket I bought "very old" 200D wobbly legs. Liked it so much I bought a second somewhere else 140D and much better quality. Small bowl asking around 400D bought for 70DEating... We all agreed most of the local food we had was tasteless, bland and often not hot. I did persevere with the Tajines and had 5 from markets, main square to high end restaurants. Where do they put all those spices, fruit and nuts we wanted to know as they were not in any food we had. Meat mostly tough and chewy. Pastries not too bad. Orange juice very good but watch no added waterRecommend...Cafe Arabe, Cafe Nero and Marrakech Dejeune had very good meals in allSleeping Marrakech....Riad Dar Dialkoum. Excellent, full review on T.AEssaouria.... La Grand Large. Cost nothing, great location, clean friendly, good brekkie on roof terraceWorst things.. Bland food. And if you are a animal lover some of the donkeys are hard to look at. I did yell at one guy beating his with a big stick, did nothing! I personally didnt like the Al Jemaa el Fna. It was good for a drink and people watching but all the food we had there was pretty tasteless and I found the crowds annoying. Hated the poor chained monkeys, some not treated well. My friend however loved the ambianceBest things.... interacting with locals. Had loads of fun in the Souks laughing and joking with the traders. Orange juice and Essaouria. Go and have fun

Look don't touch. It is quite safe even if you do get lost, but some traders will hassle you just because you have touched an item. If you try anything on they assume you will buy it. Just say window shopping, they all understand that.

Haggle or die.... You will get lost there!. It is a must, yea. But it is not all relaxing shopping....It can get on your nerves to be grabbed and talked to all the time, not being able to look at the things. You have to know what you want, to not being talked into buying crap.Yu can haggle down the prizes about 70 %. Don't worry if someone doesn't want to meet your prize. The next one will! And in the end they all sell the same.But as I said, tourist trap or not, it is a must!

Shop Til You Drop. Marrakech has the second best souks in Morocco. Fez is the best, but difficult to navigate without a guide. Start at the Djemaa el-fna plaza and wander off in any direction. Some of the guide books have walking routes, but we just meandered from one alley to the next. Yes, we got lost but we showed a shopkeeper our map and pointed to the plaza and he set us on the right route back.If you are traveling around Morocco you may want to do most of your shopping here or in Fez for the best prices and selection.

Get haggling!. The souks are great fun, even though they can be hard work as the shop owners are all trying to attract potential buyers' attention. We bought lots of lovely souvenirs and enjoyed wandering around the maze-like alleyways. Make sure you haggle as the opening price was at least double what we ended up paying and we probably could have got things even cheaper. Note - if anyone points you in the direction of the square or any other landmark there is a 90% chance it is in the opposite direction! As you aren't far from the Tanneries read those reviews (whether you want to visit them or not) as you need to get mega street smart to avoid having your trip tarnished by more intimidating scams than people sending you in the wrong direction!

Amazing everything. Turkish bazaars, KL Jalan Penang and Hoi An in Vietnam make way to my new favourite shopping destination of all time. Enjoy shopping for the genuine artisan leather and other goods. Find a shop keeper you like and only ask for a price if you like the item. Opening price is likely to be eye watering, but eventual transaction might take place at 25% of the asking price. Most sellers are super friendly and you might even get small freebies once the deal is closed. Don't say no to mint tea if offered after a purchase. The best conversation and tea we've had (in Morocco) was with Abdul in his small shop next to Marrakech Museum - even shop keepers from other stalls smelled the brew and asked for a glass! We also loved our experiences in two different spice/herb etc shops. Knowledgeable and friendly owners explained the different products to us. We left the shops very happy with heavy bags.

Chaotic!. Reminds me of the Grand Bazaar in Istanbul. Friendly vendors, never felt pressured or intimidated, and if you pay attention, you might just find something wonderful. Don't think twice, just have fun. Was there with my husband, and also ventured back on my own - never any trouble, or moment of worry. Enjoy! Tip, though - avoid anyone wanting to take you to the tanneries!

Amazing. The Souk was a site to behold and some what scary. Beggers galore and be careful not to get mowed down by donkeys and scooters, and the smell was aweful. Saying that the sites where amazing, how these people live like this I will never know but they are all happy and willing to help. The colours are vibrant and the work they put into their wares was amazing. Well worth a visit. Just be mindful that they are very different to us and take advantage to tourists. The place is VERY dirty and smelly, but if you can see pasted this you will see some great sites.

best to go with a guide. it's a bit chaotic and overwhelming, so we went with our guide, as we were travelling with our four children. good decision. also, do some research and try to decide what you would like to purchase in advance. be willing to bargain and enjoy!

Shop till you drop. Although a bit tacky when getting closer to Jemaa el Fna, true gems can be found in the various souks in the North-East side of the medina. Look for silverware and leather and prepare to negogiate hard. Asking prices generally mean nothing. Think 1/3 of the initial price as the end result when you start bargaining.

Women travelling without men be wary. I recently took my sister here for a holiday planned for a week (I'm 24 and she is 30). Having looked at all the great reviews about Marrakesh I was very excited. However we left after only 2 days as we were groped and sexually harassed by the local men about 10 times, and had only been walking to museums and around the souks for about 3 hours in total. I should also note that we were both extremely covered up (down to floor skirt, baggy t-shirt, cardigan and scarf wrapped around body as well), as we have lived in Muslims countries before and are respectful of their dress codes. The place itself is amazing, the food is great and the envirnment was beautiful. It was such a shame that it was ruined by explicit phrases being yelled at us, groups of men following us down alleyways and forcefully groping us. Apparently this is because white women (due to the media) are seen as 'loose' and if you are without a man you aren't anyone's 'property' and so are free game in their eyes. But, as I said it's a great place so either travel with a man or a guide as I have been told they will not touch you if you are accompanied.

Fantastic experience. The souks are miles of covered stalls in the Marrakech Medina (just north of the Jemaa El Fna square) and are an absolute assault on the senses. The colours are amazing and the assortment of beautiful craftsmanship is endless. One of the major problems is that there is just too much to take in and so much to see you do not actually seen any individual item - it gets lost - but perhaps that is just me.The sellers will hassle you but it is generally all harmless and friendly. You have to haggle to buy and you should not pay more than about 30-40% of the price they first ask for. If you cant get them low enough just politely walk away and they will chase you with a better price. Also try several stalls for the same thing as the prices can vary enormously.I normally hate shopping of any sort but the souks are an experience not to be missed. You cannot go to Mararkech without visiting them.

Flea market where even the fleas had run away. This place held something of a fantasy-like appeal based on what I had read and researched prior to visiting Marrakech, but on arrival, it was a murky, filthy cesspit where traders hassled tourists to part with their hard-won dirham.... i'm not even going into detail, but if there were any goods worth checking-out the environment prevented you from caring. Even the whirlwind-like evening "entertainments" failed to impress.... so I will leave it there. Just an awful place, Marrakech.

An positive assult on the senses.. The souks are a must see! There is every kind of craftsmanship at work here, and being able to see the goods on sale being made right opposite where they are sold is facinating. The Balcksmith's and Dyer's souk's are definitely worth a visit. There are some real bargins to be had here. Some of the stallholders can be a little pushy but as long you politely say 'no thankyou' and move on, there is no trouble.

Enchanting. The souks did not disappoint. Very lively and bustling but also very freindly and never once felt under pressure to buy - sellers were happy with an acknowledement and 'no thank you' if they approached. Such an interesting place, like nothing i've ever seen before.
The place to be!. This is the heart of Marrakech... please try the orange juice!Just wonder through the square and take in the atmosphere, it's is simply amazing.

Colourful but crazy. A visit should be taken with a local guide as the back streets are a maze. See the colours of the fabrics and the aroma of the food but be aware. My camera get damaged by a local who thought I was taking a picture of him (I wasn't).

Not as intimidating as feared.. The Souks were much easier to explore than I had thought; the sellers were not aggressive and there were clear overhead signs to help direct you to the Jemaa El Fna when you needed to exit. Lots of "stuff"; thanks to having Easyjet cabin baggage only managed to resist. Moped users in the Souks are a nuisance, but they are banned in the vey heart of them.
Venture to the edges. Great spot but the try and get out to the edges away from the tourist trinkets. Unlike Fez Souk easy enough to navigate without a guide.

like another world!. this place is full of colour noise and activity. you will certainly get lost but avoid letting the lads guide you they will take you round about demand money and if you dont give it them swear at you!dont let this detract from an a very exciting experience

Take a deep breath and enter.... Everything you've read about the Souks is true...It's a don't miss trip for people watching and some fun haggling. No matter what you want to buy I guess it's here - Spices, Perfumes, Bongos, Lizards, Trainers, Scarves, Handbags - of course none of the designer stuff is genuine but the kids were happy with their booty!Have in mind a price you want to pay, let the vendor give you a price and divide by three - hopefully the two figures are close then you begin to haggle. Don't insult them with silly prices but also be prepared to walk away - you'll be surprised how quickly deals can be resurrected
Wow. This is like an assault on the senses,noise colour smells but clear on what your looking for,think what it's true value is and never show weakness,very difficult but don't be warn down.

Fantastic. Whilst not everyone's cup of (mint) tea, we really enjoyed the souk, visiting many times during our stay.Initially we just roamed trusting our instincts to find our way out - although there are plenty of signs back to the main square. After a couple of times you do get your bearings and my teenage sons really enjoyed proving their knowledge.Most stall holders are respectful, and the haggling is all part if the fun.Do expect some odd smells, sights, and grubby feet (sandle wearers) or shoes. The best quality and prices are often a little off the beaten track - as with anywhere the cheapest is rarely the best buy.

Some souks are better than others. From my understanding the old city has lots of different souks/areas where sellers specialise in certain goods eg spice souks,woodwork souk, jewellery souk. All are interesting but the one that I would avoid is the leather /tanning area. we got hassled a lot there and taken on a tour that we didn't ask for - we were shown the "highlights" which included a bucket of pigeon crap- and then taken to a leather shop. When we didn't buy anything we were chased down and asked to pay a fee for the tour - it did get a bit nasty at the time. To be honest Id avoid the northern area of the old city.

Dont be daunted. Lots of men talk, and offer to guide you. Why not? Just be prepared for the uncles shop, cousin shop and a tip which is always too small according to the guide. After the first guide its easy to find your way around. Set the price you want to pay for goods in your head and walk away if you dont get it, the shop owners are better than most of us at haggling.Second tip is check the quality thoroughly of the one they decide to wrap for you.

Enjoy but beware. The first time we went with a local guide and enjoyed the experience. The second time was different, to say the least. I would advise those who want pictures on the large square with monkies, snakes, men dressed in old local costumes: DON'T!!! The hassle, fright and rip-off isn't worth it, once it comes down to making you pay through the nose. And let's be honest, why would you want pics with a monkey in a diaper and skirt and a snake coiled around your neck, showing you off as an ignorant yokel? We did some wonderful shopping, but I feel that was only possible because we had this guide with us. When we were three women by ourselves, we were regarded as fair game, although to be honest we were not touched or threatened in any way. Just cursed at. We quickly moved on, as far as possible, when we accosted birds of prey on display - they had this dead look in their eyes. Any tourist posing next to them is encouraging this cruelty towards animals going on. Maintaining this cultural heritage should not depend on practices like this.A practical warning: It had been raining the night before our second visit and the square was exceptionally dirty. Sturdy shoes/sneakers are an absolute must to start with, but especially then.

Eclectic junk. As if you didnt have enough junk in your home, the Souk will convice you that you need more. The myriad of alleyways leading for one zone to another is fascinating. Excellent Leather products if you are on the small size. They have never heard og XXL
Souk. Put your bargain at on and keep kids close at night don't touch if your not gonna buy at night it can be a bit scary its very very busy

Busy, Crazy, Colourful!. Marrakech souks are a maze within which you cannot help but get lost! Yes people hassle you for money, yes you have to haggle, yes some of the people call you funny names.... but yes it is well worth seeing! Hold you ground, have a smile on your face and be relaxed and you will enjoy it.

Hustle and bustle!!. It took a bit of getting used to being hassled by the vendors at every turn but if you said no there was no nasty retort just a smile.We loved the tiny streets.....took you right back to another world. It is a fascinating experience with lots of interesting things to look at......and buy.

If you can't find it, it doesn't exist!. What do you want? Handbag, scarf, spices, sheep's head? They have it all. Scarves, babouches, bread, sweets, pastries, cosmetics, argan oil, wrought iron gates. Don't be afraid to barter. It's an insult NOT to! Be prepared to walk away, there's always another nearby. You will get the price you want eventually!

Great. A must place to see. Don't pay too much for your souvenirs!! They want £££, you pay £. My advice is to get yourself lost for the hell of it and see where you end up. We came across a carboot sale in a carpark. We felt safe 100% of the time.

Busy and boisterous. As with many other Arab countries there many sights and sounds to be seen and heard in the Souk – cheaper than Aldi & Lidl being different from Asda price! Marrakech has plenty to offer there is the blacksmithing souk, where all manner of metalwork is undertaken, the leather souk where you can see slippers and handbags being made, then there is the shopping area for tourists, where bartering is de rigour, but be warned, even though we tried very hard to barter the prices down, there are very few if any bargins to be had?I would say enjoy it for what it is and barter hard if there is something you really want.

Very busy but good prices!. The souks in Marrakech are very busy and crowded, but very good to bargain. The prices are normally three times higher! So bargain. They always tell you ridiculous prices first. Act like you dont care and leave, and they will come behind you with your matching price lol.
SOUK POUK. out of the High season there are some great deals to be had They want to haggle so go in low and start to walk1 hour is all you need is the same stuff in every shop

overwhelmed,. I can never quite get over the sheer level of artisanal skill in Morocco - and in Marrakech Souk they are all on display! Of course there's a hassle factor - but it's relatively mild - especially if you adopt a polite and consistent "I'm just looking" policy for the first few days. Everything from beautiful leatherware to rugs to beaten and hand cut lampshades - I'm not so keen on the rows of shoes, the junk trinkets and and the cheap end of the fabrics on sale but if you've an eye for genuine craftsmanship and real quality you can find it there. A few things to watch out for - first day there we were very politely invited into a Riad that was a treasure trove of Moroccan antiquities - we still can't quite work out what the place was - We weren't hassled to buy or to pay but we were let out via a different exit to the one we came in by and through a very big carpet warehouse - We were given a very sophisitcated hard sell - asking prices that were well in excess of the kind of money you would pay in Europe, and told we couldn't leave until we bought a rug - don't ever be intimidated by this kind of treatment - be polite and walk away - we've spent a fair bit of time in Morocco back in the 80's and this seemed to be a step back to that era! Another little tip about carpet prices - when we finally did buy - in the big carpet souk on the place des epices we stumbled on a shop that started at "Moroccan" prices - all their carpets were actually marked with another price - around 5 or six times higher which was the price they quoted when people arrived with guides - we still knocked to Moroccan prices down a little and ended up with a real bargain - but it's worth knowing that guides may well cost you dear!
Exciting and atmospheric. full of wonderful smells, hustle and bustle of life. A place to explore or just sit at the side lines over a cup of coffee and watch the world unfold before your very eyes.

different world. We loved this place, so different. Quite mad but a must see. shopping food, people places all different and the people selling try their best to make you come and buy by making you laugh, a good start.

Lots of closed shop fronts but good haggling. Had been looking forward to entering the vast mazes of shops which had been recommended by friends who had visited previously in August time. However, in February, it seems that many of the side areas are not open and you are faced with dark alleyways of closed shutters, which can get very disorientating and a little nerve tingling in the dark. What shops were open had a range of goods from the usual tourist camels, to bags and fabrics and many of the shop owners were prepared to haggle. In general, if you half the price they start with and then rise a little then you will get your goods. Do not be afraid to walk away, and if they really want to sell it they will actually chase after you ! Most of the sellers were friendly, although there were a few who were rude and some can be a bit pushy - just be firm and carry on walking.Good bargains to be had and just a shame there werent more shops open.

Souks suck!. Constant assault from hawkers trying to get you into their stalls, merchandise quality that's unreliable at best, prices that are on par with the civilized world and a system of haggling that only benefits those with oodles of time on their hands. What does it all add up to?A place and time that's long been dead and should be avoided at all costs!

Ethic, Hectic & Definitely Charming. The Souks were Crowded & mostly offered the same wares, many local leather slippers, wood carved boxes & trinkets, Plates & metal work.There were tons of replica Designer goods, including Hand-bags of all makes, Size & models, Sunglasses etc. but that’s really not my "Thing", but suffice you giving a mere glance at a stall & you may be in for a long tedious haul, in which the vendors are begging you to part with your Dirham & you’d find it hard to get away.My Hosts at the Riad Dar Charkia Recommended that if there was anything I wanted to buy then I should start bargaining at 60%-70% less than their asking price which I did.Overall, I think this is how the Moroccans make their living, you can fill in a fun afternoon or two if you like that sort of thing

Help I am lost!!!. Seemed to be full off traders who wanted to rip you off. Very intimidating, and not for the feint hearted, we were with a guide and still got taken for a ride. Still would not have missed the experience.

Be careful!. Amazing experience, to wind in and out of the souks. Definitely something everyone should experience. Be careful, and only take the amount of money you want to spend. There are pickpockets (first 3 minutes arriving in the Souks we saw this happen) so just keep everything close and you'll be fine.

Tourist and local. Some people will love the cramped streets, the local exotic flavor of fish and meat for sale on the ground. But go there for the experience and for the opportunity to buy leather goods, woodwork, argan oil etc.

'Come and look at my stall'. I was visiting Marakech alone, and ended up spending lots of time wandering round the souk. Instead of seeing sales approaches as hassle, I used them as an opportunity to talk to Moroccans and learn about their culture and produce. Two traders shared tea with me, without any pressure to buy. It's an example of how a change of attitude can change the experience!

Hassle everywhere... but this is Marrakech!. Yes you get hassled in the Souk by people trying to get you to buy their goods. It can get pushy and in your face at every turn, but people must understand that this is the way things are in Marrakech and much of the Arabic world. If you really do not like this kind of thing then Marrakech is probably not the best destination choice for you. If you want to visit but are a little nervous, it is probably best to hire a guide who knows their way around - we managed to get one by asking the staff at our riad.It can be very off-putting when you just want to browse something on a stall, but if the salesman gets pushy just say a firm no thank you or explain that you are just looking for now. If they keep getting pushy then walk away - I'm sure what they are selling will be at another stall further on. When buying something, make sure you barter a price and if you are still not happy then politely decline and leave. Some may still try and barter with you as you leave - carry on bartering if you want, or just continue to walk away.I personally thought going to the Souk was a good but slightly intense experience - the sights, sounds and smells are a complete attack on the senses and it can be very off-putting when you have so many people trying to get you to buy their goods - but overall I enjoyed my experience. Be prepared for a bit of chaos, be firm but polite, don't make too much eye contact if you aren't interested in buying anything and barter barter barter!!
Like nothing else. The noise and amount of merchandise is unbelievable. The constant harrassment from traders is very offputting.

Good Rug-buying Experience. The souk is (of course) chaotic, and some of the salespeople are a bit high-pressure. We tried four rug shops but found the easiest to deal with was Al Matjar at 26 Souk seramarine in the carpet souk. For attractive rugs at very reasonable prices in a friendly and civilised atmosphere, this is the shop we'd recommend. The salesperson listened to what we had to say about colour, size and style, he had a good range and was patient with us. The rugs are individually priced, but when it came time to bargain, we were immediately offered less than half on the tag - after that it's up to you!

Real Marrakech. No better way to experience life in Marrakech than the gauntlet of the souks. Wander through and look at the different stalls. Yes, you will get pestered to come and look at a stall but politely say no thank you and carry on. Give bartering ago and if you don't like the price, walk away - there are plenty more of the same shops around the corner waiting for your custom.

Marrakech souk. Some good and bad experiences had here. The sights, smells and colours were fantastic but can be one big hassle if you don't take heed. I am sure the story will be the same on most reviews, don't get taken in, if you are the friendly type try and think twice about who you are talking to....otherwise you will believe every other man there 'works at your hotel, don't you recognise him!' I loved the sights but had a horrible experience with girls doing henna, to the extent my daughter was physically pushed, which completely spoilt her and her husbands experience of the market. Had a wonderful meal at the Kasbar restaurant and cafe des epices. If you get the chance to go to a traditional hammam do it! I am very glad I have experienced Marrakech but its 'a seen it done it got the t-shirt' kind of place and I know that bartering is a way of life for Arab nations but I am sure they would sell more if it wasn't such a hassle.

Friendly Kind Sellers. Yes, it's a bit touristy but its fun! Barter, Barter, Barter! You have to really look to find quality goods, great for gifts, little bags, rings shisha pipes, they sellers were very nice and loved a chat!

Too much aggressive sales. Souq life isn't for me, I like to browse then decide not be pulled into shops and harassed About the ' very good price' on something I don't want! Many con men about saying a price that's 100x what it's worth! I really didn't enjoy it and wouldn't recommend it to women travelling alone or without a man ( I hate to say this as I often travel alone but morroco is still in the dark ages when it comes to equal opportunities!)Beware of people taking you to the 'leather market' we got directed to the tanneries and I was nearly sick in the street due to the smell and sights! Awful! There are some true artisans in there but I preferred the set price shops and workshops!

Be warned over rated!. We recently cut short our visit to Marrakech! The Souk was over rated, they only appear to be ripping you off. Not to be trusted at all, make no eye contact with them and communicate as little as possible. You are not left alone for a minute. This relates to the Souk and the square but be careful where ever you go in Marrakech. We even had people approach us on their bikes to guide us for money.It was not a place you could afford to relax in at all. One of safest place to go was the Artisan Centre in the West near the City wall. DON'T take directions of anyone other than your Hotel and shop keepers. We were lead off through the back streets towards the The Tannerys by a guy who said he definitely wasn't a guide only to find that he was then on his phone and more men appeared. It was an awful experience. My husband is well travelled visiting Many parts of China ans the South East and has never experienced anything like the scale of deception that these people use.
Souk delight. I am sure everyone knows about the Souk. It is full of goods and sellers wanting to sell them. It is atmospheric, cool when it is hot and a must do when visiting Marrakech.

Hits all of the senses. Great experience. Don't be scared. However, don't follow anyone to their uncles, cousins shop etc. Don't listen to directions from anyone especially kids as they try to direct you back towards the centre. Road closed is a popular phrase.If you get totally lost and can't get out pay a kid a fiver or so to lead you out - its worth it.

Chotsky heaven. Be prepared to get lost. But that is OK, the store owners will gladly tell you the way back to the main square (Djemma el Fna). Just don't accept help from the arrogant local teens waiting to find the lost tourist to help so as to "earn" a few dirham. You will be verbally accosted innumerable times to check out the wares in a particular nook. But they are polite. It just gets tiring. Lots of stuff to look at, little to really purchase unless you like colorful stuff of dubious quality. Helps to have good garage sale negotiating skills. Never never pay the first price stated. It is a must do experience here but it will sap your energy and you will get lost. Just DO NOT feel you need to pay to be shown the way out.

Manic Marketing. Everything you've heard about Arab markets plus more! Peristant shopkeepers try to tempt you into their shops - "just for looking, no buying" - but then proceed to try to sell you all sorts of stuff you never knew you wanted. Don't be put off - a firm Non Merci of a ludicrously low opening offer in the haggle usually puts them off! Turn a corner and you;re in an area used mainly by locals - less frenetic and less pressure. Personally we always feel that the presence of an ironmongers suggest you're in a "locals" market

Magnificent Marrakech. Marrakech is a magnificent place to get away for an extended weekend. We where there on a Saturday night during the school holidays. There was an abundance of people both buying and selling goods. The atmosphere was brilliant, lively and colourful. The only place we where hassled was near the food vendors otherwise we where left alone to browse down the various back streets. Thoroughly enjoyed it although like many others, it is very easy to get lost!

Nice to see. This place is strange on one side you see colours perfume that you will remember all your life. But on the other side you will be accosted by locals to visit shop or will guide you in the souk to get money. They could be quiet invasive. But going to Marrakesh without visiting the souk is missing this charm.
Spooky. Like other souks, too many dark allies and too much hassling. Keep you bags closed and your money tucked away safely. If you never been its quite an experience.
Pretty Cool Visually. Though we didn't buy anything, we walked through the souk with a guide and it was visually very interesting. We weren't pressured to buy anything since we were with a guide.

Haggle. Haggling is a must in the souks. They will start at a stupidly high price and it's up to you to decide what you are willing to pay for what ever it is that you want. The store holders are very pleasant and some can be very persistant but it's not realy a problem.

Day trip to Marrakech. First off,I have to confess, that I was on a one day excursion to Marrakech, so obviously didn't see all it has to offer. However, what I did see in company with a guide, who no doubt, took us to anything worth seeing, during our 12 hour tour.?Possibly, I arrived with romantic or exotic visions, from tales of yester year? Anyway, for me it was a great disappointment. The so called famous square, was nothing more than a mish-mash of various stalls, selling items, which in most cases, you wouldn't give house room to. The square, plus the Souk, although bustling,and loud, also had a feel of decay. Buildings were in state of disrepair, pealing paint, crumbling walls. The people sat around the winding lanes of Souk in a state of malaise, or indifference. A few groups of men sat around with couple of snakes lying on ground, exotic? hardly. We also called at Bahia Palace, again just ok for me, the Alhambra Palace in Granada, was way above in class. Taken to a lovely restaurant, which was once a palace, of former prince or whatever. Beautiful place, pity the food didn't compare. Eight people at our table, all of them left meal half eaten.Reading back over this review, I appear to be a right miserable nark, lol I assure you that's not the case, I was just, very very disappointed, with Marrakech. I had come to Morocco, and thought you can't come here and not do Marrakech. Well you can! Passing through Agidir back to ship, I wished I had just stayed and explored this area.Again I realise a day trip may not be best, to give a true review of a place. Just be aware, that it's neither romantic or exotic.

Bargaining at its peak. It was fun to shop at the souk in the market square of Jma el Fna. English speaking shop keepers were a rip off. Try and buy from a Berber as they are lot cheaper. Given price of 450 dirhams for a pair of sandals and later bought the same for 120 at a different shop. Dont feel shy at naming your price. Look around before you put your price as sometimes people do get offended if you look at it, try it and then later leave it. Must try the almond bars made with Honey/caramel and the lovely grounded almond biscuits/sweets. Mmmmm

"Looking is for free". If you like to go shopping, and if you know how to bargain, this is the place for you. Keep in mind you need time, and some money. It's a wise thing to go see the Ensemble artisanal and look at the fixed prices there to get an idea of what you should pay for the different items before you go in to the souks. And remember that you should never pay more than what it costs in the Ensemble artisanal, preferably less then what it costs there, when you go shopping in the souks.And when that's said, enjoy, it is a fun place to be!

Souks. Was a bit nervous to go on our own so went with a guide . Once there we were fine . Obviously some hustle and bustle and a bit of culture shock , but would of returned on our own and felt safe .

Go with a guide to the Central Souks. After trying to find our way in the Souks near Jemaa el Fna on our own, Hubby got fed up with being hassled and gave up, so I asked our Riad hostess to take me to where she shops. We went to the Central Souks, which were quieter and less hassled than the others, especially the specialist ones. Even though she knew the sellers we visited, they still tried to rip me off ad I had to haggle, walking away from one selling scarves in the Dyers Souk. However, I did get some good pottery but probably paid too much for the spices, however it was a nice shopping experience.We stopped at a kiosk to take lunch back to Hubby, some kebabs in flatbreads and tajine, which was all delicious and cost a ridiculous 45Dh (£3.50) for 3 of us!Go with a guide for the best way to see the Souks.
The Souk. Want to check your bargain talent? That's the place; cut all prices in 3 to obtain max 1/2 of the requested price.

Not for the faint-hearted!. Having had a guided tour at the start of the holiday I decided to return on my own for a spot of souvenir -hunting. I found the people very friendly and helpful, especially when I needed the W.C.! I loved watching the artisans making silverware and ceramics and also visited a pharmacy where you could buy Argan Oil and other herbs and spices.

Everthing you expect it to be. amazing array of shops..you get the authentic ones and fakes too - the shop keepers will test your bargaining skills to the limit, but they will let you go, if you don't match their sale price and wont pester...but there are lots of "fake" branded items as well.. but they don't pass it you to as original, a fake Loui Vutton bag would cost you about 150 MAD and Rayban @ 50 MAD

If you can cope with this, you can cope with anything!. Haggle, barter and barter again, again, again. Just like ebay really. You need to know approximately how much things cost before you enter the Souks and of course how much you are prepared to pay. Please be aware of the shop Maison Du Caftan. They tried to pass off damaged goods to me and when alterations were promised on a garment which I purchased I had to wait in the shop for two hours. All garments were wrapped for me before I arrived to collect my garments, I duly opened the wrapped garments only to found damaged clothing, stained clothing, two items were not wearable as there were damaged beyond repair. Please, please keep clear of this shop.
Bring out the money!. Very nice and diverse if you compare to other cities in the country. Take home a nice tajine, a lamp or some spices. Do however bargain down to 20 percent of what they ask.
Anything and Everything. Good place to find bargains if you can stand the haggling.... so many little shops, very interesting experience not to be missed.

welcome to a new world. it's an awesome experience for who has never been to a muslim country! a journey of colors, flavours, smell..and all your sense. I recommend you to be zen and curious, and to stop to one of those hidden the shop in the souk.

Shop till you drop!. We love getting lost in the souk, and we love shopping there. it's good to read a good guide book about haggling, don't pay a price you wouldn't dream of paying at home, and don't get too mean about it if you're a good haggler - merchants need to make a living. There are some lovely bits of the souk where you can visit the old 'foundouks', also known as 'caravanserai'. They are apartments built around a large open courtyard with verandas, where the travelling tradesmen would stay and sell their wares. Some still have huge weighing scales in them! Things I've been very happy to buy for excellent prices recently include leather messenger bags, rucksacks and briefcases; ornately pierced brass and tin lamps; fabrics in stunning striped colours; pottery; clothes; and paintings by Moroccan artists. You'll get a lot of people trying to entice you into their shops or stalls, and everyone wants to sell to you of course - be good-humoured, have a laugh, and carry on your way if you don't want to go in. Above all, just relax and enjoy it!

Wonderful Souks!. Shopping paradise! So much fun to wander around the various souks... chat with the sellers and find yourself a treasure! Get lost... drink some tea... throw in a few words of Arabic and let the bartering begin!

Not for animal lovers!. Although Im glad I visited the Souk it wasn't an entirely pleasant experience. Apart from being quite dirty we got hassled to the point where we didn't want to stop and look at anything and as an animal lover it was quite disturbing seeing various no-cage animals in cages! Animal welfare doesn't seem to be high on the list of priorities in Morocco but if you can overlook this it is an experience that shouldn't be missed if you want to see the real Morocco.
Bewildering but fascinating. We visited less touristy areas with a guide which were fascinating and picked up some good bargains (with the help of the guide doing the haggling!)

Best time of my life. This experience is not to be missed, the culture, food, smell, hustle and bustle and the entertainment is top notch! Go to the cafe in the far right corner of the square if you can as they have the best seats to people watch and take the atmosphere in!
Same old, same old. Just go there (you should see it for a few minutes). They are selling the same stuff in every shop and probably the same they've been selling foor decades (to tourists).

Overwhelming - a great experience but be prepared. wow, a complete maze of souks selling everything you could possibly want. What became a bit tiresome though was that you couldn't simply browse because as soon as you showed any interest in anything, you were just accosted by the stall holders. We ended up not really dwelling long, which was a shame as it was a fascinating place with lovely items. We would have spent more time and money if we had been left alone

Great fun noisy and colourful. Noisy, busy and wonderful fun if you are sensible. Travelling in a group of 3 women, no guide, felt completely safe. People very friendly. Good bargains to be had if you are willing to haggle

Colourful bazaars. Set in winding alleys/streets off of the Jeema El Fna are an astonishing amount of souks and bazaars selling almost everything you could think of; carpets, rugs, scarves, herbs and potions, silverware, lanterns, handbags and pointy slippers. Sadly also livestock and baby tortoises. Very colourful - just wished vendors allowed you to browse without the hard sell.
You cant not do this.. Do it with a local guide that way you can relax and take it all in. We felt safe but the sales pitch was stronger away fron the Square.
What fun. Hustle and bustle, bartering, enormous change since I was here, 20 years ago. Very enjoyable as long as you have your head on the right way!
Prepare to haggle. Loved the attitude of the stall holders, they want to sell you what they have even if you don't want it and you must then haggle. Be stern but not rude.

A labyrinth complete with full sensory overload. This is a must do when in Marrakesh. If you're brave enough battle it on your own and chance your luck not to get lost in the midst of what is essentially a rabbit warren then take your chances. Recommend you remember markers along your route or you may well find yourself paying someone to help you get back to the square. Otherwise get yourself a guide who'll help you navigate through the many twists and turns of what is an outstanding experience. Sure the guide will take you to the places they want you to see and where they'd prefer you spend your money, but you'll see so many interesting things along the way and be hassled a lot less that it doesn't really matter. This place lights up all your senses and is an outstanding experience. Keep your wits about you while walking along though as you can and will encounter all modes of transport from bicycles, donkeys with carts attached to motorbikes travelling long the very narrow lanes of the souk. If you're taking children, make sure to keep a very tight grip and eye on them as it's very easy to get lost. Totally enjoyed our time here and would recommend a visit to anyone.

Be confident, try to relax, but be on the edge of the square before it gets dark!!. You have to visit the Souk, its mad, busy, noisy, confusing, but great!!.Some really good advice from other reviews, follow all of that. My top tip, get to the edge before it gets really dark, then relax and enjoy the sights and sounds, inc a shake charmer the day we went!!We caught a horse and carriage back to the hotel, it was a great way to end the day and was cheaper than a taxi!! If your wife/partner has blonde or even light coloured hair beware the local gents who will be drawn to her and will make her and you wary. I suggest covering her hair with a hat/scarf or (bit more drastic) dying a darker colour just for the trip to morocco?!One of my fellow travelers was a blonde lady who was sick of the attention within a couple of days.

Got screwed....LOL. Beware, dangerous place.Ignore talking to the locals, they will take you in the middle of the labyrinth and you won't have any alternative but to buy something and give a good tip to be brought back to the Jemaa. el-Fnaa square. Got screwed again when I bought lamps from the ferblantier market. I guess that's all part of the local experience.

A buyers paradise. The nest time I visit Marrakech I will bring an empty suitcase. the colours, noises and smells was both appealing and intrusive at the same time. Someone needs to address the issue of the the motorcycles, donkeys cars, tuktuk etc who thought they had the right of way in the narrowest streets of the souk. This was nerve wracking at times but added to the experience
Never be scared. People want to be helpful- it's a shoppers paradise. Just accept what you're getting into and go with the flow- it's worth it.

Haggle!. Loved the winding streets,but it did get tiring saying no thanks constantly. It's a shame you can't have more fix priced shops because sometimes you just want to look without the hassle and time spent getting away, you have to be firm. You will get offered to be shown the way back to the square, be careful they can side track you to tanneries, carpet shop etc, just keep saying no if you don't want to.

A labyrinth of discoveries!. We visited the souks on three occasions. It was easy to get lost at first but it got easier each time. The sights, buzz of merchants, the sounds, and smells, are spellbinding! Baragain hard! The shops are ready for you. I started at about a 1/3 of asking and was happy to settle for half.

An experience. The alleys of the souks are fascinating with so many things to see. Walk through them for a while. However, they are full with tourists and people living on tourists. Be careful if you want to buy anything and avoid people that want to show you the way. The streets of the iron workers are particularly fascinating to see. More genuine markets can be found outside of the wall near Bab Khemis.

walk on the right. a must visit at least once, very lively place to shop, you can haggle loads here. i got a large leather satchel for about £38 pounds. Take your time, instead of saying no thank you all the time try saying maybe later. All the stall holders speak very good english, try going into some of the shops you can,t see many sell a huge variety of leather wood lanterns silver and clothing including the leather slippers.

very touristy prices. they are too aggressive in selling products, sometimes they grab your arm and won't let go, very annoying. prices are MUCH MUCH HIGHER than other towns even after bargains, i found out as i visited Fez and Essaouira later on. my advice'd be don't buy anything yet until you get to other town, their prices can be almost half even before bargains. don't worry, you can find similar stuff in every town.

Worse than a maze!. Bit of a mixed review here.Well, I think our experience here was downed by the sheer fact we got lost! I recommend when anyone goes it is worth paying a guide, but only from recommended source or your hotel, as the guides around the medina can screw you over and con you, as I found out. My wife got so nervous I ended up getting done for 250 DH for a guide in the souks to show us the way out!Don't get me wrong, there are some people around the souks that showed me around for free, but when I really needed to be shown the way I found everyone wanted money.The souk owners seem very friendly and want to show you there wears, but don't except their prices, haggle haggle and haggle again.

Mad - But Must Be Done. From one of many entrances the Souks are a must do in Marrakech. We had a unique & fantastic time getting lost in the labarith of shops. My words of wisdom are -1 Do not be afraid to walk away.2 Don't be afraid to be blunt and use the word NO firmly.3 If someone offers to show you the way, they are probably directing you to their mates shop.4 Try not to look lost (even though you will be) & put on a confident poker face5 Decide what you want to pay for an item before negotiating6 EMBRACE THE MADNESS

Exploring the Souk. We were just two couples and a compass. Most of our party enjoyed bartering with the traders and although we thought we did ok we suspect the traders did better. Very enjoyable experience, we were there on a Friday.

You won't see anything like this anywhere else! . The souks are just outside the jemaa el fna and are a must see! We went on a Sunday and explored the souks and I can imagine when we went it was quieter than normal. There are shoes, bags, silverwear, scarves, leathers, trinkets, charms eveeywhere you look. It's incredibly beautiful, we took lots of photos and haggled with a few people down there, it truly was a pleasurable experience. Very friendly and beautiful place .

Quite an experience. Its quite daunting having to haggle for everything but after a couple of goes, it becomes fun! Start at a third of the price they ask for as starters and move up from there depending on how much you want the item. Laugh and smile a lot and you will get a great response and be ready to walk away - 9 times out of 10, they will come chasing you...good fun!!

Cheapest place for gifts/souvenirs- go early!. We visited the souk on our last day to buy some gifts and souvenirs. We went early at 11.30am and was nice and peacefull walking around. We didnt het hassled much, just a 'no thankyou' with a smile does the trick. It is very easy to get lost but thats part of the fun. Its split into sections- leather goods, wood, lamps etc. Be prepared to barter- i would say 50-70% off what they say to you at first. Be prepared though- as soon as u ask the price even if u are not sure if u want it- to haggle. We walked away many times and they chased us after and offered us the price we wanted. They are also very helpful in explaining everything to u which is nice. A little warning- we webt back later in the afternoon around 3pm, it was a little busier which was fine- but the sellers all appeared to be grumpier. In the moning most were happy to help and fine if you did not want to buy but by the afternoon the mood had changed- maybe under nore pressure if they were bot having a good days trade. Therefore to get best prices and have fun with happy sellers i recommend going in the morning!

Not for the faint hearted. We were really looking forward to the Medina and wanted to experience a unique atmosphere we had heard so much about. Unfortunately we found the atmosphere to be very odd, a bit of an uneasy atmosphere and not very friendly. The narrow streets were very intimidating and we thought and as seemed to be the pattern with this holiday we once again witnessed the disregard for animal welfare with a number of the mules and donkeys looking underfed and severely over worked and beaten and on this day we felt the full force of poor beggars a number of whom had open wounds and looked so malnourished we spent more of our time trying to provide for their needs. We have travelled to countries such as India and therefore we are not unused to sights.

Touristy Covered Markets. Although the Souks are mainly for the tourists, if you plan to buy something I have 2 recommendations.1. Go deep back into the souks where there aren't as many shoppers and no crowds. The shops here will be much less expensive.2. After finding what you want at the souks then ask someone where ever you are staying an alternative place you could purchase it to save a ton of money. We wanted to buy a camel hair medium sized carpet. In the souks we saw many people purchase one like what we wanted for a few hundred US dollars (and the prices started even higher). We found a more out of the way shop near the Bahia Palace where we got the same quality of work for a fraction of the cost.

Over rated ,,,. The souks of Marrakech ! You have to go with an open mind,,, there is good, bad and atrocious, the olive stalls are great, the central square can be fun ( snake charmers etc ) ,, but the souks,, ,,, let's put it this way, if you have been to other bazaars in turkey, Egypt, Asia then this is no different,,, other than the people are more aggressive to the point that it's not fun, it's intimidating ,,, sure you have to do it,, and for the uninitiated it's an experience,,, for others , get in , get what you want and get out,,, go to cafe France and enjoy the view !

Intimidating. As we disembarked out hotel mini bus we were surrounded by 'official ' tour guides who expected payment to be shown which way to walk. As my partner is not very mobile at the moment we were sitting ducks for all wishing to make a quick buck. If you made eye contact with any of the stall holders they then expected you to buy something. After buying some fresh orange and some nuts from a couple of stalls we persevered towards the souk but began to felt uncomfortable, found a roof to cafe to have a drink and then returned to our hotel

Shop 'til you drop.
