We had a guide on our first visit, well worth it if you want to find particular items ~ rugs, lanterns etc. Abdul also did some hard haggling on our behalf which more than paid his fee! I thought the Grand Bazaar in Istanbul, and Chatuchak Market in Bangkok were about as crazy as you can get, but not in the same league as the Marrakech souks

Excellent Experience. The ship docked in Casablanca, so it was a 3hr trip to Marrakech, and well worth it.Passing through furtile country, and Shepherds tending their flocks, was a real treatWalking through the "Grand Souk" and trying just to view things and take it all in was quite an art, but the stall holders were quite ok when you said " no thanks". Out in the Huge Open Markert Square in the evening, was another storey, and had to be very aware of the entertainers.If you stood to view them, or tried to take a photo, you were surrounded, and needed to hand over cash for the "look & photo" before being allowed to move on !! You also had to be careful of them placing a Monkey on your shoulder for the same reason. The site and smell of it all, was something I will remember for quite some time, and would return if I could.

Must master the art of bargaining. So many things to buy but please bargain! We bought lamps and many other things but we heard that we could have gotten them at a better price. The staff at the shops are nice to banter with and most of them are warm and just want to make a living.

Absolutely!. First off, you cannot go to Marrakech without going to the souk at least once. Maybe once is enough for some, but at least once.My advice:1) Prices are cheaper the deeper you go in the souk;2) Start bargaining around 30% of the first given price;3) Don't start bargaining for anything you don't want to actually buy...4) Shopping is easier during the daytime, but the square in front of the souk is more enjoyable at night, when all of the performers come out;5) At night, a group of food stalls open in the square. There are men that will come and try to encourage you to eat at their stalls. We ended up doing it, and it was pretty good, but I would be happy never doing it again. Just walking through the area you will be bombarded with sales pitches, people will tug on your shirt, and stand in your way to prevent you from moving forward.6) Best advice for turning down an sale of something you don't want: don't say "no" (it's rude and not likely to work). Look the vendor in the eye and just say "shukran" (thank you). They will understand, and it takes any ill feeling out of the situation.

Test your sense of direction. The deeper you go inside the more aggressive the sell. You get to see lots of different objects divided by areas, steel workers, wood, leather, glass, etc the shops outside the souk closer to the main square are mostly expensive and fake fake. quality seems to be generally poor but haggling seems to be harsher than any other market i've been to. I was told by our guide to start with 10% of the price they quoted first.

Good for a visit not to buy. Its great full of energy colors ppl bikes. Things r very exp. Expect to pay more then the ARTISANA ENSEMBLE. Even when u discount 50per cent.Its a fun plc must see be happy get ripped off all part of being in Morocco. It is alive. What the hell lets contribute to the ppl. If we don't there may not be a Marrakech for our children and their children to experience.

Don't rush to buy! Take your time there!. Look, walk around, talk and only then buy! Its not cheap, its true, but I always look at this as a charity. Spices are amazing - you can find really good sellers! Just dont buy at the first place! Also, if you like Moroccan style things - it is your heaven! Beautiful things and colors!!!

Very scary, but different. I found the souks exhausting, got lost a few times, but that is part of the experience. Be prepared to be hassled by relatives taking you to families stalls, or offering to give you directions. We only had for days in Marrakech and had a full day in the mountains and saw palaces, tombs, museums and gardens so maybe if we had spent more time wandering around it would have been different. It really was an experience though.

Eclectic, MAD, wonderful!. Djema el Fina just needs to be experienced. No words can describe the transformation dt square gets from dusk to dawn. You must try the goathead and bread. If that's not for you, the square will definitely have something that will catch ur fancy - from wares being touted, to freshly cooked targine, to snails, to freshly squeezed orange juice. And if u really could not eat another drop, well just join the numerous acts performing and playing all sorts of music and dance the night away. Love it!
not great. 2 women and a child travelling! we got lost, followed, too many motor bikes and tasseling sellers, it was fine once we had a Marrocan friend with us and we managed to buy quite a lot.

Overpriced. Not sure if I looked like a sitting duck but the prices the vendors were throwing out for the poor quality things was ridiculous!!!!!! 100 euros for smelly shoes and 1600 euros for a bowl?!
The Real Marrakech. The atmosphere is unbelievable and a visit to the Souk is a must. This is the real Marrakech with everyone working so hard to sell you stuff.

labyrinth. I like shopping, as many women and this is the perfect place. Remember that you have to burgain everything , starting from one third of the amount they asked you . This will take you a lot of patience and time but it works.

Not Just for Tourists. There were plenty of tourists, day and night, but outnumbered by locals doing shopping or running their booths. The deeper we went into the Souk the finer quality of goods we found.

Lovely Place :). Excellent souk, bought a few keyrings and lovely bracelets. Their hand crafted items are exceptional. Felt like a kid in a sweet shop whilst walking through the Souks. However, they do tend to overprice items to tourist - I only went for products with price labels on them to avoid this. Haggle, haggle, haggle. Never settle for the first price which is normally 200% higher than the original price!

The Crowded Labyrinth That Is The Souk -. was the highlight of our trip to Marrakech. At first we were almost afraid to leave our riad convinced that we would never find it again but we steeled ourselves and set out. We actually took pictures of the corners where we turned and landmarks (handy to find your way back!). The souk looked impossible to navigate but we plunged in and were soon having a ball - sure we got lost but it all leads back out to the square. The shopkeepers are constantly trying to entice you into their shops but were always pleasant. A smile and "maybe later" was all it took to pass by comfortably. We actually returned to a few of the same shops and bought more. The bargaining was always done with goodwill and ended with "we're friends". The babouches, poufs, spices were fun to shop for and great bargains.
shopping heaven. oh my god - so much fun,, bargains everywhere stallholders were all very jokey and we felt so safe love those souks
fun. got to be done - take care if you want to buy to go to the Berber souk - cheaper and authentic as many things in main souk are from india!
The real life inMarrakech. It is impressive the artisan work from morocco people! The products are great, you will wish to bring a lot of products to your home!

bustling and fun. great to wander around but be careful to not point at everything unless you are considering buying. Try not to get bogged down by merchants trying to sell you things just walk through and soak up all the variety (and repetition!)

fantastic!. There's a lot going on--and a lot to buy--and if you're up for an adventure and a treasure hunt this is the place! This is not a souk for all kids but our kids love it and have never been bored.
love to haggle...... love shopping for Babouch and Spices .....haggling is fab :...was told I was a Berber many times....which means I like a hard bargain!

Enter another world.... From before: Better than NYC where I find it overwhelming already. Steel yourself for the constant pitching and polite "no thank you-ing" you will have to endure, but it's well worth your time to engage because this is an incredible place, full of lovely people. Wow. Can't wait to spend real time here.

Not worth the effort. Due to the sellers being sooooo pushy I did not enjoy the experience and in the end did not buy as much as I wanted as found it too stressful. Looks really pretty with all the colours and I normally enjoy a barta but not here!

Great shopping. We loved the souks... bargaining takes a bit of effort but is part of the cultural experience. Aim to pay about half the given starting price. Great place to buy leather,silver jewellery, woven cushions, traditional musical instruments etc. The stall holders can be very pushy and you do get a bit sick of being harassed so if you're not interested in buying best advice is to look straight ahead and don't engage. Good idea is to go to the artisans 'department store' near Kasbah mosque to get an idea of prices, then aim pay about 15% less than what you'd pay here. Enjoy!
Maybe worth a twirl but not much more. There are good value carpets if you look hard enough but overall isn't worth the effort - unless you want spices and knick knacks.
Colourful and Interesting. Everything you imagine a souk to be. Take your time and enjoy the haggling if you see anything you like.

Sell, sell, sell. I like the atmosphere, I disliked a guide trying to get you into a shop to buy whatever. The most interesting part is however you normally don't see, the places where leather is sold and the workingplaces where shoes are made but not sold.

Shopping Paradise. Everything Moroccan you could possibly need to buy (and everything else) is available in the souk.It is not a myth - haggle!! Start at just above half and pay the price you want - if you cannot agree just walk away (be brave!). If they liked your last price they'll come running after you - as happened to us, twice!

two sides of djemaa l-fna. In the day time i did not enjoy this square at all: it was dirty, few people were there and they pushed you with such insistence to buy stuff or do pictures with folkloristic people that even the moroccon visitors were really tired and get rid of them. The square is not magnifique, there is nothing there. In the night it changes completely, it is plenty of people eating and having fun: the smell of food, the smoke of cooking, the colours of things contribute to render the square one of the main fashinating places of marrakech!
A travel back in time. The place is amazing and you could easily get lost. Would advise a guide but be bold and haggle it is expected and you can get some fantastic bargains especially leather goods.
buzzing. A hive of activity, lots to see,variety of wares, some items unique to Moroccan culture. Was weary about eating any foodstuff though.

Haggle is the name of the game. The Moroccans seemingly never tire of haggling. These bustling narrow lanes are both charming and difficult at the same time. Maps don't make much difference, you just get used to the feeling of being a bit lost, around every corner you will discover something new and interesting.

The Souk!. Motorbikes and bicycles not allowed but you still have to watch out for them. You can buy anything and everything. Whatever price they offer, deduct 70%! It helps not to be white and European as they charge you more!
Smile,Smile,Smile. These guys can bargain (simultaneously) in any language and currency. They expect and enjoy bargaining. Pay half the price and they still make a profit.

what an experience. If possible do this for the first time with a guide. Not for the fainthearted but oh so enjoyable. The haggling is so much fun and everybody tries so hard to entice you into their work place.
Watch out for all the donkey carts, bikes and taxis which just drive into you.

Not for the fainthearted!. We have traveled a fair bit, and I thought I could bargain, but this place is in a league of its own! Its impossible to just have a look around and browse and disappointingly we didn't buy a single thing! Its pretty much tat, ridiculous prices and a pain to get past persistent sellers. That said, its fascinating to walk through from a historical point of view and it would be a shame to go to Marrakesh and not visit the souks. We didn't feel threatened, just harrased.

the best. loved haggling , never felt pressured or worried. Loads of guys tried to be unofficial guides but left us be once they realised we were fine. Don't be daunted , do some deals and get some bargains. Everyone very very charming and even when you feel lost just keep walking and there you are again on the square!!

What would it look like when I get it home?. Fun to go through an get lost in. Traders can be intimidating until you're firm. Imagine your potential purchase at home after a week to see whether it's actually worth it! Haggle and haggle again. We found that most things ended up being 25% of what was originally asked for. Can't be beaten for atmosphere, though.

Fantastic Shopping. I truly enjoyed wandering around the alleys of the souks; the shop keepers weren't terribly aggressive. But once you stop, look and or touch the merchandise, be prepared to politely say "no thank you" or get ready to bargain for the right price. It is quite an experience, the carpets, tassels, scarves, spices and so much more are exquisite. And there are great photo opportunities, take time to drink the mint tea you may be offered and have fun! The shopping in the Marrakesh souks is much better than the Grand Bazaar in Istanbul; the openness and lack of crowds likely influenced my opinion.

December visit. What fun! We had a great time here. Yes it is exhausting doing all the bargaining, but it is important to have a price you are willing to pay in your head. The colours, and smells and noises are incredible. We did fall for a trick when we asked how to the get to the photography museum, a man told us it was closed as the tanneries were having an auction and he promptly took us there. It was fascinating to see, but not where we wanted to go. A "non merci" got us away from most unwanted pursuers, we never felt threatened at all.

Thoroughly Enjoyed it. As long as you know what you are looking to buy and how much you are looking to spend you will be fine. I had great fun bartering for some Christmas presents and if I had,had more space in my suitcase I would have bought more. Will certainly be going back for a long weekend next time with an empty suitcase.

A great place to get lost!. The souks are extensive and rather overwhelming. Stalls and shops either side of the passageways and bicycles, mopeds, hand carts and donkey carts rushing up and down. Walk in single file on the right and you should be OK. Within the apparent chaos there is a certain logic; the dyers are all together as are the leather workers and tanners, the lighting specialists, the wools, the silks, the pots and pans and so on.You will get lost; when you do ask a stall holder the way out (e.g. "How do I get to Jamaa El Fna?"); not some local youth who will willingly lead you and then pester you for some money for his service. Bargain for anything you buy. We were advised that you should not pay more than 25% of the initial asking price. We struggled to get down to 33%. Fun and just a little scary

This souk is a must. A must see and do whilst in Marrakech. Dining in the tents set up every evening is a part of the experience. Remember don't use the utensils as they may not be washed properly, use the bread instead. Daytime and evening visits are two different experiences. Explore into the depths of this souk for unique cafes, restaurants and shops.

Great fun, but be prepared to walk away from "deals". The souks are amazing - mixtures of spice, fabrics, leather, brass, silver, gold and wood are all there for buying. Be prepared to bargain hard and also to walk away. We looked at two lamps which were unique to this one vendor (and we did look around a _lot_ of shops) and his starting price was 4500 dirham (450 euro)... Even with the expected 45% haggling room, they were still expensive. We ended up paying 2300 dirham (230 euro) which was about 500 too much. We learnt from this and when we looked a handbag, the price was again, over the top, even as a starting price. We bargained and when we didn't get the value we were prepared to pay, we walked. The proprietor came after us and came down to our price we asked which was a fair price of 210 dirham. If he didn't want to sell at that price, then we didn't make him, so if you really want it, be prepared to give a fair price and walk if they don't play ball. It may not work, but you haven't lost out either way...

hide and souk. no 1 hassles you too much its their way of life of course so called guides will try it on a polite no will do, get yourself lost its part of the fun haggle to your hearts content they love it bargains galore have fun i know you will

If you look to your right you see pottery and lamps, if you look to your left you see exactly the same. The Souk is divided within a very touristic part near the Jemaa el Fna square and a bit calmer part which is located deeper in the medina. I enjoy shopping, but as a Dutch citizen I also prefer to look around and touch everything before I think about buying it. This was practically impossible, since all the store owners tried to sell you everything you didn't need and didn't take no for an answer. Since we didn't really enjoy this experience we ended up buying the majority of or souvenirs at the hotel and airport giftshop, terrible but true.I recommend you to have a drink on one of the rooftop café's deeper in the medina since you can enjoy the scene from above.

Close. The Souks are very narrow and very busy but are brilliant to look round some of the shops have some lovely products although you do find that even tho the walkways are narrow you still get the locals driving there Mopeds and motorbikes. WE DO ADVISE GOING IN A GROUP.

Not for the faint hearted, but a must see. The souk is not for the faint hearted but well worth one or more visits. All very exotic, but full of things you may not really want back home....! It is a very confusing maze, but you don't really need a guide if you are reasonable with maps and orientation. You should initially offer 20-25% of any price quoted and go no further than 40%.

Busy!. once you understand that you have to say NO agressively and stand your ground its fine and fun. So many nice thing, but you cant just look otherwise the shop owners pounce on you try to show you everything and are a little in your face, once you've got the hang of it, its fine. Dont go into the shops tho, it's hard to get out without a purchase! other than that huge culture shock, and so many interesting things to see!!!

fun...but go in full of energy. bartering was fun but it wears on you. i definitly enjoyed it though.... DONT buy things straight away. just survey the shops first and find out the general price people are giving youa local lad we knew said that DONT PAY more than 30-40% of what the shopkeeper offers! its a rip off if your not carefulhowever if your good at bartering and find a GOOD shopkeeper (rare) youll manage to get some really lovely stuff

Must go. If you panic under pressure do not enter. Shop owners will try everything to get you to buy something. Remember to offer less than half of their asking price and work your way up, slowly! Also have a good look around first and try go further in for a better deal.

Crazy but I love it.. Bought a lot of stuff I shouldn't have on this trip. REMEMBER to bargain like crazy, it's recommended you should at least start with 1/4 of the asking price, and the sellers are really good at what they do so I ended walking away with the item at 1/2 the price they offered. Not too upset about it though, because the leather goods ARE quite cheap as compared to what I can get at home so I'm still getting a bargain. While you can get a better price at the Ensemble Artisinal, it is well worth the experience to try haggling and the shopkeepers are all really friendly people. It is recommended that you visit the Ensemble at Mohammed V avenue before you head to the souks so that you know what is the maximum price you should pay for an item. Also, if you buy 2 items it is a lot easier to bargain.
Good place for bargins.. Be prepared to haggle, this is like a game to them and it's almost rude not to. also make sure you take a good walk around before buying, lots of the smae things.

Intertesting. Not a pleasant experience, you cannot walk without being 'hassled' to buy, word of warning, do not buy leather goods from the market as the leather is not treated and it smells very bad, so top tip 'smell before you buy'. YOu will find prices are cheaper away from the Souk.

Sensory Overload!. But worth the visit. There are some excellent spots for lamps and silverware as well as Berber Rugs. Negotiate half the price of what they ask and you are getting a decent deal. Most reputable artisans will ship as well.
Loved it!. Wow - amazing network of streets and so much going on. Leather area, wool dying, shoe making, bag making. ..... carpets. shops are just ful of amazing colours and things!!!
Souk till you drop. Nice if you like shopping and getting the price reduced cant beat it ladies, and even see blokes doing it as well, it's a must.

Time share sellers they're not. An interesting few days, getting lost, walking in front of donkeys, scooters cyclists and ducking out of the way of the henna tattooists, false guides and spice sellers. Daunting to enjoyable, theres everything to see, lots to buy, don't be afraid to say no sometimes quite a lot! Everyones trying to earn a living one way or another but we never felt threatened or unsafe just at times out of your usual comfort zone but hey its Marrakech and an experience you can talk about. If you use a guide , use an official one there's plenty who try it on saying its free then try and charge you , just say no.

Great for Shopping authentic Souvenirs of Morocco. Loved the souks. Once you have mastered the art of saying no thanks and just walking through then you will love it. Stop and browse but dont feel intimidated by there constant bartering, even if your not intrested, they will keep persisting!!.. Smile and walk away. The advice I was given was to pay roughly a third of there opening price. This seemed to have worked quite well for me.

So much to see.... This is definitely something to experience. The hustle and bustle, the fantastic smells of all the food available (which tasted superb, by the way), the colours, the people. I can't describe how awe inspiring this place is....it's a 'must see'

Dark, oppressive with surly stallholders... Yes, I expect to be 'sold' to; yes, they need to make a living and no-one would go there and expect not to have to haggle, but Ramadan made many stall keepers aggressive and grumpy and not at all friendly or polite.. A shame - but perhaps understandable given the heat, the length of the day and their fasting..
Annoying and not really that cheap. For shopping, I prefer the Grand Bazaar of Turkey. BUt go to this place for a day or two. Be prepared to be firm and almost mean.

Dont get lost. There are two main souks, either side of the medina. The largest is to the left as you approach from the main road, it is absolutely massive. If you do venture in there, and you should, please be very wary of the route you're are taking because we got lost for over an hour.

Perfect for a bargain.... We spent a couple of hours walking through the Souks each day (we were in Marrakech for 4 nights). Once you get used to the locals trying to get you in their shops you will start to enjoy and love the place. Make sure you don't get ripped off though, the locals always try and get away with charging you a crazy amount to start with (our Riad said to never pay more than 1/2 what they tell you the price is)

Aladdin’s Cave. Took a guided tour from the outskirts of the Medina through to the centre of the souks.The journey through the labyrinth was both a step back in time and very informative on the everyday way of life to the haggle for a vast variety of goods on offer.

An experience. We found the Souks very interesting. They all want you to step inside their shops and are not overly aggressive. Negotiating is expected, found most items can be had for 30-60% off the asking price.
Great experience. Liked the fact that we could look at what we wanted without having to commit to buying. Be prepared to haggle and have a price in your head that you are willing to pay

Marrakech Souks. Make sure you have a guide. Even though we had a guide the first day, we went back the next day, thinking we could find where we had been and were "taken" by locals who offerred to take us to where we wanted to go, only to be accosted for "payment" for guide services.

A vibrant and aromatic real-life game of maze!. Aside from the bumper car ride scenario experienced in Casa, the second thrilling and most memorable experience of my Moroccan trip was walking through the souks particularly the souk in Marrakesh; it was an event in and of itself! Case in point: the Jamaa el Fna (a huge central square at the entrance to the souk/market place. It is THE place to be at night). A huge open market-place with vibrant colours, fragrant aromas and surprises everywhere (motor bikes, camels, people!) I got lost countless times in the maze-like, windy streets and alley ways. The Marrakech souk is bigger than the ones I visited in Fes and Casablanca. There's a lot more going on here. The souk has everything you could ever imagine and need! It goes on forever and one wrong turn rendered me lost for hours!

Mixed feelings about them. I found the souks quite an experience, good and bad. Its tiring, all you hear is "excuse me" "look here" "cheaper than Asda" (made me laugh first time, 20 or so times later, not so much). We made it around 40% in we reckon before we simply could not take anymore and called it a day. It is something you have to try, but do not go tired or if you not in a good mood, cos it will ware you down further.

Marrakech souk by wheelchair user. A step back in time in this bustly, exciting maze of treasure troves! Even though I am a wheelchair user I felt safe and welcomed by the vendors, one of them even pushed my wheelchair for a while...admittedly to his spice shop but it was well worth a visit and we had a neck and shoulder massage there for just one euro! Yes, it's busy and you have to negotiate around crowds, laden donkeys, motorbikes and carts.. but it is entirely possible and definitely worth a visit. We managed to haggle down to about a third of the original asking price after a lot of friendly chatting, accepting many cups of mint tea and giving an English lesson! Moroccan people are very friendly but you do have to remember that nothing is for free...! Don't try and have your photo taken with traditional musicians without paying, we saw one young man being chased by an elderly Moroccan who produced a metal club out of his waist band and tried to use it as a weapon! I can't wait to revisit next year with my teenage children. It is an amazing, traditional place.

Here's a tip for carved wood.... We got some nice carved wood items from L'art Du Bois Cherif, 21 Bis Souika Riad Laarouse, in the souk. This is one of the places where the woodworker sells his own stuff. They were not pushy and were very reasonable to haggle with.

the souk is excellent. See Marrakech Medina for comments too. Our Ryad was in the heart of the the medina near the Mellah. We could walk to the souk from the Ryad and medina easily to do our shopping. The souk was wonderful except for the dangerous and noisey motor bikes. It was a maze of alleyways full of wonders with lots of little alladins' caves crammed side by side adn facing each other. they were vendors calling wanting us to sample their wares but no one was rude or aggressive. After a while one gets used to it and enjoys the whole experience.

A maze of shopping. Do not follow those who offer, unless you are willing to buy something at the end! My husband was taken to a nontourist part where they make the leather and had to pay a man to get a ride back because he didn't know where he was! We were also guided by someone to have an almost hour presentation on their products!! Just keep saying no until you see something you want. Then act like you don't like it and talk them down like crazy. Keep walking away until they give it to you!!

The Heart Of Marrakech. Thank heavens this souq still exists as it has old world charm and carries the atmosphere of days gone by. It is a maze that seems endless with many stalls selling repetitive goods. It may seem a perfect tourist destination and most of the goods are cheap in standard but it is fun to wander around and adds to the Marrakech experience. Tips: do be prepared to haggle and hard as it is the well loved game of the sellers. We were advised to watch our bags but felt very safe.Enjoy!

What you expect.. It was a good experience, but the aggression of the henna artists and the monkey trainers will put you off. Once you find a nice guy with good stuff in the souk then barter with him and don't bother going elsewhere. They all sell the same stuff anyway.

The worst ever..... Like everyone,we went to the Souk for a nice walk in a colorful place but it was a nightmare...Crazy prices,agressivity from shop keepers.The motorcycle ,the smell not to mention the fake guide who follow you and ask for money ...The quality of the product is very poor and not original at all.You can find nice shopping center outside La Medina with nicer people and product.Avoid also Major shop in an area called Sidi-Ghanem especially companies like Maison Mediterranee or Mamad Decor who are real crooks.I DON'T UNDERSTAND WHY THE AUTHORITIES ARE NOT DOING ANYTHINGBut I understand now the expression ARNAQUESH

Fun!. Amazing markets with some great things. Be prepared to barter. Our rule was take a 0 of their first offer and pay nothing than 50% of the first offer. 300Dr? Offer 30Dr then settle at nothing more than 150Dr...!!

A Fantastic Experience!. The souks are a maze of lanes with stall after stall of souvenirs. There are people who shout and try to get you into their shops/stalls but just keep walking if you do not want to go in. They can be very pushy, do not be afraid to say no. Haggling is an absolute must, they will start off at a high price. Stick to the price you want to pay and even walk away when they say it is too low - they WILL come after you and give you your price.

An experience. Colourful, lots to buy and lots of haggling.Before I knew it I had bags of unique jewellery, lots of spices, a few antique items and an empty wallet.But it was so much fun and our guide was the best. He spoke 4 different languages.
Busy!. Look confident and keep your hands in your pockets to avoid being hassles too much by the street sellers.

Unique experience. If you overlook the fact of being constantly hassled and go around the Souks with the local guide (as otherwise, getting lost is pretty easy, there are about 900 little streets inside), the experience is very unique and shows you hard word of people making the goods you see (blacksmiths, tanners, yard dyers).

What can one say - if you've never been there, you need to go!. Don't wear your best shoes and ladies, don't bring your purse as it will likely stress you. Be prepared to haggle, be latched on to, and just be in the hustle and bustle of everyday life as it has been for centuries...

A great place to get lost !!. We had a lot of fun walking around here, I think it took us all day including a tour of a shop keepers carpet and scarf making shop !! Just be ready to barter, they expect it.

Disappointing and annoying. A maze that goes on for ever. Expect to be hassled incessantly - if you show the slightest interest in anything you will be followed and virtually pulled into the shop. You find that you become reluctant to look at anything - it just isn't worth the hassle. It is quite interesting to see the vast range of life in Marrakech - the relative poverty and dirt, the colourful blankets etc and the interesting range of Burbar jewellery, Morroccan lamps, native knives etc. It is very easy to get lost in the Souk - our Riad owner suggested having small denomination notes at hand to offer the children to show you the way to the exit - if you take this advice I would do so with caution for obvious reasons. I found that Googlemaps worked intermittently and it allowed us to navigate our own way out into the town.

Amazing but have your wits about you!. Amazing atmosphere but continuously hassled to buy even if you just glanced!!!! We have been to Tunsia and the Tunis Souk so we wer prepared but first time visitors be aware that even of you want to take a picture you will be expected to buy something.

Discover Marrackech. This was a Maze, without the guide I would have been lost, we had great time, so colourful, I found the people very friendly, I did expect some hassle, but we got none. You have to be careful about the bikes zooming around, they are everywhere even in the smallest alley and we did see minor accidents. Fortunately no one was seriously injured.

A Maze of small shops, treat the stallholders with respect and you'll be OK. The hustle and bustle of this famous souk is awe inspiring! People working for little money, but happy. Try the tin ware and leather goods, good value as are the spices and herbs.

Busy, Busy, Busy...... This was quite an experience to visit! I've been to many markets and souks, but not quite like this. It's VERY busy and full of people most of the time. I would recommend you get yourself a good guide if you are looking for something specific otherwise you could be in there all day! LOL

be sure to be in good mood! (and in good shape aswell). (English is not my mother tongue... Sorry for mistakes)I went there with my girlfirend and we played a game together:Walk in the souk and stop. Measure elapse time between you stopped and when a "seller try to help you to find material". I won!!! (Yeahhh)... It takes to me 15 seconds and it's very long!My story seems to be funny at first sight but after 2 or 3 hours in souk, I really needed a break because it's a perpetual harrasment. The worst I lived in souk was a guy who jumped on me to put me a headscarf like lawrence of arabia. It's very aggressive but I was in good mood and I just told him I will not buy his scarf.The worst we lived outside the souk was a tannerie visit that end with a "racket" tentative of 20 dollars approx. for 5 min. of visit. (We had a guide for 4 dollars for 6 hours of visit dispatchon 2 days) A guy showed us the path to tannerie buy recommandation of an another one. The guide showed us the tannerie and drived us to a very expensive selling point. We didn't bought anything and when we went out of the shop and...surprise!....: we were drove in a small dark street were we met again the first guy who recommend us the second and the guide. They became to be very aggressive but we refused to pay (200 dirham = 20 $) and we were very close to have a really bad fight. I'm quite young (33 years old) and in good shape so they were a little bit beware and I was ready to go if it was necessary.If you are two girls imagine...So to make a summary: never follow anybody if he don't have an " official guide card". Be in good mood. If you are a girl be ready for harrasment and will enjoy your travel to the souk!Sincerly yours... le gabe!

colourful and noisy. One of the highlights of any visit to Marrakech, this is a noisy and colouful place. Shopping can be fun, but if like me you dislike haggling, it can geta little tiresome. Also, be warned - it is easy to get lost in here - though you can find your way out eventually!

Wow, your head will spin!. I enjoyed walking through the souks. The merchants can be very pushy at times, yes, but if that bothers you enough to let it ruin your Marrakech experience, you need to vacation elsewhere. Period. You need to take Marrakech the way it is, or not at all. I throughly enjoyed my time there!!!! I had already braced myself to having to haggle and/or the attempt to pressure me into buying but turns out it was much more mild in that aspect than I anticipated. You're walking into the souks to shop...and that is how the merchants see it as well.You're not there to eat or sightsee, you're there to check out the merchandise. This does NOT mean you have to buy anything you do not WANT to buy, Don't be pressured. Price compare, go back as many times as you desire before you make a purchase, if you make one at all. If you want to go just to look inside the souks you've heard so much about...go look. Take little money with you if you are the type to be easily swayed. If you see something you like, odds are it will be there another day & you can go back & get it. The merchants start high. Then it's your turn to cut that price in half or less than half. Then you will both meet somewhere in the middle. If it's a price you can live with, buy your beautiful souvenir, if not, there are many many many many MANY other merchants. Enjoy :)

a crazy mix of colours. You could wander round here all day. Be prepared to bargain for everything which can become a bit wearisome after a time. The colours are fantastic - every shop and stall merits a photo. Just don't get lost in here late at night as alot of the souk is closed off and it all looks very different from how it does in the daytime.

Good place to spend your money. Like any other souk in the Arab countries, almost everything can be obtained here. For the tourists a large choice of local produced leatherware, pottery and real-fake clothing is available. As fart as pricing is concerned, half is most of the time the correct price.

Excellent adventure in the souk. The best way to attack the souk is to wander in and get lost ! Spend a few hours walking around in the maze of covered streets, haggle for leather and pottery, sip tea with the locals and soak up the atmosphere, sights and smells.
You must visit here. The souks in Marrakech are great fun you will get lost but that is part of the charm There is everything here that you could possibly want to buy
ALOT of harrasment. You tend to get harrassed alot as you're walking by and the people become agressive if you don't buy from their stalls

CHAOS!!!. I love to visit Souk's and this one was excellent, loads of stalls selling everything under the sun! The tradesman, trying to lure you in to buy anything from a fridge magnet to a carpet! Wonderful bargains to be had if you're prepared to haggle for ages!

marrakech souk. Was intresting but Have in mind what you want.
If you get pestered just put your hand up like the halt sign and say no
I found that workd with out being rude
bargins. plenty to see . plenty shops really good but mind you dont get lost .its good to wonder round and get yourself a bargin

Crikey x2!. Bring your best French and best haggle for good prices- Go to the Artisan Ensemble the first day where they have set prices so you can judge what a fair price is better when you go into the Souks and Medina. Bring your A-game!

Hectic and colourful. There are so many lovely things you can buy! Lanterns, leather bags, shoes, tagines, teapots, cups, shisha bongs, jewellery etc. You just remember that they can come at a very good price! Don't be afraid to barter with them, they are expecting it. And don't be afraid to walk away either as there will be many more people selling the same! Watch your bags in the busy areas, i had my bag stolen by a child when it suddenly became very crowded! If you look lost for a second, someone will come over to 'help' you. They may do but at a price. They will also try to take you round the shops for commission so don't follow them. Be firm and tell them 'no thank you' or 'we know where we're going'. The people are friendly but its all driven by money so be aware. Otherwise have a lovely time shopping and haggling!

They have wised up..!!. Well.. they have wised up the locals...and obviously checked to see what you pay in the UK, and try and charge you the same amount - for fakes!! Honestly, I love shopping... (I am female) but I got sooo sick of haggling that I eventually gave up. My boyfriend got bored too..but unfortunately for him, I couldn't go on my own - or else they get too friendly (!!!!) - had to polite remove one shopkeepers hand off my arm 2 or 3 times before walking out of his shop. Pottery is good value and really beautiful ..but you can only get so much of it. When you're there, please buy some napkins or those light things from the little kids. They cost 10 dirs.. (80p)...and the kids are soo sweet.
stressfull but great goods. Essaouira is my shopping ot spot, here you can get the same, if you negotiate you can even get good prices, but you will get bothered by vendors every 10 secs...
Very interesting souk. It was a dream. and it came true :) Very unusual place, but very nice. The souk is very large. So many kinds of goods. Most of them are made ​​directly on the souk.

No trash cans, no restrooms, but it's magical!. Imagine an Arabian 1001 Nights market, full of little stores with locals who want to sell you their traditional stuff, always trying to make you pay 4 times as much as it's worth, just because you are European/ American. Imagine a place with no trash cans, so you have to walk with an empty bottle of Coca Cola for 3 hours. The other option is throwing it on the ground. Also, no restrooms are inside the Souks. Restaurants are close by, so you can go there if you have to pee. It's strange, it's magical, it's unique. However, if you have been to Istanbul before than it's not that special, because the Bazaar in Istanbul is similar.

A culture shock. Noisy and scary initially as you are deluged by the sights and sounds,and offers to "come in to my shop" by the various vendors.After 2-3 days you become very comfortable with it all, and start to enjoy the haggling experience.

Was on my bucket list and did not disappoint!. The party atmosphere of the square after arriving via horse carriage, the food, the dancing, the shops,the spices, the snake charmers, and the sensory overload will stay with me the rest of my life.
Nightmare. If you like to get lost easily and enjoy being pestered for money or to buy something then this place is for you

Invasion of the senses but buyer beware. There are excellent guide books with routes (Frommers and Top10) for the Marrakech souks but they never prepare you for the colours, smells and sounds. Prepare to be lost - there are few signs but as long as keep the view of the main mosque (Koutoubia) in your sights when in a clearing then you can find your way back to the main square. If you find you need a direction to the square ask someone working in a stall which way. Don't accept to be taken there and don't ask anyone walking around or you'll be whisked away to another souk area they are linked to.You have to stand your ground on saying no, thank you in French or Arabic but the stalls will have a ready banter. Walking away is the simplest bet - they will not leave their stalls. The rule is as soon as you touch one of their products or observe their stall then they have you hooked. So you either want something and can haggle a deal or don't want to buy ( say 'no shopping today') . If he (they're all men) invite you into his lair - whether a carpet, some spices, woodwork or jewellery - and offers you mint or herbal tea then generally it is customary/polite to accept. We've used excuse of tummy upsets to refuse.Keep your money hidden away at all times and always be prepared to walk off. If you want to haggle we always assume 30% of their starting price and work up to 50%. But this depends on the seller's day and the buyer's need. Remember there are plenty of other sellers around touting the same wares and they know this, so shop around first.There are a good few cafes around the souks (eg Terrasse des Epices) for a break. Take advantage as by returning to the main square exposes you to a different hassle. The square has many cafes - try to sit upstairs to avoid the shoe-shiners, beggars, tissue sellers etc.We would recommend you work in two's or more as it is easier for your friend or partner to pull you out.

Real or surreal!. Get a guide and find the real working areas that show what life is really like for the artisans.Be prepare to bargain - aim to pay 35 to 30% of first price offered. If you don't want to buy don't take any money with you!Areas nearest the square are more touristy.Don't miss the live animal souks.

Mugged in Marrakech!. I went to Marrakech last weekend my sister. We visited the souks early evening (had left by 7.30). We had an official guide to show us round, who was very good, although clearly took us to the shop he wanted us to go to (we had expected this and actually were not disappointed with it!).I would not want to put anyone off going to Marrakech as I think it is an amazing place (and we stayed at Tikkida Gardens which was a fantastic hotel with very kind, funny and attentive staff throughout the hotel). However I would like to give a warning to other women. We were 5 minutes away from our taxi when a motorcycle drove at me at speed and the driver either wrenched (or cut?) my handbag from my neck. This was done with considerable force (my back is still giving me problems a week later!) but thankfully the strap broke as the incident could have been far worse!! Also thankfully, there was not much of value in my bag! I had my bag across me (as advised) and of couse this could happen anywhere. But the nature of the souks make this so much more likely. SO ladies please be on your guard. I would advise going out in an organised trip, don't take a handbag and possibly not an expensive camera (mine was not taken but had I not had a handbag, could have been!).Otherwise, enjoy this amazing city and I hope you have more luck than I did!

Warning:. If you want to really experience this and not get ripped off, get yourself a trustworth Arabic speaking guide from the Bureau of Tourism. Ask your hotel/riad to arrange it. It costs 300dh (about $30.00 US and is well worth every cent.
Barterers Heaven!. If you like to barter the souks are for you! only touch merchandise you really want or you will start the bartering process before you know it!!!!!

Retail therapy. Ideally give yourself plenty of time to explore the souks. I was expecting to feel hassled but that didn't happen - yes, they want to sell you things but will leave you alone if you make it clear you're not interested and if you get lost and ask those I encountered were happy to point me towards Jemaa el Fna.

Fantastic way to while away the hours. So so so much to look at! We didn't feel intimidated or hassled at all. Although some of the souks holders near the square are a little more forceful. Found those in the northern area a little more authentic.
Be prepared to haggle and laugh at the crazy initial price you are offered! A must....

Take a Compass!. I know Lonely Planet says you must get lost in the souk for the experience, I would agree wholeheartedly but when you end up going in a circle three times it's a bit much! Someone in our hotel had the answer, a compass! The furthest in from the square are really fascinating, the real artisans working in the back of the stall in only a few square metres. You do get hassle sure, but a firm no is usually enough, we experienced nothing uncomfortable. The souks directly off the square are more upmarket, spacious and colourful, perhaps you should start with these. Beware the mopeds, they are an absolute pain!

BARTER. The souks can be an overwhelming place to be there is so much to see and take in it can be a bit of a sensory overload. Market venders are very pushy and will try and sell all of their products to you, at first this is quite difficult to deal with as this was not something i was used to. We got caught out a couple of times when trying to leave and someone would show us the way for "free" ("no charge no charge!") and then we would be taken on a rather long walk to many different traders and when shown out of the Souks we were asked for "a small present" or "something for me". This is difficult to avoid due to language barrier and easily getting lost within the labrynth of the souks. Generally the best thing to do is not make eye contact or reply "non merci" firmly as we were led on a merry dance a couple of times! However in saying this some of the people are very lovely and not out to con you, The products in the souks are lovely and reasonably priced, you can get a nice leather bag for under £20.00 as well as scarves, jewellery, pottery and metal work. My advice would be to go to the Souks during the day for first trip as it is not as busy and get use to the feel of it and bartering. My understanding was ask the initial price and then offer half and generally go up 10 or 20 from there. But if you feel confident haggle a little more.
Be prepared to be hassled. You will get hassled, and you will get lost, but its is an experience that you should not miss, and the main square is a real experience as the sun goes down

Go with a party. The labyrinths of the Souks are a wonderful place to explore - but if you can get on an organised trip you will have a much better understanding of the people that sell their wares in the narrow passageways. Don't use one of the many 'guides' at the start of the Souks or you will never get rid of them.The sights, sounds and smells of the place are not to be missed - and you must do some bargaining - although it can take a while and the locals are experts!
Amazing.... really good walking around and haggling with the locals, this was all part of Marrakech. Great during the day and the evenings..

When Will They Learn to Stop Bothering Tourists??. We really wanted to explore the souks, but being western tourists, we stood out as such and were CONSTANTLY pestered to stop, look and buy things. It was interesting at first, but got to be so bothersome and annoying, that we cut short our visit.

Fascinating and friendly. So many stalls, yes you will get lost but always seem to eventually reach the main square. Sellers are friendly without being too persistent and if you like bartering, you will be in heaven.

Amazing shopping.. Best shopping available in all of Morocco is here. Better quality rugs are to be in Fes though, but everything else you get here. Save this city for your last stop so you don't have to lug around all over Morocco all of your souvenirs.

Great fun to visit. It is of course not possible to visit Marrakesh without visiting the great souk attached to the grand sqaure Jemmael Fna. It is i teresting to visit it both in the day time and the evening. The multi colourful stalls and particularly the spices are quite beautiful.
too many sellers try to approach you, so beware.

Have your Wits about You. Again, a must do visit. To see the traders showing off there wares, and busily making things by hand at the same time is extremely interesting and in some ways humbling. Avoid the Henna Tattooists and thge Monkey men!

hassle. The first time we went we were with our guide and it was fascinating. I especially liked the metal recycling area and the spice shops. The second time we were on our own and were immediately joined by a persistant hooded unofficial guide who refused to leave us alone. Extremely irritating.

did not like the souk square. terrible smell, people in your face begging, at night times frightening snakes monkeys the animals very neglected, so thin the horses, the locals riding about on bikes scooters, no respect for peoples safety.

Absorb the frantic world of bargaining. If you're not used to the atmosphere of a souk, it can be a bit overwhelming initially. Prepare to be dragged into a fascinating world where anything can be bought, at any price. You have to be hard nosed when bargaining - every price you get quoted will be at least 2x what it should be. And the patter of the shop keepers will often distract you from the business of getting a fair price. But when you get into the rhythm, chatting and bargaining with the shop keepers is a lot of fun and after you've sealed the deal, you can often get some useful info from the shop keepers.

a real maze. make sure you have a map and plenty of time or you can get lost and be led to all sort of places by the locals that try to make you spend money on the pretest to get you where you want.great place to wander and spend some money. Huggle and huggle again. they won't sell unless they make a profit. so decide what you want to spend and stick with it. some will ask for extortionate prices. shop around

A maze of wonders!!. Absolutely enchanting. Although the do hassle tourists (to be expected) don't let that deter you. I fell in love with the hustle and bustle of the Souks and could've spent a small fortune in there. DO make sure you HAGGLE and don't be afraid to walk away. The smells and the colours, different shops with lots of different items was mesmerizing. Want leather belts, purses, handbags? Ladies - you will love it. Lots of pottery and spice shops to take a taste of Morocco home with you.If you don't go you will miss out on a such a cultural experience.
great choice. great choice of gifts and souvenirs, make sure you haggle and you can get a great bargain, locals are very friendly so if you get lost they are there to help you out!
Shopping Excursion. There was plenty to see and haggle over here - you MUSt be prepared to haggle and you can get a great price!

Lively, colourful and noisy. A real spectacle of colour and noise. Lots of stalls although mainly selling the same things. I quite enjoyed the haggling which is expected and you can strike a hard bargain as there is so much competition. Beware of the ladies who walk about and start talking to you then start painting your hand with henna telling you it's free, as soon as they finish ( it only takes them a few seconds ) they then demand money. We were a bit naive, and it can be a bit intimindating, but if I| went again I'd be aware. Other than that everyone was really friendly and we felt very safe.

Learn how to make a deal!!. This is not like shopping in Sweden, this is lika a stand-up comedy. Be tough and do it with a smile. The people in the shops loves to argue and sell. Start with 30% of their first price and deceide what is your maximum price. An if you do not get it, leave with a smile!
Plenty of souvenirs. Mostly souvenirs, not really a market where the locals get their supplies. Sales tactics can be rather aggressive, especially if you're a group of girls.

for your shopping of traditional goods. best place to learn who to bargain before buying,,,prices change all the time so when you find something you like ask for the price and you must expect you can still have a rebate of 30 to 40 % more

Amazing. Watch the souk - no one tells you a price, you have to guess, then barter. Where to start? Demand a price and start at A THIRD of that price. We did that and found prices elsewhere were similar - including the airport. Pay a major distributor or pay a souk stall holder? Choose but go on a third of asking price.

Another world!. Very nice place! A MUST see in Morocco. You can have a guide on place if you want.. It will help to go thru this maze lol! Its HUGE! You can get lost very easily so look where you're going and dont go too far haha! It can be hard to get out of there! But wow, there is sooo many things to see and buy! Its a huge market with artisans, women who does the paint on the hands, people with snakes and monkeys, etc.. You really feel you are somewhere else in the old days in the world.. Its a MUST MUST do. You always have to negociate price with the people. They love to play the game.. They speak arab and french.

Souk Market. Everyone should vist this place like Aladdins Caves, they sell everything- leather, wood, pottery, blingy jewellery, silver and gold, thousands of shawls, bags, slippers. Hundresds of cobbled-stone alleys easy to take a wrong turn and get lost. We used a guide for our first experience. The bartering is a must, expect to pay less than half original price. The Morroccan stallholders are a bit pushy although we grabbed a few good bargains, need to be street savvy here as it can be intimidating at times but a wonderful experience.
Pushy pushy pushy. Pushy vendors, selling rubbish for ridiculous prices. Motorbikes race through the souks, although it's forbidden so it's dangerous as well.

Bonkers but fun. I was amazed how much less hassle you get there than in Egypt for example. You aren't followed about by children and beggars and people don't touch you unnecessarily. Of course haggling goes on and on and on, and more or less everyone will happily rip you off. If you're lost, ask a woman. They won't lead you on a wild goosechase or ask you for woman. Having said this, you need to be a woman really to ask a woman and you need to ask in French. Sorry!

Either a great place to get a bargain, or somewhere to pay a fortune for a load of old tat - but, great fun either way. Being British I sort of struggled a bit with the whole idea of having to haggle for nearly everything you can buy in the souks, and didn't really find it 'fun' as I know some people do, but my partner loved it, even though she knew that she did pay over the odds for 1 or 2 things. We also saw quite a few things for sale in the airport on the way home, which shattered any illusions we may have had to having bought something exclusive. That said though, it was a far more enjoyable experience walking though the little twisting alleyways and looking at the various stalls than it ever would be at an airport, and is a must for at least 1 afternoon/evening while in Marrakech

A little manic but great. This was certainly an experience to remember! A great place to shop, bargain and be entertained. At night the main square is transformed with all the food stalls (not there during the day) and additional stalls. A warning, it is very full on and can be a little intimidating at first but worth a visit.

so bright and colourful. put your bartering skills to the test. great fun. spice part was fantastic so bright and aromatic. the other stalls were just so colourful whether you were looking for carpets, shoes and lamp shades!.

Haggling for beginners. I'd never haggled before and made several mistakes. These tips may help: (1) Best not to ask the price of anything you don't actually want (2) Think of the least you could get this item for at home and then halve it and use this as your maximum. (3) Never go beyond your maximum: walk away if you have to; they'll relent eventually (4) Don't look or get cross (5) If you pay over the odds (as I did often) just remember it's a 3rd world country, you're probably not breaking the bank and you're making their day. Finally, if you can find a local to tell you the value of something, say a leather bag, you're in a very strong position.

We liked it!!. It is very easy to get lost in the souk. The shop owners were somewhat pushy, but not too bad, we just ignored them if we were not interested, and that usually worked. I was not good at haggling, and obviously got ripped off, as I found the same items at the fixed price shop at a lower price than what I ended up paying in the souk. So, I suggest that you try to get the price down to 30-40% of what they are initially offering.We visited the souk both of the days we stayed in Marrakech, though we did most if our shopping in the fixed price shop Centre Artisinal. The souk is great for people watching, seeing the locals go about with their business and also there are some great photo opportunities.

What it says on the tin. As described in the travel guides, lots of narrow windy streets. The outlets were variable. Found ourselves in the "meat" area and found it all very unpleasant. Frankly, its an experience once done I have no wish to repeat. I didn't like having no idea where I was in a strange place and barely able to speak the language, it was extremely claustrophobic and I felt uneasy all the time. Not my cup of tea....mint or otherwise !!

Same same. It's good fun to get lost here. And you will get lost. The is no map of the place and there are only 10 types of shops. But the multiplied themselves 100 fold. So no points of recognition :)

Colourful and fun. Although it can be a little daunting at first, once you learn how to shake the ever persitant sales guys off it's really great fun. And the haggling is part of the show, alrhough we were told offer half of any price they tell you, reckon they've got wise to that, because we were paying a quarter of their first offer price. And yes it's easy to get lost but somehow you always seem to end back up at the main square, and there are plenty of very helpful young chaps who will gladly lead you to the square for a small fee of course.

buzzing gem. there were thousands of stalls selling all manner of goods , the twisting alleyways the hub-bub of people trying to sell , however it could be very easy to get lost(as some people did while there), not for the faint hearted, we loved it, we love haggling
amazing place. a visit is a must wen ur in marrakech..its so lively and so colorful..each time i have been there i have enjoyed every single moment

A must if 1st time in Marrakech. You have to go there when oing to Marrakech for the 1st time. Then the next times you go to Marakech you can avoid unless you know where you are going and for what. What is an nice experience is going for dinner in one of the luxury Riads and walking a night in the souk in small allays and then arriving at a small door that opens on to a great Riad,

Amazing atmosphere. Yes you do get pestered by the traders but a polite "no thanks" is quickly understood. The range of goods, colour and light makes the Souks a unique experience. Some good bargains when you are prepared to stick to your price. Start off by offering around a third of what is asked and don't give more than half the starting price was our experience to get the best deals.
Market Madness. Madness, some bargains to be had. Highly recommend stopping for a drink at one of the rooftop terraces in the big square where you can take it all in and escape the crowds

plenty of choice, bargains to be had. We didnt experience as much hassle as some people seem to, so it may be getting better. You get more 'attention' if you wander round slowly (as you'd often want to) than if you walk purposefully. Kids still take great pleasure in taking tourists the wrong way and getting them lost. Some beautiful stuff to buy though, and a great experience. Best ask before taking any photos.

Daunting but compulsory to get lost. You need to gird your loins, assume you will get lost and take the plunge. When it all gets too much retire to a cafe with a view and watch the world go by while you relax and unwind!

Souks of Marrakech. We were warned about the souks by a few friends,but things have changed.The King of Morocco has decreed that the old City will be crime free,so there are plain clothes police everywhere.The souks are by and large,clean and good value.DO NOT give the asking price.Start at about a quarter of whats asked.Go to some fixed price shops if you're not sure.You may get people offering to be your guide,saying "no money".There is always money required,so say no.If you get lost,just ask for the square...most shopkeepers speak some English,and will point you in the right direction.A lot of the stalls make their own goods,and you can watch your leather slippers,or your chess set being made for you.Don't tempt fate by flashing your money or cards around,but I have to say that I felt very safe in the souks.Fantastic day.
be ready to haggle. be sure to allow plenty of time, know what you are looking for and know what you want to pay for an item. Haggling is part of the experience, have fun!

Don't be fooled by the first impression. At first glimpse, the souk can seem overwhelming. But wander north in the souk and soon it changes to a more pleasant atmosphere where you are actually allowed to look without being pulled from all sides to buy at a very special price.

An amazing experience. We did have an excellent guide arranged by Kuoni travel and I think that very important especially on your 1st visit. It was an amazing experience and as most of the people speak very little English you could very easily get lost and not discover a different world. Beside the hundred of stalls and little shops in narrow streets the people were extremely friendly. Even when one was not buying a souvenir or item of clothing. Our tour was supposedto be about 3 hours but we spent 5 hours enjoying ourselves. There was a bustle of vehicles, motorbikes, bikes, carts, people, sheep and Goats. Just amazing but best to go in a small party with your own guide.
Souk. Loved the souk. did not feel threatened the stall holders spoke most languages but I love haggling some great bargains some expensive tat but a good experience. I avoided the snake charmers

Don't be surprised.. I liked the man who tried to sell me a tortoise - no I couldn't take iit in my suitcase. He then lifted the lid off a pot and exposed a couple of chameleons. I remembered a film 'Snakes on a Plane' and thought maybe not..he then refused to give up and suggested 'Viagra'You can get practically anything in the souks and don't be feint hearted. You will see ridiculous sights. Fancy a gazelle's head, a leather bag, dodgy looking stuff that turns out to be slimming tea, a dried lizard...and negotiate like a Berber..be tough or they will be disappointed!

labyrinth. We had to get used to the small streets, the motors and dust in the small streets at first, but we enjoyed the colourful souk and it's shops and goods. Don't forget to bargain, you should pay max 40% of the original price.

Simply a tourist trap. Our visit to Marrakesh promised a mixture of a bustling modern town and old fashioned romanticism. The first part was exactly as expected but the market and the town square were just tourist traps without any charm or appeal. People on holiday are simply targetted to hold monkeys, watch snake charming, etc. and the only intention is to position you where you have to give money. Whilst I realise that Marrakesh has to make money from tourism, this hard nosed, pressurised approach to extracting cash is genuinely unpleasant. It was a relief to walk out of this area.

Forget the map, it won't help. This is something, as cheesey as it sounds, that you just have to dive in to and get immersed in. In parts the street is quite wide and there's plenty of space to move but most of the time there's barely enough room for one, let alone the dozen or so people squeezing through.The souks are divided into their different specialities with the main street your entry into those worlds. Everyone says to look for the dyers souk but my favourite was the where the craftsmen actually make the items on display, it's like going back in time to see them all tucked away in their tiny room beating away with hammers.You can and will get lost but most of the souks will lead back out to the main street or an exit, but if you're really stuck a local will help for a small 'donation'.

Souks!. OUr first experience of the Souks were negotiating then in order to find our Riad! After that they were no where near as scary. Watch our for the lovelt helping locals, they will offer directions even when not solicited, they will then chase you around suggesting that they can take you to where you need to go. We said we were not prepared to pay for directions and after 10 minutes of being told there was not charge the impeciably dressed 'non-guide' lead us out of the souks and asked us for 400 dirham (£35) for the privalege - needless to say I didnt pay!!!! although I did feel very threatened oh - always remember to walk on the right - save you getting run over!!!

A must in Marrakech. The souk in Marrakech is huge and very exotic, more so than eg. in Istanbul. It is divided into different trade areas, often with open workshops like in the blacksmith section. You will inevitably loose your way, but don't worry - eventually you'll find one or another way out. On the first day we found a tiny drink parlor with tea and lemonade - and we never found the same place again!Most of the time you can walk around and browse unattended. Only in the dyer's section we were approached by insisting sellers who tried to lure us into shops with exorbitant prices.

Utter madness. An assault on your senses first time in. The colours are astonishing, the smells vary from wonderful to awful, you will drop your jaw at some of the things you see and the noise is constant like any close market. You will love it or hate it. I got fed up of not being able to browse in peace, I said 'non merci' more times in an hour than in all my life. The people are very friendly but they don't give you a minute to really enjoy what you are seeing. Watch out for your handbags and pockets, keep bags firmly zipped up and close to your side.

Expensive and the same as any foriegn market. They really try and rip you off. I have been to souks in Tunisia and its the same thing. Would be the same as Turkey also. The locals are very friendly but the items are pricey

Check the times. The main souks are open until 8, but when you go deep in they seem to start shutting at 5. Yes I think you get a better deal and the objects are more unusual deeper in, but be wary as there are a lot of strange characters deep in. There was a crazy man running up and down one part screaming which was quite intimidating but defiantly go As you get some beautiful things.
good experience. lovely leather goods and fabulous lightsDisliked agressive selling techniques and men trying to lead you to their friends and families shops

Not pleasant.... Crowded, dirty, disorienting - the souk was full of winding alleys, and very easy to get lost in. I disliked the continual pressure from the salespeople - I am used to it from my travels, but the usual response of "No thank you" is enough in most places....here it isn't. I really did not feel safe, and found the place terribly claustraphobic. Not my kind of place at all.
You will get lost but have fun. A great place to visit but will probably get lost - we did just enjoy and have fun. You need to experience this for yourself. Take small change.

Dont get lost. Full of small traders selling just about everything for tourists and residents, we had a guide, maps are useless as there are many passages and roads just about big enough for donkeys and traps.

Bargain!. So many wonderful things to buy in the souks. The stall owners are friendly & will usually try to entice you inside & offer you mint tea. Know how much you are prepared to pay for any item & bargain hard!! They are fascinating & seem endless.

use a guide to get the best of the souk. a mass of alleyways and stores. Different parts of the souk selling/ making different things. Our guide was very informative and showed us a wide variety of trades people. The bakery was fascinating and we all enjoyed a neck & shoulder massage at the natural medicine shop.

Look out for the tooth seller!. This was something straight out of Globe Trekker! We turned the corner and saw the square for the first time at night and it was a sight that will remain in my memory for ever. It is a mad crazy place, lots of snakes and monkeys on leads! watch out they will put one on your shoulder! everybody is after your money in one way or another! If you take a photo expect to be asked for a contribution!The children can be a bit of a pain at night , following you and asking for money.If you keep focused and are prepared to say no and walk away you will not have a problem.Beware of the henna ladies, they will grab your hand and start painting it. Even if you say you have no money they will continue and demand payment!The tooth seller is great, selling false teeth from a table (no NHS here!) In all it is an amazing place to go and one you must not miss. Eating in the evening is a must (seperate review) I will go back again, we went every night of our five night stay. Go enjoy and you will love the experience.
Lots of local colour. These were much as any Middle Eastern Souk - narrow streets, easy to get lost, a bombardment to the senses. Motor cycles everywhere, ridden by people with a death wish

An absolute must. Wondering around in the Souk is essential to get the feel of Marrekech - the noise, the smell and the colours. Be firm with haggling - we found we ended up paying 1/3-1/4 of the original price offered. Don't be afraid to walk away - if they are interested they will chase you.

the Souk. I understand that different cultures have to be respected but I do not like seeing animals such as monkeys being kept on a lead. as I said this is just my opinion. I did not like seeing dead lambs hanging from shops. The good things are you can get a bargain and the Berber Pharmacy was lovely best Knee massage I ever had and only 20 dnr but take your own guide .

Fascinating - but be careful..... We decided to take a personal walking tour of the Souk, during the day, which meant that we were able to see all the artisanal areas, and we didn't get lost! It's a fascinating place full of craftsmen -and shops, of course - working in silver, wood, carpets - but because of its intricate, close passages, I don't think I'd like to venture in at night-time...

be prepared to get lost!!. I spent quite a few hours on a few occasions strolling through the souks of Marrakech. If one gets lost and ends up on a totally different side or exit to the square it can be rather unsettling but hey - you just get new places to explore!!Hassling was not a problem, just be firm and only end up paying what the goods are worth to you - the stall holders are experts at looking very affronted when bargaining but all part of the fun.

The reason people come to Marrakech.... One way or the other, if you walk around the heart of the medina, you will cross the souks and their narrow labyrinthine streets lined with all types of goods. Its a place like nowhere else Spend some time in the Trip Advisor forums and arm yourself with knowledge of the hassles...and then dive right in.

Friendly People. An abundance of colours, sights and smells, all interspersed with smiling, friendly people. If you just want a casual wander, beware people who will appoint themselves as your guide (and then expect a small fee) - a polite + firm "No thank you" will resolve this. Carry a small bag of shopping with you when you set out and then you can always say that you have already bought XYZ if you are being pressured into looking at something. Otherwise, sharpen your haggling skills, don't pay more than you're happy to, and enjoy the game!
Haggling. This takes a while to get used to if you are new to Morocco. but becomes fun having banter with the stall holders.

Lots to see, lots to buy. THis is very much for the tourists rather than the locals. You will find spices, fabrics, shoes and clothes, lovely wooden gifts, all sorts of things. Be prepared to barter, and be prepared to walk away

Easy to get carried away. Wonderful array of artefacts and although many are clearly mass-manufactured you can also see others that are being made as you watch. Try and find out prices you should be paying from a local before you start to bargain!

A surprise around every corner. A veritable maze with a surprise around every corner. Beautifully displayed spices quickly giving way to leather poofs then live chickens. Don't pause for thought or you will be pounced on and solds something you hadn't ploanned buying or be given directions to the square, at a cost! Worth every minute of the hassle for a memorable experience.
A great destination. It was a great vacation. So oriental. But if you don't like spices, keep away from famous meal Tajin ;)

Madness and mayhem. Visited the souk first during the day to acquaint ourselves with all the alleys. Saw some stalls preparing meat of some discription which meant we did not eat when we returned on another day in the evening!! The stall holders will turn on the charm in order to make a sale, but when I pointed out that the scarf was made in China, the charm turned a little sour. You can not go to Marrakech and not visit the souks.

millions of bargains. Bantering and bartering with the sellers in the souk is great fun if you keep a sence of humour and have some fun with them....don't go when you are weary. Some real bargains to be had but shame the luggage allowance restricts importing back home. Try and buy the nuts and dried fruit and enjoy the delicious freshly squeezed orange drinks.

Not like the Saturday Market..... The souks are utter madness..... They buzz all day long and are a complete assault on all the senses!!! There is no way to navigate your way around them so if you see something you like and pass it by you might never find it again!!!The souks are so much more than what is close to the market place. The closer you get to the Museum of Marrakech, the more likely you are to find the artisan souks that don't sell but you can watch them work. Closer to the market place you get the mass produced rubbish but you will find some gems but prices can be cheap.Whilst walking around you will be shouted at, summoned and invited in. On day three of our stay we did a guided walking tour around the medina and were told by our guide to ignore the shouts and not even acknowledge them with a "No thank you." It's hard but the sooner you learn to zone it all out the more pleasurable the visit will be. First thing in the morning and towards the end of the day are the best times to venture further in as the souks aren't so busy. Around 4pm though and throughout the weekend the souks were horrendously busy, especially closer to Jemaa el Fna (the main square) as all the out of towners come to stock up.It is exhausting but a spot of haggling is a must.

A guide will give you so much more. We arranged a guide to take us around and we were so glad we did. She took us to the little workshops of the craftsmen and to little places we would never have found. It really is worth it, whe spent almost 5 hours with us around the medina, souks and some of the monuments and it only cost us 500dhs between 7 0f us

An overload for the senses. Challenge yourself, try and find your Riad without assistance or pick a restaurant in the Medina and see if you can get there without assistance. If you manage this challenge I believe that you have done your training for the TV show "Amazing Race!" Good luck it is a fun game everyone should try atleast once.James

A great place to wander. It was fun to get lost and wander around here. We went in to back areas behind the shops to see the tradespeople actually doing the making of some of the items, which was very interesting.

Interesting souks. It is difficult to review the souks as you either love them or hate them as they are noisy and you do get harrassed a lot. Then again this whole culture makes them interesting and you can certainly get bargains

So good and so bad...just be bold, brave and careful.
