Well, you either do as I suggest above or ask your hotel to provide a guide for half a day, in order to feel safe and learn the ropes of the hustle and bustle of the souk way of life. I know I do not speak here to the seasoned traveller...more the gentile and polite westener who has little idea of the whole place.TAKE a camera...watch your purse and do not wander off alone.Have fun...it is possible...its an aladins cave of goodies...

was ok. everywhere we walked, there were people came to ask you if you need directions. we tended to blind out, and kept walking. goods sold there are ok, nothing particular, and be careful the price high. One light shade made in broze asking price EUR100?!?!?! and owner didn't even want to bargain. Also do compare the price, as you are easily been hassled.

hectic..... phew...you need to have your wits about you - the entire souk area is awash with colour and every type of item that you might want to buy. Beware everyone trying to entice you in. You must have a go at haggling, but make sure you want the item first. Even if you don't buy, you have to walk about and just ignore everyone offering you everything but the kitchen sink

Bring a compass. Its just fun to get lost in the streets. Not all the areas are clean, and probably won't look safe, but the entire time I was there, aside from some eager store owners wanting to show off their goods, I didn't feel unsafe at all. Everyone I met on the streets were friendly and extremely helpful. Bring a compass with you and you'll always be able to find your way back.

Great for atmosphere, prepare to get lost.. The souks are a must-visit in terms of soaking up the atmosphere and seeing Marrakech trading life. Whether you'll buy anything is another matter and whether you'll buy something you actually want a different thing again! We didn't find them too hassley at all and enjoyed wandering around just soaking it all up. We got lost more than once and used the sun's location to just about navigate our way back out. This was half the fun though, as what seems like a wrong turn can bring you out in a little square with local fruit and veg market. Enjoy :-)
A MAZE OF MADNESS. Be careful not to get lost, we did twice and had to pay a kid to extract us. Very difficult to navigate and find any points in guide book but fun trying!

Home made. Is is very large, if you want you can walk this market whole day. They are making everythig on this place by their hands for you. Everything is hand made. You can talk about price hours and hours.

Overwhelming - but good deals to be had. We didn't spend much time in the Souks as it was so hot and stuffy that it was hard to be in an enclosed space for long. While we walked through the souks often to get to the square, we didn't really do any serious browsing until our last day. Many of the stalls had similar goods, so we chose where to shop based on the friendliness of the people working there. Haggling is a must, but use some sense as the last thing you want to do is offend someone! All in all, it's something to be experienced, but definitely not my highlight.

Seen better. I've seen busy markets all over the world and Marrakech souk is nothing special. Too many shops selling exactly the same things - mostly for the tourist trade. And too much hassle avoiding the shopkeepers - some of whom are downright rude.

An Amazing Experience!. A little frightening as you naviagate the labyrinth of streets and alleyways that take you into dark corners, it is however something you must experience. The artisans and stall owners are largely wonderful people, as are all the muslims that you will come in contact with. Every American should see it. It will change your impression of the Arab world for the good.
crowded narrow alleyways full of flavour.. Worth going , even if not to shop.We bought spices and sweetmeats, and a couple of pasminas, at bargain prices after haggling.Good fun.

Organised Chaos. We went to the Souk on our first day in Marrakech and although it was meant to take only 5 minutes from our Riad to the Souk, we got terribly lost and it took us two hours to get there. There were so many alleyways, and paths that its very easy to get lost. There are alot of touts working the street who will claim to take you to various places and try and get money off you for taking you. The common line is that this area is closed, etc. We should have read the reviews more carefully before we went. We made the mistake of following a guy to the Tanneries where we were made to pay 100dh and taken to 1 leather shop which was way more expensive than shopping in the Souk. If asking for directions, make sure you only ask the shopkeepers as they will try and help you without asking for money. Unfortunately, without any real proper street names in the alleyways, they also frequently get confused. We were constantly being pointed down one direction and the next person would point us back in the opposite direction. Before you enter the souk, make sure that you can retrace your steps going in and out from the square. In the evenings, there are tents set up for food stalls. However, make sure that you give only the exact change for the food or they will take your money and refuse to give you back any change claiming its 'tips'. We found the food in the cafes/restaurants around the souk better for the equivalent price and the service to be better. But if you just want the experience of eating at the stalls, its still worth it. We finally got the hang of getting around in the Souks and how to handle the street touts and started to enjoy it more. Forewarned is forearmed and if you know what to expect, then it will be much more enjoyable. The souk is quite an amazing sight to see at night and its worth going to have a look just to see the bustle and the liveliness of marrakech.

Experience it!. I don't suggest you do this all day every day. It is fun to a point but it really can be exhausting. Best thing is to have a look around for a day or so. Spot a few things that you like and compare prices then go back when you are rested and bargain,bargain,bargain.

A fool and his money..... This was my first visit to Marrakech and I'd done all the homework on the Internet but noting can really prepare you for the experience. It's a complete assault on all your senses. I have never been anywhere with just so much going in in every direction or so much colour than here; the drums, people shouting, and mopeds buzzing around never cease; the smell of bbq's, spices and the tanneries (horrible!); the fresh orange juice is the freshest ever and the street food is the best I've tasted; and the feeling of the whole place is amazing. BUT and there's always a but - everything comes at a price and that price depends on just how gullibe, stupid, charmed or wealthy you appear. Unfortunately armed with an expensive camera to capture every moment I quallified for all of the above. The locals can read you like a book and will charge for their services accordingly whether you asked for them or not. I was hassled by a friendly local, whom I recognised about 30 seconds into our improptu conversation as "a guide", for 300dh for taking me to the tanneries (not that I ever wanted to go in the first place) and a further 200dh for a 10 min tour of said tanneries by someone else I was handed over to - you just get sucked in. I got away with half but they weren't happy - nor was I to be honest as i felt quite intimidated. So beware as people appear genuinely very friendly when they smell money, of any quantity. Sadly, as a lone traveller, with expensive camera in hand I was a sitting duck. Would I go back? Well yes I did about four hours later, when I parted with just 6dh on things I actually wanted. "Once bitten twice shy" or "A fool and his money are soon parted" - your choice!

Shop till you drop. You get totally lost, that is for sure. But don't mind, because very far away you can't be. When ready with shopping you just ask the way to the square. they all will point you the good direction. If you don't like to bargain, don't go there. It is part of the game. And Bargain with a smile. You will get the best prices!!
very good. vendors are nice, and the prices are reasonable. I invite you to visit the souk in marrakech essamarine

some bargains to be had be prepared for hassle. Huge, with endless permutations of stalls, all keen to make a sale. Very colourful.If you like shopping try to wander to the Kasbah area (5/10 mins walk) - the shops and area feel much older.If you hate haggling there is an artisan market and/or a couple of government run huge shops selling just about everything Moroccan, and actually by the time you have finished haggling the price you pay will not be so different from these shops.
Rip off. The souk was a big disappointment, full of 'tack' for the tourists with little in the way of genuine quality goods. Far better to go to the covered market down by the Bahia Palace.
Mindblowing Maze. If you want to pass the time away just wandering through the maze of souks take a guide otherwise you may never get out! Oh be careful of the motor bikes that go roaring through!!

Great fun!. The souks were by far the best part of Marrakech and you can have a great time as long as you understand the rules.1. If you want something, you will need to pay. This includes taking photos or having someone guide you out of the maze, it won't be much and agree a price beforehand.2. Haggle. Decide how much you want to pay, then offer half. If the shopkeeper refuses then say no and start to walk away. They will try and make you feel guilty, but this is part of the game. Remember - they wouldn't sell it to you if it was under cost so don't believe that line!3. Don't stress out about getting 'ripped off'. Decide how much the item is worth to you. If you get it for that price or below, who cares what others pay?!4. Say no. If you aren't interested, say no (and only the word 'no') firmly. Walk away and refuse to make eye contact. They will leave you alone.5. If you are a woman alone, wear a ring and mention in conversation that you are married. This carries a lot of weight in Marrakech - I was travelling with a girlfriend and it was amazing how fast shopkeepers back off when you casually say 'my husband wouldn't approve of that!'
Fun to haggle. As long as you can take it in your stride enjoy the haggling, but don't get too upset with the constant harassment from the shopkeepers to buy their wares

Keep out! Its not worth it.. I got the impression that they really didn't like tourists! I don't know if it was desperation because of effects of the global economy or whether they are just greedy and inhospitable. Somewhere between the two I suspect. If you take their photo, they'll want paid or become angry, or even both. If you ask them nicely for their permission to take a photo, even in French and Arabic, like I did, they become angry or want paid. If you want souvenirs, gifts or some of the local wares, go to the Ensemble Artisan or another artisan co-operative. They are genuine and lovely people. There's also good number in the new town that are worth visiting.

Great experience. Stallholderswere all friendly respectful and sharp businessmen. Great fun bartering and something for everyone. we were warned about pickpocketsbut didnt experience this , The only slightly annoying aspect is the incistence of snake charmers or monkey owners wanting you to have a photo with them and want paying even if you only look. Eating in the square was fun too.

Overwhelming. Sounds, colors, smells, shapes... everything gets mixed in the Souks of Marrakech. From slippers to lamps to cotton shirts to pastries. You must get lost there in order to experience the real soul of Marrakech.
lost and hassled. You will get lost in the Souks, I found the people most unfriendly and they are just after your money.

This is not all that Marrakech is about. I like the Souks but everyone seems to head here when there is so much more to see in Marrakech. It's great to wander about and we have never had any hassle other than people trying to sell you stuff you don't want, but hey that's their living. It's fun but it's like going to any market in any other country in the world or Kasbar in any other Middle Eastern or North African Country. Visit and enjoy but don't let it be the focus of your time in Marrakech.

ONCE IS ENOUGH. OK I agee the Souk is a must see place, but the problem is that you simply cannot just BUY something, it takes 40 mins or more to reach a conclusion, and whilst novel to begin with it becommes very tireing, and somewhat boring to have to go through the whole bargaining escapade EVERY single time...if something is worth a Fiver, then why do you have to have a mini argument everytime to get it down from £50.....maybe there are mugs...sorry people out there who will pay £40 or £50, that's why they do it...and whilst I understand battering is in their Blood, it does becomme tedious after several days.Plus Restaurants around Square are just awefull, ok for a Coffee or Ice Cream but that's it, pictures on outside Menu's do not tell the whole story.

You have to go there. You have to go there - so much to see & if you are happy to haggle you will get some good deals. Don't be put off by the traders hassling you - just walk away and look elsewhere. If you want to see the monkeys and snakes go in the morning though beware they try to ask for lots of money for photos so just knock them down or walk away. Everyone wants to be your guide & if you get lost just ask someone but beware they either want money or to take you via a store or stall. Best time to visit at night when it all comes alive, however during the day good for looking round.
Full of Life!. A place every visitor must experience at least once. You either like or you don't, but give it a try and surprise yourself with true cultural life.

Wildly fantastic. It's the Mother Ship for all things hand-made and arty. Not too busy, but vibrant. Haggle to your hearts content, if your not happy with the way the bartering is going, simply walk away..there's plenty of alternatives selling similar products. Use their competition to your advantage. Ladies...be aware of the occasional wandering hand upon your derrier! My husband developed hawk eyes on this trip :-)

What a place on earth !. I LOVED the souks ! before we left i read loads of reviews, watched you tube videos due to the fact that i am claustrophobic, i was so worried of getting lost and then getting into a panic that i hired a guide to take us through.. dont bother, he will only take you to some VERY expensive stores in hope that you will buy and he will take the commission .... quite the contrary, this place is great, do not worry about it at all, if you get lost ask a store owner they are more than helpful. I loved the bartering for items, i found myself buying things i did not really need, just for the sheer fun of it, fantastic place on earth !

A great experience. Wonderful to wander around the different shops and see all the colours of North Africa, together with the spice smells. Donkeys laden with goods walking passed you. Be prepared to bargain hard.

Land of dreams. This is one of the best souks in the world. It contains everything one would imagine a souk to contain, from fine weavings and textiles, and of course carpets, to hand embroidered kaftans, soft leather slips ons, jewelry, fine metal work and on and one. Go and feast on the beauty of this place and be transported back several hundred years!

souk. i loved the souk and didnt get lost it is so colourful and interesting in went in 3 times dont be fooled you need a guide just stay on the main route and you will be ok . loved the sweets and all the shops with lamps and plates really amazing

Didn't get as much hassle as expected!. great value, lots of nice traditional Morrocan items to buy. you have to be good at bargaining! I was expecting to be hassled by sellers as I passed by but this did not happen at all. Anything we bought we bargained down to half or less than half of what they originally asked us to pay. well worth a visit. The pharmacies are interesting - they offer only natural products.

Exhausting fun. The hassle from shopkeepers is remarkable so you have to develop a thick skin but if you can do that the shopping is wonderful and there are some lovely people there too. We came home with such beautiful things and will enjoy being reminded of this crazy, hectic, foreign place for years.

Marrakech Souk. We visited the Souk with a tour guide and found this to be invaluable both from a history point of view and from a purchasing one. We certainly would not have found our way round the Souk on our own.

good deals if u can haggle. the souks are lively and there is lots of street entertainment about. the goods are nice and priced well, although be prepared to haggle. the henna ladies can be quite annoying trying to grab your arms.

Have fun in the souks. A brilliant place for doing a bit of bargaining ! It is brilliant and you will get lost - but it is all quite safe and some bits are really interesting - including the metalworking souk where they make padlocks and ironwork . The bargaining is great fun and you have to be tough !

Fun, touristy, and safe!. I was unsure about going into this area as I was just tagging along with another couple I met on the tour. (I am a solo traveler.) After very primitive camping and hiking for a week in the High Atlas Mountains, I was ready for a little touristy type of area. I little cafes were cute and the area was clearly for the tourist to enjoy. I love seeing individual, thriving buisnesses like this in a world full of Wal-Marts. I would advise US citizens this really is a place to feel safe in. There are cameras everywhere and there is a secret police force assigned to ensure tourist are not harrassed or robbed. (Our guide told us that the king has reserved the severest punishments for those who bother tourists in this manner.) I would have felt safe as an individual without a tag-alone. It was fun to try haggeling with the vendors. The food was simple and good. Beware though that resturant owners will harrass you to get you to their resturant and you will also be, "funneled" by the locals to the tanneries. Also, don't ask for directions from the local children, they will try to fleece you for alot of money and not put you in the right direction. I was concerned with safety due to the uprisings in the countries surrounding this area but it became very clear to me that the people or the government want NO part of it. The city is progressive and becomming very modern. The changes toward moderinism is very embraced by the people who seem quite laid back. Do go if you have the chance!

Everything you want. It is incredible the amount of good you get in this place.Leather, coper plate and tray, shoes, lamp, spices, clothes, decoration, carpet, etc...One advice, when you get a price, just divide it by two to get a good price.

Great bargains to be had......... Very friendly locals, remove the thought of "Health & Safety" and you will have a great time. You get to see the locals doing there daily routine. We witnessed the bread being prepared and baked and was encouraged to come inside as see them working. We saw how handbags we made by hand being stitched together. The pharmacy with all remedies on the shelf for certain illnesses. We took a guide for the day for 200MAD He took us to places the normal tourist doesn't get to see. It is a maze so also we didn't get lost on route. Must go to witness for yourself.
Only if you like chaos and shopping. The souks were a little bit too busy and chaotic for me.You can however buy a lot of stuff for a very good price (if you can bargain)

Amazing!. Now this is life! Crazy, colourful, hectic, hot, sweaty...too much to buy - great deals and good fun to barter! Just be careful of the snake charmers and monkey men who are in the main square...if you make eye contact they approach you at some speed and I found myself staring a rather large cobra in the face....aaaargh!!

an experience that's for sure. we recently visited marrakesh on a much needed break and as part of this experience we also had quite a few days wandering around aimlessly in the souk. if you are a shopper and are an experienced haggler (tip take about 20% of the price they will start with and then calculate a profit on top decide on a price so he still makes a living and stick with that, should be about the the right amount then) you will be in second heaven. the streets are very narrow and the traffic is heavy with bikes, mopeds (lots of tooting going on behind you there) and donkeys pulling carts as this seems to be the only thing able to negotiate the narrow streets.they say you either love it or hate it, well in our case we did neither, we were glad of the experience but not being consumers by nature i guess the goods on offer didnt hold out much pull. you can find lovely little cafes to have a bite to eat, reminded me of the the 70's and my backpacking days.
Great vendors. We had wonderful experiences with the vendors and following our purchases, they would greet us each time we passed. Very pleasant shopping.

Amazing Maze. We found that every one tries to be your guide (which is illegal) so we ended going opposite ways to what people were trying to direct us we heard no that way is closed so many times but ignored them and ended up finding the souks the best way i would advise to get in to them is to go through the entrance almost dead opposite the Cafe De France you go through a little walk way of shops and you are soon in the souks. if your not interested a polite no thank you and keep walking works if you are interested do not pick anything up until you are certain its what you want as they will try sell you something else and you end up comng away not sure if you bought the right thing! and always haggle its fun and they expect it so they put their prices up initially!!

The real deal. If you are claustrophobic or suffer from panic attacks - I would guess that this is not the place for you to be!If not - the excitement of the place is immense - just don't expect the Louis Vuitton bags to be genuine...

Interesting and exciting. The souks here are very extensive in all ways. They cover a vast area for a maket place and have on offer a very wide range of products for locals and tourists. The streets are narrow and as always in Africa you will be pestered by the traders, although with the exception of the Berbers, we found they backed off when confronted with a firm but polite 'no thank you' (which they all understand). You will need to haggle but this can be very rewarding - our son acquired Beat headphones for just £10! The initial price will be very high so stay tough. There is so much to see that time just flies but in the end tiredness creeps in and it is best to retuern another day. The back streets of the medina can feel intimidating and poverty abounds. Take care when offered directions by a guide as they will require payment even for taking you just a few metres.

Its best to just get lost. We have been lots now and we find its best to just keep walking, turn left, turn right and cut through little alleys and you find some really different sellers the further you go back into the souks. Smile, be polite and if your not interested just say NO Thanks and walk on. dont forget to barter. Always worth getting a slice of pineapple or coconut from the man that walks around with his barrow or a maccaroon from the street sellers ( best I have ever tasted and only 1dhr each (7p) be brave but be careful !

DON'T BE SCARED - JUST ENJOY THE EXPERIENCE. Firstly, before you visit the Souk - BE PREPARED - The Souk WILL be scary; WILL be intimidating; WILL be annoying; WILL be an amazing experience - A few things to know: you will be fooled, tricked and your day won't go to plan, but if you retain your sense of humour and keep a smile on your face, you'll have a fantastic time.On entering the Souk, usually via the street (Derb Dabach) at the north of the main square (Jamaa El Fna) you'll be approached numerous times by boys and men telling you the souks are rubbish/ closed/ 'down another street etc etc) - IT's ALL UNTRUE - Ignore them or just smile and go where you want to. TIP: don't let anyone drag you off or lead you anywhere - just go where you want to. They'll even tell you streets are 'forbidden', just smile and ignore them. They just want you to go where they get paid to take you - The Tanneries, The leather Market, a shop etc . . . . Once you get used to it it's fun, go in shops, ask how much things are, talk to the shop owners, they really are funny people and real characters. And don't be afraid to say no, if it's too much, just walk away and you'll find it in another shop. There are 2 ways of approach buying things, 1) decide what you want to pay and stick to it - 2) offer a quarter of the asking price and stick to it, or a third if you really want it. Tell then you're British and you don't barter, take it or leave it - THEY'LL TAKE IT. With all that said, it is easy to get angry, especially at the end of the day, or when you get a particularly aggressive seller. I did. We got an aggressive seller and I actually lost my 'rag', so make sure you walk away or your partner takes over (like my wonderful wife did), that way you still get what you want and you don't feel so bad afterwards. As I say, keep smiling and have fun. learn from my mistake.

Plenty to see and buy. It is a very interesting souq - lots of neat little arts and craft and souvenirs, and be prepared to bargain. Went to the souq a couple of times during our visit, as the place is quite big, and we probably didn't see all of it.

Get lost and enjoy!. Spent a total of 5 hours in the souk over two days. Know what you want, know the approximate value (head to fixed prices places first to give you real bargaining power!) and then enjoy the ride. Be firm yet polite and I can honestly say you should have no trouble, nothing that a firm "La Shokran" (no thank you)wont fix.

colorful. i enjoy getting lost in souks exploring off beat and without tourists around. you MUST huggle hard otherwise you will be ripped off. i have been to marrakech four times and each time i discover something new in the medina and souks. also very safe to wonder around (in a day time everywhere evenings i stick to main roads/souks) as a single female just ignore comments from the local men
Overwhelming. The merchants were very aggressive. We had more enjoyment going downtown to the small artisan shops.

Marrakech Souk. A market town with a difference all the mysteries of the east. The cobbled narrow streets the aromatic smells of the herbs and spices. The muezzin calling the faithful to prayer, snake charmers, the berber women with their henna tatoos. Being able to haggle for a good bargain. In the evening it is transformed in to a gourmets delight of row upon row of different dishes being served, not to be missed. Wear sensible shoes for walking.

Alladin's Cave. What an exciting place - narrow streets, fantastic craftsmen. Although haggling is daunting to us Brits, its quite fun once you get into it and is the expected way of buying something. Watch out for the mopeds and bikes!

You will get lost!. We had a good guide book, planned where we wanted to go and what we wanted to buy and we got lost again and again, didn't by what we planned but other things we hadn't planned on and ended up having to pay people to help us get back to the 'Big Square' that being said we had a ball, felt very safe, saw more than we could have imagined, nearly got run over by a donkey and cart and ate in a lovely rooftop cafe, all in all an amazing experience we are glad we had. We went back a few days later and bought all the things we had planned to buy first time, now we had a little experience!

Guide's take commission. The souks are really fantastic! Leather poofs, bags, jackets, handbags, pouches,shoes. Table cloths, scarfs, carpets, jewelery, argan oil, soaps and many more. Yes there is some china imports as well but only at the outside of the souk. We have had 2 different tour guides. All they do is take you around and show you the stalls of their friends who then charge you a premium price and give the guide a kickback. We paid triple the price for our table cloths since we fell for this scam! The guides are ALL untrustworthly and malicious. The guides anyway walk so fast that you can't orientate yourself and anyway don't remember where which stalls are.I suggest you get a good map which indicates the different souks and then a Loney Planet guide book. Start walking and you need a day and you would then know your way.Also - haggle haggle - start and offer at least two thirds less of the initial asking price. Also shop around. And if they ask you if it is your first time in Marrakech say No! Otherwise they charge an even higher price because they know you are unfamiliar with this kind of shopping.Otherwise enjoy the vibe and the ambiance!!

des Tapis Karimi. We had a great time visiting this rug shop. He had a huge selection and great taste! He was also willing to show us dozens of rugs before we picked the perfect one! Fair prices and he will ship them for you. Great experience.Location:m9 Souk - des Tapis Karimi
Amazing. An amazing experience. Worth getting a guide for the first visit as you can get quite lost in the maze of tiny streets!
Souk. don't be frightened to really have a good look round even thought you sometimes thing you will not find your way out again.

Great - if you have a tour guide. We had a tour guide so it was a joy to visit the souks with someone who knew it like the back of their hands...otherwise we would surely have gotten lost and wasted a lot of time.I got some authentic argan oil from a pharmacy in the souk. Beware: the street sellers selling argan oil are typically actually selling ordinary cooking oil and passing it off as argan oil.

Great wares to be found!. You can spend a lot, b/w the food, spices, carpets, ceramics etc. etc. etc. Be prepared to barter as they always start high and need to be worked down. I would suggest pricing at a couple vendors rather than leaping at the first opportunity, b/c the price will vary and the vendors will come down if they think they will lose a sale.

Istanbul is Better. Having read the views of others who have reported on the these Souks, we were disappointed to find that there was so much "tat" for sale and that the good stuff is too large to bring back on the plane. We idi visit the area where most of the goods are made (although 20% are made in China!)
madness. the colour,the sounds and the sights,we disliked the very pushy traders.we loved the mint tea and tagines served everywhere.

Must be done.. If you do nothing else during your time in Marrakech you must visit the souks. Put a whole day aside and take lots of water and be prepared to see some amazing sights. Do not be scared to ask questions as the locals love to talk.

Fun marketing!. Walking through the souk is a bit of an adventure. If you are nervous about people asking you to come into their shop or try something on or asking where you're from, or if you're simply in a hurry to get to the next site, then it's best to not get distracted by all the colors and scents and just focus on where you're going. These shop owners know tourists are interested in many of the items they're selling and if you look like you're willing to linger, you may find yourself bombarded by many shopkeepers. Don't be nervous, try to have some fun!

Lively place. The most lively place, it's like a maze. One can find everything here: clothing, instruments, soaps, spices, lanterns, carpets, jewelery, leather goods, animals, orange juice, teeth (!!!).... At night there's also many small good restaurants in tents (chose the ones where the locals eat), and attractions (musicians, monkeys...).Prepare yourself to share your space on the narrow streets with lots of motorcycles, bicycles,big wheelbarrows and donkeys.Crazy!

Has to be done!. Having spent time in Egypt I was a little apprehensive about the "requirement" to haggle but need not have been concerned. The attitude of Moroccan traders is totally different from the rude and aggressive tone you experience in Nama Bay, Egypt. You can actually really have a bit of a laugh and generally agree a price around half of their inital starting point. However, the best thing is to find something you like and set in your mind a price you'd be happy to pay for it. Generally you;ll be surprised that you can get things so much cheaper than in the UK. Scarfs, leather goods, pottery, shoes, metalwork, often being made in the back of the shops. Warning, you will get lost. There doesn't appear to any signage and you can wander around for hours passing many stalls that all begin to look the same. You can hire a guide but simplest just to ask a trader to direct you back to the main square. That, particularly at night is also a must do as well.

Hectic. Very, very hectic. Easy to get lost so just walk up an alley then back, then up another alley and back and so on. Best to go in the evening when it is cooler and more of an atmosphere....it's mental. The worse thing is trying to cross the roads, my god, you just have to go for it and then thankgod you made it in one piece. But that aside we loved it.

Enjoy the experience of shopping here. It's a little overwhelming when you enter the souks, there are little shops with men sitting outside or shouting at you from inside. Tip: think about what you'd be happy paying, then haggle up to that number. There are no set prices at all, it can be frustrating but you will find other tourists that paid too much or got a complete bargain each day. A leather bag caught my eye initially and i found myself talking to Mohammed about qualities of leather (he got a lighter to show me that it was real leather, apparently if you put a light to leather and it does not light, then it is real) and compared it to other bags which were harder and lighter in colour. When it comes to price, you know it's hard here, he started at 1000Dirams (they seem to always start here), we started at 200. Met at 300, but hold your ground when you've reached a place you will not pay more for. They enjoy the game and you must too. I wanted to get a few more things like a tea-set and was taken by Mohammed to the far end of the souk (the walk on the way was amazing, it was a maze) to his cousin and we looked at some good quality teapots, trays and glasses. Paid 350dirams for all of that, had to haggle quite a bit on that one. Great experience!!!! Enjoy it!!
Haggle hard. Just remember to haggle and bluff and if you love it too much then settle on a price you can live with!

Excellent. Never had so much fun spending money. The traders will try to make a connection with you by using your nationality. A couple of traders shouted to me that their prices were cheaper than ASDA/Primark. If you are going to buy something, ask how much they want for it and offer half of what they say, but keep smiling as you haggle. This was the highlight of my stay.

Fun at the Souks. The souks are a great experience, you will have a great time bartering with the traders which is expected. We went through lots of winding streets and did get lost a few times but you are always helped by a local if you need to get back to the square. We were able to make some great purchases and we loved the banter - if you learn a few Arabic phrases especially for expensive you will do well.

Bargains, but you must be determined. Day 1 a complete nightmare! Sensory overload, a maze of stalls, disorientation, constant approaches to buy, look, visit and false friends.Day 2. Tamed, thicker skin - buried negotiation skills tried on cheap items and enhanced for the expensive stuff.A simple mantra to help - if you pay half the starting selling price then you have probably paid double its worth! To get a better idea of true values start by going to the Ensemble artisanale near the central square. Prices are fixed and clearly marked. Take notes on what items you would like as you will see many similar items in the Souks. You now have a clear idea of value in which to start your bids. Remember to smile, stand your ground and look the trader in the eye. If he gives you a free gift at the end then your negotiation skills have room for improvement!

cant miss it. While you wouldn't go to marrakech for the souk you can't really miss it while you are there. In part this is because passing through is the best route to lots of places and partly because it's there!Take your time and greet everyone but have no truck with anyone who: touches you, tries to block your way, is begging without any obvious disability. Know what you are willing to pay for anything you might like to buy. For me the best thing is to concentrate on things you have absolutely no desire for, that way you know you will not have to worry about luging unexpected purchases and can enjoy the spactacle.Don't be afraid to say you are just looking and if there is something specific you are looking for try approaching the oldest available vendor and asking them where you might find it. If you are lucky you will be dispatched with a boy to find what you need and then brought back for tea and a look round the vendors shop.Try not to just ignore people - it is their job to gain your attention.
Be prepared to barter. The Souks are really a test, be prepared to haggle for your purchases its all part of the game, but the colours & smells are amazing

Lost more than once. Take time to loose yourself, not hard, in the souks.......move stealthly through the scene. Espy what might be interesting, and return with your "bargaining" skills razor sharp......or at least as good as theirs.

Amazing. Here you find everything you expect when travelling to an exotic place as Marrakech: nices rugs, handicrafts, jewelry, pottery, spices, silk. Everything is cool but I thought kind of expensive because they don't have a fixed rate for their stuff, you have to deal all the time. It's tiring sometimes and in my case I don't like to bargain, so prices keep high.

Shopping like you've never known it. The Medina is the city centre made up of hundreds of tiny lanes, many of which are souks or streets of shops and stalls. These are just like you imagine from the movies - dark, narrow alleys full of exotic stuff on sale hanging in vast amounts outside mysterious interiors. In every case a shopkeeper will be sitting outside shouting at every passer-by that he has just what they are looking for and why not stop and come in. This does tend after many hours and days start to wear you down and you end up not browsing at all which is a shame. But you will go back again and again because the sights, sounds and smells are quite addictive and like nothing you have seen before.

great quality and best prices!. something you almost forgot that it does exist: crafts from metal, woods, natural fabrics and leather of the best quality. all SO AFFORDABLE! nothing like Chinese crap you'd buy in the chain stores. I LOVED IT SO MUCH!
a bit daunting. small area with lots of motorbikes and busy locals. but good experience to immerse in the culture!!!!
Great atmosphere. Get a guide or get lost!!!Labyrinthine passageways with motor bikes etc in the way! Wow! great shops & experience!Loved it!!!Haggle well!!!!
Bargain,Bargain,Bargain. You soon learn that even though it says "fixed price" everty item is negotiable. Patience and smiles and you you'll get the item.

Marrakech at full speed!. Fabulous. Really busy, hot, loud, everyone wanting your dirhams.Do haggle, but be respectful. Don't be afraid to walk away if you're not happy with what's going on. Do take pictures as its hard to remember just how full-on it was afterwards! Had great fun buying a rug. The greatest feline population I've come across in a city.
Souk Sucked. It was hot, crowded, over priced and full of mostly junk. I have been to such places all over the Middle East and Africa and they are always the same.

An absolute must ... but take care!. I've actually written a great long review about the things to watch out for in the souks - it's under Jemma el Fna with the same title. Basically, the huge network of souks next to Jemma el Fna is an absolute must to visit, but to make it a worthwhile visit rather than a negative experience you need to keep your wits about you and not be too trusting if some helpful salesman tries to guide you to another stall where he reassures you that he has exactly what you are looking for. These salesmen, plus almost every other Morrocan that you might ask directions from, are motivated solely by the commission that is on offer if they introduce new customers to stalls/shops rather than by a desire to help a needy tourist! Other advice is never pay the asking price. They massively inflate their prices and love those Brits and other tourists who are simply too polite to barter! My advice is to go in with an offer of at least half of their price. If they let you walk out of the shop, then you know that you've beaten them down too low. A good tactic is to say that you've been offered something similar at another stall at a much lower price. The souks can be quite unpleasant as there seems to be no highway code in Marrakech about motorbikes driving quite speedily down the cobbled paths of the souks and it the polluted air inside the souks is very unpleasant and oppressive. Further details on my review under Jemma el Fna (same title). Enjoy but don't be too trusting!

bad. We were followed managed to get away 2 men trying to trick us please be very aware do not go off the beaten track do not show your camara phone or money. we hated every minute of it ciuld not wait to get back to the hotel

As much sport as shopping.... The souks are a uniquie experience. Prepare to haggle - and check your guide book first to make sure you do it well. Don't just let your guide take you to 'his' shops - no doubt it's good for his wallet, but less so for yours. And not nearly as much fun. Sellers will probably have bags, but you'd be wise to take you own just in case. There are many good deals and your loot can become quite tiring to carry around. Well worth a visit, even if you don't buy anything.

Shop till you drop in the souks. Great experience, especially if you want beautiful hand-crafted goods. The people of Morocco are so skilled and talented. Be prepared to haggle and have an idea of what you would like to pay, can be a bit drawn out at times but more often than not you get what you want for the price you want. As previously mentioned be careful of the mopeds that ride throughout the souk as some parts are quite narrow and they do ride at speed.

good craftmanship. It`s amazing to see them working wood with their feet! Always haggle the price, and the better you are, the more fun you get. the herbalists stores are very good, with demonstrations of pots and lotions. We took a tour, which for the first time visit, it`s probably advisable.

Must see. Great experience. Too many mopeds-fear of getting run over. Homeless people would follow us around trying to get us to give money (there is plenty of them). Great spice shops. Haggle, haggle, haggle! The lantern shops look really pretty at nighttime. We saw snakecharmers which were a treat!

The sights, colours and smells of the Souks.... Likes:1. Great for genuine hand craft products such as fabrics, metal work, leather work, wood work and lamps...2. Awesome photography of the products - people here don't like their photo being taken so be respectful of their wishes.3. Getting to see typical Marrakech life at the food markets.Dislikes1. Getting a tab lost and adolescent boys trying to make a quick buck...beware and just be savvy.2. Busy, busy, busy - donkeys, mopeds, bikes, people everywhere in a tiny space. Just stick to the right hand side and go with the flow like everyone else.

what an experience. youve got to be tough to survive it, but as long as you are firm but fair this is an incredible experience. evening is the perfect time to visit, hearing the call to prayer as you wander around the maze of corridors is lovely. I went with my seven year old son and while we got quite a bit of attention it didnt detract from the wonderful time we had. just remember, when you start you haggle you're going to end up having to buy, unless you want a very angry local as we saw on numerous occassions!!! and walking through the food stalls is like an assault course, dodging the vendors, great fun if a little overwhelming :-)
Get lost. Get lost in the souks for a great experience. dont bother asking for directions as most locals will ask for money to point anything out.

dip in and out. We have done souks all over Africa.
We dipped in and out but generally bought from the exterior stalls.
The mopeds were a real pain and spoiled our enjoyment as you couldn't relax for fear of being hit by one. They need to ban them from bombing up and down unecessarily.

A feast for the senses. There are shops for tourists like knock off designer bags and futbol shirts and there are shops for travellers with names like 'Ali Barbars' stocking old and unique Morocian wares. The latern shops are amazing especially at night when they are all lit up.
Cultural experience. A good way to spend an early evening. Just remember, offer no more than 1/3 of the asking price and settle for no more than a little over.

Keep your Money handy!. You'd be amazed at what you can buy here! So many different things available, enjoy bartering down to get a good price! Watch out for the men if you are a lady but everyone is friendly so don't worry! Came home with a lot of new things for the house!! It's a must see in Morocco!
A Feast of Colours and Scents. A much enjoyable experience though busy and bustly. Watch out for those scooters making their way through the narrow alleyways!

The Souks - Great fun and an experience. If you visit Marrakech, you must visit the souks. We went to the Ensemble Artisanal in the Kasbah first, which is a government run fixed price shop - this gave us a good idea of what would be fair prices for things. If you like things then ask a price, but once you engage in the haggling you won't get away without buying it!! We found that most prices settled on were about half of the original asking price. We were not hassled in the souks, (we had far worse in India!) the stall holders do engage you in conversation they want you to look at their stalls, but if you aren't intersted a simple no thanks, or Non Merci, or Laa Shokran did the trick. Only a few people tried to drape you in clothes, and put things in your hands; most stall holders seem to have realised that hassling potential customers just puts them off looking, and if they don't look they won't buy! - Many stalls just let you wander in and have a good look around, and wait for you to ask them before the fun starts! Whilst in the Souks, check out the spice souk and have a drink at Cafe de epices, seek out the dyers souk, and listen to the talk about the different dyes used, find the souk des ferroniers... Great bargains - Babouches, spices, olives, preserved lemons, Brassware and Silver. Not as cheap but great Quality,- one of the many Morrocan Lanterns; you can get cheap, but if you want a good one, then expect to pay.  Although the souks had a great choice, we'd also recommend checking out Place de Ferblantiers in the Medina for lanterns, as that is the metalworker square and they have some dfferent styles to the ones in the souks.

Assault on the senses. Love Love Love the Medina, snake charmers, smoke, orange juice stalls, bells, dancing, acrobats, story tellers, Food stalls selling snails - kebabs, shops, henna ladies, beggers, motor bikes, horse and carts ita a hubbub of noise, sights and smells!!!

tourist trap. like every other souk but you don't get hassled as much here - barter hard. Prices tend to be the same in the various 'shops' so if you like what you see in one you'll probably find it in another for the same price - cuts down on alot of tooing & frooing

Chaos but fun!. Although we didn't explore the whole area we got a feel for the place and haggled for one or two items. Be prepared to dodge the mopeds which drive through constantly but it generally feels very safe and people will happily direct you if you get lost.

Eat Anywhere. loved the souk...its even better if you go deep into the side streets and alleys and let your eyes wander!! eat in here and the food is even better but dont expect to be served at a table etc!! this is street food at its best!!!

Be purposeful!. If you are browsing then you are fair game and will get hassled but it is much less aggressive and far more good natured than I expected. If you know what you want you can ask and expect to get about 50% of the initial price. Good things to buy are leather ( pencil cases make small gifts), slippers ( but search for quality), walking sticks ( but beware as some have swords inside), mirrors and of course carpets. These vary hugely in quality and again know beforehand the size and color and style you like. We got exactly what we wanted at Artisanat du Sud from Hossni ( and brother Khalid) in the carpet bazaar - good quality, good range, will find what you want and then bargain quite fairly. It is also quite easy to wander on the main streets and not get lost!
Exciting experience. barter all the way.... and you will get some really good prices. I recommend using most of a day, there is a lot to see.

Another wow!. This city is truly amazing and so worth a visit - there is just so much to see and this is one of the musts. It just lives the culture and liveliness of Marrakech and you soak it up and really feel you are in another part of the old which has much to give.

A treat for the senses. WOW! amazing. they are rather daunting, and we visited with a guide. the paths wind, and go on and on...and when you think you have reached a potential dead end, there is another little path darting off to the right or left, colours, people, sounds, smells, a treat for the senses. and we did not get hassled half as much as I expected.

Money Grabbers!. We went in excited about all the bright colours and wonderful things we would see. What we saw was terrible tripe, nothing of any great excitement and then a man took forced us down a dirty smelly passage and into a rug sellers shop. To be fair the rugs were beautiful and of excellent quality. The shop keeper was very nice but we hadn't gone there to buy anything but were unable to leave without buying anything. In the end we were able to knock him down by 60% as he said he could make more money out of the Americans and he liked us. I am not sure how much of this is true or if he was making it up! After that the original shop keeper who we now think was an unofficial guide was trying to get us to go all over the place but we had to run away to get away from him which meant that we were unable to explore fully. Nothing I saw was like I expected and I was disappointed

madness. this place is like a warren you cant find your way out of here to me it just is,nt worth being hassled and if you ask the way out they expect you to buy something you wont be shown without paying ,we was took to ten stalls and when we asked to be shown the exit he asked for money,

You just have to experience it.. It was packed, So many things to see and buy. Dont Go without at least a tour guide on your first attempt. Beware ladies of the Henna women as soon as they see bare flesh they will try and stamp you and then demand payment. But its a trip not to miss.

days tour with dades experience. The imperial city called the ìPearl of the Southî will captivate you, but you must also know how to approach it and be imbued with its atmosphere. The great square of Jemaa-el-Fna alone, with its night and day hustle-bustle, is worth the trip. But people come especially for the colorful and lively souks, unquestionably the richest ones, the most diverse, the most fascinating. A thousand little crafts thrive side by side in an astonishing atmosphere. Tourism, so often criticized, has greatly favored the rediscovery of handicraft. Marrakech is also a fascinating architectural ensemble, increasingly safeguarded in the Medina, with its superb Mosques and remarkable palaces that cast a spell on the traveler with their unforgettable charm. Marrakech is also the door to South Morocco. Its atmosphere, colors and climate remind you that the desert isn't far. Nonetheless, it has a flourishing vegetation; in fact, the public parks, the gardens and fruit trees planted along the main arteries have always been perceived by the Moroccans as a challenge to drought.This imperial city appears as a gem set in the natural landscape of the surrounding High Atlas mountains.
Great shopping!. Huge area, easy to get become disorientated. Friendly atmosphere, not at all hassling. Go in afternoon when it is quieter.

a visit is a must. we preferred the visit in the evening. It's much less hassle and you can see everything lit up at night. The Moroccans are friendly and not too pushy. This visit was a very important part of our viist to Marrakech!
shopping!. really fun for buying souveniers and bits and pieces!! Insane shopping experience, but really good- a must do in marrakech!
Frightening. It takes a lot to make me feel intimidated but I did here. My husband was hit twice by mopeds as we wandered around. Not an enjoyable experience

Chaos you have to experience at least once!. Chaotic is the only way to describe it! if you go to Marrakech you have to see the main square and the Souks but for goodness sake be careful and aware of your surroundings, i dont care what anyone says about the locals they are fine but will harras you and will rip you off wherever possible. Avoid the men with monkeys at all costs, they put the monkey on your arm and then wont take it off until you pay them silly money, always always agree a price first for everything, the women doing henna will try and draw on you without you consenting and then you again will have to pay silly money for it, one had me in a vice grip trying to draw on my hand and i hadn't said i wanted anything! The stuff in the market varies, some stalls have good quality stuff and others dont, but always bargin! Its the whole fun of the place! If you can, avoid taxis at all costs, once you are in they try and take you to their uncle or friends store instead of where you want to go, and if you refuse (like we did) they take you and drop you in the middle of nowhere! not very helpful or friendly! Also dont stray too far, always know your way back to the main square when you go exploring the square, we got lost for a good 45 mins as it was getting dark and i have to say it was the most intimidated i have ever felt! All in all its mad, they treat there animals awfully (you will see horridly skinny horses and donkeys and was disappointed to say some tourists paid for carriage rides which only makes it worse and means they continue to make the horses work to death in the awful heat), they try and scam you and rip you off at every turn but its not something i would have missed, honestly really like another world but so glad i saw it ... and then got back to the safety of the hotel pool where i stayed for the remainder of the holiday! lol! If you are a little apprehensive I would suggest going to one of the cafes on the side of the market that are on top of the buildings, that way you can sit with a drink and watch the madness unfold below, its really amazing to look down on the market square as it goes from day to night, and you feel a little safer not being in among the mayhem!

Constantly Harassed!!.... Visited at 11;30am... From the moment we arrived we were targeted!.. And harassed into trying to pay for a tour guide!.. Which we didn't need or want!.. Despite saying " no!, no Thank you!", scare tactics was then used to " you will be pick pocketed!!!, you need a guide"... This lasted for at least half hour!. We were then forced to look at things we had no interest in buying... When we showed no interest in wanting to purchase anything the Men became very aggressive!!.. And at times rude and offensive!. Everything is overpriced... And haggling is exhausting because they take offence!!.. I ended up buying nothing and we left after 45 minutes!. Instead we spent our money at a lovely hassle free place called Plaza ( modern city) where we saw the exact same things bring sold in the souks for less than half the price!. We revisited on our last day at 3:15pm because we needed a cash point to find a completely different atmosphere... No harassment, and less busy and more calmer.... We realised that because it was Ramadan everything dies down at this time..... Probably the best time to go to avoid the constant harassment!.

chaotic. many things, if you wanna buy something, negotiate!!! its easy to get lost in the streets.. the locals will tell you "the street is closed" and try to navigate you,dont trust them, they just take you another way and ask for money

Fantastic!!!. If you choose to holiday in Marrakech then this is exactly what you expect to see. Excellent atmosphere and great experience. Personally after reading reviews and having been to various other African countries such as Kenya and having explored Eygpt where we were harrassed and hassled constantly I was concerned about this experience. However it was so much friendly than any other holiday I have been on. Yes it is a very busy place and people do approach you to look in their souks, a simple smile or no thank you and they leave you alone! They were such lovely people and we even got lost twice and they helped us find our way back to the main square. Be prepared for hussle, however no-one hassled us if we said no and we were able to explore at our leisure. Of course it is very hectic and we visited mainly in the day when it was less busy. We had great fun bartering as they expect you to do and got some amazing bargins, just start to walk off and then they drop the price. As long as you are aware that there will be people approaching you, but no where near to the extend we were expecting you will have a lovely experience. Even if you just pop in to have a look at get a taste for the city its well worth it!

Another world!. Went several times to the souk, without a guide and loved it. We eventually got our bearings in what is a maze of madness. At times it can be very busy with scooters racing past and the occassional donkey and cart, in what are narrow walkways and, on our last day, a small van was edging its way through the crowds which left little space - enough for people to pass in single file. Having said that there are areas that are really also very quiet. You get calls from young men asking if you are looking for the square, do you want to see the 'dyers area' etc etc and stall holders asking you to see their wares. The only hands on people were those delling scarves,.All in all a great experience, even the bartering (once you get the hang of it) is great fun,
mad. really bustling manic and busy! if you can cope with this, its lovely! not for the faint hearted though! interesting selection of stuff to buy but be firm and say no if you don't want it!!

For us it was missable. The constant begging and motorbikes buzzing past you spoil this, we look at 'stuff' for sale as would you have it even if it was free and there was nothing that we liked, needed or wanted on any stall. This maybe a great place for some people but for us it was just like a very average market but in an oven with your life being put in danger by passing motorbikes.

BARGAINS!!!!!!!!!!!!. so so sos so so so goodforget the Harrods sale. my advice is be prepared to buy a bag, to fill with all the stiff you will buy. the market is STUNNING. you will get lost and that is cool relax and just ask for directions every now and again. you will always be shown for a small token tip ;)take pictures of leather bags you lie back home including the designer brands, go to the leather makers and they will make the same thing for you no difference but for £50 topalways cut whatever the guy offers as his best price in half at least and BARTER, if you dont then its no fun and the sellers dont enjoy it nor will youyou have to go its a must so so so good

Be positive!. Hey, you are continually harrassed! so be prepared and take it as a bit of fun! Look out for the live chickens, and bunnies!! have to keep fresh somehow, goats heads in wicker baskets and plenty of spice, flies, smells and want a taxi!

Marrakech: An unmissable city!!. I just loved marrakech!!!!!Marrakech is a mystical city and is full of live. The streets of the souks, the smells, rhythms, sounds and the warm colors of this city are fascinating. It is impossible not to like Marrakech.The Souks:In the souks we can find everything: Olives, mint, fruit and vegetables, meat, clothes, musical instruments, carpets, lanterns, scarves, shoes, jewelry, among other things.Exploring the souks is an adventure, and escape without being hit by sellers with hand carts, bikes, donkeys or people is a real achievement.If you don´t want to be bother by the sellers a don’t-mess-with-me expression may work =)

Dont forget to negotiate your price.... Historically tourists were harassed by vendors in this souk, but a visible tourist police force has almost completely stopped this. Our experience was very positive, and we also found some very interesting items to bring home. If you will be going to Essaouira, keep in mind that the souk there tends to have better prices, though many items seem reasonable in both shopping areas compared to prices back home.Don't be afraid to work your way into the back layers of the souk, as you will come across pockets of shops where Moroccans actually shop, not just tourists, and this is pretty interesting too.
cheap as chips!!!. great bargins to b had...just need to barter or you will get ripped off...xloads of choice to choose from, trainers,converse..ect,,,, just be prepared to get a bit of hassle....lol
Great experience. There were many children begging, hurts your heart. It was cleaner than the other souks in Morocco, and good for tourists. Safe

Fascinating, but avoid the tanneries. The souk is crowded, loud, and crazy. Motorbikes compete with pedestrians even in the narrow alleys. Hawkers can be relentless. Avoid trying to visit the tanneries. Young men will tell you it is the last day for the tanneries but it isn't true. If you need to ask for directions, ask a shop owner or a family, not a young man.
souk. what a maze, guide is useful even if its just to get out of the souk. again, interesting info can be gained by having a guide, such as the election info chalked on the wall

The best Moroccan Shop in the New City. Selection Artisanales has the most eclectic mix of items. It has bags, silver thé sets, jewellery, paintings, rug...You name it...Let this be your first stop. It's worth going to this shop, because there are a lot of interesting things and the prices are very low compared to the Shouks in Jemaa el Fna, Marrakech.

Get Excess luggage - you will need it.. Its hard to know where to start with this review. Firstly you need to know - I love to shop. The souks runs off Jemaa el Fna. They wind and twist for miles. You could get lost, however most lanes lead back to the square. The shopping here is amazing. Lanterns, leather everything, ceramic everything, arabic bowls, spices, potions, perfumes, cooking utensils, tea sets, linen, clothes, did I say lanterns? The best part of it all is the bartering. Go in with an easy going nature, smile, joke and you will "think" you get a bargain. I drive a hard bargain, however when you haggling over a dollar, I tend to back down. I saw some tourists get a bit upset with the vendors, its all about attitude - if your guarded, they will be. They love to chat and and at one souk I was there for over an hour to buy a bedspread and some cushions he offered 10,000 camels if i would stay with him. What would i do with 10,000 camels? The souks are open all day but I found them best at dusk. They are busy, noisy and lots of fun. If you are a shopper you will spend hours here. If not, visit to experience the bartering. Relax and enjoy it. Take some of your local money, especially gold coins - they love it!

Do you have money to spend?. You can find decorative but useful things as well. Do not accept the initial price they ask you to pay. Do not stop bargains until you get the price you want. Hang around and locate the shops you want till the time you decide to buy. Make bargains and always pretend to leave the shop unsatisfied till you hit your target.
A well of smell and colour. Loved the Souks and could walk there for hours. We went there several times, and did not find the traffic a problem. The rule was simple, walk to the right :)

Which souk ? => visit them all !. Whether it's leather, copper, woodcraft, jewelry, pot and pans or herbs you're interested in, you'll find plenty of choice for good prices. Negotiate HARD, so when asked a hundred, instead offer THREE and find your common ground around thirty. Don't be afraid, it's a game everybody like to do.

At the end of the day it's shops. You might be an avid collector of holiday tat, you might not ... but if you are then this is the place for you. Lots and lots of shops ... not my sort of thing at all ... you have to see it while you're there ... but I don't need to go back

Need to go to the Souk. I have to say that we did have fun in the Souks in Marrakech. Its nice to get the sense and mingle with the locals and enjoy some haggling. One thing I couldn't stand was the constant need to keep checking over your shoulder just in case a motorbike decides to run you over. Imagine shopping in your local shop market and motorbikes going up the isles.. Shocking and how nobody gets killed / seriously injured frequently is a miracle.
Don't miss this. Why come to Marrakech if you are not going to visit the souks? Keep your eyes peeled and be sensible and you will have a great time. This is what Marrakech is all about!
souks. brilliant shops and all sorts of trinkets and fresh fruit i f you do not find what you are looking for here you never will
The Hard Sell!. These guys know every bargaining trick in the book. No matter how smart you think you are in getting the price down they will best you.

Absolutely mental... !. I have rated this attraction as a 5 star although i did not think it was the first time i visited it. I had read reviews on here and was very excited to visit it as everyone made it sound so beautiful, amazing and a crazy experience. So when i visited it the first time i was... (the only word i can use is)....... TERRIFIED. When we stepped off the bus, fake guides followed us until we told them firmly 'no thanks' which was scary.... i wanted to avoid seeing the snakes and the monkeys because I think it is cruel so we headed in the other direction to the souks. The souks were an experience as every turn you made it was another souk.... shoes.... spices..... jewellery.... so much stuff. There are cars and motorbikes zooming along side you which was daunting also. I had been warned about the henna ladies and at one point seen one aprroaching us and we ran away. Also, one of the guys with a monkey on his shoulder came up behind us and i ran away as i did not want the image of a monkey in chains in my head. i left the market thinking OH.... MY.... GOD.... Mental !! we decided to return to the market the following week and im so glad we did as we got to experience the real marrakech. We bought some amazing fake converse, jewellery and a football top. Many of the shop keepers are very friendly. Some called me lady gaga and said they loved my pale white skin. We also got chatting to a guy in an orange juice stand and he asked us to come into his stall and take a picture with him. We would have loved to have sat on a cafe and watched the world go by. All you have to remember is if you want someone to leave you alone tell them NO THANKS.... easy. they will walk away. it is honestly such an amazing experience.... its so busy and there are definately alot of smells to take in.... including spices, donkeys, horses, and sewage. Do not pass on the opportunity to visit the jemaa el fna market. I loved it the 2nd time and aslong as you get involved you will enjoy it too.

Must see. Just walk and experience the souk, go in early in the morning when everyone is starting up. Be prepared to negotiate, it's ok, they expect it! Friendly people, they don't harass you like in Egypt. Be prepared that when someone helps you or points the way, they expect money; but hey, that's ok, it's only a dollar or so.

Magical Maze!. I got all my souvenirs and gifts to take home from the souk and hardly spent a penny! Everyone I spoke to in the souk spoke 'almost' perfect english and bartering was easy. Look out for the authentic hand made items, as most of the stalls sell fakes. There are a few jewellery stores in the souk and they are worth a look, they have some interesting pieces and are reasonably priced.
A Shopper's Paradise. Reminds me of the shopping in the undergrounds of Shanghai, China. I don't really like the haggling. It wearies me. I would rather just get the bottom price, pay and move on.

Exciting. Wandering around the souks in Marrakech is amazing. I would say you have to watch the mopeds, they can be very annoying and have no respect for the people walking around. There are so many sights to see, you could do with a few days. I only spent a night in Marrakech and felt by the following morning I was able to find my way around with ease. The square at night is a totally different experience with all the food sellers and definitely one not to miss. I was determined to experience the whole of Marrakech so eat at one of the stalls, I wasn't disappointed. I choose a beef tangine and can report no tummy upset after. Just take your time look for a busy stall one that the locals frequent and you'll be fine, give it a try.

Souk of Marrakech - Fascinating. You have to walk the souks of Marrakech and take in the ambience, the smells, the noise. We did have a guide which was useful as we dnt miss any of it and the rules are that you not get pestered if with an official guide. But you can do this without. A fascinating place. Much busier than my previuos souk visit which was Muscat.
shopping mania. so much choice. the price variations could be a bother but its goes as part of the experience
They Love To Bargain. To the vendors it's a game they enjoy and they are good at it in a variety of languages and currencies.
best shopping!. got to drive for a bargain but you will get one. Leather and lanterns top of the list!

Touristy but still amazing. Overlooking the daily activities at the square with a cup of mint tea or coffee at a cafe is superb. You don't want to take a photo with the performers such as men 'selling' water and playing with the monkey. You could just walk past them without looking them into the eyes when they were approaching you. They won't bother you anymore. But once you play with their monkey or take photos with them, you must pay them.The food at the night market is a rip-off. It was expensive and the people were aggressive. I was even charged for the bread and olives which was supposed to be free. Let alone they sometimes charged tourists three or four times more than the locals.

Exellent place to shop. i love to visite that souk where you can enjoy a good shopping, good articles specialy tradional products... For men, women and kids.....The best thing you will enjoy is that you will discover a new sport called negotiating.....all the prices are high by 30 to 50% so you need to bargain your price......With crises of tourism the prices are low people need to sale their products and make moneyEnjoy your shopping.....don't buy from first sight come next day you may get it cheaperAllam

Magic craziness!. Make sure you have at least three days to do the Souk. The first day you will be overwhelmed, the second day you will start making friendships with the less aggressive salesmen and the third day you can go back to make some deals!
Bartering and Pestering. Very good bargains to be had - Very Cultural - Watch out for the mopeds and barrows.

If you're not ready to haggle... don't go. I love haggling. I'm the embarassing person who would haggle in shops. so this was like paradise to me. There are stalls everywhere. It's small, there are narrow corridors, everywhere you look there are things to buy. If you didn't feel like you were on holidays, now you do.All you need to do is ask the price and walk away! They will chase you! This is a great holiday experience where they expect you to bargain the price down so if you don't well it's your loss and their gain.I paid 10 dirhams for a pair of earrings that a lady before me had paid 100. They will price according to what you look like so dress down when you go there and just remind them you are a tourist not a pigeon.It's important to look around before you buy or you will be tempted to buy everything.I must say i did end up buying a lot of things which i will never use and did get carried away with the shoppig frenzy and that good deal feeling.The one negative point I would say is that many people are selling the same things which is not great for that unique holiday souvenir but is good for business (yours).
Big souk, lots of sights. Leather products were not as nice but pricier than Fez. Otherwise lots of variety, many things to see, great to find interesting souvenirs to take back home.
the most intersting place to get lost in. bargain hard, enjoy the smells, colours and modern versus antiquity, so polite and not at all pushy like we had been warned, just be firm.

ello geezer! wanna take a shufti?. loved it. spent loads of time over a ten day trip, just wandering about and looking. forget all the advice about not making eye-contact and not looking at anything. some will give it the chat, some won't. what you do doesn't matter. so go ahead and look. it's what you came for isn't it?the general advice is pay 40-50% of their opening price. in fact, in many cases, you really should not pay more than 10%. do you think they don't know what you've been told? take a look at the pictures on this site before you go. think about what you might be interested in. and check out it's price on the internet. for instance, googling 'moroccan carpet' or 'kaftan' brings up loads of sites. spending so much time in the souks, i did begin to wonder how much the residents of the medina resent the tourist trade. much of the stuff on the market, fake leather shoes, highly glazed ceramics, thin monkey metal lanterns, has no use at all to a local person. and those places must have displaced a good number of useful, everyday shops.there are good buys to be had. the further you are from the square, the more 'real' the shops. baking tins, cookie-cutters, thread, embroidery silk, trimmings, fabric, all these are extremely good value. do keep your money safe, and watch/listen out for mopeds, bikes, donkeys and handcarts. if you can get out of the way, do. these guys are working, not on holiday....although others call it crazy, mayhem, bedlam and the like, i was always pleased and relaxed to get back into the 'safety' of the souks when i'd been over to the kasbah or in the new town. and i never got lost once. i had a map and a compass. simple!
Great experience with friendly people. Souks not too pushy and happy just to chat. Remember to seriously haggle if you want to buy something.

crazy but nice. it's more that what you can imagine : it's an incredible experience. Moroccan art is beautiful. Carpets, lamps, plates, clothes, jewelry, leather, and much more. You will loose your way, but with pleasure !

Interesting, smelly, noisy, and fun!. Went here with my wife and 3 daughters (12, 9, and 7) so was in ultra protective mode to start with but didn't really need to be. My 12 year old got plenty of winks from the younger boys but all the stall holders were polite and could take a "non Merci" without hassle and it didn't feel too intimidating at all.Got some good leather and crockery and although the girls called my haggling technique "arguing" it was all part of the fun and every sale ended with a handshake and a smile.I paid about 40% of the starting prices on everything and had to use the tactic of I'm leaving as too high on most of those so stand firm! I'm sure they still make a decent margin at that price as they offered me cups of tea and gave the kids gifts.
Market. Good fun and well worth a trip better to walk down and get a cab back.

A sensory over-load. There is so much to see, smell, hear and taste in these souks. They are incredibly colourful and energetic, with loads of different products and skills to see. The main square is quite a sight with all the performers. I didn't like the monkeys on chains but other than that it was a brilliant experience.

best souk for shopping. i really love this place - been here many times . please note that the further you move away from the Fna the easier it is to haggle and prices are far more affordable . also shopkeepers are less agressive.
An Aladins cave. It's a must to see both during the day and at night

Step back in time. We decided to take a guide so not to be hasseled and found we were less of a victum than we would have been otherwise. Thought it was wounderful to see and experience 2 hours and we were finished though.
Can Be Exhausting. You really have to be rested and in the right frame of mind to deal with the souks. But avoid being rude or losing your temper at the merchants agressiveness.

stick closely to your guide. The narrow streets of the souk run in circles and can be confusing if you don't watch out for some landmarks. A huge variety of goods and fresh produce for sale with endless motorcycles weaving in and out along very narrow streets.

Marrakech. We spent 4 nights in Marrakech and had planned this 8 months in advance and done loads of research and watched many a travel programme on Marrakech.We love markets and eating the local cuisine and Travel programmes spoke so highly of the wonderful foods and markets. We polished up on our bargaining skills and approached Marrakech with an open mind.After our trip we sat down and discussed where we had been and our opinions on our trip.OverAll Experience: Was it a circus or side show?Food: Very dissapointed - not enough spices/flavour. Found the food to be very stoggy!Markets: Rip Off of the highest degree, one can only bargain so far.People: Staff at Riad were fantastic. On the street - rude and appears that the tourists are only there for their money. I was shouted at for taking a photo of the carpets in Medina!? Hands are held out for a smile? I believe that tourists should be treated with some respect as they do boost the economy and do create jobs.Transport: Be careful, a local lady shared a taxi with us and paid 4 dinah for her trip and we paid 40 for an extra kilometer?? I certainly will not forget the experience but for all the wrong reasons. Marrakech is overrated and not a place I would return to.Travel is a huge part of our lives and we have visited many cities around the world.
