Lot of varieties. in Marrakesh souk you will find whatever you are looking for; I think it's the biggest among all other Morrocan Cities; you have to bargin; but in nice manner....and when price agreed don't argue further

Magical and Amazing. The souks are never-ending mazes of surprises. There are four things you need to navigate the souks. 1. A companion you trust with a good sense of direction 2. Sunglasses so you don't have to make eye contact with aggressive vendors (don't worry they aren't that bad) 3. The book "shopping in Marrakech" which has detailed maps and walks (the alleys are not marked, so this book was super helpful 4. A professional guide on your first day to help you get acquainted.

Get lost. Mingle with the locals!They will "touch your shoulder" to bring you in their store but they won't harass you! Learn to bargain!Don't worry getting lost but don"t listen to the "voluntary guides" you will encounter walking by you.(better book one in advance)If you don't have a guide :when ready to return to your Riad/hotel ask for directions to the merchantmen.

be ready be hassled. it a maze of different finds. from leather to cheap tacky fakes. we got some nice items for the house like painting, cushions etc. they quote you big prices. i realise that i had to take 2/3 off the price. and if they refuse, then just walk away. they usually ask you back if they give the price u ask for. beware that the souk, sometimes the quality is not great and the finishing are not perfect. the leather bags were a good buy.
MADNESS!. It takes a few days to get used to the hustle and bustle and being mithered every two seconds be sellers but thats the souks!
Good natured shopping. One important thing, when you said 'No thank you ' firmly , you were with good nature left alone.
Yeah this is a bustling hub. Getting out if the square and into the souks is a welcome relief....plenty to see, haggle over and buy and mostly very good humoured.

Shopping and bargaining. Told the guide from the Raid that I wanted to shop for some jewellery in the souk, he took me to this shop he knows. I liked 2 pieces, the total price was 6,500Dh. I managed to bargain down to 3,900Dh; Later that day; I went to Garden Majorelle by myself. the same pieces were on sale for 1,000Dh each. I don*t blame anyone but myself, buyers beware. Lesson learnt.Aussie88

Good fun, lots to see and get lost. I loved the coulorfullmess, hated all the men following you and trying to get you n their shops. And the guides always taking you to special places where they have the same and more expensive.

Sensory Overload - Watch your Wallet. Colors, sounds, people can be overwhelming. A huge variety of goods in a huge variety of quality can be found in this market. Visitors are invited into every stall and encouraged to spend money. Uneducated buyers may find themselves purchasing low value goods for high value prices. Do your research, buy quality you appreciate at a price you are willing to pay.Walking through the souk, taking photographs and soaking in the atmosphere costs nothing and is quite the experience.

Take it all in. We took our time, shopping for mini-tagines (conical pottery for preparing stew) and looking at wonderful lambskin lamps and other artisanal items. It was hopeful to be able to bargain sometimes and feel that we could all come out all right in the end. Loved all the color and activity! Dislikes? Just some of the more aggressive sellers, but they were in the minority.

Souks - what are they really like?. Very busy, narrow spaces. If your not interested in something or someone is bothering you say 'no' or 'la' (arabic for 'no') but be polite and confident, if they continue say 'no' with more force then move on. It may seem impolite but if you are firm and then ignore them they go away (it's what the locals do). Make minimal eye contact. Don't get into bartering for something unless you actually want the item. You can be there a very long time (they will make mint tea). Decide how much you are willing to pay for it then start at 1/3 of the price - it will go up. If you like it buy it - prices are cheaper than in the UK and considerably so if you barter well and the Souks are a maze you will not be able to find your way back to the same stall! Start at the Ensemble Artisanal to get an idea of the prices at the higher end it will help you when you're looking for bargains. Relax, but be confident, watch where you're going there are bikes and scooters everywhere. Don't keep all your money in the same wallet. Enjoy the experience. If it gets to much make your way back to the main square for a break (but try not to ask for directions from the locals) ask other tourists which way they came in.

Go find the real Moroccan Souk. Don't be frightened to explore the depths of the real Souk way at the back where you will see the proper shops, butchers chopping their meat, tripe and intestines, spices and herbalists, apothecaries selling chameleons and tortoises for medicinal purposes and the fruit and veg streets. The Souk is not just for the tourists, it is for the Moroccans to do their everyday shopping and that;'s the authentic part! Don't be wary, the people are friendly and helpful - everyone helped us with directions when we were lost and we never felt threatened or worried. Enjoy!
shopping. The souks were a welcome retreat from the hot sunshine. Be prepared to bargain hard as starting prices are ridiculously high.

good fun. Great day out in the souks. Had lots of fun bartering with the stall holders, Lots of nice things to buy at your price, barter politely and you will get a bargin and a happy smile from the stall holder. Be friendly and respectful cover your shoulders if you are a lady.
Great shopping. mirrors, lampshades, hats, baskets, herbs, mirrors, leather slippers - wonderful

Same same but different and more expensive.. Save your money and see the real Morocco instead of haggling over the same thing in every store. If I could just find a few more places where they had ticketed pricing I might have had a more relaxed fun time.

Salesmen are pushy, but it's a great place to shop. I wish the salesmen would understand that hounding tourists to come into their shop actually makes tourists not want to go in there. They need to know: I want to buy something because I like what you are selling, Mr. Salesman, not because you pressured me to buy something. Friendliness and the chance to browse at my leisure will increase the chances that I will buy something, not telling me I must come in for two minutes and that looking is free, then giving me a dirty look when I don't buy anything. That said, take your time and look around at the things you want to buy. Quality varies, as do prices, so buy what ou think is well-made and is a fair price. Bargaining is expected there, so expect to pay at least 30% less than what they first quoted you. If you don't like the price you are quoted, walk away. Chances are you'll see the same item at another shop within five minutes. Have fun, and ship your purchases home from the post office in Djemaa el Fna if they don't fit in your suitcase.

So many Souks!. A labyrinth of Souks awaits you to one side of the main square. While you can find many interesting items to purchase you'll often be confronted with pushy sales people. At one point one of them told me "We need the money!". It was a bit strange but if you can deal with haggling a little bit then this place is a must see. Even if you don't I would recommend walking through the Souks, most won't hassle you too much if you keep walking.

Wow. Get lost in the souk and discover friendly people everywhere. All is negotiable, and Marrakech is one of the most expensive places in Morocco, so haggle, don't be shy - have fun and a laugh with the locals.
Shopping heaven. Always a delight to explore the souks and experience all the sights and sounds of a buzzing marketplace of delights.

.A real eye opener.. Try to go as early as its very hot after 11am. The shop owners have a difficult job to sell their products as there is so much competition. Try your haggling skills its fun but remember they are there to earn a living and although we want a bargain most prices are fair. One time is only pay half of the original price quoted.

Colorful place with lots to see and buy !. A "must-do" when in Marrakech. Whether it#s the spices, the wool, the soaps, the handcrafts, the food or souvenirs....just being in the souk is something you will never forget. the noise, the smells, the people and animals walking around. It is a bit overwhelming at first but a fun experience. Soon you will be able to find your way around the souks too, it is not as complicated as it appears to be on first sight.

Getting lost and hasle. The place was good for bartring but you would ger grabed to go and buy and very easy to get lost go with a guid if a local offer,s to take you dont go as they will take you anywear and leave you of take you to there shop and want you to buy.
Classic. Truly a classic spot, well worth UNESCO rating, not the high pressure sales I was expecting.

A Real Experience. The first timeyou visit it can seem a bit intimidating. It is a maze of tiny lanes lined with stalls and bartering merchants and you must haggle or you will pay two or three times what you should!It is great fun and a place to go for real bargains and more importantly you get a sense and feel for the real Marrakech of days gone by.
Worth the Experience. An assault on the senses but worth a visit. You will never experience anything else like it. Be very wary of pick pockets!
a maze. some bargains to be had but you must haggle, you will get lost but what a place to be lost in.

Fun to Visit. The souks, markets, in Marrakech are fun to explore. Tons of stuff and great prices. Haggling to get even better prices can make it like a game of wills if you prefer. Most stalls have similar stuff, and the same types of goods; leather, pottery, lanterns; get clumped together. So explore different areas and compare prices. Also the coops are a great place to get better quality stuff without high pressure sales tactics.
Love to shop. Loved the bustle and bartering getting some great spices a tajine to try some Moroccon dishes at home
Lost.... You can get lost in the souks full of clothes, plates, morrocan lights, bowls and lanterns wonderful for shopping.
In your face!. Be prepared to be pulled into a shop or taken by a 'guide' and have money demanded for their 'service'.

What a riot of colour!!. Get yourself lost in amongst an array of clothes, metal lanterns, food and ceramics... That's half the fun just getting totally lost and seeing where you come out! If you can't get your bearings when you emerge just ask a local for directions back to Jemaa el fna. Haggle hard and you can get yourself a bargain. Be prepared to walk away if it seems expensive, chances are they'll follow you and negotiate a better price.
A complete culture shock. As with everywhere else make sure you haggle properly or they'll get upset and don't get put off when the shop owner asks 2000 Dihram for a pair of slippers!
Colourful and interesting. Great warren of shops/stalls from TV's to slippers.

Marrakech. I had a really facinating week in Marrakech The souk was so interesting with all the different products from live stock to leather goods and jewellery In the evening the main square turns into a fast food paradise with locals setting up stalls to intise you
Colourful. Quite a maze, hard to work your way without getting lost at first. But take note of route names where there is one and landmarks.

Everything you expect. It was 95 degrees, so the dark medieval areas were especially appealing, they felt cool and mysterious. Lots of fun shopping. It felt safe and welcoming. We generally had a guide, which I am sure made the experience easier. We were in the main square at dusk, and the water sellers were a trip, as were the snake charmers. For 20 dirhams we had photos with snakes wrapped around our necks. Didn't eat at any of the stalls, though.

Interesting. Make sure you hire a guide to take you around the souks. Not only do they provide you with information and history about Marrakech and Morrocco, they tell you where the best place to shop is and advice you on haggling!

Just truly unmissable.. Lots of noise and bustle especially in the evenings as it starts to get dark. Don't be intimidated as there's really NOT much hassle at all from shopkeepers and stallholders. Not sure how they survive really as most stalls sell a lot of the same stuff. PLEASE take time to wander, We saw all kinds of things including falcons, hedgehogs,acrobats, snakecharmers,dentists and the ever present henna ladies who didn't hassle AT ALL.I loved it all.

Fun. Wow!!! This is an experience!, but be prepared to negotiate the prices. since I did not know what things really cost there, I paid what I was willing to even if I knew I was paying more, since they looked like they needed that little margin more than us.

Loved the haggling!. The souks were crowded and busy and very interesting. My husband and I did run into a few men who wanted to hassle us, but a few firm words of mixed french and english, and they got the message that we were not interested and they left us alone. Just don't be timid. As far as the actual sellers go, everyone wants you to come into their area/stall and buy something from them. They are a little persistent but as long as you have a good sense of humor and remember exactly what you want, you'll be fine. My husband is a little more timid than me and he was just fine and had a good time. I think everyone should go into the souks even for just a little walk. They're pretty twisted and narrow, but definitely fun and a unique experience!

Loved the souks!!. The souks of Marrakech are so fun, even if you are not a shopper. Take cash, as ATMs are hard to find and not a ton of the shops take credit card. We ended up buying a lot of souvenirs, many of which are now displayed in our home. Highly recommended to anyone staying in Marrakech!
An experience. Always remember to haggle.... and 50% of the original price is still too much

Everything in a place. Marrakech souk is all I expected, full of colours, smells, mistery! I walked from one store to another and loved! The first day with a guide and the other days with my husband. It' necessary to bargain, a lot, and it's a little bit tiring, but worth it!
Brilliant. Loved it, my eyes were on swivels and so was my bank account when I left the herbalist!

Marrakech Souks. The sights, sounds and smells was incredible, mopeds coming at you from every direction. If you try and take photos of any of the street entertainers, snake charmers, acrobats etc, you will be pestered for money. Watch out for the men who will suddenly put a snake around your neck or let a monkey climb on your back, your'll be expected to cough up again. A firm 'No thank you' was enough for them to leave you alone. Bartering was good fun, whatever the price asked for it was possible to get it down to a third.

If you love bargaining this is the place!. A labirynthic heaven for shopping and contact with the real moroccan culture. Sellers can be quite harassing if you show an interest over something, so do it only if you're willing to spend time bargaining - it's fun and part of the experience.

Shopping avenue. One of the "must do" things in Marrakech is go shopping in the Souk.This is a large and wide open market that offer everything imaginable. From luxury goods and antiques to humble babouches. It is mainly covered, so the heat of the day can not tamper much with your desire of finding something beautiful to bring home as a memento of this magic city.I found that the vendors were not as pushy as in other places I have been, which indeed made a difference when trying just to look around.Once you have found a piece of your liking (in my case a carpet) the barging time starts and just then, they could become overbearing. Nevertheless, the experience is great and they always try to meet your expectations. Do not worry if you dont speak Arab or French, most vendors manage English, Spanish, Italian and even German!Visiting the Souks is always a nice way to enjoy the cultural heritage of each place. It shows the colors, the aromas, customs and traditions of every nation and makes you realize how wonderfully diverse we are.And yes, the beautiful kilim rug we fell in love with decorates now my living room ;)
Amazing!. Loved it. Our first visit. Will definitely go back. Amazing place, people and culture. So much to take in and only 5 days. Really looking forward to our next trip.

go for sure but be aware of things. brilliant place to visit but if you're a little nervous just look around and buy/haggle at the stalls around the market square - same stuff available with less stress

Stray from the touristy bits. The souks are so magical but I'd recommend straying from the touristy areas nearer the Medina and discover the antique areas and herbs/spices etc to see how the locals live. Must haggle or you'll be ripped off. Have in your head the price you are willing to pay - the suggestions of offering 1/3 of what they say is often too much still. Laugh off their original price and offer extremely low then you can meet somewhere near the bottom/middle. They will quote tourists a much higher price than locals. Have a walk around to get a feel of what's available before buying. And I wouldn't ask for prices unless you actually want something because they will hassle you.
It's an experience. It was sensory overload, with the smells and colours. Dont' get involved in chat with those offering to show you round. Be prepared to barter in the shops/markets.

So much on offer. I am taking home 27 pairs of babouches slippers - bought some on a previous visit admired by friends and family - so had a shopping list. Go to the spice market and buy the freshest spices ever - and hammam gloves and black soap - a testament as to why the Marrakechi people have such lovely skin!

A Hagglers Paradise. The Souks arer well worth a visit particularly if you are looking for a bit of bargain shopping. Haggling is expected and prices will start high, but remember they want to sell so you can nornally come to a good compromise.Historically the Souks are also great to visit to glimpse Marrakech's medieval past, there are many workshops where you can see the merchandice being made. I wouldn't recommend it if you are travelling with a baby buggy or wheelchair as the allies are narrow and mopeds are frequently flying around the corners. I would also recommend you take someone with a good sense of direction as it is very easy to get turned around and lost.A must see when visiting Marrakech.
Crazy..... This was my third trip to Marrakech so I knew what to expect. Still love the place - go with an open mind....

A tourist trap. Endless alleys of stalls all selling the same things. Leather shops, scarf shops, copper shops, hundreds of each.Bargain like mad for everything - start at half the price that they start at. And certInly don't go higher than the halfway point between your two starting prices. You can't just browse and look at things at your leisure. Show the slightest interest and they pounce on you, "first time in morocco? Welcome my friend. What you want to buy? No pressure, we give you very good price at my uncle's shop, just look, don't buy if you don't want" and then it starts.Nice to look at and to get lost in, but you can't do that without constant hassle
Great if you can deal with the heat and dust!. You can by "anything"! Provided the crowds, unusual smells, heat and flies don't turn you off!

Must see. The Souks are really good - good to barter! Be careful with your handbag and make sure someone doesn't offer to show you around - they will expect a lot of money from you! Always say no!! It is a bit of a labryinth, but, if you keep your wits about you, you'll find your way out - it's not that bad - just don't go too far into it - There's not much to see in the centre of the Souks - It's mainly on the outside and towards the middle - You'll know when to turn around as the stalls start to thin out. Extremely worth going though!!
Shop till you drop. take it all in and go back and back and back. Fin corners the usual flock of people wander into
shops shops shops. walk around and get a look at the shops, dont ever buy the asked price or you will be sorry.

Only Do It Once..... I visited the souks with my partner and teenage kids while on our visit last July 2011. There are some really nice things to look at and stunning bright colours surrounding you. The people here arnt very polite, they dont always take NO for an answer and can hound you constantly to buy. Its very hard to look when your getting harrassed. The locals will expect money if they give you directions, even if you dont ask for them. One local got abusive when my partner refused to pay them, we didnt even ask for directions! I didnt enjoy my time in the souks however i am glad i have tried it and know not to do it again.

A must do, but . . .. I just don't like the hassle, especially being told constantly that what I was looking for (Museuem, gallery, etc) was closed, they could take me somewhere better. This is rubbish. Be firm and tell them to go away.
take care!. Perhaps everybody knows that Arabic trade should be taken with caution. O the other hand, it needs some time to get used, and then it might become attractive.

Great rug-buying experience. We recently purchased a gorgeous Berber rug from Aux Merveille De Marrakech, 14 Souk Semmarine in the medina. A friend of a friend bought here last year, so we gave it a try. Be prepared to take time, drink some mint tea, bargain down to ridiculously low prices and say you'll return after lunch. They won't let you leave. We purchased a 6,000 dirham rug for 1,600. It was stress-free in what is otherwise a totally stressful shopping environment.

Wonderful shopping but here are a few gems. The souks are an amazing place to shop unlike many western places. You can find fabulous leather, spices like saffron, pottery like serving dishes and fun souvenirs like Moroccan shoes and thobes. However there are a few gems here including La Porte d'Or and La croix d'Agadez, the former for rugs and the latter for wooden sculptures. They aren't aggressive in their negotiations and while you pay a bit more they are authentic pieces

ONCE IN A LIFETIME EXPERIENCE. If you are looking for the Morocco of old movies, this is the place. It is non stop people watching, and once the food stalls open after evening prayer, it is a non stop beehive of humanity. From stalls specializing in Escargots (snails) to fresh squeezed orange juice, to fabulous salad plates and meats of all kinds, this is the spot. Watch a snake charmer with his cobras and other snakes, watch the local dancers do their things. Be prepared however, as to take photo's one expects a coin of 5 dirham for compensation. Best bet is to go to one of the many upper care's and get a seat near the railing, sip your local very strong coffee and click away. It is a real treat for photographers
Agressive Bargaining. These is where you really test you skills. The vendors know can calculate in any currency and bargain in any language.

Dangerous. I did not enjoy my time in Marrakech. People would try to grab you as you walked by. Between the traffic and the environment, I never felt safe. The animals were pitiful. Some people had chained monkeys with diapers on. It was also sad and heartbreaking.

the souk. now if this wasn't the most thrilled experience, winding your way thru this maze of shops,food stands and people. so exciting, loved every moment. had a great guide so we did not get lost. be careful sending parcels home and make sure that the address is clearly labelled as their printing is not as clear as ours?? got it..print boldly the information and give a cel,# where you can be contacted if the postal service needs to call you..have fun, great shops, carpets,,,,careful where you buy the spices,don't go into those places where they try to sell everything....r.c.f.
hectic!. Definately need to visit while here but being two girls together felt a bit uncomfortable. Was harassed quite a bit and didn't like to look at anything for fear of never getting away.
smells and sounds. everything just relaxing letting go and getting absorbed by everything

super scary souk. well this sure was an experience we will never forget!the atmosphere is crazy, everybody wants you to buy their stuff and if you say no they dont give up, i even got pestered by a little boy around 10years old to buy a bag and i had to say no about 10 times before he gave up and went away!we actually bought nothing in marrakesh because we found it all too intimadating to go in their shops, we felt that if we went in we would never come back out! this wasnt the worst part though, in the middle of the souks there were snake charmers and men with monkeys on chains, there were 3 poor little monkeys outside in the sun all day with no water shoved on peoples shoulders for picture (which we ended up payin 20dirham for, u should give no more than 5) but the men swarm u with the monkeys and you feel as if you have no choice but to take a photo, the poor things are also made to were nappys, which i dont think get changed at any point. and the worst bit that we didnt see (until after dinner when another tourist told us) is that next to the men with the monkeys is a black/green box with a very small mess window for air WITH ABOUT 12 OTHER MONKEYS INSIDE!!!!!!!!!!!!! when we walked past the box was moving so the poor things must have been very distressed and hot. its all i could think about all day!that and the amount of horses made to pull carriages round all day in the sun, with no sign of anyone giving them water. one girl on the tour told a man his donkey need water and he laughed in her face! if u go i would recommend staying clear of making the poor horses pull you around on a carriage!!!!the souk is a great experience but the images of the poor animals has definatly scared us for life. would never go back. once is enough!oh and also we got called fish and chips and lemon chicken alot!!
Haggle if you can. I don't dislike anything about the Souk but you do have to be aware that you have to bargain and they will try and get one over on you. It has happened to me many times.
shopping heaven. Liked what was on offer, also liked the openess of bartering. Disliked feeling watched whilst shopping, i would have bought more if i was left to look on my own.

A definite 'Must See'. The souk is a massive place and you will get lost in there, but don't let that put you off.There's so much to see, the goods, the people, the colours and smells etc.If you've been to North Africa before you'll be used to the persistent selling manner of the traders but if you haven't a polite but firm ' no thanks ' usually works.Haggling is great fun and a cheeky offer combined with a smile avoids offence. Walking out of the shop and having them run after you is common!All I would advise is don't bother to start haggling if you have no intention of buying.Being right next to the main square you can't miss it.

A different world. This is a real experience, the people, what they are buying and selling, how they make a living, you can easily get lost so be careful and keep an eye on your wallet, there are animals, bicycles, motorbikes, taxis and all modes of transport on the narrow streets so you have to be careful, remember to carry water with you in case you get a little lost.
It's part of the tour.... Always fun, but can get tiresome with the same merchandise over and over...but must be done

SO much stuff!. Definately worth a walk through. Just walk to the right so you can see the bikes and the mopeds coming towards you. There is SO much there! Extraordinary! Unless you want to buy ignore all advances! Just wander through at your own pace....very easy to get lost.... ask a tourist if they know which way the square is or you are likely to taken to someones brother/uncle/fathers stall and strongly urged to make a purchase.

amazing place. What an amazing place, as long as you can just say no to those you dont require the services of you will have an amazing time and you can get cheap everything here. Check on mobile ebay prices of things you are interested in first to make sure you are paying at least half of what you would pay on ebay. It worked for me and my partner.
Madness. Just has to be visited, barter hard and don't point at the goods on show as the stall holders will be all over you!

It's a game. You have to be a smart trader too and play the game with the locals. In case a shop owner approach you, and you are not interested, stay calm and friendly but say resolute "NO merci" or "La shukran"

Old nice medina and colorful souks. Wao!! amazing place and real experience. The medina of Marrakech is the best of we have seen. The narrow alleys and the colorful hand crafts are something that you need to see and admire. Don't squander time and visit Marrakech and its souks.

Labrynthine alleys paved with gold. Chaotic bustle, you will get lost, but don't worry about it. Just enjoy marvelling at just how many trinkets they can fit into such a small space, and haggling and bantering with the vendors. No MArrakech trip is complete without a souk visit.
bit scary!. Must admit to being a bit intimidated by some of the souks. .. especially the ones with corrugated roofing! But quite an experience and not to be missed

Absolutely fantastic, once you get over the buzz. You have to go! Yes, when you first enter and get a little lost it can be a concern but ask a shopkeeper or stall assistant and they will help you to find your bearings. I am not a shopper but you cannot help being interested in the variety and quality of merchandise, some being made right in front of you. Stop off at the cafes and top up your fluid intake. Some are busy and hustling but many are serene and relaxing. If you are a nervous type take a hotel organised familiarisation tour within two days of your arrival. Afterwards, make your own way into and around the Souks. As in all busy environments worldwide, take sensible security precautions but do take a camera. You should ask beforehand first and offer to tip those you are taking pictures of to avoid offence.

Aggresive. You will get lost. If you are without a guide, be prepared. The aggressiveness of the vendors can be overwhelming. There seems to be no best rule on how to deal with them. You think one thing works, and then it doesn't. sometimes I found them to be downright nasty, othertimes, wonderfully humourous and even kind. Give it a try. a definite life experience. If its too much, step away, get your confidence back, and duck in again. Just smile and know you're doing something wonderfully unique and exciting.

Don't pay more than a quarter of the price they give you!. Great place to get a bargain - but don't pay more than a quarter of the quoted price. Don't be deceived by the appearance of the souks - these people are very rich and some of the richest people in Morocco, so you will not be ripping them off! They expect you to barter, but don't get conned!

Marrakech Souk. The random men and young boys who will approach you and try to steer you towards their shops and give you misleading directions are a pain in the backside. Be firm and decline their offers.
saw it in movies experienced it in person. great place, great friendly people. always bargain before you pay for souvenirs.

Busy. The souk is as busy and noisy as you would expect, with the usual array of shops selling slippers, wooden objects, clothes etc.We weren't hassled as much as expected, which was a pleasant surprise.
friendly people. The souks were great, we were not harrassed, just good business people trying to sell their wares. It was nice to get away from the tiny/narrow streets with all the motorcycles too.

colourful and buzzing with interesting things and people..... you'll find every kind of market leading out of this square, from ceramics to clothing, carpet to silverware. and the kasbah leads into back streets with even more unusual looking rickity shops and workplaces. you can stand and watch many of the products for sale being made. but you'll find that every stall, shop or business owner will ask you to come in and start showing you goods whether you are interested in buying or not. he'll start bartering with you before you can turn and walk away. so if you're just looking make sure you stand your ground. they can be quite bullish. and if you are buying, shop around first. always offer half the price they say they want and walk away if they wont come down. then you'll often get your price. its a buyers market just now because the tourists aren't spending money like they used to. and they're feeling it. women on their own can be harassed on occassion. there's always someone wanting to take you to see great goods and prices at their relatives' shops. they follow you around. young men may try to brush up beside you so don't let them corner you in a shop. most are friendly and respectful though. just don't go to the souk in a vest and pair of shorts. cover your legs and shoulders. you don't have to wear a scarf. the young girls wear long denium skirts and long sleeved tops and scarves so its not all old worldly... it's actually a modern city. most shop keepers will invite you to sit and enjoy mint tea and a chat after you buy. they love tea the same way british people do. so enjoy and make new friends. or get a guide. even those of us who live here still need a guide for parts of the city.

Just let us look. Instead of trying to push everything and the kitchen sink under our noses, just let us browse, we'll spend more money...I couldn't even get to the things I really wanted to buy because I was being hassled so much with give me your best price... It's not that I want buy!!!!
Fantastic array of goods and great banter. Unbelievable just how much there is to buy, enjoy the banter and the haggling!!!

One day. Certainly have lost count of the number of times we have wandered through the best souk in Morocco. Perhaps more than fifty times and still have not seen everything. Many shop keepers now recognise us and offer warm greetings...with each journey or adventure into the labyrinth offers new sounds, sights and smells... Not to mention new and terrific bargains and the fun of good-natured haggling.

Pick you time. Its great going through during the hustle of the day....and hustle does not just apply to the crowds. So if you can look during the day and return in the evening to haggle. It can be just as intense an experience, but you may be more satisfied with the outcome

loads to see and buy. Plenty of offer although it is repeated continuously. The metal work lanterns and household items were particularly interesting. We are used to shop owners touting vigorously for business, but found the constant 'sitting on your shoulder' approach very annoying. The ones we bought from were the ones who gave us a little space to view the wares once we stepped into the shop.

Awesome!. The souks are such a fun place! Careful of getting lost, but it seems you eventually pop out. Make sure you debate the price, if they aren't mad, you aren't getting a good deal. After you've walked through a little it all starts to look the same, but there are some good treasures.
crowdy. Wat you want to Here? It's dirty, po or andere the people asking only for money. You don't have the time to take a quitte look for the things you are interested in

Enjoy the experience. A maze of small lanes and tiny shops. The shopkeepers will try and entice you in, but a small shake of the head and a smile means they don't hassle you to much. If you do want to shop sometimes the banter can be quite amusing, but be prepared to walk away if you don't get the deal you want. They will often chase after you with a better price. Don't be afraid, just enjoy the experience.

Hire a guide.. We ventured around alone first to get a feel for what was for sale. For your serious shopping, try hiring a guide. Time efficient and they will bring you to the higher quality souk merchants which offer great service. They also can step in during the bargaining process to make that go quickly and fairly.
labarynths. Plenty of places to get lost - always offer less than 50% and walk away if you don't get your deal. There is plenty of other stuff!

Enjoy, but be careful. Fantastic experience, but keep your wits about you. Haggling is great fun and there are bargains to be had but beware of beggars and people wanting to charge you for photographs you take whilst there.
the souk. i love it im starting to find my way round this maze its full of life ...pay a third of the asking price and you maybe somewhere near the real value of the goods

Time to Negotiate!!. If you really want to negotiate, and buy a few bits and bobs, head to the souk. Do be ready to barter, the stall holders will start off at a silly price!! All part of the fun. Good place to buy the spices, lemons and olives you may need to take back home for memories of Marrakech!!
Naviagtion. Ther is very little navigaton required around the souks, you will get lost! Friday is the quieter day, being prayer day.
Wow. My wife and I love it so much, we have got many stuff to mark our lovely visit to Marrakech

Enjoy but be careful. The Marrakech souks are fascinating and offer every conceivable handicraft. People are generally friendly but beware those who are intent on selling at all costs and leading you not where you want to go but where they want you to go. All very friendly for the most part...keep cool and ignore unwanted offers of direction or help....and bargain hard!

I don't like rude sellers!!!. dirty place full od shops and rude sellers with no respect to women - I have managed to learn some swear words from Morrocan boy from my hotel that's how I understood what sellers were saying !!!! most of things are made in China, prices are ridicolously high--you need to haggling to drop off, but even after that it is still quite expensive...Or I was very unluckly

Marakesh Souk - interesting. We did some shopping. Be carefull the prices are going down when you go inside the souk - on the suburbs usually higher. First go around and than come back to do your shoppings

A bustling chaos. If you stop to look you may have to buy, and in order to buy you will have to barter so be prepared to offer about half what you would expect to pay and don't be tempted to go to high through embarrassment.
Shops galore. Shopaholics paradise! Shoes, leather bags, scarfs, wooden crafts, metal lanterns, kaftans, etc etc. Have a go at haggling - you will get a bargain. Such friendly people too.
Where to look?. Loved the shops, colors, smell, and all that was going on around us. Easy to get lost but then who cares?
Another world, amazing. We loved the souks, we got lost and we found the spice market (fantastic) and on our last day we shopped, lots of haggling, great fun, this is a must whilst in Marrakech.

An experience not to be missed. The souks are a wonderful experience, I never miss the opportunity to dive deep into the souks and explore the different areas, the hassle of the traders can be overwhelming at times but a happy disposition on my part usually helps, but not always!Time will see this wonderful city change so go now and experience something so different to any shopping experience to be found in Europe.
Hectic. Awakens the senses. Great to interact with people even if you don't want/need anything. Beautiful chaos at its best
too much aggressive haggling. Advise other medinas in other Moroccoan towns: Rabat, Fez, Casablanca Quartier des Habous

Nice. This place is very surprising. I have visited so many souks all over the world, fes, istanbul, cairo, but Marrakech is unique. the shops show different type of products but you need to bargain at 50% (seems to be national moroccan sport).There are also some shops dedicated to new designed products.

For the Bargain Hunter.... I love the Souks..... I cant really ellaborate on that because Id be here all day! But if you like a bargain and your french or arabic is good and you like a haggle then forget the market and come to one of the souks, Trust me you will see a huge difference in quality and price.Only gripe is .... Mopeds.... People are allowed to ride them through so dont wear earphones be alert and NEVER walk in the middle of the pathway because people dont stop for you EVER!
loads of fab shops. plenty to buy, all kinds of good fakes and originals...bit pricey

Very cool. I loved the souks. It was a great chance to practice bargaining skills, but it can also be kind of tricky to navigate. Make sure you have a map, and watch out for pick pockets, and little kids who try to "lead" you the right way...

call this is a souk!. I would not put this place on my must see before you die.I was expecting a lot more but and it is a big but I have been to souks that would not consider this place an addition to the league of souks premier division. Perhaps it was because we traveled so far over treacherousness roads (great coach driver) and expected...well I don't know what, but something different at least. Apart from haggling for a nice piece of jewelry for my wife and some herbs and spices for our kitchen back home, there was nothing that would make your heart flip and give you the must have jitters. We had a 'typical' Moorish dinner in a upmarket restaurant, this included a belly dancer who to be fair, tried. The meal was o.k. without being memorable, we had some lovely meals out in various restaurants (whose names escape me now) which were easily found, look to where the locals eat. Morocco? yes I would go back, but for the sun and the craic I prefer lots of other places and for a great souk experience, try Turkey or Tunisia.

Amazing. Wow, what a place to wander around. If you aren't getting hit my motor scooters or push bikes you are getting hit by donkeys! again, it would be a much pleasant experience if the stall holders left you alone to look! one even chased me down the street as I stopped to look at his wares, realised it wasn't what I was looking for and walked off. Moroccans need to learn they would sell far more if they left people to look.
Wonderful Experience. A unique experience. A definite for all visitors to Marrakech.

Unique experience. Unique experience, quite tiring that take you back to Middle Age and where is possible still to find good items if you are ready to negociate the price with a never ending deal.Unfortunately for my wallet, my wife found a beautiful antique amber necklace, a nice jellaba and an old berber carpet It is a pity that the that motorcycles can enter !

Crazy but Fun!. The best shopping and deals I've ever seen! But it is CRAZY! Mopeds and bikes rushing around and shop owners dragging you in their shop. Soooo worth it, but be prepared to bargain and dodge mopeds like its a sport!
Bargaining Can Fun. Make sure you are not tired or hungry because bargaining, is only fun if you are in the mood for it.
Great experience. Worth looking round but it takes time to get used to being hassled every second. Found some great bargains. Haggle hard, usually pay max 10-20% of original quote to tourists!!

Too agressive. We were looking forward to the haggling and the amount of shops were breathtaking! However, it wasn't as much fun as we expected! The items were the same in every store, and although they claimed to have crafted them themselves it was obvious they were mass made, probably in China! We had a few goes at haggling and although we got the price down there wasn't much banter, it was all rather aggressive. Except for in the Dyers Market where the guy actually had a laugh with us, showed us how they dye everything, dressed us in different attire and then got a good sale from us! It didn't help that someone got stabbed as we walking through the souks a few metres ahead of us! I would still recommend you go, but just be careful! And don't expect peaceful shopping, as soon as you even look at a product they jump on you and pester you!

have I got a deal for you?. A great experiance the souk the hotel provides a free bus service ,It is just so out of this world there are motor bikes wizzing by you, every body saying,please come and look .The snake charmers, What an experiance, do go,
too touristy. Fez is much better. Marrakech souk is full of made-in-china goods. Sellers are too aggressive. Unpleasant overall
Test Your Skills. The merchants are very,very good in bargaining. Keep a smile on your face and enjoy the game. I'm told 50% of the asking price is the norm.

Must have been the main tour attraction. We were on a guided tour and really this must have been the highlight, there was a lot to see and about everything you could want was available on one stall or another. Took a lot of bartering for a fair price and they were clever as we could not get them down as low as we would have liked.
Excellent Quality of Items to Buy. The colours are amazing with all the fabrics, clothes, jewellery and household goods. I avoided the live animal sector as I think they could manage it better
Has to be seen to be believed.. A real rabbit warren with every conceivable article for sale. Fascinating, seems to go on for ever, and be prepared for crowds of people - just get swept along!
Shops galore. An experience not to be missed. Practice your bartering as it WILL be tested.
shoppers heaven. There is everything you could ever want in the souk, if you look long enough, many times over.But hone yur bargaining skills first.
Bitter and Sweet. The variety was fantastic. Slightly intimidating though with the hard selling. Also slightly frightening because of the snakes outside

Haggle Haggle Haggle!. Stand your ground when haggling, you make the price you want to pay and pay it! They need the money, you don't necessarily need the item, think about it that way and you will do well in haggling at the Souks!
We didn't get lost. Amazing place and well worth the experience of haggling and getting a bargain - we also avoided a guide and didn't get ,lost

Mystical and mysterious - chaotic and exciting SOUK and grand bazaar. I loved the snake charmers, the monkeys, the storytellers (even though I couldn't understand a word but I could understand the fervour of the performance) and even the dentist sitting at a stand with 1000s of little teeth and a big pair of pliers!!! The food was great but the freshly squeezed orange juice was to die for! Lots of Moroccans were lining up for the freshly squeezed juice. There are plenty of cafes around the square where you can go and have an ice cream on a hot day and watch all the activity below. My friend had a 'gazelle' pastry and coffee and said it was bliss! We watched all the people with their haggled-for purchases and then we went in for ourselves - buying a great leather tooled belt with silver plating on it and some beautiful scarves as gifts - in the grand bazaar.
A must when in Marrakech. Let the young guides show you around, but remeber you have to pay them. It's worth it.

Souk 'Marrakech. staying at the sofitel Marrakech we were advised to take a guided walking tour of the Souk for €25 , supposed to have been a bit of a cultural tour but we were taken from shop to shop where the guide was clearly on commission . Should have been a 4 hour tour but it was clear that after 2 hours he was fed up, He was friendly enough & took us to parts of the Souk that we probably would not have wandered into . The Souk is a myriad of shops where you can spend hours. We Took a drink on a rooftop cafe overlooking the market square which was nice as we could watch the hustle & bustle from a safe distance . We decided to take a horse drawn carriage back to the hotel - a disaster as the driver was a maniac going too fast and whipping the horses, we paid after 500m and walked back to the hotel, real shame as it upset the children and carriages oseemed to be going a more pedestrian speed
Gifts for everyone. exploring the market, the mint tea offered by the shop owners, the interesting alleys and the bargains!
A great experience. The Souks are where locals shop too so its not there just for tourists.

Alive Night in the square. We enjoyed the big square of Jemaa lfena. it is a nice place to see and entertain. This haven is an open area where you find: Snake charmers - Moneky handlers - story tellers - acrobats and fortune tellers. Visit Marrakech to enjoy this authentic enjoyable place.

Fun and interesting. It is easy to wander around for ages and see so many things. Definitely look around before you buy anything, but enjoy the experience. The souk sellers are a pleasure to deal with.
Intense but fun. Be aware that you'll be constantly pestered to look or buy items and it's very crowded but definitely interesting. Haggle everywhere!
The sights and sounds are amazing!. It is a fascinating place to visit....The fact is the goods are all same, same but different, but it doesn't matter. The experience is enriching.

Negotiating the Souks - Finding someone we can trust!. Fantastic time in the souks! What an experience! Wanted to buy a rug, but so many shops and unsure who we could trust among all the alleys of shops & salesmen. Our Riad owner recommended Mohammed at Aux Douria in the Souk des Tapis. 30 secs from the place des epices. After pouring us mint tea and offering the kids Coca Cola we went through his massive selection of wonderful authentic carpets - each laid out in front of us for a family preference/decision.Patient, friendly, good English...and not pushy. When the call to prayer came at 3pm he even left us with his assistant for 10 mins. Clearly some things were more important than a sale to him!When it came to bargaining we reached a good natured deal which left both him and us very happy - and I am not easy to bargain with!If you are looking for a quality carpet, rug, cushion, jilaba (Arab cloak) this is a man it is nice to do business with! Our week in Marrakech included hot air balloon, quad biking, trip to the mountains - but buying a rug from Mohammed was the standout highlight for me!
Real good fun to discover!. Dont feel frightened to go in, you do not get hassled like in Egypt or the Caribeean. Stick to your guns when bartering and buy something gorgeous for your home!

The Moroccan people have a great sense of humour!. We were lost and trying to avoid looking at the map (again). You're looking for me? came the voice out of the silks. You have to be robust but there is always a twinkle in the eye with the lovely Moroccans we dealt with in the souk.
Fun. We had a great time exploring and bargaining and trying to tell real from fake. A delightful maze but again cars, motorbikes horses et al

Restrained madhouse. Didn't get hassled anywhere near as much as I thought we would. Most stalls selling similar things. Prices have to be negotiated. We were quoted 250, 150, 120, 75 dirhams for the same product at different stalls. Eventually got it for 25 dirhams plus 1 euro! If you want to do this then you will have a hoot.
good place to get lost.... Nice to visit, and great place to buy spices and other Morocco stuff. Bear in mind you have to bargain at least 30% of the cost!

North Africa at its most exotic. Like the main square you must see it to believe it! Safe and comfortable just to wander (but easy to get lost until you remember it's one long main street with a myriad turnings off). The Dyers Corner is fabulous; the fabrics are just a dream. My wife bought a long scarf and has absolutely no regrets.

Bargains!. You will find great bargains on leather bags here, do not pay more than 50% of the first price they say. If you want cheap pottery do not buy it from the souks around the Jemaa el Fna, go up a street in the right had corner of the square on the same side as Cafe de Paris and there is a shop selling pottery on the left for about 1/5 of the price in the square.
Mysterious and hectic. I like bartering and the people [very hospitable]Dislikes, dusty, too much traffic ie; cart-donkeys, motor bikes
Fun and exciting. It is a must do of course if you visit Marrakech - but be ready to be approached to buy everything in sight....

Spoilt for choice. Amazing array of beautiful things to buy. Arranged in areas of speciality: metalwork,woodwork,carpets,leather,jewelry,lanterns,etc.etc.Easy to get lost but its not so huge that you wouldn't escape the maze eventually. You need to hone your haggling skills though.
Very cool!. Very cool ! Very colorful, very lovely !Very cool ! Very colorful, very lovely !
A colour Feist. A feast for the eyes and some lovely photo opportunities. Some good bargins if you haggle but only on the more expensive items.
Incredible bargains. Great bargains, but be prepared for throngs of people! Everyone was very friendly, but bargaining a must.
Pay 1/3 of the price. Learn to haggle and lern to enjoy haggling, but don't be the ugly tourist. We saw tourists turn haggling into an excuse for being rude.
Lots of stuff. If you don't mind constant badgering and ALWAYS having to bargin than this is a fun place. Great to see the craftsmen at work too.
hard sell. I've been before so it's not a novelty and the selling pitch is too intense - you can't even think without being spoken to

Great carpet, hand made in Artisanat du sud. though needs patient and lenghty negotiation, the atmosphere is good, the owner will host you with tea and will show you everything they have. At the end if you pay 25% of the first price you have got a grest deal. The owner Hosni, address 109-111 souk des tapis. Tel 0524 38 04 99
Souk in Marrakech. Better than others, real bagains to be found and great people to meet - how do they all make a living. never threatened or uncomfortable - great fun!
Souks. It's like aladdins cave of treasures. You could happily overspend without realising.
:). INteresting experience once you got used to haggling :)

Great shopping experience. We would recommend having a "Riad recommended" local guide who won't take you to his uncle's carpet shop. Don't worry about getting lost, the female locals are the most helpful in showing you the way out. Haggling is great fun and the experience very colourful. The part of the souk where the locals shop is the most interesting, but the chances are you won't find it without a guide.

Allow a few hours - you will get lost!!. Loved the atmosphere and eclectic shops, stalls and workshops - the fact that this isnt just a tourist attraction, its for real!Downside is the blisters I got from walking round and round seemingly in circles - but its all part of the fun - go with the flow and you'll enjoy it!!

Hectic marketplace. Stall after stall of silver, leather, and carpets. All men working in the "shops" tried to get your attention. Interesting to see all the goods and very reasonable prices....but you have to negotiate.

Go for the 'quieter' sellers. Don't be dragged into the first stall you see, bide your time and wait. We bought a superb runner carpet for roughly the same as what you would pay back in the UK, but the experience of the sellers hospitality and the haggling process made the purchase value for money.

Exciting. Lots on offer and lots of back streets view a wide variety of goods.Once you get the hang of it you know where to go for certain things i.e. textiles, leather goods etc.A great experience and make sure you haggle and barter - you will find the price will come down by as much as 75%! Have your price in mind and be prepared to go to another shop if needed.

Shop til you drop. Before I arrived I expected the souk to be more like a bazaar, but it's actually lots of little shops all crammed together in winding streets. There are lots of wonderful things to buy, but it can be a bit repetative and you are expected to bargain.Do try to be respectful, women should cover their shoulders and upper arms and not wear anything too short - the locals will appreciate it and be respectful in turn.

Just as pictured. the constant bargaining and occasional followers trying to guide you (always for a price) to your next destination can be wearying but the souks are a riot for the senses and you actually can real deals (don't believe that the "official" assemblies by the govt always offer better prices) as well as just enjoy taking it all in. Hunt out the few shops that sell something different than all the others - pick up Shopping In Marrakech by Susan Simon before you go. And try the gazelle/horn almond cookies - delicious!
Smile!. Keep a smile on your face even as the vendor insults you with a price many times what it should be. Let him know that you know and he will probably like you for it.

A feast for the eyes. So much to see. a great place to get lost in. Noticeably quieter on Friday. Take your time and have a look, but if you ask for a price, be prepared. You won't be able to go for a while without being rude. Looking and thanking and moving on, without talking prices seemed to be fine.

Not for me I am afraid.. Perhaps it was me on a bad day but I did not really enjoy the experience of walking around the souks. Yes you will get lost, yes you will be hassled, yes you will have to avoid all the motor bikes screaming around, I expected all that but I am afraid not for me.We walked through here to get to a particular museum and at one stage we were hassled rather aggressively by a young man who insisted showing us the way even though we said non merci, we eventually had to pay him off. The advice I would give if you are lost, ask a shop owner who will hopefully help but not 'show you the way' and have some change just in case.I hope you enjoy it more than I did.
souk success. find the area where they do the craft work and go to the square in the middle for lovely cafes

Amazing. Marrakech is a place that inspires, provokes superlatives, and the souk is no exception.A visit to the souk is an unforgettable experience, a fascinating assault on the senses, an intensity of contrasting light, colour, sounds and smells.There is a bewilderingly vast array of goods, ranging from the sublime to the rediculous. A careful and patient buyer can locate real finds, unique items at bargain prices.It is easy to be a little overwhelmed in this place. The trick is to step back, walk around at a measured pace, without expressing too much interest in anything, stay relaxed and don't stop if you don't want to, refusing unwanted solicitation with a polite, and firm ' no thank you'. Walk on, until you find something you really like, there is plenty to choose from, then take your time, bargain well and you should come away with a lasting treasure.

A Different... shopping experience!Great atmosphere and lots to see but far too much hassle from each shopkeeper, some of whom were too insistent. My husband bought stuff he didn't want just to get away! A map of the souk would be helpful to visitors who are looking for certain merchandise.

Little and often to avoid overload!. The souks are vast and confusing. If time permits, stroll and look, return and browse then when you are certain about what you want and are happy to pay go for the full haggle!Compared to Tunisia and Egypt, we found Moroccan sellers more good humoured and less persistent especially if you speak French.

Pack your patience. This was my second trip to Marrakech this year. We came in January and i could not stop thinking about all the things i wanted to buy so i came back, who needs ABC Carpet and Home ( in NYC)when you can go the Souks?!What a collection of treasures, So much fun but definitely not for the faint at heart. Negotiating with the vendors is fun, but a full day of it wears you out. Never pay the price they ask. I usually end up paying one third of the asking price...sometimes less. The shopkeeper will always try to act defeated, like they wont be able to feed their family because you just got a good price...IGNORE it hahaha. What fun. Never felt unsafe. Wear your mirrored aviators so they cant see your eyes and whatever you do, dont look like your afraid. That invites the local guys to try to have a little fun with you. I didnt eat the food there, probably best not to.

Superb! you can stay days and days. An amazing place. You can spend days and days looking at the stuff and the people. You "feel lost" but you cannot really get lots. Hundreds of exotic alleyways, little doors, little shops, and lots of cats everywhere. At some point you see someplace familiar and you get out. We always felt safe, day or night. Quite an experience: food, spices, carpets, clothes, perfumes, pets (lizards!!). Be ready to bargain, and hard.
Bargain Hunting. Got some spice from here at a very reasonable price but you do have to look around and be prepared to haggle. My friend also bought a Tagine which we got for a good price.

be prepared to bargin. I love a good deal, and I enjoy to hagle. It was difficult to navagate through the souks with my giant stroller, but we managed. I have been to the Istanbul, Casablanca, and the Marrakech souks. It seems that in Marrakech the original price is sometimes over 50% marked up. Be Prepared to bargin.
Beware. Beware of people who want to be your friends and guide you every where. It will cost money!!
souks. we spent a lot of time in souks and bought spices and some soveniers andhad some mint tea with Morracan pateceries.

Filled to the brim. Such a ratway of such a variety of stools that you could spend hours in there. Scarf stalls are colouful, spice stalls smell intreging and the trinket stalls intice. Such a lovely place to walk around if you dont mind the stall owners trying to constantly get your attention
I love souks. It's like alladins cave,I love they choice of wonderful goods and bargaining.
Amazing experience but can be full on. if you do not like to be hassled when you shop take a guide with you but make sure he is recommended.
Hold your breath!. Interesting shops, but lungfuls of fumes from all the mopeds using the very narrow lanes as streets!

Learn to haggle first. anything you may want you can find it there... but do learn how to haggle or you will find it a very cumbersome experience. Equally, do not allow for just anyone to convince you to go to another shop with them, just follow your route, smile and say no merci, no thanks, no gracias, 'la sucran', salaam, etc, and you will be fine
Fun, Fun,Fun, Fun,& Fun. The Souks were so much fun, friendly and exciting..!

First Choice Excursion - Marrakech Royale Trip. We stayed at the Riu Tikada Dunas hotel in Agadir and as one of the excursions offered by First Choice we decided to book the Marrakech Royale excursion (about 750 Dirhams each). We were met at 7.00am at the hotel by the coach and introduced to our driver for the journey and to our guide Idris. The coach journey took approximately 3 1/2 hours (with a short 20 minute comfort break at a service station) and we arrived in Marrakech. The coach journey itself was fantastic, travelling through the Atlas Mountains and seeing some fabulous sights. On arrival in Marrakech we meet up with our local guide Jamal (both our guides were exceptionally polite and very very knowledgeable indeed). We were taken to the Bahia palace which was fascinating, the architecture was unbelievable and we spent about 1 hour there on a tour with our guide. We were then taken down the narrow back streets (we did wonder where we were being taken at one point!!) and into the most beautiful open restaurant on the top of a building with fantastic views of the Atlas Mountains. We were seated under a tented area with lovely furnishings and served a very tasty meal (plenty for everyone) please note that while your meals throughout the day are included in the price your drinks are not and i guess they are quite reasonably priced depending on what you have - coca cola about 20 Dirhams. From the meal we were taken to the Souk and spent about an hour being taken through the narrow back streets where the stalls are set up and the goods are being made. This was the most fantastic experience and it is something we will never ever forgot. The workmanship from these people is incredible. Our favourite area was the blacksmiths (the souk is divided into different areas - blacksmiths/fabrics/spices/wood turning/leather and the items for sale were unbelievable - the most unique and fantastic ornaments being produced from a single bolt!!!!! Unbelieveable. We were very glad we had our guides as we would have never have found our way out of the souk - it is an absolute maze with no signposts or anything and once you are in there YOU ARE IN THERE!!!! Once we had finished our whistle stop tour of the souk we were taken back to the square Jemaa el-fna which was filled with stalls and shops. The traffic has no rhyme or reason to it - with people, motorcycle, scooters, cars, taxis and horse drawn carriages coming at you from every angle. We had about 1 /2 hours to look round the square and at first it is quite intimidating with people trying to sell you things the second you stop to look at something (but that is what they are there for!!!). We went for a soft drink on one of the rooftop cafes in order to look down on the square - what a sight. We then met up with our guide again who once again led us through the backstreets of the souk to the most remarkable restaurant hidden in the depths of the souk - fantastic food, fantastic decor and Moroccan entertainment. Once finished the meal we were taken back to the square and this had changed beyond belief. Full restaurants had sprung up out of nowhere and the sights, sounds and smells is something that will stop with us forever. This trip organised by First Choice is fantastic value for money without a doubt and we would most definately do this again (apart from the public toilets in the square!!!!)What a place!!!!!

Fabulous and different shopping experience. The souks were amazing places to walk round. In parts, they were a bit smelly, and they are crowded and there is a constant stream of scooters and horses and carts moving by , but that is surely what a visit to Marrakech is all about. There were also a lot of cats - I was a bit concerned until I realised that the cats seem to be tolerated, and while they are dirty, they seem to be fairly well fed. There are as many stalls selling stuff from China as there were selling genuine Morroccan goods. The stallholders do hassle if they see you looking, but mainly, they are charming and good natured, although they all have a tendency to grab your arm to keep you at their staff, which is a bit off putting. We found that walking away got us a better price than trying to bargain them down and sometimes we bought something we had been ambivalent about just because the price they were offering was so low!We did the one thing they advise against and walked with a (non registered) "guide" (a young man), away from the touristy part towards what we were told was a leather market ('only today - you get cheap leather') In hindsight, pretty stupid and as we were being taken through the maze of streets and back alleys, I was wondering if we would ever find our way out. We ended up in a place where we were given a quick lesson in how they dye leather, what plants etc they use, shown shoes, pouffes and carpets and ended up buying both shoes and a silk carpet - bargains and lovely quality (We never did find the market) Although we had to pay two boys to take us back (they seem to have their own territories and will only guide you within those - so if you want to get right back to the square, it means a couple of helpers!) it was an experience - we saw where the artisans live and work, saw kids playing in the streets and experienced a bit of Marrakech which I am sure most tourists don't see. And it only cost us about 5 dirhams each to get in and out of the central souks!If you stick to the main souks, round the square you can always find your way out again and there is enough there to satisfy most shopping needs. Overall a wonderful shopping experience and the best part of any holiday to Marrakech

MAD. Completely mad - not as touristy as I expected as although some good sold are for the benefot of tourists, it is also a place where the Moroccan people buy and sell their produce etc. Thought it would be intimidating but the people are friendly on the whole and haggling was good fun. Beware of the motor bikes speeding down the narrow lanes, no such thing as health and safety!!

fascinating myriad of alleys full of stalls alive with colour. Didn't get lost although I can see how people might!! The alleyways, full of stalls, seem to go on for ever and there is so much choice of goods to buy. Coloured slippers, herbs, carpets, wood carvings, leather goods. The list is endless as were the alleyways!

Fascinating. Nothing to dislike.A fascinating insight into Moroccan life, narrow crowded streets dodging scooters, horses and carts and donkeys.There is a lot of junk for sale but also great quality hand crafts, leather, brass ware, inlaid furniture etc. traders are not too pushy but expect haggle.
An amazing maze. Loved getting lost and wandering around aimlessly, tear up the map and just dive in and then head for La Place for a OJ and some space!
Zoco. I like the environment, less stressful than in the past. Now it is fine to walk around without lot of pressure to buy

hundreds and hundreds of stalls.. Mad, streets so narrow, smokey,and crowded. You be asked ever 4 foot " look her please, asad price, luvly jubly," YOU WILL GET LOST IN THIS MAZE" . full of key rings ,wooden carving,scarves etc, etc.every body wants money from you even to show to out of the maze back to you Hotel,even if you think and know you are heading in the right direction ,they will convince you, the way is wrong.With follow me i can take you , followed by 30 euro- 40 euro
Tourist trap. Constant hassle - quite vibrant colours - assertive to aggressive vendors and general hassle the whole time. Mopeds keep coming through - not for the claustraphobic. Not for me thanks

Fascinating. We found the souks a most intriguing place, a real hustle and bustle. Plenty of people walking through narrow alleys, along with donkey and carts, and the mopeds whizzing along at 20mph+ - absolute madness, yet no accidents. Fantastic, and you walk wherever you want and not feel threatened, nor get hassled to buy goods.
very different. be wary of prices and your bags. People very friendly, Snake charmers etc worth looking at.

negotiate the price for EVERYTHING!!!!. you are guaranteed to get a bargain! if the seller is not willing to drop the price, just walk away - you are guaranteed to be able to find it cheaper elsewhere... and chances are he will run after you with a better price the moment he sees u walk away and looking at his competitors' stuff!! But most importantly, have fun with it!!! :)
The Souk. Everyone should go here at least once - love it or hate it, and I love it, it's always an experience! Bargain for everything and have fun!

Magical Souk. I have never been in such a large souk, a long almost never ending central path through it with lots of little offshoots which lead you into evermore delightful places. I didn't buy but not because I didn't think the merchandise wasn't good as the quality of most was excellent. I did however think that it was expensive even allowing for the bartering.

Not for the faint of heart, the claustrophobic or shy.. This is why many people come here, but it's not for everyone. Those happy bargaining and bargaining hard can have lots of fun, and even those less into bargaining can get into the spirit of it for a while. It's close, though, and noisy, and you absolutely will get lost if you venture in any decent distance, which can be uncomfortable. I got in, got lost, got some great stuff and got out eventually, but this is not for everyone.
Busy. Beware motorbikes and donkeys up your backside as you walk through the marketplaces. The stalls are eye candy but it does feel very foreign if you're never visited Africa / India before!

Travel back in time..... Walking into the Souk is an amazing sensory overload - but you mustn't miss the experience. On first look it can be scary, but you will soon realise the it isn't. There was little of the hard selling that we had expected, and when we did venture into a stall, without exception, the first thing that the stall holder said was 'Welcome to Marrakech'. We felt they meant it as well. At no stage did we feel threatened, only welcomed. You do have to get into haggling, but this is part of the fun.Start at 40% of their initial price and you won't be far out. Don't be afraid to walk out, they will lower their price to keep you there! Key piece of advice - keep smiling an enjoy it. They love it!
Very exotic. it could have been so much better if cleaner and without the motos and bycicles driving straight on you !Still it is very pretty and there is some good trouvailles to be made .
Interesting for 1 day. A lot of things to buy, and to see, don't forget to take a map because you will get lost. But you will always find somebody who wwants to show you the way for a few dirhams

Crazy. A fantstic experience but very crazy. If you point to anything you will be pounced on but a firm "Non merci" will keep you moving. There are 2 main routes into the souk but if you divert off then you can see the manufacturing of items which is so interesting. Be prepared to haggle but keep it cheerful and you will get a price at least half of what was originally stated. It is fantastic just to wander around and see the variety of goods
different. keep hold of your purse because there are so many things to buy and look at
Get lost, and end up at the square. In the beginning it looks like a maze, but all roads lead to the jemaa el fna square. Moroccan crafts are absolutely stunning.

Not that intimidating.. I've been to Istanbul and fled the vendors in the bazaars. I was pleasantly surprised at the souk experience. There were calls to check out stalls, but no high-pressure sales and even the first prices given was usually perfectly reasonable. The touristy stuff like a souvenir magnet was overpriced, but ceramics and handcrafts were fine.
The real thing. It is the real Marrakech its there you will meet the locals and experence there way of life, with the sent of the souk. Well worth a visit.

Love shopping. The souks are fantastic - be prepared to haggle and you can be rewarded. Never short on someone giving you directions - avoid this if possible, wandering through sometimes gets you to the best places!

Bargains if prepared to barter.. Loads of lovely things to buy and interesting sites to see.Prepare to get lost and just keep walking you'll find your way out.Lots of haggling required which can be a bit waring after a while.But didn't feel intimidated everyone very courteous.

Pain in the Bum. Quite fun for a very short while but pretty soon the highly pushy nature of the vendors turned us off. The stuff being sold are tacky tourist trinkets of little genuine interest and all stalls & shops sell the same old stuff. Seems far less individual then when I was last here some 7 years back. Maybe spend an afternoon in souks but they'll drive nuts.
Super shopping. Excellent fun, be sure to take everything in good humour and your day will be so much more fun.

An experience. The souk is great, I love it (it was my 3rd time in Marrakech). Yes, you can get lost but so what, you will find your way or end up in Jemaa el Fna. Don't be put off by haggling, there's no other way, be aware that you most certainly will pay more than what a local would but what counts its that it should be a good price for you, for what you consider a bargain to be at home. Don't miss the tangled little streets, it's fun!
get lost here - everyone does. get lost in the souk and wander for a while - the sellers are very friendly (of course they want you to buy but they enjoy the chat even if you don't)
You Have to Visit. Much less hassle than I expected and once you develop eyes in the back of your head to avoid the motorbikes and bicycles it is good fun.
Good place for local shopping. Good selection of local products. Go and search narrow pathways inside!
Same as the square. A lot of pushing around too crwded , easy to get lost in it , too many tourists shops , i feel so much better in the open areas of Marrakech !!!!!!

NIce and Organised. This Souk was as you expect from a Souk , however was better organised and cleaner than expected. I disliked the fact that motorbike and scooter traffic is allowed in the Souk and can be very dangerous if you dont have your wits about you. Also 8pm is way too early to close , in a town like Marrakesh tourists would want to have an evening wander to make their purchases, they should open till 10pm.

Some good, some bad. It is fun to get lost in the souk and see what you can discover. However, a lot of people seem out to rip tourists off and start at a ridiculous price. You are expected to haggle which is fine, but some of the starting prices are ridiculous, you would not pay £21 for 'junk jewellery' at home and even though you can often haggle down a long way, especially by beginning to walk away you can still end up paying too much without realising because you appear to have already knocked a lot off the price. Most people in the souks are friendly and will leave you alone if you say no thanks. Some are a bit pushier and will try and drag you in to their stalls/shops. Fortunately this is the minority.

Great!. Loved the souks! Was expecting bad things but had a fab time mooching about in the little alleys. We were two women on our own in the evening and had a great time as well as picking up some great bargains....I think!! That's the thing, you never know if you could have got it cheaper!! We felt like we were in the sex and the city film...haha
buying. shoppers paradise, wonderful sights and smells, a feast for the senses.

Takes me three days every trip to start to enjoy bartering!. A wonderful assault on the senses! Colour, sounds, smells! Stop and take a break for lunch or mint tea at the lovely Terrasse des Tenturiers near the dyers market or at Hassam's great street cafe near Mosque Ben Youssef. (Le Jardin near here was shut for refurb).

Even Time Machines need a map.. The souk in Marrakech is up there with the best. You don't go to Marrachech and not spend at least the best part of one day wandering around, exchanging banter with the the market people, stopping for a coffee or lunch and, even with a good map, getting lost a few times. One point to bear in mind:If you do miss your way and ask somebody they will generally and happily point you in the right direction. If somebody does this and then proceeds to walk a few metres in front of you expect them to eventually ask you for payment for their "guide services". This can be quite compromising - best to say clearly, from the start - "we don't need you to show us the way thankyou" - or words to that effect.

Different and unusual.. The Souk is a large warren of narrow alley ways entered through a main square in downtown Marrakech. If you wish to see Cobra snakes being "charmed" or buy a huge variety of spices, leatherware or jewellery this is the place. Prices start high and must be negotiated.
