There are many local restaurants with cheap tasty meals. The prices are much better than near to or in the hotels. We went to a leather tanning pit and found it filthy and stomach turning. Be wary of "hustlers" and volunteer "guides" if you use their "services" they will seek to rip you off and get hostile real quick.

One needs a lot of time to explore!. It is an huge area with a great selection of goods, and one can easily get lost! I hated all the motorcycles and bikes who were driving in the souks at all times of day and night!

Boy oh boy. Loved every minute! There are so many traders, all essentially selling the same thing and yes they want your money. BUT with a positive attitude, you can easily walk away. Don't be intimidated. If possible learn a little Moroccan, which with French and English will get you what you want at the right price, (£250 UK Price spices for £45 approx!!) Fabulous people, very friendly and we did not encounter any potential pickpockets.

an experience. visit the ensemble artisanal with all prices fixed ,before hitting the souks, you will feel knowledgable of what to pay then, and if you start bartering know you are in for a sale eventually, or they will get mad

Hassled beyond belief!. You got hassled beyond belief. I went with my boyfriend and at one point a guy literally pushed in front of me to speak to my boyfriend and followed us down round the market for 5 mins trying to sell us stuff refusing to go away!The over the top pushy attitude in the souks really ruined the experience
Not worth seeing!. Terrible products, greedy shopkeepers forcing you to spend, not a pleasant visit!
Buy buy buy. So much to look at and so many bikes to avoid! An assault on the senses in the best way.

Be carefull. Marakech was an edgy place with lots of hawkers touts and monkey con artists.People offer to guide you,Be aware they are after your money or even your valuables.Not the nicest of places especially at night.
Crazy but fun!. A riot of colour, sounds, smalls and cholce - fantastic fun!

A rainbow of colours ,scents anf flavours... Very colourful displays.. The scents & flavours ,the spices, and the multi-ethnic crowds are what makes Marrakech so special.I was born & have lived here all my life, but I still think it's a blessing to enjoy life here everyday ..Marrakech has a worldwide reputation for being one of the top Ten Tourist Destinations ,but what makes its fame is the fact that it's a city where the sun shines 300 days out 360 ,It's a place where you can ride a camel in the desert, go skiing or have a swim ,and all this in ONE day ,as it is situated in the Valley of the Atlas Mountains ,& the Toubkal, the highest summit in North Africa , which is always covered with snow during winter . Its people have a reputation for being friendly,outgoing and very cheerful .It is also very secure , as millions of tourists come here every year and some of them(especially the French retirees) even choose to live here for the rest of their lives.

Getting lost. Getting lost is easy but you can always find a kid that will point you in the right direction or for a small fee lead you to the square.Here you can find a very good selection of a lot of thing that you do not need. However, not so much boring fake brands but crafts which sometimes even may originate in Morocco.
hassle in the souk. too many pushy people wanting your money and being rude about it.

As you would expect from the movies but more ....... Expect your senses to be overwhelmed by the sight, sounds and smells of the various souks. Get lost because that is the fun and be prepared to consdier buying the ridiculous, the tacky and also occasionally the impressive and the beautiful. Parts are tourist fare only, part genuine local market and associated poverty -peope actaully live here. Of course sellers are in your face - but not excessively so. Barter hard - that's the point - and be prepared to walk away if not paying at least half the sellers first named price!
Busy times. Wow - the first day u are like a rabbit in headlights by the end of the week its banter with the locals all the way
Mad. total chaos with a twist. Learn to haggle first and get a map. Always have a supply of small notes and coins as they dont like to give change.

Bargain hard and keep walking. Great fun. Allow your self to get lost but done be fooled by the lads who tell you where to go, that the square is closed ( its isn't) or that the Tanneries are very close (they aren't). Just soak up the noise, sights and smells and offer less than half what they ask for and you'll be OK.

Always an experience. Souks are souks..........if you like them then they are a fun way to spend a few hours and take away a few 'treasures'. Normal rules apply, check out prices at the artisanal centre first, know what you want to pay and be prepared to engage.

Bargain hard...but nicely!. Well worth a visit. So much to see. Twisty lanes with shop after shop selling all you could want to try and buy. Negotiate hard but fairly and they will respond. Think what its worth to you and stick to your price and you will feel you have a bargain. Such colour, and shade for the hot months. A must visit.
Shop til you drop!. Retail therapy at it's most intense. Get your bargaining hat on and prepare for a big day at the market.
Shopping at its best.. Great hustle and bustle with great smells and noise.
Guided tour. Good for first time travellers to get bearings and rules of the medina!
hassle. too much hassle to do any serious shopping, we were constantly harased for money
Souks. The souks are a place to have some fun haggling with the sellers of local goods!

Brilliant, but very very busy!. You can get some great bargains in the Souks but do haggle hard. We were initially offered a tea set for 1200 dirham and got this for 300 in the end. It's hard to find your way around the souks (or we found this) but it can be fun to get lost. There are lots of different souks (slipper, spices, material, metal etc..) I don't think we even found them all!
Colourful. Very colourful but you need to negotiate prices always

Souk shopping crazy. I have been souk shopping in several pan Arabic countries and I always find that there are a lot of stalls selling similar items. Pottery, lamps, leather goods, textiles,rugs, metalwork, jewellery. As you wander along you will be called out by the sellers and of course you have to haggle as prices are always inflated.Try opening at a third of the asking price and hold your nerve. Also be aware that quality is not always great but you will find something that takes your fancy.
shop till you drop. shop, but look around first and get your bargains!

great bargains - but more importantly, incredible experience. when you first enter the souks, you are immediately overwhelmed, whichever souk you happen upon first - slipper, leather goods, carpets, meatal work, dyers, jewellers market - each product having its own area and did find lonelyplanet book helpful for gaining some idea of how things flowed. Quite daunting on first visit - maybe best to stay to main street with stalls;perhaps venture into the smaller alleys where the artisans manufacture the goods another day when feeling a little more confident about the layout of the souks.The sellers do call out to you, but in a friendly way and never felt intimidated. As other reviewers say, do bargain - usually managed to pay between a third to half the original price mentionned and you will come away with great quality product and an experience second to none.
scary. locals sending us wrong way, chaotic, unnerving, couldnt wait to get back to the safety of the hotel.

Tiresome but rare experience. The thusand different shops, all with kind of the same products :) You have to bargain to be polite, but don't underestimate this, because it is really hard to know how much you would like to give for a product you don't know the price of... When you for example like a scarf, do you like it that much that you want to give €10 or €40? Know your price before you start the bargain race!

Haggle all you like!. Start with a third of the price they mention then work your way to 50% of the original price they mentioned. The art and crafts are beautiful, especially the metal lanterns. Don't pick up any items unless you definately buying it as they are reluctant to let you put it down.
A myriad..... sights, sounds and smells, this maze of amazing treasures is a must-see when visiting this amazing city! Haggle!!!

Bright and colourful, but go deeper in. Pretty easy to navigate in comparison to Fes. Bright and colourful, lots to see, great to get lost. Get deeper into the souk, and you will find better bargains. Get off the beaten track, and you will find some lovely art work and hand made goods, and be able to spend a little more time with the artisans, and prices are generally much better and you can bargain to a very fair price.
Souks. Stay vigilant and watch your belongings and you will have a wonderful experience in the souks!

A sprawling great living market. The souks of Marrakech are huge and easy to get lost in. Fortunately that just means more time to enjoy the miles and miles of stalls organised semi-haphazardly by theme, with souks for carpets, brasswork, brassieres, whatever you are looking for. While tourists shop here, so do locals, and there is something for everyone.
Haggling. Bought loadz of gift for family and friends but haggling is a must they will drop the price alot 1/4 of the original price quoted at times

MAD!. Thats about it really, madness! Just make sure when you DO get hassled you say no politely, best to tell them its your last day and you have all your gifts already. Its almost impossible to just do a bit of window shopping, I challenge anyone to go in and not come out with something! Try and find your way to the top end where you get to see the craftsmen making the goods, especially the metal making area, very medieval and really interesting. try not to wonder around looking too lost (which is hard as most of the time you will be too lost!) as the penny scammers can spot you a mile off and will want to "guide" you to your destination, always carry small coins for this inevitable occasion.Be on your guard for Pick Pockets, they are rife whens its busy, just keep your wits about you. The more you dress and behave like a tourist the more hassle you will get, simple rule!Enjoy and spend some money, if you can find that Flying carpet we kept being promised then good luck to you!
like any souk in north africa. worth a look and walk through but not much more.it was like any souk ive ever been to in tunisia,egypt
madness!. wow! totally amazing out of this world! enjoy the haggeling!!!
amasing. Try enjoy it in a relaxed way, keep on laughing and people will be very friendly, they all try to sell you things, but if you say no in a kind way they stay kind, don't get angry!
Hectic place but fun!. I bought some lovely scarves here, no price tags, just keep haggling and you will get the price you want, or walk away.... they will soon call you back!!!

A delight to wander round.. Before I went, I'd heard all sorts of scare stories about how everyone tries to hard-sell, and you can't walk away without being forced to buy, etc etc.It's all nonsense!The Souk is a rambling maze of tiny winding streets and covered walkways, with some glimpses of fascinating architecture behind the stalls and down alleys.They are lined with seemingly never-ending stalls selling the expected range of goods (spices by the tonne, lamps, shades, wooden boxes of all descriptions, bags, clothes, shoes, carpets and more), with dozens of stalls all selling the same things, so there is plenty of choice and competition.Yes, if they see you looking at their wares then the stall holders will try to engage you and entice you to come and browse, and then try to sell you anything they can, but that's their livelihood for heaven's sake! And there is no obligation to buy. Ever. A firm but polite "no" (or maybe a few) and they will leave you alone when they realise you won't buy, all with no hard feelings (for they know very well that someone not buying today may well be in the mood to buy next time).Sure, they will try to entice you, even pleading with you to follow or good bargains, but if you don't want to go, don't go, and that's an end of the matter.Be prepared to haggle and haggle strongly, and you can get some great bargains - yes their initial price will be really high, it's the market culture to start high and haggle to an agreeable price. Respect the culture, go with the flow, and you'll be fine. And if you can't agree a price, just leave; they will either follow you and negotiate, or else leave you to go somewhere else. No problem either way.One thing to be aware of though is that the Souk is VERY windy and is like a labyrinth which means it is easy to get lost if you enter too deeply. No major problem, there are always people eager to guide you back out again - for a price (which is never mentioned up-front, and will always be more than you offer! Again, be firm when you've offered a good price).Watch for people walking along-side you and pointing things out - they expect to be paid as an unofficial "tour guide", but a firm indication you are not interested at the start is all you need.So all in all, just keep your wits about you (sage advise anywhere in the world), keep a note of your route, and enjoy the experience.

hundreds of stalls and shops. You can find all the riches of North Africa here, spices, foods, ceramic, metal work and textiles. After a while you realise that most of the shops sell the same things so try to find the areas where the craft workers actually make them like the leather workers area or the dyers souk and haggle.

colourful but salespeople far too eager to sell. There is a marvellous range of products for sale and very colourful especially the spices etc. One can easily get lost in the winding alleys but not for long. I have but one criticism of the Souks and it is an important one. Many (not all) of the sales people are far too keen to sell, desparate almost. In my opinion they are losing many sales by this behaviour. I came prepared to haggle but found at many places I dare not linger because of the over enthusiastic manner of the stall keepers. My advice to them is step back a bit and give the potential customer time to browse
shop till you drop. What a great place to shop, unlike other Arabic/north African countries, this one is virtually hassle free! look out for jewellery, lighting and dishes....

My symbol of Marrakech!!. Great atmosphere!!! Decent cheap food aplenty. Lots of market stalls full of interesting souvenirs. The downside is that business is seen as a real hussle for morroccan people. Every vender will try to stop you to get you into their market or food stalls. You have you not worry about being so polite and to just ignore them when you are not interested. And whenever buying anything just remember they are usually going to try to get at least double the real value of you. If you enjoy the art of haggling then this is the place for you!!! :) also the is a lot of child beggers which is always painful to see.If you are able to get past these things then you will find it to be a great and really interesting experience!!!
Over-touristy. A pity that the old souqs have all become quite blended together and are mostly selling all the same things now.

Facinating. When we eventually found it it was facinating, haggle for everything, wooden goods, and beaten metal items were particularly good. Haggle and don't be persuaded to go into a shop unless you really want too - you will end up buying something!
exciting performances. The snake charmers, and performing monkeys are facinating!! Dont take any picture though or the owners will chase you for payments!!!"

I miss Marrakech. I went to Marrakech and Morocco many times in the 90's to buy commercially. It was as intense as anything I have ever undertaken but exhilarating. I recall after my first day, having started cold and alone, back in my hotel room feeling defeated by the beggars, hustlers, obnoxious kids, and all the sound and fury that is Morocco. I got myself up and went back into the fray. I had come from the US and had to buy to be a success. Over the next weeks and years I learned much about how to take it, make it, feel, and express myself and deeply enjoy my time in the soulks.1. it ain't easy. No one is immune unless you have a guide of some sort (more about this later) and even then: you are fair game. People have been passing through Marrakech for thousands of years and "I'll come back." means nothing. They want you to buy and they have 100 tricks to induce you.2. hire a guide. They'll get a commission on what you buy. But he'll keep the hordes off you. Think about paying him just to guide: you will not buy. Then go back. I hired a guy for very little and found him to be friendly, helpful, and instructive.3. forget the 1/3 rule! I started bargaining on a tea silver set and it ended up going from 2000.00 US to 35.00 US! Spend time everywhere asking "what's your best price?" Say "Shokran" and you'll start to figure out at least the ball park.4. sometimes the price is the price. Many sellers know that Americans don't like bargaining and they'll give you the actual price. It happens. 5. Keep in mind they have a simple philosophy "Why should a rich man pay the same as a poor woman?" Makes sense to me. 6. Drink the fresh OJ: it was heaven and I still fondly recall visiting with my favorite OJ squeezer.7. tips are expected if you photo acts in the square. Have a pocket full of dirhams.8. They give money to beggars as normal for people with money in their pockets. You should too. A dirham buys a meal for a beggar. 9. If someone treats you disrespectfully RAISE your voice, if they raise theirs, RAISE yours again. But don't take it seriously: verbal combat is the national sport. 10. they will always win. After many visits I found that I could never win 100%. They always found a way to over charge me, screw up something, etc. etc. Be prepared. 11. drink it up/ eat it up. Marrakech soulks are one of the most intense public experiences on the planet. 12. watch your pockets and purses 13. I carried a compass and navigated by myself through the winding convoluted alleys and always came out fine. It's big but it's not the Sahara. 14. Marrakech prepares you for anything in Morocco.15. Essouira for some reason was the absolute opposite: very straight forward and business like. 16. you came here for the experience: enjoy. You will always remember Marrakech

Magnificent buys. The souks are the best place to buy all your souvenirs and nick nacks. The souk is where they will be the cheapest goods and you must bargain all you can. Wonderful crafts and lamps are there. Also stone jewelry such as quartz and agat. Of course there are vendors selling argan oil here as well, I don't know if the one I bought was pure, as some sold are fake or diluted so do research before buying.
Bargaining in the souk. I loved the bargaining and the bustle and the colour and constantly changing vistas but hated the constant hassling to buy and the demand for money for just looking.

Take Care. I am a seasoned traveller and knew what to expect. But, I found the hard-sell far more than I could tolerate. I think that they potentially loose possible sales because of the 'bully' tactics.
BREATH TAKING. So much to see, buy and enjoy. You will be spoiled for choice when it comes to eating and as for buying - you will be paying excess baggage if you're not careful.

Not for the feint hearted!. Steel up and grab a bargain!Enjoy the hustle and bustle, the array of colours and the cheeky stall holders. You must barter and start low with a view to paying about a third of what the original price was.Go right to the very back of th souks to where the locals shop and you may find the same items cheaper. Look out for almost jumble sale style stock just thrown in a heap, often you will find scarves etc here for a faction of the price on the official stalls. I bought 2 scarves which I had seen selling for 100d each and paid just 45d for both.Don't be out off by the aggressive sales techniques, be firm, say no and stick to your guns.Do take care and watch out for motorbikes, my partner was hit by one in th souks!

A Must Do In Marrakesh. An experience that you have to do while visiting Marrakesh. As long as you are polite to the sellers, you will have no problems. Haggling is part of the experience, but only buy if you believe you are getting a good deal! Be careful with some fakes; the stitching etc leaves a lot to be desired!

OMG - such an assault on the senses. The selection of goods is intense! So many colors and you just want to buy everything! But it is very stressful bargaining, even for an experienced haggler. China, Indonesia, other parts of Southeast Asia do not compare to these guys. We found it really hard to get down to a reasonable price much of the time. Combined with the motorbikes whizzing past and the young touts following and apparently "guiding" you to the next place, and then demanding money for the service, it was all a bit unpleasant at times. But we are very pleased with what we got in the end. Just be prepared for stress. Oh yes, and we had been warned against bringing a stroller - this is simply wrong. The alleyways are not cobblestones, just regular paving, so an umbrella stroller would have been very welcome. It's dangerous for toddlers and young children to wander along by themselves with the motorbikes coming out of nowhere.

Look!. Amazing and thought provoking when i think of the dreadful way we live, with all on tap. Not here, it takes hard work and need, and pride to put it out there, and in the Souks thats what you get, world class traders, that see colour and beauty simply.
Bargains galore. beautiful handbags, carpets, sandals etc but you must be prepared to haggle as the quadruple the price. Bought a rug that was priced 4800 dirhams (£450) for £120.
Fascinating. Fascinating. Sounds! Colours! People! Explore and discover!
very cool. So many different smells and sounds. The shopkeepers would try to engage you and it was fun to see all the different food, fabrics and items for sale.

Get a guide then visit on your own. Its worth paying 200Dh for an engish speaking guide to orientate yourself. they will explain the main routes in and take you back to your Riad or the nearest gate to your hotel on the way out of the Medina.. remember the nodal points on the route as you will be lost without them, We bought lots of pashima for my shop, but also got sandals.. slippers are everywhere - look at prices on the outer roads not medina to get a guide or you will overpay. 100-140 Dh for sandals and between 50 - 80Dh for splippers is about right. I got silk/pashimas for a rediculously low price for WOW Gallery stock which I am selling at £28 - would be £45 in LIberties! So you can get a bargain, but remember they need to make money too...

Getting lost in the Souks is so much fun!. The labyrinthine glory that is the Souks is practically impossible to reliably render in map form. To me, it's better to just give in and wander around without worrying about where exactly you are and how to get to anywhere else in particular. Discovering all the cool things there are to buy there is lots of fun. Unexpectedly coming upon something you were looking for but never thought you'd find feels like a major triumph.The endless negotiating is tricky and takes a bit of patience and a sense of humor. These people will not take no for an answer. Whatever they have, whatever they are selling, they cannot believe that you don't really need one. It was fun playing the game of appearing uninterested even when we were interested.There were two occasions when we needed to get somewhere in particular, and needed to pass through the Medina to get to those places. Honestly, I don't know how we did it, but we did. I had to keep my girlfriend from paying too much attention to what was around us. It's hard not be distracted, not to get pulled in, with all the cool things there are - rugs and everything else. But for pure shopping, other than the Grand Bazaar in Istanbul, I have never had such a great experience.
very busy. good fun if you like to barter and haggle. Start low because very overpriced to begin with. great finding way through tiny alley ways and streets but beware of the hustlers
you've got to do it........ its not a relaxing experience. I felt like I needed a medal for my achievements at the end of it!!
Hello! Hi! Sorry! Hello!. An aural and visual assault of the finest kind. The world's sharpest businessmen ply their trade and simply can't fathom why you wouldn't be interested in their wares...

just play the game & have fun. I loved the souks! Once again a little over whelming at first. Don't take offence, just play the game & have fun. These are good people just trying to make a living. Bartering in part of the culture they are not trying to rip you off. May the best men or women win. They told my husband that he was very good! Just remember if you look at rugs it will turn into a half an hour at least! Enjoy it!
Need GPS ! :-). This souk is sooo huge ! Its neverending tangle of small tiny streets full of very nice goods to sell...don´t forget to bargain !!

The true negotiation course. The souk is full of good, the quality very so I advise you first to check the quality vs price and the to buy. Offer 1/3 from the price they ask, the leave the place if they do not accept and as a last negotiation tactic show them the money, less the the agreed price. you will thank me for this and you will have great savings.

Fun experience. Finding goodies and bargaining endlessly! Getting lost is all part of the fun! If you have the feeling that you have already seen that stall, you probably haven't. Or you have, on the opposite direction:)
A must. People are very nice and they really have nice things to propose: from delights to leathes bags, tea cups and "tadelack" pieces

My Favorite Shopping Ever!. Shopping in the souks was so much fun. I discovered a flair and love for haggling that I never would have expected to have. They saw a woman who was obviously a tourist and started pretty high, but I got everything down to a price I was willing to pay, (which I'm sure was still more than the items were actually worth), and I think we all came away happy. Just know that if somebody offers to show you a shop, they will expect a tip. We discovered that they will also take you into the deepest reaches of the souks and then want another tip to lead you back out. If you have the time, just find your own way out, that's what we did. The souks are a rabbit warren of streets. Most of them are divided up into categories, so you'll go through the silver section, the shoe section, the chicken section, etc. It's fun to get lost in there.It was wonderful seeing a culture so very different from ours. I know that we had a tourist experience in the souks, but it felt a lot more real than a lot of the places we've been.

Shop till you drop!!!!. Its like a maze of colours and smells. The sellers are friendly and pushy at the same time!! Just make sure you keep your sense of humour and don't take them too seriously. If you don't agree the price you want just smile, pat them on the back and walk away smiling. Check carefully what you are buying. They do have a habit of holding onto the products you are interested in themselves and this prevents you seeing if there are any faults with it. Barter for your life as its all part of the fun of it. Dont be shy to offer a third of the price they quote to begin with. Enjoy the experience and then go for a coffee as its very tiring!!

Big Welcome! Yeah, right........... This was a truly ghastly place, I suppose you've got to see it, but it's great to leave it behind. It's built up in all the guide books as this wonderful mystical place, instead of which it is full of crooks, pick pockets, hustlers and con men; and mountains of tourist tat. It is impossible to walk more than 10 yards without being accosted and hassled. 'Big Welcome', 'Big Square', big con.Some of the stalls are obviously selling quality merchandise, and it's fascinating to watch some of the craftsmen working, but who wants to stand and argue for hours over the price of some holiday tat while getting run over by mopeds and donkey carts? You will, of course get lost and being guided back to the 'Big Square' is going to set you back a few coins, although the negotiation will start at around 100 dirham - tossers.This is the centre of shafting. If you're lucky you won't get your pocket picked, or be leered at, or sworn at if you don't come across with sufficient dosh. Save yourself a wretched half a day. You could create the same effect by filling Poundland with 10,000 sweaty people and then getting kids to ride round on mopeds while 300 barbeques filled the atmosphere with smoke and rancid cooking fumes.You've got to go, but you'll get lost, and you'll hate it.

Crazy!. Crazy but fun! And make sure you haggle well. Most were trying to sell things to me for around 650 dirham and I was starting at around 90 - 150 walking away having paid between 120 - 170. Much cheaper than their original price!
Better than TK Max. Superb crafts, sparkly leather shoes and bags for a snip of the price in europe

Wonderful culture, but be prepared to say no thanks!. The Souks are little alleys lined with people selling you all sorts - but make sure you know how to say no thank you... if they think you might buy something they will try and corner you! Other than that, a great way to experience the culture of Morocco.
amazing. It is impossible to visit the souk without getting lost, which makes it possible to see many more stalls than you ever would have imagined. Don't miss the Women's Cooperative of Marrakesh.

back in time. it was a fantastic experience , got lost in the little streets of the Medina for hours , but decided to find our way back to the square where we too a cab to go back to our hotel . But it was a fun day ! Bargaining is a way of life here , always offer 50% .

You must shop the Marrakech Souks!. Part of traveling is experiencing the different cultures. Hassan of UndertheMoroccanSun tours booked Jo and me deep in the Marrakech medina at the riad Marana. We followed our baggage porter down the street from the outskirts of the medina into the very large open plaza, several square blocks. Crossing the plaza we encountered orange and nut sellers with their carts. We could see the souks radiating out from the plaza.Our riad was on a very small street, 5-6 feet wide that was entered through part of the souks. Souks are shops in the medina. Shopkeepers constantly tried to sell us everything from clothes; to tourist junk; to handicrafts and antiques. We were initially overwhelmed, but quickly found our way around.We ventured through all of the souks scouring for trinkets for our grandchildren and a signature piece for our home. If you make an offer do not expect to walk away easily. The shop keeper will follow you trying to close the sale. We found that most items could be bought for about 20% - 25% of the shopkeeper’s initial price. Be strong and haggle, haggle, haggle.As we shopped over three days we were in and around the plaza. At times it was crowded with masses of people shopping for their daily needs. Entertainers asked for small payments for their shows; snake charmers would place a small snake around your neck and take your picture. (This was definitely not for Jolene.) I bravely sat down with a viper and a king cobra for bragging rights when I returned home. There seems little reason to travel all the way to Marrakech and then miss haggling in the souks. Allow a couple of hours and a couple of days if possible. Have Fun.Dave & Jo
Madness. If you like shopping you'll love it, however, if it's just a walk about you want, it can get a little stressful!

Be firm. Stick to your guns with haggling - end of the day is best. If they really don't like the price you're offering, they'll let you walk away. Depending on what they think they can get away with, they can start as high as four or five times what you can eventually hand over. But even if you end up thinking that you've paid too much, part of what you've paid for is the experience of bartering in the first place - keep smiling and so will they!

Souk. A maze of streets and a feast for your eyes. Be careful you know which way you are going or ask someone you have bought something from to be sure you know how to get back. Only problem is that unlike Souks in other countries, Marrakech souk had hundreds of shops selling pretty much identical things. Nice place to pick up little souveniers to bring back home.
Keep quiet or buy!. Much more chilled out than one might fear.. but if you ask the price, they think that means you are ready to buy.. Tricky one that.
Retail therapy . . .. , , , with a difference. Should cure the most addicted shopaholic
Great. Amazing experience, a must place to go!! Haggle haggle Haggle all the way :)

OMG you can get lost but it's fun !!. Don't let people intimidate you to buy something. If you do want to buy something start at 1/3 of their initial price. Learn in advance how much a local would pay for it (i sneaked behind a local and listened to their negotiations whilst watching how much money he paid.. the stall owner wasn't impressed but I got myself a good deal without much effort)
Unable to Browse. As a seasoned haggler in muslim countries even I found the constant barrage from shop keepers too much and ended up not even looking at things I was really interested in.

Colourful, fun and vibrant. You can buy anything here--I love the souks of Marrakech but they get better the further you wander into them. The spices, the carpets, the ceramics. Morocco has some wonderful items for the shopper I could take a lorry and fill it easily! I do get a bit tired of haggling but some of the shop keepers are easier to deal with than others--if you feel uncomfortable walk off--the same goods will be on sale just around the corner. I stay longer when they dont hassle me so much but that is obviously your choice. You have to go --spend at least half a day wandering through them.

Magic. Budget at least 2 days to spend wandering the souks. I would suggest skipping a guide and just going it alone. If you find yourself completely lost, pay a kid a few dirham to lead you back to the main square. Be sure to haggle and don't be afraid to stand your ground! Make sure to make it to the Kissenia which has some higher-end, less difficult shops.
not sure if its worth the trouble. leave your wallet at home or youl come back skint, you have to barter for everything, dont listen to those who say offer half of what they ask, 10% is closer

The Souk. So interstesting to see the workshops wihtin the Souk - the quality of the produce was amazing with such antiquated tools. But beware - your guide will probaby have a few mates lined up to sell you stuff. We wasted half an hour in a carpet shop because we couldn't get away.
The archetypical souk. The souks and the square form a UNESCO world heritage site, and for good reason. This is the best part of our trip to Morocco, and that will be true for most people who visit.
amazing. You have to experince the Souks - there is literally no place like it!Amazing!
Cheap and good!. Nice people, for the most of the time. Bargain, 50 % from the start price.

great fun. When you actually want to buy something, offer a quarter of the price and do not move from your original offfer. You will get it for this price!!! If the shop lets you leave, you know you pitched too low but they sometimes come running after you!

like the medieval period with motorbikes!. The famous souk of Marrakech is brilliant. Its teeming streets are crammed with dusty little shops and stalls full of brightly coloured cloth, metal trinkets, butchery goings-on, leather slippers and rip off designer bags next to cages full of tortoises and chameleons. If you dislike crowded shopping centres then avoid it, but otherwise it is a marvel of crafts and architecture of times gone by. We marvelled at a chap making amazing wood turning items with his big toe, haggled long and hard for leather slippers, and bought delicious fresh bread rolls for one dirham each (about 10p) and walked along eating them. Traders will call out to you and try to dodge you into their shop but it's all very good humoured and if you simply say no thank you and walk on it'll be fine. My husband had his arm grabbed by a stallholder once or twice but the (male) stallholders would not touch a woman shopper. It's easier to leave the blokes at home to be honest and shop til you drop. Lots more fun than the trafford centre and loads cheaper too!

A world apart. Loved the fact that i managed to get my pouff here. Camal leather and large but only a small price. love the hagling, love the sounds and the smell.picked up some really authentic hand made stuff. Love the whole souk experience. A MUST VISIT.
Great fun!. Not as pushy as I thought it was going to be. We left the majority of our souk shopping to the last day as we had a fair idea of prices by then and were up for a good bit of haggling.

Fantastic but take a guide or a map!. A must do if only for the sense of other world. The range of sights and smells packed into the souks is fascinating, oils, herbs, leather, jewellery. I bought an iPad charger for £2, bargain!

Hustle and Bustle. Yes, would go back. Be prepared to just be firm and polite if you don't want to shop or otherwise accept that you may well come home with tat but it was fun getting the lowest price and part of the Souk experience!

Follow the maze. You have to follow the maze to get through the souk but it is so culturally different than anything we had experienced. Loved it and deals to be had all over. Stay away from snake charmers.

Eye candy!. The souks are in a class of their own. All little stalls on the fringes of Jemaa el Fna square selling everything from pastry and candy to fabric, rugs and household goods. Our favourite stall is a family stall of rug makers. The grandfather and grandson were there. Grandfather making a rug with his arthritic fingers and the grandson doing the selling. I purchased a small rug for beside my bed, as how could I walk away? All our Moroccan souveniers were bought in the souks, along with most everything else purchsed on this trip. Everyone is willing to bargain. Do not pay full price for anything, as the next stall down will be happy to sell it to you for 1/2 of what is quoted. Be respectful in your bargaining and complete a sale once a deal is made. Variety is the spice of life and you will find it here in the souks!
You can buy anything here!. Lots of shops selling the same things so be prepared to haggle. Spices,Beautiful leather and wood items the sights and smells are not to be missed.
Mysterious. We went in the evening and so weren't hassle at all. Was just lovely strolling throught the narrow streets.

Market Market Market. Not for the timid! the souk is a riot of color and sound - but very safe. Certainly not to miss as part of the Moroccan experience - but get advice from reliable sources about where to visit for good merchandise and be sure to barter, even if they tell you prices are fixed. They're not ! and if they don't want to meet your price they'll let it go and you'll know the limit you can go.

Negotiation. I have shopped in the souk several times over the years. Whatever price they start at remember to offer around 10% of that and walk away. You must decide what you are prepared to pay as you perceive as good value and then try and pay less! They always come down to your price.....but it does take time. It is all part of the experience. Enjoy shopping in the souk....it is the national sport!!

Great Deals post haggling. I loved the handicrafts that the souks had to offer. Gorgeous and stunning, from lanterns to traditional clothes, to ceramics, to nougat! Make sure to try their NOUGAT!!! The white one especially. The night life of the market is beyond amazing.Con- as many traveller comment- haggling is just almost the point of awkwardness and uncomfortable. Not just that, but the persistent pressures of buying. Dare you make the mistake of forget window shopping, but even glance a look at a merchandise in the store will the store workers start calling you over in every way possible. If you can get use to it, get by it, ignore, dont make eye contact and ALWAYS start with at least 50% off the asking price you'll find some amazing treasures.
nightmare of hideous tourism and lowrent tourists. truly the armpit of the country- the plac eis a monstrocity and should be avoided unless you are a brainless consumer

A different experience. You need to be quite strong willed to enter this place and to be prepared to bargain. We didn't ask for a guide but a few local lads latched on in the hope of getting a few dirhams. They were helpful and harmless.
Amazing Markets. You have to visit the Souks. We felt very safe and enjoyed the banter with teh locals - we also picked up some brilliant items including a tagine and lamp.

More than what you might expect.... Hundreds & hundreds of small stores, alleyways, people, wares, etc. Nothing to describe this twisting, turning experience as you decend deeper & deeper into the souks. If you go to Morocco, this is a must...but then again, most of what we experienced in Marrakech was!

Busy Market. The souk of Marrakech does not have reasons to be emty at anytime you will visit it you will find it plenty, but the souk i found it contains only a touristy things which make a visitor looking only for pure things that he can not find in this souk, and make the local get expensive prices for a touristical stuff, anyway i recommend Souks of Fes than Marrakech one, because this one has only some touristical things, and when i go there i get lost inside the colourful stuff, but when i want to buy something will find the right thing.

Easy to get lost but oh what fun it will be. Having taken along Susan Simon's book on shopping, getting lost was made all that much more fun. While it can be imposing, you really have three major streets that all intersect and you are not really lost all though it may feel that way- just go with it and you will find all sorts of treasures along the way

A real shoppers' paradise. Plenty of tat but even more amazing 'stuff' - pottery, lamps, leather goods, textiles,metalwork, jewellery. Haggling always tricky but you can still get beautiful things at a good price.

Tiring!!. So much fabulous, tempting stuff to buy, but an absolute minefield for being ripped off, not to mention run over by the many scooters. Find out the fixed prices at the Ensemble Artisanal and don't be fooled by the faux-outrage when you make an offer much lower than the original price.
Great experience but too much hussle. A very good experience but careful not to get ripped off. Also too many motorcycles, carts etc

I am lost, wait no I am not. So getting lost in the souks is probably the most fun you will have (much smaller and easier to manage than Fes) be prepared to fend off dozens of young men that want to be walk with you (they want money for being a 'guide' and commissions from shops they take you to).Haggling for a few trinkets can be fun:-Never have your heart set on something-Never go above the price you want to or can pay-Never say your price first, make them give a starting price-Always start at at least 1/4 the original price they say-Never increase your price twice in a row

Vast market of narrow lanes. Locals and tourists alike shop in the souks. It is probably a good idea to have a registered guide show you around first up so that you see some of the more interesting bits that you would otherwise miss. Just let the guide know that you are not buying today, nor want to see the monuments so that he takes you walking rather than dumping you at various carpet sellers and spice markets. However, some of the carpet sellers, antique and artifact sellers are in some pretty amazing riads so take a look and have them display their wares but again let them know you are not buying today. Get their card if you wish to revisit. Afterwards you can just get lost in the souk, we always found our way out. Try entering them from different spots off the square. The shops tend to get a bit repetitive evetually. Try a walk down to Bouchaib, the fixed price super store south of the square on Rue de la Kasbah to get an idea of prices before buying.
market. If you love to go shopping or bagger then that's the place to go to. But be aware because it is really crowded.

You will get lost!. So difficult to find your way out of! Was good to go round and look at everything they sell. Only ask the price of something you actually are interested in buying because they don't let you go easily once you've seen an item you like. You MUST haggle though because they will rip you off otherwise. Ignore the hassling, it's part of Marrkech, don't let it annoy you too much, just go with it/ignore it!
Great shopping. Make sure you bargain! You should never pay more than 1/3 to 1/2 of the starting price! Good luck!
Duplicated rubbish. Hassel and full of rubbish goods at silly prices even after barter even found chinese imports Not a culture site a rip off sit.
Real souks. We saw a lot of different workshops for all kinds of products
Barter away. Just great fun negotiating prices and buying stuff that you simply won't find anywhere else.

To buy or not to buy. Great experience is you like to bargain. If not follow the road down past the Sadien tombs to the posh shop with the statues of 2 large white horses outside. Same products can be found in here at fixed prices. Saves the haggling.

Like nothing else except the souks in Fes. See above, what I wrote about the medina, basically: but, endless fascination of people, craft items for sale (alongside tacky stuff), foods... There's even a vegan cafe (advertising itself as such) - called the Earth Cafe, I think: quite good.

Chaotic but lively !!!. An interesting market place..its quite extensive and most popular for the leather goods,plates/ ceramics, carpets, tea lights, etc....is a maze and easy to get lost but go woth the flow...bargaining is a must and the sellers know it..we started from at least 1/6th the price and were successful on many a occasion... of course they made a profit but gave you some satisfaction...its a game you either love or hate ! Was a great place for photography with all the vivid colors...just chill and don't let the sellers hassle you...enjoy it !

Stressful and rip off! A way for the locals to make fools of the tourists!. We visited at the end of October 2011 as I was enticed by the idea of the oriental souks and hoping to find a few nice bits for the house. The whole experience has left me never wanting to visit such a place again. Firstly you cannot relax even for a minute as you are constantly worrying that you may be hit by a passing motorcycle whizzing down the pedestrian areas. You can see cruelty to animals as the people there have no soul, also they are the rudest most obtuse race I have ever had the misfortune to come across. You cannot look at their stalks without being hounded and if you 'dare not buy' any of their tat you must be ready to receive verbal abuse. They were so nasty it made me scared to look at anything. They rip you off as well and cant be trusted. We were informed the Argon oil on sale there is mixed with cheap oil for tourists (as apparently we wont know any better), the spices they sell are of poor quality (you are better of buying them from tesco when you get back for a fraction of the price) and every stall pretty much sells the same tourist junk. There are few enticing places to sit and take a break as everywhere is so filthy and unhygienic its off putting and if you do dare sit you will get non stop hassle from vendors or beggars. This is my true opinion. I have traveled a lot and lived and worked in Greece so I am not small minded but this is the worst place I have ever been and I think it was the first flight I ever took back to the UK where I felt happy! I would not recommend this dump to anyone (except my worst enemy perhaps! Lol).
VEry beautifull a little dangerous.. It's a wonderfull place, just avoid to go really inside the Souks without a local guide

But hey, take with pinch and enjoy!. Careful of the mopeds! Snakes on the floor! Beware of scouts trying to get you to their shop which is "just round the corner"! Very in your face! But hey, take with pinch and enjoy! Bought handmade leather slippers, scarves, bags, jewellery and sat and watch the mayhem from the plenty cafe/ tea houses.

Bigger than you think: go deep inside!. Besides that the shopkeepers are far too pushy to make this an enjoyable experience, try to ignore them and see the marketplace for what it is: a place where you can get almost anything and at bagarin price if you decide with yourself what you will be willing to offer (and not exceed this no matter what)

epic snoozefest. Have you ever seen that Peter Kay sketch re:the wedding buffet?"Vol au vents, chicken legs, cheesecake... Vol au vents, chicken legs, cheesecake"Replace with: carpets, low-quality metal work and locals that wants to know where you're going and will help you get there because the moroccan people are friendly people PS I'll be wanting some dhs for my trouble - and you're there.Some how, Marrakech manages to offer endless souk after endless souk filled with tat. Transport these wares to your typical local market/boot or garage sale and you'd wonder why anyone would even bother selling (or buying) such garbage.Enjoy a relaxing snooze in your riad, explore the gardens, read a book atop a restaurant with views of the Atlas Mountains, get a prostate check, fly home, beat yourself over the head with a plank of wood <<-- just some of the more enjoyable things you could be doing instead of wasting your holiday time in this hell hole.
Jama Alfana Souk. Make sure to bargin the prices. A lot of variety and more than 1400 stores. Also look at the items for quality.
Living Chaos. Good shopping fun as long as you do not take any of the encounters personally. Very "in your face"! Have fun bargaining.
A mass of colour and mayhem. Fascinating and unforgettable place. The fresh fruit and vegetable for sale looked terrific, the spice stalls smelt and looked amazing.

bargain hard. not as chaep as you would think. lamps were about the same (after hard bargaining) price as our local shop in Toulouse. Great deal on saffron and cinnamon. get a Jalaba but push hard. These guys have been haggling since the womb

a must see in marrakech. wonderful friendly stallholders, careful of the mopeds.....best souk stalls are away from the main square....visit the tanneries but DONT be taken in by people claiming to be "going that way anyway"must buys - scarves, tagines, leather slippers and lighting...
Harrassment plus but very entertaining. You have to love the variety of goods, the mad people and the craziness. Just make sure you dodge the scooters / bikes & so forth.

Rock the Kasbah!. This is a traditional Arabian souk - and it is huge. And it's very easy to get lost or wander around in circles. it sells everything - traditional kaftans, genie slippers, leather goods, Moroccan teapots and glasses etc. It's very well laid out with a 'section' for each type of merchandise. The only downside was the amount of sales pressure/harrassment to look from the stall holders - they were very persistent and didn't want to take no for an answer.

don't buy a carpet. what a laugh. join in and try everything, eating is a joy although a bit off putting to the eye it tastes wonderful, city of spice. people friendly and very helpful but rather pushy when selling. if you want a carpet they are cheap and brilliant quality but haggle. i was offered one for 5000 diarham ( £400 ) i got it for 1000 so don't be scared just go for it.

get lost in it!. One of my favorite places in the world. My advcie would be to just get lost in it because it is the best way to get to know it. I love it and I get the best gifts in this place and if you are more on the posh side, they get the best replicas of LV, Prada and Burbury! lol
Hustle and bustle. Not pestered like I thought would be tho didnt go inside stalls - obviously this is what Marrakech is all about !
Truly an experience. Fun discovering the stores and life styles of those that work and live there.

Leather Bags & Traditional Morroccan Pouffes. We found a really good trader who sells handmade leather bags and traditional Moroccan pouffes. The prices are reasonable - even when you haggle and what we really liked about Ajib (young man who was our sales man) was that he was not pushy. He does not drag you off the street... if you like the goods and are interested then he will negotiate a good price with you. I do not feel as if I have paid more for the things that I bought from him. I was happy that I had found exactly what I was looking for, I didnt see the same styles of pouffes in the other shops within the souks. Before leaving to come to Marrakesh, we had already researched how much the cost of bags and pooufes hand made from goat leather is in the UK. Therefore, we knew what a realistic price should be.Where to find Ajib? His shop is called Merzoga Cuir, on 159, Rahba Lakdima Sidi Ishak (googlemap the road), right near to the area where Cafe Des Epices is. You will see a sign above the road for a Bureau du Change. Along that road there are only 2 shops selling leather bags. I have posted a picture of Ajib and his co-workers.
Oriental soul that's Souk. There are thousands of shops with an assortment of consumer goods that could get any supermarket in the West to turn pale

Nice. The souk is fine... The souk is s big that you will spent so many hours in there.. A tip: Dont buy anything from the beggining of the souk. The more you go into the souks the cheaper it gets. Fx. i bought some ballerina shoes to 120 dh and when i went longer i got some more to 80 dh!!Otherwise i didn't thing some other things where cheap, it was quit expensive (Im danish morrocan, i talk the language so i dont think they cheated whit the price)
We didn't like it very much. I thought the shop owners were obnoxious and the people in the square were very aggressive....fez was much better.

Great place to barter. Improve your bartering skills at the souks! There are so many stalls that at least one will take your interest but remember to make those prices best for you! BARTER! If you are happy to pay what they are offering then do so but if you feel confident for a barter then take a stand and barter away!

Shop till you drop!!!. We visited this souk numerous times and each time we would discover new treasures. It was always fun haggling with the shop keepers. Was pleasantly surprised to find them engaging and enthusiastic but never pushy to the point where it was uncomfortable.
Crazy shopping. Start at half of what you want to pay and stand your ground don't walk away until the talking stops.

The Experience of a Lifetime!. Time has stood still here. The people are so nice! If anyone sees you are lost, they will lead you to where you want to go. AND at times, when we pulled out some coins to thank them.... they said NO! Our first day, we did get lost in the souks and were "found" by an unauthorized guide. He was AWESOME! For an equivalent of $10... he spent over 3 hours with us and took us EVERYWHERE! We saw things that we would never have found and were unable to find when we returned the next day. We got lost looking for the jewish cemetary... which is a must see. 5 little boys led us there and in return, we gave them a few coins. They waited for us and led us back. The streets lead to nowhere so have your map handy at all times. This is a culture of "tipping" and the people are totally appreciative. You will need to bargain for everything in the souks. I got AMAZING leather bags that would have been HUNDREDS AND HUNDREDS of dollars in NYC. Paid between $30 and $55. We did get a lamp and spices as gifts. For a true experience, stay in the old city at a Riad. We ate at our Riad Armelle every night. Including breakfast AND a incredible dinner every night. Get the "Best of Marrakech" book. It is great. Also, if you have time, take a trip into the Atlas Mountains for a change of scenery. It is beautiful and you will see the Berber way of life.
enjoy. it is like going back in time they do things the same way as their ancesters did very interesting but again beware the money grubbing guides
Shop till you drop!. Great place - but beware of rogue 'guides' they only want your money!
interesting. if you want to get lost, then you could, we where accosted by guides, but i wanted a guide i would have asked for one!
Completely mad but bargains galore. Lots to choose from. Don't be afraid to barter hard and you will come away with plenty of bargains.

A maze of colour. A maze of colour, sights and sounds. An afternoon spent wandering in the souks passed unberlievably quickly. It's easy to get lost but generally retracing your steps will lead back to the main square and a stall holder will always point you towards 'la place'.

give it a go. bartering is fun to start with then gets tedious. do your homework on prices. know how much you want to pay and stick to it. beware so called 'guides' and women offering henna tattoos - unfortunately you have to be tough skinned and be ruthless.Be prepared to be upset by the condition of the 'carriage' horses and performing monkeys.Great place to sit, have a mint tea and people watch and try to imagine what it must have been like centuries ago. Soak it up and I hope the sun shines.
Cultural cornucopia. One of the world's most beautiful market places where you can find anything from the mundane to the exotic. Reminds me of being a child as I grew up in Africa

Scents and sounds and dangerous driving. fabulous range of exoticalia
bargaining essential and terrifying motorcyclists cards and horse drawn carriages that seem to drive at you

A complete sense of going back in time.. If you removed the western dressed tourists you could just imagine that the souks haven't changed in a thousand years. Take a tour with a guide initially then wander on your own. You will get lost but it's not a big area and if you're desperate Morrocans are friendly and helpful, they're not all out to fleece you. treat them with respect and the compliment will be returned.

Busy, colourful - just what I was expecting. anything you want you can get here and if the stall you're standing in doesn't have it - the guy running it will get it from another shop - they all seem to share stock! The prices aren't that cheap - we got a couple of bargains but some things like the tassles seem to be overpriced even for the tourists!I heard horror stories about the agressiveness and deceptiveness of the locals but i found that being polite, speaking French and looking them in the eye always got a polite response. Make sure that you are agreesive in haggling though as they have a knack of making you go 10D higher than you wanted to go! We managed to haggle hard enough to get booted out of one shop!Have fun but if you skulk along slowly looking at the stuff don't be suprised when they try to sell you things. And if they tell you that the road is closed - they're lying!! (but there are plenty of nice people who will help - free - about)
Only for the brave hearted!. Can be quite intimadating and very easy to get lost

A different world. If you like shopping - go to the souks, everything Moroccan you can imagine and more. Some otf the touts can be a bit insistant but just keep walking if you dont want to shop there. If you like something, bargain heavily - they WILL do a deal!!! The textile and leather are great and the pottery is quite good and some of the artworks are quite nice. dont bother with the touristy trinkets though as they are just cheap. Make sure your not buying cheap chinese imports. Once you have finished go to Jemaa El Fna.(Main square) and sit at one of the cafe's and enjoy some refreshing Mint Tea, its a great day to finish the walk through the souks.

huge inside. take an empty suitcase with you so much to buy, but YOU HAVE TO BARTER FOR EVERY THING, IT CAN BE HARD GOING IF YOUR A SOFT PERSON,you have to be able to say no to them i speak no french but i got what i wanted to pay, lovely lamps leather slippers bedspread, you can get lost in there its so big but thats half the fun, good flat shoes to wallk about in, be careful when buying spices only take a small amount as they weight it, there mony exchange places as it easy to change up pounds and you get a much better rate than in london

Let loose and get lost in the maze!. Amazing place! Don't worry about where you're going, just go with the flow... Getting lost in the souks is part of the experience! Be careful of touts and even the so-called official guides. Friends of mine hired one of the official guides, and the guide took them to an Aladdin house where they were led into a room after walking through a labyrinth. They were pressurized into buying severly overpriced carpets. Imagine being pushed to buy something you don't want, and can't afford (as the touts are trying to sell a carpet for DH30,000!), by a few men, in an unfamiliar and tight space! Luckily my friends manage to get out of there fine, without buying anything! So beware.. BUT other than that, it's a wonderful place to get good bargains and experience where the locals actually shop. There's an interesting ex-slave market section, where they sell falcons and turtles.
The Souks. They were nice and colourful and busy and a great attraction of the city, slightly expensive but always helped to bargain.
Great for a bargain!. Lots to see and buy - but always bargain hard and beware of pick pockets

Overated. Had my wallet stolen, which didn't help. Everything in the thousands of Souks, seemed pretty much the same. It got boring and with the owners constantly hassling you, t wasn't an enjoyable day in any shape or form.

Excellent!. Brilliant, Keep a happy disposition about you when bartering. Moroccans are really very poor at negotiation and will give in eventually to your price as long as you are pleasant. Friendliest people we have met in a long time. :)
It's like being mugged on a continuous basis. The shopkeepers and the touts who made looking around and choosing anything to buy impossible

The ultimate maze experience. At first I thought the souks are only the few places around jama'a el Fna but I was very wrong... let yourself get lost in Marrakesh maze and to loose all sense of direction :)
Love Shopping!. amazing, fabulous, will be back soon! Avoid the henna women on the square!

shopping for gifts. great place to shop for gifts for your friends + Family and also for yourself :-)
bargaining is a MUST.
talking to the shopholders is great, lots of them will sit down with you and serve some complimentary tee. nice way to learn more about the country!

loved it, make sure you barter. less than half is what you should aim for. defo must see....barter barter!!! less than half is the key and make sure u shop around as each shop charges a different amout.
Interesting shopping experience. I loved the beautiful textiles and the handicraft, especially silver works. I totally disliked the motorbikes all over the place.
Back in time. Its like you travelled back to the 16th century. The spice market the copper market and tussle market must be visited
Everything under the sun for sale!. Like a lot of Souks, but without too much hassle! Quite easy to get lost if you stray too far.
In your face!. Learn to barter...enjoy the experience , be polite and enter into the spirit of things...
Great colours & shopping!. I wasnt expecting so many of the store owners to be so relaxed..... you do need to be prepared to barter for goods though!
Shoppers delight. Street shops overloaded with Moroccan goodies, lamps, leather goods, souvienirs, shoes etc.... Check for quality and bargin hard and enjoy.

A must on any visit to Marrakech. A myriad of narrow alleyways lined with shop after shop selling everything from shoes, hand bags and jewellery to butchers, fruit and woolly hats! It's an experience in itself - try your hand at haggling and bag yourself a bargain. We found that the shop owners don't tend to bother you until you ask the price - then let the bartering commence. I managed to get a few bargains so stick to your guns and make it look like you're leaving the shop if it's still too dear for you, chances are they'll agree to drop the price more to get the sale. Don't go too deep into the souk though or you could get lost - if this happens find a local and offer them 10dh to take you back to the square!
you can bargain. if u like talking that where you should do your shooping

quite expensive, but vendors aren't pushy. this souk is a real maze. every little street has the same shops, from carpets to pottery, so it's quite easy to get lost. You can walk around without being harassed, and even in the stores the vendors allow you some time look around. I did find that most goods were quite expensive, even after a lot of negotiating.

A Maze!!. With what is supposidly 30.000 stalls the souk in Marrakesh is the largest I have ever visited.It is really easy to get lost and, unless you pay them the locals will not show you how to return to civilisation.Saying that it is a really interesting place with donkey carts and mopeds vying for the very limited space between the rows of stalls.
Fab!. Loved the shopping experience although you have to be in the mood for all the haggling!!

Like a human soup...and a tasty one at that. Just an amazing place...narrow little lanes crammed with stalls ranging from everything from shoes to spices and mint to fish. The smell, the way the sun cuts through the roof coverings, it truly is a remarkable experience.You will get lost - but never fear - you'll soon emerge in the main square (just follow the crowds); and be aware if you dwell for a moment you will be ushered into a shop where you will need your haggling skills up to speed.But always remember to keep friendly and if you don't want to pay the price...just walk away. But everyone is pretty friendly.Great fun...just keep your wits about you and enjoy it.
A, eye-opening experience. Loved seeing how people work and the 'real culture' - we had two tour guides - without this we wouldn't have felt safe walking around
Guided Tour. The tour took us through quite quickly seeing the leather/tanning areas, metal workings and pharmacy! A little disappointed probably thinking it would be similar to Cairo.

Heavy on the purse!!!. There should be warning a warning sign outside the Marrakech Souk - enter at your own risk. And I mean it in a nice way.The market is splendid, has some good leather bags and shoes. If you are the anti-leather types there are a wide variety of spices and souvenirs to choose from. It acts as a combination of a touristy joint as well as a place where locals can buy stuff - though you have to bargain hard. Things are usually 1/3rd the price quoted.And when you have had enough of the stalls you could venture into the bylanes of the market and get a feel of some of the old world that has lived there for centuries.

Best fun to be had in Morocco..friendly stall owners..enjoy the haggling!. Loved this place and loved haggling.. think some stalls have really good silver.. only wish I'd had a bigger bank balance to buy more.

Souk of Marrakech.. A feast for eyes, very colourful , amazing. sometimes too much .very crowded in some places ,that s where you can sharpen your bargaining skills, know in advance that they charge more for visiters. if you are not planning to buy something do not ask for it s price, otherwise you will be followed for a long time.
Really great experience. There is so much to see in the souk, you must watch out for pick pocketing but that can be said of most cities. The souks have a relaxed feel and not too touristy.

Very Interesting Visit. Thius is one of the must do tours when visiting Marrakech. The Souk is a hive of activity with plenty to choose from. There does however seem to be an increasing amount of goods made in China being sold, judging from the number of packing cases bearing that country's name. Also, if you want to buy a carpet this is a great place to go. If you don't, make it clear right at the outsrt or you will have to sit politely for up to 20 minutes looking at products that you will not be buying.

Very busy, noisy but great interest. I loved the whole experience but some of our group were scared as you do get people coming up to you all the time. Kids begging etc. I liked the busyness, smells and noise.

Expect to haggle. You need to come out of your comfort zone and haggle prices. Its all good fun and is part of the Marrakech experience. We found that we ended up at least half of what the original price was set at. Colourful, exciting and prepared to get lost. All worthwhile!
Horrible. absolutely hated it! we got harassed by the shop men and they were rude, its ok to go for a day but never travel in during the night.
A Maze!. We wound our way throughout. It was fun bargaining. The sellers are not as aggressive as they are in Egypt. They have quite a sense of humor and were glad to see Americans.
lots to see there very interesting. like the markets not keen on seeing people having to beg all the time
Souk. A bit overwhelming but very interesting and a hagglers paradise. If you are more reserved though you can take in the atmosphere and watch others bagging a bargain!

Watch out for the Mopeds/Scooters!!!!. One of the attractions for going to Marrakesh is to so to the Souks.Although motorcars are not allowed into ther Sopuk area,mopeds and Scooters are. The riders have no sense as to which side of the road they should drive and one feels really unsafe on occasions.There is still a lot of pressure from the shop keepers to but really ordinary souvenirs but if you find the shops e.g. Al-Kawtar (run by and for disabled women) these have set prices and are of much better quality.
part of the experience. colourful noisy amd magical lots of things to see and bartering will get you a real bargain!

Bargain hard. I bought 2 carpets but I had to really bargain hard. I had visited the government shop so I had an idea of what I wanted to pay. It took ages, but eventually I paid less than a quarter of the asking price.

Awesome leather goods. Better souk here than in Egypt or Turkey. Try going away from the main streets into where the leather artisans actually make their goods. That was a wonderful experience to sit and drink tea with the leather worker and his family. We're Muslim so going to the mosque with them was even more special. Bargain hard but always smile :)

Shop till ya drop. The main square has everything and then there are the souks. These are individual shops selling just one sort or merchandise. A leather shop, a patisserie, a ceramic shop for your tajine, that sort of thing. No supermarkets there.

Be careful lol. During the day not very exciting, snake charmers don't take pictures or camera unless you feel flush lol. I watched people get harassed for money after taking pics. Nothing is free so don't take anything from anyone thinking its free as it's not!Walk away from people trying to sell you things they will harass you but politely refuse. As an Asian I didn't get much harassment as I blended in and spoke some french.White people especially women be careful and try not walk alone always walk in groups. During the night the souks are very nice and well lit up and a must see. Hope this has been helpful.Sha&shadz.dot
suk. nice to go to the suk in the evening lods of little place to eat and very crowded with locals and hagle for the price if you go shopping

pleasantly mad. you cannot go to marrakech and not do the souk, the deeper you get into it the better it gets and unlike other souk/markets/bazzars there next to no hassle from the vendors but you really must try the haggling it,s fun

Don't be afraid to barter!. It can be quite intimidating when you visit as we're not used to bartering but once you get the hang of it it can be quite a laugh. the Morrocans actually encourage you to barter because they love it!
Bargain Away. great fun be prepared to haggle down 2/3 of their origional asking price, we nearly bought a rug that the mansaid 1000 euro , he came down to 250 euro in the end!!!
Barter..but be realistic !. We bought a lovely silk throw for a great price. Don't be too aggressive though...its fun and part of the experience...charm gets you further than attitude.

Going back in time. A great experience wandering through the little alleyways. no need to panic when you get lost you eventually find your way out. Good time to go is around 3-4pm as most of the stall holders are half asleep and this means that they are not as pushy as normal. Good time for bargaining!
great place. we wandered these areas for ages and loved the haggling you just get into the spirit of it

Madness but fun. A shopper and bargain hunters delight.
Some mass produced items but it is an absolute experience to wander around the maze of walkways and explore the wares of the locals.
Shopping heaven. Masses to see and a fascinating glimpse of an old world

Haggle Haggle Haggle!. No matter what people say, you have to visit the souks for the experience and you don't get forced into buying things. Naturally, these people rely heavily on tourists buying souvenirs so they're keen for you to explore but there's nothing wrong with that. If you fancy buying something, make sure you haggle, just for the experience if nothing else and you'll definitely have a great time and most likely get some bargains too! If you decide to haggle the price of an item, be aware that you're committing to buy so you can ask prices and walk away, but not haggle and walk away.The souks are so amazingly mazey and deep that despite our best efforts we got lost everytime! That was part of the fun though and the locals are more than happy to help direct you.

Relax and Enjoy. The souks are great fun and you get to barter which is very unBritish but great fun!If you're looking for multiple of items e.g. leather bags, try to can get them from the same place as you'll be able to barter for a better price if buying them together.Once you buy one item you'll have more people asking you to look in their stores as they know that you're in the market to buy something but we always said no with a smile and even if they asked again, they didn't pester us.

The Famous Spice Blends of the Souks of Marrakech. Two of the best known spice mixtures are to be found in the spice souks of the red city. These are:1. Chermoula: dried spice mix of cumin, coriander, paprika and chilli, added to fresh coriander and/or flat leaved parsley, fresh garlic and/or onion, lemon juice and olive oil, blended together. Used as a marinade especially for white or oily fish and veal or chicken. Will keep refrigerated under oil for days.2. Ras el hanout: may contain the following ingredients. The “head of the shop” is the person who chooses!Rosebuds, orrisroot, belladonna berries, cinnamon, Chinese cinnamon (dar el Sini ed dun), green and black cardamoms, cloves, kebala (cubebe) – a West African black pepper, turmeric, galangal, root ginger, lavender (khuzama), almond husk, ginger seeds, black cumin seeds, chilli pepper, Malayan pepper and black pepper, thyme, rosemary, nutmeg, mace, fenugreek and (possibly) cantharides (Spanish fly).Buy these mixes from a well frequented shop and store in a dark glass container, away from direct sunlight. Alternatively freeze in small bags and use as required. Note that import regulations may apply to visitors returning to their own country.

Don't be shy in the Souks - they know their game well and love it when you play well!. We had an amazing time in Marrakech and explored the Souks - even got lost in them. Do not, underline, do not, ever trust the children who offer you help! We got lost, were helped through a series of alleyways and then the child demanded money - we gave him a coin and he threw it at us, swearing like a knavvy! His friends then turned up and hurled abuse at us!We got some amazing bargains - leather pouffe for £10 - the same in graham and Greene catalogue for £130!Barter friendly - not hard and they enter into the spirit of it with you. Make a list of what you want before you go - you can easily end up buying things you have no place for! don't be afraid to walk away - there will always, always be another seller with exactly the same thing or better, they know this, so keep that in mind when you're bartering. If they let you walk away, you'll find it somewhere else.Be brave enough to go deep into the souk as this is where the best bargains are to be had - but make sure you remember where you came from - it's so easy to get lost. We took photos of landmarks to look out for and felt like hansel and gretel!Things like black olive soap and rose otto oil that are really expensive here, are worth bargaining for out there - they cost a few pounds.Try the orange juice in the market square - the best i've ever tasted.Take straws with you in your bag, as the glasses and cans are not all that clean!We stayed at the Riad Kaiss, not far from the square - it was stunning and the staff were wonderfully polite.

lovely experience. our visit to marrakech was great, was very maniac dodging cycles motorbikes, horse and carriages, snakes and monkeys yes was chaotic dident know where to look . many many stalls spoilt for choice for shopping, we stayed till the evening when it is transformed was all lit up and foods tables galore, would recommend this place because it is a lovely experience and true maroccan culture

An amazing cultural and shopping experience. As you may know, the souks are basically undercover markets that sell everything from vegetables, fruit and chickens to high-quality crafts. Marrakech’s souks are considered to be among the best in Morocco. The souks are divided in small areas that are specialized in a certain good or trade. There’s the souk of metal workers, the souk of tailors, jewelers, wool dyers, spice merchants, carpet salesmen and so on. Walking through the souks is like walking through a magical fair of colors and sounds… Its tiny streets are full of life. Sellers try to get your attention. Some sellers try it with a smile and nice words others are more decided and try to pull you by the arm to see their goods. The souks are an amazing cultural experience that you won’t forget.Sadly I must confess that I and my wife, especially her, were a bit nervous before entering this crazy world. We have been warned by others, that had visited Tunisian souks, that the souks were dangerous, that the sellers almost force you to buy things you don’t want, that if you are not careful they will take to their shops, give you suspicious tea and they would make you buy what they want… Fairy tales from people with little tolerance to other people’s culture and way of life. Before going I read many reviews from people who went to Marrakech’s souks and I was more confident in a good experience.
