However it was difficult to convince my wife that nothing special would happen. That’s why we were nervous. At the end we concluded that there were no reasons to be afraid. You just have to be firm by saying “No” but at the same time polite to the sellers. If you are firm and polite they may insist two or three times but they will give up on you with a smile. At least that happened with me and my wife.Entrance fee: It’s free! But if you want to buy any souvenir you have to take a good amount of money because there are many, many beautiful things you can buy. Bargaining is needed and it can be quite amusing. Because of my wife’s nervous state of spirit we weren’t in a mood to do shopping. Besides that we were in a guided tour that would take us to other places and we didn’t want to walk with bags in our hands. That’s why we didn’t buy anything. But if our mood was different and if we left the souks directly to our Riad…and if I had much money, I would buy many souvenirs, especially metal handcrafts. The lamps are magnificent. And I must leave a compliment to an artisan who works with wood. Unbelievable work. He makes fantastic boxes and wooden artifacts. In his shop he has photos of him with Zidane and Leonardo Di Caprio. If you find him, please tell him I’m sorry not to have returned to his shop to buy something. He was very nice, he showed us how he worked the wood and he gave my wife a small souvenir. We were thinking on returning in our last day but we didn’t have the chance. Sorry! We made our souvenirs’ shopping in stands close to Jemaa El-Fna, in the souks’ entrance. It went well. Bargaining was a challenge but we manage to buy 6 silk scarves, a beautiful duvet for our bed and a couple of t-shirts with 400dirham discount! We paid 900. Each scarf was 160. We bought it for 100. The duvet was 400. We bought it for 300. And the t-shirts were an offer!!! I think it was a nice deal. The quality of the handicrafts is impeccable. If we bought something with the same quality in our country, Portugal, we would have to pay at least the double. How to get there: The souks are situated north of the Jemaa el Fna and finding your way around the narrow alleyways can be a bit tricky. We went with our guide. I think it’s a good choice. Abdul was very helpful. He told us and explained many things about the souks. He didn’t try to take us to any shop of his friends. You may find many guides to take you through the souks. Be sure of deciding how much to pay before accepting his services. After visiting the souks with a guide I advise you to go on another tour on your own. Sadly we didn’t have the time to do it. After our initial nervous mood, we were very pleased with our visit to the souks and we’ve decided to go there to buy some souvenirs. We’ll do it the next time we visit Marrakech.In conclusion, YOU HAVE TO VISIT THE SOUKS, YOU HAVE TO FEAST YOUR EYES WITH ALL THE COLORS OF ITS STANDS, YOU HAVE TO FEAST YOUR EYES WITH ALL THE ARTISANS’ TREASURES YOU’LL FIND…YOU’LL HAVE TO LISTEN, TASTE AND FEEL IN YOUR SKIN THIS WONDERFUL AND UNFORGETABLE EXPERIENCE. WE’VE LOVED IT. NO REASONS TO FEAR THE CONTACT WITH THE PEOPLE. WE ALWAYS FEAR WHAT WE DON’T KNOW. HAVE THE COURAGE AND TOLERANCE TO FACE THE UNKNOWN. IT’S MOST LIKELY YOU’LL CONCLUDE THAT MOROCCO AND ISLAMIC PEOPLE ARE VERY NICE. MA’SALAAMA.

Very expencive but very interesting. Good orienal street market, u can find speciall hand made things, exclusive hand madecarpets, textille, but also full of fake famouse trade marks! Be attention! Price u must devide on two ! Good luck !

A great experience. It is a great experience to walk around the souks of Marrakech. The vast range of goods on offer in the souk is amazing, you can find anything that you could possilby want here. Some of the goods are tacky but others are authentic hand crafted goods, some of the best you will find anywhere in the world.Take some time out here, and keep confident, the storekeepers seem to be able to sense fear and will take advantage of anyone not appearing to know what they are doing.Happy shopping........

Give me a diplomatic price!!. Is what you will hear alot in the souks!Personally I loved it, I didn't find the hassle was as bad as place like thailand, indonesia or even Turkey to get you to come into the shops or to buy.Yes alot of the stalls sell similar things so one shoe stall is very similar to the next and so on but there are some variations and bargains to be had.We had a great giggle with the stall holders joining in with the banter, hearing lots of fish and chips, cheaper than asda price and a few you have a nice bum!! We always kept a sense of humour and a smile on our face and got that response back.The first time we went we hired a local guide at the entrance to the sqaure for a couple of pounds to help us navigate and also saw a few demonstrations in the chemists about what the spices were for which was really interesting. I think you have to know your own mind here and if you don't want to do or see something firmly but politely say no and move on as otherwise you could find yourself drawn in to an endless display or demonstrations which would quickly become old.We bought quite alot the prices started off ludicrously high and the response we got was its not made in China, when asked if they had anything that was made in china because we quite like that stuff we got some laughs along with looks of confusion. We paid about 70 -90 dirhams for shoes, 60 for a medium sized tangine, 10 for the small roll on scented oils like amber and jasmine and I got a large hand luggage bag on wheels for 300dh which I thought was a bargain for what it was. You do have to be prepared to haggle and I did find that some stall holders seemed much more willing to reduce the price whereas some would not drop below 150dh for shoes which is double what we got them for. I think that some of the stalls may be operated on a kind of racket and the final decision isn't with the person you are speaking to sometimes so they can't go below a certain price. If you shop around you will get the price you want though.To do some serious shopping I preferred the souks in the morning as it was quieter and I found it easier to bargain but in the evenings we ventured into the beginnings of the souks for a wander around before dinner for the atmosphere. I enjoyed seeing the shoes being hand made, tasting the various cakes and fruits on offer and just having a laugh with the people. Its nice to turn a corner and find somewhere unexpected and by the end of the week I even seemed to know where I was going and find my way out which was a bonus!Definately part of the Marrakech experience.

A Must Do in Marrakech. I loved the whole experience of the souks. Got myself a couple of bargains (3 leather handbags, a tea-set with glasses and tray, gorgeous painted tagine and matching bowl to name but a few). Not once did I feel uneasy, yes they want you to pay as much as possible but not once did they turn down a reasonable offer - remember the people there need to make a living and give them a decent price and it will be yours.It is a bit of a maze but we found the stall holders to be lovely, offering us (genuine!) directions towards the square without us having to ask, we were offered guides but politelyu refused to take them up on the offer with no problems although some are very very persistent and it does wind you up at times.

Fascinating to stroll through the souks!. One of the most interesting places I've visited, just strolling through the souks in Marrakech. The sights, the sounds, the smells!Be prepared to be hasseled, everyone trying to pull you in and sell to you...but that is part of what makes it so interesting. Only once was I uncomfortable and taken aback, a young woman trying to get me a henna tattoo...which ended up with henna splashed up my arm & clothes as I pulled away...other than that for the most part everyone is friendly and you just play along, bargaining and meandering through the narrow passages of souks. Definitely allow a full day...you can easily get lost with the winding alleyways and no exit in sight. Eventually you will notice it's the same items for sale over and over, many obviously playing to the tourists, however there are some beautiful items and I love that behind the souks you can find craftsmen working on welding something right in front of you.Breathe in the smells...while some not to pleasant (the animals), it's the aroma of the spices that just fills the senses and now it always reminds me of Marrakech!If you plan to shop, I suggest saving your purchases for the city stores, which are a few blocks away, yet they are regulated and no haggling necessary, but for the real experience be sure to spend some time getting lost in the souk!

Seen one, you seen them all. What a giant let down the souks were. Djemaa el Fnaa was nothing special really, but the souks were very disappointing. Stalls were either selling spices, leather/babouches, jewellery or clothes, hardly any diverted from these staple products. As I say, seen one, you seen em all. I had fun haggling for a couple of things, but it was hardly the experience I had hoped for. I was far more energised by the Gueliz area to be honest, where I went to some Moroccan bars off the tourist trail - but that's a whole other story...

Don't know what the fuss is all about. Yes, check out the Souks by all means to get an understanding of what peddling and bargaining is all about but if you are looking for serious finds then look elsewhere. Here are a few tips to probably help you understand your bargaining upper hand- (well you will never get out on top) :)1. If they clearly mark how much it will cost then that is your safest place to buy...they will not bargain that price down.2. A simple Tagine (size-2 persons meal; the ones locals use-the kind that is not painted and therefore can be used for cooking) costs anywhere from 50-75 MADs (50 if u r really good at bargaining-paying any more than 75 for a plain Tagine means you were had). 3. A hand-painted Tagine will cost anywhere from 100-120 (size 2persons meal; hand-painted and though you may serve hot food in it you may not put it on a heat source for cooking). We paid 120MAD for a Tagine fro 4 persons. 4. Remember that the cost of 1 months rent is 600 MAD. So if you are paying someone 100 MAD for a camel ride for 5 minutes he is only going to laugh at you when he reaches home. We paid 30 MAD for a 5 min ride on a horse carriage (of course, I come from India so I know all the tricks they could use). 5. NO! You DO NOT NEED A GUIDE to visit the Souk! It is just a way to fleece you!

Jemma el fna ...The place to be. Jemma el fna is like marmite..you will either love it or hate it.The pulse of the Medina. It has many moods depending on the time of day which you visit. I loved it! The spectacle of the entertainment, dancers, snake charmers, water sellers, dodging petit taxis, and other traffic, avoiding the women who want to paint henna on your hands...adds to the buzz.. For me the square really came to life at dusk when the food stalls set up. My friends and I ate there twice. As recommended by previous reviewers, We had great fish and chips at stall no 98. We had to wait to be seated ( always a good sign) and had a mixed plate of fish/calamari for 40 dirhams (£3) The other stall we ate at was stall no1. Had a traditional meal of lamb tagine, a few morracan salads, which again was delicious and cheap.No tummmy upsets either. Highly recommended.

It you love mayhem, you'll love this!. What an experience! I absolutely love it here - the madness, the colours, the shouting, the mopeds whizzing down all the tiny side streets though the market. There is such a variety of things you can buy and haggling is so much fun!Be wary of people trying to show you where to go though. Some people are genuine and dont want your money but others take advantage of niave tourists. If you are prepared to give money then go ahead and follow them but set a price first. Even if they tell you it is free - it isnt.I cant wait to return next year!

An experience that shouldn't be missed. Although I had read reviews and heard stories from fellow travellers, nothing can prepare you for the experience of the souks. The windy paths of shop after shop selling lots of hand made artifacts is staggering. You will probably like the experience if you are a confident person as you are enticed by the locals all the time. Just say no and they move on to the next punter ! We bought a few items in the souks but you have to barter hard. One guy started at 12000Dh which was apparently a discount as I was English. In English money that is £100. After 20 mins of haggling later, I walked away just 200Dh lighter so it is worth it.I'm not sure I'd want to go back, but I am glad I experienced it for myself.

Be wary. Just a note of caution. Walking round late at night 10 pm souks closed looking for spice cafe we got into conversation with youths wanting to show us the way. Naively we followed and then were unsure of where taking us. Began to get unnerved but Was then picked by Street guardian in uniform. A bit of argument followed and had to pay off youths. Got back to main square via guardian and then had to pay him. Not sure if guardian was official or notAfter this we always kept away from asking people information etc

Very different to any flea market I've.... Very different to any flea market I've been to... It's great to walk around a kind of get lost in all the little streets... Lots of colour and very time you go in you discover new things

"Lady.. you look please??". The souks of Marakech are uncomparable. The colours, the sounds and even the quality are unbeatable. We came from Spain and went to the Istanbul Grand Bazar days afterwards, so we did compare. The souks of Marakech have so many things to buy, and alot of them you dont even know you want. Shoes, bags, door knocks, bbq skewers,lamps,rugs, silk, cotton, tassles, pottery, plates and even sinks. Yes we bought a sink, beautiful hand made Bereber sink . Its endless...but you have to haggle and haggle hard. Always haggle with a smile and dont be offended at the aggressive nature of their sales pitch. Its not personal, they know there are hundreds of other shops just waiting for your money.Try to use a little French, the basics are welcomed. And take your time.There are bargains aplenty to be had. I invented starving children to feed at home, and did it with a huge smile. I told shtall owners that they smiling so were obviously making a profit. Its all fun and games.You can spend days in the souks ( we did) and not see every stall...so enjoy what you do see and try to work out a guding point so you dont get lost. Enjoy.......

"Come inside for Asda/Primark price.....". Visiting Marrakech without experiencing the Souks is like visiting an ice cream farm and not buying a cornet. It truely is an experience you will not forget and one I really enjoyed. Filled with the various denizens of the medina, the souks and covered markets are a labyrinth dedicated to retail. But not retail as we know it. This is retail stuck in medival times and is in no way theraputic. Beggars walk the narrow passages asking for some coins and the air quality is constantly lowered by the buzzing of mopeds that zoom up and down the walkways.As you walk around make sure you look into the shops. Sometimes you'll see mini shopping malls hidden away. Or you'll glimpse dusty mystical aladdins caves, full of caskets and north african carvings. There is some order to this madness however, The souks are divided up into areas dedicated to specific trades, such as metal, food, cloths and wood. Just enter and go with the flow. I've never had so much fun getting lost before.

If you know some french, then use it!. You'll be paying more than you could. But why not? And the salesmen are pestering you a bit, but only a bit.If you know a bit of french then use it. Much better then English. You'll get lower prices faster. And a happier saleman. I guess Arabic or Berb is even better.It's fun in the Souk of Marrakech!Try not to get lost in there though.

An experience!. It's a great place to walk arround and get to know the morrocans. They will seem very invasive at the beggining, but are all very friendly and polite - if you are also. Don't offer a too low price, since they can be offended. Try to negotiate reasonably. Don't miss the "souk des épices" where you can find great spices and teas.

Arabian nights markets!!. The souks…what do I say… its never ending, its timeless, its like your walking through the markets where Aladdin got up to his mischief. But wow is it huge or what! You could end up walking for days and days! And you could end up walking days and days… and days looking for the people you came with because you can get lost. But the people are lovely, I went with my boyfriend and he just knew what to do and how to work with them, it was entertaining! A seller will call out and ask for you to come and take a look, my boyfriend will go and speak to them confuse them make them laugh they will make us laugh. It was like this throughout, its better to blend in with them and behave like them they find it amusing. Learn a bit about their culture and the different types of people. We were looking to buy their famous Berber shoes and my partner made the whole experience amazing as he walked in and introduced himself as a Berber from the Sahara (they knew he was kidding around) and that he only wants and deserves original Berber shoe’s and for a very good Berber price and for that reason most of the locals loved talking to him. Like I said keep talking and be like them, you will land yourself a big discount!Make sure your haggling non stop… nothing is never the price it really is, someone wanted to sell an item to us for 200 dirhams and we took it down to 50 dirhams the man refused with his dear life stood there for 10 minutes explaining why he will NEVER bring it down to that price…ok… so we walked away… he called us back… agreeing on 50 dirhams… ok. So be ready to battle it out with the haggling in the souks don’t be the one that loses!We went for a shopping spree and loved it, the Moroccans are wonderful and so friendly. You can never be scared walking up the emptier parts of the souks. You will find wonderful things in the souks just walk in with a smile, jolly attitude and discover it all!

"I'll do you nice price"... i wish they would!!!!. Everyone raves about the shopping experience in the souks of Marrakech... so on a recent trip to the 'red city', i was genuinely looking forward to the chance of landing some bargains. After two days i've come away with moderate disappointment.Maybe it's me, maybe my girlfriend and myself were going about it completely wrong, but the the promise of fun bartering, a bit of a challenge in landing that prized lantern at a 'cheap as chips' price tag never really materialised.On our first day we wandered through the northern section of the souks, with the idea that prices would get more expensive the nearer stalls got to Djemaa el Fna. Most of the shop keepers wanted to charge 1300 dh (approx £90) for a lamp. The majority we looked at were poor quality, badly soldered, some painted gold/brass, some with cracked glass, to be honest you find much better at craft fairs back home. We tried to adopted a reasonable approach... tried to enter the bartering in a good humored manner, was respectful and realistic about the price. Instead of some firm and friendly bargaining we were met with either nonchalance and in some cases they were just plain obnoxious. Unless i was willing to part with 900dh they weren't interested. After two days of looking for decent lamp at a good price we gave up... Lamps weren't the only problem, we had similar experiences with poufs, mirrors... generally, most of the 'bargins' we were looking for. The quality was poor and the final prices ridiculous!In addition, my girlfriend (who took the advice of many of the guide books by keeping her clothing respectfully moderate and her shoulders covered with a scarf) received several derogatory comments from the Moroccan men and on one occasion we were met with a "f@*& you" after turning down an offer to 'look for free' in a spice shop. Offensive market traders aside, the souks were amazing to wander around. By keeping an open mind and forming a tough skin i still found the experience... the colours, the smells, the sounds, the chaos... absolutely fantastic. Just let me know the secret to haggling before i go back!!!
